title: In a Final Proposal, Players Make Concessions
description: Less than a week before National Basketball Association owners convene to vote on whether to cancel the season, the union yesterday prepared a final proposal that included a major concession: putting a cap on players salaries.

title: Korea to Sell Control of Bank to U.S. Investors
description: The South Korean Government signed an agreement today to sell a controlling stake in Korea First Bank to a consortium led by GE Capital, the world's largest nonbank financial services company, and Newbridge Capital, a buyout fund backed by the financier David Bonderman's Texas Pacific Group.

title: Big Board Resets Trading-Halt Levels
description: In its quarterly adjustment of the so-called circuit breakers, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had set the level for a trading halt in United States equity markets at a drop of 900 points, up from 800 points last quarter.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL RISES. Heating oil rose more than 3 percent on expectations that frigid weather in the United States would set off a surge in demand. Heating oil for January delivery rose 1.08 cents, to 34 cents a gallon.

title: New Year's Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Power Play Lifts Rangers to a Rout
description: A big moon, one night short of full, rose over downtown while New Year's Eve party-goers gathered in the bars, the restaurants and the hockey arena of the Mile High City. Inside McNichols Arena, the organist greeted the spectators with the tune ''Werewolves of London.'' A dozen seconds after the puck was dropped, two tough guys for the Rangers and the Avalanche exchanged punches in a lengthy brawl.

title: Weekend Essay; How to Just Say Know: A Guide for Dummies
description: I've never gone in much for the whole concept of adult education. I suppose that a microscopic examination of my academic transcripts by an ill-wisher could lead to the conclusion that I wasn't so keen on childhood or adolescent education, either.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Indonesian Economy Shrank 13.7% in Year
description: Indonesia's economy shrank 13.7 percent in 1998, less than the Government expected, while consumer prices rose 77.6 percent to their highest since 1967. The Government had forecast a 15 percent contraction in the economy for 1998. Helped by the stronger rupiah, the economy contracted only 0.27 percent in the fourth quarter from the third.

title: On Stage and Off; The Tinkerers Never Rest
description: Take two long weekends, add a couple of libational holidays, stir in a little icy weather, and you've got a recipe for the near hibernation evidenced in Broadway's corridors of power this week.

title: Cost of Stadium Worries Those Who Count on Aid
description: The Connecticut Council of Small Towns faxed the alarm to its 85 members late last week, contending that Gov. John G. Rowland was about to cut tens of millions of dollars in aid to municipalities in the two-year state budget he is to present in early February.

title: Home Video; Looking Back At Small Gems
description: At the end of the year some videos stick in the memory for one reason or another. Here is a selection from 1998.

title: Honduras Retreats From Estimate of Storm Deaths
description: Two months after a hurricane mauled this country, it is still unclear how many Hondurans died in the storm, but the Government has been forced to retreat from its earlier conclusion that at least 7,000 people perished.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGANN, THOMAS J.

Proud grandfather of Michael and Katie League, Monica Mowery, Thomas, Carolyn, Kelly, Brian, and Kaitlin McGann. Dear brother of Sr. John Raymond CSJ, Most Rev. John R. In lieu of flowers donations to Mercy Medical Center, 1000 No. Village Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY 11570, would be appreciated.

title: Opposition Emerges to Plan To Avert Full Trial of Clinton
description: In the first signs of serious discord among Senate Republicans over impeachment, several senators, both conservative and moderate, said today that they opposed a proposal that would permit a preliminary vote on articles of impeachment without a full trial.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: No Missing the Message; A Bit of Parcells Diamond Dust Falls on the Jets
description: Ray Lucas saw it shimmering in the meeting today as the Jets went back to work. But he was afraid to say a word.

title: 2 Critically Hurt in Crash
description: A collision between two vehicles last night at Farmers Boulevard and 110th Avenue in Queens sent at least four people to the hospital, injuring two critically, the police said. A Long Island man was arrested on suspicion of driving while intoxicated, the police said.

title: THE PREACHERS: A special report.; New Wave of Evangelists Vying for National Pulpit
description: One is an Argentine-born preacher who appeals to both Hispanic and Anglo audiences. Another is a young megachurch pastor in Southern California who peppers his sermons with quotations from Hollywood stars and sports idols. A third is an African-American equally beloved by convicts and unhappy homemakers. And then there are two of the Rev. Billy Graham's children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERSTEIN, DAVID
description: SILBERSTEIN-David of 146 Petticoat Ln, East Haddam, CT. Died December 30, 1998. He was born in New York City on September 5, 1917, son of the late Sarah and Harry A. Silberstein. He graduated from Townsend Harris High School, New York University and New York University Law School. He was a member of the New York Bar Association. He enlisted in the United States Naval Reserve in 1940 and was stationed at Pearl Harbor when the Japanese bombed the base. He was Commanding Officer of cruisers and a destroyer in heavy combat in the Pacific and Mediterranean war zones for which he received many decorations including the Silver Star. He attained the rank of Commander and was Director of the Separation Center in New York City 1946-1947. After the war, Commander Silberstein entered the publishing business. He became Vice President of Prentice-Hall, Inc. and later President of the Bureau of Business Practice in Waterford, CT. He was an avid naturalist, ornithologist, environmentalist and tournament bridge player and director. He married Margaret Mary Kirrane on Easter Sunday 1950. Their children are David Shay, his wife Mollye, Deirdre Ellen and Donald James, his wife Mary-Margaret. The grandchildren David, Marget, William, James and Alana. He is also survived by a brother in law Rev. James A. Kirrane. Family funeral services will be held at St. Bridget Cemetery, East Haddam, CT. The Swan Funeral Home, 27 W.F. Palmer Road, Moodus.

title: JURY ORDERS DAYTON SUPERIOR UNIT TO PAY $36.4 MILLION
description: The Dayton Superior Corporation said yesterday that a jury had ordered its Symons Corporation unit to pay $36.4 million in damages to the EFCO Corporation for false advertising and other misdeeds. Dayton said the damages, awarded by a Federal jury in Des Moines, could be changed by the trial judge. EFCO, a Dayton competitor, charged that Symons had engaged in false advertising, misappropriation of trade secrets and intentional interference with contractual relations. The events occurred before Dayton acquired Symons in 1997, Dayton said. Dayton Superior, which had sales of $167.4 million in 1997, makes and distributes accessories and forms used in masonry construction. EFCO, based in Des Moines, makes forms for concrete construction.

title: On Campus, Tripping the Light Fantastic
description: The E-mail messages arrived first in a trickle, then in a flood.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 6.

title: SKYMALL SHARES PLUNGE AFTER CHIEF EXERCISES OPTIONS
description: Shares of Skymall Inc., the biggest catalogue retailer for airline passengers, plunged yesterday after its chief executive bought out three major shareholders at a steep discount. The chief executive, Robert M. Worsley, exercised options to buy the 2.4 million shares held by the company's co-founder, Alan Ashton, and his wife, Karen, for $7.35 each, or $17.6 million -- a 74 percent discount to Wednesday's closing price. He also paid $6.75 each for the 518,000 shares held by Bert Getz, chairman of the Cincinnati-based Globe Corporation. Mr. Worsley financed his purchase by selling 675,000 Skymall shares on Monday at an average price of $35. He now owns 54 percent of the company's outstanding shares. Skymall fell $6.875, to $20.875.

title: Corrections
description: A book review on Wednesday about ''Thurgood Marshall: American Revolutionary,'' by Juan Williams, referred incorrectly to the precedent for a major biography of Marshall. There was indeed an earlier one, ''Making Civil Rights Law: Thurgood Marshall and the Supreme Court, 1936-1961,'' by Mark Tushnet, published in 1993 by Oxford University Press.

title: Keeping Military Secrets From China
description: A bipartisan House investigation has uncovered serious damage to American national security from two decades of inappropriate, careless and in some cases illegal nuclear and missile technology transfers to China. These findings constitute an urgent warning that American businesses and political leaders must deal more carefully with China, a country with great power ambitions and nuclear weapons. Chinese interests sometimes conflict with those of the United States. The White House and Congress should quickly declassify as much of the report as possible, so that vulnerable areas can be identified and corrective measures taken.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Verne Dawson

title: BANKAMERICA SAYS BUSINESS WITH SHAW WILL CUT PROFITS
description: The BankAmerica Corporation's business with D. E. Shaw & Company, a securities firm and hedge fund, is expected to reduce profits in the fourth quarter by about $100 million, analysts said yesterday. BankAmerica took over a $20 billion bond portfolio from D. E. Shaw, after taking a loss of $372 million in the third quarter on a loan to the firm, which is based in New York. BankAmerica's stock fell $1.5625 a share, to $60.125. BankAmerica's loan to D. E. Shaw and trading losses caused profits to plunge 50 percent in the third quarter.

title: Sports of The Times; A Season Of Renewal For the Jets
description: THE Jets celebrate the first day of the new year with an unfamiliar personae. They begin 1999 as champions.

title: Fast-Track Trial In the Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: Anita Hoffman, 56, Partner And Wife of Yippie Leader
description: Anita Hoffman, who aided and abetted her Yippie husband, Abbie Hoffman, in his anti-establishment protests and pranks and then sustained him through her letters during his years as a fugitive, died on Sunday at the age of 56.

title: For Rebels In Congo, Popularity Is Elusive
description: This city at a bend in the Congo River will soon become the new rebel headquarters, in a move that concedes a reality no one bothers to hide anymore: the rebellion may control ever-growing chunks of Congo, but it remains deeply unpopular with the people.

title: Firstplus Sells Mortgages
description: Firstplus Financial Group Inc., a high-risk lender that is struggling with liquidity problems of its own, said on Wednesday that it had sold $900 million in mortgage loans to an unidentified United States bank for an undisclosed price. Lenders like Firstplus typically make home-equity loans for up to 125 percent of the property's value. Firstplus has been hurt by volatility in financial markets. In October, the company dismissed 3,000 of its 6,250 employees.

title: Afghans and the U.N. Agencies Are Far Apart on Resuming Aid
description: A hardening of positions by the United Nations and the movement that controls most of Afghanistan is crippling efforts to resume international relief work there, officials from both sides say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VEREBAY, MAX
description: VEREBAY-Max, died peacefully at home on December 29th, 1998 at age 85. Beloved husband of Mollie, father of Hildi & Leonard, grandfather of Alyssa, Andi, Wendi, Brad and Amy. Service Sunday, at 12:30, at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Atlantic Ave., Delray, FL. Memorial contributions may be made to UJA Federation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOPPELMAN, MORRIS
description: KOPPELMAN-Morris. So dearly remembered. So sadly missed. Happy birthday. Love, Nina

title: Turning a Museum Into a Vast Menorah
description: The Jewish Museum has come up with a nifty way to celebrate Hanukkah this year. In a show called ''Light X Eight: The Hanukkah Project,'' eight works by eight contemporary artists, all using some form of electrical illumination, have been installed around the museum, indoors and out. Starting on Dec. 13, the first night of the Festival of Light, the pieces were turned on, one each day, transforming the whole museum into a giant environmental menorah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, ESTELLE
description: BARNETT-Estelle. Beloved mother of Marcia Saunders. Cherished grandmother of Dr. Deborah Saunders and Karen Bakst. Adored great-grandmother of Caroline, Michael and Lauren.

title: Centenarians
description: As the yearlong countdown to 2000 begins, you may want to consider one of these 12 restaurants, all of which were serving meals at the last turn of the century. No luck in finding restaurants experienced with a new millennium, though. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Bell Atlantic In Talks to Buy Cellular Giant
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, the nation's largest local telephone company, is in talks to buy Airtouch Communications Inc., the largest wireless phone company for $45 billion in stock, executives close to the companies said last night.

title: Nets Might Be Interested In Sale Involving the Devils
description: The Nets' president, Michael Rowe, denied a report yesterday that stated that the team had made informal offers to buy the Devils from the hockey team's owner, John McMullen.

description: Don't be fooled by their size. These young people are all seasoned veterans of Broadway. They are currently appearing in shows like ''The Lion King,'' ''The Sound of Music,'' ''Les Miserables'' and the forthcoming revival of ''Annie Get Your Gun.''

title: A Hybrid From Honda
description: The Honda Motor Company will offer this lightweight, superefficient car in the United States next year, which would beat the Toyota Motor Corporation to market with a hybrid-powered vehicle in North America. The Honda, whose name has not been publicly disclosed, will be shown next week at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit. It has both a three-cylinder gasoline engine and an electric motor, and can reportedly travel 70 miles on a gallon of gas. It will also meet extremely strict pollution standards, Honda said. Toyota, which has been selling a small hybird sedan, the Prius, in Japan, has announced plans to sell a hybrid car in the United States, but probably not until late 2000.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They don't like to go out because they don't know how many people like them and how many people don't like them. But all the people don't like them.''

title: A Last Holdout of the Spit-and-Polish Crowd
description: THERE'S not much left of Shoeshine Row, the blocklong stretch of Eighth Avenue below 42d Street that once sustained 15 or so shoe-polish professionals. These days Eddy Crawford and Ray Davis pretty much keep the trade alive on a wedge of pavement that has so far resisted the area's real estate juggernaut.

title: REIT Plan Finished, Host Marriott Says
description: The Host Marriott Corporation said today that it had completed its plan to convert to a real estate investment trust and had closed its purchase of a $1.2 billion portfolio of luxury hotels from the Blackstone Group.

title: In Quiet Corners, a Rhapsody for the Eyes and Soul
description: In terms of material things, there's no place like New York and no time like the Christmas holidays. The rituals of buying, giving and getting are pronounced here, and phase two -- returning, exchanging and sale-hopping -- can be even more intense. Add to this the movements of people heading for the city's major blockbuster art exhibitions in their final days, and you've got object-oriented human gridlock of unparalleled proportions. Right now it feels like the whole world is here on a class trip.

title: Markets Closed
description: All United States financial markets, Government offices and banks are closed today in observance of New Year's Day. Most foreign financial markets are also closed. The markets will reopen on Monday.

description: WELCOME to the last New Year's Day column of the dying millennium. Exciting, huh?

title: County Sets Aside $1 Million for Claims on Ex-Prosecutor
description: Officials in Somerset County, N.J., have set aside a $1 million fund to cover fees, lawsuits and claims of wrongful prosecution that have arisen in the two years since Nicholas L. Bissell Jr., the former county prosecutor, was convicted of fraud, disappeared and then committed suicide.

description: Capping a splurge of individual honors he has not known since his Heisman Trophy season of 1986, Vinny Testaverde today got the one that means the most to him as a pro: his teammates voted him the Jets' most valuable player.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about plans by Russia and Belarus to unify their currencies and much of their economies referred imprecisely to the Russian border. (An editorial on Wednesday repeated the error.) The Russian enclave of Kaliningrad borders Poland; thus a political merger of Russia and Belarus would not be the step that recreated a Russian boundary with Poland.

title: A Solitary Visionary at Home in His Own Backyard
description: A small-town artist with a large talent, Charles Burchfield (1893-1967) was most comfortable working close to home. He spent his life in two communities: Salem, Ohio, where he was raised, and Gardenville, N.Y., outside of Buffalo, where he brought up his own family. He liked to paint the views from his studio, his neighbors' gardens, their crotchety houses, the cars and dwellings of nearby streets, the local drama of nature. If he could reassemble his paintings, he once told an interviewer, he would have an exhibition called ''From My Backyard.''

title: A Turbulent but Profitable Year
description: Investors who stuck with United States stocks in 1998 were rewarded, defying expectations by many Wall Street professionals that the market would falter on the uncertainty of economic turbulence abroad. The Nasdaq market rose nearly 40 percent on the strength of Internet and technology stocks. The Standard & Poor's index rose more than 20 percent for a record fourth consecutive year. Business Day, page C1.

title: New Year's Day: Now Just a Warm-Up
description: No matter how tortured or how beholden it was to those blasted computers, the Bowl Championship Series did its job. No. 1 Tennessee will play No. 2 Florida State for the national championship here on Monday night in the Fiesta Bowl. The other seven bowl games over the New Year's weekend are simply warm-up acts, except for one, the Dissent Bowl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORKIN, SYLVIA HOLLAND
description: ORKIN-Sylvia Holland on Thursday, Dec. 31, 1998, of Bal Harbour, FL, formerly of NYC. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Lazarus A. Orkin. Dear mother of Dr. Fred and Susan Orkin and Drs. Stuart and Roslyn Orkin. Cherished grandmother of Jane, Jeffrey and Jennifer Orkin. Loving sister of Emil Holland and the late Jack J. Holland, Louis Holland and Sadie Zatt. Dear aunt to many nieces and nephews. Sylvia with her late husband was a woman of great generosity. She was the Founder of The Douglas Gardens Jewish Home for the Aged in Miami, a Founder of Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami, a Patron of the Women's Cancer League at Mount Sinai, and a Board Member of The Wien Center there. She was also a long time supporter of the National Women's Committee of Brandeis University. In addition, Mrs. Orkin established The Orkin Skills Center in the Department of Nursing at Beth Israel Medical Center in NYC in memory of her late husband. Private graveside services will be leaving from The Riverside, Amsterdam and 76th Street, Manhattan, at noon on Sunday, Jan. 3. A separate memorial service will be held at The Riverside at noon on Jan. 31. Donations in Sylvia's memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Bomb Materials Found at a San Francisco Utility's Building
description: Police and fire investigators today safely removed an assortment of bomb-making materials, including 250 pounds of the type of fertilizer used in the Oklahoma City bombing, from a Pacific Gas and Electric Company service center here and took a company employee into custody.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSHMAN, JANE
description: CUSHMAN-Jane. The MacDougal-Sullivan Garden Association mourns the death of our longtime friend and neighbor, Jane Cushman. Jane was an esteemed member of our community and we will miss her. We extend our love and deep sympathy to her son, Tom, and her sister, Amanda.

description: Liberated at last from a life of revolution, two Khmer Rouge leaders came to the beach today with their families, their leisure wear and their sunglasses.

title: Taiwan Phone Operator Seeks Stake in Rival
description: The KG Telecommunications Corporation, one of Taiwan's private mobile phone operators, will acquire from Tuntex Group a 59 percent stake in the Tuntex Telecommunications Company, another private operator, for 6.49 billion New Taiwan dollars ($201 million), a KG spokesman said yesterday. (Bridge News)

title: Back to Israel, but Not to Play, for Blizzard Guard
description: When the American Basketball League folded on Dec. 22, most players got the news that afternoon from their team's offices. But not Limor Mizrachi of the New England Blizzard. She heard about it in a phone call a day later from one of her sisters in Israel.

title: Gay Charity Cites Drug Use In Canceling a Fund-Raiser
description: Because of a growing chorus of concern that a major AIDS fund-raising event was encouraging illegal drug use and unsafe sex, organizers of the popular annual gay party on Fire Island announced yesterday that they were abandoning the event.

description: ST. JOHN'S KNITS INC., Irvine, Calif., a women's clothing company, said a group led by its founder and chief executive, Robert E. Gray, had extended until Jan. 15 its bid to take the company private.

description: The Griffin Trading Company, a Chicago futures trading firm, filed for bankruptcy on Wednesday after some $10 million in losses by a London trader left Griffin unable to meet its obligations, the firm's lawyer said today.

description: Gore Taking a First Step

title: Inside Art; Israel Gets A Poussin
description: A painting that Sotheby's experts attributed to the 17th-century artist Pietro Testa and called ''The Sack of Carthage'' was estimated to sell for $16,000 to $24,000 when it was included in a London sale in 1995. But what began as a minor work in an Old Master auction has ended up being one of the stars of the Israel Museum's permanent collection, thanks to a combination of scholarship and beneficence.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Wall Street's Banks Kept To Hierarchy During 1998
description: The finance industry had a turbulent year, with sharp swings in stock and bond markets and the spreading global financial crisis threatening America's long bull market. But in the end, major United States investment banks did more business and earned more money than ever, and the hierarchy of Wall Street banks remained as solid as the limestone portico of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Robert Johnson, a Leading Air Ace in World War II, Dies at 78
description: Robert S. Johnson, an Eighth Air Force fighter pilot who shot down 27 German planes in an 11-month span in World War II and then came home to a hero's welcome from President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died on Sunday at St. Francis Hospital in Tulsa, Okla. He was 78 and the second-leading American air ace of the war in Europe.

title: Lhasa Journal; For the Bountiful Yak, the Road Ends Sadly Here
description: A man with a crumpled brown fedora picked through the yak hoofs that lay on a flimsy roadside table, next to the slabs of fresh red yak meat. The man, whose name was Gomchen, seemed to be looking for something he could not find.

title: LIBERTY SUBSIDIARY BUYS TV STATION IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: The Liberty Corporation said yesterday that its Cosmos Broadcasting Corporation subsidiary had purchased WWAY-TV, an ABC affiliate in Wilmington, N.C., for $34 million. The seller was Hillside Broadcasting of Atlanta. Liberty, based in Greenville, S.C., is a holding company with operations in insurance and broadcasting and 1997 revenue of $660 million. Cosmos owns 10 other network-affiliated television stations, including 6 NBC affiliates, 2 other ABC affiliates and 2 CBS affiliates. ABC is a unit of the Walt Disney Company.

title: Fast-Track Trial In the Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: Palisades Park Hires Its First Korean Officer
description: Among the many public servants to be sworn in around the state today is John Yoon, Palisades Park's first Korean police officer.

title: President At Retreat: From Putts To Partying
description: When the choice came down on this bright cool day to golf or heartfelt, indoor gab, President Clinton, who has not had much recreation lately, made his preference clear.

title: TEXACO SAYS IT WILL CUT CAPITAL BUDGET 14% IN 1999
description: Texaco Inc., the third-largest United States oil company, has cut its 1999 capital spending budget 14 percent from the level it set at the start of this month, to $3.7 billion, because it is less optimistic that crude oil prices will improve, a Texaco spokesman, said yesterday. Texaco expects oil prices, now at their lowest since 1986, to average $10 to $12 a barrel in 1999, Texaco's chief financial officer, Patrick J. Lynch, told Business Week magazine. The magazine also reported the newly reduced spending budget.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, MELVIN D.
description: WEBER-Melvin D. Beloved husband of Thelma. Devoted father of Jay Weber and Susan Weber. Loving grandfather of Laurie, David and Steven, great-grandfather of Devyn. Dear brother of Carolyn Silverman. Service 11AM Friday at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, N.Y. Memorial contributions would be appreciated to either American Cancer Society or Arthritis Foundation.

title: AMP of Australia Pursues GIO Purchase
description: AMP Ltd., Australia's biggest fund manager and life insurer, has acquired eight million shares of GIO Australia Holdings Ltd. and said yesterday that it would complete the nation's biggest takeover ever by the deadline of Monday. Executives at GIO -- which is advising shareholders to reject AMP's offer of $5.35 (United States) a share or one AMP share for four GIO shares -- maintain AMP will not gain control.

title: Family Fare; A Playground Without Limits
description: The usual place for a grandmother visiting a playground is a park bench. But the play equipment in ''Unlimited by Design,'' an exhibition at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, accommodates 70-year-olds as well as 7-year-olds and disabled children as much as able-bodied ones. Best of all, it is not behind ropes, but in an open room, making the Cooper-Hewitt the only Fifth Avenue museum with an indoor playground, at least until spring.

title: Singapore Ends Year Falling Into Recession
description: Singapore fell into recession as 1998 ended, according to figures in the Prime Minister's New Year's message yesterday that disclosed a 1.5 percent contraction of the economy in the fourth quarter. But Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong never used the word recession in his speech. Instead, he put a positive cast on the news, saying the city-state's growth for the entire year was 1.3 percent and describing it as ''not a bad performance, considering the unfavorable climate.''

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column yesterday, about high and low points in advertising in 1998, misidentified the agency handling the Planters account for the Nabisco Foods unit of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation. It is the Foote, Cone & Belding unit of True North Communications, not the Ammirati Puris Lintas unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Van Horn Says Players Should Put Deal to Vote
description: Keith Van Horn called for a shift in the union's stance yesterday, saying that Billy Hunter, the union's executive director, and his 19-member negotiating committee should let the league's 400-plus players vote on the owners' latest proposal.

title: Detaining Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Design; Plan-It-Yourself Cars And Other Visions
description: THESE days, almost every car is safe, reliable and performs well,'' Gregory Brew said. ''Now, the trick is to provide that extra little something that creates attachment to an inanimate object.''

title: Extra Blankets Can't Make Up for Lack of Heat
description: For two nights, Lisa Ortega and her three children huddled together on her bed, wrapped in four layers of clothing and wearing the hoods of their sweatshirts to try to keep warm.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Alfonso Ossorio

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLOP, LUIS A.
description: GALLOP-Luis A. On December 30, 1998 of Myelodysplasia at home in Chapel Hill, NC. Formerly of Old Greenwich, CT and Francestown, NH, he was an advertising executive for many years with Reuben Donnelley, Time-Life Inc., Benton & Bowles and Venture Magazine. Predeceased by his first wife Kathryn N. Gallop and a daughter Nancy Cristman Thoman. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Maggie R. Matthews of Chapel Hill, NC; Deborah Cristman McMullen of London, England, Dana Cristman Eaton of Sunnyvale, CA, Anne Gallop Pace of Sudbury, MA, Charles Andrew Gallop of Winchester, MA and eight grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COHEN, SARA
description: COHEN-Sara 1/1/29 1/1/99 In cherished and loving memory on her 70th birthday. Forever missed. Sonia.

title: A New 'Traviata' Cast, but Where's Violetta? Alfredo?
description: Since Franco Zeffirelli's ele phantine new staging of ''La Traviata'' opened at the Metropolitan Opera at the end of November, new singers have taken over all the principal roles. Normally, the assumption is that the original singers have moved on to other projects, but in this case it seems likely that some of them were simply lost in the scenery and may not be heard from again. A singer who wanted to hide out for a while, in fact, could hardly do better than to get a role in this production.

title: Fast-Track Trial In the Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore Forming Organization For 2000 Bid For President
description: Vice President Al Gore will take his first formal step toward running for President in 2000 by notifying the Federal Election Commission that he has formed a campaign organization, aides to the Vice President said today.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: HOCKEY

title: Wartime Remorse as Prevention?; Pride, Not Guilt
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Phone Companies May Benefit in Britain
description: Orange P.L.C. and One 2 One Ltd., the smallest two of Britain's four mobile phone companies, will benefit the most from today's start of number portability, which lets customers keep their phone numbers when they switch to another mobile network, analysts say. In a market dominated by Vodafone and Cellnet Ltd., which is a venture of British Telecommunications P.L.C. and Securicor P.L.C., Orange and One 2 One have had a difficult time gaining market share. Together, they control about 30 percent of the market. Portability may help Orange and One 2 One lure customers by removing a drawback to leaving the more established networks. (Bloomberg News)

title: In Puerto Rico, a Fugitive in Full Cry
description: A few days before the referendum two weeks ago on this island's political status, Filiberto Ojeda-Rios, a radical Puerto Rican nationalist, denounced the vote as illegitimate and called for a boycott.

title: NORTHWEST EXPECTS BIGGER LOSS, ANALYST SAYS
description: The shares of the Northwest Airlines Corporation fell yesterday after an analyst said the carrier, the No. 4 United States airline, expected its fourth-quarter loss to be wider than expected. Northwest has told analysts that its loss would widen because it had not regained customers lost during a 15-day pilots' strike in September as quickly as expected and its maintenance costs had risen, said the analyst, Kevin Murphy of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. The shares fell 37.5 cents each, to $25.5625, in Nasdaq trading. Northwest, which is based in St. Paul, had been expected to lose $1.41 a share, the average estimate of nine analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings.

title: Islanders' Offense Ends the Year Quietly
description: When the Islanders wake up on Friday, it will be a new year. Too bad they will not wake up to a new season.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GRIST, KEITH PAUL
description: GRIST-Keith Paul. 7/24/67-1/1/98. First year in heaven Always missed. Always loved. Mom and George

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MALIN, MILDRED
description: MALIN-Mildred. My beloved aunt, I miss you every day. Always, Freya

title: 11 COUNTRIES TIE EUROPE TOGETHER IN ONE CURRENCY
description: Finance ministers from 11 countries celebrated New Year's Eve today by launching the euro as Europe's new single currency, the culmination of an effort first conceived in the 1950's as a means of unifying Europe and thus preventing another world war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, JOANNE ORA
description: JONES-Joanne Ora. Age 63 of Hudson, WI died December 28, 1998. She was born February 27, 1935 in Appleton, WI, the daughter of Harvey and Ora Gygi. Wife of the late Donald R. Jones. She enjoyed traveling and in the last few years visited China, Russia, Germany and Egypt to see first-hand the cultures and governments. She is survived by five children and nine grandchildren-and a vast collection of The New York Times

title: David C. Adams, 85, a Former Chairman of NBC
description: David C. Adams, a former chairman of NBC and a member of its board, died Sunday at Cedar Manor Nursing Home in Ossining, N.Y. A resident of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., Mr. Adams was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDSTEIN, FRANK H.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Frank H. - Would have been 107 today (but fell short by 22 years). He faced all the difficulties of our century and despite them persevered and by persevering he triumphed. He succeeded in raising five children who became contributors to the strength of America, his adopted country which he loved so dearly. He reared spiritually, physically and psychologically sound children who remain forever in his debt. Those loving children.

title: Modern Rugs That Broke With the Past
description: Jed Johnson, the interior designer, used to advise clients to ''start with a good rug and build the room around it.''

title: A Doctor's Dilemma in an African State
description: Eric Heumann has a way with violence. In his new film, ''Port Djema,'' the sound of a single gunshot on the nearly empty streets of an African town is absolutely horrifying. Mr. Heumann conveys a suddenness and an immediacy to the gunfire that the average Hollywood action thriller, with thousands of rounds of ammunition, can't achieve. ''Port Djema'' has a great sense of the sinister; too bad the rest of it is so shapeless.

title: Why the Millennium Counts
description: It seems only fair to begin 1999 by taking a strong stand on whether we endorse holding a big millennial celebration next Dec. 31, or playing down the event. So far the countdown has not produced much more than a catchy name for consumer products and a list of the century's greatest books that ranks the Studs Lonigan trilogy above everything written by Joseph Conrad. Purists claim that next New Year's Eve will not begin a new millennium anyway, since mankind will not have actually lived through a thousand-year cycle until midnight on Dec. 31, 2000. Millennium-phobes argue that the whole event has an air of cultural and religious chauvinism, and that the celebration of the 2,000th anniversary of Jesus Christ's birth might be an event of more interest to Christians than Muslims, Buddhists or Jews.

title: Stocks Soar Phoenix-Like in Big 4th-Quarter Turnaround
description: The fourth quarter of 1998, when ''technology'' and ''Internet'' were synonymous with almost instant paper wealth and the stock market staged as stunning a turnaround as any in recent memory, left many professionals rubbing their eyes in disbelief.

title: Chicago Logs More Killings Than New York City in '98
description: For the first time in many years, New York was not the city that recorded the most killings in the country last year, officials said yesterday: Chicago had more homicides.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, DAMON
description: WRIGHT-Damon, playwright, 48, on December 28, 1998, after a long illness. Beloved son of Artis and Birdell Wright, and loving brother of Joni and Lydia, all of Long Beach, California, and of Carter and Rosemary, his sister-in-law, of Jefferson, TX. He will be sorely missed by his family and friends. Contributions in his memory may be made to New York Theater Workshop, 79 East Fourth Street, New York, New York 10003. A memorial gathering will be held in SoHo in Manhattan on Saturday, January 2, at 3 P.M. at 113 Prince Street, Apartment 4-EF, between Greene and Wooster Streets. For information 212-502-3502.

title: Shrine to a Hardy Dream That's Nothing but Net
description: This is about my family's trip to the Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass. A little background might be helpful. Please humor me.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Reading through the menu at Heartbeat, you begin to sense something different about the food. What is it, you wonder as you peruse the offerings. Organic vegetable consomme with sage dumplings. Arborio rice with butternut squash and wild mushrooms. Cured venison loin with dried cherry chutney. Whole poached turbot and heirloom potatoes in a celery broth. Grilled paillard of salmon with caramelized cauliflower and herb salad. Fillet of naturally fed beef tenderloin with autumn mushrooms and baked Yukon potato.

title: Drug Safety for Children
description: Since the early 1960's, the Federal Food and Drug Administration has required pharmaceutical companies to prove through clinical tests that the drugs they market are safe and effective. Such tests are typically conducted only on adults. But new regulations effective in April will at last require separate testing on infants and children.

title: Poland's Deficit Falls $113 Million in Month
description: Poland's current account deficit fell $113 million in November from October as imports declined because of lower demand prompted by slowing economic growth. The current account deficit totaled $781 million in November, compared with $894 million in October, the National Bank of Poland said yesterday.

title: 2 Peoples Separated By Ocean, Not by Borders
description: The Borders bookstore version of the Tower of London stands four stories tall, with such vast space devoted to words, chilled chardonnay and house blend coffee that at least one British author felt the acute need to retreat to the new gleaming restrooms for refuge from a panic attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALVIN, ANNE
description: MALVIN-Anne. Of Hollywood, FL. Formerly of Rockville Centre, New York. Passed away December 30, 1998. She was the beloved mother of Susan (Dr. Noel) Nathanson and Wendy (Stephen) Miller. Loving grandmother of Gary (Susan), David (Allison), Karen (Ted), Debra (Vic), Lisa (Jeff) and Barry (Lea). Cherished greatgrandmother of Brian, Alex, Hayley, Rachel, Nicole, Sarah, Jacob, Daniel and Lauren, and proud sister of Hyman Rabinowitz. Service 1 PM, Sunday, January 3, 1999, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: ARGENTINA GOLD SAYS OFFER FROM RIVAL IS INADEQUATE
description: The Argentina Gold Corporation, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, said yesterday that it had rejected a takeover offer of $91.7 million from the Barrick Gold Corporation as ''inadequate, opportunistic and coercive.'' Barrick's offer of $4 (Canadian) a share, or $142 million (Canadian), significantly undervalues Argentina Gold, the company said. The offer, Argentina Gold said, is an attempt to acquire 100 percent of the two companies' Veladero gold mining joint venture in Argentina before further exploration results are announced and Argentina Gold's stock price climbs as a result. Argentina Gold has a 60 percent stake in the venture and Barrick a 40 percent interest. Toronto-based Barrick Gold, like Argentina Gold, is a mining company.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYSS, LILLIAN D.
description: WYSS-Lillian D. of Hillsdale, NJ died unexpectedly early December 24, 1998. Beloved wife of Albert C. Wyss. Devoted mother of Nancy and Caroline. Dear aunt of Robert C. Wyss, William Britton, Charles and Richard Van Patten, Dorothy Mayer and Catherine Koenig. As an outstanding artist, Lillian worked as a medical artist at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and during W.W. II as a civilian artist with the U.S. Army Signal Corps. She was a member of the Pascack Art Association and received blue ribbons for paintings exhibited at Bergen Community College and at various banks and libraries. She was a graudate of Pratt Insititute. Visiting at Becker Funeral Home, 219 Kinderkamack Road, Westwood, NJ on Tuesday, January 5, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Services at 11:30AM on Wednesday, Jan 6. Entombment at Garden of Memories, Soldier Hill Road, Washington Twp, NJ.

title: Midwest Shows Rise In Industrial Activity
description: Manufacturing activity in the Midwest picked up unexpectedly in December, helped by rising production and an increase in inventories.

title: THE NEW EUROPE: Founding Fathers; Its 3 Fathers Are Proud of Baby Euro, and Certain It Will Grow Up Strong
description: Twenty years ago, when he was Chancellor of West Germany, Helmut Schmidt thought there would be a single European currency by the early 1980's. Instead, he is still carrying around six different kinds of money in his briefcase.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, GILDA H.
description: GORDON-Gilda H. On December 30, 1998, of Great Neck. Beloved wife of Sidney. Devoted mother of Jon and Marc. Loving sister of Stanley Kessler. Services Sunday 10:30 AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (Opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, NYC.

title: Brazil Slashes Money for Project Aimed at Protecting Amazon
description: Under intense pressure to reduce its spending, the Brazilian Government has slashed funds intended for a $250 million pilot project backed by seven leading industrial nations that has been the centerpiece of Brazil's efforts to save the Amazon rain forest.

title: U.P.S. Rates to Rise 2.5%
description: United Parcel Service of America Inc., the world's top package delivery company, plans to raise rates about 2.5 percent next year -- its smallest increase in 11 years, helped by the lowest oil prices in more than a decade. The new rates for most domestic air express and ground shipments take effect on Feb. 8. U.P.S. does not plan to raise rates for shipments sent abroad but will charge $1 extra for shipments to remote areas.

title: A Century Portrayed In Movies
description: Next year, New Year's Day will be about looking foward to the third millennium. So maybe this year, it should be about looking back. The 20th century has been quite a ride, as these films - from a lush, pastoral Bernardo Bertolucci drama, set at the turn of the last century, to Stanley Kubrick's space classic, set at the turn of this one - show. They could make an interesting holiday-weekend videofest (lots of love, war and politics), but be warned: they're not all masterpieces.

title: STOCK OF WIRELESS COMPANY DROPS ON EARNINGS NEWS
description: Shares of Electromagnetic Sciences Inc., which makes wireless communications systems, fell 13 percent yesterday after the company said that fourth-quarter earnings would fall from year-earlier levels and that it had cut 10 percent of its work force. The company, based in Norcross, Ga., said that it had cut about 120 jobs in the quarter and that earnings would be ''near break-even'' because of delays in orders for its products. The company expects fourth-quarter revenue to be about $44 million, down from $48 million a year earlier. It had net income in the 1997 quarter of $2.4 million, or 28 cents a share. The company's stock fell $2.125, to $14.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAWCETT, JACKSON
description: FAWCETT-Jackson. On December 24, 1998, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Bessie, loving father of Susan Sosin and Cynthia Parham, adoring grandfather of Clifford, Tyler, and Clarissa. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Monday, January 4th, at 12 noon. Interment to follow at Hackensack Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Hospice Family Care, 310 South Williams Boulevard, #

title: Vintage Dickens, Dark and Sunny
description: In June 1865, Charles Dickens was traveling to London when his train derailed, leaving his car dangling off a bridge 10 feet above a riverbed. Dickens helped rescue the two women with whom he had been vacationing and whose connection to him he did not want revealed: his lover, the young actress Ellen Ternan, and her accommodating mother. After hours of helping attend to the wreck's victims, some seriously hurt and others dead, he climbed back into his compartment to rescue the manuscript he carried with him, a chapter of his novel in progress, ''Our Mutual Friend.'' As he wrote in a postscript to the book, his characters ''were much soiled, but otherwise unhurt'' by the experience.

title: Hollywood Hokum Countered by Venom
description: To a movie critic, the holiday season now ending might be summed up in a single Shakespearean phrase: ''the winter of our discontent.'' Two of the season's finest films, ''Affliction'' and ''A Simple Plan,'' both set in rural small-town America, are draped in snow. Both are bleak, devastating meditations on human frailty, and yes, discontent. The treacherous landscapes in which they are set make their desperate characters seem all the more weak and fallible.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about large Italian companies that want to increase profits by reducing their real estate holdings misidentified one, a large bank created in a recent merger of two banks. It is the Istituto Bancario San Paolo di Torino. (Banca Intesa is a holding company for two other banks.)

title: The Neediest Cases; For Disabled Children, A Respite in the Country
description: ''1998 has been a good year,'' Bridget Arroyo said yesterday afternoon. Then a flicker of terror crossed her face. She put a hand to her heart and knocked on some nearby wood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUBEN, FRIDA
description: HAUBEN - Frida. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Men's Club mourn the passing of the beloved mother of their devoted member Benjamin Hauben and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Haskel Lookstein, Rabbi Joshua Lookstein, Assistant Rabbi Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Fast-Track Trial In the Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: Portland Journal; An Idea + a Philanthropist = a Market
description: Owen Wells, financial adviser to the Maine philanthropist Elizabeth B. Noyce, had just returned from a trip to the Pacific Northwest, where he had visited the Pike Place Market in Seattle and the Granville Island Public Market in Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Many museums are closed today for the New Year's holiday and most galleries are closed today through Monday, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Bowl Games at a Glance
description: Ratings by the New York Times computer. All times Eastern.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHEINMAN, ALAN
description: SCHEINMAN-Alan. Happy Birthday. Seven years, many tears. We will always miss your love and great sense of humor. Love, Roni, Greg, Sandy and Jarret

title: ODS Networks to Cut Jobs
description: The networking-products maker ODS Networks Inc. said today that it would cut 72 manufacturing jobs and 45 professional jobs and take a fourth-quarter charge as it restructures its operations. The size of the restructuring charge was not disclosed. The company, based in Richardson, said it would consolidate its supplier base, reduce facility space and write down the value of inventory associated with older technologies and the value of certain fixed assets that will no longer be used.

title: Pataki Inaugural Speech To Take a National Tack
description: Gov. George E. Pataki will begin his second term today with an inaugural address providing a glimpse of the themes he plans to emphasize as he seeks to broaden his reputation nationally over the next year.

title: Buses and Bets: A Way of Life; Despite Crashes, the Ride Is Part of the Casino Outing
description: They are as different as the games they play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, RAE
description: POLLACK-Rae. Passed away peacefully December 28, 1998 at the age of 89. Loving mother of Leslie and Yvonne Pollack and the late Susan Pollack. Devoted grandmother of Jonathan Pollack, Jennifer Reiner and Fredrica Pollack. Proud great-grandmother of Annie Reiner. Beloved wife of the late Martin Pollack, the late Samuel T. Cohn, and the late Arnold A. Freedman. Adored sister of the late Bill Fischer and the late Murry Fischer. Service Sunday January 3, 1999, 9:15AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla NY, after which the family will be receiving visitors until 9PM at their home. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Katonah Museum of Art, Route 22 at Jay St, Katonah NY 10536 or the American Jewish Historical Society, 2 Thornton Rd, Waltham MA 02453 or the charity of your choice.

title: Beyond Cliched Interpretations of Exile, Suffering and Death
description: Photography introduced a number of new subjects to the pictorial canon and then revised some old ones radically. Refugees, for instance: throughout history, wars and politically repressive regimes have left refugees in their wake, but the search for safe haven and the condition of refugees have seldom been painted. The holy family on the flight to Egypt is the exception, a kind of ur representation that usurped all others and did not call for pity alone.

title: Damon Wright, 48, Playwright and Reporter
description: Damon Wright, a playwright, died on Monday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan after a long illness, his family said. He was 48 and lived in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Embassy in Israel Shut; Said to Be Under a Threat
description: The United States Ambassador to Israel ordered the American Embassy in Tel Aviv closed today after what embassy officials called a ''direct and credible'' threat of a terrorist attack against the building.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Rockin' and Rollin' And Dining

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DEIN, GITTIE
description: DEIN-Gittie. Our Gittie-My Sister, today and every day we miss you.

title: Residential Real Estate; From Church Parking Lot to Apartment Tower
description: A parking lot at the corner of East Broadway and Rutgers Street on the Lower East Side will begin to fill this spring with an 83-unit apartment building that its developers are betting will draw young professionals searching for a less expensive alternative to Greenwich Village and SoHo.

title: Low Hog Prices Hurt Agricultural Index
description: The lowest hog prices since 1964 helped drag down the December index of prices received by farmers for their goods, the United States Agriculture Department said on Wednesday.

title: Teacher's Libel Suit Dismissed
description: A Massachusetts trial court judge has dismissed a Wellesley professor's libel suit against a student journalist who had written, incorrectly, that the professor ''gained tenure within the Africana Studies department only after successfully suing the college for racial discrimination.''

title: Times Square Revelers Raise an Orderly Ruckus for 1999
description: With what the police described as the biggest but most orderly crowd in years herded neatly into barricaded quadrangles, New Year's Eve descended on Times Square last night in a carefully controlled explosion of festivity that felt like both a gala and a warm-up.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bell Atlantic in Talks To Acquire Airtouch

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, BEATRICE (NEE WEISS)
description: RUBIN-Beatrice (nee Weiss). Passed away Tuesday, December 29, in Florida. Beloved mother of Ira and Maddy and Stuart and Carol. Beloved sister of Bernard and Sylvia and Jerome and Isabel Weiss. Adored grandmother of Scott, Neil, Stephanie, Jonathan, Farrah and Jessica. Services Sunday, January 3 at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, N.Y. at 9:45AM.

title: Small Stocks Star in Market's '98 Farewell
description: Shares of large companies fell yesterday and shares of small companies had their best day in two months as investors completed tax-related selling on the final day of 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARDELMANN, DR. ROBERT L.
description: FARDELMANN-Dr. Robert L. of Garden City, NY died peacefully at home December 27. A memorial service will be held Saturday, Jan. 2, 10:30 AM at the Garden City Community Church, corner Stuart Avenue and Whitehall Blvd. in Garden City, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Rutgers University Crew Program, Rutgers University Foundation, 7 College Ave., New Brunswick, NJ 08901-1261.

title: A Private Line for the Rose Bowl
description: All the other college bowls succumbed first, to the likes of Fedex, Nokia, USF&G, Jeep, CompUSA, Tostitos, Carquest, Chick-fil-A, Culligan, Toyota and Insight.com.

title: At the Movies; Kevin Spacey, Destiny Shaper
description: Kevin Spacey describes his career strategy straightforwardly: ''In life, you have to make your own fate.''

title: McKay Is Trying to Catch Up With Devils
description: After his first rigorous practice in more than a week, Randy McKay sat down on the ice at the South Mountain Arena to speak with Devils Coach Robbie Ftorek.

title: Ukrainian Auto Venture Halts Assembly Line
description: Avtozaz-Daewoo, the car making joint venture between Ukraine's largest car producer, Avtozaz, and the Daewoo Corporation of South Korea, shut down its assembly line until February after disagreements between the partners and low sales, a director of the venture said yesterday. Avtozaz said that Daewoo did not fulfill an obligation to invest about $55 million to cover Avtozaz loans to nongovernment domestic companies and another $20 million to set up a sales network in 1998, the director said.

title: Hofstra Is Seeking Conference Supremacy
description: Their visibility has soared. Their answering machines have been crammed with congratulations.

title: Late Rallies Fail to Lift Asian Stocks
description: Overseas stocks rebounded sharply in the fourth quarter of 1998, both in developed and emerging markets. But in some emerging markets even 100 percent rallies were not enough to make up for the selloffs that pushed stocks to their lows just as the quarter began. Many of these markets still ended the year with declines.

title: Parted Siblings In Foster Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Korea Plans to Raise $24.5 Billion for Banks
description: South Korea plans to sell 29.6 trillion won, or $24.5 billion, of Government bonds this year, one-third more than it sold in 1998, to help pay for the revamping of the nation's battered financial institutions.

title: About New York; Starting Anew To Liberate Young Minds
description: FOUR preschoolers clung to Ned O'Gorman on Columbus Avenue near Lincoln Center, when a stranger in the crowd nudged him. ''Excuse me,'' she said impatiently. As Mr. O'Gorman carefully shepherded the four youngsters to the other side, he looked over his shoulder at the woman.

title: No Orders for Japanese Shipbuilders
description: Japan's biggest shipbuilders said this week that they had received no orders in the final quarter of 1998.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: HOCKEY

title: A New Year's Eve Gala With a Bit of Newness
description: You'll get no complaints here about the waltzes of Johann Strauss Jr., which are absolutely perfect pieces. No less a formidable composer than Brahms was an enormous admirer of the waltz king's work, and having tried his own hand at waltz writing, he knew it wasn't as easy as it looked.

title: Markets Closed
description: All United States financial markets, Government offices and banks were closed in observance of New Year's Day.

title: Beyond the Stacks of Pride and Money: A 3-Way Library Race
description: It was the year of the library. Last summer London inaugurated the new British Library; in October Paris witnessed the grand opening of the new National Library of France; the next month the New York Public Library unveiled its renovation of the Main Reading Room at the 42d Street flagship building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, BEATRICE
description: BELL-Beatrice. The Board of Governors of the Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member and dear friend, Mrs. Charles (Beatrice) Bell, and offers its heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends. David L. Rudnick, President Robert S. Puder, Secretary

title: Hyundai Is Starting Truck Exports to U.S.
description: The Hyundai Motor Company began exporting commercial vehicles to the United States this week, becoming the first South Korean car manufacturer to do so.

title: Getting School Construction Right
description: The New York City Board of Education's new report on its 1,100 schools consists of 71,000 pages of disheartening news. Conditions are still generally poor, and in the best-case scenario they will only be ''fair'' after five more years of intensive effort. Many schools are also overcrowded, and the city will not be able to take advantage of new state aid for smaller classes and pre-kindergarten programs unless it gets more classroom space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINK, LAWRENCE B.
description: MINK-Lawrence B. The Partners of Saiber Schlesinger Satz & Goldstein mourn the sudden death of their Partner, a distinguished lawyer, and a devoted friend.

title: Banks and Brokers Gear Up for the Euro
description: A day after 11 European countries christened the euro as their new currency, financial institutions across the Continent began the enormous job of reprogramming their electronic networks before markets reopen Monday. Although most institutions are bracing for technical glitches, financial executives say they are cautiously optimistic about a smooth start. And investment experts predict the euro will boost the popularity of European stocks and bonds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODWIN, WILLIAM
description: GOODWIN-William of NYC. Suddenly on Dec. 30, 1998. Husband of Maria Dudin, father of Andrew & Peter, son of Helen and Charles Goodwin, Jr. & brother of Patricia, Anita, Charles & Robert Goodwin. Will was a loving and devoted husband and father, a kind and caring son and brother, a loyal and firm friend, and a brilliant & dedicated attorney who was very much loved and who will be greatly missed. Reposing at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave, NYC. Visiting hours are Saturday 7-9PM, Sunday 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Monday at 10 AM at the Epiphany R.C. Church, 239 East 21 Street, New York City.

title: Outlook Is Dim for Guangdong's Creditors
description: The Chinese Government will soon announce how it plans to cover the debts of the nation's second-largest financial company, which it closed in October, and the news for foreign bankers is likely to be bad.

title: Literature as a Test?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, JOHN A.
description: PARKER-John A., age 81, of Mt. Sinai, NY, on December 30, 1998. Beloved husband of Catherine (nee Henry). Loving father of John T., Carol Ann Blaine and Alan. Dear father-in-law of Patricia and Armin. Cherished grandfather of John, Daniel, Stacy and Harry Oehl, Timothy and Joan, Kimberly, Susan & Frank Turano, and Brian. Adored great-grandfather of Katie, Molly, Courtney, Jack, Timmy, Megan and Matthew. Fond brother of Annette Falasco, the late Isabelle Buck, the late Marie Chatterton and the late Frances Conforti. Mr. Parker was a retired employee of The New York Times. After he retired he spread a lot of love and cheer as Santa Claus at the Sun Vet Mall for seven years. The family will receive friends Saturday 7-10PM and Sunday 2-4PM and 7-10PM at the O.B. Davis Funeral Home, 4839 Nesconset Highway (Route 347), Port Jefferson Station. Mass Monday, 10AM at Infant Jesus R.C. Church, Port Jefferson. Interment Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELSON, SYLVIA
description: DELSON-Sylvia. Beloved mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, sister. Services private.

title: BASKETBALL: She Can Go Home Again; In Her Senior Season, Holdsclaw Gets to Play in the Garden
description: She knows it would make for a nice, romantic story, but Chamique Holdsclaw cannot tell a lie. She did not grow up dreaming about playing basketball in Madison Square Garden, did not go to Knicks games very often as a child and will not feel jitters, tingles or any other manifestation of awe when she steps onto the famed court for the first time in her career.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GALT, MICHAEL TRISTAN
description: GALT-Michael Tristan. January 2, 1995. I love today and always. Stephanie

title: Stripping the Amazon
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLATTBERG, NORMAN
description: BLATTBERG-Norman. on December 29, of Deerfield Beach, FL and Brooklyn. Loving husband of Evelyn, father of Dr. Paul Blattberg, Faith Oland, Karen Eichel. Grandfather of Bess, Maxine, Ruthie, Andrew, Josh, Nicole, Russell, Eric. Services Jan 3, 11:30AM, I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 1985 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIGLAND, SHEILAH
description: SPIGLAND-Sheilah. The Auxiliary of Montefiore Medical Center is deeply saddened by the passing of its member, Sheilah Spigland. Sheilah was a dedicated volunteer who worked in the gift shop as well as in the library. She gave unstintingly of her time in the library and donated many, many books. We will miss her energy, devotion and her very warm and friendly manner. Our deepest sympathy to her beloved husband Dr. Ilya Spigland, her two daughters Nitsana and Karen and her son Ethan. Auxiliary of Montefiore Medical Center Ruth Saporta, President Mary Goldsmith, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEDER, LUCY
description: FEDER-Lucy, on December 31, 1998, of New York City. Beloved wife of Morris. Caring mother of Harry and Karen. Devoted grandmother of Jean, Laura, Alison and Emily. Dear sister of Eva Roberts & Hanus Kraus. Services Sunday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to the American Lung Association.

title: Closing TV's Racial Divide; Reflecting the Audience
description: To the Editor:

title: A Haunted Future
description: To the Editor:

title: New Sprinklers Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOKARZEL, YEMNA HELEN
description: MOKARZEL-Yemna Helen. We miss you so much Dearest, but we know you are happy. Much love, the Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAKE, EDITH (NEE EHRLICH)
description: LAKE-Edith (nee Ehrlich) on Thursday, December 30, 1998 at Mt. Sinai Hospital at age 83. Predeceased by her husband Daniel Arthur Lake (Lackowitz). She is survived by two nieces, Laurie Beckoff Nagy and Jill Beckoff Nagy and two grandnieces and two grandnephews. Services on Sunday at 1 P.M., at ''Parkside'' Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, corner 66th Avenue. Interment at New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDIN, CLARA
description: RUDIN-Clara at 92 years. Beloved wife of the late Lazaruz (Lefty). Devoted mother of Dr. Barry and the late Dr. Arthur. Cherished mother-in-law of April. Loving grandmother of Dr. Andrew, Gregory, Dr. Steven, Douglas, Alec and Joshua. Dear sister of Gersten Lebowitz, Marcia Geminder and Goldie Degani. Service Sunday 11:30am ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn (near Ave V). Donations can be made to Hadassah of Queens.

title: Walker Hancock, 97, Sculptor On War and Religious Themes
description: Walker Kirtland Hancock, a sculptor known for his monumental war memorials, celebratory depictions of Presidents and works with religious themes, died on Wednesday at his home in Gloucester, Mass. He was 97.

title: Orange Shorts and Red Ink; Hooters Chain, a Hit Elsewhere, Falters in Manhattan
description: As if more evidence were needed that Manhattan is not really part of America, consider this: The Hooters here is bankrupt.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEINBERG, PAUL
description: KLEINBERG-Paul. 1/2/94. Dad, you would have loved the challenges we faced last year-personal & political. Miss your perseverance, insight and love. Larry

title: Euro Expected to Unleash Bull Market
description: Euroka! That's the view of many investors looking forward to the debut in major financial markets on Monday of the euro, the single currency that now binds 11 European countries and promises to create a more unified economy in much of Europe.

title: William A. Lee Is Dead at 98; Marines' Acclaimed 'Ironman'
description: William A. Lee, whose exploits in Nicaragua between the two world wars earned him three Navy Crosses, the nickname Ironman and a lasting place in Marine Corps legend, died last Sunday at Mary Washington Hospital in Fredericksburg, Va. He was 98 and lived in the nearby town of Ferry Farms.

title: Quarterbacks Are Wild Cards This Week
description: This weekend the American Football Conference playoffs are about quarterbacks: who will play, who won't, and who should have kept his mouth shut.

title: Beyond the Clinton-Bashing, Agony Among Conservatives
description: Really, truly, they are not the Anti-Clinton Party, say the conservatives who are meeting in this sunbaked desert city for their annual examination of who they are.

title: Beijing Journal; Writer Rides Dirty Laundry to the Top in China
description: Each day An Dun receives a dozen calls from people desperate to spill their deepest secrets, vying to have their private lives laid bare and dissected in her popular weekly newspaper column. Some have become pregnant out of wedlock. Some have been raped by their bosses. Some have been abandoned by their husbands. Others have done the ditching themselves.

title: Looking Back at 20th Century, Pope Says Respecting Human Dignity Is Key to World Peace
description: Pope John Paul II declared today that the defense of human dignity forms the foundation of world peace, and he urged the world to renew its dedication to the respect of individual human dignity at the end of a century often marked by its violation in war and violence.

title: For Oilfield Workers, Not the Best of Times
description: As Tim Gimbel sees it from the double-wide trailer near here where he now spends his days, even working a drilling rig when it's 25 below beats a layoff. He will not have the money to build a garage this summer, so his wife, Laura, has at least two more winters of creeping an icy hundred yards uphill every morning to fetch her car from a shed as she leaves for her job as a secretary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERVOSH, EDWARD
description: MERVOSH-Edward. On December 29, 1998. Beloved father of Heather; loving companion of Patty Swain; cherished friend of many. Economic journalist and editor for Business Week magazine for 14 years; New York editor for the Economist Group; editor-in-chief of International Business magazine; most recently with KPMG online publication. He will be missed greatly by all. Visiting Sunday, 2-4 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Work, Work, Work: It's Joyous for the Jets
description: As the first playoff bye week in Jets history sailed along today, some members of the organization found themselves in unfamiliar territory.

title: Religion Journal; Group Sees Mixed Trend In Giving by Protestants
description: In the recessionary years of the early 1990's, some Protestant denominations faced budget shortfalls and were forced to downsize, cutting back staff at the national levels.

title: Pataki, Starting His 2d Term, Sees State as Model for Nation
description: George Elmer Pataki began his second term as Governor today by declaring that his success in scaling back government had rekindled New York's spirit, saying that the strides of the last four years showed that the state was ready to lead the nation into the next century.

title: E*Trade Cut Option Price Just Before Stock Surged
description: E*Trade Group Inc., the No. 2 on-line broker, reduced the exercise price on employee stock options two weeks after its stock traded at a 21-month low and began a three-month surge that increased its price sixfold.

title: Closing TV's Racial Divide; Too Many Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: A Backup With Bluster Will Lead the Seminoles
description: It is the red hair shorn close that earned him the nickname Rooster. But a cocky strut was there long before Marcus Outzen wandered onto the field during Florida State's 10th game of the season. It was there last spring when the quarterback, bothered that his name was listed near the bottom of the Seminoles' depth chart, busted into Bobby Bowden's office for an explanation.

title: A Montana Wilderness Is Fly-Fishing Paradise
description: With temperatures seasonably wintry out here, it seems as good a time as any to unhook and release a fish story about a particularly satisfying adventure in Montana trout country. At the least, it will help address my cabin fever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILENSKY, RUBIN I.
description: WILENSKY-Rubin I., died at age 86 on December 31, 1998 in Florida. Beloved husband of Esther, loving father of Harris and Phyllis Akins, devoted grandfather of Sheri & Marc. Founding member of Bellerose Jewish Center in 1948. Service is on Sunday, January 3rd at Noon at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, West 150 Route 4, Paramus, NJ. Interment at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ. Donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Once-Beaten Buckeyes Win, And Now Wait On the Fiesta
description: Even when his team was leading Texas A&M by 24-7 late in the third quarter tonight, Ohio State Coach John Cooper had the expression of a desperate man trying to climb out of a pit with its sides lined with sand. Many of the Ohio State fans among the 76,503 here at the Superdome could feel Cooper's pain.

title: Sports of The Times; Glut of Bowls Cheapens All but One
description: I NEVER thought I'd see the day when a U.C.L.A. football team would view a trip to the Rose Bowl as settling for something. But the day has come. U.C.L.A.'s players are grousing about a mighty tumble that sent them from an undefeated season and a national championship showdown with Tennessee to a beauty pageant game yesterday against Wisconsin. After U.C.L.A.'s stunning loss to Miami last month, guard Andy Myers said: ''Oh well, we're still going to the Rose Bowl. Didn't that used to be the big one?''

title: As Nations Shed Roles, Is Medieval the Future?
description: Is it possible that cyberspace and economic globalization are pushing the modern world back into the Middle Ages?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLIN, MARSHALL (MIKE)
description: PERLIN-Marshall (Mike). The family of Loretta Rowe-Perlin mourns the loss and celebrates the life of Loretta's beloved husband, Mike. they were deeply devoted to each other for more than 20 years. Mike was the cherished son-in-law of Lillian Rowe-Lynch, trusted friend and brother-in-law of Kathleen Rowe and proud uncle of Bernie, Robert, Thomas, Virginia and Peter Rowe-Eck. The love and joy he expressed in caring for Loretta was an inspiration to us all. He will live on in our hearts.

title: CAMBODIAN DENIES HE OPPOSED TRIAL FOR KHMER ROUGE
description: In an angry statement, Prime Minister Hun Sen denied today that he opposed a trial for two high-ranking Khmer Rouge defectors and said he supported an investigation into the mass killings of the 1970's when the movement controlled Cambodia.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEST, DOUGLAS
description: WEST-Douglas. January 2, 1931November 27, 1995. Remembered.

title: Soft Oil Prices Take Their Toll On Wildcatters
description: Until late November, the shed next to one of George Fancher's wells here in northwestern Wyoming was alive around the clock with the chugging and hissing of pistons and pumps. They filtered water coming out of his well and injected clean water back in to keep the oil flowing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VEREBAY, MAX
description: VEREBAY-Max, died peacefully at home on December 29th, 1998 at age 85. Beloved husband of Mollie, father of Hildi & Leonard, grandfather of Alyssa, Andi, Wendi, Brad and Amy. Service Sunday, at 12:30, at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Atlantic Ave., Delray, FL. Memorial contributions may be made to UJA Federation.

title: Meeting of Comic Minds But No Bam! Splat! Zap!
description: A middle-aged guy with long, dirty hair and a sweatshirt was weighing his options. ''Girls?'' he said, raising one hand like a dish on a balance scale. ''Or comics?'' He raised the other.

title: Arabic Newspaper Office Is Attacked by Arsonist
description: A car was driven into a distribution center of an Arabic-language newspaper in Queens yesterday and set on fire, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PELLMAN, EDWIN
description: PELLMAN-Edwin. ''In time the Rockies may crumble, Gibralter may tumble (They're only made of clay), But-our love...'' MSP

title: The Stoics Have a Stand on Everything, Even on Dinner Parties and Sex
description: After being off the best-seller list for nearly 2,000 years, the Stoic philosopher Epictetus has been revived, thanks to Tom Wolfe's new novel, ''A Man in Full'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux).

title: Penn State Finds Ways to Confuse Couch
description: If it was Tim Couch's final game at Kentucky, it was not the best way to leave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, GILDA H.
description: GORDON-Gilda H. On December 30, 1998, of Great Neck. Beloved wife of Sidney. Devoted mother of Jon and Marc. Loving sister of Stanley Kessler. Services Sunday 10:30 AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (Opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, NYC.

title: Giuliani-Pataki Dispute Over Financing Stalls Housing for Mentally Ill Homeless
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki are at odds over the second phase of a housing program for mentally ill homeless people in New York City, arguing over the scope of the program and the size of the state's contribution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHALEN, JOSEPH, SR.
description: WHALEN-Joseph, Sr., 91, of Avalon, NJ, died at his winter home in Brewster, NY on Thursday, December 31, 1998. He is survived by his son, Joseph Whalen, Jr., of Brewster, his daughter, Patricia Whalen of Westminster West, VT, and six grandchildren. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated Saturday, January 2nd, 12:00 noon at St. Elizabeth Seton Church in Ridgefield, CT. Interment will be private. Friends may call at the Beecher Funeral Home, 1 Putnam Ave., Brewster, NY, 10:00-11:30AM on Saturday. Contributions in his memory may be sent to Children's Activity Fund, Green Chimneys, Box 719, Brewster, NY 10509.

title: CLINTON PROPOSES A BUDGET INCREASE FOR THE MILITARY
description: Heeding warnings from the nation's military chiefs, President Clinton has decided to propose the first real increase in the Pentagon's budget in nearly a decade and the largest since the cold-war buildup of the mid-1980's, Administration and defense officials said.

title: McCain Calls Gore Flawed Over Actions In '96 Race
description: Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who took formal steps on Wednesday to run for President, wasted no time today in signaling that he would make Vice President Al Gore's fund-raising techniques a major part of his campaign.

title: Hong Kong Apartment Sales Jumped 96% in November
description: Ivy Lam thinks property prices in Hong Kong will not fall further, so she and her husband are buying their first home, a small, Government-subsidized two-bedroom apartment, for $1.09 million (Hong Kong), or $140,800 (United States).

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, a front-page article yesterday about a visit to a Cambodian resort by two Khmer Rouge leaders omitted several sentences at the continuation in some copies. The affected passage should have read:

title: Is Guam Available?
description: All 700 hotel rooms in Tonga are already booked for next New Year's Eve. This is unhappy news for people who had toyed with the idea of being right on the spot when the new millennium crosses the international date line. Many New York City residents, having heard that 46 percent of all American pleasure travelers would like to celebrate the great event in Times Square, have undoubtedly also started thinking that Tonga would be a very nice place to be. Too late.

title: This Time, Albany Party Is Short on Pageantry
description: George E. Pataki's inaugural celebration four years ago had the trappings of a coronation -- a pageant replete with marching bands, celebrities, a laser show, confetti and a black-tie gala for 13,000 guests.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY
