description: SOVEREIGN ISLANDS -- Cruise ships' dumping of oily waste threatens the environment. But prosecution must surmount the efforts of an influential industry to make itself exempt from American regulations. A special report by Douglas Frantz, in section 1.

title: 7 Are Killed And 7 Injured In Car Crashes As Year Begins
description: In three and a half hours on New Year's Eve, seven lives were lost and others were forever altered in car wrecks in the New York metropolitan region, and in each case the police said a drunken driver might have been to blame.

title: Journal; Force-Fed Fun
description: Perpetual New Year's Eve anxiety is officially here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAPIRO, DAVID
description: SCHAPIRO-David. A Holocaust survivor, born in Wilno, Russia, February 18, 1893. Beloved father of Nina Holzman, father-in-law of Sy Holzman. Grandfather to Luba Mayo and Larry Holzman. Great grandfather to Jason, Ronni and Michael Mayo. He died peacefully at his home December 31, 1998. Funeral on Sunday, January 3, 11AM at I.J. Morris Hempstead. He was a very special individual and will be greatly missed.

title: Economists Foresee a Stumble in Uzbekistan's Stride
description: A striking new look has crept into this capital of Soviet-era concrete blocks, where a half-dozen swank hotels, office buildings and a theme park that people call ''Mini Disneyland'' are open or under construction.

title: In Australia, a Tribute to Lost Sailors
description: A thousand yachtsmen and women and an estimated 4,000 more visitors and summer tourists gathered here at Constitution Dock this afternoon to pray for those affected so traumatically when a fierce storm ripped apart the fleet in the 54th Sydney-to-Hobart yacht race Sunday and Monday.

title: Politics a Hot New Internet Investment
description: Though Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has never declared himself a Presidential candidate, at least 39 pieces of prime Internet real estate have already been claimed in his name. Yet only two of those addresses for sites on the World Wide Web -- Bush2000.org and GeorgeWBush.com -- belong to people officially affiliated with Governor Bush.

title: Parted Siblings In Foster Care
description: To the Editor:

title: As Oil Prices Languish, Contractors Take Rigs Out of Service
description: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc. did something in the second half of 1998 that would have been unthinkable 12 months earlier: It idled two rigs used to drill for oil and natural gas in the deep waters of the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Customers in Cyberspace
description: On-line shopping jumped dramatically this holiday season, and when preliminary estimates indicated that 1998 Christmas sales more than tripled the figures for 1997, investors flocked to buy shares in Internet retailers. Stock prices -- fueled by dreams of mass marketing on line -- soared even though actual sales on the Internet are still tiny compared with sales in the bricks-and-mortar world. Even a tripling of sales is not terribly surprising given how limited on-line retailing has been.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, JAMES PEARSON, SC.D.
description: GOULD-James Pearson, Sc.D., Geotechnical Engineer. Member National Academy of Engineering. Retired partner Meuser Rutledge Consulting Engineers. Died December 25, 1998. Funeral services 3PM Sunday, January 3, 1999, First Church of Round Hill, Greenwich, CT. Contributions to Cabrini Hospice, 227 E. 19th St., NYC 10003.

title: South Africa Limps Out Of Bad Year For Police
description: This Christmas-New Year's season has not been kind to the South African police. But then, 1998 was not a very good year for them in general.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Riches May Roil Caspian Nations; They Surely Need Money, but Can They Survive a Bonanza?
description: A forest of ancient and rusting oil derricks, relics of the last oil boom here a century ago, stretch from this gritty town toward the shore of the Caspian Sea. They are still producing low-grade crude, worked by laborers who live nearby in wretched hovels. Oil permeates the soil, and in warm months its stench becomes nearly unbearable.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a multivehicle accident in Michigan misstated the number of people killed. It was one, not two.

title: U.S. Insurers Expect Slim Fourth-Quarter Profits
description: The nation's property and casualty insurers are expected to report slim profit gains for the fourth quarter of 1998 because competition has held down premiums.

title: Avalanche Uses Tough Guys, and Ranger Coach Responds in Kind
description: Late last season, shortly after he became coach of the Rangers, John Muckler ignited a shouting match with Coach Mike Milbury of the Islanders after Milbury called a timeout with a big lead late in a game. The confrontation took place with each man behind his bench. Late Thursday night, Muckler verbally confronted another counterpart, Bob Hartley, the rookie coach of the Colorado Avalanche. It happened as both teams and their coaches crossed the ice after the final buzzer in a 6-3 Rangers victory.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Independent Oil Companies Suffer During Weak Market

title: Auto Production Off in Argentina
description: Argentina's auto makers increased production by an estimated 6 percent in 1998, less than expected, as slumping demand in the second half of the year forced makers to curb output.

title: For Cadbury, Candy Looks Sweeter Than Soda
description: By agreeing to sell nearly all its international beverage business to the Coca-Cola Company, Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. made it clear last month that it was leaving the global soft-drink field to Coca-Cola and Pepsico Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCHER, ELSIE
description: DEUTSCHER-Elsie. Beloved wife of the late Ben and mother of Allan (Becky), Freda, Jane Fishman (Lewis). Adored grandmother of Matthew, Andrew, Zachary, Joshua and Danielle Deutscher, Amy and Jessica Fishman. Services are on Sunday, at 11 A.M., Beth David Cemetery, Elmont.

title: Curious Rulings on Capital Punishment
description: In a sound ruling last week, New York State's highest court struck down most of the plea-bargaining provisions of the state's four-year-old death penalty statute. These provisions, the Court of Appeals found, unconstitutionally penalized defendants in capital cases for exercising their Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial.

title: Edward M. Mervosh, 57, Business Journalist
description: Edward M. Mervosh, an economist and business journalist, died on Tuesday at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 57.

title: Clinton's Unusual Year Ends in the Usual Way
description: President Clinton rang out his most unusual of years in his usual, if peculiar, way: in very earnest policy discussions with more than a thousand acquaintances and hangers-on -- and a few old friends and unimpressed strangers -- assembled at the annual Renaissance Weekend here.

title: Parted Siblings In Foster Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, HARRY
description: GREENBERG-Harry, died peacefully at home on January 1. Beloved husband to Sylvia. Devoted father to Neil, Steven and Lucia. Loving grandfather of Jennifer, Judy and Jane. After 52 years of teaching the fashion trade at the Fashion Institute of Technology, he recently retired as a Professor Emeritus. He will be forever in our hearts. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Harry Greenberg Scholarship Fund at FIT. Funeral Services will be held Sunday, January 3, 1PM at the IJ Morris Inc. Funeral Home, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York. For further information call 1-800-624-8282.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROEMER, SADIE
description: ROEMER-Sadie. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Devoted mother of Phyllis & Jerry Satin & Sandra and Bert Dorfman. Cherished grandmother of Leslie and Dean, Basha & John, Sally, John, Jessica and Anthony. Dearest Great Grandma Boo of Joshua, Simone and Luke. Services private.

title: Gay Charity Event Seen as Sending the Wrong Message
description: The news that organizers had canceled the Morning Party on Fire Island did not surprise Michael Ruggiero. He has attended the annual AIDS fund-raising event and social gathering for the last three years, and while he described it as ''a very spiritual thing,'' he also recognized that ''it was meant to die.''

title: Financial World Scrambles To Be Ready for the Euro
description: Thursday was a day for champagne and confetti. Today began the long weekend of strong coffee and takeout food.

title: Facing 'a Century of Opportunity on the Horizon'
description: Following are excerpts from the second inaugural address that Gov. George E. Pataki gave yesterday in Albany:

title: Badgers Prove Doubters Wrong
description: At least U.C.L.A. will not have to wonder about the national championship that could have been.

title: On Brink of Millennium, It Was Just Another Day
description: Nothing ages faster than the ephemera of New Year's Eve. The discarded funny hats by dawn seem like ancient relics, the sequined gowns as odd as the discarded styles of some justifiably forgotten decade.

title: The Neediest Cases; After Years in a Storm, A Safe Place to Rest
description: As a young woman in Minnesota, Elizabeth E. used to stand outside in the rain, mesmerized by the lightning that flashed across the plains. She knew nothing of physics then, and as an Orthodox Jewish woman, she was principally concerned with metaphysical phenomena. But the lightning attracted her, because, she said, it was like her father and her boyfriends: powerful, unpredictable and potentially destructive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEYNE, HANNAH F.
description: ALLEYNE-Hannah F. Of NYC, on December 27, 1998. Daughter of the late Dr. James D. and Mary (Fitzgerald) Alleyne. Sister of Julia, Agnes and Mary Alleyne, all of Peabody, MA, and Jane Thompson of Maine. A memorial funeral service will be held on Monday, January 4, 11 AM in St. John's Church, Peabody, MA. Relatives and friends kindly invited. Retired secretary of Servomation Corp.

title: Era May End For Floating Currencies
description: Last year's dominant economic story might be summed up this way: When currencies float, economies sink.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASLOFF, RUTH
description: KASLOFF-Ruth. On New Year's Day, 1999. Devoted wife of the late George Kasloff; beloved sister of Lilyan Simels; loving mother of Harriet and Stan Berman, Tina Carver; adored grandmother of Jeffrey, Brian and Daniel Carver, Jessica, Jonah and Eliza Berman; devoted aunt of Toba Stutz and Robert & Evelyn Simels; Jennifer, Rebecca and Edward Stutz, and Alexandra Simels. Thirty-seven years of energetic devotion to The American Lung Association enriched her life as she contributed her expertise, professionalism and grand sense of humor. Her wisdom and counsel enriched us all, & her indomitable, youthful spirit will live on with us. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The American Lung Association, 1740 Broadway, NY NY 10019. Funeral service Sunday. Jan. 3, 1999, at 12:30PM, Riverdale Temple, 246 Street and Independence Ave, Riverdale, NY.

title: INSIDE
description: Castro, Four Decades Later

title: When Nature Becomes A Game
description: After eight people died climbing Mount Everest two years ago, troubling questions were raised: What drives so many rich and successful people to endanger their lives climbing the world's most fearsome mountain? Why are professional climbers so willing to take dramatic risks on their behalf?

title: Owners Get a Proposal, By Way of News Media
description: The National Basketball Association owners finally got a glimpse of the union's latest proposal yesterday. The only problem was that they found out about the players' compromises through the news media.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEIZHALS, BENEK
description: GEIZHALS-Benek, born Cracow, Poland on December 31, 1921, died New York, New York on December 31, 1998. His deep-felt belief that he survived the atrocities of the Holocaust for a reason and purpose manifested itself in his love of family and Israel. He dedicated his life to these two loves. He is survived by his wife Esther, his children Benjamin, Michael and Jacqueline Merker, and eight grandchildren. Services at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY at 11:30AM on Sunday, January 3rd.

title: ON PERMANENT PAROLE: A special report.; Days on Methadone, Bound by Its Lifeline
description: Shortly after 9 A.M., Pamela Carlo arrived at the tiny, nondescript clinic in Chinatown for her daily deliverance. It was a cool day, with a packed gray sky. The tang of fish was in the air.

title: Closing TV's Racial Divide
description: To the Editor:

title: Don Taylor, 78, Movie Actor Turned Director and TV Writer
description: Don Taylor, a film actor of the 1940's and 50's who later turned to directing, died on Tuesday at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 78 and lived in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: From the Pacific, Many Hands Link Up to Provide Fish for the Poor
description: The 15-pound king salmon in Tuck Donnelly's arms could just as easily have been dropped, end over end, to the bottom of the Bering Sea. Instead it was headed for the dinner tables of hungry people, courtesy of a program that acquires fish previously discarded by fisheries in Alaska.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, RAE
description: POLLACK-Rae. Passed away peacefully December 28, 1998 at the age of 89. Loving mother of Leslie and Yvonne Pollack and the late Susan Pollack. Devoted grandmother of Jonathan Pollack, Jennifer Reiner and Fredrica Pollack. Proud great-grandmother of Annie Reiner. Beloved wife of the late Martin Pollack, the late Samuel T. Cohn, and the late Arnold A. Freedman. Adored sister of the late Bill Fischer and the late Murry Fischer. Service Sunday January 3, 1999, 9:15AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla NY, after which the family will be receiving visitors until 9PM at their home. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Katonah Museum of Art, Route 22 at Jay St, Katonah NY 10536 or the American Jewish Historical Society, 2 Thornton Rd, Waltham MA 02453 or the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAWCETT, JACKSON
description: FAWCETT-Jackson. On December 24, 1998, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Bessie, loving father of Susan Sosin and Cynthia Parham, adoring grandfather of Clifford, Tyler, and Clarissa. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Monday, January 4th, at 12 noon. Interment to follow at Hackensack Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Hospice Family Care, 310 South Williams Boulevard, #

title: New Sprinklers Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Bringing Cuba in From the Cold
description: Forty years after Fidel Castro seized power it is time for the United States to reorient its policy away from Fidel Castro and toward preparing for a democratic transition in Cuba.

title: Parted Siblings In Foster Care
description: To the Editor:

title: In City of Castro's Triumph, Most Still Back Him
description: It has been 40 years since Fidel Castro led his rebels into this seaside colonial city and declared the end of the Batista dictatorship from the balcony of city hall. For residents here, it has been 40 years of Communist rule, economic sacrifice and endless maneuvering in a cold war with the United States.

title: In Run-Through for Next Year, Mostly Sedate Merrymaking in Times Square
description: New York's New Year's Eve party was a cold, crowded and -- at one point -- smoky, but largely peaceful trial run for the celebration planned for next year to welcome in 2000, according to police officials.

title: Closing TV's Racial Divide; Niches and Chasms
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYSS, LILLIAN D.
description: WYSS-Lillian D. of Hillsdale, NJ died unexpectedly early December 24, 1998. Beloved wife of Albert C. Wyss. Devoted mother of Nancy and Caroline. Dear aunt of Robert C. Wyss, William Britton, Charles and Richard Van Patten, Dorothy Mayer and Catherine Koenig. As an outstanding artist, Lillian worked as a medical artist at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and during W.W. II as a civilian artist with the U.S. Army Signal Corps. She was a member of the Pascack Art Association and received blue ribbons for paintings exhibited at Bergen Community College and at various banks and libraries. She was a graudate of Pratt Insititute. Visiting at Becker Funeral Home, 219 Kinderkamack Road, Westwood, NJ on Tuesday, January 5, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Services at 11:30AM on Wednesday, Jan 6. Entombment at Garden of Memories, Soldier Hill Road, Washington Twp, NJ.

title: Foreman-Holmes Is Called Off
description: George Foreman is pulling the plug on his Jan. 23 bout against Larry Holmes. According to Roy Foreman, the former heavyweight champion's brother, the promoter Roger Leavitt could not secure financing in a timely manner.

title: Work, as Redefined By the Young
description: The meaning of retirement has changed with every American generation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORKIN, SYLVIA HOLLAND
description: ORKIN-Sylvia Holland on Thursday, Dec. 31, 1998, of Bal Harbour, FL, formerly of NYC. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Lazarus A. Orkin. Dear mother of Dr. Fred and Susan Orkin and Drs. Stuart and Roslyn Orkin. Cherished grandmother of Jane, Jeffrey and Jennifer Orkin. Loving sister of Emil Holland and the late Jack J. Holland, Louis Holland and Sadie Zatt. Dear aunt to many nieces and nephews. Sylvia with her late husband was a woman of great generosity. She was a Founder of The Douglas Gardens Jewish Home for the Aged in Miami, a Founder of Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami, a Patron of the Women's Cancer League at Mount Sinai, and a Board Member of The Wien Center there. She was also a long time supporter of the National Women's Committee of Brandeis University. In addition, Mrs. Orkin established The Orkin Skills Center in the Department of Nursing at Beth Israel Medical Center in NYC in memory of her late husband. Private graveside services will be leaving from The Riverside, Amsterdam and 76th Street, Manhattan, at noon on Sunday, Jan. 3. A separate memorial service will be held at a later date (CORRECTION). Donations in Sylvia's memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHAMBERS, ROBERT
description: CHAMBERS-Robert. Remembering Bob. January 2, 1998 in Wilmington N.C. G.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOOLMAN, SELMA (NEE MENDELSOHN)
description: SCHOOLMAN-Selma (nee Mendelsohn). On December 30, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Dear mother of Richard, Michael and Karen, and Judith. Adored grandmother of Ned, John, Alexandra and Susannah. Long time teacher in Plainview-Old Bethpage schools. Graveside services Sunday 11 a.m. at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn L.I.

title: Florida Ponders A Chance It Missed
description: Tony George insists he does not dwell on what might have been. Others do it for him. They say that if George, the University of Florida cornerback and co-captain, had shown some restraint, the Gators might well be in Arizona playing for a national championship instead of settling for the Orange Bowl Classic here.

title: The Euro Will Work (Because It Has To)
description: This weekend a new territory is born: Euroland. It is not a nation or a continent but more like something out of cyberspace -- where most of its first transactions will likely occur. Nonetheless, it is the climax to the most benignly ambitious geopolitical experiment since the founding of the United States.

title: Nature Ceded the Missouri to Man; Now Some Would Give It Back
description: Lewis and Clark would not know the Missouri River now.

title: A Farsighted Play at Trick 2 Averts a Squeeze at Trick 11
description: Ask the top players to make a short list of America's best partnerships, and all would include David Berkowitz of Old Tappan, N.J., and Larry Cohen of Boca Raton, Fla., who came within a hairsbreadth of winning the World Open Pairs Championship title in Lille, France, in September. Last month, Bridge Today magazine named their effort on the diagramed deal as the best defense of the year.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Before I die, I want to know what it feels like to be clean. You see, I don't remember. Imagine that: forgetting what it feels like to be straight. But I don't remember. And I want to feel it.''

title: Hall Refit for Pomp and Happenstance
description: Not since the 1920's has the sunlight glinted so brightly from San Francisco's City Hall dome, a shapely structure taller than the 90-foot dome of the Capitol in Washington

title: Closing TV's Racial Divide; Networks' Tired Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGANN, THOMAS J.
description: McGANN-Thomas J., of West Hempstead, NY on December 31, 1998. Beloved husband of Anne C. (nee: Carroll). Loving father of Anne Marie (Howard) League, Kathleen McGann and Edward Mowery, Maureen, Thomas Jr. (Denise), Francis (MaryAnn). Proud grandfather of Michael and Katie League, Monica Mowery, Thomas, Carolyn, Kelly, Brian, and Kaitlin McGann. Dear brother of Sr. John Raymond CSJ, Most Rev. John R. McGann, James F. and the late Sr. Thomas Joseph CSJ, Madeline & Joseph McGann. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY Saturday and Sunday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Thomas the Apostle R.C. Church, West Hempstead Monday 11 AM, Interment Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, New York. In lieu of flowers donations to Mercy Medical Center, 1000 No. Village Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY 11570, would be appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing on page 39 of the Arts & Leisure section today about a recital on Thursday at Cooper Union commemorating the 100th birthday of Poulenc misstates the starting time. It is 7 P.M., not 7:30.

title: Luxury Resort Off Antigua Becomes More So
description: Jumby Bay Island, the Caribbean retreat that closed in 1997, is open again after an extensive refurbishing, and an expansion that will add a spa, a third restaurant and 30 more rooms is scheduled to be completed in the fall.

title: Too P.C.
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Barry Goldwater; The Consistency Of a Conservative
description: When Barry Goldwater ran for the Presidency in 1964, he was treated as a bizarre menace by much of the American press corps. But when he died in May, you would have thought it was Eleanor Roosevelt breathing her last, the way some of the liberal pundits carried on. The odd thing is that while the tenor of his press clippings changed, Goldwater never did. He started out and remained a fiercely independent Westerner who didn't like people telling him what to do, whether they were government bureaucrats, party muckety-mucks or self-appointed moralists. What had changed was the world around him.

title: Lost Man of the Lost Generation
description: MAN FROM BABEL

title: Court is Asked To Set Aside Cosby Verdict
description: Lawyers for the man convicted of killing Bill Cosby's son have filed a petition to set aside his conviction, citing testimony in another trial that their client did not write letters admitting to the murder.

title: An Artist Who Didn't Know She Was One
description: DURING a lifetime of obsessive creativity, Nellie Mae Rowe apparently gave little thought to her place in art history. The hundreds of drawings and collages she made in her three-room house in rural Vinings, Ga., the figures she fashioned out of old stockings and chewing gum, and the densely decorated found-object environment she created in her home and yard were to her simply an intense and deeply satisfying form of play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASMAN, RUTH
description: ASMAN-Ruth. Age 79. Died on December 26, 1998. A courageous, independent spirit who consistently chose life. It truly was ''la vie en rose.'' I thank you, my mother, my friend. Candy

title: 'Bible-Based' Town
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Drive Without 'Roo Bars'
description: WE first heard about Ningaloo on a balmy November evening after a day of swimming with bottlenose dolphins in Shark Bay, off Western Australia's outback coast, north of Perth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONRAD, FRANCIS B.
description: CONRAD-Francis B. Devoted father of Peter and Margery and Alan and Susan. Grandfather of Jennifer, Samantha and Allison. Service on Monday, 11 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: ON THE STREET
description: Youngsters on holiday visits to Fifth Avenue and Rockefeller Center looked as if they had walked through a rainbow in their cuddly fake-fur coats. Pastels overwhelmed primary colors, the perennial favorites. Many of the coats matched hats, like the iridescent plush ensemble, left. A popular style with the under-10's is lavishly bordered in fake fur, bottom right. Below, two junior sophisticates in high-style coats, one with a scalloped hem, the other with appliques. Grown-ups might cling to all-black, but the Lilliputian set is drenched in color.

title: Childhood Cancer Patients Find Survival Has Price
description: The scrapbook that documents Camelia Cruz's days as a teen-age cancer patient is yellowing now, its photographs and clippings fading with time. On this sunny Monday morning, Mrs. Cruz cracked it open, as she does every now and then, unleashing a flood of memories from what seems like a former life.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: The Sex Squad

title: Dec. 27-Jan. 2; Fallout From Bus Crashes
description: The cruel fact is that if people climb into vehicles and hit the road, some will die. So the question is: What's the safest way to travel?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIGLAND, SHEILAH
description: SPIGLAND-Sheilah. The President, the Chairman of the Board of Trustees and the entire Montefiore Medical Center community are deeply saddened by the passing of Sheilah Spigland, beloved and devoted wife of Ilya Spigland, M.D., Director of the Division of Virology at Montefiore. Mrs. Spigland was an extremely enthusiastic member of the Medical Center's Auxiliary. Her devotion to the patient library where she served as Chairperson of the Auxiliary's Library Committee and where in recent years she could be found almost every day, will leave a void that will be difficult to fill. We offer our deepest condolences to Dr. Spigland; their two daughters Nitsana Spigland-Kudler, M.D. and Caren Spigland-Turner; their son Ethan Spigland and their entire family. Spencer Foreman, M.D., Pres. Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Linking Acquisitions To Executives' Esteem
description: When investors criticize executives for undertaking acquisitions that do little to increase shareholder value, they often speculate about why these managers feel compelled to build empires by buying up other businesses. An academic study, highlighted in the most recent issue of Capital Ideas, a quarterly newsletter that reviews new research at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business, suggests that executives may be rewarded for their acquisitive nature by improving their status in the business community.

title: Changes In Mental Care
description: THE 24 students enrolled in the course called ''The Mad, the Bad and the Sad'' at Marymount College here had in mind images of the film ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'' when they first visited Rockland Psychiatric Center in Orangeburg, in Rockland County.

title: A Century Limned in the Critical Eye of the Photographer
description: THE coming year will be filled with reminders of the century's best in all areas of culture. Photography lends itself naturally to such assessment since the evidence is readily available.

title: Scrambling to Get on Board The Issue of Bus Safety
description: The spate of bus accidents on New Jersey highways this holiday season didn't take long to cause a political chain reaction in Trenton, sending lawmakers into a frenzy of bumper-to-bumper partisan posturing.

title: All for Haute
description: Since the birth of nouvelle cuisine some 25 years ago, obituaries for haute cuisine have appeared on a regular basis. But as often as it has been left for dead, haute cuisine has reappeared, mostly, it seems, for the purpose of being slain by yet another fad.

title: A Two-Career Man: Theater Director And Jewish Mother
description: SOME encores are more unpredictable than others. Take the case of Michael Mayer, the 38-year-old stage director who had three productions running on Broadway last season. One, ''A View From the Bridge'' by Arthur Miller, won a Tony Award for best revival; its star, Anthony LaPaglia garnered a Tony for best actor in a play, and Mr. Mayer was nominated for best director. A record of sorts and not likely to be repeated by Mr. Mayer anytime soon.

title: Distributor Of Arab Paper Got Threat Before Attack
description: Two days before an attack on the Queens company that distributes the influential international newspaper Al Hayat and a number of other Arabic-language newspapers, an unidentified caller left a vague but threatening message in Arabic on the company's answering machine, Yazid A. Mourani, its president, said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAWCETT, JACKSON
description: FAWCETT-Jackson. On December 24, 1998, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Bessie, loving father of Susan Sosin and Cynthia Parham, adoring grandfather of Clifford, Tyler, and Clarissa. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Monday, January 4th, at 12 noon. Interment to follow at Hackensack Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Hospice Family Care, 310 South Williams Boulevard, #

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Kwame Ture; Say It Loud
description: The phrase ''Black Power!'' stands as Kwame Ture's defining contribution to the 1960's. In 1988, Ture told me that the phrase had been used before. But he alone used it ''scientifically.'' Dr. King had been continuing James Meredith's ''March Against Fear'' after Meredith was shot by a sniper. When King left the march for a short while, Carmichael took over and changed the motto from the lyrical ''We Shall Overcome'' to the piercing demand ''Black Power!''

title: Unknown Jets Line Seizes Last Shot
description: Wherever they're shopping today, enjoying their week off before joining the playoff battle, the four players on the Jets' defensive line will hardly be bothered.

title: Sundance, the Sequel
description: Students at the University of Pennsylvania used to refer to West Philadelphia, the area surrounding the campus, as a great place to get mugged -- not exactly an ideal location to sip latte and discuss Hegel. While that might not be high on the university's list of priorities, the president, Judith Rodin, a Philadelphia native and Penn graduate, decided to make it her mission to clean up the neighborhood.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Leibish Lefkowitz; The Rabbi's Riches
description: When the Satmar Jews were struggling to rebuild in Brooklyn after near annihilation in the Holocaust, their Grand Rabbi asked Leibish Lefkowitz, a businessman, to be his right-hand man in secular matters. In return, the rabbi promised, he would give Lefkowitz a share of his own place in the world to come.

title: The Practice
description: THE GOOD BLACKA True Story of Race in America.By Paul M. Barrett.296 pp. New York:Dutton. $23.95.

title: What's That Sound? A Relic From the Past, Finding Its Voice Again
description: SITTING on a tall stool and wearing a long country-style dress that her great-great-grandmother might have worn to church, Bonnie Leigh picks and strums the instrument in her lap. The music she coaxes out of the instrument, which looks like an elongated guitar with three strings, reminds the listener of a banjo or a mandolin or a harpsichord, yet it has a sound all its own.

title: The Bottom Line
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  USADI, KATHLEEN
description: USADI-Kathleen, age 57, died Monday, December 28, 1998, in Brooklyn. Wife of Bob, mother of Douglas and Ben, sister of Patty Lollis. Her life was rich with feelings for growing things, painting, listening, talking, information, friends. She loved working with children. She was not a simple person. Contributions to Sixth Avenue & Fifteenth Street Community Garden, 565 6th Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11215 would be welcome.

title: North Korea's Hardening Line on U.S. Raises Fear of New Crisis
description: With warnings like its latest threat to wipe American imperialists ''from this planet for good,'' North Korea seems to have grown more hard-line and militarized in recent months, and some experts fear a major security crisis on the Korean Peninsula later this year.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Buffalo Bob, Gene Autry, Roy Rogers and Shari Lewis; Stand-In Parents
description: For all of Benjamin Spock's influence, he left his mark on baby boomers indirectly: his audience was their parents. Last year also brought the death of four figures who made a direct imprint, through children's television -- Roy Rogers, Gene Autry, Buffalo Bob Smith and Shari Lewis. Early on, each of them recognized that generation -- my generation -- as unique, and they were among our first heroes.

title: Hotel Plus Van Gogh In Los Angeles
description: Eight hotels in the Los Angeles area are offering packages with passes to the exhibition ''Van Gogh's Van Goghs: Masterpieces from the Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam'' at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, on Wilshire Boulevard in West Los Angeles, between downtown and the coast. The show of 70 paintings, now at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, will be in Los Angeles from Jan. 17 through April 4 -- on a rare tour outside the Netherlands during the expansion of the Van Gogh Museum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAND, STANLEY W.
description: WAND-Stanley W., 63. On December 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Zenia. Devoted father of Adam and Jordan. Devoted son of Fay and brother of Sondra. Loved by his family and friends. He will be sorely missed.

title: In Senate, to Call Witnesses or Not?
description: To the Editor:

title: Christmas: Hey, Folks, It's Over!
description: TUESDAY will be Twelfth Night, the traditional end of the Christmas season. Before midnight on Tuesday, all your decorations should be taken down, your tree recycled and the last traces of the holiday removed. This was a sad night when I was a child. The house looked stripped and bare without its holly and paper chains. But failure to clear away the festive clutter meant bad luck for the family all year.

title: Word for Word/Help-Wanted Ads; If You're Tired of the Same Old Grind, It's Time to Bone Up on Your Pushtu
description: WHAT better moment than the dawn of a new year to start scanning the horizon for a new job, a new career, a new life?

title: In the Region / Long Island; Historic District Plan Advances in Roslyn Heights
description: WHEN a builder applied to the Town of North Hempstead for a variance that would enable him to knock down an 85-year-old house done in the Arts and Crafts style in Roslyn Heights and build two houses in its place, neighbors banded together and raised $1,500 to defeat the proposal.

title: Recital? Concert? Try the Library
description: MORE than books can be found in several public libraries this month, with musical events encompassing classical recitals, jazz and children's entertainment. And many of the events are either free or with reasonable admission prices.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN; Bus Driver Goes Extra Mile
description: Ever feel as if you're not getting your money's worth on public transportation? You may want to take a ride on the M42 bus when Rene Price is at the wheel. Ms. Price's route runs along 42d Street from the Circle Line pier on the West Side Highway to the U.N. building on First Avenue and back again. But what makes a trip on her bus different is that she narrates the sights as she drives.

title: The Shock of the Familiar
description: Your history of design omitted any mention of the great Raymond Loewy (''100 Years of Stuff''). Loewy (1893-1986) designed everything from locomotives for the Pennsylvania Railroad, buses for Greyhound and the Avanti for Studebaker to the logos for Shell and Exxon. He was largely responsible for the introduction of a streamlined appearance in items as mundane as refrigerators, duplicating machines and pencil sharpeners. He was showered with commissions and awards during his lifetime.

title: David Manners, 98; Menaced on Screen by Lugosi
description: David Manners, who starred in Hollywood films in the 1930's and played the hero in Tod Browning's 1931 ''Dracula'' and other classic horror movies of that day, died on Dec. 23 in the health center of a retirement community in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 98.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Tracking Animals

title: Sports of The Times; Green's Success Lifts Black Coaches' Stature
description: DENNIS GREEN doesn't deserve the burden of being a beacon. He has been too successful for too long. But the more games that Green and his Minnesota Vikings win in the Super Bowl XXXIII playoffs, the more visible other black candidates should be in the fog that seems to surround most National Football League club owners when searching for a new head coach.

title: New in Copenhagen: Train to the Plane
description: There is now a faster and cheaper way to get to downtown Copenhagen from the airport. Three times an hour, the Air Rail train departs from its new terminal beneath Copenhagen International Airport for the 10-minute ride to the Central Railway Station. The trip costs about $2.50, at 6.8 kroner to $1. The same ride in a taxi would cost about $18.

title: Warehouse to Schoolhouse
description: Three years ago, Alan Alpert's son, John, then 4, was having trouble speaking and understanding in preschool. School officials, Mr. Alpert said, suggested he enroll his son in the private Mary McDowell School for Learning, which specializes in teaching the learning disabled. But the school, based at the Brooklyn Friends Meeting House on Schermerhorn Street in Brooklyn Heights, simply couldn't fit any more students in its space.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A page of revolutionary history, an impression of World War II, a Hollywood satire and an extraordinary horror thriller lend spice to the start of a new year of films on television.

title: Newer Riverside Wing Has Much in Common With Old
description: To the Editor:

title: Rutgers Is Playing on Center Stage
description: For the last two years, the Rutgers women's basketball program has been rising steadily, like a mountain climber striving to reach new heights. Last season, the Scarlet Knights reached the Round of 16 in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. This season, Rutgers is 10-2 and ranked No. 15 in the Associated Press poll, and the Scarlet Knights are expected to challenge Connecticut and Notre Dame for the Big East championship.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Betsey Cushing Whitney; The Last Princess
description: America during the Depression was captivated by the ''fabulous Cushing sisters,'' three glamorous daughters of an eminent neurosurgeon, famous for marrying into some of the nation's richest and most powerful families. The women had six husbands in all, among them an Astor, a Whitney, a Roosevelt and William S. Paley, the founder of CBS. But the middle and last surviving sister, Betsey Cushing Whitney, who died in March, acquired the best -- the best husbands, the best houses, the happiest family life.

title: A Doctor Tackles the Mysteries of Fatigue
description: WHO -- Dr. Benjamin H. Natelson, 57, a professor of neurosciences at the University of Medicine and Dentistry-New Jersey Medical School, director of the New Jersey Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Center, and medical director of the Gulf War Research Center at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in East Orange.

title: The Shock of the Familiar
description: My family owned a Citroen in the early 60's. This was a car with a back seat so comfortable and luxurious that we vied for the chance to sit on it. Because there was no drive shaft running down the middle, there was no hump under the middle passenger seat and no hump on the floor -- just a spacious, cushiony seat with tons of leg room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, JASON K.
description: LEWIS-Jason K. Age 85, of NYC, on December 30, 1998. He is survived by his loving wife of 53 years, Verda Lewis, two dear sons, Donald E. Lewis of NYC and Peter S. Lewis of Santa Cruz, CA; sister Alice Kruger of West Newton, MA, brother Elliott Newmark of FL and five grandchildren living in CA. Interment private.

title: From the 15th Century, A Tale of Two Cultures
description: IT'S magical. I left 15th-century Tibet, took an elevator up one floor at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and stepped into the Netherlands: same century, different universe. In the exquisite ''From Van Eyck to Breughel: Early Netherlandish Painting in the Metropolitan Museum of Art,'' Christian Europe opens its eyes to the Renaissance. In ''Sacred Visions: Early Paintings from Central Tibet,'' spiritual splendor and flowing Buddhist cosmology inhabit the main-floor galleries off the sculpture hall. Two cultures at opposite poles of the 15th century -- neither knowing of the other -- are housed, 500 years later, under the same roof. The metaphor seems inescapable. East and West are no longer twain. So why not ask what these two handsome exhibitions, on view through Jan. 17, can tell us about the worlds that gave them birth?

title: Storm Pummels Full Depth of Middle U.S.
description: A giant storm howled across the Midwest today, reaching from the Canadian border to the Gulf of Mexico, grounding most flights in Chicago and St. Louis, knocking out power, closing roads, and threatening to drop a foot of snow or more on northern states.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Dec. 20 with an article about the costume designer Sandy Powell misidentified the actor shown with the actress Judi Dench. He was Colin Firth, not Joseph Fiennes.

title: State Raises Standard in Lawyers' Education
description: LAST Thursday New York joined the majority of states requiring continuing legal education for all of its practicing lawyers. Jonathan Lippman, Chief Administrative Judge of New York State and a Rye Brook resident, said in a recent interview, ''As Chief Judge, I, myself, felt it was important that we aspire to the highest level of professionalism.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HEMACHANDRA, RITA
description: HEMACHANDRA-Rita. A Memorial Service will be held Saturday, January 9, 1999 at 1:00 PM at the Unitarian Universalist Congregation at Shelter Rock, 48 Shelter Rock Road, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society, 400 Post Avenue, Westbury, New York 11590.

title: A Royal Crush
description: IN a short story serialized on the Internet this month, Prince William, the 16-year-old heir to England's throne, has just rushed to the side of his injured girlfriend, Hannah, who lies in a hospital bed, enmeshed in a network of life-support tubes.

title: Steps to Installing an Electrical Box
description: IN a house the electrical wires run from the main service panel to receptacles, switches and fixtures. The National Electrical Code specifies that the wires must be protected with either heavy-duty plastic vinyl sheathing, flexible armored sheathing or metal conduit.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Benjamin Spock, M.D.; A Spock-Marked Generation
description: More than any other figure of our time, Benjamin Spock embodies the cultural contradictions of expertise -- and of our dependence on it. His most famous piece of advice -- ''Trust yourself. You know more than you think you do'' -- was the opening of a book that by its seventh edition had bulked up to almost 900 pages. Inside were detailed instructions on everything from managing colic to inculcating idealism.

title: Dec. 27-Jan. 2; Octuplet Mother Goes Home
description: The Houston woman who gave birth to octuplets last month left the hospital three days after the death of one of the infants on Dec. 27. Nkem Chukwu and her husband, Iyke Louis Udobi, said they were too busy caring for their seven surviving babies to get involved in ethical debates over the births.

title: One Word on Campaign Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Holmgren Home, Maybe to Stay
description: Is this where Mike Holmgren's heart really resides? Is his dream job to coach the San Francisco 49ers, where he coached under Bill Walsh and helped win championships before traveling to Green Bay seven seasons ago? Well, Holmgren comes home this afternoon, back to his hometown, back to where he left his heart long ago. Holmgren brings his Green Bay Packers here one more time, in the National Football Conference wild-card playoff clash against the 49ers at 3Com Park.

title: Please Don't Change
description: To the Editors:

title: Gators Strike Fast, Making It Look Easy Versus Syracuse
description: Syracuse against Florida had been billed as a bowl matchup of explosive offenses. At least Florida lived up to the billing.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: John Henrik Clarke; Self-Made Angry Man
description: As a freshman at California State University at Long Beach some 17 years ago, I discovered Dr. John Henrik Clarke and my own intellectual voice in the department of black studies. It was in those small but lively classes that die-hard partyers were transformed into angry young ''Afrikans.'' And we had good reason to be angry: after 12 years of public miseducation, we had new worlds opened up for us, reading works by Eric Williams, Cheikh Anta Diop, Angela Davis, W.E.B. DuBois, J.A. Rogers and Dr. Clarke, who emphasized the origins of Western racism and the history of African kingdoms before the European invasion. Sometimes we couldn't read fast enough; other times, we were so overtaken with emotion that we put our books down and wept, or fantasized about revenge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOKES, KATRINA ROELKER
description: STOKES-Katrina Roelker. 89, died at Hanover, NH on December 24, 1998 of heart failure. Widow of Isaac N.P. Stokes, who died in August 1998. Survived by three children from her first marriage to William R. Huntington: Lydia H. Sparrow, Madge Huntington Cooper, Mary H. Silloway; 13 grandchildren, five great grandchildren; five stepchildren: Samuel N. Stokes, Thomas H. Stokes, Janet R.C. Stokes, Olivia S. Dreier, Mitchell P. Stokes, five step grandchildren. Service: March 13, 1999, 2:30 PM, Kendal at Hanover, NH. Donations: Shelburne Farms, 1611 Harbor Road, Shelburne, VT 05482.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: The Shock of the Familiar
description: I, too, love the Pilot Varsity disposable fountain pen and, like Ian Schrager, find it invaluable for correspondence (''My Favorite Thing''). However, the pens are almost impossible to find here in the San Francisco Bay area and now we know why. Schrager has cornered the market with his 100 boxes of them in his office.

title: Squeezed by Life, a Barkeep Squeezes Back
description: Ernie has had only one aspiration in his 55 years of his living. He wanted his very own saloon. And except for a couple years (centuries?) working for the post office, running bars has been his life. He specializes in what he calls ''upper-low class'' cocktail lounges in Times Square and Hell's Kitchen.

title: Optimism by The Numbers
description: The most fruitful telephone call of my reporting career took place in 1985 when I was preparing to go to Kenya for an article on the population crisis. I had heard about an economist named Julian Simon with unusual views on the subject, so I phoned him. I was reciting Kenya's hopeless statistics -- eight children in the average family, a population that would double in just 17 years -- when Simon interrupted.

title: Listing Agreements
description: To the Editor:

title: Article on Caimans Needed A Broader Retail Focus
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Really Staggering?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Muse With a Vision of Her Own, Built on Crystal
description: NOW that many artist's lives have been limned by biographers and filmmakers, it seems only fair that their muses are being rediscovered. And their own creativity, too. Picasso's women, for instance, offer an inexhaustible supply of beauty allied with talent, from Francoise Gilot (a well-regarded painter before she ever met the father of her children) to Dora Maar (whose photography is overshadowed by her role as professional doormat). Now, perhaps, it is time for a re-examination of the muse to end all muses, Misia Sert, and the captivating oeuvre she called her own: bejeweled miniature trees.

title: Fun, Policy-Wonk Style
description: How do you teach children about bull markets,

title: How the Sunshine Harmed Congress
description: Twenty-four years ago I came to the United States Senate filled with awe, excitement and determination. Despite the occasional victory, the combination of my losses on issues about which I felt strongly and Congress's unwillingness to confront problems that can't be postponed much longer causes me to leave the Senate feeling more dismayed than exhilarated.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Dan Quisenberry; The Sinkerball Poet
description: Dan Quisenberry, a red-haired, submarining relief pitcher for the Kansas City Royals, specialized in the unexpected. His rising-then-drooping sinker crossed the plate with diffidence, making hitters change plans in midswing. His 45 saves in 1983 set a major-league record.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: The Last Mogul

title: Jennifer Ludden and Gerald Holmes
description: Jennifer Ann Ludden and Gerald Allen Holmes were married on Thursday at Trinity United Methodist Church in Paris, Va. The Rev. Mary J. Lock performed the ceremony.

title: Private Sector; A 'Hound Dog' Hunts on Wall St.
description: A YEAR ago, when the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson organized a Wall Street conference on race, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin rose to speak and then asked for questions. One came from the floor.

title: Future Is Cloudy for Another Historic House
description: ALONG a harborside road, one of the best examples of the historic architecture for which the Stony Brook area is known survives in solid splendor -- and a shaky future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOTT, RICHARD
description: SCHOTT-Richard, age 72 on Dec. 30, 1998. Pres. of Merchants Buying Syndicate. Beloved husband of Paula. Father of Leslie Kane & Stacy Dietzler. Grandfather of Chelsea. Services Frank E. Campbell, Sun. 1:30PM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the New York Organ Donor Network, 475 Riverside Dr, NY 10115

title: The Imaginings of an Eccentric Gentleman
description: ROBYN HITCHCOCK: 'STOREFRONT HITCHCOCK -- MUSIC FROM THE JONATHAN DEMME PICTURE'

title: The Nation; When, and If, Impeachment Meets Wall Street
description: AS the Senate returns to Washington this week to begin an impeachment trial of the President, the airwaves and Op-Ed pages are filled with prophecies of doom. A year of scandal and partisanship on a scale unseen in a generation has, it is said, left the capital adrift and the President paralyzed no matter how the Senators vote. The White House rarely misses a chance to exploit that worry, warning darkly about how a prolonged trial, much less the removal of a President, could unravel this Age of Prosperity.

title: Clashes in 'Medea'
description: To the Editor:

title: Storybook Finish to Record Season
description: WHEN it was over, when the last harness drive of a storybook season had finished Tuesday night at Yonkers Raceway, when the bar in his sport's most precious statistic had been raised in McGwire-like fashion, Walter Case Jr. was able to sit and assess what he had done.

title: Afflicted by Many Ills, but Trying to Cling to Home
description: It may not be apparent from her placid and dignified demeanor these days, but Sonia Gorritz quietly wrestles with manic depression and anxiety attacks while she copes with severe asthma and debilitating pain in her hands.

title: Bangkok on the Hudson
description: SNUGLY situated among the multitude of bustling restaurants on Washington Street, Bangkok City is an intimate, pleasant dining area filled with the delicate yet exotic aromas of Thailand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTORE, DR. NICHOLAS
description: PASTORE-Dr. Nicholas. Age 82, died December 26, 1998. Noted psychologist, author, lecturer and former professor at Queens College. Beloved brother of Dolores, Mildred and Vincent. He was dearly loved and will be missed by his family, friends and colleagues. He devoted his life to the pursuit of truth. May he rest in peace.

title: The World; Smart Bombs, Dumb Sanctions
description: FROM the terrace of his home on the outskirts of Baghdad, a carpet dealer named Ziad al-Kadhimi watched the mid-December bombing while sipping a fruit drink.

title: David Duke Heads North to Raise Money for House Race
description: Seeking donations from an audience sympathetic to his view that too many Federal policies favor blacks, Jews and other minorities over whites, David Duke arrived in the Washington area today to drum up support for his latest political endeavor.

title: The Boy in the Bright Green Hat
description: A Slant of Sun

title: Voices of Soldiers, Voices of Common Men
description: IMAGINE a wartime take on ''Much Ado About Nothing,'' with a cast of African-Americans giving voice to the infantrymen, not to the lords of Padua.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, JOSEPH BEN
description: BAUM-Joseph Ben. Of NYC. Passed away at home on December 30, 1998. Adoring husband of Martha. He is survived by many nieces, nephews, grand nieces and nephews and great-grand nieces and nephews. He retired from the U.S.M.C. 1953 as a Master Sergeant. He was quite a guy. Services 1 PM Monday, January 4 at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Packing Relief For Health Woes
description: MEDICAL preparations for trips to exotic places must include a visit to a doctor or travel clinic for inoculations and advice. But even trips to more conventional places like a spa in California or your cousin's cabin in Colorado should involve gathering items for first aid or other health problems that might arise.

title: Alexi Assmus, Robert Dodge
description: Alexi Josephine Assmus, an assistant professor of history, and Robert William Dodge, a research scientist, were married yesterday in the Old Moravian Chapel in Bethlehem, Pa. The Rev. Dorothy Burcaw performed the ceremony.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Harry S. Ashmore; The Laughing Liberal
description: Harry S. Ashmore's reputation was made during the angry years, and that was odd. He himself was a laughing man. He poked fun at the absurdities of racism, which prompted true believers to erupt in fury and call him names.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Andrei Svetlichny; Piano Man
description: The pianist Abbey Simon remembers the one occasion -- it might have been at Carnegie Hall, it might have been in Texas -- when he heard his favorite piano tuner actually sit down at the piano to play. Andrei Svetlichny had accompanied Simon, as he often did, to warm up the piano prior to a concert. ''He was just playing various passages of a Rachmaninoff piano sonata,'' says Simon. And, he adds, with a touch of surprise that may make for the ultimate compliment, ''he played really quite well.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ICELAND, MARIANNE
description: ICELAND - Marianne. Beloved wife of the late Ben. Died on December 30, 1998 after a long and very interesting life. She will be missed by her family and her many friends of all ages. Marianne, we will certainly miss you. Memorial service to be held Sunday, January 24 at 1:30 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Which Way to the Salad Bar?
description: WHEN CHOOSING A college, high-school seniors and their parents invariably say that cost and academics come first. Students also want a school that is as far away from home as possible, or as close as possible, and to go where siblings and friends have gone before. But there are other, far subtler factors influencing a student's choice.

title: Around the World in Four Days in London
description: IN the 1920's, my grandfather boarded a ship in Bristol that was bound for New York. In the next 50 years he never set foot in his native England again, for the cost of a visit was unthinkable on a coal miner's wage. Although I have grown up accustomed to affordable travel, I can still remember when a European trip was a special event involving months of planning and anticipation. I thought about this as I zoomed across the Atlantic toward London in late November, with a $239 round-trip air ticket in my hand that I'd purchased on impulse just six days before.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Wildflower Trip

title: Political Affairs
description: RFK

title: Remembering 1998 in Ratings and Dishes
description: LET us pause to recall the dining-out highlights of 1998. They were considerable.

title: One Word on Campaign Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: 3-D Space Trips At Chicago Museum
description: If the return to space by John Glenn and the start of construction of the international space station has put you in the mood for space travel, a new exhibition opening on Friday in Chicago may be a good first stop. The Adler Planetarium and Astronomy Museum's Sky Pavilion, a 60,000-square-foot wing, contains four galleries, including an interactive 3-D theater that simulates space travel.

title: SOVEREIGN ISLANDS: A special report.; Gaps in Sea Laws Shield Pollution by Cruise Lines
description: Shortly after 10 A.M. on Oct. 25, 1994, radar and infrared sensors aboard a Coast Guard jet over the Atlantic off Puerto Rico detected a possible oil discharge. As the aircraft swept low, its crew saw a long oil slick trailing a ship entering the San Juan harbor.

title: In West, Giuliani Wins Over Conservatives
description: The Mayor of New York, a tough-talking Italian-American with a reputation as a liberal, swept into this Southwestern outpost today to take on some of the Republican Party's staunchest conservatives.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Henry Steele Commager; The Presidents' Man
description: Henry Steele Commager, who died last March, taught for 60 years, wrote prolifically, lectured everywhere and, above all, made Americans take the Constitution and the Bill of Rights seriously.

title: New Film, New Chapter in a Storied Union
description: Console me! I am inconsolable! -- Anna, in ''Private Confessions''

title: Seeing More Fire In the Eyes Of the Bull
description: AS 1999 begins, it is hard to make the case that stocks will continue to race ahead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWY, EDWINA
description: LEWY-Edwina. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Brian and Barbara Lewy and the late Jayme Lewy. Cherished grandmother of Jacki and Keith. Services Sunday 11:30 AM at ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Delicate Holiday Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Experienced Huskies Handle Young Hoyas
description: CONNECTICUT 87, GEORGETOWN 64

title: Stefanie Lewin, Edward Handler 4th
description: Stefanie Michelle Lewin, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Kurt J. Lewin of Beverly Hills, Calif., was married on Thursday to First Lieut. Edward John Handler 4th of the Marine Corps, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Handler of Darien, Conn., in a nondenominational ceremony. It was performed by the Rev. Harold J. Kilborn, a minister of the Assemblies of God, at the Sheraton Kauai Resort in Koloa, Hawaii.

title: A Wrangle Over a Rediscovered Artist
description: WHEN Cathleen Scott agreed to be the co-host of the gala opening of ''William H. Johnson: Truth Be Told,'' at the Montclair Museum of Art in Montclair, N.J., she expected Johnson's art to be the show's principal draw. Ms. Scott, a member of the Bibliophiles, one of three black organizations sponsoring the opening, had admired the African-American painter's work at a 1992 Whitney Museum of American Art show and eagerly awaited the 54 objects that Steve Turner, a Los Angeles art dealer and independent scholar, had purchased from European collectors. Most of the works had not been previously exhibited in this country. That was, however, before Ms. Scott saw Mr. Turner's catalogue.

title: Celestial Prices Come Down to Earth
description: If German whites become hip in 1999, the rieslings of Weingut Robert Weil, a spare-no-expense estate in the Rheingau, Germany's oldest wine region, should head the parade.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAURENCE, RICHARD ALAN
description: LAURENCE - Richard Alan. 1953-1981. You left us a treasury of beautiful memories and gave us a special kind of devotion. Your love and compassion will forever be imprinted in our hearts. Lovingly remembered, Mom, Dad & Wendy

title: Dec. 27-Jan. 2; On-Line Shopping Takes Off
description: Early holiday sales figures for Internet retailers were stronger than even the most bullish predictions of a month ago.

title: The World: Caspian Logic; Democracy? Sure, Sure. Now Buy Our Oil.
description: KAZAKHSTAN, on the steppe between Moscow and Mongolia, was only recently a forbidden southern Soviet hinterland, a synonym for obscurity. But it is rich in oil and natural gas, recently independent, and in a region that forms a corridor separating Russia to the north from Iran to the south.

title: The Long, Erratic Arm of Justice
description: As two Khmer Rouge leaders accused of killing more than a million people toured a balmy seaside town with their military escort and deferential guides the other day, they drove past a jail where two Cambodian human rights workers were receiving different treatment.

title: Helping Traders Confront Their Fears
description: OVER the years, Dr. Ari Kiev, Manhattan psychiatrist and author, has researched witch doctors, counseled suicidal students and advised Olympic athletes. What better preparation could he have for coaching Wall Street's traders?

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Eldridge Cleaver; A Soul's Jagged Arc
description: ''We are a very sick country -- I, perhaps, am sicker than most,'' Leroy Eldridge Cleaver wrote in ''Soul on Ice,'' his brutally critical assessment of himself, written when he was serving a sentence in Folsom State Prison in California for assault with intent to kill. ''But I accept that. I told you in the beginning that I am extremist by nature -- so it is only right that I should be extremely sick.'' This proved to be not only trenchant self-analysis but prophetic for his furious-yet-instructive passage among us. In Cleaver's person and on the pages of his occasionally insightful but always incendiary essays, first published by Ramparts in 1966, America's twin obsessions of race and sex found their long-awaited prophet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORKIN, SYLVIA HOLLAND
description: ORKIN-Sylvia Holland on Thursday, Dec. 31, 1998, of Bal Harbour, FL, formerly of NYC. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Lazarus A. Orkin. Dear mother of Dr. Fred and Susan Orkin and Drs. Stuart and Roslyn Orkin. Cherished grandmother of Jane, Jeffrey and Jennifer Orkin. Loving sister of Emil Holland and the late Jack J. Holland, Louis Holland and Sadie Zatt. Dear aunt to many nieces and nephews. Sylvia with her late husband was a woman of great generosity. She was a Founder of The Douglas Gardens Jewish Home for the Aged in Miami, a Founder of Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami, a Patron of the Women's Cancer League at Mount Sinai, and a Board Member of The Wien Center there. She was also a long time supporter of the National Women's Committee of Brandeis University. In addition, Mrs. Orkin established The Orkin Skills Center in the Department of Nursing at Beth Israel Medical Center in NYC in memory of her late husband. Private graveside services will be leaving from The Riverside, Amsterdam and 76th Street, Manhattan, at noon on Sunday, Jan. 3. A separate memorial service will be held at a later date (CORRECTION). Donations in Sylvia's memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Dressing for Off-Welfare Success
description: TWANA Phills, a welfare recipient and mother of three boys, was transfixed, studying her reflection in the full-length mirror. There she was in an Ellen Tracy red wool blazer over a black turtleneck sweater and black and white houndstooth slacks. She clutched a black leather briefcase and smiled brightly. ''I feel like I got the job,'' she said.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Dolphins Stop Flutie And Put Him to Heel; Johnson Marks Victory With a Locker-Room Stunt
description: The floor of the Miami Dolphins' locker room was covered with Flutie Flakes, minus the milk. After Miami beat the Buffalo Bills by 24-17 today in their wild-card playoff game, Dolphins Coach Jimmy Johnson, during a raucous speech to his team, took a box of the cereal named after Bills quarterback Doug Flutie, tore it apart and threw the flakes on the floor. Some in the locker room began to stomp on the cereal, crunching the flakes to bits.

title: Where the Choices Are Almost Limitless
description: TAKE one of Greenwich Village's biggest, funkiest basement restaurants, plunk it down in tiny Brookhaven Hamlet and you have Painters. This rustic, spare, 175-seat, 10,000-square-foot former catering hall, with its casual barny charm, is as much an art gallery as a restaurant. Its white brick walls are covered by paintings for sale by local artists. Sculptures hang from dark wood overhead beams. Nearby Long Island Rail Road trains rumble through this one-of-a-kind, city-like spot at 416 South Country Road (286-6264). It is an eclectic venue with french doors, dried flowers, candles, bare tables, a piano and a cavernous open kitchen in its two dining rooms and sofas, pool tables and a big television in its bar and lounge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINDIN, PAUL
description: HINDIN-Paul. On Saturday, January 2, 1999. Of West Orange, NJ. Formerly of Bronx, NY. Devoted husband of Judith (nee Freedman). Beloved father of Michelle and Alisa Hindin. Dear father-inlaw of Joe Coresh and Robert Mencarini. Adored brother of Howard Hindin. Loving son-in-law of Beatrice Freedman. Funeral services conducted from The Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd., Union, NJ on Monday, January 4, 1999 at 11:30 AM.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Ray Nitschke; Hard Man In the Middle
description: With his domelike head and horn-rimmed glasses, Ray Nitschke, the Green Bay Packers' middle linebacker, could have been taken for a college professor. On the field he was anything but that. He had lost his parents when he was very young, when such a tragedy has dire consequences, in Nitschke's case a sense of outrage that fate could allow such a thing. He scared people. Dan Pastorini, who played quarterback for the Houston Oilers, remembers Nitschke's intensity, a rage before a Packer-Oiler game that boiled over at the coin toss out on the 50-yard line: ''Come on, ref, toss the goddamn coin.. . .Let's get on with it! I want the hell out of here! Let's get the game going!''

title: Software; Toonsville Tutors
description: It used to be that I could walk past the study, see the children huddled in front of the computer screen fighting over who would hold the mouse and sigh with relief: at least they weren't watching television.

title: Money Maven and Friend of the Mayor; Can Howard Koeppel, a Queens Car Dealer, Give Giuliani a Lift to the Senate?
description: IT was quite the evening for Howard Koeppel, the Queens car dealer who is a top fund-raiser for Mayor Giuliani -- as well as the Mayor's close pal. There he was at the ''Friends of Giuliani'' banquet on a recent Sunday, presiding over 11 guests at the much-watched Table 24, holding forth under the puffy painted-on-plaster clouds of the St. Regis Roof.

title: Eric Crull Baade, 70, Scholar and Teacher
description: Eric Crull Baade, a scholar of the classics, teacher and co-author of a widely used Latin textbook series, died on Dec. 15 at his home in Rockport, Mass. He was 70.

title: Crafting of History
description: To the Editor:

title: Camden Police Increasing Patrols at Night
description: Following a takeover of Camden's troubled police department last month, law enforcement officials last week unveiled a plan to put more officers on the street during hours when crime most often occurs.

title: Where the Lions Stand Guard, a Mouse Can Explore
description: Nothing will ever replace a visit to the New York Public Library, where the big news last year was the reopening of the Main Reading Room in November after a renovation that took 16 months and cost $15 million. But the next best thing to a visit, for scholars, students and the lay public, is an electronic sojourn at the library's Web site, which was also renovated recently.

title: Prune Tender Plants Wintering Indoors
description: Tender plants like pelargoniums and fuchsias brought indoors have months of light deprivation ahead. Unless you have greenhouse conditions, the best you may be able to do is to keep them comfortable, not growing: remove dead or diseased leaves, keep flower buds pinched out and water just enough to keep them from wilting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ODZA, MARIAN
description: ODZA-Marian. Died suddenly in New York City on January 1, 1999. Survived by beloved brother Paul Varkell, sister-in-law Jane Varkell and grandchildren Randy and Samantha Odza. Her loss will leave a deep void in our lives. Active member in C.O.M.A. Micrological Group, N.Y. Audubon, and Fern Society. Receiving Monday, 1 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. Graveside service 2:15 PM, Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Commerce St., Mt. Pleasant, NY.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Circumnavigation

title: Lusty New Papers Take On the Powerful in Mexico
description: A red-headed soap opera star startled mourners at the recent funeral of a senior Mexican governing party politician by stepping forward, just as the coffin was being lowered, to proclaim flamboyantly that she had been his longtime mistress.

title: Stress Test
description: Among the epidemics spreading from one school district to the next in recent years has been the compulsion to test. By the time they were ready to graduate to sixth grade last June, New York City fifth graders had taken eight standardized tests over the previous 14 months; this year's fourth-grade reading test, to be given statewide next week, will take three days to administer. In Chicago, pupils took 12 standardized tests from the winter of third grade through the spring of fourth grade. And President Clinton's proposed national tests in fourth-grade reading and eighth-grade math, while tabled by Congress for further study, still loom.

title: PULSE: A New Face for a New Year; Retro and Rouge
description: Pleated skirts and cuffed jeans aren't the only 1950's-era styles making a comeback. Body and Soul, a new line of vintage-inspired cosmetics sold at Barneys New York, contains bold red lipsticks with names like Bombshell and Showgirl and foundations that offer thick, cakelike coverage -- an about-face from the trend for sheer, minimal makeup. ''I do a lot of thrift shopping,'' said Carisa Janes, 25, the line's creator, ''and I was captivated by how feminine and glamorous the makeup was back then.'' The packaging -- sea-foam-green compacts and tin talc boxes -- is based on antiques Ms. Janes collects. Cecilia Bonn, communications director at the National Academy of Design, recently bought the foundation. ''It's like old Max Factor,'' she said, adding that most new makeups ''fall off my face in about four hours. I put this heavier makeup on in the morning and I don't have to worry about it all day.'' AMY SYNNOTT

title: Newspapers That Speak In Tongues
description: IN a blue colonial on a quiet street in this Somerset County suburb, the last 10 days of the month are always hectic for Dr. Arturo Roberts. That's when, and where, he publishes a monthly newspaper called Ninnau.

title: Notes From Cyberclass
description: Adult education, the concept, has never much appealed to me. Volunteer for more school? No thanks. I was quite pleased, more than 20 years ago, when it was done with the first time. Every now and then I still have that dream about being unprepared for a final exam. (For some reason, the exam is always in French.) There's something about entering a classroom that feels like a withdrawal from the actual business of the world, participation in which I'd earned by virtue of enduring two degrees' worth of pedagogy. I'm not one of those people who get nostalgic about college: I like to get paid for my work, not graded on it.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Redding, Conn.; An Upscale Town With Upcountry Style
description: WHEN Samuel L. Clemens first looked out at the Redding countryside from his newly built villa in 1908, he was unprepared for its magnificence. ''How beautiful it all is,'' he is said to have exclaimed. ''I did not think it could be as beautiful as this.''

title: In Senate, to Call Witnesses or Not?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Shock of the Familiar
description: The issue was extraordinary. But I think you overlooked the simple elegance of a familiar and sleek object, brimming with style and sex appeal: the Chanel No. 5 perfume bottle (in an advertisement on the back cover), well over 70 years old, and still displayed prominently by women everywhere.

title: The Shock of the Familiar
description: Your magazine (Dec. 13) was a Christmas gift two weeks early. I was so engrossed in it that I didn't realize, until I got to ''Cover Story'' on page 124, that the logo was upside down and at the bottom of the page.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Alan Shepard; 15 Minutes of Fame
description: In 1961, when Alan Shepard came home with the news that he had been picked to make the first Project Mercury flight, he said to his wife, Louise: ''Lady, you can't tell anyone, but you have your arms around the man who'll be first in space!''

title: Backtalk; Sydney-Hobart Horror Reminiscent of Another Tragedy
description: Storms at sea may seem the stuff of romance to some, but not to the sailors who desperately endure them.

title: Because Being Brilliant Isn't Enough
description: There are geeks, and then there are M.I.T. geeks -- or so the stereotype goes. Pegged as a haven for nerds who wear taped-up eyeglasses and pocket protectors, the university has always been a little sensitive about its students' apparent lack of social graces.

title: Loss Leaves Islanders' Milbury Dazed and Confused
description: After today's 4-3 overtime loss to the San Jose Sharks, the Islanders' fourth straight defeat, a disgusted Mike Milbury considered shaking up the team before the next game.

title: In Harbor Mud, A Vanishing Era; New York's Ghost Ships May Soon Be Lost Again
description: As the daily parade of giant container ships and tankers negotiates the twisting inner channels of New York Harbor, the waves pushed by the bluff bows of the computer-guided vessels wash through the rotting oak ribs of a ghost fleet.

title: 'Bible-Based' Town; A Quick Conversion
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking the Straight Path on the Shelter Island Ferry
description: TO say that Clifford D. Clark's company has been a fixture on Shelter Island is a severe understatement, as severe as the weather the Clarks have at times been forced to endure.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: The Agent

title: The Millennium Bug, A Bite or a Nibble?
description: A YEAR from today, the so-called millennium bug computer time bomb will have exploded, and if the experts are correct, our microprocessor-dependent society will be experiencing the greatest collective headache in history.

title: Sale of Lavish Hotel, Four Seasons, Is Mired in a Legal Fight
description: The Four Seasons, whose lavish rooms and panoramic views of the New York skyline make it one of the world's most expensive hotels, is not an easy sell.

title: One Sister's Betrayal Of Memory, and of Art
description: A YOUNG instrumentalist of promise, identified in the movie with a grand post-Romantic concerto, cut down by mental and physical illness: haven't we seen this film before? In part, yes. Anand Tucker's new ''Hilary and Jackie,'' the ''true'' story of the English cellist Jacqueline du Pre and her elder sister, draws formulaically on Scott Hicks's ''Shine,'' the 1996 film biography of the Australian pianist David Helfgott, notably in the way it evokes a disastrous breakdown in midperformance.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; Soloists Unify as Bargainers
description: FRANKLY, it's hard to think of John Coltrane ever saying, ''No play without 401(k).'' And the thought of Louis Armstrong demanding a collective bargaining agreement before blowing his lungs out at a gig in the 20's paints a peculiar picture.

title: In America; The Giuliani M.O.
description: City Hall is set off from the rest of New York by metal barriers, concrete barricades, signs that say ''DO NOT ENTER'' and ''NO THRU TRAFFIC,'' and coils of yellow tape marked, ''Police line -- do not cross.'' It's an ugly and depressing sight.

title: The View From/Briarcliff Manor; When Fat and Lazy Give Way to Will
description: IT began with a man who said, ''Let's just be friends.'' The object of this declaration, a woman in her 40's who agreed to be interviewed only on the condition of anonymity, recalled the disappointment -- and the subsequent embarrassment -- she felt when the man told her he could not return her romantic interests because he was physically attracted only to thin women.

title: Fatal Fire Poses Mystery of Why No One Noticed Shut Sprinklers
description: Investigators may never find out who turned off the sprinkler system in a Brooklyn high-rise building where three firefighters died in a fire last month. But an equally troubling mystery is how the system's uselessness could have gone undiscovered -- probably for years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEIZHALS, BEN
description: GEIZHALS-Ben. Dedicated volunteer for Israel. Survivor. A true friend. To Esther and family, our love. Paul and Rose Safro

title: Both Mind and Ear
description: To the Editor:

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Bella Abzug and Paul O'Dwyer; When Politics Had Passion
description: Bella Abzug and Paul O'Dwyer came from a time when people practiced politics as compulsively as they now work out at the gym. ''There were meetings every night,'' remembers Sarah Kovner, a longtime friend of both. Argument-filled strategy sessions went on for hours -- about Vietnam, about civil rights -- with victory often going to the side that stuck around the longest. ''Bella's life was just one circus of meetings and protests,'' Assemblyman Edward Sullivan recalls.

title: In Toulouse, a Blast From Past and Present
