description: TOULOUSE, the city of ancient pink-brick churches and stately homes on the Garonne River in southwestern France, may be noted for foie gras, but it is just as proud to be the aerospace capital of Europe.

title: Last Bow for an Irish Lord
description: 'FEET OF FLAMES'

title: In Senate, to Call Witnesses or Not?
description: To the Editor:

title: BEST SELLERS: January 3, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Surprise! Even The Boss Has a Heart
description: Who would have thought it? Bosses, those storied ogres who stereotypically withhold raises, tear up expense accounts and send out pink slips on Christmas Eve, can actually have hearts of mush. The softies among them help finance vacations, give Cupid a hand and spring to the aid of the distressed. So next time you see a boss, honk -- or at least smile.

title: Jolson: The Greatest
description: To the Editor:

title: Science Fiction
description: Religion has always been a problem for science fiction writers. While they are occupationally biased toward rationality, their stock in trade is imagining plausible futures -- and no speculation about future societies can be complete without considering the evolution of current belief systems or the advent of entirely new religions. Yet few writers have taken this challenge seriously. When religion has not served merely as a symbol of irrational reaction, it has usually figured as window dressing -- a few hints of altered rituals or creeds to remind the reader that this is indeed ''the future.'' Among the memorable exceptions: Walter M. Miller Jr.'s ''Canticle for Leibowitz,'' James Blish's ''Case of Conscience,'' Frank Herbert's ''Dune'' series, Gene Wolfe's multivolume ''Book of the New Sun.'' Add to these Octavia E. Butler's PARABLE OF THE TALENTS (Seven Stories, $24.95), which continues and deepens the story she began five years ago in ''Parable of the Sower.''

title: The New Faces of Retirement
description: AS an elder-law attorney in the resort town of Truth or Consequences, N.M., John C. Wheeler can't help but spend most of his time thinking about retirement. Retirees come from all over the Southwest to have him draw up wills and estate plans, so they can feel secure about spending decades doing little but soaking in the hot springs of T. or C., as it's known; boating in nearby Elephant Butte Lake, or roaming the country in recreational vehicles.

title: Asian Economic Woes Hurt Canadian Tourism
description: THE cartoon colors that Japanese tourists seem to favor in ski suits -- orange, pink and shiny silver -- may not be missed on Canadian ski slopes this winter, but the extravagant spending habits that Japanese tourists used to bring with them certainly will be.

title: Tennessee Is No Longer a Bunch of Characters
description: Their quarterback says with soulful eyes that football is just a sport to him and has nothing to do with what he's about. Their captain, once a boxer, now a linebacker, calls the game war and plays through injuries that would sideline others.

title: BENEFITS
description: Hudson Guild Gala

title: Julie Dobrow, Jason Rossi
description: Julie Michele Dobrow, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey R. Dobrow of Franklin Lakes, N.J., was married last evening to Jason Mark Rossi, a son of Carol G. Rossi of Palo Alto, Calif., and the late Franco Rossi. Rabbi David Lincoln performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYSS, LILLIAN D.
description: WYSS-Lillian D. of Hillsdale, NJ died unexpectedly early December 24, 1998. Beloved wife of Albert C. Wyss. Devoted mother of Nancy and Caroline. Dear aunt of Robert C. Wyss, William Britton, Charles and Richard Van Patten, Dorothy Mayer and Catherine Koenig. As an outstanding artist, Lillian worked as a medical artist at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and during W.W. II as a civilian artist with the U.S. Army Signal Corps. She was a member of the Pascack Art Association and received blue ribbons for paintings exhibited at Bergen Community College and at various banks and libraries. She was a graudate of Pratt Insititute. Visiting at Becker Funeral Home, 219 Kinderkamack Road, Westwood, NJ on Tuesday, January 5, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Services at 11:30AM on Wednesday, Jan 6. Entombment at Garden of Memories, Soldier Hill Road, Washington Twp, NJ.

title: Shaw in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Sector; Another Day, Another $100 Million
description: Another Las Vegas executive has given $100 million to a citadel of higher learning. Just before Thanksgiving, James E. Rogers, owner of Sunbelt Communications, doubled an earlier pledge to the University of Arizona's college of law, to $100 million. Then, before Christmas, Ralph Engelstad, owner of the Imperial Palace Hotel and Casino, pledged $100 million to the University of North Dakota in Grand Forks.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: Winning Siblings

title: Deals and Discounts
description: APRIL ON A BARGE -- French Country Waterways has cut prices by $500 a couple on April barge cruises in Champagne, the upper Loire and Burgundy. Rates, incorporating the discount, are $2,645 to $3,745 a person, double occupancy, on departures from April 4 to 25. The five barges on those routes take 8 to 18 passengers. Rates cover accommodations, meals, wines at lunch and dinner, open bar, tours and excursions and transfers between Paris and the barges. Reservations: (800) 222-1236, (781) 934-2454 in Massachusetts.

title: Disclaimers Are Hazardous To Our Health
description: AN invitation came to spend the weekend at a vacation home in the mountains. There would be hiking, gourmet meals and companionable guests, all friends and significant others. But when I arrived, my hosts had left a request: that I read the disclaimer they provided and sign where it said I wouldn't sue.

title: Eat Drink Man Woman
description: Jim Harrison is best known for his novels and essays, but in the introduction to THE SHAPE OF THE JOURNEY: New and Collected Poems (Copper Canyon, $30) he maintains that poetry ''is the portion of my life that means the most to me.'' In fact, Harrison has published nearly as many books of poetry as prose, from the youthfully expansive ''Plain Song'' (1965) to the Zen-inflected ''After Ikkyu'' (1996). This large collection, which also includes a new grab bag of nature verse and prose poems called ''Geo-Bestiary,'' has a meandering feel, although Harrison's concerns -- aging, women, eating and drinking, hunting, the craft of writing and above all the spirit and rhythms of the natural world -- are remarkably constant, as are his intentions: ''In our poetry we want to rub our nose hard / into whatever is before it; to purge / these dreams of pictures, photos, phantom people.'' His voice is obsessively unaffected and colloquial, which is surprising for someone so quick to acknowledge his lifelong debt to poets as diverse as Apollinaire, Rimbaud, Li Po and Keats, and who experiments with Buddhist-inspired verse and obscure poetic forms like ghazels. Harrison's writing is graceful, direct and muscular, even in those occasional places where the poems feel like dashed-off diary entries or, rarer still, when they hit a mawkish note. Much of the best verse -- particularly the fine introspective reveries in ''The Theory and Practice of Rivers & New Poems'' -- is set in rural Michigan, where Harrison is clearly most comfortable, pacing through the woods or confronting his appetites and his mortality: ''It is not so much that I got / there from here, which is everyone's / story: but the shape / of the voyage, how it pushed / outward in every direction / until it stopped.'' Throughout his wanderings he is great company -- a restless, self-questioning, intelligent writer, humble before nature and above all grounded in the flesh and blood and feathers of the planet: ''A modern man, I do not make undue connections though my heart wrenches daily against the unknowable, almighty throb and heave of the universe against my skin that sings a song for which we haven't quite found the words.'' Scott Veale

title: Thick and Thin
description: The days just after the holiday eating and the related New Year's resolutions are a fine time to resent those who don't worry about the former and don't need the latter. Women who want to give words (and pictures) to their feelings might borrow some from Kathy Shaskan, author of ''101 Perfectly Good Reasons to Hate Young Skinny Women.'' An example: ''They're the only ones who stand a chance with the young skinny guys, but they always seem to be dating the old geezers you thought you'd be dating.'' Ms. Shaskan, 43, who lives in Morristown and is a consultant in corporate communications, was inspired by the fact that her female friends use humor to deal with aging and its insecurities. She wrote and illustrated the book and published it herself last fall, under the Motherbee Productions imprint. Not all women are chuckling, Ms. Shaskan says. ''Women either love it and howl with laughter or absolutely hate it.'' The book, $11.95, is available at bookstores in northern New Jersey, from amazon.com and barnesandnoble.com and from Book Clearing House, (800) 431-1579.

title: Commercial Property / Westchester; Big Corporate Shifts Raise Office Vacancies to 18%
description: WHILE surrounding office markets thrived last year, Westchester County's -- tied to large corporations -- ended with a higher vacancy rate than in 1997, leading some brokers to wonder what it would take to turn the market around.

title: The Jazz Singer At a Crossroads
description: THE death in September of Betty Carter ended an era in American vocal music -- the era of classic jazz singing. A few giants remain: Abbey Lincoln, Shirley Horn, Joe Williams and Jon Hendricks would win votes in any poll of jazz listeners for a seat at the head of this artistic class. And the names of Cassandra Wilson, Dianne Reeves, Diana Krall and Kevin Mahogany do suggest a groundswell of fresh activity in the field.

title: Ms. Radomsky, Mr. Braham
description: Rosalie Ray Radomsky, a daughter of Gloria and Hyman Radomsky of Brooklyn, was married on Wednesday to Robert Max Braham, a son of Elizabeth Braham and Prof. Randolph L. Braham of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens. Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon performed the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in Manhattan.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Robert E. Gould; Dr. Defender
description: If the late 1960's hadn't wrought havoc on social power in America -- race riots and sexual revolution; draft-card and bra burnings -- Bob Gould would have had to invent the moment. He was the chief of adolescent services at Bellevue Hospital when hippies came to flower, waving long hair and free-love banners instead of the flag. Psychiatrists, and many others, called them sick. Bob wanted to invite a group of these ''sickies'' to invade Bellevue for an evening of confrontation. His superiors balked, predicting a circus, if not a riot. But the old guard was no match for Bob's righteous passion. Hippies versus Bellevue graybeards made news, and Bob emerged as a shrink for changing times.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Betty Carter; The Perfect Note
description: Betty Carter was born Lillie Mae Jones, in Flint, Mich., and by the time she first recorded under her own name, she had settled on being the fearless Betty Carter, having passed through a Betty Bebop stage for a moment or two, working with the vibraphonist and big-band leader Lionel Hampton. Her first recordings, from the middle 1950's, are utterly individual. In 1956 she recorded the song ''Social Call,'' and in it you hear the curved elegance of her mature style. She quickly became, in the acidity of her individuality, a taste one had to work on. Sarah Vaughan once said: ''I'm not a jazz singer. If you want a jazz singer, go talk to Betty Carter. She's a jazz singer.''

title: Bitter Bills Curse Costly Penalty
description: One by one, angry and bitter Buffalo Bills filed into their locker room today. A coach threw his cap against a wall and cursed. Most of the players clenched their teeth, spent after a game sprinkled with just enough to make the heartbreak that much deeper.

title: Catching On at the Movies: A Clear View for All
description: It is the week after Christmas, schools are out and in towns everywhere grandparents and grandchildren, cousins and uncles, sleepover friends and just moms and dads are flocking to the local movie house. Then, the minute they sit down, a giant with hair up to here sits down in front of them and blocks the screen.

title: A Jew's Perspective
description: To the Editor:

title: Vikings Reflect Green's Boldness and Savvy in 15-1 Season
description: Several days before last April's draft, Minnesota Vikings Coach Dennis Green was on the telephone, predicting that if the Vikings were able to draft wide receiver Randy Moss, their offense would be practically unstoppable and the Vikings and Denver Broncos would be the two best teams in football.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, SAMUEL H.
description: GREENSTEIN-Samuel H. 82, on January 1, 1999. Services at 1:30 PM Sunday, January 3 at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, LI. (516) 764-9400.

title: Against Arizona, Dallas Is History
description: Arizona quarterback Jake Plummer said that during the past week, he and his teammates tried to block out all the talk about their sorry recent history against the Cowboys and the lack of playoff experience. During the week leading up to their wild-card game against Dallas at Texas Stadium today, Cardinals cornerback Aeneas Williams said he stopped reading the newspapers and turned off the sports talk shows.

title: Driving in France
description: To the Editor: My husband and I thoroughly enjoyed Nicholas O'Connell's essay. Our driving adventures through France, and especially through Paris, were a most sobering experience as well.

title: Hats Should Be Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STORCH, MARCIA
description: STORCH-Marcia, M.D. 1933-1998. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, January 6, at 5:30 PM at the New School auditorium, 66 West 12th St., NYC.

title: Q&A/Yolanda G. Campbell; Aunt Who Became Mom to Neglected Girl
description: LETTERS from relatives at home and occasional phone calls gave Yolanda G. Campbell, stationed in Japan with the Navy in the 1980's, bits and pieces of the plight of her niece Whitney. Born in 1987 to a mother who was a crack addict and a father who was in prison for murder, Whitney was taken away from her mother, put in foster homes and physically abused by a stepgrandmother. All this by the time she was 3.

title: No Longer Playoff Time, but Nightmare Continues
description: Robbie Ftorek, the Devils' coach, did not want his team to think about its last visit to the Corel Center. He did not want his players' thoughts to linger on how last season ended, when the Senators sent the Devils home in the first round of the playoffs in a tremendous upset.

title: The Importance of Being Busy
description: As with most elite schools, all Harvard applicants must submit to an interview with a local alumnus, who describes Harvard to the candidate and then the candidate to the admissions committee. The chats take place in November and January. Jenny Lyn Bader, a Harvard graduate whose ''Manhattan Casanova'' was featured in the 1998 National Playwrights Conference, has conducted such interviews. They inspired this playlet.

title: Howl
description: A WEREWOLF PROBLEM IN CENTrAL RUSSIA

title: Going, Going, Gone on Line
description: I JUST bid $180 for a Donna Karan black cashmere sweater I've never seen. It's supposed to be new, but for all I know it has spent the last three years locked in a closet with bulimic moths. Until very recently I had assumed that anyone foolish enough to buy anything through an Internet auction had too much time, money or both. But today, I find myself eager to shell out $100 for a used scarf.

title: Heating Winter Chill With Cabbage Rolls
description: STURDY leaves of cabbage make delicious wrappers for all kinds of fillings. Assembling stuffed cabbage rolls and cooking them is somewhat time consuming but hardly difficult. The results yield hearty cold weather dining. Here are several ideas, to serve as first courses, side dishes or main dishes.

title: Not Lifelong Soldiers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Umbrella of Italy And a Customer From Vegas
description: It is no coincidence that a recently opened, intimate Italian restaurant in Greenwich Village shares the name of a giant new Las Vegas casino, Bellagio.

title: Independent Bookstores Say Big Deal Is a Big Deal
description: As part of a national push by the American Booksellers Association, about 50 independent bookstores in the city are circulating among their customers a petition asking Federal regulators to block Barnes & Noble's purchase of the nation's leading wholesale book distributor, Ingram Book Group.

title: How 20 Artists Treat the Human Body 20 Different Ways
description: AN exhibition called ''Extensions'' focuses exclusively on representations of the human body in recent art. The show, a bristling and entertaining spectacle, is at the Joseloff Gallery at the University of Hartford in West Hartford through Jan. 17.

title: G.M. Knocking at Auto Show Door
description: THE General Motors Corporation practically invented the auto-design extravaganza, piquing the public's interest in the 1950's with its glitzy Motorama shows that included futuristic concept cars. But in recent years, as its budgets were cut and its marketers gained prominence over its designers, G.M. has pretty much sat in the shadows at the leading auto shows, upstaged by its crosstown rivals.

title: Help for Those Like Laura Is Available in New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: On-Line Searches For Off-Line Work
description: The Internet is no longer just for technophiles, and neither, it seems, is on-line job-hunting. A growing number of services are catering to job seekers of all types, offering everything from on-line classified ads to aptitude evaluation questionnaires and resume advice. And a new study suggests that most people searching the World Wide Web for employment opportunities are not looking for jobs involving computers and software.

title: Arts Council Plans
description: The Westchester Arts Council has bought the former Chase Manhattan Bank on Mamaroneck Avenue in White Plains and will convert the eight-story building to a cultural arts center, which will include exhibition space, offices for nonprofit groups and apartments and lofts for artists.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Telford Taylor; Atrocities Answered
description: The war crimes tribunals for Bosnia and Rwanda, the newborn international criminal court and a Spanish judge's indictment of Gen. Augusto Pinochet of Chile are expressions of the idea that how a nation treats its own citizens is everybody's business. That principle was established 50 years ago at the Nuremberg trials, and one of its most important architects was Telford Taylor, who died of a stroke on May 23. Taylor was a deputy prosecutor at the International Military Tribunal that tried the top Nazi officials and chief prosecutor at a dozen American-run trials that followed. His work at Nuremberg helped shape the human rights movement and define modern international law. But Nuremberg was just one piece of a long career marked by a moral courage unusual in American public life. After the International Military Tribunal ended in 1946, Taylor was promoted to brigadier general and led 12 American trials of German military officers, concentration camp doctors, industrialists and death-squad members. These trials, which convicted about 185 defendants, established the idea that accountability for crimes is not limited to those at the top. The notion that a soldier confronted with an immoral order cannot simply turn off his conscience has become part of most of the world's legal systems.

title: DataBank: December 28-31; The Nasdaq, the Bull's New Corral
description: As the year closed, every major market index pointed up, but clearly it was the technology-laden Nasdaq that lassoed the bull. The Nasdaq 100 Index, madeup of the largest stocks traded in that market, surged an astonishing 85 percent in 1998, the best showing in its 14-year history. The broader Nasdaq Composite index closed at a record 2,192,69, up 39.63 percent for the year.

title: Annette Sforzo and Alan Geiss
description: Annette Sforzo and Dr. Alan Charles Geiss were married on Thursday at the United Nations Regal Plaza Hotel in Manhattan. The Rev. Orlanda Brugnola, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARWOOD, W.B.
description: HARWOOD-W.B. ''Pete'' Jr. Formerly of Locust Valley, N.Y. in Bath, ME. on 12/26/98. Born 11/24/ 17 in Flushing, N.Y. to the late Wm. Bradford Sr, and Jane Crawford, husband of the late Sylvia White and father of Wm. B. III of Pennsburg PA., Phyllis H. Munro of Bath, ME. and Peter T. of Sag Harbor, N.Y. Attended Lawrenceville Academy & Princeton University '39. Retired as senior vice-president of the marine division of Frank B. Hall & Co. Served with distinction as a navigator on B-17's in the Army Air Corps. Memorial donations would be appreciated to Literacy Volunteers or Parkinson's Disease Research.

title: The World: War Without Casualties; Not Taking Losses Is One Thing. Winning Is Another.
description: I WANT you to remember that no bastard ever won a war by dying for his country,'' Gen. George S. Patton Jr. roared in May 1944 to soldiers preparing to invade Europe. ''He won it by making the other poor dumb bastard die for his country.''

title: Atonality as Accident
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Christmases and 3 Kings
description: SOMETIMES Puerto Rico is called the Land of Two Christmases, so important is the celebration of the Epiphany, honoring the visit from the three kings, or wise men, to the infant Jesus. The day will be observed in East Harlem on Wednesday with El Museo del Barrio's 22d annual Three Kings Day Parade. This year the kings will be played by Benny Ayala, a Puerto Rican folk artist and musician; Papoleto Melendez, a Nuyorican poet and educator, and Antonio Martorell, a Puerto Rican visual artist. The marchers will walk with an assortment of animals, like sheep, donkeys and camels, and enjoy a special performance by a renowned Puerto Rican folk artist, Yomo Toro, as they walk through the streets of El Barrio for two hours.

title: Simple Solutions for Houseplant Ailments
description: WITH most people in a mood to unwind from the holiday season, this might be called a sort of caretakers' primer for house plants. Too often, people complain that their house plants die, the leaves turn brown or other ills strike. And too often, when plants wane, their caretakers look for an outside cause. Is it a bug? Or a disease? Or is the plant a bad choice for one's home?

title: INSIDE
description: Fidel Castro, 40 Years Later

title: Private Sector; Prepare for Departure. Quickly.
description: It's the little things that count in making the planes fly on time. Make that the little things you don't have to count. The flight attendants on Delta Air Lines' no-frills carrier, Delta Express, complained they were wasting time totaling up the beverages and napkins for the next flight before loading them in galley drawers. So Paulette L. Corbin, Delta Express's managing director (and a former flight attendant), told them to skip the task. Also at their suggestion, magazine racks were moved from the front to the back of planes, so browsing passengers would not slow down boarding.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Alan Cumming; 'Cabaret' Is Just A Warm-Up
description: ''I NEED a new tattoo,'' announced Alan Cumming, washing down a Reese's peanut butter Christmas tree with a glass of Champagne. On a recent Wednesday night, backstage at ''Cabaret,'' the hit show that has made him a star, several friends were draped on a leopard-print divan. One jumped up to help apply a fake tattoo to Mr. Cumming's thin, pale upper arm. ''It's a bar code,'' Mr. Cumming said, ''because I'm a commodity.''

title: Wireless in a Big Way
description: For at least a year, the main question on Wall Street and in the telecommunications industry about a potential acquisition of the Airtouch Corporation, one of the world's biggest wireless telephone carriers, by the Bell Atlantic Corporation has been not if but when. Partners in a joint venture since 1994, Bell Atlantic and Airtouch have seemed like natural, if not preordained, corporate mates.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE; Postal Plan Delivers a Fight
description: For Lincoln Square residents, the new Ansonia Station post office that is to open in March on the ground floor of Millennium Tower on Columbus Avenue between 67th and 68th Streets has become a Catch-22.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about regional politics misidentified the home state of Representative Henry J. Hyde, the only non-Southern Republican with a major role in the House. He is from Illinois, not Ohio.

title: JERSEY; What's Hot for '99: Systems Analysts Who Keep Their Cool
description: A FEW months ago, I was at the supermarket checkout when one of those cheap tabloids caught my eye. ''January 1, 2000: The Day the Earth Will Stand Still!'' the headline screamed. ''Electricity Will Be Cut Off! Vehicles Using Computer Chips Will Stop Dead! Domino Effect Will Cause a Worldwide Depression!''

title: The Joint Is Still Jumping, But the Floor Is Shaking
description: THESE feel like such good times. People have jobs. Their pay is rising in many cases. The stock they own is gaining in value, and so are their homes. They spend rather freely, and as the weeks pass they feel less threatened by the economic turmoil elsewhere in the world. So it is hard to get people to focus on the precarious underpinnings, right here at home, of these boom times.

title: After-School Program Neglects Transportation
description: What your Dec. 20 article about the Bellmore-Merrick Central High School District's after-school program [''After School: Somewhere to Go, Someone to Help''] did not take into account are the many children who live south of Sunrise Highway and north of Merrick Road who find it difficult to participate in the program due to the lack of transportation. These children are forced to cross either Sunrise Highway (by walking directly home from the school) or Merrick Road (by taking a late bus) in the dark during rush hour. If the purpose of the program is to create ''a safe, supervised environment'' for students, with particular emphasis on those students with working parents, then let's not let the safety concern end at school's front door and provide safe transportation for all the children who want to be part of the program.

title: The Shock of the Familiar
description: Your issue on design, a visionary tour de force, scared the apocalyptic daylights out of me. From Herbert Muschamp's exploding-chaos theory of design (the day ''when dreams and things can no longer be told apart'') to Luc Sante's hunt to maintain his identity with a Citroen DS (''there will be one style -- one car, one coat, one chair'') to Tupperware that ''deinvidualizes'' us, I now have no doubt that one day everything will be decanted and distributed in ''virtually'' airtight containers. Egad. Maybe the sky is falling.

title: Prostitutes Barred
description: The manager of Macedonia Towers, a housing complex for the elderly in Mount Vernon, says some residents have recently allowed prostitutes into their rooms.

title: OPINION; A Monorail System Is a Necessity
description: LONG ISLAND desperately needs a new and totally different means of transportation. It is choking on its inadequate automotive roadway system. Traffic jams are now routine on a daily basis on most major roads, highways and parkways, as well as on the Long Island Expressway, often referred to as the world's longest parking lot. The major north-south routes are just as crowded, aggravating and frustrating to drivers and traffic engineers as the east-west ones are. The traffic jams get worse each year as housing developments and malls and shopping centers are created and filled with more residents and businesspeople who use their preferred methods of travel: automobiles, vans, trucks and now sport utility vehicles. These not only clog our highways, they also pollute the air we breathe with noxious fumes. Their tailpipes belch out toxic noisome exhausts that create violations of the Clean Air Act and increase sickness and death among people with asthma and lung and cardiovascular problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, DOROTHY ZARLIN
description: ISRAEL-Dorothy Zarlin. Predeceased by husbands Harry Zarlin and Dr. Martin Israel; and son, Marvin Zarlin (Lolli). Survived by sons Michael and Sheldon (Phyllis) Zarlin; sister Grace Waldman; niece Natalie Silver; grandchildren and great grandchildren. Graveside services Monday, January 4 at 11:00 AM, Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Going Along for the Ride In the Auto Racing Rush
description: BASEBALL, basketball, hockey -- such is the televised fare on which American couch potatoes have long gorged themselves. But these days, it is auto racing that captures more TV viewers than any sport except football, according to A. C. Nielsen, the ratings company.

title: Business; Playing 'The Price Is Right' With Windows
description: IF the Microsoft Corporation is the predatory monopolist that the Government claims it is, why isn't the price of its monopoly product -- its industry-standard Windows operating system -- higher?

title: The Air Gets Chillier Between Pataki and Giuliani
description: In struggling to describe the curious relationship between Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, people who are close to the two men sum it up this way: It's nothing personal.

title: A Mad Rush to Convert I.R.A.'s
description: In the closing days of last year, so many people wanted to convert their traditional individual retirement accounts to Roth I.R.A.'s, in which investment gains are exempt from income taxes, that the Vanguard Group activated its ''Swiss Army,'' Fidelity Investments put people on overtime and T. Rowe Price revised upward its projections of conversion volume.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Mae Questel; A Squeak for The Ages
description: Betty Boop was never just kids' stuff. The cartoon character, popular throughout the 30's, displayed a sexual knowingness that was usually found only in jazz songs. Take the lyrics of Cab Calloway's title tune for the 1932 Betty Boop short ''Minnie the Moocher,'' a song about a ''lowdown hoochie-coocher'' who falls for a coke-addicted pimp named Smokey. He takes Minnie down to Chinatown and introduces her to the illicit pleasures of opium; she spends her time in narcotized daydreams of riches. Not exactly Snow White.

title: PULSE: A New Face for a New Year; Human Filler
description: Cosmetic filling agents that flesh out wrinkles and plump up lips are in high demand -- dermatologists are doing everything from stitching in Gore-Tex to injecting fat extracted from patients' own bodies. The latest filler is Dermalogen. Unlike commonly used bovine collagen, a protein extracted from cows, Dermalogen is collagen taken from the tissue of human cadavers donated to the Muscular Skeletal Transplant Foundation, an agency accredited by the American Association of Tissue Banks. The tissue is screened for viruses, sterilized and shipped to physicians in syringes to treat smile lines and other facial imperfections.

title: PULSE: A New Face for a New Year; No Gain Without Pain
description: The ''Epicuren facial'' is the Advanced Skin Care Day Spa's version of extreme sports. The power facial, $125, includes a stinging enzyme exfoliation followed by two nutritive enzyme masks that cause blood to rush to your face as if you were standing on your head. That may be putting it mildly. Jonn Wasser, a talent agent who has the 75-minute pulse-quickening treatment about once a month at the spa at 532 Madison Avenue, said: ''I can't daydream like during a normal facial. It makes me feel like a more active participant rather than a passive person lying there.'' The aggressive facial uses a high concentration of proteins, enzymes and nutrients like niacin. While dermatologists are skeptical that it can produce all the results it promises, clients like the fact it feels drastic. ''The first part feels like someone poured Tabasco on open skin,'' said Brent Hatcher, who had the facial last week at the Castro Day Spa in San Francisco. ''Another side effect is your face feels like it's throbbing. Imagine if you accidentally hit your thumb with a hammer or slammed it in a car door.'' Next week, he's going back. KEVIN BISCH

title: POSTINGS: $400 a Night on East 41st Street; The Former Chemists Club Is Being Turned Into a Hotel
description: It has been at least 20 years since the glory days of the Chemists Club in its own building at 50 East 41st Street. Unable to support a building of its own, the club sold it some years ago and now carries on at the Club Quarters Hotel at 40 West 45th Street, which caters to membership clubs.

title: PULSE: A New Face for a New Year; Macho Package
description: Cellex-C, the Toronto-based manufacturer of last year's must-have anti-aging cream for women, discovered in focus groups that male consumers might want to use the topical vitamin C products, too -- so long as they don't look like girlie stuff. So in December, the company gave its products' image a sex change by taking two of its best sellers -- High Potency Serum (to repair wrinkles and prevent aging) and Hydra-5 B-Complex chaser (to hydrate the skin) -- and switching the green-and-white labels to black and encasing them in a black-and-gray box. The Cellex-C men's kit is $130 in the Bliss Spa catalogue (888-243-8825), or can be ordered from Cellex-C (800-235-5392). How effective are the products? ''While vitamin C can prevent skin damage, it's questionable whether a topical cream can repair existing damage,'' said Dr. David Biro, a dermatologist in Brooklyn. ''Still, if it makes you feel good, you should go ahead and do it.'' ELLEN TIEN

title: At the Helm, After 22 Years
description: Stephan Russo was 25 and unemployed in 1976, and had just returned from a Peace Corps assignment in Colombia when Goddard Riverside Community Center offered him a job as a youth organizer. He had no idea that taking the job would mean spending almost half his life there, so far.

title: A Long Goodbye, With Much Accompaniment
description: DENNIS RUSSELL DAVIES is about to give up the music directorship of the American Composers Orchestra, a contemporary-music ensemble he helped found in 1975. But his formal parting will be as protracted as a diva's farewell tour. His final project as music director, ''20th-Century Snapshots,'' a series of 11 thematic concerts, begins next Sunday with ''The Gershwin Circle'' and ends in 2001. A survey of Cuban works in March and a program of Walt Whitman settings in May round out the first season.

title: Miami
description: Miami, which is registering ever-increasing numbers of visitors, is undergoing a building boom that sometimes makes the area look like a giant construction site. Visitors will find new and renovated terminals at Miami International Airport and the Port of Miami, numerous restored hotels and other expansions.

title: Classics From Many Times and Places Could Add Up to a Classy Season
description: THE classics are coming, and with a vengeance. Trend-spotters, still marveling at the triumphant journey of Sophocles from the McCarter in Princeton to the Barrymore on Broadway, might like to say that ''Electra'' fever is spreading. Somehow, the Greeks' artistic victory just might establish a more receptive mind-set for world theater of all styles, all ages.

title: Looking Past Hussein, U.S. Is Peering at a Pretender
description: American officials are casting their nets wide to find a credible opposition leader or perhaps a figurehead who might lead Iraq after Saddam Hussein, meeting even with a man who would be king.

title: Our Towns; Impeachment As Legacy For Pizza Guy
description: DON'T worry, Mr. President.

title: Stick-On Bird Images Might Prevent Collisions
description: To the Editor:

title: Robyn Weiss and Seth Frisch
description: Robyn Ellen Weiss, a rabbinical student, and Rabbi Seth Harold Frisch were married last evening at Har Zion Temple in Penn Valley, Pa. Rabbi Gordon Tucker performed the ceremony.

title: ENDPAPER: Henny Youngman -- b. 1906; Take My Wife
description: Henny Youngman once said that ''death was nature's way of telling a man to slow down.'' He must have had himself in mind. Long after fellow graduates of the Borscht Belt retired, he stayed onstage. At 91, just weeks before his death on Feb. 24, he went on the road one last time, doing two gigs a night.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Lucien E. Conein; Spook
description: A stocky figure with a leathery face, Col. Lucien E. Conein belonged to a vanishing species -- the swashbuckling soldier of fortune on whom the Central Intelligence Agency relied to perform America's ''dirty tricks'' around the world. Nicknamed Lulu or Luigi, he could be rowdy, impudent and obscenely irreverent, particularly toward bureaucrats determined to make him comply with rules and regulations. But despite the legends that portrayed him as a loose cannon, which he delighted in circulating himself, he was a seasoned, thoroughly conscientious clandestine operative who served as an instrument for the policies conceived by his superiors.

title: A Talk-Show Analogy
description: To the Editor:

title: INTRODUCTION
description: The Design special issue inspired readers to offer their choices of ''favorite thing'' (a grand piano, a soccer ball) and to appeal for utility over whimsy in the design of practical objects. Luc Sante's favorite thing, a Citroen, prompted reveries and yearnings for this slick car.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

title: Purloining Style, Faking Creativity
description: ANYONE who listens to new music these days will be familiar with the experience of deja entendu evoked by the works of many composers favored by our musical institutions. The name in the program may be that of a contemporary; there may even be a live person sitting in the audience. But the piece turns out to be shamelessly reminiscent of the style of someone long dead, and the individual among us -- now perhaps taking a bow onstage -- is yet another ghostwriter on behalf of the past.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Six inventors who improved our daily lot.; Masters of the Mundane
description: Car Radio

title: Pipes Of Sorrow
description: AT each of the three funerals for the firefighters killed last month, Timmy Grant was there, standing alone in his kilt on the steps of Roman Catholic churches in Queens, Brooklyn and Long Island. He is the bagpiper who, as custom dictates, separates from his band after it marches past silent firefighters clad in dress navies. As the coffin is lowered from a fire truck onto the shoulders of pallbearers and the color guard snaps a white-gloved salute for a fallen comrade, Mr. Grant fills the air with the plaintive notes of ''Amazing Grace.''

title: Allies on Malta
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Denise Fainberg's report,''On Malta, History Is Carved in Stone'' (Nov. 8). One or two suggestions might be made.

title: Feeling Like One of the Flock
description: THE green and fire-engine red vehicle pulling up to the visitor center clashed badly with the pastel Art Deco environs of Napier, a city on New Zealand's North Island. Propped high on large tractor tires with a convertible open-air seating area suitable for a safari, it looked like an escapee from a monster truck rally. But 15 of us would be riding this thing (called a Unimog) to the seabird colonies on Cape Kidnappers about 15 miles south of Napier.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about 1998 battles over open space in the city referred incorrectly to the status of a proposal to expand the hours that cars are banned from Prospect Park on weekdays from April to November. The park administrator has not put the proposal into effect; it is subject to approval by the Department of Parks and Recreation, the Department of Transportation and the Mayor's office. Because of an editing error, the article also referred to the administrator incorrectly. Tupper Thomas is a woman.

title: Pancreas Transplants
description: Westchester Medical Center has received approval from the United Network for Organ Sharing, a component of the United States Department of Health and Human Services, for a pancreas transplant program. The hospital is already authorized to perform liver, kidney, bone marrow and cornea transplants.

title: School Safety Officers Bridle At Transfer to Police Control
description: The New York Police Department took control of security in the city's schools on schedule on Dec. 20, police officials said last week.

title: Hassler's Owners
description: To the Editor: I read with great interest the article of Dec. 6 by Geraldine Fabrikant about the Hassler Hotel in Rome and its manager, Roberto Wirth (''Roman Roost for the Rich and Famous'').

title: POSTINGS: $100 Million Development in New Jersey; 602-Home Project Going Up in Nutley
description: Even before construction begins this month on a gated 602-home community in Nutley, N.J., most of the 135 town houses and 33 single-family detached homes in the first phase are spoken for, conjuring up images of the mid-80's building and buying boom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALTIMORE, HARRY
description: BALTIMORE-Harry. Loving husband of Sheila. Devoted father of Jeffrey and Julie, Keith and Nancy and Richard. Cherished grandfather of Dani, Ryan, Casey, Emily and David. Dearest son of Ruth. Harry's humor and loving way will stay in the hearts of his family and friends forever. Services Monday, 12:30 PM at ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Creating a Landscape Of Characters in Turmoil
description: FEW people in the movie business are as versatile or as seemingly contradictory as Paul Schrader. The 52-year-old Mr. Schrader has written such renowned films as ''Taxi Driver'' and ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' and has directed 12 others, including ''American Gigolo,'' ''Light Sleeper'' and a new one, ''Affliction.'' Yet in the film world he is both a maverick and an insider, respected for his uncompromising choices but known for defying definition. ''I don't think Paul has had an easy ride of it,'' said Geoffrey Gilmore, the director of programming for the Sundance Film Festival, which showed ''Affliction'' last January. ''But there are very few other American filmmakers who are capable of creating characters with such a tremendously rich inner life.''

title: PULSE: A New Face for a New Year; Creams With Pull
description: Magnets, used to treat everything from sports injuries to pets with insomnia, are now being utilized on complexions. Skin Maximizer, face cream from Lancaster, contains mineral microcrystals that carry a natural magnetic charge. Iron in blood's hemoglobin is supposed to be attracted to these charged bits; when applied to the face, they pull blood to the skin's surface, resulting in luminous skin, the company maintains. ''It sounds interesting and it may work,'' Dr. Mary Ellen Brademas, a Manhattan dermatologist, said. ''The problem is the magnets eventually lose their effectiveness. Like everything else, it probably works a couple of hours and loses its effects.'' Skin Maximizer products, $38.50 to $45, will be in Bloomingdale's in February. DANA DICKEY

title: A Partnership's Blueprint for Success
description: IT is a blueprint for restaurant success: one partner in the kitchen, the other in the dining room. Gail and Jim Grasso at Trattoria Grasso in Cold Spring Harbor epitomize that teamwork. She of the bubbly personality is a welcoming hostess. He, a Culinary Institute of America graduate, is a chef with a knowing hand.

title: Ideas & Trends: Storm Warning; The Coming Crime Wave Is Washed Up
description: IN 1994, when a small but influential group of criminologists and politicians began fixing their gaze on the end of the 20th century, they saw a crime storm on the horizon, one teeming with a new breed of superpredators who would soon be reaching their teens.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 13 about a vintage model of the Citroen misstated the location of the engine. It is under the front hood, not under the back seat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, HARRY
description: GREENBERG-Harry, died peacefully at home on January 1. Beloved husband to Sylvia. Devoted father to Neil, Steven and Lucia. Loving grandfather of Jennifer, Judy and Jane. After 52 years of teaching the fashion trade at the Fashion Institute of Technology, he recently retired as a Professor Emeritus. He will be forever in our hearts. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Harry Greenberg Scholarship Fund at FIT. Funeral Services will be held Sunday, January 3, 1PM at the IJ Morris Inc. Funeral Home, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York. For further information call 1-800-624-8282.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, DAMON P.
description: WRIGHT-Damon P. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Damon P. Wright, associated with The Times from 1985.

title: THE NEW EUROPE: United and Divided; Shiny, Prosperous 'Euroland' Has Some Cracks in Facade
description: Europe has two faces, light and dark, and they are evident on Germany's western and eastern borders as the continent crowns four decades of integration with the adoption of a single currency, the euro.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Alfred Kazin; A Last View From the Bridge
description: Alfred Kazin, the Brooklyn-born critic who rhapsodized about American writers in books like ''On Native Grounds,'' kept a journal from 1938 until his death, last June. In its pages, embryos of Kazin's latest ideas could gestate until they were ready for public consumption in vibrant midcentury forums like The Partisan Review and Commentary. During his long career, Kazin showed that literary criticism could itself be a form of poetry; his eternal foe was the academic who analyzed art with the sterile voice of a scientist.

title: For Young Drummers, a Chance To Share the Stage With Masters
description: THE yearly event, MusicAmerica, is a sentimental favorite of its organizers and a time of serious pump priming for its beneficiaries. Perhaps nothing in Westchester compares with the loftiness of its goals and the sheer extent of its reach, at least in the realm of music.

title: A Rural Town Takes On Obstacles to Internet Ties
description: Even unimaginative futurists predict that some not-so-distant day, geography will barely matter. Humanity's web of electronic connections will trump it utterly. That will be particularly nice for isolated spots like this long-depressed former mill and factory town, cupped in the Berkshire Mountains in the remotest corner of Massachusetts.

title: SOAPBOX; The Accidental Concierge
description: A BELL rings and I try to get to the intercom quickly, before whoever is there decides I'm not home.

title: More Money Is Approved For a Ball Park in Newark
description: The Newark Bears minor-league baseball team, which played its first season's home games in Bridgeport, Conn., should have a park of its own by summer, now that Newark and Essex County officials have approved spending $6.9 million more for a stadium. Most of the extra cost is for acquiring land near the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, shown above. The stadium was originally to be built in the Ironbound area, but was moved after community protests. The total projected cost is now $29 million.

title: Wendy Hill, William Mills 2d
description: Wendy Elizabeth Hill and William Joseph Mills 2d were married on Thursday by the Rev. William McD. Tully at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Patrick Clark; The Man Who Loved To Cook
description: Patrick Clark's food gave off heat. At 3 A.M., which is when most of us remember going there, the Odeon had a warm, comforting feel. ''The place makes you feel reasonable at any hour, often against bad odds,'' wrote Jay McInerney in ''Bright Lights, Big City,'' his 1984 novel of the minute, which had a picture of the restaurant on its cover.

title: Habitats / Roosevelt Island; Apartment in a Day
description: SOME people anguish for months about whether to buy an olive-covered couch or one that is taupe. Sometimes they end up not deciding. They live with what they have.

title: Two Shows Feature Human Form Without Looking Contrived
description: ONE of the many distinctive characteristics of 20th-century art is the many ways in which artists have represented the human form. In two concurrent, one-woman shows at the Hudson River Museum here, the Expressionist Katherine Hu Fan and the minimal New Imagist Sarah Haviland stake their claim on the figure and, without looking contrived, create an unexpected connection.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARSKY, SAMUEL
description: GARSKY-Samuel To My Beloved Husband: It is now some time that you are not with us, but you are in our minds and in our hearts. We all miss you very much, Joyce, Jeff, Staffard and Mellissa and our great grandchildren that are delightful. We all miss you very, very much. Love, your broken hearted Betty

title: Time for Some Plain Talk
description: The tornados that hurtled through world markets in 1998 varied in nature, scope and power. But they all had something in common: Their risk to investors was hidden.

title: How Much Is That Robot In the Window?
description: Vacuums, power drills and other merchandise in the display window of Vercesi Hardware at 152 East 23d Street are marked ''special,'' but it's an item that's not for sale that has the most value, at least to the store's owner, Paul Vercesi Jr. It's a robot figurine that stands two feet tall, with a body fashioned from metal electrical boxes and fittings and, for a head, a yellow 25-watt party bulb that blinks on and off.

title: A Glossary For the Millennium
description: First there was the age of innocence; then there was the age of information. Next? The age of uncertainty, say Marshall Blonsky and Edmundo Desnoes, who are experts on semiotics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, ALFRED D.
description: RAPPAPORT-Alfred D. On December 31, 1998. Beloved husband of Marguerite. Loving father of Lori LaCroix and Robin Rappaport. Dear grandfather of Hunter and Courtney and Jamie and Shelby. Loving son of Sylvia. Services Monday, 11:30 AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 No. Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: After the Lobster Dinners, the Portuguese Soul Erupts in Song
description: Portuguese restaurants in Newark are popular with out-of-towners who come for low prices and large portions. But few who come for the food are aware that after hours on weekends, some restaurants also offer performances of the dramatic Portuguese musical genre known as fado -- short, intensely emotional songs performed by a singer called a fadista and two guitarists. Fado's lyrics often tell mournful stories of loved ones separated by the sea -- an apt subject for Newark's large immigrant community from Portugal and Brazil.

title: Ms. Simon, Mr. Nathan
description: Arlyn Eve Simon, a daughter of Linda Pill of West Orange, N.J., and Michael Simon of Titusville, N.J., was married on Friday to Frederic da Silva Solis Nathan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan of New York. Rabbi Marc Angel performed the ceremony at the Water Club in New York.

title: The Art of Beginnings
description: ON a recent morning, Kweyao Agyapon carried six bags of percussion instruments into Public School 17 in Jersey City. He had a private set of hopes as he wisecracked and handed out drums and rattles to rowdy sixth-grade class after rowdy sixth-grade class. And he fulfilled them: by the end of each session, the students had not only drummed, they had also learned new words and concepts, some math, a little foreign language and a lot of cooperation. They may not have noticed, though. They were having too much fun.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Disinfecting the Wards

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: FOOTBALL

title: THEATER; Surfing The Waves Of Racine's Poetry
description: WHY do I -- an American far from the kind of French classic theater represented at its finest by the great playwright Jean Racine -- admire and love his dramas and know that his works should not be confined to the Francophone countries but experienced by everyone?

title: Ideas & Trends; For Managed Care, Free-Market Shock
description: WHEN the Prudential Insurance Company of America decided last month to sell its health-care operations to Aetna Inc., it was the latest example of a company that could not make money caring for sick people. Despite Prudential's best efforts, the business, mostly in managed care, had lost hundreds of millions of dollars. Prudential finally gave up.

title: Go Hollywood, Moses
description: THE PRINCE OF EGYPT

title: In Senate, to Call Witnesses or Not?
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: LOST WOODS

title: Mary Ann Unger, 53, a Noted Sculptor and Curator, Is Dead
description: Mary Ann Unger, a sculptor and curator, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 53.

title: Matchmaker, Matchmaker
description: More new terrain for the Web: college recruitment.

title: Christmas Joy
description: The Christmas season at first looked bleak to a retired couple from Peekskill who lost $1,500 in cash on a holiday shopping expedition to the Jefferson Valley Mall in Yorktown.

title: Elizabeth Schub and David Browde
description: Elizabeth Schub, a film director, and David Browde, a radio and television reporter, were married on Friday evening on the island of Anguilla. The Rev. Theosopholus Rolle, a United Methodist minister, performed the nondemoninational ceremony.

title: Corruption Tests Labor While It Recruits
description: A wave of union corruption, including a widening scandal at New York City's largest municipal union, has thrown the labor movement off stride at a time when it is straining to improve its image and persuade millions more Americans to join unions.

title: Ireland, by River
description: To the Editor: I read with interest your answer (Q & A, Nov. 8) to the question about chartering boats in Ireland. For three years, I've been boating in Ireland; twice on the Barrow Line and once on the Shannon Waterways. They are very different.

title: Dec. 27-Jan. 2; McCain Tests the Water
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona took a big step toward a Presidential candidacy in 2000 by announcing the formation of an exploratory committee to begin raising money for a campaign.

title: Why Would Anyone Be a Washington Insider?
description: I was intrigued with the article about Harold Ickes [''Ex-Clinton Aide, Back on the Island, Reflects on the Presidency,'' Dec. 27]. Why would an individual expose himself to the treachery and duplicity that Washington has now become? I thought Richard D. Winsten's observation was telling: ''To subject myself to ethics suggestions and snide media questions, in addition to the large pay cuts that usually go with these kinds of things, I'd have to convince myself it would be best for me and my family.'' Mr. Ickes was inspired by Allard Lowenstein. I wonder what Allard would think of what public service or government contracting has become. Can idealism survive in the face of such scrutiny, legal costs and sacrifice? It gives me pause.

title: After Judge's Rebuke, Commerce Secretary Widens Inquiry Into Mishandling of Papers
description: Commerce Secretary William M. Daley has asked the department's inspector general to expand his investigation into whether officials systematically concealed and destroyed documents sought in a lawsuit, after a Federal judge made those charges in a stinging rebuke of the department, officials said this week.

title: Silence in Restaurants Might Be Best Music of All
description: To the Editor:

title: Erotica in Ireland
description: To the Editor:

title: Hello, HAL
description: THE AGE OF SPIRITUAL MACHINES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, LEONARD
description: LEVY-Leonard. Died January 1, 1999, late in his 97th year. His life was full and joyful and lived with integrity, grace and achievement. He graduated in 1924 from Dartmouth College and joined the Riverdale Drapery Manufacturing Co., which he and his partner took control of several years later, building it into a highly regarded and successful business. His 70 year marriage to Leona, who predeceased him by three years, was one of constant love and respect. He deeply loved his children John and Dorothy Levy, Lee and the late Nancy Gunst, his grandchildren Kathy and John Rudolph, Michael Gunst and Donna Eberle, Lee and Andrea Gunst, John C. Levy, Tom and Valerie Levy, and his seven great-grandchildren, all of whom filled him with pride. We will greatly miss him. Private services. Contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: A Tax-Break Deadline, in Case You Missed It Before
description: CONCERNED that it is offering a school tax break that tens of thousands of eligible homeowners are not aware of, the state has once again extended the deadline to sign up for the program.

title: Dreaming the Impossible Dream
description: In 1999, things will be different: You will carry out your New Year's resolution to advance your career or resolve a workplace conflict. Well, maybe. But what about past years? How close did you come to meeting a work-related goal that you set for yourself in January? Or, how did your efforts go awry?

title: To Forecast 1999, Don't Dwell on '98
description: I'M going to break with the tradition of most year-end market retrospectives, which tend to highlight a few of last year's events and pontificate on their grand significance for the new year. Instead, I will argue that most of what shook the markets in 1998 has little or no significance for 1999.

title: Trouble, A Desk Away
description: Q. Recently, my boss of seven years and I moved from our old office to a separate company he owns. One of my new co-workers is constantly complaining, ridiculing my boss (to whom I am devoted) and speaking loudly during personal calls -- which I can't avoid hearing because our desks are just 15 feet apart. This woman has been with the company for five years, and everyone else seems to think she is great. I am civil toward her, but my patience is wearing thin. Should I talk to my boss or to the human resources department about her behavior? Or should I try another approach?

title: Anne Cottrell and Paul-Jon Patin
description: IN many ways, Paul-Jon Patin is a sailor to the core -- he's hardy, stoical, mechanical minded and seems to have a built-in compass. When he gives driving directions, he doesn't say turn left or right. Instead, he tells people to go south at the traffic light or to head west at the stop sign. He draws the line -- but just barely -- at telling the driver to use the North Star for guidance.

title: BOOKEND; The Tree Still Grows in Brooklyn
description: Betty Smith was five years older than her creation, Francie Nolan, who was born in 1901. Francie was the tree that grew in Brooklyn, the one that blossomed out of the pavements, whose strength was not recognized because the breed was so common. ''It grew in boarded-up lots and out of neglected rubbish heaps and it was the only tree that grew out of cement.'' ''A Tree Grows in Brooklyn,'' published in 1943, was an immediate best seller, and since then has become for its devoted readers a treasured rite of passage. A friend told me it was where she first learned at 12 about sex. Another reader was dismayed to realize that her mother had purloined incidents from Francie's childhood and made them her own, telling her daughter tales from the book as if she had lived them herself. The novelist Helen Schulman would read the book again and again, never finishing, each time starting from the beginning so that for her the book never ended.

title: Make Way for Civilization
description: ASSAULT ON PARADISE

title: That's Entertainment
description: Life the Movie

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, REV. ROBERT J.
description: STONE-Rev. Robert J., 1919-1999. Union Theological Seminary NY, 1949. Pastor: Morrisania, AdamsParkhurst, and Jan Hus Presbyterian churches. Associate Secretary Church and Race Council, PCUSA. Beloved husband: Mae Gautier; father: Margaret and Susan; best man: Elizabeth & Dudley Sarfaty. Spring services Jan Hus. In loving memory, AMGD

title: The Nation; Test-Tube Babies: Private Public Schools
description: AS New York prepares to become the 34th state to operate charter schools, the model of the future may be in Chicago. Last week, a Chicago priest proposed closing down a Catholic parochial school and reopening it as a charter school, financed by taxpayers. Religious instruction could be available before and after the regular classes, he said.

title: Singing Those Retirement Blues
description: Business publications regularly note how Americans are not saving enough for retirement. A recent study by Ohio State University researchers of data collected by the Federal Government confirmed the trend, finding that 48 percent of Americans would not be able to maintain their accustomed living standards, as measured by current levels of spending, after they retired.

title: The Shock of the Familiar
description: I was disappointed that your issue on ''the objects of ordinary life'' largely neglected the people who actually design these objects. You found plenty of room for architects, fashion photographers, museum curators, magazine editors, Martha Stewart -- all of whom get plenty of media attention. But except for Phil Patton's elliptical article, ''From Eureka to Your House,'' about Karim Rashid's chair, there were few industrial designers.

title: Ford Eager to Make a Splash
description: WHEN J. Mays took over the top design post at the Ford Motor Company in October 1997, he boldly promised to put his signature on Ford's cars at the Detroit auto show in 1999. He would begin, he said, by making the company's brands more distinct from one another.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Beatrice Wood; A 'Titanic' Figure of the Avant-Garde
description: The time is summer 1917, the place, Coney Island. Beatrice Wood is seated on a fake ox while behind her, in an oxcart, against a painted backdrop, sit Marcel Duchamp and Francis Picabia. They have come from the roller coaster. ''With Marcel's arm around me,'' Wood recalled years later, ''I would have gone on any ride into hell with the same heroic abandon as a Japanese lover standing on the rim of a volcano ready to take a suicide leap.'' In the photograph she looks more queasy than lovestruck, clutching her hat as if afraid it might still blow off.

title: A Bit of Africa, Portugal, Italy, Spain, SoHo and Hell's Kitchen
description: A confluence of Moroccan, Portuguese, Spanish and Italian foods served in a space designed to resemble a 1970's SoHo gallery, and named for what is sometimes called the spice island, opened Monday. Zanzibar, at 645 Ninth Avenue (at 45th Street) is owned by Emilio Barletta, an architect from Florence, who also owns Trattoria Dopo Teatro at 124 West 44th Street. Zanzibar -- a combination of bar, dining room and two lounges -- has an illuminated fiberglass bar and a small outdoor garden. Dishes include saffron risotto cakes with roasted wild mushrooms, baked sea bass and seasoned tuna with capers, olives and peppers. ALEXANDRA McGINLEY

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT:; He Preserves, Protects, Defends the Nation's Symbol
description: Two hundred years ago, lured by waters teeming with aquatic life, bald eagles commanded the skies over the Hudson River near the city and roosted in Central Park.

title: A Baby Sitter in the Bronx
description: For almost all her adult life, my mother, Juanita James, was the neighborhood baby sitter. Every morning, working women brought their infants to our apartment in the Melrose Housing Projects in the South Bronx; children from outside the neighborhood stayed overnight. On any given day, there might have been four youngsters playing in the apartment.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Owen Bradford Butler; A C.E.O. for Children
description: For most of his working life, Owen Bradford Butler was busy climbing the corporate ladder at Procter & Gamble, becoming chairman in 1981. But Brad Butler will be better remembered for something he sold even more enthusiastically: the idea that early-childhood development is crucial to a child's ability to learn -- and that corporate America should support that development.

title: Unstrung Heroes
description: THE TRAVELLING HORNPLAYER

title: Clearing the Tracks for Penn Station III
description: AFTER six years of pushing and pulling, negotiators believe they have arrived at a workable division of the General Post Office in Manhattan, allowing it to remain a hub of mail service even as it is transformed into a new version of the lost Pennsylvania Station.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRDOFF, HELEN
description: BIRDOFF-Helen. Died December 24, 1998. She was and always will be a wonderful person. Her presence and our memories will never leave us. Her thoughtfulness and class were terrific. A most loving wife, mother, grandmother and great grandmother, she will be missed. With all our love, we tearfully mourn her passing. Vicki, Rick, Alix, Kayle and Reid Birdoff

title: Castro Talk Shows Him Still a Rebel And Prophet
description: It was the same rebellious figure, but older, and though his message was that of a prophet predicting doomsday, there seemed to be fewer people listening, both here and abroad, than on that day 40 years ago when Fidel Castro began his long and lonely tenure as Cuba's maximum leader.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: Veneer

title: Even a Mobster Needs Someone to Talk To
description: THE concept for the new hourlong HBO series ''The Sopranos'' sounds simple enough: an upwardly mobile Mafia capo from North Jersey slams head-on into a midlife crisis, enters therapy and starts taking Prozac.

title: Where to Get Help Assembling an Outfit
description: Darina Byrne and Kim Manocherian, native New Yorkers who like to help others resolve the perennial ''What shall I wear?'' predicament, recently opened Nina, a boutique at 20 East 69th Street, off Fifth Avenue.

title: Old Friends
description: In the five years that we have published this annual issue about people who made a difference, we have observed patterns of death. Some years seem marked by the passing of many celebrities. That was true about 1997, for instance, though with a jolting variation: the violent, untimely deaths of Diana, Princess of Wales, and Gianni Versace. Not 1998; last year brought a sad but quieter pattern, one reflecting how people born during the baby boom are advancing into their 50's. Even as their own children are becoming adults, familiar faces from their childhood are passing from the scene.

title: Junk by Any Other Name . . .
description: While other shopping areas glowed with holiday decorations, a car lacking doors and tires sat for nearly two months on 37th Street near 13th Avenue, across from a Pergament Home Center, caught in the backlash from a city scandal as two departments wrangled over whether it qualified as a junker or had some value.

title: Bachelor's Degree for New Suffolk Police?
description: BESIDES carrying a badge, Suffolk County police officers may soon be carrying a college diploma. A proposal now before the County Legislature would require all applicants for the county police force to have a four-year college degree, and it has drawn fierce opposition from police officials and minority advocacy groups.

title: Guide to Bonds: Risky, Arcane, But Essential
description: JAY GATSBY was a bond guy in F. Scott Fitzgerald's yarn of the Roaring Twenties. The bond market was also the playground for John Meriwether's 1990's band of Nobel laureate-speculators who made eight-figure fortunes for Long-Term Capital Management before its recent meteoric fall.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Andre Weil; Numbers Man
description: The Parisian emigre Andre Weil, perhaps the last of the great mathematical generalists, did not suffer fools lightly, and university bureaucrats headed his list of fools. Once, when asked to submit a budget for the math department, Weil responded, ''Give us enough chalk.'' Mathematicians generally aren't fussy about where they work: important mathematical conjectures have been proved in the bathtub and on the trampoline. Weil (pronounced VAY) knew this firsthand: In 1939, at the age of 33, he solved an important number-theory problem while serving time in a French military prison for evading the draft.

title: The County Executive After Round 1; Despite Spano's Boast of Promises Kept, Critics Say He Lacks Vision for the Future
description: ANDREW J. SPANO summed up his first year as County Executive as a ''successful, quiet renaissance,'' -- everything, he said, that he promised voters he would deliver, and then some.

title: Is a Buffer-Zone Law Fair if There Is No Room for a Buffer?
description: Customers stroll in and out of Pleasure Plus on Route 46 in Saddle Brook, a small, densely packed community of modest one- and two-family homes interspersed with businesses. Attracted by the bright pink sign that advertises the store's wares, people go to Pleasure Plus for the latest in XXX-rated videos and ''romantic accessories.''

title: Big Moments on Campus
description: Colleges and universities are not just places for teaching -- they are birthplaces of discovery, settings for invention and forums for the nation's discourse. Below, test your knowledge of academe's brush-ups with history.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: George Wallace; What He Stood For
description: I met George Wallace only twice -- very publicly -- and I have no idea whether his latter-day denials of being a racist at heart are true or not. What I do know is that his political career was founded on racial discrimination, and that he left a political heritage that exploits racial feelings for political gain.

title: Do Higher Standards Help or Hurt?
description: I have been in school all my life and I am still struggling with grades and standards. Standards are important. They give us goals to strive for. But they have to be realistic and, as much as possible, individually chosen. We all have a different configuration of strengths and weaknesses and the aim of education is to improve both. What happens all too often, however, is that unrealistic standards and too much criticism close us off to our true abilities.

title: Cashing In, and Staying Put
description: MORE than a decade ago, Cynthia Brown, a retiree in Monroe, La., was having trouble making ends meet with her monthly Social Security check. So she trekked to the local welfare office and signed up for food stamps.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Antonio Prohias; Yin and Yang, Cold War Style
description: I never loved ''Spy Vs. Spy.'' I was an aspiring 13-year-old cartoonist in 1961 when the feature first began appearing in Mad magazine, and although I admired Antonio Prohias's voluptuous brush strokes, his pantomimed sequences and streamlined drawing style struck me as forced and difficult to decode. I worshiped Mad -- it was the distorting mirror through which I learned to see the world -- but ''Spy Vs. Spy'' didn't really seem to reflect the outside world, like the parodies and lampoons that made the rest of the magazine so urgent for me. Since then I've come to appreciate Prohias's variations-on-a-narrow-theme school of comics (in its highest incarnations it brought us Krazy Kat and the Roadrunner cartoons), and his black-and-white spies are universal signs. They are, in fact, the comic-strip equivalent of the yin-and-yang symbol, good and evil, interdependent and interchangeable, forever chasing after each other's tails.

title: Ms. Clayton, Mr. Parsons
description: Katherine Lawler Clayton, the daughter of Denise and Joe Clayton of Brooklyn Heights, was married yesterday to William Chase Parsons, a son of Mary S. Payson of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., and William Parsons Jr. of Locust Valley, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Louise Parsons Pietsch, an Episcopal priest and an aunt of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden with the Rev. Dr. Llewellyn Parsons Smith, a United Church of Christ minister, who is also an aunt of the bridegroom.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: UPPER WEST SIDE

title: THE NEW EUROPE: United and Divided; Shiny, Properous 'Euroland' Has Some Cracks in Facade
description: Europe has two faces, light and dark, and they are evident on Germany's western and eastern borders as the continent crowns four decades of integration with the adoption of a single currency, the euro.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, VERONICA GREEVEN
description: EDWARDS-Veronica Greeven. Memorial service to be held Jan. 9, 11:30 AM at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at 53rd Street.

title: God Save Greenwich Village
description: ''THE Blue Room,'' ''Electra'' and ''Cabaret'' with Alan Cumming, all imported to Broadway from London. ''Shakespeare in Love,'' ''Elizabeth'' and ''Hillary and Jackie'' on our screens. ''Two Fat Ladies,'' ''Sister Wendy'' and ''Teletubbies'' attracting cults to PBS. More British names on mastheads. English deejays at Twilo and Limelight. The oh so post-modern Wallpaper magazine. Alexander McQueen, the Verve, Ewan MacGregor and the well-tousled Tony Blair, all giving off glamour rays from afar. In the buzz kingdom of Manhattan, it's a felicitous time to be British.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Dec. 13 with an article about the most influential designs of the last hundred years omitted the name of one of three designers of the MTV logo. She is Patti Rogoff.

title: The View From/Ten Thousand Villages; Hand-Made Craft Items From Around the World
description: IT is a special event when handcrafts from around the world not only appear on the Internet but also land on the doorstep of a nearby boutique.

title: Some Quietly Take Pleasure in N.B.A.'s Pain
description: People in baseball wouldn't wish their 1994 experience on their worst enemy, but David Stern isn't their worst enemy.

title: Mr. Pataki's New Year Challenge
description: Gov. George Pataki of New York must be looking at 1999 with particular curiosity. Mr. Pataki was sworn in for a second term on New Year's Day, following a comfortable re-election victory last November. The state's economy is still strong and the upcoming legislative season does not seem to hold any dramatic challenges.

title: One Word on Campaign Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: The World: Dissonance
description: LAST week, while governments and the press abroad dwelled on the harsh sentences meted out to Chinese dissidents, exuberant middle-class couples crowded into the newly opened Ikea warehouse store here, snapping up stylish, modestly priced furniture and housewares.

title: Dentist on the Airwaves, Sound Bites and All
description: HARVEY PASSES was on grin patrol. Not that checking out smiles is unusual for a dentist, particularly a cosmetic specialist. But Dr. Passes was holding neither a drill nor a toothbrush.

title: Crafting of History
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTELNUOVO, DR. LAMBERTO G.
description: CASTELNUOVO-Dr. Lamberto G. Lamberto's loving family in Rome, Italy mourns his passing. He is survived by his niece Piera and her son Bruno, his nephew Paolo, nieces Rosella and Lori, sisterin-law Sally and great nieces and nephews Federico, Francesco, Gabrielle, Ricardo, Victoria and Olympia. Lamberto was the youngest of three brothers and he died December 23 on route to the funeral of his oldest brother Piero who died suddenly that same morning. Lamberto was raised in the Jewish community in Rome and obtained his medical degree at the University of Lausanne, Switzerland during the war. After coming to America in 1953, he stayed close to his family in Rome returning frequently.

title: The Shock of the Familiar
description: CD's have taken away one of the wonderful things from my childhood: the large, gorgeous, artistic covers on LP's that we'd hang on our walls.

title: Private Sector; Down for the Count, a Stock Becomes a Net Heavyweight
description: For George Horowitz, chairman of the Active Apparel Group, reviving his small clothing company's dead-in-the-cellar share price often seemed like the name of his line of active wear, ''The Grind.'' The thinly traded stock wallowed around at $1.25 a share as recently as Monday.

title: Philanthropy, From the Rest of Us
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Wild, Watery Realm
description: LOOK! Dolphins!''

title: White's Words
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Where's Kasparov? Anand Rules Tournament Play
description: Garry Kasparov's colleagues are sniping at his claim to be the world's best player. They point out that he has virtually abandoned the elite tournament circuit in favor of exhibition matches with opponents of his own choosing. Moreover, the Indian star, Viswanathan Anand, whom he defeated in a 1995 title match, has now become pre-eminent in tournament play.

title: DaimlerChrysler Hopes Green Will Be Red-Hot
description: SO far, alternative fuel vehicles have tended to be commuter cars so underpowered that they can barely keep up with expressway traffic. But DaimlerChrysler is to present four concept vehicles today that run on something other than gasoline, yet have plenty of horsepower.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASKIND, ROSELLA
description: BASKIND-Rosella (Rose), on December 31, 1998. Beloved wife of the late George. Loving mother of Anita Baskind & Linda Stone. Dear grandmother of Ian and Matthew Stone. Services Sunday 9:45AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Dec. 27-Jan. 2; Europe Greets the Euro
description: The euro, the currency common to 11 European countries, arrived on Jan. 1. So must francs and marks be traded in now? Far from it. There won't even be euro coins and bills until 2002, and local currency will be good for six months after that.

title: ALLY McBEAL; Same Old Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: Oregon Falters On a New Path To Health Care
description: Nearly five years ago, Oregon began putting an idea to work that seemed both harsh and humane: In return for health insurance paid by the government, the poor would be required to join health maintenance organizations and have their care rationed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORNSTEIN, HAROLD
description: ORNSTEIN-Harold (Ernie) age 71. Loving husband of Cary, father of Billy and Nancy Jane, and brother of Don.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDENBERG, PAUL
description: SEIDENBERG-Paul. January 7, 1928-December 21, 1998. Survived by his beloved wife, five adoring children, and ten grandchildren. We will forever keep you in our hearts and minds with the greatest love and memories. B. Seidenberg and Family
