title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Bob Kane; Ultimate Fantasy
description: Batman was born in 1939, the brainchild of two graduates of DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx: Bob Kane, 23, a comic artist of great flair and dramatic sense (pictured at left), and Bill Finger, 25, a former shoe salesman and a writer of considerable literary taste. They were brought together by a challenging offer from D.C. Comics, publisher of Superman, introduced just a year before. Would they create a character that could compete? In short order, they created one that in time became at least as globally famous as the Man of Steel.

title: Revisiting Holiday Imagery And Nostalgia for Childhood
description: ' 'Tis the Season'

title: Paths of Bears and People Increasingly Crossing
description: Samantha the bear came from the Wawayanda State Park into Susan and Vincent Kehoe's woodsy backyard and acted outrageously cute, lolling on her back, eating from their hands and, over the years, bringing about 15 cubs to visit. The Kehoes keep a framed 8-by-10 photograph of Samantha in their kitchen.

title: Dec. 27-Jan. 2; Woman in Top Swiss Post
description: Switzerland's first woman President -- and the first Jew in the largely ceremonial top post -- took office on Friday. Ruth Dreifuss, 58, was elected in December in one of the narrowest Parliamentary votes in recent years. Her presidency comes amid recent revelations questioning Switzerland's cherished myths about its neutrality during World War II.

title: The Limits of Technology
description: Amusing as it is simply to sit back and watch the calendar of the Western world flip over, it is reasonable to expect that 1999 -- prologue to a new millennium -- will yield some themes that ask for real reflection. Here is one. In the blizzard of commentary already blowing in, it is becoming apparent that we are nearly blinded by technology. Trying to gauge the meaning of a new millennium, we almost instinctively do so by marveling at the rate of technological change, which we cannot help believing will only increase. It seems like the most salient feature of human culture during the last 200 years.

title: With New Cars, L.I.R.R. Gathers a Bit of Momentum; Diesel Lines Go to the Head of the Class; Electric Service is Next Project
description: MORE than a year late but now finally arriving, shiny new bi- level coaches are transforming diesel service on the Long Island Rail Road and inspiring awe in customers who long ago grew surly about riding the railroad's dingy, rickety diesel trains.

title: Swimmer Says Olympic-Size Pool Has Been Officially Shrinking
description: William H. Depperman, who lives on East 16th Street, takes two subways twice a week and every weekend to get to Riverbank State Park, at West 145th Street on the Hudson River, to use the only Olympic-size swimming pool in the city that is open to the public. Mr. Depperman, 57, won second-place and third-place medals in the New York State Senior Games in June, and is now training to represent New York in the National Senior Games in Orlando, Fla., in October 1999.

title: The Shock of the Familiar
description: A friend and I were staying at the Philippe Starck-designed Delano Hotel, in Miami Beach, on the day ''Philip Johnson's Starck Choice'' appeared in your magazine. In his panegyric to Starck, Johnson declares, ''One does not use beauty.'' One does, however, use bathrooms, and the bathrooms in the Delano's guest rooms are as functionally frustrating as they are visually prepossessing.

title: Old Mill Town Has New Bustle, Thanks to Antiques
description: AT the start of the 1990's, Putnam, in the northeast corner of the state, was a prime example of an old mill town slowly dying. Its population was less than it had been at mid-century and since then had suffered through two catastrophic events, one natural, one manmade. The first was the great flood of the mid-1950's when the Quinebaug River leaped its banks and destroyed some 200 homes. The second was the post-World War II economic disaster, when textile companies that had fueled the economy of eastern Connecticut for generations started moving South because it was cheaper and warmer there.

title: Streetscapes / The Old Gotham Hotel, Now the Peninsula New York; A History Shaped, in Part, by State Liquor Laws
description: FROM the time it opened in 1905, the Gotham Hotel at Fifth Avenue and 55th Street -- now the Peninsula New York -- played second fiddle to the 1904 St. Regis across the street. But the former Gotham -- bankrupted in 1908 after it failed to get a liquor license -- has reopened after a gut renovation and is aiming for parity with its more famous neighbor.

title: Artest's 25 Points Lead St. John's To 8th in a Row
description: Ron Artest came to St. John's two years ago with high expectations. As he showed tonight in the 12th-ranked Red Storm's 77-73 victory over Rutgers, he might be better than that.

title: Julie Schupper and Gregg Klein
description: Julie Michele Schupper and Dr. Gregg Roger Klein were married on Thursday. Rabbi Barry Friedman performed the ceremony at the Essex House in Manhattan.

title: Video Verite
description: THE YOUNG WOMAN ON THE TELEvision screen simply will not look up.

title: Atlantic Avenue As Restaurant Row
description: CAROLINA COUNTRY KITCHEN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, JAMES PEARSON
description: GOULD-James Pearson, Sc.D., Geotechnical Engineer. Member National Academy of Engineering. Retired partner Meuser Rutledge Consulting Engineers. Died December 25, 1998. Funeral services 3PM Sunday, January 3, 1999, First Church of Round Hill, Greenwich, CT. Contributions to Cabrini Hospice, 227 E. 19th St., NYC 10003.

title: One New High School or Two? Another Round of Debate
description: For almost a year, community leaders, elected officials and residents have debated the creation of a high school for students from Riverdale and Kingsbridge as an alternative to the district's overcrowded John F. Kennedy High School in Marble Hill. After months of deliberation on a proposal to turn Middle School 141 in Riverdale into a school that includes grades 6 through 12, the District 10 superintendent, Irma Zardoya, released a new plan on Dec. 22, starting a new round of debate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, LOUIS
description: KRAUS-Louis. January 1, 1999. Cherished father of Marya Wintroub and John Kraus; loving father-in-law of Bruce Wintroub; fabulous grandfather of Anne, Benjamin and Molly Wintroub; beloved friend of Betsey Steeger. Service Tuesday, January 5, 11 AM, St. James' Church, 865 Madison Ave. (71-72 Sts.). In lieu of flowers, people are invited to make contributions to Holy Cross Monastery, West Park, NY 12493.

title: Robin Rittenband, Charles Lubinsky
description: Robin Jill Rittenband, a daughter of Lynn and Elliot Rittenband of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Charles Arthur Lubinsky, a son of Marian and Leonard Lubinsky of South Deerfield, Mass. Rabbi Stephen Klein officiated at the Marriott Marquis in New York.

title: Holiday Week: School's Out. Kids Shout. Parents Pout.
description: THE SETTING -- The big circular exhibition room in the New York Hall of Science, a museum on the outskirts of Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, where hundreds of children, attended by parental figures, were wandering around, playing with lights, staring into microscopes at microbes, spinning propellers and filling the air with playground sounds on Tuesday morning.

title: Dec. 27-Jan. 2; Mixing Work and Welfare
description: Most states are meeting the work requirements of the 1996 welfare law, and 28 percent of adults on the rolls are participating in some type of work activity, the Administration reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARRAN, ALVIN
description: TARRAN-Alvin, on December 29, 1998. Devoted husband of Adele. Beloved father of Jeffrey and Susan, Billy and Debbie, and Matthew and Jennine. Dear brother of Ruth Kabram. Loving grandfather of Leah, Emily, Gabriel, Benjamin and Nikolai. He was deeply loved and will be missed by all.

title: Pop Goes the New Year
description: Ciliegia Amabile, nonvintage. (About $14.)

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: MY ONE GOOD NERVE

title: 'James Herriot' Of West 18th St. Treats Last Pet
description: The city's kinkajou population had better stay healthy. Dr. Joseph W. Adams has lost his lease.

title: . . . But Twilight Cloaks Russia
description: It was near midnight seven years ago when a vast crowd gathered outside K.G.B. headquarters here as four cranes hoisted from its pedestal a statue of a hated man: Feliks Dzerzhinsky, founder of the secret police that helped keep the Soviet Union in fear for 74 years.

title: The Shock of the Familiar
description: My heart jumped when I turned to Luc Sante's article ''A Madeleine on Wheels,'' and I dawdled over it with an almost erotic pleasure. My dream life is always dominated by a traveling shot of me at the wheel of a Citroen DS 21, driving away from a farmhouse in the south of France as evening falls, heading toward the sophisticated revelry of Paris.

title: State Democrats Fined On Campaign Finances
description: The New Jersey Democratic State Committee has been fined $15,000 by the Federal Election Commission for illegally using money raised for state, county and local races to pay campaign costs for Federal candidates in the 1996 elections

title: The Historical Society Sheds a Rather Staid Image
description: THE staid demeanor of the Connecticut Historical Society has lightened up since the creation of two new galleries in its Hartford headquarters.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 3, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRUDEN, DURWARD
description: PRUDEN-Durward, New York University Professor Emeritus, passed away at his home in Manhattan, December 9th. He was 93 years old. Professor Pruden began his career in Texas as a teacher and academic dean of two colleges before coming to New York University where his Doctoral dissertation was on his personal friend, Justice Hugo Black of the U.S. Supreme Court. Author of many articles and books, Professor Pruden was also a member of many academic associations; a long time member of the New York County Grand Jury and a Fulbright professor to the University of Chile where he was a lecturer and advisor to the Ministry of Education in Santiago. He is survived by his wife Kathryn.

title: Rangers Are Optimistic After a 1-Goal, 10-Shot Victory
description: Visiting teams often try to ''take the home crowd out of the game'' by playing a conservative style that is not very entertaining. In theory, this can make the local fans disgruntled and tempt the home team to take risks and make mistakes.

title: To Burnish the Loop, Chicago Turns to Live Theater
description: IN an effort to revive the downtown Loop commercial district as an entertainment area and add a substantial new tourist attraction, Chicago is betting heavily on live theater.

title: To the Beat of the Bleat, Ranchers Aim to Satisfy the Demand for Goat
description: LIKE many other families across America, Salvador Ortega's sat down on Christmas Day to a dinner featuring big, savory helpings of the traditional holiday entree: roast goat.

title: Libraries Offer Events Among the Stacks
description: LIBRARIES offer more than books, and that becomes abundantly clear with the number of recitals, jazz events and children's programs taking place around the region. The New Rochelle Public Library has planned at least four events, including auditions for New Rochelle Theaterworks' production of Stephen Sondheim's ''Company'' in March. The auditions are scheduled this Tuesday, Thursday and Friday at 7:30 P.M, and those who attend should be prepared to sing a musical comedy number, preferably from the show, and do a dance routine.

title: Looking Back on Issues of '98
description: IN the last year, dozens of issues have been discussed in this column. And while some situations change little, others continue to evolve -- among them electric deregulation, luxury decontrol, and restitution in the Manhattan co-op scandal.

title: Remembering Father
description: To the Editor:

title: Lott in Spotlight on Impeachment's Center Stage
description: After the Republican losses in November's elections, a disheartened Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, quickly got the hint: Voters wanted a mended Social Security system, an orderly budget, good schools. They wanted action, not self-serving brawling about legislation and impeachment.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Junior Hernandez; Street Talker
description: Junior Hernandez was better at waking up New Yorkers than a broken car alarm wailing in the morning darkness. He and Luis Jimenez were hosts of El Vacilon de la Manana, a Spanish-language radio show that was wildly popular among Latino listeners looking for a laugh before heading to wearisome jobs. If you ever spotted the Mexican flower vendor laughing outside the corner deli, Junior was probably the reason.

title: A Six-Decade Fight for a Library for Future Generations
description: Belinda Dixon, a Mariners Harbor resident for 25 years, wrote to Santa Claus last year requesting a library for her neighborhood. In the meantime, she is working with the Fellowship Baptist Church, where she is a member, and the Mariners Harbor Civic Association to insure that her 2-year-old grandson, John, and other children grow up with access to a local public library, which her three children, now in their 20's, did not.

title: A Racial Divide That Needn't Be
description: SOONER or later, the political polarization disrupting the rest of the arts was bound to become a salient feature of that prominent microcosm known as the jazz world. Not surprisingly, the fault line is racial, with critics and too many musicians implying or declaring outright that jazz is simply ''African-American music.'' In their view, contributions by whites, especially in the formative pre-World War II days, are musically expendable.

title: Dec. 27-Jan. 2; Adding a Stitch in Time
description: Since the time of Isaac Newton, many scientists have maintained that the solar system is a big clock that keeps perfect time and never runs down. Alas, celestial goings-on are rarely quite as neat as the explanations devised by humans, and the solar system now seems rather creaky compared with the atomic clocks used by the world's official timekeepers.

title: U.S. Long View on Iraq: Patience in Containing the Ever-Deadlier Hussein
description: Nearly eight years after the 1991 Persian Gulf war started, Saddam Hussein is still shooting at American pilots and the United States still has no clear strategy for defeating him.

title: Q. & A.
description: Co-op Bars Tag Sale In a Unit

title: After 100 Years, Finding the Old In Today's Nassau
description: THE beginning of 1999 is more than just another new year in Nassau County. It was a century ago, on Jan. 1, 1899, that Nassau officially split from Queens, which had become part of New York City the year before. The new county was the 61st in New York State.

title: Steal This Page
description: Here is an innovative way to suppress the news: remove the newspaper. According to the American Council of Trustees and Alumni, a nonprofit group in Washington dedicated to academic freedom, 453,123 newspapers were either stolen or destroyed at 121 campuses between 1992 and 1998. Most of the publications were conservative, and the actions usually went unpunished.

title: That Healing Touch in a Brutal Century
description: It's going to be a cold, cold world without the warm heart and healing hands of Brother Cadfael, the 12th-century Benedictine monk who was brought to life by Sir Derek Jacobi on a PBS ''Mystery!'' series. Based on the historical novels of Ellis Peters, ''Cadfael'' will begin its fourth, and final, season on Thursday at 9 P.M. with ''The Holy Thief,'' followed by ''The Pilgrim of Hate'' on Jan. 14 and ''The Potters Field'' on Jan. 21.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: The Grassy StreetBy Asar Eppel.Ivan R. Dee, paper, $14.95.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Russell P. (Red) Reeder; Born at Reveille
description: From birth to death, on the playing field and battlefield, among the writers who hung out at Toots Shor's and the Presidents and generals who were his friends, Col. Russell (Red) Reeder Jr. was known as a man's man. The son of an Army officer, he was ''Born at Reveille'' (the title of his autobiography) in Fort Leavenworth, Kan., in 1902, starred in football and baseball for Army at West Point and then turned down an offer to play pro baseball with the New York Giants (at triple the salary) for a military career. In 1944, at 42, he led his soldiers ashore at Utah Beach on D-day, and by dusk Red Reeder's regiment was the farthest inland. On the fifth day of battle he was seriously wounded by a German 88-millimeter round, and his left leg had to be amputated.

title: Joshua Klahr, Suzanne McKechnie
description: Suzanne Amy McKechnie and Joshua Klahr were married last evening at the Kohl Mansion, a historic house in Burlingame, Calif. Rabbi Jerry Levy performed the ceremony.

title: Brotherly Love and Hate
description: AS JOSHUA ETHAN CORDOVA APPROACHED his dorm room at Colorado State University one afternoon about a year ago, he noticed a bloody hand print on the door handle. Then he looked down. A dead rat was at his feet. As if the warning weren't clear enough, its intent had been spelled out on the door. ''Go Home Faggot!''

title: Amy Berry, Ralph Reichle
description: Caroline Amy Berry, an advertising executive, and Dr. Ralph Lee Reichle, a physician, were married yesterday at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Old Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Peter T. Vanderveen performed the ceremony.

title: A Turn for the Better at the U.N.
description: Kofi Annan has brought renewed idealism and strengthened management to the United Nations since taking charge as Secretary General two years ago. He has also improved relations with Washington from the sorry level they had sunk to under his predecessor, Boutros Boutros-Ghali. But the U.N.'s diplomatic credibility continues to erode, especially with regard to Iraq. Most of the blame lies with a Security Council divided by Saddam Hussein's endless provocations. But Mr. Annan's own efforts at dialogue with Baghdad have complicated matters.

title: Giving Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Sector; Ballooning? It's Just So 1870's
description: Richard Branson, the gung-ho chairman of the Virgin Group of Companies, presumably did not enjoy seeing a picture of himself -- windswept and waterlogged -- on the front pages of Britain's newspapers the day after Christmas. But he was unable to escape the barrage of publicity that came when he aborted his fourth effort to circumnavigate the Earth and ditched his hot-air balloon off Hawaii.

title: Doing Wagner In a Big Way. (How Else?)
description: WAGNER tends to attract people who think big. So it should surprise no one that as Zdenek Macal and the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra turn their attention to Wagner, they are going all out, spending almost three weeks on a ''Ring'' Festival that offers orchestral syntheses of all four operas of Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle, with, here and there, even some bouts of singing. The performances begin on Thursday, with Mr. Macal's own synthesis of ''Die Walkure,'' at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark, where most of the events take place.

title: Q & A
description: Literary Paris

title: Layovers
description: To the Travel Editor: ''Layover or Mini-Vacation?'' by Rose Moss (Nov. 22), reminded me of one. Not looking forward to a four-hour layover in Salt Lake City, my husband and I discovered a free tour of Temple Square, the center of the Mormon faith. Volunteers drove us to the Square in an air-conditioned van. The driver was a church member, whose wife seconded him from the passenger seat. (Vans leave regularly.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERSTEIN, DAVID
description: SILBERSTEIN-David of 146 Petticoat Ln, East Haddam, CT. Died December 30, 1998. He was born in New York City on September 5, 1917, son of the late Sarah and Harry A. Silberstein. He graduated from Townsend Harris High School, New York University and New York University Law School. He was a member of the New York Bar Association. He enlisted in the United States Naval Reserve in 1940 and was stationed at Pearl Harbor when the Japanese bombed the base. He was Commanding Officer of cruisers and a destroyer in heavy combat in the Pacific and Mediterranean war zones for which he received many decorations including the Silver Star. He attained the rank of Commander and was Director of the Separation Center in New York City 1946-1947. After the war, Commander Silberstein entered the publishing business. He became Vice President of Prentice-Hall, Inc. and later President of the Bureau of Business Practice in Waterford, CT. He was an avid naturalist, ornithologist, environmentalist and tournament bridge player and director. He married Margaret Mary Kirrane on Easter Sunday 1950. Their children are David Shay, his wife Mollye, Deirdre Ellen and Donald James, his wife Mary-Margaret. The grandchildren David, Marget, William, James and Alana. He is also survived by a brother in law Rev. James A. Kirrane. Family funeral services will be held at St. Bridget Cemetery, East Haddam, CT. The Swan Funeral Home, 27 W.F. Palmer Road, Moodus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BJORKLUND, JOHN
description: BJORKLUND-John ''Brodie'', Jr. Of Glen Head, NY. On December 31, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Frances. Loving father of Betsy (Shaun) Convey and Hank (Victoria). Dear grandfather of Tyler Convey. Also survived by his brother Paul and sister Marie Wilson. Visiting Monday 3-5 and 7-9 PM, Whitting Funeral Home, Glen Head, NY. Funeral service Tuesday 11:00 AM, St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, Port Washington, NY. Interment private. Contributions may be made to Dartmouth Class of '41 scholarship c/o A. Hills, 26 Rip Road, Hanover, NH 03755.

title: Visitors Pile Into the City, Leaving Residents Feeling the Pinch
description: Waiting in line at the 47th Street Starbucks on Thursday afternoon, Denise Vasquez and Georgia Locko took a break from sightseeing to assess their first 12 hours in New York City.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: DESERT FLOWER

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Jerome Robbins; Dancing Outside the Box
description: ''I suppose you know I'm engaged to Nora Kaye,'' Jerome Robbins told Buzz Miller -- an acclaimed show dancer who lived with Robbins from 1950 to 1955 -- during their first weekend together. (The 1952 photograph of Robbins, right, is from Miller's private album.) Even so, Robbins never married Kaye, American ballet's great dramatic ballerina of the 1940's and 1950's. But she was a principal dancer in Robbins's ''Facsimile'' -- appropriately enough about a love triangle. Robbins's truest love was classical ballet. Although he mounted such musical monuments as ''The King and I,'' ''West Side Story'' and ''Gypsy,'' Robbins left the commercial theater after directing and choreographing ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' in 1964. Drama critics begged him to return to Broadway -- ''where he belongs'' was how they typically put it -- without success. Ballet purists, meanwhile, were inclined to regard him as a show-business type aspiring above his talents. Robbins's ballets, however, are masterpieces precisely because his imagination refused to be contained. In works as varied as ''Fancy Free,'' ''Interplay,'' ''The Cage,'' ''Afternoon of a Faun,'' ''Dances at a Gathering'' and ''The Goldberg Variations,'' he exhibited an extraordinary range of style and subject, marrying classical ballet technique to an exploration of human emotions.

title: Caring for Animals on Their Own Turf
description: DR. JEFF FEINMAN pulled into the driveway of a house near the highway in Westport and gathered his black bag and laptop computer. It was his first house call of the day -- a matter of routine check-ups for the five patients inside.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURR, ROBERT PAGE
description: BURR-Robert Page. On December 31, 1998, of Matinicus Island, Maine, formerly of Lloyd Harbor, NY. Beloved husband of Elizabeth, loving father of Susan, William, James, Jonathan, Elizabeth, and David, and devoted grandfather of ten grandchildren. Born in Mineola, NY, on September 28, 1922, the son of Robert Page Burr and Laurence Hewlett, Mr. Burr attended Princeton University, graduated with a degree in electrical engineering from Cornell University and served as an officer in the Navy during World War II. During his career, Mr. Burr made significant contributions to some of the most important technologies of our time, for which he received numerous patents and awards. He retired as Senior Scientific Officer of Kollmorgen Corporation in 1987. A service will be held aboard M/V SUNBEAM in Rockport Harbor, ME, on Monday, January 11 at 10 AM. A memorial service will be held on Matinicus Island, ME in early June. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Maine Seacoast Missionary Society, Bar Harbor, ME.

title: Bidding for a BID on a Resurrected Avenue
description: Efforts to create a business improvement district on Columbus Avenue date from 1992, when the avenue was recovering from the economic recession of the late 80's. In 1994 came the start of a two-year street reconstruction project that crippled business for the boutiques, specialty shops and restaurants.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARR, KRISTEN ANN
description: CARR-Kristen Ann. Year after year we're reminded of her powerful presence. Our thoughts and love go out to her family and friends. Marilyn and Seth

title: Driving in France
description: To the Editor: Nicholas O'Connell's amusing essay ''The Grand Prix Approach to Paris'' (Nov. 29) could have the unfortunate effect of discouraging many who might otherwise enjoy touring France by car. Based on our own experiences, beginning in 1970, and as recently as last September, traveling the Auto routes between major destinations, as well as the national roads and local roads to discover historic, cultural and scenic sites, and just to explore the varied aspects of that country, have not presented the problems described by the writer.

description: GALT-Michael Tristan. January 2, 1995. I love you today and always. Stephanie

title: Millionaires Increase By the Thousands
description: The number of millionaires in New Jersey nearly tripled in three years, from 3,000 in 1993 to 8,000 in 1996, according an analysis of the 3.4 million 1996 state tax returns filed by residents. The analysis was released by the state Department of the Treasury last week.

title: Sitting Pretty With Zero Down
description: LAST summer, Robert Cramer asked his financial adviser to sell about $250,000 in stock so he could make a down payment on a million-dollar triplex in Malibu, Calif.

title: Where's the Party?
description: Spring break, just around the corner, is often considered a time to whoop it up on sunny beaches in bikinis or in Jams. So how else can you find this year's hot spots than to consult students at the State University of New York at Albany? According to the Princeton Review, which prepares college guides, SUNY-Albany was the ''No. 1 party school in the country'' in 1998. With a reputation like that, its students should be breaking spring in all sorts of ways, right? Here are the results of an informal survey posing the question, Where are you going?'':

title: IN MY... SHOULDER BAG: MICHAEL J. KOSS
description: Most everyone has heard of the paperless office. But Michael J. Koss, chief executive of the Koss Corporation, the Milwaukee-based maker of stereo headphones and classical music recordings, has a nearly paperless shoulder bag.

In 1986, my cousin Vinny Testaverde broke all passing records as quarterback for the University of Miami and went on to win the Holy Grail of college football -- the Heisman Trophy.

description: IN just 10 years, the food industry has undergone a complete transformation, more stunning than any other in the last century. The availability of ingredients from all over the globe and in all seasons has brought new vitality to restaurant kitchens.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Marjory Stoneman Douglas; Don't Mess With Her Wetlands
description: Marjory Stoneman Douglas's green streak seemed almost bred in the bone: at age 5, she sobbed inconsolably when her father read to her from ''The Song of Hiawatha,'' the part where the young brave commands the birch tree to give up its bark so he can build a canoe. Half a century later, that passionate empathy for nature had evolved into a fierce advocacy for the restoration of South Florida's fragile wetlands.

title: The Greening of a Highway
description: As Robert Moses, the city's master builder, originally planned it, the Sheridan Expressway was to run north-south through Bronx Park and curve east to meet up with the New England Thruway somewhere near Co-op City.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Marvin E. Wolfgang; Charting the Devious Mind
description: Studying crime is much harder than studying the economy. Criminals conceal their behavior; only a fraction of all crimes lead to an arrest; some, but not all, convicted offenders are imprisoned.

title: As Ethnic Pride Rises, Rhinoplasty Takes a Nose Dive
description: THERE was a time not so long ago when the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital on East 64th Street was as chic a destination for Christmas vacation as St. Barts or Telluride.

title: 45 Debuts
description: The wraps are off Daniel, and 44 young women bow.

title: Carrie Outhier, Jonathan Banks
description: Carrie Outhier, the daughter of Barbara and Frank Outhier of Nashville, was married on Friday evening to Jonathan Banks, the son of Nan and Allen Banks of Ossining, N.Y. Paul Kent Bramlett performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Willard Hotel in Washington.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Florence Griffith Joyner; So Fast, So Cool
description: It always was difficult to tell what shocked the world more, Florence Griffith Joyner's times in the sprints or the outfits she wore to run them. She once appeared at the starting blocks in what she called ''an athletic negligee,'' and then ran faster than any woman on earth. Another time she wore a purple bodysuit with a bare left leg and a turquoise bikini: her ''one-legger.'' Griffith Joyner designed these clothes herself. Sometimes they matched her six-inch-long fingernails, meticulously painted. Sometimes they did not.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Dorothy West; Last Leaf on the Tree
description: ''As a child, I decided I never wanted to be the last leaf on the tree,'' she told a reporter in 1995, ''and now here I am, the last leaf. I was a member of the Harlem Renaissance, you know, and the youngest person is the one who lives the longest.'' A chatty, nut-brown woman barely big enough to see over a steering wheel, Dorothy West -- accustomed to being the youngest, the first, the only -- was almost congenitally predisposed to think of herself as special.

title: GURU: Dr. Patricia Allen; The 'Small Town' Doctor Whose Lab Coat Is by Chanel

''I was hot, cranky, impossible to live with, angry in my own body and looking for love in all the wrong places,'' said Ms. Brown, who owns a high-end designer boutique in Port Washington, N.Y. ''Not one person could be near me. I could alienate a planet.'' Her doctor referred her to Dr. Patricia Allen, an obstetrician and gynecologist with a reputation for taming the most unruly patients.

title: More Hitchcock Remakes? A Daunting Proposition
description: I WAS not one of the purists made automatically indignant at the very thought of ''Psycho'' being cloned. It's an intriguing experiment to see how a classic film can be faithfully performed or reinterpreted, like ''Hamlet'' or Beethoven's Ninth. Besides, most of my undergraduate students -- Hollywood's target demographic -- had not seen the original ''Psycho.'' I've grown used to them dissing the classics, and using Oliver Stone as their primary source on the assassination of J.F.K.; but it still shocks me to discover that many have never seen a single Hitchcock film.

It didn't seem wise to arrive in midsummer during the throes of this year's sunflower fiasco. Moses, as he is universally known, doesn't suffer failure lightly, and he finds helianthus-related humiliations particularly hard to bear.

They are from ethnic working-class families but attended an Ivy League school, entering Columbia University at the same time, in the fall of 1989. He becomes a two-time all-Ivy League wide receiver in football and makes the dean's list; she is an all-academic Ivy point guard in basketball. They meet, don't connect, then fall in love after they happen to take a course together as juniors, History of Ancient Mesopotamia.

description: With the birth of the new multinational European currency, the euro, comes the necessity of referring to it somehow in documents and messages. This week many a busily keyboarding finger will encounter its first euro figure and stop in midair: Which key to hit?

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Martha Gellhorn; War: From Both Sides
description: By the general agreement of her peers, Martha Gellhorn was the premier war correspondent of the 20th century, a century that is for war correspondence what the 17th was for sacred music. She was fearless, she operated from a sound ethical center (broadly, her ideology amounted to a hatred of bullies), she had a connoisseur's eye for the flaw in the pretty picture and she wrote with eloquence and wit. (In the 1980's she discovered ''Reagan's chocolate voice.'')

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Otto L. Bettmann; Pack Rat With a Vision
description: Otto Bettmann was lucky enough to get out of Germany in 1935, when Jews were still allowed to emigrate. They were not, however, permitted to take along valuable possessions. You can imagine the scene at customs: up and down the line people are sweating, hoping that nest eggs in the form of jewelry or securities will not be discovered, tucked away under their clothing or in hidden compartments in their suitcases. Then along comes Bettmann, lugging two large trunks. The customs agents open them: a load of pictures. Not paintings or original etchings, just photographs, copies -- in a word, junk. They paw through the piles, suspecting a trick. An exhausting hour or two later, an agent taps his temple; the man must be toll -- nuts. With a shrug they let him and his trunks go on.

title: In New York, 'Whole Language' vs. 'The Test'
description: I've been getting the sweats here over making my 9-year-old daughter miss three days of school next week. (All the earlier flights back to New York were booked.) That means she'll have three fewer crucial days of cramming for the controversial new standardized test that all of New York State's public-school fourth graders must take, over three days, soon after our return.

title: Watery Ballet, Potent Music
description: NO composer since World War II has been more resistant to pigeonholing than Hans Werner Henze. At 72, Mr. Henze is still a force in European modernism. Yet his life's work can be seen as an attempt to revitalize traditional Classical forms and genres -- sonata, concerto and symphony, theme and variations, and especially opera -- through cutting-edge innovation.

title: Not So Fast!
description: It's relatively easy to find a label for a policy that involves the promise of action. Both ''Fifty-Four Forty or Fight!'' and the more temperate ''Speak Softly and Carry a Big Stick'' carried messages of stern forewarning. Policy slogans beginning with Remember, with their pledges of vengeance, had a good run in wartime, with the outrages to be recalled ranging from the Alamo to the Maine to Pearl Harbor.

title: Winter Storm Howls Across the Midwest
description: A huge storm wreaked havoc yesterday in the Midwest, from the Canadian border to the Gulf of Mexico, grounding many airline flights, knocking out power and closing roads. It threatened to drop a foot or more of snow on northern states.

title: Memo From Winter: Remember Me?
description: With the bone-piercing cold that ushered in the new year set to give way to snow, sleet and ultimately freezing rain, emergency crews across the New York metropolitan region were on alert yesterday, watching the forecasts as they prepared to salt hundreds of miles of roadways and respond to downed power lines and other weather-related problems.

description: To the Editor:

title: Layovers
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from a business-and-pleasure trip to Kenya, I can address the question of bribery that Rose Moss experienced at Nairobi Airport.

title: Homework Bound
description: Heidi Lehman was always an academic achiever. She finished high school a year early, went through college in three and a half years and then earned a law degree. But nothing in those 18 1/2 years of formal education prepared the 36-year-old lawyer for her daughter Carly's first-grade homework.

title: The Artist vs. the Art World
description: ''The appearance of struggle,'' Nicholas Fox Weber writes in CLEVE GRAY (Abrams, $39.95), has often been identified with being '' 'the real thing.' '' This is a key argument in his attempt to dispel the aura of privilege that the painter Cleve Gray believes has interfered with the art world's perception of him. Written as a continuing encounter among artist, author and several barnloads of paintings, this monograph is unusual both in its frankly informal tone and its subordination of the work to the worries of the maker. ''I've often been mistaken for a rich boy who could buy his way in,'' Gray laments, in a manner that reveals his private fear more than it elucidates his artistic ambitions. What does emerge from Gray's hand wringing, however, is an oddly affecting and sympathetic portrait of the struggle to create in the face of indifference. The book also traces the delicate path required to achieve success and shows how sincere efforts can turn into self-sabotage -- like Gray's diatribe against the Abstract Expressionists written in 1959 for The American Scholar, in which he excoriated the art world's poor taste. Curiously, as his ideas evolved Gray's own paintings came to resemble that very work he dismissed as lacking content. But his conversion came too late, and despite prestigious commissions, including the ''Threnody'' series -- 14 enormous murals commissioned for the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College of the State University of New York -- poor critical reviews have dogged his career, rendering elusive the recognition that every artist hopes for. Though Gray emerges from this fragile paean to his perseverance as a worthy martyr to art, Weber fails to make a convincing argument for a reconsideration of Gray's work as commensurate with the struggle that made it. Andrea Barnet

title: SOAPBOX; Greetings From Millionaire's Row
description: IN the reams of newsprint about my town descriptions include ''lush and lolling,'' ''old money,'' ''horse country,'' ''exclusive'' and ''blue blood.'' In my favorite, the town is called Millionaire's Row. Shall I call in the foxhounds? Perhaps they are causing a nuisance on Route 124 near Friendly's. The smell of cheeseburgers always stirs them up.

title: Sports of The Times; At Last, a Bowl Game With Some Meaning
description: Anyone lethargic enough to spend time in front of the tube this past week is no closer to enlightenment than when this long and trivial clutter of bowl games began.

title: Dec. 27-Jan. 2; Chinese Got Arms Secrets, House Panel Says
description: A special House committee concluded that over the past two decades China obtained, sometimes through theft, some of the United States' most sensitive military secrets, including designs for nuclear weapons.

title: Spit Shine and Spitballs
description: It's an appealing image: rows of students in crisp, matching outfits, shoes spit-shined and unscuffed, hair neatly combed. It's also increasingly common nationwide that millions of students are now required to wear uniforms; as of September, New York City elementary school children will join the pack. The reason is clear: many education advocates, including President Clinton, think uniforms curb violent behavior and bring order to classrooms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBOW, HARRY
description: DUBOW-Harry. Cherished and beloved husband of Charlotte. Loving father to Marilyn, Martin, Renee & Robert. Devoted grandfather to Molly, Juliet, Jeremy, Matthew, Alicia, Acey, Katie-Rose and Devin. Dear brother of Ruth Hoffman. A caring and dedicated French teacher, he taught at Christopher Columbus High School, the High School of Music and Art and his last five years before retirement at the Bronx High School of Science. He was a sensitive pianist who got and gave immeasurable pleasure from playing chamber music with his family and friends. He will be remembered and loved forever. Funeral services will be at 1 PM, Sunday at Northwood Funeral Home, 5608 Broadway, West Palm Beach, FL. 33407.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We can never be an American melting-pot, even with a single currency. People here are firmly attached to national ideas. They like to live in a big, open European market, but within their own language and culture.''

title: 2 Are Accused of Aiming Laser Pointer at Officers
description: Two teen-agers were arrested Friday evening, the police said, after they aimed a laser pointer at two officers on patrol in the Bronx.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Frank Sinatra; Sinatra Generations
description: Frank Sinatra is gone, but Sinatra fandom lives on, although in a quieter way than the post-mortem hoopla surrounding Elvis Presley. Last fall, at the annual Frankfest '98 convention in Atlantic City, there were no reports of Sinatra sightings. Just a group of devotees who came from as far away as Holland to swap memorabilia and watch concert videos of the pop icon, who died in May. One sign that Sinatra's legacy will endure: his loyal fan base of aging bobby-soxers and middle-aged couples is expanding to include young hipsters drawn in by the swing- music revival. ''I think Frank will survive the ages,'' said Tom Rednour, a fan who attended. ''Bing Crosby had a fantastic career, but I've never heard of a Bing Crosby convention.''

title: A Crowded Docket of Courtroom Shows
description: EDWARD I. KOCH, the former Mayor turned television judge, was talking about how justice is mind-bogglingly swift on ''The People's Court,'' the syndicated tribunal where he keeps the testimony moving along. He has to. On ''The People's Court,'' a decision must be handed down before the next station break.

title: INDUSTRIES PRESS PLAN FOR CREDITS IN EMISSIONS PACT
description: Even as a proposed treaty on global warming faces an uncertain future in the Senate, big companies are maneuvering to push through legislation giving them valuable credits for early actions to control the waste gases that the binding treaty would strictly limit.

title: For the Toddler Set, Another Dose Of Enticing Babble
description: I POPPED the video into the VCR and waited in anticipation. As the theme music began, I noticed a telltale sign: his head began to bob. Soon, his whole body was gyrating to the beat, and as the racket coming from the television bounced off the walls of my living room, so did my 16-month-old son, Spencer Papay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VEREBAY, MAX
description: VEREBAY-Max. We observe with great sadness the passing of Max Verebay, age 85, one of the founders of Queens Group, Inc. From the earliest days at Brooklyn Tech with his lifelong partner Martin Kaltman, to the founding of Kaltman Press in New York City in 1932, and on to partnership with Jack Hecht and the evolution to Queens Litho, Max brought his innate technical and creative engineering skills to their growing enterprise. His technical innovations and unique modifications of manufacturing processes helped to grow and secure for the company a prominent place as a leading producer of packaging for recorded music. He took great pleasure in designing numerous factories for the company and homes for members of his family, and never lost the interest in architecture that he developed in high school. In the last decade of his life, Max refocussed his energies from business to his personal life and interests. He enjoyed many creative pursuits, which he shared with Mollie, his beloved wife, to whom he would have been married sixtytwo years next March. He was an accomplished amateur violin player and a prolific sculptor, working in stone at his home studio. All of us at Queens Group extend our condolences to his family: to his wife Mollie, his son Lenny and daughter-in-law Jodi, his daughter Hildi and son-in-law Walter, and his six grandchildren. While we mourn his passing, we celebrate the long and wonderful life of this man who followed his own path, our friend, Max.

title: Heartbreak Hotel
description: Careless Love

title: College Prep; The Grand Tour
description: The car is littered with empty plastic bottles of spring water, granola bar wrappers and CD's by the Dave Matthews Band, Live and the Grateful Dead. That last band name takes on fresh resonance as we drive west on Interstate 90 toward Utica, N.Y. It is the fourth day of a five-day, 1,383-mile car journey, which pushes the odometer past 100,000 miles.

title: Dec. 27-Jan. 2; A Conductor Has a Coughing Fit
description: Diplomacy is an often overlooked skill among musicians, something needed to deal both with one another and with audiences. Under provocation, that diplomacy can break down, as it did at a New York Philharmonic concert last week. Frustrated by what he called ''uncontrolled coughing'' during an intense moment in the third movement of the Shostakovich Fifth Symphony, Kurt Masur, the orchestra's music director, stopped the performance and left the stage.

title: The Kremlin Connection
description: THE HAUNTED WOOD

title: Publications Are Trying New Techniques to Win Over Loyal Readers
description: For most newspapers, the numbers game played out in the twice-yearly audited circulation figures has been a losing proposition for the last 14 years. The figures, which are often considered a basic measurement of the industry's economic health, have dwindled more than 10 percent, to slightly more than 56.7 million copies from a peak in 1984 of 63.4 million newspapers.

title: Companies Prepare for Year 2000
description: For the information technology industry, 1999 will bring back memories of cramming for a final exam.

title: Slow Change in Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: Striving to Keep a Loose Hold on a Tight Ship
description: Managing people is hard. And it's going to get even harder.

title: Despite Cold, Some Homeless Devise Strategies to Avoid Shelters
description: As a frigid night gave way to a dismally wet morning, homeless people across New York City yesterday continued what for many will be a winter-long ritual: the search for a warm place to sleep.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, MALACHI K.
description: O'CONNOR-Malachi K. Of Upper Montclair. On January 2, 1999. Husband of Christine Sheehan O'Connor. Father of Malachi and his wife, Bonnie; Mary Beth O'Connor, Christine Donohue and her husband Robert; Thomas and his wife, Beth. Also survived by four grandchildren. Funeral from the Hugh M. Moriarty Funeral Home, 76 Park Street, Montclair, on Tuesday at 10 AM, then to Saint Cassian's Church, Upper Montclair where at 11 AM a Mass of Christian Burial will be offered. Visiting hours 2-4 and 7-9, Monday. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Hospice Care Center, 3 High Street, Glen Ridge, NJ.

title: With a Difficult Road Ahead, H.M.O.'s Are Set for Many More Mergers
description: This is bound to be a better year for the health care industry than 1998, which, to borrow Queen Elizabeth's mournful phrase, was an annus horribilis for some of the nation's biggest insurance, hospital and physician practice companies.

title: No. 70 Goes After Another Record; A Fan's McGwire Baseball Is an Auction's Holy Grail
description: On Jan. 12, a baseball that was made in Costa Rica for considerably less than $5 will be auctioned at a price some think will exceed $1 million.

title: A Locked Door Is Broken, and Seoul Lawmakers Have a Spy Furor
description: Room 529 in the National Assembly Building in South Korea has an inconspicuous brown door that is usually locked, but a growing mystery about what goes on inside has set off a ferocious political dispute and raised questions about whether Korea's spies are running out of control.

title: Whither the Tube?
description: No one in the television industry has enjoyed the past year. The networks -- six of them now -- preside over a steadily falling audience share, and NBC has even considered suing Nielsen Media Research for what the network says is under-reporting of the critical 18-to-34-year-old viewing audience. Nielsen's measurements allegedly cost the network $60 million in advertising revenues. Meanwhile, network programmers have left their jobs in droves, and the networks have begun to replace them with programmers from cable. The production costs of prime-time shows have gone through the roof.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, JEROME
description: FREEDMAN-Jerome. Born September 21, 1907. Died December 31, 1998, in Delray Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Beatrice for 68 years. Much loved father of Lee and Vivienne and Ruth. Adored grandfather of Jill and Bruce, Andrew and Georgia, David and Leah. Proud great-grandfather of Ryan and Erica and Alexander and Jared. Cherished brother of Anna Raven and the late Irving, Frances and Ruby. Funeral January 4, 1998, noon, at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAVY, DORIS ELAINE
description: KAVY-Doris Elaine. On January 1, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Loving mother of Carla and Peter. Dear grandmother of Nancy, Marc, Gregg, Nicholas and Mackenzie. Service private.

title: Is Russia-Belarus Union a Danger?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Urge to Merge Continues Among Telecommunications Concerns
description: Every year is a big year for mergers in the telecommunications industry. At least, that's the way it has seemed since the Telecommunications Act of 1996 kicked off the biggest round of changes in the industry since AT&T was divided into eight pieces in 1984. But AT&T can still throw its weight around, as it did in forging the most important communications deal of 1998 - its agreement to acquire Tele-Communications Inc., the No. 2 cable company, for $32 billion. And that was in addition to taking over Teleport Communications Group for $11.3 billion, and putting together a $10 billion joint venture with British Telecommunications. The big local phone companies also continued to consolidate: In May, Ameritech agreed to become part of SBC Communications for $56 billion; in July, Ivan Seidenberg, far left, chief executive of Bell Atlantic, and his counterpart at GTE, Charles R. Lee, announced the planned $52 billion merger of their companies. Worldcom Inc.'s 1997 pact to acquire the MCI Communications went through last year, as well, but only after MCI agreed to sell its Internet business to Cable and Wireless of Britain for $1.75 billion.

title: Partisan Tone Seen in Return Of Legislature
description: With the capital's political landscape left virtually untouched by the November elections, lawmakers return here this week for a 1999 legislative session that experts say is likely to yield the same sort of partisanship and acrimony that have become synonymous with Albany.

title: Seeing With New Eyes in a World of Exotic Obsession
description: THE ORCHID THIEF

title: Riding to a Hedge Fund's Rescue
description: Fearing a worldwide financial panic, on Sept. 23 the Federal Reserve Bank of New York orchestrated an 11th-hour rescue of Long-Term Capital Management, the giant hedge fund that was on the brink of collapse. Markets around the world heaved a collective sigh of relief after 14 Wall Street banks and brokerage firms pumped in $3.6 billion and took 90 percent ownership of the fund, which was founded by John W. Meriwether. The Federal Government also considered stepping up the regulation of hedge funds. The Fed warned banks that it might insist that they scrutinize hedge funds more carefully and lend to them less freely.

title: Equity Offering Is Set
description: The following equity offering is expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ISAAC
description: SCHWARTZ-Isaac. On January 2. Beloved husband of Anna Jacobson Schwartz. Loving father to Jonathan, Paula Berggren, Naomi Pasachoff, and Joel; and devoted grandfather of Rachel, Rebecca, Eloise, Deborah, Nathaniel, Ezra, and Leah. Services Monday, January 4, 1:30, at ''The Riverside.'' Shiva at 490 West End Avenue.

title: Microsoft Battles a Bevy of Foes
description: The Justice Department's antitrust suit against Microsoft began in November and continues into this year. The department and 20 states are contending that Microsoft used its monopoly position in operating-system software to stifle competition. William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, and lawyers for the company have denied all of the claims. During the course of the trial, three of the software maker's competitors joined forces. In a complicated arrangement, America Online agreed to buy Netscape Communica-tions for $4.2 billion and also entered a marketing arrangement with Sun Microsystems. Microsoft quickly responded in court that the deal proved that competition was indeed thriving, thereby undermining the Government's case. The Government, however, disagreed.

title: Europe's Great Leap of Faith
description: The euro, the most audacious gamble in the history of currency, has become a reality. What will this crucial step toward unity mean for Europe, the United States and the world? The Op-Ed page asked several experts in economics and observers of European culture to offer their insights.

title: Treasury Offers Bills and Notes
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, one-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and 10-year Treasury inflation protected securities being auctioned on Wednesday.

title: Don't Blame Laws For Clinton Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: 90's Mantra: Bull Market To Carry On
description: The economy will probably cool and corporate profits will probably slow, but stocks will stay in the stratosphere. That is the dichotomy that market strategists believe is in store for investors in the United States stock market this year.

title: The Small Get Big And the Big Get Bigger
description: A year ago, the choice for Lycos, then a struggling Internet search engine, was to make acquisitions or become irrelevant.

title: Steps Get Trickier for 4 Countries Still Dancing Alone
description: The European Union's single currency, the euro, was meant as an act of unification. But, initially at least, it has created a division among the 15 member nations.

title: Henry Schwartz, 89, Surgeon and Lecturer
description: Dr. Henry Gerard Schwartz, a neurosurgeon and lecturer who trained a new generation of specialists in his field at Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis, died there on Dec. 24 at St. Mary's Health Center. He was 89 and lived in suburban St. Louis.

description: Donovan McNabb was among the last to leave the Syracuse locker room at the Orange Bowl in Miami early yesterday morning. He emerged wearing an olive suit and white shoes and feeling heartache beneath his ever-present smile.

description: In the Sonagachi red-light district, where thousands of women sell their bodies along narrow, thronged lanes, it is the prostitutes themselves who have become the leading crusaders against AIDS.

title: The Fed Seeks an Even Keel
description: The Federal Reserve reduced interest rates three times in seven weeks late last year because the global financial crisis was making it hard for companies to raise money, threatening the long expansion in the United States.

title: Philharmonic Violinist Steps Forth as a Soloist
description: In September, Sheryl Staples, a violinist originally from Los Angeles, was appointed principal associate concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic. Previously she had been associate concertmaster with the Cleveland Orchestra, a post she earned when she was just 26.

title: Bell Atlantic Continues Talks For Acquisition of Airtouch
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation remained in negotiations yesterday to buy Airtouch Communications, one of the world's biggest wireless telephone carriers, for more than $45 billion in stock, but an agreement had not been completed and a final deal remained at least a few days away, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Bomb Threat Delays Flight From La Guardia
description: A Delta Air Lines flight bound for Florida from New York was abruptly stopped before taking off from La Guardia Airport and evacuated yesterday after a bomb threat was telephoned to the police.

title: Mr. Clinton's Budget Opportunities
description: A new year always presents the President with an opportunity to outline his domestic agenda in a State of the Union Message and a budget. This year, the impeachment furor seems all-consuming, but by most accounts President Clinton is preparing a sensible, measured program likely to gain broad support in Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODWIN, WILLIAM

Husband of Maria Dudin, father of Andrew & Peter, son of Helen and Charles Goodwin, Jr. & brother of Patricia, Anita, Charles & Robert Goodwin. Will was a loving and devoted husband and father, a kind and caring son and brother, a loyal and firm friend, and a brilliant & dedicated attorney who was very much loved and who will be greatly missed. Reposing at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave, NYC. Visiting hours are Saturday 7-9PM, Sunday 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Monday at 10 AM at the Epiphany R.C. Church, 239 East 21 Street, New York City.

title: A Frenzy of Cross-Border Mergers
description: In a move that reshaped the global automobile industry last year, Daimler-Benz A.G., the German maker of Mercedes-Benz automobiles, acquired America's third-largest car maker, Chrysler, for $36 billion. This was but one of the many American companies that merged with or was acquired by a foreign concern. The News Corporation of Australia got the ball rolling in January with a $311 million deal for the Los Angeles Dodgers. In March, Bertelsmann of Germany acquired Random House for $1.4 billion. Amoco agreed to a $48.2 billion takeover by British Petroleum, Deutsche Bank made a deal to buy Bankers Trust for $10.1 billion and Scottish Power agreed to pay $7.9 billion for Pacificorp.

title: Slow Change in Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: A Surge in Popularity of Software That Unlocks the Code
description: The seers of 1997 had the computing trends of 1998 pretty much nailed down -- the Justice Department's antitrust challenge to the Microsoft Corporation, panic over the Year 2000 bug and Wall Street's infatuation with Internet stocks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENINGER, JOHN E.

title: Dissident, Still on Hunger Strike, Leaves Hospital
description: A Chinese dissident on a weeklong hunger strike to protest China's crackdown on a fledgling democratic party was released from Bellevue Hospital Center yesterday after being taken there Saturday, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Cambodia Town's 'Luck' Leaves Illness in Its Wake
description: When 3,000 tons of industrial waste from Taiwan was dumped in a field here a month ago, the poor villagers living nearby were thrilled at the windfall.

title: In Pursuit of Moses, From Exodus to 'Prince of Egypt'
description: It doesn't take long before we recognize Moses in Dreamworks' new animated film, ''The Prince of Egypt.'' He is one of us.

His colleagues remember him with affection as an exceptional teacher, an intellectual companion and a valued friend.

title: The Case for a Trial
description: The immediate politics of impeachment, to most senators and to President Clinton, dictate avoiding a full-blown trial -- with lengthy arguments, witnesses for and against him, and a requirement that senators sit there silently day after day, listening.

description: Michael Jordan has been a pantomime during these last tense weeks of the National Basketball Association's six-month-old lockout, a figure in motion on the golf course but silent on the issues.

title: Sewing a Label on a Decade
description: Some decades in the life of the business world are easy to label. The 1960's saw a rebellion against the established order. Inflation dominated the 1970's. Deals branded the 1980's. But the 1990's, so far, seem to be the fill-in-the-blank decade.

title: Sports of The Times; If Nothing Else, This Game Sounds Right
description: WHEN football speaks, it does so in a Southern accent. For example, when Bobby Bowden of Florida State voices his fears that a Tennessee running back will burn him for a long gain, he calls it ''a big 'un,'' and Yankees and Californians and Dakotans know exactly what he means.

description: Little more than 12 hours after the Devils had put the finishing touches on their worst defeat of the season, an embarrassing 6-0 loss in Ottawa, the entire team was on the ice at South Mountain Arena in West Orange, N.J., yesterday.

title: The Big City; On Changing Our Approach To Change
description: BEFORE Mayor Giuliani or Governor Pataki gives another rousing speech about New York's bright prospects for the 21st century, he might take a look at a new book by a journalist who lives in Los Angeles, Virginia Postrel. The book is titled ''The Future and Its Enemies,'' and New York clearly belongs with the enemies.

title: 2 Top Khmer Rouge Defectors End Tour
description: Two Khmer Rouge leaders ended their six-day grand national tour today and returned to a remote jungle town that has become a well-guarded haven for defectors from the Communist movement, officials said.

title: Midwest Begins to Dig Out, But Storm Cripples Air Travel
description: Pummeled by the most ferocious snowstorm in more than 30 years, this high-stepping city started to come back to life on today after being slowed to a crawl.

title: Marshall Perlin, Lawyer in Rosenberg Spy Case, Dies at 79
description: Marshall Perlin, a civil-liberties lawyer who was engaged on a decades-long quest to keep the Rosenberg spy case in the national consciousness, died last Thursday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 79 and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

description: FRIEDMANN-Olive. On December 31, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Jack Friedmann, dear mother of Robert J. S. title: Out of a Father's Grief, a Fight Against Terrorism
description: Amid the staggering shock and numbing grief after his daughter Alisa, 20, was killed in a terrorist bombing while studying in Israel in April 1995, Stephen M. Flatow fell back on his instincts as a lawyer.

title: Record Rainstorm Douses the Holiday Weekend
description: The New York region's first major storm of the winter churned out of the snowbound Midwest yesterday with a deluge of lashing sleet and record-setting rains that disrupted air travel, flooded roads and whole neighborhoods and caused hundreds of traffic accidents, including a 50-car pileup in Queens.

title: CLINTON SEEKS AID FOR CARE OF THOSE WITH CHRONIC ILLS
description: President Clinton will announce a $6 billion package of tax and budget proposals on Monday to help provide long-term care for people with chronic illnesses or disabilities, Administration officials said today.

title: 2 Industries Unite to Pave the Way for High-Speed Internet Access
description: Anyone who has used the Internet at both work and home knows that those are vastly different experiences. Whatever the metaphor they choose -- jack rabbit and tortoise, water and molasses, heaven and hell -- most people who access the Net from home via dial-up modems miss a big part of what cyberspace ought to be all about: high-speed, low-hassle access to text, graphics, audio and video.

title: Craft Joins Mars Quest For Water
description: A robot lander and two piggy-backed microprobes embarked today on the second of NASA's water missions to Mars, launched here atop an unmanned Boeing Delta 2 rocket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORETZ, PAUL
description: KORETZ-Paul. Aged 92 of New York City. On January 1, 1999, after a short illness. Beloved husband of the late Helen. Services Tuesday 12 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Sharon Garden Cemetery.

title: High-Wire Act Of Playing From Memory
description: Two contrasting images stand out from among the last year's evenings in the concert hall. One is of a young violinist, a well-trained, interpretively astute contest winner, who played a Mozart sonata at his debut recital. I have forgotten the details of his reading, and even his name, but what I remember is that he stood before a music stand and played the sonata from the score.

title: Unthinkable Happened Throughout Oil Industry

description: STORCH-Marcia, M.D. 1933-1998. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, January 6, at 5:30 PM at the New School auditorium, 66 West 12th St., NYC.

title: The Long Arm of the Ruble
description: The fall in value of the Russian ruble last August was responsible in part for toppling Prime Minister Sergei V. Kiriyenko and his reformist Cabinet, wrecking Russia's banking system and inflicting considerable damage to commerce. Traders ran into roadblocks in buying foreign goods on credit, consumers scrambled to pay inflated prices for items that quickly became scarce. And banks, including Bankers Trust, J.P. Morgan and Citigroup, reported ruble-related losses.

title: Mexico City Journal; Tortilla Rises: Must Belts Tighten?
description: With most of her New Year's Eve dinner keeping warm in the oven, Sylvia Cortes, a mother of five, stepped out last Thursday to make one last-minute purchase. But that trip to the store turned her festive mood sour.

title: Strong Medicine for Oxford
description: Oxford Health Plans, the struggling managed-care company, spent last year trying to recover from the chaos created by its computer systems and by guessing wrong on how much it would cost to deliver care. Having charged too little for its popular health plans, the company was losing money.

title: Parcells and the Playoffs: Together Again
description: For a pro football coach, the Super Bowl playoffs are the test tubes of his career. It's where a compelling coach separates himself from the merely competent, where he discovers who he is and what his team is, where he learns how to win because he has learned why he lost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, JASON K.
description: LEWIS-Jason K. Age 85, of NYC, on December 30, 1998. He is survived by his loving wife of 53 years, Verda Lewis, two dear sons, Donald E. Lewis of NYC and Peter S. Lewis of Santa Cruz, CA; sister Alice Kruger of West Newton, MA, brother Elliott Newmark of FL and five grandchildren living in CA. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARRAN, ALVIN
description: TARRAN-Alvin. Beloved friend and cousin. His warmth, wit, generosity and loving kindness will live in our hearts and memories. Dottie, Marty, Leslie, Eric Payson Michele, Mark Rosenfield

title: N.H.L. Legend Sees Finish
description: His best moments are still as great as ever, even in his 20th season, even in the month of his 38th birthday. When Wayne Gretzky of the Rangers controls the puck behind the net on the power play, he seems like a master puppeteer, feinting and faking and making two teams jump and dance like sets of marionettes. These moments, when the Rangers have the manpower advantage and the checking is light and the offense is in place, bring out Gretzky's best talents: his ability to create, to anticipate and to pass to the open man. These moments bring cheers and murmurs of appreciation even on the road. These moments produce points, most of them assists, which keep Gretzky among the top 20 scorers in the National Hockey League.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: New Technology Revives Old Debate
description: The technologies may be new, but the debate that promises to dominate the patent industry this year dates from at least the days of Thomas Edison and Alexander Graham Bell.

title: Sports of The Times; With 3 Days Left, It's the Real Beginning of the End for the N.B.A.
description: THE media campaign began the last two weeks with full-page newspaper advertisements. The blitz continues on ''Larry King Live'' tonight, when Billy Hunter, the executive director of the National Basketball Players Association, and Patrick Ewing, the union's president, bring their case before the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, LOUIS
description: KRAUS-Louis. January 1, 1999. Cherished father of Marya Wintroub and John Kraus; loving father-in-law of Bruce Wintroub; fabulous grandfather of Anne, Benjamin and Molly Wintroub; beloved friend of Betsey Steeger. Service Tuesday, January 5, 11 AM, St. James' Church, 865 Madison Ave. (71-72 Sts.). In lieu of flowers, people are invited to make contributions to Holy Cross Monastery, West Park, NY 12493.

title: Rolf Liebermann, Impresario at the Paris Opera, Dies at 88
description: Rolf Liebermann, a Zurich-born composer who was the dynamic general administrator of the Paris Opera from 1973 to 1980 after directing the Hamburg Opera for 13 years, died on Saturday in Paris. He was 88.

title: A Reunion's Glitter in a Panorama of Images
description: Beaming, beautifully dressed women and handsome men of all ages surged up the stairs and poured out the elevators to the promenade of the New York State Theater in November, soon filling that vast marbled space with laughter, anecdotes and embraces. The parade of 50 years of New York City Ballet dancers, gathered for the alumni reunion that began the company's anniversary celebrations, might have been a dance lover's fantasy. It was certainly one of the happiest memories of the dance year of 1998.

title: As Big East Gains Stature, It May Lose Lowerclassmen
description: The Big East's mediocrity in men's basketball in recent years is spawning a resurgence. No player left early for the National Basketball Association last season, giving the conference much-needed continuity.

title: A Marriage Maelstrom Industrywide, as the High-Technology Plot Thickens
description: After a year of page-turner mergers and major deals with unexpected plot twists, the book industry is preparing for still more radical changes that could come with further consolidation, expanded on-line sales and increased clout for the nation's leading bookseller, Barnes & Noble Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, MILTON I.
description: LEVY-Milton I. On Saturday, January 2, 1999. Of Teaneck, New Jersey. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice Levy. Loving father of Bruce and Alan. Funeral Monday, January 4, 11 AM, at GuttermanMusicant, Hackensack, New Jersey. Memorial donations to American Diabetes Association.

title: Turning Financial Dialects Into a Common Language
description: Life would be simpler if all companies, whether in Thailand, Tanzania or Tennessee, spoke the same financial language.

title: Debut of Euro Has the British Underwhelmed
description: Holding back on the brink as it has at every turn of Europe's integration, Britain this weekend observed the birth of the euro single currency as a nation apart, its leaders mute even as its major banks prepared to trade the new money by the trillion.

title: At Long Last, It's the Battle for No. 1 (as Promised)
description: Back in the summer, the Bowl Championship Series organizers took their charts around the country and explained how the voting polls and computer rankings would conspire to make the Fiesta Bowl a true national championship game this season. When Tennessee and Florida State take the field here Monday night, the public opinion campaigns will be over and all that interfacing will have indeed produced an undisputed title game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSER, EDWARD G.
description: KUSER-Edward G. Formerly of New York City, Elka Park, NY, and Tucson, AZ. On January 2, 1999. Alumnus of Fordham University and Fordham University Law School. Husband of Adelma Merz Kuser. Father of Cynthia Zokhrouf of Tucson, AZ, William H. Kuser of Mesa, AZ, Elizabeth Kuser of Denver, CO, and Patricia Kaplin of Suffern, NY. Stepfather of Edward A. Pennington of Boyertown, PA, and brother of Mary Baenziger of Tucson, AZ. Memorial services will be held on a date to be announced at St. Francis DeSales Church in Elka Park, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Santa Catalina Mission, 14380 North Oracle Rd., Tucson, AZ 85739.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANC, CHERYLANNE
description: BLANC - Cherylanne. Devoted daughter of the late Lillian and Cye. Beloved sister of Stephanie Tuchman and Robin Blanc. Loving aunt of David, Samantha, Kevin, Carter and Logan. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: 5 Problems Tarnishing a Robust Economy
description: It might seem churlish to find fault with a best-in-a-generation economy. Unemployment and inflation rates are at record lows, and low-paid workers are, for the first time in decades, receiving wage increases that outpace price increases. But despite the benefits of a temporarily buoyant economy, deep-seated problems remain.

title: New York Investigation Firm Plans to Buy Internet Consultant
description: Anticipating an era in which fighting computer crime will be as big a business as Internet commerce, the Kroll O'Gara Company, a private security and investigation company in New York, said it would announce today that it was acquiring Securify Inc., a Silicon Valley computer security firm, for $55.2 million in stock.

title: Rutgers Halts Holdsclaw But Not the Other Vols
description: It would have been an outstanding accomplishment, one that might have given Rutgers its biggest victory of the season and sent tremors through women's college basketball. It would have made the Scarlet Knights defensive legends and had every team from Rhode Island to California studying videotape of their game against Tennessee.

title: For Dessert, Feasting on a French Bonbon
description: After five weeks of ''The Nutcracker'' at the New York City Ballet, any additional dancing foodstuffs might seem a surfeit. But Isabelle Guerin's guest appearance as the Sugarplum Fairy on Saturday night was welcome icing on the cake.

title: Police Charge Pair With Swindling Retiree
description: A man and woman were arrested yesterday and charged with bilking an 83-year-old retired welder out of at least $200,000, the police said.

title: As Big Stocks Whiz Along, Hope Exceeds Returns in the Small-Cap Universe
description: Conventional wisdom has held that small companies grow faster than big companies, small companies are more nimble than big companies, and over time, small stocks outperform big stocks. But recent experience has cast doubt on how valid these precepts still are.

title: Is Russia-Belarus Union a Danger?
description: To the Editor:

title: OBITUARY
description: George Beaumont, 73, a media consultant who co-managed his Paris advertising agency, Liger Beaumont & Aljanvic, from 1961 to 1972, died Dec. 24 in Apt, France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORSZYNSKI, ALEXIA JOAN
description: DORSZYNSKI-Alexia Joan. On January 1, 1999. Beloved wife of Jeffrey Neuman. Devoted daughter of Donald and the late Rita. Adored sister of Ann and Joan. Dear daughter-in-law of Hans and Billie Neuman. Cherished niece of Dorothy Lepeska and loving aunt of Joanna, Ben and Sam. Service Tuesday, 12 noon, at Plaza Memorial, 91st St. and Amsterdam.

title: Coastal Residents Get Lesson in New Math of Homeowner Policies
description: After a hurricane battered his home on the Mississippi coast, Eugene Arnold got a big surprise that may prove instructive to tens of thousands of coastal residents as they renew their homeowners insurance this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARPIARIAN, VARTOUHI
description: ARPIARIAN-Vartouhi. 90 years old. Born in Kharpert, Turkish-Armenia. Died on Tuesday, December 29, 1998. Survivor of the Turkish genocide of 1915, she and her remaining family eventually migrated to the U.S. Beloved sister of Anahid Kludjian; nieces Sona Kludjian and Carmen Collins, and two grand-nieces, Jennifer and Arda Collins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACKER, HOWARD G.
description: ACKER-Howard G. Died peacefully January 2. Loving husband of Helen, father of Ruth, father-inlaw of Paul Heller, grandfather of Michael, and brother of Louis. He enjoyed his profession as a CPA and his many community service activities. Memorial service on Thursday, January 7, 11 AM, at Temple Israel, 112 East 75 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Big Brothers Big Sisters of NYC, 223 East 30 Street, NY 10016 would be appreciated.

title: Vicissitudes in the Marriage of Vienna and New Year's Eve
description: Not that the New Year's concerts of the Vienna Philharmonic are in any way sacrosanct. Far from it.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is extremely frustrating. If we don't make the flight to Melbourne, we might be out of a vacation.''

title: John D. McDonald, 92, Author of a Classic on Business Strategy
description: John D. McDonald, who with Alfred P. Sloan Jr. wrote ''My Years With General Motors,'' a classic volume on business strategy that has been used as a college text for 35 years, died Dec. 23 of respiratory failure, his daughter Joan McDonald Miller said yesterday. He was 92.

title: Aching and Angry, Brunell Forces Meeting With Jets
description: Quarterback Mark Brunell's Jaguars were ahead of the New England Patriots by 12 points late in the first half today, but he was highly agitated. He screamed at coaches on the sideline. Once, after he was sacked, he slammed the football to the turf. The Pro Bowl quarterback was frustrated since he was not sharp after a nearly monthlong layoff because of a severe ankle sprain. But Brunell was angry about something else -- he knew that Jacksonville should have been beating New England by 30 points.

title: Council Role on Shelters
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAOLUCCI, HENRY
description: PAOLUCCI-Henry. The City University of New York mourns the passing of Dr. Henry Paolucci, beloved husband of CUNY Board of Trustees Chairwoman Dr. Anne A. Paolucci. A noted scholar, prolific author, influential political leader and commentator, and distinguished alumnus of City College, he was Professor Emeritus of Government and Politics at St. John's University, Vice Chairman of the Conservative Party of New York State, and candidate for the U.S. Senate. He also taught ancient Greek and Roman history at Brooklyn, City and Iona Colleges and Columbia University. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Christoph M. Kimmich, Interim Chancellor

title: Asia Regains Confidence As Its Stability Returns
