description: Like a cyclone victim emerging from a storm cellar to survey the damage, Asia ended 1998 with equal measures of shock and relief. Shock at the enormity of the devastation wrought by the economic crisis; relief that its storm-tossed markets and currencies had finally regained their footing.

title: With Euro, Europe Reinvents Itself
description: Europe is making history today, but there will not be much time for self-congratulation.

title: The Cases for a Senate Trial
description: A full Senate trial of President Clinton is being urged by his critics and some who view his impeachment by the House as frivolous. Page A14.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BJORKLUND, JOHN ''BRODIE''
description: BJORKLUND-John ''Brodie'', Jr. Of Glen Head, NY. On December 31, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Frances. Loving father of Betsy (Shaun) Convey and Hank (Victoria). Dear grandfather of Tyler Convey. Also survived by his brother Paul and sister Marie Wilson. Visiting Monday 3-5 and 7-9 PM, Whitting Funeral Home, Glen Head, NY. Funeral service Tuesday 11:00 AM, St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, Port Washington, NY. Interment private. Contributions may be made to Dartmouth Class of '41 scholarship c/o A. Hills, 26 Rip Road, Hanover, NH 03755.

title: Good News for Consumers Is Bad for Many Exporters
description: Oil is about $12 a barrel, near its lowest level in 12 years. Copper is 66 cents a pound, its lowest price in 11 years. Aluminum is $1,241 a metric ton, the least expensive it has been in almost five years, and, like other commodities, still falling in price. The major commodity indexes are at or near their lowest levels in more than two decades. And analysts are not predicting a turnaround soon.

title: 6 Packers, 1 Receiver, 3 Seconds: 49ers Rewrite History
description: There were two Green Bay Packers behind him and two more in front of him and by the time the pass play was over there were two more around him, all falling into a pile smack in the middle of the Green Bay end zone. That made six, more than half the Packers on the field, on the heels of Terrell Owens when the clock struck three seconds. When time stood still in 3Com Park.

title: The Neediest Cases; Therapy Enables Boy To Fight Effects of Abuse
description: In 1995, when Joey T. was 7, he stopped walking, and began to crawl again. He started having nightmares and wetting his bed.

title: Chips Are Hidden in Washing Machines, Microwaves and Even Reservoirs
description: As companies and government agencies race to fix the Year 2000 computer problem, they have discovered to their chagrin that problems lurk not only in computer rooms and personal computers. There are also risks in billions of microchips, doing such diverse things as mixing the fuel in automobile engines, controlling factories and medical equipment and even automatically flushing some toilets.

title: Sports of The Times; Holdsclaw Receives Garden's Embrace
description: WAITING outside the locker room yesterday in the arena in which Chamique Holdsclaw dreams of playing professionally was Dawn Staley, a pro point guard of renown who was, fittingly enough, hoping to get paid.

title: How the U.S. Consumer Feels . . . and How the Economy Is Doing
description: The American economy is in good shape, according to 85 percent of the 895 adults polled in the middle of December by The New York Times and CBS News.

title: Devils Silent on Stevens Report
description: Devils General Manager Lou Lamoriello refused to comment on a report that the National Hockey League has completed a four-year investigation into tampering allegations regarding the St. Louis Blues' courting of Scott Stevens before he became a free agent after the 1993-94 season and that the Devils would be awarded draft picks and cash as compensation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, BARBARA CONNOLLY
description: LEWIS-Barbara Connolly. A choral conductor and teacher of ensemble singing, died at her home in Belmont on Saturday, January 2, 1999. A graduate of Radcliffe College and the Harvard Graduate School of Education, she began her career as an assistant to G. Wallace Woodworth at Harvard. After a period of teaching at Milwaukee Downer Seminary and the Winsor School in Boston, she moved to Princeton, NJ, with her husband. From 1959 until 1970, she was co-conductor of the Princeton Musical Amateur Society, a group which used an invited orchestra and soloists to perform the major choral works on a monthly basis. All singers were welcome to participate. In 1970, Mrs. Lewis moved to Belmont, MA, and began to teach at Boston University. In 1972, she founded the Belmont Open Readings and was its conductor until 1994. The Open Readings followed the tradition of the Princeton Group which was itself based on a pattern established by the Drinkwaters of Philadelphia at an earlier time. Barbara Connolly Lewis conducted for many years a choir at the Memorial Service for Radcliffe alumnae at Memorial Church in Cambridge and Christmas concerts at the Saint Botolph Club in Boston where she was one of the early female members. Mrs. Lewis is survived by her husband, Henry R. Lewis, a son, Peter of Marblehead, MA, two daughters, Susan of Swampscott, MA, and Abigail of Ossining, NY, five grandchildren and her sister, Louise Clark of Lexington. A Memorial Concert will be celebrated in her memory at a date to be announced.

title: Stocks, Bonds, Money: the Funds Party On
description: Even the stock market's wild gyrations in August and October were not enough to shake the faith of steadfast mutual fund investors who switched gears through the turmoil, but stayed in the race. That means the fund industry is likely to record another stellar January of heavy cash flows into stock, bond and money market funds this month, traditionally one of its strongest of the year.

title: Lie Low but Brook No Lie, Gingrich Advises G.O.P.
description: Newt Gingrich may be on his way out of the Speaker's office, but his mind is still actively concocting grand strategies to save the Republican majority in Congress that his critics say he nearly destroyed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, VERONICA GREEVEN
description: EDWARDS-Veronica Greeven. Memorial service to be held Jan. 9, 11:30 AM at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at 53rd Street.

title: Crime Rate and Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, IRVING
description: ROBBINS-Irving ''Rab.'' Madison, Wisconsin. 43 years principal, educator, NYC. Dear friend, husband, father, grandfather. He made the world a warmer place. Friends, Bob, Ann, Al, Margherita, Lee, Rose. Family, Esther, Sue, Paul, Michael.

title: I.R.S. Anticipates Year 2000 Well Ahead, Early in 1999
description: For taxpayers, the pesky software flaw known as the Year 2000 problem could cause lots of trouble -- not in the year 2000, but this spring, when the Internal Revenue Service processes 1998 income tax returns.

title: CONGRESS RETURNS TO A SHADOW CAST BY IMPEACHMENT
description: With a new Congress set to be sworn in this week, several influential Senators said today that President Clinton should postpone his State of the Union Message if the Senate was still grappling with an impeachment trial when he is scheduled to appear before a joint session of Congress on Jan. 19.

title: Two Suspects Arrested In Brooklyn Robberies
description: Two men suspected of robbing as many as 17 gas stations and fast food restaurants in Brooklyn were arrested after being caught in the act on videotape, the police said yesterday.

title: Israel Arrests 8 U.S. Cultists Who Expect Apocalypse
description: Israeli police officials today arrested eight American members of a Denver-based apocalyptic cult who the officials said were planning to mark the millennium by committing suicide or provoking their own killings in the streets of Jerusalem.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: FOOTBALL

title: Bill Paxon Reflects On His Resignation
description: Bill Paxon, the exuberant five-term Republican Congressman from upstate New York, has yet to show any sign that he regrets his decision to retire from Congress last year just months before his dream job, Speaker of the House of Representatives, became available -- twice. ''You have to know when to fold 'em in politics,'' said Mr. Paxon, 44.

title: A Village Pied Piper For the Spirit of Folk; Weekly Gathering Fosters Songwriters' Dreams
description: Jack Hardy perched in a leather chair in the cramped living room of his Greenwich Village walk-up, cocking an ear as his old Martin guitar was passed around and half a dozen songwriters took turns trying out new tunes.

title: World Economies On a Tightrope
description: Last fall, with global financial markets imploding and recession fears rampant, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told a group of business forecasters that he had been ''looking at the American economy on a day-by-day basis for almost half a century'' but had ''never seen anything like this.''

title: Car Makers Predict Strong Sales This Year
description: Global slowdowns in the auto industry have consistently started in the United States, which accounts for nearly a third of worldwide demand. But that pattern, which dates back to the end of World War II, seems to have been broken in the last year as plunging sales in Asia and South America have hurt auto makers around the globe.

title: Elizabeth Dole May Be Leaving Red Cross Post to Run for President
description: The American Red Cross said today that it would make a major news announcement on Monday, lending credence to widely reported expectations that Elizabeth Dole, the organization's president, would resign, possibly as a first step toward running for the Republican nomination for President.

title: Woman Killed in a Subway Station Attack
description: In what the police said appeared to be an act of random violence, a woman was killed yesterday when a man pushed her in front of an oncoming subway train as it entered a station in midtown, the police said.

title: A Flurry of Home Improvements
description: Call it the nesting instinct. Last year, kitchens, bathrooms and dens made the best-dressed lists of many as consumers favored chenille throws over sweaters, scented candles over trendy perfumes and designer labels on their linens and tableware over ones on their jackets. Also, a strong economy and interest rates hovering at 30-year lows pushed sales of new and existing homes to record levels for the third consecutive year; Fannie Mae estimated that 5.6 million units were sold. Consumers -- especially aging baby boomers, confident about the prospects for jobs and income -- went shopping, lifting home ownership to an all-time high. All told, Americans spent about $1.5 trillion on new loans and refinancings, channeling some of that cash to renovations as well.

title: Merle E. Frampton, 95, Advocate for the Blind
description: Dr. Merle E. Frampton, an internationally known leader in the education and rehabilitation of the visually handicapped, died on Dec. 17 in Portland, Ore. He was 95.

title: Bitten by the Beetle Bug
description: If this were the 1960's, Volkswagen's New Beetle could be aptly described as groovy. In 1990's speak, the retro car is simply way cool.

title: The Euro: For U.S., Gains and Losses
description: For the last several years, the Clinton Administration has articulated a simple policy toward the single European currency: Anything that helps build a more prosperous trading partner on the other side of the Atlantic is good for the United States.

title: Biracial Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Euro Makes Asian Debut
description: As Asian markets began trading the euro for the first time, Japanese officials braced for battle amid forecasts that the new currency could ultimately chip away at the yen's international influence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ODZA, MARIAN
description: ODZA-Marian. Died suddenly in New York City on January 1, 1999. Survived by beloved brother Paul Varkell, sister-in-law Jane Varkell and grandchildren Randy and Samantha Odza. Her loss will leave a deep void in our lives. Active member in C.O.M.A. Micrological Group, N.Y. Audubon, and Fern Society. Receiving Monday, 1 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. Graveside service 2:15 PM, Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Commerce St., Mt. Pleasant, NY.

title: A Decidedly Drab Year for Many Fashion Companies
description: It's been a tough year for the fashion industry. Among the year's casualties: Isaac Mizrahi, below, lost his financial backing and closed his design business. Anne Klein & Company was put on the block, Kenar Enterprises filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, Andrea Jovine shut its doors and Todd Oldham closed his wholesale collection business.

title: FOOTBALL: N.F.L. NOTEBOOK
description: CAROLINA

title: Rose Bowl Audience Plummets
description: The three Bowl Championship Series games on ABC that preceded tonight's Fiesta Bowl between Florida State and Tennessee to decide the national championship suffered ratings declines.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: History of House Calls
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles Earl Cobb, 82, Minister And Advocate for Civil Rights
description: The Rev. Dr. Charles Earl Cobb, a civil rights advocate who led a major Protestant commission on racial justice, died Dec. 27 after a lengthy illness. He was 82 and lived in Washington, where he died.

title: George Jackson Eder, 98, Expert On Latin American Economics
description: George Jackson Eder, a lawyer and economist active in Latin American affairs, died last Wednesday in Shands Hospital in Gainesville, Fla. He had collapsed the previous evening while Christmas shopping at Wal-Mart, his son Richard said. He was 98.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Jets See An Edge Against Jaguars
description: None of the Jets -- and especially their coach -- came right out and said it, but an anonymous poll of the players might well have shown that they are quite content to meet the Jacksonville Jaguars, and not the Miami Dolphins, in their American Football Conference divisional playoff game next Sunday.

title: Broadcast Network Executives Struggle to Reinvigorate Their Business
description: The network television business will enter the last year of the century groping to find a strategy that will insure its future profitability, and even viability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, BABETTE WALDSTREICHER
description: DIAMOND-Babette Waldstreicher. 86, of New York City. Died Sunday, January 3. Loving mother of Judy Bergner. Loving mother-inlaw of Bob Bergner. Beloved grandmother of Michael, Eric and Scott Wilker. Great-grandmother of Jordon, Melissa and Samantha Wilker. Beloved sister of Eugene Carlin. Sister-in-law of Lillian Carlin. Also surviving, her husband Irving Diamond. Mrs. Diamond and her late husband, Harold Waldstreicher operated the Babette Shop in Norwalk and Westport, CT, for many years. Private funeral services were held.

title: Decent Showing, and Maybe an Encore
description: What was one of the best kept secrets of 1998? That being in bonds was not such a bad idea.

title: U.S Role as World Savior: A Delicate Balancing Act
description: Markets and governments around the world operated under an unshakable assumption throughout the economic turmoil last year: if things really got bad, the United States would be there to engineer a bailout.

title: Essay; Three Reasons for a New China Policy
description: A couple of Shanghai prostitutes let themselves into a hotel room occupied by a Chinese man who had discussed human rights in a local teahouse. With a quick couple of zips, the girls stood naked. Moments later, police entered the room and arrested the dissident for patronizing prostitutes.

title: ''Out of Sight'' Called Best Film of '98
description: ''Out of Sight,'' Steven Soderbergh's frisky adaptation of an Elmore Leonard crime novel, with Jennifer Lopez and George Clooney as shrewd, sexy opposites who attract, was voted best film of 1998 by the National Society of Film Critics, a 51-member group consisting of critics from New York, Boston, Los Angeles, Chicago and other cities. Mr. Soderbergh's zesty and entertaining genre film became an unexpected winner after several earlier ballots had favored ''Saving Private Ryan'' and ''Affliction.'' Those became the best film runners-up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUFRICHTIG, ETHEL
description: AUFRICHTIG-Ethel (nee Horowitz). On January 3, 1999, of cancer at age 79. Beloved wife of Jess. Devoted mother of Michael and wife, Amy. Adoring grandmother (Nana) of Elyse. She was a graduate of Hunter College, an active member of The League of Women Voters, and a very special person. She will be remembered for her desire and efforts to make this a better world, for her rare qualities of insight and understanding, and her great spirit despite much adversity. Services Tuesday, 9:30 AM, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Price Rises Ahead for Road Warriors
description: By the time business travelers fly to their destinations, hop into rental cars, check into hotels and sit down for meals, their trip will most likely cost their employers 5 percent to 7 percent more than it did last year. That is, if they are among the lucky ones who get to travel at all.

title: After 4 Years of Optimism, Not Giving Up Now
description: Abby Joseph Cohen did not flinch in August when the stock market sank. Instead, Ms. Cohen, the chief investment strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, telephoned her clients and told them the same thing she told them a year earlier when the market seemed to be in free fall: ''Stay the course.''

title: The Year's Top Media Buys
description: Most Wanted 1998: The Annual Numbers

title: Natale Laurendi, 75; Investigator And Expert With the Lie Detector
description: Natale Laurendi, a New York criminal investigator whose expertise with lie detectors helped convict the guilty and clear the innocent for many years, died on Dec. 21 at his home in Brooklyn. He was 75.

title: INSIDE
description: Israel Arrests Cult Members

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMALVA, RAYMOND P.
description: LaMALVA-Raymond P. Of Jackson Heights, New York. On Thursday, December 31, 1998. Son of Mark J. and Joan LaMalva. Brother of Christopher, Ben and Lee LaMalva. Grandson of Patrick M. and Joan LaMalva; and Armando and Teresita Agulto. Funeral services and interment were held in Saint Rose of Lima Church and Cemetery, Short Hills, NJ.

title: For the Strikeout King, A Sure Hall of Fame Hit
description: At about this time in the winter 14 years ago, Nolan Ryan was asked what he thought about his race with Steve Carlton for the career strikeout record.

title: Investors Study Drug Pipelines for the Next Blockbuster Medicine
description: The successful introduction last year of Pfizer Inc.'s Viagra, the impotency pill, delivered huge returns to investors who bought shares in the company. The windfall -- Pfizer's stock zoomed 68 percent in the year -- has encouraged investors to study the current pipelines of the world's largest pharmaceutical companies, hoping to spot the next boom drug.

title: Waiting and Still Waiting for a Computing Vision to Materialize
description: Here in Silicon Valley, there is perhaps no greater mystery than why it has taken anytime-anywhere wireless computing so long to arrive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHINN, ELEANOR H.
description: SHINN-Eleanor H. Of Blue Point, Long Island, and Rego Park, Queens, NYC has left this world on December 31, 1998 to be with God and her beloved husband, Arthur F.W. Shinn. She is the loving mother of Cecilia and Arthur, Jr. and adored grandmother. Funeral mass will be held at St. Patrick's Cathedral; crypt interment private

title: A Resolution for the Mayor
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's war with the New York City Council on homeless shelters has led the administration to serve an eviction notice on a Brooklyn community psychiatric center that serves 500 mentally ill outpatients. That was a peculiar way to celebrate the holiday season. It is also dreadful policy making that should be allowed to die with the old year.

title: Don't Blame Laws For Clinton Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, MARGARET HASKELL
description: ROSS-Margaret Haskell. Of Basking Ridge, NJ, and Edgartown, MA. Beloved wife of Edmund Burke Ross and mother of Edmund B., Jr., Amory L., Benson T., Parthenia Kiersted, and the late Robin. A memorial service will be held at the Church of St. John on The Mountain, Mt. Harmony Rd., Bernardsville, NJ, Tuesday, January 5, at 11 AM. Interment Wednesday in Edgartown, MA. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her name to the Martha's Vineyard Hospital, Oak Bluffs, MA 02577 would be appreciated. For further information, contact Gallaway & Crane Funeral Home, 908-766-0250.

title: St. Croix Hopes Gambling Will Bring Back Tourists
description: When Lisa Newkirk-Svarczkopf heard that casinos would soon open on St. Croix, the biggest of the three United States Virgin Islands, she moved her clothing store to a location three times the size of the old one in anticipation of a tourism boom.

title: No Second-Guessing for Paxon as He Walks Away From Congress
description: Bill Paxon, the exuberant five-term Republican Congressman who many people thought could have been the next Speaker of the House, was maneuvering his Ford Tempo through a cold rain here recently when his cell phone rang. It was an urgent call about the house. The one in Alexandria, Va., that is, with the torn-up kitchen.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BADER, ROBERTA LYNN
description: BADER-Roberta Lynn. January 4, 1994. Beloved daughter, sister and aunt. Mother, Michael, Elaine and Jerry, Judith and Louis, Matthew, Alison, Elizabet

title: Snaring a Piece of the Net
description: Shares of companies involved in the Internet blasted to heights last year that were unthinkable in 1997. The search engine company Yahoo, for example, saw its shares jump 584 percent, to give it a market value of more than $23 billion. Amazon.com, the bookseller, surged 966 percent, to a value of nearly $17 billion. And America Online rose 586 percent, to give it a value of $71 billion. What's the magic fuel? Certainly not the companies' earnings. It's probably the fact that investors think the Internet is becoming an important part of more and more people's lives, and want to ride the soaring stock spaceship.

title: Going Out With a Big Ad Bang1
description: Jerry, George, Elaine and Kramer said goodbye last May when NBC broadcast the final episode of the popular ''Seinfeld'' show, the biggest hit television comedy of the last decade. Marketers saw the occasion as reason enough to pay record rates to run commercials during the show, just as they do for spots during the Super Bowl. NBC charged an estimated $1.5 million to $1.7 million for each 30 seconds of commercial time.

title: A Tough Match: 'Jesse the Gov.' vs. Daily Grind
description: The new Governor of Minnesota doesn't know exactly what he'll do in office yet, but he has made a decision about his daily schedule.

title: Mustering a Whistle in a Graveyard Economy
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin left his sickbed to deliver a surprisingly bullish year-end verdict on Russia's economy. ''Russia is on the up,'' he declared.

title: China Thrives, but Critical Year Lies Ahead
description: While much of Asia stagnates, China is still growing at a relatively healthy rate.

title: Nobody Is Budging, but Players Still Hope for a Season
description: With four days left to save the National Basketball Association season, Billy Hunter wants the owners to negotiate, David Stern wants the players to capitulate and no one -- neither the league commissioner nor the union executive director -- is budging.

title: Bracing for Another Year of Reckoning, Amid a Few Hints of Change
description: When economists and investment strategists in Japan talk about the country's prospects for this year, even those who classify themselves as optimists predict horrendous times ahead.

title: Bring on the Bubbly
description: Demand for Champagne is expected to increase by almost a quarter in Britain, France, Germany and the United States this year as consumers look to put some fizz into the biggest New Year's Eve party in a while, the welcome for the year 2000. Industry experts put the demand for sparkling wine at around 300 million bottles, just 25 million bottles short of worldwide availability. Some wineries are planning to release special millennium sparkling wines, while others have increased the amounts they produce. There will also be an emphasis on distinctive packaging, with bigger bottles and memorable labels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, LEONARD
description: LEVY-Leonard. Died January 1, 1999, late in his 97th year. His life was full and joyful and lived with integrity, grace and achievement. He graduated in 1924 from Dartmouth College and joined the Riverdale Drapery Manufacturing Co., which he and his partner took control of several years later, building it into a highly regarded and successful business. His 70 year marriage to Leona, who predeceased him by three years, was one of constant love and respect. He deeply loved his children John and Dorothy Levy, Lee and the late Nancy Gunst, his grandchildren Kathy and John Rudolph, Michael Gunst and Donna Eberle, Lee and Andrea Gunst, John C. Levy, Tom and Valerie Levy, and his seven great-grandchildren, all of whom filled him with pride. We will greatly miss him. Private services. Contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: SPECIAL TODAY -- Outlook 1999
description: Business Day's annual survey of the economy, markets and industry examines whether the prosperity enjoyed by Wall Street and Main Street in 1998 can continue for another year, and whether problems like the Asian and Russian financial crises will endanger global economic growth. It also looks at the debut of the euro, the common currency of 11 European nations.

title: Financial Institutions Are Going the One-Stop-Shopping Route
description: Banking is dead. Long live banking.

title: Don't Blame Laws For Clinton Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLAUGHLIN, MYLES
description: McLAUGHLIN-Myles. The New York City Central Labor Council extends its deepest and most heartfelt condolences to the family of our President, Brian M. McLaughlin for the loss of his father Myles McLaughlin. Our thoughts and prayers are with Myles' wife, Ilene, their sons Brian and Stephen and their grandchildren and greatgrandchild. The memory of Myles McLaughlin will live on forever and his spirit will be carried forward through the thoughts, actions and deeds of his one and one-half million brothers and sisters within New York City's labor family. From the officers and staff of the N.Y.C. Central Labor Council

title: After $2.5 Trillion in Combinations in 1998, the Sky's the Limit in 1999
description: You would think that after last year's more than $2.5 trillion in announced mergers worldwide -- the largest on record -- corporate executives might take 1999 off. Think again.

title: A Joust With Inflation, Recession and Mountainous Foreign Debt
description: If investors were buoyant over Brazil's prospects in 1997 and sobered by its vulnerability to a world credit squeeze in 1998, they are focused this year on the Government's efforts to cut costs and reduce debt.

title: A Good Idea: Think First
description: Your resolution for the New Year might be to do something you know quite well you ought to do: When the dummy comes down, think before playing to the first trick. Even experts fall into this trap, as witness the diagramed deal from the National Senior Knockout Teams in Orlando, Fla., in November.

title: Don't Blame Laws For Clinton Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: History of House Calls
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROLLINS, FOSTER
description: ROLLINS-Foster. On January 1, 1999. Beloved husband of Charlotte. Much loved father of Vicki. Dear brother of Abby and Bob Kirsch.

title: Deal in Canned Seafood
description: International Home Foods agreed today to buy Canada's top two canned-seafood brands from George Weston Ltd. for an undisclosed price. The move is an attempt by International Home, based in Parsippany, to build on its Bumble Bee business, which is the No. 2 canned-tuna company in the United States. The Clover Leaf and Paramount brands of tuna and salmon, with about $131 million in annual sales, are made by the British Columbia Packers unit of George Weston. As part of the deal, the unit will provide canned salmon to Bumble Bee under a long-term agreement.

title: Let Doctors Control Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Gunmen Wound 2 Jewish Settlers in Hebron
description: Gunmen opened fire this morning on a van transporting Jewish settlers in the divided city of Hebron, wounding two Israeli women as two dozen bullets riddled the vehicle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPIDUS, EDITH J. (JUDY)
description: LAPIDUS-Edith J. (Judy), 96. Cherished mother of Jacqueline Lapidus and Elizabeth Zelvin, grandmother of Alexander Zelvin, sister of Hilda Berry, friend an inspiration to many. Funeral Serivce Wednesday, January 6, 12 noon, Schwartz Bros., 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, JEROME
description: HOROWITZ-Jerome. Of Netanya, Israel, on January 4th. Beloved husband of Frances, loving father of Susan (Craig Beech), devoted grandfather of Rochelle Beech.

title: Intuit's Chief Urges Division of Microsoft
description: A senior computer industry executive, testifying in Federal court today, urged the judge to divide or limit the Microsoft Corporation so that the company could not use its market-dominating Windows operating system to promote its other products.

title: Using Magnets on Corners of the Mind
description: A team led by a St. Louis neurosurgeon has performed the first surgery on a human using superconducting magnets to direct a surgical instrument into the brain, around corners or on a curved path, to reach and perform a biopsy on a tumor. The technique enabled the surgeons to eliminate the requirement -- and the danger -- of pushing a needle through important areas of the brain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IDE, DORA DONNER
description: IDE-Dora Donner. On December 18. At age 82. At home in San Francisco, California. Formerly of New York & Palm Beach. Memorial service at 11:30 January 12 at Christ Episcopal Church followed by interment at the Jay family cemetery in Rye, New York. Call 914967-0129 for directions to Christ Episcopal Church. Donations may be made in Dora's name to the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOIES, WILLIAM G.
description: BOIES-William G. Former president of Colonial Bank & Trust Company of Naugatuck and Southbury, CT, died January 3, 1999 in Southbury. For information, The Alderson Funeral Home of Naugatuck, CT.

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL RISES 2.5 PERCENT. Frigid temperatures in the Northeast and Midwest spurred demand for heating fuels. The February contract increased 0.86 cent, to 35.14 cents a gallon.

title: SHONEY'S TO RESTATE RESULTS AFTER COURT RULING
description: Shoney's Inc., the restaurant chain operator, said yesterday that it would restate its results to account for a court ruling that it had failed to pay overtime to some management personnel in accordance with the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act. The restatement, which adds a $3.5 million noncash expense for the fiscal fourth quarter, increases the company's loss for the quarter, ended Oct. 25, to $12.1 million and for the year to $107.7 million. If the ruling is upheld, Shoney's said, its liability could exceed the amount that it has recorded. The company, based in Nashville, owns more than 1,300 Shoney's and Captain D restaurants in 33 states, primarily in the South.

title: Devils Get $1.4 Million and Draft Pick in Tampering Case
description: Lou Lamoriello, the president and general manager of the Devils, had his suspicions in 1994 when the St. Louis Blues tendered an offer sheet to the free agent Scott Stevens. Even though the Devils matched the offer and retained Stevens, who went on to become their captain and cornerstone, Lamoriello and the Devils did not forgive and forget. Instead, they pursued an investigation into the dealings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BESMERTNIK, BLANCHE
description: BESMERTNIK-Blanche, 78, a 22 year resident of Coral Springs, FL, and formerly of Brooklyn, NY, passed away on January 1, 1999. Blanche was the devoted wife of the late Joseph Besmertnik and the daughter of the late Samuel and Sarah Burstein. She is survived by her loving children, Zena and Edmund Horowitz, of Coral Springs, FL; Paul Besmertnik, of Dix Hills, NY; and Sid and Laurie Besmertnik, of Dunwoody, GA. She was the proud grandmother of Gregory, Wendi, and Lauren Horowitz; Brett, Seth, Bonnie, Todd, and Sara Besmertnik.

title: Mother and Son Arraigned In Woman's Disappearance
description: Appearing confident and describing the case against them as weak, Sante and Kenneth Kimes pleaded not guilty at their arraignment yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on charges of murder, conspiracy and fraud in the disappearance of Irene Silverman, an Upper East Side millionaire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAMBERS, ISABEL
description: CHAMBERS-Isabel. Died on January 3rd, 1999. Born in New York City on July 2nd, 1909. She was a life-long resident of New York City. Daughter of the late Margaret and William H. Finegan; beloved wife of the late Norman; mother of Denise; grandmother of Elaine, Sue, Marilyn and Debora; great grandmother of Jennifer, Douglas, Skye, Randall and Brandon. She will be missed and remembered with love.

title: Carbon, Nitrogen, Boron - And Shine
description: With a little extra boron, these diamonds turned blue, like the famous Hope Diamond. With nitrogen, they went yellow. And when radiation hit their crystalline carbon structure, these diamonds-in-the-rough shifted to shades of green.

title: Diversity Survey For the Industry
description: The foundation affiliated with the American Advertising Federation in Washington and the Procter & Gamble Company in Cincinnati will conduct a survey to gauge diversity in the advertising industry.

title: Let Doctors Control Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Patient or Guinea Pig? Dilemma of Clinical Trials
description: When pharmaceutical companies recruit sick people for studies of experimental drugs, what are the companies' obligations to the patients? And once people sign up, accepting risk but hoping for benefit, receiving free medical care and drugs, what do they owe to science, to future patients who may be helped by the research and to the company that may profit from it?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, RHODA
description: JAFFE-Rhoda. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Arlene and Stephen Sakatos, Ellen and John Wagman. Loving grandmother of Lauren, Melanie, Alexandra and Molly. Services ''Wien & Wien'' Hackensack, NJ, Tuesday, 12:30 PM. 1-800-522-0588

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, LOUIS
description: KRAUS-Louis. January 1, 1999. Cherished father of Marya Wintroub & John Kraus; loving fatherin-law of Bruce Wintroub; fabulous grandfather of Anne, Benjamin and Molly Wintroub; beloved friend of Betsey Steeger. Service Tuesday, January 5, 11 A.M., St. James' Church, 865 Madison Ave. (71-72 Sts.). In lieu of flowers, people are invited to make contributions to Holy Cross Monastery, West Park, New York 12493.

title: NEWS
description: Beat Generations

title: Motorola Revises Job-Cut Numbers
description: Motorola Inc. said today that it cut 1,000 more jobs than expected from its chip business, reflecting steps by the big semiconductor and cellular phone maker to cut costs and reduce its chip-product line to increase profits.

title: Talks on Aerospace Merger Continue
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G.'s military unit and British Aerospace P.L.C. have ''a few issues'' to resolve in merger talks and a combination is several months away, said Jurgen E. Schrempp, the co-chairman of the German company, at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORETZ, PAUL
description: KORETZ-Paul. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its long time member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Martin I. Klein, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVERETT, GEORGE TODD
description: EVERETT-George Todd. Died peacefully at home in Chapel Hill, N.C. On January 1, 1999. Husband of Helen Burton Everett, father of Todd Everett, Davis Everett, and Susan Rawes and grandfather of Caleb and Silas Everett, Rachel and Samuel Rawes, and Zoe Everett. Retired in 1988 as General Manager for Latin American Operations after 30 years with General Mills. His positive energy, generosity, and caring for family and friends will be deeply missed. Donations may be made to The Lake Champlain Committee (14 S. Williams St., Burlington, Vt. 05401).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYSOHIR, WALTER
description: LYSOHIR-Walter. Died January 1, 1999 of Boynton Beach, Florida, formerly of Queens, New York. Beloved husband of Betty, loving father of Steven and Bonnie, adored grandfather of Jack, Charlotte, Keith and Wallis. Cherished brother and uncle. Born July 10, 1917 in New York City, he was a pilot in WWII where he commanded a B-29 Bomber in the Pacific. He made his living in the brewing business until his retirement in 1983. An outgoing and charismatic friend legendary for his humor and honesty, equally well known for his passion for sports, the cinema and operatic tenors. He died of a massive heart attack after years of heroic prevention. Services to be announced. Donations in Walters name may be made to the heart fund.

title: 3d Blair Official Steps Down in Scandal Over Secret Loan
description: A scandal that has already cost Prime Minister Tony Blair his closest political confidant and a principal connection to big business claimed a third Government official today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, STEVEN R.
description: PERLMAN-Steven R., age 46 of Hartsdale died January 4, 1999. He is survived by his beloved wife Meryl, loving daughter Barbara Lindsay Perlman both of Hartsdale, his mother Shirley Jutkowitz of Belle Harbor, NY, brother Matthew of Manhattan, stepbrother Jacob Jutkowitz of Valley Stream. Funeral Wednesday 10 am Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery. Memorials in his name to Scleraderma Foundation or Pulmonary Hypertension Assoc., appreciated.

title: G. I. Joe in Barbieland
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANCOCK, WALKER
description: HANCOCK-Walker. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be mourned by the world of art.

title: On State of Union, Partisanship Again
description: To the Editor:

title: On-Line Giant May Link To CBS News
description: CBS News will announce a deal with America Online Inc. later this week to become the exclusive broadcast news provider for the on-line service, executives involved in the agreement said yesterday.

title: Republicans Warn Clinton Not to Dilute Satellite Export Law
description: Republican leaders have warned President Clinton not to weaken a new law that makes foreign policy and national security the only basis for approving exports of American satellites.

title: Jerry Quarry, 53, Boxer Battered by Years in the Ring, Dies
description: Jerry Quarry, a heavyweight contender of the late 1960's and early 1970's who faced the sport's greatest names of his era and then spent his final years debilitated by boxing-induced brain damage, died Sunday at Twin Cities Community Hospital in Templeton, Calif. He was 53.

title: Changing of the Guard at Receiver
description: No wonder Jerry Rice blew up during the regular season over his desire to catch more footballs and in bigger moments. Rice must have seen this coming. He must have realized long before we did that receiver Terrell Owens was the new apple of the 49ers' eyes. Especially of quarterback Steve Young's eyes. That in the post-season Owens might get more calls. More passes. More chances to win games. More glory. The Guy. The Star.

title: Q & A
description: Avoiding Colds

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRITT, HENRY G.
description: MERRITT-Henry G. On Saturday, January 2, 1999, at age 84. Dear husband of Agnes (nee Piquet). Beloved father of Joanne, Lawrence & Henry. Loving stepgrandfather of Shannon Hyacinthe and Mark Ross. Funeral service on Wednesday, 10 AM, at the funeral home. Interment private. Visiting hours Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 732 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITING, JOHN R.
description: WHITING-John R. On Dec. 16, 1998. Memorial service Saturday, January 16, at 2 PM at South Presbyterian Church, 343 Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Community Hospital of Dobbs Ferry, South Prebyterian Church, Dobbs Ferry or the Block Island Library, R.I.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Mother, Helped, Finds Struggles Less Daunting
description: Wanda Gaddis never had much money, but she has always tried to provide a decent life for her children. But this fall, despite her efforts, it looked as if her children's lives were unraveling like one of the old, threadbare sweaters they wore to school.

title: Debate Over Instant Replay Flares Anew After Officials' Questionable Calls
description: When a rash of high-profile controversial officiating calls marred several games during the National Football League regular season, there was a move afoot to reinstate instant replay for the league's post-season play. Criticized as both an overreaction and as hastily conceived, the instant replay playoff proposal was retracted.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Dec. 14 about a lawsuit over insurance liability for disruptions caused by the Year 2000 computer problem referred incorrectly to the relationship between Keane Inc. and the defendant, Source Data Inc. Keane purchased some of Source Data's assets in 1995, but does not own Source Data and is not involved in the suit.

title: U.S. READY TO EASE SOME RESTRICTIONS IN POLICY ON CUBA
description: The United States is ready to let more people and more money flow to Cuba, senior American officials said today, while rejecting a fundamental review of American policy toward Cuba.

title: China Hopes to Sell Bad Loans at Discount
description: Moving to tackle as much as $240 billion of bad loans at its biggest banks, China will introduce a pilot program to sell those loans at a discount, officials said yesterday. China Construction Bank, the nation's second-largest bank, will be the first to take part in a program that may be extended to all four of China's state banks, said Tong Pin, deputy head of planning at the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China.

title: Daewoo Motor Is No. 1, In Korea, That Is
description: The Daewoo Motor Company, traditionally South Korea's second-biggest auto maker, said yesterday that it had sold a total of 893,295 vehicles in 1998, taking over the No. 1 position from the Hyundai Motor Company for the first time. By comparison, Hyundai Motor sold a total of 880,066 vehicles last year, while Kia Motors sold 467,545 vehicles. Combined domestic sales of Korea's three largest auto makers in 1998 dropped by 54 percent, underscoring the nation's worst recession since the 1950-53 Korean War.

title: PATTERNS
description: Color Her Prescient

title: Incoming Speaker Seeks Renewed Faith in House
description: Representative Dennis Hastert, the Speaker-designate, said today that after a scandal-racked year punctuated by the impeachment of President Clinton, his top priority is ''restoring America's faith in this U.S. House of Representatives.''

title: How Errol Flynn Made It Look So Easy
description: ''Just show up with a T-shirt, workout-type clothing,'' said Lee Roy Longenbach, a manager at Metropolis Fencing, when I called to sign up for a few classes.

title: Wariness Creeps Onto the Platform
description: Some people looked over their shoulders. Others stayed away from the edge of the platform. Yesterday, many people were being just a little more cautious after hearing what happened to 32-year-old Kendra Webdale, who was pushed in front of the uptown N train on Sunday afternoon.

title: Methadone Users Don't Deserve Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: The Euro Is Launched
description: The euro, the new currency for most of Europe, got off to a strong start yesterday as it appeared to be the magnet for capital that its designers desired. The euro gained against the dollar, and big European stocks -- now traded in euros -- rose sharply.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Living? Let Live

title: Bargaining Continues For Building Workers
description: Negotiators for New York City's real estate industry continued their marathon talks yesterday with the union representing 30,000 building maintenance workers to try to avoid a strike at roughly 1,000 office buildings.

title: Methadone Users Don't Deserve Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Bare' Is the Name, But Not the Dress Code
description: Although there were moments of semi-nudity, fancy trappings dominated ''Bare,'' the program that several choreographers presented on Saturday night at La Mama.

title: Now, Midsize Is Beautiful; Cincinnati Exemplifies the Cities Driving the U.S. Economy
description: When a recruiter offered her a job as a research specialist at a rapidly growing medical company, Kimberly Belknap grabbed it and moved here from Grand Rapids, Mich., to get herself, as she put it, on a more lucrative career path.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STICKNEY, ALBERT, JR.
description: STICKNEY-Albert, Jr. In Essex, CT on January 3, 1999. Husband of Eleanor Herrick Stickney, father of Albert Stickney 3rd of Pound Ridge, NY and Harold Herrick Stickney of Guilford, CT. Brother of Elizabeth McCagg of Essex. Also survived by 3 grandchildren. Memorial service Friday, January 8, 11:30 am at St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Old Lyme, CT. Contributions in memory of Mr. Stickney to Brave Hearts/Kind Souls, c/o Dr. Peter Dixon, 192 Westbrook Road, Essex, CT 06426 or Essex Meadows Foundation, 30 Bokum Road, Essex, CT 06426. For information, Guilford Funeral Home, 115 Church Street, Guilford, CT.

title: Dresdner Bank Moves Money to Partnerships
description: Dresdner Bank A.G., Germany's third-biggest bank, said yesterday that it had put shareholdings worth about 12.8 billion euros ($15 billion) into partnerships, sheltering the assets from a Government clampdown on tax loopholes this year.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article yesterday about arguments for an impeachment trial misattributed a quotation concerning the Senate's ''constitutional responsibility'' to hold a trial. The statement was made by Representative Asa Hutchinson, Republican of Arkansas, not by his brother, Senator Tim Hutchinson, also an Arkansas Republican.

title: INSIDE
description: A Pre-emptive I.M.F.

title: Chattanooga Times Publishes Final Issue
description: The Chattanooga Times, the newspaper that Adolph S. Ochs took over 120 years ago with borrowed money and the same stubborn confidence that later led him to buy The New York Times, published its final edition yesterday as control passed from Ochs's 13 great-grandchildren to the owner of its evening rival, The Chattanooga Free Press.

title: California's New Governor Promises to Overhaul Schools
description: Declaring ''a time to do great things again,'' Gray Davis took office today as the 37th Governor of California, pledging to overhaul the troubled public schools of the nation's most populous state as the centerpiece of his efforts to shepherd its growth and preserve its prosperity in the coming years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, HARRY
description: GOLDSTEIN-Harry. The Past District Deputies Assn. of the Seventh Masonic District are saddened by the passing of our brother Harry. Our sincere condolences to Shirley and the Goldstein family. Mario Giudice, President

title: Traffic-Ticket Writers as Stress Magnets
description: Anyone who has ever become livid at the sight of a parking ticket anchored under his windshield wiper will not be surprised by what scientists have recently quantified: an average of three times a day, a traffic-enforcement agent has a hostile confrontation with a member of the public. Taking advantage of this real-life laboratory, researchers at two New York universities used parking-ticket writers to understand how heart rate and blood pressure may change during verbal conflicts.

title: No Airs or Consultants For Reluctant First Lady
description: There is, of course, the matter of the silverware.

title: No Coughing, Please!
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KIEFFER, MARTIN
description: KIEFFER-Martin, on November 16, in Colmar, France, after a long illness. The Lycee Francais de New York mourns his passing. Professor of History and Geography from 1995 until his retirement in 1986. Ph.D., Columbia 1960, sports enthusiast, outstanding educator and friend. Memorial Mass on Wednesday, January 13, at 6 PM. Madison Avenue Presbysterian Church at 73rd Street, NYC.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, SHIEKIE
description: SNYDER-Shiekie. The Executive Board, local presidents, staff and members of District Council 37 are deeply saddened by the sudden death of the longtime president of Local 2021 New York City OffTrack Betting Corporation Employees. The Shiekie was a great trade unionist who fought long and hard for his members for more than 20 years. He had been a DC 37 Vice Present and Executive Board member for over 15 years. He was the oldest active president of an AFSCME local in the country. Shiekie was also part of the special fabric that makes New York unique. He had great stories to tell, knew more jokes than anyone, could tap dance with the best of them and knew the lyrics to songs most of us had never heard of. We will miss his tireless leadership and winning spirit. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his beloved wife Betty, daughters Sharon and Vicki, son Sandy and much loved grandchildren. Lee Saunders, Administrator Executive Board District Council 37 ASSCME, AFL-CIO

title: No Funeral For OPEC Just Yet
description: Even as cruise missiles rained down on Iraq in mid-December, oil prices scarcely budged from their severely depressed levels of about $11 a barrel. In the past, Middle East tension inevitably spooked the oil markets, provoking panic buying. This time, the December price slump presented us with a stunning paradox: we had waged war against Saddam Hussein precisely to safeguard the Persian Gulf oil fields, yet the market's blase reaction to the fighting seemed to underscore the marginal status of Mideast oil in the global economy.

title: Performance Anxiety: Hiding Onstage
description: A substream of independent-label rock could be called wool-gathering music. It is Spartan folk-rock for downcast college students: mulish, painfully drawn-out, occasionally pretty stuff, dealing obliquely with anxieties and dreams, and it can swing slowly between two chords for many minutes with no embroidery. Its practitioners (including Will Oldham, once of Palace; Jeff Mangum of Neutral Milk Hotel, and Bill Callahan of Smog) are young, but they sound as if they've lived long, tortured lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROWTHER, G. KENNETH
description: CROWTHER-G. Kenneth, 90, of Southbury, CT. On January 2, 1999. Husband of the late Mary Jenkins Crowther. Retired Vice President of Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. Survived by a brother Gwynn Crowther, Jr. of Dover, Ma. There are no services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINDAC, LEVY G. (NEE GONZALES)
description: SINDAC-Levy G. (nee Gonzales), of Clifton, N.J. on January 3, 1999. Funeral services to be held on Saturday, January 9, 1999, 9 A.M., St. Brendan's R.C. Church, corner of Lakeview and Crooks Avenue, Clifton, N.J. Visiting Thursday and Friday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Bizub-Quinlan Funeral Home, 1313 Van Houten Avenue, Clifton, N.J.

title: Birth of Octuplets Reignites Fertility Debate
description: Fertility drugs provide a mix of hope and fear to those who are taking them -- hope that the treatment will result in pregnancy and fear that it will cause high-order multiples, defined as triplets or more. This fear has been heightened with the birth of the Chukwu octuplets in Houston, whose mother took fertility drugs. Their birth has reignited a long simmering debate over what should be done to prevent high-order multiple pregnancies and what should be done when they occur.

title: Tenants Gone, Landlord Held In Tax Case
description: More than a year after a lower Manhattan couple argued with their landlord and then disappeared, the landlord, Robert Rodriguez, was arrested yesterday, and investigators searched his Orange County home, as well as the apartment building where the couple lived.

title: Methadone Users Don't Deserve Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARING, BERNARD J.
description: WARING-Bernard J. The Weizmann Institute of Science and its American Committee mourn the passing of the brother of Saul Waring, member of the Institute's Board of Governors, Vice President of the ACWIS Board of Directors and member of the New York Region Executive Committee. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Saul and the entire Waring family. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Haim Harari, President Robert H. Asher, Chairman American Committee Albert Willner, M.D., President Martin Kraar, Exec. V.P.

title: Birth of Octuplets Reignites Fertility Debate
description: Fertility drugs provide a mix of hope and fear to those who are taking them -- hope that the treatment will result in pregnancy and fear that it will cause high-order multiples, defined as triplets or more. This fear has been heightened with the birth of the Chukwu octuplets in Houston, whose mother took fertility drugs. Their birth has reignited a long simmering debate over what should be done to prevent high-order multiple pregnancies and what should be done when they occur.

title: Starbucks Has Disappointing December
description: The Starbucks Corporation, the largest American coffee retailer, said yesterday that sales at stores open at least a year rose only 1 percent in December on lower-than-expected sales of mugs, gift baskets and other holiday items.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLIN, MARSHALL
description: PERLIN-Marshall. For the record, Mike was 78 and his Air Medal has three oak leaf clusters! Loretta

title: Nash Finch Cutbacks
description: The Nash Finch Company, a grocery wholesaler, said today that it planned to close its distribution center in Appleton, Wis., in early March, eliminating 165 jobs. The company, based in Minneapolis, said it would consolidate the Appleton operations into its St. Cloud, Minn., and Cedar Rapids, Iowa, distribution centers. Volume at the Appleton center was not enough to justify keeping it open, Nash Finch said.

title: Unsettling the City's Campaign Law
description: Pity the candidate who ventures now into New York City politics. The ground rules for local elections have suddenly become vastly more chaotic as lawyers for Mayor Rudolph Giuliani squabble with the city's Campaign Finance Board about the formula for matching public subsidies with private political contributions. This internecine argument threatens to unsettle candidates in special elections for City Council this year and could undermine one of the best and fairest campaign finance reform systems in the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNHEIM, PALMER
description: TURNHEIM-Palmer. It is with profound sorrow that the Officers, Board and members of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City express our heartfelt condolences to Joy Turnheim on the untimely passing of her father, Palmer Turnheim. He was a devoted friend and staunch supporter for UCP over many years and an advocate for children and adults with cerebral palsy and related disabilities. We share her grief. Leo Hausman, President Edward R. Matthews, Exec. Dir. Ronald J.H. Napal, Director of Development UCP/New York City

title: Revenue Rises 19% at Accounting Giant
description: PricewaterhouseCoopers, the world's largest accounting and consulting firm, said yesterday that its revenue for the fiscal year 1998 rose 19.9 percent, to $15.3 billion, driven by growth in management consulting.

title: Kirch Group to Split Into Holding Companies
description: The German media owner Leo Kirch detailed the reorganization of his empire yesterday, opening the way for the possible sale of stakes to foreign investors. Kirch Group said it would be split into three holding companies for film and television rights, pay-television and other assets under the Kirch Foundation, formed in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORSZYNSKI, ALEXIA JOAN
description: DORSZYNSKI-Alexia Joan. On January 1, 1999. Beloved wife of Jeffrey Neuman. Devoted daughter of Donald and the late Rita. Adored sister of Ann and Joan. Dear daughter-in-law of Hans and Billie Neuman. Cherished niece of Dorothy Lepeska and loving aunt of Joanna, Ben and Sam. Service Tuesday, 12 noon, at Plaza Memorial, 91st St. and Amsterdam.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COOPER, WYATT
description: COOPER-Wyatt. 5 January 1978. Daddy and Carter within us always. Gloria and Anderson

title: Plumbing Black Sea for Proof of the Deluge
description: Two Columbia University marine geologists, inviting incredulity, came forward in 1996 with astonishing evidence suggesting that a catastrophic flood of the Black Sea 7,600 years ago could have played a pivotal role in the spread of early farming into Europe and much of Asia. The deluge also may have cast such a long shadow over succeeding cultures that it inspired the flood account in the Babylonian epic of Gilgamesh and, in turn, the story of Noah in the Book of Genesis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELNER, BETTY
description: WELNER-Betty. The Rabbi, Officers, Trustees and Members of Temple Beth El, Cedarhurst, New York and its Affiliates express deepest sympathy on the passing of the mother of its member Frank Welner. We grieve with the family on their loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAFF, LOUIS
description: GRAFF-Louis. On January 3, 1999. Beloved father of Harriet Greenfield and father-in-law of Joel. Cherished grandfather of Stuart and Mark. Services Tuesday, 12:30 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment Beth David Cemetery.

title: Haris Journal; Iranian Snapshot: Idle Townsmen, Hocus-Pocus
description: Aziz the Magician pulled into town in his rattletrap Russian truck and waited for the crowd to gather.

title: In South Africa's Varied Rites, Equal Rights
description: The Zulu bride had intended to approach the groom's family homestead in her shimmering white wedding gown, with her pearl-studded headdress and 20-foot-long train. But her husband's relatives would have none of it.

title: For Consumers, Easy Transition : Powerful Debut for Euro; Stock Markets Also Surge
description: PARIS  'It's a Head Start on All Fronts'

title: Washington Meets Its Mayor; Forgive Him for Being Early
description: The first hint that things might be different was Mayor Anthony A. Williams's arrival time today, 1:59 P.M., one minute early for his first news conference as the District of Columbia's Mayor. His predecessor for 16 of the last 20 years, Marion S. Barry Jr., usually appeared about 20 minutes late.

title: Dunkin' Donuts Sues Shop Owner Over Mice
description: This was 15 minutes of fame Dunkin' Donuts did not want.

title: Prices for Treasuries Tumble As Investors Look Overseas
description: Treasury bond prices fell yesterday as the dollar slumped and European stocks and bonds soared on the euro's first day of trading, curbing demand for Treasury securities.

title: And When It Pours, Part of Queens Nearly Drowns
description: Danyelle Hillman waded through the calf-high mud that covered the floors of her basement apartment yesterday and searched for the irreplaceable items she feared might have been stolen from her by the weekend storm that flooded dozens of homes in southeastern Queens.

title: Burberry Modernizes and Reinvents Itself
description: It was a neat trick, and between Rose Marie Bravo and Roberto Menichetti, they seem to have pulled it off. They took a moldering old British clothing company called Burberrys, known mainly for its plaid umbrellas and raincoat linings, altered the name to Burberry and gave it a spiffy new look without destroying its essential character.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUCHIN, MORRIS G.
description: DUCHIN-Morris G. Captain, USN Ret. On January 2, 1999, at home in his 92nd year. Beloved husband of the late Norma. Loving father of Leslie (Hugh) Heller and Paul. Cherished grandfather of Peter and Roger Heller, and uncle of Joel and Howard (Mattie) Hirschel and family. Services 11 AM, Tuesday, January 5 at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made in his memory to UJA Federation or East End Temple, New York City.

title: In Coughlin vs. Parcells, Student Faces Mentor
description: When Tom Coughlin was the Giants' wide receivers coach in the late 1980's under Bill Parcells, he was a relentless man on a staff of relentless men. On Christmas Day Parcells called the Giants Stadium office to leave a message on Coughlin's voice mail. The phone rang. No one would be working on Christmas Day.

title: AGRICULTURE DEPT. TO SETTLE LAWSUIT BY BLACK FARMERS
description: The United States Department of Agriculture has agreed to pay hundreds of millions of dollars to settle a lawsuit brought by thousands of black farmers who say the department discriminated against them by denying loans and other subsidies, representatives of the department and the farmers said yesterday.

title: A Paris Suburb Recalls the 30's, Its Era of Glory
description: Even distant European cities feel intimidated by the elegance, culture and history of Paris. Consider, then, how difficult it is for an adjacent suburb like Boulogne-Billancourt to establish its own identity. Indeed, were it not for the circular highway that defines the limits of the French capital, it would be impossible today to know where Paris ends and this town begins.

title: About the Euro
description: The European Union's switch yesterday to a single currency, the euro, has affected both the foreign stocks and foreign exchange tables, which appear today on page C15. Stocks traded in eight of the countries in the foreign stocks table -- Austria, Belgium, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands and Spain -- are now quoted only in euros. In the foreign exchange table, the euro exchange rate is now included, though exchange rates for other European currencies that will be phased out in 2002 remain listed as well. Separately, The International Herald Tribune has discontinued its stock indexes, which had appeared with the foreign stocks table.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AFZELIUS, ROLAND CARL
description: AFZELIUS-Roland Carl. On January 3, 1999 at the age of 82 years, of Bayville, NY. Beloved husband of Marie, loving father of Ellen, Ron and Adrianne. Cherished grandfather of Kohl, Isabella, Cepi and Shiel. We will miss him dearly. Private services. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Association for the Help of Retarded Children (AHRC), 189 Wheatley Rd, Brookville, NY 11545, Attn: #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HATFIELD, HURD
description: HATFIELD-Hurd. The faculty, Board of Trustees, and administration of Bard College mourn the passing of actor and alumnus William Rukard Hurd Hatfield. His acting entertained generations; he is most strongly identified with his portrayal of the title character in the Oscar-winning movie ''The Picture of Dorian Grey.'' We extend heartfelt condolences to his family and friends. David E. Schwab II, Chairman Leon Botstein, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, AIMEE FLECK
description: MYERS-Aimee Fleck, 95. On January 2. Wife of the late Clifford L. Myers. She is survived by her children Ronnie Eldridge, Lawrence Myers, their spouses Jimmy Breslin and Barbara Myers; her grandchildren Daniel, Emily and Lucy, their spouses Jean McGavin, Michael Silberman and Laurence Freedman, her three longed-for great grandchildren Glynnis, Nathaniel and Sophie; Ernest Londa & other special friends. She was an elegant strong woman with great style and beauty. She thought we were wonderful and we loved her very much. She was the center of our lives. She was here before the subway. We thought she would last forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSTON, RUBENSTEIN, ALICE
description: WINSTON-RUBENSTEIN-Alice, of NYC, on Sunday, January 3rd, 1999, of cancer. Master drama teacher of the Stella Adler Theatre School. She is survived by her husband, Boris Rubenstein, son, Stephen Rubenstein, and two sisters, Irene Wyman of Boston and Fay Rosen Bain of NYC. Services today, 10 AM, Congregation Ramat Orah, 550 W. 110th St., NYC.

title: Imperial Chemical's Sale of Unit Collapses
description: Imperial Chemical Industries acknowledged today that a $1 billion deal to sell its white pigment business to the DuPont Company and NL Industries had collapsed, renewing analysts' concerns about the British company's ability to reduce a mountain of debt.

title: High Rates Of Asthma Are Found In Athletes
description: How common is undiagnosed asthma among athletes? Worried about the risk the increasingly common lung disease poses, Temple University researchers have come up with a straightforward method of finding out: they asked a group of high school football players to run a mile, and then used a simple breath test to quantify the huffing and puffing afterward.

title: Isles Hope Salo Can Save Their Season
description: Tommy Salo can make this season's biggest stop when he returns to the Islanders' net on Tuesday. He can stop the Chicago Blackhawks along with the Islanders' four-game losing streak.

title: Old Anchors Seek to Rescue ABC Mornings
description: In a move that underscored how far the fortunes of ''Good Morning America'' have fallen, and how much that hurts the fortunes of the ABC television network and its stations, ABC News yesterday plucked one of its biggest stars, Diane Sawyer, from the firmament of prime-time news and named her co-anchor of the morning program, where she will be twinned with Charles Gibson.

title: Senator Rodham?
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton's spokesmen say she has not thought of running for the Senate in 2000. But Robert Torricelli, who heads the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, floated what certainly looked like a trial balloon over the weekend.

title: Suit Says Prosecutors' Court Notices to Youths Are Illegal
description: Prosecutors in New York Family Court routinely tell thousands of juvenile suspects to show up in court unnecessarily, according to a lawsuit filed last month that asserts that the notices are illegal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALFANI, DARIO, M.D.
description: ALFANI-Dario, M.D. Professor of Surgery, University of Rome ''La Satienza.'' Died in Rome on January 4th, 1999. Professor Alfani was an internationally respected transplant surgeon who made significant contributions to the field. His colleagues at Columbia University remember him with affection as an exceptional teacher, an intellectual companion, and a valued friend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEON, JOSEPH
description: LEON-Joseph. At age 90. Of Brooklyn, N.Y. On January 3, 1999. Beloved husband of Mildred (neeCantor). Devoted father of Nancy Gershon, Maryanne and her husband Sander Lehrer and Dr. Robert and his wife Nancy Leon. Cherished brother of Florence Winston. Loving grandfather of Russ, Alessandra, Andrew, Gail, Jill and Laurie Gershon, Jon, Rise and Marc Lehrer, and Alicia James, Michael and David Leon and great-grandfather of Luca, Alexander and Sophie Gershon. Services at 1 PM Tuesday Gutterman's Inc., 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I. (516) 764-9400. Donations suggested in lieu of flowers to East Midwood Jewish Center, Brooklyn, New York or charity of your choice.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Trading Begins Smoothly As Euro Enters Markets

title: Spreader of AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Housing Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIGHTINGALE, BERTRAM MAURICE
description: NIGHTINGALE-Bertram Maurice. On January 4, 1999. Husband of Phyllis, loving father of Carol, Stephen, Robert and Howard. Devoted grandfather to Amy, Jennifer, Ryan, Max, Kimberly and Cheryl. A wonderful, gentle man, his loss will leave a deep void in our lives. Contributions in his name may be made to The American Lung Association.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''She was the kind of person who would have helped the kind of person who did this.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: PENNCORP FINANCIAL TO SELL 2 UNITS FOR $222 MILLION
description: Penncorp Financial Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its career sales division and the Professional Insurance Company unit, which is part of its Pacific Accident and Life Insurance Company, for a total of $222.5 million. The Universal American Financial Corporation agreed to acquire the career sales division for $175 million in cash and notes, Penncorp said. Universal, based in Rye Brook, N.Y., is an insurance holding company. Penncorp, based in New York, also said that GE Financial Assurance Holdings Inc. had agreed to purchase Professional Insurance, a provider of work-site insurance, for $47.5 million. GE Financial Assurance is a unit of GE Capital, which is a subsidiary of the General Electric Company of Fairfield, Conn.

title: UConn Says 'We're No. 1' (Twice); State Savors Men's and Women's Basketball Dominance
description: Tip-off was three hours away and the temperature was 14 degrees, but it was party time outside the University of Connecticut basketball arena. Three early birds had started at daybreak, pitching a tent on the top steps, and other students staked their claims in the line with a barbecue, sleeping bags, a sofa, a Ford Escort for blasting tunes and a pillow for playing soccer.

title: Iron Eyes Cody, 94, an Actor And Tearful Anti-Littering Icon
description: Iron Eyes Cody, the actor who played an Indian shedding a tear at the sight of a littered American landscape in one of television's best-known and most-honored television commercials, died yesterday at his home in Los Angeles, the police said. He was 94.

title: Spacecraft Speed to Mars, High Hopes on Board
description: Fresh off the launching pad, two new spacecraft are heading for Mars as part of a 16-year effort to determine once and for all if life ever arose on the red planet. The two probes make up a second wave of inquiry, the first having begun in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERMAN, BETTY
description: KERMAN-Betty. Devoted mother of Edward Kerman and Carol Feldman. Loving mother-in-law of Rona Stein and Ian Feldman. Adoring grandmother of Joanna and Jonathan Feldman. Services today, 10 AM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 West Broad St., Mount Vernon, New York.

title: By Design; For Winter Vacations
description: Anyone who is lucky enough to be heading for a warm place in the sun can find lightweight pants in the newest shape: wide-legged and cropped anywhere from below the knee to above the ankle.

title: When Vegetarianism Raises a Red Flag
description: There are many legitimate reasons for eating vegetarian. But according to a recent article published in the journal The Physician and Sports Medicine, the practice of vegetarianism may be a red flag for eating disorders in young athletic women.

title: Weekend Rain Did Little To Raise Reservoir Levels
description: Sunday's rain -- bountiful in some areas, sparse in others -- did little more for the reservoirs serving New York City and northeastern New Jersey than stop the steady decline in levels that began last fall, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, ROBERT L.
description: COLLINS-Robert L. Suddenly on December 30, 1998. Artist and designer. Brother of Barry. Memorial service Thursday, January 14th, 2PM, Saint James Church, Madison Ave at 71st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Jericho Project, 891 Amsterdam Ave, NY NY 10025.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODWIN, WILLIAM
description: GOODWIN-William. The Board, staff and community of the Hamilton-Madison Settlement House on Manhattan's Lower East Side, are deeply saddened by the passing of its immediate past President and current Chairman of the Board. We will miss the great contributions, legal expertise and love that Will bought to this one hundred year old Settlement House in his unassuming, quiet but determined manner. The entire Hamilton-Madison House family extends its deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Maria, his sons, Andrew and Peter and the rest of his family. Will, you will be sorely missed at the House. Barbara L. Christen President Frank T. Modica Executive Director

title: Iraq Moves to Oust U.S. and British Aid Teams
description: Iraq took its first step today toward expelling American and British relief workers, saying their visas would not be renewed because their safety could not be guaranteed in the face of public anger over air strikes last month.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's; A Cuban Sound Dancing North
description: There has been a flood of traditional records from Cuba recently, and the reasons for it are simple. The first is the descent into irrelevance, perhaps temporary, of the Havana-based Timba dance music world, which started receiving plenty of attention five years ago and is now self-destructing. The second is the international success of the Ry Cooder-produced album, ''Buena Vista Social Club,'' released last year. Given the easy availability of hundreds of fine little local Cuban son bands and older singers playing the same music made by Buena Vista Social Club, it's not surprising that the market is overflowing. Here are a handful of the best; all are available from Descarga, (800) 377-2647 or at www.descarga.com.

title: Metro Business; Merged Company To Develop Housing
description: Seeking to take advantage of the aging populations of New York and New Jersey, Castle Senior Living L.L.C. of Teaneck, N.J., and Chelsea Management Group of Summit, N.J., yesterday announced their merger.

title: 3% Drop in Sales Of Licensed Goods
description: The retail sales of licensed merchandise in North America dropped 3 percent in 1998, according to the 22d annual licensing industry survey by The Licensing Letter, a newsletter published by EPM Communications in New York.

title: I.M.F. Weighs Swifter Action to Bar Economic Crises
description: The International Monetary Fund, sharply criticized for how it handled crises from Southeast Asia to Russia, is discussing an overhaul of its operations that could let it intervene directly in national economies long before they get into deep trouble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAKE, THOMAS E.
description: DRAKE-Thomas E. On January 1, 1999. Husband of the late Constance Drake and Elizabeth Twyeffort Drake. Father of Thomas Hoyt Drake and Daniel W. Drake. Stepfather of Joan Talbot, Carl Sangree, Walter Sangree, Harold Buttrick, the late Griffith Buttrick, John Buttrick, Katherine T. Greene and Susan T. Spoor. He is also survived by 23 grandchildren and 15 great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Religious Society of Friends, 15 Rutherford Place (15th Street between 1st & 2nd Avenues), NYC at 5:30PM Thursday, January 7th. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Nantucket Maria Mitchell Association, 2 Vestal Street, Nantucket, MA. 02554.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEILL, MARY C.
description: O'NEILL-Mary C., aged 89 years. (Retired from American Bank Note Co.). Beloved daughter of the late John J. and Margaret. Dear sister of the late Rev. John J. and David J. Family will receive friends Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 St., Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial, Our Lady of Angels Church, Wednesday, 9:45 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Strong 49er-Packer Ratings
description: San Francisco's stunning 30-27 victory over Green Bay on the Fox network Sunday produced a 24.2 overnight Nielsen rating -- the highest for a National Football League wild-card playoff game since 1991. The rating represented a 27 percent jump from the comparable game last year, Tampa Bay against Detroit.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT CORP. Plymouth Meeting, Pa., said it had acquired 26 industrial buildings in South Carolina for $49.6 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACHARACH, MIRIAM
description: BACHARACH-Miriam. The Riverdale Jewish Center mourns the loss of our member, Miriam Bacharach. We extend profound condolences to her husband, Ernst, former Vice President, her sons and daughters-in-law Gary and Esther, Neil and Hannah, her grandchildren and the entire family. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Eroticizing Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Man Charged With Stabbing Youths
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested and charged with assault yesterday after stabbing two youths and killing a dog in a hallway in his apartment building, the police said.

title: New Rival Arrives, but Dollar Is Still the World's Champion
description: The euro -- the new European currency -- had a positive debut yesterday in foreign exchange dealings. But it is still unclear how the euro will fare against the dollar this year and what kind of challenge it will make over time against the United States currency.

title: Plan to Curtail Trial of Clinton Hits New Snags
description: Senators searched today for the formula that would produce bipartisan support for a curtailed impeachment trial of President Clinton as a few more Republicans expressed opposition to the compromise plan under consideration.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the efforts of a New Jersey man to win damages in the terrorist killing of his daughter misstated the names of two other victims of terror and misstated the year of their deaths. They were Sara Duker, not Sarah, and Matthew Eisenfeld, not Eisenberg. They died in 1996, not 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWIMMER, IRVING SIDNEY
description: SCHWIMMER-Irving Sidney. Beloved husband of the late Carol. Devoted father of Alan and Judy Schwimmer, Marjorie and Frank Goldstein.
