Loving grandfather of Kristin, Aaron, Joshua, Talia, and Laura. Adoring great grandfather of Charlotte and Elias. Loving brother of Charlotte, Esther, and Bernice. Services will be held at The Bernheim and Apter Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, NJ, Wednesday at 11:30 A.M. Contributions to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: No Poll Needed: Tennessee Locks Up No. 1
description: Two identical plays involving the same two Volunteers made Tennessee college football's national champions tonight. Tee Martin to Peerless Price. Twice.

title: The Face of Hate Made Plain
description: First prize in tomorrow night's contest for crudeness and cruelty to homosexuals must go to middle managers of a West Coast branch of Cantor Fitzgerald, a big securities trading company. The disgusting adolescent pranks of these million-dollar-a-year traders drove Mark Anderson out of what he thought was a bright new career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECK, DAVID WARNER
description: PECK-David Warner. On January 2, 1999. Dear husband of Susan Harfield Peck. Father of Heather, Lisa and David. Brother of M. Scott Peck and son of the late Judge David W. and Elizabeth Peck. Stepfather to Amanda, Susie and Tony Leness. Phillips Exeter Academy '50, Princeton '54 and Harvard Business School '59. Funeral service at Saint Mark's Church, Westhampton Beach, at noon on Saturday, January 9. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the Quogue Association, P.O. Box 671, Quogue, New York 11959.

title: Indonesia Cracks Down on Separatists in Sumatra, Killing 9
description: At least 9 people were killed, more than 20 injured and scores arrested over the weekend in Indonesia after a crackdown by security forces in a province that has been a center of separatist violence.

title: Sihanouk Offers to Be Put on Trial
description: As passions rise over whether to put former leaders of the Khmer Rouge on trial, King Norodom Sihanouk volunteered today to join them in the dock to answer for his past associations with the brutal Communist movement.

title: Let Doctors Control Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Top-10 Status Puts St. John's In 3-Point Mode
description: There were easy smiles and a few giggles around St. John's last night, and it was still hours before the Red Storm's 115-70 demolition of Niagara.

title: Sports of The Times; Stern Plays His Ugly Endgame
description: COMING next season to an arena near you: 29 variations of the Vancouver Grizzlies. Choice club seats and luxury suites on sale soon.

title: Methadone Users Don't Deserve Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Seeks War Crimes Trial of Top Khmer Rouge Leaders
description: The Clinton Administration, working to insure that two top Khmer Rouge defectors are put on trial for their roles in the deaths of more than a million Cambodians in the 1970's, is quietly trying to organize an international tribunal under United Nations auspices that would not be opposed by China and the current Cambodian Government.

title: Suit in Liz Claiborne Dispute Is Given Class-Action Status
description: A Federal judge has granted class-action status to a lawsuit filed by a group of Brooklyn garment workers who accuse their union of failing to fairly represent them in a dispute with Liz Claiborne several years ago. But the ruling, released last Wednesday, still leaves the workers facing an uphill fight.

title: In Vino No Veritas, but Religion Intervened
description: CONSIDER a typical 1980's New York evening in the life of Susan Cheever, the writer, daughter of the famous novelist and alcoholic:

title: Seton Hall's Reserves Hold Off Feisty Hoyas
description: These are not the Georgetown Hoyas of old, but they can still drive teams crazy. They play tenacious defense and can vacuum the artistry out of a game with their hard-nosed play. Against the Hoyas, Seton Hall badly needed its supporting cast to come through tonight.

title: Dain Rauscher Buys Artemis Capital Unit
description: The Dain Rauscher Corporation, a Minneapolis-based securities firm, said today that it had bought the public finance business of Artemis Capital Group Inc., expanding its reach as a municipal bond broker in the states that sell the most bonds. The transaction dissolves Artemis. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed.

title: Life on Mars: Science Fact or Science Fiction?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: E*TRADE ANNOUNCES 2-FOR-1 STOCK SPLIT
description: E*Trade Group Inc., the on-line brokerage company, said yesterday that it would split its shares 2 for 1. The stock split will double the number of diluted shares to 95.8 million, but halve their value. The new shares will be issued Jan. 29 to shareholders of record as of Jan. 15. E*Trade shares jumped 18 percent, gaining $8.65625, to $55.4375. Last week, the stock rallied after E*Trade said its free Web site had gained more than 500,000 registered users since September. E*Trade, based in Palo Alto, Calif., lost $15.7 million, or 33 cents a diluted share for the fourth quarter, which ended Sept. 29.

title: Stocks Begin the Year Mixed, as Technology Issues Dominate
description: In the first trading session of the new year, stocks jumped, then retreated and finally closed mixed yesterday, as traders and investors began to focus on coming quarterly earnings reports and a fairly hefty calendar of expected initial public stock offerings.

title: INVESTORS WANT CORPORATE EXPRESS CHAIRMAN REMOVED
description: A group that is a major investor in Corporate Express Inc. urged the company yesterday to replace its chairman and hire an investment banker to help consider alternatives like a merger. Marlin Partners I L.P. and Brahman Management L.L.C., which together hold 7.1 percent of the company's common shares, made their request in a letter to the board at Corporate Express. Based in Broomfield, Colo., the company supplies businesses with products ranging from software and paper to office furniture and janitorial supplies. Jirka Rysavy, who founded Corporate Express in 1986, now serves as chairman. Marlin and Brahman want the title of chairman transferred to Robert L. King, currently chief executive.

title: Search for Cause of Diet Pill's Risk Yields New Warning
description: A scientist who helped to develop Redux, one of two weight-loss drugs taken off the market in 1997 after they were linked to heart damage, is now suggesting that the problems were not due to Redux alone, but rather to its being combined with other drugs that had unrecognized effects.

title: Suspect Has a History of Mental Illness, but Not of Violence
description: He graduated from the Bronx High School of Science. His roommates described him as gentle and not prone to violence.

title: When Rules for Better Care Exact Their Own Cost
description: I recently spent a week as a ''night float'' at a major New York City teaching hospital, staying up all night while other residents slept. My shift began at 5 P.M., when residents departed for the day, and ended at 7 the next morning, when they returned. Meanwhile, I was responsible for up to 80 very sick patients.

title: Harvey Gives the Spark And Rangers Respond
description: After a successful road trip, the Rangers returned to New York and took the ice last night at Madison Square Garden, trying to avoid a letdown. But they skated through the opening 30 minutes at about the pace of families gliding around Rockefeller Center's rink.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACQUENEY, THEODORE

description: The record number of mergers of large companies into even larger ones last year has raised concerns at many arts organizations and other nonprofit groups that a decline in corporate donations may be an unfortunate byproduct.

description: BBDO West in Los Angeles is naming a new top creative executive as part of a revamping effort that includes reopening a full-service office in San Francisco.

description: When Robert Hopkins opened a strip club along the tattered main street here earlier this month, he expected to wrangle with city officials, who had warned him that he was not permitted to offer adult entertainment.

title: Fifth-Grade Teacher Is Charged With Sexually Molesting 2 Brothers, 10 and 8
description: A popular fifth-grade teacher here was arrested this weekend on charges of sexually molesting two brothers, one of whom was his student, after a New Year's Eve party at the boys' home, law enforcement officials said today.

description: When top auto executives gather here each winter for the North American International Auto Show, the talk in the halls is usually about the latest car or, more recently, the latest sport utility vehicle or pickup truck. But at this year's show, there is also another theme: merger rumors.

title: Japanese Stocks Hit 3-Month Low
description: Japanese stocks suffered their biggest declines in three months today on concern a stronger yen would prevent exporters from meeting their profit forecasts.

description: People here expect Jerry Brown to be a different sort of mayor. On his first day, he did not disappoint.

description: United States manufacturing had its weakest month in December since the end of the last recession in 1991 as production slumped, factories cut jobs and weak demand hurt prices.

title: Taking Care of Those Bumps on the Head
description: Like that favorite nursery rhyme egg, children commonly suffer great falls not only off walls, but they also tumble from changing tables, jungle gyms and down stairs. Older children bump heads on playing fields or fall off bicycles. Most end up with only a bad headache, but sometimes complications require emergency treatment and hospitalization.

title: Eye on 2000, Elizabeth Dole Leaves Red Cross
description: Two years after her husband's unsuccessful effort to oust President Clinton, Elizabeth Hanford Dole announced today that she was resigning as president of the American Red Cross, a move that several advisers said was intended to clear the path for her own campaign for the White House in 2000.

description: AFTER some stops and starts that made a ride on the IRT seem smooth by comparison, Fallon McElligott is hoping that a reconfigured management team will get its operations in New York back, well, on track.

description: Three children were injured, one critically, when a fire broke out in their Bronx apartment yesterday, the authorities said.

title: $7.6 Billion Invested In Thailand in 1998
description: Thailand attracted $7.6 billion in direct foreign investment in 1998, of which $2.1 billion was foreign funds for recapitalization of domestic banks, a Government spokesman said yesterday. The remaining $5.5 billion was put into nonbank sectors, the spokesman, Akapol Sorasuchart, said. Japan remained the biggest foreign investor in Thailand in 1998, accounting for 33 percent of all foreign investment. The United States followed with 17 percent and Hong Kong with 9 percent.

title: Swedes Will Sell Shares in Pharmacia
description: The Government of Sweden plans to sell its 7 percent stake in Pharmacia & Upjohn, saying that market conditions are right to divest itself of the shares of the drug producer.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Bell Atlantic and Airtouch Stocks Slip on Uncertainty Over Merger
description: By the time the stock market had opened yesterday, the Bell Atlantic Corporation and Airtouch Communications Inc. had publicly confirmed their merger discussions. But investors remained uncertain that a deal would materialize -- and on favorable terms -- and sent down the value of both companies' shares.

title: Jets, Veterans of Tough December, Are Playoff Hardened
description: Once upon a time, when Mo Lewis was a rookie, he was in a playoff game wearing a Jets uniform.

description: * Audrey Margolies was named to the new position of associate publisher at Mirabella magazine, New York, which is published by the Hachette Filipacchi Magazines unit of Lagardere Group. She had been publisher at Swing magazine, New York, which closed.

The moves will reduce its parent company's holdings below 50 percent and give Network Solutions greater flexibility to make acquisitions.

description: To the Editor:

title: Harold Edelman, 75, Architect Who Helped to Save Small Treasures for New York
description: Harold Edelman, an architect and teacher who helped to preserve some of New York's small treasures -- a park, an ornate library and a quiet church -- died on Dec. 21 at the Beth Israel Medical Center hospice. He was 75.

title: New York Nightmare Kills a Dreamer
description: She came to New York from Buffalo in the spring of 1996, like so many young, ambitious people, in search of adventure and the writer's life. But unlike the dreamers who envision fame and fortune in the towers of Manhattan and find only misery and loneliness in its slums, Kendra Webdale seemed ready for the city.

title: Among Players, an Eagerness to Vote
description: There was confusion. Not everyone knew how the vote would be conducted or how the union would map out the logistics of gathering 430 members in New York on 48 hours' notice, but players seemed clear on wanting a resolution to the six-month National Basketball Association lockout.

title: Giuliani Lingers With a New Ally in Arizona
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani extended the length of his weekend political trip to Phoenix, staying until late last night to burnish a mutually advantageous relationship with Senator John McCain of Arizona. The Mayor is considering a run for the Senate, while the Senator is considering a run for the Presidency -- and each man could use the other's support.

title: A Political Lesson Proves Apt for Film, Too
description: After David Puttnam shifted from movies to politics, he was an advance man in Tony Blair's campaign to become Britain's Prime Minister. On his way to Torquay for a meeting before the 1992 election, Mr. Puttnam was asked to stop at a small town en route to make a speech. The talk was scheduled for 7 P.M. at a schoolhouse, and the train to Torquay left at 7:30. To his chagrin, there was only one person in the audience. Mr. Puttnam talked for 20 minutes and said he would omit the question-and-answer period because he did not want to miss his train. The man pleaded with him to stay, finally explaining why he was so insistent. He said, ''I'm the next speaker.''

title: Watching for the Warning Signs of an Invisible Killer
description: You can't see it, hear it, smell it, taste it or feel it. But it can poison or even kill you without you ever realizing it's around. It is the deadly gas, carbon monoxide, and winter is the season it does most of its damage. Despite annual warnings about the many sources of carbon monoxide and how problems can be prevented and detected before it's too late, this product of combustion kills an estimated 2,100 people who did not intend to die and sickens 10,000 others in the United States each year.

description: THIS is a good-news story in the sense that everything turns out all right. But it takes a while to get there, way too long as far as Gail Bernstein is concerned.

title: Without a Hitch, the Euro Opens To Trading in World Marketplace
description: The euro, Europe's new single currency, had a nearly flawless debut in world markets today as European financial institutions opened for business without a hitch and the euro climbed in value against other major currencies.

title: Cambodia's Surreal Beach Party
description: The annals of justice contain few scenes as bizarre as the goings-on in Cambodia last week. In late December Khieu Samphan and Nuon Chea defected from the straggling remains of the Khmer Rouge guerrillas and turned themselves in to the Government. In the past the Cambodian leader, Hun Sen, has favored prosecuting Khmer Rouge leaders, whose regime in the late 1970's killed more than a million people. Instead Mr. Hun Sen declared that these men should be welcomed ''with bouquets of flowers.'' They were, quite literally. Then, as Seth Mydans of The Times reported, they were treated to beach vacations. After this engendered outrage in Cambodia and worldwide, Mr. Hun Sen said he supported a trial for his guests. He should prove it by arresting them, and then the United Nations must quickly move toward setting up a court.

title: Search for Missing Otters Turns Up a Few Surprises
description: Sea otters are appealing, no doubt about it. In recent decades they have cruised the cold waters off the Aleutian Islands and the Alaskan mainland in robust numbers, like crowds of carefree vacationers.

title: Prize Money Offered For Indoors Mile
description: At 12:50 P.M. Saturday, on the new, superfast 200-meter banked track at the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan, 11 or so of America's fastest runners will meet in the men's invitation mile of the New Balance Games. At 1:10 P.M., 10 or so women will compete in another invitation mile. Depending how fast they go, one runner may leave with $10,000 or two may leave with $5,000 each.

title: Sports of The Times; Tennessee Is Still King of the Hill
description: There was room for one on the symbolic pinnacle, and it was captured by the team that celebrates to the tune of ''Rocky Top.''

description: ANGRILLI-Frieda Slatkin. Beloved sister, sister-in-law, aunt. Much cherished and admired. The Slatkin Family

title: POOL ENERGY OPENS TALKS WITH NABORS INDUSTRIES
description: The Pool Energy Services Company, an oilfield-services company based in Houston, said it had begun talks with Nabors Industries, the largest United States driller of land-based oil and natural gas wells, which is also based in Houston, about a $444 million takeover offer that Pool had previously rejected as inadequate. Pool shareholders are to vote next Tuesday on a resolution backed by Nabors that Pool be sold at the highest price. In October, Nabors offered 0.481 shares and $6.125 in cash for each Pool share and said it would assume about $178 million in debt. Pool shares rose $1.8125 each yesterday, to $12.625, and Nabors shares rose 93.75 cents, to $14.4375.

title: Its Offer Spurned, Union Will Vote on N.B.A. Plan
description: Calling the players' latest labor proposal inadequate, the National Basketball Association's negotiating committee voted unanimously yesterday to reject it, reaffirming that it would recommend the cancellation of the season to the league's board of governors when it meets in New York on Thursday.

title: From a Discarded Novel To Fugard's New Play; Writer Fulfills a Youthful Promise to His Mother
description: In 1953, Athol Fugard quit the University of Cape Town and hitchhiked up through Africa to Port Sudan. Stranded, without money, he booked passage on a tramp steamer, working as ''the captain's tiger,'' or all-purpose assistant. On board, he found time to write his first novel, a book about his mother. But in Fiji, in a fit of desperation, he threw the manuscript into the sea.

title: FA Chief Is Forced To Resign
description: KEITH WISEMAN, under pressure of a bribery scandal involving cash for votes, stepped down yesterday as chairman of England's Football Association at a meeting of the 91-member FA Council in London. He had refused to resign earlier despite a unanimous call from the group's executive committee.

title: MEDITRUST SELLS 34 NURSING AND ASSISTED-LIVING HOMES
description: The Meditrust Companies said yesterday that it had sold 34 nursing and assisted-living homes for $232 million in separate transactions as part of a plan to sell as much as $1 billion of assets and cut debt. Meditrust, based in Needham Heights, Mass., sold 25 assisted-living properties operated by the Emeritus Corporation for $155 million. It did not identify the buyer. The remaining nine properties are nursing homes that were sold to three closely held companies for $77 million. The real estate investment trust has now sold $613 million of assets since it announced its revamping plan in November.

description: About 500 people were massacred in eastern Congo during the New Year holiday, a Roman Catholic news agency reported today.

title: Best Memories Of a Musical Year Full of Echoes
description: Last year was a momentous one for the music business. Record stores, music labels and the concert industry all underwent massive consolidation putting them under the control of a shrinking number of corporations. And use of the computer for downloading and playing music exploded, particularly on college campuses, much to the chagrin of those few corporations.

title: LOTT SAYS A TRIAL ON IMPEACHMENT BEGINS TOMORROW
description: Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, announced today that he expected Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist to open the impeachment trial of President Clinton on Thursday. Mr. Lott said he sought a conclusion ''that is fair and hopefully quick'' but gave no details of how the trial would proceed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGILL, THOMAS P., MD
description: MAGILL-Thomas P., MD. Professor Emeritis Downstate Medical Center, age 95, of East Hampton, formerly of NY City, on January 4, 1999. Beloved husband of Elizabeth nee (Jotz). Services private. Memorial donations to East End Hospice, PO Box 1048 Westhampton Beach, NY 11978 would be appreciated.

title: AMERICA ONLINE ENLARGES ITS STAKE IN TEL-SAVE.COM
description: America Online Inc. has enlarged its share of ownership in Tel-Save.com Inc. to about 15 percent and said it had extended its marketing agreement with Tel-Save, a reseller of telephone services, by two years. America Online said it would make a $55 million investment in Tel-Save.com common stock at $19 a share and would exchange about $19 million in Tel-Save.com warrants for common stock. The investment will add to America Online's current holding of about 8 percent, according to Gabriel Battista, who became Tel-Save's president and chief executive yesterday. Since 1997, Tel-Save, which is based in New Hope, Pa., has sold phone services to the customers of America Online, which is based in Vienna, Va.

title: D'Amato, Out, Sounds Anything but Down; Ex-Senator Talks Issues, Business, Reflections, Maybe Even the Senate
description: In discussing the Senate seat he lost so painfully last year, Alfonse M. D'Amato, private citizen, has to admit to a certain yearning about the other Senate seat from New York, which Daniel Patrick Moynihan plans to leave in two years.

title: Phone-Call Price War Heats Up in Hong Kong
description: Units of Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. and Wharf Holdings Ltd. yesterday became the latest companies to contend that they offer the cheapest international phone calls from Hong Kong. On Monday, Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd., the dominant phone company, cut long-distance charges by an average of 25 percent to protect its dwindling 70 percent share of the international calling market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWE, ROBERT E.
description: HOWE-Robert E. Died Monday January 4th at Saint Peter's University Hospital, New Brunswick, New Jersey. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on September 16, 1930, son of Edward H. Howe and Anna Coyle. Mr. Howe was a resident of Old Bridge, New Jersey for the past 37 years. He was a communicant of St. Ambrose Parish in Old Bridge, as well as a member of the Knights of Columbus and the American Legion. He was a member of the Lake Naomi Club in Pocono Pines, PA and a parishioner of Our Lady of the Lake Church. He served in the United States Naval Reserve from 1948 to 1953. Mr. Howe retired from William H. McGee and Co., New York in January of 1997 after 50 years of service. He held numerous positions within the company throughout his career. He was promoted to Executive Vice President in 1979, President and Chief Operations Officer in 1989 and President and Chief Executive Officer in 1991. He served as Vice Chairman from 1995 to 1997. ''Bob's story is the kind of success tale that books and plays are made of. He started in the mail room and worked his way up to the CEO of this well respected Marine Insurance Company,'' said Vincent Papa, current McGee Chairman. In addition to serving as President of various McGee companies, he also was a member of the Board of Directors of numerous industry organizations. These included Director and Chairman of the Inland Marine Underwriters Association, Director, National Cargo Bureau, Director of the Hull Syndicate and Director of A.I.M.U. Mr. Howe was also a member of the American Institute of Marine Underwriters and the Water Quality Syndicate. ''Bob was a mentor for many of us here at McGee imparting on us his underwriting and business skills. He was a great insurance man and friend,'' recounted George Spagnolo, Vice President of McGee. Mr. Howe is predeceased by his wife of 48 years, Johanna in April of 1998. Surviving is a son, Robert F. Howe of Colts Neck, NJ, three daughters, Barbara Borretsky, Joan Kibbler and Marianne Jarvis, all of Old Bridge, and seven grandchildren; two brothers, Donald Howe of Staten Island, Joseph Howe of North Bellmore, Long Island, and a sister, Loretta Scancarello, of Brooklyn, New York. Funeral services will be Thursday at 9:00am at the Michael Hegarty Funeral Home, 3377 US Hwy 9 N, Old Bridge, NJ, followed by a 10:00 am Mass at St. Ambrose R.C. Church, Old Bridge. Burial will be in Holy Cross Burial Park, Cranbury Rd, East Brunswick, NJ. Visiting hours Tuesday-Wednesday 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Donations in memory of Mr. Howe can be made to St. Peter's University Hospital, c/o The Foundation Dept at 254 Easton Avenue, New Brunswick, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOYLE, PAUL R.
description: DOYLE-Paul R. Age 84. Died unexpectedly December 23, 1998 of complications of pneumonia, after a brief illness. Born in Providence, R.I. Son of Mary Ellen McLaughlin and Thomas F. Doyle. He was a Foreign Service graduate of Georgetown University and a U.S. Navy veteran of WWII; served as Assistant to U.S. Ambassador in Rome; as Director of U.S. Displaced Persons Commission's Mission in Austria; and, on staff of U.N. High Commissioner for Refuges in Geneva. Retired as Foreign Government Relations Representative of Standard Oil Company (Indiana). A member of the New York Athletic Club, generous host, extraordinary chef, cultivator of friendships that he never allowed to die, Paul's death leaves a void in many lives in all corners of the world. He is survived by several nieces and nephews. A memorial service in N.Y. will be held later. Contributions in Paul's memory may be made to Coalition for the Homeless or to Salvation Army. ''In the midst of the word he was trying to say, In the midst of his laughter and glee, He softly and suddenly vanished away--''.

title: Henry Paolucci, 77, Scholar and a Leader in Conservative Party
description: Dr. Henry Paolucci, a prolific scholar of classical politics and literature, professor emeritus of government and politics at St. John's University and vice chairman of the New York Conservative Party for the last 20 years, died Friday at New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens. He was 77 and a resident of Beechhurst, Queens.

title: Man Accused in Subway Death Says He Tried a Similar Attack Before, the Police Say
description: The man accused of pushing a woman to her death in front of a subway train in Manhattan has told investigators that he tried to push another woman in front of a subway train in Brooklyn less than a year ago, but that the woman fought him off, police officials said yesterday.

title: Jumping on the Pan-American Express; The Hidden Beauty of Latin Roots
description: THE first impulse of many uninitiated cooks who happen upon root vegetables from Latin America in the market is simply to shake their heads and walk way. These tubers -- brown, bumpy, sometimes even scaly -- look for all the world like miniature logs that were tossed into the vegetable bin by mistake.

title: How Much Military?
description: C ritics have likened today's United States military to the post-Vietnam ''hollow force'' of the 1970's. They are wrong, though they are right to point out that the military is in worse shape than it was a few years ago.
