title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAMPTON, DR. MERLE E.
description: FRAMPTON-Dr. Merle E. The Board of Trustees of The New York Institute For Special Education (founded in 1831 as The New York Institute For The Education Of The Blind) records with deep regret the death of one of its former Directors and nationally-renowned figure in the field of education and rehabilitation of the visually handicapped. Our sympathy is extended to his family. Gordon C. Dewey, President, Board of Trustees Robert L. Guarino, Ph.D Executive Director

title: QLT'S STOCK JUMPS AFTER REPORT ABOUT AN EYE TREATMENT
description: The Canadian company QLT Phototherapeutics Inc. said yesterday that a new study showed its Visudyne therapy helped treat macular degeneration, an eye condition that is responsible for severe vision loss. Shares in the company, which develops light-activated drugs for cancer and other conditions, jumped 23 percent, gaining $5.3125 each, to $28, in Nasdaq trading. QLT, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, said patients in the trial were injected with either a placebo or Visudyne, a light-sensitive drug.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DUGGAN, STEPHEN PIERCE, JR.
description: DUGGAN-Stephen Pierce, Jr. A Memorial service on Wednesday, January 13 at 4PM at the Institute of International Education. 809 United Nations Plaza, 12th Floor.

title: Mother of Suspect in Killing of Gay Student Freezes to Death
description: The mother of one of two Wyoming men charged in the killing of a gay college student froze to death after leaving a bar, Wyoming police officials said today.

title: Wrong Hose Was Used in Fire That Killed 3, Officials Say
description: Firefighters struggling to rescue fallen colleagues in a Brooklyn apartment building last month were using a hose considered too narrow for high-rise blazes, and department officials want to know why, firefighters and city officials close to a Fire Department investigation said yesterday.

title: QUINTILES BUYS HOECHST RESEARCH CENTER IN KANSAS CITY
description: The Quintiles Transnational Corporation said yesterday that it had purchased Hoechst Marion Roussel A.G.'s drug innovation and approval operation in Kansas City, Mo., for $93 million and had opened a contract research facility in Kansas City. Quintiles, based in Durham, N.C., assumed management of the research facility and agreed to retain about 500 Hoechst Marion workers there. The companies said the transaction guaranteed Quintiles revenue of $436 million over five years for continued support and completion of Hoechst's development projects. Hoechst Marion is the American pharmaceutical arm of Hoechst A.G., the German chemical giant.

title: New iMac's Are Introduced Along With $100 Price Cut
description: Unveiling a colorful array of sleek machines that more closely resemble a pack of Life Savers than a new computer line, Apple Computer's interim chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, today introduced the second generation of the company's popular iMac computers.

title: Missing Couple's Landlord Arraigned in Fraud Case
description: The landlord of a missing Manhattan couple laundered $1.3 million to avoid state taxes and also carried out a sophisticated scheme that involved assuming the identity of a man who died in 1994, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITZ, DR. ARTHUR C.
description: SPITZ-Dr. Arthur C. Beloved husband of Frances for 56 years. Much adored father of Darcy, and son-in-law Bob Yucikas. Lifelong companion of Jean and Harold Robbin. A son of Hungarian immigrants, he proudly served his country in the United States Army during World War II. A quiet man, he loved music, books, travel and his work as an optometrist. He will be deeply missed.

title: British-Norwegian Deal Seen in Oil Services
description: Prosafe A.S., a Norwegian oil service company, said yesterday that it was in talks to merge with Abbot Group P.L.C. as companies seek to offer oil companies a wider range of services. The deal would involve Abbot's buying Prosafe in a stock swap, with each company's shareholders getting 50 percent of the new company. A final agreement may be signed within four weeks, after a review of financial details, Prosafe said.

title: Corrections
description: A letter published on Monday about a possible union of Belarus and Russia misspelled the surname of the writer. He is Hans Koning, not Konig.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARQUARDT, WILLIAM
description: MARQUARDT-William. January 5, 1999. Beloved husband of Marie. Loving father of William, Jr., Douglas and Anita. Cherished grandfather of Justin. He was the Past District Deputy Grand Master for the Third Manhattan District of the State of New York and Past Master of George Washington Masonic Lodge 285. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial, Friday, January 8, 10 A.M., at Saint Jean Baptiste Church, 184 East 76 Street, New York City.

title: Anti-Castro Exiles Won Limit on Changes
description: Foreign policy experts, Catholic archbishops, the Chamber of Commerce and senior Senators tried hard to push the United States to change its policy toward Cuba significantly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACKER, HOWARD
description: ACKER-Howard. The Board of Directors and members of the East Sixties Neighborhood Association mourn the passing of our friend, advisor and treasurer. His council during the formation of ESNA was invaluable. He will be greatly missed. Judith MacLennon, Pres.

title: The News Is Old, but the Joke Lies Elsewhere
description: Unlike, say, vegetable soup, topical comedy cannot be cooked up months in advance and then put in the freezer until you're hungry. That's one lesson that might be learned from the return of ''Lateline'' to the NBC schedule tonight. The network's programmers, who apparently didn't grasp the show's limited potential when it failed to catch fire last year, are looking in vain for nourishment.

title: Retrial Moves Ahead in Westhampton Beach Beating Case
description: After a late effort at plea bargaining failed, jury selection began today in the retrial of a Queens man accused of attempted murder in what the police say was a racially motivated brawl outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub in May 1996.

title: In Euro's Leap, Some Look for Net
description: To the Editor:

title: Mission Accomplished, If Sloppily, by the B.C.S.
description: The coach was talking about his team, the undefeated, undisputed national title-holder, but Phillip Fulmer might as well have been summing up the Bowl Championship Series and its computer-age way of matching the nation's two best teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORNTON, RICHARD
description: THORNTON-Richard. Died on January 4th in Selden, LI. He was born in the Bronx in 1941. He worked in advertising for JTJ Printing Corporation in New York City. He was the son of Arthur and Helen Jackowicz Thornton, both predeceased. He was the widower of Susan Thornton. He is survived by a brother, Robert A. Thornton of Washingtonville, NY, a niece, Kerriann Thornton and a nephew, Robert M. Thornton. Services will be held at the David T. Ferguson Funeral Home on Thursday, January 7th from 2-4, 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered on Friday, January 8th at 10:00 A.M., at St. Mary's Church. Interment is at St. Mary's Cemetery, Washingtonville, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAOLUCCI, HENRY
description: PAOLUCCI-Henry. The City College of New York mourns the passing of Dr. Henry Paolucci, a distinguished alumnus of CCNY's Class of 1950. A noted scholar who taught ancient Greek and Roman history at CCNY and other leading colleges, he was also a prolific author and an important voice in politics and public policy. On behalf of the City College community I wish to extend my heartfelt condolences to his wife, CUNY Board of Trustees Chairwoman Dr. Anne A. Paolucci, and to his family. Yolanda T. Moses, President The City College of New York/ CUNY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMENGARTEN, JEANNE
description: BLUMENGARTEN-Jeanne. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Jeanne Blumengarten. To her family and loved ones, we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: Apply Common Law In a Senate Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial by Fire Is Set to Begin For Untested Speaker-to-Be
description: In the 17 days that he has known he will be Speaker, Representative Dennis Hastert has hardly had time to move into his new office. The cupboards are bare, the desktop empty and glistening. But he has shipped in a few items, including a ceramic puppy on a quilted pillow, that give a softer, friendlier feel to an office that was dominated for the last four years by Newt Gingrich's Tyrannosaurus rex.

title: Fiesta Bowl Becomes Jackson's Long Goodbye
description: At 12:05 A.M. yesterday, the Fiesta Bowl mercifully ended. The Tostitos were soggy, the Diet Coke flat. After 3 hours 50 minutes -- not counting a 15-minute pre-game show -- Tennessee won. The Christmas yule log burned faster.

title: Tokyo Aide Questions 'Bubble-Like' U.S. Economy : Dollar Takes a Pounding As Investors Flock to Yen
description: HONG KONG  The dollar tumbled Tuesday to a 27-month low against the yen after a leading Japanese financial official described the U.S. economy as "bubble-like."

title: German Software Maker Falls Short on Profits
description: The German software maker SAP A.G. said yesterday that its 1998 profits were far below expectations, signaling an end to a period of dynamic growth and leading analysts to lower recommendations.

title: Iranians Assert Rogue Officers Slew Dissidents
description: In an extraordinary statement, Iran's Intelligence Ministry said today that rogue Iranian intelligence officers were responsible for the killings late last year of five prominent critics of the Government's conservative wing.

title: Journal; The Bloviators' Ball
description: Was it coined by H. L. Mencken? Warren G. Harding? Gore Vidal? Lewis Carroll? To the many vocal readers who have searched in vain for a dictionary that might give the definition and derivation of the term ''bloviate'' since it appeared here, in a November column about the nattering nabobs of Washington, I say: Forget the O.E.D. and consult the essential ''Safire's New Political Dictionary,'' in which the history of this ''made up'' word is traced back as far as 1850. Its creator? Unknown. Its meaning? ''To orate pompously.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, AIMEE FLECK
description: MYERS-Aimee Fleck, 95. On January 2. Wife of the late Clifford L. Myers. She is survived by her children Ronnie Eldridge, Lawrence Myers, their spouses Jimmy Breslin and Barbara Myers; her grandchildren Daniel, Emily and Lucy, their spouses Jean McGavin, Michael Silberman and Laurence Freedman, her three longed-for great grandchildren Glynnis, Nathaniel and Sophie; Ernest Londa & other special friends. She was an elegant strong woman with great style and beauty. She thought we were wonderful and we loved her very much. She was the center of our lives. She was here before the subway. We thought she would last forever.

title: 65 Cents, and Sometimes Worth It
description: IN the days before fast-food chains, roadside dining was a hit-or-miss affair. The inviting cafe just off the highway could be the home of truly hellish cuisine. On the other hand, it could be the White Rose Diner, a tiny white rectangle in Hannibal, Mo., whose dinner included a choice of smothered chicken and dumplings, prime rib or T-bone steak, served with green beans, new potatoes in cream, asparagus vinaigrette, a beverage and ice cream. When the White Rose opened in 1938, the price for this spread was 65 cents.

title: IRAQI'S ANGRY CALL FOR REVOLT SPLITS THE ARAB NATIONS
description: A bitter war of words between Iraq and its Arab neighbors has followed last month's American-led bombings, leaving Iraq more isolated than at any time since the Persian Gulf war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, ELAINE
description: STONE-Elaine died January 5, 1999. Devoted wife of Louis; most beloved mother of Richard, Susan and Stuart Wilks; cherished and adored Goggy of Lisa and Adam; dearest cousin, sister, aunt, and friend. She was the epitome of goodness & generosity. Services, Wednesday, January 6, at 1:30PM, Temple Israel of Jamaica, 188 Street and the Grand Central Parkway, Holliswood, New York.

title: Long-Term Care
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Still-Moist Dried Fruit Arrives From France

title: Dehere Backing Union, But Doubts Players Will
description: Terry Dehere has heard David Stern's threats about canceling the season and using replacement players. He has seen the dour expression on the commissioner's face as he laments how the agents have sold the players in the National Basketball Association ''a bill of goods.'' He has read Stern's prediction that the careers of 20 percent of the league's players will be ruined.

title: Hearing Brings Out City University's Staunchest Defenders
description: After six months of visiting campuses, commissioning consultants and questioning administrators, teachers and students, a panel appointed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to recommend changes in the City University of New York held a public hearing yesterday that was dominated by defenders of CUNY and its mission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUDSON, AUDREY M.
description: HUDSON-Audrey M. On December 30, 1998. Audrey Meyer Hudson of Severna Park, MD. (Formerly of Bayside, N.Y.) Beloved wife of the late James Hudson. Devoted mother of Jody Hudson. Dear sister of C. Frederic Meyer. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, 7PM at the Barranco & Sons Funeral Home, Severna Park, MD. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Cancer Society.

title: More Than the Season Rests on Players' Vote
description: Did David Stern goad Billy Hunter into calling today's vote of National Basketball Association players, or has the head of the union scheduled a vote whose outcome he knows?

title: Jets Counting on Martin to Stay Cool and Grind It Out
description: Bill Parcells's message to the Jets this week is simple: one bad play can ruin a season.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: In Vino Veritas

title: Apply Common Law In a Senate Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Firehouse '97, and Other Proud Parisian Appellations
description: Avoiding the crowds waiting to ascend the Eiffel Tower last week, a few intrepid tourists made their way instead to Bercy Park at the southeast corner of the city to view an exhibition called ''Vignes, Vins et Paris,'' or ''Vines, Wines and Paris.'' In doing so, they joined the few insiders who know that Paris, a city as urban as any, has eight vineyards. Six are cultivated by the parks department, two are privately owned and all are very small.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MALLEY, THOMAS J., JR.
description: O'MALLEY-Thomas J., Jr., The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Thomas J. O'Malley, Jr., a Life Member of the Society, and extends sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMALVA, RAYMOND P.
description: LaMALVA-Raymond P. Of Jackson Heights, New York. On Thursday, December 31, 1998. Son of Mark J. and Amelita LaMalva. Brother of Christopher, Ben and Lee. Grandson of Patrick M. and Joan LaMalva; & Armando and Teresita Agulto. Funeral services and interment were held in Saint Rose of Lima Church and Cemetery, Short Hills, New Jersey.

title: Most of the Mob Scene in Times Square Hails From Elsewhere
description: Even in New York, where pedestrians know they are not entitled to much personal space as they navigate the city's sidewalks, Times Square stands out. Getting around the neighborhood on foot has come to resemble a contact sport.

title: Robert Kirby, 80, Former Chief Who Helped Save Westinghouse
description: Robert E. Kirby, a former chief executive of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation who masterminded a turnaround of the company in the 1970's, died last Thursday at Naples Community Hospital in Naples, Fla. He was 80.

title: MANY EXECUTIVES CHOOSE TO STAY WITH NEW BANKAMERICA
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said yesterday that about 80 percent of 1,134 of the executives eligible to leave under change-of-control agreements touched off by the recent merger with the Nationsbank Corporation were still with the combined bank. While not all executives of the former BankAmerica were offered positions, 900 of the 918 top executives who did receive such offers have agreed to stay, according to a company spokesman. After the $42.8 billion merger, which formed the biggest bank in the United States, a number of BankAmerica's highest-ranking executives left. One who did was the former chief executive of BankAmerica, David Coulter, who resigned in October after becoming president of the combined bank in September.

title: Governor to Emphasize Fighting Crime
description: In a State of the State Message freighted with anticrime proposals, Gov. George E. Pataki will call Wednesday for abolishing parole for all felons and for requiring that all felons' DNA fingerprints be logged into state computers, aides to the Governor said today.

title: U.S. May Sell Ginnie Mae to Raise Money
description: The Clinton Administration is considering a plan to raise $2.5 billion by selling the Government National Mortgage Association, a Government agency that finances more than 12 percent of all the nation's mortgages.

title: First Atlantic Capital Deal
description: First Atlantic Capital Ltd., a private investment firm, has purchased a majority interest in Otis Spunkmeyer Inc., a maker of frozen cookie dough, muffins and other specialty baked goods. Financial terms were not disclosed. First Atlantic said yesterday that it had acquired majority ownership through a recapitalization, with management and existing shareholders retaining a stake in the company.

title: Japanese Is Sorry He Called U.S. a Bully
description: The Japanese Government backed away today from remarks by a Cabinet member suggesting that Japanese were unhappy with their ''Peace Constitution'' and that the United States bullied other countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIKELMAN, RICHARD A.
description: RIKELMAN-Richard A. Age 53. Died December 31. Beloved son of Benjamin and the late Rose Rikelman. Devoted brother of Brenda Mahler and Cynthia Bassi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOLEY, JOHN FRANCIS
description: FOLEY-John Francis, 55, lifetime resident of New York City, died on Tuesday, December 22, 1998, in Naples, FL. He attended St. John's College & served in the U.S. Army in Vietnam. Working with life-long companion, Charles Chevillot, he was integral in the opening of La Petite Ferme restaurant in Greenwich Village in 1971, which, later continued on the Upper East Side and became a Lexington Avenue institution until 1994. He and Mr. Chevillot also opened restaurants in the Dominican Republic, San Francisco, and St. Martin. He is survived by Patricia Sweeney Acopolos, his cousin, Charles Chevillot, and many friends. Services will be held at Saint Joseph Church, 371 Sixth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10011, on January 8, 1999 at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Saint Joseph Church.

title: Old-Fashioned in an Up-to-Date Way
description: IF you crossed the ''21'' Club with Balthazar and threw in a bit of the Oyster Bar you would end up with something like City Hall. No wonder everybody likes the place so much.

title: To Vestige of Black Farmers, Bias Settlement Is Too Late
description: Willie E. Adams, a fourth-generation black farmer, is raising 48,000 chickens here on the same land that his ancestors farmed, some 85 miles east of Atlanta. But with $150,000 in debt, $90,000 to the Federal Government and $60,000 to banks, Mr. Adams says he is ''just keeping my head above water.''

title: Tenneco Expects Earnings Below Estimates
description: Tenneco Inc. expects to report fourth-quarter earnings ''substantially below'' consensus estimates, primarily because of weak performance in its automotive aftermarket business and several charges related to the automotive business.

title: Lines Quivering With Mischief
description: ''The Line King: The Al Hirschfeld Story'' will be shown tonight at 9 on PBS (Channel 13 in New York) as part of the ''American Masters'' series. This is an hourlong version of the 1 1/2-hour film released theatrically. Here are excerpts from Nora Sayre's review of Sept. 27, 1996.

title: Magnets Lessen Foot Pain Of Diabetics, a Study Finds
description: In one of the first scientific studies of the centuries-old and highly debated use of magnets for treatment of medical disorders, a New York neurologist reported today that he had significantly lessened the foot pain that afflicts millions of diabetics.

title: Salo Keeps Chicago In Check
description: ISLES 1, BLACKHAWKS 1

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHING, HERTA
description: HECHING-Herta. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the mother of its devoted and dedicated member, Harry Heching. May her entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: Attack Is Investigated As Possible Bias Incident
description: The police are investigating an assault on New Year's Day as a possible bias incident, they said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENARSKY, MAURICE, M.D.
description: LENARSKY-Maurice, M.D., on Tuesday, January 5, age 95 of Natick, MA, formerly of Riverdale, NY. Beloved husband of the late Mary (Bresnahan). A pediatrician, he graduated from NYU, Phi Beta Kappa and Johns Hopkins Medical School and was affiliated with several New York hospitals. He was on the faculty of Albert Einstein Medical School. A Navy veteran of W.W. II and Korea, he retired as a Commander. He is survived by a daughter, Jane, of Natick, MA. Donations in his memory may be made to the Dr. Maurice Lenarksy Scholarship, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Office of Medical Alumni Affairs, 1620 McElderry Street, Baltimore, MD 21205-1911. Graveside services, Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island, New York, on January 7 at 1:00 PM. Levine Chapels 617-277-8300.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HENRY SCHEIN INC., Melville, N.Y., a distributor of medical supplies to doctors and dentists, said it had bought Heiland Group G.m.b.H., a German direct marketer of medical, dental and veterinary supplies. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Ryan, Brett and Yount Are Named to the Hall
description: In a first-ballot bonanza unseen in more than 60 years, Nolan Ryan, George Brett and Robin Yount breezed into baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday. Ryan and Brett made the trip in particularly glittering fashion.

title: 'Sunshine' Is Good
description: To the Editor:

title: Air Skirmish Over Iraq
description: In the first confrontation between United States and Iraqi fighters in more than six years, American warplanes fired on but missed Iraqi jets that were reported to have penetrated the southern ''no flight'' zone.

title: In Euro's Leap, Some Look for Net
description: To the Editor:

title: Deutsche Bank Invests In Unicredito Italiano
description: Deutsche Bank said yesterday that it had acquired a stake of 0.75 percent in Unicredito Italiano in the latest sign of foreign interest in Italy's underdeveloped banking industry. While Unicredito Italiano is Italy's second-largest bank, it ranks only about 25th in Europe. But, like other Italian banks, it is expected to benefit from the introduction of the euro.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANDOLFO, RICCARDO N.
description: GANDOLFO-Riccardo N. On January 3, 1999. Beloved husband of Dawn. Loving father of Andrew and Ericca. Dear son of Ermes and the late Frank Gandolfo. Devoted brother of Barbara Gandolfo Frady, James Gandolfo and Georgette Gandolfo. Mass of Christian burial Thursday, 10AM at St. John the Baptist Church. The family will be present Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 P.M., at F. Ruggiero & Sons Inc., 732 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers, New York.

title: People
description: * Lee Rudnick, director at DBI Media, New York, a unit of Diane Bardy Inc., was promoted to the new position of president.

title: Crime Rate Hits 33-Year Low; All Major Categories Decline
description: Crime rates continued a steep decline in New Jersey during the first half of 1998, dropping to the lowest levels since the State Police began keeping figures in 1966, according to a report released today.

title: Death Toll Rises in Sumatran Violence
description: The death toll from separatist violence in Aceh Province has reached 16 and security forces are continuing house-to-house searches for suspected rebels.

title: Hewlett-Packard Plans Inexpensive Printers
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it had formed a subsidiary, Apollo Consumer Products Inc., to enter the low end of the ink-jet printer market.

title: Pricing at Issue As U.S. Finishes Microsoft Case
description: The Government called its last witness in the Microsoft trial today after presenting 110 pages of his written testimony that amount to a summation of -- and economic justification for -- the Justice Department's sweeping antitrust suit against the software giant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, MARGARET HASKELL
description: ROSS-Margaret Haskell of Basking Ridge, N.J. and Edgartown, MA. on January 2, 1999. Beloved wife of Edmund Burke Ross and mother of Edmund B. Jr., Amory L., Benson T., Parthenia Kiersted and the late Robin. Sister of Anne Ellis, Hope Jones and Isabel DeTomaso. Also survived by nine grandchildren. A memorial service was held yesterday at the Church of St. John on The Mountain Bernardsville, NJ. Interment Wednesday in Edgartown, MA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent in her name to The Martha's Vineyard Hospital Oak Bluffs, MA. 02577.

title: Changed Terrain on Cuba
description: When the White House endorses the idea of a visit to Havana by the Baltimore Orioles it is clear the ground is starting to shift in United States relations with Cuba. After four decades in which Washington successively tried to remove Fidel Castro by invasion, assassination plots and rigid economic isolation, signs are multiplying that the long American siege of Cuba is starting to wind down.

title: Ruling Belarus
description: To the Editor:

title: The Homey Joys Of Simple Paella
description: YOU wouldn't know it from the elaborate meat-and-shellfish dish in Spanish restaurants, but paella has simple roots. Like most peasant dishes gone ritzy, paella is quite comfortable back in the home kitchen. Indeed, a plain rice-and-shrimp dish can be as much a ''real'' paella as the $25-a-plate version.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WECHTER, SHOSHA (SOPHIE)
description: WECHTER-Shosha (Sophie). Wife of the late Karl. Mother of Mira Rosenfeld (Tim) Sennett of Atlantic Beach. Dear mother-in-law of Joel M. Rosenfeld. Caring grandmother of Dr. Melissa (Dr. Thierry) Abitbol and Avery (Robyn) Rosenfeld. Great grandmother of David and Lauren Rosenfeld, and Dani Hannah Abitbol. Born in Simyaticz, Poland in 1914. Avid Zionist and pioneer in Israel. Sole survivor of the Melamed & Lev families. Her legacy will be cherished. Graveside services Thursday 1:30 pm Mount Hebron Cemetery.

title: Mayor Threatens to Cut Off Funds for Campaign Board
description: Bringing a long-simmering feud to a boil, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani threatened yesterday to cut off funds to New York City's Campaign Finance Board, hoping to block its planned fourfold match of private donations to candidates in next month's special elections for City Council.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, BENJAMIN
description: ROSEN-Benjamin. Greater New York Hospital Association mourns the passing of Benjamin Rosen, the father of our esteemed friend, colleague and former Chairman, David P. Rosen, President and Chief Executive Officer of Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Rosen family. Mark J. Mundy, Chairman Kenneth E. Raske, President Greater New York Hospital Assn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPIDUS, EDITH J. (JUDY)
description: LAPIDUS-Edith J. (Judy), 96. Cherished mother of Jacqueline Lapidus and Elizabeth Zelvin, grandmother of Alexander Zelvin, sister of Hilda Berry, friend and inspiration to many. Funeral Service Wednesday, January 6, 12 noon, Schwartz Bros., 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: Reduction in Car Insurance Rates Set For March, but Not All Wil Benefit
description: The Whitman administration has scheduled the long-awaited 15 percent reduction in auto insurance rates for March 22, but almost half of the state's drivers will not get the full savings and some will instead face higher rates.

title: Thompson Revamps Office in New York
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company division of WPP Group P.L.C. announced a series of personnel changes yesterday as part of a reorganization of the J. Walter Thompson New York office by Bob Jeffrey, who recently became president.

title: Cubans Skeptical About Expanded Contacts
description: Cuban officials reacted with cool skepticism today to President Clinton's decision to expand contacts between Americans and Cubans, while the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro, maintained a pointed silence.

title: Drug Treatment in Prisons Dips as Use Rises, Study Finds
description: The proportion of prison inmates who were drug users at the time of their arrest increased this decade, while drug treatment in state and Federal prisons fell sharply, according to a study released yesterday by the Justice Department.

title: Indonesia Leader Offers Aid To Poor in His New Budget
description: President B. J. Habibie announced his first budget today, including a proposal for substantial aid for the nation's 80 million poor people -- about 40 percent of the population.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Making New Yorker Hotel New Again
description: The New Yorker Hotel -- yes, the New Yorker -- is a major tourist hotel again. A four-year, $20 million renovation is nearing completion, and the building at Eighth Avenue and 34th Street, which was once the largest hotel in the city and for many years housed followers of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, now has 860 functioning guest rooms -- with a total of 1,005 expected by June.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Biographers Take To the First Lady

title: Seeking Stolen Cars, Police Find Man's Body
description: Police officers investigating a tip about stolen cars in Brooklyn yesterday unearthed the body of a man who had been missing for four years, the police said.

title: Panelist Says New Taxes Are Needed For Medicare
description: One of President Clinton's appointees to a Federal advisory commission studying the future of Medicare said today that new taxes or other revenues would be required to keep the program intact for millions of baby boomers.

title: Players Vote Today on Endorsing Their Negotiators
description: In the most chaotic day of the six-month-old lockout, the National Basketball Association players' union was trying to arrange an almost impossible travel schedule for its 400-plus members while trying to prevent the group from falling into disarray on the eve of the threatened cancellation of the season.

title: Women Dominate Grammy Nominations
description: It will be a battle between divas young and old at the 41st annual Grammy Awards, judging from the contenders announced here today by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences. Lauryn Hill received the most nominations, 10, followed by Celine Dion, Madonna, Sheryl Crow, Brandy and Shania Twain.

title: 3 Appointments Made at Distribution Unit of Times Co.
description: The New York Times Company has appointed a president and two senior vice presidents at City and Suburban, its wholesale distribution subsidiary in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEGENSHEIN, EDWARD DAVID
description: DEGENSHEIN-Edward David, 87 years old died peacefully on Jan. 4, 1999. Beloved husband of Pearl. Loving father of John Degenshein and Beth Diskin. Devoted grandfather of Robyn and Jonathan Diskin. Also survived by his sister Pearl Gordon. Graveside service Wednesday 11 A.M., at Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, New York.

title: A Small World: Classes In Home Kitchens
description: WITH all due respect to New York's great cooking schools, they are, for the most part, worlds away from home kitchens. They have space and equipment undreamed of in most apartments, but they lack the warmth of home and hearth.

title: Expanding Ties, Clinton Extends a Hand to Cuba
description: WASHINGTON  The United States, seeking to ease the plight of the Cuban people without strengthening its government, will allow a greatly expanded flow of cash donations to Cuba, authorize food sales and permit easier travel to the Caribbean island, President Bill Clinton announced Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, EMANUEL
description: GOLDBERG-Emanuel. The officers, Board of Directors and staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn the passing of our Honorary Board member, Emanuel Goldberg of Rochester and Palm Beach. He served with great distinction bringing to bear his broad Jewish communal experience, his deep commitment, and his broad global outlook. Our condolences to his wife, Nathalie and the family. Jonathan W. Kolker, President Michael Schneider, Executive Vice President Ambassador Milton A. Wolf Chairman of the Board

title: Business Travel; Many of those headed to Europe are a bit bewildered about coping with the euro.
description: ONE of the first phone calls Alami Driss received yesterday morning was from someone asking how he could buy euros for a planned trip to Europe. Responding as he had done to similar phone calls for more than a month, Mr. Driss explained that the euro is not available for purchase anywhere for three more years.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Technology Stocks Lift Nasdaq to 3d Straight High

title: Top British Wireless Carrier Joins Battle to Acquire Airtouch
description: Britain's largest wireless carrier, the Vodafone Group, confirmed yesterday that it had approached Airtouch Communications, the largest all-wireless carrier in the United States, with a preliminary proposal to buy the company, complicating merger talks between Airtouch and the Bell Atlantic Corporation.

title: Human Drugs Approved for Mental Problems in Dogs
description: The Food and Drug Administration announced yesterday that it had approved two drugs already used in people as the first treatments ever marketed specifically to treat mental problems in dogs.

title: Sports of The Times; The Players Will Give In To Get a Deal
description: A MAN named Smith once told me the story of his two uncles, Uncle Sile and Uncle Howard. They were chopping wood on their farm one day when Sile said, ''Howard, put your finger on that block and I'll chop it off.'' Howard did, and Sile did. Howard didn't think Sile would chop, and Sile didn't think Howard would leave his finger there.

title: ANTITRUST SUIT SAYS DENTSPLY RESTRICTED TOOTH TRADE
description: Dentsply International Inc., the world's top maker of artificial teeth, was accused by the Justice Department yesterday of illegally restricting competition among denture distributors. An antitrust suit filed in Federal court in Wilmington, Del., said Dentsply, based in York, Pa., sells 70 percent of the artificial teeth in the United States and had enforced restrictive arrangements affecting more than 80 percent of distributors. Last month, Dentsply sued the Justice Department, noting it had been under investigation since 1995 and asking for a ruling that it was not a monopoly and did not illegally restrain trade.

title: Thou Rodgers, Thou Hart, So Fizzy, So Smart
description: One was tall, handsome, self-confident and aloof, the other pint-size (barely five feet tall), witty, lovable, and consumed with self-loathing for his physical shortcomings. They were the composer Richard Rodgers and the lyricist Lorenz Hart, partners in one of the greatest songwriting collaborations of the century.

title: Shopping for Groceries in Electronic Aisles: A Revolution at Hand
description: THE idea of doing the week's marketing at a computer screen used to be the stuff of science fiction. But the number of American households shopping for food on the Internet may reach almost seven million by 2002, a projection of Emarketer, which tracks business on line.

title: 2 Bipartisan Mavericks Behind Clinton Trial Plan
description: Senator Slade Gorton has often called himself a ''passionate moderate'' and, as Washington State's Attorney General more than two decades ago, was one of the first prominent Republican officials to call for the resignation of President Richard M. Nixon.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: About New York; Neighborhood Is the Source Of Real Capital
description: ON Saturdays, the checkout line at the Elmhurst branch of the Queens Public Library looks like a rush-hour token booth crowd. Nearby every seat is taken at the tables, where Asian and Latino readers pass the time. A few people browse through the racks of compact disks in Korean, Spanish and Chinese.

title: New Jersey Top Court Hears Arguments Over Gay Scouts
description: For the Boy Scouts of America the basic Scouting tenet of living a ''morally straight'' and clean life does not leave room for open homosexuality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUFELD, ABRAHAM
description: NEUFELD-Abraham. Of Hewlett Harbor, New York, veteran of World War II, active in many humanitarian causes. President of LI Committee of Soviet Jewry. Beloved husband of Helen, loving father of Jeffrey, Pam, and Robert. Cherished grandfather. We will miss you. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI. 11:30 AM Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, DR. SAMUEL P.
description: ALTMAN-Dr. Samuel P., 80. Of Monroe Twp., NJ, formerly of Brooklyn on Jan. 4, 1999. Educator with New York City School System for 35 years, most recently as Principal of Susan E. Wagner High School, Staten Island. Husband of 46 years of Doris (Rosenhouse). Father of Marjorie Tesser, Roy L. and Kenneth W. Brother of Lillian Rosenfeld and the late Irving. Grandfather of Shauna., Benjamin, Randall and Lauren. Service 11:15 AM Thursday, Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, New Jersey. Memorial gifts to American Parkinsons Disease Assn, 1250 Hylan Blvd, Suite 4B, Staten Island, New York 10301.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, JOSEPH
description: BAUM-Joseph. On December 30, 1998. Beloved husband of Martha (Marge). Services Wednesday, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St.and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment King Solomon Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: A pop music review on Thursday about a performance by the rapper Slick Rick at Tramps misstated the crime for which he was sent to prison in 1990. It was attempted murder in the second degree, not murder in the second degree.

title: Aggressive Competitor Outside of Britain
description: The Vodafone Group P.L.C. has grown to be Britain's leading mobile phone company by employing an aggressive mixture of foreign expansion and domestic price-cutting in a furiously competitive market.

title: Pharmacia Stock Drops On Sweden's Plan to Sell
description: The shares of Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. fell yesterday as the Government of Sweden said it planned to sell its 7 percent stake, increasing the number of shares available in the company, the No. 10 drug maker in the United States. Pharmacia said Sweden would sell at least 31.1 million of the 35.8 million shares it holds in the company and might sell its entire stake, which is worth $2 billion at current prices. The shares of Pharmacia dropped 28.5 kronor, or 6 percent, to 444.5 kronor, in Stockholm trading.

title: The N.B.A. Misfires
description: Seven months ago, as Michael Jordan nailed down the Chicago Bulls' sixth championship of the decade, the National Basketball Association appeared to be on top of the world. Attendance was strong, top players were recognizable around the globe and the league's management was viewed as the best in professional sports. The N.B.A. had never missed a game due to labor problems. Now the league seems bent on self-destruction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, SYLVIA
description: BROWN-Sylvia on January 5, 1999. Beloved mother of James, Barbara, Bruce & Anita. Devoted grandmother of Marlene, Caren, Michael, Laura and Eric. Loving great grandmother of Allison, Mark, Benjamin, Caroline and Jonathan. Her friends and family were blessed by her unconditional love, loyalty, generosity and enthusiam for life. She will be missed.

title: 3 French Minds, Defiant and Brave
description: THE BURDEN OF RESPONSIBILITY

title: Qualms Over UConn's Big Plans
description: At the main campus of the University of Connecticut here, a building boom is under way that would be the envy of most university presidents.

title: Family Suffers Double Loss From U.N. Crashes in Angola
description: As a special United Nations envoy held talks in Angola trying to negotiate a rescue mission to the crash sites of two United Nations chartered planes reported to have been shot down over rebel territory, a South African family got bitter news today.

title: Cadence Raises Quickturn Offer
description: Cadence Design Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had raised the value of its offer to acquire Quickturn Design Systems Inc. to $15 a share in stock from $14.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACHARACH, MIRIAM
description: BACHARACH-Miriam. The Officers and members of the Kingsbridge Center of Israel record with sorrow the passing of Miriam Bacharach. May her loving family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Harvey Crupar Ben Lobenberg, Chairman

title: Romantic Films Trump Thrillers
description: Which movie is a more valuable piece of programming for a broadcast network, the first run of the recent action-packed thriller ''Mission Impossible'' or the fourth run of the gooey sudser ''The Bodyguard?''

title: Chupa Chups USA Hires Richards
description: Chupa Chups USA, part of S. A. Chupa Chups, said it had named Richards Group in Dallas to handle the creative part of its account, which had been handled by Lois/EJL in Chicago, a unit of Lois/USA. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Devils Add Insult to Andreychuk's Injury Against Sharks
description: Dave Andreychuk stood on crutches outside the Devils' locker room, trying to find a bright spot in what had been a miserable night for the Devils.

title: Prisons Are Deterrent
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Agitated Tyson Lays Out His Plan to Fight Botha
description: Mike Tyson didn't sound as if he was in a mood for chatting yesterday afternoon during a telephone conference call from his training site in Scottsdale, Ariz. With two weeks to go before his heavyweight bout against Francois Botha, the former International Boxing Federation champion, Tyson sounded irritated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, DR. ALFRED
description: SOLOMON-Dr. Alfred. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses heartfelt condolences to our member Evelyn Solomon and family upon the loss of her beloved husband. May the families be comforted among those who mourn for Tzion and Yerushalayim. Evan Torczyner, President Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALEN, ELI
description: MALEN-Eli. We mourn the passing of the husband of our esteemed member, Harriet Malen and the father of our esteemed member Ronald Malen and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Broadway And Museums Set Records For Holidays
description: The streets of New York weren't the only crowded place this Christmas season. Driven by swarms of tourists, Broadway theaters and many of the city's museums posted record numbers last week.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the dancer and choreographer Viola Farber on Dec. 31 misstated the work and the year in which she last performed. It was in James Cunningham's ''From the Horse's Mouth'' at the Joyce SoHo last April, not in ''Threestep (Shipwreck)'' in 1995.

title: Communications Chief Gains As Mayor Shifts Assignments
description: The Giuliani administration kicked off its sixth year yesterday with some changes in the ranks of those who have dedicated their careers, often anonymously, to the governmental and political objectives of their leader. And with those changes came indications of who in that notoriously tight circle had been granted more power.

title: A Bohemian Spirit Comfortable With the Classical
description: Few composers in any age have been able to live solely from writing music without also pursuing careers as teachers or performers, or having private means. The life of Hans Werner Henze, who has dedicated himself to composition for more than 50 years of vigorous industry, is all the more instructive, and in his rich, informative and engaging new autobiography, ''Bohemian Fifths'' (Princeton), he has much to say about his career and the music that has filled it.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Charter Schools Are Not A Threat
description: I have been invited to speak in a few days at a local synagogue about the charter school I direct and about the entire charter school movement -- if one can call it that. My audience will consist of people like me, deeply committed civil libertarians who consider themselves guardians of two cherished principles, the preservation of the public school system (this despite the fact that many of them sent their children to private schools) and the separation of church and state.

title: Bogota Sees Drug War as Path to Peace
description: President Andres Pastrana said today that ending the civil war that has ravaged his country for nearly 40 years depends on the rebels' willingness to help stamp out drug trafficking in areas they control.

title: Netscape Site Numbers Up
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation said yesterday that more than 10 million individuals had subscribed to its Internet portal site, Netscape Netcenter. The company, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., said it had more than doubled its membership rate since July. Netcenter is a World Wide Web site that serves as an access point to the Internet. In 1998, Netscape Netcenter added 18 business and consumer channels and 16 services, including free electronic mail.

title: SPRINGS INDUSTRIES TO SELL A UNIT TO MANAGEMENT GROUP
description: The home-furnishings concern Springs Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Springfield division, which makes woven fabrics for the apparel industry, to a management-led group for about $46 million. The move will allow Springs, based in Fort Mill, S.C., to concentrate on making sheets, towels and other home furnishings. About 275 employees of the division, based principally in South Carolina and New York, will become employees of the new independent company, Springfield L.L.C.

title: Engineering School Names Its Founding President
description: The nation's newest engineering school, which will admit its first class in fall 2001, has announced that its founding president will be Richard K. Miller, the engineering college dean at the University of Iowa.

title: Diplomatic Field of Dreams
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Arizona's Women at the Top
description: Five women were sworn in to the top elected offices in Arizona this week by another Arizonan, Sandra Day O'Connor, the first female Justice on the United States Supreme Court. Jane Dee Hull is the Governor, Betsey Bayless is Secretary of State, Janet Napolitano the Attorney General, Carol Springer Treasurer, and Lisa Graham Keegan the Superintendent of Public Instruction. Such a sweep has not happened anywhere else, but it is not so surprising in a state with a long history of women as government leaders. Indeed, four of these women have had years of service in state and local elected offices. Only Ms. Napolitano is new to elective politics, and she ran on her experience as the United States Attorney for Arizona.

title: Schedule May Force Top Lawyer Off Gotti Team
description: One of the chief lawyers for John A. Gotti, the accused Mafia leader, said yesterday that he would probably not be able to represent Mr. Gotti at a racketeering trial set to begin next month because of a scheduling conflict.

title: Auto Makers Up On Merger Rumors
description: Shares in the Honda Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Company rose sharply today in the Tokyo stock market on rumors that the auto makers may be acquired by foreign competitors. Automotive executives called the rumors untrue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIGHTINGALE, BERTRAM MAURICE
description: NIGHTINGALE-Bertram Maurice. ''A Prince of a Man with a Golden Heart''. You will always be remembered. Sam, Randy, Bobby and Kim

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, VIOLET
description: COHEN-Violet. Our dear sister Violet Cohen (nee Schwartz) left us at age 82. We love you. May you rest in peace. Adele London and Rena Zinkin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEMAN, ROBERT SPALDING
description: COLEMAN-Robert Spalding. 1921 to 1998. a New York public relations executive whose interests extended to thoroughbred horse racing, investment counseling and writing, died on December 16, 1998 after a long illness. He was 77. A native of Lake Forest, IL., Mr. Coleman was educated at The Phillips Andover Academy and the University of Virginia. As an owner & breeder of thoroughbred racehorses, Mr. Coleman became Director of Public Relations for the American Owners & Breeders Association and was subsequently elected President of the New York State Racing Association's Turf and Field Club from 1977 through 1985. During this time he also served as Vice President of Cowen and Company, a New York investment firm and published two collections of memoirs drawn from his horseracing adventures and stockmarket experience. Mr. Coleman is survived by his brother John Coleman, Jr. of Lake Forest, Ill., six children, Tangley Lloyd DeLaney, Robin Coleman, Gwendolyn C. D'Agostino, all of Greenwich, CT., and Bertrande C. Coleman, Caroline M. Coleman, both of New York City and Anne C. Laffoon, of Saratoga, California, six grandchildren, and his former wife, Nancy Tenney Coleman. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, January 9, at 3 P.M., St. John the Martyr Parish, East 72nd Street near 2nd Ave. Donations may be made in his memory to the Memorial Fund for the Class of 1944, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA. 22906.

title: For Pre-Theater, a Little Club With Classic Cuisine
description: OF all the questions I receive, none are more frequent than, ''Where can I eat inexpensively near the theater district?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNHEIM, PALMER
description: TURNHEIM-Palmer, 77. Retired Executive Vice President of First Union National Bank and retired Senior Vice President of the Chase Manhattan Bank, on Monday at home of pancreatic cancer. Advisor to the U.S. government on cash management, member of the U.S. Government Advisory Committee on Gas Rationing, key negotiator in the New York City fiscal crisis, World War II radio operator 10th U.S. Army Air Force, China-Burma-India theater, active Former Alumni Board Officer for New York University, Stern School of Business, Member of Harvard's 42nd AMP Class, Beta Gamma Sigma member and former director, former Director of the New York State Bankers Association, former President of United Cerebral Palsy Associations, former UCP Humanitarian and Firestone awards recipient, and Director of the Fund for Theological Education, Princeton, NJ, former member, Zoning Board of Adjustment of Mountain Lakes, founding member of Prince of Peace Lutheran Church, and former Trustee of Zion Lutheran Church. Beloved husband of the late Gloria Freer Turnheim, beloved father of Joy K. Turnheim and the late Nancy Elizabeth Turnheim, loving brother of Esther Kolbjornsen, loving uncle of Ruth Nybro and Art Kolbjornsen, loving friend of Ruth Larsen, and cherished ''Uncle'' to many. Viewing at the Norman Dean Home for Services, Denville, New Jersey, Wednesday, 7-9PM and Thursday, 2-4PM, 7-9PM. Funeral service at Zion Lutheran Church, 505 Watchogue Road, Staten Island, New York, at 10 A.M., on Friday, January 8. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Zion Lutheran Church, United Cerebral Palsy Research and Educational foundation for New York University Stern School of Business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VISITACION, FLORENDO M.
description: VISITACION-Florendo M. January 4, 1999 at the age of 88. Father of Edward, Laura, and Bladimir; grandfather of Cari, Joshua, Julie, and Dylan; father-in-law of John and Beverly. A tenth degree black belt and W.W. II Veteran, Grand Master ''Prof. Vee'' was the Founder of Vee Jitsu (''The System of Systems''), a form of self-defense unique in its incorporation of diverse techniques drawn from various martial arts. His decades of teaching enriched the lives of generations of martial arts students throughout the United States and in other parts of the world, and the valuable legacy of his art and philosphy lives on in us all. Time and place of Memorial Service to be announced.

title: Pension Woes: The Rule, Not the Exception
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AFZELIUS, ROLAND CARL
description: AFZELIUS-Roland Carl. On January 3, 1999 at the age of 82 years, of Bayville, NY. Beloved husband of Marie, loving father of Ellen, Ron and Adrianne. Cherished grandfather of Kohl, Isabella, Cepi and Shiel. We will miss him dearly. Private services. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Association for the Help of Retarded Children (AHRC), 189 Wheatley Rd, Brookville, NY 11545, Attn: #

description: ''You're 10 minutes late.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DECKER, NORMA S.
description: DECKER-Norma S. Of Southold, NY and Jupiter, FL. (formerly of Garden City, NY) passed away on January 4th after a brief illness. Mrs. Decker was the beloved wife of 41 years to the late Honorable George K. Decker Jr., and loving mother to Stephen of Brentwood NY; G. Kelly of Centreville, VA., a daughter Kerry Anne Ducey of Ridgefield, CT and was the grandmother to seven grandchildren. She was the daughter of the late Karl Schedler and Clara D. Blaschka and two sisters; the late Helga Pisani of Larchmont, NY and Claire Tschudin of Switzerland. Reposing Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial 10 AM, at Church of St. Joseph in Garden City, New York. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in her name to Whittingham Cancer Center, Norwalk Hospital Foundation office, Maple Street, Norwalk, CT. 06856.

title: Steinbrenner Invited To Visit Cuba
description: George Steinbrenner, owner of the Yankees, was extended an invitation to visit Cuba yesterday, one day after news emerged that the Baltimore Orioles and the Cuban national team may play a home-and-home series in March as part of an overall easing of the relationship between the United States and Cuba.

title: Economists Reject Notion Of Stock Market 'Bubble'
description: In all the talk at their annual meeting about the United States economy and what keeps it so robust, the nation's economists gave short shrift to one concern -- that the soaring stock market might be a speculative bubble that could burst, damaging the economy.

title: Sports of The Times; 'How Many of You Have Made an Illegal Bet?'
description: IN its scarlet and black practice uniforms, the Rutgers men's basketball team gathered in the Rutgers Athletic Center meeting room where the players usually listen to Coach Kevin Bannon and watch game tapes. But yesterday there were no X's and O's on the chalkboard, no videos rolling.

title: Ex-Member of Assembly Pleads Guilty in Bribery
description: A former member of the State Assembly pleaded guilty to a Federal charge of conspiracy yesterday for his part in a bribery scheme to steer insurance contracts awarded by Passaic County, said the United States Attorney, Faith S. Hochberg.

title: Bidding for Publicity, and Touchy About It
description: FIFTEEN minutes of fame can make anyone anxious, especially if the last go-round was, as the auctioneer's wife puts it, ''nightmare time,'' and that is perhaps why there is more tension than gaiety in the Upper East Side offices of Guernsey's auction house.

title: More Prime Time News
description: Pushed into the shadows by the dazzle of ABC News's announcement on Monday that Diane Sawyer and Charlie Gibson would be co-anchors of ''Good Morning America'' was a companion announcement, that ABC is giving yet another hour of prime time to a news program.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN EXTENDS ITS GAINS. Japan's currency rose for the sixth consecutive session against the dollar as yields on Japanese bonds continued to surge. In New York, the dollar declined to 111.21 yen, from 112.07 yen on Monday.

title: Gun Marketing Is Issue in Trial Against Makers
description: On the night of July 27, 1993, Njuzi Ray, 17, was fatally shot in a dispute on a Brooklyn street. A suspect was later acquitted, and nobody else has been arrested for the killing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, SHIEKIE
description: SNYDER-Shiekie. The Executive Board, local presidents, staff and members of District Council 37 are deeply saddened by the sudden death of the longtime president of Local 2021 New York City OffTrack Betting Corporation Employees. Shiekie was a great trade unionist who fought long and hard for his members for more than 20 years. He had been a DC 37 Vice President and Executive Board member for over 15 years. He was the oldest active president of an AFSCME local in the country. Shiekie was also part of the special fabric that makes New York unique. He had great stories to tell, knew more jokes than anyone, could tap dance with the best of them and knew the lyrics to songs most of us had never heard of. We will miss his tireless leadership and winning spirit. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his beloved wife Betty, daughters Sharon and Vicki, son Sandy and much loved grandchildren. Lee Saunders, Administrator Executive Board District Council 37 AFSCME, AFL-CIO

title: Liberties; Discipline Us, Please
description: In politics, as in romance, you often crave the complete opposite of your last relationship.

title: Miami Generally Welcomes Easing of Ban
description: Hemley Gonzalez calls an aunt in Cuba every weekend, and he travels to the island once a year to take medicine and clothes to the scores of relatives he left behind when he moved here 10 years ago.

title: Sports of The Times; Yogi and the Boss Complete Makeup Game
description: Let the record show that a celebrated grudge held for nearly 14 years was dropped here a few minutes after 5 this evening when a contrite George Steinbrenner arrived at Yogi Berra's doorstep and thanked the self-exiled Yankee great for the opportunity to make this day necessary.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, LILLIAN ELIZABETH
description: THOMPSON - Lillian Elizabeth, died peacefully on January 1, age 76, in London at the Royal Hospital for Neuro-Disability. Despite being severly disabled from MS for over thirty years she had a wonderfully strong spirit, a love of life that turned into a great will to live. She is lovingly remembered by her only daughter Anne-Marie and son-in-law Jeffrey A. Jannuzzo.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOORE, GENE
description: MOORE-Gene. A memorial service for Gene Moore will be held on Thursday, January 7, 1999, 4:00PM at The New-York Historical Society at 77th Street and Central Park West

title: U.S. and Iraqi Jets Tangle in the Southern 'No Flight' Zone
description: In the first confrontation between American and Iraqi jet fighters in more than six years, American warplanes today fired on -- but missed -- Iraqi jets that were reported to have penetrated the ''no flight'' zone over southern Iraq.

title: Officer Shot by Husband With Her Service Pistol
description: A Jersey City police officer was in the hospital last night after being shot by her husband with her service pistol on Monday night, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, MARTHA (MARGE)
description: BAUM-Martha (Marge), March 23, 1908-January 3, 1999. Beloved wife, devoted sister, loving aunt, grand aunt, great grand aunt and cherished friend to many. Always active in caring and helping people to the very end. We miss you Marge and Ben, together as always, forever. All our love, all our lives-Services Wednesday, 1 PM, at ''the Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment King Solomon Cemetery.

title: Depleted Dolphins Focus on Davis
description: The Miami Dolphins readily acknowledge that Terrell Davis is the Broncos' most indispensable offensive player. Trouble is, the Dolphins are also aware that their two defensive linemen most responsible for holding the National Football League's leading rusher to 29 yards late in the regular season will be missing for the teams' rematch on Saturday in Denver.

title: Friends in Buffalo Reflect On an All-Too-Short Life
description: The first blizzard of the season dumped on Buffalo Monday night. And this morning, after people dug themselves out of their homes, salted their walks and staggered into work, the topic around the water cooler naturally turned to Kendra Webdale, a hometown girl.

title: Firstenergy Acquisitions
description: The Firstenergy Company a utility company in Ohio, said today that it had acquired Dunbar Mechanical Inc. of Toledo, Ohio, and L. H. Cranston & Sons of Timonium, Md., in late December for an undisclosed sum. The heating and air-conditioning companies have combined annual revenue of $91 million. Firstenergy also plans to buy Webb Technologies Inc., a Norfolk, Va., contractor.

title: 2 Chemotherapy Overdoses Lead to Review of Nurses
description: In an action that reopens the question of how much responsibility nurses have to question doctors' orders, a Massachusetts licensing board said yesterday that it had started disciplinary proceedings against 18 nurses in the chemotherapy overdoses of two women in 1994 at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston.

title: Forsaken in Russia's Arctic: 9 Million Stranded Workers
description: Here in Russia's most northern city, a winter's day is two hours of cheerless gray. The temperature plunges to 40 below. And delays in getting wages are measured in years, not months.

title: Jumping on the Pan-American Express; On Menus, the Ticket Is Nuevo Latino
description: FOR years, trend-spotters have trotted out the same old prediction: South American food will be the Next Big Thing in New York restaurants. It's a sleeping giant, they would say, coming any day now. Any day.

title: A Hot, Sweet Taste Of the Spanish North
description: TO the list of ingredients that have jumped from regional specialties to international stars we can add piquillo peppers, crimson beauties from the Navarre region of northeastern Spain. On a plate, these horn-shaped peppers are visually stunning -- you can't see them without wanting to eat them. On the palate, their flavor is a near-perfect blend of sweet and hot, intense but not fiery. And nature could not have designed a better shape for stuffing.

title: Jumping on the Pan-American Express; The Hidden Beauty of Latin Roots
description: THE first impulse of many uninitiated cooks who happen upon root vegetables from Latin America in the market is simply to shake their heads and walk way. These tubers -- brown, bumpy, sometimes even scaly -- look for all the world like miniature logs that were tossed into the vegetable bin by mistake.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUB, HELEN
description: LAUB-Helen. The Laub family deeply mourns the loss of their beloved Helen on January 5, 1999 at the age of 88. She was the linchpin of our family in guiding us to the ultimate in kindness, understanding, ideals, warmth, integrity and love for the arts through her philosophical wit and spirit. The Laub family is most appreciative to her dear friends and neighbors for their devoted kindness to her in her many times of need. A special thank you from the Laub family to Mrs. Sally Riccardi. Visiting on Thursday 6PM-9PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Services will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORSER, PAUL
description: CORSER-Paul. We, the Board of Directors and Staff of the American Foundation for AIDS Research, mourn the loss of our most esteemed colleague and valued friend, Paul Corser, due to AIDS-related complications. A determined warrior in the struggle against AIDS, Paul never lost sight of the needs of people living with HIV/AIDS and was an invaluable inspiration to AmFAR's continuing efforts to bring an end to the AIDS epidemic. His unswerving dedication, rare intelligence, and unfailingly good nature will be sorely missed. As Program Officer, Paul oversaw AmFAR's grantmaking program and in-house activities in clinical research, behavioral sciences, and scientific publications. He previously directed AmFAR's pathbreaking community-based clinical trials program, achieving the creation of a nationwide network of clinical trial centers, and served as associate editor of AmFAR's AIDS/HIV Treatment Directory. Paul also served on the Board of the Lower East Side Harm Reduction Center. Our love and deepest condolences go to Paul's wife, Sally Morrison, and to his family. American Foundation for AIDS Research (AmFAR) Elizabeth Taylor National Founding Chairman Mathilde Krim, Ph.D Founding Co-Chair Jerome J. Radwin Chief Executive Officer and the entire Board of Directors and Staff of AmFAR

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with an article in the arts pages about fears that corporate mergers will lead to a reduction in total corporate donations misstated the year in which Exxon made the contributions shown. It was 1997, not 1977.

title: A New Season Begins With New Questions
description: Beginning a new year at a new site, the 1999 PGA Tour starts this week, with new questions to be answered.

title: AT&T Wins At Home Deal and a Foothold as a Data Carrier
description: Advancing its aspiration to become a major carrier of Internet data, the AT&T Corporation has won a long-term contract to provide the At Home Corporation, the nation's largest provider of cable modem service, with 15,000 miles of high-speed fiber optic lines.

title: THE CHEF
description: THIS is the third incarnation of a dish that started very simply and changed serendipitously. I had a pheasant that I was going to marinate and reached for juniper berries, knowing that juniper and game are a classic combination. And I had it in mind to do something classic, when, crushing the juniper berries, their powerfully fresh, bright fragrance forced me to take a detour. I headed straight for the ginger root, with its similarly crisp, clean fragrance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRENNAN, PHILIP
description: GRENNAN-Philip. Died January 1, 1999. He was the husband of Sally. Father of Christopher, Phyllis Huffman, Christine Stiller and Matthew (deceased). A partner in the architectural firm of Poor and Swanke, he was Chief Design Engineer for all AT&T projects. The first anacoic chamber and renovation of the American Express building in Paris. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: MEAD HAS SOLD OFF $90 MILLION IN LAND AND OTHER ASSETS
description: The Mead Corporation said yesterday that it had sold $90 million in assets, including its Mead Ink Products, and was ahead of its schedule for divesting itself of more than $100 million in assets by mid-1999. Mead, based in Dayton, Ohio, described its core business as the manufacture of coated and specialty papers, packaging paperboard, and school and office products, and said that it had recently sold timberland in Michigan, a warehouse in California and an undeveloped mill site in Tennessee. In October, Mead sold its Ink Products unit to Alper Ink Group L.L.C. of New York for $21 million.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Marshall Perlin, a civil liberties lawyer, misstated his age and the number of his war decorations. He was 78, not 79, and the Air Medal he earned in World War II had three oak-leaf clusters, not two.

title: Shares Record Big Gains, Paced by Technology Issues
description: Stocks rocketed higher yesterday, propelled by a ravenous appetite among investors for technology shares.

title: Jose Vela Zanetti Dies at 85; Painter of Mural at the U.N.
description: Jose Vela Zanetti, a Spanish artist who in the 1950's created the imposing mural ''Mankind's Struggle for a Lasting Peace'' at United Nations headquarters in New York, died on Monday in a hospital in Burgos in northern Spain. He was 85.

title: Dining North of the Border
description: HERE are some of the pan-Latin and South American restaurants that have opened in the last year or so, along with six that serve classic South American cuisine. All are informal, and most are moderately priced, with main courses costing $10 to $20.

title: Aviation Agency Delays Debut of Satellite Navigation System
description: After spending $430 million to begin a ''new era'' of aviation in which planes would use satellite signals for navigation, the Federal Aviation Administration announced a delay today, saying it could not write the software that assures pilots that the system is working and does not know enough about its vulnerability to sabotage.

title: A man of more than one hat finds he likes an unconventional arrangement with Quaker State.
description: IT has long been said that anyone who represents himself or herself in court has a fool for a lawyer and a fool for a client. But the verdict may be somewhat different in the case of a marketing executive who has had himself for an agency and an agency executive who has had himself for a client.

title: The Neediest Cases; 'Little Push' Helps Family to Begin to Right Itself
description: Edward Hillman apologizes when visitors arrive at his family's basement apartment in the Richmond Hill section of Queens.

title: Avoiding a Lengthy Trial
description: The ceremonial start of President Clinton's impeachment trial has been set. Chief Justice William Rehnquist will swear in the senators as jurors tomorrow morning. But the substantive questions as to how the trial will be conducted are still undecided. The reason is that some influential Republicans are blocking the plan of their majority leader, Trent Lott, to move the Senate with appropriate speed toward a censure verdict that conforms with the public will, the evidence against Mr. Clinton and the national interest.

title: A Fast Trial, With All the Facts
description: The Senate is struggling to find a compromise between its obligation to have an impeachment trial and the desire to avoid an extended proceeding. But even a trial in which only essential witnesses testified in person would take months. Doubt that? Consider the amount of time the testimony in this case consumed before the grand jury. Now add cross-examination and rebuttal witnesses. It adds up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALBO, MARIE
description: GALBO-Marie. Of Manhattan on January 4, 1999, beloved wife of the late Vincent J. Galbo, devoted mother Gloria J. Galbo and Vivian J. Mannello, of Waldorf, Maryland. Friends may call Thursday January 7, 1999, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10 A.M. Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Japan Inc. That Can't Say No; Overcapacity in Manufacturing Sector Slows Recovery
description: Some 25 years ago, Itsuhiro Ochi quit his job as a salaryman at a large textile manufacturer and built a factory here to make towels.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Under Pressure, Kellogg Speeds a Shift at the Top
description: The Kellogg Company, struggling to wake up its sleepy breakfast business, said yesterday that its chief executive would be replaced by the executive who had been widely expected to succeed him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, RAE
description: POLLACK-Rae. Temple Israel, Lawrence, New York mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends deepest sympathy to the bereaved family. Brooks R. Susman, Rabbi David M. Land, President

title: Texaco Is Said To Set Payment Over Sex Bias
description: Texaco Inc. has agreed to pay $3.1 million to 186 women who were found by the Labor Department to have been systematically underpaid relative to their male counterparts, people involved in the case said today.

title: Namath Likes Team's Chances
description: Perhaps it is because Vinny Testaverde is a Jet wearing the same style uniform Joe Namath did way back when, or perhaps it's because Sunday's playoff game against Jacksonville is only two days shy of the 30th anniversary of the most famous Super Bowl of all, but Namath said yesterday that, yes, the Jets could do it again this year.

title: INSIDE
description: Congo Missionaries Report Massacre of 500 Villagers

title: CALENDAR
description: The Icemen Come to City Hall

title: Cambodia Faces Past
description: To the Editor:

title: An Analytical Channel
description: There may be plenty of news on the air, but much of it lacks substance and analysis, in the opinion of the Freedom Forum, a nonpartisan foundation focused on media studies, and WETA, the public-television station serving the Washington area. The two have joined to start a cable channel devoted to analyzing and interpreting news -- a sort of round-the-clock ''News Hour with Jim Lehrer.'' It will also carry other public affairs programs.

title: Spiced to Give Off Heat and Light
description: THE food sounds prosaic at DIMPLE, a bright little vegetarian Indian takeout spot just off 37th Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens. Ask the woman behind the counter what she's including in your thali, a selection of little dishes for $6, and she is straightforward, if not especially descriptive. ''Lentils,'' she says, ''some potatoes, cabbage and soup.'' It sounds like a nightmare of vegetarian cuisine.

title: Scenes From a Marriage, This Time Mom and Dad's
description: In ''Private Confessions,'' an unfaithful wife hesitates beside the telephone, wondering whether to call her lover. Were it not for this scene's period clothing and antique instrument, there would be little about the moment to anchor it in 1925, though that is when most of this sensitively acted, extraordinarily pedigreed film takes place.

title: Season Is On, Now It's Who, What, When and Where?
description: Finding a way to cram a six-month season into three months while maintaining its legitimacy has now become the key issue confronting the National Basketball Association in the wake of the deal that settles its labor dispute.

title: Immigrant Dies While Detained By the I.N.S.
description: A Dominican immigrant, who for two days complained of chest pains and a persistent cough, died on Monday at a Federal detention center in lower Manhattan without having been examined by a doctor, fellow detainees and Federal officials said yesterday.

title: Northrop to Take a Charge; Profits Seen Below Analyst Forecasts
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation, the nation's largest maker of airframes for commercial aircraft, said yesterday that it would take a $125 million fourth-quarter charge and that 1999 annual profits would be about 20 percent below expectations because of the downturn in demand by Asian countries for Boeing 747's.

title: Airtouch Now Tries to Pick the Best Partner
description: Representatives of three telecommunications giants holed up in New York offices yesterday as negotiators met to discuss which company would be the best partner for Airtouch Communications, the nation's largest independent wireless carrier.

title: Modernism Rerun: Ballet, at 50, in Leotards
description: It was a capital idea for the New York City Ballet to move both into repertory and into high gear in its 50th-anniversary season on Tuesday night with four gloriously danced ballets that George Balanchine choreographed to Igor Stravinsky's music.

title: Irish Debate Forums Are Reined In by AOL
description: America Online has decided that subscribers who favor or oppose Irish nationalism can continue their heated disagreements in AOL's on-line forums, but they're going to have to be more cordial about it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNHEIM, PALMER
description: TURNHEIM-Palmer, 77. Retired Executive Vice President of First Union National Bank and retired Senior Vice President of the Chase Manhattan Bank, on Monday at home of pancreatic cancer. Advisor to the U.S. government on cash management, member of the U.S. Government Advisory Committee on Gas Rationing, key negotiator in the New York City fiscal crisis, World War II radio operator 10th U.S. Army Air Force, China-Burma-India theater, active Former Alumni Board Officer for New York University, Stern School of Business, Member of Harvard's 42nd AMP Class, Beta Gamma Sigma member and former director, former Director of the New York State Bankers Association, former President of United Cerebral Palsy Associations, former UCP Humanitarian and Firestone awards recipient, and Director of the Fund for Theological Education, Princeton, NJ, former member, Zoning Board of Adjustment of Mountain Lakes, founding member of Prince of Peace Lutheran Church, and former Trustee of Zion Lutheran Church. Beloved husband of the late Gloria Freer Turnheim, beloved father of Joy K. Turnheim and the late Nancy Elizabeth Turnheim, loving brother of Esther Kolbjornsen, loving uncle of Ruth Nybro and Art Kolbjornsen, loving friend of Ruth Larsen, and cherished ''Uncle'' to many. Viewing at the Norman Dean Home for Services, Denville, New Jersey, Wednesday, 7-9PM and Thursday, 2-4PM, 7-9PM. Funeral service at Zion Lutheran Church, 505 Watchogue Road, Staten Island, New York, at 10 A.M., on Friday, January 8. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Zion Lutheran Church, United Cerebral Palsy Research and Educational foundation for New York University Stern School of Business.

title: More Than a Good Morning
description: After several sleepy years, ABC News has finally decided to do something about ''Good Morning America,'' a daily decaffeination that now ranks a distant second in the networks' wake-up time slot. Like CBS, whose morning show has struggled for years, ABC seemed inclined to cede this rich territory to NBC's ''Today,'' where the warm chatter is paired with a daily bracing of hard, cold news.

title: 'The End' for a SoHo Institution
