description: AFTER 17 years, Wolfman-Gold and Good Company, the SoHo institution that put white dinnerware and oversize platters on New Yorkers' tables, is closing.

title: Return to Work Prompts General Feeling of Relief
description: For Jalen Rose of the Indiana Pacers, there were no high-fives in the elevators or chest-thumps in the lobby of the GM Building as scores of National Basketball Association players, grimaces chiseled on their faces, made their way from yesterday's meeting to ratify the new collective bargaining agreement.

title: Auto Industry Finds Surprises At the End of a Rainbow Year
description: Last month was the best for auto sales since December 1986, lifting the industry's sales for 1998 to the highest level in a dozen years despite a nearly eight-week strike last summer from which the General Motors Corporation has not fully recovered.

title: He Got Game Again, and It's About Time
description: IT'S been a rough three months for Spike Lee, the filmmaker and famous Knicks fan, who has weathered the lockout as well as can be expected for a man who once jetted back from the Cannes Film Festival rather than miss a regular game. ''Actually I flew back twice in one week,'' he said.

title: Red Storm Goes South, As Does Its Game
description: All Ron Artest could remember near the end tonight was University of Miami forward Dwayne Wimbley's pointing a finger at St. John's players and laughing.

title: Detective's Kindness Helps Awaken City; After a Death, Poughkeepsie Notices Its 3,000 Mexicans and Their Roots
description: On the night of April 10, the police radio crackled out a report that a man riding a bicycle had been struck and killed by a hit-and-run driver.

title: FCB FINANCIAL SHARES RISE ON ANCHOR BANCORP TAKEOVER
description: Shares of the FCB Financial Corporation rose 38 percent yesterday after Anchor Bancorp Wisconsin Inc. said it had agreed to buy it for $172 million in stock. Anchor Bancorp, based in Madison, Wis., will pay shareholders of FCB Financial 1.83 shares of Anchor Bancorp for each FCB Financial share. That valued FCB shares at $44.03 when the purchase was announced after the close of trading on Tuesday. The stock of FCB Financial, which is based in Oshkosh, Wis., rose $10.25 each, to $37. Anchor's stock dropped $2.9375, to $21.125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEMAN, LAWRENCE S.
description: ROSEMAN-Lawrence S. Of Forest Hills, New York. Age 69. Died January 5, 1999. Deeply beloved husband of Audrey. Beloved father of Donna and Jeffrey. Dear father-in-law of Edward. Loving brother of Rosalind and Daniel. Most cherished grandfather of Emma Faye. Loving uncle of Steven, Abbey, and Beth. His love, wisdom and compassion will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Services to be held at Riverside Funeral Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, at 10 AM. on Thursday, January 7.

title: Dow and the Other Leading Gauges Advance to Highs
description: Stock prices rocketed to new heights yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average breaking the 9,500 mark as it climbed 233.78 points, the biggest gain since Oct. 15, to pass its previous record set just before Thanksgiving.

title: Trading Wheels for Hope on a Road Less Traveled
description: DUANE'S DEPRESSED

title: Corrections
description: An inset photograph in Weekend on Friday showing Charles Simonds's ''Dwelling,'' an installation depicting an adobe ruin at the Whitney Museum of American Art, with the continuation of a Critic's Notebook article about New York museums' permanent collections, was reproduced sideways. The adobe dwelling should have appeared above the hills, not at the right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUFFER, DR. PAUL G.I.
description: LAUFFER-Dr. Paul G.I., former President of the Society of Cosmetic Chemists, died on January 4, 1999 in Newtown, Bucks County, PA. He was 98. He received the SCC Maison G. De Navarre Award in 1962, and was a Director of the Association in the 1950's and 60's. He began a seminal report in cosmetic chemistry entitled, ''New Keys to Cosmetic Chemistry.'' It served as basic instruction to young scientists entering the field of cosmetic chemistry. Dr. Lauffer was born in Farmersville, OH in 1900. He graduated from Washington and Jefferson College and received an M.S. in Chemistry, and in 1926, a Ph.D. in Organic Chemistry from Columbia University. He was Chief Chemist at Pinaud Inc. and George W. Luft Co. and Research Director for Northern Warren Corp. until its merger with Cheseborough Ponds where he was Principal Research Chemist. On retirement in 1965 he was a consultant to Merl Corp. until 1972 when he retired to Arizona where he continued to write ''New Keys'' through 1985. Dr. Lauffer was Mayor of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY from 1949 to 1950. Since 1989 he resided in Bucks County, PA with his daughter, Elizabeth Biester of Furlong, PA. He is also survived by a daughter-in-law, Patricia Lauffer, seven grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. His first wife, Jean Robertson, predeceased him in 1959, his second wife, Doris Adams, died in 1989 and his son, John Lauffer, also predeceased him in 1986.

title: Progress in Move for Law On Building Sprinklers
description: After accusing each other of blocking safety laws that might have averted recent fire deaths, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council now say they are cooperating to adopt tougher rules for sprinklers in apartment buildings.

title: November New-Home Sales Hit a High
description: Sales of new homes rose in November to a record, which should bolster economic growth in coming months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALEN, ELI
description: MALEN-Eli. The Board of Trustees, Officers, Administrators and Faculty mourn the passing of the father of our esteemed past president Ronald Malen and pray the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. William Helmreich, President North Shore Hebrew Academy

title: Boat Crewman Dies in Sea And Three Men Are Missing
description: A crew member of a clamming boat died and three men were missing last night when their 84-foot boat foundered in rough seas and sank in the Atlantic 13 miles off Manasquan, N.J., the Coast Guard said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POST, RIKI
description: POST-Riki. Our dearest friend; always there for us and a devoted partner. Goodbye, Mrs. Charlie. With deepest condolences to the family. Barbara and Jim

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITTELMAN, BEATRICE
description: MITTELMAN-Beatrice. Loving mother of Fred, Sara and Amy. Grandmother of Louis, Alan, Louise and Theresa. Devoted widow of Louis Mittelman and cherished sister of Ruth Block and Martin Stewart. Died peacefully January 5th. Serivces Friday, January 8th, 9AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAXON, DON
description: SAXON-Don. January 5, 1999. Beloved husband of Bernice, loving father of Jan, Robert and stepsons Marc and Glenn Gross. Service Friday, January 8, 1999, 1:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St.

title: Full Trial Allows Airing of Evidence
description: To the Editor:

title: Full Trial Allows Airing of Evidence
description: To the Editor:

title: Rowland Vows to Rein In State Spending
description: John Grosvenor Rowland showed two political faces as he was inaugurated today for a second term as Governor of Connecticut, calling for civility and moderation in government even as he vowed to rein in state spending despite the economic boom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANLON, R. BRENDAN
description: HANLON-R. Brendan. Died of cardiac arrest at his home in Marshfield, MA, on January 2, 1999, at the age of 62. Brendan was an actor, author, accountant, jazz enthusiast, a rare literary man, and an illustrious raconteur on practically everything from the Marx Brothers to poet Seamus Heaney. He appeared in a number of films shot in Boston and New York, including ''A Civil Action'', ''Good Will Hunting'', ''Meet Joe Black'', ''The Spanish Prisoner'', and the 1998 film ''Dirty Laundry'', starring Jay Thomas, where he was featured as a gynecologist. Brendan wrote a book entitled ''The New Tax Guide for Performers, Writers, Directors, Designers and Other Show Biz Folk'', that remains a definitive guideline for artists and their taxes. Brendan was born in Boston, graduated from Boston Latin High School, earned a bachelor's degree in theater and speech at Emerson College, and did graduate work in theatre and literature at Smith College. He lived and worked in New York City before moving to Marshfield. He leaves behind his wife, Marjorie J. Hanlon, and his daughter Nell Anna O'Dea Hanlon of Marshfield, and his sisters and brothers all of Massachusetts: Kathleen Fulton and Maureen Smith of Sandwich, Robert Hanlon of Pembroke, and George Hanlon, of Carver. He also leaves behind 23 nieces and nephews as well as many, many broken-hearted friends and admirers. Brendan will survive in the memory of all who had the pleasure of knowing him. A memorial service will be held at 2 p.m. Saturday, at the First Parish Unitarian Universalist Church in Duxbury, MA, where Brendan had founded and operated the Fine Performance Concert Series and was also an active member. Burial services will be private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Social Responsibility Committee of the First Parish Unitarian Universalist Church, P.O. Box 1764, Duxbury, MA. 02331-1764.

title: INTIMATE BRANDS REPORTS STRONG FOURTH-QUARTER SALES
description: Intimate Brands Inc. said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would top expectations, as sales surged in December at its Victoria's Secret and Bath and Body Works stores. The company, the biggest United States retailer of lingerie and bath products, said it expected earnings to be 2 cents a share higher than the average estimate of 93 cents among analysts polled by the First Call Corporation. A year earlier it earned 79 cents a share before charges. The company, based in Columbus, Ohio, said sales in December rose 9 percent, to $905.4 million, from $831.5 million a year earlier. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 6 percent in the five-week month, which ended last Saturday. Intimate Brands shares' rose $1.625 each, to $31.625.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Maybe Less Basketball Is More
description: Now that the National Basketball Association lockout is apparently over, the league will be scrambling to save its season and to woo back fans. But in fact the long layoff and, more important, the shortened season may work to everyone's advantage.

title: Watching the Trial: Limited Tickets
description: Fifty seats of the 596-seat Senate gallery will be allocated to the general public ech day during the impeachment tria. Tickets will be handed out one hour before the proceedings begi on a first-come, first-served basis at the tour entrances to the Capitol. Most tickets go to various Government officials to hand out at their discretion.

title: Governor Pataki's State of Mind
description: Freshly re-elected, Gov. George Pataki gave a State of the State address yesterday that was a disappointing effort to make the incremental sound grand. Politically unadventurous, the speech allowed New York's Governor to stick to his old, comfortable issues. He was tough on crime and taxes and offered a jot for education, a tittle on the environment. In a long hour, however, Mr. Pataki spoke for only a few seconds on health care, not a word on how to allocate the tobacco settlement and one sentence, an afterthought perhaps, promising to clean up the state's abysmal campaign finance system.

title: Sports of The Times; For Commissioner Stern, a Battle Is Won but an Image Is Changed
description: A FEW minutes past three in the afternoon, with a salvaged season and unprecedented union concessions in his pocket, David Stern took the longest elevator ride of his 15-year life as commissioner, from the low ground he had taken in dealing with his desperate players, to the 25th floor of the Fifth Avenue high-rise where about half of them were waiting.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Robust Start To '99 Dazzles Stock Investors
description: Nothing but up. So said stock markets around the world yesterday, wowing investors with one-day gains of better than 2 percent and in some markets, more than 3 percent.

title: 2 Votes in House Are Defended as Not in Conflict
description: Last month, they voted for articles of impeachment that call for the removal of President Clinton from office. Two days later, they urged the Senate to consider censuring, not removing, the President. Then today, they voted to reappoint the 13 House managers whose job will be to convince the Senate to convict Mr. Clinton -- and thus remove him from office.

title: Acer May Delay $200 Million Stock Sale
description: The personal computer maker Acer Inc., one of Taiwan's most visible companies, said that because of the nation's recent stock market slump it might delay a $200 million international share sale that it began arranging last July. Shares of Acer tumbled 13 percent last month. Taiwan's benchmark index hit a two-and-a-half year low on Tuesday.

title: Buyer of a Church Was No Benefactor
description: Members of a struggling Southern Baptist church on the edge of Park Slope were thrilled several years ago when a developer surfaced to rescue them from financial trouble.

title: Queens Man Arrested In Clerk's Fatal Stabbing
description: A 19-year-old Queens man was arrested yesterday on charges that he stabbed and bludgeoned to death a clerk at a Laundromat during a robbery last month, the police said.

title: Sideline Or Booth? Reeves's Call Today
description: Since he needed just two years to turn a franchise best known for losing into a division champion with Super Bowl aspirations, perhaps it's no surprise that Atlanta Coach Dan Reeves plans another extraordinary comeback this weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASS, LEONARD
description: BASS-Leonard. Beloved husband of Marion. Loving father of Barbara and Michael, Janet and George, David and Ronnie, and Shari and Russell. Adored grandfather of Elissa, Evan, Lauren, Stephanie, Sarah, and Emily. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, 11:30 AM, Thursday.

title: MINDSPRING IS IN $245 MILLION DEAL WITH ICG
description: Less than a year after acquiring Netcom, a big Internet service provider, for $284 million, ICG Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell most of Netcom's operations to Mindspring Enterprises Inc., another Internet provider, for $245 million in cash and stock. For ICG, a new local phone carrier, the deal ended a mostly disappointing experiment in providing retail ''dial up'' Internet service. While ICG kept Netcom's network of roughly 45,000 modems, it sold Netcom's United States customers to Mindspring. J. Shelby Bryan, ICG's chief executive, said he hoped to sell Netcom's overseas units within a few weeks. ICG's shares dipped 18.75 cents yesterday, to $22.9375. But Mindspring's shares leaped by $8.5625 each, to $75.125, as the deal increased its customer base by around 60 percent.

title: After Fluff, A Fat-Free Production
description: What is a poor opera company to do? Or for that matter, a rich one?

title: Pucci for the Home
description: ''Everything Pucci sells like crazy,'' said Cameron Silver, owner of Decades, a boutique for high-end 1960's and 70's couture and accessories. But, he said, people often prefer to have Pucci around the house rather than to wear it. Mr. Silver recyles Pucci fabric as cushion covers, $200 to $400, left; he upholsters chairs and footstools in Pucci, even makes Pucci art (framed scarves). Mr. Silver, who started collecting vintage clothing while touring as a torch singer, sells Pucciana at his store, 8214 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles; (323) 655-0223.

title: Stocks Score With the News
description: The settlement of the National Basketball Association strike may not have been the main reason behind a powerful stock rally yesterday, but it didn't hurt.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KIEFFER, MARTIN
description: KIEFFER-Martin. On November 16, in Colmar, France, after a long illness. The Lycee Francais de New York mourns his passing. Professor of History & Geography from 1955 until his retirement in 1986. Ph.D., Columbia 1960, sports enthusiast, outstanding educator and friend. Memorial service on Wednesday, January 13, at 6 PM. Madison Avenue Presbysterian Church at 73rd Street, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABINOWITZ, SOL
description: RABINOWITZ-Sol. Of Hackensack, N.J. Beloved husband of the late Miriam. Devoted father of Jonathan Rabinowitz, Barbara Goldstein & Judith Rabinowitz. Loving grandfather of five grandchildren. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ, Thursday at Noon. Contributions to Parkinson's Disease Center at RWJ University Hospital Foundation, 16 Scott St, New Brunswick, NJ 08901 would be appreciated. For information call 1-800-522-0588.

title: Address by Minority Leader At Opening of 106th Congress
description: Following are the comments of Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader, at the opening session of the new House today, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Remarks to Congress by Dennis Hastert in His First Day as Speaker of the House
description: Following are the remarks today by Representative Dennis Hastert, the Illinois Republican who was elected Speaker, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: With a Doomed Contract, It Can Pay to Be Sneaky
description: Many experts find team play to be the most satisfying form of the game, since it eliminates the artificial striving for overtricks that is a feature of pairs play. The Greater New York Bridge Association therefore recognizes the player who does best in team competition in a calendar year, and the 1998 title went to Tom Smith of Greenwich, Conn., with William Ehlers of West Orange, N.J. in second position.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I guess we both blinked.''

title: Building Up to Bedrock
description: DESIGNING a home can be fraught with anxiety. In Norah Pierson's case, it was a real cliffhanger.

title: INSIDE
description: Stocks Surge to Records As Dow Climbs 233.78

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECK, DAVID WARNER
description: PECK-David Warner. On January 2, 1999. Dear husband of Susan Harfield Peck. Father of Heather, Lisa and David. Brother of M. Scott Peck and son of the late Judge David W. and Elizabeth Peck. Stepfather to Amanda, Susie and Tony Leness. Phillips Exeter Academy '50, Princeton '54 and Harvard Business School '59. Funeral service at Saint Mark's Church, Westhampton Beach, at noon on Saturday, January 9. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the Quogue Association, P.O. Box 671, Quogue, New York 11959.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWIMMER, IRVING
description: SCHWIMMER-Irving. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges with deep sadness the death of Irving Schwimmer, beloved father of our esteemed colleague, Alan Schwimmer, D.D.S., Chief of Dental Medicine in the Department of Otolaryngology. To Dr. Schwimmer, the entire Schwimmer family, and to all who loved him, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO Jerome S. Breslaw, M.D. President of the Medical Board Roy B. Sessions, M.D. Chairman, Dept. of Otolaryngology

title: Brokers Said to Agree to S.E.C. Fines
description: About two dozen brokerage firms, including many of Wall Street's biggest, will agree to pay millions of dollars in fines under a settlement with regulators that will conclude the Federal investigation of trading abuses on the Nasdaq stock market, lawyers involved with the talks said today, confirming a report in The Wall Street Journal.

title: Sports of The Times; A Lockout, Not Love-In, For Players
description: This was not the Armageddon I'd been waiting for.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATSAKIS, STEVEN C.
description: MATSAKIS-Steven C., of Wyckoff, N.J., died Tuesday, January 5, 1999, at the Hackensack University Medical Center. Beloved son of Victoria (nee Lucas) and the late Constantinos Matsakis, who died in 1986. Cherished husband of Mary (nee Finlayson), and adored father of Louise. Much loved brother of Demetrios and Nicholas. The grandson of an immigrant, Steve was born May 1, 1958, in Passaic, N.J., grew up in Rutherford, resided in Lyndhurst for 15 years before moving to Wyckoff 3 years ago. Mr. Matsakis attended the Rutherford public schools, received his undergraduate degree from New York University, graduating Summa Cum Laude, and also received his M.B.A. from N.Y.U. He began his career at Bankers Trust Company and in 1980 was elevated to the position of Vice President of the Corporate Finance Department. He later became an Executive Vice President of the Atlantic Bank of New York City. He was also C.E.O. and Cofounder of super Video Stores that started with one store in 1987 and flourished into a 14 store chain in northern New Jersey. In 1996 the company was sold to West Coast Entertainment Corp. Steve was a strong believer in the values and wonderful opportunities America provided. To help others Steve recently established a scholarship fund to benefit Rutherford High School graduates. His loving and passionate persona will be greatly missed. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral on Saturday, January 9, 1999, 9:15 AM, from the Thomas J. Diffily Funeral Home, 41 Ames Ave in Rutherford, and 10 AM at St. George Greek Orthodox Church in Clifton, N.J. Interment at Hillside Cemetery in Lyndhurst, N.J. Visiting Thursday & Friday, 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Victoria & Costantinos Scholarship Fund at the Rutherford High School, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARWOOD, DEAN B.
description: HARWOOD-Dean B., 38, of Lake Forest, beloved husband of Kathleen; loving father of Cullen, Molly, Brooke, and Graham; dear son of Jerome and Ruthella Harwood; fond brother of Jill Legler. His intelligence, charm and irrepressible wit will be greatly missed. Memorial service 11 A.M. Thursday, Jan. 7, 1999 at the First Presbyterian Church of Lake Forest, 700 N. Sheridan Rd., Lake Forest, Illinois. Visitation 5 to 9 P.M. Wednesday at Wenban Funeral Home, 320 E. Vine Avenue, Lake Forest, IL. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Dean B. Harwood Children's Educational, Fund, c/o Gelber Securities, 141 W. Jackson Boulevard, Suite 2150, Chicago, IL. 60604. Information 847-234-0022.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERK, JOSEPH, D.D.S.
description: BERK-Joseph, D.D.S. Beloved brother, uncle and friend. Donations to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, c/o Beth Israel Hospital, NYC.

title: Surf the Net by Telephone? That May Be Possible Soon
description: Several high-tech companies are working on a ''telephone browser'' that will enable users to surf the Internet by speaking into the telephone.

title: Union Leader Faced Mutiny From Members
description: For six months, the members of the National Basketball Players Association were, with the occasional fractious dissent, a unified outfit, following the lead of their negotiators and appearing proud of what many outsiders regarded as a surprising show of strength in the face of enormous financial losses.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FREYDBERG, VI
description: FREYDBERG-Vi. Missing you with all our hearts, especially on January 7th. We were the luckiest daughters in the world because you were our mom. Judy and Susa

title: At Brooklyn Academy, An International Lineup
description: Dramas old and new, early choral music and opera, and a play staged by Ingmar Bergman are part of the 1999 spring season that began this week at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: New Jersey to Provide Full-Day Preschool in Its 28 Poorest Districts
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced yesterday that the state would provide full-day preschool education for all 3- and 4-year-olds in the state's 28 poorest urban districts, an early childhood program that experts say may be the most comprehensive in the country.

title: Hastert Is Sworn In as 51st Speaker and Puts Forth a Conciliatory Tone
description: Representative Dennis Hastert was sworn in today as the 51st Speaker of the House and offered his low-key, workhorse style as an antidote to the inflammatory politics that have paralyzed the Capitol.

title: It May Have Seen a Lot of Miles, but It's Home
description: Bruce Campbell has heard all the jokes, thank you very much. He knows he has bought himself a real fixer-upper. He knows his project will never fly -- not anymore, that is. When guests come to visit at his new home, they will inevitably ask whether they have to keep their safety belts fastened, and whether it is time to return their chairs to a locked upright position.

title: Rare, Delicate Books You Can Maul to Your Heart's Content
description: OCTAVO, a company that puts rare books onto CD-ROM's, avoids the sound and fury of quick-time movies, computer animation and musical scores. Instead, lush printed pages are the bells and whistles of Octavo's elegant, searchable, printable, magnifiable renderings of first editions by Milton, Shakespeare, Copernicus and other masters of the printed medium.

title: 4 Childbirth Specialists Challenge U.S. Goal of Reducing Caesarean Births
description: Four leading childbirth specialists in Boston are challenging the Federal Government's goal to reduce the rate of Caesarean births, saying the effort could in fact be endangering some mothers and their babies.

title: Fashion Shoot Decor
description: If you feel you keep seeing the same Barcelona chair or Hermann Miller period stool in photo spreads, maybe you do. That's because Bruce Kramer, the owner of Sunset Studios West, includes furnishings in the package for the shoot. His studios are stocked with classic modern furniture for clients to use.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column on Dec. 22, citing a BBC News report, misstated the number of Peruvian women in poor areas who underwent forced sterilization in the last three years according to an investigation by the Latin American and Caribbean Committee for the Defense of Women's Rights. Many of the 250,000 women who were sterilized in the last three years were forced to undergo the procedure, but not all.

title: The Great Pork Gap; Hog Prices Have Plummeted. Why Haven't Store Prices?
description: Inside a giant Dominick's Supermarket here, Sam Ventura was buying some high-grade pork chops.

title: Preventing Subway Tragedies
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: As Stocks Rise on the Continent, Euro Falls Against the Dollar
description: The euro fell sharply against the dollar yesterday, marring what was expected to be a pleasant honeymoon after the currency's introduction on Monday. A drop of 1.5 percent to a value of $1.15920 left the new currency below the initial reference rate of $1.16675 set on Dec. 31.

title: In Congress, The Theme Is Resilience
description: For all the impeachment foreboding washing about the corridors of the Capitol today, the new Congress first faced the vital routine of democracy and the unabashed joy of its political survivors.

title: Net Presence: If No One Sees a Web Site, Is It Really There?
description: HOMESTEADING on the World Wide Web can be a lonely proposition.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SWANSON, ELSTON H.
description: SWANSON-Elston H., past Chairman of the YMCA of Long Island died on December 27, 1998 at his home in Florida. A memorial service will be held at the Sea Cliff Gospel Church on Sea Cliff Avenue in Sea Cliff on Saturday, January 9 at 1:45 P.M.

title: Union Suspends Three Top Officials in Inquiry Into Mismanagement of Funds
description: The executive board of a union local representing more than 2,500 New York City emergency medical technicians and paramedics has suspended its president, vice president and secretary treasurer on allegations of financial wrongdoing.

title: In 'Phedre,' A Mix of Lust, Anger and Chic
description: If you live in the world of Jean Racine, the 17th-century French tragedian, you definitely don't want to mess with Venus. The goddess of love is also, as one of the dramatist's characters puts it, the ''goddess of pure remorseless cruelty.'' She's implacable and unbeatable, and she takes no prisoners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYSOHIR, WALTER
description: LYSOHIR-Walter. Died January 1, 1999 of Boynton Beach, Florida, formerly of Queens, NY. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, uncle, brother. Reposing at Fred H. McGrath & Son, 20 Cedar Street, Bronxville, NY. Visitation Friday, 5 PM-8 PM. Cemetery service on Saturday, 10:30 AM.

title: Goro Yamaguchi, 65, a Master Of Traditional Japanese Music
description: Goro Yamaguchi, a player of the shakuhachi, or wooden flute, who was named a ''living national treasure'' in Japan and who introduced the instrument to many Western listeners, died on Sunday in Tokyo. He was 65 and lived in Tokyo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBLATT, FLORENCE
description: GOLDBLATT-Florence. On January 6. Beloved wife for 53 years of Aaron Goldblatt; caring mother of Susan Wolk and Michael Goldblatt; devoted mother-in-law of Lawrence Wolk; loving grandmother of Adam and Daniel. Member of the A.S.I.D., senior designer at W. & J. Sloane Co., and owner of Country Collector Antique business. Memories of her caring nature and the love and joy which she brought to others will live on. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Hospice of Orange, 800 Stony Brook Court, Newburgh, NY 12550 are appreciated. Services Friday, January 8, 11 AM at Monroe Temple of Liberal Judaism, Monroe, NY. Interment in Cedar Hill Cemetery, Middle Hope, NY. For information Quackenbush Funeral Home, Monroe, NY.

title: Improved Koznick Sheds Notes and Pounds
description: If she had had her way, Kristina Koznick would have preferred a career on the diamond. Instead, without regrets and with impressive results on the World Cup tour, her life is on the slopes.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Dec. 26 about concern over drug use in the Olympic movement misstated the action taken against the German runner Uta Pippig after a test in 1998 showed an elevated hormone ratio. She was suspended according to international rules pending the completion of an inquiry. She was not officially punished for cheating.

title: Arts Council Chairman Resigns
description: Earle I. Mack, an arts patron and former real estate developer who helped restore financial aid to the arts in New York State to a level not seen in nearly a decade, has resigned as chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts.

title: Residential Sales
description: MANHATTAN

title: Teen People to Start National Campaign
description: Teen People magazine in New York is beginning a national campaign for its first anniversary, with a budget estimated at $1 million. Commercials feature the pop group 'N Sync, which also appears on the cover of the January issue of Teen People, published by the Time Inc. unit of Time Warner Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIEDER, ETHEL
description: WIEDER-Ethel. 92. Died peacefully on January 5, 1999. Beloved mother of Amy Ellner and the late Grace Wieder. Dear mother-in-law of Gene Ellner. Devoted grandmother of Joey, Nancy, and the late Eddie Ellner. Ethel was a very special woman known for her sharp intellect, great wit and generosity of spirit. She will be remembered fondly by all those who knew her.

title: Excerpts From Speech Of Rowland to Legislature
description: Following are excerpts from the State of the State address delivered today by Gov. John G. Rowland to a joint session of the Connecticut General Assembly as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Israel's Crowd-Pleasing General Throws His (Civilian) Hat In
description: Amnon Lipkin-Shahak, the telegenic former army Chief of Staff, formally announced his centrist candidacy for Prime Minister today, casting his first dart, a particularly pointed one, at Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Lawyers for Shooting Victims Clash With Top Gun Makers
description: Lawyers for major gun makers and wholesalers and for the families of six people killed with illegally possessed handguns clashed sharply in a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday over whether the companies were liable for the slayings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, CHARLES T.
description: COOK-Charles T., of Dublin, NH and Brooksville, FL, formerly of New York City died January 2, in Florida after a brief illness. Former teacher at the Browning School and Collegiate School, NYC. Survived by a daughter, Tracy C. Wagoner of Wilbraham, MA; stepchildren James Y. Brame III, Hartford, CT, Margaret S. Gurney of Dublin, NH; brother of Thomas Cook of Newtown, PA, Grace Ramus and Jane Taylor both of Princeton, NJ, and five grandchildren. Services January 9, at 11:00 AM at St. James Episcopal Church, Keene, NH. In lieu of flowers, donations to Brantwood Camp, The Cook Scholarship Fund, c/o Linzee Coolidge, 101 Tremont St, Ste 1000, Boston, MA 02108. Jellison Funeral Home, Peterborough, NH.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Pataki Gets Laugh Alluding to Gaffe

title: Singtel to Buy 19% Of Thailand Company
description: Singapore Telecommunications Ltd. said yesterday that it would pay $317 million for an 18.6 percent stake in Advanced Info Service, Thailand's largest mobile phone company, in a bid to expand in Asia as it faces more competition at home. The purchase price, 230 baht ($6.31) a share, is a 14 discount to Advanced Info's closing price of 270 baht. Singtel will buy 14.3 million shares from the majority shareholder, Shinawatra Computer and Communications, Thailand's monopoly satellite operator, and 36 million new shares.

title: Dwarf Galaxies May Hold More Dark Matter, New Studies Show
description: Compared to luminous giant galaxies like the Milky Way, dwarf galaxies are faint and fuzzy, like celestial ghosts. Yet they may outnumber the giants and apparently harbor far denser concentrations of invisible dark matter, the enigmatic stuff that constitutes nearly all the mass of the universe. astronomers reported here today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARBER, VIOLA
description: FARBER-Viola. The Board, staff and artists of the Danspace Project mourn the loss of Viola Farber, a master teacher and unique presence in our community. Her spirit, though sorely missed, will live on in the many dancers whose lives and work she has touched. Karen Brosius, President Laurie Uprichard, Exec Dir.

title: A FULL IMPEACHMENT TRIAL, INCLUDING VOTE ON ARTICLES, LIKELY AS COMPROMISE FADES
description: Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, said tonight that the Senate was getting ''closer and closer'' to a plan for a full trial of President Clinton that could last into February and would end with an actual vote on the two articles of impeachment.

title: Vanity, Thy Name Is (Insert I.S.P.)
description: Die-hard fans of the band Kiss can do more to show devotion to their rock idols than just buy CD's. They can now join Kissonline.net, the official Internet service provider of the band.

title: Bell Atlantic Seeks to Show Its System Is Open to Rivals
description: Trying to show that its network is open to competitors, the Bell Atlantic Corporation intends to announce today that it has developed a system that would allow its New York customers to change local phone companies almost as easily as they switch long-distance carriers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONKOWSKI, JADZIA
description: KONKOWSKI - Jadzia. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the sister of its esteemed Trustees, Mr. Bernard Bernard and Mr. Albert Blinbaum, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi, Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres., David Yagoda, Chairman, Dr. William Schwartz, President

title: Republicans to Push for a Tax Cut of Up to $500 Billion
description: Key Republicans in the House and the Senate said today that they planned to push for a tax cut of as much as $500 billion over the next decade, including cuts in income tax rates, to take advantage of Federal budget surpluses that appear to be growing faster than previously projected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTTERMAN, FRANCES
description: GUTTERMAN-Frances. Formerly of Bay Harbour Island, FL and Jersey City, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Irving R. Gutterman and also of the late Joseph Gottlieb. Dear mother of Barbara Wolfson and John Gottlieb. Step-mother of Stephen and Henry Gutterman. Adored sister of Sydell Feinberg and Jack Schultz. Cherished grandmother of Ronald, Jill and Mia and great-grandmother of Max and Mollie. Funeral services will be held at The Chapel at Beth Israel Memorial Park, Woodbridge, New Jersey, on Thursday January 7th at 1 P.M.

title: Bad Deal for Pensioners
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Jordan Back When N.B.A. Is?
description: Now that the big question of whether there will be a National Basketball Association season has seemingly been settled, one more big question remains:

title: Full Trial Allows Airing of Evidence
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance Is Enhanced On an Interactive Site
description: An innovative display of dance and digital technology has found a home on the Web. Ghostcatching, ''a virtual dance installation,'' features original movements by the choreographer Bill T. Jones that have been captured and digitally manipulated by a new media studio in New York called Riverbed. The Ghostcatching Web site (www.cooper.edu/art/ghostcatching) offers an interactive view of the installation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANON, HERBERT
description: KANON-Herbert, Beloved husband of Rosalind, dear father of Leon (Eugenia), proud grandfather of Jordan, Evan and Corey.

title: Johnson's Trial: 2 Bitter Months for a Still-Torn Nation
description: It was the hottest ticket to the biggest show in town, a pink piece of pasteboard about the size of a dollar bill but worth much more that fevered spring of 1868.

title: Small Changes Could Improve Police Hiring, Panel Says
description: Though it does a good job weeding out people with criminal backgrounds, the New York Police Department could improve the overall quality of its officers by administering polygraph tests to new recruits and more aggressively investigating their backgrounds, a mayoral panel said yesterday.

title: Profitable Forecasts
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Are Done In by Devils Again
description: One of these nights, one of these years, the Rangers will beat the Devils in a regular-season game. Twice last night they scored power-play goals to take early leads on their New Jersey rivals at Madison Square Garden. With the Devils missing two regular players and the Rangers in good health, it seemed as if it might be the night for New York, which was on a three-game winning streak, to change the course of recent history.

title: Mother of 2 Killed in Fire Is Released on Bail
description: A Newark woman whose two young daughters died Monday night in an apartment fire that erupted while she and their father were out was released from custody yesterday on $5,000 bail, the police said.

title: Morristown Preparing Domestic-Partner Law
description: The Mayor of Morristown has announced that he is preparing a domestic-partnership ordinance to provide health benefits to domestic partners of the town's 200 employees.

title: Jets Are at the Ramparts for Jacksonville's Elusive Brunell
description: No matter how many times Bryan Cox sees Mark Brunell fake a run, or fake a pass, or otherwise disorient the Jets' defense on Sunday, Cox promises he will not waver. He will charge.

title: Averting Retrial, Queens Man Pleads Guilty to Long Island Beating
description: Facing a retrial and potentially damaging new evidence, a Queens man pleaded guilty today to the near fatal beating of a Long Island man in 1996 in what the police said was a racially motivated brawl outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub.

title: A Diplomatic Look Back at a Met Career
description: In more than a dozen years as president and chief executive of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, William H. Luers never really spoke out about the nation's biggest art museum or his tenure there. That was the deal he cut with the museum's director, Philippe de Montebello.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIPORKES, HORTENSE
description: ZIPORKES-Hortense, on January 6, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Joseph Ziporkes. Loving mother of the late Melville H. Locker. Grandmother of Joan Thuring and Robert C. Locker. Great-grandmother to Ashley and Charlie. Services on Thursday at 12PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: U.S. SPIED ON IRAQ UNDER U.N. COVER, OFFICIALS NOW SAY
description: United States officials said today that American spies had worked undercover on teams of United Nations arms inspectors ferreting out secret Iraqi weapons programs.

title: More Distinctive Than Downtown
description: The Joyce Theater's annual Altogether Different festival was created in 1986 as a showcase for choreographers intent on developing and expanding their work. Sean Curran was a good choice to open this year's five-company series, which runs through Jan. 17. Judging by the program presented by the Sean Curran Company on Tuesday night, Mr. Curran is poised to move beyond the yeasty but sometimes confining world of downtown or avant-garde dance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, BILHA
description: BLOOM-Bilha. Loving wife of Norton. Devoted mother of Oren and Jane and Edra and Jeffrey. Caring sister of Meir. Funeral services Thursday, 1 PM, January 7, 1999 at I. J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, NY.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: For Help With a Benefits Package, Help Yourself
description: AT many companies and government agencies, open-enrollment season -- that annual ritual in which workers choose or change their employer-sponsored benefits for the coming year -- has just ended. Some employees may leaf through plan summaries or peruse health-care provider directories to make their choices, but at an increasing number of companies, employees are doing things differently. These tasks are, or soon will be, completed electronically, from the desktop at the click of a mouse, and by the people getting the benefits, not by human resource departments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALBO, MARIE
description: GALBO-Marie. Of Manhattan on January 4, 1999, beloved wife of the late Vincent J. Galbo, devoted mother Gloria J. Galbo and Vivian J. Mannello, of Waldorf, Maryland. Friends may call Thursday January 7, 1999, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10 A.M. Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column yesterday about a new Protestant political party in Northern Ireland referred imprecisely to the four politicians who are forming it, and to the Northern Ireland Assembly. The Assembly includes more than 100 Unionist members, not 5; the politicians forming the Northern Ireland Unionist Party have left the UK Unionist Party.

title: Lott Juggles Priorities on the High Wire of Impeachment
description: As Senator Trent Lott moves from meeting to meeting in search of a bipartisan plan for an impeachment trial, he says he wants a formula that is fair to all and speedy enough to satisfy a scandal-weary nation.

title: Male Officers Accuse Internal Affairs Inspector
description: The Police Department filed administrative charges yesterday against a deputy inspector in the Internal Affairs Bureau after two male sergeants filed complaints that he had sexually harassed them.

title: A Game That Melds Fighting and Dancing
description: DANCE FEVER'' meets Mortal Kombat.

title: Hamilton Scores 39 To Lead a Husky Rout
description: Top-ranked and undefeated Connecticut beat Boston College, 91-78, last night at Chestnut Hill, Mass., and demonstrated anew the disparity that exists between the few elite teams and the host of also-rans in the Big East Conference.

title: Full Trial Allows Airing of Evidence
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; Mr. Lott's 'Big Mistake'
description: I asked Gordon Lee Baum if he felt black people were intellectually inferior to whites.

title: Essay; Let the System Work
description: The White House message is plain: If the Senate dares to call Monica Lewinsky as a witness, the Clinton lawyers will drag out the impeachment trial clear through to the summer and blame the G.O.P. for shutting down the Government. Yesterday the Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle, snapped a partisan salute, announcing ''universal, unanimous opposition to witnesses.''

title: Preventing Subway Tragedies
description: To the Editor:

title: Edward Windsor, Prince, Will Take Sophie . . .
description: Queen Elizabeth's youngest child, Prince Edward, is finally to follow his royal siblings' path down the aisle.

title: The Big City; After Fire, Call for Safety At Any Cost
description: TELEVISION cameras will be in the City Council chamber tomorrow morning for a public hearing on the ''high-rise fire crisis,'' as it was described in The New York Post. The debate over requiring sprinklers in apartment buildings should produce a nice simple drama.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the naming of Diane Sawyer and Charles Gibson as co-anchors for the ABC program ''Good Morning America'' misstated the involvement of Shelley Ross, the newly appointed executive producer, in Ms. Sawyer's November interview with Kenneth W. Starr. Ms. Ross assisted in preparations for the Starr interview, but Chris Vlasto was the producer.

title: If Only DeMille Had Owned a Desktop
description: The camera glides in on a tableau: Jesus and His apostles gathered solemnly at a long table, each frozen in painterly poses familiar from ''The Last Supper.'' Then Jesus suddenly comes to life, and in a flurry of special effects that owes more to Dali than da Vinci, he miraculously provides a banquet of breads, crackers and grapes from thin air and transforms water into a blood-red wine cooler called New Testament. Along the way, he transforms himself into a robed pitch man for the new bottled beverage.

title: Philip Sterling, 76, an Actor
description: Philip Sterling, an actor whose long career embraced theater, films, television and radio, died on Nov. 30 at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 76.

title: Disney Plans to Reduce Chairman's Bonus
description: Michael D. Eisner, chairman of the Walt Disney Company, is about to have his bonus cut in half, to $5 million from $9.9 million, because of the company's weak performance in the 1998 fiscal year.

title: A $215 Million Bid For Finansbanken
description: Storebrand ASA, Norway's largest insurer, said yesterday that it had bid 40 kroner a share, or a total of 1.6 billion kroner ($215 million), for the Norwegian commercial bank Finansbanken ASA. Storebrand, which already holds a 10 percent stake in the bank, said its bid had been accepted by more than 50 percent of the shareholders; it must receive acceptances from more than 90 percent to complete the deal. Finansbanken specializes in lending to the shipping and real estate industries.

title: Before Anyone Yells 'Fire!'
description: TUESDAY was a busy day at the Banco Popular on 116th Street in East Harlem, but Joyce Lynes wasn't lining up for the teller or an A.T.M. She was in a throng surrounding a table arrayed with fire extinguishers, smoke detectors, a circuit breaker and coloring books with a fire-safety theme.

title: Filmmaking, Minus the Camera
description: YOU enter a musty-looking building that looks as if it is about to fall down around you and continue down a dark hallway until you see an aged security guard snoozing at his desk. Dread and anticipation fill the air as he wakes up and looks you over. Is he going to whip out a rifle and blast you?

title: About School Uniforms
description: To the Editor:

title: Both Sides Lose With Audience
description: There were fans like James Lowry of Chicago, a Bulls season ticket-holder for 20 years, who were overjoyed by the news that the National Basketball Association and the players union had very likely settled their differences and were ready to begin play on Feb. 2.

title: Out of Latin America
description: There is a delicious new restaurant in Los Angeles in a place you might least expect: at the base of an office tower downtown. The Brazilian-flavored Ciudad is the latest enterprise by the celebrity chefs Mary Sue Milliken and Susan Feniger (who also created the Border Grill and the City Restaurant here), and the architect Josh Schweitzer. Ciudad is both a homage to Hispanic culture and a vote of confidence in the future of downtown Los Angeles.

title: Challenging System to Master
description: PRO LANDSCAPE 5.0

title: Federal Panel Urges Overhaul of Medicare Payment System
description: Leaders of a Federal advisory commission today proposed radical changes in Medicare, recommending that the Government, instead of paying separately for each medical service, offer a fixed amount of money to each beneficiary to buy private health insurance.

title: French Premier Assails U.S. Over Iraq Air Strikes
description: France's Prime Minister criticized American and British air strikes against Iraq in an interview published today and said that France would soon be ready to propose ways for ending the impasse with Saddam Hussein.

title: A Spy Enigma in Iraq
description: Divisions within the United Nations over Iraq have created a poisonous atmosphere in which it can be difficult to determine fact from fiction. That makes caution essential in assessing accusations of misconduct, including reports this week that the Clinton Administration may have improperly used United Nations weapons inspection efforts in Iraq to augment its own intelligence operations against Saddam Hussein. It is not yet clear that such a violation of U.N. independence occurred.

title: Sipping Sake in Style
description: As pan-Pacific cuisine becomes increasingly popular here, so does sake. Indeed, so trendy is the rice wine that its accouterments are becoming de rigueur household items. In the vanguard of the sake revolution is Algabar, which stocks ochoko (sake cups) and tokuri (sake bottles), from $10 cedar cups to white porcelain cups ($24 apiece), shown here, by the German potter Stefanie Hering. Her work was recently offered in the Museum of Modern Art's catalogue. Algabar is at 920 North La Cienega Boulevard, West Hollywood; (310) 360-3500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERLIN, ANTHONY
description: SERLIN-Anthony. The officers and staff of SSEU Local 371 note with sadness the untimely passing of Tony Serlin, longtime Associate Director of Research and Negotiations. Tony worked for the Union for over 25 years and helped negotiate all the Union's contracts since 1972. Over the years his knowledge of detail and history made him an invaluable resource to the institution and his willingness to share his time made him a special friend to many, many members who went to him for assistance. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Justina, also a longtime union activist, and his children Tevin, Charles, Megan, and Rebecca. Charles Ensley, President SSEU Local 371

title: Put Your Feet Up
description: Christina Kim is a darling of fashion cognoscenti. Her Dosa line of clothing and accessories fuses a minimalist sensibility with ecological concerns. Distressed leather poufs, above, are stuffed with leftover pieces of Polartec. ''There's a pouf revival going on at the moment,'' she said. ''The inspiration comes from Morocco.'' The poufs, in silver and gold, cost $350 and are available at OK, 7924 Beverly Boulevard, Los Angeles, and at the Dosa store in New York, at 107 Thompson Street (Spring Street).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLER, ELIAS A.
description: STOLER-Elias A., age 88, formerly of NYC, died January 6th, 1999 in Minneapolis, MN. Devoted husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. His kindness and gentleness will be missed by his family and friends.

title: Pataki Offers Light Agenda, Setting Aside Budget Surplus
description: Treading cautiously as he begins his second term, Gov. George E. Pataki today delivered a State of the State Message notably light on new initiatives, while proposing that the state's budget surplus be set aside to pay for the ballooning tax cuts already enacted.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday comparing major libraries in New York, Paris and London misstated the given name of a trustee of the New York Public Library who donated money to renovate the Main Reading Room at 42d Street. She is Sandra Priest Rose, not Sylvia, who contributed with her husband, Frederick P. Rose.

title: ISLANDERS
description: When Tommy Salo returned to the nets for Tuesday night's game against Chicago, it meant that the Islanders were forced to demote one of their other goalies, either the veteran backup Wade Flaherty or the newcomer Marcel Cousineau.

title: BAAN TO SELL UP TO $225 MILLION IN SHARES TO FLETCHER
description: Baan N.V., Europe's second-largest maker of business management software, said yesterday that it would sell as much as $225 million in new common shares to Fletcher International Ltd. to finance future growth. Fletcher, a New York-based private investment company, has already paid $75 million for at least five million shares to be purchased between Aug. 1, 1999 and Dec. 31, 2001, Baan said. Baan has been cutting jobs and reshuffling management, spending $110 million on reorganization to improve performance after it reported a third-quarter loss. Its shares dropped to a quarter of their value six months ago, but they rose $1.125 yesterday, to $12.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, ALFRED
description: SOLOMON-Alfred. You were the brightest star on Lynbrook's horizon, a master, a mentor, a brilliant mind-an educator supreme. Rest well, dear friend. We'll miss you. Judy Silverman Diane Bunkin Nadel

title: The Ultimate Y2K Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: When a Site Won't Load
description: Q. My Web browser crashes when I try to look at a certain page. Every other page I want to look at loads fine, so is something wrong with the page?

title: Preventing Subway Tragedies
description: To the Editor:

title: Baltimore's Push on Crime Creates Backlog of Cases
description: More aggressive efforts by the Baltimore police to reduce the rate of homicides and other serious crime in the city has created such a backlog of cases that a circuit judge has dismissed first-degree murder charges against four men who had been awaiting trial for almost three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANTONINI, SANDRA, NEE PASIMENI
description: ANTONINI-Sandra, nee Pasimeni. January 4, 1999. She was born November 13, 1913 in New York City. Visitation 6:30-8PM Thursday with 7PM Vigil Service at Rhodes Funeral Home, Druid Chapel, Clearwater, FL. Services 1PM Friday, January 8, at St. Brendan Catholic Church and burial at Sylvan Abbey Cemetery, Clearwater.

title: Economic Scene; The President's plan on tax credits for the disabled has new ideas but also serious problems.
description: President Clinton's proposal to use tax credits to help about two million disabled Americans, many of whom depend on relatives for long-term care, includes some innovative ideas, but it also has some serious problems.

title: Forget the Oscars, Here Come the Webbys
description: The digerati should already be picking out formal gowns and making sure that their shoes match their mouse pads. Yes, the International Academy of Digital Arts and Sciences on Wednesday announced nominations for the 1999 Webby Awards, the ''Oscars of the Internet.''

title: The Name of the Almighty
description: To the Editor:

title: Myth of Reparations
description: To the Editor:

title: Preventing Subway Tragedies
description: To the Editor:

title: Detour on Capitalist Road: Die-Hard Maoist Collective
description: In the center of this well-kept community stands a giant statue of Mao Zedong, complete with honor guard, that was erected only in 1993 -- well after many places had torn down monuments to the late Chairman.

title: Michel Petrucciani, Romantic Of Jazz Piano, Is Dead at 36
description: Michel Petrucciani, a French jazz pianist and composer with an international following whose keyboard virtuosity earned him comparisons to Art Tatum and Bill Evans, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 36 and lived in Manhattan.

title: With Little Time on Clock, N.B.A. and Players Settle
description: National Basketball Association players and owners brought an end to the most calamitous and costly labor dispute in league history yesterday, agreeing to an 11th-hour deal that saved the season only a day before the owners were to vote on canceling it.

title: The Pharaoh Still Beckons
description: The American Cinematheque, a nonprofit film forum, opened its new quarters at the Egyptian Theater last month, helping revitalize a down-at-the-heels stretch of Hollywood Boulevard. The Egyptian Theater, which was opened in 1922, suffered alterations and earthquake damage before closing in 1992. It has been skillfully remodeled by Hodgetts & Fung, which has brought the building back with a mix of old and new and set a standard for restoring Los Angeles's historic theaters. The auditorium, top, has been modernized, and the courtyard, lined with palm trees and stone benches, is open to the public. The theater entrance at 6712 Hollywood Boulevard, with its columns and bust of Pharaoh, right, stands in all its jolly, themed glory.

title: Hotel Staff May Include A New 'Technology Butler'
description: Staffs at a few Ritz-Carlton Hotels in the United States will soon be glad to turn down your bed, fluff up your pillow and answer your questions about configuring software.

title: Financiers Plan To Put Controls On Derivatives
description: With the blessing of the Federal Government, some of the world's largest financial institutions reached an agreement today to try to set their own industrywide standards in the huge and volatile market of the complex securities known as derivatives.

title: Big Rise Urged for After School Programs
description: The Administration is seeking a $400 million increase in financing for after-school and summer school programs to tutor struggling students and to keep children of working parents off the streets after school hours, the White House said today.

title: Whitaker's Comeback a Tonic for Sport
description: Pernell Whitaker, a six-time champion in four weight divisions, spent all of 1998 on the outside of boxing looking in because of a drug suspension and a stint in drug rehabilitation. But he said he wasn't disappointed with that, because when he looked in on the sport there wasn't anything going on.

title: The Neediest Cases; Take-Charge Tenants Save a Building
description: In 1989, the three-story building at 59 Troutman Street in Bushwick, Brooklyn, was home to dozens of rodents, scores of roaches and half a dozen frustrated families.

title: Starr Finds Nothing Wrong With Revealing Details of Talks
description: The independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr told a Federal judge who is investigating his office over possible illegal grand jury leaks that it would have been appropriate for him to disclose to reporters information about negotiations with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Excerpts From the Governor's Address to the Legislature
description: Following are excerpts from Gov. George E. Pataki's State of the State Message to the Legislature in Albany yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: House Eases Restrictions on Inexpensive Gifts
description: The House of Representatives voted today to allow members to accept modest gifts, like inexpensive meals and souvenirs, easing a strict limit on gifts that has been in force for three years.

title: LG Will Let Hyundai Take Lead on Chips
description: Bowing to Government pressure, the LG Group agreed today to allow the Hyundai Group to run a merged computer chip business.

title: Apple Shows Its Colors
description: In a barrage of introductions that blended technological prowess with a delightful sense of style and fun, Apple Computer this week introduced a powerful new line of desktop computer systems in a color scheme it calls translucent blueberry and ice, as well as an array of improved iMac computers that come in an assortment of colors including blueberry, grape, lime, tangerine and strawberry.

title: From Gutenberg To Cyberstories
description: Reader, you are to know that I am one who naturally like stories and love the tactile, sensual feel of a freshly minted book as well as anyone. I am a person whose appetite for a book is often particularly tempted by the lush coloring and crisp lettering of its cover. Further, that I am of a temper that is, if not outright technophobic, certainly not that of one who is a technophile.

title: Gun Homicides by Young People
description: The continuing decline in homicides in New York City and elsewhere last year is cause for celebration, but it does not end the need for strict gun-control laws. A new Justice Department study shows that while the nation's overall homicide rate fell in 1997 to its lowest level in three decades, the number of firearm homicides by young people remains alarmingly high. The report offers no explanation for this discrepancy. But criminologists point to the phenomenal spread of illegal handguns among young people that began with the start of the crack epidemic around 1985 as a major reason for the continuing high level of violence.

title: Microsoft Presses Its View About Rivals' 3-Way Deal
description: In its antitrust trial today, the Microsoft Corporation made its most concerted effort yet to convince a Federal judge that the recently announced deal that brings together three of its rivals -- America Online Inc., the Netscape Communications Corporation and Sun Microsystems Inc. -- seriously weakens the Government's case.

title: A Japanese Version of 'Geisha'? Well, It May Sound Easy
description: It seems the Great Japanese Novel: the tale of a poor fisherman's daughter who parlays a pair of beautiful gray eyes into a career as one of Japan's most bewitching geisha, setting a record price when her virginity is auctioned.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: 1998 Auto Sales Post Best Gain in 12 Years

title: Away From Spotlight, Jaguar Rookie Thrives
description: He is a National Football League rookie who has toppled records the way he has toppled defensive backs: with an explosive combination of power and speed. He has given the Jacksonville Jaguars dimensions that frighten teams. Yet some teams were afraid of him when he came out of college because of several off-the-field incidents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORSER, PAUL
description: CORSER-Paul. The Board, staff and volunteers of the Treatment Action Group mourn the sudden, premature loss of Paul Corser. As a colleague, a friend and a person living with AIDS, Paul inspired us with his passionate commitment, despite the challenges of his own illness, to the search for an AIDS cure and a vaccine. He never swerved from this quest. No matter how badly AIDS ravaged his body, Paul remained unfailingly cheerful and optimistic. His life's work is a legacy which will continue to inspire us in coming years. Our thoughts are with his loving wife, Sally Morrison, his family and his colleagues at AMFAR. Odell Mays II, Executive Director Mark Harrington, Policy Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, BENJAMIN
description: ROSEN-Benjamin. Greater New York Hospital Association mourns the passing of Benjamin Rosen, the father of our esteemed friend, colleague and former Chairman, David P. Rosen, President and Chief Executive Officer of Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Rosen family. Mark J. Mundy, Chairman Kenneth E. Raske, President Greater New York Hospital Assn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUFELD, ABRAHAM
description: NEUFELD-Abraham. The Long Island Committee for Soviet Jewry, its Officers and Board are saddened by the untimely loss of our dear friend and president. May the family remember how much he has been cherished by all who knew him. Lynn Singer, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENKRANTZ, YETTA
description: ROSENKRANTZ-Yetta. 89 years. Died January 5, 1999. Devoted and beloved mother of Stanley (Helene), Evelyn (Harvey) Littman and Lester (Gail). Loving grandmother of Amy, Marni, Eric, Ellen, Michael, Barbara, Susan, Debra, Adam and Jana. Adoring greatgrandmother. Dearest sister of Mae Wilke and the late Jean Stein and Mollie Ehrlich and caring aunt. Services Friday, 11:30AM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, N.Y.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Grass on a Roof? No Problem. Just Don't Change Your Mind.
description: COMPLETE LAND DESIGNER

title: Coaches Play Down Marquee Match
description: Tonight come the warm-ups: Connecticut at Pittsburgh and Tennessee at home to South Carolina. On Sunday afternoon on national television (CBS, 4 P.M.) is the game of the season in women's college basketball: No. 2 Tennessee (11-1), the national champion the last three years, at No. 1 Connecticut (11-0), the national champion the year before Tennessee started its run.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Clinton to Pledge $7 Billion For Missile Defense System
description: Sixteen years after President Ronald Reagan envisioned a ''Star Wars'' program to protect the United States from ballistic missile attacks, President Clinton plans to pledge about $7 billion over six years to build a limited missile defense system, even though he will leave a final decision on whether to build it until later, officials said.

title: Ewing Says Goodbye to One Battle and Hello to Another
description: Snowflakes swirled around a weary Patrick Ewing as he stood outside a toy store in midtown Manhattan yesterday. He slipped a hood over his head, but it might as well have been a towel after a long night on the court.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Nurturing Lantanas

title: A Pataki Reprise
description: Rather than seeing his convincing re-election victory as a mandate for daring new initiatives, Gov. George E. Pataki seemed determined today to give New Yorkers more of what so many of them liked the first time around.

title: Bad Deal for Pensioners
description: To the Editor:

title: Duval Focuses on 1999
description: As David Duval looks forward to 1999, it will be difficult for him to improve on 1998. He led the PGA Tour with four victories last year and he won the money title with more than $2.59 million. Though Mark O'Meara, who won the Masters and the British Open, was named the tour's player of the year, some believe Duval was the best all-round player.

title: Iran Says It Displays Candor With Admission on Rogue Killings
description: Iranian political leaders said today that an extraordinary admission that rogue intelligence officers had carried out a wave of political killings showed that their fractured Government was capable of cleaning house.

title: Shows, Tours, Talks
description: Glass Exhibition

title: Landlord Admits He Is Guilty Of Trying to Kill Two Tenants
description: A Lower East Side landlord pleaded guilty yesterday to trying to kill two of his tenants who had complained about conditions in his building and planning to set fire to one of their apartments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIDENGER, ABRAHAM C.
description: EIDENGER-Abraham C. Beloved husband of Mildred. Loving and devoted father of Karen of Potomac, MD, and Mark of Belle Harbor, NY. Service today, 11:30AM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York (corner of Avenue V).

title: Paul Corser; AIDS Group Officer, 37
description: Paul Corser, the senior program officer of the American Foundation for AIDS Research, died Monday at his home in Harlem. He was 37. The cause was AIDS related, his wife, Sally Morrison, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, BORIS
description: FEINBERG-Boris. Of Scarsdale, NY on January 5, 1999. Beloved husband of Sylvia Schwartz Feinberg. Father of Cynthia Jacobson, Renee Feinberg and Henry Feinberg. Father-in-law of Paul Jacobson and Janet Feinberg. Grandfather of Adam and Steven Jacobson, Sheelah Feinberg and Hannah, Rachel and Samuel Feinberg. He was the president of Consolidated Terminal Warehouses and was active in Manhattan commercial real estate. Donations in memory of Mr. Feinberg may be made to the Phelps Memorial Hospital, Mental Heath Clinic, Sleepy Hollow, NY.

title: Gardening Via Computer: Losing More Than Calluses
description: MAKE no mistake: making a garden is outdoor work. So I was a bit skeptical of garden design software promising that ''you can create an outdoor paradise without leaving your chair.'' I have been a garden writer for 16 years and, for the last 6 have been wrestling a one-acre plot into some sort of garden that makes design sense. So I know that I can write about gardens without leaving my chair, but creating an outdoor paradise means I have to get up and get out there.

title: Metro Business; Gambling by Minors Leads to Casino Fine
description: New Jersey casino regulators fined an Atlantic City casino $30,000 yesterday for allowing three minors to gamble.

title: CHIEF EXECUTIVE SAYS TELLABS IS NOT IN TAKEOVER TALKS
description: The shares of Tellabs Inc. fell yesterday after its chief executive, Michael J. Birck, said he was not in discussions to sell the phone-equipment maker. Tellabs fell $3.6875 a share, to $75.125, after trading as low as $72.50. The stock surged 20 percent on Tuesday after Mr. Birck was late to a meeting with investors at a conference in Phoenix. Analysts said this gave rise to speculation that the chief executive was tied up in merger talks. In an interview late on Tuesday, Mr. Birck said that the company was not in takeover discussions and told investors in a later conference session that he did not know why the stock rose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARSHAUER, ROSE
description: WARSHAUER-Rose. Age 98, adored, beloved aunt, great aunt, sister-in-law and friend to many. Died January 5, 1999 in Miami Beach, FL. Fondly remembered by Helen and Jerry Spielman. Cryptside services January 7, 1999, at 12:30 P.M. at New Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: A Litigator to the Rescue
description: Jim Quinn, whose entry into the stalled National Basketball Association labor dispute marked the beginning of the end of the six-month impasse, is the most prolific litigator of sports antitrust cases in the quarter-century history of those high-powered court battles.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SILVER SURGES. Silver futures rose as hedge funds and other speculators entered the market to take advantage of oversold conditions. In New York, silver for February delivery rose 12.5 cents, to $5.129 an ounce.

title: Ex-Black Panthers Look Hopefully at Oakland
description: There were times, David Hilliard concedes, when the Black Panther Party carried a stigma, conjuring images of violence rather than community empowerment, of black separatism rather than multiculturalism.

title: Full Trial Allows Airing of Evidence
description: To the Editor:

title: When Walls Don't Speak but Still Shed Light
description: TO install a sconce is to decorate a wall with light.

title: Davis Is Ready To Run for Broncos
description: As if the Denver Broncos needed positive reinforcement for Saturday's playoff game against the Miami Dolphins, they have received some from Terrell Davis, pro football's running back of the year. He said his bruised ribs are feeling fine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKEL, ERICH, HANS
description: MARKEL-Erich-Hans, 78. President of The Max Kade Foundation, Inc, New York, died January 4, 1999. His family and friends mourn the death of this exceptional man with a remarkable career and life. He was respected, admired and honored by so many and will be dearly missed. During his 40 years as President, The Foundation made grants to major universities in American and Europe to promote medical research and cross-cultural understanding. He received Orders Of Merit from The Federal Republic of Germany and Austria, and several honorary doctorate degrees from American universities for his philanthropic efforts. A service is being held in his honor at The German Evangelical-Lutheran Church of Saint Paul on Saturday, January 9, 1999, at 12 P.M., 315 West 22nd Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Friends of Dresden, Inc, a charity which supports the reconstruction of the historic ''Frauenkirche (Church)'' of Dresden, 1675 Broadway, Suite 1900, New York, New York 10019-5820. He will especially be missed and remembered by his daughter, Anne, son, Michael, daughter-in-law, Gail, and his grandchildren, Julie, Katie, Erin, and Jason.

title: Office Maintenance Strike Is Averted
description: After 25 straight hours of talks, negotiators representing the managers of 1,000 New York City office buildings averted a strike yesterday by reaching a tentative agreement with the union representing about 30,000 building maintenance workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, MERLA
description: ABRAMS-Merla. Suddenly on January 5th. Devoted wife of Larry for 56 years. Beloved mother of Andrew. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 11 AM Friday. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Franklin Hospital Medical Center or charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: New Kids in The Hall
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Stubbornly Wrapped Notion; Christo, Rebuffed, Clings to His Central Park Dream
description: Christo and his wife, Jeanne-Claude, waited 24 years for the German Government to allow them to wrap the Reichstag in Berlin in more than a million square feet of aluminum-colored fabric; 10 years for permission from the French authorities to swathe the Pont Neuf in Paris in 454,178 square feet of a champagne-colored textile that shimmered like silk; seven years to plant a forest of giant umbrellas in the rice paddies near Tokyo and along the open hillsides of Southern California, and 32 years to veil 161 trees in black and white polyester mesh in a park in Basel, Switzerland.

title: The N.B.A. Finally Returns and Marketers Yawn
description: The agreement in principle reached yesterday to salvage the National Basketball Association season is being welcomed by most marketers and agencies, particularly those that covet the younger male consumers who fervently follow the Bulls, Knicks, Lakers and all that Jazz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, PAUL
description: LEVINE-Paul. Died January 5, 1999 at ABC Hospital, Mexico City. Beloved father of Susan M. Levine, M.D., and grandfather of Thomas and Richard. Paul was born in New York City, where he worked as an accountant before moving to Mexico in 1952. A pioneering entrepreneur, he was successful in his own businesses as well as financing the startup of many Mexican firms. He will be missed. Memorial gifts may be sent to The New Jersey Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Association, Inc., P.O. Box 726, Oradell, New Jersey 07649.

title: House Pushes to Open Report on China and U.S. Technology
description: The House of Representatives extended today the life of a special committee examining Chinese acquisition of American technology in order to expedite the release of the committee's report, which is still secret.

title: HUSSMANN TO BUY GRUPO KOXKA FOR $145 MILLION IN CASH
description: Hussmann International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Grupo Koxka, a Spanish commercial-refrigeration company, for about $145 million in cash. Hussman said the deal, expected to close in February, would add slightly to its 1999 earnings. The company had 1997 revenues of $1.1 billion. Koxka, based in Pamplona, Spain, employs 750 people in five manufacturing sites in Spain. With 1997 sales of $103 million, Hussmann expects 1998 sales to increase by about 25 percent. Hussmann, based in Bridgeton, Mo., makes refrigeration systems for the commercial food industry. Its shares rose 31.25 cents, to $18.

title: Defenders of Jefferson Renew Attack on DNA Data Linking Him to Slave Child
description: DNA evidence of Thomas Jefferson's presumed affair with his slave Sally Hemings continues to reverberate, with defenders of Jefferson arguing that others in his family could have fathered her children.

title: New Lowe Executive Is Leaving Agency
description: Robert Kantor, president for United States operations at Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York, is unexpectedly leaving after less than five months.

title: LVMH Moet Increases Its Stake in Gucci
description: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the world's biggest luxury goods maker, said today that it had raised its stake in Gucci Group, the fashion goods company, to more than 5 percent.

title: Bronx Man Arrested In Child's Sexual Abuse
description: A Bronx man with a history of sex offenses was arrested yesterday on charges of sexually abusing his girlfriend's 9-year-old niece, the police said. The man, Charles Davis, 32, was charged with first degree sexual abuse, said Detective Joseph Pentangelo, a Police Department spokesman. The girl told her mother that she was abused at the man's house, which he shares with her aunt, at 2 A.M. on Jan. 4. She was treated at Jacobi Hospital.

title: Schools Head Has Concerns About Exam For 4th Grade
description: Just days before fourth-graders are scheduled to draw their No. 2 pencils to take a new state standardized test, City Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew called on the state not to use test results to determine whether a school is placed on its list of failing schools.

title: Six-Man Team Settles in a Marathon
description: The rescue of the National Basketball Association season began at 6 P.M. Tuesday with a surprise guest and ended at 6 the next morning with three middle-aged lawyers walking the frigid, empty streets of Manhattan.

title: American Topics : Not Much but Nostalgia Left Of the Catskills Borscht Belt
description: For decades, predominantly Jewish crowds flocked to the green mountains and grand hotels of the Catskill Mountains north of New York City for fresh air and caustic jokes, big bands and mountains of all-you-can-eat food: rib steaks, blintzes and borscht (hence the nickname, the Borscht Belt). "It was like New Year's Eve every night," said Jackie Horner, a dance instructor in one of the big hotels. "We danced all day and danced all night, then we danced some more."

title: Move Over, $ and $:, Here Comes the . . .
description: TRADING in the euro -- the first common European currency since the Roman Empire -- began on Monday, and financial institutions spent millions getting ready.
