Even in London -- Britain is not one of the 11 countries using the euro -- some 30,000 computer experts worked through the weekend adapting programs for the new exchange rates, and the Belgian Government is handing out calculators specially designed for conversions. So far, Europe seems to be proving that it can smoothly draw on euro bank accounts, but drawing the euro symbol on a yellow pad or a computer screen is another matter.

title: Distributor Accuses Coca-Cola Enterprises of Fraud
description: In court papers disclosed this week, Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., the world's largest Coca-Cola bottler, is accused of engaging in fraud, wiretapping and other tactics in an effort to drive a small Maryland soft-drink distributor out of business.

title: The Rise and Fall of the Modem King
description: PARIS  In a field in which everything is focused on the future, on how fast and smart and cool technology will be in just a couple of months or years  just you wait and see  sometimes we need to pause for a little history lesson.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AIRGAS INC., Radnor, Pa., an industrial gas distributor, agreed to sell investments in Poland and Thailand to Linde A.G. for about $50 million.

title: Giants Dismiss Line Coach
description: In the first chapter of a subtle retooling of the Giants' offensive line this off season, Coach Jim Fassel yesterday fired the offensive-line coach John Matsko.

title: Metro Business; Whistleblower Complaint
description: State and local authorities in Connecticut are investigating a Stamford man's claim that he is being harassed because he helped the state investigate a Fairfield company accused of selling private financial information to bill collectors.

title: Real Help for the Mentally Ill
description: Whenever a mentally disturbed person turns violent, a search for blame begins. In the few days since 32-year-old Kendra Webdale was pushed to her death under a Manhattan subway train and a schizophrenic man named Andrew Goldstein was charged with the crime, advocates for the mentally ill have blamed Gov. George Pataki for failing to re-invest the savings from de-institutionalization in community mental health services, as he promised. Others have blamed the de-institutionalization of people with problems like Mr. Goldstein's in the first place.

title: Libraries May Be New, but Problems Are Old
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, MARTIN LEWIS, III
description: COHN-Martin Lewis, III. On January 5th. Beloved husband of Nita and the late Myra. Devoted father of the late Audrey, of Elizabeth and Mayo Stuntz, Ellen Cohn and Larry Berkowitz, and Peggy Cohn and Peter Orlov. Dear brother of Raymond D. Cohn. Adored grandfather of Allison, James, Katie, Adrienne, Maggie, Alex and Juliana. Gentle stepfather of Bonnie and Daniel Tisch, and Freddie Jeck. Loving brother-in-law of Carolyn Cohn and Billie and Laurence Tisch. Wonderful uncle and friend to many. Funeral 11 A.M. Friday, January 8, Hoidal Funeral Home, 236 Monmouth Road, Oakhurst, New Jersey.

title: An Order for Airbus Hits Its Rival, Boeing, Close to Home
description: Airbus Industrie made further inroads yesterday against its archrival, the Boeing Company, when Boullioun Aviation Services, a fast-growing aircraft leasing company founded by a former Boeing executive, E. H. (Tex) Boullioun, announced its first purchase of Airbus jets.

title: A Twinkling Terrace That Reaches for the Stars
description: ZOOMING up the Champs-Elysees in her Saab, Kathryn Gustafson, an American landscape architect, stopped to admire bouquets of roses tightly arrayed in the rear window of a florist's truck. ''That's a garden, too,'' she said, and she drove on.

title: Sworn In as Senator, Schumer Promises Money for New York
description: With his left hand on his silver-and-jade-trimmed bar mitzvah Bible, Charles E. Schumer was sworn in today as New York State's newest United States Senator, vowing to be a legislator who not only passes bills but also -- in the tradition of the man he defeated, Alfonse M. D'Amato -- delivers money and services to the state.

title: Cisco Planning a Multimedia Network
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the computer-networking company, is expected to announce on Thursday its strategy for blending Internet data with voice communications to reach consumer households.

title: With a Theatrical Flair
description: Frank Lloyd Wright spent some time in Los Angeles, and left behind a few landmarks. So did his son Frank Lloyd Wright Jr., known as Lloyd Wright, who lived and built in Los Angeles for some 50 years. Overshadowed by his superhuman father and by the frugal modernism of Richard Neutra and R. M. Schindler, Lloyd Wright, who died in 1978, designed buildings that blended the geometric and organic concerns of his father with a love of landscaping and theatricality. Probably his most noted building is the poetic Wayfarer's Chapel in Palos Verdes, Calif. He also designed the concrete block Millard Studio, 1926; the sleek white and copper Samuel-Novarro house, 1928, whose entry is at left, and the Bowler House, 1963, which looks positively Jetsonian. Alan Weintraub, a photographer, spent 10 years documenting buildings for his fine ''Lloyd Wright'' (Harry Abrams, $75). An essay by Thomas S. Hines sheds light on Mr. Wright's work and his relationship with his father.

title: Congo Rebels Say 400 Hutu Died in Battle, Not Massacre
description: Congolese rebel leaders admitted late tonight that some of their soldiers had killed about 400 Hutu militiamen last week, but denied that they had massacred 500 civilians.

title: Newest Members Share Old Tales
description: The members of the Hall of Fame Class of 1999 -- Nolan Ryan, George Brett and Robin Yount -- recalled yesterday their first encounters of the close kind, with Ryan firing fastballs and Brett and Yount trying to hit them rather than be hit by them.

title: Chase Bank to Levy Fees on A.T.M. Users Without Accounts
description: Chase Manhattan Bank, the largest bank in New York City, said yesterday that it would impose fees for non-Chase customers who use its automated teller machines. Chase had been one of the last holdouts among banks in the city in not imposing the fees.

title: Methadone in Pregnancy
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 30 about the use of computers in schools quoted incorrectly from a comment by Judy Salpeter, editor of Technology and Learning magazine, about the Hunterdon Central Regional High School in Flemington, N.J. She said that only 20 to 30 high schools in the United States were as advanced as that school in the use of computers -- not that only 20 to 30 high schools used them.

title: Where All Lanes Are Fast Lanes: The High-Tech Bowling Alley
description: Pity the pin boys. They were the shadowy tough guys at the ends of the bowling lanes who risked life ad limb to line up the pins, someties for as little as a nickel a game. Extinct for decades, they are the dodo birds of bowling.

title: Israel's 'Who Is a Jew' Perennial Sprouts Anew
description: The chief judge of the Jerusalem district court struck a profound nerve last week with a ruling that undermined the overarching power of the Orthodox Chief Rabbinate to determine who is a Jew.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSKEY, JILL ANN
description: BOSKEY-Jill Ann. On January 3, after a brief illness. Jill was beloved as a daughter, sister, aunt, friend, anti-war activist, colleague, and of course, advocate. Her passing leaves a deep void in all our lives. Contributions may be made to the Center for Disability Advocacy Rights, 841 Broadway, NY, NY 10003, or the War Resistors' League, 339 Lafayette Street, NY, N.Y. 10012. A memorial service will be held in the near future. Call 212-979-7772 for information.

title: Web Lust: More Money, More Stuff
description: A PERSON can live blissfully for 37 years without a coffee table, then one day suddenly look at the big empty area in the center of the living-room rug and realize: it's all wrong.

title: Man in the News: John Dennis Hastert; THE 106TH CONGRESS: THE SPEAKER -- Humble Man at the Helm
description: Only minutes after he was elected Speaker of the House today, Dennis Hastert displayed the regular-guy charm and Midwestern sensibility that his backers hope will insulate him from the warfare that toppled the two men who came before him in less than two months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, CHARLES FRANCIS
description: ADAMS-Charles Francis. Of Dover, MA. January 5, 1999, at home. Beloved husband of Beatrice (Dabney) Adams and the late Margaret Stockton. Loving father of Abigail A. Manny of Brunswick, ME, Alison A. Hagan of Fairplay, CO., Timothy Adams of Louisville, CO. and stepson Giannotto Penati of Washington, D.C. Also survived by nine grandchildren and thirteen great grandchildren. Funeral services private. A memorial service will be held Friday, January 8th, 2PM in the Memorial Church, Harvard Yard, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA. Relatives and friends are kindly invited. Former CEO and Chairman of the Board of the Raytheon Corp., graduate of Harvard College class of 1932. Veteran W.W. II, U.S. Navy. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Mass Historical Society for The Preservation of The Adams Papers, 1154 Boylston Street, Boston, Ma 02215 or to the charity of your choice.

title: Libraries May Be New, but Problems Are Old
description: To the Editor:

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: When Main Street turns into Calle Ocho, it is time to pay attention. And that is exactly what happened on the Upper West Side when the all-American, down-home restaurant segued into this pan-Latino fantasy. The owners may be the same, but everything else has changed.

title: Starr's Actions Cast Doubt on Senate Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: PARKER DRILLING AND SUPERIOR ENERGY CALL OFF MERGER
description: The Parker Drilling Company and Superior Energy Services Inc. said yesterday that they had mutually agreed to end a merger agreement under which Parker was to acquire Superior. Parker, a drilling company based in Tulsa, Okla., had recently sweetened an earlier stock offer for Superior, a Harvey, La., company that rents tools for oilfields. The deal was worth about $145 million when it was announced in October, but Parker's stock then started declining as the outlook for the oilfield services industry deteriorated. As a result of the termination, Superior will make a cash payment to Parker to settle certain obligations under their agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMPEI, BRUNO M.
description: POMPEI-Bruno M.., January 4, 1999, beloved husband of the late Ellen Gherlone Pompei. He is survived by his daughter Ornella Winston, his son, Mark, and sister Bianca Arengi. He will be missed by his grandchildren, David, Lori, and Robin and great grandchildren Lilia and Sarah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, RABBI MORTON
description: GOLDBERG-Rabbi Morton. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague, age 97. Ordained in 1925, he served as rabbi of Temple Beth El in Fall River, MA when he was called to the pulpit of Temple B'nai Israel in 1937 where he served until becoming rabbi emeritus in 1972. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his widow, Doris, daughter-in-law, Harriet, son-in-law, Irwin, grandchildren Steven, Stuart, Cathy and Jeffrey, and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Seymour L. Essrog, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DACHS, RICHARD A.
description: DACHS-Richard A. . Beloved son of Alan and Hilda. Brother to Carol and Enid. Brother-in-law to Robert. Nephew to Mary, Sally and Julie. Passed away suddenly Wednesday, January 6, 1999. His untimely passing left a vacant space in all our hearts. He will be sorely missed. He was a Deputy General Counsel to the New York City Council. Services will be held Sunday, January 10th, 11:15AM at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, VERONICA GREEVEN
description: EDWARDS-Veronica Greeven. Memorial service to be held Jan. 9, 11:30 AM at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at 53rd Street.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We think the best way to keep cool and calm and dignified is to hear each other and talk to each other. Now does that solve all the problems? No.''

title: Starr Indicts an Ex-Friend Of an Accuser of Clinton
description: The independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr has brought a four-count indictment against Julie Hiatt Steele, a Richmond woman who cast doubt on accusations by Kathleen E. Willey that President Clinton had made an unwelcome sexual pass at Ms. Willey.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wall St. Firms Nimbly Handle A Hard Quarter
description: Wall Street's major trading houses, buffeted by the financial upheaval that began when Russian markets collapsed in August, are starting to breathe a little easier.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'A Treasure House of Books'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, MARTIN LEWIS, III
description: COHN-Martin Lewis, III . On January 5th. Beloved husband of Nita and the late Myra. Devoted father of the late Audrey, of Elizabeth and Mayo Stuntz, Ellen Cohn and Larry Berkowitz, and Peggy Cohn and Peter Orlov. Dear brother of Raymond D. Cohn. Adored grandfather of Allison, James, Katie, Adrienne, Maggie, Alex and Juliana. Gentle stepfather of Bonnie and Daniel Tisch, and Freddie Jeck. Loving brother-in-law of Carolyn Cohn and Billie and Laurence Tisch. Wonderful uncle and friend to many. Funeral 11 A.M. Friday, January 8, Hoidal Funeral Home, 236 Monmouth Road, Oakhurst, New Jersey.

title: Hubble's Power Bolsters Count Of Galaxies
description: Taking a census of the galaxies in the universe is like counting the grains of sand on a beach. Even with leaping extrapolations, the task is probably impossible, and the numbers become, well, astronomical.

title: Man in Carjacking Is Found Dead In Hudson River
description: A car thief who vanished from the George Washington Bridge on Nov. 10 after a bizarre and fatal carjacking in Newark was found dead in the Hudson River on Nov. 26, the authorities disclosed today.

title: Justice Dept. Will Review Capital Police
description: Bowing to public complaints and his own concerns, the District of Columbia's Police Chief has asked the Justice Department to review all fatal shootings by District police officers over the last 10 years.

title: Commissioner's Office Won't Take On Umpires
description: Richie Phillips, the head of the umpires union, met with two Major League Baseball officials yesterday and afterward declared dead a plan to take jurisdiction of the umpires away from the league offices and place them under the commissioner's office.

title: After Kendra Webdale's Death
description: Right now, New Yorkers are particularly conscious of the problems of mentally ill people who are homeless or living without proper supervision. A 29-year-old man with a long history of mental illness has been charged with shoving Kendra Webdale of Manhattan to her death under a subway train. It is the sort of event that terrifies the millions of people who use the city subways regularly. Inevitably, it is sparking a political debate about whether Andrew Goldstein, Ms. Webdale's accused killer, was receiving the necessary care, and whether some new law or program is needed to prevent similar tragedies in the future.

title: A Historian Who Wielded a Brush as Well as a Pen
description: Once upon a time in this country, there were actually more artists than art historians. In fact, there was only one real specimen of the now ubiquitous breed, William Dunlap (1766-1839), a man-about-culture who was also a painter. His two-volume ''History of the Rise and Progress of the Arts of Design in the United States,'' published in 1834, is a chatty but far from naive rundown of American art from its inception to Dunlap's own day, and it established his reputation as the father of American art history. The book is still useful as a lode of information about its period.

title: Lockout Left Many Cash Drawers Locked
description: Through the 191-day National Basketball Association lockout, the economic losers were not only the players and the owners. There are the television networks that lost lucrative programming and the advertisers who lost a reliable way to reach young male viewers.

title: A Kariya Is Leading Maine's Turnaround
description: With the holiday tournaments -- whose results do not count in the league standings -- history, the long midwinter voyage to the post-season championships has begun.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MOORE CORP., Toronto, a maker of business forms, sold its operations in the Asia Pacific region in a management buyout.

title: Doctor Is Sentenced To Prison for Fraud
description: A Bordentown physician who pleaded guilty in November to faking paralysis in order to cheat four insurance companies out of claim payments was sentenced yesterday to five years in prison and ordered to pay fines and restitution of $136,000, state officials said.

title: Representatives Say They Want to Call Up to 15 as Witnesses for Senate Trial
description: As Senate leaders struggled to sketch parameters for a trial, the House members appointed to prosecute President Clinton said today that they wanted to present testimony from as many as 15 witnesses, including not just Monica S. Lewinsky but also an array of current and former Presidential advisers.

title: In Final Staredown, Players Take the Hit
description: Perhaps the best development for the union in the settlement of the National Basketball Association labor dispute is that the players and their negotiators won't have to go through the process again for six or seven years. These basketball guys haven't got it right yet.

title: Man Accused of Murder Is Competent for Trial
description: An Irvington man charged with killing a Newark prostitute has been declared competent to stand trial for murder after undergoing a monthlong psychiatric evaluation, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Some H.M.O.'s Plan Limited Coverage for New Arthritis Drug
description: Arthritis sufferers who want to try Celebrex, a new anti-inflammatory drug that was approved by the Food and Drug Administration last week, may have to pay for the drug themselves, as several of the nation's largest insurers plan to limit coverage of the pill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIEFENDORF, JOHN B.
description: DIEFENDORF-John B.., 67, of Georgetown, SC, died Tuesday. Husband of Patricia. Contributions in his memory to the Salvation Army Building Fund, PO Box M, Georgetown, S.C. 29442.

title: Union With Canada
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Danger, Under Construction
description: THE number of traffic fatalities has held steady in recent years, but experts say one category may be poised to rise: deaths in construction zones.

title: Dow Recovers From an Early Slide to Close Down 7.21, to 9,537.76
description: Stocks retreated from record levels but then rallied in the afternoon and finished little changed in a session marked by some warnings of profit shortfalls and a mildly negative reappraisal by one of Wall Street's most prominent strategists.

title: Reaching for A Glass Ceiling
description: The Girls are catching up to the Boys. Almost.

title: 17 Syllables to Share, And a Captive Audience
description: Opening today's session of the Microsoft antitrust trial, Federal District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson advised the lawyers that he had recently been handed a news item that it turned out had been circulating on the Internet in one form or another for years.

title: ATTRACTIONS
description: Museums and Sites

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, HERBERT
description: ADLER-Herbert . Died on Wednesday, January 6, 1999 in Naples, FL, having taken a very difficult path with great courage. Herbert was the only son of Lothar and Ellen Adler, and dearest friend and beloved husband of Susan. He was husband in first marriage to Elin and father of Eric and Marc. Funeral service will take place at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, New York on Sunday, January 10, 1999 at 11:30 A.M.

title: A Chance For Giuliani To Bend a Bit
description: ''I SPEND a lot of time compromising, and you just don't see it.''

title: So Dashing, Yet Humble And Forlorn
description: No matter how dashing or romantic he appeared in the movies, Marcello Mastroianni always projected the vulnerability of a European everyman who, even in the best of times, understood the fragility of life. This sense of a submerged fearfulness and innate humility was part of what made Mastroianni the most sympathetic of leading men, even when he was portraying scoundrels.

title: Weight Watchers' Tool: Plain Old Restlessness
description: It was a couch potato's dream: the announcement, three years ago, that the Mayo Clinic was looking for volunteers ''willing to overeat for the sake of science.''

title: 'Amnesiac' Gets His Name, and a Jail Cell
description: A young man who attracted international attention with his strange tale of waking up in a Montreal parking lot in October without any memory finally found his identity on Wednesday when police showed up to arrest him.

title: Foreign Affairs; While You Were Sleeping
description: Say, I've been away for the past four months writing a book. Has anything happened while I was gone?

title: For Some Divers, an Epiphany for All Their Lives
description: As the Greek Orthodox Archbishop of the Americas tossed a white wooden cross into the green bayou, a young man, destined for glory, plunged himself into the cold water after it, while an old man, warm and dry on the bank, sank deep into his own legend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAER, JAMES B.
description: BAER-James B. . The Board of Governors and Members of the Boca Rio Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member of the board, James B. Baer. Beloved husband of Margie. We extend our deepest sympathy to the family. Boca Rio Golf Club Norman Ricken, Pres.

title: The N.B.A. Lockout Is Over? Who Won?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, PAULA
description: SIEGEL-Paula. Of New York City on January 6, 1999. Daughter of Gladys Siegel of Albany, New York and the late Dr. Fred Siegel. Mother of William and George Duffy of New York City. Sister of Sharon and Sylvia R. Siegel and the late Toby Siegel. Services at the Levine Memorial Chapel, 649 Washington Avenue, Albany, NY on Friday, 11AM. For information call 518-438-1002.

title: A Puppeteer Thrives in a Watery Wonderland
description: ''Symphonie Fantastique'' may be, drop for drop, the most difficult piece of theater in New York to describe.

title: Network Opposes a Provision To Hold Private Deliberations
description: The Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton began today in the glare of television, but how much of the rest of the proceedings will be open to the public remained unclear.

title: Bank of England Cuts a Key Interest Rate
description: For the fourth time since October, the Bank of England cut a key interest rate today as Britain's economy continued its slide toward recession.

title: The N.B.A. Lockout Is Over? Who Won?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Setting for Debates And Oratory of Legend
description: The ceremonial Old Senate Chamber where 100 senators plan to discuss impeachment on Friday in a rare bipartisan caucus has been the site of legendary events and debates in the nation's history.

title: The Senate Takes Over
description: After the strife in the House, the opening of the Senate trial of President Clinton looked reassuringly decorous. Senator Strom Thurmond, who was born only 34 years after Andrew Johnson's impeachment, swore in the big, calm-looking Chief Justice, William Rehnquist. Then after a period of turmoil over the issue of calling witnesses, the majority leader, Trent Lott, and his Democratic counterpart, Tom Daschle, ended the day by announcing a plan to seek agreement on rules for the trial.

title: Sports of The Times; Players Saw It Was Time To Provide
description: HAVING seen coal miners crawl back into the 36-inch seam at the end of a strike, convinced they had been done dirty by the coal operators, I have the tiniest bit of trouble seeing the basketball players as an oppressed class.

title: Starr's Actions Cast Doubt on Senate Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Foes of L.I. Mansion Lose a Zoning Battle
description: The battle of the billionaire versus the millionaires came to a head at Town Hall here tonight, and the billionaire won. For now, at least.
