description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Bennett Bean

title: Reports of Spying Dim Outlook for Inspections
description: Reports that the United States used the United Nations weapons inspectors in Iraq as cover for spying on Saddam Hussein are dimming any chances that the inspection system will survive and that its head, Richard Butler, will remain in his job much longer, officials and diplomats here said today.

title: Next Step Is Courting The Fans
description: After the National Basketball Association's 29 owners officially insured labor peace for the next six years, Commissioner David Stern was asked if he was bluffing when he said he would scrap the season. ''You didn't pay to find out,'' he said, smiling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSELLE, DR. LEONE ROSE
description: ROSELLE-Dr. Leone Rose. Musician, scholar, linguist, teacher, died on Monday, December 21, at the Kateri Rehabilitation Residence in Manhattan. Dr. Roselle performed professionally on piano and organ. She held several degrees from Columbia University, including two PhDs. She spoke French, Spanish, Italian, Babylonian, Roumanian, and Japanese. She taught Latin and Greek in the Mamaroneck School District for many years. Her students remember her as dynamic, erudite. Among Dr. Roselle's accomplishments are a book on language, ''Secrets of Word Power'', and a Latin version of Dr. Seuss's Oh, the Places You'll Go, called ''O, Loca tu ibis!'' Dr. Roselle was a member of Marble Collegiate Church where a memorial service will be held at 2 PM on Sunday, January 10. Memorial donations in her name may be sent to the Marble Collegiate Church, 1 West 29th Street, New York, New York 10001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANHEIM, PAUL E.
description: MANHEIM-Paul E.., age 93. On January 1, 1999, of heart failure in Easthampton, attended by his wife of thirty years, Simone Hegeman Gardner. Brother of Frank Manheim of London, Louise Espy of Manhattan and the late Alice Kaplan. Father of Martha Green and Anthony A. Manheim of Brooklyn and Emily Goldman of Santa Fe. Also survived by seven grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Memorial service 11 AM, January 22, 725 Park Ave., NYC. Donations may be made to East End Hospice, 1111 Riverhead Road, Westhampton Beach, New York 11978 or to Dominican Sisters Family Health Service, PO Box 866, Amagansett, NY 11930.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Michael Bevilacqua

title: The Voices of the Chosen? O.K., but Who Chose These?
description: Provocative but not profound, strident but not subtle, and eclectic without being embracing, ''The American Jew'' takes on a complex subject that exceeds its blinkered vision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUTNY, FRANK J.
description: KUTNY-Frank J.. 86. Of Brooklyn, N.Y. Died Sunday after a long illness. Survived by his wife of 47 years, Barbara Burns Kutny; son, James Kutny, of Clifton Park, N.Y.; and daughter Kathleen Kutny, of Portland, ME; and six grandchildren. He worked for the New York Racing Assn. for 40 years.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Off the Menu column of the Dining section on Wednesday about Veritas, a new Manhattan restaurant, misstated the address. It is 43 East 20th Street, not West.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWOMEY, JEROME D.
description: TWOMEY-Jerome D.. Born October 27, 1920, died January 7, 1999 in Delray Beach, Florida. Beloved husband of Eileen O'Shaughnessy Twomey for 52 years. Much loved father of Robert (Kathleen) of Barrington, R.I., Diane Berk (Alexander) of Glencoe, Il., Carol Hafer (Jeffrey) of Port Washington, NY and Brian (Merethe) of Ossining, NY. Proud grandfather of 12. Cherished brother of Claire (Thomas) Dunne of Ridgewood, NJ and brother-in-law of John, Joan and Patricia O'Shaughnessy. For information Kraeer Funeral Home of Boca Raton, Fla. 561 395 1800

title: Rules Shouldn't Say Who Is a Jew
description: To the Editor:

title: Houston Wants Knicks To Get the Ball Rolling
description: The gymnasium was as are as a bachelor's refrigerator. Just a couple of leftover souls. A group of students had just filed out, and there was silence but for the faint sounds of someone hulking about in the basement one flight below.

title: Plan to Cut Electric Rates In New Jersey
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and legislative leaders reached agreement today on a plan to cut commercial and residential electricity rates by 10 percent over the next three years and deregulate the state's energy market.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about William H. Luers, the departing president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misstated the relationship between his position and that of Philippe de Montebello, the museum's director. The two have been equal, both reporting to the chairman; the director is not subordinate to the president. As the article noted, Mr. de Montebello will assume the additional title of chief executive on Jan. 31.

title: Paul Manheim, 93, Partner At Lehman for Many Years
description: Paul E. Manheim, a collector of Asian art, died on New Year's Day at his home in East Hampton, N.Y., 55 years to the day after he became a partner at the old Wall Street investment house of Lehman Brothers. He was 93.

title: Weekend Warrior; Following Her Bliss Into a Blast of Jabs, Hooks and Crosses
description: The double jab set up a right-cross, left-hook combination that landed firmly on the bridge on my nose with an audible crack. We were only 30 seconds into the first of two three-minute rounds. My eyes burned; my previously unblemished nose throbbed. Which, I suppose, was only natural since I was being pummeled by the 119-pound female Golden Gloves champion. More painful than the blows was the realization that this was my idea.

title: When Trouble Was Harder to Find
description: ''What it used to wind up is, nobody was tough. We were all tough, but nobody was the toughest, although we knew which guys in the gang were tougher.'' These confounding words come from Bengie, one of the few surviving members of the Jokers, the gang of teen-agers that Bruce Davidson photographed in the summer of 1959. In an exhibition of 50 of Mr. Davidson's black and white Brooklyn photographs at the International Center of Photography, you can see exactly what Bengie means.

title: PRIME CAPITAL AGREES TO BUY CONTROL OF HORIZON GROUP
description: Horizon Group Properties Inc., a developer of factory-outlet retail centers, said yesterday that a company controlled by its largest shareholder had offered to acquire control of Horizon in a transaction valued at as much as $90 million. The offer by Prime Capital Holdings Inc., a real estate finance company, values Horizon at about $7 a share. The shares of Horizon rose $1.25 each, or 32 percent, to $5.125. Under the offer, Prime Capital would sell its $40 million of net assets -- mainly loans -- to Horizon for 5.71 million shares valued at $7 each. Prime Capital would purchase 2.86 million more shares for $20 million and have an option to buy $30 million more in shares at $7 each. Prime Capital is controlled by Prime Group Inc., whose chairman, Michael W. Reschke, is Horizon's largest shareholder.

title: On My Mind
description: So here we are at the U.N. A half-century ago it was created to keep peace and expand freedom, not a feckless dream but a reachable goal dear to the United States, the key founding member.

title: Outsize Visions Crammed With Shapes
description: Kevin Wynn thinks big. True, there was a solo on the program presented by the Kevin Wynn Collection on Wednesday night in the ''Altogether Different'' festival at the Joyce Theater. But that solo was performed by an outsize talent named Matthew Rushing, a guest dancer from the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. And dancers spilled across the stage for the rest of the evening in what was the equivalent of a cast of thousands for scrimping downtown dance, the population from which the Joyce series draws most of its choreographers.

title: Rival Plans for Trial
description: Following are preliminary proposals by Democratic and Republican senators for President Clinton's trial:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONESIFER, RICHARD JAMES
description: STONESIFER-Richard James. 76. Died Tuesday afternoon at his home after an illness. A graveside memorial service will be Saturday at 11 AM in Cedardale Cemetery in Mullins. Rev. Paul Frey will officiate. Dr. Stonesifer was born June 21, 1922 in Lancaster County, PA. A son of the late Rev. Paul T. & Esther Wittlinger Stonesifer. He received his AB from Franklin & Marshall College, 1946; MA from Northwestern Univ., 1947; PhD from Univ. of PA, 1953. He was faculty member at Franklin & Marshall College, 1947-63, Assistant Professor of English, 1954-63, Assistant to the Dean, 1957-60, Assistant President, 1960-63; Assistant to the Provost, also Director of the College of General Studies, Univ. of PA., 1963-65; Associate Professor of Communications, Annenberg School of Communications, 1963-65. He was Dean of the College of Liberal Arts, Professor of English at Drew Univ., Madison, NJ, 1965-71; President of Monmouth Univ., West Long Branch, NJ, 1971-79; Woodrow Wilson Professor of Humanities & Social Science at Monmouth Univ., 197982; Moderator TV Discussion Series, 1954-60. He was author of ''W.H. Davies: A critical Biography'' 2nd Edition, 1965, also authored articles in professional journals. He was a newspaper columnist and a weekly commentator; a free lance journalist. He was a member of the PA Advisory Commission on Educational Broadcasting, 1963-65; Member of Board of Directors of Harrisburg Area Center of Higher Education, 1963-65; Trustee of the NJ Cancer Institute in 1975; Member of ''Who's Who in America''; served with USAAF, 1943-46; Member of Phi Beta Kappa. Retired to Mullins, SC in 1983 where he wrote a weekly column for ''The Marion Star-Mullins Enterprise'' Newspaper and was Rotarian of the year 1987-88. His life was devoted to Higher Education, and to Keeping the Liberal Arts at the center of the enterprise, even as of necessity he put new emphasis on professional and career matters. In teaching and in administration he took as a fundamental guidance the teaching from ancient Greece: Moderation in all things. He is survived by a daughter, Pamela S. McClellan and a grandson, Jason M.R. Hurley both of Mullins, SC. Memorials may be made to the Hospice of the Pee Dee, 555 E. Cheves St., Florence, SC 29506-2617. For information Meares Funeral Home of Mullins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECTOR, MERI M.
description: SPECTOR-Meri M.. On January 6, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Isaac Spector. Loving mother of David, Adam and Victoria. Service on Sunday, January 10, 4 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Colombian Rebel Chief Is Absent as Peace Talks Start
description: Colombia's first steps toward talks aimed at ending its civil war stumbled today as the commander of the largest rebel group did not appear at an opening ceremony with President Andres Pastrana.

title: Family's Love Is Focus at Subway Victim's Funeral
description: Years from now, most people will probably remember Kendra A. Webdale as the young woman who was pushed off a subway platform in Manhattan by a stranger with a history of mental problems. As the young woman whose tragic, touching story was the stuff of national news and tabloid headlines like ''She Was An Angel.'' As the young woman whose case triggered a critical reassessment of mental health programs.

title: Alcan Selling German Unit
description: The Federal-Mogul Corporation, the world's largest maker of engine seals, agreed today to buy Alcan Aluminum Ltd.'s German piston unit for an undisclosed amount to expand its products for European auto makers. Alcan Deutschland G.m.b.H., with annual sales of more than $150 million, makes aluminum pistons under the Nural brand name for cars and trucks. The company employs 1,100 workers at a plant in Nuremberg, Germany.

title: What a 'Full Trial' Means
description: WASHINGTONAs the debate intensifies about how to conduct the impeachment trial of President Clinton, one suggestion that has gained momentum is a hybrid procedure involving a ''quick'' evidentiary trial that could culminate in a vote in mid-February. However attractive a quick resolution might be, the bottom line is that the Senate can legitimately choose between only two straightforward alternatives: a proceeding based on the factual record already established in this matter, or a full evidentiary trial with live testimony. Trying to steer a middle course is not only unrealistic, it is also unfair.

title: Clinton Takes A Middle Path On Steel Curbs
description: The White House told Congress tonight that President Clinton would not yet limit imports of foreign steel to the United States, despite the demands of steel unions and some producers, but would take a range of lesser actions intended to aid the industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGFORD, VELMA MOURINE
description: LANGFORD - Velma Mourine. (nee Haskew), age 80, December 19, 1998 in New York City. Beloved mother of Barbara Kathryne Langford-Miles. Devoted daughter of the late Anna Marie Hiedle-Haskew. Born February 12, 1918 in Stockton, Alabama. Resident of Abilene, Texas until 1984. Business Administration graduate, 1940 Abilene Christian University. A memorial service will be held on Sunday January 17, 1999, 2:30 PM, at the Chapel of St. George Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Park off 2nd Avenue between East 16th Street and Rutherford Place, Manhattan. Velma, a fragile flower among the weeds, whose light will shine forever in the hearts of those she touched by her grace and love.

title: Prosecution Almost Rests in the Microsoft Trial
description: As the last Government witness nears the end of his testimony, it is increasingly clear that the Government's antitrust case against Microsoft is an indictment not only of the business practices of the world's dominant software maker but also of its corporate character.

title: The Rural Life; The Everyday Returns
description: All of the days with eves before them are behind us now for another year. The grand themes -- rebirth and genial carnality -- have come and gone like a chinook wind, bringing a familiar end-of-year thaw to body and spirit. Now the everyday returns, and with it the ordinary kind of week in which Friday doesn't turn into Sunday -- and Saturday into Sunday -- as it has for two weeks running. It's time for a week in which each morning throws off a magnetic field all its own, when it's no trick telling Tuesday from Wednesday just by the sound of the alarm clock or the mood of your spouse.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 29 about the new Governor of Minnesota, Jesse Ventura, misidentified the sponsor of a poll that found that more people would vote for Mr. Ventura today than did in November. It was conducted by The St. Paul Pioneer Press, not The Star Tribune in Minneapolis.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Ordinary Parker Vector rollerball pens retail for $7.95. But they do not have little white letters on the side that say ''United States Senator.'' The Parker Vectors handed out as senators signed their names in the ''oath book'' at the beginning of the impeachment trial yesterday did.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Charles Pratt

title: Jackson Refuses Bulls' Offer
description: Jerry Reinsdorf, principal owner of the Chicago Bulls, placed a phone call on Wednesday morning to Phil Jackson, the retired coach of the Bulls. Reinsdorf asked Jackson if he would reconsider and return to the team for this season. ''They had an amicable little chat,'' said Tim Hallam, a Bulls spokesman, ''but Phil said he declined the invitation.''

title: A Loving Home Life, Right Down to the Nits
description: A mother delousing her child's hair may not be the most appealing subject, but the Dutch painter Pieter de Hooch (1629-1684) saw it as a labor of love. In ''A Mother and Child With Its Head in Her Lap'' (1658-60) he conjures up a convincing scene of domestic felicity.

title: Tiffany Holder To Sell Stake
description: Tiffany & Company, the second-largest United States jewelry retailer, said yesterday that its largest shareholder, Mitsukoshi Ltd., planned to sell its 12 percent stake in a public offering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, BORIS
description: FEINBERG-Boris. The Officers and Members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of their dear friend and fellow member Boris Feinberg. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife Sylvia, to his children and other members of his family. Samuel G. Weinberg, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELIN, JEFFREY
description: ZELIN-Jeffrey. The Great Neck Synagogue notes with sorrow the passing of our member and extends its heartfleft condolences to his entire bereaved family. May they be comforted among those who mourn for Zion & Jerusalem. Dale Polakoff, Rabbi Dr. Ephraim Wolf, Rabbi Emeritus Mark Bunim, President

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Inez van Lamsweerde

title: THE TRIAL OF THE PRESIDENT: THE SCENE -- Capitol Sketchbook; For Senate, a Stirring Time Of Worry and Wonderment
description: Even before Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist appeared as a berobed outsider to preside at the Senate trial of President Clinton, there was an unscripted moment that was no less spectacular: an informal and thoroughly anxious floor gathering of dozens of senators suddenly evolved, scrambling in an ad hoc grasp at last-minute bipartisanship and common agreement in the well of the Senate.

title: LEAR AGREES TO BUY SEAT BUSINESS OF HYUNDAI MOTOR
description: The Lear Corporation, the world's biggest maker of car seats and automotive interiors, agreed yesterday to buy the seat business of the Hyundai Motor Company of South Korea. Lear is expected to pay about 100 billion won ($87 million) for the business, which accounts for 3 percent of Hyundai Motor's sales, the Korean company said in a statement. Lear would also take over the seat business's 605 employees. Lear, based in Southfield, Mich., has 179 factories worldwide, with few in the Pacific Rim.

title: Classic Balanchine, Pared of Distractions
description: The New York State Theater was a glorious place to be on Wednesday night. The New York City Ballet continued its 50th-anniversary season by offering George Balanchine's ''Agon,'' ''Concerto Barocco'' and ''The Four Temperaments,'' masterpieces that surely rank high on almost everybody's list of Top 10 Balanchine ballets.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the Agriculture Department's settlement of a discrimination lawsuit filed by black farmers in 1997 referred incorrectly to bonuses offered some black farmers after the Civil War. Although Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman set aside thousands of acres of confiscated and abandoned land in Georgia and South Carolina for settlement by blacks, with each family also receiving an Army mule to work it -- a program known as ''40 acres and a mule'' -- the offer was canceled by President Andrew Johnson, who returned the property to its prewar owners.

title: City Ends Contract With a Foster Agency
description: City officials, continuing a crackdown on the foster-care system, said yesterday that they would cancel a multimillion-dollar city contract with a Brooklyn foster-care agency accused of mismanagement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOIFER, ROSE
description: SOIFER-Rose. Beloved wife of Hyman. Devoted mother of Tina. Services Sunday, 10:30 AM at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Rego Park.

title: Residential Real Estate; Brooklyn Project Aims At People 75 and Older
description: Work began last month on transforming an empty lot along Emmons Avenue in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, into a 104-unit apartment building that will provide elderly tenants with meals, services and personal care.

title: Buildings Destroyed At Brotherhood Winery
description: Fire gutted two large buildings last night at the Brotherhood Winery, the country's oldest continuously operated winery.

title: INSIDE
description: Embassies at Risk

title: A Reimagining: What If Big Ben Tolled for Hitler?
description: The politics of two centuries separated by 300 years inform the two intelligent, understated and absorbing black-and-white films by Kevin Brownlow and Andrew Mollo that are being revived today at the Film Forum for a run through next Thursday.

title: City Ballet: 50 Years Of Thrills For Stars
description: ''Balanchine always talked about his ballets as if they were something only for the moment, for now -- his familiar word,'' Mikhail Baryshnikov wrote in the foreword to ''Tribute'' (William Morrow, $50), a recent book of pictures and essays celebrating the New York City Ballet's 50th anniversary.

title: First Pair of Glasses Is Unexpected Joy
description: Children often sit close to the television, so Tysha Kinred thought it was no big deal when her 4-year-old son, John, watched ''Barney'' with his face just inches from the screen.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the economic prosperity in many midsized American cities misstated the ownership of a telephone operator center in Jacksonville, Fla. It is owned by a subsidiary of Cincinnati Bell; AT&T sold it last March.

title: U.S. Jet Fires Missile at an Iraqi Battery After Being Targeted
description: Pressing its challenge against American and British control of its skies, an Iraqi antiaircraft battery today turned its radar on an American fighter jet, which responded by firing a missile at it, the Pentagon said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: CENDANT SETTLES LAWSUIT BY INVESTORS FOR $350 MILLION
description: The Cendant Corporation, a franchiser and direct marketer, agreed yesterday to settle a class-action lawsuit by investors for $350 million. Cendant, based in Parsippany, N.J., agreed to raise by $350 million the market value of securities it issued last year to help finance a bid to buy American Bankers Insurance Group Inc. Plaintiffs contended that the company's executives had misled investors by failing to disclose accounting fraud in April that resulted in a drop in Cendant's share price. The accounting troubles also caused the $3.1 billion purchase of American Bankers Insurance to fall through. Cendant stock rose 50 cents yesterday, to $19.9375.

title: Fishermen Recount Perils as Search Continues for 3 Off Jersey Shore
description: The men puffing smoky breath in the cold of the Point Pleasant Packing Company warehouse here today could all tell firsthand stories of close calls they had in their years as fishermen and clammers, working the sometimes unforgiving waters off the Jersey Shore.

title: Partisanship Lapping at Senate, Too
description: After the extraordinary rancor and the party-line impeachment vote in the House, many senators, priding themselves on serving in a more deliberative, more temperate chamber, predicted that they would have an easy standard to beat.

title: Boeing Received Orders for 656 Planes in '98
description: The Boeing Company, the world's leading commercial aircraft maker, announced last night that it had received orders for 656 planes in 1998, 15 percent more than the 568 ordered a year earlier.

title: Critics Gather To Fight Plans For a Shelter
description: More than 500 people gathered at a Brooklyn synagogue last night for a forum where local politicians detailed strategies that they hope will persuade Mayor Rudolph W. Guiliani to rescind his decision to put a homeless shelter in their neighborhood.

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Manufacturing Orders Increase
description: Orders placed with United States manufacturers rose six-tenths of a percent in November, the fifth increase in six months, as domestic demand offset weak exports, Commerce Department figures showed today.

title: Dairy Group to End Work With Burnett
description: Dairy Management Inc., which conducts advertising and promotional programs for the American Dairy Association and the National Dairy Council, and the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago are negotiating to end their relationship on an account with billings estimated at $30 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALMODOVAR, JOAN KAREN,
description: ALMODOVAR-Joan Karen,. 64. At home in Winter Haven, Fla, on December 18, 1998. Formerly of New York, where she worked as an alcoholism counselor at St. Vincent's Hospital. Memorial Mass, 2 p.m., January 9 at St. Francis, 135 West 31st St. Interment at St. Michael's Cemetery, East Elmhurst, NY.

title: Ford's Idea for Safer Safety
description: IN an effort to reduce injuries caused by air bags and safety belts, the Ford Motor Company plans to add computer controls to its cars and light trucks that would activate safety devices in different ways, depending on the severity of a crash, the size of the car's occupants, the position of the driver's seat and whether safety belts are being used.

title: Five Dissident Army Officers Are Reportedly Detained in Mexico
description: Five dissident army officers who tried to deliver to President Ernesto Zedillo a letter complaining of abuses of soldiers by army commanders were arrested today by the military authorities, the army's top prosecutor said.

title: Jane Cushman, 68, A Writer and Agent
description: Jane Clapperton Cushman, a writer and literary agent, died on Dec. 30 at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 68 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: A More or Less Proven Liaison
description: Many people thought that recent DNA studies settled a longstanding historical debate by proving that Thomas Jefferson was the father of Eston Hemings, the last child of his slave Sally Hemings. But this week a rear-guard group of Jefferson buffs and historians argued that the evidence was not conclusive, that the DNA tests showed that any one of several Jeffersons who were in Virginia at the time could have fathered the child and that the assertion about Thomas Jefferson was therefore only ''a probability.''

title: THERMO INSTRUMENT TO PAY CASH FOR SPECTRA-PHYSICS
description: Thermo Instrument Systems Inc. said yesterday that it would offer 160 Swedish kronor, about $20, a share for all outstanding shares of Spectra-Physics A.B. At that price, Thermo Instrument Systems would buy Spectra-Physics, which has about 17.62 million shares outstanding, for about $355 million. The Spectra-Physics board has recommended that its shareholders accept the offer. Spectra-Physics, which makes laser-based instrumentation systems and is based in Stockholm, had revenues of about $432 million in 1997. Thermo Instrument Systems, which is based in Hurst, Tex., provides analytical instruments. Its stock was unchanged at $14.3125.

title: Sure, Mom May Be Dead, But That Won't Stop Her
description: A beautiful cosmetic surgeon named Sydney Hansen (Melina Kanakaredes), brown curls cascading down her back, travels from Los Angeles to her hometown of Providence, exuding the aura of Glinda the Good Witch. The resemblance may be accidental, the result of a hideous green bridesmaid's dress she wears for her pregnant sister's wedding, but it suits her. Before you know it, Syd is dispensing kindness and wisdom, being nice to puppies, saving human lives in a clinic. Soon all the people of Providence are clicking their heels and chanting, ''There's no place like home.''

title: 2 Killed in Harlem in Apparent Case of Mistaken Identity
description: In what police say was a case of mistaken identity, gunmen burst into a Harlem apartment Wednesday night, killing a woman and her nephew with single shots to the head as the woman's two children cried nearby.

title: Many Flaws Blamed in Embassy Attacks
description: A State Department investigation of last summer's bombings of two American embassies in East Africa found that a ''collective failure'' by senior Government officials and lawmakers over decades had left a number of American embassies vulnerable to terrorist attack, senior Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: Progress on Environment?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, ZALMAN CHAIM
description: BERNSTEIN-Zalman Chaim . ''She weeps bitterly in the night and her tear is on her cheek''. A prince in Israel has fallen. A treasured jewel of the Jewish people has been called by the Almighty to return his soul to its eternal reward. An extraordinary and humble man whose very being radiated kindness, dignity and modesty, his life reflected the majesty of Judaic values and ethics. His complete commitment to the health and well being of Klal Yisrael and the strenghthening of Torah in America and Israel were exceptional. His acts of tzedakah and chesed were the daily inspirations that guided his life, but he would not allow plaques or markers to identify his exceptional largesse. In fact, his generosity excelled beyond any rabbinic definition of tzedakah. He always viewed his resources as granted to him by the Almighty to benefit others. In the world of international business and finance where he was a giant, he never forgot for a minute who he was, his purpose in life, and his bond to Jewish tradition. He was tall in stature but reached greater heights in his deeds. When a modern day history of the Jewish people and the State of Israel is written an important chapter will be devoted to the remarkable deeds of compassion that he performed during his life, including his status as a Benefactor of the ''Hospital With a Heart''. The people of Jerusalem and Israel will be grateful for his patronage of the Jesselson Heart Center and the Harry, Judith and Leonard Wilf Woman and Infant Center on ''Charle's Floor,'' in memory of Charles H. Bendheim, z''l. Our sincerest condolences to his mother, Martha, wife, Mem, son, Claude, daughters Rochel Leah and Leslie, and the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President Lee Weinbach, President, National Women's Division Sidney Adler, Treasurer International Board of Directors Jack C. Bendheim, Co-Chair Michael G. Jesselson, Co-Chair Stuart Tauber, Executive Director BERNSTEIN-Zalman Chaim. The National Jewish Outreach Program mourns the passing of Zalman Chaim Bernstein, noted businessman, distinguished philanthropist, and devoted Jew. Reb Zalman played a key role in NJOP's founding, and his magnificent generosity through the AviChai Foundation, which he created and endowed, enabled NJOP to offer the Turn Friday Night Into Shabbat and Beginners Services programs to the entire Jewish community of America. Mr. Bernstein's love for the Torah and the Jewish people was exemplified by his vital role in the establishment and support of the Association of Jewish Outreach Professionals, dedicated to improving the professional status and skills of the Jewish outreach worker. Reb Zalman, you will be sorely missed. Our sincere condolences to his mother Martha, wife Mem, son Claude, daughters Leslie and Rochel Leah, and brother Paul. Hamakom Yinachem Etchem Btoch Shear Aveilay Zion V'yerushalayim. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir. BERNSTEIN-Zalman Chaim. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of our esteemed friend, the eminent investment manager who expressed his devotion to the Jewish people through the support of such outreach programs as adult education strengthening commitment to Jewish values and observance. We remember him too as a founder of the Avi Chai Foundation, which has generously supported our Bernard Revel Graduate School, and as the inaugural speaker at the Dean's Forum of our Sy Syms School of Business. We extend our heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees BERNSTEIN-Zalman. The Orthodox Union deeply mourns the passing of a visionary and resourceful friend who invested much of his life and drive in an unparalleled effort to inspire and motivate scores of thousands of alienated Jews to emulate his personal example-to return to the faith of his fathers. His philanthropic Foundation and slogan ''Avi Chai'' ''My father lives'' promoted Jewish education and outreach with unprecedented creativity and independence. Who will take his place? May the family be comforted amongst the mourners for Zion and Jerusalem. Mandell I. Ganchrow, MD, Pres Marcel Weber, Chair, Bd of Dir Dr Marcos Katz, Chair, Bd of Gov Rabbi Raphael B. Butler, Exec VP Rabbi Pinchas Stolper, Sr Exec BERNSTEIN-Zalman Chaim. January 6, 1999, 19 Tevet 5759. Zalman was the founding Chairman and sole benefactor of THE AVI CHAI FOUNDATION, which was established in 1984 to promote Jewish commitment and Jewish unity. Zalman brought to his philanthropic work a broad vision, incredible energy, a keen eye for detail, and a passionate love for the Jewish people. He will be sorely missed. AVI CHAI's culture will always reflect Zalman's spirit and vision, as we continue in his path to advance the goals of the Foundation. AVI CHAI's Trustees and Staff BERNSTEIN-Zalman Chaim. Lincoln Square Synagogue mourns the passing of our dedicated trustee and one of our strongest and most devoted benefactors, Zalman Chaim Bernstein. His commitment to Torah, the Jewish people, and the land of Israel all began here and spread to the entire Jewish world. Zalman's vision of the future of our people through education inspired his generosity to many Torah institutions. May his memory serve as a blessing for his family and all of Israel. Adam Mintz, Rabbi Richard Kestenbaum, President BERNSTEIN-Zalman (Sanford). On behalf of Yeshivat Har Etzion (Gush) and the Herzog College, its leaders Rabbi Dr. Aharon Lichtenstein, Rabbi Yehuda Amital and Rabbi Shmuel Wygoda, heartfelt condolences are offered to the family and friends of Zalman Chaim Bernstein. As a proud philanthropic Jew always striving for more knowledge, he passed that pride and love of Torah on to countless Jewish students across the world. Terry Novetsky, Dorothy Berman Tobias Schapiro, Herbert Seif BERNSTEIN-Zalman Chaim (Sanford C.). Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the father of its esteemed member, Rochel Leah Bernstein. We extend to the entire family our sincere condolences on the passing of a dedicated Jewish personality. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi, Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres., David Yagoda, Chairman, Dr. William Schwartz, President BERNSTEIN-Zalman C. The Shalem Center mourns the loss of Zalman C. Bernstein, devoted friend and partner. We extend our condolences to his wife Mem and to the entire Bernstein family. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Roger Hertog, Trustee Barry Klein, Trustee Yoram Hazony, President BERNSTEIN-Zalman Chaim. We mourn the loss of our beloved friend, Zalman. He strove to perfect the world; he inspired by his deeds and words; his concern enriched all who knew him. Rose and Morty BLECHMAN-Lillian. /d. April 23, 1918 to January 6, 1999. In timeless adoration and loving remembrance of a matriarch unsurpassed by all others. Lil was born in NYC and raised in Hurleyville, NY, where her father, Sam Newberg, had a general store. She was like a beautiful and delicate flower, loved to travel and laugh. A child of a bygone era, Lil managed to incorporate Old World values and tradition with modernday life. She was a shrewd businesswoman, had an eye for fashion and was the essence of a true ''yiddisha Momma.'' Lil's unwavering devotion, love, strength and nurturing kept this family bound together despite all tragedy, strife and adversity. Perhaps of greatest merit was her steadfast devotion to her husband of 56 years, who became ill in recent years. Her courage and love enabled Ben Blechman to live with dignity at home. Throughout Lil's lifetime she continued to give of herself and was always prepared to sacrifice for her loved ones. Whatever else failed, we could always depend on Lil. Lil was our home. Her wonderful stories of her life and times always kept us amazed and riveted. Her genuine concern and interest in our lives never waned. What a joy and honor it has truly been to know and love her. An angel of a Mom, a loving and proud grandmother, a champion negotiator and a best friend. She was precious beyond words. Lillian, Our Angel, God Bless and keep you in his loving embrace. Watch over us, Lil, guide us and stay with us forever. We will never stop thinking of you and loving you Your Family and Friends

title: Excited to Be Headed Back to the Sideline
description: When TNT returns to televising National Basketball Association games on Feb. 5, Hubie Brown will be ready. The cable network's lead analyst has run clinics throughout the United States and abroad to stay busy during the lockout. He watched a lot of college basketball and envisioned himself at courtside, but TNT and TBS, its Turner Sports sister network, carry no collegiate games.

title: Purring Along Nicely, Thank You
description: ''Don't you know nobody's 38 anymore?'' Eartha Kitt scoffed in her signature growl to the youngish waiter who presented her with a bottle of champagne and a glass onstage at the Cafe Carlyle on Tuesday evening. ''How would you like to be 78 before this night is over?'' she purred, pouring a glass and tilting it to his lips.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANNER, ANDREE W.
description: BANNER-Andree W. . Age 92. Wife of the late Warren M. Banner. Diretor of Urban Leauge. Died on January 1, 1999, at Nyack Hosptial, Nyack, New York. For information call T. J. McGowan Sons Funeral Home, Garnerville, New York.

title: Head of Housing Authority Quits Under Rising Scrutiny
description: Ruben Franco, whose tenure as chairman of the New York City Housing Authority had come under growing scrutiny since a fire in an authority building last month killed three firefighters, announced his resignation yesterday.

title: Two Big Names On Small Screen
description: It may be a first: a $35 million movie that goes straight to video without a theater run. Movies on that route usually don't cost a fortieth of that price. They also usually don't involve a name star and a big-time producer. But this is a peculiar case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, LILLIAN
description: HOROWITZ-Lillian. On January 6, 1999. Wife of the late George Horowitz. Beloved mother of Bronnie Hindin, Diane Stoller and Cindy Drachman. Cherished grandmother to Jillian. Services private

title: Watchdog for Abused Children Has Its Own Woes
description: The latest plan to rebuild New York City's troubled child welfare system relies heavily on a little-known state office to push, prod and strictly monitor the city as it struggles down the road to reform.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Youth Says He Got Idea for Sexual Abuse From Springer Show
description: A 15-year-old boy accused along with a younger brother of sexually abusing his 8-year-old half-sister over the last three years maintains that he got the idea from watching a show on incest on ''The Jerry Springer Show,'' the police say.

title: A Conductor With a Soul Matched to Balanchine's
description: George Balanchine once said that music was the floor that dancers dance on. Hugo Fiorato, the principal conductor of the City Ballet Orchestra, said he agreed, particularly in the case of the Balanchine repertory.

title: Police Chief Resigns Over Anwar Case
description: KUALA LUMPUR  The top police officer in Malaysia resigned Thursday, saying he accepted "full responsibility" for the beating of Anwar Ibrahim, the former deputy prime minister.

title: Clinton Trial Opens, but Process Talks Go On
description: Raising the specter of a trial that ''could go on forever and ever,'' the White House warned today that if the Senate called witnesses to testify about President Clinton, it might use every tool available to build his defense.

title: U.S. Used U.N. Team to Place Spy Device in Iraq, Aides Say
description: In March, in a last-ditch attempt to uncover Saddam Hussein's covert weapons and intelligence networks, the United States used the United Nations inspection team to send an American spy into Baghdad to install a highly sophisticated electronic eavesdropping system.

title: Steel Dreams That the Eye Can Cherish
description: People often complain that buildings seldom look as good as the renderings artists make of them. But whose fault is that? The truth is that few people are born with sharp eyes. When vision is not cultivated by memory, shock and enthusiasm, the world can look remarkably dull.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS FALLS. The price of natural gas dropped in reaction to a forecast that calls for above-normal temperatures in the next 10 days. Gas for February delivery fell 9.5 cents, to $1.836 for each 1,000 cubic feet.

title: Behind Parcells, 12 Silent Soldiers
description: Bill Parcells, the tyrannical coach of the Jets, demands as much from his assistant coaches as he does from his players. He does not cut corners with them. There is little sugarcoating.

title: MCI Worldcom May Join The Bidding for Airtouch
description: MCI Worldcom Inc., the No. 2 long-distance telephone carrier, is considering joining the bidding for Airtouch Communications Inc., the big wireless phone company, executives close to the discussions said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stock Market Recovers From an Early Deep Plunge

title: FINOVA GROUP TO BUY SIRROM CAPITAL WITH STOCK
description: The Finova Group Inc., a commercial lender, agreed yesterday to buy a small-business lender, the Sirrom Capital Corporation, for about $379 million in stock to expand the services it offers its clients. Phoenix-based Finova agreed to pay 0.1634 share for each Sirrom share, valuing Sirrom at $9.30 a share based on Wednesday's closing prices. Sirrom provides secured loans to United States companies with annual revenue between $5 million and $50 million and offers mergers and acquisition advice through its Harris Williams & Company subsidiary. Sirrom reported a third-quarter loss after writing down the value of loans on its books. The stock of the Nashville-based Sirrom jumped 33.3 percent, or $2, to $8. Finova fell $1.50, to $55.4375.

title: Brazilian Stocks Fall Sharply After State Threatens Default
description: The Brazilian stock market tumbled yesterday after the Governor of one of the country's largest states said he would not make debt payments to the central Government for 90 days.

title: ASSOCIATES FIRST CAPITAL TO DISMISS 5% OF AVCO WORKERS
description: The Associates First Capital Corporation, the largest publicly traded United States finance company, said yesterday that it would dismiss about 5 percent of the employees of Avco Financial Services as it begins to combine the two companies. Associates, based in Irving, Tex., completed its $3.9 billion purchase of Avco from Textron Inc. on Wednesday. It said it would dismiss 425 of Avco's 8,000 employees as it combined offices in the United States, Britain and Canada. Avco's base in Costa Mesa, Calif., is to close and 200 workers dismissed; 200 others will have the option of moving to Irving. Avco's loan-processing office in Denver is to close and its 200-member staff eliminated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, HERBERT
description: FINKELSTEIN-Herbert. (Herbert Reynolds). Son of the late Louis and Evelyn. Served in the U.S. Army Air Force in World War II and later was an entertainer on stage and TV. Burial today, 10 AM, Mount Zion Cemetery.

title: Fluffy Eggs and a Haze of Medication
description: The most intriguing thing about ''Some Voices'' is a mushroom omelet. It's prepared onstage by Max Baker at the conclusion of the two-hour play, and the actor makes such a pleasant production of the chopping, sauteeing and whisking that you find yourself more engrossed in his labors than in virtually anything else that happens all evening.

title: Much More Than Meets The Eye
description: In Modernism, form is supposed to follow function. In antiques, form often hides function, which is much more fun.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Waltercio Caldas

title: Pate, Using Anger Control, Shares Lead With 3 Others
description: Even when Steve Pate made mistakes today, the result was usually positive.

title: Giuliani Calls for High-Rise Sprinklers
description: In the aftermath of fires that killed seven people in apartment buildings in Brooklyn and Manhattan last month, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed yesterday that sprinklers be required in all new or rehabilitated high-rise apartment buildings, and that emergency public address systems be required in existing apartment towers.

title: Starr's Actions Cast Doubt on Senate Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about DNA evidence that Thomas Jefferson fathered a child with a slave, Sally Hemings, omitted a historian's reply in some editions to a charge that racist thinking motivated some historians who discount the possibility. The historian, Joseph J. Ellis, who studied Jefferson, said that before the DNA testing, there had been evidence on both sides of the issue. Further, he said, historians note that most of Jefferson's contemporaries dismissed the fatherhood account, and he said it was hard for many historians to believe Jefferson would have persisted in such a liaison after having been publicly accused of it.

title: THE TRIAL OF THE PRESIDENT: THE MEDIA -- Critic's Notebook; Television Highlights Discordance Between History and Emotional Force
description: Conditioned by the Diana years, television viewers have come to expect ceremony to mean regal extravagance, a fairy-tale wedding in St. Paul's Cathedral or a funeral in Westminster Abbey. But the American ceremony on view yesterday looked like men and women in business suits (mostly white men in dark suits), standing in line, signing a book and keeping a souvenir pen.

title: High Mark for New York Student Standards
description: A new state-by-state study of public schools placed New York first in the nation in holding students to rigorous academic standards and assessments.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Rehnquist, in New Arena, Appears at Home
description: For his 27 years on the Supreme Court 27 years to the day, coincidentally -- William H. Rehnquist's working life has followed a steady rhythm.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Rules Shouldn't Say Who Is a Jew
description: To the Editor:

title: Palisades Center, the Rumor Mall; Rosie O'Donnell Wants to Know: Is It Really Going to Sink?
description: Ever since it opened in March, the huge Palisades Center mall has been dogged by rumors.

title: In the End, Most Retailers Had a Happy Holiday
description: What was supposed to be a good season for retailers turned out to be a great one instead as last-minute and post-holiday shopping propelled December sales gains to their highest in half a decade, according to figures released yesterday by merchants.

title: New Video Releases
description: The Truman Show

title: Conner to Merge Teams for America's Cup
description: Dennis Conner, the veteran America's Cup skipper, said yesterday that he has taken the flailing Virgin Islands America's Cup Challenge under his wing in a joint effort to win yachting's oldest trophy.

title: Rules Shouldn't Say Who Is a Jew
description: To the Editor:

title: John Lennon's Sketches Find an Innovative Outlet
description: With baby boomers as serious about their children and grandchildren as they were about their music, maybe it's not so farfetched to think that John Lennon would find a second career in the layette department.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Doug Aitken

title: Paul M. Zoll Is Dead at 87; Pioneered Use of Pacemakers
description: Dr. Paul M. Zoll, a Harvard cardiologist and pioneer in developing the heart monitors, pacemakers and defibrillators used by millions of people around the world, died on Tuesday at the Heathwood Rehabilitation and Nursing Center in Chestnut Hill, Mass. He was 87 and had lived at the nursing center for three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEHLMAN, RAE.
description: MEHLMAN-Rae.. Lido Beach Synagogue mourns the passing of Rae Mehlman, beloved and devoted mother of our esteemed Rabbi, Harav Daniel H. Melman. May God console the family in their hour of bereavement. Shiva will be at 223 Beech 140 Street, Belle Harbor until Wednesday morning, January 13th. Alex Berkovitch, President MEHLMAN-Rae, Mrs. We record with sorrow the passing of the beloved and devoted mother of Diane Schiff, Rabbi Daniel and Mimi Mehlman, Evelyn and Stanley Liker, and Chani and Abie Dear, and adored grandmother and cherished greatgrandmother. May the family be consoled in their hour of bereavement amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shiva will be observed at 223 Beach 140th Street, Belle Harbor, NY until Wednesday morning, January 13th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, RUTH
description: COHEN-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Henry Cohen. Loving mother of Lucille Schlecker and Barbara Courtian, and mother-inlaw of Austin Schlecker and Martin Courtian. Devoted sister of Sylvia Hollander. Cherished grandmother of Jane and Jeffrey, Burton and Elyse, David and Susan, Lauren and George, Jennifer and Michael. Adoring great-grandmother. Graveside services today 10:45AM at Mount Neboh Cemetery, Brooklyn. Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel.

title: Progress on Environment?
description: To the Editor:

title: An Out-of-the-Way Mix Of Humor and Nostalgia
description: There are two KT Sullivans. One is a serious cabaret singer whose lyric soprano suggests she spent years studying the mother of them all, Barbara Cook. The other is a jiggling, eye-batting, swiveling, peaches-and-cream-skinned, 50's-style bombshell whose comic stage persona suggests Marilyn Monroe doing Judy Holliday.

title: Flavors of Mexico
description: With week after week of winter ahead, here's an opportunity to head south of the border to 12 of New York's improving group of Mexican restaurants. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's restaurant reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Surgery to Keep Payton Out for 4 to 6 Months
description: There has never been any question about Jay Payton's playing ability. What has never been clear is whether the 26-year-old Mets outfielder, who made his long-awaited major league debut last season, will ever be healthy enough to play with any sort of regularity.

title: Progress on Environment?
description: To the Editor:

title: Parent Cells Found in Brain May Be Key to Nerve Repair
description: Scientists in Sweden have identified for the first time the parent cells that give rise to many and maybe all of the different cell types in the adult brain. These neural stem cells, as they are called, are of great interest because, if they could be manipulated appropriately, they would be the obvious repair kit for replacing damaged neural tissues in everything from spinal cord injuries to Parkinson's disease.

title: Chicago Options Exchange Ends Merger Plan
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange today abandoned its planned merger with the Pacific Stock Exchange, attributing the decision to pressing technological issues and lingering antitrust questions.

title: Inside-Out Meditations On the Poison of Racism
description: The subject of race has prompted some of the most mettlesome American art in the 1990's. And much of that work owes a debt to Adrian Piper, an artist who helped introduce identity politics into Conceptualism nearly 30 years ago.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 6.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SWANSON, ELSTON H.
description: SWANSON-Elston H.. past Chairman of the YMCA of Long Island died on December 27, 1998 at his home in Florida. A memorial service will be held at the Sea Cliff Gospel Church on Sea Cliff Avenue in Sea Cliff on Saturday, January 9 at 1:45 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, LESTER
description: STONE-Lester. The officers, members of the Board and the Administration of OHEL, BAIS EZRA and The Lifetime Care Foundation for the Jewish Disabled mourn the passing of the beloved father of James L. Stone, Commissioner of the New York State Office of Mental Health. Commissioner Stone and his department are partners in our efforts to help people with mental illness who depend upon caring members of government and the community to provide vital services. Moishe Hellman OHEL President David Mandel Chief Executive Officer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EICHEL, TERRY
description: EICHEL-Terry. Respected and beloved wife to the late Seymour Eichel; supportive and everlastingly committed to deceased parents Hilda and Hyman Glassman and brother Martin Glassman; dedicated and loving mother to Dawn J. Kenzer and the late Dennis S. Eichel. Proud, devoted and unconditionally loving grandmother to Ashley Kinzer and respected and kind mother-in-law to Robert D. Kinzer. Died of natural causes. Her death leaves a void and emptiness that will never be filled. She will be sorely missed by all who knew her. Memorial services are planned at ''The Riverside'', New York City, on Friday, January 8, 1999 at 12:30 PM. Family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Cancer Research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, DR. ALFRED
description: SOLOMON-Dr. Alfred. May his memory be blessed. We shall miss him. May our dear Evelyn, Todd and Julia be comforted by all who mourn him. Love, Aunt T, Cousin D, Lainiekins, Steven, Carole, Leslie, Erica and Jill

title: A Frolic With Flutes
description: There's hardly a child who hasn't at some time picked up a soda bottle and blown a playful toot. That bit of silliness isn't so far from the flutist's art, says Linda Chesis, a member of the Three Flute Moms. Ms. Chesis and her fellow musicians, Carol Wincenc and Laura Gilbert, will prove the point tomorrow, when they will call about 25 children up to the stage at Symphony Space to blow across the tops of bottles filled with varying amounts of water. Peter Schickele, the composer known for his own offbeat experiments with classical music, will conduct the group.

title: Kinshasa Journal; Tintin at 70: Colonialism's Comic-Book Puppet?
description: They still fight over his legacy, from Paris, where legislators will soon mark his 70th birthday by debating whether he was a rightist or a leftist, to this city formerly called Leopoldville, where he had his defining adventure.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, SILVIA R.
description: WOLF-Silvia R.., on January 7, 1999. Silvia R. Wolf (nee White) wife of the late Justin R. Wolf. Mother of Judith Miodownik and Laura Williams. Mother-in-law of John Miodownik and Daniel Goldstein. Sister of the late Bernard White and Constance Todman. Daughter of the late Morris and Lillian White. Grandmother of Derek Miodownik, Justine Williams, Ruth and Benjamin Goldstein. Funeral service and interment in Baltimore, Maryland on January 8th, 1999. Please omit flowers. Sol Levinson & Brothers, Baltimore, MD. 800-338-1701.

title: Dominating Flyers Leave Isles, and Palffy, Frustrated
description: The frustration that eats at every Islander finally consumed Zigmund Palffy tonight. And he has played in only eight games this season.

title: Health Care Aide Pleads Guilty in a Plot to Kidnap Brooklyn Boy
description: A woman who kidnapped a Brooklyn boy with cerebral palsy because, her lawyer said, she believed he needed more attention than his parents were giving him, pleaded guilty yesterday to a Federal charge of kidnapping conspiracy.

title: Dolphins Scoffing at Sharpe's Criticism
description: Shannon Sharpe's words live.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAVESH, NATHANIEL
description: KAVESH-Nathaniel., 89. Last of the six sons of Rose and Isaac. Dearest brother of Fannie K. Goldstein of Canton, MA, generous uncle and grand-uncle and great-grand-uncle of many who loved him like the children he never had. A wise man who graduated CCNY and served in World War II. His life was characterized by sage wit and he will always remain in our hearts. Services on Sunday 1:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street & Amsterdam Ave.

title: National News Briefs; Woman Killed by Police Was Legally Drunk
description: The young woman who was shot to death by police officers in Riverside as she sat in her disabled car was over the legal limit for blood alcohol content, according to initial toxicology results released today by the Riverside County Coroner's office.

title: Times Makes Appointment
description: The New York Times said yesterday that Kenneth G. Hackett had been named vice president for national circulation. Mr. Hackett, 48, will be responsible for the newspaper's circulation across the country, including single-copy sales, home delivery and national expansion efforts. Mr. Hackett is returning to The Times after having served as vice president for sales and distribution for the North American edition of The Financial Times since last April. He began his career at The New York Times in 1984 and held several positions in the circulation and advertising departments.

title: Khmer Rouge Haven: Past or Future?
description: With the toot of a trumpet and a ragged salute by 300 soldiers in rubber sandals, Khmer Rouge defectors raised their new Government's flag today to mark the darkest day in their history: the overthrow of their brutal Government 20 years ago.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR CONTINUES SLIDE. The dollar plunged to a 27-month low against the Japanese yen but then gained ground as speculators began buying dollars back. In New York, the dollar traded at at 111.04 yen, down from 112.66 yen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMERSTEIN, JAMES B.
description: HAMMERSTEIN-James B.. We at The Rodgers & Hammerstein Organization celebrate the life of Jamie Hammerstein as we mourn his passing. We enjoyed his wisdom and his irreverent and wicked sense of humor. We loved him and felt that he loved us. His tall, graceful and handsome presence will live on in our memories. We shall miss him. Our thoughts are with Dena and the rest of his family. Mary, Ted, Nicole, Bert, Vicky, Maxyne, Tom, Mike, Bruce, Cindy and the rest of the gang James B., 67. Of New York and Pawling. Died January 7, 1999. Husband of Dena, father of Oscar Andrew, Will, Jennifer, and Simon, grandfather of Dashel, Grace, Julian, Charlie, and Jackson. Service will be private; a memorial will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to GMHC Child Life Program or the Pediatric Unit of the Rusk Institute, New York.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

description: CARELESS LOVE

description: GOLD, Beatrice-Jan. 8, 1994. Our memories of you dear Mother are strong & vivid in our hearts & thoughts. You are with us every day...deeply loved & missed. Your children, San, Joel, Stephen

description: NEWMAN-Elizabeth C.. March 9, 1916-January 8, 1997. In loving memory. Your Famil

title: The N.B.A. Lockout Is Over? Who Won?
description: To the Editor:

title: For Lewinsky, Some Risk In a Senate Appearance
description: If Monica S. Lewinsky is summoned to testify at President Clinton's Senate trial, she will have no choice but to answer all questions completely and truthfully.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Versions: Perversions, Subversions and Verse'

title: Next Stop: Subway's Past
description: Whenever the Seventh Avenue train races between 86th and 96th Streets and offers a fleeting, darkened glimpse of what looks like latter-day catacombs, the question invariably arises: What is it? From the windows of the Broadway Local the ghost of this Stone Age grotto, suddenly illumined by the speeding train, is a place only Dante or Kafka might have imagined. The walls are begrimed with thick 1970's-style graffiti while something resembling a platform, strewn with debris, stands in the ashen dimness of places most cities would rather forget about.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, MARTIN L.
description: COHN-Martin L. . The Board of Directors and members of the Ocean Beach Club mourn the loss of long time friend and member Martin Cohn and extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Sandy Paskin, President Laurie Lowenstein, Secretary

title: Amazon.com Is Adding A Warehouse
description: Amazon.com, the E-commerce pioneer whose stock price keeps soaring even though it has yet to make a profit, announced yesterday that it had leased a huge, highly mechanized warehouse near Reno, a sign that it intends to expand its own distribution system for the books, music CD's and videos it sells.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKEL, ERICH, HANS
description: MARKEL-Erich-Hans., 78. President of The Max Kade Foundation, Inc, New York, died January 4, 1999. His family and friends mourn the death of this exceptional man with a remarkable career and life. He was respected, admired and honored by so many and will be dearly missed. During his 40 years as President, The Foundation made grants to major universities in America and Europe to promote medical research and cross-cultural understanding. He received Orders Of Merit from The Federal Republic of Germany and Austria, and several honorary doctorate degrees from American universities for his philanthropic efforts. A service is being held in his honor at The German Evangelical-Lutheran Church of Saint Paul on Saturday, January 9, 1999, at 12 P.M., 315 West 22nd Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Friends of Dresden, Inc, a charity which supports the reconstruction of the historic ''Frauenkirche (Church)'' of Dresden, 1675 Broadway, Suite 1900, New York, New York 10019-5820. He will especially be missed and remembered by his daughter, Anne, son, Michael, daughter-in-law, Gail, and his grandchildren, Julie, Katie, Erin, and Jason.

title: Like Cash In the Bank
description: At first glance ''Electra'' looked like a money loser par excellence. The subject matter was grim; the cast had no naked Hollywood stars, and the playwright hadn't written a play in 2,400 years.

title: No Horse Heads, but Plenty of Prozac
description: THE SOPRANOS

title: Deal Struck For Ending Busing Plan In St. Louis
description: The St. Louis school system, which has the country's largest busing program, may soon be released from its longstanding court-ordered desegregation plan.

title: Labor Deal Improves Odds of Keeping Nets' Core Intact
description: Perhaps the time has come for the Nets to experience prosperity. Equipped with a talented roster, in the possession of new, philanthropic ownership, and outfitted with a fresh, state-of-the-art practice facility, the long-suffering franchise received more good news yesterday when the National Basketball Association's new collective bargaining agreement was ratified.

title: Investigators Cite Cash Payments In Salt Lake City Bid for Olympics
description: Cash payments were made by local Olympic officials to members of the International Olympic Committee during this city's bid to be awarded the 2002 Winter Games, according to investigators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETRUCCIANI, MICHEL
description: PETRUCCIANI-Michel. Suddenly on January 6, 1999. Acclaimed musician and composer. Survived by his son, Alexander, both parents and brothers, Isabelle Maile, and Marie-Laure and Rachid Roperch. Visitation on Friday, 1-2PM only at Krtil Funeral Home-Yorkville Funeral Service Inc. 1297 First Avenue, NYC. Burial at Pere La Chaise Cemetery, Paris, France.

title: G.M. and Union Are Near Deal on New Plants
description: The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union are close to an agreement on the construction of three new assembly plants in the United States that would need only a third as many workers as the operations they replace, company and union officials said this week.

title: Rules Shouldn't Say Who Is a Jew
description: To the Editor:

title: No Complaint Filed Over Fine
description: The National Football League Players Association said yesterday that it had not received a formal complaint and thus was not actively investigating the decision of Jacksonville Jaguars Coach Tom Coughlin to fine two rookies who were late for a meeting because of an automobile accident. A union spokesman, Carl Francis, said: ''We have not received a formal complaint, just a phone call to one of our attorneys asking for information. We can't make any moves or decisions until they make a formal complaint.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEMAN, LAWRENCE S.
description: ROSEMAN-Lawrence S.. Of Forest Hills, New York. Age 69. Died January 5, 1999. Deeply beloved husband of Audrey. Beloved father of Donna and Jeffrey. Dear father-in-law of Edward. Loving brother of Rosalind and Daniel. Most cherished grandfather of Emma Faye. Loving uncle of Steven, Abbey, and Beth. His love, wisdom and compassion will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Services to be held at Riverside Funeral Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, at 10 AM. on Thursday, January 7.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORSER, PAUL
description: CORSER-Paul . The Board of Directors of CPFA mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague. Our deepest condolences to Paul's wife, Sally Morrison. Roberta Bogen, President Carol Gertz, Vice President Concerned Parents for AIDS Research

title: Thompson Reportedly Ready to Step Down at Georgetown
description: Georgetown University will hold what it terms a major news conference this morning, amid strong speculation that Coach John Thompson, now in his 27th season, will step down from his legendary, but recently troubled, program.

title: Striving to Make Extraordinary Days Look So Ordinary
description: All was made to appear normal at the White House today on another historically abnormal day in the Presidency of Bill Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUPENIE, HARRIET RUTH
description: KRUPENIE-Harriet Ruth., died on January 4, 1999. Loving sister and aunt. She was a legal secretary at Davis & Polk. Services Sunday 11AM at Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave. (Ave M), Brooklyn. Interment at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASMANTIER, CATHERINE MARGARET
description: PASMANTIER-Catherine Margaret. The physicians and staff of 407 Medical Associates send their deepest sympathy to Dr. Mark Pasmantier on the loss of his beloved wife Catherine Margaret Pasmantier. Dr. and Mrs. Pasmantier were major influences in the founding and success of our organization and we will all miss her greatly. 407 Associates

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATSAKIS, STEVEN C.
description: MATSAKIS-Steven C.., of Wyckoff, N.J., died Tuesday, January 5, 1999, at the Hackensack University Medical Center. Beloved son of Victoria (nee Lucas) and the late Constantinos Matsakis, who died in 1986. Cherished husband of Mary (nee Finlayson), and adored father of Louise. Much loved brother of Demetrios and Nicholas. The grandson of an immigrant, Steve was born May 1, 1958, in Passaic, N.J., grew up in Rutherford, resided in Lyndhurst for 15 years before moving to Wyckoff 3 years ago. Mr. Matsakis attended the Rutherford public schools, received his undergraduate degree from New York University, graduating Summa Cum Laude, and also received his M.B.A. from N.Y.U. He began his career at Bankers Trust Company and in 1980 was elevated to the position of Vice President of the Corporate Finance Department. He later became an Executive Vice President of the Atlantic Bank of New York City. He was also C.E.O. and Cofounder of super Video Stores that started with one store in 1987 and flourished into a 14 store chain in northern New Jersey. In 1996 the company was sold to West Coast Entertainment Corp. Steve was a strong believer in the values and wonderful opportunities America provided. To help others Steve recently established a scholarship fund to benefit Rutherford High School graduates. His loving and passionate persona will be greatly missed. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral on Saturday, January 9, 1999, 9:15 AM, from the Thomas J. Diffily Funeral Home, 41 Ames Ave in Rutherford, and 10 AM at St. George Greek Orthodox Church in Clifton, N.J. Interment at Hillside Cemetery in Lyndhurst, N.J. Visiting Thursday & Friday, 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Victoria & Costantinos Scholarship Fund at the Rutherford High School, would be appreciated.

title: The N.B.A. Lockout Is Over? Who Won?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNHEIM, PALMER
description: TURNHEIM-Palmer. With great sadness, the Board of Directors, volunteers and staff of United Cerebral Palsy Associations and the United Cerebral Palsy Research and Educational Foundation extend our condolences to Joy Turnheim, her family and friends on the recent death of her father, Palmer Turnheim. As a national volunteer and Board member, his years of dedication and tireless commitment to our organizations have made a positive impact in the lives of individuals with cerebral palsy and other disabilities. He will be missed. Michael H. Simonson, President Jeanette E. Harvey, Executive Director, UCPA Murray Goldstein, DO, MPH, Director UCP Research and Educational Foundation

title: Starr's Actions Cast Doubt on Senate Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Caps Crush Lackluster Rangers
description: When the Rangers arrived at Baltimore-Washington International Airport at 1:30 A.M. today, they were hoping to leave with a .500 record and feeling a little more secure about their playoff hopes. Their hopes went unfulfilled in a 5-1 defeat tonight.

title: Casting Folk Art To the Winds
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art is selling a group of 23 folk art paintings from the 19th century, which were given to the institution in the late 1960's by Edgar William Garbisch and his wife, Bernice Chrysler Garbisch. The paintings are expected to sell for $400,000 to $600,000 and will be auctioned at Sotheby's in New York on Jan. 17.

title: Sounding Off About Impeachment
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Russell to Manage Tampa Farm Team
description: The Tampa Bay Devil Rays named the former Los Angeles Dodgers manager Bill Russell to manage their Orlando club in the Class AA Southern League.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about 1998 auto sales reversed the market-share figures for Chrysler and Toyota cars, and included incorrect light-truck market-share figures for Ford, General Motors, Chrysler, Toyota and Nissan. A corrected chart appears today on page C2.

title: Clinton Trial Opens, but Process Talks Go On
description: In a hushed chamber under heavy security, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist opened the first Presidential impeachment trial in 131 years today, swearing in senators to ''do impartial justice'' in judging whether President William Jefferson Clinton should be removed from office for perjury and obstruction of justice.

title: Metro Business; German Fund Buys Jersey City Tower
description: Prudential Real Estate Investors has sold a 30-story Jersey City office tower on the west bank of the Hudson River known as Exchange Place Center for $175 million to BBV U.S. Real Estate Fund III of Germany.

title: A Senate Conviction Could Be Overturned
description: Does the Senate have the final word on whether President Clinton will be thrown out of office, or can the case be appealed to the Supreme Court?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSSEN, IRA A.
description: JOSSEN-Ira A.. Beloved husband of Louise. Loving father of Jenifer and Jonathan. Cherished grandfather of Samuel and Elias. Decades of loyal and dedicated service to the Broadway theatre, Ira's death leaves a void in the lives of all the people he touched. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation. Services are at Riverside Funeral Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76 Street, 11AM Friday, January 8.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMETT, ED
description: SAMETT-Ed. The Board and staff of the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America, Greater New York Chapter, are profoundly saddened by the loss of our esteemed former Board Member and Treasurer, Ed Samett. Our heartfelt sympathy to his beloved wife Molly, his children and grandchildren. He will always be in our thoughts. Judy Saphir, President Daniel Crown, Chairman Joan Telley, Exec. Dir.

title: New Officer Posted to a Listing ABC Ship
description: SAM DONALDSON of ABC News put it succinctly: ''Is Shelley in this new job because Diane has confidence in her? Absolutely. Shelley wouldn't be there if Diane didn't. Whatever Lola wants, Lola gets, kid.'' Mr. Donaldson paused just a beat, then decided to be a gentleman. ''And that's the way it should be.''

title: RITE AID AND GENERAL NUTRITION AGREE TO AN ALLIANCE
description: The Rite Aid Corporation and the General Nutrition Companies, a retailer of vitamins and mineral supplements, have agreed to form a strategic alliance that includes opening GNC stores within Rite Aid stores and selling vitamins on line. Under the agreement, Rite Aid, the drugstore chain based in Camp Hill, Pa., is to open 1,500 GNC stores within Rite Aid stores in the next three years. The companies also plan to develop and market a new vitamin and nutrition brand, Pharmassure, supported by $30 million in advertising in the first year. The new line of vitamins and supplements is to be sold on the Internet and at Rite Aid's 3,900 stores and GNC's 3,650 stores, starting in the fall.

title: Into a Minefield: 'Cold War' on TV; Three Historians, Three Perspectives And Some Discord
description: Tomorrow night CNN will begin broadcasting the second half of its 24-part documentary series ''Cold War.'' The first half has already brought several angry critiques from historians and commentators over how it interprets the cold war and how it assigns blame. Some critics have complained that the series does not deal critically enough with American responsibility for perpetuating the cold war. Conservative critics have taken the opposite tack, saying it draws no moral distinctions between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Journal; Go for the Full Monty
description: Enough is enough. Move on. Let's get back to the people's business. It's bad for the country. The country is so bored it would rather watch ''Patch Adams.''

title: A Beloved Pachyderm Enlivens a Poulenc Party
description: The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts has an impressive number of original manuscripts by the French composer Francis Poulenc, including many in the permanent collection of Pierre Bernac, the French baritone who was the composer's closest colleague.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist's day in the Senate located him incorrectly in some copies. He was second from the right; Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, was second from the left.

title: Parcells Tailored Dress for Success
description: Over the summer, the Jets put on new uniforms with an old logo, the one they wore as the surprising winners of Super Bowl III. Now, 30 years later, they are in the playoffs and thinking it can happen.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER RALLIES. Prices rose 1 percent from 12-year lows on optimism that strong economic growth will increase demand for copper wire and pipes in construction. The March contract rose 0.65 cent, to 65.90 cents a pound.

title: Bouncer in Lounge Killed After Patron Is Ejected
description: In the first homicide in Newark this year, a bouncer at a late-night lounge was shot and killed yesterday. The police said the killer may have been a man who was removed from the bar by the bouncer earlier that night.

title: Beijing Journal; China's Pigeons Perch on Pedestal, Not Just Statues
description: In New York it might have seemed like a mysterious blessing, but here it was regarded as a most malignant curse.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economy Rewards Workers With a Boom in U.S. Jobs

title: Limelight Owner Admits Tax Evasion
description: Peter Gatien, the nightclub magnate, pleaded guilty yesterday to state tax-evasion charges, accepted a sentence of 90 days in jail and consented to pay $1.88 million in back taxes and fines under an agreement that may let him remain in the nightclub business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSTER, VIRGINIA ESTABROOK
description: CUSTER-Virginia Estabrook. 80. Of Naples, FL died Tuesday, January 6, 1999. Formerly of Chestertown, MD. She was a graduate of Hofstra University. Survived by three daughters, Barbara Ann Custer of Los Angeles, CA, Mimi Kaine (Jay W.) of Oak Ridge, TN, and Mary Custer of Los Angeles, CA.; one sister, Barbara Estabrook of Washington, D.C.; four grandchildren, Capt. James, Christopher, Timothy and Patrick Kaine, and a great grandson, Daniel. She was preceded in death by her husband Merton D. Custer in 1985. Graveside services will be held at St. Paul's Cemetery in Chestertown, MD. Memorials to the American Heart Association.

title: Stocks Take A Wild Rise To New Highs
description: The stock market took a volatile ride to new highs yesterday, finishing a week marked by an Internet stock frenzy, a surge in other technology stocks and new economic data that showed the American economy is refusing, so far, to slow down.

title: Economy, Long a Friend, Brings Clinton More Help
description: The stock market is in record territory. The economic expansion just hit its 93d month, making this the longest peacetime period of sustained growth in American history.

title: That Sniffly, Sneezy, Achy Feeling Again; The Dreaded Cold and Flu Season Is Crowding Emergency Rooms
description: Gesundheit, New York. Just as snowy winds and freezing temperatures have finally besieged the city, so, too, have high fevers, runny noses, achy joints -- the hallmarks of the cold and flu season -- gripped its residents, by the thousands.

title: UNHEEDED WARNINGS: A special report.; Before Bombings, Omens and Fears
