description: In the spring of 1998, Prudence Bushnell, the United States Ambassador to Kenya, sent an emotional letter to Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright begging for the Secretary's personal help.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about the Republican delegation from the House that delivered the articles of impeachment to the Senate identified Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois incorrectly in some editions. He is chairman of the House Judiciary Committee and of the managers of the House impeachment effort, not majority leader.

title: For Knicks, Only Ward Will Do to Start As Point Guard
description: The Knicks will enter the season in need of a compass. Amid the flurry and confusion of a lockout-shortened schedule, the team will look to lean on simple direction, solid guidance and a straight arrow.

title: 7-Year Term for Leader In Betting-Chip Thefts
description: The ringleader of a band of thieves that persuaded problem gamblers to snatch betting chips off blackjack tables in Atlantic City casinos was sentenced yesterday to seven years in prison, state officials said.

title: Mayor Puts the Defenseless Into the Crossfire
description: To the Editor:

title: AT&T Alters A Key Term In TCI Deal
description: The AT&T Corporation yesterday changed a major part of its $31.8 billion plan for acquiring Tele-Communications Inc., the No. 2 cable television company, saying it would not issue a new stock to track the combined company's consumer operations.

title: One Senate, Indivisible (For Now)
description: Down the corridors the lawmakers fairly danced, their mood approaching giddiness, as the Senate rallied today around its own need for dignity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASMANTIER, CATHERINE MARGARET
description: PASMANTIER-Catherine Margaret. The Thoracic Oncology Group of Cornell Medical Center notes with great sadness the death of Catherine Margaret, beloved wife of our esteemed colleague and friend, Dr. Mark Pasmantier. We extend our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to Mark and to the entire Pasmantier family. Thoracic Oncology Group, Cornell Medical Center ST#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, LINDA
description: MANN-Linda. Beloved wife of Hank, loving mother of Jeff and Eileen Stanger, Debbie and Brian Ezratty, Adam & Nancy Stanger, Michelle Mann, Robin and Adam Flaks and Michael Mann. Loving grandmother of Meghan, Ross, Robbie, Sydney and Gregory. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 12:30 P.M., Sunday.

title: Bid Is Awarded for Times Sq. Subway Project
description: New York City Transit has awarded an $82.8 million contract for the first phase of a Times Square subway station renovation project to a consortium of companies headed by Slattery Skanska Inc., a Swedish-owned construction company.

title: Pitcher Changes His Story on Injury
description: Toronto Blue Jays pitcher Paul Quantrill said he broke his right leg on Tuesday while driving a snowmobile, not while tobogganing, as he initially said.

title: 2 Officials Quit in Salt Lake City As Olympic Scandal Details Grow
description: The top two local organizers of the 2002 Winter Olympics resigned today as new details continued to emerge in a mushrooming bribery scandal.

title: New York Democrats Pin Hopes On Clinton (Hillary, That Is)
description: When Charles E. Schumer wanted a compelling figure to campaign with during the final hours of his Senate race last year, he turned to a Democrat who has never even lived in New York State: Hillary Rodham Clinton. Mrs. Clinton flew in for a clamorous reception at a Schumer rally in midtown Manhattan. After the votes were counted, Republicans and Democrats agreed that her four visits had a lot to do with Mr. Schumer's defeat of Alfonse M. D'Amato by nearly 10 percentage points.

title: As Parents Sweat It Out, 4th Graders Cram for New Test
description: Linda LoPresti paid a price for her anxiety: $120.

title: Sports of The Times; Resignation Doesn't Mean Retirement
description: FOR most of a snowy flight yesterday morning, I considered what was about to unfold, and couldn't comprehend it. The Georgetown University sports information director had called Thursday evening and left a not-so-cryptic message: a major news conference was scheduled for Friday morning involving Coach John Thompson.

title: Carriage Horse Is Electrocuted on Street
description: One of the carriage horses that charm tourists and lend a touch of history and romance to the bustling Manhattan streetscape was electrocuted last night when it stepped on a steel Con Edison service box cover on East 59th Street between Park and Madison Avenues.

title: 120 Twin-Engine Jets Under Caution After 3 Have Trouble in Flight
description: Three twin-engine jets have had an engine shut down in flight in the last week, probably because a seal weakend by cold let oil leak out, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: The Grace Between The Notes
description: For all their focus on bare movement in time and space, George Balanchine's most experimental ballets are metaphors for human existence. How to get through the day might be the subliminal theme of ''Episodes,'' which Balanchine choreographed in 1959 to orchestral music by Webern.

title: A Badge for Tolerance
description: To the Editor:

title: LAUDA AIR PLANS TO BUY ABOUT 11 BOEING JETS
description: Lauda Air A.G., Austria's No. 2 airline, said yesterday that it planned to add as many as 11 Boeing planes worth $519 million to its current fleet of 19, as it seeks to build up routes to Southeast Asia, where traffic is growing. Lauda, founded and 40 percent owned by Nikki Lauda, the former Formula 1 motor racing world champion, ordered six next-generation 737's and one 767-3003ER from the Boeing Company. It also took options on another four 737-700's. Founded as a charter airline and now 36 percent owned by Austrian Airlines A.G., Lauda has evolved into a full-fledged carrier that serves mostly tourist destinations such as Bangkok, Hong Kong and Sydney.

title: INSIDE
description: Hard Stance on Israeli Spy

title: Fixing Embassy Insecurity
description: The bombs that killed 258 people at the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania last summer also destroyed any lingering illusions about the protection America offers its diplomats and their employees overseas. The dismal state of security was deplored again yesterday by two State Department commissions that investigated the August attacks. They found that Washington has neglected embassy security for decades. The Administration and Congress should carry out many of the report's recommendations.

title: TEXACO SETS A $350 MILLION CHARGE AGAINST EARNINGS
description: Hit hard by a glut of supply and falling oil prices, Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it would reduce the value of some of its inventory and assets on its books in a move that will lower fourth-quarter earnings by $350 million. Texaco, based in White Plains, said the charge includes inventory write-downs of about $170 million. The charges also include a $100 million write-down of exploration and production business investments and a $95 million expense associated with cost cutting in corporate operations and a reorganization of upstream and natural-gas businesses. The company expects to earn 13 cents to 16 cents a share for the quarter, before charges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, HENRY H.
description: ROTHMAN-Henry H. Of Salinas, CA, formerly of Sea Cliff, NY, age 74, died January 6th, 1999. Beloved husband of Ana and the late Rhoda. Loving father of Jan and Debra, Sheldon and Kim. Adored ''Zaidy'' of Robyn, Joshua, Hayley and Tandarra. Cherished stepfather of Gilberto and Ana Melissa. Brother of Victor Rothschild. Services Sunday, 9:15 AM, at ''Gutterman's Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, NY.

title: Failing the 1868 Test
description: In the past few months, Bill Clinton has often been compared to Andrew Johnson, who came within one vote of being impeached by the Senate. By that measure, can Representative Henry Hyde, the chief prosecutor in the Senate trial, be compared to Thaddeus Stevens, who as leader of the Radical Republicans pushed the hardest for the impeachment of President Johnson?

title: Impeachment Trial: Finding a Balance; Trial Is Our Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Push to Require Sprinklers Raises Complex Issues
description: Fire safety breakthroughs are often born of terrible losses of life that show the shortcomings of the status quo.

title: Charles Francis Adams, 88, Former Chairman of Raytheon
description: Charles Francis Adams, a former president and chairman of Raytheon, the military and commercial electronics manufacturer, died Tuesday at his home in Dover, Mass. He was 88.

title: Recompense for Black Farmers
description: The proposed settlement of a class-action lawsuit brought by black farmers against the United States Department of Agriculture for racial discrimination in farm loans probably will not curb the decline of independent black farmers, who now account for only 1 percent of the farming force. But it provides some redress to many who have had their livelihoods destroyed by illegal practices.

title: Doggy Angst: Pet or Owner Issue?
description: To the Editor:

title: At Long Last, Leadership
description: Every now and then sanity breaks out, even in Congress. Through bipartisan effort the Senate has devised something that was missing in the House, a system for planning and managing the inquiry into President Clinton's offenses in an orderly way. The essence of the agreement is that it sets up a multi-vote hurdle to prevent the wholesale calling of witnesses, and it sternly limits the fire-breathing House prosecutors to arguing the existing record developed in that body's Judiciary Committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, RUTH LESSALL
description: WEINER-Ruth Lessall. Age 94. Died Friday, January 8th. Devoted wife of the late Joseph L. Weiner. Loving mother of Stephen A. Weiner of Sands Point, NY and Elizabeth W. Vorenberg of Cambridge, MA, and mother-in-law of Mina Weiner and James Vorenberg. Aslo survived by her grandchildren Amy Troubh, John Troubh, James Weiner and Karen Goss and five great grandchildren. A memorial service will take place on Sunday, January 10th at 2PM at Community Synagogue, 150 Middle Neck Rd., Sands Point, NY.

title: Takeover Rumors Help Cable and Wireless Rise
description: The shares of Cable and Wireless P.L.C. surged on speculation that Deutsche Telekom A.G., Europe's largest telephone company, may bid for Britain's No. 2 telecommunications company.

title: Doggy Angst: Pet or Owner Issue?
description: To the Editor:

title: Growth in Consumer Borrowing Less Than Expected in November
description: Borrowing by American consumers increased more slowly than had been expected in November, rising by $3.9 billion, to a total of $1.301 trillion, according to figures released today by the Federal Reserve Board. Analysts had expected an increase of $5.5 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, JAY M.
description: MARCUS-Jay M. The Marcus family mourns the loss of their devoted husband, father, brother, uncle and mentor, Jay Mordechai Marcus. Son of Solomon & Bessie Marcus, his immutable drive taught and inspired, opening our horizons to culture through his descriptions of books, food, love of arts, Judaism and hard work. He was an honorable man who was respected and admired by many and leaves behind a void that will never be filled. He will be sorely missed by his loving wife of 36 years, Sylvia, five children: Lisa, David, Robert, Jonathan, Sabrina; four grandchildren: Jarred, Kendall, Justin, Elana, brothers and sisters, Morris, Reuben, Lillian and Charlotte. Services on Sunday, January 10, 11:15am at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Court Overturns Its Ruling On Plea Deals for Witnesses
description: In a decision with broad implications for prosecutors, the full Federal appeals court in Denver yesterday overturned a ruling by three of its members that it was bribery for prosecutors to offer witnesses leniency in exchange for their testimony.

title: Very Espresso Philosophy
description: Is there a future in America for the cafe-philo, the philosophical discussion sessions in public cafes that have become the rage in France? Judging from the one Bernard Roy moderates at the cozy Le Poeme bistro at Prince and Elizabeth Streets in Little Italy, the answer has to be a Kierkegaardian ''Maybe.''

title: Iraq Damage More Severe Than Reported, Pentagon Says
description: Almost three weeks after the bombing stopped, the Pentagon's senior commanders said today that the American and British raids on Iraq had caused more damage than initially reported.

title: Mayor Puts the Defenseless Into the Crossfire
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Sinking in Buoyant Waters; Meanwhile, Euro Sails Through Week
description: Except for a few minor procedural glitches, the euro finished its first week as Europe's new single currency with remarkable smoothness.

title: MCI Won't Make Bid for Airtouch
description: Speculation over whether MCI Worldcom Inc. would join the bidding for Airtouch Communications Inc. appeared all for naught yesterday. MCI Worldcom said in a press release that after reviewing the possibility of acquiring Airtouch, it had ''determined not to pursue a bid for the company at this time.''

title: New Postal Rates
description: A higher basic postal rate will take effect tomorrow. The cost to mail a one-ounce, first-class letter will increase to 33 cents from 32 cents. Each additional ounce will cost 22 cents, down from 23 cents. New stamps are available now. The new rates at a glance, page A9.

title: Louis J. West, 74, Psychiatrist Who Studied Extremes, Dies
description: Dr. Louis Jolyon West, a charismatic leader in psychiatry whose work centered on people who have been taken to the limits of human experience, like ''brainwashed'' prisoners of war, kidnapping victims and abused children, died last Saturday in his home in Los Angeles. He was 74.

title: Slavery's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBERG, CHARLOTTE
description: WEISBERG-Charlotte. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Edwin and Karen Weisberg and Linda and Earle Altman. Dear sister of Bernie Feibush. Cherished grandmother of Leslie, Jennifer, Elizabeth and Eric. Adored great-grandmother of six. Service on Sunday 9:30AM, at Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETRUCCIANI, MICHEL
description: PETRUCCIANI - Michel. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sorrow the untimely passing of our beloved friend and devoted Steinway Artist, Michel Petrucciani, on January 6, 1999 in New York City at the age of 36. Mr. Petrucciani was a dazzling pianist with a generous and an indefatigable spirit, and his artistry captivated and inspired audiences throughout the world. His significant discography will keep his legacy alive in the hearts of music lovers everywhere. To Isabelle, Alexandre and to his entire family, we extend our deepest sympathy. His loss is keenly felt. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, Vice President, Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: THE S.A.T. NUMBERS GAME
description: As high school students sharpen their No. 2 pencils for the grueling S.A.T. season, some parents are opening their checkbooks for prep courses that can run as high as $400 an hour. But just how much are these courses, and the tests themself, really worth? A report by Tony Schwartz in the Times Magazine.

title: Seahawks Make Holmgren Top Paid
description: Maybe it was the seven-year itch. Maybe it was a chance to earn the highest salary ever for a National Football League coach. Maybe, as Mike Holmgren said, despite all his success he wanted to achieve more.

title: Malaysian Prime Minister Acts to Consolidate Power
description: KUALA LUMPUR  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE ON JANUARY 12, 1998:

title: Kirch Group Estimates Its Value at $9 Billion
description: Kirch Group, Germany's No. 2 media company, has given three potential investors -- Mediaset S.p.A., the News Corporation and Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia -- a document that estimates its net value at 15 billion marks ($9 billion), one of the investors said yesterday.

title: GENERAL CHEMICAL GROUP IN DEAL TO ADD DEFIANCE
description: General Chemical Group Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Defiance Inc., a supplier of testing services, tools and other products to the auto industry, for $9.50 a share, or $57 million. Defiance's shares rose $2.718, to $9.218, in Nasdaq trading. General Chemical shares were up 43.75 cents, to $15.5625, on the Big Board. General Chemical, based in Hampton, N.J., a maker of chemicals and related products, had 1997 sales of $653.6 million. Defiance is based in Cleveland.

title: Report on Security Suggests Closing Some U.S. Embassies
description: Special panels set up by the State Department to investigate the bombings of two American embassies in Africa called on the department today to consider closing a number of embassies around the world that are vulnerable to terrorist attack and replacing them with regional ''super-embassies.''

title: In Rare Visit To Vatican, Ex-Marxist Pays a Call
description: Prime Minister Massimo D'Alema, a former Communist, had a private audience today with the Pope who helped make ''former Communist'' a common moniker throughout the world.

title: For Broncos, Dolphins Up To Old Tricks
description: Forget Marino against Elway. Never mind Shannon Sharpe's braggadocio. Coach Jimmy Johnson of the Dolphins has elbowed his way onto center stage for Miami's American Football Conference divisional game Saturday against the Denver Broncos. Even though it snowed lightly today, temperatures for the game are expected to be in the 40's.

title: Impeachment Trial: Finding a Balance
description: To the Editor:

title: Into a Minefield: 'Cold War' on TV; Soviet Ambition Worried All, But It's Not the Whole Story
description: The opening sequence in CNN's first episode of ''Cold War'' takes viewers on a tour of the secret underground rooms where the business of government was to be carried on in case of nuclear war. In a subsequent episode, Robert S. McNamara tells an interviewer that when he became Secretary of Defense in 1961, he knew almost nothing about nuclear weapons. Learning quickly, he said, he dedicated his life to making sure that they would never be used. ''It's not mad,'' Mr. McNamara says quietly of the nuclear stand-off and the policy of mutual assured destruction (MAD); it was the best way to keep the peace.

title: Colombian Rebel Chief Says Threats Made Him Miss Talks
description: The commander of the largest rebel force in Colombia sought out Government officials and foreign dignitaries here today, saying that he was committed to seeing talks progress to end the civil war. He said he was absent from a ceremony on Thursday to start the effort because of death threats.

title: Impeachment Trial: Finding a Balance; When Closed is Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: Facing a Suit, CUNY Board To Vote Again
description: To skirt a legal roadblock to their new policy on remedial education, the trustees of the City University of New York plan to retake their hotly contested vote ending remedial courses at four-year colleges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLECHER, SHEILA JANET
description: BLECHER-Sheila Janet. Loving wife, mother and grandmother. Longtime resident of White Plains, New York, and Boca Raton, Fla. Passed away on January 7, 1999, after a brief illness with ovarian cancer. Sheila was a retired reading specialist with the Pelham School District and devoted many years to charitable organizations. Surviving are her bereaved husband Ivy, her children, Donna Lichti and husband Charles, of White Plains, NY, Karen Moseman of Henderson, NV. and Lynn Weinig and husband William of Pleasantville, NY, and seven grandchildren. Memorial services will be held at the Congregation Kol Ami (Jewish Community Center) 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, N.Y., on Sunday January 10th at 12 noon. The family plans to announce its commitment to the battle against ovarian cancer and will be accepting donations through ''The Sheila Fund '', P.O. Box 325, North White Plains, New York 10603-0325.

title: Mayor Puts the Defenseless Into the Crossfire; Troubling Turn in Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIZZO, AIDA
description: RIZZO-Aida. January 6, 1999. Retired NYC Board of Education teacher. Beloved sister of Josephine. Family will receive friends at Williams Funeral Home Inc., 5628 Broadway at 232nd St., Bronx, Monday 9-10 AM. Mass of Christian burial at St. Nicholas of Tolentine Church Monday, 10:30 AM. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANYI, GEORGE R.
description: LANYI-George R. Nine years-eternal pain. Mother, John, Paul and Da

title: Zalman C. Bernstein, 72, Iconoclastic Broker
description: When he started a securities firm under his own name in 1967, Sanford Charles Bernstein made sure that hurried investors would not fail to notice. To announce the firm, the 41-year-old upstart ran a series of full-page newspaper ads emphasizing in bold, black type a single word: ''Bernstein.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTRO, MURIEL
description: CASTRO-Muriel. On January 7, 1999. Dear mother of Harvey (Margot Levy) and David Castro. Adored grandmother of Chloe Sage and Daniel. Loving sister of Florence Fletcher. Former and beloved wife of Albert Castro. Services Sunday, January 10, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: SENATE, IN UNANIMITY, SETS RULES FOR TRIAL; WITNESS ISSUE PUT OFF
description: The Senate achieved bipartisanship for now.

title: Extent of Sprinkler Law at Issue as Fire's Survivors Share Their Horror
description: Survivors of a deadly high-rise fire in Manhattan and the widow of a fallen firefighter pleaded with City Council members yesterday to mandate sprinklers in all high-rise apartment buildings, but city officials appeared to be far from a consensus on the most far-reaching fire safety proposals under consideration.

title: Impeachment Trial: Finding a Balance; Rehnquist's Option
description: To the Editor:

title: Duval Roars Into Lead With a 10-Under Round
description: According to his girlfriend, David Duval has been shopping for a new car. And whoever wins the Mercedes Championships this weekend will be awarded a 1999 Mercedes-Benz SL 500 coupe-roadster.

title: Aid to Colombia
description: To the Editor:

title: MENTOR GRAPHICS ABRUPTLY DROPS QUICKTURN BID
description: The Mentor Graphics Corporation abruptly dropped its unsolicited offer for Quickturn Design Systems Inc. yesterday, clearing the way for Quickturn to merge with Cadence Design Systems Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $268 million, or $15 a share. Mentor also said it had withdrawn its call for a special meeting of Quickturn shareholders. Mentor had proposed replacing Quickturn's board with its own nominees, who would then would have probably put the company up for auction. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Quickturn fell 68.75 cents, to $14.25, and the stock of Mentor rose 68.75 cents, to $10.6875. Cadence's shares fell $1.25, to $28.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Many U.S. Officials Adamantly Oppose Clemency for Pollard
description: Law enforcement and intelligence officials said today that they remain adamantly opposed to shortening the life sentence of Jonathan Pollard, a former United States Navy intelligence analyst convicted of spying for Israel.

title: Bribery Attempt Added To Disorderly Conduct
description: When the police told him he was under arrest for disorderly conduct, the man put his hands up in the air. Thousands of dollars in cash spilled out from under his jacket.

title: Into a Minefield: 'Cold War' on TV; The View From Inside: Answering Some Criticism
description: It has always been hard to view the cold war dispassionately, so it's no surprise that CNN's televised version has provoked controversy. Ted Turner's involvement alone -- he conceived the series -- would have insured that. Then there's the fact that historians are still hotly debating the significance of new evidence from the former Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and China. And of course visual images always pack more of an emotional punch than the printed page, especially the academic prose in which most cold war history has been written.

title: Destiny and Falcons Confront the 49ers
description: After San Francisco had sent Green Bay tumbling in a wild-card playoff thriller last Sunday, the 49ers hugged and celebrated and then quickly turned to the next task -- the Atlanta Falcons.

title: Hyundai Announces Plan To Sell 11 of Its Affiliates
description: Bowing to pressure to bring its debt down from stratospheric levels, the Hyundai Group, South Korea's largest conglomerate, said today that it would sell 11 of its affiliates in an effort to raise more than $5 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANHEIM, PAUL E.
description: MANHEIM-Paul E., age 93. On January 1, 1999, of heart failure in Easthampton, attended by his wife of thirty years, Simone Hegeman Gardner. Brother of Frank Manheim of London, Louise Espy of Manhattan and the late Alice Kaplan. Father of Martha Green and Anthony A. Manheim of Brooklyn and Emily Goldman of Santa Fe. Also survived by seven grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Memorial service 11 AM, January 22, 725 Park Ave., NYC. Donations may be made to East End Hospice, 1111 Riverhead Road, Westhampton Beach, New York 11978 or to Dominican Sisters Family Health Service, PO Box 866, Amagansett, NY 11930.

title: HIRING LAST MONTH KEPT A BRISK PACE
description: Despite an unsettled global economy, lower corporate profits and a new round of layoffs, the American economy keeps creating jobs at an astonishing pace.

title: Marine Prosecutor Subpoenas '60 Minutes' Interview Tapes
description: A Marine Corps prosecutor has obtained a subpoena seeking tapes the news program ''60 Minutes'' made of an interview with the pilot of the jet that sliced through cables supporting a ski gondola last year in the Italian Alps, killing 20 people. Yesterday CBS filed a motion to throw out the subpoena.

title: A Quick Draw, and Yet, So Slow It's Excruciating
description: Very few men can stand quietly in the middle of an empty street with the authority and the tough, soft-spoken sexiness of Sam Shepard. And the TNT movie ''Purgatory'' is Mr. Shepard's best opportunity since he played Chuck Yeager in ''The Right Stuff'' 16 years ago to show that off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLGENOS, DAVID
description: DOLGENOS-David. January 9, 1931-May 6, 1997. Happy Birthday BIG D. Miss you more every year. Time doesn't heal anything at all. All our love, Peter, Peggy, Carey, Tom

title: East Can't Save the Queen In Von Zedtwitz Playoff Deal
description: Circumstances contrived to extend the Greater New York Bridge Association's 1998 Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Teams beyond the calendar year. The final last month, between teams led by Janos Racz and Chris Willenken, ended in an exact tie. In a 32-deal playoff Wednesday night at the Beverly Club, 150 Central Park South, Manhattan, the Racz team overwhelmed the opponents, winning by 78 imps to take the title.

title: A Former Buckeye Signs With Browns
description: The Browns signed the former Ohio State University running back Pepe Pearson and four other free agents to contracts.

title: Mayor Puts the Defenseless Into the Crossfire
description: To the Editor:

title: Rights Groups Are Suing Florida for Failure to Educate Pupils
description: A coalition of Florida civil rights groups filed a lawsuit in state court in Tallahassee yesterday, accusing the state of violating the rights of tens of thousands of schoolchildren by failing to provide them with an adequate education as required by the state Constitution.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Modest Snowfall Leaves a Blanket for Playfulness and Panic
description: The first snow worth mentioning this winter in the New York metropolitan area fell steadily yesterday, spreading a light, soppy blanket that exhilarated children but forced rush-hour traffic to creep along slush-slickened highways.

title: Into a Minefield: 'Cold War' on TV; Finding a Moral Difference Between U.S. and the Soviets
description: Ted Turner and the producers Jeremy Isaacs and Pat Mitchell have managed to produce an often riveting and generally comprehensive account of the cold war that will probably become the source most used to acquaint young generations with its history.

title: About New York; Street Name For Impasse: Homeless
description: ROBERT FEINBERG lives in a tiny room. He has a bed, a dresser and a stand where his television shares space with a dozen amber medicine bottles. Not much, but infinitely more than what he had four years ago, when he drifted on the streets, marking the change from summer to winter by migrating from breezy boardwalk at Coney Island to the subway stations of Herald Square. Back then he suffered from infections, heart palpitations, anxiety attacks and seizures. Sometimes, all he did was sob.

title: In a Rarely Used Venue, Rarely Seen Bipartisanship
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd, guardian of dignity and decorum, warned ominously that the Senate was on the verge of tumbling into a ''black pit of partisan self-indulgence.''

title: Memories of Hardship Inspire Many to Give to Fund
description: Roma G. is convinced that the good will of a New York Hospital administrator saved her life in 1965. That year, the official, whose name she cannot remember, admitted her to the hospital's psychiatric ward, even though her father could not afford to pay the bills.

title: Impeachment Trial: Finding a Balance; Exedience or Justice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Writing Dangerously in Iran
description: Last month, two Iranian writers -- Mohammad Mokhtari, a poet and literary critic, and Mohammad Jafar Pouyandeh, an essayist and translator -- were murdered. Iran's official news agency published a statement from the Information Ministry on Tuesday saying the killers were ''irresponsible colleagues of this ministry.''

title: 2 Child Welfare Workers Suspended After Girl Dies
description: Two child welfare workers have been suspended without pay while city officials determine whether they properly monitored the safety of a 3-year-old girl who the police say was killed by her father this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORSER, PAUL
description: CORSER-Paul. With the passing of Paul Corser, humanity has lost a good friend and the AIDS crisis a valiant warrior. Paul's dedication and unwavering spirit will live on however and serve to guide all of us on the road ahead. Our sincere condolences to his wife Sally Morrison and his family. Daniel J. Osheyack Joseph Moran Denise Pruitt Jonathan Scharer

title: Couple Who Feared a Breakup Are Found Shot in a Restroom
description: A 15-year-old girl was found shot to death today in a high school restroom here and the 17-year-old boyfriend whom she had apparently been forbidden to see was seriously wounded.

title: In Firearms Suit, Mother Recalls Night Her Son Was Slain
description: A Brooklyn woman whose son was shot to death personalized the human toll taken by illegally obtained handguns as she testified yesterday in a lawsuit that she helped bring against the gun industry.

title: Policeman Hoping for The Best Vs. Jones
description: Richard Frazier, a New York City police officer in the 26th Precinct, is way out of his jurisdiction down here in this Gulf Coast town. And some would say that he is also way of out his league, challenging Roy Jones Jr., arguably the best boxer in the sport, for Jones's World Boxing Council and World Boxing Association light heavyweight titles.

title: Impeachment Trial: Finding a Balance; Right Time to Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Sinking in Buoyant Waters
description: Even while the stock market hits new highs, a crucial indicator of foreign confidence in the United States Government and its economy -- the dollar -- has been falling. No one can agree why.

title: Andrew Cuomo Decides Against Seeking Moynihan's Seat in 2000
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said today that he would not run for the United States Senate in 2000 and would instead stay in the Clinton Administration, where he can play what is expected to be a major role in Vice President Al Gore's campaign for President over the coming year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, MARTHA
description: FELDMAN-Martha. On Friday, January 8, 1999 (nee Fisher) of Livingston. Wife of the late Norman S. Feldman. Mother of Roberta Lonoff and William Feldman. Sister of Robert Fisher. Grandmother of Jeffrey, Cindy, Michael and Nancy Lonoff and Allison and Noel Feldman. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, NJ at 1 P.M. on Sunday, January 10, 1999. Interment at Temple B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGLYNN, RITA MARY
description: McGLYNN-Rita Mary. Of Bronxville, New York on January 7, 1999. Wife of the late James. Mother of John, Patricia Viola, Robert and Thomas. Sister of Joan, Martin and Peter Nevins. Grandmother of five. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 1:00 PM and 5:00 PM, Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Monday, January 11, 10:00 AM.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Dec. 17 about sales of counterfeit goods on the Internet misstated the location of Cyveillance, a company that specializes in brand protection on line. It is in Alexandria, Va., not New York.

title: The Case of the Unlikely Sleuth
description: Gene Wilder might seem an unlikely choice to play a quick-witted sleuth. But that's just the point. Playing winningly against type, he makes a charming and surprisingly low-key amateur detective in ''Murder in a Small Town,'' a two-hour A&E movie to be shown tomorrow night.

title: Gore, on a Visit to Iowa, Accentuates the Positive From Washington
description: As the Senate debated how to conduct an impeachment trial, the chamber's nominal president, Vice President Al Gore, was 1,000 miles away today, talking about hogs, methamphetamines and Social Security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKEL, ERICH, HANS
description: MARKEL-Erich-Hans, 78. President of The Max Kade Foundation, Inc, New York, died January 4, 1999. His family and friends mourn the death of this exceptional man with a remarkable career and life. He was respected, admired and honored by so many and will be dearly missed. During his 40 years as President, The Foundation made grants to major universities in America and Europe to promote medical research and cross-cultural understanding. He received Orders Of Merit from The Federal Republic of Germany and Austria, and several honorary doctorate degrees from American universities for his philanthropic efforts. A service is being held in his honor at The German Evangelical-Lutheran Church of Saint Paul on Saturday, January 9, 1999, at 12 P.M., 315 West 22nd Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Friends of Dresden, Inc, a charity which supports the reconstruction of the historic ''Frauenkirche (Church)'' of Dresden, 1675 Broadway, Suite 1900, New York, New York 10019-5820. He will especially be missed and remembered by his daughter, Anne, son, Michael, daughter-in-law, Gail, and his grandchildren, Julie, Katie, Erin, and Jason.

title: James Holmes, 59, Composer, Choir Director and Organist
description: James Holmes, an organist and choir director long associated with the Episcopal Church of St. Matthew and St. Timothy on West 84th Street in Manhattan, and a sometime composer of considerable skill, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 59.

title: Mannesmann Profit Grew 50% in 1998
description: Mannesmann A.G., the German telecommunications and engineering company, said yesterday that its operating profit rose by more than 50 percent in 1998, with the largest contribution coming from its rapidly growing telecommunications business.

title: Thompson Suddenly Steps Down
description: With his past star players along with his current team flanking him, John Thompson ended an illustrious, influential 27-year coaching career at Georgetown today.

title: Justices Will Decide the Issue of Correctable Disabilities
description: Taking up an issue that could substantially extend the reach of Federal disability law, the Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether someone with a correctable condition, like high blood pressure or nearsightedness, falls within the law's protection against discrimination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORMAN, OWEN T.
description: GORMAN-Owen T., 92 years, suddenly on January 7, 1999. Beloved husband of Alice. Much loved brother of Sr. M. Jane Thomas, member of Franciscan Missionary Sisters of Peekskill. Survived by three nieces, four grand-nephews and one grand-niece. Reposing at the Conway Funeral Home, Northern Boulevard at 82nd Street, Jackson Heights, on Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 9:30 AM, at St. Joan of Arc Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Spontaneity That Begins In Repetition
description: Toward the end of his first set on Tuesday night at the Village Vanguard, the pianist Brad Mehldau played his ''London Blues,'' and the best aspects of his music made themselves clear. Mr. Mehldau can be obsessive when he improvises, stubbornly repeating phrases, and he did just that; then he slowed the repeated idea down, letting it jut out against the swing of the band like a rock in the current of a river. The band slowed down, picked up his rhythmic ideas and then was on its way.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You know, we didn't ask for this trial. We didn't ask for the President to conduct himself the way he did, and we didn't ask for the House to make a mishmash of this thing. But all that's happened and now we have to preserve the Senate and give the country a sense of credibility.''

title: Senate's Unanimous Agreement on How to Proceed in Clinton Trial
description: Following is the impeachment measure passed today by the Senate, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: 1 Killed in Indonesia Riot
description: One person was killed today and six were injured when the police opened fire on rioters in the town of Karawang, witnesses and medical workers said.

title: In Bow to Reality, N.B.A. Allows Talks With Agents
description: Fearing a mad scramble for free agents three weeks before the season is scheduled to begin, the National Basketball Association agreed yesterday to permit teams to negotiate with player agents immediately.

title: Surging Internet Stock's Trading Halted for a Time
description: In the latest twist on highflying Internet stocks, the Nasdaq exchange yesterday temporarily halted trading of Broadcast.com, a Dallas Internet company, after a more than 70 percent jump in the price of its shares -- then allowed trading to resume even though the company declined to comment on what might have caused the surge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, ZALMAN C.
description: BERNSTEIN-Zalman C. The officers, members and staff of the American Society for Technion (ATS) and the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology express profound regret at the loss of Zalman C. Bernstein, of New York and Jerusalem. Deeply committed to excellence in education, Mr. Bernstein funded the Andre Ballard Chair of Biological Psychiatry at the Technion's Rappaport School of Medicine. We extend our sincere condolences to Mem Bernstein and the entire Bernstein family. American Society for Technion Lawrence S. Jackier, President Irving Shepard, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Jonathan Sohnis, NY Metro Region Chairman Joseph Huber, NY Metro Region Director Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Henry Taub, Chairman International Board of Governors General Amos Lapidot, President ST#

title: Where Comity Prevails, There Was a Day It Didn't
description: Appealing for harmony, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, reminded colleagues gathered in the Old Senate Chamber for a rare bipartisan caucus today that the room was the scene of a ''tragic event'' in 1856: a brutal physical assault by one member of Congress on another.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODWIN, JAMES M.
description: GOODWIN-James M. Retired Colonel US Army, on January 7, 1999 of Garden City. Beloved husband of Constance. Loving father of Blake, Gregory and Lynn. Dear grandfather of four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Saturday and Sunday. Religious services at Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City, Monday 10 A.M.

title: In the Politics of Film Awards, Cantankerousness Has a Role
description: And the winner was . . . ''Out of Sight''?

title: School Construction Trustee Quits After Being Criticized
description: The Governor's appointee to the board of the New York City School Construction Authority resigned yesterday, three weeks after city and state investigators sharply criticized his role in the hiring of a project supervisor at the Brooklyn elementary school where a falling brick killed a girl last January.

title: SENATE, IN UNANIMITY, SETS RULES FOR TRIAL; WITNESS ISSUE PUT OFF
description: After an extraordinary bipartisan caucus that lasted about three hours, the Senate voted unanimously today to approve a plan for President Clinton's impeachment trial that calls for opening arguments to begin on Thursday and defers a decision on whether to summon witnesses until later in the month.

title: If Weather Is Frightful, Jets Won't Mind at All
description: Some were laughing about the weather today, and some said it did not matter at all.

title: Lands' End Officer Quits
description: Lands' End Inc., the catalogue clothing retailer, said today that Bradley Johnson had resigned as chief administrative and financial officer, less than three months after the ouster of the chief executive, Michael Smith. It said Mr. Johnson had quit to pursue other interests. The chief operating officer, Stephen A. Orum, will reassume his position as executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: CENDANT SETTLES LAWSUIT BY INVESTORS FOR $350 MILLION
description: The Cendant Corporation, a franchiser and direct marketer, agreed on Thursday to settle a class-action lawsuit by investors for $350 million. Cendant, based in Parsippany, N.J., agreed to raise by $350 million the market value of securities it issued last year to help finance a bid to buy American Bankers Insurance Group Inc. Plaintiffs contended that the company's executives had misled investors by failing to disclose accounting fraud in April that resulted in a drop in Cendant's share price. The accounting troubles also caused the $3.1 billion purchase of American Bankers Insurance to fall through. Cendant will take an after-tax charge of $220 million, or 26 cents a share, in the fourth quarter to pay for the settlement.

title: Unavailable for Now, Jordan Weighs Choice
description: Michael Jordan has disappeared. It's not the first time. Usually when Michael Jordan vanishes, he's overhead, soaring in his customary Air Jordan, First in Flight fashion. People now are looking for Jordan because they want an answer to the question they have been asking since he sank the winning jump shot from the top of the key in the final game of the 1998 National Basketball Association championship series in Salt Lake City in June.

title: James Hammerstein, 67, Producer and Director
description: James Hammerstein, a producer and a frequent director of the musicals of his father, Oscar Hammerstein 2d, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 67.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANSEN, FREDERICK H.
description: HANSEN-Frederick H. On Jan. 7, 1999. Loving father of Anthony Craig, Frederick James, Astar Elizabeth, & stepfather of Jeffrey. Adoring grandfather of Linnea, Lorielle, Sean & Evan David. Dear uncle of Peggy Anne. Historian, businessman, raconteur, cherished and lifelong friend to so many here in New York & around the world. Visiting Saturday 7-9 PM and Sunday 4-8 PM. Service Monday, at 9:30 A.M., at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory to The American Cancer Society or Bide-A-Wee Animal Shelter.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: APARTMENT INVESTMENT AND MANAGEMENT CO., -- Denver, a real estate investment trust, agreed to buy Calhoun Beach Club Apartments, a 351-unit property based in Minneapolis, for $79.6 million.

title: INTEGRATED ELECTRICAL SET FOR FIVE ACQUISITIONS
description: Integrated Electrical Services Inc., the No. 2 United States electrical contractor, said yesterday that it would acquire five electrical companies with combined annual revenue of $66 million as it follows its strategy of growth through purchases. The Houston-based Integrated Electrical said it would disclose the names of the acquired companies when the purchases closed. The company, which provides contracting and maintenance, said there would not be any job cuts resulting from the acquisitions. Integrated Electrical said the latest purchases would allow it to enter the West Coast market for the first time and expand in the Southeast.

title: Unanswered Questions in a Fatal Police Shooting
description: The last hour of Tyisha Miller's young life in this ''all-American city'' began with a flat tire and a stranger's act of kindness in the early morning darkness three days after Christmas.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: Ex-Official Is Accused In Vote-Machine Rentals
description: A former supervisor at the Somerset County Board of Elections has been charged with illegally renting out the county's voting machines to a union in Linden, county prosecutors said yesterday.

title: The Preteen Sexual Harasser
description: Should Federal sexual harassment laws apply to the conduct of a 10-year-old boy? Next Tuesday, the Supreme Court will be hearing arguments on this question. Common sense suggests that fifth-grade misbehavior is best handled by teachers, principals and parents, or, where appropriate, under local and state laws. But common sense and gender politics are often at odds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMERSTEIN, JAMES B.
description: HAMMERSTEIN-James B. The cast and companies of ''I Love You, You're Perfect, Now Change'' and ''Over The River And Through The Woods'' mourn the sudden passing of our loyal friend, mentor, partner and producer. As a producer, Jamie embodied the ideal his father once described as, ''An idealist, a realist, a practical dreamer, a sophisticated gambler, and a stage-struck child.'' He was everything we could have wanted him to be. We will miss him greatly. Our thoughts and prayers go out to his family, Dena, Simon, Andrew, Will and Jennifer as well as to the directors, writers, and actors for whom he cared so deeply. ST#

title: Slavery's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Scale of Mr. Trump's Dreams
description: The normally loquacious Donald Trump has quietly amassed enough real estate and air rights to build an 861-foot-high skyscraper near the United Nations. What he touts as the world's tallest apartment project is too lanky, even for the architectural mishmash of Manhattan's East 40's. His bronze-glass monolith, the equivalent of 90 stories, would dwarf the 39-story U.N. Secretariat and its waterfront park. The project should be scaled back. But for the moment, Mr. Trump appears well positioned to put his signature on New York's skyline anew since his project is as-of-right, or not subject to extensive public review.

title: OXFORD HEALTH SEES PROFIT IN 2D HALF OF YEAR
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc., the troubled health insurer based in Norwalk, Conn., said yesterday that it might be profitable in the second half of this year. Oxford has registered up to more than $900 million in losses in the last five quarters after losing control of its billing system. The company has been working to turn itself around by raising premiums, focusing on key markets in three states and cutting the fees to doctors. The shares of the company, which peaked at $89 in July 1997, rose $1.203125, to $20.015625. Oxford said it expects to have positive cash flow as early as the first quarter of this year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Asian Stocks Take a Rest From a Dizzying Rally
description: The bulls finally stopped stampeding across Asia today, after a week of powerful gains in stock markets from Seoul to Singapore. Analysts seemed almost relieved, since many were alarmed by the growing disparity between the rising markets and Asia's still-sinking economies.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 15 about education as an issue in the election for California governor referred incorrectly to a link between Dan Schnur, a Republican political consultant, and a 1993 campaign for a ballot measure to create a voucher system for public schools. He took no role in the 1993 campaign; it was managed by another consultant, Ken Khachigian.

title: Rebellion in White: Doctors Pulling Out Of H.M.O. Systems
description: For Dr. Clement Barone, a radiologist on the Upper East Side, the final straw came when Blue Cross Blue Shield told him it was cutting reimbursements for mammograms to $42 each. (He charges $200.) He dropped the plan, and said he might stop accepting all managed care soon.

title: BENEFITS
description: An Evening With Baryshnikov

title: Boy, 8, a Witness in a Murder Case, Is Found Slain With His Mother
description: An 8-year-old boy who was a witness in a pending murder case was found shot to death on Friday, along with his mother, in their Bridgeport, Conn., home, the police said.

title: Surveying The Course For Cup's Challengers
description: America's Cup yacht racing has taken on an immediacy with the beginning of the new year. Challengers are scrambling to get their sailboats built in time for autumn trial races in New Zealand. But observers are speculating on which teams will make it at all.

title: A Prospector Among the Stacks
description: David Shulman's blue eyes glistened as he showed off his most topical prize: an unused ticket to the impeachment trial of President Andrew Johnson dated April 21, 1868.

title: Maura Starkey, Nicholas Balaban
description: Maura Elizabeth Starkey was married yesterday to Nicholas Balaban at Landmark on the Park in New York. The Rev. Richard Viladesau, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Jon Scheffres, a member of Temple Judea-Mizpah in Skokie, Ill., took part in the ceremony.

title: In the County, Stages Come and Stages Go
description: WHEN the people of Westchester search for signs of professional theater away from the crush of Manhattan, they are drawn to plays and musicals in progress at New York Stage and Film, which sets up residency in Poughkeepsie on the campus of Vassar College.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLAUGHLIN, MYLES P.
description: McLAUGHLIN-Myles P. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Myles P. McLaughlin, associated with The Times from 1957 until retiring in 1992.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWITT, LILLIAN
description: HOWITT-Lillian. Will be deeply missed by Diane and Arthur, Neil, Michael, Adrianne, Mildred and many dear relatives, friends and colleagues. We will all attempt to carry on for her with the help of her countless friends. Lil inspired us with her great spirit. A true and truly good individual, always ahead of her time. An educator and principal, a devoted mother, grandmother, mother-in-law, aunt, sister and friend. To a powerful woman who believed in people, peace and humanity to all, we salute and raise our heads. We are proud and better people for having known Lil. Services Sunday, 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACKERMAN, SEYMOUR ''CY''
description: ACKERMAN-Seymour ''Cy'' . On December 24, 1998 at age 80 peacefully at his Phoenix residence, formerly of Plainview, NY. Navy veteran, master mason, importer of dental supplies. Beloved husband of Geraldine (deceased). Devoted father of Joel (Marie), Ian (Wendy), Wendy Stephens (Chris). Adoring grandfather of Todd, Lindsay and Garrett. Donations to charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: The Nation; To Love, Honor and Run for Higher Office
description: IT may be the ultimate slap at the boys in suits who have long dominated American politics: the hottest electoral commodities, as of last week at least, are best known for the men they married, and their last tries for elective office were in student Government.

title: Capital Carousel
description: Now that we have loosed the genie of impeachment, why stop with the President? If the aim is to clean up the political environment, there is no end of other potential defendants. The best place to begin is with those who command the political discourse. At the millennium, it is the media that most need saving from the media. So:

title: In New Discoveries, a Planetary Mystery
description: In a stunning run of discoveries over the last three years, astronomers have observed 17 nearby stars that appear to be orbited by planets more or less the size of Jupiter. The most recent detection of a planet around a star other than the Sun was described here today.

title: Beethoven's Hair Tells All!
description: Will Beethoven's hair ''tell all'' -- or nothing (Philip Weiss, Nov. 29)? Mercury was used to block hats in the 19th century -- hence the phrase ''Mad Hatter'' -- and arsenic was used to treat syphilis as early as 1498. If Beethoven's hair does contain mercury or arsenic, will it indicate that he had syphilis? Or that he was poisoned? Or merely that he may have worn a hat!

title: There's Money to Spend But Priorities Differ
description: FLUSH from their joint success in landing the New England Patriots, Gov. John G. Rowland and the Democrats who control both houses of the General Assembly were tripping over themselves last week with promises to work together during this year's legislative session. At the same time, however, they have announced conflicting priorities that could mean tense months ahead.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BROWNLEE, JOHN
description: BROWNLEE-John. Always remembered and sadly missed for all these past 30 years. Bette and Valerie

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACK, SUSAN VAN WYCK
description: SACK-Susan Van Wyck. January 5th, 1999, at her home in Bermuda, after a long battle with cancer. Beloved wife of A. Albert Sack IV and devoted mother of Carter and A. Albert VI of Bailey's Bay, Bermuda. Daughter of the late Halsey A. Van Wyck and the late Dorothy I. Van Wyck of Long Island, NY. Also surviving, stepchildren, Alexandra Sack Cogswell and Whitney Sack Corderi; grandchildren, James and Caroline Cogswell; Joseph Corderi IV. Board Member of SPCA and Member of Colonial Dames & Daughters of American Revolution; former Ford model. Burial in Family Plot at Swan Point, Providence, Rhode Island, with Memorial Service to be held at Holy Trinity Church, Bailey's Bay, Bermuda, on a date to be decided later. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to PALS, P.O. Box DV19, Devonshire DV BX Bermuda; SPCA, 32 Valley Road, Paget PG 05 Bermuda.

title: Birding, Gaining Stature, Becomes a Peacock; 54 Million People and a $20 Billion a Year Business Work to Protect Threatened Habitats
description: FOR the record, the serious ones prefer to be called birders, not bird-watchers. And although some may be little, old and female, many are male, middle-aged and professional, research shows. As for a birder's reputation for being eccentric, perhaps compulsive would be a better description -- at least when it comes to a penchant for keeping lists, which increasingly birders do on laptop computers.

title: The Empty Net; A Strong Back and a Long Memory Won't Help a Bayman if the Fish, and the Freedom to Haul Them In, Grow Scarce
description: THE two fellers went down to the harbor. The old man wanted to go fishing. The young feller didn't know nothing from fish.

title: Advocates Joining Forces To Fight Pataki DNA Plan
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton and Norman Siegel, executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, pledged yesterday to fight together against Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal for a statewide database containing information on the DNA of all felons.

title: Avoiding the Worms When Bobbing for Overseas Investments
description: SOUTH KOREA is reviving, Thailand isn't far behind, Europe may be less sexy than it looks and Latin America is a minefield. As for Russia, it is an investor's version of where you go after losing at Mortal Kombat: a long, hard fall into a pit full of spikes.

title: A Prisoner Is the Focus of an Abortion Debate
description: Five months pregnant, her belly just beginning to show through the orange prison jumpsuit, Karen Ptaschnik has become an unlikely lightning rod for the abortion debate here.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MONES, ARTHUR.
description: MONES-Arthur. A memorial gathering for Arthur Mones will be held at the Hebrew Union College, 1 West 4th Street, NYC on Sunday, January 24, 1999 at 1pm.

title: A Sea Change
description: Yes, I admit it. I was a founder of the annual Trash Fish Banquet in Provincetown, Mass. And yes, I appreciate how offensive that name sounds today. I can only say in my own defense that 20 years ago those of us who began the annual fund-raising event intended no disrespect. The Trash Fish dinner is not now, nor was it ever intended to be, a vehicle for perpetuating species bias.

title: If It Doesn't Rain or Snow, You Might Not Wash
description: What will happen if it doesn't rain soon?

title: Ah, Sausage and Noble Potato, a Marriage Made in Heaven
description: SAUSAGES and potatoes are the ultimate comfort food. I grew up in England where the combination is called bangers and mash, the quintessential Sunday dinner on a chilly winter night. Another favorite was toad in the hole, a dish most Americans might not find comforting at all, since it consists of sausages baked under a thick layer of batter.

title: Fidelity Wants S.& L. Unit
description: If Fidelity Investments has its way, it will open a Federal savings and loan association aimed at providing trust services to its 14.4 million mutual fund clients nationwide.

title: Strawberry Has Surgery
description: Darryl Strawberry underwent surgery on Friday to relieve pain caused by scar tissue that resulted from his operation for colon cancer in October, the Yankees announced yesterday.

title: Symphonic Film Score, Antisymphony Symphony
description: BY the late 1970's, Philip Glass was poised to conquer the mainstream. ''Einstein on the Beach,'' of 1976, a non-narrative music-theater work created with the director Robert Wilson, had solidified his reputation in the downtown arts community. It had also served to clarify and codify Mr. Glass's distinctive language. Now he was firmly in control of his materials and could turn them to new goals.

title: PULSE; Dancing in Their Seats
description: The basement of Izzy Bar, 166 First Avenue at 10th Street, was jammed with club kids and ravers on a recent night, but no one was dancing. The surprisingly still crowd was there to sit back and listen to the quartet Nerve perform a few sets of the dizzyingly fast dance music known as drum-and-bass. With its 164-beat-a-minute tempo and complex rhythms, drum-and-bass is ordinarily machine-generated and played by deejays -- not exactly easy listening. But Nerve, with a stand-up double bass, guitarist, drummer and keyboardist, is one of a handful of downtown bands that have been turning drum-and-bass into a form of music performed live. ''I'm trying to reverse-engineer electronic music,'' said Jojo Mayer, the drummer for Nerve. Popularized by such English artists as Roni Size and Goldie, drum-and-bass has been adopted by artists as disparate as Metallica and Madonna. At Izzy Bar, the full house listened to improvised sets, applauding midsong after a virtuoso drum fill or feedback guitar break as if they were trumpet solos at the Blue Note. ''Live drum-and-bass is very different from listening to a deejay,'' said Yuki Ando, a Japanese graphic-design student at Parson's and a regular at Nerve's shows. ''It's like going to listen to music in a jazz club, but in a more modern way.'' Six months ago, Nerve was playing to a near-empty house, but on Jan. 19, the group will move to Shine, a larger club at 285 West Broadway, for a party called ''Prohibited Beatz.'' KEVIN BISCH

title: Saying No to Summer Panic Brings a Winter of Content
description: IN a dramatic comeback that cheered the holders of more than 100 million mutual fund accounts, the fund industry turned in a rollicking performance in the final quarter of 1998. The average United States diversified stock fund returned 18.8 percent, the fattest gain for any quarter since 1982, when the business was less than one-eighth its present size.

title: One One-of-a-Kind Comic Impersonating Another
description: ONE chilly November night, a crowd of about 250 people who looked as if they had been cryogenically frozen 20 years ago and then unpacked for the occasion, poured into the lunchroom of Midtown West elementary school on West 48th Street in Manhattan. Neatly arrayed on the lunch tables in front of them were hundreds of half-pint milk cartons and chocolate-chip cookies on bright red paper napkins. There to greet them was a man wearing a wool stadium coat, his shoulders hunched forward and eyes ablaze. They cheered. He beamed. And then, as the crowd surged toward him, the man broke into a spasmodic victory dance, his knees pumping and his arms thrust out awkwardly like a pelican learning to disco.

title: OUTDOORS; Mild Restrains a Feast, but Cold Can Bring a Bounty
description: For the past few years, bagging a brace of ducks for a celebratory Christmas dinner and another pair for a New Year's Day repast has been difficult for me on the island of Martha's Vineyard, but this year it was different.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLOP, LUIS A.
description: GALLOP-Luis A. On December 30, 1998 of Myelodysplasia at home in Chapel Hill, NC. Formerly of Old Greenwich, CT and Francestown, NH, he was an advertising executive for many years with Reuben Donnelley, Time-Life Inc., Benton & Bowles and Venture Magazine. Predeceased by his first wife Kathryn N. Gallop and a daughter Nancy Cristman Thoman. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Maggie R. Matthews of Chapel Hill, NC; Deborah Cristman McMullen of London, England, Dana Cristman Eaton of Sunnyvale, CA, Anne Gallop Pace of Sudbury, MA, Charles Andrew Gallop of Winchester, MA and eight grandchildren. Also survived by his sister, Fifi G. Bronstein of Los Angeles, CA, and three nieces and one nephew.

title: For Decorous Dijon, a Splash of Miami Flair
description: MIAMI is a long way from Dijon, further even in mood than in miles: the one, loud and brash, bouncing with Latin sounds and tropical colors; the other, sober and conservative amid the damp clouds and stone buildings of medieval Burgundy. And yet, in 1991, when Dijon's political elders decided to embark on the city's largest urban project in decades, they chose a quintessentially Miami architecture firm to do the job. How come?

title: Four-Dog Nights
description: The illuminated ball dropped in Times Square again on New Year's Eve, but that's a once-a-year thing. The same night, there was a lighting on the Camden waterfront at the old ''Nipper building,'' once home to the Radio Corporation of America and its predecessor, the Victor Talking Machine Company. This illumination continues nightly and, it might be argued, casts a more meaningful glow. In 1916, the tower atop the building was decorated with four 15-foot windows showing Nipper the dog, leaning toward a gramophone and listening to ''his master's voice.'' It was a beacon displaying a well-known commercial logo and a symbol of industrial Camden. The building closed in 1992, and since then windows have been disappearing to vandalism. But they have been refurbished and now shine in hope of lighting a candle against the darkness of urban decay, and perhaps sparking a rebirth of historic preservation, if not industry. The building's owner, the Camden Redevelopment Agency, hopes to sign up tenants in the Nipper building in the year 2000.

title: MANY HAPPY RETURNS
description: *According to the National Retail Federation, 5.5 percent of all merchandise purchased in department stores in 1997 was returned. *Zeroing in on the Federated Department Stores empire: Customers reject 25 million items worth $820 million every year, according to Stores magazine, which follows such things. *Peanuts, says the Consumer Electronics Manufacturers' Association, reporting that its members take back $15 billion in products. *In Japan, returns are extremely rare because repudiating a gift is considered impolite. *Many retailers now offer coded gift slips that allow the recipient to return goods at full price, without knowing what that price was until arriving at the store. *At Barneys New York, a store executive relates, the biggest holiday return issue is breaking the news to folks that what they received in the Barneys box wasn't from Barneys.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: BAD MAN BLUES

title: Wilder Goes Back in Time to Move Ahead
description: Gene Wilder had just finished filming his new movie's climactic scene, a dramatic moment that required him to catch a swooning actor and drop to his knees. It took several takes, and when he finally was done, he left the set, eased himself into a chair, rolled up his pants legs and yanked hard.

title: Never on Sunday, Says Cayman Islands
description: Beginning this year, cruise ships will no longer be allowed to dock at the Cayman Islands on Sundays, Christmas Day and Good Friday, apparently because of complaints from church officials. The decision, by the islands' department of tourism, was conveyed to the cruise lines in a letter last month from L. Angela Martins, the director of tourism. While Grand Cayman, the islands' capital, is a familiar stop on cruises to the western Caribbean and through the Panama Canal, only a few ships call there on Sunday.

title: Meatballs Devour Worms!!
description: For the past six years NASA has been trying to wipe out the tubular red logo (''the worm'') that has symbolized space exploration since 1975. The chief exterminator is Dan Goldin, NASA's administrator, who says that the original 1958 emblem (''the meatball'') better commemorates the program's mission. But wasting the worm, which has adorned everything from welcome mats to wind tunnels, is taking longer than Goldin would like.

title: When the Gain of a Pawn Is No Match for Mobility
description: Part of the effectiveness of a positional sacrifice is that the pawn or other material offered the opponent is concrete and visible, whereas the benefits must be developed in the less tangible future. It is often easy for the opponent to convince himself that the nebulous will never become reality and strike him.

title: Questioning The Cause Of Dylan Thomas's Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Before a Trim, a Quiz
description: Too often, it seems that hairstylists are from Mars, clients from Venus. To bridge the planets, the Kim Lepine Salon at 61st Street and Madison Avenue has patrons take a multiple-choice personality quiz. Questions range from ''What's your favorite TV show?'' to patrons' shopping habits and the kinds of music they listen to. The answers determine whether the client should have a high-, medium- or low-maintenance style. Ms. Lepine, the salon owner, explained the scoring logic: '' 'Friends' is considered a high-maintenance show because the actors' hair is a big part of who they are. 'Law and Order' is moderate maintenance because, while the people need to look good, the focus is on their professional lives. The Super Bowl is no maintenance.'' Quiz scores are explained with celebrity examples. High maintenance is Susan Lucci, the soap-opera star; moderate maintenance, the actress Helen Hunt; no maintenance, the actress Jada Pinkett. ''Customers often can't articulate what they want,'' Ms. Lepine said. ''The quiz helps them communicate with the stylist.'' Still, as one customer asked Ms. Lepine midquiz, suppose you drive a Volvo but want a haircut that reflects a Porsche-like sensibility? ''No cheating,'' Ms. Lepine said. ELLEN TIEN

title: 7 Artists Integrate Color and Rudeness
description: IT is always enlightening to see how the other half lives, no matter what aspect of life is being divided. Now at the Castle Gallery of the College of New Rochelle here, the line is between those who were born with a color television on, and those whose first notions of the world were formed before television. The exhibition, ''More Fake, More Real, Yet Ever Closer,'' features drawings by seven artists, all of whom are painters born between 1964 and 1970. A shared youthfulness is doubtlessly why the curator, Robert Evren, brought them together.

title: Police Education Standards: Let's Not Go Overboard
description: Many of my students at Suffolk Community College dream of being Suffolk County police officers. Their instructors in the criminal justice program, all of them retired police officers, are role models for a sophisticated, educated police force. Few faculty members are more popular than these men who share with their students anecdotes of the ''real world'' of policing as well as teach the knowledge, values and demeanor that should characterize law enforcement officials. Certainly, two years spent at Suffolk with such mentors is an enriching experience, whether or not the students ever become police officers.

title: Fewer Firefighters But Lots of Chiefs
description: At an appearance here last month to talk about the regional fire department formed by five communities in Hudson County, Governor Whitman praised the effort to overcome the state's history of home rule. The merger, the Governor told the crowd, would result in a property tax savings by stripping away overlapping layers of bureaucracy strewn across municipal borders.

title: Retirement-Happy Funds
description: Direct-marketed, or no-load, fund firms have a striking success story in 401(k) and defined-contribution retirement plans. Assets quadrupled to $52.9 billion in 1997, from $13.6 billion in 1996, and accounted for 49.4 percent of all money flowing into such funds, according to a study by Cerulli Associates, a research and consulting firm in Boston.

title: Bridge Is Inching to a Finish
description: When work began in June 1994 on the 12-foot-wide, 246-foot-long Victory Boulevard Footbridge, Elliot G. Sander was the Commissioner of the Department of Transportation. Three commissioners and four and a half years later, the bridge is almost, but not quite, finished.

title: Canal St. Problems Predated Change in Verrazano Toll
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking 13 Hours To Fix the Errors Made in 90 Minutes
description: IF it's true, as the adage goes, that a second-rate novel can be made into a good movie, then surely a second-rate movie can be made into a good television show. Or so it would seem in the case of ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer,'' a flatly directed horror spoof that lived and died on the big screen in 1992 but was reborn five years later as the critically lauded series that legitimized the struggling WB network. In its second incarnation, the quirky title, the stake-flinging blond high school girl and her all-knowing, older mentor (the Watcher, as he is known, sort of a guru regarding all things creepy) remained. But everything hackneyed had been tossed aside and craftily replaced with new ideas by Joss Whedon, the creator and executive producer of the television ''Buffy.''

title: Protecting Mentally Ill and Society
description: To the Editor:

title: January 3-9; A Plan for Tax Relief
description: President Clinton proposed a program of $6 billion in tax credits and other assistance to people providing long-term care for relatives with chronic illnesses and disabilities. The proposal amounts to a tax cut for the middle class. People with relatively high incomes would be ineligible, as would people with incomes so low that they do not have to pay income taxes.

title: Sorrow in Deeper, Darker Tones
description: HE was the Pavarotti of his age.'' Thus Thomas Hampson describes Mattia Battistini, whose nearly five-decade reign as Don Giovanni and Rigoletto, as the William Tell of Rossini and the Hamlet of Ambroise Thomas in opera houses from Rome to London by way of St. Petersburg at the turn of the century featured no episode stranger than his assumption of the title role of Jules Massenet's ''Werther.''

title: America's Role in Iraq
description: From the information so far disclosed about American intelligence activities in Iraq, it does not appear that Washington acted improperly or misused the United Nations. But it is clear that the international effort to monitor Iraq's development of unconventional weapons will not resume in the form used over the last seven years. That obliges the United States and its allies to develop new methods to prevent Saddam Hussein from stockpiling chemical and biological agents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, LAURA
description: BERMAN-Laura , on January 6, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Samson, loving mother of Susan and Carrie, dear sister of Charles. Adoring grandmother of Sophie, Lily, Sam and Clara. Service Monday 11:15 am at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in her memory to: The Cooper Union.

title: January 3-9; The Happiest Michael Jordan
description: No one was happier with the salvation of the National Basketball Association season last week than Michael Jordan.

title: Sharing Fears of a Cancer Cluster
description: When Gwendolyn G. Madden got a diagnosis of colon cancer in 1997, she began to take unofficial note of the other people who lived in her building, 409 Edgecombe Avenue, and in a five-block area of her neighborhood, Sugar Hill, who had cancer. From 145th Street north, she said, she has counted 15 people in the throes of the disease, and 4 or 5 more who have recently died.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUSHMAN, ARMAND
description: PUSHMAN-Armand. January 8, 1999, age 98. Beloved son of the late Hovsep and the late Hulia Pushman, devoted brother of the late Arsene Pushman. He was the last surviving son of the celebrated American Armenian artist Hovsep Pushman. Armand and his brother were partners in Pushman & Company dealing in fine oriental rugs. Armand was a talented musician having studied the viola in Paris with Maurice Vieux in his youth and enjoyed playing chamber music to the present. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call Sunday and Monday 2-5 and 79PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Service Tuesday January 12th, 1PM at The Armenian Evangelical Church, 152 East 34 St, NYC. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Juilliard School Armenian Scholarship Fund.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: COLLUSION

title: A Political Act
description: MURDER IN THENAME OF GODThe Plot to Kill Yitzhak Rabin.By Michael Karpin and Ina Friedman.Illustrated. 292 pp. New York:Metropolitan Books/Henry Holt & Company. $24.95.

title: Back to America, Trailing His Legend
description: AT an age few Russian men reach, Igor Moiseyev is taking his dance company on its 10th United States tour. The choreographer, who basks in his role of living legend, will celebrate his 93d birthday on Jan. 21, as the Moiseyev Dance Company performs in Reading, Pa. It is one of dozens of performances during a seven-week trip that will take the troupe from New York to Los Angeles.

title: Mountaineering Proves Much to UCONN's Liking
description: Connecticut's Richard Hamilton was no offensive slouch to begin with, but practicing against the former UConn stars Ray Allen and Donyell Marshall has made him better.

title: A Kids' Store, No Charge
description: Early in the fall, Ellen Chuse, a childbirth and parenting educator, received a telephone call from a young woman looking for children's clothes, toys and books. The woman, Julie Brown, said she was stocking a ''store'' called Room to Grow for infants to 3-year-olds in Harlem, where low-income parents could pick up items for their children at no charge.

title: A Model City
description: To the Editor:

title: The Power Of Personality: How Divine!
description: HE was the Fred Astaire of repartee, a man whose tailoring seemed to precede his birth. Noel Pierce Coward -- even his name, at once patrician and amusing, fit him, as did the fair hair molded to his skull with Savile Row precision, the skin stretched sleek across angled cheekbones, and the speech so crisp and pressed that it draped his most offhand ''darling'' in a knife-edge crease of implication.

title: Marlins Rebuild, but Uncertainly
description: These names are known little, if at all, beyond their own households, but they have something in common: Armando Almanza, A. J. Burnett, Joe Fontenot, Braden Looper, Rafael Medina, Jesus Sanchez, Ramon Castro, Derrek Lee.

title: Johnson's Actions Unforgivable
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Canal St. Problems Predated Change in Verrazano Toll
description: To the Editor:

title: Dining Fashionably in Sao Paulo
description: PAULISTANOS, the residents of Sao Paulo, like to say that of their city's 10 million people, there is a core of 10,000, each of whom sees another in that group every day. And much of that seeing takes place at one of the city's fashionable restaurants.

title: Where Beatles and Stones Ruled the Airwaves
description: Sure, WMGM was there first, and WINS and WMCA were, well, a little hipper. Still, for man years, WABC was the undisputed powerhouse of the airwaves. The advent of FM radio in the late 1960's changed everything, and lessened WABC's influence. The station was but a shadow of its former self when, in 1982, it finally succumbed to broadcasting reality and converted to the all-talk format it continues to feature today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLENBOGEN, EVELYN JACKTER
description: ELLENBOGEN-Evelyn Jackter. Died January 8, 1999 at 93 years. Born in Brooklyn in 1905, she taught elementary school in the NYC public schools for 38 years. Wife of the late Nath Ellenbogen, mother of Marian Isenberg and Ruth Flaxman, grandmother of Alison, Neil, Caroline, Gary and Laura. We will miss her. Contributions to charity of your choice.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: The Oddest Couple; Johnson and Chrebet Have Little In Common, Except Uncommon Ability
