description: To watch Jets receivers Keyshawn Johnson and Wayne Chrebet play off each other, to watch them block for one another, it seems apparent that they have a unique relationship.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: THE BIRTH OF EMPIRE

title: From Conservative Steps, Liberal Gains
description: MUTUAL FUNDS used to be sold as one-decision investments. If they weren't held for a lifetime, at least they were held for many years. And because they were so diversified, in theory you needed only one fund. Life was simple.

title: Fewer Jet Flights In Caribbean Skies
description: WHEN American Airlines announced a year ago that it would soon end jet service between San Juan, P.R., and five Caribbean islands, routes on which it said it was losing millions of dollars, officials on those five islands decried the decision as a blow to their tourist industries. Even American's plan to replace the jets with much smaller, turboprop planes operated by American Eagle, American's commuter carrier, did little to mollify them for what they regarded as an insult.

title: In a Parish in Peru: The Priest, His 2 Sons and a Very Angry Bishop
description: Catholics cannot be baptized or married in Morrope anymore. The graceful colonial church is locked shut. And the Roman Catholic Church hierarchy has threatened to suspend all charitable donations to this desert town of 39,000 souls, who are still reeling from the floods brought by El Nino.

title: An End to Burnout
description: How many employees does it take to change a light bulb at Ether, a new store in NoLIta? None. The shop, which sells oddities and clothing, is one of the first commercial spaces lighted with L.E.D.'s, light-emitting diodes. ''You can leave these lights on for 11 years continuously,'' said Joel Fitzpatrick, the owner of Ether, which is at 28 Prince Street (between Elizabeth and Mott Streets). ''Plus, they never get hot, so you don't have to worry about fire.'' A spokesman for Color Kinetics, a Boston-based light supplier that sells light-emitting diodes, said that the reason stores like them is that they don't emit ultraviolet rays, which can fade fabrics or paint. Nine West and Joop! are using L.E.D.'s, which can be set on a standard white light or programmed to melt into many hues, bathing customers in a Lava lamp-like glow.

title: In Albany, Openly Gay State Senator Tests Unfamiliar, Conservative Turf
description: In the first roll call of the 222d session of the New York State Legislature, the clerk had to say Thomas K. Duane's name three times before he responded, ''Here.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't want a practice just for rich people. That was never my plan. But I also want to be able to give the kind of care that I think people deserve.''

title: French Bakery Isn't Saying Adieu Quite Yet
description: Patisserie Bonte's customers from the neighborhood and beyond who thought they would sample the final morsels from the popular French bakery on New Year's Eve, have three months more to savor the establishment's large brioches, fresh fruit tarts and other pastries.

title: Wellstone Says He Won't Seek Presidency in 2000 After All
description: Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota announced today that he would not seek the Presidency in 2000, further shrinking the field of Democrats.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Museum Lectures

title: Sex Enters the Fray in Inquiry in Utah
description: As reports of cash payments, a land deal, tuition aid and excessive gift-giving continued to flow in a torrent this week, it seemed inevitable to some Olympic officials that the issue of sex would surface in the bribery scandal involving the 2002 Winter Games.

title: Throwaway Bags
description: To most people, Tide is a detergent, Ritz is a cracker and compact disks are for music. To Gabbriel Ichak, they are some of his materials for making handbags and a line of recycled accessories. Mr. Ichak, an East Village artist, makes bags and backpacks from vintage magazine spreads, including one featuring Lee Radziwill, and product packages and other memorabilia in a process that involves lamination, upholstery plastic and steel rivets. They are sold in his showroom at 430 East Ninth Street and at Fred Segal in Los Angeles. Prices range from $26 to $80, and styles from noir (bags of pulp fiction covers) to risque (topless pinup postcards) to exotic (prints of Mexican wrestlers). Mr. Ichak no longer uses images from Playboy and Mattel since the companies sent letters threatening legal action. ''What I'm really using is magazine garbage,'' said Mr. Ichak, who added he was thinking about making bags from leftover computer circuit boards. No one has a copyright on them yet. ANNA HOLMES

title: Florendo M. Visitacion, 88, Martial Arts Master, Is Dead
description: Florendo M. Visitacion, who built upon childhood experiences in a rural Philippine village to develop and promote his own eclectic and well-known system of martial arts in New York, died on Monday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 88.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENT, JOSEPHINE
description: KENT-Josephine. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Marjorie Millman and Richard. Cherished grandmother of Mark, Matthew, Kimberly, Martin and Gregory. Graveside services at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, 7800 Myrtle Avenue, Glendale, Queens today at 2:00PM.

title: Q&A/Dr. Penelope J. Ryan; Catholicism, as Seen by a Loyal Dissenter
description: DR. PENELOPE J. RYAN defines herself as both a life-long practicing Roman Catholic and a ''loyal dissenter.'' Dr. Ryan, an adjunct professor at Fordham University and a full-time teacher at the School of the Holy Child in Rye, where she teaches religion courses, has her disagreements with some of the teachings of her church: those relating to the ordination of women, birth control, abortion and celibacy of priests, among others.

title: Ntsu Mokhehle, 80; Fractious Land's Premier
description: Ntsu Mokhehle, who introduced the former British protectorate of Lesotho to modern politics, died on Wednesday after falling ill during his 80th birthday party.

title: Ideas & Trends; In Television News, an Epidemic of Pencil Envy
description: THEY have a weighty title -- anchor -- but an evanescent legacy. Their faces are etched into the public eye by weightless electrons 30 times a second, but after 1,800 seconds, the music swells, the screen changes to ''Jeopardy'' and they are gone until the next evening, the next bulletin, the next interruption of that regularly scheduled program.

title: Jewish Life, in Hit Films and Premieres
description: THE 24 films to be shown at the eighth annual New York Jewish Film Festival address ''the experience of being a Jew in the world and the experience of the Jewish world,'' said Richard Pena, program director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Chateau Brooklyn

title: The One-State Solution
description: Given the collapse of the Netanyahu Government over the Wye peace agreement, it is time to question whether the entire process begun in Oslo in 1993 is the right instrument for bringing peace between Palestinians and Israelis. It is my view that the peace process has in fact put off the real reconciliation that must occur if the hundred-year war between Zionism and the Palestinian people is to end. Oslo set the stage for separation, but real peace can come only with a binational Israeli-Palestinian state.

title: McGreevey's Running Again. Or Maybe He Never Stopped.
description: Jim McGreevey is running again.

title: Impeachmentese
description: 'Even in survival,'' wrote Jim Hoagland of The Washington Post, ''Clinton will emerge from this experience chastised if not chastened, humiliated if not humbled.''

title: In Defense of the Inalienable Right to . . . Boogie
description: Last October, when Baby Jupiter, a bar and restaurant at Orchard and Stanton Streets, was fined and padlocked for two days by the Department of Consumer Affairs for violating the city's cabaret law, the Rev. Jen Miller and Robert Prichard decided to protest.

title: Authoritative Fiddling
description: WIENIAWSKI: WORKS FOR VIOLIN AND PIANO

title: Officer Wounded and Assailant Killed in Newark
description: A routine drug arrest turned violent last night when a Newark police officer was shot and his assailant was killed, the police said.

title: Medical Center Charts Own Course
description: FREE at last from the county government -- this time apparently for real -- the Westchester Medical Center is setting out to make itself as highly regarded as any of the nation's most prestigious hospitals.

title: Protecting Mentally Ill and Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Different Views
description: To Sunday Styles:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, LEON M.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Leon M. The administration, faculty, staff and students of Kingsborough Community College, City University of New York, deeply mourn the passing of Leon M. Goldstein, its beloved President for the past 28 years. His visionary leadership made Kingsborough one of the finest institutions of higher education in the country. His innovative, pioneering educational, cultural and community service programs for the residents of the borough of Brooklyn and the City of New York have demonstrated all the positive aspects of collaboration, cooperation and commitment to excellence. President Goldstein's creative programs including College Now, Family College, My Turn, Diploma Now, New Start and the Kingsborough High School for the Sciences have responded to the needs of people of all ages and have served as models for other colleges across the nation. Through his forceful leadership and dedicated professionalism Leon Goldstein has been an inspiration to all those he has touched. As a student of the City University of New York, a member of its faculty, an administrator and as a president, Leon Goldstein exemplified the very mission, heart and soul of public higher education. He was a strong voice for the educationally and economically disadvantaged, women returning to the workforce and education for new immigrants. He championed the cause of access to higher education for all New Yorkers. President Goldstein will long be remembered for his extraordinary ability to bring out the best in people. He was loved and will be missed by the entire Kingsborough Family. Our hearts go out to his wife, Mary, his son, Michael, his daughter, Lisa and her husband, Glenn. Funeral services will be held Sunday, January 10 at 1:15 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, New York City. GOLDSTEIN-Leon M. The City University of New York deeply mourns the passing of Kingsborough Community College President Leon M. Goldstein. Dynamic leader of the College for 27 years, distinguished educator and administrator, extraordinary champion of the New York State community college movement, and outstanding alumnus of City College and Brooklyn College, he served CUNY in numerous capacities with great distinction as Acting Chancellor, Acting Deputy Chancellor, Chair of the Fiscal Affairs Committee of the Council of Presidents, Chair of the Chancellor's Advisory Committee on Academic Program Planning, University Dean for Community Colleges and Dean and Professor of History at New York City Community College. Recognized nationally for his leadership and commitment to higher education, he served as Vice President of the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools, and Chair of its Commission on Higher Education. Committed to access and excellence in education throughout his career, he was in the forefront of pioneering programs established at Kingsborough Community College including College Now, Family College, Teacher's Academy, the Kingsborough High School for the Sciences, My Turn and New Start. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Anne A. Paolucci, Chairwoman Board of Trustees Christoph M. Kimmich Interim Chancellor GOLDSTEIN-Leon. On behalf of the instructional staff at CUNY, the Professional Staff Congress notes with profound sadness the passing of President Leon Goldstein of Kingsborough Community College. President Goldstein's contribution to the building of Kingsborough and its widely admired place in American higher education is his great legacy. The university community is also in his debt for his admirable service as CUNY Dean for Commmunity Colleges, Acting Deputy Chancellor and Acting Chancellor of CUNY. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his widow, Dr. Mary Goldstein, and the entire Goldstein family. Dr. Irwin H. Polishook, President Dr. Richard J. Boris Vice-President Dr. Rina Yarmish, Chapter Chair Professional Staff Congress/ CUNY

title: What Welfare-to-Work Really Means
description: Today, more than two million mothers are on welfare. For many, the path to reform is not as simple as finding a job. Estimates vary, but as many as 800,000 are drug addicts and alcoholics. These women are the most neglected segment of the welfare population and have the toughest time getting off welfare and finding a job.

title: These Pilots See a Bumpy Flight
description: ALTHOUGH most mutual fund investors closed out 1998 with gains, the road was rocky, with their climb hampered by sharp dips and the summer selloff.

title: OPINION; Let's Get a Land Bank for Nassau
description: THERE are instances where a public policy issue exposes more facets than the protagonists had intended. Such is the case of the development of the 39-acre former Cerro Wire and Cable Co. manufacturing site in Syosset. There is a basic understanding that an owner, as of right, can do what he wants with his property, so long as the development conforms to existing local zoning and land use regulations. The Taubman Co., a respected developer of retail malls, is proposing to do just that on the Cerro Wire site with its proposal for an upscale retail center.

title: Clinton Revives Proposal to Expand Medicare
description: In his new budget request, President Clinton will again ask Congress to open Medicare to people 55 to 64 years old, Administration officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACKLER, MILDRED.
description: MACKLER-Mildred. At home on January 1, 1999. She touched the lives of everyone who knew her with much love, warmth, humor and friendship. A truly elegant woman will be deeply missed but forever in our hearts. Private burial. Memorial service to be arranged at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice or the Robert E. Barrett Fund for Neurological Research, 71 E. 77 St, NY NY 10021.

title: Julie Dobrow and Jason Rossi
description: FOR as long as Julie Dobrow can remember, she has known exactly what kind of man she wanted to marry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERRICK, IRA T.
description: HERRICK-Ira T. January 6, 1999. Unique individual. Accomplished art director in advertising, TV, print and publication. A friend, husband, father and grandfather. Charming, he will be missed by all whom he touched with his wit and anecdotes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNENSCHEIN, EDITH H.
description: SONNENSCHEIN-Edith H. ''Lene''. On January 8, 1999 after a long life of 97 years. Beloved wife of the late Hans. Dear sister of the late Greta Kramer. Survived by a cousin, Francis Gordon of London, England. Cherished lifelong friend of the Wells and Weinreich families. Donations in her memory to Congregation Emanu-El of The City of New York. Private services.

title: What's in a Fund Name? In Japan, a Dead Italian
description: With deregulation prompting a flood of new mutual fund offerings in the Japanese market, fund managers anxious to stand out from the crowd have abandoned the traditional nomenclature of fund names -- ''equity,'' ''growth,'' ''global,'' ''strategic'' and so on -- in favor of a new trend, naming funds after Italian classical and Renaissance icons.

title: Crime
description: Here it is, just in time for those read-for-your-life months in the dead of winter: a new 87th Precinct novel from Ed McBain. It happens to be a good one, too, from its swaggering title, THE BIG BAD CITY (Simon & Schuster, $25), to the ending that leaves Steve Carella, the detective who has been on duty in this series since 1956, weak in the knees.

title: SOAPBOX; The Tyranny of Testing
description: THE Earth is no longer flat, doctors do not use leeches to suck blood and someday the creators of reading tests will not be our youngsters' evaluation Gods. Test threats -- like those imposed by the state's three-day exam for all public-school fourth graders starting on Tuesday -- are sad substitutes for genuine motivation. The latest reported decline in elementary school scores is scant cause for depression, just as the previous year's increase did not warrant jubilation.

title: Backtalk; The N.B.A. Is All About Spinning
description: It's going to be tougher now. Rooting for local teams or resenting individual players is no longer smart enough. Now that political-style spin has engaged the arena, the National Basketball Association spectator has to bring to the court an attitude worthy of the disinfomercials that have emerged since the lockout ended. ''Love that game'' is a peeling bumper sticker.

title: A Lofty Landmark Disappears From the Queens Skyline
description: The sky above the factories of Long Island City got a little darker last week.

title: In the Region / Long Island; The Movies Are the New Stars of the Mall
description: THE 15-screen Loews movie theater that opened here on Route 347 on Dec. 23 is -- for the moment -- the biggest, plushest and most elaborate on the Island.

title: The Face of Eco-Terrorism
description: I am sick and tired of eco-freaks whining about trees and animals while welfare is being slashed and bombs are being dropped on countries like Iraq.

title: Police Brutality Claim Roils Southold
description: AS chairman of the Southold Anti-Bias Task Force, the Rev. Marvin Dozier of Unity Baptist Church of Mattituck has heard many accounts from blacks about mistreatment by white Southold Town police officers.

title: Growing Into Old Age and Some of Its Support Services
description: Penn South Mutual Redevelopment Houses, a large moderate-income co-op complex on the west side of Eighth Avenue between 23d and 29th Streets, was seen as such an exemplary model of affordable housing for working families in 1962 that its dedication was attended by President John F. Kennedy, Eleanor Roosevelt, Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller and Robert Moses, who shaped much of the city in the post-war era. Now Penn South is on the verge of making a mark again.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Donald J. Trump; Previewing The States Of Beauty
description: ON Thursday, the temperature had dropped to a sub-freezing chill, but at Life, the nightclub on Bleecker Street, things were heating up. Donald J. Trump was expected at any moment for a promotional party for the Miss U.S.A. Pageant, which will be broadcast live next month on CBS.

title: Outreach, the Wandering Museum's Specialty
description: ART gets around. Museums are pretty well stuck in one spot, but their treasures keep on truckin'. At a time when museums build buildings that tend to be more significant than the collections they shelter, some centers have gone the less expensive route of converting existing industrial centers into galleries. A few others are experimenting with putting art, at least temporarily, into essentially unconverted places that respectable museums would once have thought dreadfully infra dig: marginal retail areas, department stores, dance halls.

title: The State of the Art Museum, Ever Changing
description: WHAT is it about museums, and art museums in particular, that makes them such compelling topics of conversation as this contentious century draws to a close? Is it the phenomenon of their soaring attendance when many cultural institutions are undergoing a decline of interest? Is it the spectacle of their often-dramatic architecture? Or is it their seemingly anachronistic quality of dealing exclusively with the physical reality of objects at a time when we have become obsessed with the ephemeral nature of virtual reality?

title: Protecting Mentally Ill and Society
description: To the Editor:

title: In Praise of Poetry, Preferably Brief
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about investing in the bond market misstated the occupation of Jay Gatsby, the character in ''The Great Gatsby,'' by F. Scott Fitzgerald. Gatsby was a bootlegger; it was Nick Carraway, the narrator, who was in the bond business.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article in the Arts & Leisure section today about the state of art museums carries an erroneous page number in some copies for the continuation. The article continues on page 40.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: January 3-9; Jesse Becomes The Body Politic
description: So he didn't begin his inauguration ceremony by rappelling into the Capitol from a helicopter. The mere fact that Jesse ''the Body'' Ventura became Governor of Minnesota was enough of a curiosity.

title: Crime Down in County
description: Overall, the violent crime rates in Westchester, like those for the rest of the United States, have decreased, according to the State Department of Criminal Justices Services.

title: One Track, Two Loads
description: Like the goose that suddenly started laying golden eggs, New Jersey's rail system has turned from an unwelcome burden to an invaluable treasure, a vital artery for commuters as well as goods. While that may be welcome news for the region's economy, it may not be for the commuters whose trains will face growing competition for track space on crowded freight lines.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 13 about diving off Cozumel, Mexico, included an outdated reference to Scaramouche, a discotheque in San Miguel de Cozumel. It is now closed.

title: No. 1 Huskies' Competition About to Get a Lot Tougher
description: To provide his starters with tougher competition, Geno Auriemma, the women's coach at Connecticut, sent two assistants in search of male practice players on the Storrs campus a few years ago. But with 11 players capable of starting for most teams in the Big East, Auriemma must no longer find men to practice against his front liners.

title: Lucky Parcells
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Hoopla on Fifth
description: They weren't playing basketball outside the GM Building on Fifth Avenue on Wednesday afternoon, but the 179 players who voted to end the National Basketball Association's six-month lockout gave the scene the air of an All-Star Game. The players from 29 teams left the vote in a swirl of media and fans. Their nonchalant style of dress stood in contrast with the area's usual suited executives. The occasional white or brown mink parka added a splash to the camel hair and leather trench coats of many players. Top, from left: Tom Gugliotta, Derrick Coleman, Charles Barkley, Sam Perkins, Shaquille O'Neal and Sharone Wright. Bottom, from left: Tyrone Corbin, Felipe Lopez and Jason Kidd, Dickey Simpkins, Grant Long, and Anthony Mason.

title: The Test Under Stress
description: When Gabe Schwartz received his P.S.A.T. results early in his junior year at New York's private Fieldston School, he wasn't pleased. He earned a 980. ''That gave me no shot at getting into a top college,'' he explains. ''I knew the P.S.A.T. didn't count officially, and I knew I was capable of doing better. But then you read in the College Board literature how no amount of studying will increase your scores, and you really begin to feel stressed out.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARQUEZ, CECIL G.
description: MARQUEZ-Cecil G., 91, physician, died at home in New Rochelle January 8, 1999. His family mourns his passing with deep sorrow. He is survived by his wife, Gloria, and children, Yolanda, Donald, Cecil Jr., Camilo and Rita. Grandfather of twelve. Great-grandfather of thirteen. Funeral was private. A memorial service is planned. Contributions in his memory may be sent to Pamela C. Torres Day Care Center, named after his deceased grandchild, at 161 St. Ann's Avenue, Bronx, New York 10454.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEXLER, ROSE KUPCHICK
description: WEXLER-Rose Kupchick. Beloved mother of Harriet Stern, mother-in-law of Mel, devoted grandmother of Jeff and Caroline Stern. Devoted sister and aunt.

title: Ashley Williams, Brian Rieck
description: Ashley Williams, the daughter of Christine Vanderwarker Ness of Greenwich, Conn., and Alexander Hazard Williams 3d of Southhold, N.Y., was married yesterday to Brian William Rieck, a son of Kristine J. Coffey of Lake Forest, Ill., and Ronald R. Rieck of Las Vegas, Nev. The Rev. James L. Burns performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Dec. 27 about the introduction of new European currency misstated its name. It is the euro, not the eurodollar.

title: In Iraq, Preserve Unscom's Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: A Culinary Frame For Museum Mile
description: BUSBY'S +++

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION; Working on Commission
description: ''How . . . could the much-studied Impressionist revolution . . . espouse a genre which . . . might be considered the least amenable to any divergence from accepted practice?'' asks Colin B. Bailey, the chief curator of the National Gallery of Canada, at the beginning of RENOIR'S PORTRAITS: Impressions of an Age (Yale University/National Gallery of Canada, $30). Financial necessity is the primary answer: commissioned portraits paid the rent. Moreover, we learn that Renoir was the only Impressionist to achieve financial security through the practice of portraiture. ''Yet, just as the Impressionists catered, at one level, to the conventional requirements for bourgeois representation -- namely, portrait painting -- so did they also expand and redefine the genre,'' Bailey writes. During the years of his greatest demand as a portraitist, between 1878 and 1883, Renoir painted his most ambitious compositions of contemporary life, including ''Luncheon of the Boating Party,'' ''Ball at the Moulin de la Galette,'' ''Dance in the City'' and ''Dance in the Country.'' Anne Distel, the chief conservator at the Musee d'Orsay in Paris, contributes a cogent essay about the Impressionist patron and collector Leon Clapisson. But it is the art historian Linda Nochlin who offers the sharpest and most perceptive essay in the book, giving the social context for Impressionist portraiture and offering a fascinating explication of Degas's ''Place de la Concorde,'' among other paintings. Nochlin's essay, which scarcely mentions Renoir, is accompanied by reproductions of portraits by fellow Impressionists like Manet, Degas and Cassatt that invite comparison with Renoir and present an odd disjunction; some readers may feel that the detailed, psychologically oriented and less romanticized portraits by these painters are more successful than Renoir's. Nevertheless, Renoir's portraits, Bailey believes, are distinguished by ''the extraordinary light with which they are imbued.'' Robin Lippincott

title: Contemplative Time, Catalogues in Hand
description: THE catalogues are arriving from seed houses and nurseries. Now, while there is plenty of reading and planning time, the new garden can be set out -- on paper at least.

title: Making Films, Making Waves
description: LIGHTS! Camera! Complaints! When the thrill of film production gives way to the reality of traffic jams, generators and klieg lights, some residents, particularly those in small towns and villages, find themselves less than star struck. Reflecting what many Manhattan neighborhoods have been complaining about for years, some municipalities are seeking to limit the disruption that can come with movie, television and commercial production in their neighborhoods.

title: The World: The Khmer Rouge Legacy; In the Killing Fields, Even the Future Died
description: PUT the Khmer Rouge on trial for mass murder? ''Who's going to try them?'' asked a foreign human rights worker. ''They killed all the lawyers.''

title: Word for Word/Kissinger Transcripts; Sex, Spooks and the Hereafter: Private Banter With Brezhnev and Mao
description: PRESIDENT NIXON went to China. Henry A. Kissinger came along. They talked with Chairman Mao and his aides of war, peace, sex, death and the incendiary powers of the potent rice liquor known as mao tai.

title: Tracking Campaign Financing
description: CAMPAIGN finance reform may be dead and with it further limits on what a candidate may spend or where he can get his money from. But at least it will soon be easier for the public to keep track of who is getting how much from where because of computerization of campaign finance records.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASMANTIER, CATHARINE MARGARET
description: PASMANTIER-Catharine Margaret. The Board of Directors of The Fund For Blood and Cancer Research deeply mourns the passing of Catharine Margaret Pasmantier, our newsletter editor and the wife of our co-chairman, Dr. Mark W. Pasmantier. She was the paradigm of selfless devotion to serving the needs of her community. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to her husband, Mark; her children, Elizabeth, James and Meredith; her parents, William and Catharine Sitterley; her sister, Beth Newman; and her brother, William Sitterly, Jr. Morton Coleman, M.D., Co-Chairman PASMANTIER-Catherine Margaret. Died on January 7th, 1999 at the age of 56 after a brief illness. Beloved wife of Dr. Mark Pasmantier. Devoted mother of Elizabeth, James and Meredith. Loving daughter of William and Catherine Sitterley; and sister of Mrs. Lawrence Newman and William Sitterley, Jr. She resided in Ridgewood, New Jersey, and was active in many community activities amongst which were the Family Counseling Service, College Club, and the Center for Electronic Learning. Memorial services will be held on Thursday, January 21 at 5 P.M. at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, 1157 Lexington Ave at 80 Street. Donations in Margaret's memory may be made to the Family Counseling Service of Ridgewood and/or the Fund for Blood and Cancer Research. PASMANTIER-Catherine Margaret. The physicians of The Association of Practicing Physicians of The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center extend their deepest sympathy and condolences to Dr. Mark Pasmantier and his family on the loss of their beloved wife and mother Catherine Margaret Pasmantier. Mrs. Pasmantier worked tirelessly as a volunteer at The New York Hospital and both Dr. and Mrs. Pasmantier were major influences in the life of our hospital and medical college. We will miss her warm presence. Assn. Of Practicing Physicians PASMANTIER-Catherine Margaret. With great sadness the Faculty and staff of the Division of Hematology and Medical Oncology and the Department of Medicine of Weill Medical College of Cornell University extend our condolences to Dr. Mark Pasmantier, his family and friends on the recent death of his wife Catherine Margaret. PASMANTIER-Catherine Margaret. With great sadness the Oncology Care Team at New York Presbyterian Hospital-Weill Cornell Medical Center extends our deepest sympathy to Dr. Mark Pasmantier and his family over the recent loss of his wife Catherine Margaret.

title: On the Expressway, a (Set) Time to Grieve
description: Chad M. Compton was asleep at the wheel when his Subaru coupe veered off Route 42 and careened into the guardrail near the Atlantic City Expressway in Turnersville, the police think. The 27-year-old Sicklerville man did not survive the Dec. 9 crash, which was so violent that it caused his car to ricochet into a lamppost then flip into oncoming traffic.

title: BEST SELLERS: January 10, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Letting Your Fingers Reserve a Campsite
description: Camping reservations for the most popular National Park areas can be made on the Internet, using a Visa, Mastercard or Discover credit card. The secure Internet address is reservations.nps.gov.

title: INSIDE
description: Mob Is Linked to Protests

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLECHMAN, BURT
description: BLECHMAN-Burt. Age 71. On December 29, 1998 in Providence, Rhode Island of pancreatic cancer. Survived by his mother, Mae and brother, R.O. Blechman; nephews, Nicholas and Max; and companion John Marsh. His first novel, ''How Much'' was adapted by Lillian Hellman for Broadway, and praised by Alfred Kazan as ''a book that comes off with painful power ...inimitable.'' Critically acclaimed by W.H. Auden, Anita Loos, and Susan Sontag, he subsequently wrote four novels, ''The War Of Camp Omongo,'' ''Maybe,'' ''Stations,'' and ''The Octopus Papers.'' ''Turn Off The Television Awhile,'' wrote Saul Bellow, ''and for the sake of your souls, read Burt Blechman.'' A generous contributor to The Yivo Institute for Jewish Research and the Pearl Theatre, he was a brilliant conversationalist and wit. He will be sorely missed by family and friends.

title: The World; To Sicilians, Russia Has No Mafia. It's Too Wild.
description: In the old days, Russians traveling abroad were often and often rightly -- suspected of being K.G.B. agents. Now they are more likely to be suspected of belonging to something called the Russian mafia -- a nebulous term that has taken on real meaning in Budapest, Geneva, Brooklyn, Los Angeles and anywhere else where Russia's brazen criminal class has managed to set up branch offices.

title: Smoke Signals
description: Smokers in New Jersey took such a shellacking at the cash register last year that they stopped buying cigarettes in numbers never seen before. How many stopped smoking is a separate question.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZELIN, JEFFREY
description: ZELIN-Jeffrey. My dearest Jeff. I can't begin to tell you how lonely it is without you. I will love you forever. Although it is your heart that has stopped, it is mine that is aching for you to be here. You were the most wonderful husband in the world. I will miss you terribly. I love you, Jeff, today, tomorrow and always. Your loving wife, Shari ZELIN-Jeffrey/m. Dear Daddy, we know that you are no longer here with us, but we want you to know how much we love you and miss you. We will never forget you, Daddy. You were and always will be the best Daddy in the world. We all will love you forever. All our love, Joshua, Jennifer, Ryan, Jared, and Nicole

title: Protecting Mentally Ill and Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, ZALMAN
description: BERNSTEIN-Zalman. It is with great sorrow that the Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Zalman Bernstein, one of the most significant philanthropists of this generation. His philanthropic endeavors, through the AVI CHAI Foundation and the Sanford C. Bernstein & Company Foundation, have greatly enriched Jewish life in New York, Israel, and around the world. By showing the foresight to support projects which bring Jews from different backgrounds together, he has left a legacy that will benefit thousands of individuals in immeasurable ways well into the 21st century. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Mem, his children, Leslie, Claude, and Rochel Leah, and to the entire Bernstein family. May his memory be a blessing to us all. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P. BERNSTEINZALMAN ST#

title: January 3-9; Together Again
description: When you reach the fork in the road, take it, Yogi Berra is said to have once told a friend who was coming to visit. Last week, when George Steinbrenner, the New York Yankees' principal owner, made his way to Berra's home turf to ask that they bury their 14-year feud, the Hall of Fame catcher decided it was time for both men to take the high road. ''Fourteen years,'' his son, Dale, told him, ''is long enough.''

title: January 3-9; A Tiny Opening to Cuba With Little Political Risk
description: The Clinton Administration took steps to allow more American money, airplanes, food and mail flow into Cuba, with an eye toward the day when Fidel Castro no longer rules the isolated island. But the White House, which is wary of the political power of anti-Castro Cuban-Americans, rejected calls for creating a national commission that would study the 37-year-old American economic embargo that has stifled Cuba's economy. TIM WEINER

title: My Account Statement Is Better Than Yours
description: AS part of an unceasing quest to find new ways to show that I am right and my wife is wrong, I recently took haranguing to a new level. I found fault not with her Spanish -- or with the fact that she has been working on a sweater for me for six years and has only one sleeve finished -- but rather with the cluttered presentation of her mutual fund statements.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Dec. 27 with the Streetscapes column, about town houses on a block on East 55th Street, misstated the address shown. It was 116 East 55th, not 116 West.

title: Pride, as Fragile as Glass, Is Shattered
description: THERE are thousands of things to break in the southern New Jersey glass-making city of Millville. Go there with a toddler, as I did recently, and you can expect a day full of lessons in fragility and frustration.

title: How Henry Hyde's Resolve Was Shaped Against Clinton
description: A year ago, after the first reports of the President's affair with Monica S. Lewinsky, Representative Henry J. Hyde reacted predictably enough, tamping down what he clearly saw as a lot of loose, hotheaded talk about impeachment: ''You don't impeach him for a peccadillo,'' he said then.

title: Court v. Court
description: STRANGERS TO

title: Avoid the Crazed Fan in This House of Games
description: BACKSTAGE

title: To Russia With Gifts For a Partner on Ice
description: WHAT do you get the teen-age girl who has everything? A horse? A Miata? How about a real live Russian ice-dance partner?

title: MAKING IT WORK; An Artist at Work on Two Kinds of Canvas
description: TO his students, Tim O'Brien is the guy with the lantern jaw who will go to the gym nightly, if he can, and teach boxing moves without charge. To the publishing world, he's the man who knows President Clinton better than anybody: every stray hair, every pore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEYTON, PHYLLIS.
description: LEYTON-Phyllis. On January 8, after a long battle with emphysema. Dear nice darling Phyllis, cherished wife of Samuel for forty years. Loving mother of Nina and Greg Holm. Grandmother of Michael, Justin and Candis. Devoted cousin of Phyllis and Sydney Sacks. Treasure of my life. Funeral private. Memorial donations to New York Lung Association.

title: Moving Gingerly Toward Civilian Rule, Nigerians Cast Ballots
description: Casting ballots on sidewalks, under trees, at construction sites, next to a man selling yams, in garages and countless other neighborhood spots, Nigerians today elected governors and state legislators in voting that is the second step in the military government's plan to restore civilian rule by May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERTIE, GEORGE A.
description: BERTIE-George A. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of George A. Bertie, associated with The Times from 1937, until retiring in 1982.

title: What's in a Name? Magic, Mystery, Allure
description: IMAGINE a map without writing, a world where mere naked coordinates take the place of places. Then try to flesh out your next itinerary, or conjure visions of somewhere unlike all that you already know. I can't speak for anyone else, but it's the lore -- and love -- of names that first jump-started my wanderlust and drives it still. Even when it gets down to neighborhoods to stroll through and avenues to cruise, certain exotic sounds, a special combination of incantatory syllables, are what connects travel as an act accomplished with one's two feet to the travel that begins and ends in the mind.

title: Dreaming the Impossible Dream
description: In 1999, things will be different: You will carry out your New Year's resolution to advance your career or resolve a workplace conflict. Well, maybe. But what about past years? How close did you come to meeting a work-related goal that you set for yourself in January? Or, how did your efforts go awry?

title: Giving Hot Air a Push Toward Cold Corners
description: SOME homeowners get perturbed when they find that even though they have a new furnace with a state-of-the-art heating system, there is always one room in the house that is cold. Turning up the thermostat will warm the room, but it may also make the rest of the house too hot and create higher heating bills.

title: A Goalie Is in the Islanders' Future
description: Far from Long Island, where for the fifth straight season the Islanders are nowhere close to making the playoffs, there is help in Canada for the struggling franchise.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Lincoln Park in Yonkers; A Convenient Slice of Middle America
description: KEVIN GORMAN and his wife, Marie, have just passed the kind of landmark that most people can only dream about: They have lived in their Lincoln Park home long enough to have just made their last mortgage payment.

title: Show Me the Money!
description: THE NEW DOLLARSAND DREAMSAmerican Incomes andEconomic Change.By Frank Levy.Illustrated. 248 pp. New York:Russell Sage Foundation.Cloth, $39.95. Paper, $16.95.

title: Beth Sklar and Jedediah Baker
description: Beth Linda Sklar, a social worker, and Jedediah E. Baker, a clinical psychologist, were married last evening by Rabbi Peter J. Rubenstein at the Penn Club in New York.

title: Personal Business; Some Credit For Those Who Must Give Care
description: CAROL LEVINE has been caring for her husband, Howard, at home since 1990, when their car skidded on an icy highway in upstate New York and crashed into a guardrail, leaving him with a traumatic brain injury.

title: Lethal Chemistry at Harvard
description: Stephen S. Hall's account (Nov. 29) of two graduate-student suicides in a single Harvard lab mentioned the pressures of long hours -- pressures that are so intense that graduate students have often engaged in elaborate deceit to expand the apparent number of hours they worked.

title: Dream Weaver
description: THE DREAM MISTRESS

title: POSTINGS: Developer's Town House on East 61st Street Is Sold; Durst City Memorabilia Gets a New Home
description: The Durst family has sold the town house at 120 East 61st Street where the late Seymour Durst, an owner, developer and assembler of Manhattan real estate, gathered a celebrated collection of New York City memorabilia.

title: Gift of a Piano Is a Grace Note for a School's New Auditorium
description: FIRST, a brand new high school-middle school auditorium gave people in this arts-minded school district something to be proud of.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDEMAN, DR. THOMAS
description: SEIDEMAN-Dr. Thomas. At age 87, on January 9, 1999 after a long and valiant battle. Beloved husband of Francine. Devoted father of Gail Fieldston (Dr. Kenneth) and Dr. Bruce A. Seideman (Abby). Loving grandfather of Evan, Ross, Todd, Brett, Lauren, Blair and Harrison. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Woodbury, NY.

title: N.F.L. Teams Tape Players While They Tape Up
description: Earlier this season, a Jets defensive player went into a small room at the team's practice facility in Hempstead, N.Y., and was stunned by what he saw. Inside was a bank of video screens, he said, showing various parts of the complex. On one screen, to the player's surprise, was a view of the locker room.

title: Fundamental Issues for the Jets: Who Will Run and Who Will Not?
description: Leave it to Bryan Cox, time bomb turned team spokesman, to break down the essence of today's Jets-Jacksonville Jaguars playoff game.

title: Gulfs Among Republicans Weren't Too Wide to Bridge
description: In the privacy of the Senate Republican cloakroom, a gaggle of senators was furiously working on ground rules for President Clinton's impeachment trial when the majority leader, Trent Lott, suddenly appeared on television with his Democratic counterpart, Tom Daschle.

title: Eliminating Parole Boards Isn't a Cure-All, Experts Say
description: Fifteen states so far have taken the politically popular step of abolishing parole boards, a vestige of what most Americans regard as a failed system of penal rehabilitation, and last week Gov. George E. Pataki of New York proposed to make his state the 16th.

title: Maureen Tsao, Paul Manetti
description: Maureen Tsao and Paul Manetti were married yesterday at the First Parish Church in Portland, Me. Chief Justice Daniel E. Wathen of the Maine Supreme Judicial Court performed the ceremony.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: HOTEL

title: Too Rare to Grow Anywhere but in a Catalogue
description: TOMATOES do not grow on trees. It's an immutable fact. It's also a fact that some nursery catalogues ballyhoo the ''tree tomato,'' often with a drawing of a roundish, tree-shaped plant laden with what look to be fat, red-ripe tomatoes.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday about the Mary McDowell School for Learning misidentified the people shown. Christine Irwin, a teacher at the school, was at the right, talking with Alex Granito and Amanda Copeland, former students.

title: A Canadian Rousts Diplomacy (and Ruffles the U.S.)
description: As a graduate student at Princeton University in the 1960's, Lloyd Axworthy spent many nights at the old Madison Square Garden watching greats like Dave DeBusschere, Walt Frazier and Bill Bradley outplay almost everyone in the league.

title: The Promotion That Wasn't
description: Q. I am an engineer at a manufacturing company. When a resignation opened up a manager's job, I held up my hand. A slate of candidates was evaluated, and I was told that the job was mine. At the last hour, however, the outgoing manager had a change of heart about leaving -- and the company let him stay. I got an apology and some vague promises about future opportunities. My mentor's advice is to get out as soon as I can, reasoning that these people can't be trusted. But a job change would require relocating, which I would rather avoid. I was satisfied with the company until this happened, and I'm tempted to use the situation as an excuse to ask for a raise.

title: Car Insurance Reductions Are Set for March
description: The state has set March 22 as the date when car insurance companies must give all policy holders a 15 percent rate reduction. Under a law pushed by Governor Whitman and enacted last year, insurers must institute several cost-saving procedures and pass along savings to drivers.

title: A Mountain Lake Teeming With Myths
description: THE first staggering views of Lake Titicaca come just after the ferry crossing of the Strait of Tiquina. The short trip across this relatively narrow section of Titicaca is deceptive: The lake appears to be, well, a lake. Ten minutes later I'm on a bus climbing a crest of the La Paz-Copa cabana road. Far below I see an endless expanse of Aegean-blue, island-studded water -- Lake Titicaca seems, quite suddenly, a sea.

title: Cleansing and Writing
description: FIRST, you gorge on Haagen-Dazs: one whole pint of vanilla, one of chocolate. It feeds the craving for rebellion, but it does not satisfy the need to rage.

title: Trying Out for Conductor
description: GUEST conductors continue to perform with the New Haven Symphony, as the finalists in the competition for a new music director meet Connecticut audiences (and vice versa). In the case of Raymond Harvey, it's actually more of a homecoming, since he received his Doctor of Musical Arts degree from the Yale School of Music. A former music director of the Springfield (Massachusetts) Symphony, he now is in his fifth season with the Fresno Philharmonic.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT: To Beat the Market, Hire a Philosopher; Bill Miller Rethinks Value, and Keeps Thumping the S. & P.
description: PERHAPS it is the references to the fiction of Jorge Luis Borges, the late Argentine author whose metaphysical imagery he uses to illustrate a point about price-to-earnings ratios. Or maybe it is the nods to the philosophy of William James, whose theories are called upon to justify why America Online is a value stock. Certainly some hint is in the ''thought experiments'' that he calls upon his staff to perform.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about new Long Island Rail Road trains with double-decker cars misidentified the decade in which the line retired an earlier generation of double-deckers. It was the early 1970's, not the 1950's.

title: The Revolution Will Be in Stereo
description: Driving down 23d Street, Havana's main strip, in a Volkswagen convertible with David Calzado at the wheel is a little like cruising Sunset Boulevard with Puff Daddy. Every man, woman and child waiting for the bus, pedaling a Chinese bicycle or just walking waves, smiles, screams or tries to touch the leader of Charanga Habanera, the hottest and most controversial dance band on the island. Even the lucky few with cars honk.

title: Ski Web Site Lists Resorts, Snow Reports
description: Winter-sports enthusiasts can now plan their vacations at www.skiresorts.com on the Internet. One feature of the site, begun in late October, is an online booking directory for more than 400 resorts throughout the world that allows comparison shopping and room reservations. The site also includes information about weather, snowfall, lift ticket prices and trail maps.

title: Fire Safety: Planning Is Key
description: WHAT would you do -- what specific action would you take right now -- if you just learned there was a fire in your building?

title: Another Indictment?
description: To the Editor:

title: Surfin' N.B.A.
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Our Towns; Yale Gene Pool Seen as Route To Better Baby
description: YOUNG women scanning The Yale Daily News over the last year have found their eyes straying to advertisements offering up payments of $7,500 -- not quite for them but for their eggs.

title: January 3-9; Ed, Formerly Known As Prince, to Wed
description: The last child of Queen Elizabeth, Prince Edward, 34, has decided to marry his long time girl friend, Sophie Rhys-Jones, 33, this summer, and the public well-wishing at the engagement announcement was mixed with expressions of anxiety over whether he could do better than his three siblings, all of whose youthful marriages ended in divorce.

title: A 'Wrapped' Central Park: No Way!
description: To the Editor:

title: The Military Mind-Set
description: To the Editor:

title: Finally, His Chance to Play Pierrot
description: LIKE twins separated at birth, music and theater seem to have an eternal yearning for each other. ''New Visions,'' a series of events beginning this week as part of Lincoln Center's Great Performers program, is specifically devoted to presenting staged versions of classical works not necessarily intended for theatrical presentation. Between now and the end of May, the series will pair the internationally renowned theater artists Peter Sellars, Robert Lepage and Bill T. Jones with the esteemed singers Lorraine Hunt, Rebecca Blankenship and Jessye Norman.

title: The Nation: Timetables; The Speech, the Trial and the State of the Politics
description: ON Friday, the Senate finally settled on some basic details for President Clinton's impeachment trial: when procedural motions are due (tomorrow), when the prosecution will begin its case (Thursday) and how long each side will have to present the now-familiar evidence and arguments (a numbing 24 hours).

title: Mounting a Defense of 'Centralized Religion'
description: A letter writer criticizes the next bishop of the Diocese of Rockville Centre, James T. McHugh [''Island's New Bishop: A Stalwart of the Faith,'' Dec. 20], for stating an obvious fact about the Roman Catholic Church: that it is ''a centralized religion.''

title: After a Subway Horror, Tips on Watching the Back
description: THE SETTING -- The Aikido School of Self-Defense on Northern Boulevard in Little Neck, Queens. It was Tuesday, two days after a woman was pushed off a subway platform in Manhattan and crushed by an oncoming train. The sensei, or teacher, was Robert E. Waltzer, who was using the nightmarish event to teach his class of nine men and three women defensive techniques to avoid a similar fate. Noting that the slain woman had answered the suspect's question about the time, he even showed how to do so while keeping an eye on the person.

title: Creative Competition Between Chambers Heating Up
description: It was a slip of the tongue, and not necessarily Freudian. But after the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, referred to Representative Henry J. Hyde, the Republican chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, as a senator on Thursday, a careful observer could practically see the steam rising from other senators' heads.

title: In 'Cabaret,' Evolution Repositions the Stars
description: IF you couldn't get in to see ''Cabaret'' last year when it was on West 43d Street, the chances are you'll have better luck now. The hit revival has moved to larger quarters 11 blocks north at Studio 54, the former disco that in the heedless 1980's still exemplified Manhattan chic and decadence. A fitting space, maybe, for a show that is set in Berlin, circa 1929-30, just before the Weimar Republic collapsed, and that ostentatiously flaunts gaudy style to find deadly significance in ephemera.

title: A 'Wrapped' Central Park: No Way!
description: To the Editor:

title: Cellblock Chic
description: Sorry to say, being a supermodel isn't all shimmy and sheen. Beyond the gorgeousness, the adulation, the tabloid trumpets, there are stumbles down the runway of life. Witness poor Naomi Campbell, who was arrested by the Toronto cops and charged with assaulting a onetime assistant. The Crown has yet to determine whether to prosecute the case as ''an indictable offense'' or ''a summary conviction,'' Canadian equivalents of felony and misdemeanor. Naturally, Naomi denies all, and even if convicted of anything, the likelihood of her doing hard time is remote. But the notion of a supermodel in stir led to thoughts of jailhouse frocks. Prison blues were just too declasse to imagine, vulgar, even, in the context of such physical radiance. We asked a few designers for alternatives.

title: Passion and Will, Undimmed by 80 Years of Ballet
description: IN the constellation of great Russian dancers, Marina Semyonova is, at 90, a long-shining star. While not as well known internationally as other Russian artists -- she retired before the landmark 1956 Bolshoi tour to London -- Ms. Semyonova was among the first representatives of Soviet ballet to dance in the West in the 1930's. She was also the first important protegee of the legendary teacher Agrippina Vaganova. And in the cultural turmoil of post-Revolutionary Russia, it was Ms. Semyonova whose dancing made an eloquent case for preserving classical ballet in the new order. However, the oldest, most revered bearer of Russia's ballet traditions is not about to start looking back and writing her memoirs: she's too busy.

title: Mortgage Tax Break: Who Gets What
description: The income-tax deduction for home mortgage interest is one of the most popular politically, but its economic effects are perverse: Experts call it an ''upside down'' subsidy because the more a taxpayer earns, the greater the tax cut it yields.

title: A Director Who Sees Ancients As Realists
description: DAVID LEVEAUX is drawn to plays that are ''killers,'' he says, and one could argue that this English theater director certainly knows how to slay the New York critics. Although he has worked only three times over the last 14 years on Broadway, where his production of Sophocles' ''Electra'' -- starring Zoe Wanamaker -- is currently playing at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, on each occasion he has come away with mostly raves. (''Electra'' has been extended to more than double its initial eight-week run, and is now scheduled to close on March 28.)

title: Silver Collections On View in Virginia
description: Two galleries displaying fine silver have opened in eastern Virginia within an hour's drive of each other. One is at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts in Richmond, the other in Colonial Williamsburg.

title: Devils Get Into the Game Too Late
description: In the opening minute of the third period tonight, a handful of hats flew onto the ice at Continental Arena. There was no hat trick, just a hat giveaway at the arena and a disappointing performance by the home team.

title: Fireworks in Chinatown
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rape of Nanking
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial Accord Shifts Focus Back to Starr's Evidence
description: The Senate's agreement on how to conduct the initial phase of President Clinton's impeachment trial sent House prosecutors and the President's lawyers diving this weekend back into the voluminous evidence collected by Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel.

title: W.N.B.A. Got Game
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Golf Fund Draws Criticism
description: Ross and Jeffrey Provence, the father-and-son co-managers of the Value Trend Links fund in San Diego, may be looking for an eagle, but analysts say their new equity mutual fund, which will invest in golf companies and sponsors of the sport's tournaments, may face its share of sand traps.

title: As Gas Prices Fall, East End Feels Left Out
description: IF East Enders have the impression that they are in their own little world out there, this time they may be right. While the rest of the country is enjoying gasoline prices that, adjusted for inflation, are the lowest since the 1950's, on the East End prices are among the highest in the nation.

title: A New Boathouse for Yale
description: YALE UNIVERSITY has had a long and proud tradition in the sport of rowing. Its first crew raced in the waters of Lake Winnipesaukee in New Hampshire in 1852 (against Harvard). Since then, Yale crews have won dozens of championships and sent many members to Olympic competitions.

title: A Legend Captured in Five Sets
description: THE DORIS HUMPHREY LEGACY

title: What Welfare-to-Work Really Means
description: Workfare participants are working for less than they would receive if they were being paid the Federal minimum wage. There is something inherently coercive and unfair in the idea of men and women picking up trash along the West Side Highway, in their orange vests, 35 hours a week, and being ''paid'' what amounts to slave wages for their efforts. No wonder the unions are concerned; after all, slaves are far cheaper than union employees.

title: Court Rejects Suit by Professor Challenging Harassment Case
description: A state appeals court has again rejected a Cornell psychology professor's lawsuit challenging the procedures the university used in finding him guilty of sexual harassment.

title: Frauds! Fakes! Phonies!
description: Unweaving

title: Naturalist Ahead of Her Time
description: IN the climate of the turn of the century, when a woman walked three steps behind a man, Mabel Osgood Wright (1859-1934) stood out as someone to be reckoned with.

title: Enough News To Keep 'Em Rolling
description: Jon Stewart takes over as the host of Comedy Central's ''Daily Show'' tomorrow night, but don't expect many changes in the nightly news parody. ''Except I'll be reading the news with a Yiddish accent,'' Mr. Stewart warned, and proceeded to ad-lib the day's headlines sounding uncannily like Jackie Mason. ''We're going after the audience that never got over the cancellation of 'Chicken Soup,' '' he said, referring to the Jackie Mason-Lynn Redgrave sitcom that made a brief and forgettable appearance in 1989.

title: In Iraq, Preserve Unscom's Mission; Handle With Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Architecture Is Multilingual
description: IF the walls of Buenos Aires could speak to me, I know they would speak in French, Italian, German, Hungarian and English.

title: Joining the Fray, More Funds by Blacks, of Blacks and for Blacks
description: WHEN Mellody Hobson was growing up in Chicago, a month without Ebony magazine or a week without Jet signaled a possible mail problem. ''It's just a way of life for every African-American household I've come in contact with, no matter what their socioeconomic status, to have an Ebony and Jet subscription,'' she said.

title: Parents Chafe at Teacher's Arrival
description: When the Manhattan School for Children was established in 1991 as a public alternative school to encourage parental involvement, its teachers voluntarily extended the school day by 40 minutes, to 7 hours. They also decided to meet after school for two hours at least twice a week to build lesson and curriculum plans.

title: Opera for the Ear Alone: Wagner's 'Ring,' Distilled for Pure Listening
description: THE stage of Prudential Hall was crowded on Tuesday as Zdenek Macal rehearsed a New Jersey Symphony Orchestra of 94 players, 18 more than its usual maximum. The solitary listener in the dark auditorium was Russell Johnson, chief acoustician of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. Clearly, a portentous event was afoot.

title: Next!
description: WHAT REMAINS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, EDITH
description: ABRAMS-Edith . Beloved wife of the late Alvin. Loving mother of Andrea, Penny and Bob, motherin-law of Joel, Janet and Virginia. Cherished grandmother of Adam, Stacy and Amanda, step-grandmother of Allison, Mark, Brian and Maria, step great-grandmother of Natasha. Dear sister of Hedda, Alma and Lenora, sister-in-law of Joseph and Judy. Beloved aunt of Pam, Tony, Stanley, Marna, Margie, Mark, Douglas, Miranda and Brad. Services today, 9:45 AM, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Exp, Fresh Meadows, NY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FURMAN, ABRAHAM L., DDS
description: FURMAN-Abraham L., DDS. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Beloved father of Andrea, Kim and Daniel. Brother of Beatrice Nortman and William Furman. Grandfather of Erika, Sean, Jonathan, Kelly, Rachel, Jeffrey and Brian. Deceased January 8, 1999 in Sarasota, FL. Dr. Furman practiced dentistry and resided in Crompond, NY for over 30 years. A former Major in the US Army, he was 83 years old. For information contact Hellman Memorial Chapels, 914-356-8600.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, JAY M.
description: MARCUS-Jay M. The Marcus family mourns the loss of their devoted husband, father, brother, uncle and mentor, Jay Mordechai Marcus. Son of Solomon & Bessie Marcus, his immutable drive taught and inspired, opening our horizons to culture through his descriptions of books, food, love of arts, Judaism and hard work. He was an honorable man who was respected and admired by many and leaves behind a void that will never be filled. He will be sorely missed by his loving wife of 36 years, Sylvia, five children: Lisa, David, Robert, Jonathan, Sabrina; four grandchildren: Jarred, Kendall, Justin, Elana, brothers and sisters, Morris, Reuben, Lillian and Charlotte. Services on Sunday, January 10, 11:15am at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Clinton to Field a Much-Practiced Legal Team
description: Some now-familiar faces will be presenting some now-familiar arguments on the Senate floor to defend President Clinton as he goes on trial next week.

title: 'If a Lion Could Talk'
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; You Can Look It Up, Hopefully
description: FOR years, language purists have rent their garments over the use of the word hopefully to mean ''I hope,'' as in, ''Hopefully, that will never happen again.'' Such use, they assert, arose in the rule-smashing 1960's. For many, it was and remains a sign of the decline of civilization.

title: DataBank; Stocks Catch Fire in the New Year
description: Last week the Nasdaq composite index had a pretty fair year. Other major market averages didn't do badly either.

title: Forget the Datebook. Start a Diary.
description: NOW that our New Year's resolutions are all forgotten, we can get on with planning the year ahead. In fact, I see that my year is fully planned already. The appointment book that I purchased fresh and new from Office Max just a few weeks ago is already looking worn, and has commitments and reminders scribbled on almost every page: conferences, deadlines, veterinary appointments, birthdays, travel dates and survival plans for the year 2000. There goes 1999, scheduled down to the last day before it has really begun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SETTEL, ANITA
description: SETTEL-Anita. Beloved wife of Hyman Cohen. Loving mother of Stephanie Rosken and Andrew Settel. Cherished grandmother of Scott and Todd Rosken. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Sunday, January 10 at 1 PM.

title: Yes, Those Junk-Bond Funds Are Still Cheap, but Go on Tiptoes
description: ALTHOUGH prices of junk bonds, which can give a portfolio diversity and extra income, have risen since their tumble late last summer, it still costs less to buy mutual funds that hold this high-risk, high-return corporate debt than at any time since 1990.

title: The Ad World Recognizes a Good Thing: Obscurity
description: FORGET Michael Jordan, Cindy Crawford, Bill Cosby and the other superstars and supermodels. Here comes a phalanx of the prefamous: gonnabes, wannabes and whozzats peddling products in commercials, ads and billboards as if they were instantly recognizable.

title: Five-and-Dime Counts Down
description: Elizabeth Bolton, a native of Park Slope, remembers the old days in the neighborhood. Ms. Bolton is only 20. But she remembers when the McCrory store on Ninth Street near Sixth Avenue was one of the few chain stores in the area, and she is sorry that it will be closing at the end of this month. A CVS drugstore is expected to open in its place.

title: Rachel Miller and Gregg Dick
description: Rachel Miller, a daughter of Judith and Richard J. Miller of Millwood, N.Y., and Gregg Dick, the son of Carole and Joseph Dick of Dix Hills, N.Y., were married last evening. Rabbi Chaim Stern officiated at the Pleasantdale Chateau in West Orange, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEFKINS, NETTIE
description: JEFKINS-Nettie. On December 29, 1998. Loving aunt of Kenneth and Jeffrey Hirsch; great aunt and great great aunt. Memorial service Sunday, January 17, 1999, 2:15PM, at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the charity of your choice.

title: Euro Neurosis
description: For more than 50 years washington longed for a strong Europe as a political and economic partner. With the limited introduction of the euro last week, will the gods be punishing us by granting our wish?

title: Business & Investing; Buying In to 'Communicopia,' a Rich New Data Landscape
description: ONE week it is a white-hot debut for a new business on the Internet. The next it's a telephone company breaking a taboo by buying a cable network. Last week, a spirited bidding war broke out over a major wireless phone company.

title: Events That Made 1998 Memorable Eleven parties whose organization was forward-looking, and some of the stylish guests who set a standard for fashion to bridge millenniums.
description: EVENING HOURS Correction: January 14, 1999, Thursday A picture caption with the Evening Hours column in Sunday Styles this week about memorable events of 1998 misspelled the given name of a guest at a benefit for the Museum of Modern Art. He is Laurance S. Rockefeller, not Laurence.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Backtalk; Offering the Illusion Of Reform on Drugs
description: Last February, at a news conference held on the eve of the 1998 Olympic Winter Games, the president of the International Olympic Committee, Juan Antonio Samaranch, launched a pre-emptive strike against long-festering criticism of the I.O.C.'s campaign against doping in elite sport. ''We are going to invest $50 million in the doping struggle,'' he proclaimed. ''We have won many battles, but not the war. Yet that, too, we will win. I just don't know when.''

title: Snappy Sauce, Not So Snappy Service
description: AS the singer belted out ''I Will Survive,'' I found myself wondering about Da Mino's future. Would it break the jinx that has plagued so many restaurants at this Port Washington site? Jimmy's Backyard was here for 25 years, but between 1993 and 1996 there were three seafood restaurants (Waves, Main Stream and the Restaurant) that opened and closed in rapid succession. I dined at this spot on Manhasset Bay so often during those years that I felt like I was caught in a revolving door.

title: Problem: 1 Great Cover Man, 3 Top Ends
description: It's a big secret: which of the Vikings' dangerous wide receivers will be covered by one of the best cornerbacks in football, Aeneas Williams, when the Arizona Cardinals play the Vikings at Minnesota in today's divisional playoff game?

title: Ejected Patrons Suspected In Killing Outside a Club
description: Seeking revenge on a bouncer who had just ejected them from a Bronx club, three men returned to the establishment a few minutes later on Friday night and opened fire from a moving car, missing the bouncer but killing a bystander, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEELE, MADELINE
description: STEELE-Madeline. On December 12th, 1998, at age 75, in London, England. Survived by her sons Joshua Steele, Mark Siegeltuch and Andrew Siegeltuch, daughter Abby Siegeltuch, her beloved grandchildren, Daniel Siegeltuch and Kathryn Siegeltuch, her sister Alice Erhard, and by her many friends. A memorial gathering will be held in New York City on January 23, 1999, at 2 PM, For details call 212-505-7535.

title: When the Taste Buds Cry Out for Pizza
description: THE increasing number of Indian restaurants opening in just the last year indicates a welcome trend in the county. What is particularly delightful is that each of those we now have -- old as well as new -- offers such culinary distinctiveness that diners could eat at a different place every night without experiencing deja vu.

title: Twilight Of a Soap Opera
description: I grew up on a ridge in eastern Kentucky, where we got one television channel that went fuzzy on rainy nights. By eighth grade many of us had quit watching TV out of sheer boredom. Most shows were about fake people doing fake things with a laugh track to remind us it was supposed to be funny. You didn't even have to watch TV since the darn thing laughed at itself.

title: Business Pacts at Hospital That Goes It Alone
description: IN 1893, when a group of 22 women and 3 men received a state charter to open the first White Plains Hospital in a four-bed cottage, their sole objective was to make health care available to local residents.

title: For the Fed, a Sideshow Takes Center Ring
description: THE Federal Reserve, as Alan Greenspan so often says, deals in the real economy, not sideshows. Inflation, output, profits, employment, exports, productivity -- these are all aspects of the real economy. The stock market, in the Fed's scheme of things, is a sideshow. But the sideshow has now decisively moved into the center ring, creating a terrible dilemma for the Federal Reserve and the public, too.

title: Crime Creeps Into a Suburb
description: Amid the sprawling fields, winding roads, run-down farms and 19th-century stone houses that typify much of Hunterdon County, there is an increasing intrusion more alarming than the deer or bears that wander into people's backyards: crime.

title: Funny, They Don't Look Like Fat Cats
description: THREE decades ago, Congress, embarrassed by the disclosure that 155 wealthy Americans had paid no Federal income taxes, enacted legislation aimed at preventing the very rich from shielding their wealth in tax shelters.

title: Neglected Blacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Healing the Wounds of Racism Through Expression
description: A CONNECTION between Newark and next month's PBS broadcast of ''I'll Make Me a World,'' an examination of black contributions to American culture, may have been a marriage made in heaven.

title: Museums Experiment With New Exhibition Strategies
description: IT is reported that more people in America today go to museums than to sporting events; those of us in the field make a great effort to find out who these museumgoers are, where they come from and why they're here. When we ask our audiences what they want (and we do this all the time, even if we don't always act on the answers), they say over and over again that it's to feel some connection between the art they see and their everyday lives.

title: Private Sector; High Over Manhattan, A Downbeat Farewell
description: As a holiday tribute to the late restaurateur Joseph Baum was winding down at Town Hall, the Manhattan theater, David Rockefeller invited everyone to the Rainbow Room, the nightclub at 30 Rockefeller Center that Mr. Baum had run for more than a decade. About 750 people showed up -- but it is probably just as well that Mr. Rockefeller, who still owns 5 percent of Rockefeller Center, didn't.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, SANFORD
description: BERNSTEIN-Sanford. We will miss you, not just for the turbulence, excitement and craziness you always caused, but also for your first class mind and big heart. From playing backgammon in Cannes, Anguilla, Mykonos, Jerusalem and New York, eating at Verge or Tetou, from the tallest tree in Westchester, Presidential ambitions, to blown up birthday cakes...Sandy, it was a ball. But you did not have to shout at me during our last game at New York Hospital when you lost eighty dollars! Fred Howard

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Ferrari F355-F1; A Performance Edge, And It's an Automatic
description: SELLING Ferraris to Americans is no longer just a matter of flattering the customers and wearing Armani suits really well. While the current models are knock-down gorgeous, they are also far more expensive than the Porsches, BMW's and Jaguars that can be nearly as alluring. Besides, Ferraris have a reputation for being difficult to drive and needing service every third time they circle the block.

title: Healing A Strained Bond
description: THE future of medicine will begin when every young doctor walks into a hospital room, puts a hand on a patient's shoulder and says, ''It would help me out if you told me a little about your home life.'' There have already been amazing breakthroughs.

title: Founders Gone, School Adjusts
description: Jennifer Miley greeted the young, freshly scrubbed faces arriving at the Kiddie Academy last week with a phrase that Henry Brown, one of the preschool's founders, recited each New Year.

title: Monica on the Stand?
description: For all its ''once in a lifetime'' aspects, the impeachment trial of President Clinton has much in common with most other criminal trials. From exculpatory evidence suppressed by a zealous prosecutor to the intimidation of defense witnesses, we are seeing it all. And just as the inclusion of witness testimony would make this proceeding more like a ''real'' trial, it would also mean that Mr. Clinton's defense -- as well as Monica Lewinsky's legal team -- would face some familiar pitfalls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLECHER, SHEILA
description: BLECHER-Sheila. Loving wife, mother and grandmother. Longtime resident of White Plains, New York, and Boca Raton, Fla. Passed away on January 7, 1999, after a brief illness with ovarian cancer. Sheila was a retired reading specialist with the Pelham School District and devoted many years to charitable organizations. Surviving are her bereaved husband Ivy, her children, Donna Lichti and husband Charles, of White Plains, NY, Karen Moseman of Henderson, NV. and Lynn Weinig and husband William of Pleasantville, NY, and seven grandchildren. Memorial services will be held at the Congregation Kol Ami (Jewish Community Center) 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, N.Y., on Sunday January 10th at 12 noon. The family plans to announce its commitment to the battle against ovarian cancer and will be accepting donations through ''The Sheila Fund '', P.O. Box 325, North White Plains, New York 10603-0325.

title: Hamptons Hubbub: The Birds Have Flown
description: FORGET Basinger and Baldwin, Spielberg and Capshaw. For years, a pair of mute swans were East Hampton's most famous couple, living blissfully on Town Pond in the heart of the village and becoming symbols of East Hampton's self-image of elegance and tranquillity.

title: Red Storm Regains Confidence and Its Touch
description: Perhaps it was the abysmal shooting from the field. Maybe it was the sense that the St. John's players had simply forgotten where the rim was when standing at the foul line. Or was it the Red Storm's somnolence in its loss to Miami last week that stirred Coach Mike Jarvis before last night's game against Seton Hall?

title: January 3-9; U.S. Admits Using Spies In Arms Inspection Team
description: United States officials acknowledged that American intelligence officers worked undercover on teams of United Nations Special Commission inspectors ferreting out secret Iraqi weapons programs.

title: Last Holdout Joins Airline Smoking Ban
description: All flights, both domestic and international, on United States airlines are now completely smoke-free, according to the Department of Transportation. In 1989, Congress banned smoking on all domestic flights. Since then more and more airlines have been instituting no-smoking policies on their international flights. Last month the last holdout, Tower Air, eliminated smoking on all its international flights.

title: If Proust Had Lived In Coney Island . . .
description: Intending to capitalize on reminiscences of a simpler time, the owners of Custard Beach, which opened Friday, are serving up frozen custard, a legendary dessert that is said to have been created early in this century in Coney Island. The inventor, trying to make his ice cream less drippy, added egg yolks.

title: Liberties; Avid Ovid Readers
description: Now that impeachment has moved to the Senate, the greatest deliberative body since Roman times, Peter and Dan and Tom and Tim and Cokie and Greta keep telling me I should be awestruck by the solemnity and majesty of the occasion.

title: British Researchers on Animal Rights Death List
description: Colin Blakemore, Wayneflete Professor of Physiology at Oxford and director of the university's Center for Cognitive Neuroscience, spends his days like any academic, in an office with brimming in-trays and bookshelves stacked high with research volumes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOKRZYCKI, WALTER B.
description: MOKRZYCKI-Walter B. On January 8, 1999. Loving husband of the late Frances (nee Koscielny). Beloved father of Michael. Grandfather of Brady Leo and brother of Anthony.
