Dear father-in-law of Virgilia Gambon and friend of the Gambon family. Cherished by nieces and nephews. Retired NYPD, World War II veteran, USMC. In lieu of flowers donations to Angel Guardian Children and Family Services. For information, Megiel Funeral Home, Maspeth.

title: St. John The Unfinished; Dean of Cathedral on Morningside Heights Vows to Fix What He's Got, Not Build More
description: THE Cathedral of St. John the Divine, more than a century in the making, may never be really finished. Construction of the world's largest cathedral has always been on-again, off-again. Now it's off again, for the forseeable future, as guardians of the Episcopal cathedral turn to preserving what has been built instead of pushing further skyward. While the unbuilt towers, spires and transepts designed years ago wait, church leaders face a new challenge: how to raise millions of dollars to maintain the beloved stone church at Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street on Morningside Heights.

title: TEQUILA SUNSET
description: Drinking didn't used to be a convenience sport; it took a little exercise. A shot and a chaser demanded a couple of arm pulls. But now Anheuser-Busch is plopping something called Tequiza on the bar, combining the tequila and the beer (and a hint of lime) in a single 12-ounce bottle. Not that Tequiza will knock you off the stool faster -- it's just 5 percent alcohol, the same as a Bud, and just 10 proof. The tequila in the beer is real, however, a dollop added in the last step of brewing. (Anheuser says just how much is ''proprietary.'') And following NASA into orbit (see previous page), there's no worm for your $6, either, though bars will throw in packets of Tequiza Twang, a lemon-lime salt. At the moment, Tequiza is available in Texas, Florida, New Mexico, parts of California and New York City, and should be guzzlable nationwide by the end of the year. What next -- bourbon-flavored Coke, whisky-sour Popsicles, boilermaker Jell-O?

title: Janet Prindle, Charles Seidler Jr.
description: Janet W. Prindle is to be married this afternoon at her home in New York to Charles John Seidler Jr. The Rev. Dr. Maurice Boyd, a nondenominational minister, will officiate.

title: Collared: Subway Elevator Loses its Pet Pantheon
description: Four hundred times a day, Anthony T. Washington, an exuberant elevator operator with a showman's heart, ferries subway riders at the 190th Street Station of the A train. His enthusiasm has long been clear from the posters and snapshots of animals that lined his elevator's walls, transforming a sterile box into a moving artwork.

title: Dear Diary
description: Heart of a Wife

title: Contemplative Time, Catalogues in Hand
description: THE catalogues are arriving from seed houses and nurseries. Now, while there is plenty of reading and planning time, the new garden can be set out -- on paper at least.

title: What Welfare-to-Work Really Means
description: If Mayor Giuliani's goal is that people on welfare find jobs, then the logic of making it very difficult for them to pursue their studies at CUNY escapes me. A college degree is the best avenue leading to a successful career.

title: Editorial Observer; A Yearning Bigger Than Billy Graham Can Fill
description: Aunt Carolyn was my godmother, and one November night she phoned to ask if I would go with her to hear the Rev. Billy Graham in crusade on a day three months away. I couldn't say no. I was 16. My calendar was clear for 1961. And Aunt Carolyn's determination was well known.

title: Giving the State's Literary Lights a Place to Shine
description: Many New Jersey residents would be hard pressed to name a famous author from their state. Dr. Herman Estrin's mission is to change that. In 1976, Dr. Estrin founded the New Jersey Literary Hall of Fame, and since then, the hall has inducted 144 writers.

title: Another Left Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Modern Views, From Springs and Elsewhere
description: IT might at first seem strange to compare the neglected landscape painter Alexander Theobald Van Laer (1857-1920) with Theodore Roosevelt, but they match up in certain, telling ways.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EICHEL, TERRI
description: EICHEL-Terri. Our deepest sympathy to our dear friends Dawn, Bob and Ashley Kenzer on the death of their beloved mother, mother-in-law and grandmother. Joyce and Eric Segal EICHEL-Terri. All of us at Kenzer Corp extend deepest sympathy to the Eichel and Kenzer families on the loss of their beloved mother, esteemed mother-in-law and most treasured grandmother.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Dec. 27 with an article about living in Washington Heights referred incorrectly to the view on West 181st Street. It was to the west from Broadway, not to the east.

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; Don't Be Shocked, But Money Isn't Everything
description: I'VE never wanted to make a lot of money. Though I knew that early on, I've seldom stated it so boldly.

title: The View From/Branchville; From a Bartered Farm, An Impressionist Haven
description: THE painter J. Alden Weir -- who would become known as a pioneer of American Impressionism -- got an offer in 1882 that would change the course of his life, and that of American art as well.

title: Falcons Gain Title Game Behind Anderson's Running
description: A spin, a twist, changed the entire complexion of the playoff clash between San Francisco and Atlanta in the Georgia Dome today. It was a 7-yard run and a spinning move by running back Garrison Hearst on the game's first play from scrimmage that made the 49ers play the rest of the game looking backward. Hearst broke the fibula in his left leg on the play.

title: 20 Years On, Anger Ignites Against Khmer Rouge
description: ''I'm just a small person,'' said Un Samath, a customs inspector, using a common phrase among Cambodians, ''so I dare not say.''

title: A Nontraditionalist Who Altered Japanese Tradition
description: WHILE most of the centuries-old Buddhist temples and gardens in Kyoto, Japan, were designed for quiet contemplation, one, called Koetsu-ji, was a bustling center of creative activity. Its rustic teahouses and earthen huts nestled along woodland paths on the outskirts of the city formed a village where artists and craftsmen in the 17th century lived under the leadership of Hon'ami Koetsu. In a culture where tradition ruled more often than not, Koetsu infused the arts of calligraphy, ceramics and lacquer ware with a freedom and originality of technique and design that still appears fresh and spontaneous today.

title: Back to Ifrik
description: MARA AND DANN

title: Cry Cry Cry
description: Three of the most distinctive voices in modern folk music belong to Dar Williams, 31, Richard Shindell, 39, and Lucy Kaplansky, 38. All are performing songwriters with successful solo careers. Last fall, the trio, calling themselves Cry Cry Cry, produced an album of cover songs by lesser-known artists and began touring. (They perform at Town Hall in New York next Sunday night.)

title: ART REVIEWS/Phyllis Braff; Modern Views, From Springs and Elsewhere
description: 'An Intimate View From the Pollock-Krasner House'

title: Miss Pickering, Mr. Bullard
description: Whitney Winslow Pickering, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick B. Pickering Jr. of Rye, N.Y., was married last evening to Hamilton Wallace Bullard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger C. Bullard of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Edward Johnston performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church in Rye.

title: The Nation: Fixing Medicare; Light at a Tunnel's End
description: A TENSE exchange last week between two liberal members of the National Bipartisan Commission on the Future of Medicare moved the group toward a dramatic agreement. The members agreed to develop a plan to radically revamp Medicare by giving its beneficiaries a fixed sum of money to buy private or public insurance. In short, the use of vouchers -- something liberals have shunned in education -- might be good for Medicare.

title: Promise Kept: Broncos of Old Dominate Dolphins
description: Shannon Sharpe's lip runneth over today in the aftermath of the Denver Broncos' steamrolling of the Miami Dolphins.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: OUT OF THE DARKBy Patrick Modiano.Translated by Jordan Stump.University of Nebraska Press,cloth, $40; paper, $12.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEHLMAN, RAE
description: MEHLMAN-Rae. Lido Beach Synagogue mourns the passing of Rae Mehlman, beloved and devoted mother of our esteemed Rabbi, Harav Daniel H. Mehlman. May God console the family in their hour of bereavement. Shiva will be at 223 Beech 140 Street, Belle Harbor until Wednesday morning, January 13th. Alex Berkovitch, President

title: January 3-9; Hello. Anyone Alive Here?
description: The hunt for extraterrestrial life picked up speed as the National Aeronautics and Space Administration launched the second of two new spacecraft toward Mars.

title: Bookend; God Help the Spiritual Writer

title: SOAPBOX; She's Leaving Home
description: YEARS ago, I worked with a man who came to be called Boomerang Bob. A fast-track employee and a lifelong New Jersey resident, Bob sent shock waves through the department when he announced that he was moving to Florida. We held a luncheon for Bob. Speeches were made; tears were shed. A co-worker and I had selected a farewell gift that we thought reflected Bob's free spirit: a clock tethered to its base with a spring cord.

title: Capitol Couples
description: Think of ''Profiles in Courage'' or ''Mr. Smith Goes to Washington,'' and you have a popular image of the Senate: a place where principled individualism and collective deliberation reign. The daily reality usually falls short of the idealized images. But Friday's accord on the rules for the impeachment trial of President Clinton did offer a stirring picture of divergent ideologies blending together for the greater good. The odd-couple cliche got a heavy workout in news stories about the sudden flowering of bipartisan comity.

title: To Get From Here to There, More Long Islanders Choosing a Limo
description: WHEN Herbert Gross of East Northport needed to get to Islip MacArthur Airport the other day for a flight to his vacation home in Tamarac, Fla., he called Charlie. Charlie is Charles Lo Bianco Jr. of Class Limousine Inc., of Bellmore, who chauffeurs Mr. Gross, his family and his dog to and from the airport several times a year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOLMES, JAMES
description: HOLMES-James. Organist, choir director and composer, died on January 7. Memorial Service Wedneday, January 13 at 6:30PM, Church of St. Matthew and St. Timothy, 26 W. 84 St., New York City.

title: An Un-SoHo Store In an Old-World Milieu
description: Though it has an Old World feel, Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, has also emerged as a place for bistros, cafes and fashionable stores where designers, fleeing Manhattan's stratospheric rents, display their creations. It is in this environment that Stacy Johnson opened Stacia New York, one month ago, at 267 Smith Street (at DeGraw Street). A Parsons School of Design graduate, Ms. Johnson has trained in various aspects of the fashion industry, working at Calvin Klein, J. Crew and Cynthia Rowley. She designs and sells women's apparel and accessories she makes in the store, which doubles as her studio. She has lived in the neighborhood for two years and has chosen Smith Street because of its charm and because she likes ''the pressure of not being in SoHo.'' A layered chiffon dress in mauve, gray or light blue is $190; a merino wool top in navy, gray or oatmeal is $75 to $78; her signature sling bag is $50.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: In America; The Real Disgrace
description: So there were the two of them, the one with the sparse and unruly tufts of orange hair and the other with the silly yellow stripes on the sleeves of his black robes, presuming to speak for the nation about justice and the rule of law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, SOLOMON, JUDITH.
description: GORDON - SOLOMON - Judith. Died January 6, 1999, at the age of 79 in Sarasota, Florida. During her long career as an early childhood educator, Judith Gordon-Solomon touched the lives of hundreds of families and teachers. As nursery school director of The Walden School, and in the communities of East Harlem, the Lower East Side, and Roslyn, L.I., she strove to give young children nurturing opportunities to grow, develop, and value their world. The Solomon and Gordon families honor her for caring and making a difference.

title: Where the Venues Are Virtually Infinite
description: THERE are plenty of unlikely places to see art in the physical world, but for sheer range and pure oddity, terra firma has nothing on cyberspace.

title: Con Ed Workers Protest Union's Takeover of Local and Leader's Ouster
description: Thousands of Con Ed workers are angry at their Washington-based parent union for taking direct control of their 10,000-member local in July and ousting their popular leader, who plans to renew calls to a Federal judge this week to end the trusteeship.

title: Joining the Aquarium: A Children's Garden
description: The Camden waterfront, now home to exotic fish, will also feature Alice in Wonderland, Jack and the Beanstalk and the Three Little Pigs starting this summer. They will be part of the Children's Garden, to be built next to the New Jersey State Aquarium. Groundbreaking for the new attraction, which is being developed by the Camden City Garden Club, took place last week.

description: JOHN M. SMITH, the third generation of his family to run the Cranston Company in downtown Norwich, decided 16 years ago to move his art gallery and framing business out of the downtown and into a strip mall in the Norwichtown section.

title: Joanna Fein, Herrick Siegel
description: Joanna Leigh Fein, the daughter of Susanne and Ronald Fein of Sands Point, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Herrick Jove Siegel, the son of Marsha Siegel and Dr. Michael E. Siegel of Los Angeles. Rabbi Martin Rozenberg officiated at the Plaza in New York.

title: Morristown Mayor Proposes Domestic Partners Coverage
description: Mayor Jay DeLaney of Morristownwould like his town to be the first in the state to offer health benefits to the domestic partners of municipal employees, gay or straight, married or unmarried.

description: Once a station for fireboats, the house that sits out over the East River on a short pier near 90th Street is now itself in need of rescue.

title: Introduction
description: Readers praised Jason DeParle's evenhanded analysis of welfare reform. But overwhelmingly their hearts went out to the poor. Several letter writers suggested they would like to have heard more about people's lives and less about Mayor Giuliani's programs.

title: Crime in the State Falls To a 33-Year Low
description: Crime fell by 10 percent in the first half of 1998, to the lowest levels since the State Police began compiling figures in 1966. The reductions outpaced the 5 percent drop in crime nationally and the 8 percent drop in the Northeast over the same period, figures that the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported in December.

title: Embezzlement Charges

title: A Teamsters Leader Known for Honesty May Be Expelled Over Finance Reports
description: Thomas R. O'Donnell, a newly elected vice president-at-large of the teamsters, is in the infelicitous position of obtaining the second largest vote total in last month's union election -- only the new president, James P. Hoffa, received more -- yet facing possible expulsion from the union.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 27 about millennium activities in Greenwich, England, referred incorrectly in one instance to the Cutty Sark, which is moored there. She is a clipper ship, not a schooner.

description: Brenda May Earl and Michael P. De Paola were married yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Randolph Weber performed the ceremony.

title: Private Sector; This Is No Pie-in-the-Sky Concept
description: If he doesn't watch out, Bill Gates could get a second serving. All that Gerrit Zalm, the Dutch Finance Minister, could think to say after getting hit in the face with two custard pies on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange on Monday was: ''This is incomprehensible.'' One of the two attackers, who were protesting the introduction of the euro, Europe's new currency, was grabbed by George Moller, the exchange's president.

title: January 3-9; A British Scandal Claims Another Victim
description: A third official has fallen from the British Government of Prime Minister Tony Blair, which came into office 20 months ago pledging an end to the kind of behavior that led 12 ministers in the previous Conservative Government of John Major to depart in disgrace.

title: Q&A/Nancy Wyman; One Woman's Passion for the Budget
description: WHEN State Comptroller Nancy Wyman was asked what book she had read most recently, she answered, ''The state budget,'' what she describes as an ''exciting and interesting'' operation.

description: ONE problem with auto makers' headlong rush to cross-breed sedans, wagons, trucks, vans and four-by-fours is coming up with ways to categorize the new, hybrid forms they are creating.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Wolf Solent

title: Airport Fumes
description: Five people became sick on Dec. 28 at the county airport in Valhalla when an overloaded baggage cart struck a valve on a wall and caused a 200-gallon spill of a corrosion inhibitor used in air-conditioning and ventilation systems.

title: Evoking in Song a Mellow City's Hard Edges
description: IT'S not one of the postcard views you will find in the tourist stores along Hollywood Boulevard, but as an emblem of Los Angeles, the ranks of high-tension towers plunging down the foothills, angling across avenues and puncturing canopies of residential foliage are almost as characteristic as the city's ubiquitous skyduster palms. In fact, to an Easterner like me, tower and tree both speak to much that is mysteriously other about this city.

title: CN8, New Jersey's Test Tube; A Statewide Television Network, Part of Comcast's Grand Design, Is Getting Some Static
description: A CABLE network for New Jersey. To many residents and political candidates who have long sought statewide television and radio stations, it sounds too good to be true. But CN8, the brainchild of the cable giant Comcast Corporation of Philadelphia, says the state is worth such attention.

title: It's a Guy Thing Now at the Spa
description: JEFF TUCKER of Waterbury used to have a fairly typical man's perspective on the concept of going to spa for a facial treatment. ''It was a feminine place to go, and that's it,'' he said.

title: Personal Business; Collectors Are Going Hollywood
description: WALK inside Perry Kinney's den and you almost expect to be greeted by a tour guide from Universal Studios. In the room is the air-powered skateboard that Michael J. Fox rode in ''Back to the Future II,'' and the plexiglass skin-scraping chamber used to get D.N.A. samples in ''Gattaca,'' a 1997 thriller.

title: With Berard for Potvin, Islanders Go on Defensive
description: In order to implement their new philosophy -- defensive practicality over offensive flair -- the Islanders had to make some changes. They started yesterday, acquiring the discontented goalie Felix Potvin from the Toronto Maple Leafs for the offensive defenseman Bryan Berard.

description: AS Joshua Redman would be the first to tell you, he is a picky kind of fellow.

title: Radio Pirates Drop Anchor Together
description: THE pirate radio operators, two Haitian guys from Brooklyn, looked nervous. The operators -- Michel Limontas of Radio Intercontinental (88.9 FM) in Midwood and Frantz Gourgue of Radio NaGo (89.3 FM) in Flatbush -- had been operating unlicensed, low-power stations for two years. In November, agents of the Federal Communications Commission told them to shut down.

title: Politically Weak at Home, Turks Flex Muscles Abroad
description: Turkey may soon have a functioning Government after six weeks without one, but its new-found assertiveness in foreign policy is likely to continue no matter who emerges as the next Prime Minister.

title: After a Roller-Coaster Year, Optimism
description: REAL estate executives used words like ''frothy'' and ''giddy'' and ''frenzy'' to describe the investment market in the New York area during the first half of last year. Fueled by a seemingly unlimited amount of capital from Wall Street, real estate investment trusts and private operators bid against each other for available properties, driving up prices.

title: FILM; Snared in Politics
description: THE pathos is so palpable as to seem forced -- a German singing ensemble called the Comedian Harmonists performing in the midst of pervasive disharmony in 1927 Berlin. But the German filmmaker Joseph Vilsmaier has exploited this tension for all it is worth in ''The Harmonists,'' a film that was a striking hit at home for all sorts of reasons, sound and dubious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETRUCCIANI, MICHEL
description: PETRUCCIANI - Michel. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sorrow the untimely passing of our beloved friend and devoted Steinway Artist, Michel Petrucciani, on January 6, 1999 in New York City at the age of 36. Mr. Petrucciani was a dazzling pianist with a generous and an indefatigable spirit, and his artistry captivated and inspired audiences throughout the world. His significant discography will keep his legacy alive in the hearts of music lovers everywhere. To Isabelle, Alexandre and to his entire family, we extend our deepest sympathy. His loss is keenly felt. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, Vice President, Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: Allies Are Cool To French Plan To Monitor Iraq
description: France and Britain conferred this week on the next steps to take in Iraq, but French officials said on Friday that wide differences still separated them.

title: Sports of The Times; Will Jets' Wizards Trap Jaguars?
description: THEIR reputation precedes them, even when they are about to propose the Jets' defensive game plan for Bill Parcells's approval.

title: The View From/Mount Kisco; When a Safe Haven Shuts Its Doors
description: THE handwritten sign read, ''We are losing our furniture,'' but the people who use the Mount Kisco Drop-In Center were losing much more. A dozen or so people who are or have been mentally ill were facing not only the loss of the tiny building on Lexington Avenue here that had been their gathering spot but also the loss of the kind of camaraderie that is born of empathy. Their ages, backgrounds and diagnoses vary, but each has been through a devastation of the psyche that only a fellow sufferer can fully understand.

title: Makeover Spot Shows Age
description: It has been years since Arnold Schwarzenegger was spotted pumping iron amid rows of Nautilus machines. Cher, Diana Ross, Liza Minnelli and Wilt Chamberlain, once regulars at the Vertical Club, no longer huff and puff beneath red neon lights and a salmon-plum-turquoise color scheme that screams 1985. The tennis area's Astroturf is worn and stained, the elevators are shaky, and the plastic ficus trees could use a little dusting. To be sure, the club in the shadow of the Queensboro Bridge -- once the place to strut in skintight Lurex -- has seen better days.

title: Heidi Schierloh, Peter Gaillard
description: Heidi Jeanne Schierloh was married yesterday to Peter Wallace Gaillard at the Lord of God of Sabaoth Lutheran Church in Christiansted, on St. Croix in the Virgin Islands. The Rev. Lester A. White performed the ceremony.

title: Library Gift
description: Manhattanville College recently received the largest contribution in its 158-year history: $1 million from an alumna, Nancy Roberts King, to establish a library enrichment fund.

title: Off the Urban Rust Heap, a Factory Goes to Work
description: THE dark brick factory complex on the Brooklyn waterfront would not look out of place in a moody industrial landscape by Edward Hopper. A few years ago, most of the windows were broken, roofs were collapsing, interiors were contaminated with asbestos and the basement was cluttered with leaking drums of toxic substances. The city, which owned the site in the Greenpoint neighborhood, was on the verge of demolishing this cluster of buildings.

title: No Headline
description: In a near idyllic setting at that dramatic point where the wet, piney coastal plain meets the undulating arms of the Texas Hill Country, Austin is one of those cities, like Seattle or Santa Fe, that gets so much praise you wish you could hate it.

title: Cemetery For the Elite Of Argentina
description: IN Buenos Aires the elegant neighborhood of Recoleta is the fashionable place to stay, to while away hours in cafes and museums, to walk the poodles in the park. And when it's all over, it's the place to end up. Across the grassy way from the outdoor cafes, a great white portal marks the most exclusive address of all: Cementerio de la Recoleta, Recoleta Cemetery, burial place of Argentina's elite. Here patricians and presidents, heroes and heroines, rest in astonishing grandeur.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKLIN, EDWARD ROBBINS (TED)
description: BUCKLIN-Edward Robbins (Ted). Passed away in Millbrook, NY on January 6th, 1999. He was born in Los Angeles on January 28th, 1921, and lived his first thirty-two years in Pasadena, Calif. He attended The Thacher School in Ojai, and graduated from Yale University in 1942. He served as an Officer in the Army Air Corps during World War II and was Co-Pilot of a B-29 at the time the war ended. For several years, he worked at the Title Insurance and Trust Co in Los Angeles and at 20th Century Fox. In 1953, he moved to NYC to work for The New York Trust Co. and its successor, Chemical Bank, from which he retired in the mid 1980's. He had lived on his ''farm'' in Millbrook, New York, since his retirement. For many years he was Secretary of the Boys Club of New York. Ted was well known by his many friends as an avid photographer who loved to share his photos. He traveled extensively in Africa and brought back many wonderful stories to go along with his collection of both films and photographs. Ted is survived by two sons, Edward R. (Rob) Bucklin, Jr. (Tina) and Timothy Schauffler Bucklin (Julia), both of whom live in Millbrook. He is also survived by his former wife and good friend, Julie Schauffler Bucklin of Sharon, Conn. He was the loving brother of John J. Bucklin of Pasadena and William N. Bucklin, III of San Francisco. Ted leaves two grandchildren, Taylor Bucklin and Sophia Bucklin, and fourteen nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held on January 22, 1999, 11AM at his home on Canoe Hill Road, Millbrook, New York. Donations in lieu of flowers, may be made to The Boys Club of New York, 287 East 10 Street, New York, N.Y. 10009, or the Ohana Scholarship Fund at Camp Lanakila, Fairlee, Vermont 05045. BUCKLIN - Edward R. The Trustees, Women's Board and Staff of The Boys' Club of New York express their deepest sympathy to the family of their dear friend, Ted Bucklin. He served as Trustee of the Club for 28 years and he will be remembered by us all with deep affection.

title: When It Comes to Cable Television, Comcast Isn't Seen as the Only Villain
description: COMCAST Corporation of Philadelphia isn't the only cable television operator to encounter the wrath of New Jersey municipalities.

title: In a Higher State of Being (That Is, Dying)
description: AT the other end of this decade I wrote a childhood memoir (''Unstrung Heroes'') that recounted my mother's six-year struggle with breast cancer. From my ninth birthday, in Year Two, almost every step she took was a step going down. ''Her hospital stays were becoming longer and longer,'' I recalled. ''I measured them by the nights that she was away. And I didn't like it now when she was home. She had become unpredictable. She wasn't dying like some movie heroine. She could be sullen and bad-tempered. I resented her.''

title: Rangers Test Smith's Job Security
description: It was just a coincidence, getting sick to my stomach while covering the hurting Rangers this past week. In Washington in time for Thursday's game, but unable to travel the last mile from hotel bed to press box, I listened, instead, to the Capitals' radio announcer screaming: ''Richter is down and out! The Capitals score!'' He said so on every goal. Lapsing in and out of sleep, redreaming the play-by-play between headaches, it seemed as if the score were 15-1 instead of the 5-1 result shown in the morning newspapers.

Taped to the bathroom door behind her is a pencil sketch for the abstract oil painting in progress on the ironing board. Books are strewn across the twin-sized bed. title: What Welfare-to-Work Really Means
description: There are only two reasons to reform welfare: saving money for Government or decreasing poverty. New York City keeps very good data on the first and none on the second. The Mayor's goals are clear.

description: Amor Sheh, a vendor for M & T Pretzel, stood on a piece of cardboard at Battery Park to prevent the cold from the frozen asphalt from creeping through the soles of his sneakers. ''We work in the rain, the cold and the snow,'' Mr. Sheh said, his breath painting his words in the frigid air. ''The only day off we get is Christmas.''

description: COHEN-Kate (nee Hirsch). Wife of the late Richard. Loving mother of Eva. Oma to Mai Margaret, Ayano Kate, and Diana Miki; sister of Ted, Paducah, KY. Services today 10 AM, Garlick Funeral Home, 1439 Unionport Rd., Bronx.

title: What Welfare-to-Work Really Means
description: Thanks to Jason DeParle for his thoughtful and revealing article (Dec. 20). He captured the contradictions of nationwide welfare- reform efforts. It is unfortunate that welfare policy continues to be gripped by the same conflicting impulses to protect and to punish the needy that have characterized American public-assistance policy for more than 200 years. The coexistence of social-services workers and fraud investigators within agencies whose stated purpose is to serve the needy epitomizes this tension. The overworked and undertrained workers on the front lines of welfare reform across the nation deserve some clarification as to whether their duty is to alleviate poverty (an economic condition, let us not forget) or to cut welfare caseloads. Without such clarification, they are being set up for failure by the powers that be.

title: Strength to Face A Cold Night
description: Charles Scicolone, maestro of the Enoteca at the restaurant I Trulli (122 East 27th Street, near Lexington Avenue), has discovered a $19 Apulian red that, served with the tender, generous veal and lamb chops, stokes the courage needed to face a frigid night. (It's $4.75 by the glass in the wine bar.)

title: Leon M. Goldstein Dies at 66; Led a City University College
description: Leon M. Goldstein, the gentle, genial, politically savvy president of Kingsborough Community College of the City University of New York and a leading candidate for New York City schools chancellor in 1995, died in his sleep Friday night at his home in Manhattan, a CUNY spokesman said. He was 66.

title: Up and Down Whites
description: Although the Lenz Winery, in Peconic, is selling its 1996 Vineyard Selection chardonnay, its out-of-stock '94 edition may still be binned in restaurants and homes. Four years has been good to the '94, tasted last weekend.

description: A NEW version of the Mozart Requiem will be presented by the Choral Arts Society next Sunday at 3 P.M. at Irvington Town Hall Theater under the baton of Timothy Vernon, music director of the society.

David DiCenso, an executive manager of the Italian spot along with Paolo Salvador, described the menu as ''northern Italian but with a little southern Italian thrown in.''

title: Dear Dr. Petshrink: Help! My Cat Is Driving Me Crazy.
description: PSYCHOTHERAPY or pills? For years, mental health professionals have differed over how best to treat people with disorders listed in the current edition of the American Psychiatric Association's Diagnostic and Statistical Manual.

title: Streetscapes / Grand Prospect Hall in Brooklyn; Colorful Restoration of a 1903 Ballroom/Concert Hall
description: IF you marveled at the restoration of Grand Central Terminal and the Main Reading Room of the New York Public Library, you should check out Brooklyn's Grand Prospect Hall, one of New York's most unusual buildings. A husband and wife team has spent 18 years colorfully restoring the 1903 structure, a public concert hall and ballroom at 23 Prospect Avenue on the edge of Park Slope.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOCH, CAMILLA C.
description: KOCH-Camilla C. After a brief illness, died on Sunday, January 3rd. At her request there has been no service. Camilla, a native New Yorker, will be fondly remembered by her many friends and associates at Columbia University where she held responsible positions for more than 40 years.

For about five minutes on the morning of Nov. 25, however, Albert Belle was a Yankee and Williams's career with the team was over.

title: Becoming an Auteur, With Help From Mom
description: MY cousin Matthew and I have a lifetime of hairbrained projects to our credit and we blame our mothers entirely. They were always too encouraging for our own good. As kids, whether we were tie-dying every article of clothing in our closets or putting on musicals starring all our pets (a tragic love story between a parakeet and ferret, not a dry eye in the house), our mothers, Theo and Joan, would look at each other and smile with some shared sisterly delusion, as if to say: ''Our boys are so brilliant, so clever, we should really have our uteruses bronzed and exhibited at the Smithsonian.'' And then they'd help us clean up the mess.

description: As state legislatures nationwide start new sessions, lawmakers are beginning to debate how to spend their biggest windfall in recent years: tens of billions of dollars from tobacco settlement deals.

title: Room in the Boardroom
description: Got time on your hands? Looking for a part-time job? You could always consider membership on a corporate board.

title: Style; The End Game
description: For designers who had run out of things to say, the looming millennium presented not a challenge, but a sound bite. There was a lot of post-collection rationalization, once somebody did the math and figured out that the October fashion shows were the last spring/summer offerings for the 1900's. The next spring for which women would be dictated to would be for the year 2000.

title: The Face of Eco-Terrorism
description: I chuckled at the strip-mall ''eco-terrorist'' Craig Rosebraugh (Robert Sullivan, Dec. 20). It's hard to imagine how anyone who claims to be a protector of ecosystems could advocate the release of 10,000 minks into the wild. Besides giving the minks ''a shot at life,'' such a sudden influx of nonnative predators into a wild area could easily mean the slaughter of thousands of birds and small mammals within weeks. Imagine if Rosebraugh released a flood of bird-hungry minks into a spotted-owl preserve. Now there's an act of eco-terrorism!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWORZAN, GEORGE R.
description: DWORZAN-George R. Artist, World War II Army Air Force veteran, educator, musician and beloved friend. His life was a sacred dance. His spirit now sits centered in eternal bliss-om shanti.

title: Lisa Hicks and Elliot Swan
description: Lisa Louise Hicks and Elliot Godfrey Swan were married yesterday in the chapel of St. George's School in Middletown, R.I. The Rev. John Rogers, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: In New Orleans, Madame John's Legacy
description: For more than 200 years, the house at 632 Dumaine Street in New Orleans has survived fire, floods and hurricanes to become a French Quarter landmark and rare example of the classic Creole cottages built by families that settled the city in the 18th century.

title: The Anti-Trump
description: I was touched by the entrepreneur Jerry I. Speyer's childlike qualities (the Mickey Mouse watch, the toy trucks in his office), but I was disappointed that someone with so much money and leverage hasn't built one architecturally important building, as James Traub points out toward the end of the article (Dec. 20).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMERSTEIN, JAMES B.
description: HAMMERSTEIN-James B. We at The Rodgers & Hammerstein Organization celebrate the life of Jamie Hammerstein as we mourn his passing. We enjoyed his wisdom and his irreverent and wicked sense of humor. We loved him and felt that he loved us. His tall, graceful and handsome presence will live on in our memories. We shall miss him. Our thoughts are with Dena and the rest of his family. Mary, Ted, Nicole, Bert, Vicky, Maxyne, Tom, Mike, Bruce, Cindy and the rest of the gang HAMMERSTEIN - James. City Center extends its deepest sympathies to Dena, the Hammerstein family, and to Theodore Chapin and the Rodgers and Hammerstein Organization on the death of beloved Encores! Advisory Committee member, James Hammerstein. His contributions to our project were both essential and deeply caring. He will be greatly missed by all of us. Judith E. Daykin, The Board and Staff of City Center HAMMERSTEIN-James. Founder of the Oscar Hammerstein Committee to Strengthen the U.N. and a strong supporter of the World Federalist Association established by his father, Oscar. His gracious charm, his creative drive, made working with him a privilege. Our cause of World Government and World Peace through World Law will miss him. World Federalists-New York 777 U.N. Plaza HAMMERSTEIN-James. The Oscar Hammerstein II Center for Theatre Studies mourns the passing of Jamie Hammerstein, teacher, friend and supporter of the Theatre Division, School of the Arts, Columbia University. His great talent as a director and producer inspired a generation of students. He will be missed by members of the Columbia University community.

title: CUTTINGS: THIS WEEK; Feed the Birds, Startle the Squirrels
description: Set out a feeder to bring birds close to the house and to supplement natural food sources in the winter garden (hollies, hawthorn, juniper, winterberry and American cranberry bush). Sprinkling cayenne pepper liberally on seed will deter freeloading squirrels. If you have any small pots you didn't get around to washing outside, scrape off excess dirt and run them through a dishwasher (unless you used pesticides in them).

title: Broccoli for Young Palates
description: Katherine Cocivera professed not to like mangoes. ''My mommy doesn't give me that,'' the 4-year-old huffed. ''My mommy gives me Tater Tots.''

title: POSTINGS: 'For Unseen Excellence'; Preservationists Reach Upward
description: The penthouse windows at 1016 Fifth Avenue, at 83d Street, are hard to see from the ground -- you must stand in Central Park, behind the Metropolitan Museum of Art -- but that makes them no less notable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, SYLVIA HITCH
description: MARSHALL-Sylvia Hitch. On January 7, 1999 in her 93rd year at Hilton Head Island, South Carolina. Widow of Lawrence Clark Marshall, retired Vice Chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank. She is survived by her sons, Allerton Delano Marshall of Hilton Head Island and David Lawrence Marshall of Green Valley, Ca; her daughter, Sylvia Marshall Alkema of San Diego, Ca; eight grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren.

title: An Awe-Inspiring Proliferation of Life Under the Sea
description: CREATURES sporting long, sharp teeth and trailing plume-like tentacles await visitors in the dark of the live exhibition called ''Aliens From the Sea'' at the Maritime Aquarium in Norwalk through Oct. 18. The show invites visitors to take a journey into underwater environments -- from shallow to deep -- to illuminate the behavior of the more bizarre of maritime animals.

title: Symphony Orchestras Test Their Survival Skills
description: THE Norwalk Symphony Orchestra is bracing for a tough decision. The loss of several major contributions has forced the 60-year-old symphony's directors to consider cutting back on the concert schedule and the number of musicians, merging with another orchestra -- or going out of business.

title: Private Sector; A Lot of Money Is Going to the Dogs
description: Twelve years ago, David A. Duffield, chairman of Peoplesoft, a California software maker, ''fell in love'' with a miniature Schnauzer named Maddie -- and as the result, millions of dogs and cats can breathe easier today. The memory of Maddie's impish personality inspired Mr. Duffield and his wife, Cheryl, to pledge $200 million in 1997 to the cause of finding homes for stray or abandoned pets, though word of the donation is just now getting out.

title: The World: Frightening Reassurances in Iran; Some Officials Ran a Hit Squad. It's Over. Still Worried?
description: BE suspicious, the better to escape another's trickery,'' the Persian maxim goes. Indeed, Iran, with its high walls, veiled women and mirror-mosaics, is a country that never was accustomed to revealing its secrets, whether its leader wore a turban or a crown.

title: Parents Learn Skills in Teaching
description: CROTON-ON-HUDSON WITH upturned faces, the first graders sat spellbound as the storyteller read them a tale called ''Rosie's Walk'' by Pat Hutchins. With squeals and smiles, they raised their hands to answer questions about the story, giggled at the pictures and marched around the library to demonstrate concepts like ''through,'' ''around'' and ''over.''

title: The Candidate
description: I am not a college application. Neither are any of the other thousands of high-school seniors who are spending their winters filling them out. We are people -- we eat, breathe, sleep and would rather not spend our Saturdays endlessly retaking the S.A.T.'s. But when admissions committees decide whether to admit us, they judge not the student but the answers on the application. There may be no better system. However, if a college can determine what it needs to know about me based on my answers, what can I learn about a college from its questions?

title: Cuba Attacks as 'Deceptive' Clinton's Easing of Embargo
description: A high-ranking Cuban official has denounced President Clinton's proposals to ease some restrictions in the United States' embargo of this Communist-run island, calling them a ''deceptive maneuver'' intended to deflect growing opposition around the world to the embargo.

title: For Small Businesses, Credit Cards Are Handy
description: It is almost a rite of passage for struggling independent film makers, six months out of school and a week away from bagging groceries for a living, to finance a movie on a credit card. Well, perhaps their example has helped inspire a generation of business owners.

title: Co-op Must Meet Once Every Year
description: Q My building went co-op in 1985. According to the articles of incorporation, an annual meeting must be held to elect board members and to attend to other corporate business. Our last annual meeting was in November 1977. Before my fellow shareholders and I complain, we would like to know the laws regarding the annual meeting requirements for a co-op. . . . Mary Elizabeth Kane, Manhattan.

Donald Trump likes to think of himself as a man of the people, and stands in line for tickets and popcorn at his favorite movie haunt just like everybody else.

title: In Congo Carnage, How Many Died?
description: There is no doubt that something awful happened here. Dozens of mud huts are burnt to the ground; in one the horns of a charred goat poke through the ashes. Most people have fled. Fresh dirt is piled up over at least four bodies.

title: Stretching a Town Car Into Something Special
description: WHEN the Lincoln Town Cars arrive at United States Coachworks in Bohemia, nobody would mistake them for compacts -- their bumper-to-bumper length is 218 inches. But when they leave, they are definitely long, longer and longest -- transformed into limousines to the tune of more than 1,000 stretch cars a year.

title: Immigrants Deserve Deportation, Not Help
description: ''Immigrants Find the Island a Mixed Blessing'' [Dec. 27] described the effects of illegal aliens on the life of Long Island. Many people interviewed work in construction or factories. Many have their children with them. Many are paid below minimum wage and pay no taxes.

title: With $5,000 Bonuses at Stake, Two Tear Up a Fast Track
description: In a sports world in which a baseball player can earn $13 million a year and a basketball player has just been limited to an annual ceiling of $14 million, $5,000 sounds like tip money. But to track and field athletes, especially those below the superstar level of a Michael Johnson or a Jackie Joyner-Kersee, $5,000 is a good day's pay, especially this early in the indoor season when no one is in the best racing shape.

title: Smart Women, Foolish Choices
description: In modern fiction about the lives of women in middle age, or fast approaching it, there seems to be one overarching goal -- to create fresh, quirky types with attention-grabbing jobs and wacky lives, characters who make at least three crackling quips per page. Writers will do anything, in other words, to avoid the cliche of the aging woman who fears she'll either lose -- or never find -- the right man. What's remarkable about Toni Graham's first book, THE DAIQUIRI GIRLS (University of Massachusetts, $24.95), a collection of short stories about four 30-something or older women, is that Graham takes characters who could easily become dreary stereotypes -- characters left feeling insecure by failed marriages and failing health, by the realities of aging, by men who treat them badly -- and fleshes them out beautifully, without doing the literary equivalent of a rain dance to convince us they're ''interesting.'' Graham doesn't wallow in these women's vulnerability, but she doesn't apologize for it either. She uses their loneliness and confusion as backdrops for the action, not as personality traits. And her prose is entertaining without being forced: Graham allows a good deal of brainy good humor to flow naturally. (One woman, who gets a chilly reception from her lover's progressive, liberal-thinking family because she's a WASP, notes dryly: ''I saw Phillip's sister Lenore last Sunday night at the family party. Her smile reminded me of the grille of an old Buick, except mean.'') Graham's characters aren't spunky role models, cozy potential best friends or women who run with the wolves. They're the sort who keep the wolves on their toes. Stephanie Zacharek

title: From 'The Black Marble Shoeshine Stand'
description: Act I, Scene 1: The interior of the one-year-old Lackawanna Station in Hoboken in 1908. Center stage is a four-seated shoeshine stand made of a rare and beautiful imported black marble. On the granite wall behind the stand are two signs. The one with an arrow pointing stage right reads ''To the Trains.'' The one with an arrow aiming stage left reads ''To the Ferries.'' It's the brink of dawn on a midweek workday as a dark, medium-sized Italian man in his early 50's prepares the unoccupied stand for the workday. Finally, he stops to sit at the heel of the ornate stand.

title: One Show Lives, One Languishes

Critics and audiences tend to love the first but can't make up their minds about the second. I had to wait a few weeks to get into ''Swan Lake'' at the Neil Simon Theater; at the performance of ''On the Town'' I saw, the oversize Gershwin Theater was half full at best.

title: Official Urges Fire Placards In Apartments
description: Because of widespread ignorance about what to do in a fire, emergency instructions should be posted on the door of every apartment in New York City, just as they are in hotel rooms, Fire Commissioner Thomas Von Essen said yesterday.

Tangibles like a rising book value at a company or even significant growth in corporate earnings are no longer required by investors who are looking to justify their stock purchases. title: 4 Who Found a 4th-Quarter Feast

On average, their funds returned a gratifying 18.8 percent. The strong close pulled their average returns up to 15.1 percent for 1998, though that was still far behind the 24 percent of 1997.

title: Nothing but Stars and Beach
description: TO reach Jericoacoara, you take a highway back through time, rippling further back with each mile of Brazilian coast. From Fortaleza, with its sleek beachfront hotels, the road grows desolate, drought painting the savanna of the northeast dull green and beige. Cars give way to horses and mules, buildings shrink to become huts, and spindly goats and cows forage over the brush. As the road goes from asphalt to dirt to just paths in the sand, you would not be surprised to find wagon wheels and animal skulls, the detritus of ancient, failed journeys, strewn by the side of the road.

title: The Redskins Said to Be Sold for $800 Million

His promoter, Murad Muhammad, sets up opponents and Jones knocks them down. Replace the human pins with wooden ones, and Jones will have nearly completed the transition.

description: A former police officer who said he helped tackle the anti-apartheid activist Steve Biko and smash his head into a wall when he was in custody in 1977 has been denied amnesty by the South African Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, MARTIN, M.D.
description: GOLD-Martin, M.D., 80 years old, died the kind of death, in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, on January 9, 1999, that he had always termed a ''blessing'' - one that came quickly and without great suffering. The lessons of his life can be measured by his achievements in the medical world and the gifts of loving compassion and generosity that he shared with all who knew him. He learned very early about inequality and discrimination as a poor youth growing up on the streets of the Lower East Side of New York. His drive to change the world from what is to what should be inspired a social consciousness that made him a committed physician who believed in the mission of medicine to comfort and heal. He served as a Navy medical officer in World War II and made the ''D Day'' invasion on Omaha Beach, which convinced him of the horrors of war and fueled his lifelong pacifism. His progressive political vision led him to join with the physician founders of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York in what was the first pre-paid group practice model of health care. His extraordinary leadership abilities resulted in his becoming the Medical Director of the Central Queens Medical Group, the Manhattan Medical Group, the Garden State Medical Group of New Jersey, the President of the Medical Group Council of H.I.P., the Vice Chairman of the Board of H.I.P., the President of Centralized Laboratories, and the President of the Group Council Mutual Insurance Company. His profound commitment to women's health led him to co-found Choices Women's Medical Center in 1971, two years before the Supreme Court legalized abortion. He was the Vice President for Strategic Affairs and was an active, dynamic part of Choices until the day he died. As a physician, he practiced the art as well as the science of medicine, and his patients loved him for it. As a mentor, he inspired many young professionals to move beyond their limitations and live their dreams. As a man, he was honorable, honest, loving, witty, and kind. He will be deeply missed and very fondly remembered by his loving wife, Merle Hoffman, and his devoted son (by his first wife, Bernice Cherkos), Edward Gold, M.D. of New Jersey; daughter-inlaw, Holly Gold; his adored grandchildren, Elizabeth, Marissa and Max; and his loving sister, Thelma and her family of Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Contributions to the United States Holocaust Museum would be appreciated. Funeral services at Schwartz Brothers Funeral Home, Queens Boulevard, Wednesday, January 13, at 12 noon.

title: Amazon Surge May Reflect The New Math Of the Internet
description: For Amazon.com, the best seller that really mattered last week was not a book title, but the company's stock. Whether it was simply more Internet frenzy, or a further sign that on-line commerce may require its own investment calculus, the company's shares had a remarkable run last week.

title: Observers Give Voting In Nigeria Good Marks
description: Officials monitoring Nigeria's countrywide elections on Saturday said today that they had been generally peaceful and well organized, describing them as an improvement over local elections last month and another positive step toward the presidential contest next month.

Professor of Psychiatry at UCLA School of Medicine since 1969, Department Chairman and Director of Neuropsychiatric Institute until 1989, at his home in Los Angeles, January 2, 1999. He will be remembered by colleagues, students, patients and others he helped, encouraged and comforted, as well as by his friends and family. Contributions in honor of Dr. West may be made to the Louis Jolyon West Memorial Fund, for use in the new Award for Excellence in Psychiatry established in his name, c/o Michelle DeLuca, NPI Office of Extramural Support, 760 Westwood Plaza, Room C7-453, NPI, Los Angeles, CA 90024-1759; 310825-6856.

title: A Lucky Deal? That's for Sure. But Was It Good Luck or Bad?
description: One of the last tournament deals played in New York in 1998 should have been one of the luckiest. In the Regional Swiss Teams, played at the Crowne Plaza Hotel in Manhattan on Dec. 29, North-South arrived in six diamonds, a contract that hinges on the division of the red suits. The contract is decidedly poor, but North can hardly be blamed for attempting the slam after his partner had responded four diamonds to a double of a three-spade opening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUFELD, ABRAHAM

title: Redskins Are Bought At Highest Price Ever
description: The National Football League's Washington Redskins and their stadium were purchased yesterday by a group headed by Howard Milstein, a co-owner of the National Hockey League's New York Islanders, for a record price involving an American sports franchise, according to two people involved in the sale. The purchase price reflects the cash flow generated by the Redskins' Jack Kent Cooke Stadium. The $800 million, to be paid to the estate of Jack Kent Cooke by Mr. Milstein and the Washington-based communications executive Daniel Snyder, far exceeds the previous record, $530 million paid for the expansion Cleveland Browns last August.

From the drummer Leon Parker, we're used to this; his hard slap on the snare and hypnotizing patterns on the ride cymbal produce a basic sound that swings yet seems almost pre-jazz.

With its astonishing selection and knowledgeable clerks, the Record Mart quickly became the center of the universe for aficionados of Latin recordings. Tourists stuffed their backpacks with purchases, and music historians found the store an invaluable archive.

title: Once More, Schumer Is Sworn In As Senator
description: In a day of pomp and celebration by a political party that has little to cheer about this decade, thousands of New York Democrats assembled at Lincoln Center yesterday to whoop and cheer as Charles E. Schumer was sworn in -- for a second time -- as New York State's new junior Senator.

title: Sports of The Times; Parcells's Haunting Possibility In Denver
description: IT didn't take long. The third or fourth question for Bill Parcells after the Jets' 34-24 victory over the Jaguars yesterday involved his thoughts on the American Football Conference championship game next Sunday in Denver, where on Saturday the Broncos, with Terrell Davis galloping for 199 yards, had stomped the Dolphins by 38-3.

title: Steve Reich and His Music Must Be Seen to Be Loved
description: Steve Reich writes action music, music that is keyed into the physical actions it exerts in performance and that is always busy and active in how it moves through time. Radio listeners to his concert at Merkin Hall on Thursday night, broadcast live on WNYC-FM, will have missed how, for instance, the drumsticks started to flicker over a line of bongos as the players moved rhythmically out of phase with one another in the first part of ''Drumming,'' or how Mark Stewart's fingers, poised over his electric-blue electric guitar, picked out the main line in ''Electric Counterpoint.'' Works for musicians playing against recorded images of themselves -- like ''Electric Counterpoint'' or, coming at the end of this program, ''Different Trains'' for string quartet -- show a particular loss when there is nothing to distinguish the visible performers from the invisible.

title: Vice President Sounds Presidential Themes
description: While still months away from officially declaring himself a Presidential candidate, Vice President Al Gore is scheduled to announce a series of initiatives this week that his aides say will be major themes of his campaign.

title: Jets' Anxiety Evaporates Into Thin Air
description: Bill Parcells stormed toward Keyshawn Johnson one day in practice last week and screamed that he had ruined a play. Johnson yelled back that he had not. Johnson explained why. Oh, Parcells said. Sorry.

description: The New Yorker's move to the Conde Nast building in Times Square, planned for the summer, has ignited a feud between unlikely opponents: a prolific author and the New York Public Library.

title: Compressed Data; Intel and Compaq Dispute One Year 2000 Bug Theory
description: Moving to debunk theories of a supposed Year 2000-related bug known as the Crouch-Echlin effect, Intel and Compaq Computer, two of the computer world's heavyweights, said last week that their own extensive tests had found no evidence of such a problem.

title: Jets Fans Exult in Payoff After a Long, Grim Vigil
description: In the pre-game tailgate parties in the Meadowlands parking lot, Jets fans were intoxicated today, some on beer, many others on a home game in January.

title: A Start on Long-Term Care
description: President Clinton's proposal on long-term care will give only modest help to most individuals with debilitating illnesses and family members who are caring for them and no help at all to the very poor. But it might do some good if it puts the long-term care problem on the nation's political agenda and becomes a starting point for increased Federal involvement. The issue cannot be put off for long as millions of baby boomers begin facing potentially huge long-term care costs for themselves or their parents.

title: '99 Problem Trips Up Few Computers
description: The world apparently sailed through the first days of 1999 with only scattered mistakes by computers confused by the approaching Year 2000 -- an outcome that added to growing optimism about the chances of avoiding widespread disruptions 51 weeks from now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUERBACH, JOSEPH
description: AUERBACH-Joseph. Age 82. Beloved husband of Leah. Father of Fran, Marla and Louis. Grandfather of Elyse, Phoebe, David and Uri. Passed away January 9, 1999. title: Working Very Hard to Catch Up Quickly With Eternity
description: ''Our Brief Eternity'' lasted slightly less than an hour. But the Holy Body Tattoo, a modern-dance company from Vancouver, British Columbia, filled this miniature eternity with strenuous activity on Friday night at Performance Space 122. As choreographed by Noam Gagnon and Dana Gingras and performed by them and Chantal Deeble, the work kept them perpetually busy.

title: HDTV Set Prices Are Falling, But Consumers Remain Scarce
description: If the consumer electronics industry can be counted on for one thing, it is that the prices of their products will plummet, even when that may not be in the best interests of the companies involved.

description: KINSEY-Robert S. Age 84, of Chestertown, MD, died Friday, January 8, 1999. Formerly of Tenafly, NJ, he attended Antioch College and graduated from University of Cinncinnati. He is survived by his wife, Minnie Sherrill Kinsey and a son, George H. Kinsey of Milford, NJ, and a daughter, Marion K. Comins of Larchmont, NY, and four grandchildren. He was a long-standing member of The Angler's Club of New York. Memorial services on Wednesday, January 13th, 1 PM, at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Church Hill, MD.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUSHMAN, ARMAND
description: PUSHMAN-Armand. January 8, 1999, age 98. Beloved son of the late Hovsep and the late Hulia Pushman, devoted brother of the late Arsene Pushman. He was the last surviving son of the celebrated American Armenian artist Hovsep Pushman. Armand and his brother were partners in Pushman & Company dealing in fine oriental rugs. Armand was a talented musician having studied the viola in Paris with Maurice Vieux in his youth and enjoyed playing chamber music to the present. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call Sunday and Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Service Tuesday, January 12th, 1 PM, at The Armenian Evangelical Church, 152 East 34 St, NYC. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Juilliard School Armenian Scholarship Fund.

title: Deadly Zeal in India
description: On Christmas Day a school run by Christians was burned down by arsonists. Another school nearby was demolished by a mob. In a separate incident, a church was stoned. Several women hiding inside were injured, as were the nuns who sought to shield them.

But those dancers more than held their own on Friday night at the Kaye Playhouse in a program of Odissi dance performed with new authority, subtlety and projection but the same youthful radiance that distinguished the troupe in 1996.

At moments, he seems as frightened and helpless as a 4-year-old who has lost his parents at the fair; at other times, he is the soul of patrician urbanity, your ideal white-tie dinner partner. Then the eruptions come in nasty bolts of anger. And they aren't half as scary as when his face freezes into a grim, affectless mask. What is he called again? Oh, right. Nero.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAGE, WALTER H.
description: PAGE-Walter H. Of Cold Spring Harbor, NY. Died January 8. Husband of Jane N. Page, who died December 15, 1998. He leaves three children, Jane Mallinson, Walter and Mark, and eight grandchildren. Memorial service at 12 noon, Wednesday, January 13, Saint John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, please donate to charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAMARKIN, NORMAN R.
description: TAMARKIN-Norman R., M.D. Age 60. A prominent Washington, DC, psychiatrist and national expert on political psychology died suddenly while battling a long illness. Born in Youngstown, OH, Dr. Tamarkin graduated from Ohio State Medical School. After completing psychiatric training at Illinois State Psychiatric Institute in 1968, he came to the Washington area to do research at the National Institute of Mental Health. He ran the drug addiction program at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Washington after which he entered private practice. Dr. Tamarkin was also on the faculty of the Department of Psychiatry at Georgetown University Medical School and was a consultant to the Public Affairs Commission of the American Psychiatric Association. During the more than 25 years that Dr. Tamarkin practiced psychiatry, he gained a reputation for his ability to help prominent political and entertainment figures deal with their many stresses. At a time when this was considered unorthodox, his sense of intellectual adventure led him to integrate psychological, social and physiological factors in both his medical practice and his life. June Bingham, co-author with Dr. Tamarkin of ''The Pursuit of Health'' (1986), said ''The world is full of people who are a lot better for having known Norman Tamarkin, either professionally or otherwise.'' Dr. Tamarkin was widely loved because of his gift for friendship. Survivors include his companion, Sabrina Cassagnol; his sister, Bryn Tamarkin-Jacobstein; his nephew, Tommy; and scores of loving friends.

title: Social Security Chimeras
description: The journalist Michael Barone recently summed up the conventional wisdom about reforming Social Security. ''The content of the reform is fairly clear -- individual investment accounts to replace part of the government benefits financed by the payroll tax, later retirement ages, adjusted cost of living increases,'' he wrote in The American Enterprise. And, he added, ''suddenly the money to pay for the costs of transition is at hand, in the form of a budget surplus.''

title: Ascend to Sell Stratus Unit To Investcorp
description: Ascend Communications Inc., a maker of advanced data communications equipment, will formally announce today that it is selling its Stratus Enterprise Computer Division for more than $100 million to a group led by Investcorp, the Middle East investment group.

title: Reducing Caesareans
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Analysts find Silicon Graphics' new technology more compelling than its outlook for investors.
description: AFTER three years of declining fortunes, Silicon Graphics Inc. is placing a big bet today as it introduces a line of work stations built around Intel chips and Microsoft software.

title: Charter Schools Divide Neighbors
description: To the Editor:

title: Corporations Cast as Bad Guys; 'A Civil Action' Defies Hollywood Practice, Using Real Names in Accusations
description: What's it worth to a company to get its soft drink or athletic shoe prominently displayed in a big movie? Tommy Hilfiger, the hip young clothing line, spent $10 million on a promotion campaign for ''The Faculty,'' a Miramax/Dimension film for Disney about high school students (dressed in Hilfiger) who battle alien invaders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDEMAN, DR. THOMAS
description: SEIDEMAN-Dr. Thomas. At age 87, on January 9, 1999 after a long and valiant battle. Beloved husband of Francine. Devoted father of Gail Fieldston (Dr. Kenneth) and Dr. Bruce A. Seideman (Abby). Loving grandfather of Evan, Ross, Todd, Brett, Lauren, Blair and Harrison. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Woodbury, NY.

title: Editorial Notebook; Beating the Yanquis at Their Game
description: Cuban and American leaders are pondering the issue of whether a Baltimore Orioles visit to Cuba would strengthen or weaken the regime of Fidel Castro. The question seems improbable, yet governments have long used baseball to promote their values and politics. When the Sandinistas took power in beisbol-crazed Nicaragua in 1979, they considered banning the sport. Instead, they decided they could use it to help build the New Socialist Man. They began with Managua's 30,000-seat stadium, called ''Anastasio Somoza Garcia'' after the father of the dynasty the Sandinistas overthrew. They renamed the stadium for the man who shot him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, ZALMAN C.
description: BERNSTEIN-Zalman C. We mourn the loss of the dynamic presence of Zalman Bernstein in our minyon and his cherished friendship. We extend heartfelt condolences to Mem and Rachel Leah. Special friends from The Auxiliary Minyon Congregation Ahavath Torah Englewood, NJ

title: Charter Schools Divide Neighbors
description: To the Editor:

title: Duval Pads His Reputation As the World's Best Golfer
description: He dominated this weekend. He has been the PGA Tour's biggest winner the past 15 months. And after watching David Duval win today for the eighth time in his last 27 starts, even more of his peers are convinced that Duval is the world's best player.

title: Charter Schools Divide Neighbors
description: To the Editor:

title: Outcry at Talk of Selling Lincoln Center Art
description: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts is considering selling Jasper Johns's only public artwork, the monumental ''Numbers, 1964,'' in hopes of raising what some people estimate could be as much as $15 million.

title: Equity Offerings Are Set
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: State of State: What Went Unsaid; Hate-Crimes Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraq's Parliament Puts Off Vote of Defiance Against U.N.
description: After more than a month of rising defiance, the Iraqi Government postponed a vote today in which its Parliament had appeared ready to take further steps along a collision course with its Western foes.

title: A Stark Awakening on the Banks of the Yangtze
description: DAUGHTER OF THE RIVER

title: Hong Kong Democrats Split on Elective Route vs. Street Protests
description: Eight months after it won a resounding victory in legislative elections here, Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement is divided over whether the Democratic Party should abandon elective politics and take its cause to the streets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZISSU, FREDERICK
description: ZISSU-Frederick. On Saturday, January 9, 1999. Of North Caldwell, N.J. Formerly of Kings Point, New York. Beloved husband of Lillian (nee Scheps). Devoted father of Barbara Kushnick, Jeffrey A. Zissu, Karen Magidson and Sandra Rosenbaum. Loving grandfather of 14 grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren. Funeral services were conducted from Temple B'nai Jeshurun, South Orange Ave., Short Hills, N.J. on Sunday, January 10, 1999. Interment Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, N.J. For information, Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey.

title: Security Reports Cite Lapses by an Airline
description: Federal Aviation Administration agents posing as passengers smuggled guns, hand grenades and bombs past an airline's security guards and their scanners, agency reports show. In November 1996, the aviation agency said it would settle 84 charges against USAir, now US Airways, for $450,000, but it gave no details on the charges. Documents show that in one of those cases, an agent in a Columbus, Ohio, airport set off a metal detector with a handgun hidden in the small of her back. The agent was twice checked by a security guard with a hand-held metal detector, and though alarms went off each time, she was allowed to proceed toward the boarding gate.

title: Black and Hispanic Leaders Seek Consensus on Senate Race
description: Now that the state's highest ranking black elected official has removed himself from next year's race for United States Senate, a group of black and Hispanic elected officials, political strategists and businessmen -- led by the Rev. Al Sharpton -- have begun meeting to discuss uniting behind a single minority candidate.

title: With Khmer Rouge Collapse, Pressure Grows to Rein In Army
description: PHNOM PENH  After the collapse of the Khmer Rouge as an effective guerrilla force and the formation of a new coalition government between previously warring political factions, the Cambodian armed forces are under increasing pressure to curb corruption and human rights abuses and to slim down and become more professional.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NGUYEN, NGOC SAN
description: NGUYEN-Ngoc San. Age 88, on December 25, 1998. Former President of the Saigon Bar Vietnam. Vice president of the International Association of Lawyers. Honorary Attorney at Law, Paris Bar, France. President of the Vietnamese Laywers Association Overseas. Interned at Fairview Cemetery, Westfield, NJ, the 29th of December, 1998. His wife, Ngoc Hai and sons, Kinh Luan, Kinh Quoc, Kinh Vy, Kinh. They are shocked and saddened by his death.

title: Subway Killing Casts Light On Suspect's Mental Torment
description: As far back as when he was 16 and first had an inkling that something was wrong with him, his life appeared to turn inward and downward. Until the police took him away, he lived in a basement shoe box of a room in Queens. He watched ''The Simpsons'' and listened to Pink Floyd and ceaselessly paced the linoleum floor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENSTER, PHILIP S., D.D.S.
description: FENSTER-Philip S., D.D.S. Orthodontist and librarian passed away January 9, 1999, after a brief illness. Loving husband of Ruth, devoted father of Michael (Sandy) and Linda, brother of the late Rhoda Daum Kenner. Funeral Tuesday, January 12, 11 AM, at The United Jewish Center, 141 Deer Hill Avenue, Danbury, CT. His good deeds touched many lives.

title: Shanahan, Eager to Face Parcells, Gets Right to Work
description: When Mike Shanahan arrived at his office this morning, he began studying the Jets. Several hours later, the Denver Broncos' coach turned on his television to make sure he wasn't wasting his time.

title: State of State: What Went Unsaid
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CASTRO DOLLAR: A special report; In Cuba's New Dual Economy, Have-Nots Far Exceed Haves
description: Some days Avilio Guia likes to come and sit outside the new Carlos III Market and watch the people coming and going from dollar-only shops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALTYS, HENRIETTA ''JINDRA.''
description: FALTYS-Henrietta ''Jindra.'' Of St. James, New York. On January 10, 1999. Loving aunt of Evelyn Sokol and Beatrice Feldman. Cherished companion of Morris Hornfeld. Also survived by many greatnieces and nephews. A private cremation was held.

title: A Colombian Town Gropes for a Peace of Its Own
description: In the streets, the campesinos of San Vicente del Caguan dared to feel a quiet pride and even hope, seeing luminaries from the nation's capital and around Latin America descend on their town.

title: U.S. Now Tells of Much Deeper Damage by Pollard Than Thought
description: Adamant that President Clinton refuse requests that he grant clemency to Jonathan J. Pollard, an American spy for Israel, United States military and intelligence officials say Mr. Pollard did more damage to national security than the public has been told.

title: Sports of The Times; Johnson Leaves His Critics to Gape
description: KEYSHAWN JOHNSON bailed out a lot of people yesterday. He bailed out a Jets team that showed signs of shrinking from its destiny. He bailed out a defense that turned careless and porous. He even bailed out Curtis Martin, his offensive soul mate, whose second-quarter fumble could have put the Jacksonville Jaguars back in the game.

title: Essay; The Loyalty Mystery
description: I love a mystery: what inspires the phenomenal loyalty to Bill Clinton?

title: With Bleachers Empty, Marineland Show Goes On
description: The parking lot is strewn with dead palm fronds. Rot has invaded the bleachers. Rust dribbles down the tanks. And the famous portholes are clouded and leaking.

title: Inmates Serving More Time, Justice Department Reports
description: The recent wave of tougher sentencing laws has succeeded in making criminals serve longer prison sentences and slowed the release of inmates, helping to increase the nation's record prison population even as crime has dropped in the 1990's, according to the first comprehensive study of the new laws released by the Justice Department yesterday.

title: Fresh Face for the Curb-Side Chat; Regulators Shaping Changes in Public Phone Service
description: They came from Long Island City.

title: New State Test Has Schools Cramming
description: For weeks, the new New York State reading, writing and listening test has spurred a frenzy of cramming more often associated with getting into law school than with passing fourth grade. Schools have virtually suspended their normal curriculums to administer practice tests and help pupils brush up on concepts like ''the main idea,'' ''topic sentences'' and ''supporting details.''

title: Abdel-Latif Baghdadi, 81, Partner in Egypt's 1952 Coup
description: Abdel-Latif Baghdadi, an energetic Egyptian Air Force officer who helped Gamal Abdel Nasser oust Egypt's last sovereign, King Farouk, in 1952 and then held key posts in Nasser's Government, died late Friday. He was 81.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARKIN, BENJAMIN
description: ARKIN-Benjamin. 77, of Boca Raton, FL and Dobbs Ferry, NY. Beloved husband of Rita. Loving father of Leslie and Russell; devoted father-in-law of Stephen Horowitz and Elaine B. Arkin; adoring grandfather of Anna Irene Arkin. Born May 6, 1921 in NYC, died January 8, 1999 in Boca Raton, FL of colo-rectal cancer. A loving, kind and gentle man who enriched those whose lives he touched. Interment private. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions to Hospice by the Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Park Rd., Boca Raton, FL 33486.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VALE, JEROME
description: VALE-Jerome . Missed, never to be forgotten. All our love, Jean and Jo

title: Ranger Victory Sets Up Move to Playoff Status
description: Except for the injury to Petr Nedved, the Rangers emerged from yesterday's victory over Tampa Bay with several reasons to smile. By beating the woeful Lightning by 5-2 in Madison Square Garden, they moved within one game of the .500 mark. They scored on their first shot of the game, off the rush, by Mike Knuble. They scored on a penalty shot by John MacLean. They got another nifty performance from Dan Cloutier, their backup goalie, who made 22 saves. And their two offensive stars, Brian Leetch and Wayne Gretzky, returned to the score sheet after modest absences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUBERT, RUE H.
description: HUBERT-Rue H. Of Sharon, CT, died on January 3, 1999 at age 66, in NYC after a long illness. Daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Patrick C. Hill of Charlotte, VT, she attended Miss Porter's School and Sarah Lawrence College. She worked as an editor at House & Garden magazine. Predeceased by her husband, Paul Hubert, she is survived by her daughter, Pauline Hubert of NYC. A memorial service will be held at St. Bartholomew's Church on Saturday, January 23, at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRYSDALE, JEANNE BOLDEN
description: DRYSDALE-Jeanne Bolden. 69 years, on January 8. Survived by children David, Susan, Roger, and six grandchildren. Services, Rosedale Funeral Home: 718-528-1180.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the killing of an 8-year-old boy and his mother in Bridgeport, Conn., misspelled the boy's last name. He was Leroy Brown Jr., not Browne.

title: Experts See No Parallel For Trial
description: In setting a detailed schedule to resume the President's impeachment trial but putting off the vexing issue of whether witnesses will be heard, the Senate demonstrated to many lawyers and others just how different the impeachment trial was from any other legal proceeding.

title: Ladies First
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Investing in Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: The Merry, Scary Old Days of Racing for the Bomb
description: For a decade after the end of World War II, the United States and the Soviet Union waged a secret war to be first to create the ultimate weapon. Few people in either country knew of it, and even the scientists and officials entrusted with the work could not grasp the full import of what they were up to.
