Their efforts and concerns are the stuff of ''Race for the Superbomb,'' tonight's absorbing two-hour ''American Experience'' chronicle of the building of the hydrogen bomb.

title: 2 Policemen Rescue 6 Children From Fire
description: Two police officers who followed their fathers' footsteps into police work got a taste of firefighting early yesterday when they pulled six children to safety from the third floor of a burning house in the Bronx, the police said.

title: The Expanding Presidential Race
description: The nation's crop of Presidential candidates is exploding. Senators John McCain of Arizona and Robert Smith of New Hampshire recently became official Republican hopefuls. Elizabeth Dole cleared the way for what her aides say is likely to be a Presidential bid, and former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee announced his intention to announce. On the Democratic side, Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley are in the race. Senator John Kerry is in what politicians like to call ''testing the waters'' mode. Things are happening so fast that other potential candidates, like Senator Bob Kerrey, a Democrat, and John Ashcroft, a Republican, have felt obliged to rule themselves out of the running for nominations that will not be formally bestowed on anyone until the summer of 2000.

title: 2 Killed and 10 Hurt as Unlicensed Livery Van Hits Car in Brooklyn
description: An unlicensed livery van that was carrying a full load of passengers along Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn slammed into a car carrying three elderly people yesterday, leaving two people dead and at least 10 others injured, the police said.

title: Patents; Where was this handy little device when the Calaveras County frogs started jumping?
description: WHAT makes a basketball player worth millions of dollars? Although that depends on many factors, jumping ability doesn't hurt. Coaches have tried to measure such jumping talent using a system of tall poles. Now two University of Tulsa students and a professor of mechanical engineering have designed a method of measuring how high someone can jump that adds a computer microprocessor and mathematical formulas to the calculation.

title: Universal and Dodge In Marketing Pact
description: Universal Studios and the Dodge division of DaimlerChrysler A. G. in Auburn Hills, Mich., have signed a multimillion-dollar marketing agreement under which Dodge will become the sole automotive promotional and advertising partner for Universal films, theme parks, new-media ventures and consumer products. Terms of the one-year agreement, which can be extended, were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, RODRICK TYREE
description: ROSS-Rodrick Tyree. 50. Professional singer and teacher, died on January 3, 1999. He held degrees from the University of Michigan and Morgan State University. Family and friends mourn the death of this extraordinary individual and acknowledge his unique qualities of compassion, wisdom and generosity. A memorial service will be held at 5:30 PM, on Thursday, January 14, 1999, at the North Presbyterian Church, 525 W. 155 St, NYC 10032. Donations may be made to the Willis Patterson Scholarship Fund at the University of Michigan School of Music, 110 Bates Dr, Ann Arbor, MI 48104.

title: In the Nation's Capital, Historians Leave Impeachment for the Future
description: With a contemporary constitutional drama going on just a few miles away, historians flocked to the nation's capital last week to discuss topics like the dilemma of the South Asian intellectual and acoustics in early America.

title: One Woman in Hospital After Fire at Subway Stop
description: A smoky trash fire on a subway platform in Brooklyn forced the evacuation of the Metropolitan Avenue station on the G line in midafternoon yesterday and shut down most of the G and L lines for nearly an hour.

title: The Kay Graham of Japan's Media Industry
description: In a wood-paneled room rich with Persian carpets in the sedate Bunkyo-ku district, Sawako Noma, 55, sat forward as she offered a visitor coffee. Wearing a neat gray suit with knee-length skirt, her short hair neatly coiffured, her crossed ankles leading to sensible low heels, Mrs. Noma looked to be the prototypical Japanese housewife: demure, gracious, unprepossessing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DACHS, RICHARD A.
description: DACHS-Richard A. Died Wednesday, January 6, 1999. Always worth the hours awaiting your perfect appearance and of course the daily commentary on our dysfunctional social and political lives. How will we ever evaluate our conduct without your analysis. Cousins Harry, Judy and Alan who will forever miss and love you.

title: Orlandus Wilson, 81, Singer In Influential Gospel Quartet
description: Orlandus Wilson, whose bass voice was the foundation of the Golden Gate Quartet's gospel harmonies, died on Dec. 30 in Paris, where he lived. He was 81.

title: WITNESS QUESTION IN CLINTON'S TRIAL REMAINS BIG ISSUE
description: Two days after the Senate struck an unexpected note of harmony with an agreement on how to conduct the impeachment trial, Republicans and Democrats disagreed anew today over the one overriding question that could continue to divide the two parties: whether to call witnesses.

title: Mexico City Journal; Cocaine Doesn't Just 'Transit': Some of It Seeps
description: If he could take control of the millions of dollars Mexico spends each year to combat drug trafficking, Miguel Gonzalez Espinosa would spend a little less of it on high-tech, heavily armed operations at airports and along the border, aimed at stopping the flow of drugs from Colombia on their way to the United States.

title: Jewish Immigrants Warn of Rising Anti-Semitism in Russia
description: Most are old enough to have defied Hitler, either as Soviet soldiers or soldiers' wives. By keeping their heads down, they survived the anti-Semitism that became Government policy during Stalin's last years. They silently endured the subtle discrimination against Jews that permeated modern Soviet society and even the blossoming of overtly anti-Semitic movements during the years of perestroika.

title: Jaguars Like Jets' Ball Control and Their Chances
description: Having upset the Denver Broncos two years ago, the Jacksonville Jaguars know what it's like to win a playoff game at Mile High Stadium. After losing today to the Jets, 34-24, several Jaguars said they liked the Jets' chances against the Broncos in next weekend's American Football Conference championship game.

title: WB Succeeds By Serving Youth Alone
description: Along with much of the audience and most of the profit, the confidence bordering on arrogance that once characterized the network television business has faded away this season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOSKOW, AMBROSE
description: DOSKOW-Ambrose. A trademark litigation expert, who practiced law in New York for over 50 years, died January 9, 1999, shortly after his 90th birthday. Following graduation from Columbia's College and Law School, he clerked for Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo on the U.S. Supreme Court. Mr. Doskow was a partner of Rosenman and Colin. He is survived by his daughter, Elsa Freud, of San Francisco, his sister-in-law, Leonore Doskow, of Croton-On-Hudson, his grandson Christopher F.A. Freud, of Vail, CO, and his son-in-law, Nicholas S. Freud, of San Francisco. At Mr. Doskow's request, no services will take place. Voluntary donations in his memory may be made to The United Negro College Fund, 120 Wall Street, 9th Floor, New York, New York 10005.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARREN, LOUIS M.
description: WARREN-Louis M., 94. On January 9, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Shirley. Devoted father of Dr. Richard H. Father-in-law of Iris. Loving grandfather of Dena. Cherished brother of Sylvia Kuehn. Dear uncle and brother-in-law.

title: New York Students Continue To Dominate Science Program
description: Nearly half of the 300 high school students named yesterday as semifinalists in the Intel Science Talent Search are from New York schools, including two city schools that have long been dominant in the competition and a Long Island school that has emerged as a science powerhouse in recent years.

title: '98 Medicare Growth Slowest Since Program Began in '65
description: The growth of Medicare slowed to a virtual halt last year as spending in the giant health insurance program for the elderly rose by just 1.5 percent, the smallest increase since the beginning of the program in 1965, new Government data show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIVES, GRACE
description: FIVES-Grace. She entered into eternal rest on January 8, 1999. With great sorrow we see the end of an era. Grace owned the North Shore Steak House in Great Neck. Prior she ran The Jolly Fisherman in Roslyn. For all who knew her, she had a ready smile and a welcome. Left behind are her two sons Michael and his wife Kathy and John and his wife Chrissy, along with her many grandchildren, nieces and nephews, her brothers Ed and Richie. She will be missed deeply. Her memory will live on.

title: A Call for Passion in the Realm of Discovery
description: Remember that television advertisement for some over-the-counter pain medication in which a soap-opera actor announced at the start of his endorsement, ''I'm not a doctor, but I play one on TV''? This is just the sort of conflation of acted-science and real-science that led a Federal judge overseeing lawsuits over breast implants to appoint a panel of four scientists to decide the central factual question of the case: Do implants cause immune disorders? The panel studied relevant scientific research and found no statistically significant difference between the incidence of immune disorders in women who have had implants and those who have not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOPAS, STEPHEN S. SR.
description: SCOPAS-Stephen S. Sr., on January 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Cleonike (nee Andromidas). Loving father of Pamela Basedow (her husband William) and the late Stephanie Ann Scopas & Stephen Scopas Jr. Cherished grandfather of Stephen William and Stephanie Cleonike Basedow. Mr. Scopas served twelve years as a member of the Parish Council and six years as President of St. Nicholas G.O. Church. He was a Past President of St. Basil's Academy and the Archdiocese Council and was honored as an Archon of the Greek Orthodox Church. Mr. Scopas served as Chairman of the First Justice for Cyprus Committee and helped build the Ahepa Hospital at Salonica and the Ahepa Wing at the Evangelismos Hospital in Athens. He was awarded the Royal Order of Phoenix by King Paul of Greece. Mr. Scopas served on a local district and national level in the Order of Ahepa having held the office of Supreme President in both the Ahepa and Sons of Pericles. He has served as a Judge of the Crimnal Court of the City of New York and he founded the St. Paul's Society. He also served on the Professional Ethics Committee of the Queens County Bar Association. Mr. Scopas served until his death as the National Chairman of the Ahepa Cooley's Anemia Foundation. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing Northern Blvd. at 193rd St. Visiting hours 2-5 and 7-10 PM. Funeral services will be Wednesday St. Nicholas G.O. Church at 12 noon. Interment Flushing Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to The Ahepa Cooley's Anemia Foundation, 1909 Q St. N.W., Suite 500 Washington, D.C. 20009.

title: Jobs in Salt Lake City Questioned by I.O.C.
description: Relatives of International Olympic Committee members from Ecuador and Finland were employed by the Salt Lake City bid committee while it pursued the 2002 Winter Games, Olympic officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOHR, KATHRYN STANLEY
description: DOHR-Kathryn Stanley. Aged 99, died on January 3, 1999. Wife of the late James Dohr, Professor at Columbia Business School, she was an alumna and long time benefactor of Wellesley College and Columbia University, and an active supporter of Planned Parenthood of New York.

title: The Hospital, at Night
description: To the Editor:

title: RAYROCK RESOURCES ACCEPTS OFFER FROM VICEROY
description: Rayrock Resources Inc., a Toronto mining company, said yesterday that it had agreed to be bought by the Viceroy Resource Corporation for $157.4 million (Canadian), or $104 million (United States), in cash and stock. The transaction would combine two small mining companies with short-lived gold reserves into one that will produce about 300,000 ounces a year. Viceroy, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, said it would pay $2.50 (Canadian) in cash and 1.9 Viceroy shares for each Rayrock share. Rayrock stockholders also will receive shares of Blackrock Ventures Inc., an oil-and-gas company based in Toronto, in which Rayrock has a 46.7 percent stake. And Rayrock will pay Glamis Gold Ltd., based in Reno, $2 million (Canadian) for calling off a November agreement to buy it.

title: About the Tables
description: The Times is revising its financial tables today.

title: Corrections
description: A jazz review yesterday about a performance at Birdland by the guitarist Charlie Hunter and the drummer Leon Parker with the singer Kurt Elling referred incorrectly to Mr. Hunter's guitar. It has 8 strings, not 10. The review also misidentified the drummer in the trio that accompanied Mr. Elling. He is Victor Lewis, not Lewis Nash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWE, DANIEL J. JR.
description: HOWE-Daniel J. Jr. The American Legion Post #

title: Excerpts From Brief Filed by House in the Clinton Impeachment Trial
description: Following are excerpts from the House brief filed yesterday in the impeachment trial of President Clinton, as provided by the Judiciary Committee on its Web site:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Metro Business; Utility Eyes New Jersey
description: Peco Energy Company, a Pennsylvania utility company, said that it wanted to sell electricity in New Jersey if lawmakers passed a bill opening the state's power market to competition.

title: Government Weighs Protections for Prairie Dogs
description: On the very cold morning of Sept. 7, 1804, Meriwether Lewis and William Clark climbed to the domed top of a 70-foot Nebraska mound overlooking the Missouri River, where they ''discovered a Village of Small animals,'' their journal records. In their travels all the way to the Rocky Mountains, they saw millions of the little yapping things, which they first called ground rats, then barking squirrels and eventually prairie dogs.

title: TICKETMASTER ONLINE-CITYSEARCH TO BUY AUCTIONEER
description: Ticketmaster Online-Citysearch Inc., which offers entertainment-event tickets and city guides over the Internet, plans to buy the closely held Internet auctioneer Cityauction Inc. for about $54 million in stock so it can offer local auctions of bulky items or items difficult to transport. Ticketmaster Online-Citysearch, owned by USA Networks Inc. and based in Pasadena, Calif., plans to integrate the auctions into its network of guides of about 19 cities and regions in the United States, Scandinavia and Australia. Cityauction, based in Palo Alto, Calif., had listed about 115,000 auctions as of Dec. 31.

title: In Capital Case, Man Pleads Guilty to 2d-Degree Murder
description: A murder defendant whose case led New York's highest court to restrict plea deals under the state's death penalty law pleaded guilty yesterday to second-degree murder.

title: Abroad at Home; The Knock on The Door
description: In his speech to the House urging impeachment of the President, Henry Hyde said that our safety depends on respect for the law. ''The rule of law,'' he said, ''protects you and it protects me from . . . the 3 A.M. knock on our door. It challenges abuse of authority. It's a shame 'Darkness at Noon' is forgotten.''

title: Families Still Cut Off From Cult Members
description: Family and friends of members of an apocalyptic cult who were deported from Jerusalem kept vigil today in hopes of seeing grandchildren they had never met or sons and daughters who had disappeared months ago.

title: S.E.C. Fines 28 Wall St. Firms $26 Million
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission fined 28 Wall Street firms more than $26 million and suspended 51 traders yesterday for reputed abuses on the Nasdaq stock market, ending an investigation that began in 1994.

title: A Dragnet That Gives Sharks a Lease on Life
description: ''Snitch,'' the outdated slang insult for an informer, is back in fashion, and along with it a new career for drug dealers and users, which tonight's ''Frontline'' charges is corrupting the nation's criminal justice operations. Relying mainly on horror stories of low-level drug suspects who are serving long prison terms on evidence supplied by more culpable pals and collaborators, the producer, Ofra Bikel, makes a case that the famous war on drugs is being perverted by incentives that reward the guiltiest and punish the less guilty.

title: NABORS INDUSTRIES IN DEAL FOR POOL ENERGY SERVICES
description: Nabors Industries, the largest American driller of land-based oil and natural-gas wells, said yesterday that it would buy the Pool Energy Services Company, an oilfield service company, for around $357 million in stock, based on yesterday's closing price, and $144 million in assumed debt, ending a takeover battle begun in October. Shareholders will receive 1.025 shares of Nabors stock, valued around $16.46, for each share of Pool. Pool's board had refused to discuss an earlier bid of $13.85 a share from Nabors, which owns about 10 percent of Pool's shares. Both companies are based in Houston. The purchase would create a company with 1,190 land rigs in North America and 100 overseas, as well as 60 offshore rigs around the world. Shares of Nabors fell 87.50 cents, to $15.1875, while Pool rose $1.4375, to $15.0625.

title: Regional Fire Service Succeeds in Its First Test
description: On the day that five northern Hudson County towns began operating a joint firefighting service called the North Hudson Regional Fire and Rescue Department, more than 20 firefighters responded today to a routine call in West New York from the closest firehouses, which happened to be in Weehawken and North Bergen.

title: New Jersey Reservoir System Is Faltering During Dry Spell
description: The Wanaque Reservoir looks nothing like the workhorse of northeastern New Jersey's water supply system these days. Even after a weekend storm, it is only about 32 percent full, and some sections of it resemble a parched and snowy flatland, with naked rocky banks, tufts of trees atop exposed mounds, and a few ice-covered ponds.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSHAM, DR. MARY C.
description: PETERSHAM - Dr. Mary C. (Jones) Riley, 81, of 32 Sunset Lane, Petersham, MA died Saturday, January 9, 1999, in her home. She was known to her friends as Polly. She leaves her husband of 52 years, Dr. Richard L. Riley; a son, Richard C. Riley of Ithaca, NY; two daughters, Mary L. Riley of Hong Kong, China, Susan H. Riley of Petersham; a sister, Peggy Brooks of New York City, NY; and two grandchildren. She was born January 18, 1917, in New York City, N.Y., the daughter of T. Catesby and Louisa (Brooke) Jones and was a resident of Petersham for 22 years coming from Baltimore, MD. where she resided for 27 years. She graduated from Brearley School in New York City. She Received a B.S. from Bennington College, Bennington, VT, and went on to receive her M.D. from Johns Hopkins Medical School, Baltimore, MD, in 1948. She worked in several clinics in the Baltimore area specializing in internal medicine with emphasis on chest diseases, and achieved the rank of Assistant Professor of Medicine at The Johns Hopkins School of Medicine. She was also active in the Baltimore chapter of the League of Women Voters. She enjoyed singing, listening to music and painting. She was active in town activities including the Petersham Board of Health, the Library Committee, the Carpenter Concert Committee, the Petersham Branch Alliance, and the Petersham Craft Center. In recent years she was a regular attendant at the Monday lunches of the Petersham Council on Aging. A memorial service will be held in the Petersham Unitarian Church Sunday, January 24, 1999, at 3 P.M. Burial will be at the convenience of the family. There are no calling hours. For information Fiske Funeral Home, 1356 Main Street, Athol, MA 01331.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARUSO, MARGARET MARIE
description: CARUSO - Margaret Marie. Passed peacefully at home on Sunday, January 10, 1999. Her parting will leave a void which we will fill with remembered joy. Mother touched our lives with much love and warmth and friendship. Funeral Services at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave, NYC.

title: Bill Would Extend Protection to Abortion Clinic Workers and Clients
description: Spurred by the recent killing of a Buffalo doctor who performed abortions, the Democratic leaders of the State Assembly today proposed legislation intended to protect employees and clients of abortion clinics from harassment and violence.

title: Campaigns: New Law, New Suit?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, BERNARD
description: GOODMAN - Bernard. Beloved father of Mark, Beth and Steven. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Loving brother of Carole. Dear friend of Janet. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BIG ENTERTAINMENT INC., Boca Raton, Fla., an Internet-based seller of entertainment merchandise, agreed to acquire the Times Mirror Company's Hollywood Online Inc. unit, which operates a Web site for movie and celebrity information, for $31 million in stock.

title: Johannesburg Journal; A Post-Apartheid Tribute: Art Leading the People
description: South Africa, a nation top-heavy with ponderous memorials to British and Boer victories, is struggling to come up with a few catchy post-apartheid monuments.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Appeal to Save English-Only Law Fails
description: The Supreme Court today turned down a last-ditch defense of an Arizona law requiring public employees to speak only English on the job. Without comment, the Justices let stand a ruling by the Arizona Supreme Court that the measure, the most sweeping of two dozen state ''English-only'' laws, was unconstitutional.

title: Charlton and Beckenbauer On Center Stage Again
description: Bobby Charlton and Franz Beckenbauer, famous foes of the 1966 World Cup final, which England captured in overtime at Wembley Stadium in London, will go into battle for more World Cup honors this week as the race to stage the event in 2006 intensifies.

title: People, Bah! Who Needs Them?
description: It was a grand alliance of amiable cranks when Vic Chesnutt and Lambchop performed at the Bowery Ballroom on Saturday night. Mr. Chesnutt, from Athens, Ga., and Lambchop, a band from Nashville, are kindred back-porch Southern eccentrics who have long shared the alternative-rock circuit. Lambchop backs up Mr. Chesnutt on his new album, ''The Salesman and Bernadette'' (Capricorn), and Mr. Chesnutt sits in on Lambchop's current album, ''What Another Man Spills.'' On Saturday, Lambchop played its own set, then accompanied Mr. Chesnutt.

title: Two Experts Do Battle Over Potty Training
description: Toilet training is not rocket science, says John Rosemond, a syndicated columnist and best-selling author of parenting books. He considers it ''a slap to the intelligence of a human being that one would allow him to continue soiling and wetting himself past age 2.'' The process, he says, should be as simple and straightforward as housebreaking a 4-month-old puppy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWORKIN, SAMUEL
description: DWORKIN-Samuel. Beloved husband of Clarice, devoted father of Maxine Polyocan and Susan Rubenstein, adored grandfather of Nicole and Jennifer Poloycan, dear brother of Celia Horowitz and Joseph. Services Tuesday, 12:00 noon at ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Exp, Fresh Meadows, NY

title: Jury Selection Begins In School Murder Case
description: Jury selection began yesterday in the murder trial of an 18-year-old high school student accused of killing a classmate in a school locker room in 1997.

title: 2 British Oil Producers Are Considering Merger
description: Enterprise Oil P.L.C. and Lasmo P.L.C. said yesterday that they were in talks about merging in a transaction that would be worth at least $:910 million ($1.5 billion). Enterprise and Lasmo, Britain's two biggest companies that concentrate solely on oil production, have been hurt by falling oil prices and neither has other businesses to help cushion the blow.

title: On Eve of Test, Crew Gives Pep Talk at 2 Schools
description: Seeking to calm nerves jangled by the tough new statewide reading test that New York City's fourth graders will begin taking today, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew went to two elementary schools yesterday to tell students not to worry.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Political Briefing; Presidency in 2000: $2,893 an Hour
description: The cost of running for President spirals ever higher. With the primary and caucus season more front-loaded now than ever, candidates with any hope of being contenders must not only be able to raise staggering amounts of money but must also be able to raise it in a hurry.

title: Campaigns: New Law, New Suit?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rabbi Indicted on Charge That He Killed His Wife
description: A Camden County grand jury indicted a Cherry Hill rabbi yesterday on charges of murder and conspiracy to commit murder in the bludgeoning death of his wife, county prosecutors said.

title: Jetting to Victory
description: With New York's ecstatic fans barely done toasting the Yankees as World Champions, the football Jets are now giving them new reason to cheer. On a bright, cold Sunday afternoon in the Meadowlands, the Jets dominated the Jacksonville Jaguars, 34 to 24, to continue one of the most remarkable resuscitation efforts in recent sports memory. Just two years ago the Jets were the worst team in professional football, winning 1 game and losing 15. Now they are bound for the American Football Conference championship game against the Denver Broncos, last year's Super Bowl champions. This is a comeback that can make even jaded New Yorkers dream of the glory days of 30 years ago when Broadway Joe Namath carried the Jets to an upset victory in Super Bowl III.

title: Sex, Sex, Sex: A 'Preoccupation' Is Putting It Lightly
description: One midnight in Paris some years ago three friends and I took a bad recommendation and ended up in the sort of club where the minimum order is a $100 bottle of Champagne. We sighed, ordered and sat back for a little late-night conversation, or so we thought. Suddenly a movie screen appeared and a series of truly vulgar sexual cartoons began to play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINSEY, ROBERT S.
description: KINSEY-Robert S. The officers and directors of The Anglers' Club of New York express our sorrow at the loss of our fellow angler, benefactor, artisan, friend and past president and convey our great sympathy to Minnie, George and Marion. James M. Stewart, President

title: Metro Business; Suit Over Failed Buyout
description: Peekskill Financial Corporation, the owner of First Federal Savings Bank, and its senior managers were sued by a shareholder for rejecting a $48.3 million buyout offer last week from BRT Realty Trust.

title: Following the Trail of Adolescent Angst
description: Teen-agers, traditional wisdom holds, are sullen, prickly creatures, prone to mood swings and sudden outbursts of temper. But new research suggests that for some adolescents depression -- in particular, symptoms like lack of enjoyment in everyday activities or frequent thoughts about death -- signals an increased risk of serious depression in adulthood.

title: Plenty of Snow in Detroit, But Hardly a Plow in Sight
description: Every city reacts in its own way to snow. Atlantans panic and drive badly. Washington closes Government offices early and sends everyone home. Chicagoans expect their politicians to have the streets plowed immediately -- or face the consequences at the next election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, J. ELISABETH
description: WEISS-J. Elisabeth. In Cumberland, Chebeague Island, ME. January 4, age 83. A memorial service will be held in June on Chebeague Island. If desired memorial contributions may be made to the Chebeague Island Library C/O Martha Hamilton, RR1, Box 511, Chebeague Is., ME, 04017 or to Chebeague Is. Rescue, C/O Lewis Ross, RR1, Box 4, Chebeague Is., ME 04017. For information Lindquist Funeral Home, One Mayberry Ln., Yarmouth, ME 04096.

title: Salt Lake City Mayor Quits As Olympic Scandal Grows
description: For the past decade, Salt Lake City has been on a roll. It boomed as a Western high-tech center, one of the nation's fastest-growing cities, and shed its image as a backwater whose only claim was that it was the capital of the Mormon religion. The 2002 Winter Olympic Games were supposed to be the city's chance to show the world just how far it had come.

title: Airbus Orders Surge 20%, to a Record 556 Jets
description: Airbus Industrie said today that orders soared 20 percent in 1998, to 556 jets, a record for the European plane maker, which has been steadily narrowing the gap with its archrival, the Boeing Company.

title: As Green Succeeds, His Wallet Also Wins
description: Like Bill Parcells in New York, Dan Reeves in Atlanta and Mike Shanahan in Denver, Minnesota Vikings Coach Dennis Green is the biggest reason his team is one step away from the Super Bowl. Green has guided the Vikings to the National Football Conference title game against the Falcons on Sunday.

title: 2 Senators Push for Open Impeachment Debate
description: Two Democratic Senators said today that they would try to change the 19th-century Senate rule requiring closed sessions for all debates on impeachment in which senators speak, but odds are strong that the rule will be retained.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEURINGER, IRV
description: NEURINGER-Irv, 86, of Bethlehem, NH, originally of Brooklyn on December 3, 1998. He will be deeply missed by his beloved daughter Karen, his sons Martin (Maureen) and Allen (Martha), his sister Frances Yarmish and his grandsons Jordan, Jeremy, and Christopher. He was widely known for his successful carpet business. He loved and cared for many animals, he will be remembered by all who knew and cherished him for his generosity, warmth, humor and broad smile. His love and kindness touched many lives.

title: In Chicago, Fans Hope For a Return
description: Chicago Bulls fans thought they were used to such talk by now. It has become a yearly debate, something to argue about over a beer at his restaurant. ''Is he coming back?'' they ask, with a little more fear in their voices each year.

title: Let Mr. Clinton Speak
description: President Clinton, understandably eager to change the subject, wants to deliver his State of the Union address on schedule next week. Senators who have sworn an oath to do ''impartial justice'' will no doubt feel awkward listening to Mr. Clinton proclaim his achievements as if they were not sitting as jurors in his impeachment trial. House Republicans may feel the same way. As a result, many lawmakers are suggesting that Mr. Clinton put off the speech.

title: Sickly Silence For Patrons Of the Game
description: IF memory serves, George M. Steinbrenner 3d said that once the elections were over he would state his druthers as to where his New York Yankees should play after their Yankee Stadium lease expires in 2002.

title: Hoyas Make Red Storm Struggle to the Bitter End
description: St. John's gave the former Georgetown Coach John Thompson a framed Lou Carnesecca sweater before last night's game at Madison Square Garden, a totem from one coaching legend to another of a time when these two programs played magnificent games of extraordinary importance.

title: Of Mice and Elephants: a Matter of Scale
description: Scientists, intent on categorizing everything around them, sometimes divide themselves into the lumpers and the splitters. The lumpers, many of whom flock to the unifying field of theoretical physics, search for hidden laws uniting the most seemingly diverse phenomena: Blur your vision a little and lightning bolts and static cling are really the same thing. The splitters, often drawn to the biological sciences, are more taken with diversity, reveling in the 34,000 variations on the theme spider, or the 550 species of coniferous trees.

title: Europe Jetmaker Claims Half the Market : Airbus in Ascendancy
description: PARIS  Airbus Industrie said Monday it had achieved its goal of winning half of the world market for big commercial jets, and company executives said the European consortium was in a position to compete on an equal basis with Boeing Co. of the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, IRMA
description: BROWN-Irma. Adored wife of the late Frank. Beloved mother of Emily Brown, beloved mother-inlaw of Jack Russak, devoted grandmother of Charles and Sam, cherished sister of Michelle Fischler and Herman and Barbara Rubin. Loved by many nieces and nephews and their children. Her warmth and humor helped us all.

title: Braxton's Plan: Try to Rattle Testaverde
description: The Denver Broncos' strong safety, Tyrone Braxton, said he knows how to bring out the worst in Vinny Testaverde.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN SURGES. The yen rose for the ninth time in 10 days to the highest since August 1996 on hope that Japan had overcome the worst of its economic problems. In New York, the dollar cost 108.93 yen, down from 110.93.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, SOLOMON
description: SUSSMAN-Solomon (Cy). It is with profound sadness that we mourn the death of Cy Sussman. Our sincerest condolences to our dear friend Sydelle and her entire family. Bobbi, Mel and all the Weisses

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORBER, RUTH PERLISH
description: LORBER-Ruth Perlish of Delray Beach, FL., and Kings Point, New York died January 10, 1999. Beloved Jewel of Jerry Lorber's life. Treasured mother of Sandi Fox. Wonderful friend to Dan & Debbie Lorber, Hank & Liz Lorber, Julia Lorber Benson, and Larry & Carol Rizzolo. Fabulous grandmother of Cathy and Todd Raphaelson & Jonathan Fox, Andy & Eric Lorber, Kathryn Lagana, Michael, Sarah, & David Benson, Gregory, Douglas, & Trevor Rizzolo. Cherished sister of Shirley Cohen, Elaine & Kenneth Browner, and loving aunt to Cliford, Eileen, Kevin, Cayla, and Jessy Browner. Ruth was a beautiful, effervescent woman who lived her life to the fullest. We will miss her very much. Funeral services today Tuesday, Jan. 12, 1999 2 PM at Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, 7240 N. Federal Highway, Boca Raton. Interment Thursday, Jan. 14, 1999 2 PM at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, New York for further information.

title: A Killer's Ignorance Adds Poignancy to Biko Case
description: The release today of the full text of a decision to deny amnesty to a police officer involved in the death of the anti-apartheid activist Steve Biko contains an interesting twist on history: the officer, who helped kill Mr. Biko in 1977, may have had no idea how important he was.

title: Write Answers
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Protest Planned to Fight For Clean-Needle Plans
description: AIDS activists said yesterday that they would bus hundreds of residents of Newark, Jersey City and other urban areas to the State House this morning for a rally to protest Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's refusal to permit clean-needle exchange programs, hours before the Governor's annual State of the State address.

title: By Design; Paler Shades, to Chase Winter
description: Color was the big message of the spring collections, and bursts of sky blue, pink, yellow and lilac are now in stores to add cheer to midwinter wardrobes.

title: Patterns
description: Out From Versace's Shadow

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COCOLICCHIO, ERNEST W.
description: COCOLICCHIO-Ernest W. on January 10, 1999 of Beechhurst, NY. Beloved husband of Jennie (Cascone), loving father of Salvatore J. and Theresa E. Murnane. Proud grandfather of Jennifer, fond father-in-law of John Murnane. NYCDepartment of Buildings Commissioner for 30 years. Outstanding member of National Society of Professional Engineers. Born and raised in Harlem, New York on July 18, 1914, attended Stuyvesant High School, attained B.S. in Civil Engineering at Manhattan College (60 year graduate). Attained a degree in Structure at the Drexel Institute and a degree in Naval Architecture at Temple University. Master Queens builder and developer responsible for the construction of over 100 residential homes and commercial properties. Past president of Queens County Chapter of Professional Engineers; worked for the Atomic Energy Commission, Engineer for Philadelphia Navy Yard and New York Public Water Works, former employee of Vetro. Served New York City under 5 mayors as Plan Examiner and Borough Commissioner. For information, Frederick Funeral Home, Inc. (192-15 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, NY) Tuesday 2-5 & 7-10PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 9:45AM at Sacred Heart RC Church, Bayside, NY. Interment Mt. St Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITTY, BARBARA
description: WHITTY-Barbara (nee Smart). On January 10, 1999. Beloved wife of James P. Devoted sister of Doris S. Sandstrom. Also survived by her loving nieces: Lisa Tosh and Karin Sandstrom. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. (at 20th St.), NYC, Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Interment Thursday, January 14 at St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Sports Of The Times; FINAL SHOT, PARTING SHOT
description: The last time Michael Jordan considered retirement, it was from baseball, not basketball. There was a lockout in professional baseball in 1994 and he was then a minor league fly-chaser. He would return to basketball and the Bulls because he had become disgruntled with the baseball labor dispute. It seems history may be repeating itself, in a fashion. After this season's N.B.A. lockout, Jordan has apparently once again decided to retire from a sport. This time it's basketball.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MERSON, ROBERT M.
description: MERSON-Robert M. It's been two years & we still hear your laughter and see your beautiful smile. Love, Dad, Miriam and Larry, Ann and Ardie and all your nieces and nephew

title: Landowners Reassured About Claim by Oneidas
description: Some 20,000 property owners in central New York State whose land has been claimed by the Oneida Indians in a Federal lawsuit are in little danger of losing their property, a top Justice Department official in Washington said yesterday.

title: Before the Trial, Ask the Pivotal Question
description: A critical question has gone strangely neglected amid our preoccupation with the procedures for conducting an impeachment trial and repeated allusions to the ''somber'' and ''solemn'' character of it all. When and how will the Senate consider whether the offenses alleged against President Clinton amount to ''high crimes and misdemeanors'' -- a question that the President's lawyers yesterday rightly reminded the Senate it should ponder?

title: Year 2000 Glitch Won't Be Disruptive, Utility Operators Say
description: A succession of electric industry officials and the Secretary of Energy said today that the utilities had made substantial progress toward eradicating the threat of computer-induced blackout on Jan. 1, 2000.

title: The Modern Political Novel as a Mirror of the Bizarre
description: FACE-TIME

title: The Art of Service in the Service of Art
description: JAMES R. HOUGHTON describes himself as ''this guy from upstate New York,'' which is like calling the Metropolitan Museum of Art that place with the pictures. True, Mr. Houghton grew up in tiny Corning, but in a huge brick pile (his description) that looked down on the family glass works. That was Corning Inc., founded by his great-great-grandfather, who manufactured the first light bulb for Thomas A. Edison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SENGHAS, ELEANOR KING
description: SENGHAS-Eleanor King. On January 3, 1999. Her 80th year. in Hanover, VA. Beloved mother of Dorothy and Robert. Mother-in-law of Paul and Terri. Dear sister and sister-in-law of Doris and William. Cherished aunt of Roberta, Madeline and Donna. Memorial service January 16, 2PM at Grace Episcopal Church, Nyack, NY.

title: WHITMAN EXPECTS TO OFFER REBATES ON PROPERTY TAX
description: Under pressure to address New Jersey's high property taxes, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman was expected to outline a five-year, $1 billion plan on Tuesday that would eventually provide average rebates of $600 to homeowners.

title: British-German Mail Deal
description: Britain's Government-owned Post Office said today that it had acquired German Parcel, the third-largest private delivery service in Germany, for an undisclosed sum in its first major international expansion. German Parcel has annual sales of $:250 million ($410 million) and owns 23 percent of General Parcel, an international delivery service that operates in 30 European countries and has annual sales of $:2 billion. The deal comes as mail services prepare for full deregulation of the European postal market in 2003.

title: Giants Hope the Browns Will Pounce on Wooten
description: Every National Football League team -- except the four still in the Super Bowl playoffs -- must submit today the names of five players who will be available for next month's expansion draft to stock the roster of the 1999 Cleveland Browns.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Campbell Soup Warns Of Lower Earnings

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIND, GERALD
description: WIND-Gerald. Died Saturday, January 9, 1999 at the age of 70 after a long battle with ALS. A founder and pillar of the Jewish community of Monsey, N.Y. and current resident of Sunny Isles, Florida. He will be remembered for his generosity, sensitivity and fine character. Former President of Langen & Wind Color Labs and Gerry Wind & Associates. Loving husband of Phyllis, beloved father of Susan, Shalom, Ira, Debra (Krim) and Robert, grandfather of 8 grandchildren, brother of Sylvia Walkenfeld and Marion Klein. May his soul be bound in the bond of eternal life. Shiva will be observed until Friday morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ROSE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Rose. Age 75, West Palm Beach, Fl., formerly Director of Social Service, Jewish Home and Hospital for Aged, Bronx. Died January 8, following surgery. Services and interment Menorah Gardens, January 11th.

title: Fatal Van Accident Stokes Feud by Mayor and Council
description: A fatal accident involving an unlicensed livery van on Sunday provoked a fresh exchange yesterday between City Council members who favor greater control of the largely unregulated van industry and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who accused the Council of undermining a vital form of public transportation.

title: AGFA TO ADD AN AMERICAN DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING CONCERN
description: Bayer A.G., Europe's No. 2 chemicals maker, said yesterday that its Agfa-Gevaert film unit would buy Sterling Diagnostic Imaging Inc. of Greenville, S.C. The terms were not disclosed, but analysts estimated the price at $700 million. Sterling Diagnostic is a leading provider of X-ray film and equipment, with worldwide sales of about $500 million, Agfa said. Agfa is the world's third-largest maker of film; it also makes X-ray film and equipment and plates for newspaper printing. Sterling Diagnostic Imaging was spun off by DuPont in 1996 to private investors and is 30 percent owned by employees.

title: UNIFORM PROVIDER CINTAS TO BUY UNITOG FOR $357 MILLION
description: The Cintas Corporation, the largest publicly held American provider of uniforms, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Unitog Company for $38 a share, or about $357 million. The combined company would have about $1.8 billion in annual revenue and more than 200 uniform rental locations in 40 states and Canada. Cintas, based in Cincinnati, has about 18 percent of the market; Unitog, based in Kansas City, Mo., has about 5 percent. Shares of Unitog rose $5.5625, to $35.3125, while Cintas fell $4.875, to $67.125.

title: Quick Start for the Jets Is a Necessity
description: It has been so long since they have let a game get away from them -- back on Nov. 15, at Indianapolis -- that the Jets have forgotten what it is like to lose their heads, or become distracted, or get in a hole.

title: Lewinsky's Value as Witness Is Questioned
description: To the Editor:

title: Vallone Proposes Spending Tobacco Deal Money on Schools
description: Now that the city is expecting to receive more than $6.7 billion during the next quarter-century from a settlement with the tobacco industry, Speaker Peter F. Vallone of the City Council has emerged as the first to propose a plan on how to spend at least some of that windfall: on the repair and expansion of the city's deteriorating schools.

title: INSIDE
description: And Now, Microsoft's Turn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SECHY, ELISSE
description: SECHY-Elisse. Age 100 died January 7. Devoted member of the Oratorio Society of New York for almost half a century and its archivist for many years. Her old world charm and gentle demeanor endeared her to all. We loved her indomitable spirit and will sorely miss her. She requested that memorial contributions be made to the Oratorio Society of New York. Ellen L. Blair, President

title: Lewinsky's Value as Witness Is Questioned
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAGE, WALTER H.
description: PAGE-Walter H. Of Cold Spring Harbor, NY. Died January 8. Husband of Jane N. Page, who died December 15, 1998. He leaves three children, Jane Mallinson, Walter and Mark, and eight grandchildren. Memorial service at 12 noon, Wednesday, January 13, Saint John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, please donate to charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YORK, HERMAN II
description: YORK-Herman II. On January 11, 1999, of Upper Brookville, New York. Beloved husband for 53 years of Loretta H. Dear father of Kathleen A., and Richard C. (Stephanie). He was retired from Architectural Practice as a specialist in housing design; over 3/4 million homes have been built from York blueprints. In 1981 Mr. York was inducted into the National Housing Hall of Fame in Washington, D.C. He was a member of the American Institute of Architects, the First Presbyterian Church of Oyster Bay, and a member emeritus of the Greater New York Advisory board of the Salvation Army of which he was an active volunteer for 43 years. He served as a director emeritus of Jamaica Savings Bank. Visiting at the Francis P. DeVine Funeral Home Inc., 293 South Street Oyster Bay, NY Tuesday 35, 7-9 P.M. A memorial service will be held at the Long Island Lutheran High School Chapel, Brookville, NY on Saturday January 16, 1999 at 1 P.M. Interment Private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Long Island Lutheran High School, the Salvation Army, or a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CECILIO, LUIS P.
description: CECILIO-Luis P. On January 10, 1999, at age 90. Beloved husband of Jeanette (nee Cohen), loving father of Diane Lazinsky, & Alan Cecilio, devoted grandfather to Lauren, Cara, & Niki. Memorial services at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave, NYC, Wednesday January 13, from 6-9 P.M. Interment at Rosehills Memorial Park, Putnam Valley, NY. Donations in his memory can be made to Camp Sussex: 718-261-8700.

title: BIGGEST ONE-DAY GAIN IN 11 YEARS FOR G.M. STOCK
description: Shares in the General Motors Corporation rose 7.5 percent yesterday, the biggest one-day gain in more than 11 years, as higher-than-expected production in the fourth quarter fueled optimism that the company might earn record profits this year. The shares rose $6, to $86.0625. The company saw a 12 percent gain last week after it said it would increase production of pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles. G.M., the world's largest auto maker, is benefiting from unexpectedly strong American sales and from progress in cost-cutting, analysts said.

title: 'The Boy' With the Babe
description: To the Editor:

title: Carl Elliott, 85, Congressman From Alabama
description: Former Representative Carl Elliott, a Democrat from rural Alabama who sacrificed his political career to the principles of social justice, died Saturday at his home in Jasper, Ala. He was 85.

title: World Court Safeguards
description: To the Editor:

title: Seton Hall Joins Roster at Meet
description: The inaugural New York Sports Museum Collegiate Invitational, an indoor track meet, got bigger yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZISSU, FREDERICK
description: ZISSU-Frederick. The Laura Rosenberg Foundation extends deepest sympathy upon the loss of Fred Zissu, beloved father of Karen Magidson, Founder and Trustee. Our sincere condolences to the entire Magidson and Zissu families. The Laura Rosenberg Foundation

title: Sturdy Pillar of Turkey's Left Names Cabinet
description: Turkey's six-week-old political crisis appeared to end today when a strongly secular politician, Bulent Ecevit, announced that he had assembled a minority government. It is expected to win parliamentary approval by Sunday.

title: Review/Fashion; Now, Every Man a Sportsman
description: Nothing, it seems not an N.B.A. lockout nor thwarted balloon expeditions -- can dampen designers' enthusiasm for athletic inspirations. As it turns out, it is not outer space that will define the start of the new millennium in fashion, but sports -- those pastimes and professions that supply iconography and innocence at the same time.

title: State English Exam Tests Parents as Well as Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HSIA, WAI, TSUNG
description: HSIA-Wai-Tsung New. Wife of late Dr. Chin Lin Hsia. Died at age 98 peacefully at home January 9, 1999. Grandmother of David Jr., Judy, Peter and Lisa and five greatgrandchildren. Memorial service 10:00 AM. Saturday, January 16 at her church The Community Church of Great Neck.

title: State English Exam Tests Parents as Well as Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Briefing; What's in a Name? Ask Moseley-Braun
description: In politics, name recognition can often be, well, the name of the game.

title: Study Finds Athletes' Betting Pervasive
description: More than one of out every three student athletes playing in Division I have wagered money on sports during their college careers, a major new study of athletes and gambling said yesterday. But the study, by the University of Michigan, also reported evidence of a gender gap -- male athletes are far more likely to be betting than females, and far more likely as well to admit to things like providing inside information about their teams to others for gambling purposes, or to gambling on their own teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMCHANDANI, ATMA
description: RAMCHANDANI-Atma. The family of Atma C. Ramchandani celebrates his life and deeply mourns his passing on January 10, 1999 at age 95. Beloved husband of the late Savitri and dear father of Sunny and Prem. Grandfather of Ariel and Talia. He will be long remembered for his contribution to the building of the Institute of Electrical and Telecommunication Engineers and the introduction of TV into India through his leadership at All India Radio. He lived a full life and he will be fondly remembered by all who knew him.

title: Samsung Sells AST Brand of Computers
description: Samsung Group, one of South Korea's biggest conglomerates, said today that it had sold the brand name and patent rights of its unprofitable United States notebook computer unit, the latest South Korean company to retreat from an ill-timed investment in the United States.

title: Virginia P. Abelson, 72, Bookstore Owner
description: Virginia Eloise Peterson Abelson, a former bookstore owner and past Democratic Party district leader who also worked in publishing and created crossword puzzles, died on Sunday at her home in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. She was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREY, DAVID M.
description: GREY-David M. Film editor, died November 30, 1998. Memorial Mass Saturday, January 16th at 10:30 A.M. at Saint Edmund's R.C. Church, Rockaway Point, NY.

title: Should Stars Pitch Prescription Drugs?
description: Should drug companies use celebrities, like the Baltimore Orioles' Cal Ripken, in advertisements for prescription drugs? ALISHA BERGER

title: The Hospital, at Night
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL UP 2.8 PERCENT. Prices rose after an important Royal Dutch/Shell terminal in Nigeria was closed by protesters demanding a greater share of the revenue. Crude oil for February delivery rose 37 cents, to $13.44 a barrel.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the issue of calling witnesses in President Clinton's Senate trial misstated the party of Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana. He is a Democrat.

title: TEMBEC ACQUIRING BRITISH COLUMBIA FORESTRY CONCERN
description: Tembec Inc., a Canadian forestry company, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Crestbrook Forest Industries for about $70.4 million (Canadian), or $46.5 million (United States), in cash and stock plus around $200 million (Canadian) in assumed debt, adding to its pulp and lumber businesses. The Mitsubishi Corporation owns 30.7 percent of Crestbrook, which is based in Cranbrook, British Columbia, and the Oji Paper Company owns 20.4 percent. Tembec, based in Montreal, said it would offer Crestbrook holders the option of 0.51298 of a class A Tembec share or $4.50 (Canadian) in cash for each Crestbrook share. It will pay a maximum of $23.5 million in cash.

title: Keeping Harmony in the Marriage of Cells
description: In mythology, fire-breathing monsters with lions' heads, goats' bodies and serpents' tails are well-known chimeras.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Return To the Couch: A Revival For Analysis
description: Psychoanalysts, it would seem, have reason to be gloomy: These are difficult times for the couch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, FRANCES TAFT
description: STERN-Frances Taft. 95. Artist, teacher. On January 10, 1999 in Washington, D.C. Cherished wife of the late Hugo H. Stern, beloved sister of Howard Taft of Bloomington, IN., adored mother of sons, Carl of Washington, D.C. and George of Birmingham, MI. Dear mother-in-law of Joy and Fran. Loving grandmother of Larry, Teddy, Charles, Linda, and Julie. Great grandmother of Rachel, Samuel and Jacob. Services and interment were held in Detroit.

title: Brian Moore, Prolific Novelist On Diverse Themes, Dies at 77
description: Brian Moore, the author of 19 novels, including ''The Lonely Passion of Judith Hearne,'' died yesterday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 77.

title: Balance Drills, for the Sake of Safety
description: Statistics show that falls among older adults -- often the cause of serious injury -- can be prevented in many cases with a program of exercises specifically geared toward improving balance and posture.

title: A Down-Home, Folkie 60's Beck, Long on Quiet and Short on Theatrics
description: For a short stretch, Beck's concert on Sunday at Town Hall could have been a folk singer's show from the 1960's. Alone onstage, unassumingly dressed in jeans and a sweater, Beck played songs learned from old blues albums by Skip James and Mississippi John Hurt, dutifully finger-picking and singing about death and redemption. He also played a song of his own, ''One Foot in the Grave,'' making his harmonica hoot like a freight train. But the archival moment didn't last long. Beck is a 1990's musician who knows too much music to confine himself to folkie purism.

title: Finalists in Review By Discover Card
description: The Discover Card unit of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company has identified the finalists in a review that began in November to handle the creative and media parts of its account, with billings estimated at $70 million to $80 million.

title: Banyan Says Microsoft Is Buying Stake
description: Banyan Systems Inc., an Internet directory company, said today that the Microsoft Corporation would buy a 7.5 percent stake in the company for $10 million and work with Banyan to develop software programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPANJOL, BRUNA
description: SPANJOL-Bruna. 43. Survived by loving parents, brother, sister, niece and nephews. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 9:45AM, Most Precious Blood R.C. Church, Long Island City, New York.

title: Costly Cornflakes
description: Pity the company that courts Wall Street while offending its customers. Investors can turn out to be fickle friends, while customers bear grudges.

title: Williams Won't Let Agent Shop Market
description: Sal DiFazio wants to bluff. He wants to make threats, pound his fist on the table or even storm out of the room.

title: Banana Republic Clerk Is Charged With Fraud
description: A sales clerk at a Banana Republic store on the Upper East Side has been arrested and accused of defrauding the store out of more than $50,000 during the busy pre-Christmas rush, the police said yesterday.

title: U.S. More Isolated In U.N. on Keeping The Iraq Sanctions
description: The United States is finding itself increasingly isolated in its Iraq policy as a growing number of Security Council members and Arab nations support lifting an embargo on Iraqi oil sales or significantly relaxing sanctions in other ways to relieve the suffering of the Iraqi people.

title: ST. LOUIS
description: Philip Ozersky, the Cardinals fan who caught Mark McGwire's 70th home run, turned down well in excess of $2 million for the ball before deciding to put it up for auction tonight at Madison Square Garden, according to a person close to Ozersky who did not want to be identified.

title: Senate Democrats Debate the Timing of a Push for a Censure Deal
description: Just days before opening arguments in the impeachment trial of President Clinton begin in the Senate, Democrats are debating when would be the best time to try to put forward a censure resolution, with some advocating sooner rather than later.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: A Cloud Over Air Travel

title: Tom Stoppard In Love, With Shakespeare
description: With ''Shakespeare in Love,'' Tom Stoppard completes an arc that began in 1967 with ''Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead,'' his first produced stage play. Taken in the context of the playwright's other work, the two are primary instances of Mr. Stoppard in love -- with Shakespeare.

title: Peres Talks to Palestinian Council; Backs a New State
description: Far from the nasty bickering of the Israeli election campaign, Shimon Peres, the former Israeli Prime Minister, swept into Ramallah today with a covey of fellow Nobel Peace Prize winners to promote his vision of peace, delivering the first address by an Israeli to the Palestinian legislative council.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRORBAUGH, ELEANOR MORGAN
description: DRORBAUGH-Eleanor Morgan, 77, of Princeton, NJ on January 9, 1999. Wife of Wells, mother of Daniel and Hilary Drorbaugh Propst. Sister of Arthur & Richard Morgan and Diana Morgan Olcott. Grandmother of Thomas, aunt to several nieces & nephews. A memorial service will be held on January 30 at 11AM at the Bristol Chapel at Westminster Choir College, Princeton. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Westminster Choir College of Rider University, 101 Walnut Lane, Princeton or to YWCA Tumble Bus Project Paul Robeson Place, Princeton, N.J. 08540.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: The Ultimate Celebrity Sound Bite
description: Everything seems to be coming to an end. As 1999 began, it became impossible to escape our proximity to the end of the millennium, which has left the anxious with the task of worrying about the end of electronic civilization, and the apocalyptic worrying about the end of the world. It seems a melancholy situation. But an unlikely source may provide relief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARDONO, CHARLES
description: SARDONO-Charles. The Board of Directors, Tenants/Shareholders and employees of 480 Park Avenue express our heartfelt sorrow at the untimely passing of our longtime employee and friend. Mr. Sardono's concern and manner were always appreciated by those who knew him as he cheerfully performed his responsibilities and more during the past 27 years. Our thoughts and codolences are with his wife Theresa and children Charles Jr. and Margaret. 480 Park Avenue

title: Sinus Surgery at Edge of the Brain Gets Safer
description: It is early on a winter morning at the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary here, and Dr. Ralph Metson is executing what has been until now one of the most demanding, difficult and dangerous procedures in the treatment of sinus disease.

title: Tea Ceremonies to Zen: Japanese Culture With a Wink
description: Advance material on ''Contemporary Dance and Theater,'' presented on Saturday night at the Japan Society, suggested all sorts of new adventures in punkdom and cyberland. For better or worse, those promises were not delivered.

title: Baryshnikov Flirts With Kabuki
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov has specialized in unearthing the unusual in dance. Now he is branching out again. Tonight he will perform choreography drawn from traditional Japanese forms in ''Dance With Three Drums and Flute,'' a new solo created for him by the Kabuki star Tamasaburo Bando. The piece will be performed in Mr. Baryshnikov's single performance at St. Mark's Danspace Project in the East Village to raise money for Dancers Responding to AIDS.

title: Small Plane Crashes in New Jersey, Killing Pilot
description: A small twin-engine plane crashed into a freight yard in Kearny, N.J., yesterday, instantly killing the pilot, the plane's sole occupant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, LEON M.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Leon M. The City College of New York mourns the passing of President Leon M. Goldstein of Kingsborough Community College, who was also a distinguished alumnus of CCNY. Under his leadership, Kingsborough became one of the nation's most innovative and successful community colleges. President Goldstein also rendered valuable service to CUNY as Acting Chancellor and in other important positions. On behalf of the City College community, I wish to extend my deepest sympathy to his family. Yolanda T. Moses, President The City College of New York/ CUNY

title: Grand Jury to Hear Sex-Abuse Charges Against Veteran Detective
description: A New York City police detective has been charged with sexual abuse and other crimes in a case in which prosecutors say he exposed himself and asked for oral sex from a female robbery suspect, the detective's lawyer said yesterday.

title: Keep Pollard Locked Up, Clinton Aides Recommend
description: President Clinton's national security advisers have recommended that Mr. Clinton deny clemency to Jonathan Jay Pollard, an American who spied for Israel, Administration officials said today.

title: Campbell Sees Profit Slide After a Bad Season for Soup
description: Blaming the weather for sluggish sales of its biggest brand, the Campbell Soup Company warned yesterday that its earnings in the current quarter and fiscal year would be off by 18 to 23 cents a share, significantly lower than analysts had expected.

title: Smoking Ban Has Not Hurt Restaurants, Analysts Say
description: Since the city banned smoking in restaurants in 1995, restaurateurs have complained that the prohibition is bad for business. Yesterday, a group of academic researchers, admittedly anti-smoking ones, released a series of six analyses suggesting that the ban has not hurt.

title: Among Doctors, Pay for Women Still Lags
description: Women in medicine have made phenomenal strides over the past 30 years. They are everywhere, in every specialty, and they account for half of all medical students; women even play doctors on television -- with their trusty husky male nurses, of course.

title: Sports of The Times; Parcells Has More Tricks In Reserve
description: IT wasn't Keyshawn's receptions and it wasn't Keyshawn's end-around plays. It wasn't even the sight of Keyshawn sticking his loquacious head into a scrum and coming up with a loose ball.

title: Congo's Struggle May Unleash Broad Strife to Redraw Africa
description: The new chairman of Congo's state-owned mining company is not from Congo. He is a 39-year-old transport tycoon and former race car driver from Zimbabwe, Billy Rautenbach. Congo's President calls him ''Mr. Billy.''

title: State English Exam Tests Parents as Well as Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Netanyahu's Likud Mentor Says He'll Challenge Protege
description: Today came the clearest sign yet of just how much Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has estranged the Israeli political establishment, left and right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESTENBAUM, MILDRED
description: KESTENBAUM-Mildred. In her 101st year. Devoted wife of the late Philip. Loving mother of Ethel and Joseph Renick, Pearl and Dr. Jonas Zucker, Rabbi Leon and Vivian Kestenbaum, Roslyn and Rabbi David Clayman. Devoted grandmother and great grandmother. Beloved sister of Yetta Kestenbaum and the late Martin and Joseph Braff and Bella Glick. Member of YIFR and Amit Women. Shiva at her home.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Nobody is really sure why Medicare spending has slowed down quite as much as it has. The only thing we can be sure of is that it won't last.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRENTICE, REGINA COHEN
description: PRENTICE-Regina Cohen. A true lady who enjoyed and cherished life's most precious gifts: a loving and adoring family, many dear friends and love, love, love! Dearly loved and always unconditionally loving mother, sister, nana, ''G.G.'' and aunt, of: Linda and Matty Matluck, and David Prentice; Bebe and Bert Stern; Michael and Beth, Mitchell and Susie, and Wendy Rice; Jamie, Jacob, Sam and Nathan Rice; Fran and Fred Stern. We all will miss you so. Services will be held at I.J. Morris in Lake Worth, FL, Monday, January 11, at 10 AM, and at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, NY, at noon, on Tuesday, January 12.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGNER, NORMAN
description: WAGNER-Norman. On January 10, 1999. Beloved father of Howard. Loving brother of Elaine Gilbert. Cherished companion of Caroline Uy. Services Wednesday, 12 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINKOFF, LEONARD
description: MINKOFF-Leonard. Beloved husband of Phyllis, devoted father of Jerome and Marjorie, Ellen, Sharon and Andrew Elias and fond brother of Walter, loving grandfather of Jacob and Benjamin, Alexandra, Sam, Zack, and Claire. Funeral services are at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York, on Wednesday, January 13th at 3 P.M. Contributions may be made to Womens' American ORT.

title: Foreign Affairs; A Dangerous Peace
description: Some statesmen are remembered for having crossed the Rubicon. Israel's Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, will be remembered for swimming laps in the Rubicon. Bibi is the Mark Spitz of Israeli politics -- no Israeli leader has ever crisscrossed the Rubicon faster or more often.

title: Threat of Fire Leads to Request For Wiring Checks on Planes
description: Canadian investigators have found extensive wiring problems on several MD-11 airplanes, and United States safety experts say more inspections are needed to avert the threat of in-flight fires.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a former South African police officer who was denied amnesty in connection with the death of the anti-apartheid campaigner Steve Biko in 1977 misspelled the officer's surname. He is Gideon Nieuwoudt, not Niewhoudt.

title: Tax Break Ruling Angers Advocates of Cheaper Power
description: Even as it pushes for market competition as a means to cheaper electricity, the Pataki administration has withdrawn a tax break granted to businesses and individuals that shop around for a power company.

title: Parcells Wants to Weed Out Errors
description: The two old friends, a pair of obsessive coaches, were gabbing in the Giants Stadium parking lot Sunday night.

title: A New Stage And Lineup For Concerts At Carnegie
description: Plans for Carnegie Hall's third concert space, a flexible, technologically up-to-date chamber music hall that is scheduled to open during the 2001-2002 season, were formally unveiled yesterday.

title: Finding Opportunity Where Others See Impossibility
description: When he was 14 and growing up in 1950's Poland, Bohdan Paczynski started observing the flashing and flaring of the double stars called binaries through a 10-inch telescope outside his hometown of Warsaw. Now, with the constellation Orion gently shimmering over his shoulder like an alighting falcon, Dr. Paczynski stands on a bridge above Lake Carnegie on a chilly evening here and explains his proposal to record panoramic images of the entire sky -- all of it -- several times each and every night, ''endlessly,'' as he puts it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRYSDALE, JEANNE BOLDEN
description: DRYSDALE-Jeanne Bolden. 69 years, on January 8. Survived by her sister Barbara, children David, Susan, Roger, and six grandchildren. Services, Rosedale Funeral Home: 718-528-1180.

title: Gore Offers Plan to Control Suburban Sprawl
description: Almost 50 years after new Federal highways and the G.I. Bill made it easier for Americans to move from crowded cities to leafy suburbs, the Clinton Administration is proposing an ambitious program to combat the modern-day consequences of the exodus: traffic jams and sprawl.

title: Metro Business; Residential Property Shows Loss in Value
description: Manhattan residential real estate prices dipped in the fourth quarter -- the first decline in more than a year -- amid concern about the stock market, according to a study by Halstead Property Company.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Sticking Together

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, ZALMAN
description: BERNSTEIN-Zalman. The Boca Raton Judaic Fellows Program and the Yeshiva High School of Broward, Dade, and Palm Beach County mourns the loss of one of the great Jewish leaders of our generation, Zalman Chaim Bernstein. Zalman was not only a visionary, he gave life to his dreams by creating the Avi Chai Foundation. His commitment to all Jews served as a role model of tolerance and ''Ahavat Chinam'' for the Jewish community. I will always be in his debt for the times he sat with me in his efforts to guide, support and advise. May his wife Mem, mother, Martha and his children Claude, Leslie and Rochel Leah be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Israel. Rabbi Kenneth Brander, Dean

title: 2 More Antiaircraft Incidents in North Iraq
description: American fighter jets attacked antiaircraft batteries in northern Iraq in two skirmishes today as Baghdad continued its defiance of American and British control of its skies.

title: Excerpts From President Clinton's Response to the Articles of Impeachment
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's response to the summons of the Senate to appear for trial, as provided by the White House, but with subheadings provided by The Times:

title: Tribute to Jean Dalrymple
description: A memorial tribute to the producer and former publicist Jean Dalrymple will be held at City Center, 131 West 55th Street in Manhattan, on Thursday at 5 P.M. Among those scheduled to take part in the tribute, which is open to the public, are the singers Barbara Cook and Paula Laurence, the conductor Julius Rudel, and Judith Daykin, president and executive director of City Center. Ms. Dalrymple, who helped found City Center in 1943 and produced musicals and plays there, died on Nov. 15 at the age of 96.

description: To the Editor:

title: Lewinsky's Value as Witness Is Questioned
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITVACK, GEORGE
description: LITVACK-George, 91. Died January 9. Beloved husband of Fannie for 65 years. Loving father of Elaine, Burton and Phyllis. Grandfather of Peter, Steven, Debby, Gregg, Justin and, Emily. Greatgrandfather of Shana, Gillian and Brandon. Loving brother of Saul. Saul, Florence,Howard, Gail, Jay

title: Coaching Carousel Adds 2, Subtracts 1
description: The coaching merry-go-round in the National Football League spun wildly yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, MAURICE E.
description: FISCHER-Maurice E. Died on Sunday, January 10, in Southbury. He was the husband of Suzanne (Carey) Fischer, he was born January 1, 1912 in NYC. He spent his entire business career with United Merchants & Manufacturers of New York City where he attained the office of Executive Vice President and Director. He was also President of United Factors Corporation, the factoring subsidiary of UMM. United Factors was sold to the Crocker National Bank of San Francisco in 1978 where Mr. Fischer was employed as consultant and Vice Chairman of the Board of Directors of Crocker United Factor. Mr. Fischer was a Veteran of World War II, and had moved to Southbury 17 years ago. Besides his wife he is survived by two sons, Robert J. Fischer of San Clemente, CA., John W. Fischer of Boone, NC, a daughter Margaret Ann Rappaport of Bloomfield Hills, MI, children by his first wife Norma L. Fischer of Farmington Hills, MI. by his step-daughter Christine Saranga of Atlanta, GA., a brother Harry B. Fischer of McLean, VA, eight grandchildren, three nephews and a niece. Funeral services are private. Memorial contributions may be made to the Lutheran Home, 900 Main Street, North Southbury, CT. 06488.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABELSON, VIRGINIA ELOISE PETERSON
description: ABELSON-Virginia Eloise Peterson. Beloved wife of Alan, mother of Reed and Justin, grandmother of Robbie, Evan, Emily and Claire. Dear friend of the Van Liews. A memorial service is planned for the spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REILLY, CATHERINE
description: REILLY-Catherine. We note with sorrow the passing of Catherine Reilly, beloved mother of our dear Kathy Reilly who is our right hand and like a member of our family. The Lifton Family

title: Senators' Hex on Devils Is Extended
description: The Ottawa Senators, who were pushovers for the Devils in their first three years in the league, have become a nemesis the last three seasons.

title: Political Briefing; Anti-Tobacco Hero Rethinks a 2000 Race
description: As the first state Attorney General to win a health-costs settlement from the nation's tobacco companies -- it was worth a whopping $4 billion -- Michael Moore is a hero to many Mississippians and something of a legal icon in the anti-tobacco movement. So when Mr. Moore announced in October that he would try to parlay his popularity into higher office by running for governor in 1999, political handicappers made him the favorite to succeed the current Governor, Kirk Fordice, who cannot seek a third term under state law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENMAN, ANNA LILY
description: EISENMAN-Anna Lily. On January 10, 1999, in Florida. Devoted mother of Bernard and Rita Schifrin and mother-in-law of Della Eisenman and Sol Schifrin. Cherished grandmother of Roberta Bogash, Dr. Richard Eisenman, Ronald Eisenman, Karen Grosso, and Emily Chamberlain. Great grandmother of Robyn and Ross Bogash, Jonathan, Debra, Gregory, Heather, and Robert Eisenman. Sister of Dorothy Mark. She will be lovingly remembered and greatly missed by her family. Services will be graveside at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y. on Wednesday at 11 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, MARTIN LEWIS III
description: COHN-Martin Lewis III. The Trustees and staff of New York University School of Medicine extend their deepest condolences to Laurence Tisch, distinguished former Chairman of the Board of New York University, and his wife Billie on the loss of their brotherin-law Martin L. Cohn. Family members and friends who wish to make a contribution in memory of Mr. Cohn are requested to send their checks to NYU School of Medicine, Office of Development, Martin Cohn Fund, 316 East 30 Street, New York, N.Y. 10016. Robert M. Glickman, M.D. Dean, NYU School of Medicine

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: A Diamond Cartel May Be Forever; The Hereditary Leader of De Beers Pursues Post-Apartheid Growth
description: A diamond cartel is forever.

title: Jobs for Cambodians  or Sweatshops?
description: PHNOM PENH  At dawn each day, hundreds of shift workers file into garment factories dotted around a city that just over two decades ago was virtually an empty shell.

title: Whitman Preschool Plan Puts Focus on How to Run and Expand Classes
description: When Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced a plan last week to provide full-day preschool to 3- and 4-year-olds in 28 poor urban school districts in New Jersey, she raised the stakes in a debate about how best to educate children barely out of diapers.

title: Rebellion Grows In Managed Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Shares End Mixed as Nasdaq Rallies but Blue Chips Falter
description: Stocks ended mixed yesterday, with many issues pulling back after last week's rally to record highs raised investors' concerns that the market was getting too expensive.

title: Way Too Tethered to Roll on the Beach
description: When Sparky Watts first shows up at a naval base outside Tokyo in ''Far East,'' A. R. Gurney's uneven but poignant new play at Lincoln Center, his future is in his face. It's an open face, transfused with that raw hopefulness often seen in young men starting the first chapter of their adulthood. Yet there is also a trace of anxiety, of defensiveness in his eager smile, a sense that whatever hopes he may harbor are somehow already under siege.

title: Mergers and acquisitions on Madison Avenue continue to be alive and well in the new year.
description: ANY lingering doubts that 1999 would be another year of frenetic deal-making along Madison Avenue are being dispelled with a spate of agreements involving agencies specializing in assignments as disparate as retail advertising, entertainment marketing, employee communications and direct marketing.

title: Bank One Ends Role With Martin
description: The Bank One Corporation said yesterday that it had ended a 10-year relationship with the Martin Agency in Richmond, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, and would begin a review on its account. Billings were estimated at $60 million.

title: Executive Leaving Saatchi & Saatchi
description: Joe McDonagh, executive creative director at Saatchi & Saatchi Los Angeles in Torrance, Calif., who has been the force behind the ''Everyday'' campaign for Toyota Motor Sales USA, is becoming executive creative director at the Los Angeles office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group P.L.C.

title: Stretches Make the Arms Grow Stronger
description: A recent study indicates that adding stretching to a weight-training routine may actually improve strength, in addition to increasing flexibility.

title: To Love, Honor and Flirt Wildly
