description: In a nation where a Puritan past remains at odds with an often licentious present, a man uses his position and reputation to seduce the women in the circle around him.

title: Judge Says Rappers and State Share Blame in a Fatal Crush
description: In a blistering decision, a state judge has found New York State and two well-known rap performers equally responsible for a 1991 stampede at a City College gymnasium that killed nine young people and injured 29 others.

title: Of Tortoises, Hares and the Peopling of Earth
description: The tortoise and the hare, paired together in Aesop's fable, have been reunited by archeologists in an ingenious index for measuring the growth rate of early human populations.

title: A Frayed Deal With North Korea
description: A new and potentially volatile crisis is brewing between the United States and North Korea. Pyongyang's reckless behavior threatens to unravel a 1994 nuclear agreement with Washington. That would effectively end diplomatic dialogue between the two countries and could lead to heightened military tensions on the Korean Peninsula. Late last year the Clinton Administration appointed William Perry, the former Defense Secretary, to review American policy toward the North. He is now trying to learn more about what Pyongyang is up to and to see if the growing tensions can be diminished.

title: Campaigns: New Law, New Suit?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, JANET
description: ZUCKERMAN-Janet. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its devoted longtime member and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Marjorie Miller, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Kenneth M. Chasen, Asst. Rabbi Laurie Katz Braun, Asst. Rabbi

title: Enron Wins German Power Supply Deal
description: Enron Energie G.m.b.H., a subsidiary of the Enron Corporation of Houston, has won the right to supply electricity in Germany after Elektromark, the country's grid operator, withdrew its previous objections to such an agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOARTY, ANN E.
description: HOARTY-Ann E. Of East Atlantic Beach, NY on January 11, 1999. Beloved sister of Alice, Thomas and the late Lt. Michael J., Patrick J. Hoarty. Also survived by many nieces and nephews and grand nieces and grand nephews. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc., 52 Clinton Ave, Rockville Centre, N.Y. Tuesday 7-9 PM and Wednesday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral mass on Thursday 9:30 AM at St. Ignatius Martyr RC Church, Long Beach, New York. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; All is right with the world (well, not so bad, at least), and U.S. Treasuries are in the doldrums.
description: THE Treasury market, an unexpectedly fine performer last year, is not looking so attractive right now. And it may take another rush of panic about the world's economy and global financial stability to turn things around.

title: Corrections
description: A schedule yesterday for the Senate's impeachment trial proceedings referred incorrectly to the Fox News Channel's plans. It indeed announced them; it is scheduling continuous coverage.

title: Gauging Value on Seats and Suites
description: Last September, when Alfred Lerner bought the expansion Cleveland Browns for $530 million, Howard Milstein insisted that the economics of the deal kept him from budging above $450 million. On Sunday, Milstein and his partner, Daniel Snyder, agreed to pay the estate of Jack Kent Cooke $800 million for the Washington Redskins and their stadium, the most ever paid for a domestic sports franchise.

title: Europe Dumping Inquiry
description: The European Commission said today that it had opened an inquiry into whether Taiwan, India, Iran, South Africa, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia had been dumping steel in Europe and that it might raise tariffs to fight imports that have cut prices 40 percent in the last year. The commission has between two and nine months to decide whether to impose punitive antidumping duties on imports of hot rolled steel coils.

title: PRESIDENT OFFERS FORMAL ARGUMENT AGAINST REMOVAL
description: President Clinton formally defended himself today for the first time against removal from office by the Senate, arguing that he committed no crimes and that the charges against him are so vague and muddled that they are unconstitutional.

title: A Successful Journey From Delusion to Reality
description: When Ramon Lebron saw Neil Armstrong walking on the moon in 1969, he thought he was up there with him.

title: Rebellion Grows In Managed Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAUB, FAITH HUSSEY
description: STAUB-Faith Hussey. 73. Died peacefully after a long illness, surrounded by her loving family. Born in New York City, daughter of the late Rear Admiral and Mrs. Charles Lincoln Hussey , of Washington, D.C., and Litchfield, CT. She attended the Potomac School in Washington, D.C., graduated The Masters School, Dobbs Ferry, NY, and attended Bennington College. A long time resident of Stamford, CT and Litchfield, CT, she is survived by her husband, John Howard Staub II, of Litchfield, CT, and six children, Mrs. Sharon H. Doty, of Litchfield, CT, Mr. John Howard Staub III, of New York City, Dr. Charles L.H. Staub, of Litchfield, CT, Mrs. Leighton H. Laughlin, Jr., of Skillman, NJ, Mrs. John J. Huston, Jr., of Lawrenceville, NJ, and Mr. Nicholas E. Staub, of Mount Laurel, NJ. She is also survived by fifteen grandchildren, and her faithful caregiver, Yolanta Mickunaite. She will be missed by those who had the priviledge of knowing her and who were the recipients of her generous and kind nature. We will all miss our ''queen'' and are thankful for all the good years we shared with her. Services will be held at 3 P.M. Thursday January 14th at Saint Michael's Church, South Street, Litchfield, CT. In lieu of flowers, a donation in her memory may be made to The Litchfield Volunteer Ambulance, On The Green, Litchfield, CT 06759 or The Charlotte Hungerford Hospital, Litchfield Road, Torrington, CT. 06790.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RITZENBERG, MILTON
description: RITZENBERG-Milton. 85. Of Washington, DC. Builder and Breeder of thoroughbred race horses, passed away on Friday, January 8, 1999. He was a graduate of Rensselaer College. Mr. Ritzenberg was past president of the Virginia Thoroughbred Association and board member of the Morven Park Equine Center. He raced extensively in England as well as in the United States. He was also a patron of the arts and affiliated with the National Gallery of Art in Washington, DC and the Virginia Museum of Art in Richmond. He is survived by his beloved wife, Grace, daughter Toni and sister Adelle (Bert) Tracy. He was the brother of the late Saul Ritzenberg. Also survived by numerous nieces and nephews. A private interment was held on Monday, January 11, 1999. Memorial Contributions may be made to the Washington Home Hospice, 3720 Upton Street, NW, Washington, DC 20016

title: Chief Resigns Shared Post At Goldman
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company shook up senior management yesterday after suffering steep losses in bond trading and delaying its plan to go public last year, with Jon S. Corzine, the co-chairman and chief executive, withdrawing from day-to-day management.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONSON, WILLIAM BERGEN
description: SIMONSON-William Bergen ''Si'' of Mineola, N.Y. on Jan. 11, 1999. (Retired Guidance Counsellor and Athletics Coach-Camp To-Ho-Ne, Great Barrington, Mass.) Beloved husband of Rita. Devoted father of Virginia Bushart and William Simonson and father-in-law of Jerry Bushart. Loving grandfather of Timothy and Christopher Bushart. Dear brother of the late Franklin Simonson. Visiting Tuesday, 79PM; Wednesday 2-2 and 7-9 PM, Cassidy Funeral Home, 156 Willis Ave, Mineola. Funeral service 10AM Thursday, First Presbyterian Church of Mineola. Interment Greenfield Cemetery. Memorials to The Alzheimer's Assoc., 66 South St., Patchoque, N.Y. 11772.

title: METAMOR WORLDWIDE IN $285 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR SPR
description: Metamor Worldwide Inc., a computer staffing and services company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy SPR Inc. for about $285 million in stock, or $20.80 a share, as it expands its information technology consulting business. The purchase would create a company with expected revenue in 1999 of about $1.25 billion and 8,200 employees. Metamor, based in Houston, said that the purchase would help it expand its consulting to users of mainframe computers, since SPR specializes in helping businesses use mainframes for new applications, including data warehousing. Shares of Metamor fell $2.50, to $26. Shares of SPR, based in Oak Brook, Ill., rose $2.2813, to $20.0938.

title: The Dream of Eternal Flight Begins to Take Wing
description: Like giant feathers slowing rising on the winds to impossible heights, large gossamer wings made of wispy plastics and light composite materials are flying at altitudes where few airplanes have soared.

title: Complexity as Simplicity's Twin
description: That George Balanchine's ballets are not to everyone's taste is as true as the fact that Mozart is hardly up everyone's alley. But it is a hard heart that cannot recognize Balanchine's genius in ''Le Tombeau de Couperin,'' which was the final entry, along with ''Duo Concertant,'' in the New York City Ballet's ''Balanchine Black and White Celebration.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRANSTON, JEANNETTE
description: CRANSTON-Jeannette, 72. In Stamford, CT, January 10. Survived by her husband, George, their children, Jane, Peter, Judith, Kevin, and Margaret; grandchildren Peter, Catherine and Amber and by her sister, Marilyn Farrell. Funeral services at St. Maurice's Church in Stamford January 13 at 10 a.m. Visiting hours January 12 from 2-4 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. at Leo Gallagher & Sons, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, CT 203-327-1313.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORBER, RUTH
description: LORBER-Ruth. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its long-time member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: On Clinical Trials
description: To the Editor:

title: Lucent to Buy Kenan for $1.45 Billion, but Is Quiet on Possible Acquisition of Ascend
description: Lucent Technologies said yesterday that it would buy the Kenan Systems Corporation, a leader in billing software, but declined to talk about the far bigger deal on Wall Street's mind, a possible acquisition of Ascend Communications Inc., a leading data communications equipment maker.

title: First Goal For Knicks Is Signing Of Ward
description: It was like a mixer, casual attire only. Topped with a hairdo from the Bob Marley collection, an amiable Charles Oakley popped into the Knicks' facility and met his replacement, Marcus Camby, without incident.

title: French Pigment Maker Bids for British Rival
description: The French company Imetal S.A., the world's third-biggest maker of pigments to whiten paper, offered $:680 million ($1.1 billion) in cash for a rival, English China Clays P.L.C., but English China rejected the offer as too low.

title: British American Tobacco Will Buy Rothmans
description: British American Tobacco P.L.C. announced plans today to acquire Rothmans International for about $7.5 billion, the biggest but probably not the last cigarette-industry combination this year.

title: Body Is Found on Tracks Of L.I.R.R. in Brooklyn
description: The body of a man who had apparently been struck by a train was discovered yesterday morning on the tracks of the Long Island Rail Road in Brooklyn, railroad officials said.

title: Rebellion Grows In Managed Care
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: Timothy R. O'Connor, advertising director at Premiere magazine, published by the Hachette Filipacchi Magazines unit of Lagardere Group, was promoted to associate publisher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUSSEAU, JOHN L.
description: DUSSEAU-John L. On January 9, 1999, resident of Waverly Heights in Gladwyne, PA, age 86 years, retired Vice President and Editor-inChief of W.B. Saunders Company, Inc. Pre-deceased by his wife of 41 years, Audrey Augustine Dusseau, and by his second wife of 14 years, the former Sheila Sloane. Survived by his friend, Edna Cathcart. Mr. Dusseau requested that no formal service mark his passing. Memorial gifts may be sent to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, 2150 Towne Centre Place, Suite 120, Anaheim, CA 92806, or to Haverford College, c/o Development Office, 370 Lancaster Avenue, Haverford, PA 19041

title: Supreme Court Denies Appeal By Sex Shops
description: Capping a string of unbroken legal victories for the Giuliani administration, the United States Supreme Court refused yesterday to hear an appeal from sex shop owners and the New York Civil Liberties Union that a new antipornography zoning law is an unconstitutional infringement on free speech.

title: With a Debt to Fascinating Rhythm
description: During his brief life, George Gershwin exercised a lasting influence on many of the traditionally trained composers of concert music in his day, who responded by incorporating elements of jazz and popular song into their works. By example, Gershwin also empowered colleagues in jazz and on Broadway to believe that they had something of value to say in the genres of concert music and opera.

title: REVLON TO ELIMINATE AT LEAST 1,000 JOBS WORLDWIDE
description: Revlon Inc., the largest United States maker of cosmetics sold in discount chains and drugstores, said yesterday that it would cut 1,000 to 1,200 jobs worldwide, or about 7 percent of its work force, to lower costs as sales decline. Revlon, which also sells Colorstay and Almay makeup, also said that lenders had agreed to waive terms in its credit agreement and that it would take a charge of about $80 million, including $40 million for the fourth quarter of 1998. Revlon, based in New York, is 83 percent owned by the New York investor Ronald O. Perelman. The company's sales have been hurt by loss of consumer buying power in Asia, Russia and Latin America as well as inventory cutbacks at American drugstores.

title: Insurer to Sell Subsidiary and Take Charges
description: Renaissance Re Holdings Ltd., a catastrophe reinsurer based here, said today that it was putting its Nobel Insurance business up for sale -- seven months after buying it -- following higher-than-expected claims.

title: A Microsoft Bug Could Make Some Early Birds an Hour Later
description: As if all the panic over the infamous Year 2000 computer glitch were not enough of a problem, experts now reveal that the omission of a single equal sign has created a time-related error in the Microsoft Corporation's Windows family of operating systems that will next appear on April 1, 2001.

title: Golden Withdraws From Competition
description: Mike Golding, the English yachtsman who was a favorite to win the Around Alone solo sailboat race around the world, has dropped out of the eight-month competition.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a meeting between Prime Minister Massimo D'Alema of Italy and Pope John Paul II misidentified the archdiocese of Michele Cardinal Giordano, whose investigation by Italian law enforcement officials is a source of friction between the Vatican and the Italian Government. Cardinal Giordano is the Archbishop of Naples, not Milan. A picture caption with the article referred incorrectly to Mr. D'Alema's two children. He has a son and a daughter, not two daughters.

title: In Another Blow to N.B.A., Jordan Is Said to Be Retiring
description: Michael Jordan, basketball's pre-eminent player and the world's best-known athlete, will retire from the National Basketball Association for the second time in five years, according to three officials in the N.B.A. with knowledge of Jordan's plans. They said last night that they expected the Chicago Bulls star to make an announcement tomorrow at a news conference in Chicago.

title: New York Is Striving for Multiyear Deal With Jeter
description: Derek Jeter, the Yankees' All-Star shortstop, is eligible for salary arbitration for the first time this year. But Brian Cashman, the Yankees' general manager, may try to circumvent that process by negotiating a multiyear contract with Jeter. He opened discussions with Jeter's agent in two phone conversations last week.

title: Internet Issues Continue to Rise As Investor Interest Stays High
description: On a day when investors seemed cool toward other stocks, they continued their love affair with shares of Internet companies.

title: Managers Offer the Details Of the Case Against Clinton
description: Representative Henry J. Hyde and the 12 other impeachment managers today presented a road map of the case for removing President Clinton that they plan to make to the Senate beginning on Thursday.

title: High Court Declines to Review Ruling Seen as Software Boon
description: The Supreme Court today left intact a decision saying that mathematical algorithms used in computer programs can be patented, giving a powerful new legal tool to software developers and financial services companies.

title: In Shift, U.S. Reaches Deal For Plea by 3 In Gotti Case
description: In a surprise move, Federal prosecutors yesterday reached plea bargain deals with three co-defendants of John A. Gotti, the reputed acting boss of the Gambino crime family, in a broad racketeering case.

title: A Saner Approach On Caesarean Issue
description: When my twin sons were born 29 years ago, fetal monitoring was not a routine part of labor and delivery, and there was no way to be certain the babies were doing O.K. while my uterus tried in vain to expel them. So when the doctor announced after many anxious hours of unproductive labor that he was going to have to deliver them by Caesarean, my response was, ''I don't care if I cough them up as long as they're alive and healthy.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the resignation of Paul Atanasio as a trustee of the New York City School Construction Authority misidentified one of the city agencies that jointly issued a report critical of his role in hiring a project supervisor at a school where a falling brick killed a girl last January. Along with the office of the construction authority's inspector general, the issuing agency was the Department of Investigation, not the city schools' office of the special commissioner of investigation.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
description: The Microsoft Corporation began its defense in the Government's antitrust lawsuit today with an economist from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology bearing a massive tome of written testimony with a simple message: Microsoft's business practices are good for consumers, and any Government meddling with the software industry would likely do more harm than good.

title: Q & A
description: Evergreen or Not?

title: Potvin Shows His Rust In Debut for Islanders
description: The Islanders resembled a traveling circus today, with sideshows on and off the ice.

title: Rebellion Grows In Managed Care
description: To the Editor:

title: China Gives Foreign Creditors a Rude 1999 Awakening
description: China's relations with the international banking world may go into a deep freeze after its decision over the weekend not to bail out foreign creditors of a debt-ridden investment-trust company.

title: N.B.A. Subpoenaed in A.B.L. Probe
description: After settling its labor dispute, the National Basketball Association now faces a legal question: did it use its economic muscle to unfairly block the American Basketball League off the court and into bankruptcy?

title: Ammirati Puris Buys Agency in Chicago
description: Ammirati Puris Lintas Chicago, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, said yesterday that it had acquired Columbian Advertising Inc. in Chicago, an integrated marketing agency with estimated billings of $60 million. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Study of Public Universities Advises Changing Faculty of the Future
description: A new report by administrators and trustees of public universities urges that the nation's expanding number of part-time instructors be better paid and more fully integrated into their institutions while tenured professors be subject to reviews ending in reward or punishment.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Demands and Questions Over River's Taint
description: No one expects pristine purity from the waterways of Providence. They are urban rivers in an old factory city that is trying hard to get born again, and for all their recent beautification -- the new embankment parks, promenade, popular summer night ''waterfire'' displays, even a gondola -- they are still partly tainted by decades of industrial pollution.

title: Lewis, the Veteran, Is Enjoying the Ride
description: Kerry Kittles stood in the corner of a room at Chelsea Piers on Monday night looking over the crowd at a Muscular Dystrophy Association gala. As other athletes moved about, he asked excitedly, ''Which one is Mo Lewis?''

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Dec. 8 in The Natural World, a special section, with an article about environmental education, misidentified a student shown on a field trip to Johnson Creek in Portland, Ore. He was Alex Thomson, not Jared Blackwell. A teacher mentioned the error to the writer about two weeks ago, but word was delayed in reaching the editors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGS, EDITH FISCHER
description: BERGS-Edith Fischer, on January 11, 1999, of Nashville, Tennessee, formerly of Great Neck, New York, beloved wife of the late Norman Bergs and devoted mother of Jayne B. Workman and Mitchell Bergs; mother-in-law of Dr. Robert J. Workman, M.D. & grandmother of David and Elizabeth Workman. Former teacher in the Great Neck Schools, followed by a career in social work in the Mineola Department of Human Services. Services to be held at 10:30AM on Thursday Jan. 14 at Louis Suburban Chapels, 13-01 Broadway, Fairlawn, New Jersey, (201-791-0015, followed by burial at Riverside Cemetery, 12 Market Street, Saddle Brook, New Jersey (Route 80, Exit 62B; 201843-7600). Donations should be sent to the Cancer Research Institute, 681 Fifth Avenue, New York, New York 10022.

title: Pollard's Release Sets a Bad Precedent
description: To the Editor:

title: New Songs Spring Forth In a Lively Mixture
description: The ensemble Sequitur presented a lively concert of new songs and a few older numbers at the Knitting Factory on Sunday evening. Suiting the place (at 74 Leonard Street in TriBeCa), the repertory was generally informal and cabaret-like, but as mixed as could be.

title: Giants Say Jets Can Also Top Broncos
description: He is the only National Football League coach to play the Denver Broncos this season and be undefeated against them, but Jim Fassel of the Giants is neither preening nor flaunting that accomplishment.

title: Senate Set to Compartmentalize, Too
description: Fearing a public backlash, Senate Republicans insisted today that they could pursue an ambitious legislative agenda and conduct an impeachment trial at the same time.

title: Saudi Arabia Is Denounced By Baghdad : Saddam Turns Up Heat in Mideast
description: PARIS  The battle to sway Arab public opinion about Iraq broadened Tuesday as Baghdad accused Saudi Arabias rulers of betraying the Arab cause and colluding with the United States to punish the Iraqi people  the first time that the government of Saddam Hussein has lashed out so pointedly against the leading conservative Arab government in the Gulf.

title: Iraq Is Said to Shun Vital Food and Medicine It Could Import Under U.N. Sanctions
description: Evidence is growing that President Saddam Hussein has put off buying or distributing vital food and medicine that he can import through limited oil sales, diplomats and United Nations officials said today. They spoke as pressure mounted to lift economic sanctions on Iraq to improve the lives of its people.

title: Anti-Abortion Site On Web Has Ignited Free Speech Debate
description: ''The Nuremberg Files: Visualize Abortionists on Trial,'' proclaims the site on the World Wide Web. With simulated blood dripping from fetus parts, the site leads a cyber-visitor to the ''main archive,'' listing the names of dozens of doctors and clinic workers around the country who provide abortions.

title: O Brave New Knish, That Has Such Filling in It!
description: THERE are knishes and knishes -- and then there are knishes.

title: The Bitter Chill in Chicago: Any Future Without Jordan
description: You can have all those muscular metaphors, those Big Shoulders, that City on the Make. They were nice in their time, but their time has long passed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELMONT, YVONNE
description: BELMONT-Yvonne. Widow of Marcel died peacefully on January 11, 1999. She was 96 years old. She is survived by her sons Gerard and Francis and her daughterin-law Claudine, her daughter Nadine Grelsamer and her son-in-law Philippe. Her grandchildren Carol de Gunzburg, Patrick, Valerie and Geraldine Belmont. Vivian Rosenfield and Jason, Steven Belmont. Ronald Grelsamer and Sharon, Daniel Greilsamer and Sylvianne and eight great grandchildren. No flowers please. Family will receive friends at 4PM on Thursday at the Grelsamer residence.

title: New Yorkers Embrace a Little Shanghai Specialty
description: THEY go by more than a few names on Chinese menus: steamed tiny buns, juicy dumplings and crab-meat-and-pork soupy buns are just some of the terms for what the Chinese call xiao long bao, and for what Americans know as soup dumplings.

title: Chevron Is Investing in Venezuela Projects
description: Chevron , the fourth-largest American oil company, said today that it planned to invest up to $5.5 billion, by itself or with partners, in three oil projects in Venezuela, Latin America's largest crude-oil producer.

title: Coach Hired; Another Leaves
description: The Giants yesterday hired a new offensive line coach -- the longtime National Football League assistant Jim McNally -- but later in the day, the team learned it was also losing its quarterbacks coach, Rod Dowhower, who has agreed to become the Philadelphia Eagles' offensive coordinator.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: KING PRODUCTS INC., Canada, a maker of information kiosks and computerized directories, will develop and market multimedia products with Ascom Holding A.G., Switzerland's largest maker of telecommunications equipment, which agreed to pay $13 million (Canadian), or $8.6 million (United States), for 60 percent of King's stock.

title: AIDS Is Still Here, But Donors Drift Off; As Disease Lingers, Public Interest Wanes and Service Groups Falter
description: When the Gay Men's Health Crisis announced last month that it would no longer hold a popular annual fund-raising event on Fire Island, the move did more than end the public relations nightmare that the Morning Party had become.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALOVANY, MYRA
description: MALOVANY-Myra. Of West Caldwell, N.J. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Maida Asofsky and Dr. Robert Malovany. Loving grandmother of Dean, Douglas and Renee Asofsky, and Brian and Mara Malovany. Services at Congregation Agudath Israel, 20 Academy Road, Caldwell, N.J. Thursday, January 14th, 10AM. For information, call ''Gutterman - Musicant'' 800 522-0588. Should friends desire, contributions to Essex County Community College or a charity of one's choice dedicated to education would be appreciated.

title: Open the Senate
description: Since the trial of President Andrew Johnson in 1868, the Senate has conducted its debates on procedures and even the final verdict of impeachments in closed session. The time has come for that tradition to be altered, at least for the trial of President Clinton. Two Democratic Senators, Tom Harkin and Paul Wellstone, have announced that they will seek to change the rule on closed debates after the opening presentations begin tomorrow. Whatever would be gained by allowing senators to deliberate privately, the overriding requirement is for the American public to see and judge firsthand whether justice is being done.

title: Metro Business; Chase in Talks To Sell Office Tower
description: Chase Manhattan Corporation is in talks to sell a 2.4 million-square-foot office tower in Manhattan's financial district to Canada's TrizecHahn Corporation for about $400 million, a person familiar with the transaction said yesterday.

title: Concern Rising About Mergers In Health Plans
description: The health insurance industry is rapidly whittling itself down to a few giant companies that dominate the health systems of some of the country's biggest cities.

title: Manfred L. Karnovsky, 80, Blood-Cell Researcher
description: Dr. Manfred L. Karnovsky, a biochemist who cast new light on the way white blood cells fight off bacteria, died on Jan. 7 at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. A resident of Cambridge, he was 80 and had worked at Harvard University for 50 years.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Rare for an Internet company, Yahoo reports actual earnings. Not that such things matter.
description: YAHOO INC., a bellwether Internet stock, released earnings yesterday confirming that it had surpassed Wall Street's financial expectations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOAN, BILLIE
description: SLOAN-Billie. You fought so courageously. The Fun Bunch will never be the same. We will miss you. Our love to Sherwood and your beautiful family. Bob and Joyce, Ronnie and Jerry, Rita and Selwyn, Florence and Ben, Burt & Joan

title: Sports of The Times; NEW ERA, NEW HOPES
description: There was only a faint stir to the season here today after the morning news sounded the alarm that Michael Jordan would not be rising with a league now at risk of awakening to a global ennui. Jayson Williams and Rony Seikaly were shooting around with the well-traveled Lloyd Daniels and an apparition from the days when a Nets practice had all the iridescence of a haunted house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESCH, SAMUEL
description: LESCH-Samuel. Died peacefully in his sleep in Santa Rosa, Ca. on January 7, 1999. Loving husband for 60 years to Annie Lesch of Rohnert Park. Loving father of Harry Lesche of Eureka and Barbara Lesche McCaffry of Rohnert Park. Beloved grandfather of Benjamin Joseph Lesche and Jacob Paul Lesche. A native of New York, age 90. A member of the Forton Lodge of New York and Congregation Nershalom of Cotati. Funeral services were held on Sunday, January 10, 1999 at the Eggen & Lance Mortuary. Rabbi Elisheva Sachs officiated. Interment Shomrei Torah Cemetery at Santa Rosa Memorial Park. Those desiring may make memorial contributions to their favorite charity.

title: People
description: * Jay Shields, executive vice president at Austin Kelley Advertising, Atlanta, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was promoted to the position of chief operating officer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PYNE, PERCY R. III
description: PYNE-Percy R. III of Far Hills on January 11, 1999. Beloved husband of Evelyn Sloane Pyne; father of John Sloane, Percy R. IV, Robert Wright and Benjamin Nicoll Pyne; brother of Eben W., John W. Pyne and Allison Pyne Ewing, also survived by 8 grandchildren. Service Friday 11 A.M. at St. Bernards Episcopal Church, Claremont Rd, Bernardsville, NJ. Contributions in lieu of flowers to The James Parkinson Fund, Robert Wood Johnson Medical School, 97 Paterson St, New Brunswick, NJ 08901 or the Groton School, Groton, MA 01450.

title: Blocking Trade, or Blocking Aid?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBKIN, JAMES A.
description: DOBKIN-James A. On Monday, January 11, 1999, of Bethesda, MD, lawyer, artist, loving and adored husband of Irma, son of Eve Dobkin and the late Louis R. Dobkin, father of Jill Sacher and her husband, Gil, and David Dobkin, brother of Bonnie Stone, grandfather of Alexandra Sacher. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, January 13, 1:30 pm, at Temple Beth El, 8215 Old Georgetown Road, Bethesda, MD. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the James Dobkin Memorial Liver Transplant Fund, payable to Johns Hopkins University, mailed C/O Andrew Klein, M.D., Division of Transplantation, Johns Hopkins Hospital, 600 North Wolfe Street, Harvey Building #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, JACK
description: JACOBS-Jack on December 28, 1998 at age 88 in Boca Raton, Florida. Beloved husband of the late Ruth Jacobs. Devoted uncle of Dr. Jonathan Lyons. Thank you for your thoughtfulness and caring.

title: Metro Business; Fortune Brands' Profits
description: Fortune Brands Inc., the maker of Titleist golf balls and Footjoy shoes, said yesterday that its 1998 profit would meet forecasts and that it expected a double-digit increase in earnings this year because of rising sales and cost cuts.

title: Function vs. Fantasy :Prada and Gucci Slug It Out
description: THEY are the fashion titans of the 1990s. In one corner, a streak of blood red across the sleek hair, scarlet sequins dripping on the jacket and the crescendo from Psycho on the soundtrack.

title: ABC and Union Make Progress Toward Ending 10-Week Lockout
description: ABC's 10-week-old lockout of its 2,200 behind-the-scenes workers appeared near an end yesterday, as union leaders said they would agree to the network's no-strike provision in order to return to work and would most likely move by week's end to send the company's latest contract offer to employees for a vote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEAHAN, JOHN
description: SHEAHAN-John. Retired Lt. Commander-US Army, former FBI agent and lawyer on January 7, 1999. Survived by his brother Donald, sister-in-law Emily, and lifelong friend Jeanne Cole. Visiting Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st St. Funeral mass Friday 10A.M. at St. John the Martyr Church, 250 East 72 Street.

title: Money-Losing 'On the Town' to Close
description: Faced with faltering ticket sales for ''On the Town,'' the Joseph Papp Public Theater said yesterday that it would close the production on Sunday at a loss of an estimated $6 million.

title: NEWS
description: Favor Courter

title: Williams Frustrated By Postponed Talks
description: Jayson Williams, the free-agent center, is beginning to worry that his professed adoration for the Nets might lead to ill treatment in their contract negotiations. His concerns arose after yesterday's scheduled meeting between his agent, Sal DiFazio, and team officials was postponed until today and after he learned that the Nets might offer him less money because of the league's new collective bargaining agreement.

title: So What Explains That Loyalty to Clinton?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, MYRNA
description: GREEN-Myrna. Age 87. Cherished wife of the late Rubin Green, dear mother of Toni Mufson and Richard Green, dear mother-inlaw of the late Randee Green, beloved grandmother of Abigail and the late Joanna Mufson, Cori and Cassie Green. Dearly loved sister, sister-in-law and aunt. Services Thursday, January 14, Riverside Chapel, 76th & Amsterdam, N.Y.C.

title: Corporate Backer Tells I.O.C. to Come Clean
description: The president of John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, one of a dozen worldwide corporate sponsors of the Olympic movement, yesterday sternly admonished the International Olympic Committee to extend its investigation of irregular bidding practices beyond Salt Lake City and the 2002 Winter Games.

title: Jets' Oft-Maligned Offensive Line Is No Longer a Big Joke
description: In this season of surplus scoring, surprisingly strong defense and attitude adjustment that has taken them 60 minutes from revisiting the Super Bowl, there has been one constant more than any other unit on the Jets: the offensive line.

title: 2 Operas Have Some Fun
description: The National Opera Association held its 44th annual conference in New York over the weekend, and part of the business at hand on Sunday afternoon was hearing the two winners of the association's 1998 Chamber Opera Competition. The works, Philip Hagemann's ''Paris and Oenone, or Did the Trojan War Take Place?'' and Milton Granger's ''Talk Opera,'' were given entertaining and remarkably polished performances by the student singers and orchestra of the Manhattan School of Music Opera Theater.

title: But First, There's the Bread
description: IN a market crowded with specialized bread books that promote everything from traditional French breads to those made in machines, Beth Hensperger has gone her own way. In her latest book, ''The Bread Bible'' (Chronicle Books, $32.50), the subtitle, ''300 Favorite Recipes,'' tells the real story.

title: India's Religious Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A profile on the Public Lives page yesterday about James R. Houghton, the new chairman of the Metropolitan Museum, misspelled the surname of the museum's departing president. He is William H. Luers, not Leurs.

title: For Bronco Fever, Treatment Is Sunday
description: Todd Tilghman is just starting to get his voice back. The Denver real estate broker says he went overboard last Saturday cheering as the Broncos overwhelmed the Miami Dolphins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSCHMID, ROSE
description: GOLDSCHMID-Rose. A longtime NYC resident died on January 11, 1999. She was 100. Born June 18, 1898 to Abraham and Tillie Brown Zeigler in Wilmington, DE, Rose married the late Elliot. Survived by nieces and nephews Robert and Nancy Sylvor, Richard and Toby Gamsu, R. Anthony and Mona Zeigler and Lynne Zeigler. Grandnieces and grandnephews Elyse and Jeffrey, Andrew and Lauren, Andy and Theresa and Jeffrey. Predeceased by brothers David and Irving and sister Molly Gamsu. For more information call Zion Memorial Chapel 914-381-1809

title: Editorial Observer; What Will the Internet Economy Look Like?
description: The Internet is the wonder of the era, the tool that is expected to change everything. On Wall Street, Internet stocks are superstars. Amazon.com, the bookseller, now trades for more than 50 times the price at which it went public in 1997. Ebay, an auction house, is valued at 13 times what investors paid four months ago.

title: Tax Relief Proposal Attracts Criticism and Praise
description: Try as he may to muster enthusiasm for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposed property tax rebates for homeowners, Donald Dyrness kept sliding into cynicism today, because he has also heard from his local school board that the district stands to lose $2.4 million in state aid this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ROSE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Rose. An accomplished professional and a great lady. We have lost a dear friend. Charlotte Kirschner and family

title: Gillette Expanding Market
description: The Gillette Company plans to introduce its premium-priced Mach3 razors in Latin America and Asia this year, a company executive said. The Mach3 has become the top seller in Europe and the United States since its introduction last June. Gillette, which spent more than $1 billion to develop and market the triple-bladed razor, said Mach3 blades had won a 14.6 percent share of the United States market in December.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAD, NAFTALI
description: GAD-Naftali on January 9, 1999, at age 62. Beloved husband of Shifra, devoted father of Michael, Joseph, Lilly and Peggy, adored grandfather of Eddie, Nathan & Aaron, loving father-in-law of Irina, David and Morris. Former President of the Diamond Trade Association. He will be remembered for his commitment to the Jewish community, support of Jewish education, leadership in the worldwide emerald, diamond and precious gem industry, generosity, strength and fine character. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. May his soul be bound in the bond of eternal life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, BERNARD
description: GOODMAN-Bernard. We mourn the passing of our partner and friend. He always provided thoughtful business guidance and was a leader in the real estate appraisal profession. Our deepest sympathies to his family and children, Mark, Steven and Beth and all who loved him. The Officers and Employees of Goodman-Marks Associates, Inc.

title: Some Changes in the Market Tables
description: The Times has revised its financial tables.

title: This Time, Shared Reins Didn't Work at Goldman
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company has often been managed with a simple idea: As Wall Street largest investment banking partnership, it ought to put partners at the top.

title: Where Indulgence Grows on Trees
description: THE coast of Hawaii's Big Island is dotted with groves of stately trees, their shiny, dark green leaves forming shady canopies over the rich volcanic soil. They stand in lush contrast to the white-capped blue waters of the Pacific. From late fall to early winter, these trees, descendants of a species imported from Australia in the 1870's as an ornamental, produce graceful sprays of white blossoms that have a gentle perfume, like privet hedges in bloom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALADINO, ROSE
description: PALADINO-Rose. Of New Rochelle, on January 12. Survived by her husband Michael, four daughters Joanne Powell, Saralyn Hilde, Christine Tozzo and Miriam Bruer, two sons Joseph and Joachim, nine grandchildren and one great grandchild. Visitation Wednesday, January 13, 7-9PM, Thursday, January 14, 2-4/7-9PM at George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 Lecount Pl. New Rochelle, NY. 914-636-4938. Funeral Mass Holy Name of Jesus Church, New Rochelle, Fri. January 15, 9:30am interment Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY.

title: SBC TO OFFER HIGH-SPEED INTERNET ACCESS BY YEAR-END
description: SBC Communications Inc. said yesterday that it planned to offer high-speed access to the Internet to 8.2 million residential customers and 1.3 million businesses by the end of the year. SBC, based in San Antonio, will offer Asymmetrical Digital Subscriber Line access, which uses traditional copper telephone lines to deliver fast Internet service. The technology, which requires special equipment and installation, is the response by Bell telephone companies to cable modems, which deliver fast Internet access via coaxial cable lines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIOS, THEO
description: HIOS-Theo. Artist. Devoted wife Catherine, brother Themis. Nieces and nephews. Hours 2-4 and 7-9PM Thursday, January 14, John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Ave, NYC.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Jones, Ex-L.I.U. Star, Facing Gun Charge
description: Charles Jones, the former Long Island University basketball player who led the nation in scoring the last two seasons, was arraigned Monday in Brooklyn Criminal Court on gun possession charges stemming from an incident at a campus dormitory on Sunday.

title: The Price of Fame Includes Dinner; At Tinseltown You're a Star and the Employees Merely Players
description: The first ''adventure'' you encounter upon arriving at Tinseltown Studios, a new theme park and dinner theater complex near Disneyland here, is having your name on the guest list. Next you walk to a large grated door, which opens to reveal a red carpet and banks of klieg lights shooting into the sky. A throng of teen-agers descends on you waving autograph pads, followed by paparazzi setting off flash bulbs in your face, reporters brandishing note pads and television news crews stopping you for interviews.

title: Hague Journal; Then It Was the Klan. Now It's the Balkan Agony.
description: Gabrielle Kirk McDonald is not easily intimidated. As a Federal judge in Houston in the 1980's, she faced down the local Grand Dragon of the Ku Klux Klan, who told her in her own courtroom that she should be removed from his case because he could not get a fair trial from ''a Negress.''

title: What Is Being Tested?
description: To the Editor:

title: Quantrill Faces Minor Charge
description: Toronto Blue Jays pitcher Paul Quantrill was charged with failing to report a snowmobiling accident and faces a $60 fine, the Ontario Provincial Police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLER, BESSIE (NEE LADERMAN)
description: GELLER-Bessie (nee Laderman). Died January 10 at age 107. Beloved mother of Rose Sterling, Celia Shuman and Sally Blankenhorn. Sister of Matilda Rosenberg. Grandmother of five and great grandmother of six. Service on Sunday at Plaza Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam & 91st St, at 12 Noon.

title: Clinton Asks For $1 Billion To Buy Land For U.S. Parks
description: President Clinton asked Congress today to spend $1 billion in the year 2000 to buy more land for national parks and other conservation purposes, possibly including private holdings within public forests and refuges in New York State and the northern New England states.

title: Thornton Scores Plenty, but He Is a Threat on Defense, Too
description: Guard Bootsy Thornton is providing the offense (14.3 points a game) that St. John's expected, but Coach Mike Jarvis is more pleased with his performance at the other end of the court.

title: COURT TURNS BACK AN EFFORT TO LIMIT BALLOT INITIATIVES
description: The Supreme Court today rebuffed Colorado's effort to regulate the process of getting initiatives on the ballot, in a decision extolling the First Amendment value of uninhibited ''communication with voters.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BECKER, IDA
description: BECKER-Ida. Time goes by but your memory stays. Love, your children, grandchildren and great granddaughter

title: Reporter's Death in Mexico: Mystery Grows
description: The investigation into the apparent murder of Philip True, an American journalist who died last month during a 10-day hike through remote mountains, has become mired in conflicting autopsy reports and contradictory confessions by two men charged with the killing.

title: Pollard's Release Sets a Bad Precedent; Spy or Mercenary?
description: To the Editor:

title: OFF THE MENU
description: More Manhattan Chili

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YATTER, FAYE
description: YATTER-Faye on January 11, 1999. Devoted wife of the late Max, loving mother of Ronald, Irwin and Denise, cherished grandmother of Samara, Ahron, Galeit, Carise and Douglas. Loving mother-in-law to Marcia, Marsha and Pericles. Always devoted to her family. Private funeral services are today.

title: Clinton Settles Jones Lawsuit With a Check for $850,000
description: Just as the Senate is about to begin President Clinton's impeachment trial in earnest, Mr. Clinton sent $850,000 to Paula Corbin Jones today to settle the sexual misconduct lawsuit that started it all.

title: Whitman Sets April 15 For Property Tax Plan
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman asked state lawmakers today to enact her proposed five-year, $1 billion property tax relief package by April 15 so homeowners can get their first rebate check by Labor Day.

title: A Deep Voice Expresses A Consuming Sadness
description: ''Werther'' is perhaps Massenet's most dramatically subtle and musically elegant opera. But it survives on the fringes of the repertory, revived only when there is a compelling tenor to sing the title role.

title: Kazan, Snubbed by Some, To Get Honorary Oscar
description: Elia Kazan, the ailing 89-year-old director who in recent years has been rejected for several lifetime achievement awards because he informed on friends during the height of the McCarthy era, will be given an honorary Academy Award at the Oscar ceremonies on March 21. The decision by the board of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to give Mr. Kazan an honorary Oscar is, in some ways, a direct rebuke to the American Film Institute, which has gone out of its way to ignore Mr. Kazan in its yearly awards.

title: Jeans Makers Get the Blues as Sales Sag
description: LONDON  Lunchtime at the giant new Community College of Hackney, in the heart of fashionable Shoreditch, east London. The students milling around outside the college entrance are much like students the world over.But with one difference: not one of them is wearing blue denim jeans.There are sweat pants, track pants, cargo pants, khakis, chinos and jeans-style pants in moleskin and corduroy, but no blue jeans and precious little denim. The uniform of the young for more than three decades appears to have performed a vanishing act.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOARTY, ANN E.
description: HOARTY-Ann E. Of East Atlantic Beach, NY on January 11, 1999. Beloved sister of Alice, Thomas and the late Lt. Michael J., Patrick J. Hoarty. Also survived by many nieces and nephews and grand nieces and grand nephews. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc., 52 Clinton Ave, Rockville Centre, N.Y. Tuesday 7-9 PM and Wednesday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral mass on Thursday 9:30 AM at St. Ignatius Martyr RC Church, Long Beach, New York. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TSE, KU TEH YING
description: TSE-Ku Teh Ying. Passed away peacefully at her Manhattan residence on Sunday, January 10, 1999 at 5:25 PM at the age of 90. Born in China, beloved wife of the late Mr. Koong Kai Tse, senior executive of American International Group, Inc. (AIG). She has always been a devoted, supportive and loyal wife and the loving mother of the late son Stephen Yung Nien and the four surviving daughters: Cecilia Yung Hsien, Angelina Yung Ge, Virginia Yung Chung and Helena Yung Ngo. She is also survived by nine grandchildren and fourteen great-grandchildren. In the summer of 1987, she embraced the Truth and became a dedicated faithful Christian Witness of Jehovah. Her self-sacrificing love and generosity have touched many lives. She will indeed be deeply missed. Memorial service will be held at 4 PM on Saturday, January 16 at the Kingdom Hall of Jehovah's Witnesses, at 1499 First Ave, New York, NY 10021. In lieu of flowers the family has requested that donations be made to the Watchtower Bible & Tract Society Inc., 25 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, New York 11201. For information Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAER, JAMES B.
description: BAER-James B. The Board and staff of the American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, mourn the passing of James Baer of Boca Raton, FL, successful businessman, philanthropist and Jewish community leader. James, an esteemed member of the American Associates Board of Chancellors, along with his wife, Margie, generously supported Ben-Gurion University over the years. We extend sincere and heart felt condolences to Margie, his beloved wife of 45 years, and to his children Richard and Nancy of Palm Beach Gardens and Ronald and Marna of Coral Springs. Jules I. Whitman, President Kenneth L. Tucker, Chairman Harold L. Oshry, Hon Chairman AABGU

title: Metro Business; Job Cuts at Graham
description: Graham Corporation, a maker of vacuum and heat-transfer equipment for electric power plants and chemical makers, said yesterday that it had fired 14 office employees to reduce costs after a drop in sales to Asia.

title: The Japanese Intervene To Drive Down A Surging Yen
description: The Japanese central bank intervened in the currency markets yesterday, selling yen for dollars and sending the currency down 3 percent, its biggest one-day loss in more than three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, ALBERT
description: HELLER-Albert. NCJW, Peninsula Section, mourns the passing of Albert Heller, father of Phyllis Kaufman, devoted Past President. We extend heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Adrienne Lurie, President

title: A New Mood In Accessories
description: MILAN  Italian menswear designers are about to blow your socks off with anew range of luxurious yet functional accessories. From customized shoes to strap-on bags and wrist purses,men will never look the same again.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Fresh Peanut Butter To Spread Around

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, ROBERT J.
description: BROWN-Robert J. Age 87, of Vero Beach, Fla., died at home on Jan. 12, 1999. Former resident of Old Westbury, NY; owned Robert Chevrolet, Hicksville, NY, with his surviving son Robert for the last 40 years. In addition to his son he is survived by his wife Joan and six grandchildren: Scott, Tracy, Michelle, Todd, Shannon, Robin; one great-grandchild, Lauren. Services at Strunk Funeral Home, Vero Beach, Fla. The family suggests memorial gifts to the VNA Hospice Care, 1111-36th St, Vero Beach FL 32960 in lieu of flowers.

title: This Shot Going, Going, Gone for $3 Million
description: The bidding started at $400,000 and shot upward to $1.2 million. There was another pause at $1.7 million, and then the bidding rolled ahead to $2.6 million. A long pause. A gasp or two. Then an anonymous voice on the telephone offered $2.7 million.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DOWN. Crude oil fell more than 4 percent, the biggest drop in a month, on speculation that United States inventories rose last week. In New York, crude oil for February delivery fell 55 cents, to $12.89 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBER, ESTELLE
description: GARBER-Estelle. Beloved wife of Harry Garber, mother of David Zwiebel, Alan Zwiebel and Ruth Lukashok, sister of Evelyn Melnikoff, Adoring grandmother and great-grandmother. Wife of the late Louis J. Zwiebel. Burial was in Israel.

title: THE CHEF
description: MY restaurant's refrigerator is as well stocked as the best Greenmarket in town, the pantry is filled with everything from tuna to truffles, and there is never a shortage of chopped onions, minced garlic, stemmed parsley and freshly made broths, to say nothing of meat and fish, poultry and game.

title: Paris:Sporting Chic
description: PARIS  Call it fallout from the World Cup. In the past, French menswear stores were all about refined elegance. Now, for urbane read urban as the new generation of boutiques is about specific active sportswear crossing over to become streetwear.

title: Hartwig Heads Pole-Vault Field
description: A new generation of pole vaulters seems ready to take over from Sergei Bubka, now 35, who has dominated the event since 1983. One of the best of that group is no youngster himself: Jeff Hartwig, a 32-year-old American.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDI, ELLEN C. (COLEMAN)
description: LANDI-Ellen C. (Coleman). Of Heritage Village, Southbury, CT, in her 88th year, after a brief illness, at St. Mary's Hospital, Waterbury, CT. Originally of Pleasantville, New York, she was the daughter of the late Henry M. and Mary (Spencer) Coleman, and was married to Frank J. Landi, who died in 1953. Mrs. Landi retired from IBM's patent law department in 1975. She is the beloved mother of Frank J. Landi, Sr. of New Rochelle, the cherished sister of James, John, and Henry Coleman, and the deceased Thomas Coleman, Marie Scheland and Ann Brennan. She is the loving grandmother of Matthew, Peter, Frank and Lucy, and great grandmother of Isabella Landi. Reposing at the McMahon Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Ave, White Plains, NY. Visitation on Wednesday, 13 January 1999 from 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. A funeral mass will be held at 10 AM on Thursday, 14 January at Holy Family Church, Mayflower Avenue, New Rochelle, New York. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Honoring a Composer With a Stable Lingua Franca
description: Robert Starer will probably be best remembered for the scores he wrote for Martha Graham, but Sunday afternoon's concert for his 75th birthday at Christ and St. Stephen's Church provided a reminder of his skills in smaller genres and of his consistency.

title: New York Trash Imports Have Virginia In a Tizzy
description: Hey, New York: Virginia is for lovers, not trash.

title: Sales of High-End Chips Help Intel Beat Estimates
description: Buoyed by strong sales of its high-end microprocessors and increased operating efficiencies, the Intel Corporation reported fourth-quarter financial results today that substantially exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates. But Intel advised analysts that sales for the first quarter of 1999 are likely to fall, following a normal seasonal pattern.

title: About New York; Exploring a Cultural Universe Beyond the Limelight
description: TWO tour buses headed north on Amsterdam Avenue as their passengers caught quick glimpses of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and Columbia University. As the buses began their downhill coast to 125th Street, Jim Schlefer piped up like an impromptu tour guide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, BLANCHE
description: BERKOWITZ-Blanche. In her 95th year. Beloved wife of the late James, loving mother of Phyllis and Morton Handler, Stephen and Marlene Berkley. Grandchildren and great grandchildren.

title: For New York, 25-Year Losing Streak
description: Hipolito Burgos, a 17-year-old senior at Queens Vocational High School, is an immigrant from the Dominican Republic, co-captain of his school's baseball team and an all-round threat as a catcher, outfielder and batter.

title: Marketers from Gatorade to Nike try to decide if they will still like Michael Jordan when he retires.
description: WITH the second and apparently final retirement of Michael Jordan from basketball, which is expected to be announced today, will Madison Avenue lose the most prolific, most richly compensated and perhaps most effective endorser ever?

title: $104 Million Seagate Net Exceeds Forecast
description: Seagate Technology Inc., the No. 1 independent maker of computer disk drives, posted net income for its fiscal second quarter today that beat expectations as the company benefited from a surge in sales of personal computers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RILEY, DR. MARY C. (JONES)
description: RILEY-Dr. Mary C. (Jones), 81, of 32 Sunset Lane, Petersham, MA died Saturday, January 9, 1999, in her home. She was known to her friends as Polly. She leaves her husband of 52 years, Dr. Richard L. Riley; a son, Richard C. Riley of Ithaca, NY; two daughters, Mary L. Riley of Hong Kong, China, Susan H. Riley of Petersham; a sister, Peggy Brooks of New York City, NY; and two grandchildren. She was born January 18, 1917, in New York City, N.Y., the daughter of T. Catesby and Louisa (Brooke) Jones and was a resident of Petersham for 22 years coming from Baltimore, MD. where she resided for 27 years. She graduated from Brearley School in New York City. She received a B.S. from Bennington College, Bennington, VT, and went on to receive her M.D. from Johns Hopkins Medical School, Baltimore, MD, in 1948. She worked in several clinics in the Baltimore area specializing in internal medicine with emphasis on chest diseases, and achieved the rank of Assistant Professor of Medicine at The Johns Hopkins School of Medicine. She was also active in the Baltimore chapter of the League of Women Voters. She enjoyed singing, listening to music and painting. She was active in town activities including the Petersham Board of Health, the Library Committee, the Carpenter Concert Committee, the Petersham Branch Alliance, and the Petersham Craft Center. In recent years she was a regular attendant at the Monday lunches of the Petersham Council on Aging. A memorial service will be held in the Petersham Unitarian Church Sunday, January 24, 1999, at 3 P.M. Burial will be at the convenience of the family. There are no calling hours. For information Fiske Funeral Home, 1356 Main Street, Athol, MA 01331.

title: BSMG Has Acquired Financial Relations
description: BSMG Worldwide in New York, a public relations agency owned by True North Communications, said yesterday that it had acquired the Financial Relations Board in Chicago, an investor relations firm, for True North stock valued at $33 million.

title: Business Travel; Chances of a getting a hotel room upgrade may be better now then they have been in years.
description: BUSINESS travelers have a far greater chance today to obtain a room upgrade at hotels than they've had in many years, a prominent industry analyst believes.

title: $80 Million Sale Is Set for Whitney Couple's Riches
description: For three days and two nights in April and May, Sotheby's could once again be the center of the kind of auction frenzy that surrounded its sale of items from the estate of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis in 1996 and the Duchess of Windsor last year. Yesterday the auction house announced that it would sell $80 million to $110 million worth of property from the estate of Betsey Cushing Roosevelt Whitney, the New York socialite and philanthropist who left more than $300 million worth of art by van Gogh, Matisse and Picasso and other masters to four major museums at her death in March.

title: Silent Giants as Guides on an Ancient Thoroughfare
description: THE MUMMIES OF URUMCHI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONSON, WILLIAM BERGEN ''SI''
description: SIMONSON-William Bergen ''Si'' of Mineola, N.Y. on Jan. 11, 1999. (Retired Guidance Counsellor and Athletics Coach-Mineola High School and Head Counsellor-Camp To-Ho-Ne, Great Barrington, Mass.) Beloved husband of Rita. Devoted father of Virginia Bushart and William Simonson and fatherin-law of Jerry Bushart. Loving grandfather of Timothy and Christopher Bushart. Dear brother of the late Franklin Simonson. Visiting Tuesday, 7-9PM; Wednesday 22 and 7-9 PM, Cassidy Funeral Home, 156 Willis Ave, Mineola. Funeral service 10AM Thursday, First Presbyterian Church of Mineola. Interment Greenfield Cemetery. Memorials to The Alzheimer's Assoc., 66 South Street, Patchogue, New York 11772.

title: ANXIETY GROWING OVER INDIAN CLAIM IN NEW YORK STATE
description: The Federal Government has joined the Oneida Indians in a lawsuit that contends the state and local governments unlawfully acquired 270,000 acres of land in central New York from the Indians nearly 200 years ago, whittling down what had been a sprawling reservation into a meager 32-acre plot.

title: Are They Great Or Just New?
description: The chief programmer for a competing network checked out the rating for the opening episode of NBC's new Friday night drama, ''Providence,'' and declared it ''the most stunning development of the season.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURWITZ, BERTHA (SCHNEIDER)
description: HURWITZ-Bertha (Schneider) on January 10, 1999, late of West Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY and Revere, MA. Beloved aunt of Bernard and Esther Schneider. A graduate of Hunter College and Columbia University, she served her community as a family social worker and her country as a Field Director with the Red Cross in Australia during World War II. A true woman of valor, who enjoyed and cherished life's most precious gifts, she will be remembered with love by her family and by all who knew her and were enriched by her. Services at the Schlossberg & Solomon Memorial Chapel, Canton, MA., on Wednesday, January 13 at 12:30 P.M. Expressions of sympathy may be donated to the Jewish National Fund.

title: Share Prices Slump on Profit Taking and Woes Overseas
description: Stocks moved sharply lower in heavy trading yesterday as continued instability in key foreign economies provided a helpful backdrop for traders and investors looking to take profits on issues that have shot higher since the start of the year.

title: Lucent Is Expected to Acquire Ascend for About $20 Billion
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. is expected to announce today that it is acquiring Ascend Communications Inc., the data networking company, in a deal valued at about $20 billion, people close to the talks said.

title: Pataki Inaugural Team Told to Disclose Costs
description: A ruling today by the state's highest court forces Gov. George E. Pataki's supporters to disclose detailed expenses paid by his 1995 inaugural and transition organizations, information they have fought for four years to keep secret.

title: So What Explains That Loyalty to Clinton?
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Renames Gay Philanthropist as Envoy
description: President Clinton has defied senior Republican lawmakers by renominating a prominent San Francisco philanthropist as Ambassador to Luxembourg, a post in which he would be the first openly gay American envoy, White House and Congressional officials said today.

title: Plastic Wrap and Health: Studies Raise Questions
description: PLASTIC wrap seals so many everyday foods in the supermarket, from cheese to meat, that it's easy to take it for granted. But now there is a new worry about exactly how safe this ubiquitous convenience product may be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, LESTER
description: LEVINE-Lester. Died January 11, 1999 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Barbara. Loving father of Jeffrey and Steven. Brother of Charlotte Goldberg and Robert Levine. He will be missed by all.

title: Senegalese Cooking, With Lots of Warmth
description: CHEZ GNAGNA KOTY'S calls itself an international restaurant, serving African, African-American and French cuisine. The chef and owner, Gnagna Diene, says she will cook whatever you like. But the pride of Chez Gnagna (pronounced NYAH-nyah) is in its Senegalese stews, hearty well-flavored meals that are rich and comforting.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Patents column of Business Day on Monday about the Patent and Trademark Office's annual listing of top patent recipients, misstated the number of patents awarded in 1998 to the leader, International Business Machines. It was 2,658 (1,724 was the number for 1997).

title: Gavin Relly, 72, Dies; Helped End Apartheid
description: Gavin W. H. Relly, the retired chairman of the Anglo American Corporation who in 1985 led a delegation of business leaders to meet the banned African National Congress in Zambia, died on Sunday in Hermanus, South Africa. He was 72.

title: Hometown Favorites
description: The National Football League commissioner, Paul Tagliabue, wondered yesterday whether any other team that had reached the conference championships had as many key hometown figures as the Jets.

title: Congressional Memo; 2 Early Votes Will Shape Impeachment Trial
description: When the impeachment trial of President Clinton resumes on Thursday, the House and the White House will not only be arguing over whether the President should be removed from office. They will also be trying to shape the outcome of a critical series of votes later this month that could decide whether the impeachment trial ends abruptly or ventures into uncharted territory.

title: Class Notes; For some fourth graders in Brooklyn, there is a lot more to life than a standardized test.
description: It was undeniably a stressful day in Janet Ryan's fourth-grade classroom in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, EDYTHE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Edythe, on January 11, 1999, age 70, practicing social worker for over 25 years at Southeast Nassau Guidance Center; beloved wife of Dr. Samuel M. Goldstein, former Dean of Wurtzweiler School of Social Work; loved mother of Michelle and Jeffrey (Janet) Goldstein; grandmother of Robert and Nicole Goldstein. Services today, 12 noon, Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett.

title: The Losses Keep Mounting for an Overmatched P.S.A.L.
description: Runners from roughly 80 New York City public high schools trickled into Van Cortlandt Park on a crisp Saturday last fall, eager, after two months of training, to compete in the city's cross-country championships for freshmen and sophomores.

title: A Look That's Hotter Than Toast
description: IN the world of kitchen appliances, retro is the design du jour. Blenders are rounded and edged in chrome, pressure cookers are back in force and coffee machines are bulky and bright, in cotton candy colors like peach and mint.

title: Treading a Contentious Line; Shoe Store Owners Battle Nine West Over Its Pricing System
description: Peter Polites, owner of a Nine West store in New Jersey, slashed the price of a popular, smart-looking women's shoe last winter, knowing he would attract many more customers -- and still earn a smooth 60 percent profit on each pair.

title: A Menu Big on Words and Flavors
description: AREN'T you tired of menus that read like recipes?

title: An Acquisition By Citco Group
description: Citco Group Ltd. said today that it had bought a majority interest in Quaker Securities Inc., allowing it to offer more services to clients worldwide.

title: From Serban, The Shylock Of Yesteryear, A Go-To Guy
description: Let Shylock be Shylock! is the unspoken motto of Andrei Serban's daringly unapologetic production of ''The Merchant of Venice.''

title: G.E. Industrial Division Buys Ultrasonic
description: The General Electric Company, the top supplier of power-generation equipment and services, said today that it had bought the closely held Ultrasonic Field Services Corporation to expand the service business of its Power Systems division. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: Missing Girl, 17, Is Found Slain, Officials Say
description: A 17-year-old girl who had been missing since about 6 P.M. on Thursday was found dead today in a wooded area near her apartment building. Officials said they believed she had been killed.

title: Sports of The Times; The Tarp and the Igloo That Weren't
description: UNACCUSTOMED as they are to being in the American Football Conference championship game, the Jets might be too giddy to check for the logistical problems that surfaced in their two previous appearances in this Super Bowl semifinal: the missing tarpaulin in soggy Miami after the 1982 season, and the plastic igloo on the Raiders' bench at frigid Shea Stadium in 1968.

title: MCI WORLDCOM WINS 4-YEAR GOVERNMENT PHONE CONTRACT
description: MCI Worldcom Inc., the No. 2 United States long-distance company, won the second of two contracts to provide Federal Government agencies with at least $750 million worth of phone services over four years, the General Services Administration said. The Sprint Corporation, the No. 3 long-distance company, won the first contract in December and will also receive minimum revenue of $750 million. Each four-year contract may be extended another four years. MCI Worldcom's bid for the contract beat Sprint and the AT&T Corporation, which has 75 percent of the Government's long-distance business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARCLAY, ELIZABETH MOORE
description: BARCLAY-Elizabeth Moore, 96. Died January 12, 1999. Wife of the late George C. Barclay; survived by Elizabeth Barclay Pennink of Medford, NJ; Margaret Barclay Chambers of Philadelphia, and George C. Barclay, Jr. of Devon, England; nine grandchildren and five great grandchildren. She was public relations director at Union Theological Seminary for 20 years and a crusader with Planned Parenthood and Choice in Dying. Memorial service to be held in the spring. Contributions may be made to Choice in Dying, 1035 30th St, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20007

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLINE, GUERNSEY CHAFFEE
description: CLINE-Guernsey Chaffee passed away Wednesday, January 6, 1999, at his home in Gulfstream, Florida. Mr. Cline would have been 92 on February 16. He was born in Amenia, NY and graduated from Pawling School, Pawling, NY in 1927. He was wed to Marjorie Preston Burns & moved to Bermuda to install the Bermuda Railroad Line. On completion, they resided in Bronxville, NY, and founded the Westchester Diaper Service, Mt. Vernon, NY (1931-1944). From 1945-1968, he was President/Owner of the Dubois Fence and Garden Company, Inc, 342 Madison Avenue, NYC. In addition to his wife, Florence Whittemore Cline, Mr. Cline is survived by two daughters, Marguerite C. Beckman, Nonquitt, MA and Carolyn C. Holmes, Salters Point, MA, a son, Jerome S. Cline, Sewickley, Pa, 11 grandchildren, and five great grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, a memorial fund has been established at the Trinity-Pawling School, Pawling, New York 12564.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 17 about a threat by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to call early elections misstated the expiration date of Mr. Netanyahu's current term. It is one year from this spring, not two years. (New elections have since been scheduled for this year, on May 17.)

title: Huskies Brush Off the Irish
description: CONNECTICUT 101, NOTRE DAME 70

title: Sports of The Times; McGwire's 70th Homer Still Defying Gravity
description: TO begin with, this baseball that has been called the Hope Diamond of sports collectibles -- the Holy Grail, the fan's equivalent of a Picasso or a Renoir -- is not even in mint condition. It is defaced in two places, one where Mark McGwire's bat bashed it for his record-setting 70th and final home run of last season. The other bruise occurred when the ball hit a wall in a left-field upper-deck box in Busch Stadium in St. Louis. And rumor had it that someone was going to pay $1 million or more for this used ball?

title: Sports of The Times; Jim Brown Has Advice For Retiring Superstar
description: DYING isn't hard; it's living that's difficult. That's what Jim Brown is saying about the termination of Michael Jordan's basketball life, apparently taking place today.

title: On a Clear Day, He Sees Little of Interest
description: WHEN you get word that a cold snap is coming and have due warning to protect your extremities from freezing, the fellow to tip your hat to -- if you don't mind losing 50 percent of your body heat -- is Gary Conte, warning and coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service station at Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island.

title: Ford Has Told Volvo It Is Interested in Buying Car Unit
description: The Ford Motor Company has told Volvo A.B. that it would be interested in acquiring the Swedish company's car division if it were put up for sale, but no formal offer has been made nor has Volvo expressed a desire to open formal negotiations, auto executives said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFITHS, HELEN (KELLY)
description: GRIFFITHS-Helen (Kelly). On January 11th, 1999. Of Norwalk, Connecticut. Wife of the late Frank Griffiths. Mrs. Griffiths was the retired Secretary to the Vice President of Circulation, New York Times. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Thursday, at 10 A.M., in Saint Thomas Church, Norwalk. Visiting is on Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9 P.M., at the Raymond Funeral Home, 5 East Wall Street, Norwalk, Connecticut.

title: Corrections
description: A credit in the House & Home section on Nov. 12 for an illustration of cherimoyas from the book ''Uncommon Fruits and Vegetables,'' with the Garden Q.& A. column, misidentified the publisher. A letter from the publisher dated Jan. 8 points out that the book is from William Morrow, not Harper & Row.

title: Teen-Ager Is Indicted On Manslaughter Counts
description: A Trenton teen-ager was indicted on manslaughter and other charges on Monday, after a bullet fired by the police killed a 14-year-old girl who was riding in a stolen car that the police said the suspect was driving, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORSER, PAUL
description: CORSER-Paul. The Board of Directors and staff of the AIDS Vaccine Advocacy Coalition (AVAC) express our deep sadness at the loss of our colleague Paul Corser, Program Officer at the American Foundation for AIDS Research (AmFAR). In the struggle to end the AIDS epidemic, Paul was smart, dedicated, and real. He will be missed by many. Our sympathies go to his family and coworkers at AmFAR.

title: Issue du Jour at Microsoft Trial: Are Consumers Harmed?
description: An economist testifying for the Government conceded today that there was scant evidence consumers had been harmed by practices that are central to the Justice Department's antitrust case against the Microsoft Corporation.

title: Mayor Makes Concession On Evictions for Shelter
description: In a political retreat peppered with goading remarks, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a major modification yesterday to his plan to evict several community programs to make room for a homeless shelter in the district of a Brooklyn City Council member who had annoyed him.

title: The 100: A Jury Not of Peers but of Kin, Foe and Talking Head
description: One of the 100 men and women who will decide President Clinton's fate is related to him by marriage, a grandmother of the same 3-year-old boy who calls Mr. Clinton uncle.

title: So What Explains That Loyalty to Clinton?
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Dismisses Suit by Crane Against Coltec
description: A judge late yesterday dismissed a lawsuit by the Crane Company seeking to block Coltec Industries from merging with B. F. Goodrich, a deal that gives Coltec shareholders substantially less than Crane had offered to pay.

title: Liberties; The Abyss of Desire
description: Desperate times call for desperate measures.

title: Journal; Family Values Stalkers
description: ''This huge organization that has tons and tons of money keeps targeting our family,'' said Jon Galluccio when he contacted me over New Year's weekend. ''It's scary. The fear comes that one of their followers will be even more fanatical and take it one step further. . . .''

title: Gore to Visit to Close Deal on Dredging Harbor
description: Vice President Al Gore plans to travel to New York Harbor today to close an agreement with the Port Authority that will allow the agency to begin deepening shipping channels that are a choke point threatening billions of dollars in maritime trade.

title: In Naples, an Opera Exalting Revolt Stirs Just That
description: Politics, at least the garden variety sort, are not taken too seriously in Naples. Music, however, is never taken lightly in this city, the birthplace of bel canto. When the San Carlo opera house opened its season with a new opera, ''Eleonora,'' starring Vanessa Redgrave as a heroine and martyr of the 1799 Neapolitan uprising, it unleashed angry demonstrations and debate rivaling the intensity of President Clinton's impeachment trial. On opening night, local royalists flooded the theater with leaflets that read ''Jacobin Assassins!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERSON, OSCAR
description: PERSON-Oscar. Born April 22, 1916. Loving husband of the late Ethel Person and father of Roselle. Beloved brother of Philip and Pearl and inspired uncle of Sarah, Naomi, Matthew, Rachel and Meyer. Devoted grand uncle to their children. Died peacefully January 10, 1999. ''You can never take Brooklyn out of the boy.''

title: So What Explains That Loyalty to Clinton?
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: True North Unit Prices Its Shares
description: Modem Media.Poppe Tyson in Westport, Conn., the interactive advertising unit of True North Communications, has priced the shares to be sold in an initial public offering that was announced in November.

title: Proposal Aims at Returning Disabled Workers to Jobs
description: President Clinton will propose a new tax credit and health insurance coverage on Wednesday to help people with disabilities go back to work, White House officials said today. Senior members of Congress from both parties immediately endorsed major elements of the proposal.

title: Evoking India, Hot and Cold
description: TO order a masala chai or a Masala Mary is to speak just a little Hindi, and to have just a little taste of Indian cuisine in liquid form.

title: A Century Old but Fresh
