description: The marketers who run the music business insist that the best way to guarantee a full house is to offer works from the heart of the standard repertory. But on Saturday, in the third of its six concerts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Guarneri String Quartet took a chance on works from the periphery of the canon, and its audience trusted the group's instincts: the hall was full, and stage seats framed the quartet.

title: Clinton Pays Settlement
description: President Clinton sent $850,000 to Paula Corbin Jones to settle the sexual misconduct lawsuit that led to his impeachment trial. Page A14.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCPARLAND, JOSEPH
description: McPARLAND-Joseph. Beloved husband of Bernice, died peacefully on Sunday, January 10, 1999. He is survived by son Daniel J. and his wife Rosemarie, beloved grandfather of Megan and Tara, devoted brother of Rita, Helen, Irene, Marion. Funeral mass will be held at St. Ignatius Loyola on Thursday, 10AM. Interment private. Contributions may be made to the Inner City Scholarship Fund, 1011 First Avenue, N.Y., N.Y. 10022.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, EDITH S.
description: LIPTON-Edith S. Beloved wife of Israel. Devoted mother of Paul and Frank. She was a retired teacher. Services Thursday 1:30PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite LIRR) Great Neck, New York.

title: Knicks Left to Wonder About Chances for Title
description: For years, Michael Jordan shimmered like a hologram before the Knicks, a magical vision of multiple dimension and surreal form that they could never grasp. Obsessed with catching Jordan, the Knicks kept reaching and falling short until they viewed Jordan as a force field between themselves and a championship.

title: Calendar
description: 500 Wines at 20% Off

title: NBC Confronts the Departure of Its Must-See N.B.A. Star
description: In eight seasons of televising the National Basketball Association, NBC has been blessed with Michael Jordan. NBC purchased the rights as Jordan was exploding as a national icon and in time to carry the Chicago Bulls' first title in 1991. Five more championships followed, always in prime time on NBC.

title: Frederick Zissu, 85, Chief of Vornado Inc.
description: Frederick Zissu, former chairman and chief executive of the discount store chain Vornado Inc., died of heart failure on Saturday at the St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. A resident of North Caldwell, N.J., Mr. Zissu was 85.

title: E*Trade Investment Bank Sets Underwritings on Internet
description: E*Trade Group Inc. said today that it was starting an investment bank to raise money for companies by selling stocks and bonds over the Internet, challenging traditional securities firms as it did when it began selling stocks on line.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEABROOK, DOROTHY LITTLER
description: SEABROOK-Dorothy Littler. On January 11, 1999. Long time resident of NYC. Beloved wife of the late William Charles. Loving mother of Wendy D'Amico and William Seabrook. Dear grandmother of Alexis and Billy Seabrook. Funeral services private.

title: China Points Finger at Culprit of the Week
description: These days China's press is hauling out one big fish after another, as each is caught in the net of a national campaign against corruption and smuggling. The point, as with all political campaigns in this country, is to show the virtuous determination of the authorities, without too much concern for details like evidence or legal procedure.

title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions On Tech Labs In Russia
description: The Clinton Administration announced economic penalties today against three Russian institutions that it contends are helping Iran and possibly other nations develop nuclear weapons and missiles. The sanctions, imposed by executive order, mean that all American exports to the institutions, and all imports from them, are banned.

title: CENTRIS TO REVIEW HCC INSURANCE'S $155 MILLION OFFER
description: Shares in Centris Group rose more than 23 percent yesterday after the insurance and reinsurance company said it would review an offer by the aviation insurer HCC Insurance Holdings to buy the company for $13.25 a share, or $155 million. Buying Centris would push HCC, based in Houston, to the top of the ranks of insurance issuers, which cover unexpected medical claims against employers that self-insure their employees' health care. HCC already owns 7.8 percent of Centris. Shares in Centris, which is based in Costa Mesa, Calif., rose $2.6875, to $13.6875, an eight-month high.

title: So What Explains That Loyalty to Clinton?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHOEN, RITA.
description: SCHOEN-Rita. We remember with love and affection all the good things we enjoyed together. Marcos Del Forn & Famil

title: ACE TO BUY CIGNA UNIT FOR $3.45 BILLION IN CASH
description: Ace Ltd. said yesterday that it agreed to pay $3.45 billion in cash for the property and casualty businesses of the Cigna Corporation, furthering the company's strategy to become a worldwide insurer through acquisitions. The purchase, which was expected, gives Ace businesses whose premiums exceed its own by almost 4 to 1. It is the third acquisition for the Bermuda-based company in the last 12 months. Cigna, the third-largest health insurer in the United States, is exiting the property-casualty insurance business to concentrate on employee benefits. It said it was taking a $60 million after-tax fourth-quarter charge for reorganization and for losses at its property-casualty unit. Shares of Ace rose 18.75 cents, to $33.125, while Cigna climbed $1.375, to $84.875.1

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, ZALMAN
description: BERNSTEIN-Zalman. We mourn the loss of a close friend of Jewish education around the world. His Avi Chai Foundation provided resources for communities to create new Jewish educational opportunities. We feel privileged to be the first high school in the world to receive the Avi Chai interest-free capital expansion loan. Wisconsin Institute for Torah Study Rabbi Yehuda Cheplowitz Rabbi Avrohom B. Rauch Rabbi Raphael Wachsman Roshei HaYeshiva Elliott Katz, Chairman of the Board

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: The Answer Man

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, MILTON
description: DEUTSCH-Milton, 83. Of Parsippany, N.J. Died on January 11, 1999. Husband of Anne. Father of Joseph and Donna. Grandfather of Samuel and Jenny. A graveside service was held on January 12 at Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: So What Explains That Loyalty to Clinton?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mad About the Boy: Noel Coward's Private Life
description: For one horrible moment in ''The Noel Coward Story,'' I thought Coward was being interviewed by Austin Powers. But no, the mod BBC journalist sitting across from Coward has much better teeth. The year is 1969, and the subject, almost 70 years old at the time, looks distinctly uncomfortable, especially when asked about his humble beginnings.

title: Lemon Grass And Shrimp: Perfect Partners
description: SHRIMP is a perfect weeknight food, not only because it cooks in less than five minutes, but also because it marries well with so many flavors. A perfect but not well-known partner is lemon grass, so named because of its unmistakable citrus flavor and long slender shape.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSCHELLE, JACK
description: ROSCHELLE-Jack. On January 12, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Helen. Devoted father of Dr. Ira Roschelle and Rosalie Candell. Cherished grandfather of Jeremy & Maria, Eric, Lawrence & Amy, Karen, Emily and Amy and Len. Proud great grandfather of Micah and Allison. Loving father-in-law of Ralph Candell. Services Thursday at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: State Politics With a National Spin
description: The Texas Legislature, which meets every other year for only 140 days, cranked up for business today with the prospect of a particularly lively stretch, even by Texas standards, of political theater.

title: Pollard's Release Sets a Bad Precedent; Israeli Intelligence
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Real Estate; 14th Street Revival Moves East to Third Avenue
description: For more than 15 years, the Sahara Hotel has stood vacant and crumbling on the northeast corner of 14th Street and Third Avenue, a persistent reminder that the revival of the area near Union Square did not extend to the eastern reaches of 14th Street.

title: Two Men Shot in Newark In Encounter at a School
description: Two young men were shot outside a high school basketball game last night in what appeared to be a dispute over a girl, the police said. One of the men was shot in the stomach and was in critical condition last night.

title: Finalists Scouted Each Other Early
description: Football players are told to make one block at a time, one catch, one play, one practice, one game. Never look too far ahead. Stay in the moment. All eyes on today.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Meringue on Anise Cookies

title: OLIMAN HAS NO PLANS TO RAISE BID FOR CELLULAR CONCERN
description: Oliman, the joint telecommunications venture of Olivetti S.p.A. and Mannesmann A.G., said yesterday that it had no plans to raise its $1.5 billion bid for Cellular Communications International, even though Cellular shares were trading above the offer price. Cellular has risen as high as $70.50 since Dec. 11, when Oliman bid $65.75 for each share. Cellular's only asset is 10.3 percent of the Milan-based Omnitel-Pronto Italia S.p.A., Europe's No. 2 mobile phone company, which is already controlled by Oliman. Cellular shareholders have been waiting for a higher offer. Its shares fell $1 yesterday, to $69, in Nasdaq trading.

title: For a Much Heralded Exam, Delays and Talk of Cheating
description: After weeks of worry and feverish cramming, fourth graders across New York State finally filled in the blanks yesterday on the first section of an innovative new reading test. But the day was marred by distribution problems that delayed the exam in dozens of schools and prompted school officials to warn of widespread cheating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORBER, RUTH P.
description: LORBER-Ruth P. A gracious and sunny ''woman of valour'', who I will miss most for her consistent kindness over almost 30 years. To Pop and all who loved her, my deepest sympathy and affection. Barbara Heyman Lorber

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVERA, FERDINANDO
description: RIVERA-Ferdinando, 65, of New York died December 20, 1998. He is survived by Anthony Rivera, Michael Rivera, Richard Westbrook, Roseanne Rivera, Lisa Donovan, Diana Apodaca and 13 grandchildren. Services were private.

title: Brazil Stocks Fall Steeply Amid Currency and Capital Fears
description: Brazilian stocks plunged yesterday as rumors about devaluation and concern about capital flight undermined efforts by the Government to calm investors.

title: Myles Tierney, 34, a Journalist Who Specialized in African War
description: Myles Tierney, the Associated Press newsman who died Sunday after being shot by a Sierra Leone rebel while covering the wars, famines and riots of West Africa, was living precisely the life he had sought, according to his mother, Hanne Tierney of Manhattan.

title: Swimwear and Underwear:Suiting Up the Body-Conscious Male
description: PARIS  These are body-conscious times, but compared to women, men are still the timid sex when it comes to intimate apparel.Most men dont even buy their own briefs, their wives and mothers do it for them.For innovative mens underwear and also swimwear brands, the challenge is to create products with more style and comfort which are on the same wear and care level as the majors and then convince stores and men the difference is worth it.

title: Sommelier, What's That Smell?
description: Remember that expensive Bordeaux you sent back last year because it tasted a bit like wet cardboard? The waiter was not happy about your complaint, but after he smelled and tasted the wine, he had to agree; it was ''corky,'' that is, tainted by a bad cork. He brought you another bottle.

title: Nedved Expected To Play
description: Petr Nedved did not practice yesterday because his right knee is sore, but he probably will play tonight when the Rangers play the Islanders at Madison Square Garden. It's doing pretty good, said Nedved, the creative center, who sprained his knee in Sunday's victory over Tampa Bay. It was sore yesterday. Today was a lot better. I'm going to skate tomorrow and see how it goes.

title: HARTFORD LIFE SEEKS TO ACQUIRE STAKE IN KOREAN INSURER
description: The Kumho Life Insurance Company of Korea said yesterday that Hartford Life International, one of the four biggest American life insurers, would pay $100 million for a 60 percent stake in its business. Korea is the sixth-largest insurance market in the world. Kumho Life, a unit of Kumho Group, one of the country's 10 largest conglomerates, signed a memorandum of understanding with the United States company yesterday, said Kim Deok Hong, a Kumho spokesman. Hartford, a unit of Hartford Financial Services Group based in Simsbury, Conn., said in a statement the terms were not ''definitive.''

title: U.S. Jets Attack Iraq Again, Though Result Is Unclear
description: The Pentagon said today that it would continue its low-level war of attrition with Iraqi air defenses even though American attacks have done little to damp President Saddam Hussein's defiance of the no-flight zones over northern and southern Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURELL, ANNETTE
description: TURELL-Annette. Age 86. Passed away January 11 in Scottsdale, Arizona. She was a native and lived in Hewlett, Long Island for over 60 years. She was a member of the Woodmere Country Club. She was the wife of the late Norman Turell. She is survived by her son Robert L. (wife, Marjorie) of Scottsdale, Arizona; daughter Bonnie L. Turell of Chicago, Illinois; sister Beatrice Korn (husband, Murray) of West Palm Beach, Florida; grandchildren Laurence, Jeffrey and Laura; and greatgrandchildren Nathaniel, Jeremy and Austin. Graveside service 1:15PM Wednesday, January 13 at Old Mount Carmel Cemetery, Ridgewood, New York.

title: INSIDE
description: Going, Going, Gone

title: In a Tiny Office, Khmer Rouge Files Tell Grisly Tales
description: With portraits of their quarry on the walls around them, a dozen Cambodian researchers sit at computers in a tiny office here, processing hundreds of thousands of documents that form the core of a potential legal case against the leaders of the Khmer Rouge.

title: AEGON AND AMERICAN FINANCIAL ARE IN $115 MILLION DEAL
description: American Financial Group Inc., a property and casualty insurer, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the auto insurer Worldwide Insurance Company, based in St. Louis, from Aegon N.V. of the Netherlands for $115 million in cash. The purchase gives the Cincinnati-based American Financial, whose main business is auto insurance, about $115 million in annual premiums to add to its current $2.6 billion. American Financial also gets entry to direct-response sales, mainly through direct mail. The company has traditionally sold auto insurance through independent agents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODFRIEND, EVELYN
description: GOODFRIEND-Evelyn. January 5, 1999. Beloved wife of Morton, sister of Judge Harold Baker. Born and raised in Katonah, family then relocated to Bronx. After marriage, Queens for twelve years, then Larchmont in 1970. Hunter College graduate, worked at consumer market reserach companies and for Stewart Dougall and Associates in New York. Volunteered in NYC and Larchmont Schools. For fifteen years worked with the International Center teaching foreign visitors English and aspects of living in New York. She will be dearly missed and lovingly remembered.

title: Report Issued Early Shows Rise in Producer Prices
description: Prices paid to producers rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month after a record surge in cigarette prices more than offset declines in energy and food costs, the Labor Department said in a report that was posted by mistake on the Internet today, a day early.

title: What Is Being Tested?
description: To the Editor:

title: So What Explains That Loyalty to Clinton?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, HERBERT
description: JACOBSON-Herbert. On Friday January 8, 1999, of Maplewood, NJ. Devoted husband of the late Anne (nee Notick). Beloved father of Judith Cohn and Richard Jacobson. Adored brother of Sidney Jacobson. Loving grandfather of five grandchildren and six great grandchildren. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, New Jersey, Friday, January 15, 1999 at 3:30 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIVAK, HAROLD P.
description: SPIVAK-Harold P. Died January 12, 1999. Devoted husband of Ruth Spivak, loving father of Steven and Barbara Spivak, father-in-law of Sandy and Howard, devoted grandfather of Lisa, Eric, Katie, Adam and Elizabeth, dear brother of Pearl Levy & Evelyn Weingold and the late Ruth, Dorothy and Murray. Memorial services will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue, N.Y., NY, Thursday, January 14, 1999 at 12:30 PM. Family members and friends wishing to make a donation in memory of Harold P. Spivak are requested to send their contribution to the Richard F. Walsh/Alfred W. Di Tolla Foundation, 1515 Broadway, Suite 601, New York, New York 10036, 212-730-1770.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 5 about the film producer David Puttnam misidentified the position for which Tony Blair was campaigning in 1992, when Mr. Puttnam was his advance man. Mr. Blair, now Prime Minister, sought -- unsuccessfully -- to become Home Secretary, not Prime Minister.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCANLON, MARK W.
description: SCANLON-Mark W. January 13, 1992. We remember you today and always. With love. Your Family

title: Another Era
description: The Jets are flying to Denver on a wide-body plane so that players can be comfortable, Coach Bill Parcells has dictated. But there was a moment in Jets history when the team almost canceled its flight to Denver because there was no money to pay the players.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Intel Reports Solid Earnings In Its Fourth Quarter

title: IXC COMMUNICATIONS IN $100 MILLION COASTAL PHONE DEAL
description: IXC Communications Inc., a wholesale telephone company, said yesterday that it agreed to acquire the Coastal Telephone Company, a privately held long-distance reseller based in Houston, for $75 million in cash and $25 million in IXC stock. IXC, based in Austin, Tex., provides services and products related to the transmission of voice, video and data. It said it would combine Coastal, which provides telecommunications services to small and medium-sized business, with its Eclipse Telecommunications Inc. unit.

title: As Jordan Retires, Legend Swells
description: Out of respect, Michael Jordan first told Ron Harper and Scottie Pippen, his two closest teammates on the Chicago Bulls, on Monday that he was planning to retire. Harper and Pippen did not argue or plead with Jordan to stay. They simply sat and reminisced, the way they would in the workout room of Jordan's suburban Chicago home after each championship season.

title: 2 Brothers, 4 and 3, Die in Suffolk House Fire
description: Two young brothers who investigators said appeared to have been playing with matches died today in an early morning fire that engulfed their Suffolk County home, the authorities said.

title: Court Is Asked Not to Extend Harassment Law in Schools
description: The lawyer for a Georgia school board warned the Supreme Court today that school districts across the country would face dire financial consequences if the Court extended Federal sexual harassment law to apply to harassment of one student by another and made schools liable for failing to curb students' sexual misconduct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUGRUE, MARTHA G.
description: SHUGRUE-Martha G. On January 11, 1999. Beloved wife of the late J. Edward Shugrue. Loving mother of William, Edward and John. Service and interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Marble Collegiate Church or the Jacob Perlow Hospice.

title: Metro Business; Cablevision Sells Systems
description: Cablevision Systems Corporation, the sixth-largest cable television operator in the United States, sold two New Jersey systems to the closely held U.S. Cable Corporation, completing a divestiture ordered by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: The Neediest Cases; Compassion Moves Donors to Give Year After Year
description: Sixty years ago, a 3-year-old girl named Alice Louise Rutter entered a hospital on Long Island with a simple case of eczema. But she developed an infection, and in those days before penicillin was available, doctors were unable to treat her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, MARGOT FINLETTER
description: MITCHELL-Margot Finletter, on January 11, 1999, aged 77, of Stonington, CT., formerly of New York City. She is survived by her husband of fifty years, John F.B. Mitchell, her son, Thomas F. Mitchell, and granddaughters Ariel and Danica Mitchell. She was the sister of the late Lili Finletter O'Neill and the daughter of the late Thomas K. Finletter and Gretchen Damrosch Finletter. The funeral service will be at Calvary Church, Stonington, CT at 11 AM, Friday, January 15, 1999. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to Alzheimer's Research Association of Connecticut, 2911 Dixwell Avenue, Hamden, CT. 06518.

title: Charter Schools, Then What?
description: The time for debating the legislation creating charter schools in New York State has passed, but educators who value public education are nonetheless obliged to speak out now, before too many of the 100 schools permitted by the recently adopted law are created and before the state starts down the slippery slope toward increased privatization of education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARUSO, MARGARET MARIE
description: CARUSO - Margaret Marie. Passed peacefully at home on Sunday, January 10, 1999. Her parting will leave a void which we will fill with remembered joy. Mother touched our lives with much love and warmth and friendship. Funeral Services at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave, NYC.

title: TV Political News in California Is Shrinking, Study Confirms
description: For years, politicians in California have argued that television news here gives them short shrift, and a new study by the Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Southern California has more than confirmed their complaint.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I still don't believe this is for real. I think even if he announces his retirement, the playoffs will roll around, the Bulls will lose to the Knicks, and Michael's competitive juices will start flowing and he'll decide he doesn't want to sit around and smoke cigars all day long.''

title: Woman Raped in Her Building
description: A 37-year-old woman was raped in the stairwell of her Manhattan building late Monday night, the police said yesterday.

title: Beware of the Kyoto Compromise
description: In November the Clinton Administration signed a treaty, negotiated in Kyoto, Japan, that purports to temper ''global warming'' by imposing a schedule of emissions reductions on so-called greenhouse gases. The action was widely regarded as a public relations move, pure and simple, because the Senate has voted overwhelmingly -- 95 to 0 -- to reject the treaty as written.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMASSET, PAUL A.
description: THOMASSET-Paul A. Born on November 30, 1902, passed away January 8, 1999. Paul came alone to this country from France when he was sixteen. At 20 years of age he attended Cooper Union and studied engineering. Paul became a pigment chemist and was general manager of Anshcher Siegle in Staten Island. In 1946 he started his own business, Thomasset Colors Inc. manufacturing cosmetic and industrial pigments. Over the course of his business career, he brought a high level of discipline and a rigorous rationality to his field of expertise and to those who worked under his supervision with many going on to become leaders in the industry. He was a great teacher. Married to Henrietta Bridgewater until her death, they produced one son, Paul B., three grandsons, Paul C., Lelend P., and Clifford B. and four great grandchildren, Carly, Paul D., Ian and Genevieve, all of whom will miss his good cheer, great intelligence, and love. He is predeceased by his second wife of 12 years, Yolanda. It is for us to carry on his love of the old world ways and challenge of the new. His view of life was ''adapt or die'' and his life was a triumph of adaption, curiosity, art, music, science and politics. A memorial fund has been established at Cooper Union, (212) 353-4100.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOCHER, ERIC
description: KOCHER-Eric passed away peacefully at home at age 86 on January 2, 1999. Beloved husband of Margaret Helburn Kocher, devoted and gentle father of Eric Glenn of Atlanta, GA, Terry of Anchorage, AL, Christopher of San Francisco, CA and Debra of Tenafly, NJ. Grandfather to four grandsons and three granddaughters. A memorial service is planned for the spring. Donations may be made in his name to The Eugene O'Neill Center, New York.

title: Aetna to Allow Outside Reviews of Care Denials
description: Aetna U.S. Healthcare, the big managed care company, said yesterday that it would voluntarily allow its health plan members in 30 states to have outside reviews of decisions that deny them necessary or experimental care.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CATES, JOSEPH
description: CATES-Joseph. On October 10, 1998. The New York Friars Club and the Cates family deeply mourn his passing and extend an invitation to attend a memorial service on Monday, January 25 at 2pm at Director's Guild Theater, 110 West 57 Street, NYC.

title: 'Numbers' at Lincoln Center
description: The visual arts have been a vital part of Lincoln Center since its inception, not only as an onstage accompaniment to the performing arts but as a defining element in a visitor's experience of Lincoln Center itself. Marc Chagall's murals in the Metropolitan Opera House, Henry Moore's ''Reclining Figure'' in the reflecting pool, Jasper Johns's ''Numbers, 1964'' in the New York State Theater -- these and other works are as inseparable from Lincoln Center as Eero Saarinen's design for the Vivian Beaumont Theater or Philip Johnson's design for Lincoln Center Plaza itself.

title: 7 Accused of Castro Plot Will Be Tried in Miami
description: In what could prove a pivotal ruling in the case of seven Cuban exiles accused of plotting to kill Fidel Castro in 1997, a Federal judge today granted a defense petition to transfer the proceedings to Miami, despite opposition from the United States Attorney's Office here.

title: William H. Whyte, 'Organization Man' Author and Urbanologist, Is Dead at 81
description: William H. Whyte, the author who defined corporate conformity and warned against its growth in the classic book ''The Organization Man,'' died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Gil Haggerty, 79, Aide for 40 Years To Times Editors
description: Gilbert M. Haggerty, a skillful and good-humored aide to six metropolitan editors at The New York Times, died on Sunday at his home in Forked River, N.J. He was 79.

title: An Icon Retires
description: For selfish reasons, we wish that Michael Jordan had stayed on. His absence denies us the pleasure of watching one of the world's great athletes and surely the most accomplished basketball player in the history of the game. His presence might have redeemed this sadly truncated season and restored some of the affection we had for the game before the owners and players almost took it away. It will not be easy to replace a global icon.

title: For the Mall Rats, A New Piper
description: MOVE over, Martha Stewart and Jaclyn Smith. Costing less means selling more. Or so Michael Graves hopes.

title: DaimlerChrysler-Lagardere Talks Cited
description: DaimlerChrysler Aerospace A.G. is talking to France's Lagardere S.C.A. about an alliance following a deadlock in the German company's plan to merge with British Aerospace P.L.C., people close to the talks said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMSON, LUCIEN
description: THOMSON-Lucien., age eighty-six of New York City, died Tuesday, January 11, 2000. Survived by his first cousins Isabel D. Thomson of Atlanta, GA and Albert D. Thomson of Cotton, GA. Harpist, composer, author and teacher of the harp in New York City since 1946. Long-time member and past President of The American Harp Society, Inc. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be sent to American Harp Society Foundation-Marcel Grandjany fund, c/o Jan Bishop, 624 Crystal Ave, Findlay, OH 45840.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: As an Economy Sinks, U.S. Sees Painful Choices
description: When President Clinton and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin announced two months ago what they termed a ''precautionary'' $41.5 billion aid package for Brazil, they described it as the first test of a new strategy to help countries reform their economies before being overwhelmed by the tumultuous global market forces that have swept from Asia to Russia to Latin America.

title: Mayor Tells Non-New Yorkers That City's Trash Is Price for What They Reap
description: Facing growing resistance from other states to New York City's garbage, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the rest of the nation was obligated to take it in return for the many cultural and financial benefits reaped from the city.

title: A Bid for Gucci? Not Now, LVMH Says
description: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A., the world's No. 1 maker of luxury goods, said yesterday that it did not plan to make a takeover offer for the Italian fashion house Gucci Group N.V. ''under the present conditions.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELDMAN, SAMUEL
description: FELDMAN-Samuel. The Board of Directors, staff, and volunteers of God's Love We Deliver are saddened by the loss of Samuel Feldman, devoted father of Richard E. Feldman, our Board Chair. We extend our deepest sympathy to Richard and the entire Feldman family and hope that loving memories of Samuel will help ease their sorrow during this sad time.

title: Public Art for Sale: At What Price?
description: To the Editor:

title: Finally, Lucent and Ascend Tie the Knot for $20 Billion
description: In announcing its $20 billion acquisition of Ascend Communications Inc. yesterday, Lucent Technologies Inc. called it the ''largest technology merger ever'' and ''a leap rather than a step,'' but there was an unmistakable whiff of ho-hum in the air.

title: Going After the Social Security Chimeras
description: To the Editor:

title: Boston Celtics Stock Up
description: The stock of Boston Celtics L.P. hit a 52-week high of $17.50 yesterday, as the publicly traded owner of the National Basketball Association team said that its private partnership, Castle Creek Partners, had made an offer for up to 16 percent of the company's stock. Last June, Boston Celtics L.P. reorganized into a public partnership and a private partnership, to address tax issues. Holders of about 48 percent of the outstanding units chose to continue investing in the public partnership, while holders of 52 percent of the units chose the private partnership. Castle Creek's offer for 430,000 limited partnership units, at $17 each, expires on March 1. The shares closed today at $16.50, up $2.50, or nearly 18 percent.

title: The Better to Banish Error
description: What makes a perfect eraser? Steven Leveen, president of Levenger, a catalogue company that specializes in reading accessories, tackled that question two years ago. He found that it must be comfortable in the hand and should not smudge. Mr. Leveen and his designers played with clay until they created the Ergoraser, a ''cross between an egg and a spoon,'' he said. Three erasers made of PVC-free polyvinyl sell for $18.95 in a tin that can be recycled into an eyeglass case; (800) 544-0880 or www.levenger.com.

title: Going After the Social Security Chimeras
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPETZ, JOSHUA MARK
description: LIPETZ-Joshua Mark. The Marsha Stern Talmudical AcademyYeshiva University High School mourns the untimely passing of Joshua Lipetz, 1997 graduate. We remember his quiet dignity, intense love of learning and devotion to family and friends. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Michael Taubes, Principal Faculty and Staff

title: Removal of Healthy Breasts Is Found to Cut Cancer Risk
description: For women with a high risk of breast cancer, a study being published today offers hope, but at a cruel price. Removing both breasts while they are still healthy reduces the risk of getting breast cancer by 90 percent.

title: An Art Book For Browsing The Internet
description: SOMETIMES you have to stare at a work of art for a while before appreciating it. So it is, too, with ''Art Information and the Internet: How to Find It, How to Use It,'' a recently published book from Oryx Press.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WETTLAUFER, C. PENN
description: WETTLAUFER-C. Penn. January 11, 2000, died peacefully at home at the age of 64 after a short but courageous battle with cancer. A graduate of St. Mark's School, Southboro, MA., and Princeton University Class of 1958, he received an MBA from Amos Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth College in 1960. Former president of H.D. Taylor Company in Buffalo, New York, he was most recently professor of business management and economics at Empire State Colllege, a subsidiary of State University of New York. An avid squash player & local volunteer, Mr. Wettlaufer is survived by his wife, Margaret McAloon; his stepmother, Emily W. Wettlaufer; brothers, Warren T. Wettlaufer, Vail, CO, Denis T. Wettlaufer, Buffalo, W. Kimberly Wettlaufer, Lewiston, ME; six daughters, Alexandra W. Carpenter, Austin, TX, Jennifer W. Sednaoui, Bedford, NY, Elizabeth W. Cox, Buffalo, Talley D. Wettlaufer, Columbus, OH, Virginia S. Wettlaufer, Buffalo, Rebecca Wettlalufer, Buffalo; and 5 grandchildren. Memorial service Friday, Jan. 14 at 4 PM at the First Presbyterian Church, Buffalo, NY.

title: Treats for Off-the-Menu Tastes
description: When critics say it was a mediocre year for music, that's not the whole story. What they mean to say is that it was a mediocre year for popular music. With more than 25,000 albums released last year, the laws of probability predict that at least a few dozen will fit each taste. The problem is finding them. Record labels and radio stations often make their decisions based on trends, genres and life style instead of along purely musical lines. When the right music is released at the wrong time, it can slip by unnoticed.

title: A Big Play in Denver For Meggett and Coach
description: With the American Football Conference championship game in Denver just four days away, Jets Coach Bill Parcells and his longtime favorite kick returner, David Meggett, both remembered the same thing about Parcells's last -- and only -- visit as a head coach to Mile High Stadium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIERSTEIN, HELEN
description: FIERSTEIN-Helen. On Thursday January 13, 2000. Helen (nee Dicker) of Verona, formerly of East Orange and Jersey City, New Jersey. Beloved wife of the late Philip Fierstein. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKOLNICK, DAVID
description: SKOLNICK-David. Age 84, of Delray Beach, Fla., and New York on January 10, 1999. Adored husband of the late Barbara Skolnick. Beloved and admired father of Louis and Lee, father-in-law of Shelley and Jo Ann. Loving grandfather of Ethan, Seth, Elizabeth and Harry. Devoted brother of Rose Barrett, Marlene Lieberman, and the late Sam Skolnick. Patriarch of a great extended family. Founder, with his father, Wolf, and President of Fruitcrest Corporation. Inventor of Juicy Juice. He will be remembered as a creative, dynamic businessman and leader in his industry who brought a passion for life to all he did. And as an extraordinary individual whose generousity and devotion engendered deep respect and love. Our lives will be emptier without him, but the joy of his life and his journey will live on in our memories. Contributions in his honor may be made to the Fresh Air Fund, 1040 Avenue of the Americas, NY, NY 10018, att: Developement Department.

Donations to Guilford Free Library, 67 Park Street, Guilford, CT. 06437. The Guilford Funeral Home, 115 Church Street, Guilford, CT.

title: TURMOIL IN BRAZIL: THE MISTAKES -- Economic Scene; Brazil Swallows Another Bitter Pill
description: Brazil's surprise devaluation was anything but surprising.

title: Recoil, Then Recovery
description: Brazil's plan to devalue its currency initially deflated the confidence of stock investors in the United States and abroad. But after a sharp selloff in the first half-hour of trading, American stocks rebounded steadily throughout the day.

title: Corrections
description: The Commercial Property column yesterday, about 14th Street, misidentified a former bank building that is being converted to condominiums and a theater. It is at the southwest corner of Eighth Avenue and 14th. (It is not the building on the northwest corner, which opened in 1887 as the New York Bank for Savings and now houses the Central Carpet store. That store remains open.)

title: With Minimalist Approach, Paleontology Is Brought to Life
description: UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA MUSEUM OF PALEONTOLOGY

title: ASSOCIATES FIRST CAPITAL TO PICK UP SHELL CREDIT CARDS
description: The Associates First Capital Corporation has agreed to buy the Shell Oil Company's credit card portfolio for an undisclosed amount to solidify its No. 1 position in the gasoline proprietary credit card market. Shell Oil is part of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group of companies. The Dallas-based Associates will buy the portfolio from two joint-venture companies: Equilon Enterprises L.L.C., a joint venture company between Shell Oil and Texaco Inc., and Motiva Enterprises L.L.C., a joint venture among Shell Oil, Texaco and Saudi Aramco. Associates already owns the Texaco credit card portfolio. Associates, with 7 million active gasoline credit card accounts, will pick up about $272 million in credit card balances and about 2.3 million Shell Oil customers. As part of the deal, Associates will also issue, process and service credit cards for Shell and Texaco. Customers will not notice a change, it said.

title: We're All Equal Under the Law; Correcting History
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A music review yesterday about a performance by the Guarneri String Quartet at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday reversed the identities of two players who stepped outside their usual parts. John Dalley, ordinarily second violin, played first violin in Arriaga's Quartet No. 2 and Dvorak's Terzetto (Op. 74); Arnold Steinhardt, ordinarily first violin, played viola in the Dvorak and first violin in the Grieg Quartet (Op. 27).

In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the Alzheimer's Disease & Related Disorders Association, 1 Kendall Square, Building #

title: Identity Checks; High-Tech Help for Frequent Travelers Entering U.S.
description: AFTER a flight to the United States, most travelers want to grab their luggage and go to bed, not wait in line at the airport. But wait they do, sometimes for an hour or more as Immigration and Naturalization Service inspectors check passports and ask questions in their efforts to stop criminals and unauthorized foreigners from entering the country.

title: A Song Ascending to the Pantheon?
description: Every so often, a song becomes so ubiquitous on the cabaret circuit that it looms as a likely standard. The latest one to ring that bell is John Bucchino's hymnlike anthem ''Grateful.'' A sobbingly passionate celebration of living in the moment, it declares: ''It's not that I don't want a lot or hope for more, or dream of more/But giving thanks for what I've got makes me so much happier than keeping score.''

title: Public Art for Sale: At What Price?
description: To the Editor:

title: Elway Focuses On the Jets, Not His Future
description: He is old six months short of his 39th birthday -- and tired, too. More than 250 games in the National Football League over 16 seasons means thousands of hits and months of hurt. But John Elway got healed and got younger last year when he drank from a career-affirming fountain.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REUBEN, RICHARD N., M.D.
description: REUBEN-Richard N., M.D.. Four years have not diminished our thoughts of you and love for you. Sadly missed by those whom you loved and cared for so deeply! R; E & M; N & P; M & S. A, J, A; K, C; C, J, & D

title: Metro Business; Sneaker Store Closings
description: Footstar said it would close 30 unprofitable Footaction stores and trim expansion plans, taking a fourth-quarter charge of $22.7 million, as it slims down to stay competitive in the slumping footwear industry.

title: Personal Shopper; No More Blue Mondays
description: NO ONE is exempt from laundry, except perhaps those college students who haul their clothes home. This season brings a hamperful of goods for toting, sorting, storing, washing and ironing. Aromatherapy has even hit the laundry room: if it's worth $35 to make the experience more spiritual, there is scented water for steam irons. The cognoscenti say eau de linge.

title: The Government's first study on discrimination in radio advertising finds a lot of fodder.
description: A MANAGER in New York for three FM radio stations one aimed at a black audience, the others at broader general audiences -- reports that upscale car companies like Volvo and BMW refuse to buy advertisements on the black station, even when shown market surveys indicating that the black audience is more interested in buying such cars.

title: The $10 Billion Man?
description: Legend has it that when Michael Jordan was in elementary school, a teacher advised him to study mathematics because ''that's where the money is.'' The money turned out to be elsewhere. After accounting for Jordan's impact on everything from game attendance to Nike's sneaker sales, Fortune magazine labeled Jordan the ''$10 Billion Man.''

title: Venice Journal; Boat Gobbles Waves, but Bobbles in Political Seas
description: A small, sleek 22-foot powerboat took a maiden voyage today through the choppy waters of the Grand Canal, and, strangely, barely left a ripple.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about Crane Company's lawsuit to force Coltec Industries to consider its takeover offer misstated the reason Crane's proposal would be tax-free. In such proposals, the acquirer uses its common stock to purchase the target company's common stock, a transaction that is considered nontaxable. While the combined value of the companies' balance sheets helps determine how the acquirer will report earnings, it is not a factor in whether the transaction is taxable.

title: Seeking Speed, America Online Joins Forces With Bell Atlantic
description: In a move to compete with high-speed cable-modem services, America Online and Bell Atlantic yesterday announced a joint marketing effort to sell high-speed Internet access to America Online's customers.

title: New Leader Meets Sampras and Agassi
description: Judy Levering, who was officially sworn in as the first female president of the United States Tennis Association on Jan. 1, didn't waste any time getting down to business.

title: Deutsche Bank to Raise $:1 Billion Buyout Fund
description: Morgan Grenfell Private Equity, the venture capital arm of Deutsche Bank A.G., is raising a new $:1 billion ($1.65 billion) fund for European buyouts, the company said yesterday, as investors take advantage of restructuring among the region's companies.

title: After a Schoolgirl's Slaying, Fear Grips a Community
description: At the Kmart Shopping Plaza on Route 9 in Old Bridge, the stores were bustling tonight and the parking lot was nearly full, but few people were walking along the streets outside the plaza's rear entrance. It was on one of those blocks that Nancy K. Noga, 17, had been walking home the night investigators say she was dragged into the woods and killed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, EUNICE
description: FISHMAN-Eunice. Loving wife of Herman, beloved mother of Beth Trafton, Dr. Mindy Berstein and Leslie Snyder, and cherished grandmother. She provided the ultimate example of motherhood. She will be forever in our hearts & greatly missed. Funeral services will be held at 11 A.M., Sunday, January 16, 2000, at Beth-El Synagogue, Northfield Road and North Avenue, New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, SYLVIA
description: BROWN-Sylvia. Devoted wife of Martin. Adored mother of Miriam Teram, Wendy Porcelli, Allen Brown, Debbie Piotrkowski, Jeffrey Brown and Jaynee Yehezkel. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother. Services today, 11 AM, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: New Ideas That Differ But Point To the Future
description: The new comes in all sorts of forms, and at Birdland on Monday night two leaders brought two completely different conceptions of the future to the stage. The first was the drummer and composer Brian Blade, who mixed jazz and odd compositional ideas that sounded guitaristic, as if composed on a guitar. The second was the pianist and composer Danilo Perez, who mixed Afro-Cuban music and jazz in a way that hadn't been done before.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a mural in Johannesburg that is a testament to the role played by theater people in the anti-apartheid struggle in South Africa misattributed the play ''Woza Albert.'' It was written by Mbongeni Ngema, Percy Mtwa and Barney Simon, not by Athol Fugard, who is pictured in the mural.

title: Disney Interest Lifts Golden Books Stock
description: Shares of Golden Books Family Entertainment rose sharply yesterday, a day after Michael D. Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company, said that Disney might be interested in acquiring the troubled children's publishing company.

title: Ex-Aide to Reagan Will Head the Congressional Budget Office
description: Dan L. Crippen, who worked for President Ronald Reagan and for Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader in the early 1980's, was chosen today to be director of the Congressional Budget Office, a powerful agency with an influential voice in debates on economic and social policy.

title: Dixie Sees a Jackpot in the Lottery
description: Lottery fever hit South Carolina today, and it had nothing to do with the size of the Powerball jackpot. On a mild and sunny day, the state's 114th Governor, James H. Hodges, used his inauguration ceremonies to begin lobbying for ambitious educational improvements that he maintains can be paid for only through adoption of a statewide lottery.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; U.S. financial industry may already have fortified itself against the latest emerging-market crisis.
description: AS Yogi Berra once observed, it's deja vu all over again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORBER, RUTH P.
description: LORBER-Ruth P. A gracious and sunny ''woman of valour'', who I will miss most for her consistent kindness over almost 30 years. To Pop and all who loved her, my deepest sympathy and affection. Barbara Heyman Lorber

title: Jets Work on Containing a 2,000-Yard Man
description: The best running back the Jets ''or anyone else,'' according to Coach Bill Parcells -- have faced this season loomed on the projection screen here for the defense today.

title: Harold P. Spivak, Lawyer, 83
description: Harold P. Spivak, a lawyer for many theatrical unions for more than 40 years, died on Tuesday at his home on the East Side of Manhattan. He was 83.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHASHA, MAURICE
description: SHASHA-Maurice. Your four remaining brothers wish you to rest in peace and want to say that your memory and accomplishments will always remain uppermost in our minds. The Shasha Brothers

title: An Amusing Old-Time Gem, Except for the Plot's Victim
description: The granddaddy of all magazines in the field, The Bridge World, celebrates its 70th birthday this year by giving itself a new look: larger print, slightly larger pages and more of them. For information, (800) 366-1939 or write to 717 White Plains Road, Scarsdale, N.Y. 10583.

title: The Neediest Cases; Getting a Serving of Help At a Center for the Elderly
description: It was a Wednesday morning, and Carol Lothman was spending it as she usually does: doling out tickets for lunch at the Catherine M. Sheridan Senior Citizen Center in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: The Torchere Is Passed
description: LIKE extremely rare gilt side chairs and exceptional Louis XV what's-its, the late decorator Mark Hampton was a fixture at the Winter Antiques Show. He could invariably be spotted at the cavernous entrance to the Seventh Regiment Armory, one prestigious client or another hanging on both his words and his pinstriped Savile Row suits with twin vents.

title: Graves's Progress From Paper Visions to Giant Teakettles
description: AT last, there is reason to hope that the Whitney Museum of American Art may be casting off its reputation for trendiness. In what may be seen, fairly or not, as a defining moment in the early tenure of the Whitney's new director, Maxwell Anderson, the museum has rented its premises next Tuesday evening for the unveiling of a new line of houseware accessories and furniture designed for Target stores by the American architect Michael Graves.

title: Treading on the Mouse's Heels: The Oh-So-Subtle Touch Pad
description: FOR many, the computer mouse is a marvel of ingenuity. But for George E. Gerpheide, an engineer, it is an abomination. He set out to build, if not a better mousetrap, then something to rid society of the inelegant mouse.

title: Sitting Doesn't Suit Salo
description: If anyone knows how the Islanders' Tommy Salo feels, it's Felix Potvin. In Toronto, Potvin was in a predicament similar to Salo's -- the odd man out -- when Curtis Joseph took over in the Maple Leafs' net.

title: Next Frontier: Amateur Golf
description: Michael Jordan's retirement is bad news for the National Basketball Association, but good news for the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.

title: Retailers' 3d-Quarter After-Tax Profits Off
description: Profits after taxes at major United States retailers fell during the third quarter of 1998 to the lowest level in more than a year, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Parents, Teachers and N.A.A.C.P. Sue School District Over Grouping of Students
description: The Long Island chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., joined by a group of parents and the teachers' union, filed a Federal lawsuit today against the Amityville School District, asserting that a system of grouping elementary students by their scores on proficiency tests was racially discriminatory and unconstitutional.

title: U.S. Opens Hot Line For Year 2000 Queries
description: With fewer than 365 shopping days left until the possible onset of a millennium bug, the Federal Government has sprung into action and created . . . a telephone hot line.

title: GTS and Flag to Build Phone Cable System
description: Global Telesystems Group, a telecommunications company backed by the billionaire George Soros, and the Bermuda-based Flag Telecom said today that they planned to build a $1 billion telephone cable system to carry high-speed data across the Atlantic.

title: PUBLIC LIVES

title: Garden Q.& A.; Blooming Pips
description: Q. I have heard that it is possible to force lily of the valley to bloom indoors in the winter. I have them in my garden, and I wonder -- can I just dig them up and bring them inside or is there more to it than that?

description: FREEMAN-Ethel Wolff. On January 13, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Arthur R. Daughter of the late Louis and Rae Wolff. Loving mother of Linda (Ted) Lynn and Karen (Jack) Lowe. Adored grandmother of Jessica and Douglas Lynn and Deborah and Adam Lowe. Devoted sister of the late Shirley Cohen Dreitzer and Annette Katz. Cherished aunt, cousin and friend. Service Friday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEELEY, ALICE M.
description: FEELEY-Alice M.. A Croton-onHudson resident and former longtime Brooklyn resident died January 13, 2000. She was 97. She was born November 12, 1902 to Joseph and Mary Dillon McGrane. She was a graduate of St. Joseph's College in Brooklyn, class of 1924. Alice married John T. Feeley on February 9, 1937; he died in 1973. She was a member of the Brooklyn Women's Club. Mrs. Feeley was a retired teacher for the NYC Board of Education. She is survived by a daughter Sister Alice Feeley, R.D.C. of Elmsford. A brother Joseph McGrane and two sisters Genevieve McEvoy and Gertrude Dowd died earlier. Visitation will be Friday from 2-8 pm at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, (914) 949-7777. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 10 AM at the Chapel of the Divine Compassion, White Plains. Interment St. Johns Cemetery, Middle Village. Donations may be made to the Ministry Fund of the Sisters of the Divine Compassion, 52 N. Broadway, White Plains, NY 10603.

title: Playful Alchemy: A Movie Becomes a Game
description: IF, as Frank Zappa observed, writing about music is like dancing about architecture, then video games about movies are like synchronized swimming about opera. The media have very little in common except a flat screen. And the question is: How do you map a linear, noninteractive story onto a free-ranging environment where the player decides what comes next? How do you translate a film into a game without compromising either?

title: Argentina May Suffer Most From Neighbor's Ills
description: As shock waves from Brazil's devaluation of its currency reverberated across Latin America today, analysts said Argentina was likely to be rattled the most severely and that other countries bordering Brazil would be shaken more than Mexico, where ties to the United States economy would cushion the shock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPPLER, FRANK
description: KAPPLER-Frank. 84. Died at home in Fearrington Village, North Carolina, January 9, 1999. He is survived by his wife, Gerry, two sons and six grandchildren. Donations in his name may be made to The Hospice of Chatham County, 200 East Street, Pittsboro, NC 27312 or to Dartmouth College Alumni Fund, Hanover, N.H. 03755

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLET, BENJAMIN
description: POLLET-Benjamin. Died January 12. Beloved husband of Estelle (nee Kubrin) for 61 years. Loving father of Michael and Marian Sue and grandfather of Steven, Merryl, Erik, Alison and Jeremy. Sixty plus years as a caring, dedicated family physician to generations in the Ridgewood and Flatbush sections of Brooklyn. He will long be remembered for his care and skill and his devotion to the healing of thousands.

title: Adopted Unawares in Red Hook
description: WE never talked to each other until the big yellow dog showed up, lying like a sphinx under the goal posts of the soccer field. ''Come over here, honey,'' Charlie Mae called, only I didn't know her name then. To me, she was the jaunty woman who walked the track every morning in a colorful headdress, a loose skirt that came to her calves and red tights with Reeboks.

title: David Newton, 76, Open-Admissions Leader
description: Dr. David Newton, who shaped the introduction of open admissions at the City University of New York as chairman of its Task Force on Open Enrollment in 1969, died on Monday at his home in Brookville, N.Y. He was 76.

title: Gas Fire Injures 8 Workers in Trench, 1 Seriously
description: A natural gas flash fire last night in a Brooklyn Union Gas excavation pit left a utility worker in critical condition with second-degree burns and injured seven other workers seriously enough for them to be taken to hospitals.

title: Dueling M.I.T. Economists Testify at Microsoft Trial
description: In the Microsoft trial today, a Justice Department lawyer opened cross-examination of the company's first witness by asking him to concede that Microsoft held a monopoly in personal-computer operating systems.

title: In Home of Ballot Initiative, Court Ruling Is Seen as Boon or Bane
description: In the West, the populist cradle of the ballot initiative movement, a new Supreme Court ruling rejecting curbs on petition circulators was hailed today by issue advocates as a move toward greater democracy and denounced by state legislators as commercializing a grass-roots process.

title: BRAZIL DEVALUES ITS CURRENCY 8%, ROILING MARKETS
description: Challenged by political adversaries at home and nervous investors abroad, Brazil's Government devalued the nation's currency today, allowing it to fall by more than 8 percent and setting off turbulence in many world financial markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, LLOYD
description: GREENFIELD-Lloyd, on January 12. Beloved husband of Rhoma, devoted father of Laura and Robert, adored and adoring Pop of Blake and Kathryn, Allex and Amanda. A very dear man, cherished by all who knew him. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Ave, 1PM on Thursday, January 14.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDAN, OLIVIA EMILY (HEBERT)
description: JORDAN-Olivia Emily (Hebert). Born, Boley, Oklahoma, to William Edward Hebert and Blanche Julia Ann Hebert (nee Leon) June 30, 1912, died December 8, 1998, of lymphoma. Adored mother of Achille Edward, Blanche Jacqueline, and Cheryl Faithe. Valedictorian, Boley High School, 1927; B.A., Langston, University, 1933; M.A., Atlanta University, 1943. Taught elementary school in Hominy and Taft, Oklahoma, and high school in Wewoka, Oklahoma, 1933-1941; instructor of English, Social Science, and Math, Langston University, 1949-1954; social worker, Kings County Hospital, Brooklyn; Supervisor, Social Services, Metropolitan Hospital, New York City; Director of Social Services, Cumberland Hospital, Brooklyn; retired 1977. Resident of Englewood, New Jersey 1977 until her death. Volunteer, UrbanLeague of Bergen County, and Center of Concern, St. Cecelia's R.C. Church, Englewood. Soror, Alpha Kappa Alpha. Lifetime Member, NAACP. Lifelong Democrat. Survived by former husband, George Whitte Jordan; son-in-law, Eugene D. Skurnick; sister-in-law, Virginia C. Hebert, grandchildren David Achille, Elizabeth Sarah, and Miriam Julia Skurnick. Funeral Mass was offered in Englewood and ecumenical service in Teaneck, N.J. December 12. Interment was in Guthrie, Oklahoma, December 15, 1998.

title: Screenwriters Find a Toehold on Net
description: TO be an aspiring screenwriter today without knowing a soul in Hollywood is like trying to tackle Mount Everest without proper training, supplies or guides. First, the writer must master an art form that is prickly at best. Compared with what lies ahead, writing is the easy part. Ascending the peak means selling the script. To do that, the writer needs an agent or manager to shepherd the script to Hollywood producers and studio executives who are in a position to buy it. There's a Catch-22: reading unsolicited material is verboten for those same agents and managers. The same goes for producers and studio executives.

title: A Smaller Videophone
description: The Dick Tracy video-watch remains a dream -- or nightmare -- but some videophone makers are close. The Videophone 2020, unveiled last week at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, works through regular phone lines. Its maker, the I-See-You Corporation of Holliston, Mass., says the 2.2-pound phone provides video images at up to 15 frames a second, enough to see Pruneface's lips move as he talks. It will be available by the end of this month, costing between $800 and $1,000.

title: A Test Case for Investing Inclusion
description: When the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson opens up the Wall Street Project conference on minorities and investment today, one of the central players is expected to be Mel Farr, who heads the nation's largest black-owned auto dealership.

title: A Silicon Wall Rises on the Border
description: FROM a hillside overlooking the border with Mexico, you can see the many obstacles that illegal aliens and drug smugglers must navigate to enter the United States. There is a steel fence cutting across miles of scrub, stadium lights that illuminate the night and hundreds of Government agents posted in vans and inspection booths.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES

The cyberstrikers in Brazil join Web surfers who have engaged in ''Internet strikes'' in Germany, France, Spain, the Czech Republic, China and Poland.

title: Melodies Of Ireland, Complex Yet Sparse
description: The first thing Martin Hayes did at the Fez on Monday night was ask that the sound of his fiddle be turned down. ''He doesn't want to hear himself,'' murmured someone in the crowd. That joke seemed true as Mr. Hayes and the guitarist Dennis Cahill slid into their first medley. As Mr. Hayes bent slow notes with his bow and Mr. Cahill picked a steady pulse, the two communed as if they hardly realized anyone was listening.

title: Next, the Drink 'n' Read
description: HAVE you seen them?'' asked Carole Baron, the president and publisher of Dell Publishing and Delacorte Press. ''They're cute.''

title: Political Memo; In a Year of Acrimony, Giuliani Is Defined by the Economy
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani formally began the first year of his second administration last January with a State of the City speech that chronicled past accomplishments and made bold promises of more to come. He urged the people of New York City to take personal responsibility for this moment in time, and implicitly presented himself as the person to lead the metropolis to continued greatness.

title: SUNY's Chancellor Plans to Step Down
description: John W. Ryan, who has been Chancellor of the State University of New York during one of its periods of greatest change, announced yesterday that he would leave the post as soon as a successor was named.

title: 2 Arrested After Police Seize Huge Cache of Designer Drugs
description: Two people were arrested late Monday evening after the police seized a huge store of illegal designer drugs, two guns and more than $11,000 in cash at a Queens apartment, the police said.

title: Separate but Unequal: 2 Schools' Tales
description: Tottenville High School, at the southern tip of Staten Island, has one of largest expanses of artificial turf in the world, a sprawling $7.3 million hyper-green carpet on which it can conduct three major sporting events at once without conflict. At Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn, the sports program went broke last spring, forcing the school's principal, Lena B. Medley, to beg the P.T.A. for a handout.

title: France, in Break With U.S., Urges End to Iraq Embargo
description: France, making a formal break with the United States and Britain, proposed today that the Security Council lift the oil embargo on Iraq and institute a new weapons monitoring system to prevent Saddam Hussein from rearming.

title: CASELLA WASTE SYSTEMS TO BUY KTI FOR $337.8 MILLION
description: Casella Waste Systems Inc., a solid-waste handler, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy KTI Inc. for about $337.8 million in stock to expand its waste-processing and recycling business in the Northeast. Casella, which is based in Rutland, Vt., will exchange 0.91 share for each KTI share, valuing KTI at $25.60 a share. KTI had about 13.2 million shares outstanding on Nov. 16. Casella's purchase of KTI, which is based in Guttenberg, N.J., and operates in 21 states, will create an integrated waste management company with about $560 million in annual revenue, the companies said. KTI rose $1.125, to $23.25. Casella fell $1, to $27.125.

title: Man Is Shot in Subway After Attacking Officer
description: A 19-year-old man was shot by a police officer in a Brooklyn subway station after the suspect took the officer's gun and began attacking him, the police said.

title: Office in a Nest Hides or Takes Wing
description: Now you see it, now you don't. ''It's an all-in-one office that you can open up -- or hide,'' said Brian Kane, designer, with Mark Kapka, of the Cafe Collection home office for Offi & Company. Three parts that nest inside one another, far right, can be hidden with a shade. The largest is 72 inches by 32 inches and 22 inches deep ($1,215). The file cart ($540) and extension, right ($525), tuck inside. In maple and aluminum at Totem, 71 Franklin Street (near Church Street.)

title: BASF to Buy Back Up to 5% of Shares
description: BASF A.G., the German company that is Europe's biggest chemicals maker, said yesterday that it would buy back as much as 5 percent of its shares, bidding to bolster investor returns as profit growth slows.
