title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FATT, ARTHUR C.
description: FATT-Arthur C. 94. Of New York City and Delray Beach, Fla. Died Tuesday evening, January 12, 1999 after a long illness. Beloved husband of the late Barbara C., proud father of Marjorie Chester and Barbara Costikyan both of New York City, grandfather of Nancy Cedillo of Madrid, Spain, Priscilla Majcherska of East Hampton, L.I., Jonathan Heine of Chappaqua, N.Y., Christopher Chester of New York City and Katherine Chester of Bristol, R.I. Great-grandfather of four. A recognized pioneer in the field of advertising, he and the late Lawrence Valenstein founded The Grey Advertising Agency in 1921 and named the company for the color of the walls of their third floor walk-up office. Some of his happiest days were spent at his beloved home in Mallorca where he and his wife, Barbara, joyously hosted family and friends. Services and interment private. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: Praise For Jordan From All Corners
description: Some praised his ability to soar gracefully over defenders who were nearly a foot taller. Others spoke reverentially of his competitiveness, the trait that forced him to work tirelessly at honing skills that were already legendary. Still others paid tribute to the charisma and advertising acumen that enabled him to become the premier pitchman in sports.

title: Going After the Social Security Chimeras
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; Mystique of a Butterfly Stirs the Soul of a Town
description: IT is tiny and dainty and flits by so quickly that many residents here have never actually spied the Karner blue butterfly. But no matter. Who can resist the idea of saving a butterfly, particularly if doing so can also save a town's soul?

title: The Cost of Living With a Ski Slope At the Back Door
description: The architect Robert A. M. Stern has once again mined the past and coined a name. American Alpine is what he calls his style for the shops, restaurants and 73 condominiums he is designing at the heart of Aspen Highlands Village, a 10-acre ski resort in Colorado (top), which is scheduled to open in the winter of 2001. Dennis Wedlick, like Mr. Stern a New York architect, is designing 32 semi-attached houses (above), which will flank the village. He calls the style Great Camp. By either name, the buildings will have stone walls, exposed rafters and beams and giant posts and lintels. What inspired the architecture, Mr. Stern said, were American buildings like the Ahwahnee Hotel in Yosemite National Park and Old Faithful Inn in Yellowstone Park. The small scale of the resort -- residents will be able to walk to shops and restaurants and to ski from the slopes to the back door of their houses -- was inspired by European ski villages like Chamonix, France, and Zermatt, Switzerland. In 1995, Gerald Hines, the developer of the resort, invited Mr. Stern to tour European ski resorts with him. ''Chamonix and Zermatt -- those were little villages that evolved a street scene with cafes,'' Mr. Hines said. The two concluded that ''people like intimacy, little shops,'' Mr. Hines said, ''and they don't like a straight line in the street.'' The 5,000-square-foot houses will sell for $2.7 million to $3 million each (no prices yet for the condos); the cost of developing the resort, which will extend over 65 acres, is expected to exceed $250 million, Mr. Hines said.

title: Lawmakers in Both Parties Are Weighing Compromise Plans to Revamp Social Security
description: For the first time since President Clinton put Social Security's financial problems at the top of the national agenda, key members of both parties are seriously examining compromise proposals that could be acceptable both to Democrats who want to keep the retirement system intact and to Republicans pushing for a shift to private investment accounts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, DIANE (NEE RIFKIN)
description: EPSTEIN-Diane (nee Rifkin). Beloved wife of Howard, devoted mother of Matthew, cherished daughter of Bonnie Rifkin, dear sister of Linda and Alan, and granddaughter of Irma GoldsteinBollt. Service today, at 1 P.M. at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset.

title: APARTMENT INVESTMENT GETS 11 PROPERTIES IN 5 DEALS
description: The Apartment Investment and Management Company said yesterday that it had acquired 11 apartment communities for about $150 million in five separate deals during the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31. The company said it paid for the communities in cash, partnership units and assumed debt. The properties are in Arizona, California, Florida, Georgia, Indiana, Kentucky and Minnesota. Apartment Investment, based in Denver, operates private and commercial properties. The company has assets of about $2.10 billion.

title: Lott, and Shadow of a Pro-White Group
description: If, as the Senate majority leader Trent Lott has insisted for a month, he has ''no firsthand knowledge'' of the views of the Council of Conservative Citizens, which calls itself pro-white, it comes as news to a lot of people back home, including his Uncle Arnie.

title: Rangers Get to .500, But Harvey Is Injured
description: For the first two periods of last night's game against the Islanders, John MacLean of the Rangers was all over the score sheet. The problem was, he was in the wrong column, with two minor penalties and a 10-minute misconduct.

title: Accord Delayed on Bills To Reduce Utility Rates
description: Legislation to deregulate the state's power industry will not reach the Governor's desk for at least two weeks, officials said yesterday, after the State Senate and the Assembly adopted differing bills on Tuesday and then failed to reach a compromise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, IRVING
description: COHEN-Irving. On January 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Phyllis for 65 years. Loving father of Peter and Laurence. Adoring grandfather of Elissa, Joshua, Adam and Jonathan. Dear brother of Philip Baskir. Graveside service Thursday at Mount Pleasant Cemetry, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Excerpts From Trial Memo Filed With Senate by the President's Lawyers
description: Following are excerpts from the trial memorandum filed with the Senate today by President Clinton's lawyers for his impeachment trial, as provided by the White House. Headings were revised from the original.

title: People
description: * Eric Rosenkranz, client services director at Grey International, New York, a unit of Grey Advertising, was named regional director for Latin America, succeeding Frank Clarke, who is retiring.

title: From Unusual Homework Assignments to a Virtual Museum
description: THE HOOPER VIRTUAL NATURAL HISTORY MUSEUM

title: Vallone Urges Incentive for New Teachers
description: In his first major speech since he lost the governor's race last fall, Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, proposed an incentive program for new teachers yesterday that would pay for their graduate studies if they promised to work in city schools for at least three years.

title: Sears P.L.C. to Give More Cash to Holders
description: Sears P.L.C., the British clothing retailer, said yesterday that it would return more money than previously planned to shareholders. Sears will return $:215 million ($353 million), or 141 pence a share, to shareholders on or after April 6, more than the $:84 million it previously indicated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINLEY, JOHN W.
description: FINLEY-John W.. (CFA), on January 11, 2000. Husband of the late Marguerite. Father of John Jr., Patricia Pellegrini and Eugene. Grandfather of Evelyn, Sean Finley and Elizabeth Pellegrini. Retired from B.F. Saul, Md., and Clark Dodge, NY. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 West 72 Street. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 10 AM, Blessed Sacrament Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Propane Truck Crashes; 200 Forced From Homes
description: More than 200 people were forced from their homes last night after a truck carrying 3,000 gallons of propane gas overturned and spilled an unknown amount of the flammable liquid, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAYNE, GABRIEL M.
description: FRAYNE-Gabriel M.. Age 71. Of Croton-on-Hudson, New York. Died at home January 13, 2000 of complications from throat cancer. Beloved husband of Ruth Frayne. Devoted father of Christopher, Gabriel, Jr., Philip and Nicole. Beloved grandfather of Thomas, Nicolas and Adriana. A graduate of the class of 1950 from Columbia Law School, and a founding partner of Abelman, Frayne & Schwab, Attorneys, he spent 50 years practicing trademark law, rising to the top of his profession, earning the respect and admiration of colleagues around the world. Member of Honor of the International Association for the Protection of Industrial Property. Active in the American Bar Association, where he chaired many committees devoted to trademark legislation, and served on government delegations, negotiating international trademark law. Active in community affairs, serving as Chairman of the Croton Planning Board for seven years, during which he was instrumental in creating a Master Plan for the village. A devoted parishioner and Eucharistic Minister of the Holy Name of Mary Church. Served on the Board of the Croton Arboretum. His unbounding wit, wisdom, intellect and compassion will be missed by family, friends and colleagues. Funeral will be held at the Holy Name of Mary Church, Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., January 17th, at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in his memory to the Holy Name of Mary Church, 110 Grand Street, Croton-on-Hudson, New York 10520 or the Croton Arboretum, PO Box 631, Crotonon-Hudson, New York 10520.

title: The Impeachment Case: Accusations and Defense
description: The articles of impeachment voted by the House made 11 specific charges against President Clinton, against which his lawyers have raised specific defenses.

title: Williams's Agent Is Disappointed
description: The Nets were busy yesterday in negotiations on one of their blue-chip players, Jayson Williams. Sal DiFazio, the agent for Williams, met for three hours with Michael Rowe, the team's president, and John Nash, the general manager. The Nets are attempting to re-sign Williams, a highly-coveted free agent center, but DiFazio was not pleased with what occurred yesterday.

title: Secret Tape of Plotter's Confession Deepens the Mystery of a Political Murder in Mexico
description: The gunman, undeterred by the bright daylight of a Mexico City morning, strode up to the sedan parked on a bustling street and pumped one bullet from an automatic pistol, shattering the driver's window and killing Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu, one of Mexico's most prominent politicians.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BISHOP, FRANKLIN G.
description: BISHOP-Franklin G.. 12/6/20-1/14/96 Jerry, I miss you. Evelyn

title: Complaints Against Police Rise by 4.3%
description: Complaints of police misconduct in New York City rose by 4.3 percent last year, according to statistics released yesterday by the Civilian Complaint Review Board.

title: Knicks Also Getting Off to a Late Start on Togetherness
description: There was Patrick Ewing, committing a fraternization sin by sunning with the enemy as he worked out with about a dozen Heat players in Miami yesterday. To the chilly north, just three Knicks were scrimmaging with a collection of fringe free agents and one Toronto Raptor, Charles Oakley, at SUNY-Purchase.

title: Supreme Court Hears Welfare Case
description: The debate before the Supreme Court today was over welfare policy -- whether states can have a lower level of benefits for newcomers than for longtime residents -- but the deeper issue was the meaning of citizenship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COMBE, IVAN D.
description: COMBE-Ivan D.. 88, of Greenwich, CT and Dorset, VT. Died January 11, 2000. Beloved husband of Mary Elizabeth Combe, devoted father of Diana Bickford, Juliette Larson and Christopher Combe. He is also survived by six granddaughters and a grandson. His friends and associates are grateful for his many years of inspirational leadership, wise counsel and caring for others. A memorial service for family and church friends will be held Saturday, January 15 at 2 P.M. at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, CT. In addition, a service for all his friends & associates will be held Saturday, February 5 at 2 P.M. at the Christ Church United Methodist in New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the Round Hill Community Church or the Ivan D. Combe Fund at Greenwich Hospital, Attention Development Office.

title: WILLAMETTE INDUSTRIES TO CUT PRODUCTION AT PAPER MILL
description: Willamette Industries, a maker of paper and grocery bags, said yesterday that it would cut production at a paper mill in Kingsport, Tenn., and dismiss 150 workers at the site. The move, effective April 1, will eliminate 50,000 tons of capacity and result in a fourth-quarter pretax charge of $5 million. A total of 570 people work at the plant and at an adjacent lumber yard. Willamette said it was cutting back the operation because it was too small to be efficient. Its shares fell $1.1875, to $34.1875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAND, EDWARD SAYER, SR.
description: HAND-Edward Sayer, Sr.. An attorney and Scarsdale civic leader died December 30, 1999 after a brief illness. He was ninety-two. Husband of the late Faith Seiple Hand. Mr. Hand is survived by two sons Edward S. Hand, Jr. of Wellesley, Massachusetts and Stephen B. Hand of New Orleans, Louisiana, and by his three grandaughters Samantha, Lindsley and Bailey Hand. At the request of Mr. Hand, there will be no services. However, the family is planning a Scarsdale gathering of his family and friends on Sunday, January 23rd, 2000 from 1-3 PM at the Fox Meadow Tennis Club, 14 Wayside Lane. Sunday, January 23rd would have been Mr. Hand's ninety-third birthday. Contributions in Edward S. Hand's memory can be made to the Arthritis Foundation, New York Chapter, 122 East 42nd Street, New York, NY 10168 or to the Amphibious Ships Museum, 11414 Calhoun Road, Omaha, Nebraska, 68152-1338 to complete the LSM restoration.

title: Sports of The Times; A Very Cold Send-Off For the Hottest Athlete
description: PARDON ME for being a little disappointed, I just expected more. This was retirement day for Michael Jordan, a player we have called the greatest ever, and the send-off was flat. Not simply flat, but chilly.

title: Motorola Beats Forecasts With a $159 Million Net for 4th Quarter
description: Motorola Inc., the big manufacturer of cellular phones and computer chips, said today that its fourth-quarter profit fell 60 percent, less than expected, as it increased phone sales and cut 2,000 more workers than planned.

title: Selig Names Panel To Study Payrolls
description: On a day when the owners approved John Henry as the new owner of the Florida Marlins, Commissioner Bud Selig named a task force on baseball economics to help Major League Baseball try to figure out a solution to its payroll disparity problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORACI, MARY
description: CORACI-Mary. A great lady remembered with respect and love. Our condolences to Jim, Tony, Jeannie and Maryanne. Larry Levine, Jay and Sandra Levine, Susan and Dr. Eric Kane

title: Chief Sells Staples Shares
description: The chief executive of Staples Inc., Thomas G. Stemberg, took advantage of soaring stock prices at the second-largest United States office-supplies retailer last week, selling shares worth an estimated $40.7 million in options-related transactions. His sale of 900,000 shares, or about 15 percent of his stake, comes as the stock has more than doubled the last 12 months. The sale, disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, was to take place around Jan. 4. The shares rose $5.0625, or 3.6 percent, that day to $45.25. The stock lost $1.0625 today, closing at $40.6875.

title: Advanced Micro Profit Fails To Meet Analysts' Estimates
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. reported fourth-quarter earnings today that fell a few cents short of analysts' estimates. It was the company's second consecutive profitable quarter after it reported losses in the first half of 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, MARCIA
description: STERN-Marcia. On January 12, 1999. Beloved wife of Sandy and mother of Lisa, Adam and Geoffrey, and mother-in-law of Linda. Adored daughter of Betty Fox Maged, stepdaughter of Myron Maged, and daughter-in-law of Laura Stern. Cherished sister of Jerry Fox, sister-in-law of Marcia Fox, and aunt of Barbara Fox, Jonathan and Kristen Fox, and Erika and Rick Eden. A great lady of charm, wit and unusual character. For the last 20 years ran Lupu's in Brooklyn with style and grace. A lover of life, music, art, books, flowers, her garden, sea shells, people, and the swans in Jamaica Bay. She was beloved by all. Services Friday January 15 at 12 noon at Shermans, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. Memorials to Cancer Care Inc., 1180 Avenue of the Americas, NY, NY 10036.

title: Easy Aliases, By Any Name
description: Q. Are desktop shortcuts and alias files the same thing?

title: Reinventing The Spell Of a Master
description: The slightly distant self-consciousness that can envelop Cassandra Wilson in a concert hall was gone when she performed at the Blue Note on Tuesday, her first nightclub appearance in New York in four years. Instead, Ms. Wilson was almost giddy, and in a confident cabaret-style performance with a six-piece band, she nailed every step.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, ESTHER G.
description: KAUFMAN-Esther G.. January 6, 2000. Wife of the late Ernie. Sister of Harold Goldring and the late Flo. Mother of Kitty, Bill, Paul and Karen, Robert and Ellen. Grandmother of Emily, Jason, Zack and Gordon. Forever in our hearts.

title: A Russian Theme Takes Over
description: After opening its 50th-anniversary year with programs featuring George Balanchine's austerely designed ''black-and-white'' abstract works, the New York City Ballet is now dancing in a multitude of choreographic colors.

title: A Place For Poets, Perhaps Not For Giants
description: Where have all the poets gone, long time passing; where have all the poets gone, long time ago? It may not be that young girls pick them, everyone, but several major publishing houses do. Poetry has become a consequential part of a few publishing programs, and it's not just Jewel and Springsteen and Dylan and Cobain either, but Robert Pinsky and Mark Strand and Deborah Garrison and Frederick Seidel and Sharon Olds and others whose names and work you may not know either, but whose art is more literary than the songwriter poets.

title: Ad Executive In New Coty Post
description: Coty Inc. in New York, a unit of Joh. A. Benckiser G.m.b.H., said yesterday that it had named Douglas Toews to the new position of vice president for ideas and image, responsible for the creative direction of Coty fragrance and skin-care brands like Calgon, the Healing Garden and Vanilla Fields.

title: Hong Kong Stocks Fall on China Debt Fears
description: Fears of a debt crisis in China swept through Hong Kong today, punishing the stock market and stirring fresh anxiety in a city that seemed to be recovering from Asia's economic distress.

title: Gore Says U.S. Is Willing to Help Iraq Get More Food and Medicine
description: Vice President Al Gore said last night that the White House was willing to consider ways to loosen restrictions on Iraq's ability to buy food and medicine. He emphasized that the Administration's differences were with Saddam Hussein, not with the Iraqi people.

title: Apple Reports Earnings Gain That Beat The Estimates
description: A resurgent Apple Computer Inc. today reported its fifth consecutive profitable quarter. Excluding a one-time gain, Apple earnings exceeded Wall Street estimates by more than 10 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINMAN, FAYE
description: FEINMAN-Faye. Beloved wife of Saul. Last of six Abramowitz siblings. Died in Florida Monday. Talented artist, musician, political buff. She will be missed by the nephews and nieces she adored. Graveside services at New Montefiore, Pinelawn, Long Island, at 1PM Friday, January 15. She will join her beloved son, Michael. Natalie and Joe, Bob and Frances

title: Arts in America; For Californians, Musical Visitors Are Worth the Wait
description: The New York Philharmonic has not exactly been a stranger to points beyond Manhattan in recent years. During Kurt Masur's seven and a half years as its music director, the orchestra has twice traveled to Latin America and to Asia, and to Europe four times. But until now Mr. Masur and the Philharmonic had not made their way across the United States together.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAFFNER, BEATRICE IVRY ERNST
description: DAFFNER-Beatrice Ivry Ernst. Age 95. On January 11, 2000. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Naomi and Stuart Paley, Judith and Victor Linn and Howard Ernst. Devoted sister of Billie Ivry. Dear grandmother of Adam and Rachel, Jane and Andrew, Gregory and Lisa and Jason. Greatgrandmother of Jeffrey, Emily and Zachary Linn and Hannah Paley. Wife of Phillip and the late Abraham Ernst. Service Friday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting at ''The Riverside'' Thursday 79PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Sutton Place Chapter of Hadassah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELLNER, HILDA
description: ZELLNER-Hilda. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck George N. Abrahams, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEABROOK, DOROTHY LITTLER
description: SEABROOK-Dorothy Littler. On January 11, 1999. Long time resident of NYC. Beloved wife of the late William Charles. Loving mother of Wendy D'Amico and William Seabrook. Dear grandmother of Alexis and Billy Seabrook. Funeral services private.

title: Livery Vans Are Feeling the Metrocard Pinch; Drivers Say Their Business Is Down and the Competition Is Up
description: Desmond Forbes sat behind the wheel of his shiny gray passenger van and darted in and out of grinding traffic on a four-mile trek along Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, scooping up passengers for a dollar a ride. But business on that recent day, as it has been for the last year in this largely underground trade, was bad, said Mr. Forbes, 43, an immigrant from Guyana.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLEY, DR. MALCOLM
description: MOLEY-Dr. Malcolm. Age 75. On January 12, 2000. Beloved husband of Janis. Loving father of Jeffrey, Roger, and Janis McCarthy. Beloved grandfather of eight. Class of Harvard 1946 and Columbia P&S 1947. Over 50 years of service as a physician and attending surgeon at St. Luke's Hospital, Harlem Hospital and Columbia Univ. Interment will be private. A memorial service will be announced. Family requests a contribution to the charity of your choice.

title: Trial Coverage
description: Today

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, EDITH S.
description: LIPTON-Edith S. Beloved wife of Israel. Devoted mother of Paul and Frank. She was a retired teacher. Services Thursday 1:30PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite LIRR) Great Neck, New York.

title: Bill Cosby Joins Ownership Group
description: Bill Cosby, the entertainer and philanthropist, became a member of the Nets' new ownership consortium yesterday.

title: Old-Fashioned Bowling
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, DOROTHY
description: O'BRIEN-Dorothy. The members of the board of trustees and the staff of Catholic Medical Centers of Brooklyn and Queens mourn the passing of Dorothy O'Brien, mother-in-law of William D. McGuire, president & CEO of Catholic Medical Centers. We offer our heartfelt prayers and our deepest sympathy to the O'Brien and McGuire families on their great loss. Most Rev. Joseph M. Sullivan Episcopal Vicar for Health and Human Services Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: U.S. Pollster For Opponent Of Netanyahu Is Burglarized
description: A break-in at the Washington offices of an American polling firm advising Ehud Barak, the leader of Israel's opposition Labor Party, threatened to inject new venom into the election campaign today, but the candidates exercised restraint while awaiting results of an investigation by the United States authorities.

title: WITCO TO TRIM JOBS AND MAYBE SHED OLEOCHEMICALS UNIT
description: The Witco Corporation, a specialty chemicals maker, said yesterday that it would cut jobs, shed or seek a partner for its oleochemicals and derivatives unit and trim capital spending as part of its plan to increase profitability. Witco's oleochemicals business, which makes products like fatty acids and plastic lubricants, contributed $413 million to Witco's $2.2 billion in 1997 sales. The company also said it would cut 1999 capital spending by 33 percent, to $180 million, and hold 2000 spending to between $115 million and $125 million. The company said it would eliminate an unspecified number of jobs and use the proceeds from cost reductions and the sale of peripheral units to pay down debt, buy back shares and strengthen its main businesses.

title: Far From the Madding Crowd, Dinosaurs Await
description: WHEN a Tyrannosaurus rex shows up on your computer screen, your spine doesn't tingle as it does when the giant beast dwarfs you at a museum. On the other hand, when you read on line about how dinosaur eggs were discovered in Patagonia, you are not likely to be bashed in the shin by errant baby strollers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OAKS, JAMES HOWARD
description: OAKS-James Howard. Vice President for Health Sciences at SUNY Stony Brook from 1973 to 1996, died at his home in Indianapolis on September 16, 1999. His friends and colleagues remember him with affection and profound respect. Howard gave irreplaceable leadership in creating a new institution that embodies his vision and his caring for human achievement. The Schools, University Hospital and other clinical services of the Center are major sources of health care, new health professionals and research. A memorial event to recall Howard's career at Harvard (where he served as Faculty Member and Dental School Dean) and at Stony Brook will be held January 28, 2000 beginning at 11:00 AM at SUNY, Stony Brook's Health Science Center, Level 2, Lecture Hall 1. For more information or to RSVP call Betty Ahner at 1-516-444-3423. Friends of J. Howard Oaks

title: Leo Cherne, Leader of Agency For Refugees, Is Dead at 86
description: Leo Cherne, who turned the International Rescue Committee into the largest agency in the world for the relief and resettlement of refugees, died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 86 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Surf-and-Turf Living Room (With Art, Too!)
description: ANDREA URBAN was in the kitchen washing dishes when she heard something strange. ''Suddenly there was this sound of splashing in the living room,'' she said, ''and I thought, 'Somebody's floating through the house.' '' Then it clicked. It was just her husband, Glen. He had shoved off on his inaugural swim in the lap pool.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, GERTRUDE
description: HALPERN-Gertrude., age 85, medical editor and journalist, former Managing Editor of Hospital Practice Magazine, died at her Manhattan home after a brief illness. She was a 1934 graduate of Barnard College, (Phi Beta Kappa, English honors) and was editor of the Barnard College newspaper. During the Second World War she worked at Life Magazine, organizing photographic surveys of the country's wartime experiences and covering the death of Franklin D. Roosevelt. After the war she produced the American Heart Association's annual report for many years. She was known for piercing intelligence, combined with unfailing grace and sweetness. Her husband of fifty-one years, Milton Halpern, died last year. The warmth of their home will be missed by many. One daughter and son-on-law, two brothers, a sister and a grandson survive her.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Lucent Deal for Ascend Comes With Little Fanfare

title: Judge Orders City to Stop Housing Homeless in Office
description: In a move that increases pressure on the city in a long-running battle over homeless policy, a judge yesterday ordered the Giuliani administration to comply with a new City Council measure aimed in part at ending overnight stays by homeless families on the floors of a city office in the Bronx.

title: War of Words: 2 Sides' Briefs Disagree Even in Their Styles
description: In their trial briefs, the President's defense team and the House prosecutors present their Senate jury with a legal version of ''Rashomon,'' in which the main characters recall the same events differently.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Saturday illustrating the sequence for President Clinton's impeachment trial misstated the events that would precede two critical votes. Senators plan to debate both a motion to dismiss the case and a motion to subpoena witnesses before voting on either issue. The chart, corrected, appears today on page A17.

title: EMERITUS ADDING 19 MORE ASSISTED-LIVING COMMUNITIES
description: The Emeritus Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 19 additional assisted-living communities in 11 states from the Meditrust Companies for $125 million. Emeritus, based in Seattle, had been leasing the properties. The company holds interests in 134 assisted-living communities in 28 states and Canada. It had revenue of $110.8 million in the nine months ended Sept. 30. Meditrust, a real estate investment trust based in Needham Heights, Mass., has been selling assets as part of a revamping intended to separate its health care and lodging businesses while reducing its debt. The transaction, expected to close before spring, brings to 44 the number of assisted-living communities that Emeritus has purchased or has agreed to purchase from Meditrust.

title: Want Your Own Talk Show? You Can Get One, on the Net
description: It only seems as though everyone and her grandmother has a radio talk show. Soon, however, everybody might. The catch is that the shows won't take place on the radio, but on the Net.

title: Ad Council President Is Stepping Down
description: Ruth A. Wooden, president of the Advertising Council in New York, said yesterday that she would leave this summer after 12 years. ''I feel that the time is right to pass the baton and take on greater challenges,'' Ms. Wooden, 52, said in a statement. Gregory G. Coleman, the 1998-99 chairman of the council and president for United States magazine publishing at the Reader's Digest Association, said Ms. Wooden would serve as a consultant after her departure.

title: Fork in a Folk Hero's Road
description: AMONG the sleek seals swimming through Christie's New York last Thursday, with their fur coats, thin watches, Italian loafers and winter tans, appeared John Gordon, wrapped in a wool scarf, wearing suede bucks and an imitation beaver-skin coat -- like a piece of folk Americana miscatalogued in a European sale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMPSON, CLAIRE
description: SAMPSON-Claire. Died January 12, 2000 in Chicago. Wife of the late Robert Sampson. She was awarded a prize for community service by the Mayor of Chicago. Survivors are daughter, Diane Sampson, sister Ruth Simon, nephew Roger Simon, nieces Martha Simon & Wendy Simon, sister-in-law Sis Lazar and her husband Buryl Lazar. Please send contributions to Jewish Home for the Aged, Chicago Attn: D. Sampson 1335 Astor St., Chicago, IL 60610. Piser Weinstein Funeral Parlor, Chicago, IL. Chicago papers please copy.

title: The Protocol For Trying A President
description: When the 13 Republican representatives appointed to prosecute President Clinton appear before the Senate on Thursday to begin presenting their case, they will follow an order and a plan that reflect the delicate protocol of seniority, their individual strengths and an egalitarian effort to give each of them a turn in the spotlight of history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, JERVIS
description: ANDERSON - Jervis. Maxine Greene mourns the loss of her former student, dear friend and supporting person.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLAND, BILLIE
description: FRIEDLAND-Billie. On January 12, 1999, of Kings Point. Renowned watercolor artist, wife for 56 years of Louis N. Friedland, who is the former Chairman of MCA TV and Universal Studios. Mother of Joanne Roberts and Eric Friedland. Funeral services on Friday, at 12 noon, from the ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck. Interment, Locust Valley Cemetery.

title: Time to Begin the End
description: A survey of public-opinion polls on the eve of President Clinton's trial in the Senate shows that the American people still have things figured out correctly. Majority opinion is that he should continue in office, that he should be censured and that he lied under oath. The Senate's task is to move as expeditiously toward a verdict that conforms with the public judgment, since that verdict would also conform with the evidence in the case.

title: WPP Group Buying Stake in Brierley
description: Brierley & Partners in Dallas, one of the country's biggest independent direct-marketing agencies, is selling a 20 percent stake to WPP Group P.L.C. in London for an estimated $15 million in cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, THELMA (NEE GOODMAN)
description: LEVINE-Thelma (nee Goodman), beloved wife of the late William, devoted mother of Harry Levine and Lucy Serling, dear sister of Eleanor Shore, Lillian Levy and the late Edith Bodarky and Gertrude Grossman, also survived by five grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Graveside services at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, on Friday, January 15, Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, NJ.

title: One-Year Deal Possible for Alfonzo
description: General Manager Steve Phillips indicated yesterday that the Mets likely would offer second baseman Edgardo Alfonzo a one-year deal, but that they might be willing to negotiate a multi-year pact with shortstop Rey Ordonez, who has won two consecutive National League Gold Gloves.

title: Dolphins Are Expecting Jimmy Johnson to Quit
description: It appears likely that Jimmy Johnson's career as coach of the Miami Dolphins is over after three seasons.

title: A New U.S.-Iraqi Clash; More Hard Words, Too
description: American and Iraqi forces clashed in northern Iraq for a third consecutive day today as Iraq's Vice President vowed to defy American and British control of its skies ''with all of our capabilities, regardless of the cost.''

title: Producer on the Side of Ugly Ducklings
description: It was 1966, and Irwin Winkler, an aspiring producer, had come to Hollywood from New York with a project for Julie Christie. Mr. Winkler went to the offices of MGM and saw its president, Robert O'Brien, who agreed to make the movie with one proviso: he wanted to replace Julie Christie with Elvis Presley.

title: Progress Is a Slow Train for Girls' Teams
description: Oshto Edobor-Osula, 17, plays basketball.

title: Pagers Big In Keeping Customers In Touch
description: To the ski-school staffers at Sugarbush, Vt., the 4-year-old who likes to dabble in sink water is known as the ''little shower kid.'' But thanks to modern technology, it became someone else's problem when the preschooler was too drenched to go skiing.

title: Bad News in Brazil
description: It has been only two months since the International Monetary Fund put together a $41.5 billion rescue package for Brazil that was predicated on Brazil's enacting fiscal reforms. But in that short time, Brazil's situation has been deteriorating. That led to its 8 percent currency devaluation yesterday, a move that unsettled world markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMENTHAL, ADELLE L.
description: BLUMENTHAL-Adelle L. Beloved of her husband Sam; their children Janet Jamieson (wife of Stephen) and Robert (Antje Rickel); and grandchildren Zachary and Joshua. She will be sorely missed by us. Funeral services at the Reconstructionist Synagogue, 1001 Plandome Road, Plandome, New York, Thursday at 11:45AM.

title: The Big City; Jets Fever Can Get Lost In the Crowd
description: NO matter how the Jets or the Broncos play in Sunday's football game, one prediction can be made with confidence: the final score will matter a lot less in New York than in Denver.

title: FIRST SECURITY TO SWAP STOCK FOR COMSTOCK BANCORP
description: The First Security Corporation, the second-largest bank holding company in the Western United States, said it had agreed to buy Comstock Bancorp for about $65 million in stock as it expands in northern Nevada. First Security said it would swap common stock for all of Comstock's 5.2 million outstanding shares, warrants and options. The acquisition will be valued at about $65 million as long as First Security's average stock price is between $18.70 and $24.05 during the 10 trading days before the transaction is completed. Comstock, which has $225 million in assets, will become part of First Security Bank of Nevada. First Security shares rose 9.375 cents, to $22.59375. Comstock shares climbed $1.375, to $11.75.

title: For Sale: The Garden of Eden
description: Winter is not such a good time to show a community garden. It can easily look like a field of dirt, suitable for sale to anybody who wants to buy it and is willing to pay New York City's taxes. That may be why Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and his administration have launched plans to sell more than 118 lots including a number of neighborhood gardens, all now empty of the noisy eco-protesters who would certainly be there in high summer.

title: Regents Look at Private Schools' Standards
description: In a sign of its determination to include nonpublic schools in its campaign to raise academic standards statewide, the New York State Board of Regents spent two days this week in an unusual meeting with leaders of private and religious schools.

title: Of Fairness and Federalism
description: A pair of provocative cases before the Supreme Court this week, one on sexual harassment and one on welfare benefits, raise very different legal issues. Yet the challenge for the justices in both cases is the same -- to act firmly against discrimination.

title: A Subdued Tyson, Lacking Punch at News Conference, Says He's Muzzled
description: The fizz left the Mike Tyson-Francois Botha heavyweight fight press conference the moment Steve (Crocodile) Fitch of Tyson's entourage -- screaming ''Guerilla warfare!'' -- was led away in handcuffs by two Las Vegas police officers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRAUER, PAUL H., M.D.
description: BRAUER-Paul H., M.D.. A memorial gathering for Dr. Paul Brauer will be held on Sunday, January 16, 2000 at 3:00PM at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th St, NYC.

title: Did You Get Her E-Mail Address?
description: MAUD LAVIN and Locke Bowman were each other's first loves, college sweethearts who were together for three intense years, then went their separate ways. One day, 22 years and three marriages later -- one for her, two for him -- Mr. Bowman was in New York on business. He called Ms. Lavin, and they met for dinner.

title: Newark Receives Grant For AIDS Programs
description: City officials announced yesterday that they had received $14 million in Federal money to operate programs for AIDS patients in the Newark area. They account for 40 percent of the cases in the state.

title: Court Rejects Baby-Food Pricing Suit
description: Novartis A.G.'s Gerber Products Company unit, the largest maker of baby food in the United States, did not conspire to fix prices with other manufacturers of pureed fare for babies, a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIFFORD, JAMES P.
description: GIFFORD-James P. Age 56. Of New York City. On January 9, 1999. Respected civic leader, lobbyist. President and founder of Hudson Strategies, Inc. Former President of the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and Executive Vice President of the New York City Partnership. Active, committeed board member of numerous civic and non profit organizations. Beloved brother of Judith Neunzig of Bethlehem, PA. Cherished uncle of James Neunzig of Pawling, N.Y. and Sarah Neunzig-Sauer of Brookfield, CT. Separated from wife Karen. Private burial 2PM Friday, January 15th at family plot, Poughkeepsie, N.Y. (Schoonmaker Funeral Home). Memorial service 11AM Friday, January 22nd in NYC, Saint Thomas Episcopal Church, 5th Ave and 53 St. No flowers. Contributions in his memory to Gifford Scholarship, Hamilton College, 315-859-4011, Saint Thomas Choir School, 212247-3311, and Historic Hudson Valley, 914-631-8200 ext 612.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KHOOBIAR, SARGIS (''SERGE'')
description: KHOOBIAR-Sargis (''Serge'') of Smoke Rise, Kinnelon, New Jersey, on Tuesday, January 12, 1999. Owner and Founder of Scientific Research & Development, Inc, Kinnelon, NJ and former research director of Halcon, Montvale, NJ. Beloved husband of Andrea (nee Ferretti) Khoobiar. Dear father of Sargis A. Khoobiar and Anne R. Khoobiar, both of Kinnelon. Funeral Liturgy will be celebrated on Friday, January 15th at 11:00 AM at Our Lady of the Magnificat Church, Kinnelon. Visitation on Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Mackey Funeral Home, 107 Essex Avenue, Boonton, New Jersey.

title: Golden Oldies Among The Lamps
description: ''Kitsch charms me,'' said Cara Greenberg, the author of ''Midcentury Modern: Furniture of the 1950's'' (Harmony Books, 1984). She is now a weekend dealer in lamps from the 1950's and 60's. ''Lamps can take any shape, unlike a chair or a table,'' she said. She is offering 80 lamps, including a 50's green plaster number (top, $495 for a pair, two and a half feet high) and a tulip style (lampshades with feline paw prints, $325 for the pair, two feet tall). The tulip shades appeal to Ms. Greenberg's whimsy. ''I like the way they droop,'' she said. She will sell her lamps at Showplace, an antiques dealer at 40 West 25th Street (Avenue of the Americas), on Saturday and Sunday, from 8:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M., (212) 633-6063; or by appointment: (718) 330-0575.

title: Rising Sharply, Police Overtime Pay Exceeds Budget Estimate
description: In a year when the number of police officers is at a record high and crime has sunk to a 30-year low, the New York City Police Department is in the midst of setting another record of sorts: for overtime spending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUMHOLZ, HENRY
description: KRUMHOLZ - Henry. Passed away on January 8, 2000. Beloved husband of Diane. Devoted and loving father of Gloria Young and Dr. David Krumholz. Loving father-in-law to Adrienne Krumholz and Michael Young. Proud grandfather of Evan, Douglas, Richard and Melissa. Dear brother of Benjamin Krumholz and the late Jack Krumholz. His loving memory will remain in our hearts forever.

title: Millrose Qualifiers
description: Campus Magnet High School of Queens, Clara Barton of Brooklyn and two Long Island schools -- St. Anthony's of South Huntington and Holy Trinity of Hicksville -- won qualifying races last evening for relay events at the Chase Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 5.

title: Access to Instant Replay With a Mouse Click
description: Thanks to technology fresh out of Silicon Valley, it has just become even easier to go stark raving mad at officials who blow crucial calls during football games.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I knew growing up, my whole life, that women in my family got breast cancer and died. It was not a question of, will I get it? It was a question of when.''

title: It Started From a Spark Set Off in the Political Powder Room
description: The unraveling of Brazil's economic plan yesterday began with the political equivalent of a lover's quarrel last spring. On one side is a spurned and humiliated former President, Itamar Franco, and on the other, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, the onetime underling to Mr. Franco who had outshone him by becoming President himself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPORTA, HERMAN
description: SAPORTA-Herman. Yeshiva University and its Albert Einstein College of Medicine mourn the passing of a dear friend, a distinguished communal leader who was a YU Guardian and AECOM Founder. He established AECOM's Herman Saporta Fellowship in Cardiology in Memory of Rachel Saporta. We extend heartfelt condolences to his children, Nuny Grey, Alan (and Sallie) Saporta, and Marcia (and Elliott) Hanin; brothers, Sam Saporta and Jack Saporta; sisters, Julia Rousso, Barbara Schram, and Jean Friedman; granchildren; great-grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Designs From the Wine-Dark Sea
description: ''I am inspired by nature,'' Lilia Melissa, a Greek architect, said of her furniture designs the other day. A 35 1/2-inch ebony side table, left ($4,500), resembles a bolt of lightning. A sinuous ribbonlike double chaise, below ($19,850), echoes the movement of waves. Extra-long cushions, fastened with Velcro, turn the chaise into a comfortable double reading chair with bolsters. The double chaise is 82 1/2 inches long by 51 inches wide and is constructed of three layers of bent wood. The top and bottom layers are plywood; a middle layer is cherry wood. Ms. Melissa's wood-frame brushed-aluminum screen (bottom) evokes an aerial view of the pattern of stone walls that divide property on the Aegean island of Santorini. The screen ($5,945) is 71 inches square. All the pieces can be ordered in different wood finishes from Studium V, 150 East 58th Street.

title: Home Movies, in Digital
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARCLAY, ELIZABETH MOORE
description: BARCLAY-Elizabeth Moore, 96. Died January 12, 1999. Wife of the late George C. Barclay; survived by Elizabeth Barclay Pennink of Medford, NJ; Margaret Barclay Chambers of Philadelphia, and George C. Barclay, Jr. of Devon, England; nine grandchildren and five great grandchildren. She was public relations director at Union Theological Seminary for 20 years and a crusader with Planned Parenthood and Choice in Dying. Memorial service to be held in the spring. Contributions may be made to Choice in Dying, 1035 30th St, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20007

title: Notebook Gets a DVD Player, But What a Battery Hog It Is
description: A new ultrathin notebook from Compaq Computer includes a DVD player, which could be a neat addition for mobile movie buffs, just so long as they don't plan to watch ''Titanic.'' The reason is that the DVD player gorges on battery power, cutting about an hour from the average useful battery life of 2 1/2 to 3 hours.

title: Quirky Moves as a Language
description: Sally Silvers, who presented three of her dances in the Altogether Different series at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night, has a refreshing experimental style that is amusing and darkly resonant at the same time. She does not know how to end a piece, but she never runs out of creative steam along the way.

title: AIRTOUCH RAISES STAKE IN ITALIAN MOBILE PHONE COMPANY
description: Airtouch Communications Inc., the largest United States cellular telephone company, said yesterday that it had raised its stake in Omnitel-Pronto Italia S.p.A., Europe's No. 2 mobile phone company, to 17.8 percent from 15.5 percent for an undisclosed amount. Airtouch, the object of a bidding war between the Bell Atlantic Corporation and Vodafone Group P.L.C., said it had bought the stake from Germany's Mannesmann A.G., exercising an option. Airtouch said it had a separate option with other investors, valid until the third quarter 1999, to raise its Omnitel stake to 21.7 percent, which would turn Airtouch into Omnitel's biggest shareholder after Oliman, the Olivetti S.p.A. and Mannesmann venture that controls the Italian company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUGER, HARRY
description: LUGER-Harry. Beloved husband of the late Ida. Father of Leon and Gloria, Joan and Bob Karan and Sally and Pierre Cotte. Grandfather of Carol, Lorraine, Andrew, Amy and Frank and their spouses. Great-grandfather of nine. Survived by brothers Ben, Nat and Sol and sister Rose Appel. Our Poppa will be missed.

title: Flat TV's, Still for the Fat-Wallet Set, Improve as Prices Fall
description: FOR decades, flat-panel, hang-on-the-wall televisions have been a staple of science fiction and viewers' fantasies. And not too long ago, the only place anyone could actually see one was at a World's Fair or geeky science expo.

title: Vikings Taking Falcons Seriously
description: Randy Moss had to travel about 30 feet to get from the Vikings' locker room to his sports utility vehicle yesterday in Eden Prairie, Minn., yet he still sprinted as if he were running a fly pattern at the Metrodome. A temperature of minus 4 degrees will cause that sort of hurried behavior, even to someone as smooth as Moss.

Visiting Thursday 2-5 & 6-9 PM and Friday 9:30-11 AM, Whitting Funeral Home, Glen Head, NY. title: Suit Says 18 Companies Conspired to Violate Sweatshop Workers' Civil Rights
description: Apparel workers and human rights groups yesterday filed the biggest legal challenge ever against sweatshops on American soil, accusing Tommy Hilfiger, Sears, Roebuck & Company, Wal-Mart and other prominent companies of conspiring to place thousands of workers in involuntary servitude and otherwise mistreat them to hold down production costs.

title: THE FINAL WORD FROM JORDAN
description: The deciding factor was not the sordid state of the National Basketball Association after the lockout, or even an old and bitter feud with team management. In the end, Michael Jordan said his basketball career was over because an undeniable feeling would not go away:

title: Whoosh! The Next Pentium
description: WHEN Nick built his own personal computer from scratch in 1996, it was the fastest machine in our house. He spent his life savings for components, including a motherboard that contained an Intel Pentium 166 microprocessor. He was 13 years old then. Now he is 16 and in high school, with the keys to my car, and he cannot believe he ever thought a Pentium 166 was cool.

title: Port Authority Offers Its Vision of New York Harbor
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey outlined a 40-year blueprint for New York Harbor yesterday, including spending at least $500 million to improve derelict piers and warehouses along the Brooklyn waterfront.

title: Fujimori's Burden in Peru: The Magic's Missing
description: Claudencia Martin Gustavo cheered when President Alberto K. Fujimori, defying the thin mountain air in this remote village 12,000 feet above sea level, took two women into his arms and twirled them in a vigorous Indian folk dance.

title: Help for Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

Adored grandfather of Alexis and David, Benjamin, Naomi, Liberty and Laura. Dear brother of Sidney. Services were held at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Delray Beach.

title: After Russian Lesson, Bond Prices Remain Stable in Latest Crisis
description: This time investors were better prepared to absorb the shock.

title: Double Duty For St. John's Senior
description: When Gina LoMonaco of Dix Hills, N.Y., was an eighth-grader, her brother, Mark, was a shot-putter, and she resolved to make the track team. She did -- as a long jumper.

title: Nicklaus Likely To Miss the Masters
description: Jack Nicklaus will undergo hip replacement surgery later this month that is likely to keep him out of the Masters tournament for the first time since 1958.

description: To the Editor:

title: In America; The Politics of Cruelty
description: Barry Turner lives alone in a fifth-floor walkup on a quiet street in the Prospect Heights section of Brooklyn. He's a nervous man. Fidgets all the time. He smokes Kool cigarettes and drinks prodigious amounts of orange Kool-Aid. He suffers from obsessive-compulsive disorder. He takes two types of medication to stave off psychotic episodes.

title: Quitting Time
description: If I could have picked a moment to retire right on the spot, it would have been opening day, 1975. It was my first game as a Milwaukee Brewer after 21 years with the Braves. Somehow, I reached first base in that game and then took off to steal second. I ran as hard as I could, and when I was finished sliding, it seemed as if I was about half a block from second base. Needless to say, it was the last time I tried to steal a base.

title: Coffin Filled With Cash? So Where's Mother?
description: Perhaps the most disturbing thing about the plays of Joe Orton is that what was first seen as outrageous farce a scant 30 years ago sounds today more like satirical social commentary. If audiences and critics of the 1960's were shocked by Orton, he knew what he was doing. ''People think I write fantasy, but I don't,'' Orton is quoted as saying by John Lahr, his biographer. ''Some things may be exaggerated or distorted, but they're realistic figures. . . . There's nothing incredible about it.''

title: Bobbing for Literary Plums on Line
description: WHEN my 9-year-old daughter brought home an arts and crafts book called ''Confetti'' from the school library three months ago, she must have had me confused with a different sort of mother, the kind who likes to create perfect homemade decorations for a Halloween party.

description: PETERSON-Daniel Edwin. Holland Lodge #

title: For Surfers, the World's a Stage
description: AS William Shakespeare observed in ''As You Like It,'' all the world's a stage -- but these days it helps to have some idea of exactly where to find the good stuff. The American Theater Web (www.americantheaterweb.com) is helping people do just that, providing links and listings in one place for more than 1,000 theaters nationwide. The site's goal is to list as many Web sites from American nonprofit performing arts groups as possible.

title: Essay; Loyalty Mystery II
description: Knock yourself loose calling all over the world to produce a column about the Syrian dictator Hafez al-Assad sending hoodlums to trash our Damascus embassy, and nobody cares.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZELIGSON, BERNARD
description: ZELIGSON-Bernard, January 3, 1998. ZELIGSON-Helene, January 14, 1994. Your loving wisdom, kindness and humor are greatly missed by your family. Marilyn, Laurie, Sheryl and famil

title: AETNA ACQUIRES BIGGEST ARGENTINE HEALTH CARE COMPANY
description: Aetna Inc., the largest United States health insurer, said yesterday that it had acquired Asistencia Medica Social Argentina S.A., a closely held Argentine health care company, for $100 million in cash and $20 million in assumed debt. With 250,000 members, Asistencia Medica is Argentina's largest health care company, Aetna said. Aetna, based in Hartford, provides insurance, as well as health and pension benefit plans. Aetna shares fell $1, to $88.

title: Clinton Vows to Do His Job Rather Than Dwell on Trial
description: President Clinton said today that he intended to spend as little time as possible thinking about his impeachment trial, choosing instead to do the work of the people, who he says have already heard more than enough about impeachment.

title: Hurricanes Grind Out a Victory
description: MIAMI 74, RUTGERS 62

title: Wall Street Recoils From Brazil's Turmoil, Then Collects Itself
description: Stock markets around the world shuddered yesterday in response to another dose of emerging-market turmoil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILBURN, DEVEREUX, JR.
description: MILBURN-Devereux, Jr.. The Boards, Faculty and Staff of the New York-Presbyterian Hospital and the Joan and Sanford I. Weill Medical College of Cornell University are saddened by the passing of our friend and esteemed Life Trustee, Devereux Milburn, Jr., Esq. We extend our deepest condolences to his beloved wife, Elizabeth, and family. Mr. Milburn was elected to the Board in 1961 and rendered nearly 40 years of distinguished service to the Hospital. Mr. Milburn will long be remembered for his unfailing dedication, wise counsel and cheerful and courageous spirit.

title: Public Art for Sale: At What Price?

title: Three Children Killed In Two Apartment Fires
description: Three children died in two apartment fires early yesterday in Trenton and Newark, police and fire officials said.

title: A Scanner Is Really Big, But It Still Comes Up Short
description: A Stanford University research team plans to use cutting-edge technology to scan three-dimensional images of some of the greatest works of art in Florence, Rome and the Vatican. But it seems the team could benefit from the use of some old-fashioned technology, namely a tape measure.

title: 30 Years as Grand Old Man of '60 Minutes'
description: ''YOU'RE going to hate the beginning,'' Andy Rooney grumbled yesterday to his boss, Don Hewitt, who has been the executive producer of CBS's ''60 Minutes'' forever. Mr. Hewitt was in his office with Mr. Rooney and was about to look at a tape of ''A Few Minutes With Andy Rooney,'' to be broadcast on Sunday. It was like sending your article to a really tough editor.

title: Skewing of Scores Is Feared in a Test For Fourth Graders
description: On the second day of the new fourth-grade reading test that has aroused so much anxiety around the state, education officials scrambled yesterday to deal with a problem that appeared on the first day: thousands of children who took the test's first section had already studied much of the material on which it was based.

title: On the Eve of the Impeachment Trial, an Uneasy Quietude Slips Over the Capitol
description: The debating chamber doors were masked today to prevent early peeking at the bar of the Senate where tables for contending lawyers had been set up along with other trappings for the opening arguments in the trial of President Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TSE, KU TEH YING
description: TSE-Ku Teh Ying. Passed away peacefully at her Manhattan residence on Sunday, January 10, 1999 at 5:25 PM at the age of 90. Born in China, beloved wife of the late Mr. Koong Kai Tse, senior executive of American International Group, Inc. (AIG). She has always been a devoted, supportive and loyal wife and the loving mother of the late son Stephen Yung Nien and the four surviving daughters: Cecilia Yung Hsien, Angelina Yung Ge, Virginia Yung Chung and Helena Yung Ngo. She is also survived by nine grandchildren and fourteen great-grandchildren. In the summer of 1987, she embraced the Truth and became a dedicated faithful Christian Witness of Jehovah. Her self-sacrificing love and generosity have touched many lives. She will indeed be deeply missed. Memorial service will be held at 4 PM on Saturday, January 16 at the Kingdom Hall of Jehovah's Witnesses, at 1499 First Ave, New York, NY 10021. In lieu of flowers the family has requested that donations be made to the Watchtower Bible & Tract Society Inc., 25 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, New York 11201. For information Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave, NYC.

title: Bankruptcy Of Another Firm Deepens China Fears
description: HONG KONG  Stocks of major Chinese-controlled companies trading here plungedWednesday amid fears that their lines of credit were drying up as a second state-controlled company stunned investors by announcing that it was effectively insolvent, with debts far larger than expected.
