title: Rules for Senators On Trial Decorum
description: In the course of normal business, the Senate chamber is mostly empty except for one senator delivering a monologue. The few senators in their seats often read or sign mail. Others wander in and out and whisper to their colleagues and their aides.

title: Dutch Publisher to Buy Dudley Jenkins Group
description: Wegener Arcade N.V., a Dutch media and publishing company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Dudley Jenkins Group P.L.C., a British data base services company, for $:80.6 million ($132 million), adding to its direct-marketing business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPP, CONSTANCE
description: LAPP-Constance. Beloved wife of the late Milton H. Lapp. Dear aunt of Edward and Joanne Kabak and great aunt of Elizabeth and Jacqueline Kabak. Services are today, 1 P.M., at the Riverdale Temple, Independence Avenue, Riverdale.

title: Advocates of Campaign Finance Overhaul Ready a New Push
description: The leading Congressional sponsors of legislation to overhaul the way political campaigns are financed said today that they would push hard for their bills this year so that new restrictions could be in place for the elections in 2000.

title: Crane Not Expected to Make Hostile Bid for Coltec
description: Following the dismissal of the Crane Company's lawsuit to block Coltec Industries from merging with B. F. Goodrich, analysts and investors said yesterday that they did not expect Crane to pursue a hostile bid.

title: Carpenter's Home Companion
description: For years, Norm Abram, above, has been sharing carpentry secrets (''measure twice, cut once'') with viewers of ''The New Yankee Workshop'' on public television. The show's 11th season, which began last Saturday, will dwell on ''Kitchen Stuff,'' as its unpretentious title says. These are not rudimentary projects like coat racks and spice shelves. On this weekend's program, Mr. Abram will tackle a giant kitchen pantry made of antique chestnut with punched copper doors (shown alfresco above). On March 6, he will tell the secret of making kitchen cabinets with cornice moldings and soapstone counters. The series will reach a dramatic peak of sorts on March 13, when Mr. Abram shows how a community organization in Cincinnati saved storm-damaged trees from being buried in landfill and how he turned a hunk of rescued Cincinnati black cherry wood into an Empire-style sink base. The program can be seen on Saturdays. (Check local listings.)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: STANDARD REGISTER CO., Dayton, Ohio, a data management and business forms company, agreed to acquire DuPont's printing operation in Boothwyn, Pa., for undisclosed terms. The company also signed a $100 million, five-year outsourcing agreement with DuPont.

title: U.S. Charges Ex-Livent Executives With Fraud
description: Garth H. Drabinsky, the Canadian impresario who founded Livent Inc. and brought shows like ''Ragtime'' to Broadway, was charged yesterday with orchestrating a criminal fraud of tens of millions of dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, HENRY PAUL
description: ALLEN-Henry Paul. Son of the late jazz musician Henry ''Red'' Allen and Pearly May Allen, and husband of Josephine Allen, died on January 10, 1999. Funeral will be held at Granby's Funeral Service Inc. in the Bronx on January 14, 1999. Viewing 2-7PM, Service 7PM in Granby's Chapel. For information: 718-519-6047.

title: FORD TO TAKE $630 MILLION IN FOURTH-QUARTER CHARGES
description: The Ford Motor Company, the world's No. 2 auto maker, said that it would take $630 million in fourth-quarter after-tax charges for a loss on the sale of its stake in the Kia Motors Corporation, early retirement programs and a new joint venture. Ford said last week that it would take a pretax charge of at least $250 million for North American and European job cuts and the sale of its Kia stake. The pretax amount of the charges announced today total $950 million. Ford sold its 9.4 percent stake in Kia last month to J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. for about $11 million. Ford stock fell $1, to $60.375. The amount of the charges was announced after the close of trading in New York.

title: One Charge: 'A Scheme That Was Developed' to Impede Justice
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by Representative Asa Hutchinson, Republican of Arkansas, about Article II in the impeachment trial of President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, EDITH M.
description: BROWN-Edith M. A resident of Stuyvesant Town, on January 12, 1999. A Funeral Mass will be held at Immaculate Conception Church, East 14th Street, Manhattan on January 15, 1999 at 10:00 AM.

title: A Football Dome for the City
description: For his startling State of the City speech yesterday, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani shed the formal podium, dropped his cumbersome chart routine and laid out a long list of ideas -- some aimed at his new national fan club, others an effort to cement his entry in New York City history. At the top of this list is a grand plan for the warehouse and storage area on Manhattan's West Side. Replacing today's bleak landscape near the Jacob Javits Convention Center, the Mayor would build, as he put it, ''the most famous sports facility in the world.''

title: DROPPING THE BALL: The Decline Of School Sports; Working to Preserve a Vanished World
description: Hank Whitney's life turned a corner in the early 1950's when he discovered basketball. He was poor and black and growing up on welfare in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, and the best he could look forward to, he said, was a factory job. Instead he found a whole new world.

title: District Council 37 Expects a $4.5 Million Deficit This Year
description: District Council 37, the umbrella group representing 120,000 New York City municipal employees, is expected to have a $4.5 million deficit this year, the council's new trustee told union officials at a meeting on Wednesday.

title: Union Revokes Agent's Certification
description: The National Basketball Players Association has revoked the certification of an agent who criticized the union during its labor negotiations with the league.

title: From Stone Age To Streamlined
description: At the 45th Winter Antiques Show, which runs through Jan. 24 at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue in Manhattan, 72 dealers from North America and Europe offer opportunities for immersion in some wonderful aspects of human ingenuity: fine art and folk art, several centuries of furniture and decorative objects, and artifacts from non-Western and prehistoric cultures. The decorated child's blanket chest from Pennsylvania, above, with a miniature chair and doll, is at the Olde Hope Antiques booth.

title: HEALTHEON RENEWS PLAN FOR INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERING
description: The Healtheon Corporation, formed by the chairman of the Netscape Communications Corporation, James H. Clark, to process health care transactions through the Internet, renewed plans for an initial stock offering. The company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to raise as much as $35 million. In October, the company said it planned to raise $51 million by selling a 12 percent stake to the public, valuing the start-up at $430 million. In its new filing, the company did not disclose the number of shares it would sell or their expected price range. The $35 million top value was estimated to calculate a commission registration fee.

title: Argentine Rates Jump And the Market Tumbles
description: Argentine interest rates surged as the local stock market tumbled for a second day in response to the devaluation of Brazil's currency. But several senior Argentine officials pledged that they would not budge the peso from its one-to-one linkage to the dollar or veer from other free-market policies.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Turning the Tables

title: Gephardt Apparently Leans Against a Run for President
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, seems poised to forgo a run for President and try instead to get more Democrats elected to the House next year so that he can become Speaker.

title: Discovering Clouds After Listening to the Rain
description: In ''At First Sight,'' Virgil Adamson (Val Kilmer) is a blind man living peacefully in a little Hudson River town. His sister makes his meals. He's such a terrific masseur that one client threatens to divorce her husband. He jokes with his beloved guide dog and listens happily to sports on television. He never has to watch slow-paced, stubbornly conventional movies like this.

title: French Mischief on Iraq
description: If the United Nations were to end sanctions against Iraqi oil exports and let the proceeds flow through the hands of Saddam Hussein, there is little doubt what would happen. He would use the oil money to rebuild his arsenal of biological, chemical and nuclear weapons and extended-range missiles. That is why France's proposal to lift the oil embargo and move to a weakened system of weapons monitoring and anemic safeguards against Iraqi weapons purchases is unacceptable. Sanctions can safely be lifted only when Iraq has fully complied with the disarmament requirements the Security Council imposed after the Persian Gulf war.

title: Teen-Agers in the Bible Belt Discovering Sex and Booze
description: Every American city has its band of young, self-styled outsiders. And in the unidentified Bible Belt town that is the setting for Sarah Jacobson's crude, heartfelt movie ''Mary Jane's Not a Virgin Anymore,'' they all seem to work in the same seedy local movie theater. The modes of teen-age and post-teen-age rebellion on display aren't especially exotic. Hard drinking, sleeping around, some bisexuality and cautious body piercing are the chief manifestations of nonconformism among the staff.

title: Haitian Leader's Foes Raise The Specter of Dictatorship
description: The streets of this impoverished capital buzzed with the normal hubbub of life today, but inside the corridors of power opposition leaders were accusing the President of trying to establish a virtual dictatorship. The President insisted he was trying to build a democracy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURTIS, MORT
description: CURTIS-Mort. On January 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Ida. Dear brother of Doris Lasky. Also survived by nieces and nephews. Services Sunday 12:15 PM. at ''The Riverside'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Trainer Holds Key to Tyson's Comeback
description: The way the trainer Tommy Brooks sees it, he and Mike Tyson are locked in the same orbit. If Tyson spins out of control in his comeback bout against Francois Botha at the MGM Grand on Saturday night, then Brooks hurtles into oblivion with him.

title: Rights Report on Mexico Says Abuses Continue
description: Policemen and soldiers commonly kidnap, torture and kill people across Mexico, despite Government reforms aimed at eradicating the abuses and despite the authorities' claims that they have largely ended, Human Rights Watch said in a report issued today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLOSIN, HAROLD J.
description: WOLOSIN-Harold J. Died suddenly at his home in San Diego, Janurary 10. He is survived by his wife Dory, and children Ken, Donna and James.

title: Statements of the Obvious
description: The most striking thing about the House managers' recitation of evidence against President Clinton was its redundancy. We know Mr. Clinton lied with persistence. We know he coached others to cover up for him. We know that he failed, through careful planning and steady irresponsibility, in his constitutional duty to see that the laws were faithfully enforced. We have long known, as Representative James Sensenbrenner pointed out in his opening statement, that William Jefferson Clinton is a terrible example for youth, as well as for adults involved in legal proceedings.

title: Time Warner Forms an E-Commerce Unit
description: In a move to expand and solidify its presence in the electronic marketplace, Time Warner Inc. yesterday announced the formation of Time Warner E-Commerce. The unit will consolidate the company's direct-marketing efforts already on the World Wide Web and introduce other programs.

title: Jazzman's Wife Feels The Blues
description: Edie Falco is the real thing. Whether she's playing an ethically compromised guard on HBO's prison series ''Oz,'' or a suburban Mafia spouse on the same cable network's new show ''The Sopranos,'' or even a bit part as a wounded policeman's wife on ''Homicide,'' Ms. Falco brings an emotional thoroughness to any dramatic situation. She is the kind of grounded actress who can convey a complex web of feeling -- she's tough and soulful in the very same instant -- without a trace of ostentation.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY /Technology; Cars and Natural Gas: A Better Fit
description: THE Dodge Charger design study, introduced by DaimlerChrysler last week at the North American International Auto Show here, looks like a modern rendition of the 1960's muscle car from which it got its name. Under its long hood, the Charger concept car, like its predecessor, has a powerful V8 -- in this case, a supercharged 4.7-liter engine producing 325 horsepower.

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column yesterday, about contemporary American poets, misspelled the surname of a senior editor at Random House. He is Daniel Menaker, not Meneka.

title: Like the Rolling Stones, Eric Clapton, Tina Turner . . .
description: Something spangled, something red: those are the flashiest tools in the Black Crowes' project of seizing the classic rock songbook and kicking its cliches into lusty overdrive. This Atlanta-based band is scornfully derivative as only preservationists can be: Chris and Rich Robinson learned the truth about rock as lads listening to 1970's FM radio, and they won't let fashion lead them astray. On Tuesday night at Irving Plaza, playing for fans who couldn't get in to Monday's show at the Bowery Ballroom, the brothers Robinson and their mates renewed their vows to rock in a performance whose electrifying spark was its artistic conservatism.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Mimi Smith

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKOVITS, ALEXANDER
description: MOSKOVITS-Alexander. We will miss our loving uncle who took us on ''Shabbos walks'' in Irvington on-the-Hudson and played baseball. We will miss the dogs, the many loving fun stories, the way you taught our children ''survival'' and the way you embraced our husbands and family with open love and joy. We will always cherish our memories. Barbie (Yitzhok) Lehmann Siegel Karen (David) Lehmann Eisner

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONES, IRENE G.
description: MONES-Irene G., 95. On January 10; wife of the late Isidore Mones; mother of Robert & the late Helen; grandmother of eight; greatgrandmother of seven. Services Sunday, January 17, 10:30 A.M., Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck. Interment at Beth-David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Taking the Children; Mother Doesn't Always Know Best
description: Stepmom

title: '98 Featured Low Inflation, Brisk Buying By Consumers
description: Consumer prices rose in 1998 at their slowest pace in 12 years and retail sales surged in December, capping a year in which rising wages allowed consumer spending to rise at its fastest pace since 1984 and energized the economy's longest peacetime expansion.

title: Envy, Conquest, Revenge: It's All in the Maps
description: When it comes to the fusion of visual beauty and useful information, is anything as glorious as a map?

title: Beyond Mother's Antiques: Ax Heads and an Ivory Guillotine
description: So many objects, so little time -- and space. The 1999 Winter Antiques Show is upon us, and 72 dealers from North America and Europe have armed the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue to the teeth with things to see: fine art and folk art, several centuries of antique furniture and decorative objects, artifacts from non-Western and prehistoric cultures.

title: Highlands to Lowlands: Malt Geography
description: Scotland has four main whisky-producing regions, each with a distinctive style of malt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNDWERG, MOE
description: GRUNDWERG-Moe. Of Jerusalem and Miami, our dear friend passed away on January 12, 1999, in Miami. Survived by children Matthew, Sammy and Sylvia, brother Saul, nieces, nephew and extended family. Burial was Thursday, January 14, 1999. Shiva at Saundra and Saul's at the Tiffany, Collins Avenue, Bal Harbour. Ita and Joshua Aber

title: The Rebirth of a Renaissance Painter
description: The way Christie's told the story, about a decade ago a man arrived out of the blue at the door of the auction house with a painting strapped to his car. The picture was dirty and had a few holes in it. He wanted to know what it was worth. Experts identified the painter as Dosso Dossi (1486?-1542), a contemporary of Titian and Raphael, from Ferrara in northern Italy, and when the work went on the block, the J. Paul Getty Museum paid $4 million for it.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Turning the Tables

title: Africa's Borders at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Senators Hear First Plea by House to Remove Clinton
description: In an atmosphere of sober formality, the impeachment trial of President William Jefferson Clinton began in earnest today in the United States Senate, with the Republican prosecution asserting that he should be removed from office because of ''egregious and criminal conduct.''

title: Trial Coverage
description: Following is the schedule of presentations by the House managers as outlined yesterday by Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, and presentations by President Clinton's lawyers:

title: Senate Trial: Fair Play?
description: To the Editor:

title: An Obligation 'to Tell the Truth, the Whole Truth and Nothing but the Truth'
description: Following are excerpts from the remarks today by Representative James E. Rogan, Republican of California, who presented the perjury case as outlined in Article I against President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Gibes at the Experts From an Enigmatic Chatterbox
description: Ray Johnson's suicide by drowning in 1995 brought him the kind of public attention that his art never had. Not that he was ever invisible. But for years he invited exposure only on his own terms, and kept careful control of how high his profile rose.

title: Mapmaker, Mapmaker, Make Me a Map!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Senate Trial: Fair Play?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hebron's Returns Are a Plus for Denver
description: This is the way the Broncos kickoff returner Vaughn Hebron describes the Jets:

title: '60 Minutes II' Gets Big Ratings
description: The introduction of the second CBS news magazine ''60 Minutes'' was a success Wednesday night, scoring the highest rating of any program that night and more than doubling the audience that the network had been attracting in that time period.

title: Florida Ends Support for a High-Speed Train
description: Plans for a high-speed train that would link Florida's three major metropolitan areas appeared dead after Gov. Jeb Bush pulled out state financing today, saying the project posed too much financial risk for taxpayers.

title: Queens School Gets a Music Man; Immigrant Teacher Donates Tiny Violins, and Himself
description: The 16 third- and fourth-graders filed into Room 207 in a straight line during their lunch hour, picked up the perfectly tuned violins that were waiting for them and then, wordlessly, began to play.

title: Study of Prehumans' Teeth Suggests That They Dined on Meat
description: Applying a new method of analyzing the chemistry of tooth enamel, scientists have examined molars of prehuman ancestors who lived in Africa three million years ago and determined that they had more varied diets than had been supposed. They dined not only on fruits and leaves, as modern chimpanzees do, but may also have already become meat eaters.

title: On Iraq, Time for an Accounting
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets and Williams Agree on a Deal
description: Jayson Williams and the Nets agreed in principle last night to a deal that will keep the charismatic center in New Jersey for the remainder of his career, according to Sal DiFazio, Williams's agent.

title: U.S. to Allow Organic Label On Some Meats and Poultry
description: The Department of Agriculture announced today that it would allow farmers who raise meat and poultry without pesticide-treated feed, growth hormones or antibiotics to label their meat ''certified organic.''

title: At Corner, Jets Are Back To the Backup Once Again
description: Early this afternoon, Aaron Glenn admitted that his tender right ankle was still not fully healed. Hours later, the Jets acknowledged the same fact, listing Glenn as questionable for Sunday's playoff showdown with Denver and strongly implying that Ray Mickens will again start in his place at cornerback.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Eastman Kodak turns in some not-so-bad numbers. So what's wrong with this picture?
description: IN one sense, yesterday was an unusual day for the Eastman Kodak Company. About 8:30 A.M. -- an hour after it released its fourth-quarter earnings but an hour before the New York Stock Exchange opened -- George M. C. Fisher, the company's chief executive, broke with his tradition of refusing to forecast anything. He told analysts that Kodak would earn $4.81 to $5.24 a share this year and would cut $200 million more out of annual costs than the total of $1 billion it had already promised to cut by the end of 1999.

title: Kellogg's Soggy Sales
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, DOROTHY H. (NEE MCGRAW)
description: BECKER-Dorothy H. (nee McGraw). Devoted wife of the late Henry. Beloved mother of Barbara Lewis. Cherished grandmother of Stacy McCormack and Valerie. Funeral Saturday, 10:30AM from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3025 Quentin Road, Brooklyn. Mass Good Shepherd R.C. Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Officer in Squeegee Man Case Acquitted of Other Charges
description: A police officer charged with shooting a squeegee man in the Bronx last June has been acquitted of unrelated assault charges at a Police Department trial, officials said yesterday.

title: Microsoft Appeals Court Ruling on Java
description: The Microsoft Corporation appealed a court order requiring its software to pass Sun Microsystems Inc.'s compatibility tests for its Java computer language today, arguing that the dispute was about contracts, not copyrights.

title: DAYTON HUDSON TO BUY BACK $1 BILLION IN STOCK
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation, the fifth-largest United States retailer, said yesterday that it planned to buy back $1 billion in stock, after higher sales at its Target discount chain helped raise its shares 55 percent last year. The retailer, whose department stores include Marshall Field's and Dayton's, also raised its quarterly dividend to 10 cents a share, from 9 cents, payable on March 10 to shareholders as of Feb. 20. The buyback represents 4.2 percent, or 18.5 million, of Dayton Hudson's shares outstanding. The shares will be repurchased in the next two years, mostly on the open market.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Elaine de Kooning

title: The Price of 'Engaging' China
description: In the past six months the Chinese Government has carried out the most systematic crackdown on political rights since the Tiananmen Square massacre of 1989. Dozens of democratic activists have been arrested, hundreds more have been detained, and three leaders, Xu Wenli, Wang Youcai and Qin Yongmin, have been sentenced to long prison terms. Their crime? Taking President Clinton at his word.

title: Emotional Johnson Finds Reasons to Return
description: When Miami Dolphins Coach Jimmy Johnson showed up at his office early this morning, he intended to resign. The death of his mother last month left him thinking about how football had taken so much time away from family and friends. And he wanted to change that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCLUSKEY, DONALD W.
description: McCLUSKEY-Donald W., Lt. Col. (Retired) U.S. Army. Husband of the late Betty, father of Patricia McCluskey Shaughnessy. Grandfather of Tara and Tania Shaughnessy. Past Grand Regent and Supreme Orator of Royal Arcanum. Visiting Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Religious service Sunday, 8PM, McLaughlin Funeral Home, Third Avenue at 97 Street, Bklyn. Interment Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in his memory to St. Simon's Church, 1055 Richmond Avenue, Staten Island, N.Y. 10304.

title: Channel Journal; The Joy of Duty-Free Shopping, Soon to Turn Sour
description: The white cliffs of Dover looked particularly fine as the ferry sped toward France, but the tourists, swarming through the duty-free shops on board like locusts on parole, were not interested in the view. They had only 75 minutes. They had to shop quickly.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONS, HELEN
description: ARONS-Helen. Age 78. Beloved friend, aunt and sister passed away suddenly January 13. We will dearly miss her love, support and humor. Her courage was an inspiration to us all. Rest gently, dear Helen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TSE, KU TEH YING
description: TSE-Ku Teh Ying. Passed away peacefully at her Manhattan residence on Sunday, January 10, 1999 at 5:25 PM at the age of 90. Born in China, beloved wife of the late Mr. Koong Kai Tse, senior executive of American International Group, Inc. (AIG). She has always been a devoted, supportive and loyal wife and the loving mother of the late son Stephen Yung Nien and the four surviving daughters: Cecilia Yung Hsien, Angelina Yung Ge, Virginia Yung Chung and Helena Yung Ngo. She is also survived by nine grandchildren and fourteen great-grandchildren. In the summer of 1987, she embraced the Truth and became a dedicated faithful Christian Witness of Jehovah. Her self-sacrificing love and generosity have touched many lives. She will indeed be deeply missed. Memorial service will be held at 4 PM on Saturday, January 16 at the Kingdom Hall of Jehovah's Witnesses, at 1499 First Ave, New York, NY 10021. In lieu of flowers the family has requested that donations be made to the Watchtower Bible & Tract Society Inc., 25 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, New York 11201. For information Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave, NYC.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Domestic Transformations'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GATELY, ELIZABETH M.
description: GATELY-Elizabeth M. January 14, 1999. Counselor at the Religious Consultation Center of the Diocese of Brooklyn, 1973-1992. Devoted daughter of the late Mary (nee Ford) and Henry Gately. Beloved sister of Sr. Mary Gately, S.C., Henry, Francis, the late Lucy Miller, Ursula Carbone, George, Paul, Rev. Joseph and James Gately. Survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Boulevard, Friday 2-5 and 7-10PM. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Robert Bellarmine Church, Bayside, on Saturday, January 16, 10:30 A.M. Interment St. Mary's Cemetery, Lynn, MA.

title: A Scene to Impress Mom
description: It was a sight that would have made any Republican mother proud.

title: Senate Sniping Over Witness Issue Endangers a Frail Bipartisan Pact
description: Off the Senate floor, Senate Democrats and Republicans resumed their verbal brawl today over whether to call witnesses in President Clinton's impeachment trial, imperiling a fragile bipartisan pact.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, RUTH
description: STONE-Ruth. We remember a woman who was never frightened to take on the challenge; who befriended anyone in need; always gave herself for others and was forever loyal; who endured life's hardships head on and with a bright light in her eyes. Our hearts grieve at your passing and hope that life beyond is full of the joy and happiness you richly deserve. We will miss our times together. Services will be at the Nardone Funeral Home, 414 Washington St, Peekskill, N.Y. 914-737-1363 on Tuesday, January 19 at 10AM. Interment follows at Assumption Cemetery. Viewing held at Nardone Funeral Home, Monday, January 18 2 to 4PM and 7 to 9PM. The Gabriel gals

title: EU Commission Survives, But Seems to Lose Power
description: STRASBOURG  The European Parliament failed Thursday in an attempt to oust the European Commission over allegations of graft and incompetence, but many of its members said the vote marked a significant shift of power toward the 626-seat elected assembly.

title: Around the World
description: For globe-trotters and armchair travelers, these 12 restaurants offer a chance to wander the world without leaving New York. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIANG, LELAND SUNG
description: LIANG-Leland Sung. Died on January 8th, 1999 at age 78. Dr. Liang received his doctorate from the Wharton School. He was the founder of Textile Marketing Associates and an adjunct professor of marketing at Baruch College for more than 25 years. He was an active member of the Harvard Club of New York from which he received an MBA, and the American Marketing Association among many other organizations. Dr. Liang is survived by his wife of 50 years, Florence; three sisters, HuiI, Ching-Ye and Min-Yi; brother Hung; uncle, Bryan Shaw; & many nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held on April 12 from 5-7PM at the Harvard Club of New York, 27 West 44 Street. A fund in his memory will be established at a local charity to receive contributions in lieu of flowers.

title: Ecology:Cambodia's Next Man-Made Disaster
description: PHNOM PENH  The floating casino moored at the edge of this city, where the Mekong and Tonle Sap rivers meet, symbolizes the readiness of those who wield power and influence in Cambodia to gamble with its fragile environment and economic future, development specialists say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEALEY, ANTONIO
description: SEALEY-Antonio. Better known as Seventeen. Died suddenly on October 2, 1998. Age 29. Revered poet, rapper and recording artist. Star performer and urbane host of the ''Flippin' the Script: Rap Meets Poetry'' reading series at the Fez and S.O.B's, 1993-1997. Beloved son of Anna Payne Bush and Stafford Sealey, stepson of Harris Bush, cousin and buddy of Kenny Johnson. In his own words, Seventeen has been ''admitted into heaven where the true angels roam/And the pain never makes it past the barrier zone.''

title: Malaysian Opposition Insists That Anwar Case Be Dropped
description: KUALA LUMPUR  The leader of the parliamentary opposition called on the government Thursday to drop its case against Anwar Ibrahim after the trial judge ruled that two months' worth of evidence and testimony relating to the former deputy prime minister's alleged homosexuality was now "irrelevant."

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Accounts
description: * Datastream Systems Inc., Greenville, S.C., to Austin Kelley Advertising, Atlanta, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle its marketing and advertising account, previously at the Morrison Agency, Atlanta. Billings were estimated at $1.5 million.

title: DROPPING THE BALL: The Decline Of School Sports; Scoring Points, With Eye on Regents Exam
description: Damien Daniels, a 5-foot-10-inch guard for West Side High School's basketball team, routinely stops nearly at midcourt and hurls the ball up. The first time he does this in a game, and makes it, opposing coaches and players think it must be a fluke. Then he does it again, and only then do they realize that they must guard Daniels all the way from halfcourt because even there he is a threat. He averaged 40 points a game last year and has averaged 35 points a game this season.

title: A Mermaid Not for Disney
description: ''Rusalka, the Little Rivermaid'' is a retelling of ''The Little Mermaid'' that includes not just a prince but Prince -- or at least the likeness and music of the singer who once called himself that. Also using marionettes decked out as Michael Jackson and Madonna, this version never approaches Disney's or, for that matter, Hans Christian Andersen's.

title: How Victim Becomes Sleuth: Dial B for Burglary Suspect
description: Criminal masterminds, most police officers say, are rare birds indeed. And the case of a parolee who was captured and arrested on burglary charges in Brooklyn early yesterday morning did little to shake that assessment.

title: Testimony by White House Counsel Before House Panel
description: Following is testimony by Charles F. C. Ruff, the White House counsel, under questioning by Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, when Mr. ruff appeared before the House Judiciary Committee on Dec. 9, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcript agency:

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Roxy Paine

title: Ewing Is Back; Now, Where Are the Rest of the Knicks?
description: Patrick Ewing had shaken the beach sand out of his clothes and the lockout clutter from his mind. The only remaining evidence of his three-day getaway in Miami was the sunny disposition he carried into the Knicks' practice facility on this frigid afternoon.

title: INSIDE
description: A 401(k) With a Twist

title: Foundations of Civilization: Telling Victoria's Secret
description: Form fits function fetchingly on Sunday night in support of the proposition that the purpose of underwear is to reveal even as it conceals. The loosely stitched two hours of ''Unmentionables: A Brief History'' reviews undies from the useful (it's been centuries since the chemise was considered mainly a way of protecting expensive outfits from sweat) to the sensational, with peeps along the way into some pruderies and peculiarities.

title: Refinement And Status In Americana
description: The current adage that ''the best always sells'' will be tested this week at Americana sales when Sotheby's and Christie's offer a few antiques with the three prerequisites: rarity, condition and provenance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEABROOK, DOROTHY LITTLER
description: SEABROOK-Dorothy Littler. On January 11, 1999. Long time resident of NYC. Beloved wife of the late William Charles. Loving mother of Wendy D'Amico and William Seabrook. Dear grandmother of Alexis and Billy Seabrook. Funeral services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONWAY, OLGA E. (NEE TILITZ)
description: CONWAY-Olga E. (nee Tilitz) on January 11, 1999. Longtime resident of Elmhurst. Loving sister of Edmund, Walter and the late Robert and Paul. Designer of Elmhurst Public Library gardens. Active member of Newtown Civic Association. Funeral private. Memorial service to be announced. For information contact Neufeld Funeral Home: 718-424-4000.

title: G.M. WINS TAX-FREE STATUS FOR DELPHI SPINOFF
description: The General Motors Corporation's planned spinoff of its Delphi Automotive Systems Corporation parts unit was granted tax-free status by the Internal Revenue Service. General Motors plans to sell 17.7 percent of Delphi's stock in an initial public offering before the end of March. The ruling clears the way for a distribution of the remaining 82.3 percent stake to G.M. shareholders. The underwriting group plans to market each share at $14 to $18. That would imply that Delphi's initial market value is as high as $10.2 billion.

title: Giuliani Offers Plan to Put Up Sports Complex
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani backed away yesterday from his support for moving Yankee Stadium to the West Side of Manhattan and instead proposed an even more ambitious plan for the same site: a sports complex that would include a domed football stadium intended for the New York Jets, a relocated Madison Square Garden and a subway line to provide easier access to the athletics mecca.

title: Sports of The Times; Jimmy Should Follow His Instincts
description: IT is never a pretty sight when a grown man is stomping all over a box of breakfast cereal, tossing Flutie Flakes around the room, the way Jimmy Johnson did two weeks ago.

title: Indonesian Car Maker Seeks Deal on Debt
description: PT Astra International, Indonesia's biggest auto maker, is proposing a partial payment of interest on about $1.9 billion in foreign debt, seeking to break an impasse in its talks with creditors.

title: Roars of Defiance Punctuate A Funeral for a Slain Boy
description: It was billed as a funeral but turned into a foot-stomping, raise-the-roof service of defiant celebration, as friends, strangers and city officials packed a brick church tonight to send off an 8-year-old boy and his mother who were shot dead last week before the boy could testify in a murder case.

title: A Second '60 Minutes,' a Chip Off the Old Clock
description: Only in the pantheon that is ''60 Minutes'' would a group of reporters in their 40's and 50's be considered whippersnappers. Yet that was the idea behind ''60 Minutes II,'' which had its premiere on Wednesday. No one was ever shouting ''Watch out, MTV,'' but the clone of the revered CBS newsmagazine was meant to perpetuate the brand name with a fresher, younger version. As it turns out, the original ''60 Minutes'' is serious and staid; the new ''60 Minutes'' is serious and staid. Dolly the cloned sheep has no closer resemblance to the DNA that spawned her than ''60 Minutes II'' has to its ancestor.

title: Woman in Abortion Case Back in Jail on Violation
description: A woman who was released from jail to have an abortion two years ago and then changed her mind after pleas from abortion foes was sent back to jail Wednesday for violating terms of her probation, officials said yesterday.

title: Let the Debate in the Pollard Case Be Open
description: To the Editor:

title: A Day's Forceful Subtext
description: The House managers' arguments to the Senate today, on one level, were about what the evidence against President Clinton already shows, but the strong subtext was that they cannot win their case without more evidence, from live witnesses.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Billick Adds Razzle to Vikings' Dazzle
description: Brian Billick is a career football coach. Plainly and simply. He does not consider himself an offensive genius, although others within the National Football League do. Billick just calls himself a football coach, just the offensive coordinator for the Minnesota Vikings and just a man who is obsessed with locating and exploiting mismatches on the field. Just a coach.

title: In Jordan's Huge Wake, A Raft of Player Moves
description: The No. 1 commodity took himself out of the bidding on Wednesday, and for the first time in more than a decade, the six-time National Basketball Association champion Chicago Bulls find themselves hoping to rebuild rather than preparing to reload.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOREM, MRS. ESTHER AMSTER
description: FOREM-Mrs. Esther Amster. Died Wednesday, Janaury 13 in Richmond, Virginia. Beloved widow of Theodore Ross Forem; mother of Wendy Forem Alpert of New York City and Linda Forem Donohue of Richmond; grandmother of Mayme Beth and Benjamin; mother-in-law of Dave and Gary; sister of Morris Amster, Deane Amster Robbins, Jack Amster and Leo Amster. Mrs. Forem was a frequent contributor to the Editorial Page of The Richmond Times-Dispatch and was named Correspondent of the Day in 1998. She will be missed by all who knew her.

title: Excerpt From Introductory Remarks by Henry Hyde to the Senate
description: Following is an excerpt from the remarks today by Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, in the impeachment trial of President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: In the Name of the Father, a Son Carries On
description: THERE was a time when Martin Luther King 3d, the son of the man whose life we celebrate on Monday, might have been called the reluctant namesake: hunkering down in his seat at college when his father's name came up, calling himself Marty as ''a way to hide'' because the comparisons were too painful, the pressure too great.

title: KERR-MCGEE TAKES CHARGE IN RESPONSE TO LOW OIL PRICES
description: The Kerr-McGee Corporation, the oil exploration company, said yesterday that it would take a $250 million fourth-quarter charge to lower the value of its oil and natural gas reserves in response to lower oil prices. Kerr-McGee was expected to earn 3 cents a share before charges or gains in the fourth quarter, based on the average estimate of analysts polled by the First Call Corporation, down from 94 cents in the quarter the previous year. The company, based in Oklahoma City, which is buying the Oryx Energy Company for $2.8 billion, also said it was rescinding a $300 million stock repurchase program because of the acquisition, and that it would cut 1999 spending for the combined company by 45 percent. Its shares fell $1.50, to $37.375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, SAUL L.
description: GOODMAN-Saul L. 97. On January 13, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Sarah, father of Jacob Eli, father-in-law of Josy, and grandfather of Rachel and Naomi. Born in Bodzanow, Poland, he came to this country in 1921. A teacher in the Jewish secular schools, he rose to Executive Director of the Sholem Aleichem Folk Institute and Professor of Jewish Thought and Yiddish Literature on the Graduate Faculty of Herzliah - Jewish Teachers' Seminary. He was the author of several books in Yiddish and English, including ''Traditsye un Banayung'' (Tradition and Innovation), for which he received the Zvi Kessel Literary Prize, and ''The Face of Secular Jews''. He was a prolific writer and lecturer on Jewish philosophy, literature and education. Funeral to be held 11 A.M. Sunday, January 17, at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York.

title: When Only the Quarterback Is Cool
description: West Canaan, Tex., the setting of ''Varsity Blues,'' a crisply directed but entirely predictable all-American morality tale, is a small town that eats, sleeps and breathes football. For the last 22 years, the Coyotes, the local high school team, have won the district championship. Those victories have elevated the team's mean, hard-driving coach Bud Kilmer (Jon Voight) into a legend with a stadium named after him.

title: Want to Share Dreams? Be Careful; It's Murder
description: At heart ''In Dreams'' is just a campfire story, and a pretty loony one at that. But Neil Jordan has directed it furiously, with a lush, insinuating visual style that gets right under the skin.

title: Foreign Affairs; We're All One River
description: There are some who will tell you that 1999 will be remembered as the year of Clinton, Starr and Lewinsky. Wrong. This remarkable year will be remembered a decade from now as the year of the Amazon -- the cyber-river and the real river, Ama zon.com and Amazon.country, also known as Brazil.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Continue to Slide As Fears About Brazil Grow

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARPER, EUGENE W.
description: HARPER-Eugene W., 82, of Middletown, New Jersey on January 13, 1999 at home. Loving husband of fifty-five years, Muriel A. (nee Drumgoole). Beloved father of Eugene W. Jr., James D., Robert F., Gerard E., Thomas P., Daniel J., Mary T. and the late Lawrence J. & William M. Dear grandfather of Elizabeth, Virginia, Katherine and Joseph; Timothy and Sarah; Jessica; Amanda and Julia; Caitlin and Tess. Funeral Liturgy on Saturday, January 16, will be offered at St. Mary's RC Church, New Monmouth, New Jersey at 10:30 am. Visting at the John F. Pfleger Funeral Home, 115 Tindall Road, Middletown, New Jersey, Friday, January 15th, 2-4PM and 7-9PM. Memorial donations may be made to the Rosary Hill Home, Hawthorne, New York 10532.

title: Chavin Lambert Buys Florida Agency
description: Chavin Lambert Advertising in New York has acquired Creative Directors Inc. in Coral Gables, Fla., which specializes in real estate advertising. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLS, WILLIAM BULLIVANT
description: NICHOLS-William Bullivant. Died January 13 following a stroke at his home in Basse Terre on St. Martin, French West Indies. He was 82. He is survived by his wife, Janet. Funeral arrangements are pending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, MAX
description: SIEGEL-Max. On January 13, 1999 at age 90. Beloved father of Lawrence, father-in-law of Patricia, grandfather of Laura and Karen. We will miss him.

title: Delta Sets a Fee for Not Using Its Web Site
description: Starting this week, there are two new classes for Delta Air Lines passengers: wired and unwired.

title: The Wonders Of Waltzing, In Fantasy And Reality
description: What fine times people can have together. The New York City Ballet proclaimed that message brilliantly on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: A Staid and Serious '60 Minutes II'
description: A technician stares at a lump of plutonium, below, in an underground Russian nuclear plant in the city of Krasnoyarsk-26, a site that raises concerns about illicit sales to states like Iraq. The plant was the subject of the debut segment Wednesday night of ''60 Minutes II,'' which, like its progenitor, set a tone that was staid and serious.

title: Continued Growth Planned For Jazz at Lincoln Center
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center, the world's largest producer of jazz programming, announced its 1999-2000 schedule yesterday, showing continued increases in its concerts, educational outreach, financing and tours by the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra.

title: DROPPING THE BALL: The Decline Of School Sports; Finding the Middle Ground For Couch Potato and Athlete
description: Joe Featherston is a gym teacher. In the New York City public school system these days, that can be a lonely, beside-the-point occupation. Every day means offering something that the school system does not particularly seem to value.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Scott Bryan is a very good cook. His partner, Gino Diaferia, is passionate about wines. And while their Luma in Chelsea was impressive in many ways, it always seemed too cramped for the size of their ambitions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, FRANCES BURRILL
description: BAKER-Frances Burrill. The Board of Trustees, faculty, and staff of The Rockefeller University deeply mourn the loss of our beloved friend Frances Baker, a cherished member of the University community for over forty years. She will be remembered for her kind and gentle spirit, keen intelligence, and the personal warmth and great integrity that she displayed throughout her long and productive life. We extend our heartfelt sorrow to her husband, Dr. William O. Baker, Chairman Emeritus of the University's Board of Trustees, and to her son, Joseph. She will be deeply missed. Arnold J. Levine, President Richard B. Fisher, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman The Rockefeller University

title: Helping Hand Cushions A Fall From Prosperity
description: The shiny seven-foot baby grand piano in the Sam family's crowded dining room is one mammoth reminder of a lost prosperity.

title: After Two-Year Fight, Woman Sells Her Farm
description: A Monmouth County, N.J., woman who for nearly two years had fought off her local school board's efforts to evict her from her farm and build a school there agreed this week to sell.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Time and Reader's Digest Said to Discuss Link
description: The Reader's Digest Association and Time Warner Inc. are in talks to combine Reader's Digest with a number of Time Inc. titles and direct marketing businesses, a person close to the talks said yesterday.

description: In percent

title: Oracle in Internet Venture
description: The Oracle Corporation, one of the major makers of software for corporate computing, said today that it had formed a $100 million venture fund concentrating on young Internet companies working with the latest version of its data-base software. Oracle said it would co-invest with venture capital firms in companies that develop products and services based on its data-base software, Oracle8i. Oracle, based here, said revenue from its flagship data-base business jumped 25 percent in the fiscal second quarter, to $1.5 billion.

title: Senate Trial: Fair Play?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, JANET MOTTSMAN
description: ZUCKERMAN-Janet Mottsman. On January 9. Beloved wife of the late Gabriel. Fond stepmother of Michael and Jane. Loving grandmother of John, Caroline and Richard. Devoted sister of Miriam Sims. Memorial service, Sunday, January 17, 1:30 PM, Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, RUTH LITTMAN
description: GROSS-Ruth Littman. Passed in peace on January 13 in her 85th year after a long and debilitating illness. Wife, mother, grandmother, and great grandmother she filled each of these roles with love and adoration. She will live forever in the hearts of her children Rollie (Littman) and Samuel Antupit, Sandra (Littman) and Jon Kates, Arthur and Susan Littman, 10 grandchildren, and 10 great grandchildren-a woman of unsurpassed beauty and consummate grace. She shared a glowing, and story-book romance with her dedicated husband, Jack. Ruth was devoted to an extensive circle of longtime friends that encompassed people in all walks of life and with a wide variety of interests. Ruth served her community as President of the Pleasantville League for under privileged youth; as a volunteer at the NYU Hospital for Special Surgery and at The Rusk Institute of New York University. She was an active member of Metropolis Country Club, Fairview Country Club, and Delaire Country Club in Delray Beach, Florida. A memorial service will be held at Temple Kol Ami, White Plains, NY on January 18 at 2 PM. (914-949-4717). In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Greenwich Hospital C/O Development Office, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT 06830, or The Fund for Blood and Cancer Research, 525 East 68th Street, New York, New York 10021, C/O Chairman Dr. Mark Pasmantier.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Plot to Oust Castro, Run on a Shoestring, Lands 5 Underpaid Amateurs in Jail
description: When terrorist bombs began exploding in Cuba two years ago, speculation about the bombers' identity was rampant. Coup-minded military officers, some Cuban exiles insisted. Or right-wing infiltrators from Miami. A nascent rebel underground, perhaps, supplied from abroad.

title: For Simms, Big Picture Reveals Little Things
description: To Phil Simms, the view from high above a stadium is the Rosetta Stone of football analysis, a key to his game preparation as CBS's top National Football League analyst. From that vantage point, Simms distills the slants, schemes, stunts and rotations of 22 players into comprehensible nuggets of commentary.

title: HOME VIDEO
description: Dr. King's Life, For Children

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHYTE, WILLIAM H., JR.
description: WHYTE-William H., Jr. With a critical eye and a lover's heart, he figured out the subtle alchemy of places and people. With evangelical zeal leavened with wit, he persuaded city fathers to redress destructive policies and redo depressing places. His books, his mesmerizing little movies, and his long days on the lecture circuit have done their work. All over the country, better places are being built because people have learned from Holly to take the time to look. The Municipal Art Society of New York

title: Thyssen Sales Fell 6% in First Quarter
description: Thyssen A.G., which is merging with Fried. Krupp A.G. Hoesch-Krupp to form the world's No. 5 steelmaker, said fiscal year 1999 first-quarter sales fell 6 percent, as expected, amid lower demand for steel and unit sales at its Thyssen Handelsunion division.

title: Odd-Couple Senators Offer Hope for Bipartisanship
description: It is hardly unusual to find Senator Ron Wyden conducting town hall-style meetings in Oregon, nor is it unusual to find the state's other Senator, Gordon H. Smith, doing the same thing. But in these days of partisan rancor in Washington, it is unusual to find two men, like these, who faced off in a bitter election just three years ago at the same meetings all across the state.

title: Residential Real Estate; Converting to Mini-Lofts Downtown
description: A 98-year-old warehouse at 120 Greenwich Street is nearing the end of a $16 million conversion that will turn it into a 103-unit rental apartment building that is the latest addition to the residential scene in Manhattan's financial district.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAWRENCE, SCOTT ANDREW
description: LAWRENCE-Scott Andrew. Your 50th birthday. Miss you always, love you forever. Mother, Sara and Joshua

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: N.F.L. Conference Championships; AMERICAN CONFERENCE
description: Is it coincidence that the top two passers in the conference meet in the A.F.C. championship? Quarterbacks do, after all, color the personality of their teams and greatly affect their teams' achievements. Little wonder that quarterbacks attract so much scrutiny.

title: DROPPING THE BALL: The Decline of School Sports
description: Trying to address the drastic deterioration in school sports programs, the Board of Education is making high school principals responsible for participation in interscholastic athletics.

title: COKE BOTTLERS IN JAPAN BEGIN CONSOLIDATION
description: One of Japan's largest Coca-Cola bottlers bought another bottler for 78 billion yen ($692 million) yesterday in a transaction brokered by the Coca-Cola Company of Atlanta. It sets the stage for consolidation of that nation's soft-drink industry. The deal was first reported in The Wall Street Journal. Coca-Cola, the world's biggest soft-drink company, will pay about $95 million for a 5 percent stake in a new Japanese bottling company created through the acquisition by Kita Kyushu Coca-Cola Company of the Sanyo Coca-Cola Company. Coca-Cola is now negotiating agreements with Japan's 15 other Coke bottlers to strengthen its position in Japan, said Roi Suzuki, the executive vice president of the Coca-Cola Japan Company.

title: A Fading Era's Battles For the Good and True
description: Tonight's hourlong spinoff of Tom Brokaw's best seller, ''The Greatest Generation,'' is a sober celebration of a few of the men, now in their 70's and 80's, who fought the Germans and Japanese a half century ago.

title: A Brazil Domino Effect? Not Likely
description: The devaluation of Brazil's currency has spooked financial markets around the world. If the Brazilian economy implodes, some experts warn, the shock waves could devastate the rest of Latin America and reach as far as Asia.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: As Long As You Both . . .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOSULE, HELEN (CHODOS)
description: GOSULE-Helen (Chodos), died peacefully on Wednesday, January 13, 1999, after a valiant fight with leukemia. Adored wife of Alan Gosule, beloved mother and best friend of Amanda Tarter, cherished daughter of Ruth Chodos and the late Irving, loving sister of Eileen Chodos Beth. The beauty of her spirit and soul lives on through her family and friends. She will be remembered as a woman of true dignity and courage. In lieu of flowers, donations in Helen's memory may be made to UJA or The Leukemia Society. Services Friday, January 15th, 12:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORBER, RUTH
description: LORBER-Ruth. January 10, 1999. The Board of Governors and the Members of Glen Oaks Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of Ruth, wife of our esteemed member Jerome, and extend their heartfelt sympathy to her family. Board of Governors Richard A. Horowitz, President

title: Single-Minded About Single Malt
description: Some people walk into a bar to drink. Others pursue a loftier goal. Yes, they order a drink, but for them the bar is a haven for reflection, a seat of learning and even, perhaps, a house of worship. In New York City, dedicated single-malt drinkers fall squarely into the second category. With the sensitivity of a parfumeur and the tenacity of a celebrity stalker, they seek the finest that Scotland can coax out of fermented barley. Price is no object.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, RUTH
description: MILLER-Ruth. The family of Ruth Miller celebrates her life and mourns her passing on January 13, 1999. The loving wife of Alvin (deceased). The beloved mother of Carole, Arthur, and Michael. Mother-in-law of Laurence and Robin. The very proud and loving grandmother of Adam, Andrew, Alex and Zachary. She touched the lives of everyone who knew her with love, warmth, humor and friendship. We will all miss her dearly. Her passing leaves a void that will never be filled. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Eden II School for Autistic Children, 150 Granite Ave., Staten Island, NY 10303 in her name.

title: On My Mind; The U.N. Suicide Road
description: Behind the closed doors of the United Nations Security Council, three of America's major partners are closing fast on their goal: to give Saddam Hussein victory in the war he lost eight years ago.

description: ULLMANN-Eric. An exceptional human being remembered with love for the last 7 years. Lil

title: Prosecutors Take Advantage of Broad Obstruction of Justice Statute
description: In laying out their case of perjury and obstruction of justice against President Clinton, the House managers today regularly invoked Federal statutes designed to give prosecutors the widest possible leeway in determining whether to charge someone with a crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, CARL
description: O'CONNOR-Carl. Drake School of the Bronx mourns the tragic passing of Carl O'Connor, a beloved instructor, colleague and friend. Heartfelt condolences to Carl's family.

title: Treating Hepatitis Lightly
description: ''Dr. Akagi'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Here are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 28. The film opens today in New York City.

title: N.F.L. Conference Championships; NATIONAL CONFERENCE
description: The Falcons have the pedigree. Coach Dan Reeves is only one of three coaches to take teams to both conference championships (Bill Parcells and Chuck Knox are the others). They have the confidence. Running back Jamal Anderson said this week he is not intimidated by the Vikings. They have the offense and defense. Atlanta averages 342 yards a game of offense, and the Falcons' defense is rated third in the conference. The Falcons seem to have everything, so why won't they beat the Minnesota Vikings? Because while Atlanta is impressive, the Vikings possess potentially the best offense of all time. They have unparalled explosion, especially at home, where they are unbeaten this season. To beat the Vikings a team cannot play conservatively, which the Falcons are sure to try. Atlanta will attempt to duplicate the game plan of the only team Minnesota lost to this season, Tampa Bay. The Buccaneers used a pounding running game and kept the Minnesota offense off the field for much of the afternoon. But there are two important distinctions. First, the game was on grass, and it somewhat nullified the quick Vikings' defense. Second, the offensive line of Tampa Bay is bigger than Atlanta's, and that made a difference. Atlanta will score some points, because Anderson will probably gain more than 100 yards, but the Falcons will see what each team that has come to the Metrodome has all season -- it is a different ball game in the Vikings' house. They jump on you quick, then when you fall behind, 14-3 or 17-7, the crowd becomes a significant factor in the game. Reeves has pumped crowd noise into the Falcons' facility, but that doesn't come close to duplicating the effect. Atlanta's defense, average despite its ranking, gets savaged. A close game early becomes a blowout in the end. Vikings, 38-20

description: Roche Holding A.G., Europe's fifth-largest drug maker, indicated fourth-quarter 1998 sales rose 28.9 percent, helped by demand for new drugs and its $7 billion takeover of Boehringer Mannheim G.m.b.H. last year.

When Mr. Wynn learned that they preferred art by familiar traditional artists to some of the more difficult 20th-century works, he decided to make changes.

description: If it was wet and could drop from the sky, it fell somewhere in the metropolitan area yesterday, and forecasters predicted that today would unroll as a further glossary of precipitation terms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACAVOY, EDWARD T.
description: MacAVOY-Edward T., 58, died At Cabrini Medical Center, January 13. He was born to Edward and Florence Molinell MacAvoy in Brooklyn. Edward was a manager for Michael Taub Assoc., Manhattan. Contributions to American Cancer Society or Charity of choice. For info C.H. Landers Inc. Funeral Directors, Sidney, NY.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Abdication Of the 'Queen'

title: CRISIS IS DEEPENING IN BRAZIL MARKETS
description: Propelled by a drop in Brazil's international credit rating and growing doubts about the Government's ability to defend the newly devalued currency, the Brazilian stock market was forced to suspend trading again today and closed down nearly 10 percent.

title: Microsoft Witness Attacked For Contradictory Opinions
description: A Justice Department lawyer produced several prominent academic papers today that he said showed that the Microsoft Corporation's first witness in its antitrust trial had written opinions contradicting views he has offered in expert testimony for the software giant.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about secret meetings between a small group of Senate Republicans and the House members managing the prosecution of President Clinton referred incorrectly to the views of Senator Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona, about calling witnesses. Republican senators tell The Times that Mr. Kyl has told them that a credible impeachment trial needs witnesses. But this is not Mr. Kyl's public position, and he denies that he has said it privately.

title: DROPPING THE BALL: The Decline Of School Sports; Making a Difference, a Playground at a Time
description: Dr. Barbara A. Barlow was not content to simply treat the injuries she kept seeing when she came to Harlem in the mid-1970's to lead the pediatric surgery unit at the Harlem Hospital Center. She wanted to find the cause of what seemed an inordinately high rate of injured children. What she found made her a crusader.

title: Taking On The Big Test At P.S. 48
description: HAVING been told by more than enough angry critics that his articles read like the work of a fourth grader, this columnist decided to see how he stacked up against the real McCoy. He spent three mornings this week taking the much-praised, much-maligned statewide reading and writing test with Victoria Gonzalez's fourth graders at Public School 48 in Washington Heights.

title: Senator Plans Bill to Expand 401(k) Plans
description: A new type of 401(k) retirement savings plan that would allow withdrawals free of taxes is expected to be proposed today by the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.

title: Protecting Public Art
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The Senate will convene as a court of impeachment. The chaplain will offer a prayer.''

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACKER, JACK
description: PACKER-Jack, on January 13, 1999. Loving husband of the late Shirley. Beloved father of Donald Packer and Lois Scheffler, fatherin-law of Alice Packer and Mark Scheffler. Loving grandfather of Lee and Kenny Scheffler. Dear brother to Mary Bloom, the late Ira Packer and the late Raymond Packer.

title: Alcohol Abuse Imperils a Naked Rite at Princeton
description: At least since the days of disco, the keen-minded undergraduates of Princeton University have considered it a right -- a solemn duty even -- for members of the sophomore class to gather at midnight following the winter's first substantial snowfall and run naked through Holder Courtyard, a wide quadrangle surrounded by Gothic dormitory buildings. They call it the Nude Olympics.

title: Delgado Becomes The First to File
description: Carlos Delgado, the Blue Jays' first baseman, broke from the crowd yesterday and became the first player to file for salary arbitration.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LOCKHEED MARTIN CORP., Bethesda, Md., said it had been awarded a contract from the Navy for operation and maintenance of its systems equipment at two training operations. The contract is valued at $88.5 million for five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALOMBA, GEORGE P.
description: PALOMBA-George P. Died January 13, 1999. Services were held.

title: An Album Of Fosse
description: The ghost of the man being celebrated -- blurred and fleeting but definitely there -- first shows up when the girl bursts onstage with a scream. That's the signal for a sequence lasting just 45 seconds, and it occurs halfway through the first act of ''Fosse,'' the hard-working but oddly affectless evening of dance by the choreographer Bob Fosse that opened last night at the Broadhurst Theater.

title: Some Twice-Told Tales About a Pair of Rogues
description: In ''A Couple of Blaguards,'' the Brothers McCourt, Frank and Malachy, bring their two best-selling books to the stage and split the difference. The first half of the evening, a kind of storytellers' cabaret act, is devoted largely to Frank's recollections of a penurious upbringing in Limerick, Ireland, as related in his wrenching book, ''Angela's Ashes.'' After intermission comes a torrent of anecdotes detailing Malachy's adventures as a young man in Manhattan, which is the subject of his rowdier memoir, ''A Monk Swimming.''

title: European Economies Worsen Despite a Unified Currency
description: Two weeks after 11 countries successfully began using a single currency, the euro, a raft of recent evidence indicates that their economies are stalling faster than experts had expected a few months ago.

title: Wisconsin Welfare Overhaul Justifies Hope and Some Fear
description: Though Wisconsin's radical welfare experiment has drawn more interest than that of any other state, there was little information until this week on what was happening to the droves of people leaving the rolls. In a statistical vacuum, the key question -- ''is it working?'' -- was answered with a mix of hopes, fears and dueling opinions.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Deneuve and Belmondo In Restored Truffaut Gem
description: ''Francois Truffaut's 'Mississippi Mermaid' has the form of a preposterous romantic melodrama,'' Vincent Canby wrote succinctly in The New York Times when the film opened here in 1970. ''But it is so full of lovely, complex things -- of unannounced emotions, of ideas, of the memories of other movies (Truffaut's, as well as those of two of his father-figures, Renoir and Hitchcock) -- that it defies easy definition and blithely triumphs over what initially appears to be structural schizophrenia. It is the creation of a superior moviemaker who works eccentrically in the classical tradition.''

title: Picking the Crucial Witnesses
description: If the 13 Republican managers of the President's impeachment trial have their way, they will be permitted to question witnesses, who could strengthen the case for the prosecution.

title: Perlman and Zukerman, Bow to Baton
description: The Israel Philharmonic receives comparatively little in the way of Government subsidy. But the orchestra has lots of supporters in the United States, and in 1980 a group of them formed the American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra to raise money for the ensemble. With the encouragement of Zubin Mehta, the orchestra's music director, the organization established an endowment that helps underwrite tours, youth programs and archival projects. It has also started a campaign to buy new violins for the orchestra.

title: FRANKLIN RESOURCES TO CUT 7% OF WORK FORCE
description: Franklin Resources Inc., the No. 6 United States mutual fund company, said yesterday that it would take a $58 million charge to cut 7 percent of its work force, the biggest such reduction in the company's 52-year history. Franklin said it would eliminate about 560 jobs, most of them in the company's headquarters in San Mateo, Calif., following a year in which its assets under management declined $800 million, to $220.2 billion. About four-fifths of the charge will be taken in Franklin's fiscal first quarter, which ended Dec. 31.

title: High Court Was Right to Back Initiatives; A Case for Bilingualism
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Proposes Voucher Experiment in Single School District
description: After warming in recent years to controversial voucher programs that use tax dollars to send children to private schools, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed such a plan yesterday for New York City, saying it might force failing public schools to improve.

title: A New Look They'll Drool Over
description: TTS drivers never complained about its styling, but even a classic must eventually change: After 20 years with the same body, one of America's best-selling cars is getting a new look.

title: Senate Trial: Fair Play?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREDESKOV, DORIS
description: FREDESKOV-Doris. On January 12, 1999 at the Masonic Home in Utica, New York. Formerly of NYC. Survived by her father, Phillip Fredeskov. Private services.

title: High Court Was Right to Back Initiatives
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOUT, ELIZABETH SPRAGUE (SIMONDS)
description: STOUT-Elizabeth Sprague (Simonds), 92, of Hobe Sound, FL., and Prouts Neck, ME., died on January 11, 1999. Devoted wife of the late A. Varick Stout, loving mother of Elizabeth Simonds Maynard, of Chestnut Hill, MA., Daniel Simonds of Wellesley, MA., Charles Sprague Simonds, Key West, FL., and Holly S. Callery, Tequesta, FL., loving grandmother of fourteen & great grandmother of nineteen. A memorial service will be held in the summer at Prouts Neck, Maine. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to St. James Episcopal Church, Prouts Neck, C/O Robert Shepherd, 13 Federal Street, Brunswick, Maine 04011 or Prouts Neck Audubon Society, P.O. Box 3034, Scarborough, Maine 04070.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: U.S. and I.M.F. Warn Brazil Not to Try to Prop Up Currency
description: Senior Clinton Administration officials and the International Monetary Fund today warned Brazil's President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, that his Government was unlikely to hold the devaluation of its currency to 8 percent, and might waste billions of dollars of its precious foreign currency reserves attempting to do so.

title: As Snow Shuts Schools, Computer Users Boot Up
description: Hang up the sled. Put Scrabble back in the box. Surfing is the new snow day activity of choice.

title: Marks & Spencer Shares Fall After Poor Profits Are Forecast
description: Marks & Spencer P.L.C., Britain's flagship retailer, saw its stock tumble again today after forecasting that profits this year would be down to just more than half of last year's.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, ELINOR
description: SHAPIRO-Elinor. Mom, How I wish you could have stayed just a little while longer. I miss you so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, SIDNEY
description: GREENBERG - Sidney. Sidney, you left us too suddenly. Dear friend, we will miss you. Jackie & Jack

title: Train Passengers Fall Hostage to Elements
description: Yesterday's weather, if nothing else, provided some interesting lessons in mass transit logistics.

title: U.S. Censures A Major Firm On Its Auditing
description: Federal regulators censured PricewaterhouseCoopers, the world's largest accounting firm, yesterday for violating a basic rule that all auditors must follow to be independent from the companies they audit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOEPPEL, EDWARD G.
description: KOEPPEL-Edward G. 76. Died peacefully on January 11, 1999. Cherished husband of Laura. Beloved father of David, Jeff, Debbie & Carin. Loving brother of Arlene and Mel, Ben and Ann. Devoted stepfather of Wendy, Philip and George. Grandfather of Adam and Brian. Born and raised in Brooklyn, attended Boys' High School, New York University and Temple University Dental School. He practiced dentistry in New York City for forty-five years. Lived for thirty years in Roslyn and Jericho, New York. His kindness and sense of humor will be missed by all.

title: After a Day of Presentations, Neither Side Budges Much
description: Senators emerged from the chamber this evening, many of them flush with praise for House prosecutors, but it was clear that the presentations on the floor had done little to alter their party-line stances.

title: DROPPING THE BALL: The Decline Of School Sports; A South Bronx Tale: Of Promises Kept, On and Off the Court
description: Wade Williams, the assistant principal and basketball coach at Bronx Regional High School, makes a promise to every boy at the school: If you play basketball for me, he tells them, and work harder than you ever have in your life, and stay out of trouble and graduate, I can help you get out of the South Bronx.

title: U.S. Proposes Easing U.N. Curbs on Iraq Oil
description: Under pressure from members of the United Nations Security Council to find ways to alleviate the suffering of the Iraqi people, the Clinton Administration today proposed ending the restrictions on how much oil Iraq can export in order to pay for relief supplies.

title: First Union Posts 49% Increase in Profit
description: The First Union Corporation, the nation's sixth-largest bank, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit jumped 49 percent based on renewed strength in its capital markets business, strong loan growth and robust fee income.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, ALICE M.
description: RUBINSTEIN-Alice M. (also known professionally as Alice Winston. Beloved masterteacher and colleague of The Stella Adler Conservatory of Acting for over thirty years. The students, faculty and administration wish to extend their heartfelt sympathies to her family. Our sincere gratitude for her passionate dedication to the art of acting.

title: Panel to Study Late Delivery Of State Exam
description: New York State's new fourth-grade reading test limped toward the end of a nightmarish debut yesterday, disrupted by bad weather that closed scores of schools and by continuing questions about distribution and security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROMISEL, ALVIN
description: PROMISEL-Alvin, on January 8, 1999. Loving and devoted husband to wife, Gloria. Loving father to Penny Contente and Shelley Ryan. Loving ''Papa'' to grand daughters Robyn Contente and Hannah Rose Ryan, the joys of his life. Loving brother to sister, Diane Zimmerman and loving father-in-law to Michael Contente and Andrew Ryan.

title: Lemon Awards Cite Spots for Criticism
description: Advertisers including Telecom USA, the Miller Brewing Company, the Saturn unit of the General Motors Corporation and the Quaker Oats Company were among 10 singled out for criticism yesterday when the Center for Science in the Public Interest presented its 14th annual Harlan Page Hubbard Lemon Awards.

title: Testaverde Takes On His Doubters
description: Don't tell Vinny. Vinny will tell you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, ALAN A.
description: GOULD-Alan A. A respected consulting structural engineer is mourned by his colleagues. Among the many notable projects that he designed were the U.S. Mission to the United Nations, the Kearney Parcel Post Facility and many monumental buildings. His professionalism served as an example for all those who knew him. Franklin Harwood

title: Sending Authority for Athletics Back to the Schools
description: The breakdown of public school athletics in New York City over the last quarter century was to a great extent a matter of impersonal forces and unintended consequences. But in equally large part, the fate of school sports was determined by individuals -- people who made a difference or who did not, who tried to defend athletics or who stood idly by on the sidelines.

title: Graphics Card Maker Says Profit Soared
description: ATI Technologies Inc., the world's biggest maker of graphics cards that help personal computers display three-dimensional images, said today that its fiscal first-quarter profit more than doubled, beating estimates, as sales almost doubled as well.

title: Metro Business; Superfund Contract
description: Stone & Webster announced yesterday that it had received a contract from the Army Corps of Engineers to clean up the Maywood Chemical Superfund site in Maywood, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDNER, ROSE
description: GOLDNER-Rose. On January 14, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Jack, loving mother of Merle and the late Frederick, adoring grandmother of Jared and Melanie. Devoted to her family, she will be profoundly missed. Visiting on Saturday 7-9PM. Service on Sunday 10:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Untangling 'Collision' of Clinton, Jones, Lewinsky and Constitution
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by Representative Ed Bryant, Republican of Tennessee, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Business as Usual, but With TV Turned On Low
description: As the Senate listened to the case for her husband's removal from office today, Hillary Rodham Clinton's mind was a world away -- on Mars, to be precise.

description: To the Editor:

title: New Video Releases
description: Buffalo '66

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Outtake'

title: Talk About Your Golden Oldies
