description: The musicians who are banding together tonight as the New York Collegium are hoping to change the city's reputation as an inhospitable place, or at least a reluctantly hospitable one, for early music played on period instruments.

title: Jury Offers Sensation: 100 Senators in Monkish Silence
description: The Senate sat utterly mute and passive as it began its trek into the familiar details of the nation's oft-told tale of the President and the intern.

title: Spain's No. 5 Bank Reports Steady Profits
description: Banco Popular Espanol S.A. said yesterday that a drop in funds set aside to protect against bad loans left profit little changed, in line with expectations. Spain's fifth-largest retail bank said it earned 17.05 billion pesetas ($119 million) in the fourth quarter, unchanged from 1997. In the full year, profit rose 2.7 percent, to 67.7 billion pesetas, or 611 pesetas a share, in line with the average of five analysts' forecasts.

title: On Iraq, Time for an Accounting
description: To the Editor:

title: Atlanta Has an Answer To the Moss-Carter Duo
description: Tony Martin and Terance Mathis feel a little like a dime-store version of the Minnesota Vikings' celebrated wide-receiver duo, Randy Moss and Cris Carter. The Atlanta Falcons' receivers do similar work, yet operate in relative anonymity.

title: Executive Leaving Ammirati Puris
description: Mike Lotito, for 12 years a top executive at the New York office of Ammirati Puris Lintas and a predecessor agency, Ammirati & Puris, said yesterday that he would resign, effective on Jan. 29.

title: Goldberg Moser O'Neill plans revamping in a bid to make itself better known as a creative shop.
description: A LEADING San Francisco agency, Goldberg Moser O'Neill, is reorganizing to gain a higher profile among advertisers.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER PLUNGES. Copper futures neared 12-year lows amid fears that economic weakness in Brazil will escalate into a Latin American crisis. In New York, copper for March delivery fell 0.65 cent a pound, to 65.80 cents.

title: U.S.O.C. Official Quits Over Tie to Utah Group
description: An executive of the United States Olympic Committee resigned last night after it was revealed that he had a business relationship with the Salt Lake bid committee.

title: Restaurant Owner Sought In Attack on a Student
description: The police were searching yesterday for a restaurant owner who is suspected of wounding a high school student with a kitchen knife in a dispute at a Chinese restaurant.

title: Back to the Center of Turkish Power
description: Cars were parked two-deep over the weekend outside the waterfront mansion of former Prime Minister Tansu Ciller. Bodyguards strolled back and forth as they waited for their bosses to emerge from urgent political strategy sessions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BON, ISIDOR
description: BON-Isidor. Died January 13, 1999 at age 96. Beloved husband of Fannie, father of Susan & Herbert, and Nona & Ira. Grandfather of David and Jennifer, Margot and Tom, Elizabeth, Lisa, Sera and Wilson. Funeral services at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Sunday, January 17 at 10 AM. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FATT, ARTHUR C.
description: FATT-Arthur C. 94. Of New York City and Delray Beach, Fla. Died Tuesday evening, January 12, 1999 after a long illness. Beloved husband of the late Barbara C., proud father of Marjorie Chester and Barbara Costikyan both of New York City, grandfather of Nancy Cedillo of Madrid, Spain, Priscilla Majcherska of East Hampton, L.I., Jonathan Heine of Chappaqua, N.Y., Christopher Chester of New York City and Katherine Chester of Bristol, R.I. Great-grandfather of four. A recognized pioneer in the field of advertising, he and the late Lawrence Valenstein founded The Grey Advertising Agency in 1921 and named the company for the color of the walls of their third floor walk-up office. Some of his happiest days were spent at his beloved home in Mallorca where he and his wife, Barbara, joyously hosted family and friends. Services and interment private. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: Words Upon the Heart, Heard at Last
description: TURBULENT SOULS

title: Shares Continue to Fall; The Dow Drops 228.63
description: Stocks fell for a fourth consecutive session yesterday as fears intensifed that Brazil's financial turmoil, reflected in the devaluation of its currency, might spread to other Latin economies and dampen business with the United States.

title: India Plan to Reduce Deficit Is Criticized
description: India's plans to raise 75 billion rupees ($1.76 billion) by having state-run companies buy their own and each other's shares may help the Government but hobble the companies, analysts said yesterday.

title: From Moiseyev, Movements Across Time and Place
description: As a choreographer and 20th-century artist, Igor Moiseyev is a prime innovator of his time. Small wonder that the audience sprang up and cheered the minute Mr. Moiseyev, wearing a beret and bow tie set off by his blue suit, stepped on stage for a bow at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night.

title: 2 Students Shot Outside Bronx High School
description: Two students were shot yesterday outside a Bronx high school where the police had stepped up security in response to a stabbing, in what was apparently a turf war, a day earlier.

title: NEXTLINK TO EXPAND VIA WIRELESS LICENSES
description: Nextlink Communications Inc., based in Bellevue, Wash., said yesterday that it would spend $832.7 million to expand its local and long-distance fiber optic networks with wireless licenses. The phone service provider will buy the closely held wireless company WNP Communications Inc. for $695 million in cash and stock. It will also pay $137.7 million for Nextel Communications Inc.'s 50 percent stake in Nextband, a joint venture between Nextel and Nextlink that owns more than 40 wireless licenses. Under the WNP agreement, Nextlink said it would pay $542.1 million in cash and stock to WNP and $152.9 million in cash to the Federal Communications Commission for licenses.

title: Outlets Slipping Out of Fashion; Traditional Stores Counter as Off-Price Malls Overreach
description: The Monday after New Year, Karen Tipper and her daughter, Meagan, strolled the Worcester Common Outlets mall in Worcester, Mass., in search of a suit. Not just any suit, mind you. Like many shoppers these days, the women had both high expectations and tight purse strings. Their goal: a designer label for around $150. Benetton and Ann Taylor were worth a visit, they knew; they had found bargains there before. But they steered clear of tonier designers like Donna Karan and Joan & David. Meagan, a first-year law student, scoffed at their prices. ''They are saying $350 is cheap,'' she said.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Jan Knap

title: On Iraq, Time for an Accounting
description: To the Editor:

title: Tracks Register a Gain
description: What kind of year will racing have in the counting house?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANOCHERIAN, ESKANDAR
description: MANOCHERIAN-Eskandar. On January 14, 1999. Beloved father of Jeffrey and Cynthia, Dr. Darel M. and Carlos Benaim and Donald and Zaza. Loving grandfather of Joshua, Daniel and Alexander Benaim, Amanda, Margo & Olivia Manocherian. Devoted brother of Amir, Fraydun and Touran and the late Manoochehr. Cherished friend to Barbara Levey. Service on Friday, January 15th, 10:30 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65th Street. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Eskandar Manocherian Scholarship Fund, C/O International Sephardic Education Foundation, 1114 Avenue of the Americas, New York City 10036.

title: Outsider Art Opens Windows to Fierce Inner Turmoil
description: Go pick a fight with success. Outsider art, a catchall phrase in this country for folk and ethnic art as well as works by prisoners, the mentally ill and others neither trained in art nor involved with its dialectic, has had such a market push in recent years that there's no getting out of its way. Galleries devoted to it have sprung up, exhibitions abound, and a few years ago an annual Outsider Art Fair was established in New York (running this year from Jan. 21-24). Once a marginal activity, Outsider art has developed its own collecting constituency, expert critics and aggressive promotional apparatus.

title: Jerzy Grotowski, Director, Is Dead at 65
description: Jerzy Grotowski, the Polish director who was one of the most important and influential theatrical innovators of his time, died yesterday in Pontedera, Italy. He was 65 and lived in Italy.

title: From Hyde: 'You've Taken an Oath of Impartiality
description: Following is an excerpt from the remarks today by Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, in the impeachment trial of President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: The Prosecution's Case: 'Basic Questions of Right Versus Wrong'
description: Following are excerpts from the introductory remarks today by Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, who presented the overview of the House impeachment case against President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: New Home Sparks A Growing Program
description: Ohio State, a newcomer to the sport's elite, is about to make a rare Eastern jaunt with contests at Cornell tonight and Colgate on Sunday afternoon. The Buckeyes, who qualified for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament for the first time last season and reached the semifinals, are a third-place team in the Central Association and now play home games in an elegant $106.5 million rink, Value City Arena.

title: Sport Is Fighting to Toss Out Korda
description: In 1998, he was an Australian Open hero. But in 1999, Petr Korda feels distinctly unwelcome at the Grand Slam event he won last year.

title: Internet Company Has a Strong Share Sale
description: Marketwatch.com Inc., which runs a popular World Wide Web site covering financial news, raised $46.8 million in an offering to institutional investors today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HENRY
description: COHEN-Henry. With his passing on January 14, 1999, New York City lost a dedicated public servant and policy expert and New School University a passionate and creative educational leader. Henry Cohen served New York City from 1950 to 1968, blazing a path that opened the City's government to increasing numbers of highly-trained professionals. As Professor of Urban Affairs and Dean of the Graduate School of Management and Urban Professions from 1968 to 1982, he conceived new curricula and the concept of urban professionals and recruited a distinguished faculty to train the new urban leadership. The Board of Advisors to the Robert J. Milano Graduate School of Mangement and Urban Policy of New School University express their grief and deep sympathy to his wife Evelyn, daughter Alison, son Daniel and grandchildren Anna and Rosalie. There will be a funeral Friday, January 15th at 12:15 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, NYC. Bill Green, Chair Board of Advisors to the Robert J. Milano Graduate School Jonathan F. Fanton President, New School University

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Silicon Graphics to Sell Its Stake in MIPS
description: Silicon Graphics Inc., a computer-graphics pioneer, said today that it would sell its $1 billion majority stake in the chip designer MIPS Technologies Inc. by September 2000.

title: Corrections
description: A quiz question in the special Education Life section on Jan. 3 about where the film character Indiana Jones taught archeology misstated his fictional relationship with the University of Chicago. He studied there. None of the films mention where he taught.

title: No, Dozing Is Not Impeachable
description: With the Senate's stationary cameras in place and trial managers from the House of Representatives reading lengthy, detailed presentations, television producers tried desperately to liven up the visual and aural dullness with graphics. They tried everything: biographical details about the speakers appeared at the bottom of the screen; video clips or photographs of Betty Currie, Monica S. Lewinsky and any other players in this drama popped up whenever they were mentioned; there was a definition of perjury from a legal dictionary, and there were even shots of the Capitol dome, just because it was there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERNE, LEO
description: CHERNE-Leo. Died peacefully Monday night at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness at age 86. Devoted father of Gail Gambino, the wife of Dr. Richard Gambino, grandfather of Erica Lynn Gambino, and brother of Jack Cherne. Leo's wife Phyllis died in 1995. Family services will be held Thursday, January 14, at 11AM, at The Jewish Center of the Hamptons, East Hampton, LI. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, February 3rd, at 3:30PM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 81st and Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions in Leo's memory may be made to The Leo Cherne Refugee Emergency Fund, c/o The International Rescue Committee, 122 East 42nd Street, New York, NY 10168.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, a front-page article yesterday about a study of breast removal as a cancer preventative omitted a passage at the continuation in some editions. It should have read:

title: Professors or Proletarians? A Test for Downtrodden Academics
description: Maybe it was fitting that a tumultuous event in academia seemed to turn on a metaphor. Shortly before the Modern Language Association's annual meeting, Elaine Showalter, the president, informed her charges -- full-time professors, part-time professors and graduate students in English and foreign languages -- that they were on a sinking ship, the Titanic to be precise. Now there is a bitter dispute about the lifeboats.

title: Lawyer for Raul Salinas Disputes The Validity of New Evidence
description: The chief lawyer defending Raul Salinas de Gortari, who is on trial in the 1994 assassination of a prominent politician, has questioned the validity of a newly uncovered piece of evidence that prosecutors said adds weight to the homicide accusations against his client.

title: Journal; Larry Flynt Stoned
description: We didn't need Larry Flynt to tell us that Bob Barr is a hypocrite. The Georgia Congressman's sleazy marital history was already public back in '96 when he had the gall to champion an absurd bill called the Defense of Marriage Act -- which that other proud defender of marriage, Bill Clinton, then signed into law. But we may need Larry Flynt anyway -- not to expose any impeachment manager's sex life but simply because his very presence exposes the disingenuousness of everybody else, conservative and liberal, Republican and Democrat, press and public, who inhabits the epic Bosch canvas that is Monicagate. In the land of the pious hypocrite, the honest pornographer is king.

title: Religion Journal; St. Louis Prepares for a Papal Visit
description: Next Friday, Pope John Paul II is scheduled to begin his 85th pastoral trip abroad, flying first to Mexico City for five days, then on to a single, brief stop in the United States. In his fifth visit to American soil, the Pope will spend little more than 30 hours in St. Louis on Jan. 26 and 27.

title: Abbott Drops Stock Buybacks
description: Abbott Laboratories, one of the world's biggest makers of drugs, medical devices and tests, suspended its share buyback program today as it reported fourth-quarter earnings. Analysts said the move indicated that Abbott intended to make acquisitions.

title: Senate Told It's Clinton 'Who Is Not Telling the Truth'
description: The Republican prosecutors asserted today that Monica S. Lewinsky's grand jury testimony was far more credible than President Clinton's, and one of them told senators sitting in judgment in the impeachment trial that ''it's the President who is not telling the truth.''

title: The Granddaddies of All Hackers
description: Last month the United States and 32 other countries agreed to create new international controls on the export of data-scrambling hardware and software. Many nations fear that the most advanced scrambling, which makes it impossible for anyone without the key to decode the data, could thwart efforts by intelligence agencies to track terrorists. Though the issue is a product of the information age, battles over secret coding have far older precedents. Below are excerpts from ''The Victorian Internet'' (Walker & Company, 1998), by Tom Standage, in which he writes about what he calls the ''19th-century precursor'' to the Internet: the electric telegraph invented by Samuel Morse and Charles Wheatstone.

title: From Grit to Gleaming Pearl, Through Boulez's Alchemy
description: As Pierre Boulez explained before Thursday night's Chicago Symphony concert -- where he was present not to conduct but to listen, as composer of a commissioned piece -- the ending of World War II made it possible for him to hear music that had been banned during the Nazi occupation. Bartok, Stravinsky, Schoenberg and others arrived in a rush, and in a rush he absorbed them and reacted. His whole creative life since then has been one long process of assimilation.

title: Global Warming: Not a Fantasy
description: To the Editor:

title: Endesa of Spain Buys Repsol Stake
description: Endesa S.A., Spain's biggest power company, bought 3.64 percent of Repsol S.A., the country's No. 1 oil company, for 82.26 billion pesetas ($573 million), three months after Endesa signed an alliance with Repsol's biggest shareholder, Gas Natural SDG S.A.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If you believe the testimony of Monica Lewinsky, you cannot believe the President or accept the argument of his lawyers.''

title: Internet Stock Rockets 474% In Initial Offer
description: In an indication that investors remain manic for new Internet stocks, the price of Marketwatch.com, the operator of a popular financial news site on the World Wide Web, rose more than 474 percent yesterday, its first day of trading.

title: In First Bout Since His Suspension Was Lifted, Tyson Fights for His Future
description: Francois Botha said he had been thinking about Mike Tyson a lot in the last four months. He did not say whether those thoughts included any deep concerns over his own personal safety once the two meet in the ring here at the MGM Grand on Saturday night.

title: 30-Year Mortgage Rate Up
description: The benchmark United States mortgage rate rose this week, though staying under the 7 percent mark for the longest stretch on record, Freddie Mac reported in its weekly survey. The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rose to 6.83 percent in the week that ended today from the previous week's 6.79 percent. The average rate on an adjustable mortgage was unchanged at 5.61 percent, while 15-year mortgage rates rose to 6.48 percent from 6.43 percent.

title: An A Train Serenade Ellington Could Like
description: To the Editor:

title: A 'Win Right Now' Coach Keeps Driving
description: Several minutes after Coach Bill Parcells of the Jets had finished screaming at one of his players for dropping a pass, Aaron Glenn, a cornerback, figured that enough time had gone by and it was safe to approach Parcells. Glenn positioned himself next to the beefy coach on a hot day at training camp last summer and asked a simple question: What did Parcells think about the coming season?

title: Global Warming: Not a Fantasy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTON, EUGENE J.
description: PATTON-Eugene J., 87, a resident of Tequesta, Florida, and formerly of Short Hills at Applewood Estates, Freehold, New Jersey, passed away on January 13, 1999. Mr. Patton was Deputy Senior Partner, Peat Marwick, Mitchell & Co. from 1965 to his retirement in 1972. A graduate of Western Reserve University in 1935 and Cleveland Law School in 1941, he was born in Cleveland, OH and began his career with General Electric Co. in the Tax Department. He joined PMM & C in 1946 and was admitted as a partner in 1951. He headed the firm's National Tax Department and was a member of the firm's Executive Committee and Advisory Committee. He served on the Boards of the National Health & Welfare Retirement Association, the Tax Institute of America and Internal Revenue Commissioner's Advisory Board. In 1967, he served as President of the Tax Institute of America. He was a member of the American Association of the Sovereign Military Order of MALTA and the Tequesta Country Club. Mr. Patton was predeceased by his wife, Jane Patton (nee O'Laughlin) in 1995. He is survived by a daughter, Susan Desmond of Little Silver, NJ and a son, John E. Patton of Union, NJ; two brothers, Norman Patton of Cleveland and William Patton of Chevy Chase, MD. He leaves seven grandchildren and two great grandchildren. A mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated, 10:30 AM, Monday, January 18, at St. Jude Catholic Church, Tequesta with interment in Riverside Memorial Park. Friends may call Sunday, January 17, from 3-5 and 7-9 PM at the Aycock Funeral Home, 1112 Military Trail, Jupiter, with a prayer service at 7:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAUTMAN, ADY
description: TRAUTMAN-Ady. Peacefully on January 15, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Edgar Trautman. Member Kehilath Jeshurun. Funeral Service Sunday, January 17 1PM at Beth El Cemetery in New Jersey. For info call Plaza Memorial 212-769-4400.

title: Albany Notes; A Single Vote Bolsters Clout of Senate G.O.P.
description: The recent elections may have sowed tumult in Washington, but here in the state capital, the Legislature that began meeting this week was a virtual replica of the last one, as seasoned -- or calcified, depending on one's view -- as ever.

title: Strong Yen Leaves Japan With a New Set of Problems
description: Last summer, Japanese financial authorities were desperately trying to prop up their almost embarrassingly weak currency. Lately, their dreams for a stronger yen have come all too true.

title: Editor of A.M.A. Journal Is Dismissed Over Sex Paper
description: The American Medical Association dismissed the editor of its leading journal yesterday, saying that he had rushed through a paper on whether college students think oral sex is ''having sex'' to influence President Clinton's impeachment trial.

title: In India, Religious Violence Can't Be Excused
description: To the Editor:

title: Enlistments Falling, Navy Lowers Education Standard
description: Facing a shortage of sailors at sea, the Navy announced today that it would have to lower educational standards for new recruits as part of a series of initiatives to increase enlistments.

title: Witch's Curse Aside, a Happy Immersion in Illogic
description: For cleverness and outlandish complications, ''Ruddigore'' is a few levels short of top-drawer Gilbert and Sullivan, top drawer being ''H.M.S. Pinafore'' or ''Pirates of Penzance.'' But in New York, where Savoyard charm is in short supply, one is grateful for what one can get, and the production by the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players, who are performing ''Ruddigore'' at Symphony Space through tomorrow, makes a strong case for it.

title: The Only Time to Say Never Is in 'Never Say Never'
description: A player who is defending a slam and has J x x x in trump with a side ace is entitled to be optimistic. He will, of course, never lead a trump, which would jeopardize his potential trick. Never? Well hardly ever, as the diagramed deal shows.

title: Ebay to Offer Free Insurance and ID System
description: Ebay Inc., the Internet auctioneer, said today that it would offer free insurance and a user-identification system to increase users' confidence in the security of its on-line trading network.

title: Global Warming: Not a Fantasy
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Is Warned to Clean Up Its Economic Act
description: Having given up on defending the value of its currency at least temporarily, Brazil got a muted but clear warning from the International Monetary Fund and the United States today that failure to act quickly on pledges to bolster its financial condition through spending cuts and tax increases would lead to a downward economic spiral.

title: Mayor Relents On Plan to End Methadone Use
description: Six months after saying he wanted to abolish New York City's methadone treatment programs, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has abandoned his plan to move all 2,100 heroin addicts at city hospitals into abstinence programs, conceding yesterday that his idea was ''maybe somewhat unrealistic.''

title: POMEROY COMPUTER SERVICE BUSINESS TO GO PUBLIC
description: Pomeroy Computer Resources Inc., which sells and installs computer networking equipment, has split off its service business into a new subsidiary that plans to go public through an initial stock sale. Pomeroy Computer, which had revenues of $491 million in 1997, will retain a controlling stake in the unit, Pomeroy Select Integration Solutions Inc., which had revenues of $45.2 million for the same period. The unit could raise as much as $57.5 million in its initial public offering, the company said yesterday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Pomeroy Computer shares rose 68.75 cents, to $21.25. Over all, company shares have fallen almost 21 percent during the last six months.

title: Russia Allows Trading In Bonds to Resume
description: Russia allowed domestic bond trading to resume for the first time since the Government's August default, limiting annual yields to 120 percent to keep down future borrowing costs.

title: Thousands of Farmers Protest in China; 1 Dies in Police Clash
description: Thousands of farmers demonstrating against local officials clashed with hundreds of police officers in a small town in southern China last week, the latest and perhaps largest in a series of farmer and worker protests that have sprung up around China in the last year.

title: Latin Markets Rebound, But Storm Hasn't Passed
description: Stock markets throughout Latin America rebounded strongly today on hopes that Brazil's currency would not tumble out of control. But analysts warned that several countries in the region faced a period of extreme economic volatility, with the likelihood of devaluations, rising interest rates and growing unemployment through the rest of the year.

title: WILLIAMS'S FOURTH-QUARTER EARNINGS WILL BE REDUCED
description: The Williams Companies Inc. said yesterday that its 1998 fourth-quarter earnings would be reduced by $133 million because of charges related to an employee benefit program, discontinued operations and other costs. Williams was expected to earn 22 cents a share in the fourth quarter, down from 28 cents a year earlier, the First Call Corporation said. The charges include a $58 million impairment charge in the company's natural-gas pipeline business, a $30 million loss for modifying an employee benefit program, a $23 million asset write-down in its energy services business and a $22 million loss for costs associated with operations previously sold. Shares of Williams rose 18.75 cents, to $30.

title: Disability Helps Lawyer Avoid Prison for Insider Trading
description: A young lawyer with cerebral palsy who had pleaded guilty in an insider trading case avoided prison yesterday after a Federal judge in Manhattan said his illness could make him vulnerable to hardship and dangers in prison.

title: The African Question: Who Is to Blame?; The Finger Points to the West, And Congo Is a Harsh Example
description: By the late 1960's, scarcely a decade after Africa's great independence wave had begun, many of the continent's new political creations had already begun to resemble disasters. With no ready answers to their problems, many African leaders struck upon a new strategy for explaining their failings to impatient populations while simultaneously drawing more outside aid: blaming the European colonizers for Africa's seemingly intractable difficulties.

title: Hyundai Investment Planned for North Korea
description: Hyundai Group, already under pressure to finance expansion of its auto and memory chip businesses, said yesterday that it planned to invest $397 million by next year to develop a tourist resort in North Korea.

title: Man Charged in 1984 Murder That Prosecutor Ties to a Sect
description: An East Newark man was charged with murder today in the stabbing death of a homeless man here in 1984, a killing that the Essex County Prosecutor said was carried out as ''a sacrifice'' to honor the leader of a religious sect that considers itself a lost black tribe of Israel.

title: Insurer Weighs China Airlines Investment
description: The insurer American International Group said today that it would consider an investment in China Airlines, Taiwan's largest carrier.

title: TURMOIL IN BRAZIL: THE ECONOMICS -- One Choice Made, More to Come; Why Brazil Did What It Did and What Options Are Left
description: On Wednesday, Brazil drew a line in the sand in front of its embattled currency, the real. Yesterday, it erased that line, sending the sand scattering, as it allowed the real to trade freely against other currencies.

title: Harkin Wins Endorsement of Wider Role Than Jury
description: When Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, interrupted Representative Bob Barr's monologue on the Senate floor today with an objection about his repeated use of the word ''jurors,'' Mr. Harkin was expressing more than just a simple annoyance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, JANIS MERESMAN
description: GOLDMAN-Janis Meresman. 54, devoted daughter of Harry Meresman and the late Helen Chafets Meresman. Loving sister of Helaine Meresman Barnett, beloved wife of Michael David Goldman, adoring mother of Melissa Lee Goldman, Lori Goldman Zbar. Cherished aunt, dear niece, treasured friend. Funeral services will be held at 2:00 PM on Sunday at Adas Israel Congregation in Washington, DC. Contributions can be made to the Janis Meresman Goldman Memorial Fund at The Charles E. Smith Jewish Day School of Greater Washington. GOLDMAN-Janis Meresman. My life was blessed to have had such an extraordinary sister whose love, devotion, support, caring and sharing knew no bounds. She became an integral and loving part of Victor, Craig and Roger's lives as my family grew and brought special meaning of indescribable togetherness to the word sisters. Janie's unbelievable courage was an inspiration to us all. You will be forever in my heart. Laine. GOLDMAN-Janis Meresman. Full of love, humor and warmth, you played a very special and irreplaceable role in our lives. You were and still will be a part of our daily thoughts. Aunt, we will miss you and always remember your special spirit. Craig, Jennifer, Gabriel, Roger and Slo GOLDMAN-Janis. Beloved Janie to Aunt Berenice and Uncle Dick and to all the younger generations of Morrises whose loss is profound. Donny and Jeff

title: Appeals Court Lets Hinckley Take Day Trips
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., who wounded President Ronald Reagan and three other men in 1981, can make supervised day trips from the mental hospital where he has been confined for 17 years, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: It Seems Like Forever, but Road Goes On
description: Fidgeting anxiously, neck-rolling, eye-rubbing, stretching and straining in the debating chamber, the Senator resembled a driver on the midnight leg of a transcontinental automobile trip with the radio playing odd scraps of information about a woman named Monica.

title: Sweden Sells Part Of Pharmacia Stake
description: The Swedish Government raised $1.71 billion selling most of its shares in Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc., the maker of the baldness treatment Rogaine and the incontinence pill Detrol. The Government sold 31.1 million shares at $55 each, representing 6 percent of Pharmacia's outstanding shares.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 16 about Ireland's policy of neutrality referred imprecisely to the view of Foreign Minister David Andrews. While he wants Ireland to join the Partnership for Peace, an organization of countries that have agreed to coordinate their military policies with NATO, he is not arguing that Ireland's neutrality policy should be reconsidered to permit that. He has said that he fully supports the policy of neutrality and that joining the Partnership for Peace would not be incompatible with it.

title: Garden Auction Is Slap at Civility; Neighborhood Pride
description: To the Editor:

title: Garden Auction Is Slap at Civility
description: To the Editor:

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: FINE-TUNING A LEGACY
description: Bill Clinton asked Americans to vote for him based on what he would do, not on who he was. Like Andrew Jackson and Franklin Roosevelt, he's changed the Presidency's very nature, and made a legacy that should grow clearer with time. A report by Jacob Weisberg in the Times Magazine.

title: At a Conference on Wall Street Diversity, the President Finds His Own Stock Soaring
description: While under attack again by House prosecutors in Washington, President Clinton was doused with praise yesterday for the economy's strength, likened to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and generally celebrated at a Wall Street conference bringing together minority and white business leaders.

title: Life Without Parole for Murderer of Officer
description: A failed stockbroker convicted of murdering a police officer during a botched attempt to rob his own wealthy father was sentenced yesterday to life in prison without parole.

title: Theo Hios, 90, Portrait Painter With Visionary Views of Nature
description: Theo Hios, a New York painter and teacher, died on Sunday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 90 and had homes in Manhattan and Hampton Bays, N.Y.

title: Fire at Condominium Leaves 80 Homeless
description: About 80 people remained homeless yesterday after a fire Thursday night forced the evacuation of a 31-unit condominium in Union City, officials said.

title: Celluloid Comic Book About Aliens
description: As long on adrenaline and special effects as it is short on genuine novelty and intellectual content, ''Virus'' can at least lay claim to being the sci-fi thriller that literally takes the Frankenstein story to new heights and uncharted depths.

title: Struggles Continue In Lining Up Tours
description: The Australian Open, the first Grand Slam event of the tennis season, begins Monday in Melbourne. But not all the meaningful activity will be restricted to the court.

title: On Defense, Broncos Total Their Assets
description: For Tyrone Braxton, it's Wayne Chrebet drifting behind the linebackers and staking out the middle of the field. For Ray Crockett, it's about matching his swift moves and finesse against Keyshawn Johnson's towering strength. For Neil Smith, the key is burying Curtis Martin before he pops through the offensive line.

title: MAJOR GROCERY WHOLESALER CUTTING 220 JOBS
description: The Fleming Companies, the second-largest United States grocery wholesaler, said yesterday that it was cutting 220 jobs as part of its plan to reduce overhead expenses. The cuts are Fleming's first step since it announced on Dec. 7 that it would close distribution centers, sell some supermarkets and cut jobs in an effort to streamline its business. The company, based in Oklahoma City, said the moves would result in $627 million in charges, most of them to be taken in the fourth quarter. The job cuts, many of which the company said are effective immediately, represent 12 percent of Fleming's corporate staff. Shares of Fleming rose 37.5 percent, to $10.75. The shares have fallen about 23 percent in the last year.

title: Applying Witness Tampering in Civil Cases
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by Representative Christopher B. Cannon, Republican of Utah, in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Last-Place Blackhawks Too Good for Rangers
description: Play enough last-place teams in succession and eventually one will beat you. Last night it was the Chicago Blackhawks, at the bottom of the Central Division of the Western Conference, who visited the Rangers at Madison Square Garden. Without a victory in their previous seven games, the Blackhawks were well rested, having spent the previous three nights at a Colorado resort.

title: Gaels Continue to Surge
description: IONA 77, MANHATTAN 61

title: CALCOMP TO CLOSE OR SELL GRAPHICS-PRINTER PLANTS
description: Calcomp Technology Inc. said yesterday that it would dismiss 450 people in the United States, and close or sell all of its operations that make graphics printers. Calcomp had said last month that it would shut down or file for bankruptcy because the Lockheed Martin Corporation, which owns 86 percent of Calcomp, would not increase or extend its $43 million line of credit. Calcomp lost $190 million trying to make a success of its Crystal Jet line of graphics printers, which sell for as much as $30,000 each. The company will close its headquarters in Anaheim, Calif., and shut or sell its plants in San Jose, Calif., Scottsdale, Ariz., and Bruges, Belgium.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Arts in America column on Thursday, about the New York Philharmonic's United States tour, misidentified the subject of a quotation from Kurt Masur, its music director. When Mr. Masur said, ''Maybe they are a little bit proud of their orchestra,'' he was speaking of the Philharmonic musicians and their pride, not the feelings of the audiences attending their concerts.

title: INSIDE
description: Editor Ousted for Sex Article

title: Reporter's Notebook; Jackson Challenges 'Capital of Capital'
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's push to get minority-owned companies a bigger slice of America's economic pie has shown early results. But to judge by the reaction of the hundreds of mostly black executives who attended his second annual Wall Street Project conference in lower Manhattan the last two days, a main attraction is still Mr. Jackson himself.

title: The Game Hasn't Started, and the Jets Are Behind
description: The Jets' arrival here today for the American Football Conference championship game against the powerful Denver Broncos was muted.

title: Easing Pain the Hard Way
description: I was recently lying on a hospital gurney writhing in pain. It had been nearly six hours since the ambulance attendants wheeled me into the emergency room, and I had just had my first injection of pain medication. It took an intern three tries before he succeeded in threading a tube up my nose, past my throat and down into my stomach.

title: Planning a Garden in the Snow
description: Snow has been falling all day long as I write. The skylights are drifted over, and by noon dusk seems to be in the offing, the day so gray, so white, that the winter color of the goldfinches -- pale as olive oil -- feels like an overdraft on the eyes. Some days chores are barely that, just a visit to the barn and then back for coffee. But this morning the gates were deep in snow and the dutch doors on the barn needed shoveling out, as did the deck and the path to the woodpile. The horses dropped sweetfeed from their mouths, staining the snow molasses. Three crows foraging beside the black rubber feed pans seemed to stand watch over their shadows, except that there are no shadows on a day like this. One horse had rolled in a drift, leaving what looked like the wing-print of a giant owl descending on its prey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FATT, ARTHUR C.
description: FATT-Arthur C. The Officers, Board of Governors and Members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed life member, and extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Jay M. Rosen, President Corey B. Rabin, Secretary

title: Top Spanish Bank to Buy A Rival for Billions in Stock
description: Banco Santander, Spain's largest bank, said today that it was buying Banco Central Hispano, the nation's third-biggest bank, in a stock swap that is valued at $11.3 billion and is expected to lift the merged bank into Europe's top 20 by assets.

title: MAYTAG AGREES TO BUY JADE RANGE
description: The Maytag Corporation, the No. 3 appliance maker in the United States, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Jade Range for between $20 million and $25 million in cash and stock in a bid to build up its cache of higher-priced appliances. Jade Range makes stainless-steel ranges and refrigerators for the services industry under the Jade brand, and commercial-style ranges and outdoor grills for consumers under the Dynasty brand. Maytag will pay off Jade Range's debt in cash and issue stock to buy the company, a company spokesman said. The transaction is expected to close in the first quarter. Shares of Maytag rose $1, to $64.25.

title: Soaring Jets Minimize Mile High Altitude
description: Painted in blue on the wall in the visiting locker room at Mile High Stadium -- which many of the Jets will see for the first time on Saturday -- is this piece of disquieting information:

title: The Charges: 'This Is About a Scheme. This Is About a Lot of Lies.'
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by Representative Bill McCollum, Republican of Florida, in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Brazil's Currency Move Gives Shares a Lift Worldwide
description: World stock markets soared yesterday as traders saw in Brazil's decision to stop defending its currency an end to the uncertainty that has recently clouded the global investment outlook.

title: Locking Up Free Agents Tops the Knicks' Agenda
description: The Knicks are looking for closure this weekend. As teams begin to agree in principle with free agents, a trickle-down effect could help end much of the speculation and drama surrounding the frenzy of activity that has unfolded since the lockout ended last week.

title: Even Buffalo, Citadel of Winter, Grows Weary of Relentless Snow
description: Even in a city proud to be called the snow capital of America, where residents say they feel joyful when the first white blanket forms over Lake Erie, enough is enough.

title: Trial Coverage
description: Following is the expected schedule for the impeachment trial of President Clinton:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMIDT, J. FREDERICK
description: SCHMIDT-J. Frederick. On January 14, 1999, of New Rochelle, NY. Survived by his beloved wife Dorothy (nee Walker), brother Joseph, niece Jane Gilligan and nephew Robert Walker. Eldest son of the late Catherine and Louis Schmidt. Beloved brother of the late Margaret, Louis Jr., John and George Schmidt. Family will receive friends at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY, Sunday & Monday 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial, Blessed Sacrament Church, New Rochelle, NY, Tuesday 9:30 AM. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Manhattan College.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Russia Proposes New System For Monitoring Iraqi Arms
description: Russia, which is opposing any revival of the present arms inspection system in Iraq, today gave the Security Council a detailed blueprint for a new monitoring apparatus having much less independence.

title: A Midwinter Mishmash Of Weather, All Messy
description: It was slippery and soggy throughout the Northeast yesterday, as New Yorkers practically skated down sidewalks that looked in the morning as if they were coated with polyurethane, and in the afternoon like slushy, running puddles as the sleet gave way to rain and, finally, clearing skies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, FRED K.
description: SIEGEL-Fred K. The Board of Governors of the Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member and dear friend Fred K. Siegel and offers its heartfelt sympathy to his family and friends. David L. Rudnick, President Robert S. Puder, Secretary

title: Slumping Devils Get Better Against the Lowly Lightning
description: The timing was absolutely perfect for the league's worst team to visit the Devils tonight. With New Jersey having lost its previous three games, the Tampa Bay Lightning provided just the kind of soft touch needed by the Devils, who posted a 3-1 victory at Continental Arena on the strength of three goals on consecutive power plays in the second period.

title: In India, Religious Violence Can't Be Excused; Minority Protections
description: To the Editor:

title: Sudanese Foes Agree to Extend Cease-Fire in Famine Region
description: The main warring parties in Sudan have agreed to extend a cease-fire in the area of the country hardest hit last year by famine, United Nations officials announced here today.

title: The Perils From Brazil
description: For American investors and businesses, the Brazilian convulsion is the latest chapter in a contagious currency crisis that started in Thailand in July 1997 and spread to Russia last summer. If the turmoil leads to a prolonged downturn on Wall Street or cuts heavily into American exports, the ntiona' economy could turn anemic. A guide to what is at stake and what might happen next.

title: Judge Refuses To Open Files On a Suspect In 2 Bombings
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan refused yesterday to open secret court files pertaining to a former United States Army sergeant suspected of conspiring with Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile indicted in the bombings of two United States embassies in Africa last August.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLS, GWEN
description: WELLS-Gwen. January 15, 1999. The offices, executive board, and membership of the Metro New York Labor Communications Counsel mourn the passing of former President, Gwen Wells. She was a leader, a woman of courage and principle, and a good and loyal friend to many of us. Martin Fishgold, President Judy West, Vice President Metro New York Labor Communications Counsel

title: Where Oil Is Plentiful But Cash Is Short
description: Oil, for so long the source of so much easy wealth, is now fueling hard questions along the Persian Gulf.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, RUTH LITTMAN
description: GROSS-Ruth Littman. Passed in peace on January 13 in her 85th year after a long and debilitating illness. Wife, mother, grandmother, and great grandmother she filled each of these roles with love and adoration. She will live forever in the hearts of her children Rollie (Littman) and Samuel Antupit, Sandra (Littman) and Jon Kates, Arthur and Susan Littman, 10 grandchildren, and 10 great grandchildren-a woman of unsurpassed beauty and consummate grace. She shared a glowing, and story-book romance with her dedicated husband, Jack. Ruth was devoted to an extensive circle of longtime friends that encompassed people in all walks of life and with a wide variety of interests. Ruth served her community as President of the Pleasantville League for under privileged youth; as a volunteer at the NY Hospital for Special Surgery and at The Rusk Institute of New York University. She was an active member of Metropolis Country Club, Fairview Country Club, and Delaire Country Club in Delray Beach, Florida. A memorial service will be held at Temple Kol Ami, White Plains, NY on January 18 at 2 PM. (914-949-4717). In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Greenwich Hospital C/O Development Office, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT 06830, or The Fund for Blood and Cancer Research, 525 East 68th Street, New York, New York 10021, C/O Chairman Dr. Mark Pasmantier.

title: Police Stole Peddlers' Wares, An Officer Tells Investigators
description: Information from a suspended New York City police officer has prompted investigations into the possibility that he and other officers have been stealing merchandise confiscated from illegal street vendors in midtown Manhattan, then reselling it, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: The Witness Mirage
description: Henry Hyde and his House prosecution team are trying to sell the Senate and the country on the notion that summoning Monica Lewinsky, Betty Currie and other witnesses will magically seal the case against Bill Clinton. This is impeachment snake oil. Calling witnesses will not make or break the case, but it will prolong the trial for days, if not weeks, and turn it into a bitterly partisan spectacle that can only damage the Senate and anger the nation. Trent Lott, the majority leader, knows that and recognizes that Republicans will pay the price. It is not too late for him to plot a different course.

title: Prosecution Consensus Builds To Seek Testimony by Clinton
description: There is a growing consensus among the House prosecutors to ask the Senate to invite President Clinton to testify in his impeachment trial, prosecutors and their aides said today.

title: 'Pattern Offenses' Seen Within a Context of Circumstantial Evidence
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by Representative Bob Barr, Republican of Georgia, in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMLIAN, REV. FR. ROBERT J.
description: TOMLIAN-Rev. Fr. Robert J. on January 13, 1999. Beloved and longtime Pastor of St. John Nepomucene R.C. Church, 66th St. and First Ave NYC. Dear brother of Frank. Reposing at the church on Sunday and Monday, 2-7PM. Mass of the Holy Eucharist in Slovak on Monday at 7:30PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Tuesday at 10AM, celebrated by John Cardinal O'Connor. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. For further info, call Krtil Funeral Home-Yorkville Funeral Service 212-744-3084

title: TRUE NORTH SUING ITS FORMER FRENCH PARTNER
description: True North Communications Inc., the world's sixth-largest advertising company, said yesterday that it was suing the French advertising company Publicis S.A., its former global-alliance partner, for more than $60 million over what it contends was an inadequate valuation of its stake in the French company. True North, the Chicago-based owner of Foote, Cone & Belding Worldwide, said it filed suit in the London Court of International Arbitration over the consolidation of Publicis Communication into Publicis S.A. on Dec. 14. True North charged that the conversion of its 26.5 percent stake in Publicis Communication into 8.8 percent of the holding company was inadequate.

title: Soweto Journal; Racial Tokenism? That's Not Cricket
description: Here on Soweto's only cricket ground, contemplative political discussion is possible. There are so few fans that each crack of the bat is audible. So, in fact, is each gentle thump of the ball on the grass.

title: The Rudy Giuliani Wars; Trash Talking
description: If Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is even fantasizing about Presidential politics, he may already have lost two key states in the last week. New Jersey is miffed because New York City's Mayor wants to create a football dome in Manhattan to lure back the Jets. Virginia is horrified because not only does he want to send its residents a lot of the city's trash, he wants them to feel honored to take it.

title: Supreme Court to Hear Broadcasters' Suit Challenging Federal Ban on Casino Advertisements
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Federal Government could continue to ban broadcast advertising by gambling casinos. The case raises an important issue of commercial speech with implications for government regulations on advertising for other lawful but disfavored activities like smoking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISKIND, BUDDY D.
description: SISKIND-Buddy D. On January 15, 1999. Beloved husband of Pearl. Loving father of Adam and Jeffrey (Monica). Devoted brother of Howard. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday, 1 P.M.

title: Suit Alleges Frequent Abuse of Gay Children in Foster Care
description: A Federal class-action lawsuit was filed yesterday on behalf of gay, lesbian and bisexual youths in foster care, charging that because of their sexual orientation they are routinely subjected to physical violence and psychological abuse in New York City's child welfare system.

title: An Unlikely Ally
description: The new Speaker of the House, Dennis Hastert, weighed in today on the timing of the State of the Union address, saying President Clinton should deliver his speech as planned on Tuesday even though the Senate is in the middle of his impeachment trial.

title: Breast Surgery Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, CAROL
description: STONE-Carol. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, New York mourns the passing of our beloved member, Carol Stone, and extends heartfelt condolences to her family. Alan B. Lucas, Rabbi Martin Kay, President

title: Corrections
description: A picture by Reuters in Business Day on Thursday, with articles about Brazil's currency devaluation, carried an erroneous caption and has been withdrawn by the news agency. The Brazilians shown in the picture were lined up outside a Rio de Janeiro bank to conduct routine business. They were not waiting to withdraw money after the devaluation.

title: Gang Leader Pleads Guilty To Conspiracy In Drug Case
description: The head of the New York State branch of the Latin Kings street gang, who had claimed to be leading members away from violence and drug dealing to self-improvement and community advocacy, pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiring to traffic in heroin and cocaine.

title: Corrections
description: A cabaret review on Thursday about a performance by the Australian singer David Campbell and his piano accompanist, John Bucchino, who composed the songs, misstated the title of a musical by Mr. Bucchino that included the song ''Grateful.'' The show was ''Urban Myths,'' not ''Urban Legends.''

title: An Improved Defense Labors in Obscurity
description: Begin a conversation about why the Minnesota Vikings have been so dominant this season and the dialogue will almost always start with their offense. The Vikings have Randall Cunningham, Randy Moss, Cris Carter and a slew of other dangerous weapons, and they set a National Football League record by scoring 556 points.

title: U.S.O.C. Steps Up Its Scrutiny of the Salt Lake City Bid
description: About 8:30 last Sunday night in Colorado Springs, the phone rang at the home of Dick Schultz, the executive director of the United States Olympic Committee.

title: The 4 Elements of Perjury: An Oath, an Intent, Falsity and Materiality
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by Representative Steve Chabot, Republican of Ohio, in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Robert Douglas, 89, Suave Actor Turned Director
description: Robert Douglas, a stage and screen actor who made a career portraying swashbucklers and military commanders before turning to directing, died on Monday at his home in Encinitas, Calif. He was 89.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Nets Rebound With $100 Million for Williams
description: A day and half is not a long time to negotiate when tens of millions of dollars are involved. But for the Nets, the 33 hours it took to agree in principle to a seven-year, $100 million contract with Jayson Williams must have dragged along like farm machinery behind a tractor.

title: Internet Auto Seller Plans to Offer Stock
description: Autobytel.com Inc., which operates a Web site for buying new and used vehicles, revived plans for an initial stock offering today, more than one and a half years after canceling earlier plans.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Global Stock Markets Soar As Brazil Floats Currency

title: Rap Artist Is Charged With Firing at the Police
description: A rap artist from the group Wu-Tang Clan was charged with attempted murder last night after the police said shots were fired at them by one or two men who had been pulled over for a traffic violation in Brooklyn.

title: Medicare to Pay Health Plans Bonuses for Sicker Patients
description: Medicare officials said today that they would pay private health plans more for patients who were sick and less for patients who were healthy.

title: Pete Wilson Reflects on One More, Elusive Rung
description: For eight years in Sacramento, Pete Wilson had to look no farther than the big portrait of Ronald Reagan in his office to dream of what the future might hold for a Republican Governor of California. Now, in his second week as a private citizen, Mr. Wilson has begun sharing an office suite here with the former President himself, but the dream remains uncertain.

title: Garden Auction Is Slap at Civility; A Failed Policy Returns
description: To the Editor:

title: Global Warming: Not a Fantasy
description: To the Editor:

title: Germany to Compensate 240 American Survivors of Nazi Camps
description: The United States and Germany today announced a tentative agreement for the German Government to compensate an estimated 240 Americans who were imprisoned in Nazi concentration camps.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR GAINS. The Brazilian real's devaluation strengthened the dollar against key currencies. It rose to 114.13 yen from 113.61, while the euro fell to $1.1588 from $1.1710 and the British pound fell to $1.6518 from $1.6567.

title: 130 Veteran Faces For the Browns
description: There is some pedigree -- eight players with Pro Bowl experience -- to the list of 130 veteran players made available for the Feb. 9 expansion draft that will help stock the 1999 Cleveland Browns roster. For the Browns, the quandary will be determining where performance still matches pedigree.

title: Henry Cohen, 76, Urban Planner And a New York City Official
description: Henry Cohen, an urban planner, a retired dean at the New School for Social Research and a prominent New York City official in the Wagner and Lindsay administrations, died Thursday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 76.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: J. BAKER INC., Canton, Mass., said that Roger J. Osborne, president of its Work 'n Gear division, had resigned and that Alan I. Weinstein, its president and chief executive, would run the division while a successor was sought for Mr. Osborne.

title: The Odd Logic Of a Spy's Defenders
description: Several major American Jewish organizations are urging President Clinton to free Jonathan Pollard, the former naval intelligence specialist who in 1987 was sentenced to life in prison for passing classified documents to Israel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIPPNER, MAXINE (NEE LOWINSON)
description: RIPPNER-Maxine (nee Lowinson). On january 14, 1999, of New York City. A beloved cousin, and friend to many.

title: Keeneland Group Buys Turfway
description: The Turfway Park race track in northern Kentucky was sold for $37 million to a three-way partnership that included Keeneland, the aristocratic track in the heart of horse country in Lexington, Ky.

title: Man Sought in Series Of Robberies and Rapes
description: The authorities are searching for a man suspected in a series of robberies and rapes or attempted rapes in eastern Queens and Nassau County since Dec. 22.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARPER, EUGENE W.
description: HARPER-Eugene W., 82, of Middletown, New Jersey on January 13, 1999 at home. Loving husband of fifty-five years, Muriel A. (nee Drumgoole). Beloved father of Eugene W. Jr., James D., Robert F., Gerard E., Thomas P., Daniel J., Mary T. and the late Lawrence J. & William M. Dear grandfather of Elizabeth, Virginia, Katherine and Joseph; Timothy and Sarah; Jessica; Amanda and Julia; Caitlin and Tess. Funeral Liturgy on Saturday, January 16, will be offered at St. Mary's RC Church, New Monmouth, New Jersey at 10:30 am. Visting at the John F. Pfleger Funeral Home, 115 Tindall Road, Middletown, New Jersey, Friday, January 15th, 2-4PM and 7-9PM. Memorial donations may be made to the Rosary Hill Home, Hawthorne, New York 10532.

title: Book by de Klerk Shatters Any Illusions About His Feelings Toward Mandela
description: For years they were inextricably linked, so much so that while they gingerly shared a government, their images were routinely sold together in souvenir shops as salt-and-pepper shakers. But behind the scenes, it was a difficult union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRICKE, HELENE A.
description: FRICKE-Helene A. Beloved mother and aunt. Respected hotel manager of the East End Hotel for Women from 1941 to 1969. Passed away at the age of 94 on January 14, 1999. Services will be held at Thomas Quinn Funeral Home, 3520 Broadway, Long Island City, 718-721-9200.

title: Mets and Cedeno Agree on a Salary
description: The Yankees made no progress with their three expensive salary arbitration players yesterday, but the Mets made a tiny dent in their collection.

title: About New York; For Red Hook, Pierside Brawl With City Hall
description: BENNY TORRES was working the phone in his insurance office on Richards Street in Red Hook. A sign in the window declared, ''Real Estate Coming Soon.'' Mr. Torres is a loyal son of Red Hook, down to how he was born: at home in the nearby projects, not away at some hospital. He just got his real estate license. Now he has plans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, LUCETTE M.
description: CARTER-Lucette M.., 75. Of Poughquag, NY. Mrs. Carter was born in 1923 in New York City to Alfred and Marie Salles Monnier. She was a graduate of Cathedral High School and Hunter College, NYC. In 1953 at the Church of Notre Dame she married William H. Carter, Jr. who survives. Other survivors include a brother JeanLouis Monnier, sisters Bernadette T. Monnier and Elisabeth M. Vandelli, all of Northport, NY. Mrs. Carter is also survived by her children William, Joan, Raymond, Marie, Annina and Renee Carter, and Gabrielle Carter Katz; and eight grandchildren. For info: Robert H. Auchmoody Funeral Homes, Hopewell Junction, NY.

title: British Carrier Wins Battle For Airtouch
description: Vodafone Group P.L.C., Britain's largest mobile phone company, has agreed to buy Airtouch Communications Inc. for more than $60 billion, edging out the Bell Atlantic Corporation in a bidding war for the nation's largest wireless company, the companies confirmed last night.

title: Will Noise Thwart Love?
description: Zoe befriends the meanest girl (and most dangerous dodge-ball player) in school because the girl's brother is a hunk. Zoe's mom is dating an airline pilot with one eyebrow. Duncan can't get a date because he's lactose-intolerant. His mother also makes him scrape his tongue every day. Jack may be wearing enchanted shoes. Jane, his fraternal twin, likes to use terms like ''raw sex'' and has a fixation on breasts (her own). Are these New York City high school students wacky or what?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, SIDNEY
description: GREENBERG-Sidney. Dearly beloved husband of Judith. Loving father of Carol Kornheiser and Dick Greenberg. Devoted brother of Madeline Margolis. Adored grandfather of Emily Katherine Kornheiser, Allison and Jennifer Greenberg. Loved and mourned by all who knew him. Graveside services Sunday, 2 PM, at New Montefiore Cemetery. For further information please contact Gutterman's Inc, (516-764-9400).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERGENFELD, ANITA S
description: BERGENFELD-Anita S. The puzzles are no longer done and other things are undone. Miss you. Love, Howard.

title: Volvo Buys Stake and Says It Wants All of Rival Truck Maker
description: Volvo A.B., the Swedish maker of cars, buses and trucks, purchased a 13 percent stake in a rival Swedish truck manufacturer, Scania A.B., today for 5.2 billion kronor ($666.5 million) and said it wanted to take over the entire company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANNE, MARTIN B.
description: MANNE-Martin B. On January 15, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Heddy. Loving father of David and Franne. Devoted grandfather of Hillary, Jordan, Monica and Adam. Formerly married to Winifred. Funeral service Sunday 9:45AM at Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, New York. Interment Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: School Policy Could Bar Athletes With H.I.V.
description: Reviving a dormant health controversy, a northern Colorado school district has adopted a health policy that could bar students with H.I.V. infection or AIDS from playing school sports.

title: Clinton Accused of Trying to 'Destroy the Rights of a Fellow American Citizen'
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by Representative George W. Gekas, Republican of Pennsylvania, in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULHOF, RUDOLPH B.
description: SCHULHOF-Rudolph B. 1912-1999. After a short illness. Devoted husband of 60 years to Hannelore Buck, father of Michael, Ronald, Thomas, and Wendy. Devoted grandfather to Mark, Amy, Dean, David, Jonathan, Lauren, Scott, Todd, Toni, and Ronnie. Born Czechoslovakia, May 13, 1912. Czech Davis Cup tennis player, graduated from Charles University, Prague, moved to New York in 1940 creating Reproducta Company as a major force in the greeting card and publishing industry. Well known patron of the arts, business publisher, founding director of the Israel Museum, Jerusalem; Trustee, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum New York; Trustee, Peggy Guggenheim Foundation, Venice. Survived by his wife, children, grandchildren, and brother, Joseph. Funeral service at Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, on Sunday, January 17, at 10:00 AM.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be observed.

title: Tapestries' Strange Journey: Vatican to Airport to Brooklyn Basement
description: Francisco DiSanto, it seems, figured nobody else would really appreciate the delicate beauty of the tapestries in the Alitalia Airlines first-class lounge at Kennedy International Airport. The silk hangings, after all, were very old and even a little spotted.

title: Garden Auction Is Slap at Civility; A Bargain
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rudy Giuliani Wars; Vengeance in Brooklyn
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is still so angry at the New York City Council member Stephen DiBrienza that he seems willing to dislocate any handy group to embarrass him. In the latest round of a dispiriting political vendetta, the Mayor wants to evict a senior citizens' center and child-care facility in the Brooklyn Councilman's district -- and replace them with a homeless shelter. The Mayor cannot be accused of playing to the voters, since most politicians would walk a mile to avoid offending senior citizens. But displacing established community services simply to punish an adversary is still a terrible policy.

title: ABC Ends Lockout Of 2,200 Workers As Latest Offer Is Put Up for a Vote
description: ABC ended its 74-day lockout of 2,200 behind-the-scenes workers in five cities yesterday as the workers' union agreed to send the network's latest contract offer to its members for a vote, even though many of them were dissatisfied with it.

title: Still in Thrall to the Boss and His Sound
description: Duke Ellington, as recalled by his former musicians, might have been the most seductive employer in the history of popular music. On Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall, 17 Ellingtonians were assembled for a 90-minute round-table discussion for the first session of Jazz at Lincoln Center's extensive Ellington programs in the composer's centennial year. They slowly warmed up and wound up, talking about the beneficent power Ellington had over their craft, how it was not so much them or even the music but Ellington himself that made them come into their own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINSHAW, JOHN ''JACK''
description: HINSHAW-John ''Jack'', 71, of Stonington, CT, formerly of Bronxville, NY; husband of Natalie (Jones) Hinshaw and the late Kathlyne (Viele) Hinshaw. Memorial service at Calvary Church, Stonington, CT on Friday, January 22nd. For information Dinoto Funeral Home, Mystic, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOUT, ELIZABETH SPRAGUE
description: STOUT-Elizabeth Sprague. (Simonds), 92, of Hobe Sound, FL., and Prouts Neck, ME., died on January 11, 1999. Devoted wife of the late A. Varick Stout, loving mother of Elizabeth Simonds Maynard, of Chestnut Hill, MA., Daniel Simonds of Wellesley, MA., Charles Sprague Simonds, Key West, FL., and Holly S. Callery, Tequesta, FL., loving grandmother of fourteen & great grandmother of nineteen. A memorial service will be held in the summer at Prouts Neck, Maine. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to St. James Episcopal Church, Prouts Neck, C/O Robert Shepherd, 13 Federal Street, Brunswick, Maine 04011 or Prouts Neck Audubon Society, P.O. Box 3034, Scarborough, Maine 04070. SUNDHEIMER-Howard. Of White Plains, died Janaury 15, 1999. He was 87. He was born September 28, 1911 in the Bronx to Hugo and Clarice Obermeier Sundheimer. Loving husband to Beatrice, father of Steven & his wife Stephanie, grandfather to Bradley, Todd and his wife Jennifer. Also survived by a brother Charles and a sister Ruth Steinbrink. A brother Robert pre-deceased. A funeral service will be on Sunday 10 AM at Mount Pleasant Cemetery in Valhalla. For information Zion Memorial Chapel (914) 381-1809.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMPSEY, DAVID KNAPP
description: DEMPSEY-David Knapp. Of Rye, New York. Died January 13, 1999. He was the husband of the late Evangeline Dempsey, and father of Ian Dempsey, of New York City, the late David Kevin Dempsey, and Karen Dempsey McKelvey. Memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: The Rye Free Reading Room.

title: MONTGOMERY WARD PLANS TO CLOSE 56 STORES
description: The Montgomery Ward Holding Corporation said yesterday that it would shut 39 Ward stores and 17 Auto Express stores and dismiss about 4,000 workers as part of a revamping aimed at making it profitable. The closings will leave the closely held retailer -- the No. 7 department store company in the United States -- with 252 stores. Montgomery Ward, which has been operating under bankruptcy court protection since July 1997, has focused on attracting more female shoppers with remodeled stores stocked with updated clothing styles and home furnishings. The company did not say how much the closings, subject to bankruptcy court approval, would cost.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL MILLS INC., Minneapolis, the maker of packaged consumer foods, acquired Lloyd's Food Products, a maker of ready-to-heat barbecued meats based in St. Paul with annual sales of $90 million. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS 2.3 PERCENT. Prices dropped on expectations that Brazil's currency devaluation means coffee exporters there will ship more beans, increasing the supply. The March contract fell 2.8 cents, to $1.155 a pound.

title: Giuliani's Trash-for-Culture Deal Doesn't Play in Virginia
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is a man of many talents, but silver-tongued diplomacy has never been one of them. His recent remarks that other states should accept New York City's trash as a fair price for enjoying its cultural bounty drew a chilly response yesterday from Virginia.

title: Exchange Controls Lifted; Brazil Stocks Rise by 33%
description: The Brazilian Government, reeling under a hemorrhage of dollars from its foreign reserves in a losing battle to defend the nation's currency, lifted exchange-rate controls today and allowed the currency to trade at market value.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SPAR, HERBERT MARTIN
description: SPAR-Herbert Martin. May 15, 1941-January 16, 1976. You have left a lasting void in our hearts and lives. Oh, how we miss your joie de vivre, your strength, your spirit, your ''sechel'' which was like no other. All our lives would have been beautifully enhanced if you were with us. Our comfort is knowing you are resting peacefully with Mommy. Your loving famil

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, DONALD J.
description: RYAN-Donald J. Of East Williston, Long Island on January 15, 1999. Beloved husband of AliceMay (nee Plauche). Devoted father of J. Christopher (Kit), Donnita Ryan Whittier, Mark Plauche, Marisa Ryan Pankow and Alison Ryan-Landon. Loving grandfather of eight. Dear brother of Dolores Kraus. Visitation on Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Weigand Bros. Funeral Home, 49 Hillside Avenue, Williston Park, NY. Funeral Mass Monday 10 AM at St. Aidan's R.C. Church. Interment to follow at Calverton National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Ignatius Retreat House, Searingtown Road, Manhasset, New York 11030.

title: Delta Weighs Labor Move
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. may begin contract talks early with its pilots. The union for 8,000 Delta pilots asked last week to begin contract talks six months earlier than scheduled. Delta's chief executive, Leo Mullin, said today that the airline might agree. Delta dropped a plans to link routes with United Airlines in September after the Delta pilots' union demanded that in exchange for approval it get voting rights for its seat on the company's board.

title: Amid Trial, Senate Republicans Strive for a Bit of Business as Usual
description: In an opinion poll conducted last month in 21 Congressional districts around the country that tend to swing between Republicans and Democrats, three-quarters of those questioned said they agreed with the proposition that ''instead of spending time on a lengthy impeachment trial, Congress and the President should focus on issues and legislation important to average families.''

title: Whitman Seeks to Restrict Spending on City's Airports
description: Responding to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposal to reclaim Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has suggested that the agency withhold billions of dollars that it has committed for improvements there over the next five years.

title: Man Arrested in Death Of Woman in Motel
description: A 19-year-old woman was stabbed to death early Thursday morning by a man who may have followed her back to her Seaside Heights motel room after a chance meeting in a nearby convenience store, county prosecutors said.

title: Naomi Mitchison Dies at 101; Author and Feminist Rebel
description: Naomi Mitchison, author of more than 70 books, bohemian free thinker and feminist long before the term was coined, died on Monday at her home on the Mull of Kintyre in Scotland. She was 101.

title: Arthur Fatt, 94, Advertising Co-Founder
description: Arthur C. Fatt, one of the founders of Grey Advertising and a former chief executive of the company, died on Tuesday at his winter home in Delray Beach, Fla. Mr. Fatt, whose main residence was in New York City, was 94 years old.

title: Rumblings From the Back Row
description: The conductor Kurt Masur found the coughing at a recent New York Philharmonic concert so obtrusive that he stopped the orchestra, walked off the podium and didn't return until things quieted down.

title: Mayor's Stadium Plan Is Grandly Vague, Experts Say
description: When it comes to sports, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has big dreams.

title: Big Donors Say G.O.P. Leaders Lack Direction
description: Many of the Republican Party's most influential financial backers have castigated the party's chairman and Congressional leadership at closed-door meetings here in the past few days, warning that they were sacrificing voters by failing to articulate a clear message while focusing on scandal and impeachment.

title: Corrections
description: A collage in the Health & Fitness pages on Jan. 5, illustrating an article about the stresses on a hospital resident, incorporated a part of a photograph without necessary credit. The complete picture, shown above, was part of a Life magazine essay called ''Country Doctor.'' The credit should have read, ''W. Eugene Smith/Black Star.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARTELS, EVA J. (STRAUSS)
description: WARTELS-Eva J. (Strauss). Beloved wife of the late Morty Strauss and the late Lester Wartels. Loving mother of Audrey Doniger, Nancy and Sidney Freedman. Most special grandmother to Jon and Daniel Doniger, Susan Pujalte and Nancy Turner, Michael, Jane and Paul Fishbin. Adored ''G.G.'' to eight greatgrandchildren. Longtime companion to the late Sam Sherward. Services Sunday, January 17, 1999, 12:30PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, ARNOLD
description: DAVIDSON-Arnold, on Januray 14, 1999. Beloved husband of Sherry, loving father of Elisa Szweda, father-in-law of Eric, adoring grandfather of Sarah, Elizabeth and Lila. Service, Sunday 1:30pm at ''The Riverside'', 76th St & Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in his memory to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRUPE, ISABELLE (NEE TUZIO)
description: CRUPE-Isabelle (nee Tuzio). Beloved wife of the late Santo. Devoted mother of Dorothy Tomasulo, William and Peter. Loving grandmother of Stephen, Anthony, Christine Ayers, William, Jr., and Elisabeth. Fond sister of Francis X. Reposing at the Ralph Aievoli & Son Funeral Home, 1275 65th Street (corner 13th Avenue), Brooklyn, on Saturday and Sunday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, 9:30 AM, Regina Pacis Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, IRVING
description: COHEN-Irving. On January 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Phyllis for 65 years. Loving father of Peter and Laurence. Adoring grandfather of Elissa, Joshua, Adam and Jonathan. Dear brother of Philip Baskir.

title: Global Warming: Not a Fantasy
description: To the Editor:

title: Party Lines Are Toughening Over the Calling of Witnesses
description: No matter how much senators say they want to avoid it, the partisan split over witnesses appears to be hardening each day that the House managers present their case against President Clinton, with a near party-line vote in favor of taking more testimony looking ever more likely.

title: An Abandoned Boy Finds Acceptance and Support
description: It would not take long to climb Roosevelt A.'s family tree. If Roosevelt, 14, is the trunk, then his little sisters, Kayla and Melissa, are the only branches.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Thursday, about the impact of Brazil's economic crisis on United States banks and brokerage firms, misstated Lehman Brothers' financial exposure in Brazil. It is $12 million ($100 million is the size of the firm's financial exposure in all of Latin America).

title: WISCONSIN TISSUE TO BUILD PLANT IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: The Chesapeake Corporation said yesterday that its Wisconsin Tissue unit planned to build a $180 million tissue mill in Halifax County, N.C., in a move to expand into the Southeast market.
