The Richmond-based paper products company said it expected to begin production at the new site in the fall of 2000. The plant will create 150 jobs within the first two years of operation. The mill will have technology to recycle and remove ink, plus high-speed converting equipment and a distribution system for Wisconsin Tissue's away-from-home tissue products.

title: Sports of The Times; A New Day But the Same Old Page
description: THE first things that catch your eye are the brightly colored collector toy trucks, relics of the early 1950's, symbols of toys he couldn't afford.

title: An A Train Serenade Ellington Could Like; Zoning Tall Buildings
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUGATCH, MARCY
description: PUGATCH-Marcy. We mourn the loss of our dear lifelong friend. We will miss you. Arline and George

title: Dream for a Choreographer's Little Girl
description: It is hard to imagine anyone but H. T. Chen creating ''Moon,'' the centerpiece of the program presented by H. T. Chen and Dancers on Wednesday night in the Altogether Different series at the Joyce Theater. Trained in Eastern and Western dance and theater, Mr. Chen has successfully blended both influences in his choreography. But he has also followed his own lights, seeming almost unconsciously to resist the dictates of dance fashion.

description: EUROPE

title: In India, Religious Violence Can't Be Excused; Condemn Attacks

description: GREENSTEIN-Janice Glantz. May your journey be peaceful and bright. We miss you. Bob and the Family

Devoted grandfather to Mark, Amy, Dean, David, Jonathan, Lauren, Scott, Todd, Toni, and Ronnie. Born Czechoslovakia, May 13, 1912. Czech Davis Cup tennis player, graduated from Charles University, Prague, moved to New York in 1940 creating Reproducta Company as a major force in the greeting card and publishing industry. Well known patron of the arts, business publisher, founding director of the Israel Museum, Jerusalem; Trustee, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum New York; Trustee, Peggy Guggenheim Foundation, Venice. Survived by his wife, children, grandchildren, and brother, Joseph. Funeral service at Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, on Sunday, January 17, at 10:00 AM.

title: Help Working Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: New Bronx Houses Cross the $300,000 Threshold
description: AT this point I'm walking on pins and needles because we're buying something we've never seen,'' said Mohammed Harun. On the other hand, Mr. Harun and his wife, Moonina, will have the satisfaction of watching their house as it is built. Completion is scheduled for August.

title: Got-Milk Cereals Get Mixed Reviews
description: BREAKFAST has posed problems for some time now. First the milkman stopped coming around. Then bacon and eggs were deemed to be about as nutritious as bathtub gin. Butter, the reason for making toast, became almost illicit. Oatmeal, naturally, retained its virtue, proof that the secret to longevity is cardboard.

title: This Time He Really Means It
description: Charles P. (Buzz) McCormick Jr., chairman of McCormick & Company, has succeeded at many things in his 70 years, but retiring isn't one of them. He stepped down as chairman once and as chief executive twice, but just could not break away. Nevertheless, he is taking another crack at it, retiring officially on March 17. ''They don't need me anymore,'' he said cheerfully. He and his son Chris have chipped in on a 27-foot racing sloop, Wham Bam, that he'll dock near his new town house in Annapolis, Md. (For the round trip to their winter home in Florida, he and his wife, Jimi, will take his 45-foot motor boat, Miss Jimi.) ''I can't beat many people in golf,'' he said. ''Maybe I can beat some people in sailboat racing.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARSHAWSKY, NORMAN S.
description: WARSHAWSKY-Norman S. Beloved husband of Beatrice; devoted father of Laura, Bob and Harry; grandfather of Justin and Samara. Dear brother of Abe and Rubin. Loving son of the late Anna and Jacob. Services today, 12:30 PM, Schwartz Bros., Queens.

title: Stephanie Iverson, Colin Mathews
description: Stephanie Lynn Iverson and Colin Robert Mathews were married yesterday by the Rev. Randy Rentner in the Basilica of the Sacred Heart at the University of Notre Dame in Notre Dame, Ind.

title: Beyond Fiction
description: Truth

title: Linking Spano's Vow To President's Predicament
description: I read the headline on Jan. 3: ''Despite Spano's Boast of Promises Kept, Critics Say He Lacks Vision for the Future.'' Such a clever use of words and sly innuendo to diminish the integrity of keeping promises!

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: When Welfare Ends and Work Steps In
description: RHONDA McFADDEN rises before dawn, readies her children for school and, joining others in Yonkers who are on their way to work, walks with a sense of pride to the bus stop.

title: Intimate Encounters
description: Perhaps no one in our time has been able to capture the essence of an individual's character in the snap of a shutter with as much artistry as the French photographer Henri Cartier-Bresson. With a searching eye and an intuitive grasp of human psychology, he has roamed the world over the last seven decades, recording the faces of the unnamed and anonymous as well as some of the greatest artists of the century. In TETE A TETE: Portraits by Henri Cartier-Bresson (Bulfinch/Little, Brown, $65), he has selected some of the most haunting and memorable images of his prolific career. Here we see a portrait of a robed Matisse, looking like a pampered pasha; a young, distracted-looking Jean-Paul Sartre, pipe at his lips as he converses on the Pont des Arts in Paris; a pudgy-faced Jean Genet, dragging on a cigar with an expression of amused indulgence; and an aging Colette, flashing the camera a coquettish glance. Included too is a trove of photographs that are among his most legendary -- a stunning picture of Samuel Beckett looking more hawk than human, a classic shot of the melancholy Alberto Giacometti lost in thought and an electrifying picture of a hoary Ezra Pound, his brow furrowed in barely suppressed fury. Marcel Duchamp shares the camera frame with one of his ready-mades, an expression of ironic detachment suffusing his face. A bare-chested Picasso stands beside a tousled bed, unabashed in his frank physicality. ''In whatever picture-story we try to do, we are bound to arrive as intruders,'' Cartier-Bresson once wrote. Yet his great gift is to take us inside the intimate encounter without creating a feeling that we have trespassed. Andrea Barnet

title: New Jersey Already Has A Statwide Network
description: To the Editor:

title: Bottom Creams, Top Prices
description: Kate Spade and Prada turned the diaper bag into a $300 knapsack from a $20 tote. Now, diaper ointments are undergoing similar style and price inflation. Last month, Bubbe's Best, started by three mothers in Garrison, N.Y., came out with Special Cream for Special Tushies, touted to be made of the ''purest, finest'' ingredients. At $12.50 for three ounces (Zitomer, 969 Madison Avenue at 76th Street) compared with about $3.50 for a four-ounce tube of an old standard like Desitin, it had better be. This month, Burt's Bees introduces Baby Bee Diaper Ointment, a mere $7 for 1.75 ounces (800-849-7112). And Kiehl's, skin care's gold standard, offers a Soothing Diaper-Area Ointment at a platinum price of $18.95 for two ounces (at its store, Third Avenue and 13th Street). This spring, Origins will offer Diaper Service, $10 for a 3-ounce tube, and Bobbi Brown is starting a Baby Essentials line with a Diaper Balm, $14.50 for 2.5 ounces.

title: In 'Far East,' a WASP Tries to Flee the Nest
description: THE cover of the program for ''Far East,'' A. R. Gurney's dark comedy now at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center, promises something on the order of ''Madama Butterfly'': a United States Navy officer in his dress whites stands against what looks to be an antique Japanese print of a geisha.

title: An Antarctic Opera, With Penguins as Stars
description: On a cruelly cold Antarctic evening, the albatross floats in like a jetliner for a soft landing. The king penguin, once compared by an Antarctic explorer to a portly gentleman late for dinner, waddles up from the sea to nest. The elephant seal rules the beach, whiskers whipped by 100-mile-an-hour winds.

title: The Mouse Checks In, But Not Out
description: ''MICE are the No. 1 infestation problem in the city today,'' said Michael Deutsch, an entomologist with Allied/Pioneer Pest Management Companies in Manhattan. ''We have a pretty good handle on roaches. But the rodent population has been steadily increasing. I would say that most buildings in the city today have some level of infestation.''

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mazda Protege; A Sedan That Sips Gas In an Age of Big Gulps
description: THE radio headline grabbed my attention: ''Gas prices drop to the lowest level in history.'' While analysts on the newscast pondered whether gas could become even cheaper, I had to wonder if small cars, like the 1999 Mazda Protege I was driving at the moment, were on their way to becoming irrelevant.

title: Dreaming the Impossible Dream
description: In 1999, things will be different: You will carry out your New Year's resolution to advance your career or resolve a workplace conflict. Well, maybe. But what about past years? How close did you come to meeting a work-related goal that you set for yourself in January? Or, how did your efforts go awry?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKOVITS, ALEXANDER
description: MOSKOVITS-Alexander. National Jewish Outreach Program mourns the passing of Alexander Moskovits, beloved brother of Anne Lehmann. Mrs. Lehmann and her husband the late Manfred Lehmann, together with their children, Karen Lehmann-Eisner and David Eisner, have played a crucial role in NJOP's efforts to assure a Jewish future for American Jewry through their generous support and wise counsel. Karen and David have served with distinction as Chairs of NJOP's Annual Dinners since its inception. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Ephraim Buchwald, Director

title: A Visionary's Dream Fulfilled, Now as Memorial
description: GIVE a determined evolution a little time, and it can look like a revolution. ''She completely transformed the institution,'' the once revolutionary composer and conductor Pierre Boulez said last week of Judith Arron, who was no one's idea of a revolutionary, and her achievement at Carnegie Hall.

title: Between News and Music, a Place for Wordplay
description: 1. Is the definition of the word ''crawk'' (a) the distaff or downward-turning crook in a guard's spear, signifying fealty to the king; (b) the fleshy red dewlap of a male turkey's nether lip; or (c) a sound-effects technician who specializes in imitating animals?

title: Habitats / West 63d Street; Furnishing a Home As a Scavenger Hunt
description: FURNISHING a place in New York City is not like furnishing a place in the suburbs. People don't zip over to the nearest megastore and load up their oversized vehicles with rugs, tables and chairs. Nor do they spend summer weekends cruising by yard sales in search of wicker chairs and mixing bowls. Like everything else, matters here are more complicated. And often more expensive. When a tiny table at a chic little joint on Bond Street is $600, the cost of living seems unfairly high. In the presence of so many objects costing so much, it is easy to feel impoverished, even on incomes that would be considered ample anyplace else.

title: Churches and Charter Schools
description: The slapdash process in Albany that created the state's new charter-school law without any public input was a disgrace. It is no wonder that the legislation raises difficult, unresolved issues. In theory, charter schools can offer families more choice and encourage educational innovation. But they must be created without unfairly draining resources from the public system that will continue to educate the vast majority of students and without funneling public money into religious education.

title: Hollywood Roulette
description: Pick any industry and you find the earmark of successful leadership tied to the bottom line: profits equal performance. Any industry except Hollywood, that is, where money isn't made the usual way. Studio chiefs gamble billions on huge hits (and huger flops), but even box-office windfalls rarely translate into profits once the production costs are factored. In a business that lacks a clear, logical way of tallying wins and losses, executives have been judged not by their financial track records but by an ever-shifting, loosely defined set of intangibles -- taste, instinct, connections, a talent for schmooze, show-biz knowledge. The winning formula has always been tossed off as 90 percent luck, 10 percent good luck, but after a recent bit of studio housecleaning, it looks as if that luck may be changing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAEL, DONALD J.
description: MICHAEL-Donald J. 60, died Friday at home. Veteran of the U.S. Army. Served as a member of the Avenel Colonia First Aid's Squad; member of The New York Times Bowling League; a coach for Woodbridge Little League. He was employed as a Pressman for The New York Times the past 34 years, most recently at their Edison facility. He is survived by his wife of 32 years, Lucy (White), a son, Kevin Michael of Avenel and daughter, Joy. Funeral will take place Tuesday, 8:45 AM at Greiner-Costello Funeral Home, Green St. and Barron Ave., Woodbridge, followed at 9:30 AM with a funeral liturgy at St. Andrew's R.C. Church, North Madison Ave., Avenel, NJ. Entombment will be at Good Shepherd Mausoleum, St. Gertrude Cemetery, Colonia, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to the Haven Hospice, at J.F.K. Medical Center, 65 Jane St., Edison, NJ 08820.

title: U.S. Weighs Its Reaction To Massacre In Kosovo
description: After increased military buildups and violence by the warring sides in Kosovo in the last three weeks, the Clinton Administration struggled today to explain how it would react to the execution-style massacre of 45 ethnic Albanians by Serbian forces under the control of the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic.

title: On College Degrees For Police Officers
description: Regarding the proposal that future Suffolk County police officers be college graduates, Prof. William F. Powers of Suffolk County Community College disagrees (''Police Education Standards: Let's Not Go Overboard,'' Jan. 10). I think differently.

title: Shake an Egg
description: Egg shakers palm-size plastic or wooden percussion instruments filled with tiny metal beads -- came on the recording studio scene years ago for use in Latin music. But recently, they have become a hit with little groovers and shakers, too. ''The egg creates a total sensory experience,'' said Pat Conte, the purchasing manager of Kindermusik, a music organization that uses them in its classes. ''It has a tickling effect.'' Wee musicians get very attached to them. ''You can't pry them out of their hands,'' Ms. Conte said. The school sells about 35,000 plastic eggs each year (800-628-5687). The eggs, which cost about $3 apiece, are also available in music stores like Sam Ash and at Tah Poozie, 50 Greenwich Avenue (Charles Street). JOANNA BOBER

title: Another Look Urged At Charter Schools
description: For years, the Putnam/Northern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services Board of Education has joined with boards throughout the state in advocating for meaningful reforms that would give us the true authority we need to further improve student achievement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, GEORGE EDMOND II
description: HILL-George Edmond II. Died peacefully with his daughter beside him on December 18, 1998 in Falls Church, VA. Born on June 22, 1921 in Middletown, Connecticut, he was the only child of G. Albert and Katherine Hill. He attended Wesleyan University and graduated with honors in 1943. From 1947 to 1961 he worked for the United Nations, World Health Organization in New York and Geneva, Switzerland. In New York he worked on a special committee, The WHO-IC, as a liaison. He attended the UN General Assembly, The Economic and Social Council, The Trusteeship Council, and the governing bodies of: UNICEF, UNESCO, The International Bank and The Monetary Fund. In Geneva, Switzerland he handled two regions, ''The Americas'' and ''The Pacific''. He worked on expanded programs of technical assistance. In his second placement he handled the conditions and salaries of 4,500 employees world-wide and participated in the drafting and implementation of a singleself financed health plan. Following his career at WHO, he became a stockbroker. As a stockbroker he worked for Haight & Company before joining Johnston, Lemon & Company in 1970. Mr. Hill retired from Johnston, Lemon & Company at 72 as Vice President of investments. A ''Truman-like'' character, he was a man of simple tastes, definite ideas and old world formality. A member of The Civil War Roundtable, The National Alpha Chi Rho Fraternity, Wesleyan Alumni Association, and The Grande Loge Nationale Francaise. He loved history, the military, brass marching bands and steam locomotives. He is survived by his daughter, Kay Hill of New York City, NY. He was loved and he will be dearly missed. Services to be held January 23, 1999 at 2:00 P.M., at the First Church of Christ Congregational, Middletown, Conn. The Interment will be private.

title: Kristin Knapp, David Towers
description: Kristin Elizabeth Knapp, a daughter of Kathleen and Robert Knapp of Laurel, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Brent Towers, the son of Dixie R. Towers of Long Beach, Calif., and Joseph A. Towers of New Orleans. The Rev. Michael Torpey performed the ceremony at St. Peter of Alcantara Roman Catholic Church in Port Washington, N.Y.

title: Tests Are Over and Students Are Relieved
description: JONATHAN HOCH gave up playing his Game Boy for a few days. Carissa Scarola went to bed early. Reema Maracheril stayed up late cramming with her older brother's books.

title: Earplugs Right at Hand? Falcons in the Metrodome
description: Minutes before the Vikings began to demolish Arizona in their divisional playoff last Sunday, Cardinals guard Lomas Brown was talking to a teammate a foot away. Soon, Brown realized he was screaming at the top of his lungs and his friend could barely hear him. And this was before the game started.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAGOPOULOS, DIMITRI
description: TAGOPOULOS-Dimitri. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Dimitri Tagopoulos, associated with The Times from 1967 until retiring in 1989.

title: ART / ARCHITECTURE; Spaces for Worship, Places for Community
description: ADOZEN laughing children hurtled across the plush, beige wall-to-wall carpeting of the spacious room on the second floor of the Islamic Center of New Jersey, playing a lively, shoeless game of catch. Earlier, just before sunset and a festive meal to break that day's Ramadan fast, the room had become, for about 10 minutes, a holy place. Some 50 men of many races had lined up shoulder to shoulder along the faint white lines painted onto the carpet, accompanied in prayer by a few women in the balustraded gallery high overhead, while downstairs other women put aside kitchen duties. Tomorrow, they will join the thousands of worshipers expected to show up at a nearby convention center in Somerset for the Eid, a festival marking the end of Ramadan.

title: January 10-16; And Congress Plays the Windmill
description: ''Facts are the enemy of truth,'' says poor, pure-hearted Don Quixote in ''Man of La Mancha,'' the musical based on Cervantes's classic novel.

title: Huskies Turn Rematch Into a Mismatch
description: This time, there was no cause for dramatics, no need to score 5 points in the final 10 seconds, almost no point in watching the second half at all.

title: Modern Minstrel, Once Wrapped in Mystery
description: JUST 40 years ago, rumor in the West ran hot about a Russian pianist named Sviatoslav Richter.

title: No Sympathy, Just Cold Comfort
description: STAND quietly in the middle of the mall or the supermarket and just listen. The sounds of the plague are all around you: coughing and sneezing, sniffing and blowing. We are at the height of the winter cold season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ITO, CHEREL WINETT
description: ITO-Cherel Winett. Born on May 5th, 1947, photographer and filmmaker, died January 10, 1999. Ms. Ito was the widow of musician Teiji Ito, with whom she sometimes performed and with whom she made the widely shown documentary film about Haitian Voudoun, ''Divine Horsemen'', utilizing the footage and music recorded in Haiti by Maya Deren in 1947 to 1955. An accomplished film editor, Cherel Ito will perhaps best be remembered for her black and white still photographs. Startling in their beauty, these works reveal her natural instinct for stylized composition and her deep sensitivity to the human condition. Cherel Ito is survived by her mother, Mimi Feldman, her stepdaughter, Tavia Ito, and her three brothers, Dr. Gary Stolzoff, Jeffrey and Bob Winett. The estate of Maya Deren, which Ms. Ito administered, has been conveyed to Daren scholar Catrina Neiman, New York City. The important Daren collection of Haitian ritual objects and art which Ito cared for has been donated to The Museum of Natural History's African American collection, New York City. The memorial service will be held Monday evening, January 18, 1999 at 7:00 PM at 814 Broadway, third floor. Donations in the name of Cherel Ito can be made to Gilda's Club, 195 West Houston Street, New York, New York 10014.

title: Lawmaker Evokes Own Childhood in Segregated South in Case Vs. Clinton
description: Like the other Republican Congressmen appointed to prosecute President Clinton, Lindsey Graham of South Carolina went before the Senate today as a lawyer, entwining evidence and precedents to argue for the President's expulsion from office.

title: For Retired Firefighter, A Fire Still Burns
description: Donald Van Holt retired from Company 108 of the New York City Fire Department in 1983, when he was injured in the line of duty. His yearning for the old life led him on line about three years ago, but the department had not yet established an official Web site. So Mr. Van Holt decided to create his own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKSTEIN, ANNE
description: DICKSTEIN-Anne. At home in NYC in her 87th year. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Devoted mother of Morris (Lore) Dickstein and Doris (Sam) Feinberg. Loving grandmother of Jeremy (Jill) and Rachel Dickstein, Jennifer and Joshua Feinberg. May her memory be a blessing.

title: Natural Heritage Aid
description: Gov. George E. Pataki recently announced that nearly $5 million in state grants have been awarded for conservation, education and nature programs statewide.

title: In Closing, the Words of a Child
description: Following is the text of a letter from a third-grade student in Chicago that was read by Representative Henry J. Hyde today in his closing remarks at the Senate impeachment trial. Mr. Hyde's remarks were recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.

title: Neighbors' Helper Seems to Get Little Reward
description: To the Editor:

title: Orders in The Court
description: Jury duty, rarely anyone's idea of a good time, kills whole days and doesn't pay much -- except at a place called the Evidence Store in Union. The store, which sells and rents plastic skeletons, anatomical charts and other goods to help laywers present their cases, moved to new quarters last summer from Stuyvesant Avenue, also in Union, and put in a ''courtroom'' where lawyers can try out their cases. For these mock trials, the store even provides a jury.

title: Preparing to Hang a Large Mirror
description: HANGING large mirrors can be a problem because they are heavy, difficult to maneuver and require adequate wall support.

title: Roberta Walter and Lenn Goodman
description: Roberta Louise Walter and Dr. Lenn Evan Goodman are to be married this afternoon in Nashville. Rabbi Zalman I. Posner is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Sherith Israel.

title: Cousin Expected to Testify on Claim Rapper Shot at Police
description: Law enforcement officials and a lawyer for the rapper Russell Jones, who was arrested in Brooklyn Friday on charges of shooting at police officers, are giving differing accounts over whether Mr. Jones's cousin will testify in the case.

title: In 1998, It Was Safer To Stay in the Car
description: The roads were safer for drivers in New Jersey last year, but deadlier for pedestrians.

title: A Stage Re-emerges With One Clear Voice
description: DON'T talk to Nancy Giles about the black experience. ''I'm black, and I've had experience,'' she says. ''The black experience should encompass all experiences by all black people. All the generalizations about what is authentic -- ethnic, gender or racial-specific -- are garbage.''

title: Perennial Friends, Come Rain or Come Shine
description: LAST year, a group of perennials in my central New Jersey garden were just great. They sailed through the extremely wet spring months with perfect aplomb. And then, with the advent of one of the driest summers and falls in a century, they continued to delight as I walked by or stopped to give them, at most, a weekly watering. They are plants that look good, no matter what.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, SIDNEY
description: GREENBERG-Sidney. The members of Sheltor Rock Tennis Club record with great sorrow the passing of our charter member Sidney Greenberg. He was a friend to all and will be sorely missed. Our sincere condolences to Judy and the family. Joel Jacobson, President

title: Music: Ellington Emerges, Falters and Triumphs; Reborn, And Going International
description: DUKE ELLINGTON liked to say he was born at the Newport Jazz Festival in July 1956. The 57-year-old Ellington was kidding, of course. What he meant was that his orchestra, after a dry spell, had been such a hit at the festival that things were never the same again. Though it may surprise those diehards who say the band had collapsed after 1941, the truth is that had Ellington produced only the records from 1956 to when he died in 1974, he would still be one of the greatest composers of the American century.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDWOOD; Chess Is This Teen-Ager's Life (Except for a Certain Boy)
description: Fifteen-year-old Irina Krush has little time for teen-age trivialities.

title: The Constitutional Test
description: On Saturday, the House impeachment managers shifted their arguments from the facts of President Clinton's misdeeds to the central question of whether, based on those facts, there is a constitutional basis for removing him from office. The key assumption of their constitutional theory is that perjury and obstruction, while not named in the Constitution, are so serious that they are tantamount to the offenses that are specifically named, those being ''treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors.'' In their most polished presentations to date, the prosecutors also argued that the Senate has a duty to remove Mr. Clinton for his ''pernicious example of lawlessness'' that, if unpunished, would undermine the courts and harm the Presidency for years to come.

title: Backup Gets Attention
description: With Jayson Williams's seven-year, $100 million contract all but signed and sealed, the Nets have turned their attention to their other significant free agent, point guard Sherman Douglas. Coach John Calipari speaks glowingly of Douglas, as if he were sensational instead of just solid, and calls his presence on the Nets essential.

title: Liberties; Soft-Porn Nation
description: By the time we got to Bob Barr, I had become a desperate woman. I felt trapped, panicky, short of breath.

title: Sit Down. No, Stand Up. Have We Got News for You.
description: IT'S enough to get someone struggling to lose those all-important 20 pounds lathered up into a frenzy, but come to think of it, a frenzy may be just what the doctor ordered. Old-fashioned fidgeting -- tapping your pencil against a conference table in a make-or-break meeting, jiggling your leg while gabbing on the telephone, pacing back and forth until you wear a hole in the carpet behind your desk -- may emerge as a new weight-control strategy.

title: Look at Grounds To Impeach First; Facts Are Known
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Talk Can Mix With Italian Food
description: IN Fairfield, the restaurant called Mulino's of Connecticut is not simply a neighborhood spaghetti joint, but rather a sedate place featuring northern Italian cuisine.

title: Beyond Reality
description: To the Editor: In Nepal in November 1997, we too experienced a mirage ''so breathtaking as to seem beyond reality'' (''In the Eyes of the Beholder,'' by Martha Weinman Lear, Nov. 1). We are in our middle 70's, well traveled and in love with mountains. We were determined to see the Himalayas up close.

title: Independent Bookstores Harvest Their Zeal
description: A PASSION for books drives the dedicated group of men and women who own and operate independent bookstores.

title: Restless
description: What's Sean Penn angry about now? Maybe he somehow found out that my reaction was, Who cares?

title: Clinton Is Focusing On State Of Union
description: President Clinton today kept a studied distance from his impeachment trial in the Senate, focusing not on the charges laid out against him by Republican prosecutors, aides said, but on the next big event on his political calendar: the State of the Union speech on Tuesday.

title: What's Undeniable
description: To the Editor:

title: Whatever Happened to the Class of 1994?
description: Four years ago this month, an angry band of Republican tyros lit a fuse beneath the body politic. The 73 members of the class of '94, who as Newt Gingrich's foot soldiers brought their party to power in the House of Representatives for the first time in four decades, vowed to reduce Big Government to rubble. They would blast away at taxes and spending, removing entire chunks of the Government -- including the Commerce and Education Departments. They would rattle the Constitution with a series of amendments on flag burning, term limits, balanced budgets and school prayer. In their spare time, they would rewrite environmental laws and overhaul the entitlement system and tax code, all while transferring power from Washington to the states.

title: Brazilian, in I.M.F. Talks, May Ask for Early Aid
description: Brazil's Finance Minister began talks here today with the International Monetary Fund and said he might ask for early release of the next round of international assistance to the country to help stabilize its economy.

title: Children's Books
description: SNOWFLAKE BENTLEY

title: The Man Who Tracked Down Chekhov
description: THE translator, Peter Constantine, traced a pale finger across a page written in Cyrillic. His slender body was bent over some copies of an 1880's Moscow magazine called Budilnik, bound in maroon with a bookplate of Czar Alexander III. Mr. Constantine was in the Slavic and Baltic division of the New York Public Library, where three years ago he stumbled on little-known early works by Anton Chekhov in old magazines.

title: Cunningham Climbs Back to the Top
description: Randall Cunningham is talking about the power of God in his life, about the peacefulness he feels and about the beauty of humility. The setting could be a pulpit instead of the Minnesota Vikings' weight room. He is speaking so softly that 20 reporters lean closer to hear him. It is obviously worth hearing.

title: Paris Grand Prix
description: To the Editor: On a trip in October 1997 I was walking across an empty street in Avignon when I was struck by a driver who knocked me 15 feet into the air and 40 feet down the road. She stopped her car close to where I lay near dead. She told the gendarmes who arrived that she was driving a company car and it had no brakes so she didn't feel responsible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TENENBAUM, HERMAN
description: TENENBAUM-Herman. Died in Miami, FL, on January 16, 1999. He is the beloved brother of Sol, brother-in-law of Alisa, uncle of Joseph, Faith, Avner, Hannah, Tsippy, and Yaki. Born in Kobryn, Poland, he remained a lifelong supporter of Zionism and the State of Israel. Gifts in his memory may be sent to: Division of Oncology, Department of Medicine, Columbia University College of P. and S., 630 West 168 St., NY, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, CLAIRE S.
description: RUBIN-Claire S. On January 14, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Devoted mother of Laurie, Mitchell and David. Dear sister of Anne Kolasky and Lee Wall. Cherished grandmother of Sarah and Matthew. Services Sunday, 10 AM, at ''Gutterman's Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, LI. Donations can be made to the American Diabetes Association in her memory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGAN, MIRIAM
description: MORGAN-Miriam (Dodge). Age 87, in Newburyport, MA, on January 10. Abstract expressionist painter and resident of Newburyport, MA. Former 30 year resident of Manhattan, NY. Widower of Herbert A. Morgan. Mother of Abigail M. Lawton, Portland, OR, and Adelaide M. Carothers, Englewood, NJ. Grandmother of five, great-grandmother of two. Memorial service Saturday, January 23, at Unitarian Church, 26 Pleasant St., Newburyport, MA. Private burial will be in Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY, on Wednesday, January 20.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: DARKNESS FALLSBy John M. Del Vecchio.St. Martin's, $24.95.

title: Introduction
description: For a celebrity profile, Lynn Hirschberg's road trip with Sean Penn drew a surprising bagful of mail. The actor's fans and critics alike said they'd jump at the chance to go along for the ride. Readers were touched by Patti Davis's Christmas gift to her father, Ronald Reagan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, ENID
description: RESNICK-Enid. Peacefully on January 9. Beloved wife of Samuel, loving mother of Robin Amodio of Westport, N.Y. At her request there has been no service.

title: Postings: La Salle Center in Oakdale to Be Sold; St. John's to Buy School on L.I.
description: The impending purchase by St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens, of the 175-acre La Salle Center in Oakdale, L.I., where students attend kindergarten through high school, has significant implications for the two Catholic institutions that go beyond the planned property transfer.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: Merlot With Muscles

title: FUEL FOR THOUGHT
description: Playing chicken with cabbies and using sidewalks as express lanes just seems to require nothing more than a death wish. But if you're a bike messenger, business as usual also requires keeping your tank full. Which was the logic behind Wayne Scott's 16-year battle with Revenue Canada to win tax deductibility for the extra 1,300 calories of food he needed to ''maintain my playing weight and perform at optimal level.'' A Court of Appeal agreed, ruling that if car messengers can write off gas, so can. . . . Note well, New York comrades in spokes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARVIS, WILBUR
description: JARVIS-Wilbur, M.D. On January 8, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Vivian Jarvis. Father of Mady McSweeney and Kerry Nadel. Father-in-law of Eli Nadel. Grandfather of Jennifer, Daniel, Andrew and Rachel. Great grandfather of Kayla, Callie and John. Any donations in his memory should be made to Doctors Without Borders, 6 E. 39 St, 8th Flr, N.Y., N.Y. 10016.

title: Children's Books; Tune In Tomorrow
description: The great political caricaturist and magazine artist Edward Sorel has also illustrated children's books for years, and lately he has taken to writing them as well. His latest collaboration with himself, JOHNNY ON THE SPOT (Margaret K. McElderry, $16; ages 5 to 9), is an exciting yarn set in the old New York of radio serials, when gangsters toted machine guns in violin cases. Sorel's vivid and engaging illustrations include some big urban tableaus that capture the romance and innocence of the era. The plot is just as lively. When young Johnny's radio conks out during his favorite program, he takes it to Dr. Zaga, the mysterious and eccentric inventor (is there any other kind?) who lives downstairs. Dr. Zaga zaps it with ''a small charge of electrostatic magnetism,'' which causes the radio to broadcast not today's news but tomorrow's. This allows Sorel to present, in quick, deft strokes, some of the usual paradoxes and moral quandaries of time travel. Dr. Zaga tells Johnny that they must not interfere with the future, but he does not explain why, and in any event they do it anyhow, in various ways. At first Johnny merely takes pictures of a bank robbery and sells them to a newspaper, but soon he is rescuing a girl in a burning building and hanging out at the race track, placing bets. (''It's not gambling,'' Dr. Zaga explains to a reluctant Johnny. ''We know which horses will win.'')

title: Their Business Bible Is, Well, the Bible
description: Once a month, 15 heavy hitters of business -- including the chief executive of a drug company and a public relations bigwig -- meet in the Manhattan office of Howard Milstein, the real estate developer, banker and co-owner of the New York Islanders, to discuss the Torah, with a dash of ancient rabbinical commentaries thrown in.

title: Books and Authors With Roots on the Island; Lending a Guiding Hand By Her Children's Books
description: JOHANNA HURWITZ always knew she was destined to write. At 10, she said, she already had made the decision to become an author and was weaving yarns for her younger brother, William, who preferred them to library books.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULNER, HANNA F.
description: SULNER-Hanna F. 81. internationally renowned Forensic Document Examiner, passed away peacefully in her home on January 5, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Laszlo, she is survived by her son Andrew, daughter-in-law Agnes, and cherished grandson Laurence. She will be sorely missed by family and friends. Services private.

title: In Preschool Classes, Who Are the Teachers And What Is Taught?
description: On Wednesday, in a small building on Elm Street, children's voices bounced off the walls and sailed through the hallways in a happy, chaotic symphony.

title: Charter Schools Must Be Given Their Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: More of the Same for Snowy Buffalo
description: After two days of storms dropped more than a foot of snow across New York State, stranding travelers, knocking out power and causing roofs to collapse, the weather settled into relative calm yesterday.

title: A Center to Help Hispanic Catholics Take a Role in Church Affairs
description: Hispanic immigrants in North Jersey towns are active at all levels of the political bureaucracy, right up to mayor. But Catholic officials acknowledge that the area lacks the same level of involvement by Hispanic members of local parishes in church and archdiocese activities and jobs.

title: Everybody Needs Him; Not Everybody Likes Him
description: PRODUCERS are not going to tell you what they really think of George P. Lane: that they dislike him, that they believe he is too demanding, that they dread his phone calls. That's because Mr. Lane represents just about every hot young playwright and director in the theater business these days, not to mention a crop of blue-chip actors. So producers need him. They basically can't live without him.

title: Appearances; Editors In Chic
description: The best place to observe them is at a fashion show -- the public arena that is their natural habitat. See how they enter not on time, which is too soon, nor at the last minute, when lights are going down and opportunists are crowding in, but just at the proper moment to greet a few who matter and settle into their choice seats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAISE, IDA HELEN
description: CHAISE-Ida Helen. January 15, 1999. Wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Ruth (Monte) Zimmerman, Largo, FL; and Jeffry, Bayside, NY. Sister of Harold (Ruth) Neiman. Sister-in-law of Anne Brandstein, Sarah Neiman, Sandy (Alaine) Chaise, George (Ruth) Chaise. Adored by nieces & nephews. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Interment in Florida.

title: Shopping, Exit by Exit by Exit
description: LINDA HABIB'S obsession began innocently enough one day in the spring of 1997 while she was driving down Interstate-95 and discovered she had missed the exit for J. Crew in Westport.

title: Newcomers That Faltered May Find Their Legs in '99
description: EBAY, up 1,240 percent. Ubid, up 611 percent. Broadcast.com, up 325 percent. Call the roll of the red-hot Internet stocks that made their initial public offerings in 1998, and you might think it was a great year for I.P.O.'s over all.

description: An annual regatta on the warm, aquamarine seas off Key West, Fla., is a winter magnet for many of the most competitive sailboats in the United States. But this year, foreign teams, especially the Italians, are flocking to the regatta as never before.

description: Wireless communications vendors have learned that many first-time customers need a little help getting comfortable with new technology. In customer relations as in social relations, though, no icebreaker is foolproof.

title: BENEFITS
description: Wining and Dining

description: Many of my legislative colleagues and I were shocked to learn that one week after passing a county budget that featured nearly a 1 percent tax decrease, some of our communities were hit with a whopping tax increase ['Cortlandt Finds Rise in County Property Tax,'' Dec. 27]. This occurred because of equalization rates that were set by the New York State Office of Real Property Services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, ALBERT
description: HELLER-Albert. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Loving father of Phyllis and Howard Kaufman, Arleen and Irving Black, Marsha and Steven Groman. Loving grandfather of Robyn and Jeffrey Parket, Stacy and Jonathan Zauderer, Lori Kaufman, Melanie Black, Scott Black, Meredith Groman, Allison Groman. Loving great, grandfather of Alyssa, Ross, Mathew, Brett, Alex, Justin, and Adam. He stood above the rest. Loving and loved he will be a guiding presence throughout our lives.

title: Club Stages a Tournament To Promote Young Careers
description: The Marshall Chess Club's Winter International Tournament, held in its Greenwich Village townhouse from Dec. 12 to 22, was organized to give opportunities for young players to attain norms toward grandmaster and international master titles. No one did, but the club, undaunted, is considering expanding this new effort into a series.

title: The Likes Of Which We'll Never See Again
description: LIGHTS should have been dimmed on vanity tables everywhere and rattail combs flown at half-staff late last month in honor of Virginia Graham. When Miss Graham, the tart-tongued talk show pioneer, died at 86 on Dec. 22, she took her hairdo with her.

title: Odds and Ends
description: Former President George Bush told insurance executives at a conference at the Waldorf-Astoria last week that he was surprised to be invited because ''when you reach my age, it's pretty hard to even get an insurance company on the phone.'' . . . Richard Branson, the British business baron who ditched a hot-air balloon off Hawaii last month, retreated to the Caribbean for some yachting but overturned the craft and broke two ribs, The Financial Times reports.

title: What's Weighing on Buffett's Stock?
description: WARREN E. BUFFETT, the investment sage, has often said he welcomes market declines because they put some good-quality merchandise ''on sale,'' letting him shop for bargains.

title: The World; Brazil Topples Off the Verge
description: Tall and tanned and young and lovely

title: Statement by President's Lawyer
description: Following is an excerpt from the statement today by Gregory B. Craig, a lawyer for President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Hazardous Waste
description: In an effort to punish environmental polluters, a county judge has sentenced the owner of a furniture stripping business in New Rochelle to 200 hours of community service and 5 years probation for the unlawful disposal of hazardous waste.

title: Jacksonville
description: Thanks to moderate winters, golf is an all-season sport around Jacksonville, where some 50 private and public courses are busy year-round. Still, there is golf and there is golf. Coming up in the next several weeks are major professional tournaments that put that sport in the international spotlight. And one of them will take place at what may eventually become golf's version of Disney World.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Alliance Formed to Draw Money for Testing Drugs
description: Underscoring a new trend toward cooperation in the New York region's intensely competitive health industry, five major academic medical centers have quietly joined forces to pursue a larger share of the billions of dollars that drug companies now lavish on other parts of the country to test new products.

description: ROBERTS-Alan K. Beloved husband of Shirlee. Adoring and adored father of Melissa and Tom, and Jeffrey and Christine. Proud grandfather of Rebecca and Kira, and step-grandfather of Ryan and Andy. Loving brother-in-law of Gloria Schuman and Sylvia Green. Dear cousin of Rose Tieger. description: Standing at the edge of the boxing ring between sparring matches, Larry Stanton turned and shouted to Jamile Ross, 16, of Hempstead:

title: 'Bulgary' Is the Least of Ills Here in These 'Untied' States
description: Given the gravity of the occasion and everything on the line, an observer might reasonably expect an attention to detail that is, well, unimpeachable.

title: Roll Call of Some Favorites From the Past
description: SINCE the New Year is off to a good start and gardeners are in planning mode, this might be a good opportunity to talk about favorites, to review of gardens past and some of the plants that have earned the designation of special indeed.

title: Escape From Aqueduct
description: FOR New York horseplayers, January is the cruelest month. The excitement of the late-fall Breeders' Cup, horse racing's equivalent of the Super Bowl, has long since faded away, and the local action, such as it is, has moved to the dreary confines of Aqueduct. There, hard by John F. Kennedy Airport, shivering jockeys, stung by the icy wind off Jamaica Bay, thrash their blue-collar mounts across the frozen dirt, witnessed by sparse crowds made up of the desolate and the desperate.

title: A Conga Line From Rio to Cafe Wha
description: ON a doleful Monday night, so cold even the tourists were hibernating, a faint tropical beat cut through the wind in Greenwich Village. The rhythm led around a corner, down some stairs and smack into Carnaval in Rio.

title: The End of the Line; As the Swingline Factory in Queens Closes, Veteran Workers Wonder What's Next for Them
description: TO Sal Melendez, the Swingline stapler factory in Long Island City, Queens, has been, for the most part, like a benevolent parent. It has fed and clothed him for nearly 21 years. It has watched him mature from a shipping clerk with limited English to a supervisor shepherding the next generation of immigrants into the company. It even introduced him to his wife, Juana, an assembly-line worker he met in the company cafeteria.

title: Ideas & Trends; They're Sort of Like Mike
description: FOR some people, life without Michael Jordan is unthinkable. But although Jordan retired from the Chicago Bulls and the game of basketball last week, there's still a Michael Jordan of snowboarding. And a Michael Jordan of bull riding. Even a Michael Jordan of real-life bulls.

title: Colorblind Music
description: To the Editor:

title: Funky Fittings From the Far East
description: Enjoo Sohn, a 23-year-old designer, divides her time between her native Tokyo and the Lower East Side, where she and three other investors own Miks, a clothing store at 100 Stanton Street (between Ludlow and Orchard Streets). The store features Ms. Sohn's line of clothes as well as items she imports from Japan on her frequent visits. Previously, her wares were sold at several shops in Tokyo and in downtown Manhattan boutiques.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANKIN, LEONARD J.
description: HANKIN-Leonard J. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, January 19, at 5 PM.

title: Spitzer Has the Governor on Guard
description: Last month, Gov. George E. Pataki quietly switched lawyers defending him in a lawsuit. The change drew little notice, but it could be a sign of a tense relationship to come between him and New York's new Attorney General, Eliot L. Spitzer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMCHANDANI, ATMA
description: RAMCHANDANI-Atma. The family of Atma C. Ramchandani celebrates his life and deeply mourns his passing on January 10, 1999 at age 95. Beloved husband of the late Savitri and dear father of Sunny and Prem. Grandfather of Ariel and Talia. He will be long remembered for his contribution to the building of the Institute of Electrical and Telecommunication Engineers and the introduction of TV into India through his leadership at All India Radio. He lived a full life and he will be fondly remembered by all who knew him.

title: Look at Grounds To Impeach First; Smooth Transitions
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: The Frugal Traveler column on Jan. 3, about four days in London, misstated the name of the museum at which Picasso pottery was on view. It was the Royal Academy of Arts, not the Royal Museum of Arts.

title: Megan O'Hare, Mark Josephson
description: Megan Thomas O'Hare, a daughter of James J. O'Hare 3d of Hingham, Mass., and the late Karen Morris O'Hare, was married yesterday to Mark Barret Josephson, a son of Dixie Roberts Josephson and Dr. Barry Josephson of East Greenwich, R.I. Associate Justice Richard J. Israel of Rhode Island Superior Court officiated at the Milton-Hoosic Club in Milton, Mass.

title: If Ignorance Is Bliss, Why Are Stocks So Shaky?
description: LAST WEEK, the United States stock market looked a lot like the weather in New England, as described famously by Mark Twain: exceedingly changeable.

title: Bidding Wars
description: Want to lunch with George Soros? For $100,000 you can chew over money markets with the philanthropic financier. Rather discuss metaphors with Norman Mailer? A mere $2,800 will get you a seat at the writer's table. These are but two recent examples of who's up for grabs at the charity auctions that every school, foundation and nonprofit group in the business of good works seem to be staging. Where bidders once took out their checkbooks for a lock of celebrity hair or a handkerchief touched by a noted nose, they're now using their big bucks to buy ''an experience'' with ''a name,'' be it mogul or model, author or actress, pol or potentate. And as illustrated by Soros and Mailer, the index on fame can really fluctuate. As a rule, circumspection speaks when you talk to organizers of such benefits, whether out of true noblesse oblige or potential embarrassment. They insist, a tad defiantly, that the varying price tags say nothing about the relative worth of celebs on the auction block, either in terms of persona or profession. ''If Norman Mailer were auctioned off at a charitable event where there were people capable of paying 50 times more than they were paying, he would have gone for 50 times more,'' says David Saltzman, executive director of the Robin Hood Foundation in New York. Maybe so, but in addition to Soros, Saltzman's gang also sold a hockey lesson with Wayne Gretzky for a hundred grand, the same donation the Boy Scouts got for a breakfast with Phil Condit, the Boeing bigwig. Gioietta Vitale, who as chairman of the American-Italian Cancer Foundation recruited Mailer for her cause, isn't fazed. ''Next year, we'll just have some C.E.O.,'' she says.

title: Staten Island and Brooklyn Getting Into the Minors
description: The Bronx has the Yankees, Queens has the Mets and Manhattan may be getting a domed stadium to lure the Jets. And now Brooklyn and Staten Island are also getting new city ball parks, to house new farm teams for the Yankees and Mets.

title: The World: Raising the Stakes; American Pay Rattles Foreign Partners
description: AS the global economy spawns more mergers of American and foreign companies, inequities in the pay of top executives quickly become apparent. In the spirit of compromise that marks a new marriage, the lower-paid officers see their pay rise to the levels of their better-paid colleagues -- almost always the Americans -- and American-style capitalism claims a little more foreign turf.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISKIND, BERNARD
description: SISKIND-Bernard. The New York Chapter of the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation Int'l records with deep sorrow the death of Bernard Siskind. Bernard was a special friend and loyal supporter of diabetes research from the very beginning. He will be missed by everyone. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the bereaved family. James M. Lurie, President

title: Other Things to Do in a Sex Shop
description: LAST August, as Courtney Williams, an independent filmmaker, ate dinner with a friend in SoHo, the two began discussing Mayor Giuliani's crackdown on sex shops and the rule that most such places must devote 60 percent of their floor space to nonpornographic material to stay open.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A comedy drama about a surprising physician, a tale set in the Old West, a British comedy and a stunning costume drama enliven this midwinter week for fans of films on television.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  YEGEN, GLADYS
description: YEGEN-Gladys. One in a million. Greatly missed. Your loving family.

title: Onward and Upward on Curry Hill
description: AUGUST 1994: I walk along pothole-filled Lexington Avenue between 30th and 31st Streets, passing the drunks and addicts who live at the infamous S.R.O. hotel on the corner, the Rutledge. Nearing 31st, I pass a young woman (at least I hope it's a woman) wearing a torn silver lame ballerina outfit and a curly blonde wig.

title: Loose Tiles
description: After turning out a million letters a day for 19 verbose years, the saws that cut the rectangular wood tiles for Milton Bradley's Scrabble game are now still. Last month, the 57 workers who produced this ocean of alphabet soup at a small plant in Fairfax, Vt., said their good-byes, grabbed their complimentary 50th-anniversary Scrabbles and closed up shop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, HAROLD H.
description: LEVINE-Harold H. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Harold H. Levine, associated with The Times from 1949 until retiring in 1993.

title: Carry On, Carrie
description: For spring '99, Carrie Donovan chooses: The new short jacket! The new cropped pants! Pastels, pastels, pastels! And of course, animal prints!

title: Pentagon Presses Ex-Iraq Inspector on Book
description: The Defense Department has demanded that Scott Ritter, a former United Nations weapons inspector in Iraq, turn over advance copies of a book in which he is expected to step up his criticism of the Clinton Administration and detail some of his work for the United Nations.

title: De Gustibus
description: I turned to your Sunday pages (Dec. 27) and saw that the citizens of Manitou Springs, Colo., are the hosts of the Great Fruitcake Toss. Instead of throwing hundreds of fruitcakes or driving them to smithereens with a 3-wood, why not wrap and send them to homeless shelters, where they might be eaten and enjoyed. The toss is just a senseless waste of food.

title: Across Euroland, Echoes of a Devaluation
description: THE year began so brightly for Europe. After years of dreaming, scheming and compromise, a flip of the switch on Jan. 1 transformed Continental Europe into Euroland: one market, one central bank, one currency.

title: Michael Jordan, in the Leaving

title: Korda Will Play, to Players' Dismay
description: There will be no player boycott of the Australian Open, the year's first Grand Slam event, over an appeals committee's decision to rescind Petr Korda's one-year ban for testing positive for the steroid nandrolone.

title: Miss Montgomery and Mr. Millard
description: Catherine Walsh Montgomery and Richard Temple Millard were married yesterday by the Rev. Michael Keenan Jones at the Queen of the Most Holy Rosary Roman Catholic Church in Bridgehampton, N.Y.

title: The Rumors of His Death Have Been Greatly Exaggerated
description: You drive up a medley of winding streets from Ventura Boulevard to reach Richard Pryor's current residence. The notorious Northridge mansion where Pryor partied in high Hollywood style and nearly burned himself to death in 1980 was sold several years ago. This new home is a modest one-story abode that fits his scaled-back life.

description: WHEN Dave and Midge Smith shut down the Stony Brook Village Service gas station after running it for 13 years, neither thought they would become the center of a community debate.

description: When Christine Todd Whitman was trying to decide between seeking an income tax cut or property tax relief during her 1993 gubernatorial campaign, her top political advisers said lowering property taxes would earn the most points with voters.

title: Three Whose Works Transcend the Genre
description: FOR more than 75 years, the Silvermine Guild in New Canaan has established itself as an integral part of the Northeast's cultural scene. Artists from this region are sometimes associated with landscape and still-life painting, which is why the current show at the Hammond Museum and Stroll Garden here yields few surprises.

title: Jerry's Kids
description: Sweet Chaos

title: Streetscapes / Bond Street From Lafayette Street to the Bowery; A Block That Offers the Quintessence of NoHo
description: THERE is no better place to sample the contemplated NoHo Historic District than the block of Bond Street from Lafayette Street to the Bowery. This jumble of elegant 1830's row houses, quirky 1890's lofts, hard-edged modern storefronts and vacant lots is buzzing with change -- and history.

title: In America; Giuliani's Stadium Fever
description: Something must have happened while we weren't looking. Apparently it is no longer essential that the city build a stadium on the West Side of Manhattan for the Yankees. Now, if Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is to be believed, we need to build one for the Jets.

title: In the Region / New Jersey; Redeveloping a Polluted Raritan Center Parcel
description: FOR the last seven decades, a grubby swath of polluted land along Industrial Highway in the southwestern edge of Woodbridge Township has lain fallow and forgotten.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFITHS, HELEN T.
description: GRIFFITHS-Helen T. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Helen T. Griffiths, associated with The Times from 1963 until retiring in 1984.

title: Willy, Now Free, Is Receiving Visitors
description: First there was the movie ''Free Willy.'' Now, you can see Willy, on an Oceanic Society Expeditions tour. Keiko, a killer whale whose confinement in a small tank in Mexico City inspired an international rescue effort (and the movie), was returned this summer to his original home -- the waters off Iceland.

title: North Korea And U.S. Meet On Inspection Of Atom Plant
description: With tensions rising on the Korean peninsula, the United States and North Korea opened new talks here today on whether North Korea will allow inspections of a suspected underground nuclear facility.

title: Too Frugal in L.A.
description: To the Editor: Daisann McLane's Frugal Traveler account of her stay at a Banana Bungalow (''In L.A., Looking for Comfort at Banana Bungalows,'' Dec. 20) was dead on. My boyfriend and I took a trip on the cheap to the West Coast about a year ago, and also stayed there because our guidebooks listed it as one of the least expensive hotel-style accommodations. Our room must have been next door to Ms. McLane's, on the second floor facing the highway. We liked the cheery pastel pink and green decor with rattan furnishings, which gave the room some tropical atmosphere, but we, too, were unhappy with the lack of security and the disco below. The moldy bathroom had seen better days.

title: Whatever The Weather
description: Function and style have come a long way in the last 50 years. Fashion dictated, even in winter storms. Once, women's legs, in nylon stockings, were exposed by knee-length hems. Pants were unheard of.

title: Tyson Wins His Latest Comeback by Knockout
description: With one thunderous right hand, Mike Tyson crowned his second ring comeback in the last four years by knocking out Francois Botha at 2 minutes 59 seconds of the fifth round tonight at the MGM Grand Garden.

title: Common Roots
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGGERTY, GILBERT

Cowie of Washington Township, N.J. Msgr. Thomas O'Leary performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Elizabeth in Wyckoff, N.J.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Freeport, L.I.; Maritime Breezes, Canals and Diversity
description: UNLIKE areas of Long Island that are homogeneous or nearly so, the maritime and suburban Village of Freeport on Nassau County's South Shore is a community that takes its identity, in part, from its economic and ethnic mix.
