title: Alexandra Herrman, David Kamin
description: Alexandra Lamb Herrman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Herrman of New York, was married yesterday to David Warren Kamin, the son of Prof. June Warren Kamin of Newport Beach, Calif., and Sherwin Kamin of New York. The Rev. James L. Burns performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. Lawrence R. Prase, an Episcopal priest who is the bride's godfather, took part in the service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERNE, LEO
description: CHERNE-Leo. As Director of the Research Institute of America, Leo was Master Editor, Master Prognosticator, Master Speaker, and Master Friend. I know I speak for former ''RIA'' colleagues when I say Leo's brilliance lit up our lives uniquely. Eli Cantor, Former Editor-in-Chief ''The Research Institute Report''

title: Inquiry in Death of Janitor Held on Traffic Violations
description: The Nassau County police are investigating how a janitor serving a 90-day sentence in the county jail for traffic violations died Thursday night, covered in bruises, with a lacerated spleen and broken ribs.

title: A Rarefied Belgian Who Specialized In Mournful Beauty
description: PHOTOGRAPHY festivals have flourished like weeds ever since Jean-Luc Monterosso -- now the director of the Maison Europenne de la Photographie -- organized the first biennial Mois de la Photo in Paris in 1980. Many festivals were founded in the intervening years; now photographs stream en masse to international gatherings , Barcelona, Berlin, Caracas, Houston, London, Montreal, Moscow, Sao Paulo and Stockholm; to cities in Australia, Bulgaria, Korea, Mali, Mexico (which puts up 700 exhibitions around the country, including one in Texas), Portugal and more. Slovakia has two festivals, one of them annual. The Netherlands has three.

title: Family Feud
description: THE SANDGLASS

title: Teaching the Fine Art of Stand-Up Comedy
description: LEARNING to be a stand-up comic is serious business. It takes courage. It takes chutzpah. It takes a sense of humor.

title: To Leave Home, Find Someone To Leave Behind
description: UNLIKE my paternal grandfather, a central Iowa farmer whose herd of Holsteins required twice-daily milking and whose fence-busting Duroc and Poland (China) pigs, roving flocks of chickens, ducks and the odd border collie demanded he stay home, I am free, theoretically, to travel anywhere I can afford to go.

title: Life, the Universe and Everything
description: THE WAY OF THE WORLD

title: LIVES; Electroboy
description: I'm lying on a gurney in the operating room at Gracie Square Hospital. I feel as if I'm waiting for either the scariest roller-coaster ride of my life or for my own execution. I'm convinced that if I live, my brain will be reduced to a blank Rolodex. I look down at my bare feet. A flawless loafer tan line. Maybe I'll die wearing flesh-tone loafers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 30 of The Times Magazine today about President Clinton's legacy includes an outdated reference to possible contenders for the Democratic nomination in 2000. On Jan. 9, after the article had gone to press, Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota announced that he would not seek the Presidency.

title: Travelers Aid Seeking Aid
description: Since its founding in 1905, Travelers Aid has dispensed comfort, guidance and sometimes a ticket home for people who came to New York and saw their dreams dashed by crime, poor planning or just plain hard luck. Over the years, the midtown agency has helped survivors of the Titanic, victims of the Depression and World War II refugees. But after losing city financing last year, the agency now must raise money if it wants to keep helping travelers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAIDER, BERNARD
description: RAIDER-Bernard. Beloved husband of Zelda. Devoted father of Daniel, Matthew, Nancy and Sharon. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Benjamin, Sara, Carolyn and Danielle. Services Sunday, 11:30 AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Postcards From the Edge
description: FRIENDS AND APOSTLES

title: Ellington At 100: Reveling in Life's Majesty
description: IN Duke Ellington's world, people are smiling, they are dancing and they are making love. They're having a good time because his music's most basic concern is uplift of the human spirit. It's a music that celebrates freedom of expression, freedom of choice. That's why we love it. It wants us to love being ourselves and to revel in the majesty of life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, BETTY
description: LEVINSON-Betty. On January 16, 1999, after a lengthy illness. Beloved wife of George, dear mother of Jackie S. (Ira Berkower) Levinson, Lisa M. (Tom Hanrahan) Levinson and Ben W. Levinson. Revered sister of Dorothy Chester and David (Sylvia) Bashkow. Adored grandmother of Risa, Ariel and Simone Berkower. Services Sunday in Sarasota, FL, and Tuesday in Washington, DC. Interment following in Olney, MD. Memorials to Betty Levinson Scholarship Fund c/o Lynbrook Union Free School District Administration Office, 111 Atlantic Ave., Lynbrook, NY 11563 or Brandeis University National Women's Committee. For information, Tishman Funeral Home, 941-923-2000.

title: Giving the Inner Child Some Outer Expression
description: ART showed me that I could do something in my life.'' So said Travis Samuel, pictured at left, who contributed a mask to a major exhibition of artworks by New York City public school children. The show, titled ''Doing Art Together, Inspirations From Within,'' will be on display through March 4 at Aaron Davis Hall at City College. Travis is a sixth grader at the Choir of Harlem Academy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CATES, JOSEPH
description: CATES-Joseph. On October 10, 1998. The New York Friars Club and the Cates family deeply mourn his passing and extend an invitation to attend a memorial service on Monday, January 25 at 2pm at Director's Guild Theater, 110 West 57 Street, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINE, TILLIE
description: PINE-Tillie. On January 15, 1999 in her 103rd year. Wife of the late Nat Pine. Educator, longtime director, Stonybrook Playgroups. Co-author of 27 children's science books. Survived by daughter Mona, sister Mary, nephew Vic.

title: Still Some Negatives With New L.I.R.R. Cars
description: Re: ''With New Cars, L.I.R.R. Gathers a Bit of Momentum'' [Jan. 3], they got the new cars wrong.

title: More Housing on the Way?
description: A new apartment building, the first to be erected under a pivotal plan to ease Williamsburg's perennial housing crunch, may soon become a reality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATHENAU, MARION I.
description: RATHENAU-Marion I. Beloved wife of the late Hans Rathenau. Died November 19, 1998. A wonderful woman. She will be sorely missed.

title: Reclaiming Game Of Our Youth
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Turnpike in Mid-Life Crisis
description: SIX ex-governors, as well as the then-current Governor, Abraham Ribicoff, were present at formal ribbon-cutting ceremonies held in Greenwich and Killingly Jan. 2, 1958. Clergymen representing the three major faiths gave their blessings. And the Connecticut Turnpike was opened.

title: City of Rye Is Selected As Disaster Plan Model
description: TORNADOES, earthquakes, landslides those are the kinds of natural occurrences usually associated with the word disaster. In the Northeast, nature is generally more temperate, but disaster can strike in the form of hurricanes and floods.

title: Reminding Senators of 'Moment of Truth'
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by Representative George W. Gekas, Republican of Pennsylvania, in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.

title: Diane Bloom, Michael Rose
description: Diane S. Bloom and Michael L. Rose were married last evening in Washington. Rabbi Harold S. White officiated at the Corcoran Gallery of Art.

title: The Nation; Dividing News From Sleaze in the Age of Flynt
description: AN old metaphysical question asks what happens if a tree falls in a forest with no one around. Does it make a sound?

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: Here are three independent sites on the World Wide Web, each of which intends to be your main or only stop for arranging travel. They all succeed, at least to some extent; they also all fail, to some extent. They are all worth a look.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about objections to a teacher's transfer to the Manhattan School for Children misspelled her given name. She is Gabriela Klassen, not Gabreila. The article also referred incorrectly to a conversation Ms. Klassen had with the principal. Although Ms. Klassen says she will not transfer elsewhere because union rules forbid schools to exclude senior teachers, she said she did not tell that to the principal.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Comcast's venture in a statewide television network, CN8, misstated the number of times Bob Shryock, a longtime host of a cable show in Gloucester County, appeared on Comcast Newsmakers, a local public affairs program. His participation in such programs was sharply cut back by Comcast, but later restored. He appeared on about 250 segments of Newsmakers in a little more than three years, not more than 2,000 over 19 years.

title: Defining an Official's High Crime: 'Acting in a Way That Hurts People'
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by Representative Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Pregnant (Yet Again), but Hardly Barefoot
description: LET me make one thing perfectly clear. I am not having a baby.

title: In the Region / Westchester; Downtown Scarsdale Development Plan Advances
description: FOR more than 30 years, there has been endless discussion and analysis over what to do with two unsightly parcels of land on either side of Popham Road near this village's train station. Each lot measures about an acre. One has a nondescript retail building on it, the other an asphalt parking lot.

title: A Very Different Shade of Green; 30 Years Later, Don't Confuse Namath's Jets With Today's Team
description: Oh, what a time it was. The Jets' coach called his underdog team ''green and growing,'' and clearly wished he were still coaching the opposition, which had dumped him. The National Football League commissioner grudgingly gave the news media permission to use the nickname ''Super Bowl,'' although that was not the official title. The third annual A.F.L.-N.F.L. World Championship Game's lightning rod, the long-haired quarterback, was generally considered controversial because of his prediction of victory, not to mention his reputation for drinking and sex, sometimes the night before a game.

title: Still Locked in Storm's Horror, Hondurans Are Fearful of Future
description: Mirtha Martinez Arriola returned to her home on a recent Sunday and wept when she saw her husband's hat floating in brackish water beneath the roofless frame house where they once lived.

title: Michael, Manhattan Awaits
description: Michael Jordan's retirement may be bad news for professional basketball, but it was good news for the retail shop at Michael Jordan's Steakhouse NYC in Grand Central Terminal. Sales of autographed basketballs ($1,500 each), jerseys ($2,100) and other sports paraphernalia tripled, to about $4,000 a day from $1,400, after the superstar announced his departure last week, according to Peter and Penny Glazier, the owners. Jordan has been to the establishment twice, but maybe now he will appear more often. Mrs. Glazier hopes so. ''He was very personable, delightful, charismatic,'' she said.

title: Alas, No Log Cabin for Fat Cats. Will a Palace Do?
description: Posing for a photographer at the entrance to the Breakers, a palatial Italian Renaissance resort where wealthy Republicans converged this week, former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee could not resist a quip about the party of Abe Lincoln.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODS, VIRGINIA
description: WOODS-Virginia. On January 13th, 1999. Beloved sister of Sam and Susanne and niece of Ruth W. Smith. Dear cousin of John Leonard, Warren Huff, Jennifer Woods, Loretta Callahan & Susan Goolian. Memorial service Monday, January 25th, 1:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to your favorite charity.

title: IN MY ... PURSE/ELLEN GALINSKY
description: AS president of the Families and Work Institute, a Manhattan organization devoted to research on the changing workplace and family, Ellen Galinsky moves through a daily blur of meetings, phone calls and speaking engagements. Lately, she has also been writing a book on how children view their parents' jobs.

title: Elisabeth Klebanoff, David Wachtel
description: Elisabeth S. Klebanoff and David Edward Wachtel were married last evening by Rabbi Edward Elkin at the Union League Club in New York.

title: A Week of Public Appearances
description: President Clinton had almost nothing to say last week about his impeachment trial. But he made certain that the nation saw multiple images of him hard at work on matters of substance. White House officials said they were determined to project positive pictures of the President engaged in the country's business.

title: There's Something About Stella
description: THE COUNTRY LIFE

title: January 10-16; A Break-In, Yes. But No Watergate.
description: A break-in at the Washington offices of an American pollster who advises Ehud Barak, the leader of Israel's opposition Labor party, at first seemed to have the makings of an Israeli Watergate. But it caused hardly a ripple in Israel's election campaign, where the two main candidates were otherwise preoccupied. Mr. Barak was at a Labor convention securing slots for his allies on the party slate. Prime Minister Netanyahu was shoring up support in his own Likud party, where Moshe Arens, a former ally and mentor, announced that he would challenge Mr. Netanyahu for the party leadership. JOEL GREENBERG

title: How High the Crime, How Damned the Lie
description: For two days House Republican prosecutors played the short game, trying to win the right to call witnesses. Today they turned to their ultimate challenge: to convince Senators, particularly Democrats, that President Clinton's misdeeds are grave enough to warrant his removal from office.

title: C.E.O. Turns U.F.O. Hunter
description: Joseph P. Firmage, 28, founder of USWeb, a $2.5 billion Internet consulting company in Santa Clara, Calif., has been on the cutting edge of the technology revolution. But last week he quit his post with the company, lest some people think his theories had gone over the edge of credulity. He believes, you see, that extraterrestrials have visited Earth and possibly helped seed recent technology advances. He has published his ideas in ''The Truth'' (www.thewordistruth .org), a 600-page ''book'' that also discusses the influence of aliens on science and religion. Demand is such, he said, that he took the site down on Friday to triple the capacity.

title: Paris Grand Prix
description: To the Editor: The essay about traffic brought a smile to my face. I remember as a child when my father would drive to the Place de l'Etoile, now Place Charles de Gaulle. You could circle around the Arc de Triomphe several times before getting a chance to drive into one of the dozen avenues that radiate from it.

title: January 10-16; Princeton Gets the Shivers
description: The president of Princeton University, Harold T. Shapiro, suggested ending the Nude Olympics, an annual tradition in which sophomores run naked through a campus courtyard at midnight after the first big snowfall. The problem: Many of the streakers use liquor to numb their modesty before the cold numbs everything else.

title: Sports of The Times; What Best Becomes Retired Role Model?
description: AT his news conference Wednesday announcing his retirement from basketball, Michael Jordan was asked if he might now try to help ''solve some of the world's problems.'' Quite a question with which to confront a basketball player, but then Michael Jordan's persona, like few others, transcends the hemispheres.

title: Just Whose Millstone Is It?
description: INFLUENTIAL groups and public officials on the East End of Long Island are stepping up a determined campaign to close the Millstone nuclear power plant in Connecticut, even as its operators await permission to restart the second of its three reactors after a three-year shutdown.

title: The Wolves Are at the Door
description: LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD IN THE RED LIGHT DISTRICT

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

title: Photography Rooted In the Depression
description: WALKER EVANS (1903-1975) is indelibly associated with the Depression and the photographs of Southern sharecroppers he took for the 1941 book by James Agee, ''Let Us Now Praise Famous Men.'' But Evans's career was long, and more varied and contradiction-filled than the celebrated collaboration indicates. His output from 1927 through 1974 is surveyed in some depth at the Whitney Museum's branch in Stamford in an exhibition titled ''Simple Subjects.''

title: Run, Don't Walk
description: New Balance's classic 996 sneaker, introduced 10 years ago and reintroduced in 1996, is the trainer of choice for many low-key New York hipsters and, apparently, for their babies. In addition to adult sizes, the shoe, known for its simple, retro lines and no-nonsense ''N'' logo, comes in a crib model (sizes 1 to 3, $19.99) with a nylon sole for crawlers and in an infant model (sizes 2 to 8, $31.50) featuring a solid rubber midsole, for better shock absorption and durability, and a plastic reinforcer in the heel for stability. The technology may be excessive for navigating the living room, but parents seem to be buying the sneakers for their cool looks alone. Not missing a beat, New Balance is adding pale blue, red and khaki to its white, navy and gray versions this spring. JENNIFER TUNG

title: Decoding Parking-Sign Legalese
description: It has become a regular Sunday pastime for employees at stores on East 59th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues: watching drivers become hopelessly baffled trying to determine whether parking on the block is legal or not.

title: The Magic Between Photographer and Viewer
description: 'The Magic Moment'

title: 'Uncollecting Cheever'
description: Book Review DeskTo the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLS, GWENDOLYN
description: WELLS-Gwendolyn. Long-time union activist and leader, died Friday, January 15, of pancreatic cancer. She was 53. At the time of her death, she was the Director of Education and Research for the Office and Professional Employees International Union (OPEIU), AFL-CIO, and the editor of the official union publication, White Collar. Wells also served as a Vice President of the Board of the Coalition of Labor Union Women (CLUW). Born and raised in Dallas, TX, she resided in New York City. Wells was a graduate of the University of Texas and Cornell University School of Labor Relations. She is survived by her mother, Rose Wells, her sister Mrs. Patty Warren, and brother-inlaw Henry Warren, all of San Antonio, TX. A memorial service will be held at a later date in New York. In lieu of flowers, a memorial fund has been established through the American Cancer Society, 19 West 56th St., New York, NY 10019.

title: Stars of a Winter's Night
Paid Notice: Deaths  DAMES, LANGDON
description: DAMES-Langdon, died January 14th, 1999. Viewing on Monday, January 18, 2-8 at Woodward Funeral Home. Funeral service Tuesday, 11 AM at Woodward.

title: In the Region / Long Island; The Movies Are the New Stars of the Mall
description: THE recent selection of developers for three state-owned properties that once housed retarded and mentally ill patients could bring hundreds of residential units and thousands of square feet of industrial and office space to western Suffolk County, where the three sites totaling 1,107 acres are situated.

title: Awakening Memories Of Unconventional Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; Quoting Torah In Kosher War Of the Woks
description: THIS is the story of this city's Great Kosher Chinese Food War.

title: THEATER; A Place Where Musicals Can Be Sure of a Tuneup
description: IN 1995, Eric D. Schaeffer was the 32-year-old co-founder of a tiny theater company lodged in a former auto-plating plant along a bleak highway in strip-mall country across the Potomac from Washington. He had just directed a biting, highly successful revival of the musical ''Cabaret,'' in which he drenched his small Signature Theater's stage in Nazi flag imagery and jolted arriving patrons with the sound of goose-steps blaring over loudspeakers. He also reshaped the book and substituted several songs from the movie version -- something the show's venerated songwriting team, the composer John Kander and the lyricist Fred Ebb, had never allowed before.

title: Children's Books
description: MONSTER STEW

title: Shy Student Puts Iona in Big League
description: ERIN VERONICA WHALEN rises at 5:30 A.M. to practice with the Iona College crew team. Evenings may find her working as an usher at college athletic events or counseling other students in her role as campus minister, a job that provides her with room and board. She is also sports editor of the college paper. And she is earning straight A's as an honors program student majoring in English and communications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, JANIS MERESMAN
description: GOLDMAN - Janis Meresman. The Board and staff of the Charles H. Revson Foundation express our profound condolences to the family of our fellow director, Helaine Barnett on the loss of her beloved sister, Janie and to their father Harry Meresman, one of our founding directors and to our emeritus director, Victor Barnett. Janie was a spiritual force who inspired everyone she met with a deep commitment to family and a concern for the Jewish future. We will cherish our time with her. Robert S. Rifkind, Chair Eli N. Evans, President

title: Trickling Up
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Who's Likely to Win With a Roth 401(k)?
description: If you are a worker 50 or older with a big income, or a young worker with a bright future, Bill Roth has a valuable proposal for you. Everyone else may want to hold onto their wallets.

title: Michael Jordan, in the Leaving
description: To the Editor:

title: Smoldering Emotion Kindled by Motion
description: AT supper in his studio in St. Petersburg or at lunch in a New York restaurant, Boris Eifman is all good-humored gallantry. It isn't until this 52-year-old Russian choreographer reveals his life story that one understands how a surface calm harbors the emotional intensity that blazes through his ballets.

title: Talking Cooking and Fielding Questions
description: MOST weekends, Arthur Schwartz, host of ''Food Talk,'' a daily New York radio program on WOR-AM, heads for his second home in West Cornwall, known to listeners as the country kitchen.

title: School Computers Might Harm Posture
description: Some elementary school computers are set up without accommodation for healthy typing postures, and that could put children at risk of developing the painful repetitive stress injuries that have plagued office workers in recent years, according to a study by researchers at Cornell University.

title: Double-Edged Economic Crisis Whipsaws Brazil Workers and Companies
description: For 22 years and 4 months, Luiz Porfirio Diniz reported daily to the bustling Ford do Brasil automotive plant here, where three different car models are manufactured. But then just before Christmas, he got the bad news he had been fearing ever since Brazilian interest rates shot to nearly 50 percent four months ago: He was one of 2,800 assembly-line workers being laid off.

title: For Surviving Octuplets, Progress Comes in Ounces
description: At first glance, it is hard to tell a baby is there.

title: Checks in the Mail? Can't Be Too Soon for Taxpayers
description: The state Treasurer's office was deluged with calls the day after Governor Whitman announced her property tax relief plan that would eventually pay out $1 billion annually in rebate checks to homeowners.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: THE PIRATE'S SON. By Geraldine McCaughrean. Scholastic. $16.95. (Ages 8 to 12) The premise of this engaging novel is that Tamo White was sent back to England in the early 17th century by his dying pirate father to obtain a proper education. At school, Tamo befriends the orphaned siblings Nathan and Maud Gull, and they set off for Madagascar, which Tamo considers his home. They reach the island, which appears ''like a gigantic crocodile asleep along the horizon,'' and many thrilling adventures ensue.

title: Political Briefing; From Dudley Dudley To Monica Monica
description: Dudley Dudley.

title: To the Dark Wood
description: The Triumph of Love

title: Margaret Mazer and Barry Ogdon
description: ALMOST everyone describes Margaret Ann Mazer, 40, as boisterous and very, very blunt. Once, she answered a personal ad, and when the man showed up, heavier and balder than he'd said, she remembered telling him: ''You're nothing like your ad! That's false advertising!'' Then she shut the door.

title: Seeing End of Sanctions, Burundi Breathes Easier
description: No gasoline is supposed to come into Burundi, yet the streets here are full of cars. No commercial flights are supposed to arrive, yet cargo planes land regularly from Belgium and the United Arab Emirates, full of foreign goods that no one here is supposed to get: radios, Moet & Chandon Champagne, whisky, cheese.

title: Restless
description: Hirschberg's article on Sean Penn was a delight. She captures the moments brilliantly and turns an all-night road trip into a Tom Waits song.

title: Small Businesses Like Ivan's Create a Neighborhood
description: To the Editor:

title: Disclaimers, Disclaimers
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Briefing; Voter-Friendly Rules Upset Democrats
description: No state tries harder to make voting easier than Oregon. And in an era when the voter participation rate is scandalously low in most states, no state consistently enjoys a higher rate than Oregon.

title: At Last, a New Strategy for AT&T
description: THE future of the AT&T Corporation is not hard to find -- if you can read a floor plan. It is in Room 4430G2 at AT&T's sprawling headquarters in Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: Where Wyatt Earp Stood Tall
description: I HADN'T gone to Dodge City to be a tourist and see the sights and artifacts of the mythical Old West town, but I was struck from the time I arrived by the way the past -- both real and imagined -- was all around and slipped into the most routine of conversations. One man said that when he told friends in another part of the country that he was moving to Dodge City, they seemed surprised to learn there really was such a place. Folks at the Chamber of Commerce wondered if I knew that the handsome brick building in which we talked was atop the original Boot Hill, where at least 26 people were ''planted'' after meeting their final fate in less than pleasant circumstances.

title: Q. & A.
description: Renters In a Co-op Upgrade

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SPAR, HERBERT MARTIN
description: SPAR-Herbert Martin. May 15, 1941-January 16, 1976. You have left a lasting void in our hearts and lives. Oh, how we miss you! Your joie de vivre, your strength, your spirit, your ''sechel'' which was like no other. All our lives would have been beautifully enhanced if you were with us. Our comfort is knowing you are resting peacefully with Mommy. Your loving family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIN, PHILIP J.
description: MARGOLIN-Philip J. Died January 4th. He leaves two sons, Paul of Londonderry, NH, Christopher of Portola Valley, CA, daughter, Carol of Clevland, OH, four grandchildren, and sister, Evelyn Schwartz of North Wilmington, MA. Services on January 30th at The First Unitarian Church of New Bedford, MA. at 2 P.M.

title: Art at Lincoln Center
description: To the Editor:

title: Gone Haywire
description: PHANTOMS IN THE BRAINProbing the Mysteries of the Human Mind.By V. S. Ramachandran and Sandra Blakeslee.Illustrated. 328 pp. New York:William Morrow & Company. $27.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Michelle Foxman, Daniel Small
description: Michelle Pia Foxman and Daniel Isaiah Small were married last evening at the Pierre in Manhattan. Cantor Joseph Malovany officiated and Rabbi David Rosen, the director of the Jerusalem office of the Anti-Defamation League, took part in the ceremony.

title: January 10-16; A Candidate By Any Other Name
description: When Lauryn Kaye Valentine of Chicago changed her name to Carol Moseley-Braun last September, she said she wanted to honor one of her heroes, Senator Carol Moseley-Braun of Illinois.

title: Good Morning, Vietnam
description: It seemed as if it was always dark when we awoke in Vietnam. The 22-hour trip from New York had been brutal, and we were probably jet-lagged, or perhaps simply too excited to sleep. Either way, it was unfortunate that the windows in our modern Hanoi hotel were sealed shut against local smells and sounds. Otherwise, I'm sure that the aroma of beef broth would have pulled us from our gauzy dreams into the violet and gray damask of a Vietnamese dawn.

title: The Governor-President
description: As a 10-year-old glued to the TV through the summer of Watergate, I remember the air of gravity that hung over the proceedings, the sense that it was a dreadful necessity to put a President on trial. I don't recall authority figures having to explain that it was a national crisis -- even to a kid, that was pretty obvious. One of the oddest things about the impeachment weekend just before Christmas was the constant stream of reminders that the country was again experiencing such a crisis. Throughout the ordeal, legislators and commentators tried to come up with more dramatic ways to frame the events taking place. Bill Clinton was about to become only the second President ever impeached. He would be our first elected President ever impeached. All through the holidays and on into January the tone remained the same: we were having the first Senate trial of a President in 130 years. Watching TV was like having someone grab you by the lapels and shout, Don't you understand this is supposed to be historic!

title: A Chowder Champ Stirs the Pot
description: THE seafood chowder at Page One won the Gold Coast Chowder Challenge last July when the tall ships visited Glen Cove.

title: The World: A Case of Open and Shut; As the World Takes a New Look, It's the Same Old Cuba
description: AS he traveled from one end of Cuba to another a year ago, often with Fidel Castro at his side or sitting attentively in the audience, Pope John Paul II had one overriding message. In its most succinct form it was that Cuba ''needs to open herself to the world, and the world needs to draw closer to Cuba.''

title: The Newest Wave: Made-for-the-Internet Movies
description: IN the upper left-hand corner of the computer screen, a young woman materializes murkily in a patch of moving image, pauses to gather her thoughts and begins to recite an ode to the ecstasy of love. As she talks, the fuzzy image on the screen shifts and pulsates as if it were liquid.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Creative Waiting For Job Seekers
description: Q. I'm being considered for a dream job -- and am fighting the urge to shower my prospective boss with examples of my work, glowing references and even small-caliber bribes. Friends tell me that when it comes to job-hunting, there's no such thing as being too eager. Is that true?

title: Legends of the Surf at Dana Point
description: MY favorite places always seem to have sand. When not in the desert, I can generally be found at the beach. These days, my beach town of preference is Dana Point, in Orange County, just south of Laguna Beach.

title: Life Beyond the Multiplex for Serious Students of Cinema Art
description: FIRST, some bad news: the number of Garden State cinemas willing (and financially able) to show independent, experimental or revival films has shrunk in the last year with the sale of three art houses to the Clearview chain: the Red Bank Arts Theater and, in Montclair, the Clairidge and the Screening Zone. And a film festival proposed for this fall at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, meant to showcase the state's feature-filmmaking and acting talent, collapsed amid infighting after it failed to attract donations.

title: Two-Day Cliffside Getaway
description: THE rarest native pine tree in the United States, the Torrey pine, is indigenous only to two spots along the California coast -- in a grove on the tiny Santa Rosa Island off Santa Barbara and along a five-mile stretch of land in San Diego called the Torrey Pines State Reserve. With their twisted trunks and gnarled branches, the pine trees stand as a kind of monument to tenacity and adaptation, their slanted, funny-looking silhouettes stooped from the ravages of wind and water. Spanish sailors in the 1500's spotted the trees growing on a high bluff and marked the area on their maps as Punta de los Arboles, or Wooded Point.

title: National Jail Model
description: The County Department of Correction's Emergency Response Team has been named a national model by the American Correction Association. Westchester's program was cited after a two-year evaluation process by the association to define ''best practices'' in the correctional field.

title: 'A Wild, Roving, Vagabond Life'
description: A RAGE TO LIVE

title: Series Hits Home
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: So What if It's Trash, if It Has Style?
description: MY roommate, James, has a ritual: When he goes for a walk, he scans the sidewalks for stray chairs, wayward tables and homeless armoires. When he returns, I never know what will accompany him through the front door.

title: A Racial Fairy Tale
description: To the Editor:

title: Flooded Plaza Collapses Into Garage on the Lower East Side
description: With a thunderous rumble and a rush of air, a playground and a concrete plaza collapsed into an underground parking garage at an apartment complex on the Lower East Side late Friday night, crushing dozens of cars and shaking nearby buildings with the force of a small earthquake. No one was injured, and there were no reports of anyone missing, officials said.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article yesterday about Speaker J. Dennis Hastert's views on the timing of the State of the Union address omitted part of an explanatory quotation. Mr. Hastert said that Congress should go ahead with the address ''out of respect for the office of the Presidency and for a desire to hear about the state of the union.''

title: Who the Heck Is Buck Wiley and Why Is He Leaving?
description: Nicholas Weinstock's article on the exodus of American entrepreneurs from Russia (Dec. 27) is a chronicle not of Russia's economic failure but of America's moral one. Does a country where the majority lack basic health care really need a Gold's Gym? Does a populace so impoverished that most cannot afford to buy meat need a pricey steakhouse?

title: THE PRESIDENT'S TRIAL: THE SCHEDULE
description: Trial Coverage

title: Philadelphia, Home Town of Liberty
description: ON a Thursday morning in mid-December, while much of the nation was preoccupied by matters Constitutional, I stood in line at the New Jersey Transit ticket window in Penn Station and bought a round-trip excursion rail ticket from New York to Philadelphia.

title: A Buyout King Looks Ahead
description: Investors have been wondering whether there is too much cash flowing into leveraged buyout funds these days, but Thomas H. Lee, known for his buyouts of Snapple, General Nutrition, Raytheon and TRW, answered an emphatic no to that question last week at a New York City breakfast meeting for buyout enthusiasts.

title: In Pro-Clinton States, 13 Senators Face a Squeeze by Right-Wing Ire
description: It was a strange sight. Senator Slade Gorton, a Republican from Washington State, was offering a compromise plan that would have abbreviated President Clinton's impeachment trial and avoided witnesses.

title: 'Open for Business'
description: County Executive Andrew J. Spano has appointed William J. Mulrow of Bronxville, a managing director at Rothschild, a Manhattan investment firm, to replace Louis Heithaus on the Industrial Development Agency board. Mr. Heithaus, who resigned, was the chairman of the public-private agency, which sells low-interest bonds and offers tax abatements to businesses. Mr. Heithaus headed the agency for 11 years under the the previous County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke.

title: The Red Storm's Backcourt Leads Way
description: Facing an aggressive Rutgers team last night, St. John's got crucial performances from its poised backcourt and from its enthusiastic sixth man.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: The Anti-Trump
description: I assume the reason for the headline ''The Anti-Trump'' on James Traub's article about Jerry I. Speyer (Dec. 20) was that it was the best and only way you could get people to read it.

title: Bienvenue To a French Bistro
description: There may not be a Murray Hill American Restaurant on the Left Bank of Paris, but there is a Rive Gauche bistro at 560 Third Avenue (corner of 37th Street). The owners of the two-week old spot, Oren Simon and Andrew Silverman, also own L'Express at 249 Park Avenue South (20th Street). Rive Gauche's menu highlights seafood platters in several sizes with an assortment of oysters, clams, shrimp, crab and lobster ($28.50 to $48.50); duck casserole ($19.50), and salmon smoked with lentils ($18).

title: Sewing Machine Gives a Family Its Sustenance
description: Last February, a close friend went to visit Sabina O. in her apartment in Astoria, Queens, and delivered a bit of bad news: she had to take back the sewing machine she had lent Sabina nearly three years earlier.

title: Pristine Seafood on the Shores of Scarsdale
description: REFUSING to abandon his prized marlin, Ernest Hemingway's hungry Old Man stands his course as he filets and eats the fish he scoops from the sea. Despite wishing for a bit of salt, he savors the texture and sweetness of the raw fresh fish. To enjoy the pure taste of pristine fish, we do not have to go to sea. We simply go to Scarsdale -- and Gyosai.

title: Gone Today, Here Tomorrow
description: You can run, but can you really hide? Even as Edmund Pankau is disappearing people (look left), Joseph Culligan is finding them. On Wednesday in Nashville, Culligan and three gumshoe colleagues (H.C. Altes, Ron L. Brown and Millard Land) -- a k a the Manhunt Group of Daytona Beach, Fla. -- will coach some 160 private eyes, cops and skip tracers (they track folks who ''skip'' their debts) on the latest methods of digging up the buried.

title: For the Jets, the Toughest Mountain To Climb Is a Mile High
description: The Jets seem to get it, finally. They face the Broncos on Sunday in the franchise's first trip to a championship game in 16 years. In between, they became a symbol for finding ways to lose and excuses for losing.

title: Beth Neckman, Michael Klein
description: Beth Robin Neckman, the daughter of Shelley and Arnold Neckman of Hollywood, Fla., was married last evening to Michael Stuart Klein, a son of Leah Gordon of Key Biscayne, Fla., and the late Barry Klein. Rabbi David Woznica officiated at the Biltmore hotel in Coral Gables, Fla.

title: From China to New Haven
description: SONJA WONG PICKFORD, a best-selling novelist in America, writes romance novels like ''Love in the Jade Pagoda'' and ''Bound Lives, Bound Feet.'' ''You must have heard of me,'' she says. ''I'm famous.'' But not fulfilled.

title: Unyielding Chief for the Los Angeles Police
description: One of the complaints heard most often about the tenure of Police Chief Willie L. Williams earlier this decade was that he was just too soft for the job, too soft in his heart when it came to disciplining his officers and leading them to better days.

title: Killing of Pigeons Draws a Poetic Response
description: To the Editor:

title: Exotic Fare
description: To the Editor: Eating can bring extraordinary adventures, as Mary Cantwell points out (''Of Frogs' Legs and Tripe, Eel and Emu,'' Dec. 6). In Southeast Asia, I traveled to remote islands and isolated barrios to experience, shall we say, unusual gastronomical delights, such as fried beetles, incubated duck embryos and dog meat adobo. As for the latter, I discovered what I had eaten only after having finished my meal at a wedding feast in northern Luzon.

title: Conn. Nuclear Plant: A Cross-Sound Clash
description: INFLUENTIAL groups and public officials on the East End of Long Island are stepping up a determined campaign to close the Millstone nuclear power plant in Connecticut, even as its operators await permission to restart the second of its three reactors after a three-year shutdown.

title: Another Stadium the State Still Needs to Fill Up
description: Is the Connecticut Tennis Center in New Haven a gigantic white elephant and monument to imprudent state spending -- or an ultramodern stadium that may yet fulfill its promise?

title: A Gift to My Father
description: I read Patti Davis's Lives column as I finished the week of mourning for my mother, who also suffered from Alzheimer's. Just as Davis did, my father, sister and I tried to find birthday, anniversary and Hanukkah gifts that would spark Mom's memory during her seven-year battle. Often, we merely provided some sensory enhancer -- a kaleidoscope and pictures of grandchildren, Beanie Babies, music on tapes, perfumed hand cream and, of course, chocolates and cookies. In the end, we found a gift to sustain us all -- time spent together.

title: Kari Elwell, Andrew Katzander
description: Kari Brooke Elwell and Andrew Adler Katzander were married yesterday by the Rev. Dale Stearn, an interfaith minister, at the Royalton Hotel in New York.

title: Islanders Set Back Again by an Injury to Jonsson
description: Kenny Jonsson doesn't make sparkling behind-the-back passes. He doesn't make emotional speeches between periods, either. In fact, it could be said that Jonsson is most noticed when he's not there. Take him out of the lineup and the Islanders disintegrate.

title: Restless
description: Lynn Hirschberg's portrayal of Sean Penn was fascinating (Dec. 27). I only wish she had drawn a parallel between Penn and Dean Moriarty, the road-loving hero of Jack Kerouac's novel ''On the Road.'' The similarities are remarkable. Like Penn, Moriarty frenetically crisscrossed the country in his worn car, reveled in raucous bar-room and womanizing exploits, spent time in prison reading great literature, narrowly avoided disaster on many occasions and through it all maintained that he was essentially a family man on a spiritual quest for truth.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, FELIX
description: KLEIN-Felix. 1/17/11-7/26/94 Never his like before, never his like again. Janice

title: Michael Jordan, in the Leaving
description: To the Editor:

title: Bookend; THE GODSEND
Old Tree May Be Benched
description: What do you when a 151-year-old landmark dies?

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Gallery Reopening at Yale

title: Music: Ellington Emerges, Falters and Triumphs; Uneasiness As Popular Tastes Shift
description: MOST musicians making their Carnegie Hall debut don't open with ''The Star-Spangled Banner.'' But this was no ordinary debut. On Jan. 23, 1943, Duke Ellington and his orchestra played to a capacity crowd in a benefit concert for the Russian War Relief fund.

title: Restless
description: ''Hurlyburly'' was utterly compelling. The Venice Film Festival awards committee had it right: Sean Penn for best actor.

title: Kelly Maintains Loyalty as Twins Disintegrate
description: A few years ago Jim Leyland grew tired of losing with no break in sight and parlayed his unhappiness into a World Series championship and then a $2 million-a-year job. Tom Kelly is no less tired of losing than Leyland was, but as loyal as Leyland was initially, Kelly has remained so loyal he is going down with the ship.

title: Boundaries To Stealing All Those Bright Ideas
description: TO say that D. Clark Ogle is miffed is a wild understatement. His company, Johnston Industries, a $300 million textile manufacturer based in Columbus, Ga., says that it has been the victim of corporate espionage. Outside consultants hired by a competitor, he contends, posed as a prospective investor and a graduate student to gain access to Johnston's trade secrets.

title: 'Rockaway Boulevard' at Belmont Playhouse
description: IN eight years, the Belmont Italian American Playhouse has made a name for itself as a professional theater that reflects the community in which it is deeply rooted. The theater has provided just the right indigenous place for the world premiere of ''Over the River and Through the Woods,'' a lighthearted currently popular Off Broadway comedy and the one-man play, ''Behind the Counter With Mussolini,'' a valentine to the owner of Mike's Deli on Arthur Avenue. The play recently closed Off Broadway.

title: Linking the People's Trust in the President to the World's Trust in America
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: An Old-Fashioned Look for a New Technology
description: Larry Knickerbocker's favorite place in his sprawling farmhouse here is the porch. There he can look over the sloping hillsides onto the fields that he and his brother farm, as their family had done for five generations before them.

title: Q & A
description: Panama Canal Tours

title: Restless
description: Sean Penn is a perfect example of the fine line between pathological and brilliant.

title: INSIDE
description: After the Storm

title: Vegetables and Seafood Are Candidates for Braising
description: BRAISING is for winter. Long, slow cooking in a heavy casserole, using a relatively small amount of liquid and low heat, renders ingredients that are meltingly tender. The steam that accumulates in the pot advances the process.

title: After the Ottoman Empire
description: TURKEY UNVEILED

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARTELS, EVA J.
description: WARTELS-Eva J. (Strauss). Beloved wife of the late Morty Strauss and the late Lester Wartels. Loving mother of Audrey Doniger, Nancy and Sidney Freedman. Most special grandmother to Jon and Daniel Doniger, Susan Pujalte and Nancy Turner, Michael, Jane and Paul Fishbin. Adored ''G.G.'' to eight greatgrandchildren. Longtime companion to the late Sam Sherward. Services Sunday, January 17, 1999, 12:30PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Small, Ornery and Good: Denver's Offensive Line
description: Their kangaroo court remains in session, though they lost two of their founding justices. They still sit in their own corner of the Denver Broncos' locker room, though they have relaxed their rules against talking to teammates and the news media. But the Broncos' offensive line is still undersized, still downright ornery and still very good.

title: Pink Flowers Are Ejected By Red Tape
description: Nancy Corio Zappola, a New York City police officer, turned 31 on Feb. 25, 1997. In the first hours of the following morning, after her 4 P.M. to midnight shift at the 62d Precinct in Brooklyn, she shared cake with her fellow officers and celebrated for a while. Then she set off in her car for her home in Eltingville, Staten Island. But a couple of dozen feet before her exit, at Muldoon Avenue on the West Shore Expressway, she fell asleep at the wheel. Her car veered off the road and crashed, killing her.

title: Word for Word/Representative James A. Traficant Jr.; Burping Cows and Space Toilets. Beam Me Up, Mr. Speaker!
description: PEOPLE just tuning in to Washington over the past year of sex, pizza and judicial racing stripes could be forgiven for wondering: Is Government usually this diverting?

title: Older Travelers Turn to Internet
description: ELDERHOSTEL and Interhostel, which offer travel for vigorous older people, have entered cyberspace, putting their catalogues on Web sites. And in November, Elderhostel began taking registrations electronically through its site.

title: Big Bang From a Quiet Warrior
description: IN 1968, while working on his doctorate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Kenan Sahin taught courses at the Sloan School of Management. Brimming with theories on information technology and operations management, Mr. Sahin, then 26, strode into a classroom of prominent business executives one day -- only to be completely ignored. ''They thought I was the teaching assistant who had come in to erase the board,'' he recalled. He had to pound the table to get their attention.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Times Square Jr.

title: The Duke on Disk, Live, Loosened and Otherwise
description: IN the mid-1970's, the critic Leonard Feather included the following in his liner notes to what was then a three-LP set, ''The Duke Ellington Carnegie Hall Concerts -- January 1943'':

title: Corrections
description: The Economic View column last Sunday, about interest-rate issues facing the Federal Reserve, misstated an estimate from Macroeconomic Advisers Inc. of how a 30 percent decline in stock prices over 12 weeks would reduce economic growth. The estimated decline is 1.8 percentage points, not 2.3.

title: The Gas Company as Social Worker; Brooklyn Utility Tries Softer Approach to Pursue Unpaid Bills
description: Two years ago, Joy Chatel appeared in Civil Court in Brooklyn to account for her $7,000 unpaid gas bill. A contractor had bilked her out of $40,000, she told the judge, forcing her to close her beauty parlor. She had no income and four grandchildren to raise. When her husband died about this same time, she had to barter two years of free hairstyling for a proper funeral.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Whitney Winslow Pickering and Hamilton Wallace Bullard omitted the bridegroom's education. He graduated cum laude from St. Lawrence University.

title: Lights, Action, Discontent
description: The intricately carved limestone and brick row houses that line Hamilton Terrace and Convent Avenue from 141st to 145th Street recall a time when horse-drawn carriages plied these streets. But residents of the area say the modern lampposts do little to enhance the neighborhood's 19th-century ambiance.

title: MUSIC; The Ellington Year
description: TO celebrate the 100th anniversary of Duke Ellington's birth, cultural organizations nationwide will present programs in his honor throughout the year. Here are a few highlights:

title: What the County Executive Has Done for Seniors
description: The profile on County Executive Andrew J. Spano [''The County Executive After Round 1,'' Jan. 3] was a well-balanced annual report on Mr. Spano's first year in office. But the article failed to address Mr. Spano's creative vision and advocacy for senior citizens in Westchester County.

title: Saying Goodbye, Good Riddance To Silicon Valley
description: UNTIL last year, Geoff Goodfellow was a Silicon Valley Wunderkind, a pioneer in the field of wireless electronic mail. Now, as a resident of the Czech Republic, he wakes up each day and gazes from the balcony of his loft over a jumble of rooftops at the Prague Castle on a nearby hill.

title: Stanford to Reopen Museum After 10 Years
description: Stanford University's renovated and expanded museum -- home to the largest Rodin collection outside the Musee Rodin in Paris -- will reopen next Sunday after having been closed for nearly 10 years.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about the Cathedral of St. John the Divine reversed the identities of the present and former Deans of the cathedral. The current Dean, the Very Rev. Harry H. Pritchett Jr., was at the left; the former one the Very Rev. James Parks Morton, was at the right.

title: Q&A;/Marcia Lieberman; The Senator, According to Mom
description: NO one has to remind Senator Joseph I. Lieberman to call home. He phones his 84-year-old mother, Marcia Lieberman, in Stamford, every day.''I call her for selfish reasons,'' he says. ''She's always encouraging and she always has perspective.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMPSEY, DAVID KNAPP
description: DEMPSEY-David Knapp. Of Rye, New York. Died January 13, 1999. He was the husband of the late Evangeline Dempsey, and father of Ian Dempsey, of New York City, the late David Kevin Dempsey, and Karen Dempsey McKelvey. Memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: The Rye Free Reading Room.

title: Stroller Weight Training
description: A recurring nightmare: You wheel a stroller draped with shopping bags and baby gear into a restaurant, free your progeny, and the contraption tips backward, scattering packages, toys and irate waiters. After one too many such mortifying upsets, Jill Schlamm invented Tip Me Not. Two soft 1 3/4-pound weights -- much like wrist or ankle weights -- wrap above the stroller's front wheels with Velcro and provide a counterbalance for parental baggage on the handles. In a test run, Tip Me Not supported a fully loaded diaper bag, three Barney videos, a wool sweater and two large bottles of San Pellegrino (14 1/2 pounds). The addition of a folding umbrella pushed it over the edge. Even if the device ($15.95 from 877-847-6366) didn't balance out the 20 pounds it promised to, for frazzled parents, every bit of added ballast counts. ELLEN TIEN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FATT, ARTHUR C.
description: FATT-Arthur C. 94. Of New York City and Delray Beach, Fla. Died Tuesday evening, January 12, 1999 after a long illness. Beloved husband of the late Barbara C., proud father of Marjorie Chester and Barbara Costikyan both of New York City, grandfather of Nancy Cedillo of Madrid, Spain, Priscilla Majcherska of East Hampton, L.I., Jonathan Heine of Chappaqua, N.Y., Christopher Chester of New York City and Katherine Chester of Bristol, R.I. Great-grandfather of four. A recognized pioneer in the field of advertising, he and the late Lawrence Valenstein founded The Grey Advertising Agency in 1921 and named the company for the color of the walls of their third floor walk-up office. Some of his happiest days were spent at his beloved home in Mallorca where he and his wife, Barbara, joyously hosted family and friends. Services and interment private. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANOCHERIAN, ESKANDAR
description: MANOCHERIAN-Eskandar. It is with great sorrow that the Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Eskandar Manocherian, a prominent businessman and a dedicated friend to the Jewish community. Our deepest sympathies go to: his children Jeffrey and Cynthia, longtime supporters of UJA-Federation, Dr. Darel M. and Carlos Benaim, and Donald and Zaza; his brothers, Amir, Fraydun, and Touran; his sister, Lori; his many grandchildren; his cherished friend, Barbara Levey; and to the entire family. May you be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S.Tisch, President Andrew J. Singer, Chair, Real Estate Division Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: Restless
description: I don't know what Penn is angry about. I'm the one who should be angry. Last year I walked out after watching 35 minutes of ''She's So Lovely.'' That didn't prepare me for ''Hurlyburly,'' a dull mishmash of stilted dialogue, frenzied acting and a noninvolving story line. Penn should stop driving across the country and use the time to find a script worthy of his talent.

title: Transit Agencies Fight Over Control
description: WITH 17,000 daily riders, the bus system serving the Bridgeport area is the largest regional transit district in Connecticut. Only the state-operated bus lines in Hartford and New Haven transport more daily commuters.

title: The Furby: Hot Toy Turned Electro-Menace
description: As the must-have, can't-find toy sensation of the 1998 holiday season, the Furby, a vaguely owl-like stuffed critter with an electronic voice, seemed to be a threat to nothing but the wallets and emotional equilibrium of desperately shopping parents.

title: Sean Rice and Heather Cox
description: Heather Lynne Cox, the daughter of Roberta and Gary Cox of Fairfax Station, Va., was married yesterday to Sean Kevin Rice, the son of Marie and John Rice of Lexington, Ky. The Rev. Park Bodie performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LATINI, COUNTESS STELLA DE LUCA
description: LATINI-Countess Stella De Luca. On January 1, 1999, in her 83rd year. A native of NYC, where she was living at the time of her death, she had resided for 40 years in Rome, Italy, where she and her husband, the late Count Guido Latini di Mogliano, were Directors of the American College of Rome, which they founded.

title: Sports of The Times; For Field-Goal Kickers, It's a Matter of 3 Points, Not Style Points
description: FOR today's American Football Conference championship game, the marquee is crowded: Bill Parcells's opportunity to lead the Jets to the Super Bowl, John Elway's likely last game in Mile High Stadium, Vinny Testaverde's new life, Terrell Davis's galloping, Curtis Martin's workhorse burden, Shannon Sharpe's trash talk, Keyshawn Johnson's versatility, Mike Shanahan's reputation as the Broncos' ''genius'' coach.

description: Here's how they handle a sex scandal involving an elected official and an office intern in Indiana:

title: COVER STORY; Seeing Bloody Sunday Through a Child's Eyes
description: THE television film ''Selma, Lord, Selma,'' about the brief yet poignant participation of two African-American girls in the civil rights movement, fittingly opens with shots of the Edmund Pettus Bridge as a gospel-steeped wail rings out over the Old South.

title: Panthers Score First and Isles, of Course, Fold Their Tent
description: Frustration. That has become the Islanders' byword, and tonight they received yet another dose of it.

title: Latin American Fare Marking King Day at Purchase
description: FOR seven Januaries, the Westchester Philharmonic has sought to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. with vocal and instrumental presentations that, as the music director, Paul Lustig Dunkel, put it, ''celebrate the universality of his message of nonviolence and racial harmony, while benefiting 18 local human-service organizations that continue his work.''

title: Surprises in the Aisles Of Fund Supermarkets
description: WHY would an investor spend a lot of time researching which fund to buy, go to a discount broker to buy it and then end up paying a sales charge?

description: NEW YORK

title: A Box of Wonders
description: Riding on a train to Vienna in search of her runaway husband, a Canadian art historian named Helen Martin enters a twilight world of strange hallucinations, astounding coincidences and deadly conundrums. Awakening in the middle of the night, Helen finds herself sharing a compartment with an old woman named Rosa Kovslovsky, who is somehow linked to her -- so closely linked that Anna starts to believe her own body parts are being replaced by Rosa's. Then this odd companion hands her a small box full of wonders and clues, which will accompany Helen on a tour of Europe in search of much more than her missing spouse. The box contains a book on human anatomy, jewels and notes. And, in a nice twist, the design of Barbara Hodgson's novel THE SENSUALIST (Chronicle, $22.95) incorporates all these visual aids. As readers follow Helen, we see the same images she is seeing: illustrated plates from ancient anatomy texts, medicine vials, a pearl-studded picture frame. Like the historical works she researches, Helen's box -- and Hodgson's book -- provides a way of interweaving ''the significance of the words with the importance of the pictures.'' Helen soon finds herself embroiled in a historical mystery as printing blocks from the works of the anatomist Vesalius seem to have resurfaced long after they were reportedly destroyed in World War II. Helen's husband was on their trail, and she quickly resumes his quest. ''The Sensualist'' is a quirky and intense novel, full of weird events and oddball characters (a man who is interviewing every person in the Vienna telephone directory; a doctor who is inspired to become a train conductor when the conductor on his own train drops dead) built around an investigation of the senses. The best part is Hodgson's combination of pictures and text: as a physical object, ''The Sensualist'' becomes an integral part of the plot, guiding the reader as the complex narrative unravels. Erik Burns

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIFFORD, JAMES P.
description: GIFFORD-James P. The Board of Directors, Members and Staff of the New York City Partnership note with deep sadness the passing of James P. Gifford. As Executive Vice-President of the Partnership for almost a decade, Jim played a critical role in creating the legislative and political strategy that transformed New York's financial condition, economic prospects and increased the availability of affordable housing. His work was always characterized by intelligence, compassion and decency. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman

title: Corrections
description: A music listing on page 41 of the Arts & Leisure section today misstates the location for the recital on Wednesday by Christian Gerhaher, baritone. It is Weill Recital Hall, not Carnegie Hall.

title: Warmth, but No Walls, in This Incubator
description: MAURY WILLMAN says her start-up ergonomics company is receiving valuable services from a local business incubator group, even if they don't include one usual benefit: office space at reduced rents.

Reposing at QuinnFogarty Funeral Home, 162-14 Sanford Avenue Flushing. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 9:45 A.M., Mary's Nativity RC Church. Visitation Monday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM.

William served on various committees over the years and has been a member of the Society since 1983. Sincere condolences are sent to his family and the membership will miss him. Matthew V. title: Thomas Binford, 74, Executive Who Guided Indianapolis 500
description: Thomas W. Binford, an Indianapolis businessman who was a co-founder of that city's Urban League and who helped steer the Indianapolis 500 through two crises, died on Thursday in Indianapolis. He was 74.

title: Carry-On Squabbles Plague Airlines
description: THE major airlines are fighting one another over how many bags, and what size bags, passengers may carry on board. But instead of being pawns in the latest airline wars -- in which Continental is suing Delta, and the biggest flight attendant union is asking the Government to impose a uniform carry-on rule -- passengers can take some steps to improve their chances of getting their bags on board if they understand what's behind the battles.

title: Sports of The Times; Wilt or Kareem? Chris or Martina?
description: SPORTS fans, a compulsive lot, love their lists. The other day I found myself standing in front of the rather forlorn-looking N.B.A. store on Fifth Avenue evaluating a montage of the alleged 50 greatest players in National Basketball Association history and saying out loud, ''Jerry Lucas???''

title: Museum Traffic Gets Growls
description: Two years ago, the American Museum of Natural History began work on a new underground garage that will have room for 370 cars and 16 buses when it is completed by early 2000. Though museum officials say it should help alleviate traffic and parking problems on streets surrounding the museum, which covers the blocks from 77th to 81st Street, there are no parking facilities for museum visitors in the meantime, and neighbors are getting irritated.

description: If you were going to commit a crime, wouldn't it be nice to have the former chief of detectives from the local police on your staff?

description: After more than 30 years of marriage, Norm wanted a quick divorce. He and his wife, the parents of three grown children, had grown apart, as it is often put. He was eager to move on.

title: City-Bound Traffic Hit Record Volume Last Year
description: Those who have come to expect to spend 45 minutes approaching the toll booth would not be surprised at a figure released last week by Port Authority of New York and New Jersey: the number of vehicles crossing the Hudson River from New Jersey to New York City grew by 2.9 percent last year to a record 121.4 million crossings.

description: Both offenses in the American Football Conference championship game on Sunday will slyly attempt to create mismatches, either by formation or by movement. Then both will try to take those mismatches and burn the defenses. All day long.

description: SOBEL-Harold, M.D. The family of Dr. Harold Sobel deeply regrets his passing, January 12, 1999.

title: Growth of Gambling on Tribal Land Starts Trek Back Home by Indians
description: Coming home to Indian country from suburban life after 16 years, Carl Edwards recently lifted his young daughters through a window of their new house on Gunlock Lake here, and let their little feet prance on the stiffening concrete, leaving symbols of permanence.

title: Kurdish Rebel Leader, Who Is Wanted by Turkey, Leaves Italy
description: A Kurdish rebel leader wanted by the Turkish Government for terrorism left Italy tonight, the Italian Government announced. The destination of the Kurd, Abdullah Ocalan, was not disclosed.

title: Second Atlantic City Casino Set for Marina District
description: Boyd Gaming Corporation announced last week that it will break ground in the fall on a $750 million, 1,500-room casino called Borgata, to be built on 25 acres of leased land in the city's marina district. The project, first announced in 1996, had been delayed because of squabbles with its landlord, Mirage Resorts, and opposition by residents and competing casinos to a $330 million tunnel linking the district with the Atlantic City Expressway. Mirage Resorts and Boyd Gaming, both based in Las Vegas, refused to build their casinos until work on the tunnel began. The tunnel is expected to be finished by the beginning of 2001, and the hotels by summer of 2002. BILL KENT
