title: The Nation: Raising the Bar; Testing the Competence of Competence Testing
description: PUBLIC opinion surveys show that most Americans want to know, in a systematic way, how well their children and their children's teachers are doing in school. So many states have been scrambling to impose new layers of standardized tests on students, as well as on prospective teachers.

title: Look at Grounds To Impeach First
description: To the Editor:

title: Children's Books
description: BEYOND THE MANGO TREE

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY; A Legendary Leipzig Coffeehouse Reopens
description: The renovated Arabic Coffe Baum in Leipzig, Germany, reopened in November after having been closed for seven years. Famous for the artists and intellectuals who frequented it, including the composers Richard Wagner and Robert Schumann, the Coffe Baum is, along with the Procope in Paris, the birthplace of the European coffee tradition.

title: Farewell, Traveller's Books
description: Constance Christensen had just purchased a few books on Friday, but she couldn't leave the Traveller's Bookstore without saying a few words to its owner, Diana Wells, who is closing the place down.

title: BEST SELLERS: January 17, 1999
description: Weeks

title: House Prosecutors Compare Clinton to Judges Who Lied and Were Ousted
description: In 1989, the Senate removed Judge Walter L. Nixon Jr. of Mississippi from the bench for lying before a Federal grand jury. ''A single, discreet false statement,'' Senator Herb Kohl, a Wisconsin Democrat, called it. But it was enough for the Senate to convict him, 89 to 8.

title: Panel to Review Pay Of City Officials
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani named a commission yesterday to review and recommend changes in the salaries for himself and the city's other top elected officials.

title: When Doing Nothing Accomplishes Plenty
description: EVERY year around this time, the cry is heard on Capitol Hill: Let's put aside partisan politics and get down to dealing with the issues of real concern to the American people.

title: DIALOGUE: How Has 'The Organization Man' Aged?; Nostalgia's Illusions
description: William H. Whyte, who died last week, lived long enough to achieve a paradoxical fate for a social critic: the world he once criticized had become the good old days.

title: SHOPPING WITH: Valerie Steele; High-Heeled Historian Exalts the Shoe
description: ON a wintry Saturday, with the rain just letting up but the sky still chalky, Valerie Steele, chief curator of the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology, saw the summer sandal of her dreams.

title: Unity Assembled From Bits and Pieces
description: COLLAGE, the art of making pictorial compositions out of bits of found materials glued to a background, began as a pastime for amateurs and children. And even after modernists made collage one of their primary tools, there remained a division between those artists who value collage mainly for its ability to produce surprising juxtapositions of familiar images, and therefore remain close in spirit to the medium's pre-artistic origins, and those who desire to transform their raw materials, often the cast-off dross of daily business, alchemically into something completely different. For these artists, there should, ideally, be no more reference to the materials' original identity than is necessary to serve as a reminder that something has, after all, been transformed.

title: In Philadelphia, Center City Towers Get New Uses
description: Stimulated by a 1997 city tax abatement for conversion of older commercial buildings, there has been a rise in the renovation of downtown towers. About a dozen buildings have taken advantage of the abatement, and when all completed they are expected to add about 1,000 apartments to the city's inventory.

title: Music: Ellington Emerges, Falters and Triumphs; Catching The Spirit Of a Century
description: WHAT a world to step into, if you were inquisitive. And at the beginning of the 1920's, Duke Ellington, touched by genius and ambition, prepared by education and class privilege, walked into the 20th century. Imagine it from the perspective of a young musician: the recording industry was flowering, radio had burst onto the scene. Suddenly it was possible to live in Mississippi and know what was happening in New York.

title: Oral History
description: To the Editor:

title: FUNDS WATCH; Bidding Adieu to a Century
description: As the millennium draws to a close, so is time short for Twentieth Century, the former name of the Kansas City, Mo.-based American Century Investments and a moniker that still graces many of its funds. The company plans to drop Twentieth Century from all its fund names in March. The Benham name, which graces some of its other funds, will vanish, too.

title: Books and Authors With Roots on the Island; Water as a Partner During Life's Passages
description: CHARLES SIMMONS has always been in love with water. Today, Long Island Sound, which borders his farm in Mattituck, is the body of water most a part of his life. In his youth, it was the Atlantic Ocean at Breezy Point near Rockaway Beach, where his family had a bungalow. It was those languid seaside summers of his adolescence on which he drew for the coming-of-age portrait in his recent novel, ''Salt Water'' (Chronicle Books).

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: TRULY BLESSED

title: Blaming Wittgenstein
description: Language and Solitude

title: Flight From Justice
description: HERS might seem a righteous crusade. After all, she is the Governor of New Jersey and seeking the return of a ''cop killer,'' Assata Shakur, from Castro's Cuba. To Governor Whitman and state law enforcement, Ms. Shakur (previously Joanne D. Chesimard) is New Jersey's most wanted fugitive. In 1979, Ms. Shakur escaped from prison while serving a life sentence for the 1973 slaying of a state trooper, Werner Foerster, on the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLS, BILL
description: NICHOLS-Bill. '39 World's Fair usher, Navy man, Television Producer, Social Activist, Carribbean Ice Cream Entrepreneur. Husband of Janet. He lived brilliantly, and will be missed. The Hall Family

title: Standard American With Notable Spins
description: WHERE once stood the Towne House, a place for serious drinking, now there is Chadwick's, a place for serious eating.

title: Linking Up To Better Scarsdale
description: By pointing an Internet browser at www.scarsdalenet.com and clicking on the link to Better Scarsdale, anyone interested can find information about local political processes and a model for a Scarsdale civic organization. This material is in the public domain and may be used freely by anyone.

title: Children's Books
description: WHEN VERA WAS SICKWritten and illustratedby Vera Rosenberry.Holt, $15.95. (Ages 4 to 7)

title: Margot Leffler and Daniel Milberg
description: Margot Anne Leffler, a daughter of Susan and William Leffler of Manhattan, is to be married this evening to Daniel Robert Milberg, a son of Ellen and Leonard Milberg of Rye, N.Y. Cantor Bruce Ruben is to officiate at the Water's Edge, a restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Derrick Coleman Could Be the Next to Cash In
description: You can take unlimited salaries out of the new agreement, but you apparently can't stop the owners from overspending. If the Nets' Jayson Williams's deal (seven years, $100 million) was not a signal, the deal Derrick Coleman is about to sign in Charlotte is another indication of wild economic times ahead.

title: In March to Impeachment, The Making of a Partisan
description: No doubt a book will be written someday soon detailing the many cautionary tales of the 105th Congress, which just ended. It was a session marked by runaway partisan rancor, legislative gridlock and sex scandals, climaxing with the fall of a House Speaker and a Speaker-to-be and, of course, the impeachment of a President.

title: The View From/New Haven; Where Do Sleek Racing Sculls and Shells Come From?
description: ROWING is becoming more popular, which pleases Mike Vespoli. After all, he is a builder of racing sculls and shells in New Haven that bear his name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HENRY
description: COHEN-Henry. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York note with deep sorrow the death of Henry Cohen, a long-time friend and supporter. We were fortunate to benefit from his wisdom as a member of many important domestic and overseas committees. His pivotal role in the establishment of the Robert J. Milano Graduate School of Management and Urban Policy of New School University will be his enduring legacy. A dynamic professor and dean, he shaped the careers of a generation of loyal students by sharing his dedication to the future of our vital urban community. We convey our sincere condolences to his wife, Evelyn; his children, Alison and Edward Levy, and Daniel and Katherine Cohen; grandchildren Anna and Rosalie; and all the members of the family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: Jarrett Upsets N.C.A.A. Sprint Champ
description: Patrick Jarrett described himself as ''one of those athletes who would have been, should have been.''

title: Desperado
description: THE LIFE AND TIMES

title: The Argument for When a President Should Be Removed From Office
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by Representative Charles T. Canady, Republican of Florida, in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Reopening of Fishery For Baby Eels Is Stymied Until at Least Next Year
description: In 1997 on the Jersey Shore, the late-winter fishing season for baby eels was like a gold rush. By dark of night, thousands of fishermen flocked to coastal streams and estuaries to net the small, translucent creatures, worth as much as $350 a pound to buyers in Asia, where the eels are grown for food. Residents complained of trespassing, bullying and other disputes, and in one notorious incident a fisherman fired a shotgun at a rival's pickup truck.

title: Canadiens Still Have The Rangers' Number
description: Midway through the third period tonight, Wayne Gretzky picked up a loose puck behind the Montreal Canadiens' goal without a defender near him. As he looked left and right for an opening, the sold-out crowd at the Molson Center was anticipating something special.

title: Checking Airport Checkers
description: SCREENERS at airport security checkpoints miss weapons that undercover testers hide under their clothes, or they notice them but do nothing. Ticket agents forget to ask if passengers are carrying packages from strangers, or fail to react properly if the answer is yes. Airport employees don't single out passengers who buy tickets with cash at the last minute or otherwise act suspiciously. Ground crews leave airplanes unlocked and unattended, giving intruders an opportunity to plant a weapon or a bomb.

title: Paris Grand Prix
description: To the Editor: Nicholas O'Connell's ''Grand Prix Approach to Paris'' (Nov. 29) reminded me of our experience. We planned the route very carefully. After managing the roundabout off the ring road we headed for our hotel. Everything was going smoothly until our one-way inbound street suddenly became a one-way outbound. We were soon lost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, GLENDA
description: WILSON-Glenda, on January 15, 1999. Beloved wife of Robin. Loving mother of Siobhan and Christopher. For many years she was a fundraising consultant for UNICEF. Friends may call Sunday and Monday 2-5PM and 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Service Tuesday, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell. Contributions in her memory may be made to either UNICEF or Memorial Sloan-Kettering.

title: No. 1 for the Disabled
description: Because of its commitment to employing the disabled, Westchester has been named the ''local government customer of the year'' by New York State Industries for the Disabled, a state agency established in 1976. Five years ago, the state adopted legislation requiring local governments to buy office supplies and other items from Industries for the Disabled and to hire the disabled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISKIND, BUDDY D.
description: SISKIND-Buddy D. On January 15, 1999. Beloved husband of Pearl. Loving father of Adam and Jeffrey (Monica). Devoted brother of Howard. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday, 1 P.M.

title: Artists' Revenge for Surveillance
description: THE SETTING -- The Literary Book Club's Anarchist Forum, at the Brecht Forum on West 27th Street near the Avenue of the Americas on Tuesday night. Fifty people heard Bill Brown, founder of the Surveillance Camera Players, talk about his group's staging of abbreviated productions of philosophically charged plays and novels in front of security cameras, obstensibly for the edification of the police, security people and others. Of course, being anarchists, they also protest what they see as the state's growing intrusion into everyday life.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLUSHING

title: League Interested In Cooke's Bid
description: The National Football League's finance committee wants the trustees of the Jack Kent Cooke estate who sold the Washington Redskins and their stadium for $800 million last week to reconsider the unsuccessful bid submitted by John Kent Cooke, the Redskins' president and the son of the late owner.

title: Jets-Shmets, Giant Fans Say
description: New York sports fans, no doubt, are feeling terrific today. And why not? After years of heartache and embarrassment, the Jets have had an incredible season. After 30 years, they stand again on the verge of glory, with only the Denver Broncos to dispatch before, once again, the words Super Bowl and Jets can be uttered in the same sentence. The city has rallied to their cause. Everyone's a Jets fan, right?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMLIAN, REV. FR.
description: TOMLIAN-Rev. Fr. Robert J. on January 13, 1999. Beloved and longtime Pastor of St. John Nepomucene R.C. Church, 66th St. and First Ave NYC. Dear brother of Frank. Reposing at the church on Sunday and Monday, 2-7PM. Mass of the Holy Eucharist in Slovak on Monday at 7:30PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Tuesday at 10AM, celebrated by John Cardinal O'Connor. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. For further info, call Krtil Funeral Home-Yorkville Funeral Service 212-744-3084

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLANCY, ROBERT J.
description: CLANCY-Robert J. On January 16, 1999. Retired treasurer with the Theatre Development Fund. Beloved son of Mary Courneen Clancy and the late William G. Clancy. Loving brother of Dr. William G., Jr., James F., Janet Maturi, and the late Thomas V. Clancy. Also survived by his former wife Marguerite Clancy. Visitation Sunday 7-9 PM, and Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 9 AM, at the Church of St. Anselm.

title: Historian With Opposing View is Cited
description: For months, members of Congress have taken to quoting famous historians to back up their own views on the impeachment of President Clinton. Twice yesterday, for example, House Republicans, Steve Buyer of Indiana and Charles T. Canady of Florida, quoted the writings of Arthur Schlesinger Jr. to argue for Mr. Clinton's removal.

title: Michael Jordan, in the Leaving
description: To the Editor:

title: ON SUNDAY, JANUARY 17, 1999
description: ''I have a dream that my four little children will. . . .'' * Martin Luther King III, 41, is the fourth president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, founded by his father in 1957. * Yolanda Denise King, 43, an actress, played Medgar Evers's daughter, Reena, in ''Ghosts of Mississippi.'' * Dexter Scott King, 37, head of the King Center for Nonviolent Social Change, says he believes that James Earl Ray was not a knowledgeable conspirator in the 1968 assassination of his father but that L.B.J. was. * The Rev. Bernice Albertine King, 35, following in the pastoral footsteps of her father and grandfather, is a minister at the Greater Rising Star Baptist Church in Atlanta. * None of the King children have married. * Last year Dexter King made a deal to sell his father's words and image that is expected to increase the worth of the King estate -- valued at $66,492.22 in '68 -- from $30 million to $50 million.

title: Decision to Testify Haunted Boy Who Was Later Killed
description: At the Boys and Girls Club of Bridgeport, B. J. Brown was one of the most reliable and joyful leaders, always jumping up to take attendance or pass out craft supplies. He was only 7, but had the poise to ask a girl in his class if they could go on a date when he turned 10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUGATCH, MARCELLE
description: PUGATCH-Marcelle (Marcy). Beloved wife of Michael. Loving mother of Barry and Susan Pugatch and Irene and Ron Cohen. Cherished grandmother of Spencer, Dean, Randi and Samantha. Dear sister of Norman Stamm. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 10:30 AM, Sunday.

title: January 10-16; A New Look At the Right to Move
description: The Federal welfare revision of 1996 was notable for ending the concept of welfare as an entitlement, but a less noticed provision was perhaps even more radical. By letting states pay lower benefits to newcomers than to long-term residents, Congress challenged a long-held assumption about American citizenship: that people can move from state to state without being relegated to second-class status.

title: Suiting Up Men in Gentle Armor
description: A SALUTE is in order for Miuccia Prada. Her stark collection was hip, inventive and handsome, a salubrious ambrosia for men's fashion. In Milan this season, where the shows of men's clothes for fall 1999 ended on Wednesday, Ms. Prada was peerless.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: THE STORM

title: Saying Ciao To a Gelato Company
description: The Yankees and the Stock Exchange haven't left for New Jersey, but Ciao Bella, a gelato factory at 262 Mott Street (near Prince Street), is departing for Irvington, N.J., on Jan. 31.

title: Catch a Locomotive, Jump a Caboose and Take in the Towns Too
description: TWO exhibitions exploit model railroads ''Ride the Rails With Joe'' and ''Vintage Locomotives'' -- at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center here through Feb. 28.

title: Laxity in Laser Law Enforcement
description: MORE than six months after attracting national attention for banning the sale of laser pointers to minors, Westchester County has yet to enforce the law or even formally tell merchants about its provisions.

title: Edmund J. Pankau
description: A private investigator, he is the author of ''Hide Your Assets and Disappear'' (Regan Books).

title: Ideas & Trends: Dead Man Whining
description: LET'S face it. It's hard to live on $10 million or $20 million a year here.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCVITY, LEONARD H.
description: McVITY-Leonard H. January 17, 1997. Missed, never to be forgotten. Love, Frances

title: TriBeCa Dissent: A 'Postmodern Hulk'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Taste for Art Nouveau in Swedish Guise
description: IN 1972, Robert Schreiber, a New York entrepreneur, moved to Stockholm to sell Frye boots and bell-bottom jeans to descendants of the Vikings. His business flourished over the next five years, and he spent most of his profits on Art Nouveau objects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, FRED K.
description: SIEGEL-Fred K., 88, of Harrison, NY., and Palm Beach, FL. Died Thursday, January 14, 1999 after a long illness. Beloved husband for sixty years of Joan. Loving father of Kenneth and grandfather of Joseph and Eileen, father-in-law of Mary Claire, devoted brotherin-law of Ruth and Murray Schoen, loving uncle to Robert Schoen and Ronni Fitzgerald. He was a humanitarian and a philanthropist, former Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of National Shoes, Inc., a national retail shoe chain whose offices were in the Bronx NY. He will be fondly remembered by family and friends. Memorial services will be held in Palm Beach FL at Temple Israel in West Palm Beach Sunday, January 17 at 1 P.M. Graveside services will be in New York Tuesday, January 19 at 2 P.M. at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, Queens.

title: District Says School Construction Numbers Don't Add Up
description: When the Board of Education divvied up the $10.9 billion it plans to spend on construction, repair and renovation in the next five years, it allotted some districts hundreds of millions of dollars to build schools. District 15 was not among them.

title: Cadillac Keeps Its Sales Title
description: OUNTERING the expectations of analysts and even of its own executives, the Cadillac division of General Motors held onto first place in the luxury class last year -- but just barely.

title: Above the Battle, Musing on the Profundities
description: ''THE THIN RED LINE'' is a very odd movie. I think it one of the pinnacles of American filmmaking in the 1990's, but I can also appreciate the objections leveled against it by other film critics who were baffled, irritated or chagrined by this three-hour challenge. For one thing, the film had been so long-awaited (10 years in the making, by Terrence Malick, a maverick legendary for both the sparseness and self-consciousness of his output), that it could not help disappointing such hyped expectations. For another, what is actually on the screen is so singular, so peculiar, that there may not be many previous models by which to judge it.

title: Click for Customer Service. Then Wish You Hadn't.
description: IF on-line retailers steamrolled their way into the spotlight during the past holiday season, one thing is clear: They crushed a few toes along the way.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: THE HISTORY OF

title: Suit Filed to Challenge Disparities in Schools
description: THE New York Civil Liberties Union has filed a Federal lawsuit against the state to challenge disparities among school districts as a violation of minority students' civil rights.

title: Britain, of Two Minds, Contemplates Cromwell
description: The 400th anniversary of the birth of Oliver Cromwell, one of the most significant figures in British history, will be both celebrated and investigated in 1999.

title: Snip Off the Old Block
description: Classic uptown children's salons like Michael's, Cozy's Cuts and Paul Mole provide chairs shaped like cars, video monitors and diplomas for first cuts. Increasingly, though, parents are taking offspring to their own high-end stylists. Toddlers are appearing in posh salons like Frederic Fekkai (15 East 57th Street), where they can have their hair cut for $80; Pierre Michel (131 East 57th Street), $90, and AKS (694 Madison Avenue at 63d Street), $75.

title: Mets Are Talking to Watson
description: Allen Watson, a free-agent pitcher, would like to play for the hometown Mets. He is from New York and building a house here, and his agent reportedly has reached an agreement with the team on a one-year contract.

title: Small Businesses Like Ivan's Create a Neighborhood
description: To the Editor:

title: January 10-16; A Harsh Strategy For Breast Cancer
description: For women with a high risk of breast cancer, a report published last week offered hope, but at a cruel price. Removing both breasts while they are still healthy reduces the risk of getting breast cancer by 90 percent, according to a study of 639 women who had the surgery from 1960 to 1993 at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn.

title: From Britain, Friends (but Not 'Friends')
description: ANNA is a hard-smoking, tough-talking Scot who harbors a lusty crush on Miles, an old college classmate with whom she once enjoyed a one-night stand. Miles is arrogant and obnoxious, a little too proud of his good looks and studly ways. Milly and Egg are scrambling to make their long-term romance work, even though she is full of ambition and all he wants to do is lie around the house and watch soccer on television. Everyone -- except his parents -- knows that Warren is gay.

title: A Survival Course for the Sandwich Generation
description: AS a journalist, Carol Abaya covered an aborted Communist coup in Indonesia, the seizure of power by Ferdinand Marcos in the Philippines and race riots in Paterson.

title: Finding a Home Inside the Golden Door
description: BEAMING with pride of ownership, Jose and Paula Lora stood before their dark-red, split-level home in Teaneck, N.J., last weekend, a long way from the city of Santiago in the Dominican Republic and -- if not geographically, at least in their minds -- nearly as far from the cramped Bronx rental apartments in which they had lived since arriving in the United States a decade ago.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 45 of The Times Magazine today with an article about the fashion spokeswoman Carrie Donovan carries an erroneous credit for shoes. They are by Walter Steiger, not Stuart Weitzman. The caption also omits a credit for Ms. Donovan's hairstyling. It is by Craig Bryant for Thomas Morrissey Salon. A caption on page 47 omits the location of the photo session. It is the restaurant Balthazar.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GULKIN, ANITA KURMAN
description: GULKIN-Anita Kurman. Died November 8, 1998. Memorial Service, Wednesday, January 20 at 6 PM at New York University Law School, Vanderbilt Hall, at 40 Washington Square South.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAUTMAN, ADY
description: TRAUTMAN-Ady. Peacefully on January 15, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Edgar Trautman. Member Kehilath Jeshurun. Funeral Service Sunday, January 17 1PM at Beth El Cemetery in New Jersey. For info call Plaza Memorial 212-769-4400.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: Rude Behavior

title: Ideas & Trends: No Exit; The Trial May End, But the Trials Will Go On
description: WHETHER they want to see President Clinton driven from office or whether they have completely tuned out the Senate impeachment trial, Americans, on the first anniversary of the Monica S. Lewinsky scandal, do agree on one thing: They want it to be over.

title: Ward Is Displeased By Tenor of the Talks
description: The Knicks have made progress toward reaching an agreement to re-sign Charlie Ward, their starting point guard, but Ward indicated yesterday that he had been displeased with the team's impersonal approach throughout negotiations.

title: Cheri Grand, Todd Anderman
description: Cheri Robin Grand, a daughter of Carole and Allan Grand of East Brunswick, N.J., was married last evening to Todd Stuart Anderman, a son of Gloria Anderman of Coconut Creek, Fla., and Arthur Anderman of New York. Cantor Robert Abelson officiated at the Windows on the World restaurant in New York.

title: Feeling Uplifted by A Rocky Trip
description: IN the early morning light the monzogranite rock outcrops in Joshua Tree National Park look like enormous dollops of meringue browning in the desert sunshine. I'm driving to Turtle Rock, in late November, for the first day of a weekend rock-climbing course for beginners, and with great anticipation I realize that by day's end I will be climbing these seemingly smooth, soft-edged outcrops.

title: Full of Hot Air
description: Intrigued by Lobster Cappuccino, I started reading the recipe (Food: Molly O'Neill, Dec. 27). My eyes went wide at Step 3: ''To make the lobster broth and garnish, lay the live lobster on a cutting board. Place the tip of a large, heavy knife at the indentation where the carapace meets the head of the lobster, making sure the cutting blade is facing the lobster's eyes. Swiftly and forcefully, plunge the knife through the lobster until the knife hits the cutting board.''

title: Exotic Fare
description: To the Editor: Mary Cantwell's article took me back to a banquet in Suzhou, China, in 1987. Everyone at our table especially enjoyed tender, flavorful morsels of delicious black meat not translated on our menu. Upon inquiring, we were informed it was marinated breast of owl.

title: Strawberry Looking Forward to New Season
description: The gaunt figure who rode down the Canyon of Heroes after the Yankees won their 24th World Series is now back up to his playing weight of 215.

title: Books and Authors With Roots on the Island; Writing About Another And Finding One's Self
description: IN 1996 when an agent-friend asked Billie Fitzpatrick if she would be interested in collaborating with Chastity Bono on a book about coming out as a lesbian, her immediate answer was an enthusiastic, unqualified ''yes.''

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Virgil Thomson: Composer on the Aisle

title: Spilling The Beans On a Passion
description: AS they sipped Turkish saffron tea in the their daughter's coffee shop, David and Beverly Falzone seemed downright relieved. ''We locked her out of the house when she was 14,'' Mr. Falzone said. ''It was the hardest thing we ever did.''

title: Pamela Kurland, David Marchick
description: Pamela Kurland and David Matthew Marchick are to be married this evening by Rabbi Mark Kram at the Alexander Hotel in Miami Beach.

title: A NIGHT IN WITH: Patrick Demarchelier; Beautiful! Genial! Genius!
description: ASHLEY JUDD had been in the studio earlier in the day, and it sounded as if she had been a handful.

title: BABY PULSE; Child Hoods
description: Inspired by last season's ubiquitous hoodie fashions for adults, the Children's Place recently introduced Kids in the Hood, a streetwise line that features hoods on everything from microfiber jackets, $36, to fleece cardigans, left, $18. The chain is also experimenting with such trendy items as cargo pants, $18, and anoraks trimmed in fake fur, $42. Even gray has made the leap from runway to crib. ''You used to see gray only in the European children's lines,'' said Allison Grossman, the manager for trends at the Children's Place. ''But this season, it's become a very important color. In general, the time it takes for a trend to get from the runway to the kids' market has shrunk incredibly.''

title: Paper Chase: An Endless Quest for a Newsstand License
description: It sometimes seems to take forever to get things done in this city. Just ask Michael Hajovsky of Woodside, Queens, who has tried for a long time to get a newsstand license.

title: Restless
description: Tell Sean Penn that I'd road-trip with him any time. I've been thinking about doing a New York-to-San Francisco drive, and he could show me where all the Denny's are along the way.

title: Naked Came The Tiger. Brrrrr.
description: Sartorially speaking, there's Ivy League, and then there's Ivy League.

title: For Ailey Dance Company, Theater Is at Core
description: THE very name -- Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater -- suggests several varieties of food for thought. More than a nod to its founder, it implies its identity with American Dance -- whatever that might be -- and calls itself not Company or Troupe, but a media-blending term, Dance Theater.

title: Stephanie Faro, Frank Ruperto
description: Stephanie Faro, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore C. Faro of Bergenfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Frank Anthony Ruperto, a son of Kathleen Ruperto of Valhalla, N.Y., and the late Frank A. Ruperto. The Rev. Dr. Robert G. Stephanopoulos performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York. The Rev. David La Plante, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: Postings: 125,000 Square Feet on Hudson, North Moore and Beach Streets; For TriBeCa, a 49-Unit Condo
description: The legend ''Castree Building'' is still discernible on both sides of a sooty granite frieze halfway up the six-story landmarked building at the corner of North Moore and Hudson Streets in the TriBeCa West Historic District.

title: Overbooked
description: To the Editor: When a friend and I decided to spend a long weekend in Paris, I remembered the article that Caryn James had written (''A Regal Four Days in Paris,'' March 8) and called the Hotel d'Aubusson. I reserved a room with my credit card and received a signed confirmation back by fax that I took with me. I also called to confirm a few days before the trip since I had made the reservation several months earlier.

title: The Role of Bebop
description: To the Editor:

title: Miller Seething Over Fassel's 'No-Injured' Ban From the Team
description: Corey Miller spent more than seven years as a linebacker for the Giants. He played through severely sprained ankles and broken ribs and, most recently, had a bulging disk in his neck that threatened his spinal cord if he took another hard hit. Miller did not mind sacrificing his body because he was highly paid for it. And moreover, the Giants always treated him like family.

title: Q&A/Tony Parillo; Book on Michelangelo, Made for Children
description: TONY PARILLO learned who Michelangelo Buonarroti and Leonardo da Vinci were before he learned about George Washington and Abraham Lincoln. This early exposure to the great artists had a lasting impact on Mr. Parillo, creating in him a lifelong love for the art and culture of the Renaissance.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Wildlife Exhibition

title: Switching to New Jobs, Endangering Savings
description: A core tenet of this era of layoffs and diminished corporate loyalty is that workers must manage their careers aggressively, moving from company to company as they deem necessary. Indeed, Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the outplacement firm based in Chicago, reports that baby boomers -- the dominant age group in the work force -- have taken that idea to heart.

title: Sports of The Times; A High School Coach Finally Has His Day
description: TWELVE years. That is how long Bill Piner has waited to watch a game like today's, and right in his own living room.

title: 4 Cumberland County Towns Named an Enterprise Zone
description: Vineland, Millville, Bridgeton and the Port Norris section of Commercial Township, all in Cumberland County, were collectively designated last week as one of 20 new Federal economic empowerment zones.

title: Charter Schools: The Road Ahead
description: RAY MEISENHEIMER said the final straw was in 1996. ''Only 19.7 percent of the Central Islip School District's graduates received Regents diplomas,'' he said. ''As a parent whose children attend the schools in the district, this was unacceptable.'' He began looking into alternatives to conventional education for his two daughters, who are now in elementary school.

title: Who Said What
description: To the Editor:

title: Teacher's Pet
description: Amy and Isabelle

title: Money for Bike Paths Begins to Roll Out
description: Last year, Governor Whitman called for 2,000 miles of paths to be built in the state over the next decade. The state Department of Transportation last week awarded $7.3 million to 37 towns for the first 54.5 miles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMIDT, J. FREDERICK
description: SCHMIDT-J. Frederick. On January 14, 1999, of New Rochelle, NY. Survived by his beloved wife Dorothy (nee Walker), brother Joseph, niece Jane Gilligan and nephew Robert Walker. Eldest son of the late Catherine and Louis Schmidt. Beloved brother of the late Margaret, Louis Jr., John and George Schmidt. Family will receive friends at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY, Sunday & Monday 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial, Blessed Sacrament Church, New Rochelle, NY, Tuesday 9:30 AM. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Manhattan College.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Case of the Spies Without a Country
description: THROUGHOUT this murderous century, diplomats and dreamers have envisioned a world in which nations would transcend their boundaries, dispel their differences and band together to preserve peace against dictators and despots.

title: Disclaimers, Disclaimers
description: To the Editor:

title: And Baby Makes Two
description: SADIE ZHENZHEN ALPERSON delicately speared a baked ziti with one tine of her fork and with agonizing care fitted it into the narrow O of her mouth. She chewed, swallowed and barked: ''Bread. With but-ter.''

title: A Sex Sting Called 'Operation Losing Proposition'
description: Some men used to finding a bevy of prostitutes on 84th Street got a double surprise recently, finding only one and then discovering she was a police officer.

title: Article About Altar Wins Praise on Meaning
description: I am writing to you with reference to the article on Dec. 20 about the consecration of the new altar at St. Mary's Church (Church of the Immaculate Conception) in Yonkers (''As Bells Toll, a Church Celebration Takes Its Place in a City's Rebirth'').

title: January 10-16; Olympic Scandal Fallout
description: Last Thanksgiving, Salt Lake City's Mayor, Deedee Corradini, was letting slip to reporters that members of the International Olympic Committee were encouraging her to run for a third term, perhaps allowing her to preside over the 2002 Winter Olympics in Utah. But only two months later, the Olympic Committee is imploding over reports that Salt Lake got the games by bribing members with land deals, tuition payments, free surgical operations and contributions to political campaigns and charities.

title: Partisan Gulf Grows After Prosecutors Make Case
description: With the House managers' opening statements now behind them, senators from the two parties spilled out of the chamber this afternoon with sharply divided opinions about the strength of the prosecutors' case and where the trial should go from here.

title: After the Trying Early Years, Denver Savors Its Top Team
description: The Denver Broncos are the defending Super Bowl champions and one of the National Football League's most successful franchises over the last two decades. But the Broncos who will face the New York Jets on Sunday in the American Football Conference championship game first had to undergo a stunning makeover to evolve from crude league doormats to sophisticated champions.

title: January 10-16; Trash Talk From Giuliani
description: Perhaps eyeing higher office, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has roamed from California to New Hampshire touting his record of cleaning up New York. Now Mr. Giuliani is trying to spread something else around the country: surplus city garbage. New Jersey balked at his plan to ship trash there, and Virginia wants to block New York waste.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GOLDMAN, JANIS MERESMAN
description: GOLDMAN-Janis Meresman Our world will never be the same But we will always speak your name Remembering the love and joy you shared Reflecting your beauty and how deeply you cared.

title: Style; Cachet and Carrie
description: Here are a few clues that help you know you're an icon. Al Hirschfeld can draw you in four quick strokes. If your signature accessory was left at the scene of a grisly murder, you'd be framed. Your first name forces everyone else who has it to use her last name. There's a prize for your best drag look-alike at the Halloween parade. By those standards, Carrie Donovan, a former style editor of these pages and the current spokeswoman for Old Navy, is certainly iconic.

title: In the Senate, Realizing the Gravity of Task
description: When the final charges were fully heaped upon President Clinton as a man of ''subversive and dangerous conduct'' who must not ''remain in office with all his infamy,'' the Senate seemed a stunned court gravely taken with its task of judgment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIT, JESSIE
description: FEIT-Jessie (nee Kossoff). On January 13, nearing her 91st birthday. Mother of Joan Lamport. Grandmother of Harold A. and Joseph N. Great-grandmother of Alex, Jordan, Benjamin and Daniel. Widow of Frank Feit in 1988 and Harold A. Levey in 1940. Private services and interment at Mt. Nebo, Miami, FL.

title: January 10-16; Clinton Is Advised Not to Free Pollard
description: Last fall, President Clinton came under pressure from the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, to free Jonathan Pollard from the life sentence he is serving for spying for Israel. The President's key national security advisers now appear unanimous in urging the President to keep him locked up.

title: Decline and Fall of an Empire
description: TO understand the disarray and the quiet evolution transforming New Jersey's Mafia families today, you need look no further than Joseph ''Skinny Joe'' Merlino and Philip C. Abramo, two reputed mobsters who represent opposite ends of the underworld spectrum.

title: DIALOGUE: How Has 'The Organization Man' Aged; A Need To Belong
description: When it first appeared in 1956, William H. Whyte's ''The Organization Man'' hit a raw nerve. Four decades later, it is strange to note what slogans we remember from this classic and what wisdom we forget.

title: Running the Gamut In TriBeCa
description: ARQUA **

title: Clinton Says Giving Is a Tribute to King
description: President Clinton urged Americans today to honor the memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. by providing public service, which he described as ''the highest calling.''

title: Working With Owners Of Historic Properties
description: Your article ''Future is Cloudy for Another Historic House'' [Jan. 3], concerning the East Farm property, seemed to have as its focus the need to preserve historic properties regardless of the law or the wishes of the properties' owners. The article mentioned that David Acker paid $3.25 million dollars for East Farm and that according to law, he is free to do whatever he pleases with his purchase. As a local resident, I was very pleased to learn that Mr. Acker planned to preserve eight of the historically significant structures, and, more importantly, not subdivide the 30 acres of property.

title: Pinochet Without Hatred
description: Many years ago, I was asked whether I planned someday to write a novel about Pinochet. No, I said, because as a character he was insignificant. I need to retract that statement: one can say anything about him except that he is insignificant. The general has held Chile in his grip for 25 years and is still the most influential figure in the country. A decade after he stepped down from the presidency, the old dictator still holds the democratic Government hostage.

title: Chinese in the New Year
description: I reached into my bag for my wallet at the toll plaza, but before I could retrieve it, I hit upon a crumpled piece of paper containing my New Year's resolutions. Although I might never tackle this drastic list of improvements, I nevertheless view 1999 as very different from 1998 -- and thus the list remains nearby (at least for now).

title: Learning to Ride the Brazilian Roller-Coaster
description: THE lesson of Brazil's two devaluations last week is simple: If you are invested in emerging markets, accept the roller-coaster ride and make them only a small part of a well-diversified global portfolio. Or get out and stay out until you are sure that the uncertainty and volatility have settled down to a manageable level.

title: Ted Hustead Is Dead at 96; Built the Popular Wall Drug
description: Anybody who watched Ted Hustead roll into Wall, S.D., on a cattle truck in December 1931, his wife and 4-year-old son at his side, the family's entire stock of meager possessions piled in the back, would have needed quite a crystal ball to predict that by the time Mr. Hustead died two-thirds of a century later, the governor of South Dakota would be moved to open his annual state-of-the-state address with a tribute to the man who became a beloved South Dakota legend by turning a smalltown pharmacy named Wall Drug into the world's most popular drugstore.

title: An Attack on What Has Been Characterized as the 'So What?' Defense
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Following are excerpts from the presentation today by Representative Stephen E. Buyer, Republican of Indiana, in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Could the Body Take Down the Hammer?
description: For most of the 20th century, it seemed the sobriquet was in decline. These nicknames of affection or derision, from the French slang soubriquet,''a chuck under the chin,'' enlivened the political language of a previous era. From the American Fabius (Washington) to the Machiavelli of Massachusetts (John Adams) to the Sage of Monticello (Jefferson), American Presidents sported these monikers. Jackson was Old Hickory, and Grover Cleveland was the Man of Destiny to some, the Stuffed Prophet to others. Teddy Roosevelt was the Rough Rider.

title: The View From/White Plains; Students Prove That Politicians Should Act More Like Children
description: THE United States Senate had just convened to plan the format for the impeachment trial of President Clinton, but here in the County Office Building, some eighth graders from the Port Chester Middle School were learning their own lessons about legislative procedure -- on a far more local level.

title: Correction
description: The Word for Word column last Sunday, with excerpts from transcripts of conversations involving former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and Chinese and Soviet leaders, referred incompletely to the historical record of these talks. The personal papers Mr. Kissinger transferred to the Library of Congress and closed to public srutiny were copies of Government records of the talks. He does not control access to the originals or to other copies in Government agencies and archives, some of which have been declassified.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAZZA, MARIO
description: RAZZA-Mario. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Mario Razza, associated with The Times from 1927, until retiring in 1972.

title: Footnotes
description: Resources, references and the back story behind the story.

title: A Gift to My Father
description: I was not a Reaganite in the 1980's; I became one today. My eyes swelled with knowing tears as I read of Patti Davis's attempt to delight her father with a Christmas gift (Lives: Dec. 27). Alzheimer's stole my dad, too.

title: OPINION; Both Tax Relief and Good Schools
description: DURING the 11 years I was a New York State legislator I would walk door to door through my State Assembly District. The question I would hear over and over was ''Charlie, when is somebody going to do something to reduce my school taxes, they're forcing me out of my home?''

title: Three Artists Transcending Genres
description: FOR more than 75 years, the Silvermine Guild in New Canaan has established itself as an integral part of the Northeast's cultural scene.

title: Family of 'Ruined' Senator Recalls a Legacy of Honor
description: With President Clinton on trial for his political life, the name of Senator Edmund G. Ross of Kansas is apt to come up whenever people talk about courage, honor and duty.

title: A Brazilian Shot Heard Round the World
description: With Brazil as the fulcrum, the world's financial markets seesawed last week, plunging day after day, only to swing back up joyously on Friday, once the Brazilian Government decided to quit defending its currency, the real. Hoping the move will lead to falling interest rates, it will let the real float.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the Greenpoint Manufacturing and Design Center, a nonprofit venture that provides woodworkers and artists with low-cost work space, misidentified a man who works there. He is Paul Seide, a glass artist, not David Sweeny, the chief executive.

title: Entry-Level Tawny Port
description: Few dessert wines equal wood-aged tawny port in inducing feelings of well-being. The mellow nutty-caramel bouquet and flavor, satiny texture and delicate afterburn need only a languidly puffed H. Upmann cigar to pacify the id.

title: A Legend of French Film Whose Legacy Is Clarity
description: ROBERT BRESSON, the doyen of French filmmakers, keeps his Paris apartment at the western tip of the Ile St. Louis. From the small park in front of his building, a favorite site for cinephiles on Parisian pilgrimages, there is a magnificent view down the Seine, still a working river with its traffic of barges and tourist boats.

title: The Boom That Wasn't
description: The last two years have been fabulous years economically. Inflation has disappeared; unemployment, like murder, is down to levels not seen since the 1960's, and growth is a vigorous 4 percent. The stock market has made millionaires irrelevant. To be rich today, one has to be a billionaire. Nothing in the memories of those now alive compares with what has happened in 1997 and 1998. Even in the high-living 1980's, the misery index -- inflation plus unemployment -- was always far higher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, ALAN
description: ROBERTS-Alan. His humor and good counsel will always remain with us. To our dear friend, Shirlee, and Jeff and Melissa, we extend our deepest condolences. We are heartbroken and share your grief. Jerry and Honie

title: DEVILS
description: A flu virus infected three more members of the Devils over the last three days. So, instead of making the trip to San Jose with the rest of the team, Jason Arnott and Patrik Elias were left behind in New Jersey, and Vadim Sharifijanov fell ill before yesterday's practice, leaving the team with barely enough players to meet the Sharks this afternoon.

title: How Can We Stop Harassment in Classroom?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday with an article about educators trying to rebuild New York high school sports misidentified the instructor leading a salsa class. He was Carlos Mendoza, not Joe Featherston.

title: A Campaign for a No-Kill Policy For the Nation's Animal Shelters
description: When Richard Avanzino leads a tour of the headquarters of the San Francisco Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, he cannot help sounding terribly pleased.

title: M. Grossi, 74; Created Tether For Satellites
description: Dr. Mario Dario Grossi, a radio physicist and engineer who developed the concept of tethered satellites as well as the hardware that made such free-flying space maneuvers possible, died Jan. 11 at Boston Medical Center in Boston. He was 74 and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JANSON, GEORGE C.
description: JANSON-George C. Of Darien, CT on January 15, 1999. Wife of Cornelia Janson, father of Caroline Kavetas and Linda Will. Brother of Charlotte Hetzel, Dorothy Janson and Catherine Robson. Grandfather of three. Calling hours are Monday, January 18, 1999, from 3-6 PM at the Edward Lawrence Funeral Home, 2119 Post Road, Darien, CT. Funeral service will be Tuesday, January 19, 1999, at 10 AM at St. Michael's Lutheran Church, New Canaan, CT. Memorial donations may be made to The American Cancer Society, 1175 Post Road East Westport, CT 06880

title: Media Talk; No More 'Improvement,' Its 2 Stars Insist
description: Last winter Jerry Seinfeld told the world he was leaving his NBC hit comedy, ''Seinfeld.'' That kicked off the retrospectives.

title: Accounts
description: * Bayer Pursell L.L.C., Birmingham, Ala., a joint venture of the agricultural division of Bayer A. G. and Pursell Industries, a fertilizer maker, to BBDO South, Atlanta, part of Omnicom, as its first national agency of record. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated that they could be as much as $20 million.

title: Turkey's New Leader Vows April Elections, but Delay Is Possible
description: After easily winning a confidence vote in Parliament, Bulent Ecevit took office as Prime Minister today and pledged ''to take Turkey smoothly to elections on April 18.''

title: Compressed Data; Year 2000 Adds a Wrinkle To the Business of Merging
description: Once companies agree to merge, they always want to complete the process as quickly as possible. But the computer problems associated with the year 2000 have given them an added incentive. Take the expected merger of Lucent Technologies Inc. with Ascend Communications Inc., valued at almost $20 billion when it was announced last week.

title: Charter Schools Represent a Compromise in Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Revisiting a Watershed Era; Photo Show Reflects Turmoil of the Civil Rights Battle
description: Life seldom offers epiphanies. Yet Steven Kasher, the curator of the civil rights photography exhibition opening today at the 92d Street Y, can recall the slaying of three civil rights workers in Mississippi as a turning point for him.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BOWIE, WILLIAM
description: BOWIE-William 1/18/94 Bill, your spirit and sculpture live with us. Claire and Stan

title: Los Angeles Weighs Gun Sales Limit and a Possible Suit Against Manufacturers
description: The City Council is considering legislation to restrict handgun purchases while officials also debate whether to join a growing movement among cities to sue gun makers for contributing to handgun violence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, EDITH J.
description: HOFFMAN-Edith J. On January 16. Beloved wife of Lewis. Loving mother of Stefanie and Adam. Devoted daughter of Pauline Jacobson. Adored sister of Howard Jacobson, and dear sister-in-law of Kathryn. Services today, 12:15, at ''I.J. Morris, Inc.,'' 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY. For further information call 1-800-624-8282.

title: Mayor Urges West Side Subway Extension, Not East Side Line
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday described a plan to create five new subway routes under Second Avenue as ''something of a pipe dream,'' and said the city should first extend the No. 7 subway line to the site on Manhattan's West Side where he wants a football stadium built.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, ALAN A.
description: GOULD-Alan A. Died on January 12, 1999 in Tamarac, FL, at age 84. He was an accredited civil engineer at Harwood & Gould Consulting Engineers in Manhattan. Some of his projects included The Lever House-the first high-rise all glass exterior office building in New York City. Mr. Gould also worked on the U.S. Mission to the United Nations, the Hebrew Home for the Aged, The Charles River Park Urban Development Complex, and the U.S. Naval Air Museum in Pensacola, FL. Mr. Gould was a member of the National Council of Engineers in New York and Florida, and the American Engineering Arbitration Pannel. He was born in Manhattan to Abraham and Anna Kohn Goldfeder. Prior to moving to FL, he had lived in Danbury, CT. He is survived by his wife Sydell (nee Rubinger) of Tamarac, FL; two sons Richard of New Rochelle, and Kenneth of Jackson Heights; a brother David of California; and three grandchildren, Jacob age 16, Alexander age 14, and Conrad age 8. A memorial service was held on Friday, January 15 at 12 noon at the Zion Memorial Chapel of Westchester, 785 East Boston Post Rd., Mamaroneck, NY 10543. The family is requesting that donations be sent either to the American Heart Association, or to The Hospice Foundation of America at 777 17th Street, Miami Beach, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILCH, TODD DAVID
description: PILCH-Todd David. Age 37, a resident of Denver, CO, and formerly of Bay Shore. Died tragically in a skiing accident on January 15, 1999. Beloved husband of Lani. Loving father of Molly. Devoted son of Gloria Pilch and Milton Pilch. Adoring brother of Susan and Karen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSTEIN, JACK
description: ROSENSTEIN-Jack. On January 16, 1999. Beloved husband of Beatrice (nee Altshuler). Devoted father of Ilene and the late Lewis. Cherished grandfather of Matthew and Jenny Meier. Father-inlaw of Bradley Meier. Loving uncle to many nieces and nephews. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels,'' Forest Hills.

title: Sinn Fein Negotiator Predicts Success of Peace Talks for Ulster
description: Martin McGuinness, the chief negotiator for the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, said today that the growing crisis in the Northern Ireland peace effort would be resolved by the end of March, the target date for the British Government to return home rule powers to the northern British province of Ulster.

title: Ward May Test Offers, Agent Warns Knicks
description: The Knicks continue to test the resolve of Charlie Ward by not offering him a better deal than their backup point guard has, a stance that could leave the team without its starter when National Basketball Association training camps open this week.

title: Jets' Long Road Back to the Super Bowl Dead Ends in Denver
description: For more than half of today's American Football Conference championship game, the Jets could see all the way to Miami and the Super Bowl, the game that they had helped turn into one of the biggest spectacles in sports 30 years ago.

title: Elmont Comes to Life for Its Hometown Hero
description: As night fell on this working-class hamlet just over the Nassau border from Queens, the Testaverde family home looked like any other house here. The front window glowed blue.

title: Vicious Cycle of Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvey Miller, 63, Comedy Writer
description: Harvey Miller, a film and television comedy writer who was nominated for an Oscar for his collaboration on the 1980 movie ''Private Benjamin,'' died on Jan. 8 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 63 and had a second home in East Hampton, Long Island.

title: The Quest to Toilet-Train Toddlers
description: To the Editor:

title: Impeachment's Trickle-Down Effect
description: Forty years before the ''Impeach Clinton'' bumper stickers appeared, ''Impeach Earl Warren'' was a popular slogan along America's highways. The nominal provocation of the campaign against Chief Justice Warren was the Supreme Court's rather mild resistance to McCarthyism. Lurking just offstage was deep resentment of the Warren Court's decisions on desegregation and civil liberty issues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTHEWS, JANET (NEE MOCLAIR)
description: MATTHEWS-Janet (nee Moclair). On January 16, 1999 of Rye, NY. Wife of the late Edward C. Mother of Edward A. Sister of Helen Kennedy. Family will receive friends Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 10 AM, at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Xavier Society for the Blind, 154 East 23rd Street, New York, NY 10010.

title: Four Friends Try Again to Hide a College Prank That Turned Deadly
description: Rick Schroder is hot. Just a couple of months ago critics and viewers alike were having a good laugh over the prospect of his joining the cast of ABC's gritty police drama ''N.Y.P.D. Blue.'' How was a baby-faced blond former child actor going to fill the shoes of Jimmy Smits, who had brilliantly replaced David Caruso, who had been pretty brilliant himself?

title: WINTER SPORTS: ROUNDUP
description: WOMEN'S SLALOM

title: An Amateur's Love Might Cure the Common Cough
description: The spate of coughing and hacking that caused the conductor Kurt Masur to stalk offstage during a New York Philharmonic concert last month was ascribed to the usual culprits: inattentive audiences, rampant viruses and dull performances. But the medical problem, which is widespread, may be more serious than the absence of manners or cough drops. The coughing may even herald substantive quakes in the world of art music.

title: Compressed Data; Bug Watcher Sees the Pests Outrunning the Exterminators
description: Bruce Brown makes his livelihood hectoring the software industry to shape up and then honoring the companies that do. But this year, for the first time, he has decided to cancel his annual award for the most improved software performance.

title: New York's Voice Grows Fainter on Congress; Loss of Major Players Threatens to Erode State's Ability to Get Federal Aid
description: No one ever said it was easy being a member of Congress from New York State, with all those stereotypes to overcome. Too liberal. Too greedy. Too pushy. Too New York City. (Even if you are from Buffalo.)

title: Underneath the Amusement, Concern for a Nation Detached
description: There he stood today, on the back page of the Suddeutsche Zeitung, the American President dressed only in heart-adorned boxer shorts, clutching a glass of champagne in his right hand and Monica Lewinsky in his left hand.

title: An Almost-Super Sunday
description: Super Bowl Sunday, in two weeks, will have to summon up some heavy-duty drama to match yesterday's conference finals, which produced one big upset and two tense, competitive games. Sadly for New York fans, the Jets' remarkable season came to an end with a 23-10 loss to the Broncos on a cold, windy afternoon in Denver. Repeated turnovers -- fumbles, a botched kickoff return, two interceptions -- destroyed whatever hopes they had of reaching their first Super Bowl in 30 years. The Jets needed a mistake-free game to beat last year's Super Bowl champions, and they did not deliver.

title: New Reading Test Was Worth All the Anxiety, Experts Say
description: At school-bus stops and in playgrounds, parents across New York State greeted their fourth graders for three days in a row last week with the same question: ''How was the test?'' Now, as everyone emerges from the rocky debut of the feared and heralded fourth-grade English test, the state's first major new test in a decade, education officials are being forced to confront a painful version of the same question: Was it a good test, or was it hopelessly compromised?

title: Media Talk; Actor Sues Magazine Over Fashion Spread
description: The actor Dustin Hoffman was in Federal court last week pressing a lawsuit against Los Angeles magazine. The problem: the magazine's use of his face in a fashion spread.

title: Gayle Young, 63, A Ballet Dancer
description: Gayle Young, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater who partnered such leading ballerinas as Margot Fonteyn and Cynthia Gregory, died on Jan. 8 at Cottage Hospital in Woodsville, N.H. He was 63 and lived in Haverhill, N.H.

title: Corrections
description: A list of credits on Wednesday with a television review of ''The Noel Coward Story,'' a documentary on PBS in the ''Great Performances'' series, gave two incorrect names. The producer and director was Adam Low, not Adam Wall. The executive producer was Anthony Wall; Jac Venza is overall executive producer for the series.

title: Jet Returns to Kennedy With Engine on Fire
description: A Tower Air 747 bound for San Francisco turned around in midair and returned to Kennedy International Airport last night after an engine caught fire, officials said. The plane's 267 passengers were grounded until this afternoon.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Now let me see if I got it right. I come up to New York and I spend my hard-earned money and somehow in exchange for that privilege, I am supposed to take your trash?''

title: Ecstasy and Infamy From 38 Yards Away
description: Gary Anderson and Morten Andersen had their fates, the fates of the Minnesota Vikings and the Atlanta Falcons and an invitation to the Super Bowl decided on the same piece of artificial turf at the Metrodome today. Thirty-eight yards from the western goal post was where a field-goal kicker named Anderson floundered and a field-goal kicker named Andersen flourished.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Wednesday about effects of Michael Jordan's retirement on the television networks and on National Basketball Association merchandising misstated the name of the editor of Sporting Goods Business, a trade magazine, and misstated its estimate of the N.B.A.'s licensed merchandise sales for 1998. The editor is Cory Bronson, not Corey Brown. The estimate was $1.7 billion, not $2.3 billion.

title: Storm Victims Surge North, With U.S. as Goal
description: About every two days, a cargo train loaded with fuel and other supplies arrives in this city near Mexico's border with Guatemala. It heads back north after sundown, empty but for the human cargo clinging to its sides.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEREGA, AL
description: ZEREGA-Al. Beach Point Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of Al Zerega, an employee of more than 50 years. Al was a friend to generations of club members who will miss his familiar face and wonderful stories of their own, and the club's early history. He will long be remembered as an integral part of the Beach Point family. Beach Point Club Paul N. Gardner, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, FRED K.
description: SIEGEL-Fred K., 88, of Harrison, NY., and Palm Beach, FL. Died Thursday, January 14, 1999 after a long illness. Beloved husband for sixty years of Joan. Loving father of Kenneth and grandfather of Joseph and Eileen, father-in-law of Mary Claire, devoted brotherin-law of Ruth and Murray Schoen, loving uncle to Robert Schoen and Ronni Fitzgerald. He was a humanitarian and a philanthropist, former Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of National Shoes, Inc., a national retail shoe chain whose offices were in the Bronx NY. He will be fondly remembered by family and friends. Memorial services will be held in Palm Beach FL at Temple Israel in West Palm Beach Sunday, January 17 at 1 P.M. Graveside services will be in New York Tuesday, January 19 at 2 P.M. at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, Queens.

title: One Punch, and Tyson's Comeback Survives
description: With one electrifying shot, Mike Tyson jolted his career as a heavyweight boxer back to life at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas, Nev., on Saturday night. Now comes the hard part: keeping it going.

title: The Broncos Hitch Themselves to Davis's Bright Star and Take Off
description: John Elway got the victory lap around the field after today's American Football Conference championship game, his adoring fans at Mile High Stadium cheering him for perhaps the final time here. The man who made the victory possible, Terrell Davis, got ice on his powerful legs. But Davis was hardly forgotten.

title: Mosaic Is Ready For Rush Hour
description: For the last two weeks, more than a dozen artists, artisans and workers in Battery Park City have been on their hands and knees piecing together one of the largest pieces of subway art in New York history -- an oval-shaped mosaic the length of a city bus containing more than one million bits of Venetian glass and Italian marble, each rectangle smaller than a fingernail.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Equity Offerings Are Set
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDLER, BERNARD, ESQ.
description: SEIDLER-Bernard, Esq. Age 72 years. Beloved husband of Phyllis (nee Gelb). Devoted father of Wael Nishry and Beth. Loving brother of Morris and Rose Rabin. Also survived by four cherished grandchildren. For additional information call Scotto Funeral Home, 718-875-2515.

title: Dead Dream: Brazil's Plan Is Blocked
description: On the trading floor of the Sao Paulo stock exchange, it led to a breathtaking buying spree. In Washington, officials were relieved. But in Brazil, the Government's decision to stop protecting the currency that beat hyperinflation signaled the end of a celebrated monetary plan that promised to transform Latin America's biggest country into a modern nation.

title: Essay; Cast Of Character
description: Theodore Kheel, the great New York labor mediator, dropped by the other day to tell me about the ''industry university'' movement. Ted's in his 80's now, cheerfully vigorous as ever, and is getting unions and corporations together to help his foundation finance at-home ''distance learning'' for workers via the Internet.

title: They Start By Waiting
description: Commissioner Paul Tagliabue delayed the Jets-Broncos start for 10 minutes, from 4:05 P.M. Eastern time to 4:15, because the National Football Conference championship game between Atlanta and Minnesota had gone into overtime. The kickoff came at 4:17 P.M. -- the moment Atlanta won on a field goal.

title: Careful Plans to Dismantle Case Against the President
description: President Clinton's lawyers are preparing a defense to the Senate on Tuesday that broadly attacks the prosecution case presented by the House managers on the facts, on the law, on the Constitution and even on history.

title: Some Midstream Hits for the Networks
description: Maybe network television can still produce hits after all. In the space of five days, three networks started new series and all of them scored ratings that would qualify them as significant hits, by far the biggest new hits of what has been a woebegone television season, if they hold up.

title: THE BRONCOS PLAY LIKE CHAMPIONS
description: Like picking a lock, like cracking a safe, the Denver Broncos tried a variety of combinations on the Jets. The Broncos brought a slick plan and sly hands and crafty tools. But nothing was working. The Jets were leading, 10-0, with 11 minutes 56 seconds left in the third quarter of the American Football Conference championship game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, GLENDA
description: WILSON-Glenda, on January 15, 1999. Beloved wife of Robin. Loving mother of Siobhan and Christopher. For many years she was a fundraising consultant for UNICEF. Friends may call Sunday and Monday 2-5PM and 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Service Tuesday, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell. Contributions in her memory may be made to either UNICEF or Memorial Sloan-Kettering.

title: Advocates Preparing For Trial's Next Stage
description: After three days of what experts said were the strongest legal arguments yet for the removal of President Clinton, Republicans and Democrats debated the strength of the case against the President, and Democrats warned anew that calling witnesses would prolong his impeachment trial.

title: To Chief of Airtouch, a Deal Seizes a 'Bell Opportunity'
description: Sam Ginn's gamble has paid off, hugely.

title: Senators Give Views on Merits of Case and Witnesses
description: With the White House set to open President Clinton's defense before the Senate on Tuesday, Republicans and Democrats sparred today over the strength of the prosecution's case, and Democrats stepped up their warnings that calling witnesses would lead to a prolonged impeachment trial.

description: Internet-Shopping Survey Shows Mixed Reactions

title: The Quest to Toilet-Train Toddlers
description: To the Editor:

title: BORROWERS BEWARE: A Special Report; Suits Say Unscrupulous Lending Is Taking Homes From the Poor
description: By all appearances, the loan agreement Gloria Knight signed in 1995 was a classic transaction between savvy mortgage salesmen and an unsophisticated borrower in a poor Brooklyn neighborhood.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sell Art to Museum
description: To the Editor:
