title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEONE, ANNE F.
description: LEONE-Anne F. On January 16, 1999. Beloved sister of Ernest. Friends may call at the Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232nd St., Bronx, on Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 10 AM, St. Gabriel's Church. Entombment, St. Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Fabrizio De Andre, Songwriter Of Italian Protest Movement, 58
description: Fabrizio De Andre, one of Italy's most popular singers and songwriters, died on Jan. 11 in a hospital in Milan where he was admitted in December. He was 58.

title: In Courtship of Airtouch, Heavy Dates and Hefty Stakes
description: The telephone call that Vodafone's chief executive, Chris Gent, got on New Year's Day was the kind no executive wants on vacation. His chief financial officer had tracked him down in his Sydney hotel room to tell him that Bell Atlantic, the largest local telephone concern in the United States, was close to buying Airtouch Communications Inc. in a $45 billion stock swap.

title: One Person Killed In Apartment Fire
description: An apartment fire in Flushing, Queens, last night left one person dead and six others injured, a fire official said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HANKIN, LEONARD
description: HANKIN-Leonard. A Memorial Service will be held on Tuesday, January 19, at 5 PM at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison at 81st St.

title: A Post-Minimalist Film With Renewed Emotion
description: When ''Koyaanisqatsi'' had its first showings in 1983 the term post-Minimalism had not yet been coined. But this ecological meditation by the filmmaker Godfrey Reggio and the composer Philip Glass proclaimed the limitations of Minimalism as a description for a movement in the arts that stripped away certain traditional elements of structure and focused on others. There was, after all, a degree to which Mr. Reggio's and Mr. Glass's contributions to the project fit that original definition: the film has neither dialogue nor voice-overs, just Mr. Reggio's images and a score rich in the repetitive figuration that had become emblematic of Minimalist music.

title: Belief Is the Margin of Victory As Falcons Dance Off to Miami
description: The Vikings' wide receiver Cris Carter could not control his emotions. As he walked off the field after the Atlanta Falcons had beaten Minnesota, 30-27, today in overtime for the National Football Conference title, Carter burst into tears. Other Vikings players were crying, while some simply had stunned looks. Linebacker Ed McDaniel kept mumbling, ''I can't believe this.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLINS, JEANNETTE
description: HOLLINS - Jeannette. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member and wife of Honorary Trustee Lewis Hollins. We extend deepest sympathy to her bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: U.S. and EU Denounce Massacre in Kosovo as NATO Ponders Next Move
description: PARIS  The United States and the European Union reacted with outrage to the massacre of 45 ethnic Albanians in the Yugoslav province of Kosovo, with President Bill Clinton saying that "this was a deliberate and indiscriminate act of murder designed to sow fear among the people of Kosovo."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, LEON
description: BLOCK-Leon. Dear husband of Belle. Cherished father of Helene Zisholtz, Jerry Block and Paul Block. Grandfather and greatgrandfather. Funeral services today, 10:15 AM, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Sports of The Times; Second Half, Looking Grim: Elway's Time For Greatness
description: THE aura of greatness seemed to be gone from John Elway, as missing in action as his passing touch. The rumored grand exit from his hometown stage was blowing in the wind, a mile high.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Helping to Replace Essentials After a Devastating Hurricane
description: Last September, after Altagracia Fung saw on television the damage that Hurricane Georges had visited upon Puerto Rico, she called her parents in the Dominican Republic to warn them that the storm was heading there next.

title: Pentagon Backs Off on Arms Inspector's Book
description: The Defense Department announced today that it was dropping its demand that Scott Ritter, a former United Nations arms inspector in Iraq, provide the Pentagon with advance copies of a book in which he is expected to step up his criticism of the Clinton Administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISKIND, BERNARD (BUDDY)
description: SISKIND-Bernard (Buddy). You will always be in our hearts and we will miss you. The Gruber Family

title: INSIDE
description: NATO Meets on Kosovo, Appealing for Cease-Fire

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, AARON M.
description: SCHREIBER-Aaron M. Dear husband of Esther, beloved father of Joel (Judy), Simeon (Rose) and David (Dassie), cherished grandfather of Paula Lev, Jacob, Tobi Fein, Miriam Skydell, Avram, Doniel, David, Avi and Blanche and proud great-grandfather of 21 great-grandchildren. A devoted and proud Jew who was an outstanding model of Jewish values to his entire family. Funeral at the Boulevard Funeral Home, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI. Shiva will be observed at the home of David Schreiber, 828 Addison St., Woodmere, NY through Sunday morning.

title: Katherine Bain, 101, Champion of Child Health
description: Dr. Katherine Bain, a pediatrician who became a high-ranking and an outspoken Washington official concerned with the well-being of infants and children, died on Jan. 10 in a Washington nursing home she entered in October. She was 101 and had lived in Washington since 1940.

title: One of a Kind, Or Two of a Kind? Stamp Zealots Want to Know
description: One of the world's rarest stamps, issued by British Guiana in 1856 and last sold two decades ago for almost a million dollars, may be only half as rare as was thought. A second copy has turned up and has passed initial tests for authenticity.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the political pressures on some Republican senators over impeachment misspelled the given name of the chairman of the political science department at Brown University, who commented on the challenges faced by Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island. He is Darrell West, not Darryl.

title: Investigation Into Collapse Looks at Role Of Concrete
description: The inquiry into what caused the collapse of an underground parking garage on the Lower East Side late Friday is now focusing on the reinforced concrete used in building the garage, officials said yesterday.

title: Just What Constitutes a Consumer Stranglehold?
description: The Microsoft trial is a high-stakes exercise in legal warfare and the witnesses are foot soldiers. On each side they are advocates, committed to winning and thoroughly coached.

title: Walter H. Page, 83, Chairman Of J. P. Morgan in the 1970's
description: Walter H. Page, a former chairman and president of J. P. Morgan & Company, died Jan. 8 at his home in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. He was 83.

title: CLINTON TO URGE MORE U.S. CONTROL ON AID TO SCHOOLS
description: President Clinton will propose in his State of the Union Message on Tuesday the most aggressive nationwide effort ever to bring greater accountability to state and local school systems, potentially affecting the allocation of billions of dollars in Federal education aid, White House officials said today.

title: Treasury to Auction Just Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to tomorrow's auction of three- and six-month bills. The financial markets are closed today in observance of Martin Luther King Jr. Day.

title: Big Television Shocker: Tabloid Shows Go Soft; The Mainstream Networks Are Co-opting What Was Once Too Lurid for Prime Time
description: There was a time on television when Lorena Bobbitt, Joey Buttafuoco and Amy Fisher and the boy accusing Michael Jackson of sexual molestation were the special and overheated province of early-evening tabloid news shows.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Dotting the I's Hard; Camps May Open Late
description: Just when you thought the National Basketball Association was back in business, the league and the players' union are dueling again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, JANIS MERESMAN
description: GOLDMAN-Janis Meresman. 54, devoted daughter of Harry Meresman and the late Helen Chafets Meresman. Loving sister of Helaine Meresman Barnett, beloved wife of Michael David Goldman, adoring mother of Melissa Lee Goldman, Lori Goldman Zbar. Cherished aunt, dear niece, treasured friend. Contributions can be made to the Janis Meresman Goldman Memorial Fund at The Charles E. Smith Jewish Day School of Greater Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISSMAN, MILTON L.
description: WEISSMAN-Milton L. Not an hour goes by that you are not thought of and loved. You were a great guy. Helen, Steve, Stephanie, Serena

title: Holiday Use Sours a Few Consumers on Web Shopping
description: Amid post-Christmas giddiness about the stellar holiday drawing power of Web merchants like Amazon.com and portals like America Online, a survey to be released today found that while record numbers of Americans tried Internet shopping, they were not always happy with their experiences.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about Lucent Technologies' plan to acquire Ascend Communications misstated the duration of the talks between their chief executives. Negotiations began last fall, not more than a year ago.

title: 'Pentagon Maverick' Sounds Alarm
description: Not much has changed in the small office in the Pentagon where Franklin C. Spinney has worked ever since he gained a bit of notoriety in the 1980's with this jolting argument: All the money President Ronald Reagan was pouring into defense would not make the military any stronger.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of the Media Business page on Thursday about the appointment of Douglas Toews to a new executive position at Coty Inc. misstated his title. It is executive vice president, not vice president, for ideas and image.

title: How Can We Stop Harassment in Classroom?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RASH, DOROTHY E.
description: RASH-Dorothy E. On January 16, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Frank. Loving mother of Richard and dear mother-in-law of Rosemarie. Cherished grandmother of Catherine, Richard, Stephan, Christopher and Damian. Devoted great-grandmother of Jessica and Rachel. Reposing at the Harden Funeral Home of Bayside, Northern Blvd. at 209th St. Visiting hours Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 9:45 AM, St. Kevin's R.C. Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery.

title: Patents; It may be 'big, really big,' but an on-line airline ticket discounter is also being challenged.
description: A WASHINGTON patent lawyer is challenging a fundamental patent issued last summer to Priceline.com Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAIDER, BERNARD
description: RAIDER-Bernard. Temple BethEl of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We extend deepest sympathy to his bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Vicious Cycle of Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyer Convicted in Murder of Mistress
description: Thomas J. Capano, a lawyer and a member of Delaware's political elite, was convicted today of first-degree murder in the death of a woman who had tried to break off their romance.

title: Little-Known Project Developing Alternative Software to Windows
description: In painting the perils that could topple his mighty Microsoft empire, William H. Gates likes to invoke the theoretical young programmer toiling in obscurity somewhere, at work on the software project that could overtake the industry-dominating Windows software operating system.

title: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; To win and keep customers in a wired world, companies must provide value. Most haven't figured that out, though.
description: IN the early days of the Internet's commercial ascendancy, back in 1996, Jeffrey P. Bezos, founder and chairman of the Internet's retail whale, Amazon.com, made a simple observation that should have signaled problems ahead for technology companies that assumed that the information age would be business as usual.

title: Trade Trash For Culture? Not Virginia
description: Virginians are struggling to decide what odors wafting out of New York City smell more foul -- mushrooming mounds of garbage or uppity pronouncements from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: NATO Presses Milosevic After Massacre but Doesn't Plan Raids
description: Confronted with growing violence in Kosovo and an increasing sense that it is almost impossible to halt the bloodshed, divided NATO delegates meeting in Brussels tonight called on President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslav to respect a cease-fire, but backed off reviving NATO plans from last fall to bomb Serbian targets in Kosovo and Serbia proper.

title: About Bilingualism
description: To the Editor:

title: Marine Midland Awards an Account
description: Marine Midland Bank in Buffalo, a unit of HSBC Group, has named Partners & Shevack/Wolf in New York, part of Wolf Group, to its marketing communications account, which had been at the Buffalo office of Eric Mower & Associates. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: Yeltsin Is Back in Hospital, This Time With a Bleeding Ulcer
description: Barely three weeks after doctors declared him fully recovered from pneumonia and exhaustion, President Boris N. Yeltsin was found to have an acute bleeding stomach ulcer and was sent to a Moscow hospital today.

title: A Museum's Spirit Rides On van Gogh's Coattails
description: The Los Angeles County Museum of Art had been a beehive of activity in recent months as it prepared to open its biggest show in years, ''Van Gogh: Masterpieces From the Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam.'' The show, which opened today, has already been extended by six weeks into May, and nearly a third of the tickets, which are going for as much as $20 each, have been sold.

title: With Support, Iraq's Opposition Would Have a Chance
description: Whether there were spies in its midst or not, the United Nations weapons inspection team in Iraq was at best a serious nuisance to Saddam Hussein. Now that Unscom in effect no longer exists, we have only two other options. One is to try to contain Mr. Hussein through sanctions and sporadic bombing raids while we wait for him to fall. The other is that we can actively help the Iraqi opposition bring him down, as the White House suggested late last year to much derision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFBERG, LAWRENCE
description: WOLFBERG-Lawrence. Of Teaneck, NJ, on January 15, 1999. Beloved husband of Marie Worthington Harper Wolfberg and the late Dorothy. Devoted father of Barbara Lawson and Matthew. Loving grandfather of Bahiyyih Lawson Mondragon, Jonathan and David Wolfberg. Loving great-grandfather of Enrique Mondragon. Services were held Sunday. For more information call ''Wien & Wien,'' 1800-322-0533.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMAN, PEARL
description: FORMAN-Pearl. 91, on January 16, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Jacob. Loving mother of Monroe and Jane Silverman and Alan and Fanny Forman. Adored grandmother of John and Stephanie Silverman, Michael and Kate Jacobson, David Silverman, Maggie Silverman, Talia Forman, Rachel Forman, and great-grandmother of Jedediah, Woodrow and Gabriel Jacobson. Dear sister of Eleanor Leder and Larry Aldrich. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OESTREICH, MELVYN ROBERT
description: OESTREICH-Melvyn Robert. 66, died January 16. Beloved wife, Zelda. Loving children, Liza, Michael and Susan, son-in-law, Jeff, and daughter-in-law, Stacey. Services will be held Monday, 9:30AM, ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam.

title: The Big City; Is Dome Plan For West Side Doomed?
description: BEFORE discussing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's new plan for a domed stadium next to the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, I should disclose a conflict of interest. Three years ago I proposed using that West Side waterfront for a different urban renewal project: the New York XXXposition Center.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: DDB Needham Ends Bermuda Relationship
description: DDB Needham New York has resigned the Bermuda Department of Tourism account, which the agency had handled for a decade, by withdrawing from a review that began last month. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $12 million.

title: Media Talk; Group Settles Suit Against Writer
description: A drug prevention group has settled and dismissed its $10 million libel lawsuit against the writer Stephen Glass over fabricated articles he wrote about the organization for the New Republic and Rolling Stone magazines.

title: How Can We Stop Harassment in Classroom?
description: To the Editor:

title: Belarus Finds Varied Ways to Muffle Independent Journalists
description: It was a suspiciously finicky pack of burglars who broke into the sardine-can offices of the little newspaper Naviny one night in November.

title: James P. Gifford, 56, a Strategist For Business and Charity Groups
description: James Priest Gifford, a political strategist, spokesman and lobbyist for New York businesses and institutions, died in Manhattan on Jan. 9. He was 56 and lived on the East Side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLOP, ROBERT
description: GALLOP-Robert. On January 16, 1999. Husband of the late Sally S. Gallop. Father of Barbara G. Gilbert and the late Richard C. Gallop. Grandfather of five and greatgrandfather of four. Companion of Helen Weymes. He was an inspiration to all who knew and loved him. He will be greatly missed. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Botha Took a Nap, Then He Took a Fall
description: AFTER often resembling an awkward amateur for nearly five rounds, Mike Tyson upheld one of boxing's oldest truths on Saturday night in Las Vegas, Nev.: one knockout punch is worth a thousand punches that miss.

title: Critics Question Overdue Plan to Track Cancer and Pollution
description: It was an audacious plan standing uneasily at the intersection of cancer science and cancer politics: to explore possible links between pollution and cancer by mapping every neighborhood in New York State, showing cancer cases and sources of water, ground or air contamination. Nothing like it had ever been attempted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUMHOLZ, JACK
description: KRUMHOLZ-Jack. The Officers and Members of the Friends of Akim, U.S.A., Palm Beach Chapter mourn the passing of our esteemed founding member and extend our heartfelt condolences to his dear wife Mera and family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BITNER, LEON
description: BITNER-Leon. January 16, 1999. Beloved husband of Shula and loving father of Rhona. Services will be held at 3 PM on Monday, January 18, at Westside Institutional Synagogue, 120 West 76th St.

title: William Ball Is Dead at 82; Defended Religious Rights
description: William Bentley Ball, a constitutional lawyer nationally known for his defense of religious doctrine and practice against secular encroachment, died Jan. 10 at Lee Memorial Hospital in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 82, lived in Camp Hill, Pa., and was in Florida on vacation.

title: Rice Wins And Stays In National Title Chase
description: Rice High School has won three state basketball championships in five years, and it cranks out Division I collegians. But it has not won a mythical national title since 1965-66. In case the Raiders needed reminding, the skinny guard from that team, Dean Meminger, showed up at Madison Square Garden before the Nike Super Six Tournament yesterday to recount his team's accomplishment.

title: American Pair Takes a Title In Competition at The Hague
description: An American partnership triumphed in the Cap Gemini World Top tournament, which ended yesterday in The Hague. David Berkowitz of Old Tappan, N.J., and Larry Cohen of Boca Raton, Fla., outdistanced a field consisting largely of world champions and were assured of victory before the final session of play began.

title: Senegal Bans Cutting Of Genitals Of Girls
description: In a step toward eradicating the tradition of female genital mutilation in Africa, the Parliament of Senegal banned it this week, responding to a campaign by Senegalese women.

title: Compressed Data; Titans Race to Do the Policing For the Electronic Roadway
description: No policies were brokered and no deals were done, but the all-star lineup at the first meeting of the Global Business Dialogue on Thursday was enough to convey the group's basic message: The rules of electronic commerce will not be made by governments alone.

title: Schroder Backs Design for a Vast Berlin Holocaust Memorial
description: After a bitter debate over how to commemorate the Holocaust in the new German capital, Berlin, agreement has been reached on a memorial that will include a vast field of stone pillars, a 65-foot-high wall of books and a research center for scholars.

title: LVMH Raises Its Stake in Gucci to 26.7%
description: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A., the world's No. 1 luxury-goods maker, said over the weekend that it had raised its stake in Gucci Group N.V. to 26.7 percent, strengthening its influence over the Italian company and providing a platform from which to make an eventual takeover offer.

title: Subduing a Raging River, With Human Cost and Profit
description: Many Americans, on the way to or from exploring the technical wonder of Las Vegas slot machines, take a break at Hoover Dam. It may not offer quite the charge of the slots, but tonight's ''American Experience'' leaves no doubt that the dam was quite a gamble for its time and produced big winnings for its major players and for America's Southwest.

title: Charter Schools Represent a Compromise in Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Fred Hopkins, Experimental Jazz Bassist, 51
description: The jazz bassist Fred Hopkins, an important figure of the new jazz in New York during the 1970's and 80's, died on Jan. 7 at the University of Chicago Hospital. He was 51 and lived in Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUND, ROSENTHAL, MIRIAM K.
description: FREUND - ROSENTHAL - Miriam K. On January 16, age 92. Wife of the late Milton B. Freund and of the late Harry Rosenthal. Mother of Matthew and Blanche Freund, and of Harry and Matta Freund. Grandmother of Michael and Sarah Freund, Rebecca Freund, John Freund, Carmel and Franco Kostolitz, Gilead and Geri Freund, and Liza Greenberg. Great-grandmother of ten. Former National President of Hadassah and Trustee of the United Israel Appeal, the Jewish National Fund, State of Israel Bonds and American Friends of the Hebrew University, author and lecturer. Services 11:15 AM, Monday, January 18, at The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Martin Luther King Jr.'s America
description: For many young Americans, the heroic life and tragic death of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. are historical artifacts from the turbulent 1960's, distant chapters in the multi-volume history of the American experiment. In the decades since then, the ranks of those with vivid memories of the human rights struggle Dr. King waged in the South and up North have thinned. Yet neither of these circumstances should nudge Americans toward allowing each year's observance of his birthday to morph into another three-day get-away weekend.

title: Rangers Are Baffled By a Lost Weekend
description: The Rangers had looked at their last four games, a span in which they played four teams occupying last place in their divisions, and had seen an opportunity. As they walked slowly and quietly to the bus here on Saturday night, through a small crowd of encouraging family and friends, they saw an opportunity lost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUB, MARIANNA
description: LAUB-Marianna. On January 16, 1999. Of Long Beach, LI. Beloved wife of the late Leo Leib Laub. Devoted mother of Gabriella. Dear sister of Henry Polak. Loving grandmother of Jacqueline, Rebecca and Bonnie. Cherished great-grandmother of Rachael and Christopher. Services today, 1 PM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, MIRIAM
description: COOPER-Miriam. Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, NJ mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi Gail Billig, President

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ELMOWITZ, BERNIE
description: ELMOWITZ-Bernie SOKOLOF-Herb Happy Birthday guys. Still remembering.

title: Sports of The Times; One Consolation Is That Parcells Will Be Sticking Around
description: WHEN the Jets were rolling toward the American Football Conference championship game, Bill Parcells's face told you all you needed to know about how he felt. His eyes glowed, his smirk had mischief in it. But last night, after the 23-10 loss to the Broncos, the coach's eyes were flat and he had forgotten how to smile.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Ailing Chief Of Azerbaijan Flies to Turkey
description: One of the key figures in the multi-billion-dollar Caspian energy boom, President Heydar A. Aliyev of Azerbaijan, fell ill and was flown today to a hospital in Turkey for treatment.

title: Sweetheart, Give Me Reboot
description: The time? About 10 years from now. The place? A busy city newsroom. The circumstances? A breaking story -- perhaps a bombing.

title: Igloolik Journal; How to Love the Arctic Sun? With Ceremony
description: The time when the sun disappears and day becomes night is known as ''the great darkness'' by the people who have lived on this island of ice high in the Canadian arctic for over 4,000 years.

title: The Broncos' Special Teams Helped Turn the Tide
description: Special-teams play is Jets Coach Bill Parcells's pet project. He believes it is the area that can provide the margin of victory in certain games and in certain situations. Today was one of those games, and the unusual situation was a swirling wind that gusted at unpredictable times.

title: Panthers Obtain Bure In a Seven-Player Trade
description: Pavel Bure refused to return to Vancouver this season and forced the Canucks to trade him. The Rangers and the Islanders were among the teams bidding for the Russian Rocket, one of the elite hockey players in the world.

title: Martin Luther King Jr. Day
description: NEW YORK

title: More Realistic Defense Budgeting
description: President Clinton wants to increase military spending by $110 billion over the next six years, the first significant increase in the defense budget since Ronald Reagan's cold-war buildup of the mid-1980's. Congressional Republicans want to spend even more. But soaring spending is unnecessary to assure that America's armed forces remain strong, decently paid and appropriately equipped for the battlefields of the 21st century. Most of what the Pentagon legitimately needs can be paid for by trimming pork from acquisition programs, closing unneeded bases and reducing America's nuclear arsenal from excessive cold-war levels.

title: David W. Belin, Warren Commission Lawyer, Dies at 70
description: David W. Belin, a lawyer for the Warren Commission, which investigated the Kennedy assassination, and for the Rockefeller Commission, which looked at Central Intelligence Agency activities, died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. He was 70 and lived in Windsor Heights, Iowa, and on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: Friends Honor Benita Valente, Who in Turn Honors Her Voice
description: Like many other singers, the soprano Benita Valente has worked with equal dedication in opera and song. But Ms. Valente has also distinguished herself as a chamber music artist in repertory ranging from Baroque cantatas to contemporary works.

title: TECHNOLOGY; On-Line Smut Law Heads Into Court
description: As general manager of Powell's Books, Miriam W. Sontz helps oversee a successful retailer with seven stores in and around Portland, Ore., and a growing international on-line book-selling business.

title: A 'Pierrot' Lighted by More Than the Moon
description: Any creative presentation of people and places has to decide what to put in and what to leave out. ''Moondrunk'' at the New Victory Theater on Friday night subscribed to the ''more'' theory rather than the ''less.''

title: Mayoral Free-for-All in Philadelphia
description: Appearing here recently as the Wizard in a stage show of ''The Wizard of Oz,'' Mickey Rooney stopped in at City Hall to present Mayor Edward G. Rendell with a special souvenir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRILLO, REV. ANTHONY
description: GRILLO-Rev. Anthony. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the former chaplain of Ozanam Hall on January 16, 1999. Reposing at Seneca Chapels, 494 Seneca Ave., Ridgewood, Monday, January 18, from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass in Immaculate Conception Center Chapel, 7200 Douglaston Parkway, Douglaston, Tuesday, January 19, at 10:30 AM. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Charter Schools Represent a Compromise in Education
description: To the Editor:

Devoted brother of Irma, Rita and Alma. Graveside services Cedar Park, Paramus, NJ, 11:30 AM, Tuesday, January 19.

description: GODFRIED-Rita (nee Marks). January 18, 1997. Remembered lovingly. Missed. The Family

description: THE HAUNTED WOOD

title: ISLANDERS
description: As Kenny Jonsson limped out of the National Car Rental Arena late Saturday night in Sunrise, Fla., his right knee supported by a brace, the Islander defenseman felt a range of negative emotions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESTENBERG, JUDITH
description: KESTENBERG-Judith. 88 of Sands Point, NY. Died January 16, 1999. Beloved mother of Howard and Janet, grandmother, wife of the late Milton. A woman of strength, integrity and passion devoted to family and to all whom she worked with. Psychiatrist, teacher, researcher dedicated to allay suffering and prevent trauma, she made an enduring difference in the lives of children and Holocaust survivors. Funeral service Monday, January 18, 12:30 PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam and 76th St. In her memory contributions may be made to Child Development Research, 30 Soundview Lane, Sands Point, NY 11050.

title: House Managers Given Credit in Presenting Legal Arguments Against Clinton
description: After three days of impeachment arguments from the House managers, constitutional and impeachment experts said the presentations last week gave the strongest legal arguments yet against President Clinton.

title: Leading I.O.C. Official Is Linked to Scandal
description: A South Korean who is one of the most powerful members of the International Olympic Committee has been linked to the Salt Lake City bribery scandal, Olympic officials said last night, speaking on condition of anonymity.

title: The Quest to Toilet-Train Toddlers
description: To the Editor:

title: For Blacks and Jews, Hopes for Renewed Link
description: The words spoken at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem yesterday morning were probably much like those delivered from many pulpits on the day before the Federal holiday honoring the nation's most celebrated civil rights leader.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUNSTEIN, JEAN
description: BRAUNSTEIN-Jean. Our members and entire staff extend their deepest sympathy to our partner Harry, his brother and sister, and all the grandchildren, on the loss of their beloved mother and grandmother, and hope they will receive comfort in the memory of her many kindnesses to each of them. Herzfeld and Rubin, P.C. Herbert Rubin

title: Corretja and Venus Williams Survive Opening Round
description: The opening day of the year's opening Grand Slam tournament did not begin with major upsets, but that does not mean it was lacking for surprises.

title: Spectacle Pays Tribute To British Tradition
description: The New York City Ballet has promised to present 100 ballets in this, its 50th-anniversary season, an effort that has obviously recharged the company's dancing. On Thursday night ''Union Jack,'' George Balanchine's witty tribute to British tradition, received its most spirited performance in years, and ''Les Gentilhommes,'' Peter Martins's all-male ballet of 1987, returned with its good manners intact. If there was rain and slush outside the New York State Theater, there was sunshine within.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, MATTHEW J.
description: ROSEN-Matthew J. Of Chappaqua, NY. Died suddenly Sunday, January 17, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Barbara C. Salken, loving father of Billy, cherished son of Jack and the late Anne Druz Rosen, devoted brother of Marjorie and Richard Schneidman, dear brother-in-law of Judy Salken and Charles Posey, son-in-law of Doris and Irvin Salken, uncle of Amy Schneidman, Lisa and Evan Licht, Eric Kahn, Jill and Jay DiGrazio, most devoted friend of Leotha Maynard. Memorial contributions may be made to The American Paralysis Association, 500 Morris Avenue, Springfield, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENWALD, WILLIAM
description: GREENWALD-William. In Miami, FL. Loving husband of the late Lillian. Beloved father of Anita Passman, Debra and Benjamin Polk and Gary and Anne. Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. Active in the toy industry for 50 years.

title: The latest music form to find resurrection by mainstream marketers is swing, in all its glory.
description: MADISON AVENUE is learning to sing, sing, sing -- with a swing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOBODKIN, MOLLIE
description: SLOBODKIN-Mollie. 88 of Plantation, FL. Passed away on January 16, 1999. She is predeceased by her loving brother Morris. She is survived by her devoted brother Seymour Slobodkin; loving nephews Stephen and Marc Stuart; cherished great-nephews Jamie, Brian and Neil Stuart; devoted greatgreatnephews Daniel and Matthew Stuart; and loving sister-inlaw, Rose Slobodkin. Graveside services will be held today at 2 PM, Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ. Riverside Gordon Funeral Home, 800-758-1151.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VILLANY, RICHARD
description: VILLANY-Richard. It is with deep sorrow that we mourn the passing of our dear and talented friend, Dick. You will be missed by us all. Ellen Schweber and Family Tita Greene and Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KITAIN, JUDITH
description: KITAIN - Judith. Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, NJ, mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi Gail Billig, President

title: Media Talk; A Promise From NBC: Less Emphasis on Sex
description: NBC, the network that pioneered the sex comedy at 8 P.M., is promising ''less emphasis on sex.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WHYTE, WILLIAM H. (HOLLY), JR.
description: WHYTE-William H. (Holly), Jr. Friends of William H. Whyte are invited to join his family in a service of thanks for his life and presence among us. Service will be at 10:30 AM, Tuesday, January 19, at the Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Ave. at 74th St. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to the Municipal Art Society in Holly's name.

title: Media Talk; Page 2 Changes Amid Some Grumbling
description: Perhaps it is because newsrooms are famously resistant to change, but the transformation last week of page 2 at The Daily News -- the tabloid newspaper equivalent of riverfront property -- into a potpourri column about what's happening around town has left the newsroom in not the best of moods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFMAN, FLORENCE
description: WOLFMAN-Florence. Beloved wife of Philip. Devoted mother of Harvey and Mark. Loving grandmother of Jennifer, Matthew, Andrew and Vanessa. Funeral service, Monday, 11:30 AM, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Sports of The Times; Moral of the Falcons' Story: 'You Can Turn It Around'
description: THE more you think about what unfolded in Minneapolis yesterday afternoon, the more incredible the feat becomes. The noisy Metrodome was quieted, countless Minnesota hearts were broken, the powerful Vikings were disposed of, and the Atlanta Falcons, a team with dreary history and little tradition, was headed to the Super Bowl.

title: Market Place; Anything.com Likely to Be Hottest Issue In Class of '99
description: You want Internet companies? We'll give you Internet companies. That's the message Wall Street is sending investors in the first quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, MICHAEL
description: BERMAN-Michael. In loving memory to a devoted husband to Sylvia and loving father to Jane. Dear uncle to Marsha and Roberta, and great uncle to Ira and Florence. Services today 11AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DULMAN, RUTH
description: DULMAN-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Harry R. Devoted mother of Fern McBride and Robbie Dulman. Loving grandmother of Jessie and Haley. Dear sister of Esther Frankel. Service 10 AM, Wednesday, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Representative Weighs Race For the Senate
description: Amid growing concern among New York Democrats over finding a candidate to run for the Senate in 2000, Representative Nita M. Lowey of Westchester said yesterday that she was seriously considering a race for the seat and that she had begun calling Democrats and contributors to measure potential support for her candidacy.

title: 2 Japanese Companies In Cellular Alliance
description: The DDI Corporation, Japan's second-largest long-distance telephone company, said yesterday that its cellular phone unit was forming an alliance with the IDO Corporation, Japan's fourth-largest cellular phone company, to challenge the dominance of NTT Mobile Communications Network Inc. The two companies will market a single mobile-phone brand, according to Yoshitaka Odan, a spokesman for DDI, which owns about 65 percent of Cellular.

title: Sports in the Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Scania Says Profit Rose 18% in 1998
description: Scania A.B., Europe's No. 4 truck maker, reported yesterday that its 1998 operating profit was up 18 percent. The company said 1998 operating profit was 3.6 billion kronor, compared with 3.05 billion a year earlier, and predicted a rise of 42 percent this year.

title: City Opera Halts Tour Rehearsals
description: The New York City Opera National Company canceled musicians' rehearsals Sunday and yesterday for its annual tour, which is scheduled to begin in San Antonio on Monday, because of a dispute with the musicians.

title: Training in Empathy
description: To the Editor:

title: By Design; What the Dress Shoe Learned
description: Finally, here come fashionable shoes designed to be comfortable. The innovation combines the technology of athletic shoes with the styling of dress shoes. Molded bottoms of rubberized synthetic materials that conform to the contours of the foot are combined with uppers of leather or fabric, resulting in shoes that are dressy enough to be worn at the office, and maybe even out to dinner.

title: Stop Brawling Over the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Sosa Absent From a Dinner
description: Sammy Sosa, the Chicago Cubs slugger who with Mark McGwire electrified the baseball world last season, was a no-show at last night's Congress of Racial Equality dinner at which he was to be honored.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, JOAN SHIRLEY ENGEL.
description: STERN-Joan Shirley Engel. With deep sadness we record Joan's passing in her home on January 18th, in her 79th year, after a long illness. Loving wife of 40 years of Irving Stern; beloved mother of Anthony Marc Benjamin & Marian Lisa Lasday. Joan was a creative, vivacious, passionate woman, a loving and devoted friend who will be missed by all who knew her. She is survived by her husband, her son and daughter, her nephew Robert Engel, and her son-in-law David Lasday. Religious services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Tuesday, January 19th at 12 Noon.

title: Ex-Congressman Tells Blacks Not to Be Victims
description: Before a cheering crowd at a state celebration marking Martin Luther King Jr. Day, the Rev. Floyd H. Flake, a former member of Congress and potential mayoral candidate in New York City in 2001, urged listeners yesterday to stop ''talking like a victim, acting like a victim, walking like a victim.''

title: Airport '99: Hess Greets His Team in Wee Hours
description: The Jets' plane home from Denver touched down at 1:15 this morning at La Guardia Airport, and the players walked out, tired and disappointed. There was no admiring group of fans waiting; the combination of the late hour, the bad weather and the season's frustrating conclusion kept the crowd away.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''A miracle has happened.''

title: Shield Diagnostics To Buy Axis of Norway
description: Shield Diagnostics Group P.L.C., Britain's largest maker of heart disease tests, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Axis Biochemicals A.S. of Norway for $:65.3 million ($108 million) in stock to form an international diagnostics company with a value of $:177 million ($292 million). Axis shareholders will be offered Shield ordinary shares in a one-for-one swap. Shield shareholders will control 62 percent of the merged company's equity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ABNER L.
description: COHEN-Abner L., former dentist, beloved husband of the late Sarah, dearly loved by his daughters, Barbara J. Sandberg, Marjorie Cohen, and son-in-law, Dale Sandberg. He was devoted to and much loved by his grandchildren, Lisa and Scott Sandberg. He was loved as well by his sister, Evelyn Rich. Graveside services today at 2:30 PM at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. Family receiving at the Nanuet home of Barbara J. Sandberg Tuesday, Wednesay and Thursday.

title: How the Bells Can Feel Like Helpless, Pitiful Giants
description: It's hard being a regional Bell these days. When regulators are not shooting down your latest scheme for getting into the long-distance business or opposing your merger plans, your powerful unions might be threatening to strike or some upstart telecommunications wunderkind is breaking up a promising deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, ANITA ROBBINS,
description: GORDON-Anita Robbins, of Bethesda, MD., on January 16, 1999. Beloved wife of Thomas W.D. Wright, mother of Daniel Gordon, Jeremy Gordon and Elizabeth Gordon, grandmother of Alex, Mara, Ben, Josh, Sam and Will. She is also survived by her brother, Allan Robbins of New York City. Relatives & friends are invited to attend a Memorial Service at the Cosmos Club in Washington, D.C., on Saturday, January 23, 1999 at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Gordon Family Scholarship Fund at the Sidwell Friends School, 3825 Wisconsin Avenue, NW, Washington D.C. 20016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEREGA, AL
description: ZEREGA-Al. Beach Point Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of Al Zerega, an employee of more than fifty years. Al was a friend to generations of club members who will miss his familiar face and wonderful stories of their own, and the club's early history. He will long be remembered as an integral part of the Beach Point family. Beach Point Club Paul N. Gardner, President

title: Trash, Giuliani Tells Virginia, Is Good Deal, Not Obligation
description: Responding to politicians in Virginia who continue to rail against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to export more of New York City's trash, the Mayor said yesterday that he never said other states were obligated to take the city's garbage.

title: Expert Witnesses in Gun Lawsuit Offering Testimony That Helps Both Sides
description: In a Brooklyn courtroom, lawyers are arguing a case that could set a precedent on a fundamental national question: Should the American gun industry be held collectively liable for the blood spilled with illegally obtained handguns?

title: Earhart Still a Mystery
description: To the Editor:

title: Hasbro Moves Two Assignments
description: Hasbro Inc. in Pawtucket, R.I., is expanding its relationships with two roster agencies by awarding them the accounts of brands previously sold by Galoob Toys Inc., which Hasbro acquired last year.

title: Exchanging Confidences With an Electronic Neighbor
description: In the national radio ocean of wisecrack and punditry, canned music, and network news, Delilah surfaces night after night with a voice that is altogether different.

title: The Corporate Critic; Nell Minow Uses Her Zeal for Films to Investors' Advantage
description: At the Reader's Digest Association's annual meeting late last year, Nell Minow, whose Lens fund owns more than $8.5 million worth of Reader's Digest stock, spoke out about her fund's proposal to bring the company in line with others in the way it issues shares.

title: Law of Diminishing Returns for Athletes
description: For Jill Farwell, a Los Angeles public relations executive, pushing herself is almost as natural as breathing. So two years ago, when she discovered a passion for competitive rowing, she went full-throttle, training for up to two hours at a time on either an ergometer or in a boat. But after eight months of almost-daily workouts, her rowing pace began to slip -- not improve. ''I couldn't understand why my body couldn't match my drive,'' she said.

title: Editorial Observer; Where a New York Minute Lasts for Hours
description: New York City may have turned its back on nature, but it still lives by seasonal cycles. Alternate-side-of-the-street parking rules are as relentless as the tides. Street fairs are our harbingers of summer, arriving with the numbers and general irritation quotient of mosquitoes. Jury duty has always been our version of the plagues of locusts. Every two years a summons to serve arrived in the mailbox and the spirit sank.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINDER, HARRY
description: BINDER-Harry. Former President of Jaffie Mechanical, Inc. World War II Veteran of Army Engineering Corps-European and Pacific Theatres died suddenly of a heart attack in his home in Glen Cove, N.Y. January 18, 1999. Harry is survived by his wife Nanette, his daughter Dr. Karen BinderBrynes, his son Andrew Binder, his sister Shirley Rosen, brother Sol Binder and granddaughters Elana and Lily Brynes. Services today 1PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I. Please direct all contributions to American Heart Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLEPIAN, IRVING
description: SLEPIAN-Irving. The Riverdale Jewish Center mourns the loss of our Board member and Men's Club President, Irving Slepian. We extend profound condolences to his wife, Frances. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Empty Words, Filled With Silences
description: Silence in music can be just blank space and framing, or it can hum with suppressed activity. Nobody else these days writes silence as strong, suspenseful, poignant -- and loud -- as Gyorgy Kurtag.

title: A Day of Tributes to a Dream That Still Inspires
description: Ronald Glenn, a history teacher at John Jay High School in Park Slope, Brooklyn, says he still treasures a photograph of himself at 14 with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Mr. Glenn was the editor of his school newspaper at the time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, BERTHA
description: BRENNER-Bertha. On January 16, 1999. Loving sister of Robert Brenner and Sophie Gilbert. Cherished aunt of Gail Luparello and great-aunt of Kara, Josh and Lori. Services were held by Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard (76th Road), Forest Hills, New York.

title: Knicks Will Most Likely Get Sprewell
description: After a bidding frenzy of several days, the Knicks have reached an agreement in principle to obtain Golden State's outcast All-Star, Latrell Sprewell, according to three executives in the National Basketball Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPSALES, HAREKLIA
description: KAPSALES-Hareklia. The family of Hareklia (Ricky) Kapsales deeply mourns her passing on January 17 after a short illness. She will be sorely missed by her brothers, sister, their spouses and especially her nieces and nephews and their children. She will also be missed by her colleagues at AIG, where she served as a vice president for many years, and by other business associates. Viewing at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28th St., Manhattan, Tuesday and Wednesday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services Thursday, 10 AM, at the Greenwood Cemetery Chapel, 5th Avenue and 25th St., Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLETTI, PERUCCA, GERTRUDE
description: COLETTI - PERUCCA - Gertrude Gretsch. Died at Glen Cove Hospital, January 16. Loving wife of the late Sonio, devoted mother of Jackie, mother-in-law of Nick Drexel and grandmother of Nicholas. She was born in 1923, married to Jack Astor, and then to Sonio. She was a wonderful friend to all & will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be 11 A.M., Thursday, January 21, at St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley. In lieu of flowers, donations to Kips Bay Boys Club would be appreciated.

title: Suntory Acquires Cloister Spring Water
description: Suntory Ltd., the nation's No. 2 bottled-water company, said it had acquired the Cloister Spring Water Company for an undisclosed price, expanding its line of water brands.

title: Wind and Rain Disrupt Travel and Damage Buildings
description: Fierce winds and lashing rains swept through the New York region on the leading edge of a cold front yesterday, shearing roofs off buildings and causing power failures that left more than 10,000 New Jersey train commuters stalled in their tracks during the evening rush.

title: Fines Sought Against Health Club Over Refusals to Cancel
description: The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs is seeking $150,000 in fines against the Lucille Roberts health club chain because of complaints from members who were refused legitimate refunds or not allowed to cancel memberships, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRYANT, WILLIAM CULLEN, II.
description: BRYANT-William Cullen, II. Formerly of Garrison, N.Y. Died Friday January 15. A funeral service will be held Friday, January 22, at 11AM at St. Philip's Church, Garrison, N.Y. 914-424-3369 for details.

title: Passion and Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBERHARDT, RUTH E.
description: EBERHARDT-Ruth E. 94. On January 17, 1999. Surviving are her sister Marguerite Getz and nieces Barbara Butterworth and Carol Sadowski. Burial will be in St. Mark's cemetery in Lewistown, Pa.

title: Ballet Twinkles With Fun
description: Fun is not a word that is often used about ballet. But the New York City Ballet offered a strong dose of the stuff on Saturday at the New York State Theater in an inspired evening program and two lively role debuts in the afternoon.

title: Critic of Clinton in Senate Falls Silent on Impeachment
description: Senator Rick Santorum, the conservative Pennsylvania Republican, has been a strident critic of President Clinton, once accusing him of telling ''bald-faced untruths.'' But these days, with Mr. Clinton's fate in the hands of the Senate -- and with Democrats lining up to challenge Mr. Santorum for his job in 2000 -- that voice of the junior Senator has fallen silent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULHOF, RUDOLPH B.
description: SCHULHOF-Rudolph B. The Board of Directors and Staff of the American Friends of the Israel Museum and of the Israel Museum, Jerusalem are deeply saddened by the death of Ruda Schulhof one of its founding directors. For three decades, Ruda and his wife Hannelore, have nurtured this fledgling Museum into maturity and have enriched its contemporary art collection to world class status. We shall miss him terribly and extend condolences to Hannelore; to their children, Mickey and Paola, Tom and Anne, Wendy and Stanley; and to the entire family. Maureen Cogan, International Chairman Judy Steinhardt, President James S. Snyder Anne and Jerome Fisher Dir., IM Carolyn Cohen, Executive Director, AFIM

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEMING, YURI JUNE,
description: FLEMING-Yuri June, on January 17th, 1999. Beloved wife of the late William L. Loving mother of Gloria Jean Wosniak. Also survived by three grandchildren. Retired human resources administrator at SIAC. Member of Trinity Church Family Choir. Also member of ABSA and DBE. Reposing at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28th St., NYC, Tuesday and Wednesday. Visiting hours 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service 8 PM, Wednesday.

title: Witness Found Shot to Death Just Before Murder Trial Starts
description: A man who was found shot dead in a parked car in Plainfield, N.J., on Sunday was a witness in a murder trial that is to begin today, investigators said yesterday.

title: Tyson May Sell Units
description: Tyson Foods Inc., the world's largest poultry company, said today that it might sell its pork and seafood divisions to concentrate on chicken sales.

title: Los Angeles Journal; Hair Runs Wild With Stylists at War
description: The City of Angels has seen its share of war.

title: Requests Are to Include More Aid for Russia
description: In his State of the Union Message on Tuesday night, President Clinton will insist that the United States substantially increase its financial assistance to Russia to minimize the threat posed by the Russian nuclear arsenal, Administration officials say.

title: Ancient Instruments Yielding Secrets of Their Music
description: Flutes and their kin, including whistles, ocarinas, recorders and pipe organs, are among music's oldest and most versatile instruments. Yet science has long had trouble understanding all but the most elementary aspects of how they work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLIGAN, ELEANORE
description: GILLIGAN-Eleanore on January 17, 1999. Retired consultant in public health for the State of California. Beloved sister of the late Rose and Kathleen Gilligan. Devoted sister of Celestine Frankenberg. Dear aunt of James, Gregory, and the late Michael Gilligan, Susan Sckittone, Kathleen and William Crosby, and Kathryn Malone. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at East 20 St.), NYC. Visiting Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of the Christian Burial at Epiphany Church, Wednesday, 10 AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Of Herons, Goddesses and Peace
description: The program presented by Sachiyo Ito and Company on Friday night at the Joyce SoHo, billed as an evening of Japanese classical and contemporary dance, was long on good intentions but short on artistry. Ms. Ito has been performing in New York for several decades now but she has never lost sight of her roots in Japanese traditional dance. Sadly, her performance of ''Sagi Musume'' (''Snowy Heron Maiden''), an 18th-century Kabuki solo, was busy-looking and lacked the containment and inner stillness that makes such classical dance so rewarding to see.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, STEPHEN G.Z.
description: HARRIS-Stephen G.Z., of NY NY. Died Saturday, January 16, 1999. He was a beloved cousin to many relatives as well as a warm, devoted friend to a wide circle of friends around the country. He was predeceased by his parents, Walter and Emily Harris, and by his brother Edward. Before his retirement, he worked as a television director at WOR. He was a veteran of World War II, having served in the Navy. After his retirement, he devoted himself to volunteer work at his church, serving on the Board of the Episcopal Actors Guild, and pursuing one of his greatest loves: acting in the theatre. He performed in various theatres around NY. Viewing will be on Tuesday, January 19, 1999 at Walter CookeKennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72 St, NY, 2PM-5PM and 7-9PM. The church service will be held on Wednesday, January 20, 10AM at Christ and St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 122 West 69 St, NY NY. Interment will be in the afternoon of January 20 in Williamsport, PA. The theatre has lost a friend. Sadly, there will be an empty seat in many houses. We, his relatives and friends, mourn his passing.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Connecticut and Westchester sections on Sunday about a model train exhibition at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center misstated the museum's telephone number. It is (203) 322-1646.

title: Clinton to Propose Tax Break For Parents Who Stay at Home
description: President Clinton will embrace an idea long favored by conservatives and propose a tax break for parents who stay home to care for their children, White House officials said today.

title: Beyond Klezmer, Tunes Spiritual And Traditional
description: Melody was a sacrament when Andy Statman performed at Town Hall on Saturday night. It was something to honor, to contemplate, to obey and to renew. Most of the melodies came from Hasidic rabbis and Hasidic traditions in places like Israel, Poland, Ukraine and Brooklyn. The method of contemplation was more modern: jazz, drawing on approaches from meditative ballads to swirling, roiling, ecstatic flights. Playing clarinet or mandolin and backed by a jazz-rooted trio, Mr. Statman found history and timelessness in a repertory with goals beyond entertainment. Introducing one tune, he said, ''This is a melody that's really supposed to bring you closer to God.''

title: Another Chinese Investment Company Falters
description: China's foreign debt problems have spread north, with the Dalian International Trust and Investment Corporation, the finance arm of one of the nation's biggest ports, missing payments on loans.

title: Kournikova Has Trouble With Her Serve But Still Wins
description: The chair umpire, John Blom, leaned into the microphone on Court 1 and announced the understandable: ''Kournikova has won the toss and elected to receive.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMAN, PEARL
description: FORMAN-Pearl. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue mourns the death of the mother of our esteemed member and Vice President, Alan Forman, and extend to him and the bereaved family its heartfelt condolences.

title: OFFICEMAX TO TRY SELLING I.B.M. PRODUCTS ONLY
description: Officemax Inc., the No. 3 office-supply chain in the United States, said it had agreed to run a test program in six cities to sell computers and computer-related products made solely by the International Business Machines Corporation. Officemax will open special departments to display the I.B.M. merchandise and phase out sales of all other computer products in the six cities, which will be chosen in the spring. I.B.M. will operate three of the departments under license, while Officemax will run the other three with I.B.M.-trained staff. Officemax, based in Cleveland, may extend the program to all of its 832 stores in 49 states and Puerto Rico during the next 12 to 18 months.

title: G.O.P.'s Officials, Feeling Boxed In, Keep Looking for a Way Out
description: A telling sign of the impeachment troubles confronting the Republicans is that they are so fearful of ceding the White House and the Democrats a political advantage that they would not dare boycott President Clinton's State of the Union address on Tuesday night, though some considered doing so. This is no time to seem whining or pettily partisan.

title: Sports of The Times; No History, No Future, Enjoy 1998
description: AT the risk of depressing all Jets fans and there are many more than four months ago -- forget all the babble about 1998 being the stepping stone to some kind of dynasty.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTEL CORP., Santa Clara, Calif., a maker of computer chips, announced that it would work with a unit of Security Dynamics Technologies Inc., based in Bedford, Mass., to develop chips that have built-in encryption capabilities to help prevent fraud.

title: Adkins to Compete In Millrose Games
description: Derrick Adkins's parents live on Derrick Adkins Lane in Lakeview, N.Y., a small town on Long Island. But since the street was named for him after his victory in the 400-meter hurdles at the 1996 Olympics, Adkins has done little to distinguish himself. .

title: A New Group and Its Ambitions
description: The New York music scene certainly needs some of what the New York Collegium promises: a good, permanent early-music orchestra and chorus. In fact, it may need everything the group promises: good period ensembles for Classical and Romantic music as well. The question is, how much of all that can the Collegium supply?

title: Rikers Island Learns to Recycle; Behind Razor Wire, Gardens and a Composting Plant
description: As weekly pickups of recyclable trash spread to all the neighborhoods of New York City, there is one eco-friendly urban corner that is way ahead of them, already providing pickups twice a week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUALL, JOAN (NEE PARNES).
description: SUALL-Joan (nee Parnes). Of Manhattan, on Sunday, January 17, 1999. Wife of the late Bertram Suall. Died of complications relating to emphysema. Joan spent a lifetime fighting for social justice and economic democracy at home and abroad. She played significant roles in many organizations including Social Democrats, USA, the Jewish Labor Committee, the National Council of Jewish Women, the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, AFL-CIO, the Workmen's Circle, the N.Y. Coalition of Center Democrats, the Chelsea Midtown Democratic Club, the Village Reform Democratic Club, and the Tilden Democratic Club. She is mourned and will be missed by all who were touched by her passion for a world of peace, freedom and democracy. She is survived by many cousins, relatives and loving friends. A graveside ceremony will be held on Wednesday, January 20, 2 pm, at the New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. A memorial service will be held in the near future. Friends are invited to her home, 330 Third Ave., NYC, on Wednesday, January 20, and Thursday, January 21, 6:30-8:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLMAN, SUZANNE (NEE LENOIR).
description: GILLMAN-Suzanne (nee Lenoir). Beloved wife of Seymour. Devoted mother of Gary (Kim). Adored grandmother of Christopher. Visitation Wednesday, January 20, 7:30-9:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue, where services will be held at 8:30 PM. Interment at Le Grand Jas Cemetery, Cannes, France.

title: Tornadoes Hit Tennessee, Killing 8 and Injuring 105
description: Tornadoes cut through Tennessee on Sunday, killing at least 8 people and injuring 105, officials reported today, with the most damage in Jackson and surrounding Madison County northeast of Memphis, where 6 people died and more than 60 buildings were destroyed.

title: Shorter Season Is Already Molding 2000 Race
description: The compressed calendar of Presidential primaries has set off a competitive frenzy among Republican and Democratic contenders who believe that they must begin -- almost immediately -- to raise money or they may find it impossible to catch up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, BERNARD
description: KATZ - Bernard. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, NY, mourns with heartfelt sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, and extends condolences to the entire family. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Sheldon Steinmetz, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELSOHN, FLORENCE, NEE FELDMAN.
description: ADELSOHN-Florence, nee Feldman. On January 17, 1999. Beloved wife of Yale, mother of Lawrence (Lynn) and Marc, adored grandmother of Jodi (Mrs. Gregg Ruff) and Keith, beloved sister and aunt, after a long illness. Services are today, 12 Noon, January 19, 1999, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, N.J. followed by interment at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WHYTE, WILLIAM H. (HOLLY), JR.
description: WHYTE-William H. (Holly), Jr. Friends of William H. Whyte are invited to join his family in a service of thanks for his life and presence among us. Service will be at 10:30 AM, Tuesday, January 19, at the Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Ave. at 74th St. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to the Municipal Art Society in Holly's name.

title: Nothing Super In Superb Season For the Jets
description: Bill Parcells started to work on next season barely 12 hours after the Jets came within 30 minutes of going to the Super Bowl.

title: Losing Ground on Witness Issue, White House Opens Case Today
description: Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader, said today that it ''appears to be inevitable'' that the Senate would vote to depose witnesses in President Clinton's impeachment trial, and probably along party lines.

title: State of the Agendas
description: By tradition and the tense circumstances of the moment, this is President Clinton's day. In the evening, Mr. Clinton will march into a House chamber torn by emotion and partisanship over impeachment to deliver his seventh State of the Union speech. The address is to follow, by a few hours, the opening of Mr. Clinton's defense in the Senate. The President is not the only figure on the spot, however. Today the Republican Congressional leadership must begin a year of engaging a President with high approval ratings on something more than his personal scandals.

title: Courier Sounds Drug Alarm
description: Jim Courier said today after winning his first-round match at the Australian Open that he believes the biggest drug problem in tennis is not steroid use but the use of endurance-boosting substances like EPO, which was at the heart of the Tour de France scandal last July.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEFFER, VERA
description: SEFFER-Vera. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Devoted mother of Patty Schaffer (Robert) and Buddy (Joan). Loving grandmother of Mita, Amy, Steven, Shari,and Marc and great-grandmother of Michael. Services today at the New Montefiore Cemetery, 1PM.

title: BRAZILIANS PLEDGE MARKET CURRENCY
description: Brazil said today that it would continue to allow market forces to set the value of its currency, the real, all but abandoning a policy to support the currency that was draining billions from its reserves of dollars.

title: Don't Shake Faith In Government
description: To the Editor:

title: DEFIANT YUGOSLAV ORDERS EXPULSION OF  U.S.  DIPLOMAT
description: Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President, defied the allies today and threatened a fragile cease-fire when he ordered the expulsion of a top American diplomat who had blamed the Serbs for the mass killing of more than 40 ethnic Albanians in Kosovo province last week.

title: MERRILL LYNCH HIRES HELP FOR EQUITY CAPITAL MARKETS
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the largest United States brokerage firm, said yesterday that it had hired Dante Roscini, a managing director in European equity capital markets at Goldman, Sachs & Company, to serve in a similar role in its own operations. Mr. Roscini, 40, who had spent the last 10 years at Goldman, Sachs before announcing his departure over the weekend, will work in London with Brad England, who headed Merrill's equity capital markets division on his own for about a year. Mr. Roscini will start in April.

title: China Tightens Rein on Writers And Publishers
description: As they very publicly send the most outspoken democracy campaigners to prison, China's leaders have also quietly tightened the screws on liberal intellectuals, journalists and publications.

title: Nets Obtain McIlvaine To Shore Up Defense
description: For the past two seasons, the Nets have been trying to build themselves into a championship contender, and today they took another step toward their goal. In a move they believe will strengthen their defense considerably, the Nets traded for Jim McIlvaine, one of the league's best shot blockers.

title: A Millennial Angst for Particle Physics
description: As the directors of all three of the world's preeminent particle accelerators retire this year, hopes are high that technical advances they helped to bring about will lead to major discoveries. But all three agree that high-energy physics is facing an uncertain long-term future.

title: Whooping, Drinking and Praying, Atlanta Celebrates the 'Miracle' of the Falcons
description: A person can live with losing, David West knows, the same way he lives with any other chronic pain. But imagine if, one day, while sitting in his favorite recliner in front of a wide-screen television, the pain of 33 years just slipped away, and in its place was pride and joy.

title: New Bidder For British Media Group
description: Mirror Group P.L.C., publisher of the British newspapers The Daily Mirror and The Sunday Mirror, said today that Regional Independent Media P.L.C. had offered to buy it for $:913 million, or $1.5 billion, in cash after a failed bid by Trinity P.L.C.

title: A Hard Lesson In Teamwork For Huskies
description: Svetlana Abrosimova, star of the second-ranked Connecticut women's basketball team, sat weeping at an interview table afterward. Shea Ralph, the Huskies' junior guard, talked about the team's urgent need to play as cohesively as it practices.

title: Two Teams Grounded in the Basics
description: Does successful passing create productive running? Or is it the other way around?

title: Fears Over Milk, Long Dismissed, Still Simmer
description: It was the confluence of two important events that made Carol Baxter start buying organic milk about five and a half years ago. Her oldest daughter had just turned 1 and soon would move from breast milk to cow's milk. And American dairy farmers had just received approval to inject their cows with recombinant bovine growth hormone, a genetically engineered hormone that increases milk production.

title: When He Shot, He Soared: Jordan the Man and Athlete
description: PLAYING FOR KEEPS

title: FISERV TO PICK UP QUESTPOINT CHECK-SERVICING BUSINESS
description: Fiserv Inc., the nation's largest processor of checks and loans for banks and credit unions, will acquire the check-servicing business of Questpoint for an undisclosed price. The agreement will enable Fiserv to expand its nationwide item-processing network, the company said yesterday. Fiserv said it gained contracts with First USA Inc., the MBNA Corporation and Sun National as a result of the acquisition. Questpoint, which is owned by First Union Corporation, based in Charlotte, N.C., serves financial institutions in the Philadelphia area. Fiserv, based in Brookfield, Wis., will combine Questpoint with Ficats, the item-processing operation of NCO Financial Systems Inc., which it acquired late last year.

title: Brazil's Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Fashion; The Bad Boy of Paris Who Made Good
description: The shock of Yves Saint Laurent's beatnik-inspired 1960 collection for the House of Dior was proof of a rebellious nature. That was before Mr. Saint Laurent made the journey that has brought him to the stature of a classic in French fashion.

title: THE SCHEDULE: Trial Coverage
description: Following is the expected schedule for the impeachment trial of President Clinton:

title: Stop Brawling Over the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Bennett Harrison, 56, Urban Economist, Dies
description: Bennett Harrison, a leading radical economist, vocal critic of United States economic policy and the co-author of the 1983 book ''The De-Industrialization of America,'' died at home on Sunday of complications from cancer of the esophagus. He was 56 years old and lived in Brooklyn Heights.

title: The Neediest Cases; Stepping From a Van Into a Warm Bed
description: Last week, as snow and sleet descended on New York City, the heater in Samuel Liner's 1981 Chevrolet van wheezed impotently and delivered no warmth. Ordinarily, this might have been just an inconvenience, but Mr. Liner, a 78-year-old veteran of World War II, had been living in the van for almost a year.

title: Flossing Protects Far More Than the Teeth and Gums
description: I suspect that my most egregious lapse in healthful living is widely shared: Knowing that I might lose my teeth in the coming decades is not enough to get me to floss every night. I do endure thrice-yearly periodontal cleanings and admonishments to do a better job on a daily basis, but still that 18-inch strip of string does not always find its proper mark before the day is done. Even watching the misery my husband suffered in adjusting to dentures was not enough to sustain a nightly habit of flossing.

title: Corrections
description: A Sports of The Times column yesterday about John Elway of the Denver Broncos and his performance against the Jets in the American Conference championship game misidentified the receiver who caught the touchdown pass from Elway. He was Howard Griffith, not Dwayne Carswell.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Brazil Currency to Continue To Float Against the Dollar

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KAHANE, ARTHUR S.
description: KAHANE-Arthur S. 8/7/14-1/19/88 You're gone 11 years today sweet memories of you still remain in my heart. Jane

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISNER, EDWARD J.
description: EISNER-Edward J. Beloved husband of Natalie. Devoted father of Jill Heiden and Bart Eisner and daughter-in-law Trish. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Christopher, Nicole & Blaine. Devoted brother of Irma, Rita and Alma. Graveside services Cedar Park, Paramus, New Jersey, at 11:30 AM, Tuesday, January 19.

title: New Theories of Depression Focus on Brain's Two Sides
description: Two new theories of depression are rekindling interest in the once fashionable topic of how the left and right sides of the human brain interact.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, DAVID M.
description: ROSNER-David M. Endeared for his passionate dedication to his family and students. Admired for his youthful spirit and vigorous mind. Devoted to his wife, Lillian, children, Irene and Arnold, and son-inlaw, Raphael David. Services at Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76 St, Thursday, January 21st, 12 Noon.

title: As Rescue Plan for Threatened Species, Breeding Programs Falter
description: At the end of November, after bullets had felled 5 animals, biologists recaptured the last free-roaming survivor of 11 Mexican wolves released with fanfare just eight months earlier in Arizona's Apache National Forest. It was a disheartening blow for a celebrated 20-year cooperative program between the United States and Mexico to restore this distinctive subspecies of the gray wolf, which became extinct in the wild in 1977.

title: Hanna F. Sulner, 81, Expert Drawn Into Mindszenty Plot
description: Hanna F. Sulner, a handwriting expert who reluctantly helped Hungarian Communists frame Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty on treason charges in 1949, then promptly fled to the West and exposed the sham, died on Jan. 5 at her home in Manhattan. She was 81 and since 1950 had worked quietly in New York as one of the nation's leading authorities on disputed documents.

title: Immune System as Suspect in Miscarriage
description: Women who have had repeated miscarriages or for whom in-vitro fertilization has failed are often told that nothing can be done to help them. While almost 70 percent of miscarriages over all are due to chromosomal defects, at least 50 percent of recurrent miscarriages have no apparent explanation, according to the American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, BESS ASHLEY HOUSE.
description: HOPKINS-Bess Ashley House. Died January 16 in Cambridge, MA. Devoted mother and motherin-law of Terry, Mandy, Tom, Jay, Sarah and Matthew. Delighted grandmother of six and dear sister of Bina Beghe-and so loved by all who knew her. Funeral services Christ Episcopal Church, Cambridge MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMANN, HANS C.
description: ALTMANN-Hans C. On January 15, 1999. Loving and devoted husband of Ruth Rogers Altmann. Beloved father of Carol Altmann Molony (husband Ray), Peter M. Altmann (wife Cathy), John R. Altmann (wife Joyce), Althony F. Altmann (wife Lisa) and stepfather of Susan C. Friedman (husband Harris) and Victoria K. Thorson (husband Tom). Proud grandfather of Steven, Michelle, Allison and Daniel Altmann and Kate C. Boyle (husband Jeff), Ian and Alexandra Thorson. Interment will be private. Memorial will be held at a later date. Any contribution in his memory may be made to the Parkinson Disease Foundation, 710 W. 168 Street, New York, N.Y. 10032.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, MATTHEW J.
description: ROSEN-Matthew J. Of Chappaqua, NY. Died suddenly Sunday, January 17, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Barbara C. Salken, loving father of Billy, cherished son of Jack and the late Anne Druz Rosen, devoted brother of Marjorie and Richard Schneidman, dear brother-in-law of Judy Salken and Charles Posey, son-in-law of Doris and Irvin Salken, uncle of Amy Schneidman, Lisa and Evan Licht, Eric Kahn, Jill and Jay DiGrazio, most devoted friend of Leotha Maynard. Services Tuesday, 1 PM, Temple Beth-El of Chappaqua. Memorial contributions may be made to The American Paralysis Association, 500 Morris Avenue, Springfield, NJ.

title: New Service for High-Speed Net Users
description: Snap, an Internet company partly owned by NBC, has developed a service that is tailored for the small but growing number of users who have high-speed connections to the World Wide Web. An announcement is expected today.

title: Don't Shake Faith In Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about five Central Americans accused of having carried out a bombing campaign in Cuba two years ago misstated the time of a regional summit meeting in Venezuela where United States prosecutors say a group of Cuban exiles planned to assassinate Fidel Castro. It was in November 1997, not May 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYNES, ANNA SMITH
description: SYNES-Anna Smith, 100, on January 18, 1999, last surviving of eleven children of the late Max and Ida Smith of Union City, NJ. Widow of S. David Synes; mother of Mimi Bookstaver (Nelson), Janice Weissman (Bertram) and the late Bob Synes; grandmother of Jane Weissman, Nancy Weissman, Bobbi Bookstaver (George Barunas), Julie Bookstaver, and the late Douglas Bookstaver; great-grandmother of Michelle and Lauren Bookstaver. Services 11:30 AM, Wednesday at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Calls to the Capitol Slow, If Not Quite to a Trickle
description: People for the American Way has organized anti-impeachment forums in 21 cities for Tuesday evening, just before President Clinton delivers his State of the Union speech. The Christian Coalition's Web site is up and hyperlinking, allowing its constituents to sign even more electronic petitions demanding Mr. Clinton's ouster. In short, the letters, phone calls and E-mail messages are flowing again here, this time directed at the senators who will vote on Mr. Clinton's fate.

title: Tough Road Ahead for the Red Storm
