description: St. John's Coach Mike Jarvis was sounding serene yesterday, not at all like a coach about to take his team into a 10-day stretch that could either vault it into the stratosphere of college basketball or send it plunging down the polls.

title: McCann Names 2 To New Positions
description: McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising in New York said yesterday that it had reorganized management for its North American region by naming two executives to new positions.

title: Keeping 'Mad Cow' Away From U.S. Blood Supply
description: A scientific advisory panel is asking the Food and Drug Administration to consider a basic question: Should a past travel itinerary help determine who is eligible to donate blood?

title: DiMaggio Leaves for Home After 99 Days in Hospital
description: After 99 days in a South Florida hospital and numerous predictions of his hopeless condition and impending death, Joe DiMaggio went home yesterday. Since entering the hospital in Hollywood on Oct. 12, he has undergone lung cancer surgery, nearly succumbed to infectious pneumonia four times, received last rites, had a Do Not Resuscitate order posted on his bed and awakened from a coma.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABINOWITZ, TOBA BLOOM,
description: RABINOWITZ-Toba Bloom, age 95, of Westport, CT, on January 17, 1999. Widow of Irving, sister of the late Clarence Bloom, loving mother of Andrew Rabinowitz and his wife Audrey of Westport, CT; adoring grandmother of Ethan Rabinowitz, Marci Chappel, and Shari Abelson. Services Tuesday 11:00 A.M., from the Abraham L. Green and Son Funeral Home, 88 Beach Road, Fairfield, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIZZA, RUTH C.
description: PIZZA-Ruth C. On January 14, 1999 at age 70. Beloved daughter of Michelle. Services were held at the Gannon Funeral Home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLINS, JEANNETTE L.
description: HOLLINS-Jeannette L. Beloved wife of Lewis S. Hollins. Devoted mother of Peggy A. Hollins and Betsy and Bruce Gilbert. Adoring grandmother of Jason & Danielle Gilbert. Dear sister of Stanley and the late David Wolin. Services on Tuesday, at 1 P.M., at Temple Beth El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, New York.

title: A Missing Father Figure, a Mother's Grief
description: It was undoubtedly disappointing for the 200 participants in the ninth annual Robert Shaw Choral Workshop at Carnegie Hall to learn, just before the workshop began, that Mr. Shaw would not be able to lead the six-day seminar because of back problems. Singers and choral directors from 41 states and four foreign countries had signed up for the workshop; more than half had attended in past years, and were returning because they find Mr. Shaw's methods both inspirational and technically effective.

title: An Oxygen Rush: Good, Bad or Indifferent?
description: Q. Businesses called oxygen bars, which provide customers with oxygen-rich air, are cropping up on the West Coast. Do these provide any health benefits? ALISHA BERGER

title: Knicks Said to Agree To a Sprewell Trade
description: After an intense competition with several other teams, the Knicks emerged last night with an agreement in principle to obtain the guard Latrell Sprewell from the Golden State Warriors.

title: Is Wisconsin Welfare Plan Good for Children?
description: To the Editor:

title: Opera's Romeo and Juliette Demand a Happy Ending
description: Before they met in the early 1990's, Roberto Alagna and Angela Gheorghiu were well on their way to promising careers as opera singers. As a couple, though, they had something extra to offer: a touching love story for the gossip columns and an offstage passion to bring alive their onstage trysts. At least when they cry or die in, say, ''La Boheme,'' they really seem to love each other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN DE MAELE, ALBERT C.
description: VAN DE MAELE-Albert C. The Partners of Guggenheim Brothers deeply mourn the loss of our devoted friend and former Partner who passed away in Miami Beach, Florida on Sunday, January 17th after a long, courageous battle with cancer. Albert possessed unique leadership qualities as an executive and was an enthusiastic patron of the arts. His integrity and loyalty to his many friends was unsurpassed. We extend our heartfelt sorrow to his devoted wife Aimee Urrutia, and to his first wife and dear friend Joan Guggenheim. He will be deeply missed. Peter Lawson-Johnston Senior Partner

title: Ford Agrees to Pay Plan for Argentine Workers
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had agreed to a 15-month staggered payment plan for 1,400 idled workers in Argentina, where the industry has suffered a drop in output because of the weakened economies in Argentina and Brazil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSTEIN, JACK
description: ROSENSTEIN-Jack. The Jewish Center of Atlantic Beach records with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Jack Rosenstein, husband of Beatrice Rosenstein. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and know no further sorrow. Dr. Basil Herring, Rabbi Arthur Udell, President Armand Lindenbaum, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Watson the Next in Line As the Mets Sign Nomo
description: Working on two fronts while the rest of Major League Baseball took the holiday off, the Mets yesterday virtually completed a deal with Allen Watson, a free-agent pitcher, and reached agreement with Hideo Nomo, one of their six players who had filed for salary arbitration.

title: Metro Business; Plan to Buy Pulitzer Unit
description: Hearst-Argyle Television Inc. said yesterday that it would issue a fixed number of shares to acquire Pulitzer Publishing Company's broadcasting unit, revising an earlier agreement in the hope of limiting the risk of market volatility to shareholders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAIKIN, FREDA (NEE SCHWARTZ)
description: LAIKIN-Freda (nee Schwartz) of Fort Lee, New Jersey on January 17, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Lawrence Laikin and Fern Galant. Dear sister of Evelyn Chernow & Rose Lefkow. Loving grandmother of David, Peter, John, Janis and Amy. Great grandmother of Elizabeth, Jenna, Michael, Alexis, Kyle, Lauren, Elijah and Pamela. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle Street, Englewood, New Jersey today 11AM. The memorial period will be observed at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Galant, Tenafly, N.J. Contributions to Hadassah would be appreciated.

title: Philips and Sony Set a Venture With Sun Microsystems
description: The world's two largest consumer electronics companies will announce today an alliance with Sun Microsystems Inc. to create a generation of networked entertainment devices and appliances that will communicate with each other and with humans via the Internet.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: A Sweet Rent Deal for 3,000 May Be Going Sour
description: Like just about every tenant in the twin red-brick Ruppert Yorkville Towers, Marie Mitchell knows she has one of the sweetest living arrangements in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNSTEIN, ALBERT
description: BROWNSTEIN-Albert. Of Hackensack, NJ, on January 16, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Lotte. Devoted father of Irwin, Beverly Lazar. Loving grandfather of Joy, Mark, Paul and Eric. Great grandfather of Alexandra, Harry, Ezra and Jakob. Services were held Monday at ''Gutterman-Musicant'' corner Passaic and Park Sts., Hackensack, NJ. The memorial period will be observed at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Brownstein, Teaneck, NJ.

title: A Mathematician at Play in the Fields of Space-Time
description: The impish man sitting in a warren in a remote corner of the mathematics building at Oxford University in England is Sir Roger Penrose, 68, mathematician, physicist, author, teacher, perhaps one of the greatest living disciples of Albert Einstein. In the 1960's, Dr. Penrose laid much of the foundation for the modern theory of black holes, objects so dense, according to Einstein's theory of general relativity, that they would collapse space around them, creating a hole from which not even light could escape. He is also the inventor of so-called Penrose tiles, which can cover an infinite plane without ever repeating their pattern.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEINKMAN, EDWARD
description: SCHEINKMAN-Edward. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, its Sisterhood and Couples Club, mourn the passing of the beloved father of their devoted member, Mindy Leventhal and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Haskel Lookstein, Rabbi Joshua Lookstein, Rabbi Fred Distenfeld, President

title: BMW Requests Subsidies
description: BMW A.G., Germany's third-largest auto maker, said today that it would consider opening production sites away from Britain if the British Government would not provide subsidies for Rover Group, BMW's unprofitable British unit. BMW wants subsidies for retooling factories. The Rover unit has not made a profit since BMW bought it in 1994. Late last year, BMW and Rover's unions agreed to cut 2,500 jobs and introduce flexible working hours to keep Rover's plants open longer.

title: Al Sharpton meets Madison Ave., and both see progress in multicultural marketing efforts.
description: THE organizers of efforts to press advertisers and agencies to devote more attention and resources to consumers from minority groups -- and to the media aimed at such consumers -- say they are generally pleased with the initial responses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, AARON M.
description: SCHREIBER-Aaron M. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a cherished alumnus and revered leader of the Jewish communities of New York, Miami Beach, and Israel, whose good works on behalf of Jewish education and whose chesed activities were widely respected. He nurtured a magnificent Torah family with three sons, all rabbis ordained by the University's affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary who, with their wives, are RIETS Fellows. Through his family foundation, with his family, Aaron Schreiber was a YU Guardian. He also established the Blanche Schreiber Torah Tours Program at RIETS in memory of his deceased wife, and was a Founder of our Albert Einstein College of Medicine. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Esther Maidenbaum Schreiber; children: RIETS Trustee Rabbi Joel M. (and Judith) Schreiber, Rabbi Simeon (and Rose) Schreiber, and Rabbi David N. (and Hadassah, YUHS Board member) Schreiber; sister, Pearl Pincus; nine grandchildren; and twenty-one great-grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Judah Feinerman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees Elliot Gibber, Chairman YUHS Board

title: SUNGARD DATA SYSTEMS AGREES TO BUY FDP WITH STOCK
description: Sungard Data Systems Inc., a computer service and software company, agreed to buy the FDP Corporation, which makes software for the insurance and pension businesses, for about $95.3 million in stock. Sungard, based in Wayne, Pa., sells its products and services primarily to financial institutions and health-care information services. The company said it wanted to buy FDP, based in Miami, to expand into its field. FDP will operate as a separate company within Sungard. The deal is expected to be completed by the end of March.

title: Affinity for Hardball as Well as Cricket
description: Cricket, that languorous English pursuit, looms large in the life of Christopher Charles Gent, chief executive of the Vodafone Group P.L.C., which agreed on Friday to pay $60 billion for Airtouch Communications, the United States wireless phone giant, in Britain's largest takeover ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VILLANY, RICHARD C.
description: VILLANY-Richard C., Southbury, CT. Well-known interior designer died Friday, January 15, 1999. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10 A.M., St. Francis Church, Naugatuck, CT. Burial in Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, L.I. For information, Alderson Funeral Home, Naugatuck.

title: Giuliani's Friend and Cautious Fund-Raiser
description: John H. Gross is one of those people you've never heard of. His name doesn't appear in the gossip columns. His specialty is insurance law. He spends quiet weekends kayaking on Sagaponack Pond on Long Island, or taking his two daughters on nature walks. No one, it is safe to say, has ever called him a character. But if you had a lot of money, you would let him take care of it.

title: GAMBRO PLANS TO LAY OFF 1,000 EMPLOYEES WORLDWIDE
description: Gambro A.B., a Swedish company with the world's second-largest business in products related to kidney dialysis, said yesterday that it would lay off 1,000 employees worldwide, including at least 450 in the United States, as part of a reorganization. Gambro, which is based in Stockholm, said that it would transfer manufacturing from Lakewood, Colo., and Newport News, Va., to European or Mexican sites, and that it would sell or close a factory in Oklahoma City. It said 250 jobs would be lost at Lakewood and 200 at Newport News and that 30 employees would be affected in Oklahoma City. Gambro, which will take a $141 million charge for the fourth quarter of 1998, said in October that its third-quarter operating profit fell 17 percent amid production problems in the United States.

title: A Distinguished Public Servant
description: Over the next few weeks, lawyers for Swiss private banks and Jewish Holocaust survivors and victims' families will probably sign a legal agreement committing the banks to pay a settlement of $1.25 billion, with an additional $200 million in humanitarian payments to indigent Holocaust survivors. The settlement will provide some justice to survivors and close a long argument over the complicity of Swiss banks, which helped finance the Nazi war effort and, when it was over, refused to return deposits by Holocaust victims to their families. It could not have happened without the efforts of Stuart Eizenstat, a long-serving American Government official who has brought a rare degree of energy and attention to these difficult matters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFFER, MORTIMER
description: SCHIFFER-Mortimer. Age 86. On December 19, 1998. A pioneer of play group psychotherapy for children for the Jewish Board of Guardians and NYC Board of Education. Survived by his wife Esther, 2 sons, Charles Schiffer, M.D., Bloomfield, MI and Paul Schiffer, Los Angeles, and 3 grandchildren. Memorial service January 24, Brooklyn Ethical Culture Society, 53 Prospect Park West, 2:30 PM.

title: BP Amoco Will Not Join Iran Oil Venture
description: BP Amoco P.L.C. said today that it would not join a $19 million venture to explore for oil in Iran with the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Lasmo P.L.C. but that it was still interested in operating in Iran.

title: Foreign Affairs; Rattling The Rattler
description: No one quite knows how Nigeria's evil dictator Sani Abacha died last June at age 54, but the story that has made the rounds goes like this: Several Nigerian officers who finally got fed up with General Abacha's utterly venal and corrupt rule got together, imported three prostitutes from India, sent them to his villa with a poison, which he somehow ingested (One report says it may have been in his Viagra) and then dropped dead. The three prostitutes were back on a plane to India before General Abacha's body was cold. Whatever the details, a senior U.S. official privy to the intelligence told me: ''Let's just say Abacha did not die a natural death and he did not die alone.''

title: Patterns
description: The Return of Kate Moss

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLOP, ROBERT
description: GALLOP-Robert. On January 16, 1999. Husband of the late Sally S. Gallop. Father of Barbara G. Gilbert and the late Richard C. Gallop. Grandfather of five and greatgrandfather of four. Companion of Helen Weymes. He was an inspiration to all who knew and loved him. He will be greatly missed. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Hachette Closes A Magazine
description: Hachette Filipacchi Magazines in New York, a unit of Lagardere Group, made a number of personnel changes as it closed a publication.

title: G.E. of Britain in Talks to Sell Arms Unit
description: Britain's leading military contractors British Aerospace P.L.C. and the General Electric Company P.L.C. -- acknowledged today that they were in ''advanced discussions'' on a deal for General Electric's Marconi Electronic Systems that could be worth as much as $13 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GODOWSKY, FRANCES GERSHWIN (FRANKIE)
description: GODOWSKY-Frances Gershwin (Frankie), on January 18th, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Leopold Godowsky, Jr. Loving mother of Alexis Gershwin, Leopold Godowsky III, Georgia Keidan and Nadia Natali. Cherished grandmother of 8. Adoring sister of the late George, Ira and Arthur Gershwin. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Thursday, January 21, at 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Channel 13 at 450 W. 33rd St., NY NY 10001.

title: Corrections
description: The Pop Life column on Thursday, about hard-to-find albums highly recommended by pop and jazz critics of The Times, included a subheading that misspelled the given name of the chief pop music critic. He is Jon Pareles, not John.

title: INSIDE
description: President Will Seek Money To Help Parents and Russia

title: Monroe Karmin, 69; Won a Pulitzer Prize
description: Monroe W. Karmin, a reporter who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1967 for an article about links between organized crime in the United States and businesses in the Bahamas, died on Friday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 69.

title: Companies With a Lot to Lose in Latin America
description: Once again, the risks of doing business abroad are overshadowing the rewards.

title: Scientists Enlist H.I.V. To Fight Other Ills
description: In a bold but potentially frightening effort to turn one of the world's most virulent killers into a cure, scientists and biotechnology companies are trying to tame the AIDS virus and harness it to treat disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBAUM, GERTRUDE (TRUDE).
description: ROSENBAUM-Gertrude (Trude). Beloved wife of the late Ben Rosenbaum. Devoted mother and grandmother to Ralph, Beatrice and Joel. Passed away January 15, peacefully at 85. A Holocaust survivor, she will be missed. Donations in her memory can be made to Hadassah, of which she was a member for over 30 years.

title: The Sounds of Science
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUND, ROSENTHAL, MIRIAM K.
description: FREUND - ROSENTHAL - Miriam K. On January 16, age 92. Wife of the late Milton B. Freund and of the late Harry Rosenthal. Mother of Matthew and Blanche Freund, and of Harry and Matta Freund. Grandmother of Michael and Sarah Freund, Rebecca Freund, John Freund, Carmel and Franco Kostolitz, Gilead and Geri Freund, and Liza Greenberg. Great-grandmother of ten. Former National President of Hadassah and Trustee of the United Israel Appeal, the Jewish National Fund, State of Israel Bonds and American Friends of the Hebrew University, author and lecturer. Services were held.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITEMAN, ANNE NIVIN.
description: WHITEMAN-Anne Nivin. Longtime resident of NYC, died on January 17, 1999. She is survived by her sister and brother-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Paul H.H. Snyder and her nieces, Nivin Snyder MacMillan and Judith Snyder Kaufman, her grandnieces Anne Nivin Stott and Laura Fenimore Kaufman and nephew James Graham Stott. Service Wednesday, January 20, 10:30AM at St. Bartholomew's, Park Avenue at 50th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELIN, DAVID W.
description: BELIN-David W. Beloved husband of Barbara. Adoring and devoted father of Jon, Jim, Joy, Tom and Laurie. Proud grandfather of Janet and step father of Lee and Jenifer. Loving brother of Daniel Belin of CA. and loving father-inlaw of Dr. Anne Coleman and Bruce Kramer. Passed away on Sunday, January 17. The funeral will be held Wednesday, January 20 in Des Moines, IA. at Temple B'Nai Jeshurun at 10AM. Friends can pay their respects on Saturday and Sunday, January 23rd. and 24th at their New York City home. You'll be forever in our hearts. A memorial service in New York City will be announced at a later date.

title: Don't Shake Faith In Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Release Pollard
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, MIRIAM FREUND.
description: ROSENTHAL - Miriam Freund. The Ramaz School family mourns the passing of the beloved mother of its esteemed alumnus, alumni parent and generous benefactor, Harry Freund, and extends heartfelt sympathy to all the members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, Principal David N. Kahn, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Converting Life's Chaos Into Harmonious Fables
description: Justifying the most controversial choice in the repertory of Cry Cry Cry, the all-star folk-pop cover band that filled Town Hall on Sunday night, Dar Williams used a curious cliche: ''the songwriter's song.'' She was introducing ''Fall on Me,'' by the rock band R.E.M. Ms. Williams seemed sheepish about giving time to a best-selling group instead of another folk-club regular like herself and her band mates, Lucy Kaplansky and Richard Shindell.

title: Hope for a Barefoot Child in a City Shattered by the Bomb
description: A vastly ambitious autobiographical Japanese-language musical built around the atomic bombing of Hiroshima on Aug. 6, 1945, will reach the end of its brief but meritorious five-performance run tomorrow at the Sylvia and Danny Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College.

title: At Event on King Day, a Mix Of Goals Met and Hoped For
description: For President Clinton, the event offered an apparently seamless blend of symbolism and substance today, just the right formula to commemorate the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s life.

title: Isles Lose Jonsson for Month
description: Just when it seemed the Islanders' situation could not get any worse, the team learned yesterday that it would be without its All-Star defenseman, Kenny Jonsson, for a month because of a sprained knee.

title: Just How Much Is That Gizmo in the Tunnel?
description: In 1993, with $2 billion already spent on construction of what would have been the world's mightiest particle accelerator, the Congress killed the project, known as the Superconducting Supercollider, or SSC. All that remains are some buildings, a lot of land around Waxahachie, Tex., and a section of the planned 54-mile tunnel that would have housed the accelerator.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Investors Sour on Belo as Ad Sales Fall at Flagship Paper
description: It's as if, as 1998 ended, some prankster turned the A. H. Belo Corporation's stock chart upside down. Falling from $28 and change to less than $20 last year, a stock that had long paced the newspaper industry fell far behind, with its worst performance since Belo went public in 1981.

title: Knicks' Determination Becomes Desperation
description: Before the Sprewell Sweepstakes began -- if that's what you want to call it -- one Eastern Conference executive telephoned the Golden State Warriors to wish them luck in trading away what the executive considered to be ''the biggest liability in N.B.A. history.''

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Children With Cancer Found Well Adjusted
description: Children being treated for cancer are far more resilient psychologically and socially than most adults, including oncologists, would expect. In fact, they seem to function better socially and do as well emotionally as healthy children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNENWALD, THEODORE
description: TANNENWALD-Theodore. Suddenly on Sunday, January 17, 1999. Beloved husband of Selma (Pete). Loving father of Peter (Carol) and Robert (Leslie). Devoted grandfather of Alan, David and Jonathan. Services 10:30 AM Wednesday, January 20th at Temple Sinai, 3100 Military Road NW, Washington. Interment private. Memorial contributions may be made to Hebrew Union College, 1 West 4th Street, New York, New York 10012.

title: David Dempsey, 85, a Writer On Wide-Ranging Subjects
description: David Dempsey, a reviewer, biographer, novelist, columnist, fiction and magazine writer who as a Marine Corps combat correspondent during World War II covered four Pacific landings toting a rifle and a typewriter, died on Wednesday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANDET, FANNIE
description: TANDET-Fannie. On January 18. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Nathan Tandet. Loving mother of A. Joseph Tandet and mother-in-law of Erna Block Tandet. Dear sister of Estelle Brustein. Cherished grandmother of Cathy, Mitchell and Danielle and great-grandmother to Andrea, Hilary, Jenni and Jodi. Graveside service on Tuesday, 1 P.M., at Mount Hebron Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, BESS
description: WINTER-Bess. Wife of the late Herman Winter, beloved mother of Naomi and Charles Cohen, Debra and Leo Petrover, and Robert and Carol Winter. Grandmother and great grandmother. Funeral Jeffers, Tuesday, 9:30 A.M.

title: Russian Biologist Denies Work in Iran On Germ Weapons
description: A Russian biologist in Iran has denied conducting research that could have helped the Soviet Union or Iran develop germ weapons.

title: Fact, Fiction and the Health of Lesbians
description: After surveying the body of scientific literature on lesbian health and holding workshops with researchers and clinicians, a panel of experts convened by the Institute of Medicine issued a report last week deploring the gaps in reliable information about lesbian health. The panel called for large-scale studies to counter rampant ''myths and misconceptions'' and to improve the quality of treatment lesbians are receiving.

title: U.N. Chief Faults Both Sides For Dashing Angola Hopes
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan, in one of the toughest and bleakest reports to emerge from his office, faults the Angolan Government and the Unita rebel organization for destroying all hopes of peace in one of Africa's potentially richest countries.

title: Girl Killed in Fire; Police Say Mother Was Away
description: A 22-month-old girl died in an apartment fire in the Bronx yesterday after her mother left her and her two young siblings alone to visit a neighbor, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, ALAN
description: ROBERTS-Alan. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, New York mourns the passing of our beloved member, Alan Roberts, and extends heartfelt condolences to his wife Shirlee and family. Alan B. Lucas, Rabbi Martin Kay, President

title: Nomura Securities Posts a Loss Tied to Japan's Economic Woes
description: The Nomura Securities Company, Japan's largest brokerage firm, said today that it lost money in the last three months of 1998, as Japan's economy and stock market sagged.

title: Marks & Spencer Shares Rise on Takeover Talk
description: Shares of Marks & Spencer P.L.C., Britain's largest clothing retailer, rose after Peter Salsbury, the company's new chief executive, was quoted in The Mail on Sunday as saying the company could become the target of a hostile takeover bid. The newspaper reported that possible buyers could include British or French retailers or Wal-Mart Stores Inc., but the company said it was not in takeover talks and a spokeswoman said Mr. Salsbury's intent had been to express that the company must ''think about everything'' as it tried to sort out its future.

title: Istanbul Journal; You Want a Black Olive Bagel? Come to Turkey
description: Sitting in New York last year, two ambitious young Turks plotted a return to their homeland and wondered what they would do once they got back.

title: A Diva and Her Fledglings: 'Of Thee I Sing'
description: Even young singers who primarily aspire to opera should practice the art of the song recital. This was Marilyn Horne's conviction when she began her foundation six years ago, and her important work continues. Many singers have received grants, instruction and recital opportunities through the foundation. The four newest recipients, all with burgeoning careers -- the soprano Nicole Heaston, the countertenor Bejun Mehta, the mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe and the baritone Brian Leerhuber -- were presented on Friday night at the Juilliard Theater in the annual Marilyn Horne Foundation New York Recital.

title: Health Insurance Costs Rise, Hitting Small Business Hard
description: When the notice came in December that his company's health insurance premiums were going up 22 percent, Jonathan South knew what he had to do.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STROMBERG, SOPHIE
description: STROMBERG-Sophie. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Sisterhood mourn the passing of their senior member and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Haskel Lookstein, Rabbi Joshua Lookstein, Ass't Rabbi Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Passion and Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: Peacekeepers Prepare to Leave Unpeaceful Angola
description: After five years of trying to make peace in Angola, having spent at least $1.5 billion and having seen 60 of its staff members lose their lives, the United Nations is now an unwelcome guest here.

title: Q & A
description: Greek Fire

title: Clam Boat Hits Jetty, Spilling Fuel Into Inlet
description: Coast Guard personnel worked to contain a fuel spill in Manasquan Inlet yesterday after a 68-foot clam boat struck a jetty and its three crew members had to be pulled from the water, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUNSTEIN, JEAN
description: BRAUNSTEIN-Jean, 83. On January 15. Beloved wife of the late Murray, loving mother of Paula and Walter Solyards and Harry and JoAnn Braunstein and Ben and Cindy Braunstein. Adored grandmother of Bonnie, Robert, Susan, Michael, Melissa, Emily, and Andrew. Great grandmother of Jessica, Hannah and Joseph. Full of love, warmth and music, she will always be an inspiration to her family.

title: New Rules Proposed for Medical Experiments on Mentally Ill
description: A state advisory panel has proposed new rules that would allow medical experiments involving some risk to be performed on mentally ill patients and others incapable of giving consent.

title: Law Lords in London Open Rehearing of Pinochet Case
description: A panel of Law Lords, Britain's highest court, today opened a rehearing of Gen. Augusto Pinochet's plea to be freed from house arrest and allowed to return home to Chile.

title: Approval of Rate Policy, But No New Financial Aid
description: The International Monetary Fund and the United States said today that they were heartened by Brazil's pledge to keep interest rates high and slash its budget deficit. But they offered no new financial aid and made clear that Brazil's economic fate is largely in its own hands.

title: Environmentalists Battle Growth of Ski Resorts
description: Next weekend, skiers here are to inaugurate the world's highest chair lift. Whisking 1,200 skiers an hour to a 12,700-foot ridge, the lift will offer sweeping views of the Rockies and challenging runs down the Continental Divide.

title: SEAGRAM TO REVAMP ITS SPIRITS AND WINES BUSINESS
description: The Seagram Company said yesterday that it would reorganize its spirits and wines business over the next six months, shifting from a regional and brand group structure to a single, senior management team based in New York. Montreal-based Seagram, which also owns Universal Studios, said the overhaul would help improve sales, marketing and distribution. Seagram also raised its Latin American spirits and wine division to the same status as those in other geographic regions, all of which will report to Stephen J. Kalagher, president and chief executive of the Seagram Spirits and Wine Group.

title: Some X's, Many O's And 7 Hours of Z's
description: The National Football League conference championships on Sunday concluded the normal part of your viewing season. The Atlanta-Minnesota game began with Fox's hourlong pre-game show and CBS's Jets-Denver game with a 30-minute show.

title: Why Won't Clinton Cut Taxes?
description: One of the main things that frustrates President Clinton's enemies so much is his skill at identifying the issues Americans care about. So it is somewhat surprising, given the budget surplus and the magnitude of the current Federal tax burden, that Mr. Clinton has not moved to co-opt the Republicans in this area, as he has in so many others, by proposing a big tax cut.

title: Internet Service Is Planning $6 Billion Deal to Buy Excite
description: At Home Network, a high-speed Internet service aimed at cable television subscribers, is expected to announce on Tuesday that it is acquiring Excite Inc., a leading Internet destination, in a transaction valued at about $6 billion, according to a person involved in the deal.

title: New Jersey Loses A Bet on Its Jets
description: It was only a playoff game. But the Jets-Broncos game on Sunday had some officials making the kinds of ''my state's team is better than your state's team'' bets that they usually leave for the Super Bowl.

title: Is Wisconsin Welfare Plan Good for Children?
description: To the Editor:

title: School Voucher Savings
description: To the Editor:

title: I.O.C. Expands Bribery Inquiry
description: The International Olympic Committee said yesterday that it was expanding its investigation of bribery in Salt Lake City to other cities in an effort to clean up irregularities in the bidding process for Winter and Summer Games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERNDON, NOAH T.
description: HERNDON-Noah T. of Chestnut Hill and Duxbury, January 12, 1999, age 66. General Partner of private banking firm Brown Brothers Harriman & Co. Husband of Nancy R. Roberts. Father of Noah T. Herndon, Mark L. Herndon, Calista M. Herndon. Brother of John W. Herndon, Jr., Steven M. Herndon and David L. Herndon. A memorial service will be held Friday, January 22 in the First Parish Church, 382 Walnut St, Brookline, MA. at 11 AM. Memorial donations may be made to Carroll School, C/O Naomi Hitchcock, Baker Bridge Road, Lincoln, MA. 01773 or to Plimouth Plantation, C/O Anne Phelan, POB 1620, Plymouth, MA. 02362.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, ELLEN (RIVINIUS)
description: ANDERSON-Ellen (Rivinius) Hill of Essex, CT, formerly of Bedford, NY died January 17. Wife of the late John Chandler Hill and Walter J. Anderson. Memorial service January 19 at 1:00 PM at St. John's Episcopal Church, Essex, CT.

title: Walking the International Tightrope
description: As the United Nations enters a new century of challenges, we must find new ways to defeat the age-old enemies of peace and prosperity. In fulfilling this task, the Secretary General is accorded a central role -- by the United Nations Charter, by history and by the trust placed in him by member states.

title: Rape Suspect Arrested After 35-Mile Chase
description: A rape suspect was arrested on Sunday after he had led the police on a 35-mile chase that ended when he ran out of gas while trying to slash his wrists and neck in an apparent suicide attempt, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPATZ, ROSA
description: KOPATZ-Rosa. Beloved aunt of Arlene Aurnou, Marilyn Grapin and Shirley Sarris and several nieces and nephews. Private services were held on January 17th. She will be missed.

title: Devils' Offense Turns Cold At Start of California Trip
description: Unable to get their offense in gear, the Devils began a three-game trip to California this afternoon with a 3-1 loss to the San Jose Sharks.

title: Still No Changes On Roster
description: The MetroStars, who have been threatening to renovate their roster, have made no decisions yet about any personnel changes. The same players who were with the team last year will gather for opening day of training camp on Monday. Coach Bora Milutinovic and Charlie Stillitano, the team's vice president and general manager, said they needed further evaluation of the roster before making decisions.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about Manhattan bars that serve single-malt Scotches misstated the position and given name of a tasting host at the North Star Pub in the South Street Seaport. He is Deven Black, not Devon, and is the general manager, not the owner.

title: Don't Shake Faith In Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Abroad at Home; The Two Realities in Clinton's Trial
description: Were the House Republican prosecutors talking about the President or about a mafia don? Their language was sometimes so extreme -- ''conspiracy,'' ''infamy'' -- that it was hard to tell.

title: W. P. Keeton; Tort Expert And School Dean Was 89
description: W. Page Keeton, a leading expert on tort law who as longtime dean at the University of Texas Law School brought the school to national prominence, died on Jan. 10 at his home in Austin. He was 89.

title: Jury Awards $12.7 Million To a Woman Denied Tenure
description: A jury has awarded $12.7 million to a former assistant professor of chemistry who was denied tenure at Trinity College in Hartford, a verdict that some educators call the biggest by far for a tenure case in the United States.

title: CMS ENERGY ACQUIRES 750 MILES OF GAS PIPE IN TEXAS
description: CMS Energy Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest natural gas and electric utility, said it had bought 750 miles of gas-gathering pipes in north-central Texas from the closely held Koch Industries Inc., more than doubling CMS's pipeline assets in that area. Financial terms were not disclosed. The pipes, about 150 miles south of Dallas, were once used to collect crude oil from wells. CMS, based in Dearborn, Mich., plans to convert portions of those pipes to collect natural gas from wells and transport it to processing plants.

title: Culture City Talks Trash To Visitors
description: THERE is a way to keep the Great Trash War from spinning out of control and landing in court as Giuliani v. All States:

title: SEMA GROUP ANNOUNCES AN ALLIANCE WITH BROADVISION
description: Sema Group P.L.C., Europe's second-largest computer services company, said it had formed an alliance with Broadvision Inc., an Internet software company based in Redwood City, Calif., to offer systems to telecommunications companies that would allow customers to pay bills and buy services through the Internet. Sema, which declined to comment on the value of the alliance, said the systems it developed would be available to customers in the spring. Tidu Maini, Sema's senior vice president, said acquisition of Broadvision would have been too expensive, but the company said it planned to buy several companies as it strengthened its services to the telecommunications industry.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HANKIN, LEONARD
description: HANKIN-Leonard. A Memorial Service will be held on Tuesday, January 19, at 5 PM at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison at 81st St.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Extinction, Ancient Style

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOLOV, DR. BENJAMIN.
description: ZOLOV-Dr. Benjamin. The Ramaz School family mourns the passing of the beloved father of its devoted alumni parent and generous benefactor, Donna Silverman, and extends fullest sympathy to the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, Principal David N. Kahn, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: English Coal Mine to Close
description: Midlands Mining Ltd., a British coal producer backed by Candover Investments P.L.C., said today that it would close the nation's oldest operating coal mine and cease trading in September after not cutting costs enough. The company, which employs 386 people at the Annesley Bentinck mine that opened in 1865 in the north of England, lost about $:4 million ($6.61 million) in the last six months, said Dyer Bartlett, the company's finance director.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIBEL, LILLIAN (LILI).
description: KIBEL-Lillian (Lili). On January 17, 1999. Beloved wife of Henry, mother of Charles, Adam and Jamie. Grandmother of Cole and Hannah. Trustee of Project Renewal. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Tuesday, January 19 at 1:30 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to the Columbia University ALS Gift Fund, in care of ALS Center, 710 West 168 Street, NY, NY 10032.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVID, LIONEL
description: DAVID-Lionel. Age 74. At home Saturday January 16, 1999. Services private. In lieu of flowers contributions to your favorite charity.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Suit Contends Nine West and Stores Illegally Fixed Shoe Prices
description: A lawsuit filed on behalf of millions of women who purchased Nine West shoes at large department stores, contends that the giant footwear company conspired with the stores to illegally fix prices.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TUBY, DR. ROBERT.
description: TUBY-Dr. Robert. Happy Birthday, darling Daddy. We miss and will love you forever. All our love. Joan, Evelyn and Famil

title: WINSLOEW FURNITURE CHAIRMAN LEADS A COMPANY BUYOUT
description: Winsloew Furniture Inc.'s chairman, Earl W. Powell, is leading a $205 million management buyout of the company, which makes aluminum furniture for patios and offices. Mr. Powell's group offered $30 a share in cash, a 10 percent premium over Winsloew's closing share price Friday of $27. The company said its board formed a special committee to evaluate and consider the offer. Winsloew, based in Birmingham, Ala., had nine-month sales of $98.2 million as of Sept. 25. For the third quarter, ended Sept. 25, it earned $3.5 million, or 48 cents a diluted share, compared with $2.2 million, or 30 cents in the period a year earlier. The company also reported sales of $33.2 million for the latest quarter, up from $27.9 million a year earlier.

title: Vikings Are Still Shocked By Loss
description: Atlanta Coach Dan Reeves was all smiles this morning while chatting it up on ''Good Morning America.'' He made a few jokes about his quadruple bypass surgery, talked about the joy of returning to the Super Bowl and politely sidestepped questions about his stormy relationship with Denver quarterback John Elway. It was a great morning because it followed a great afternoon.

title: In Race to Develop Blue Lasers, Japanese Star Surges Ahead
description: A lone Japanese inventor has outrun some of the world's largest and most advanced high-technology corporations in the race to develop a new generation of short-wavelength lasers. The achievement is likely to hasten the introduction of high-definition digital video disks, higher-resolution laser printing and inexpensive and highly efficient light bulbs for use in the home.

title: Spotlight on Architect's Work In Wake of a Garage Collapse
description: City building inspectors plan to examine several other large housing complexes in New York City designed by the architect who handled the Seward Park Houses on the Lower East Side, where an underground parking garage collapsed on Friday.

title: The Roses Of Youth Smell Less In Old Age
description: Here is yet another reason to stop and smell the roses: They might not smell as sweet later on.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Connecticut and Westchester sections on Sunday about a model train exhibition at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center misstated the museum's telephone number. It is (203) 322-1646.

title: Don't Shake Faith In Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, IRVING
description: BRODSKY-Irving. Of Rye, N.Y. Passed away on January 17, 1999. He was a gentle and compassionate man who dedicated his life to helping others. He is survived by his wife, Jeanne, his son, Robert, and his wife, Karin, his precious grandchildren, Jake and Olivia, as well as caring extended family and many dear friends. Services will be held on January 20, 1999, at 10 A.M. at the Rye Community Synagogue, 200 Forest Ave, Rye, NY. The family is requesting that donations be sent to the Irving Brodsky Scholarship Fund of the Block-Hexter Vacation of the Associated Camps, Inc., 197 E. Broadway, NY, NY 10002. For additional information, please call Zion Memorial Chapel, 1-914-381-1809.

title: Clinton's School Plan Praised for Goals, if Not Means
description: President Clinton's proposal to use Federal education money to hold public schools accountable drew a mixed reaction from Republicans and educators yesterday. While almost all said they shared his goals, some opposed his means: the increased role of the Federal Government in local schools.

title: Subways First, Stadium Second
description: To the Editor:

title: Rating the Commercial Broths
description: IN tasting 17 commercial stocks, I found only two that could substitute admirably for a quickly made chicken broth and two that were nearly as good. The others, though far less costly, suffered by comparison. Most of those in the ''acceptable'' category will give good results if enhanced.

title: Teetering at the Summit in France
description: A SOFT winter rain is falling on this sleepy farm town on the western edge of Burgundy. The old hotels and restaurants that line the main street are as gray and somber as the overcast sky. Except one, La Cote d'Or, at the southern end of town, one of the legendary inns and restaurants of France.

title: TAKEOVER BID FOR CELLULAR COMMUNICATIONS RISES BY 21%
description: The Italian telecommunications group Olivetti S.p.A. and its German partner, Mannesmann A.G., said yesterday that they had increased their bid for Cellular Communications International Inc. by 21 percent, to $80 a share, or a total of $1.7 billion. The new bid comes after Olivetti's first $65.75-a-share, or $1.4 billion, offer for Cellular, which had the approval of Cellular's board, failed to appeal to shareholders. As of last Friday, just 10.6 percent of Cellular's outstanding stock had been tendered to the offer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULHOF, RUDOLPH B.
description: SCHULHOF-Rudolph B. The Board of Trustees and Staff of The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation deeply mourn the loss of Rudolph B. Schulhof. Ruda and his wife, Hannelore, have been invaluable supporters of the Guggenheim Museum and helped nuture the institution over several decades. Their shared dedication carries on through the continuing role of Hannelore as a charter member of the Peggy Guggenheim Collection Advisory Board. Ruda became a member of the Art & Museum Committee in 1991 and was elected to the Board of Trustees for The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in 1993, serving in both of those roles with great distinction. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, to his children, and to his entire family. Peter Lawson-Johnston Honorary Chairman The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation

title: Joppy Hospitalized After Auto Accident
description: William Joppy, the World Boxing Association middleweight champion, was injured in an auto accident Monday afternoon in Capital Heights, Md., and will not be able to defend his title against the No.1 contender, Darren Obah, in a bout that had been scheduled for Washington on Feb. 6.

title: A Double-Edged Day Ends On a Note of Hopefulness
description: Beaming indomitability, President Clinton shouldered past friend and foe in Congress tonight to personify for the nation the question of the hour: Is he on the brink of destruction, or at some fresh peak of resilience?

title: Giuliani in His Own Words
description: Following is an excerpt from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's comments last Wednesday about exporting trash:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGELBRECHT, FREDERICK F. (FRED)
description: ENGELBRECHT - Frederick F. (Fred). At age 91. Retired New York Times Pressman, World War II veteran, beloved uncle of Mary and Richard Ware and numerous other nieces & nephews. Inquiries to Bruno V. Caracciolo, Licensed Funeral Director. Reposing at Franklin Funeral Home, 42 New Hyde Park Road, Franklin Square, New York. Visitation Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass Thursday, 9:45AM, Saint Catherine of Sienna R.C. Church. Interment is at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Donations in his memory to Little Sisters of the Poor.

title: Power of the N.C.A.A. In Court Test Today
description: Renee M. Smith has always been on the fast track. A dynamite varsity volleyball player in high school, she lettered in each of her four years. A valedictorian, she went to St. Bonaventure University on an academic rather than an athletic scholarship. She walked on and became a leading player on the women's volleyball team. When she graduated in 1993, just two and one-half years after she enrolled, she had two years of athletic eligibility remaining.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORNER, WALTER H.
description: BORNER-Walter H. of Saugerties, NY on January 17, in his 89th year. Survived by Ann (Schirmer), wife of 61 years, sons Craig of San Clemente, CA, and Steven of Bedford, NY and his wife Candy and grandsons Andrew of Hoboken and Brooke of Bedford. Service at Blue Mt. Dutch Reformed Church, Saugerties, Thursday. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to his church or charity of your choice appreciated

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMEY, BRIAN N.
description: AMEY-Brian N. On January 18, 1999. Son of Nicola and the late Francis L. Amey. Husband of Maria Alicia Amey, father of Francis and Nicole. Brother of Christopher and Lowell. Friends may visit Wednesday, January 20 from 15PM, Vanella Funeral Home, 2860 Long Beach Road, Oceanside, Long Island, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESTENBERG, JUDITH, M.D.
description: KESTENBERG-Judith, M.D. NYU Psychoanalytic Institute mourns the loss of our esteemed and beloved colleague, Judith Kestenberg, M.D. As a Training and Supervising Analyst, she contributed so much to our institute, to her students, and to her patients. Her work with those affected by the Holocaust, both children and adults, is well-known, and has been of tremendous value for all of humanity. We are saddened by her loss. Dr. Michael Singer, Director Dr. Robert Fischel, Secretary

title: Clinton Social Security Plan Runs Into Opposition
description: After a year of trying to reduce the political voltage running through Social Security and months of maneuvering over who would put a proposal on the table first, President Clinton stepped up today with the outlines of a plan to strengthen the system and promptly got clobbered.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: NEWPORT NEWS TO ACQUIRE AVONDALE INDUSTRIES
description: Newport News Shipbuilding Inc., the maker of nuclear submarines and aircraft carriers, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Avondale Industries for $470 million in stock. Newport News will pay 1.196 of its shares for each of Avondale's shares, valuing Avondale at about $35.50 -- a 31 percent premium to Avondale's share price of $27.125, where the stock was trading before it was halted. Avondale, based in Avondale, La., is building the LPD-17, the first in a new class of amphibious assault vehicles for the Navy. The combined company will have $2.6 billion in revenue this year and will be known as Newport News Avondale Industries. Shares of Newport News, which is based in Newport News, Va., fell 18.75 cents, to $29.6875.

title: Correction
description: A picture of a package of plastic wrap was published in error last Wednesday with the Eating Well column in the Dining section, which reported a study of potentially harmful effects of a substance found in some plastic wraps.

title: Vouchers Aren't O.K.
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRING, WALTER DONALD
description: KRING-Walter Donald, The Reverend. Died at age 82 at his home in Brookfield, MA on Friday, January 15, 1999. Dr. Kring was Minister Emeritus of All Souls Church in New York City where he served as Senior Minister from 1955 to 1978. A memorial service will be held at All Souls, 1157 Lexington Avenue, at 1PM, on Sunday, January 24.

title: Mercedes Sets Record For Vehicle Output
description: The DaimlerChrysler Corporation produced a record number of Mercedes-Benz luxury cars in 1998, the company reported yesterday. Mercedes made 926,400 vehicles, up some 200,000 units, or 27 percent, for the year. The biggest increases were in the new A-class, M-class, CLK coupe and CLK convertible models, all introduced in 1997.

title: NATO Fails in Belgrade Talks to Halt Kosovo Attacks
description: Two NATO generals flew to Belgrade today to face down the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, on the violence in Kosovo, but they failed to win any concessions, Administration officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHEFTEL, STUART ''BOY''
description: SCHEFTEL-Stuart ''Boy''. After five years your inimitable character and presence continue to inspire us. Buzzie, Geraldine, Michael, Susan and Ric

title: A Tribute at Carnegie Hall In Memory of Judith Arron
description: As the executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall from 1986 until her death in December, and before that, as manager of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, Judith Arron established friendships and working relationships with many musicians and music business executives. About 1,200 of them, as well as members of Ms. Arron's family, and friends from outside the music world, convened at Carnegie Hall to pay tribute to her on Tuesday afternoon. Ms. Arron died on Dec. 18 at the age of 56.

title: Revolving Art Show
description: To the Editor:

title: The Schedule
description: Following is the expected schedule for the impeachment trial of President Clinton:

title: INSIDE
description: Israeli Campaign Files Taken

title: San Francisco Pie-Throwers Are Guilty Of Battery
description: The pie-throwers were on a roll. Within a few months, they had whammed their liberal objections into a gallery of unwitting political foes. They ''pied'' more than a half-dozen bigwig corporate executives and politicians in the face, and they got away with it.

title: About New York; Archive Tells How Church And City Grew
description: THE moving van has yet to roll up to John Cardinal O'Connor's residence on Madison Avenue. Although at 79 he has passed the church's mandatory retirement age of 75, he continues to serve at the discretion of his friend and superior, Pope John Paul II. So, what gives with all the boxes he has been sending to the archdiocese's seminary in Yonkers?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, LOUISE KIRTLAND
description: ALEXANDER-Louise Kirtland, actress, died at 93, in her New York apartment on January 14. She was the widow of A.L. Alexander, star and producer of radio's ''Court of Human Relations''. Ms. Kirtland appeared on Broadway in the ''Waltz of the Toreadors'', ''Tea and Sympathy'' and the revival of ''Mame'' with Angela Lansbury. She is on the original cast recording of ''Tovarich'' and substituted for the ailing Agnes Moorehead in ''Gigi''. She was in the film ''Roseland'' and in the TV series ''Car 54, Where are You''. She was in numerous productions all over the U.S. Funeral services will be held today in the Goodrich Funeral Home, 128 Washington Street, Lynn, MA. Burial will be in Pine Grove Cemetery, in Lynn.

title: Shot Blocker in Place, Nets Seeking Chemistry
description: For all of their grace, athleticism and leaping ability, the Nets have not been too skilled at blocking shots. For that reason, the few players who worked out today at the club's Champion Center praised Monday's three-player trade that sent Michael Cage and Don MacLean to Seattle for Jim McIlvaine, a 7-foot-1-inch center who specializes in swatting shots away.

title: Clamming Boat and Her Four-Member Crew Disappear Off New Jersey
description: For the second time in less than two weeks, a commercial clamming boat has vanished in the surging Atlantic Ocean off New Jersey, this time leaving only a large oil slick, a few pieces of debris and no sign of her four crew members.

title: Chinese Debt Trouble Grows; Another Company Is Bankrupt
description: The Hong Kong trading company of China's Hubei province has filed for liquidation, becoming the latest Chinese investment company to collapse under the weight of foreign debt.

title: The Essence of Tangerine
description: TANGERINE is a flavor that appeals to all tastes, but it is not easy to show off in a sauce. While a tablespoon of lemon or lime juice added at the end of cooking makes its presence felt, a similar amount of tangerine juice is lost instantly.

title: A Change of Hands for the Concord, a Catskills Icon
description: In legal terms, the auction in Courtroom 520 at the United States Bankruptcy Court here was titled ''97-20487 Fre-Par Laboratories Inc., A New York Corporation, Chapter 11 Hearing of Sale.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, IRVING
description: BRODSKY-Irving. Of Rye, N.Y. Passed away on January 17, 1999. He was a gentle and compassionate man who dedicated his life to helping others. He is survived by his wife, Jeanne, his son, Robert, and his wife, Karin, his precious grandchildren, Jake and Olivia, as well as caring extended family and many dear friends. Services will be held on January 20, 1999, at 10 A.M. at the Rye Community Synagogue, 200 Forest Ave, Rye, NY. The family is requesting that donations be sent to the Irving Brodsky Scholarship Fund of the Block-Hexter Vacation of the Associated Camps, Inc., 197 E. Broadway, NY, NY 10002. For additional information, please call Zion Memorial Chapel, 1-914-381-1809.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIBEL, LILI
description: KIBEL-Lili. Riverdale Country School extends its deepest sympathy to the family of Lili Kibel, dear wife of former Trustee, Henry Kibel, and adored mother of Charles, Adam and Jami. Her steadfast dedication to Riverdale Country School continued after her children had graduated. She remained an active member of the Riverdale family. Most recently, she served on The Campaign for Riverdale Committee. Her gracious presence shall be missed. David F. Stein, Chairman John R. Johnson, Headmaster

title: STATE OF THE UNION: THE PUNDITS -- Media Notebook; Across Networks, Adjectives (Big Ones) Abound on a Day for the History Books
description: Superlatives, sports metaphors and every imaginable synonym for the word ''surreal'' jammed the airwaves yesterday as the television networks jockeyed to do justice to a day described as a ''political double-header'' packed with events most historic, most incredible and, yes, most surreal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUMAN, RONALD
description: SCHUMAN-Ronald. The HewlettEast Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Ronald Schuman, and extends heartfelt sympathy to his wife Andrea and the entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek, Dr. Norman Doctor, President

title: Calendar
description: Toasting Robert Burns

title: Deutsche Telekom Earnings Climb 50%
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G., Europe's largest telephone company, reported an indicated earnings gain of 50 percent for the second half today, despite slow sales growth.

title: The Aperitif Moment: Sip or Flinch
description: FIRST impressions last longest. The downbeat of the conductor's baton, the first step in a tango, the opening words in a flirtation -- these initial moves can make or break. So, why is the aperitif, the traditional mood-setter for the perfect meal, so poorly understood, especially now, when restaurants all over town seem to be bending over backward to create distinctive pre-meal drinks?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEONARD, ELIZABETH DERHAM
description: LEONARD-Elizabeth deRham, in her 86th year, died peacefully on January 19, 1999. Beloved wife of the late James Richards Leonard, she is survived by three daughters, Natalie L. Vitti, Laura L. Meyers, Virginia L. Bagdady and one son, James R. Leonard, Jr. A memorial service will be held at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Old Lyme, CT., Thursday, January 21 at 11 A.M., to be followed by a reception at Essex Meadows, Essex, CT. A family memorial service will be held in Newton, MA. at a later date. Donations may be made in her memory to the American Lung Association or the Essex Meadows Employee Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVID, LIONEL
description: DAVID-Lionel. Age 74. At home Saturday January 16, 1999. Services private. In lieu of flowers contributions to your favorite charity.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
