description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by the White House counsel, Charles F. C. Ruff, in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: Jordan McGrath yields. After years of entreaties, it agrees to sell, joining Havas and Euro RSCG.
description: AND the major independent agencies continue to dwindle down to a precious few, to quote a snippet of ''September Song'': Jordan McGrath Case & Partners in New York agreed yesterday to be bought by Havas Advertising in Paris.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOVITZ, SAMUEL L.
description: SOLOVITZ-Samuel L., age 71, passed away on Tuesday, January 12, 1999. Mr. Solovitz moved to Houston in 1984, after retiring from the New York Times Newspaper after 40 years. Surviving him are, niece, Brenda Polunsky and Husband Richard; nephew, Lewis Solovitz and wife Mona; great-nieces, Anna Polunsky, Michelle and Amanda Solovitz; and a great-nephew, Jeremy Polunsky. Services and interment were held Sunday, January 17, 1999, in Clifton, New Jersey.

title: A.B.L. Player's Apparent Suicide Brings Shock and Bewilderment
description: Until she stood before her younger sister early Monday morning with a shotgun in her hand, Katrina Price seemed ready to get on with her life, friends and acquaintances of the 23-year-old Waco, Tex., native said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMANN, HANS C.
description: ALTMANN-Hans C. On January 15, 1999. Loving and devoted husband of Ruth Rogers Altmann. Beloved father of Carol Altmann Molony (husband Ray), Peter M. Altmann (wife Cathy), John R. Altmann (wife Joyce), Anthony F. Altmann (wife Lisa) and stepfather of Susan C. Friedman (husband Harris) and Victoria K. Thorson (husband Tom). Proud grandfather of Steven, Michelle, Allison and Daniel Altmann and Kate C. Boyle (husband Jeff), Ian and Alexandra Thorson. Interment will be private. Memorial will be held at a later date. Any contribution in his memory may be made to the Parkinson Disease Foundation, 710 W. 168 Street, New York, N.Y. 10032.

title: A Sure Cure for Bordeaux Sticker Shock
description: THE best 1996 Bordeaux wines are being bottled right now, the 1997's are still maturing in barrels and the 1998's are almost ready for blending. In a few months, the most famous first-growth chateaus will announce their prices for the 1998 vintage, to be delivered in 2001.

title: By Day and Night, an Argument for Survival
description: First his lawyers argued that President Clinton, an invisible presence in the well of the Senate courtroom, should not be removed from office for anything he had done.

title: Efforts To Tame A Far Out World
description: Explaining classical music of the 1960's in terms of counterculture, civil rights and Vietnam may reach a little far, but Leon Botstein's program of Carter, Lutoslawski, Dallapiccola and Berio with the American Symphony Orchestra on Sunday afternoon did indirectly put its finger on a common denominator of art and history.

title: U.S. Audit Is Said to Criticize Giuliani's Strict Welfare Plan
description: A two-month Federal inquiry into New York City's welfare program has found that city officials routinely violate the law by denying poor people the right to apply promptly for food stamps, according to two officials who have read a draft report prepared by the United States Department of Agriculture.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Clinton Outlines His Vision for Nation's Transition to the 21st Century
description: The following is the prepared text of President Clinton's State of the Union address to Congress tonight, as provided by the White House:

title: Police Officer Is Charged With Murder In Connecticut
description: A police officer in New Milford, Conn., turned himself in to the State Police yesterday after being charged with murder in the shooting death of an unarmed suspect last month.

title: Ruining Of Bulls Begins In Earnest
description: One week after the retirement of Michael Jordan, the Chicago Bulls are resembling a team that could lose as many games this season as it won a year ago.

title: INTEL AND PICTURETEL IN PRODUCT-DEVELOPMENT PACT
description: The Intel Corporation will invest more than $30 million in the video-conferencing equipment maker the Picturetel Corporation as part of a distribution and product-development deal reached by the companies. Under the agreement, announced yesterday, Intel, the world's largest maker of microprocessors, will grant Picturetel the rights to sell its Intel Proshare and Team Station video-conferencing phones. Team Station is a product for groups that can be used in conference rooms and combines computer file sharing and slide shows with video conferencing. The companies will also develop products based on personal computer technology.

title: N.H.L.: DEVILS
description: The Devils are out of sync when it comes to scoring goals and as a result they have won only twice, against two weak teams, in eight games this month.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; 'Three Strikes' Challenge Fails, but Others Are Invited
description: A California prison inmate, serving a sentence of 25 years to life under the state's ''three strikes'' law for shoplifting a $20 bottle of vitamins, failed to persuade the Supreme Court today to hear his argument that the law imposes unconstitutionally cruel and unusual punishment.

title: Subways First, Stadium Second
description: To the Editor:

title: Dressing Pears for a Dinner Party
description: THE pear, a fruit that is at its peak this time of year, has more talent than it gets credit for. Picked in autumn before it is ripe, then put in cold storage for a while, it is a staple at Greenmarkets throughout the winter, remaining crisp and juicy while some apple varieties are turning mealy.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR FALLS 8.7 PERCENT. Raw sugar prices tumbled on expectations that Brazil will export more sugar because of its weakened currency. The March contract fell 0.73 cent, to 7.69 cents a pound, the lowest since Dec. 28.

title: Farm Exports are Cited In a Call for Trade Talks
description: President Clinton called tonight for a new round of global trade negotiations beginning at the end of the year that would, above all, aides said, help promote the export of American agricultural products.

title: For Children Only
description: Next month Nickelodeon will begin a new digital broadcast channel filled with educational programs for preschoolers in partnership with Children's Television Workshop. The channel, Noggin, will face a rival from Children's Television Workshop's other partner, PBS, which on Monday announced plans to start a 24-hour children's channel in the fall. While Children's Television Workshop still makes new episodes of ''Sesame Street'' for PBS, and will for the next five years, the episodes revert to it after two years on the public network and will then be seen only on Noggin.

title: Canned Stock: Getting Over The Guilt
description: LET'S finally face the truth.

title: Finnish I.O.C. Member Resigns Over Scandal
description: Pirjo Haeggman of Finland, one of the first women selected to the International Olympic Committee, yesterday became the first I.O.C. member to resign over fallout from the Salt Lake City corruption scandal.

title: On the Road to Success, Help in the Home Stretch
description: The dog never ate Leondra Price's homework.

title: As Police Near, Man Leaps From Window to Death
description: One man was killed and another broke his leg yesterday when they jumped from a fourth-floor window in Washington Heights while apparently trying to elude officers who had come to search an apartment, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, BETTY
description: HARRIS-Betty. On January 19, 1999. Mother of Stephen and Dennis and daughter-in-law Kathy. Grandmother of Kenneth, Richard and Scott. Services on Thursday, January 21st, at 11 A.M., Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
description: In a challenge to makers of traditional communications gear, Cisco Systems Inc., the No. 1 maker of Internet equipment, says it is close to introducing a device that will allow communications carriers to route voice, video and data traffic on a single system, and at a fraction of current costs.

title: A Sense of Theater
description: For years Jac Venza has dreamed of bringing real drama back to television. Not the sort of drama seen in prime-time series like ''E.R.'' and not television movies. Real stage drama, the kind Channel 13 in New York used to present to the PBS system under the name ''American Playhouse.''

title: Magical Place Reborn as Gulf Rim Bistro
description: WHEN I was growing up, I thought the two blocks of West 10th Street between Fifth and Greenwich Avenues were the best in New York. I'd dawdle on my way to school, looking up at the house where Mark Twain once worked and, a few doors down, the one where Joseph Mitchell was working. Crossing Sixth Avenue, I'd brush past the men standing on the sidewalk in front of the Women's House of Detention, wreathed in the mingled aromas of Shapira's coffee and Sutter's bakery, calling up to their girlfriends. I always imagined that E. E. Cummings, who lived right there in Patchin Place, was making their words into poetry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELZER, BENSON
description: SELZER-Benson. We will always remember Benson's sense of humor, great wit and amazing artistic talent. He will be truly missed. Our heartfelt condolences to Liz, John, Jeffrey, Andrea, Benjamin and family. Michael, Giselle, David, Ali and Adam

title: NATO's Kosovo Bid Is Rebuffed by Serbs
description: Two NATO generals who flew to Belgrade to face down President Slobodan Milosevic on the issue of violence in Kosovo, the largely ethnic Albanian province in southern Serbia, failed to win any of the concessions they were seeking, Clinton Administration officials said.

title: Virtual Sky's the Limit for On-Line Auctions at Sotheby's Web Site
description: If the hottest auction market in the country right now is in cyberspace, why shouldn't Sotheby's get in on the action?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BITTELMAN, ARTHUR
description: BITTELMAN-Arthur. In his 94th year. In Miami. On January 17, 1999. He will be missed by all who knew him for his concern for others, his generosity and wisdom. Husband of the recently deceased Gertrude Bittelman, beloved father of Rheva and Stuart Bittelman, grandfather of Laura and Eric, great-grandfather of Michael.

title: Why the Need For Witnesses Now?; Continuity Considered
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, GRACE
description: ROSENTHAL - Grace. Predeceased by her first husband Sam muel B. Herbst. Survived by her husband Abraham Rosenthal; two sons Edward I. and Ronald S. Herbst; two brothers Bert and Harold Ballin; two stepdaughters Ellen Klick and Babette Kulka and five grandchildren. For information call the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, Stamford, CT. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, 1 Pennsylvania Plaza, Suite 4800, New York, New York 10119.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. Japan's currency improved as bond yields rose and expectations spread that exporters and banks would convert foreign assets into yen, increasing demand. The dollar fell to 113.49 yen from 114.35.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAZER, WILLIAM L.
description: FRAZER-William L. Died on January 19, 1999 at home after a long bout with lung disease. Born in Brooklyn on March 11, 1917 to Charles and Lela Frazer, Mr. Frazer grew up in Brooklyn Heights. After graduating from Pratt Institute in 1938, he went on to a very successful career as an artist, photographer and advertising art director, recently retired from McCann Erickson. Mr. Frazer served in WWII as US Army Sergeant and was a contributing editor of Yank Magazine. Along with his other accomplishments, he was a longtime member of the Society of Illustrators, official artist for the US Coast Guard, active member of the World Ship Society, NYC Sierra Club, National Audubon and was a thoroughbred horse owner. Mr. Frazer is survived by a niece Frederica King, R.N. and her husband Tim and grandnephew Christian Cerone. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Thursday and Friday 2-5 & 7-9PM. Funeral Saturday, January 23, 10AM.

title: Mayor Presses Plan for Brooklyn Homeless Center
description: As the Giuliani administration presses its plan to evict several community programs from a Brooklyn building to make way for a homeless shelter, city mechanics inspected the building yesterday to determine if it was suitable for such a use.

title: Why the Need For Witnesses Now?; Unasked Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Can a Deal For Sprewell Bear Fruit?
description: THE young player was a member of a team in the West and, angry at his manager, the player attacked him. The 28-year-old player slugged the 48-year-old manager, causing a triple fracture to the manager's right cheekbone as well as back injuries related to the assault.

title: Starks Practices in Knick T-Shirt, but Door Is Open
description: A sweat-soaked Patrick Ewing flopped a towel over his shoulder and began to leave the gym without a word. He bellowed the familiar, ''No, not today,'' as he hurried past the cameras.

title: SEAGRAM TO SELL POLYGRAM ITC LIBRARY FOR $150 MILLION
description: The Seagram Company said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell the ITC library assets of Polygram Filmed Entertainment, a unit of Universal Studios Inc., to Carlton Communications P.L.C. of Britain for $150 million in cash. Proceeds from the sale will be used to pay down debt. The Polygram film production and distribution assets are not included in the sale and remain the property of Universal Studios. The ITC Library includes approximately 200 films and about 9,000 hours of television programming. Seagram operates in two global business segments: entertainment and spirits and wine.

title: Figure in a Starr Inquiry Pleads Not Guilty; Wants Trial Moved to Capital
description: As President Clinton's lawyers opened his defense before the Senate today, a peripheral figure in the impeachment pleaded not guilty in Federal court here to charges that she had interfered with the independent counsel's investigation of the President.

title: A Series Debut and a Gym's Rumble
description: A new concert series at the 92d Street Y, International Quartets, should perhaps help put to rest widespread fears that the Y is ceding its role as a major force for music in New York and beyond. But for one listener, the first event, on Saturday evening, had the opposite effect.

title: It's Back to the Drawing Board: Jets Contemplate Moves
description: Bill Parcells says he wants to upgrade at least seven areas on the Jets. He will retool, not rebuild, a team that he seems fond of.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARDISSON, JOSEPH L.
description: HARDISSON - Joseph L. We mourn the loss of our dear friend. Joe served at Lutheran Medical Center as Director of Food and Nutrition services for more than twenty years. He was a good man who encouraged his staff to provide a high quality service for our patients. We will all miss him. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Pura, his children and grandchildren, and all of his family. The Board of Trustees Administration and Staff of Lutheran Medical Center

title: Crisis in Kosovo
description: Over the last few days, the Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic has broken just about every important promise he made last fall to end his offensive in Kosovo. His security forces, which remain deployed in Kosovo in violation of the agreement, apparently massacred 45 ethnic Albanians in the village of Racak last Friday. He is now blocking war crimes investigators from entering the country and is seeking to expel the head of the international mission monitoring compliance with the agreement. Mr. Milosevic, who agreed to the plan only to head off NATO air attacks, now seems confident that NATO is too divided to use force to hold him to his promises. To prevent further massacres and spur a negotiated solution, NATO must carry out its bombing threat if Serbia continues its defiance.

title: A Fisherman's Tale of Two Warming Winter Chowders
description: THE dividing line between North and South in this country's soup cuisine lies in the chowder served. In most of New England, it's thick white chowder or none at all. South of that, there's clear chowder, also known as Manhattan, or red chowder if tomatoes are used.

title: When Children Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Dust of Empires, St. Petersburg Embraces Exiles
description: Below a Byronesque statue of Aleksandr Pushkin that stands in a small park in front of the Russian Museum near Nevsky Prospekt, some present-day romantic has placed three long-stemmed red roses, now fading, at the poet's feet. Wandering around the canaled streets of the old capital, which bears far greater witness to its czarist than to its scarred Leningrad past, a visitor is struck by the respect paid to literary eminences.

title: Some Boycott the Speech
description: The flu felled a few of them; others didn't want to make the long trip here when the House of Representatives won't be back in session again until next month.

title: McEnroe Joins McGregor on List
description: It's official: John McEnroe will be inducted into the Tennis Hall of Fame at Newport, R.I., in July. Not as clear-cut is his Davis Cup status.

title: Without Top Scorer, Irish Defeat the Pirates
description: NOTRE DAME 59, SETON HALL 56

title: THE CHEF
description: IT'S no wonder most people would rather order roast duck in a restaurant than make it themselves. Even I find it daunting to roast a duck at home, when there is so much fat, so much spattering, so much tending and so much cleaning up afterward. But there is a way to get the taste without the trouble -- by cooking a magret de canard, a breast of moulard duck. It's as easy as steak.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NATMAN, LEONARD
description: NATMAN-Leonard. August 29, 1952-January 20, 1987. Remembered with love every day. Mr. D.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANNING, MARIE TROTTER
description: MANNING-Marie Trotter. In Florida, January 18, 1999, of Belleair, Fla., and formerly of Westport, Conn. Wife of John B. Manning Sr. Born in New York City and graduate of Columbia University School of Business Class of 1939. For information call Keenan Funeral Home, West Haven, Conn., (203)933-1217.

title: Wish of Trade Achieved, Bure Gladly Joins Panthers
description: Pavel Bure's long-awaited return to the National Hockey League could come Wednesday when his new team, the Florida Panthers, visits the Islanders at Nassau Coliseum. But the Russian Rocket, who arrived on Long Island today, weary from the 10-hour flight from Moscow, did not make any promises.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, KOEHLER, PAMELA, PH.D.
description: KRAMER - KOEHLER - Pamela, Ph.D. The entire Polytechnic University community mourns the passing of Pamela Kramer-Koehler, an esteemed professor with a 25 year legacy of dedicated service to our institution and its students. Trained in developmental psychology and psycholinguistics, Professor Kramer-Koehler will long be remembered as a champion of science, mathematics and computer education for special populations such as women and minorities. She was that exemplary academic who managed to combine her scholarly interest in gender equity in computer-related learning with a strong commitment to equal opportunity for all. At the University and in her home community of Carroll Gardens in Brooklyn, she helped thousands of students find their way to successful technology-based careers. We will sorely miss her presence, commitment and example, and extend our heartfelt condolences to her daughter, Abigail, and her son, Robert. Dr. David C. Chang, President Arthur C. Martinez Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFFY, JOHN J.
description: DUFFY-John J. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of John J. Duffy, a Life Member of the Society, and extends sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CATES, JOSEPH
description: CATES-Joseph. On October 10, 1998. The New York Friars Club and the Cates family deeply mourn his passing and extend an invitation to attend a memorial service on Monday, January 25 at 2pm at Director's Guild Theater, 110 West 57 Street, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, MORRIS
description: MITCHELL-Morris, on January 18, in his 92nd year. Beloved husband of Florence R. Mitchell. Father of Jonathan (Sandra) of Dewey, AZ, and Sarah Anthony (Telly) of NYC. Grandfather of Barbara Mitchell, David Anthony and Jessica Anthony. Step-grandfather of Karen Harris and Deana Douglas. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUALL, JOAN
description: SUALL-Joan, a longtime leader and former Executive Director of Social Democrats, USA, died Sunday, Jan. 17. Joan will be missed by all those who worked with her in the struggles for greater democracy, civil rights, economic democracy and labor rights. From her friends in Social Democrats, USA

title: Subways First, Stadium Second
description: To the Editor:

title: Chase, Among Other Banks, Posts Gains for 4th Quarter
description: Some of the biggest United States banks reported gains in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday as a strong economy lifted income from loans and fees.

title: King Hussein Back Home; Despite Joy, Jordan Frets
description: Piloting his own plane, King Hussein of Jordan returned to his kingdom today after six months of cancer treatment. His arrival prompted scenes of widespread jubilation, but also speculation about who might next take the reins of the country he has governed for nearly half a century.

title: As Angola Erupts, Youths Fear Being Forced to Fight
description: In the office where he is a typist, 24-year-old Paido said, he sits near a window on the street. If he sees soldiers starting to grab young men, he can slip out the back door.

title: Excite and At Home Confirm $6.7 Billion Merger
description: One company was started in the proverbial Silicon Valley garage. The other began as a play by some of the nation's biggest cable television interests. Yesterday, they joined forces in the race to capture Internet users and the dollars they are increasingly spending on line, and investors appeared to endorse the strategy.

title: OFFICEMAX TO SHIFT TO HIGHER-END PC'S TO HALT ITS LOSSES
description: Officemax Inc., the third-largest American retailer of office supplies, said yesterday that it would shift its computer sales from low-priced personal computers to higher-end computers in a move to halt its losses in the competitive market for PC's. The company said the shift in its computer merchandising, including costs of clearing its inventory of low-price PC's, will result in a charge of $47 million to $49 million in its fiscal fourth quarter. Officemax said it would then report earnings separately for its core office supplies and furniture business and for its computer business. On Monday, Officemax had said that it would begin a test program in some stores, selling only computers made by I.B.M. Officemax is based in Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, DOROTHY J. (CAMPBELL)
description: CARTER-Dorothy J. (Campbell), of Bronxville, NY, on January 18th, 1999. Beloved wife of T. Brian Carter. Loving mother of Pamela Ann Foss and grandmother of Heather and William Foss. Died peacefully in her sleep. Her love and warmth, beauty, courage and spirit will always remain in our hearts. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM, Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Thursday, January 21st, at 10 AM. Interment at Bronxville Cemetery.

title: As Life Goes On, Or Not
description: Life in an Arab village in Galilee and the tensions of military rule by Israel in 1964 are transmitted with insight and skill in ''The Milky Way,'' and understandably so.

title: Nissan Open To Selling Off Stake of 33% To Outsider
description: The president of the Nissan Motor Company said today that he would be willing to consider the sale of more than a third of the Japanese auto maker's stock to a foreign company. Yoshikazu Hanawa, however, continued to deny that Nissan was holding talks with a suitor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLOUGHLIN, REV. WILLIAM J.
description: McLOUGHLIN-Rev. William J., The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor emeritus of St. Margaret Mary's Church, 215 Exeter Street, Brooklyn, on January 18th. Reposing at Marine Park Funeral Home, 30-24 Quentin Road, Brooklyn, Tuesday, January 19th, from 7 to 10 P.M., and Wednesday, January 20, from 2 -5 P.M. Mass of transferral, on Wednesday, January 20, at St. Margaret Mary's Church at 7:30 P.M. Funeral Mass, Thursday, January 21 at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Second Officer Resigns From Midtown Precinct
description: As the investigation continues into allegations that officers from the Midtown North Precinct stole merchandise from street vendors and used drugs, a police officer from the precinct resigned yesterday after he refused to submit to a drug test.

title: A Piece of New York Is Leaving Town
description: John Starks Jr. heard the rumors yesterday morning and decided to confront his father.

title: A 'Volcano' With Videos And a Circus
description: Video images of an erupting volcano were projected near the beginning and end of Sarah East Johnson's ''Volcano Love'' on Thursday night at the Kitchen. The volcano was spectacular. So was much of the choreography. Yet too often it failed to make a point, even though Ms. Johnson gave the impression of trying to make one.

title: Tense Times on Front Line of Brazil's Battle on Hyperinflation: Empty Shops
description: At the Cal Center shopping gallery in the tony neighborhood of Jardim Paulistano here, there are more salespeople than customers. The employees mill about the pharmacy and the appliance store, the computer shop and the shoe boutique.

title: Israeli Opposition Party Tells Of 2d Burglary in Washington
description: For the second time in a week, the Washington offices of a prominent American polltaker advising the Israeli Labor Party have been burglarized, and Labor campaign files were again stolen.

title: Why the Need For Witnesses Now?; Political Grandstanding
description: To the Editor:

title: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC TO BUY ABT BUILDING FOR $160 MILLION
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to buy the ABT Building Products Corporation for $15 a share, or about $160 million, in cash plus the assumption of about $65 million in debt. Louisiana-Pacific is a building products company based in Portland, Ore., with manufacturing operations in the United States, Canada and Ireland. ABT Building Products, based in Neenah, Wis., makes building products in the United States and Canada. ABT Building Products shares closed at $14.75 yesterday, up 6.25 cents, while shares of Louisiana-Pacific fell 81.25 cents, to $18.

title: Slender Comes the Cookie
description: AT last, someone has figured out how to make a truly exceptional oatmeal-raisin cookie. That someone is Marcy Sansolo, owner of Love Marcy, a mail-order bakery in Manhattan. Ms. Sansolo's version is amply chewy, filled with flat, steel-cut oats, and has plenty of plump, sweet raisins. But unlike the many misconstrued oatmeal-raisin cookies in the world, it is not thick and gooey. It is as thin as a tuile. Just hold it up to light -- it looks like lace.

title: Browsers and Borders Are Argued at the Microsoft Trial
description: In the Microsoft antitrust trial, the Government spent most of today attacking the company's central defense -- that its Internet browsing software is a seamless feature of its Windows operating system and not a stand-alone product. The Government is trying to prove that the browser and operating system are two products, illegally bundled together mainly to stifle competition.

title: CORE LABORATORIES IN $181 MILLION DEAL FOR GEOSCIENCE
description: The Dutch company Core Laboratories N.V. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Geoscience Corporation, based in Houston, for $181 million in cash and stock. The deal was first reported by The Wall Street Journal. Core will also assume $33 million in debt. The sale gives Core new technology to help companies extract more oil from underground deposits. Geoscience shareholders will receive $2.46 in cash and 0.6788 share of Core Laboratories for each Geoscience share, for a combined value of $17.90. About 80 percent of Geoscience is owned by the Tech-Sym Corporation, also based in Houston. Shares of Core Laboratories fell $1.125, to $21.625, and shares of Tech-Sym rose $2.375, to $24.75. Shares of Geoscience rose $2.5625, to 16.3125.

title: Investment Grade Rating For South Korea's Credit
description: South Korea's credit rating was raised to investment grade yesterday by Fitch IBCA, a move that will ease borrowing costs for companies and deepen the pool of investors allowed to buy Korean debt. Fitch, one of the world's three largest credit rating companies, said it had upgraded South Korea's long-term foreign currency rating from BB+ to BBB-, the lowest investment grade.

title: Bush Blends Optimism and Challenge in Texas Inaugural
description: Replaying the themes of unity, optimism and social responsibility that fueled his landslide re-election victory two months ago, George W. Bush was inaugurated as Governor of the nation's second-largest state today in a sun-warmed ceremony on the south promenade of Texas's red granite Capitol.

title: Why the Need For Witnesses Now?; Fair, Not Foul
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERNDON, NOAH T.
description: HERNDON-Noah T. of Chestnut Hill and Duxbury, January 12, 1999, age 66. General Partner of private banking firm Brown Brothers Harriman & Co. Husband of Nancy R. Roberts. Father of Noah T. Herndon, Mark L. Herndon, Calista M. Herndon. Brother of John W. Herndon, Jr., Steven M. Herndon and David L. Herndon. A memorial service will be held Friday, January 22 in the First Parish Church, 382 Walnut St, Brookline, MA. at 11 AM. Memorial donations may be made to Carroll School, C/O Naomi Hitchcock, Baker Bridge Road, Lincoln, MA. 01773 or to Plimouth Plantation, C/O Anne Phelan, POB 1620, Plymouth, MA. 02362.

title: Wall Street Not Exactly Bullish On Plan to Aid Social Security
description: The bull market in stocks, running hard for more than eight years now, has already lived longer than any other in history. And if President Clinton gets his way, the gallop will continue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLINS, JEANNETTE L.
description: HOLLINS-Jeannette L. It is with profound sorrow that we mourn the loss of Jeannette L. Hollins, wife of our member, Lewis S. Hollins. We extend our sincere condolences to Lewis, Peggy, Betsy, and Gilbert. Fresh Meadow Country Club Steven Howard, President Allen Kaplan, Secretary

title: Excess Baggage On a Rite Of Passage
description: In the final scene of ''The Captain's Tiger,'' the playwright Athol Fugard, portraying himself as a young man on a tramp steamer in the South Pacific, stands at the edge of the stage and disgustedly tosses the pages of his unfinished novel into the audience. We have become his ocean, the receivers of his discarded words, and for a moment, one's inclination may be to gather up the sheets of paper and try to hand them back to him, if not for his sake, then for two characters who share the stage with him throughout this genteel and deeply personal new play, which opened last night at the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: 7 Officers Settle Charge Over Messages They Sent
description: The borough of Oakland and 7 of the 13 police officers accused of misusing the mobile computers in their patrol cars have agreed to settle departmental charges with letters of reprimand, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLETTI, PERUCCA, GERTRUDE GRETSCH
description: COLETTI - PERUCCA - Gertrude Gretsch. Died at Glen Cove Hospital, January 16. Loving wife of the late Sonio, devoted mother of Jackie, mother-in-law of Nick Drexel and grandmother of Nicholas. She was born in 1923, married to Jack Astor, and then to Sonio. She was a wonderful friend to all & will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be 11 A.M., Thursday, January 21, at St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley. In lieu of flowers, donations to Kips Bay Boys Club would be appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in the Arts & Leisure section on Sunday about this Friday's Carnegie Hall performance by the Gould Piano Trio misstated the cost of admission. Tickets are $18; the concert is not free.

title: A Full-Time Mission: Super Bowl Halftime
description: ED MICONE, the fellow at Radio City Entertainment who oversees the Super Bowl halftime show and brings in the big-name talent (harder than you might think, because what the halftime talent is paid for the Super Bowl is nothing), is a charming, fun-loving guy.

title: City Plans to Spend $4 Million To Build Youth Center in Bronx
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that the city would spend about $4 million to build a youth center in the Hunts Point section of the South Bronx.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Sunday about a commission named by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to review the salaries of city officials referred incorrectly to a post held by Richard L. Gelb, the panel's chairman. He is chairman emeritus of Bristol-Myers Squibb, not chairman.

title: The State of the Presidency; Mr. Ruff for the Defense
description: Charles Ruff put a battering ram to the impeachment case against Bill Clinton yesterday, in effect trying to bring down the entire edifice by dislodging one or more of the core arguments presented by the House prosecution team last week. It was an audacious and in some ways effective strategy, but it may invite just the kind of protracted Senate battle over witnesses and other matters that the White House hopes to avoid and the nation longs to do without.

title: 2 Big Trust Banks To Merge in Japan
description: The Mitsui Trust and Banking Company and the Chuo Trust and Banking Company agreed to a merger yesterday, creating a company with a market value of 304.4 billion yen ($2.67 billion). They said the move would help them cut costs and survive a shakeout in Japan's financial industry. The banks said they expected to save 40 billion yen annually, in part by cutting 2,000 jobs, or a fifth of their combined work force.

title: Fatal Shooting of Witness Is Called Unrelated to Murder Trial
description: Calling the occurrence ''purely coincidental,'' the Union County prosecutor said today that a man who was shot to death over the weekend, just two days before the opening of a murder trial in which he was to testify as an eyewitness, had not been killed to prevent his testimony but had instead fallen victim to his own involvement with drugs and guns.

title: How to Persuade With a Feather (or a Quill); An Editor With an Instinct for the Jugular and the Diplomatic
description: If any story illustrates the literary and diplomatic instincts that admirers attribute to Jonathan Galassi, the editor in chief of Farrar, Straus & Giroux, it is the story Tom Wolfe tells about how he came to ditch hundreds of pages of the manuscript for his new best-selling novel, ''A Man in Full.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTIMATE BRANDS, Columbus, Ohio, an apparel retailer, said it would buy back $500 million, or 6.4 percent, of its shares outstanding. It will also invest $160 million this year for growth opportunities.

title: Coca-Cola Bottler Reports Wider Loss
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., the world's largest soft-drink bottler, said today that its loss widened in the fourth quarter, mostly because it increased spending on vending machines and coolers in an effort to spur sales.

title: Subways First, Stadium Second
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOSTOVICH, MERRA
description: GOSTOVICH-Merra. On January 18, 1999. Loving sister of Kathryn, Helen, Michael, Pete and the late Nick, Evelyn, Ann and George. Dear aunt of 14 nieces and nephews. Reposing at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91 Street, NYC, Wednesday 6-9PM, Funeral Mass Holy Name R.C. Church Thursday 10AM, Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: The State of the Presidency; Mr. Clinton's New Agenda
description: President Clinton opened what was effectively the second front in the war over his Presidency last night. Shortly after his lawyers argued the fine legal points on impeachment in the Senate, Mr. Clinton outlined his most ambitious domestic agenda since 1993. Its centerpiece, a vast scheme to set aside $2.7 trillion over the next 15 years to strengthen Social Security, and $650 billion more for Medicare, served notice that the President's battle to stay in office would include efforts to revitalize the big safety-net programs that are extremely popular among the swing voters whose support he needs in the impeachment fight.

title: Club Med Rebounds To a Profit for the Year
description: Club Mediterranee S.A., Europe's largest resort operator, returned to profit last year, showing a quick return on efforts to spruce up its image and lower prices. Club Med, an operator of resort villages, said yesterday that it had a profit of 26 million euros ($30 million), or 1.73 euros a share, for the 12 months ended Oct. 31. That contrasts to a record loss of 197 million euros, or 14.3 euros a share, a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOAN, ADALAIDE
description: SLOAN-Adalaide. Of New Hempstead, NY, passed away at Good Samaritan Hospital on January 18, 1999. She was 81 years old. She had been a Rockland County resident her entire life. She was born in Spring Valley to David and Rose Orland. She married Gerald Sloan in New York City on November 17, 1946. Mr Sloan passed away last November. She was a devoted wife and loving mother of Barry Sloan and Patricia Katz. Also to her son-in-law Jay and daughterin-law Andrea. She adored her grandchildren Allyson, Jeremy, Charles and Halley. A graveside service will be held at Congregation Sons of Israel Cemetery in Monsey at 11 A.M., on January 20. Shiva will be held at Patricia Katz's home through Sunday. Donations may be made to Congregation Sons of Israel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, BESS
description: WINTER-Bess. The Mohegan Park Jewish Center mourns the passing of the beloved mother of its devoted member, Naomi Cohen. May her entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion in Jerusalem.

title: Government Says Ban on Human Embryo Research Does Not Apply to Cells
description: Federally financed researchers will soon be able to work on human embryonic stem cells, the source cells from which the embryo develops, as a result of a ruling yesterday by the Department of Health and Human Services that a Congressional ban on human embryo research does not apply to those cells.

title: McCann-Erickson Wins DuPont Plum
description: The DuPont Company in Wilmington, Del., said yesterday that it had selected McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising in New York to handle its global corporate image account, which had been handled by the New York office of Saatchi & Saatchi, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at more than $50 million.

title: Revolving Art Show
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Prosecutors Request Two Trials of Younger Gotti
description: Almost a year to the day that John A. Gotti was indicted on racketeering charges and accused of being the acting head of the Gambino crime family, Federal prosecutors asked a judge today to allow them to try Mr. Gotti twice.

title: Forgotten Flames /30 Years Later : A Czech Martyr's Dreams Give Way to Velvet Malaise
description: PRAGUE  Ten years ago Tuesday, the playwright and human rights activist Vaclav Havel laid a small bunch of lilies at a statue in central Prague to honor a Czech student, Jan Palach, who had set himself on fire in January 1969 to protest the Soviet occupation of Czechoslovakia.

title: British Aerospace Deal Upsets European Arms Industry
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. announced a $9.5 billion stock deal for the Marconi Electronics Systems unit of the General Electric Company P.L.C. today, creating a British colossus that will be one of the world's biggest military contractors.

title: Motives for a Massacre
description: The massacre last week in the Serbian province of Kosovo followed a well-established pattern: Albanian guerrillas in the Kosovo Liberation Army kill a Serb policeman or two. Serb forces retaliate by flattening a village. This time they took the lives of more than 40 ethnic Albanians, including many elderly and one child.

title: No Rise in Cancer Rate Found at Superfund Sites
description: Cancer cases among residents in six communities around three radioactive Superfund sites in Essex and Camden Counties are no greater than the average number of cases reported elsewhere in the state, the State Department of Health and Senior Services said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DINTENFASS, IRENE
description: DINTENFASS-Irene. Loving wife of the late Charlie. Dear mother of Charlotte Cohen and Claudia Karp. Devoted sister of the late Ella Davidson. Caring grandmother of Lauren, Amy, Jonathan & David. Services Wednesday, 1 PM from the Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, corner 76th Rd. and Queens Blvd., Forest Hills.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Historic Tower Near Wall Street Spruces Up for Its New Tenant
description: When a new owner took over the landmarked building at 20 Exchange Place in the heart of the financial district in late 1997, it faced an immediate decision: Convert the building to residential use? Or find a hotel operator for the vacant lower floors and keep the mostly occupied tower section as an office building?

title: Emphatic 'Not Guilty' Opens the Case for the Defense
description: Insisting that President Clinton ''must not be removed from office,'' Charles F. C. Ruff, the White House counsel, opened President Clinton's defense against impeachment charges today with sweeping denials of the accusations against him and stinging attacks on the House prosecutors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANOCHERIAN, ESKANDER
description: MANOCHERIAN-Eskander. The Officers and Board of the American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev mourn the passing of a distinguished member of the AABGU family, Eskander Manocherian. The Tuba and Yahya Manocherian Endowed Scholarship Fund he established at Ben-Gurion University in memory of his parents will help generations of students. All those whose lives he touched will forever cherish the memory of Eskander Manocherian, and we offer our heartfelt condolences to his sons, Jeffrey and Donald, his daughter, Darel Benaim, his brothers, Amir and Fraydun and his sister, Touran Waghoubzadeh. Jules I. Whitman, President AABGU Kenneth L. Tucker, Chairman AABGU Vered Mallon, Director NY Region, AABGU

title: New York Life Insurance Won't Go Public, for Now
description: The New York Life Insurance Company will announce today that unlike several other industry leaders it has decided not to change its corporate structure to enable it to issue publicly traded shares.

title: The Cookbook Battles, Round 1
description: THE Upper East Side has long been a haven for cookbook lovers. Now, it may be turning into a battlefield. For 15 years, Kitchen Arts and Letters has dominated cookbook-selling, not only in its immediate neighborhood, at Lexington Avenue and 93d Street, but also in the entire city. The small shop is the only cookbook specialty store in New York.

title: Assault in Brooklyn Recorded on Videotape
description: The police are searching for a man who pistol-whipped, sexually assaulted and robbed a woman he had followed into an elevator in her apartment building in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn last week.

title: Referrals to Special Education Fall in City
description: For the first time since 1990, New York City schools have cut down on the number of children they are referring for evaluations to determine whether they should be placed in special education, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew announced yesterday. They attributed the decline to improvements in educational programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, AARON M.
description: SCHREIBER-Aaron M. It is with great sorrow that we note the passing of Aaron M. Schreiber, beloved father of our esteemed Board Member and former Executive Committee Chairman, Simeon Schreiber and father-inlaw of our dedicated Board Member, Rose Schreiber. Mr. Schreiber's benevolent commitment to hosts of Jewish causes both in the United States and Israel characterized his days. His children who continue in his footsteps clearly learned from his magnificent example. May the Almighty comfort the entire family amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Chabad's Children of Chernobyl Yossie Raichik, Director Alan Clingman, President David Tessel, Chairman of the Exeuctive Committee

title: Liberties; Sex And Balances
description: Our newspaper banned the phrase ''split screen'' in stories about the surreal day with the President's impeachment defense bumping up against his State of the Union speech.

title: Low Numbers For Tyson-Botha
description: The Mike Tyson-Francois Botha fight in Las Vegas, Nev., fell well short of the predicted one million pay-per-view buys.

title: Sawyer-Gibson Ratings
description: ABC built it differently, and the audience came to see what was different, at least for one morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUR, FAE
description: SCHUR-Fae. On January 18th, 1999, age 91. Wife of the late Aaron Schur. Mother of sons Larry, Joel, Paul & late daughter Susan. Adored grandmother of eleven grandchildren and great grandmother to thirteen great grandchildren. Graveside services will be held Wednesday, 11 AM, Sharon Gardens Cemetery. A proud and courageous lady and mother. One of the last of her kind.

title: Journal; Inherit The Wind
description: Bill McCollum lecturing about geni-till-ia didn't get the heart racing. James Sensenbrenner's drone could be bottled as a sedative. Hence our latest ''trial of the century'' opened to thumbs-down reviews: ''Deadly!'' -- Washington Post. ''A lawyerly thud!'' -- Cox News Service. ''Snoozathon!'' -- Philadelphia Inquirer. Not even ''Meet Joe Black'' fared this badly, and its leading character was Death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIMBERLAKE, DOROTHY WINNIFRED (NOON)
description: TIMBERLAKE - Dorothy Winnifred (Noon). For 56 years beloved wife of William H. Timberlake, MD. Died of a heart block December 26, 1998, at their home in Eaton Center, N.H. Born August 1, 1916 to Professor Theodore W. Noon and Winnifred E. (Dearborn) Noon. She lived at 10 Appian Way, Cambridge, MA. She graduated from Cambridge High and Latin and from Lesley College. She taught at the Leslie Ellis School and Cambridge Friends School. She directed Crystal Lake Camp for Girls at Eaton Center for 25 summers. She lived 20 years in Belmont, MA. In 1971 she started her internationally recognized candy business. Son William H., Jr., daughters Edith, Mary, Faith and Ruth, 17 grandchildren, one great grandson, brothers Robert K. and Theodore W. Noon, Jr.

title: WARBURG, PINCUS IN DEAL FOR 51% STAKE IN FOUR MEDIA
description: The Four Media Company, a provider of technical and creative services to the television and film industries, said yesterday that the investment firm Warburg, Pincus Equity Partners L.P. had agreed to buy a 51 percent stake for about $80 million. Warburg, Pincus and certain affiliates will acquire 10.2 million shares of Four Media common stock, made up of both newly issued and existing shares. Four Media said proceeds would be used for strategic acquisitions and general business purposes. Warburg, Pincus is an affiliate of the global investment firm E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company, a unit of UBS A.G. Four Media shares rose $1.125, to $8.

title: Clinton's Lawsuit Threat Shocks Tobacco Industry
description: President Clinton's announcement that the Justice Department was preparing to sue cigarette makers came as a shock to the industry, which thought it had put most of its legal problems behind by defeating Congressional efforts to regulate nicotine and by settling a series of lawsuits brought by states.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Giuliani Says Trash Remarks Got Twisted
description: Making it clear that he was tired of talking trash, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani tried yesterday to contain the furor over his comments last week that a ''reciprocal relationship'' exists between the cultural mecca that is New York City and out-of-state communities whose residents generate garbage in their pursuit of enlightenment here.

title: Pataki Seeks New Tax Cuts, But With Delay
description: Promising to keep cutting taxes, Gov. George E. Pataki today proposed $600 million in income tax reductions, mostly aimed at the middle class, that would not go into effect until 2002 and 2003.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''William Jefferson

title: Sylvan Plans Overseas College Network
description: Since its founding 20 years ago, Sylvan Learning Systems Inc. has built itself into a little-noticed powerhouse in the world of educational testing and tutoring, the nation's leading provider of computerized tests and private remedial classes. Now it is moving into a new world, founding a network of private, for-profit colleges overseas and hiring a leading American educator to run it.

title: Memo From Belfast; Ulsterspeak A to Z: Affronts Spoken With Zest
description: The quality of debate in the Northern Ireland Assembly is reaching new metaphoric heights, or depths, in the language of Ulsterspeak, the tongue used here by politicians in which traditional euphemism is now increasingly enhanced by fulmination.

title: About All That's Missing Are the Gondolas
description: AL DI LA may seem like a peculiar name for a restaurant. A friend kept referring to this homey Venetian-accented spot as ''La-Di-Da.'' In fact, it is an Italian phrase for ''beyond'' or ''on the other side.'' No matter what you call it, though, you are not likely to call Al Di La ho-hum.

title: Subways First, Stadium Second
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, BENNETT
description: HARRISON-Bennett. The sudden loss of Bennett Harrison, Professor of Urban Political Economy at the Robert J. Milano Graduate School of New School University, is mourned by his many friends and colleagues. A generous human being with extraordinary powers to illuminate our world has been taken far too early. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Joan, his father Leo, and his sister Deborah Kuperman. M. Bryna Sanger, Acting Dean Robert J. Milano Graduate School Jonathan F. Fanton President, New School University

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHER, JANET Z.
description: ASHER-Janet Z. On January 17, 1999. Beloved wife of David, mother of Stephen Kent and sister of Leigh Zander.

title: Unbowed, Clinton Presses Social Security Plan
description: President Clinton proposed tonight that the Federal Government invest for the first time in the stock market to strengthen Social Security, as he delivered a confident report on the State of the Union to a divided Congress considering cutting short his Presidency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GODOWSKY, FRANCES GERSHWIN (FRANKIE)
description: GODOWSKY-Frances Gershwin (Frankie), on January 18th, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Leopold Godowsky, Jr. Loving mother of Alexis Gershwin, Leopold Godowsky III, Georgia Keidan and Nadia Natali. Cherished grandmother of 8. Adoring sister of the late George, Ira and Arthur Gershwin. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Thursday, January 21, at 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Channel 13 at 450 W. 33rd St., NY NY 10001.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: That Age Thing

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARANOFF, HARRY
description: ARANOFF-Harry. Age 91, on January 19, 1999. Esteemed husband of Freda Appleman Aranoff, beloved father of Dr. Shera Aranoff Tuchman, Dr. Gaya Aranoff Bernstein and Dr. Jonathan Aranoff, exceptional father-in-law of Dr. Alan Tuchman, Dr. Lewis Bernstein and Susana Krausz Aranoff, loving grandfather of Ari, Micole and Andy Tuchman; Maya, Joshua and Kyra Bernstein; Akiva, Benjamin and Daniel Aranoff; wise and respected paterfamilias to a large extended family. May his soul be bound in everlasting life. Funeral services, January 20, 10:30 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel.

title: Medgar Evers Is Falling Down; College Asks if Lack of Repairs Means a Lack of Respect
description: Edison Jackson could not take it anymore. The buckling floors. The falling tiles. The undrinkable water. Rain trickling into classrooms and hallways. A faulty fire alarm system. Then, part of his office ceiling came crumbling down.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Naomi Mitchison, the British writer and early feminist, misspelled the surname of the Labor Party leader at whom she once threw a half-plucked partridge. He was Hugh Gaitskell, not Gaitskill.

title: Of Race And Roles
description: Prime-time television is routinely criticized for having very few shows about black characters, and relatively few nonwhite actors even in supporting roles. The one network with six black family sitcoms, WB, groups four on the same night in what detractors call WB's Thursday ghetto.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEMING, YURI
description: FLEMING-Yuri June, on January 17th, 1999. Beloved wife of the late William L. Loving mother of Gloria Jean Wosniak. Also survived by three grandchildren. Retired human resources administrator at SIAC. Member of Trinity Church Family Choir. Also member of ABSA and DBE. Reposing at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28th St., NYC, Tuesday and Wednesday. Visiting hours 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service 8 PM, Wednesday.

title: Nuveen Says Profit Grew in 4th Quarter
description: John Nuveen & Company, a manager of municipal bond funds, said today that fourth-quarter earnings increased 15.4 percent, led by gains in investment advisory fees.

title: Leaving the Agency To Join the Client
description: An executive at Merkley Newman Harty in New York who has supervised the account of the National Thoroughbred Racing Association in New York is leaving the agency to join the client in the new position of marketing director.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Internet Stocks Propel Nasdaq to Another Record

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, BESS
description: HOPKINS-Bess Ashley House. Died January 16 in Cambridge, MA. Devoted mother and motherin-law of Terry, Mandy, Tom, Jay, Sarah and Matthew. Delighted grandmother of six and dear sister of Bina Beghe-and so loved by all who knew her. Funeral services on Friday, January 22, 1PM at Christ Episcopal Church, Garden St, Cambridge MA, 617-876-0200.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUND, ROSENTHAL, MIRIAM
description: FREUND - ROSENTHAL - Miriam. Equitable Bag Company mourns the passing of Miriam FreundRosenthal, beloved mother of our Chairman of the Board, Harry Freund. Our sincere sympathies are extended to her family and many friends.

title: Chief Regulator Of Futures To Step Down
description: Brooksley E. Born, the chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, said yesterday that she would step down from that post, ending a year of sharp public disagreements with other regulators and Clinton Administration officials over regulation of the financial derivatives markets.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about an Eskimo ceremony welcoming the return of the sun in the eastern Canadian arctic incorrectly described the Nunavut Research Institute, which studies the region. It is part of the government of the Northwest Territory, not the federal Government. The article also misstated the number of Eskimo elders interviewed by the institute. They conducted more than 400 interviews with a group of about 30 elders; they did not interview more than 400 elders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, MICHAEL G.
description: BURKE-Michael G. of Seaford, on January 18, 1999. Vice President of Manhattan Mechanical Contractors, Inc., New York, NY. Mr. Burke served in the army during the Vietnam War. Beloved husband of Roxanne, Loving father of Michael and Katherine. Reposing at William E. Law Funeral Home, 1 Jerusalem Avenue, Massapequa, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, Friday, 10:30 AM at St. William the Abbot RC Church, Seaford, New York. Interment, Calverton National Cemetery. Visiting, Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 PM and 79:30 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to Calvary Hospital, 1740-70 Eastchester Road, Bronx, N.Y. 10461 would be appreciated.

title: Nasdaq Index Hits a High, Eclipsing the Other Indicators
description: A further advance in Internet and telecommunications shares helped push stock markets higher yesterday, even as analysts expressed fear about hefty valuations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, HAROLD DAVID
description: SAMUELS-Harold David, 89, of Annadale, died peacefully at home on January 16th, 1999. An artist and a retired advertising executive, he was born in Hastings, Nebraska, and made his way in his teen years to the West Coast, where he became a courtroom sketch artist for newspapers, covering several notable trials, including the Lindbergh kidnapping case. Relocating to the East Coast, he had a long and successful career as an art director and as owner of a retail advertising agency. Predeceased by his wife, Joan Atkinson, & a daughter, Sheridan, he is survived by four children: David, of Clearwater, Florida, Stephen, of Anna Maria, Florida, and Mark and Christine, of New York City, as well as six grandchildren, four great grandchildren, and a great-great grandson. Both Harold and Joan will be memorialized at an interment service at St. Albans Episcopal Church, Eltingville, Staten Island, at 11:15 on Thursday, January 21st.

title: Why the Need For Witnesses Now?
description: To the Editor:

description: TENNESSEE 77 OLD DOMINION 61

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALLONEY, DORIS. (NEE VALVO)
description: VALLONEY-Doris. (nee Valvo). Reposing at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx on Wednesday 2:005:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM. Funeral mass on Thursday, Saint John's Church, 10:45 AM. Interment Saint Mary's Cemetery, Yonkers, NY.

title: Musicians Who Find Winning Isn't All
description: One lesson to be drawn from ''The Winners,'' a searching, melancholy Dutch documentary about the lives of four classical musicians who won the prestigious Queen Elisabeth Competition in Brussels, is that victory is not a guaranteed ticket into the classical music pantheon. Politics, personal health, changing musical fashions and the mysterious vagaries of personality, not to mention sheer luck, can be as strong determining factors as raw talent in the trajectory of a career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNENWALD, JUDGE THEODORE, JR.
description: TANNENWALD-Judge Theodore, Jr. The President, Chancellor, Boards of Governors and Overseers, faculty, administration and students of Hebrew Union CollegeJewish Institute of Religion records with profound sorrow the sudden death of Judge Theodore Tannenwald, Jr., who for more than four decades served the Hebrew Union College with distinction as a Governor and former Chair of its Board of Governors. He helped guide the College-Institute during a period of far reaching decisions and he offered his wise counsel and his astute perspective with unstinting zeal. Eminent jurist and public servant, he showed singular excellence in his legal career and exemplary commitment to high government office. He was a man who was highly esteemed for the invaluable assistance and unflagging dedication he rendered to Israel during its earliest days of statehood. We offer our sincerest condolences to his beloved wife, Selma (Pete), his sons, Peter and Robert, and his daughters-in-law, Carol and Leslie, and grandchildren, Alan, David and Jonathan. May the family find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman, Pres. Dr. Alfred Gottschalk, Chancellor Burton Lehman, Chair, Board of Governors

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, JAMES A.
description: JACKSON-James A., 62, of Charlotte, Vermont and formerly of Stowe, passed away on January 17, 1999 after a brief illness. Jim was born in Providence, Rhode Island on December 10, 1936, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Fielding Jackson of Ridgefield, Connecticut. He was a graduate of Proctor Academy, St. Lawrence University and Columbia Business School. Following graduation from Columbia, Jim worked for Eastman, Dillon, in New Haven, Connecticut as a stockbroker. In November of 1982, Stowe Selectboard, upon recommendation of the Recreation Commission, renamed the Stowe Ice Rink the Jackson Arena, in honor of Jim's work and support as a donating citizen. Throughout his years in Stowe and many years thereafter, Jim was an ongoing supporter of Copley Hospital and the Copley Endowment Fund as well as many other charitable causes. Jim is survived by his wife, Sandra Mayo Jackson of Charlotte, and her daughter, Kimberly Leddy of Columbus, Ohio, a sister Julia Young and brother-in-law Roslyn D. Young, Jr. of Chevy Chase, Maryland, three nieces and many dear and lifelong friends, including their dog, Finnegan. A remembrance of Jim's life will be celebrated at 4:00 P.M. on Thursday, January 21st, 1999 at the Stowe Community Church. A reception will follow at The Shed Restaurant in memory of Jim, donations may be made to the Charlotte Rescue Squad, Charlotte, VT., or the Visiting Nurses Association, 110 Prim Road, Suite 1, Colchester, VT. 05446.

title: Pierogi to Pasta for Cold Nights
description: THE night was freezing. As I ducked my head and trudged into the wind toward a restaurant, I noticed a sign on the fogged-up window of FIRST AVENUE PIEROGI AND DELI : ''Best in Town.'' Who could resist? I entered the tiny East Village storefront and was immediately enveloped in steam and the welcoming aroma of rye, dill and cloves. A man who barely spoke English indicated he had closed for the night, so I decided to come back another day to try the little half-moon-shaped dumplings.

title: Mayor Distances Himself From Lobbyist
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that his administration would stop doing business with a lobbyist who is married to one of his top aides, though he said the lobbyist had not persuaded the city to grant special parking privileges to a major Wall Street firm.

title: GTE Sees 13-15% Earnings Rise In $600 Million Belt-Tightening
description: The GTE Corporation, the phone company that has agreed to be acquired by the Bell Atlantic Corporation for $83.2 billion, said it expects to increase per-share earnings 13 percent to 15 percent this year and beyond.

title: Corrections
description: A review on the Fashion page yesterday about haute couture shows in Paris misspelled the surname of a designer whose work was associated with Surrealism. She was Elsa Schiaparelli, not Schiaperelli.

title: Discord Grows Over Plan to Sell Lincoln Center Art
description: Facing strong opposition to the possible sale of Jasper Johns's only public artwork, the board of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts has called a special meeting for Monday to discuss the disposition of the painting, the monumental ''Numbers, 1964,'' which has been on view in the New York State Theater for 35 years.

title: DURA AUTOMOTIVE TO ACQUIRE EXCEL FOR $321.9 MILLION
description: Dura Automotive Systems Inc., a maker of parking brakes, latches and jacks, agreed to buy Excel Industries, the top United States maker of automobile window assemblies, for about $321.9 million in cash and stock. Dura will also assume about $153.7 million in debt. Dura will exchange each of Excel's 12.3 million common shares outstanding into 0.4 Dura Automotive share and $12.75 in cash. Excel has annual sales of about $1.1 billion.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of a package of plastic wrap was published in error last Wednesday with the Eating Well column in the Dining section, which reported a study of potentially harmful effects of a substance found in some plastic wraps. The product shown was not part of the study. Details are on page F2.

title: Pettitte Agrees to a Deal For $5.95 Million in '99
description: Andy Pettitte and the Yankees led what appeared to be a major retreat from salary arbitration yesterday. Pettitte was one of 15 players who had filed for arbitration but reached agreement on new contracts yesterday before exchanging salary figures with their clubs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEPHART, WILLIAM A.
description: GEPHART-William A. On January 17, 1999, age 85, at Fieldston Lodge, Riverdale, of respiratory failure after a two month illness. Son of Alva R. and Pearl H. Gephart. Professional baritone and teacher of singing, he was Secretary of the American Academy of Teachers of Singing and past President of the New York Singing Teachers Association. He was educated in Oregon and Iowa, and graduated from De Pauw University, won a fellowship to Juilliard Graduate School. As a Fulbright Scholar he studied in Paris with noted French operatic baritone, Charles Pensera. He toured the US under sponsorship of the National Music League singing at Colleges and schools, was a soloist on the popular radio shows Manhattan Merry-Go-Round and National Vesper Hour with Thomas L. Thomas. He also was soloist with the Bach Choir of Bethlehem, and for many years at the Old Dutch Reformed Church, Brooklyn, the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, and member Temple Emanu-El choir. He taught at the School of Sacred Music, Union Theological; Dalcroze School; Hartford Conservatory; Vassar College and was a substitute German diction teacher at Juilliard. After retiring he continued to sing with the First Presbyterian Church Choir and became a Church Deacon. Survived by a second cousin Barbara H. Waggoner of Elnor, Indiana. Service Saturday, January 23, 2 P.M. First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Ave and 12th St. Interment Riverside Cemetery, Asheville, N.C.

title: Rangers Lose Again, But Show Signs of Life
description: In losing their third consecutive game last night, the Rangers probably played better than they have in some of their 17 victories. Although the Ottawa Senators took a 2-1 decision at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers had a dozen good scoring chances and competed well against a young, strong team that has chewed up most of its opponents in the past month.

title: Brazil's Government Struggles To Pass Bills to Fight Crisis
description: The battle to prop up the nation's currency has already been lost in a costly confrontation with international markets. Now, in an attempt to preserve what remains of its economic program, Brazil's Government is trying to pass legislation intended to reduce a huge budget deficit and calm investors.

title: Talks Are Set On Processing Of Garbage
description: As opposition to its garbage plans sparks outcries from Brooklyn to New Jersey to Virginia, the Giuliani administration has grudgingly agreed to meet in the next few weeks with community and environmental groups that think they have a better idea.

title: Children on View at an Open House
description: Dance Theater of Harlem held the first in a series of monthly Open Houses on Sunday afternoon at its headquarters, the Everett Performing Arts Center in Harlem. The event, called ''In Tribute to Martin Luther King Jr.,'' was an informal gathering genially presided over by Arthur Mitchell, the company's director, and Marion Coles, a tap-dance expert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELIN, DAVID W.
description: BELIN-David W. A rare and tireless Jewish leader, he devoted himself to the vision of Isaiah to make the house of Israel a house of prayer for all people. We were privileged to have worked with him in making that vision a reality. We mourn his loss and extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Barbara, his children Jim, Tom, Jon, Laurie, and Joy, and his stepchildren Lee and Jenifer, and to all who loved him and miss him. David G. Sacks, President Egon Mayer, Director The Jewish Outreach Institute and the Board of Directors

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUFFINE, HERBERT TAYLOR
description: HUFFINE-Herbert Taylor, Age 77. On January 18, of Manchester, Vermont and formerly of Morristown, N.J. Beloved husband of Julianne, Loving father of Phillip, Peter and Melissa, predeceased by a son Michael. Grandfather of Rachel, Taylor, Savanna and Caitlin. He was much loved and will be greatly missed. A man of fine integrity, strength and compassion for others. After service as a Navy PT boat commander during W.W. II, he worked in national sales of Mueller Company and residential real estate until recently. His many interests included model train collections, community work, including support and devotion to the restoration of Hildene, the former residence of Robert Todd Lincoln. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Friends of Hildene, Box 377, Manchester, VT 05254. Memorial services will take place on Friday, January 22, at First Congregation Church, Manchester, VT. at 9:30 A.M.

title: A Young Australian Sends Pioline Packing
description: Tennis is on the rise in Australia, as the record crowds coursing through the turnstiles confirm. And the way Lleyton Hewitt, a 17-year-old wild card, played last night in upsetting 13th-seeded Cedric Pioline, 6-3, 6-1, 6-1, in the first round of the Australian Open, will do nothing but increase the enthusiasm.

title: Business Travel; Jamaica prepares to put troops on patrol at resorts to help ease tourists' fears of crime.
description: WITH its tourist industry battered by fear of crime and by visitor complaints of harassment, Jamaica is trying to decide when to deploy troops to its tourist resorts and whether they will be in uniform or plainclothes. The move is backed by the Jamaica Hotel and Motel Association, which was previously lukewarm toward the idea. The change comes as occupancy rates have fallen after several well-publicized crimes against tourists.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Sinking Shots and Sinking Opponents
description: David Duval went skiing last week, a fitting way to unwind after an avalanche of victories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILSON, FLORENCE
description: GILSON-Florence. Beloved wife of the late George. Devoted mother of Diane and Manny Manicone and David and Stephanie Gilson. Loving grandmother of Geoffrey, June, Louisa, Julian and Genevieve. Cherished great grandmother of Alexandra. Services Thursday, January 21, 10AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

description: In percent

title: Anti-Impeachment Rallies Held in 17 Cities
description: Union leaders, Democratic Party officials and hundreds of other people came together last night in cities across the country to watch President Clinton's State of the Union address and to show their opposition to the impeachment process, warning Republicans that they would pay for it at the ballot box.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Taking the Danger Out of Risk; Chase Says Models Helped It Avoid Financial Minefields
description: What's the difference between being rich and being poor? asks a joke currently making the rounds on Wall Street. Answer: About 30 seconds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, MARY CARTER
description: JONES-Mary Carter. The Officers, Board of Directors and members of the Womens City Club of New York note with sadness the death of our former President, Mary Carter Jones. As a 40+ year member of the WCC, she was an exemplar of those women who cared deeply about their communities and are willing to devote large amounts of time to advancing thoughtful ideas and programs. Her wise counsel will be missed. Our condolences to her children and grandchildren. Elizabeth Lubetkin Lipton, Pres.

title: Frances Godowsky Dies at 92; Last of the Gershwin Siblings
description: Frances Godowsky, a prolific painter and sometime singer better known as George and Ira's little sister, Frankie Gershwin, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 92 and the last of the Gershwin siblings.

title: NATO Warning to Yugoslav: Another Hollow Threat?
description: NATO warned the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, today to stop an offensive in Kosovo or face possible air strikes, but the alliance faces enormous obstacles to ever carrying out such a threat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANTHONY, BETTINA MORAN
description: ANTHONY-Bettina Moran, 64 years old, of Palm Beach, FL, died on Thursday, January 14th, 1999, after an extended illness. Born in New York, New York, she attended the Convent of the Sacred Heart, New York, NY; Miss Hall's School, Pittsfield, MA; and Bennett Junior College, Millbrook, New York. She is survived by her beloved daughters, Lucy Webster & Laura Anthony, both of NY, NY; Her mother, Helen G. Morgan, also of NY, NY; & three brothers, Bernard A. Moran, Jr. of Fort Lauderdale, FL, John P. Moran of Ft. Collins, CO, and Michael Moran of Abescon, NJ. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated at 2:00 P.M. on Saturday, January 23, 1999 at St. Thomas More Catholic Church, New York, NY. For information Quattlebaum - Holleman - Burse Funeral Home, (561) 832-5171.

title: Love and Evil in the Last Days of the Soviet Union
description: THE AGE OF TERROR

title: Microsoft's Profit Up 75% In Quarter
description: Strong shipments of personal computers strengthened the second-quarter financial results of the Microsoft Corporation, which reported a 75 percent gain in earnings yesterday, far exceeding the most optimistic projections of Wall Street analysts.

title: In New Unity, G.O.P. Seeks 10% U.S. Tax Cut
description: Republicans sought today to dispel the image of a Congress consumed by impeachment, putting forward an agenda that calls for a 10 percent across-the-board cut in income tax rates and pledging to engage President Clinton on assuring the long-term solvency of Social Security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECKERMAN, EDWARD R. JR.
description: PECKERMAN-Edward R. Jr., Washington, CT, 93, died Tuesday morning at Rose Haven in Litchfield after a short illness. Mr. Peckerman was born in Boston, June 3, 1905. His family moved to New York in 1914. He graduated from Horace Mann School, where he later served as chairman of the board of trustees. He graduated from Princeton University in 1925 and from Columbia Law School in 1928. In 1943 he volunteered to serve in the armed forces, he joined naval aviation and was onboard an aircraft carrier in the South Pacific; he was in the command that secured the island of Guam. He was discharged in 1946 with the rank of Commander. In 1971 he retired and he and his wife moved to Washington, CT, were he became involved in environmental organizations, among others, Steep Rock Association, Housatonic Valley Association, the Roxbury Land Trust and served on the zoning commission in Washington. He was a member of the University Club in New York and the Washington Club. He is survived by the love of his wife, Kristen. Contributions in his name may be made to the Steep Rock Association, P.O. Box 279, Washington Depot, CT. 06794.

title: Obesity Drug Can Lead to Modest Weight Loss, Study Finds
description: The largest and longest study ever of an obesity medication found that a new drug, orlistat, can help obese people lose modest amounts of weight, a study being published today says.

title: Swift and Strong Support for the President, Though Some Slip Fold
description: In an almost, but not quite, unanimous display of support, Democratic members of Congress rallied around President Clinton this evening, invoking nearly identical phrases as they applauded Mr. Clinton's proposals and urged an end to the partisan warfare that has threatened his Presidency.

description: Ruggerio's Closes

title: Stocks Aided Brokerage Firms' 4th-Quarter Recovery
description: Americans' ravenous appetite for stocks helped brokerage firms recover from their autumn faint, but Wall Street is still not generating profits the way it did a year ago.

title: Eloquent Clinton Ally Chosen To Give Closing Argument
description: Dale Bumpers, a former Democratic senator from Arkansas and a political ally of Bill Clinton, will defend his longtime friend in a closing argument in the President's impeachment trial, the White House said today.

title: Watson, a Left-Hander, Signs to Bolster the Staff
description: The Mets bolstered their pitching staff yesterday when they announced a one-year deal with the 28-year-old left-hander Allen Watson, a New York native who had been pitching for the Anaheim Angels.
