title: Arena Picks Squad for Bolivia Game
description: Bruce Arena, the coach of the United States men's national team, yesterday picked his 18-man roster for Sunday's match against Bolivia in Santa Cruz.

title: Domingo Enjoys His Grand Slam
description: The gala performance at the Metropolitan Opera on Sunday afternoon, its annual benefit to support the pension fund for the orchestra and chorus, seemed like another installment in a seasonlong celebration of Placido Domingo's 30th anniversary with the company. But thanks to Mr. Domingo's drawing power, the house was full and no doubt a lot of money was raised.

title: Protecting Bidders on Line
description: For the moment, Internet auctions are no better -- or no worse -- than giant electronic garage sales, in which thousands of potential buyers can look at a photograph of an item but cannot inspect it, or consult an independent expert to verify the item's quality or authenticity.

title: Foote, Cone Direct Gets Its Own Chief
description: Steve Humphrey, a longtime direct-marketing executive, was named yesterday as chairman and chief executive at Foote, Cone & Belding Direct Worldwide in New York, the direct-marketing unit of Foote, Cone & Belding Worldwide.

title: One Virginian Who's Ready to Do His Part
description: It's time I came clean. I am a loyal Virginia citizen, a frequent New York visitor and, in light of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's comments last week, a complete freeloader.

title: Thesaurus Takes Action to Remove Gay Slurs
description: Merriam-Webster Inc., the nation's oldest and largest dictionary publisher, took steps yesterday to remove references to homosexuals in its classic collegiate thesaurus amid complaints about a word list of offensive slurs and synonyms.

title: Did Clinton Promise Too Much to Too Many?; Chicken in Every Pot
description: To the Editor:

title: Stock Price Warning
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said there was little evidence that the economy was slowing and warned that stock prices might be getting excessive. His comments, analysts said, suggested that the central bank would leave interest rates alone in the near future.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BEDDINI, LINDA
description: BEDDINI-Linda. July 31, 1947January 21, 1991. Never forgotten, forever loved. Mom and Laur

title: Making a Tough Choice: A Bowl Game or a Baby
description: The folks at Babycenter.com, which offers advice and products for expectant and new parents, want to help expectant parents answer one of life's most important questions: Will the birth of a baby interfere with a major sporting event?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAISER, EVALYN M.
description: KAISER-Evalyn M. Loving mother of Laurance and Kenneth, grandmother, sister and aunt, passed away after a short illness at 6:59 PM, on Monday, January 18th, 1999. Private burial. In lieu of flowers, donations to Make-AWish Foundation of New York.

title: G.E. Reports 14% Profit Gain As It Does More Service Work
description: The General Electric Company, which makes everything from light bulbs to locomotives, said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 14 percent as the company sold more industrial service contracts.

title: FLEMING COMPANIES AIMS TO TRIM BACK ITS MANAGEMENT
description: The Fleming Companies said yesterday that it would reorganize its wholesale and retail operations to reduce the number of its management units to 14 from 57. The Oklahoma City-based food retailer and distributor said the reorganization would eliminate more than 220 positions, or about 12 percent of its corporate staff. The revamping, which will be completed in the next year or two, will result in annual savings of $20 million, the company said. Fleming serves more than 3,000 supermarkets in 42 states and had 1997 revenues of $15.37 billion. Its shares fell 6.25 cents, to $9.375.

title: National News Briefs; Retailer Recalls Robes For Possible Fire Hazard
description: The Limited Inc. is recalling about 17,600 girls' fleece robes sold at its Limited Too stores because the clothing does not meet Federal fire-resistance standards, the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GODOWSKY, FRANCES GERSHWIN (FRANKIE)
description: GODOWSKY-Frances Gershwin (Frankie), on January 18th, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Leopold Godowsky, Jr. Loving mother of Alexis Gershwin, Leopold Godowsky III, Georgia Keidan and Nadia Natali. Cherished grandmother of 8. Adoring sister of the late George, Ira and Arthur Gershwin. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Thursday, January 21, at 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Channel 13 at 450 W. 33rd St., NY NY 10001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSOFF, ALAN A.
description: ROSOFF-Alan A. Beloved husband of Charlotte, devoted father of Mindy and Randy Belz, Bonnie and Marc Belz, Joy and Hal Mandelman. Dear son in law of Happy Bierman. Loving grandfather of Paul, Marla, Jessica, Elizabeth, Logan, Lindsey, Paige and Blake. Services on Thursday, 10:30AM ''Boulevard - Riverside'' Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Dinosaurs on Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Fed Report and Housing Data Are Strong
description: The Federal Reserve's latest reading on the nation's economy suggests the current expansion, already at a peacetime record, will persevere in 1999 while inflation remains at bay.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: LUMBER RISES 3 PERCENT. Prices advanced to a 16-month high after the Government reported that 1998 was the best year for home builders in a decade. The March contract rose $10, to $348.70 for 1,000 board feet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATINELLA, ROSE
description: CATINELLA-Rose. On January 19, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Elaine Ceruti and Joseph. Devoted grandmother of two. Great-grandmother of three. Reposing Hillebrand Funeral Homes, 63-17 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10:45 Resurrection Ascension Interment St. Raymonds Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with an article about a possible second copy of one of the world's rarest stamps, issued by British Guiana in 1856, misidentified the stamp shown. It was the known original, recognizable by its cancellation, not the possible copy.

title: Suit to Limit Net Access At a Library Is Dismissed
description: In California, library patrons of all ages are still free to check out the Net. Last week, a state court in Alameda County dismissed a lawsuit charging that a public library had violated the constitutional rights of a 12-year-old boy who used a computer there last year to go on the Web to view and download pictures of naked women.

title: Mature Love, Just as Baffling as the Puppy Kind
description: Three mature women sit in a proper British parlor. Their posture is prim, their clothes tweedy and buttoned up. They are discussing the prospect of hiring a ''girl Friday.'' Soon a white-haired man in a morning coat joins them, having just returned from a funeral.

title: G.M.'s Profit Rose 7.7% in Fourth Quarter
description: The General Motors Corporation today announced an unexpectedly large increase in profits during the fourth quarter of last year, as the very strong American auto market and the company's continued recovery from last summer's strike more than offset losses in Latin America and East Asia.

title: Releasing The Notes So Gently
description: The alto saxophonist Sherman Irby seemed slightly apart at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night -- not because the music or the mood onstage was forlorn, but because there was a difference of musical temperament between him and the rest of his band. Mr. Irby, an alto saxophonist, doesn't feel a need to rush, and that quality makes him special among young jazz players. His tone is bright and even and lacquery -- a sound that in ballads can suggest Charlie Parker's self-assuredness with a hint of Johnny Hodges's steaminess -- and he doesn't wrestle with his music but releases it gently, letting space shine through his ideas. He's a be-bop player, but he doesn't lean on its stock phrases, and when he's sufficiently warmed up he uses the emotional weight of gospel phrases in a sparing, respectful way.

title: Bure, Darting and Spinning, Scores 2 in Panthers Debut
description: The asking price for Pavel Bure was too high for the Islanders. The Vancouver Canucks wanted too many players in return, and Bure wanted too many dollars.

title: Defense Challenges Impeachment 'Mumbo Jumbo'
description: A White House lawyer accused House prosecutors today of resorting to ''word games'' and ''legal mumbo jumbo'' in their efforts to prove President Clinton guilty of impeachment charges.

title: Late Goals From Rusty Players Lift Devils
description: DEVILS 4, MIGHTY DUCKS 3

title: Economy at Risk as Israel Campaigns
description: In the first heated weeks of Israel's four-month election campaign, it appears that an early loser may be the tightfisted anti-inflation policy once championed by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu but now defended only by the politically isolated central bank.

title: Nets Bring In Murdock as Douglas Departs
description: Coming off the floor at the Nets' training facility after working out today, Keith Van Horn expressed his desire to see much of last season's team return intact when the National Basketball Association finally opens its doors on Thursday.

title: Progress Reported in New Talks on Sports Complex for the Islanders
description: Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta met this morning with officials of the New York Islanders and the National Hockey League and announced that they had made ''tremendous progress'' on plans for a new sports complex to replace the aging Nassau County Veterans Memorial Coliseum.

title: Culture Center Is Planned For Concerts In Poconos
description: The Poconos have been famous for decades for resort hotels with heart-shaped beds and bathtubs, but if Elliot Rosoff and Nat Gliserman have their way, those Pennsylvania mountains will soon become as well known for culture as for kitsch. Mr. Rosoff, a concert violinist, and Mr. Gliserman, an engineer who has designed food and housing areas for two World's Fairs and several Olympics, are planning a kind of Tanglewood of the Poconos called the Keystone Center of Music and the Arts.

title: Taking Some of the Fun Out of Life
description: LIFE was much simpler 40 years ago, when all you had to do was spin the wheel, drive down the road, get a job, get hitched, buy a house, take out an insurance policy, have a couple of kids, maybe play the stock market and retire with as much money as possible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEREZIN, MAE L.
description: BEREZIN-Mae L. Of Aventura, Florida, formerly of NYC. Cherished and beloved aunt, great-aunt & sister. A lifelong friend to many. Mae moved to Florida after a successful career in the fashion industry, where she was president of Mae Littell Fashions. Mae was a remarkable woman who gave generously to many charities, including Hadassah, the Jewish Home & Hospital for the Aged at Douglas Gardens, American Friends of Beit Issie Shapiro, Miami Jewish Federation, among others. Mae was loved by all who knew her & will be greatly missed. Services will be held on Friday, January 22, at 11:15 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 180 West 76th Street, with burial to follow at Mount Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale, New York.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Questions Clouding Future Of Men's Shelter at Bellevue
description: For more than a year, the Giuliani administration has quietly moved to shut down the city's largest homeless shelter, and city officials have been meeting with representatives of a for-profit company that wants to establish an upscale assisted-living residence for the elderly in the East Side building.

title: Separate but Equal Schools
description: Imagine two public schools, somewhere in America's checkered educational landscape. School A lacks services for bilingual children, sports teams for girls and elevators for the handicapped. In School B, meanwhile, more than half of the teachers lack training in the subjects they instruct.

title: The Shakers Meet the Movers
description: The Shakers take Manhattan. ''Shaker Gifts, Shaker Genius: The Collections of the Shaker Museum and Library'' includes 400 objects, from a fire engine to seed packets. ''They were the first to market seeds in bright envelopes,'' said Erin Budis, the curator at the museum, in Old Chatham, N.Y. The Shaker chairs (1880-1920), above, were sold by mail order. Opening tomorrow at the Paine Webber Art Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas (51st Street). Admission is free. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Birds Find Their Way From Alaska to the Web
description: The puffin and the kittiwake are rare enough that many students haven't heard of them, let alone seen them. A new site from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute could help to change all that.

title: A Tale of a Cambodian Woman: Assigning the Guilt for Genocide
description: ''If I killed anyone, you can kill me back,'' said Neang Kin, her hair matted and her clothes stained reddish-brown from her work in the flooded rice fields. ''I swear to God and swear to die in front of my children. I faint at the sight of blood.''

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about President Clinton's remarks to Representative Dennis Hastert referred incorrectly to Mr. Hastert's experience as Speaker. It was the second House session over which he presided, not the first.

title: Federal-Mogul Contract
description: The Federal-Mogul Corporation, the world's largest engine-seals maker, said today that it had won a contract from DaimlerChrysler A.G. to provide seals, gaskets and other products for an engine being developed for 2003 model year vehicles.

title: Did Clinton Promise Too Much to Too Many?; Stocks Are Too Risky
description: To the Editor:

title: Review; The Lower End of 'High Definition'
description: American consumers set a record last year. They bought more projection televisions than ever before, just over one million of them. And with that, these mammoth sets captured the largest share they have ever had of the nation's television market: a whopping 3 percent.

title: Essay; The Witness Issue
description: It all depends on what you mean by the word depose.

title: Where Have All the White Plates Gone?
description: Just when everyone was comfortable with white restaurant-size dinner plates, the restaurants themselves turned the tables. And as some of the best new chefs are creating ethnic-fusion food that is uniquely their own, so, too, they're throwing out the rules for dressing their tables. Restaurateurs are heading to craft fairs and ceramics shops to find colorful plates and handmade pottery. One chef even makes her own plates. And as often as not, the tableware is sold right at the restaurant.

title: Limousine Company Signs Union Contract
description: In a breakthrough in one of New York City's largest unionization drives in decades, the machinists' union has signed a contract on behalf of nearly 700 drivers at one of the city's largest black-car companies, Elite Limousine Plus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIBEL, LILI
description: KIBEL-Lili. It is with great sadness that we mourn the loss of our dear Board member, Lili Kibel. The Board of Trustees and staff of Project Renewal extend our deepest sympathy to her loving husband, Henry, and to her children and grandchildren. She was a gracious colleague who will be greatly missed. The Board and Staff of Project Renewal

title: New York Moves on Plan To Ship Trash Out of City
description: New York City took the first steps yesterday toward its goal of shipping up to 2,000 tons of garbage a day from Manhattan and Queens to transfer stations, landfills and incinerators outside the city, with industry officials saying sites in New Jersey, Long Island and Westchester County were all likely candidates.

title: When Your Bottler Is Your Rival; Vending-Machine Owners Ask Whose Side Coke Is On
description: One morning in October, Mike McGee stopped to inspect the Coca-Cola vending machines that he had installed in a new student recreation center at Harvey Mudd College in Claremont, Calif.

title: New Round of Job Cuts Planned at BASF
description: BASF A.G., Germany's largest maker of drugs and chemicals, said yesterday that it would cut a further 1,000 jobs at its main plant in Ludwigshafen as part of a long-term drive to keep the plant viable.

title: Lucille Kallen, 76, Writer For 'Show of Shows,' Dies
description: Lucille Kallen, the lone woman in the raucous, celebrated and astonishingly untidy group of television writers behind Sid Caesar's ''Your Show of Shows,'' died on Monday at her home in Ardsley, N.Y. She was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUND, ROSENTHAL, MIRIAM DR.
description: FREUND - ROSENTHAL - Miriam Dr. We deeply mourn the passing of Dr. Miriam Freund-Rosenthal, who was revered by us as a figure of paramount importance in the Jewish Community worldwide. She was a former National President of Hadassah and a prominent member of American Friends of the Hebrew University Council of Trustees. She helped found the AFHU Minneapolis Chapter over 67 years ago. We extend our sympathies to her sons, Harry and Matthew. American Friends of The Hebrew University Keith L. Sachs, President Fred S. Lafer, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive Vice President

title: U.S.I.A. Says Hacker Killed Web Site and Damaged Computer
description: An outsider breached the Internet security of the United States Information Agency a week ago, knocking its Web site out of action and forcing the agency to re-evaluate its computer protection, an official of the agency said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELZER, BENSON
description: SELZER-Benson. Great friend, business partner and talented artist. You have influenced and made an imprint on all the lives you have touched. We will miss you. May you rest in peace. Our deepest sympathy to your wife Liz, your sons, John, Geoff and Benjamin, your daughter Andrea and your beloved grandchildren, Jacob, Noah and Ari. Love Mina and Joe Eiger

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARON, RUTH
description: AARON-Ruth. Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, N.J. mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi Gail Billig, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAMIN, LEO
description: YAMIN-Leo. On January 20, 1999. Beloved husband of Alice Yamin. Cherished and admired uncle and great-uncle. Services private.

title: Man and Mystique Join The Ice Wars Again
description: Pavel Bure said he felt clumsy. He had not played in a real hockey game for nine months. He spent the previous day flying from Moscow to New York. His new equipment felt strange. The puck slipped off his stick a few times, and everyone could see him lose his balance and fall.

title: Did Clinton Promise Too Much to Too Many?; Expect More Waste
description: To the Editor:

title: REPUBLIC NEW YORK PLANS TO REVAMP TO SAVE 5% IN ASSETS
description: The Republic New York Corporation, the nation's 20th-largest bank, with $50 billion in assets, said yesterday that it would disclose a revamping plan within a month intended to save 5 percent of its annualized operating assets, up to $48 million a year. Republic yesterday reported that fourth-quarter profits fell 10 percent, to $104 million, or 92 cents a diluted share, from $116 million, or $1.01, a year ago. That beat the average of 90 cents estimated by analysts in a survey by the First Call Corporation. Republic also said it would repurchase 5 million of its shares, or 4.7 percent of its outstanding stock.

title: 2 Guilty of Killing Man Who Tried to Stop Fight
description: Two men were convicted yesterday in the fatal beating of a man who tried to intervene in an argument on behalf of a young woman, officials said.

title: Pen in Hand? Maybe No More
description: As a genre, the literary letter is like many a dramatic romance. One always predicts that its soliloquy will end, but often it doesn't. The form has survived the telephone and the typewriter and the personal computer. Will it survive E-mail?

title: Amtrak, Fighting Red Ink, Adds a Variety of Freight Business
description: Amtrak said today that to balance its books before Congress eliminates its operating subsidies, it would haul fruits and vegetables cross-country, United Parcel Service packages across the Southwest, express packages on Metroliners between New York and Washington, and more U.S. mail all over the nation.

title: Did Clinton Promise Too Much to Too Many?; Don't Appease China
description: To the Editor:

title: Files Lost? Perhaps Not
description: Q. Is there a way to find files deleted from a hard drive by mistake? What if the file name is not known or remembered?

title: SBC Communications to Buy Comcast Cellular Operations
description: As part of continuing consolidation in the cellular telephone industry, SBC Communications Inc. has agreed to acquire the cellular telephone operations of the Comcast Corporation for $400 million in cash and $1.27 billion in assumed debt.

title: Teen-Ager in Gun Lawsuit Tells of Being Shot in Head
description: In a lawsuit seeking to hold the gun industry liable for shootings with illegally obtained handguns, broad theories and statistics gave way yesterday as a Queens teen-ager with a bullet lodged in his brain testified about having been on the wrong end of a gun.

title: The Rule of Law Protects the President, Too, a Counsel Tells the Senate
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by Cheryl D. Mills, White House deputy counsel, on accusations of obstruction of justice in Article II in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton:

title: CHESAPEAKE HOPES TO ENTER EUROPE IN FIELD GROUP DEAL
description: The Chesapeake Corporation, the United States napkin and paper-towel maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Field Group P.L.C. of Britain for $:194 million ($320 million) to increase earnings by getting a foothold in the high-margin European specialty-packaging market. The 320-pence-a-share cash offer is a 41 percent premium to Field's share price on Jan. 8, when the packaging manufacturer first said it was in takeover talks, and a 9 percent premium to Field's closing share price on Tuesday. Chesapeake shares fell 31.25 cents, to $36. Separately, Chesapeake said fourth-quarter earnings fell to 10 cents a share from 34 cents a year earlier. Full-year net income rose 71 percent, to $42.8 million.

title: Wounded Man Made Up Hostage Tale, Police Say
description: A man found bleeding on a Bronx street corner last night told the police a harrowing story: he had been the victim of a carjacking, and the robbers shot him in the back, drove off with his girlfriend and went to an apartment about a mile away, where they were holding hostages.

title: Still Going Like 60 At 90
description: Victor Borge, who learned music at his mother's knee (the family had no piano), wasn't always 90. Often he was younger. He gave his first concert at 8 ''or a few minutes after.'' When he was about 12 he saw a Russian pianist in Copenhagen accidentally fall off the piano bench. That was for him, marveled young Victor (which wasn't yet his name). ''Such a cheap slapstick thing.'' He has been doing it himself almost ever since, although his doctors have recently warned him against it. So, he says, ''I still don't do it.'' But of course he does, in every show.

title: Build Your Own Job
description: I recently read a psychological profile of Kenneth Starr (I'm a bit behind the news). The profile was interesting enough, but even more interesting was the descriptive title attached to the professor who wrote it: he called himself a political psychologist.

title: Stronger Earnings Bolster Texas Instruments Shares
description: A slimmed-down Texas Instruments Inc. reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, sending its shares up more than 8.2 percent and fueling a continuing rally in technology stocks.

title: Yin and Yang Slashing to the Hoop
description: Allan Houston is like the un-Cola, the sparkling clear alternative, next to the cloudy image of Latrell Sprewell. Houston is passive, polite and everything nice.

title: True North's Chief Retiring by March 31
description: True North Communications in Chicago, which owns agencies like Foote, Cone & Belding Worldwide and Bozell Worldwide, said yesterday that Bruce Mason, chief executive since the formation of True North in 1995, would retire by the end of March.

title: A Well-Equipped Patrol Officer: Gun, Flashlight, Computer
description: IF you're ever stopped in your own car for speeding or making an illegal U-turn, chances are the police officer pulling you over will know your name before even getting out of the patrol car.

title: Many Updates Cause Profitable Confusion
description: THE more things change, the more they drive us insane. At least that's the way it seems in computer technology, where products have the life spans of insects.

title: Surfing in Circles And Loving It
description: IF using a search engine can be like drinking from a fire hose, Internet surfing using a Web ring is like sharing a cup of tea with a group of strangers who are batty about a favorite hobby, like collecting Australian emergency-squad insignia.

title: The Long Arm of the Law Shuts Popular Source of Lyrics
description: The International Lyrics Server (www

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the dismissal of the editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association misstated the surname of the association's executive vice president at a few points in some editions. He is Dr. E. Ratcliffe Anderson, not Dr. Ratcliffe.

title: Holbrooke Accused Of Ethics Violation
description: The Justice Department has accused Richard C. Holbrooke, President Clinton's choice to be the top American diplomat at the United Nations, of a civil violation of ethics laws involving business contacts three years ago with the United States Embassy in South Korea. The investigation began as a result of allegations about improper lobbying in Hungary in 1995, but officials said yesterday that no evidence of wrongdoing was found in that case.

title: A Slam Dunk Watch
description: MOVING from muscle power to brain power is never easy. That's the task that faces Michael Jordan, now that he has decided to leave behind burning glycogen in favor of generating marketing electricity. He's changing from shorts to a three-piece suit. A Nike advertisement from last year shows him as a chief executive, wearing a suit and sitting at a desk. And he's already on the board of another company: Oakley Inc., best known for its sunglasses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASS, BUNNY
description: CASS-Bunny. Suddenly on January 19, 1999. Dedicated wife of the late Leonard. Loving mother of Dona Cass-Lautin and Alan. Devoted grandmother of Douglas, Dana, William and Sam. Loyal friend to many. An honorable and gentle lady always, she will be greatly missed. Services private.

title: E-Mail and a Closer Family
description: To the Editor:

title: Nassau Jail Guards Beat Man to Death, Family Says
description: A man serving the second day of a 90-day sentence in the Nassau County jail for traffic violations was stomped by guards, threatened with more beatings if he did not go along with a cover-up of the attack, then left to bleed internally for three days without medical treatment until he was taken to a hospital where he died, his family's lawyer charged today.

title: Dr. Judith S. Kestenberg, 88; Studied Survivors of Holocaust
description: Dr. Judith Silberpfennig Kestenberg, a psychoanalyst specializing in child development and the emotional state of Holocaust survivors and their children, died Saturday at her home in Sands Point, N.Y. She was 88.

title: Ward and Dudley Stay Knicks
description: With training camp set to open today, the Knicks filled in two important roster spots last night by agreeing in principle to re-sign the starting point guard Charlie Ward to a five-year, $28 million deal, and the backup center Chris Dudley to a four-year, $28 million contract, according to people with knowledge of the negotiations.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRINGTON, DOROTHY A.
description: HARRINGTON-Dorothy A. On January 19, 1999. Beloved sister of John J. and the late Gertrude and William, loving aunt of Linda Doll, John, Robert, Reverend Donald J., C.M., Jane Schmeltzer, Jay and their families. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193 Street. Visiting hours Thursday 7-9 PM and Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:30 AM from Our Lady of Lourdes Chapel, St. John's University. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery.

title: First the Bulb, Then the Flower
Woman Is Hit by Falling Glass From El Train
description: A woman walking with her child underneath an elevated subway line in Queens was critically injured Tuesday night when a window dislodged from a passing train and showered her with glass, the police said yesterday.

title: E-Mail to U.S. Lands Chinese Internet Entrepreneur in Jail
description: A court here sentenced a computer engineer to two years in jail today in a case watched closely by people monitoring official efforts to control China's growing use of the Internet.

title: Arrest in Fatal Shooting Of Murder Case Witness
description: A Plainfield man has been arrested in the weekend shooting death of a man who had been scheduled to testify in a murder trial that began this week, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Sweden and Norway Set Phone Company Merger
description: Sweden and Norway said yesterday that they would merge the state-owned Telia A.B. and Telenor A.S. to form a telephone company with annual sales of $10 billion and the scope to compete in foreign markets.

title: Reducing Russian Dangers
description: No investment in American national security has paid higher dividends than the $2 billion Washington has spent over the last eight years to help Russia and other former Soviet republics dismantle nuclear, biological and chemical weapons. President Clinton was right, in his State of the Union address Tuesday night, to call for significantly increased spending on such programs. Congress, including members who oppose other foreign aid to Russia, should approve this White House request in full.

title: The Name Behind Those Ping-Pong Balls
description: FIRST, to answer the most obvious question: Yolanda Vega does always say her name that way. ''Hi,'' she said yesterday, and then without a trace of show biz: ''I'm Yo-LAHNNN-da Vega!''

title: $116 Million Punitive Award Against Aetna
description: A jury in California yesterday awarded $116 million in punitive damages to a patient's widow who contends he died after a subsidiary of Aetna Inc., the nation's largest health insurer, delayed approving treatment for stomach cancer that its own doctors had recommended. Lawyers on both sides called it the largest such verdict against a health maintenance organization.

title: BELLSOUTH TO TAKE A $172 MILLION CHARGE IN QUARTER
description: The BellSouth Corporation, the nation's No. 4 local phone company, said yesterday that it expected to take a charge against first-quarter earnings because Brazil's currency devaluation had raised the cost of debt for a subsidiary. The company said the charge would be about $172 million, or 9 cents a share. BellSouth's Brazilian subsidiary, BCP Telecomunicacoes S.A., has about $1 billion in dollar-denominated debt that will now cost the company more in Brazilian currency to service. BellSouth has a 44.5 percent stake in the company. Shares of BellSouth rose 50 cents, to $47.50.

title: UConn at 16-0 On Final-Shot Miss by Miami
description: Winless in Miami. That's what prompted Richard Hamilton and his Connecticut teammates to opt for getting plenty of sleep rather than sampling the nightlife following team meetings here on Tuesday night.

title: The Business Of Basketball Now Begins In Earnest
description: The gymnasium doors open at 2 P.M. Eastern time today, and the free-agent-signing floodgates will burst. Coaches will coach and players will be gasping for air for the first time in six months and every wild bit of speculation will either become reality or remain rumor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNOLD, PEGGY
description: ARNOLD-Peggy. On January 19, 1999, of Little Neck, NY. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Arnold. Dear mother of Patricia & Edward. Grandmother of Justin. Memorial service on Saturday 4 pm at the Unitarian Universalist Congregation Shelter Rock, 48 Shelter Rock Road, Manhasset. Donations in her memory may be made to The American Lung Association.

title: Jordan Draws a Crowd and Some Laughs
description: As Michael Jordan prepared to tee off this morning, Charles Barkley surveyed the throng of at least 5,000 spectators who surrounded the 10th tee. ''I want to thank my 10 fans for coming,'' Barkley said. ''Everybody else came to see Michael.''

title: Matters of Perspective
description: In the early 1900's, William Davis Hassler captured New York City's horizontal sprawl using a panoramic camera to make images four feet wide. Almost a century later, Horst Hamann tilted a panoramic camera to make eight-foot-high pictures of New York's skyscrapers, right. Exhibits of the two men's work can be seen through May 2 (Hamann) and May 9 (Hassler) at the Museum of the City of New York.

title: Coalition Against Ads on Channel One
description: A unusual coalition of advocacy organizations is asking marketers to stop advertising on Channel One, the unit of Primedia Inc. that broadcasts daily programs and commercials to more than 12,000 schools nationwide.

title: X-Ray Project Faces Delay, NASA Says
description: NASA today announced another delay in launching the world's largest X-ray telescope, saying the discovery of possibly flawed circuit boards in the $1.5 billion craft would delay its trip into orbit at least five weeks.

title: Lawmakers In Brazil Adopt Step On Austerity
description: In an important advance in the Government's effort to cut its deficit and reduce market pressures that have humbled the economy, the lower house of Congress tonight decisively approved a change in social security benefits for civil servants after four earlier attempts had been defeated.

title: Chancellor May Sell or Spin Off Some Units to Raise Share Value
description: The Chancellor Media Corporation, soon to be the No. 1 owner of radio stations in the United States, said today that it might sell or spin off all or part of its businesses to raise its share value to that of its biggest rivals.

title: Did Clinton Promise Too Much to Too Many?; Face of the Opposition
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Fair, Exhibitions and Classes
description: Outsider Art

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAGAN, ARTHUR
description: KAGAN-Arthur. A true and loving friend who was always there when needed. We will miss you. Condolences to Nikki, Marylyn, Karen, Linda and family. Marvin and Sally Reisman

title: Fiber Does Not Help Prevent Colon Cancer, Study Finds
description: It has been nearly three decades since Dr. Denis P. Burkitt, a British missionary surgeon who studied the differences in diseases of poor Africans and affluent Westerners, postulated that the Africans' high-fiber diet protected them against colon cancer. He spread his thesis as dietary gospel, prompting millions to change their diets.

title: Hidden Pearls; Rings Steer Web Explorers To Back Roads
description: SOME of the most obscure and most fascinating sites on the Web can be found almost exclusively sticking to its soft underbelly, in Web rings. Take, for example, Tales of Fur and Fiber (members.aol.com/daknits/index.html), run by Rachel Hecht, which includes a page of superstitions about knitting.

title: INLAND RESOURCES TO PURCHASE A REFINERY FROM FLYING J
description: Inland Resources Inc., an oil and natural gas company, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire certain assets of Flying J Inc. for $98 million in cash and stock. Inland will pay $80 million in cash and 12.8 million newly issued shares, worth about $18 million, based on Tuesday's Inland share closing price of $1.375. The stock portion represents about 60 percent of the combined company's equity, Inland said. Inland, based in Denver, will receive a 25,000-barrel-a-day refinery, 11 gasoline stations and all of Flying J's oil and gas reserves. Flying J, a truck-stop chain and petroleum producer based in Brigham City, Utah, will also contribute an undisclosed amount of working capital, Inland said. Shares of Inland rose 62.5 cents, to $2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIPILLO, VINCENT
description: DiPILLO-Vincent. The Board of Regents, Administration and staff of Long Island College Hospital (LICH) mourn the passing of Vincent DiPillo, father of our esteemed colleage Frank DiPillo, M.D., Chairman of the Department of Internal Medicine and a member of the Board of Regents. To Dr. DiPillo, the entire DiPillo family and all of Vincent's loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. John Wren, Chairman of the Board of Regents Peter A. Kelly, Interim President and CEO

title: U.S. ASKING RUSSIA TO EASE THE PACT ON MISSILE DEFENSE
description: The Administration said today that it was asking Russia to renegotiate the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty to permit a limited national system of missile defenses.

title: Court Upholds Refunds For L.I. Ratepayers
description: The state's highest court has upheld a lower court ruling that ordered Suffolk County to refund more than $1 billion to Long Island electric ratepayers.

title: Did Clinton Promise Too Much to Too Many?; Big Government Redux
description: To the Editor:

title: Meet the Beatles Less Reverentially
description: You haven't really heard the Beatles' song ''Can't Buy Me Love'' until you've heard the guitarist and singer John Pizzarelli lead his trio through an arrangement that pares away the vocal fat and slims it down into a skinny pop-blues vamp in the style of the Nat King Cole Trio's 1940's recordings.

title: A Fight on Redistricting Returns to the High Court
description: The long and skinny North Carolina Congressional district that drew the Supreme Court's ire six years ago is barely half as long now. Redrawn by the State Legislature after the Court declared it to be an unconstitutional racial gerrymander, it no longer has a majority of black voters, although it is still represented by a black Democrat, Melvin Watt.

title: Plan for Social Security Wins Support in Buffalo
description: When President Clinton gave his folksy version of his State of the Union Message today to the blue-collar and middle-class residents of Buffalo and its environs, he got an ardent response from people like Beverly Brigantia, for whom Social Security, the centerpiece of the President's message, is no academic matter.

title: U.S. Presents Documents in Case Against Microsoft
description: The Government presented documents and E-mail in the Microsoft trial today as evidence for its allegation that the big software maker had imposed contract restrictions on personal computer makers to thwart competition.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Growing Persimmons

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, HELENE (NEE DRESNER)
description: COLE-Helene (nee Dresner) of Upper Montclair, New Jersey, formerly of Paterson, New Jersey, on January 20, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Louis Cole, devoted mother of Alice Cole Oliff, George Cole, and Janet Cole Berlind. Adored sister of Rita Zemach. Loving grandmother of seven grand children. Funeral services conducted from Temple Ner Tamid, 936 Broad Street, Bloomfield, New Jersey on Friday, January 22, 1999 at 1:00 PM. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. For further information contact The Menorah Chapels At Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ.

title: Anheuser-Busch, after its best sales year ever, is spending a record sum on this year's Super Bowl.
description: LIKE a tavern owner who feels expansive enough to buy the house a round of drinks, Anheuser-Busch Inc. is spending a record sum on the most commercial time it has ever bought during a Super Bowl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULHOF, RUDOLPH B.
description: SCHULHOF-Rudolph B. The Board of Trustees and Staff at the Whitney Museum of American Art note with great sadness the passing of our beloved friend, Rudolph B. Schulhof. He will be warmly remembered for his steadfast support of American artists and his dedication to furthering the welfare and progress of contemporary American art. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Hanne, and to their entire family. Flora M. Biddle, Hon. Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Joel S. Ehrenkranz, President Maxwell L. Anderson, Director

title: Guatemala Laureate Defends 'My Truth'
description: Rigoberta Menchu, the Guatemalan Indian who rose from a childhood of want and racist violence to be awarded the 1992 Nobel Peace Prize, dismissed questions today about a book in which she described her life history, saying she had ''a right to my own memories.''

title: New Accusation May Harm Holbrooke's U.N. Chances
description: The Justice Department has accused Richard C. Holbrooke, President Clinton's choice to be the top American diplomat at the United Nations, of a civil violation of Federal ethics laws involving business contacts three years ago with the American Embassy in South Korea, Government officials said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about efforts by Los Angeles to limit handgun sales misstated the origin of a study of handgun seizures by the Los Angeles police. The study was conducted for an article in the Nov. 2 issue of ''Policing: An International Journal of Police Strategies and Management.'' It was not commissioned by the Los Angeles police.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the potential for the Linux computer operating system to pose a threat eventually to Microsoft's Windows misidentified the headquarters city of Corel, which is hoping to make its software compatible with Linux. It is Ottawa, not Toronto.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CERIDIAN CORP., Minneapolis, a provider of information services to the human resources, transportation and electronic media markets, said it would split its shares 2 for 1. The new shares will be issued Feb. 26 to shareholders of record on Feb. 10.

title: Jets' Foley Could Become a Cleveland Brown
description: Glenn Foley has once again received stunning, disappointing news from Jets Coach Bill Parcells. Foley, who never got over losing his starting quarterback job to Vinny Testaverde after an early season rib injury, is one of five Jets who will be available for next month's expansion draft to stock the roster of the Cleveland Browns.

title: Fighting Sioux Dominate
description: North Dakota continues to dominate the Western Collegiate Hockey Association and the national ranking. The No. 1 Fighting Sioux (17-2-1, 12-1-1 WCHA) swept aside second-place Colorado College, 5-4 and 5-1, at Colorado Springs and are 12-1-0 since Nov. 20. Over three seasons, Coach Dean Blais's skaters are 78-20-4. That record includes a victory in the 1997 national championship game. Coming up are two home contests this weekend against Minnesota, the former WCHA titan. The Gophers (7-11-6, 5-6-3) are in the midst of their second consecutive losing campaign and have not won at Grand Forks, N.D., since 1994.

title: From a Comic Romp To Desperation In the Wilderness
description: Toronto Dance Theater, a company known for its lively dancing and intelligent choreography, brought a stimulating program ranging from comic romps and explosions of energy to a solemn study of survival in a wilderness to the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night.

title: Did Clinton Promise Too Much to Too Many?; Dr. King's Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: United Says It Is Considering An Offer for America West
description: United Airlines, the nation's largest airline, said yesterday that it is interested in buying America West Airlines, the nation's ninth-largest carrier, a move that would escalate its battle with American Airlines in the West.

title: Surge Protectors, Again
description: To the Editor:

title: President's Counsel Dissects What He Calls 'Fudge-Making' by Prosecutors
description: Following is an excerpt from the presentation on Tuesday by the White House counsel, Charles F. C. Ruff, in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton, This section was truncated on Wednesday. The questions and answers in Mr. Ruff's presentation are his construction of a possible exchange between a prosecutor and Mr. Clinton's friend Vernon E. Jordan Jr. as a witness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENIG, JOSEPH J. DR.
description: KOENIG-Joseph J. Dr. In deep mourning upon the loss of our beloved uncle, in his 92nd year. Ruth Eleanor Fallon Mullen, Mary Ellen Mullen and Robert Leo Woronowicz, Mark Fallon Mullen, Madeline Marie Mullen and Edward J. Lowe, Ruth Ann Mullen, Luke Francis Xavier Mullen, Matthew Ignatius Loyola Mullen, Ian Gregory Ball, Emma Rae Mullen, Regina Fallon Woronowicz, Neil Alexander Ball, Roberta Madelaine Woronowicz, Piper Ann Lowe. He worked many years with Catholic Charities in New York City.

title: With Big Boys Looming, The Storm Is Growing
description: It was almost exactly a year ago that St. John's used a superb all-round effort by Tyrone Grant to beat Providence here and provide an early indicator that it was a tournament-worthy team.

title: Envoys Flock to Milosevic To Tackle Crisis He Created
description: While NATO tried to convince the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, that the alliance is serious about using force against him, Western diplomats continued to flock here today to urge him to defuse a crisis he himself created.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a decision by the Parliament of Senegal to ban genital cutting of women misspelled the name of a Senegalese women's organization that has campaigned against the practice. It is Tostan, not Tofhan.

title: Ecatepec Journal; A Rebel Creed, Stifled by the Pope, Flickers Still
description: The priests of Our Lady of Fatima parish have few resources, so they can offer friendship and faith but little else to the glue-sniffing teen-agers, jobless fathers and battered young women of this sprawling shantytown.

title: Divers Find Missing Boat That Sank During Storm
description: The clamming boat that vanished off New Jersey during Monday's storm has been found in 45 feet of water, with the hose from the vessel's clam dredge tangled in her propeller and the only life raft still stowed, uninflated, the Coast Guard said today.

title: $4.4 Trillion Windfall And Parties Square Off
description: After a yearlong transition in which both parties struggled to shift from an era of crippling Federal budget deficits to an anticipated age of fiscal plenty, the battle has at last been joined over how the country should allocate the flood of excess money streaming into Washington.

title: Rolls-Royce of Hearths, a Hit in the Rockies, Heads East
description: THE fire had burned down to a heap of coals. With a gloved hand, Randy LaFerr opened the oven door of his monumental Tulikivi soapstone fireplace from Finland and with a long-handle rake pushed the coals out the back and into the stove below. The soapstone bricks that line the oven were around 750 degrees, the perfect temperature, Mr. LaFerr said, to start the hors d'oeuvres. He placed a plate of goat cheese and cured olives with marinara sauce in the oven. In five minutes, it was bubbling gently behind the glass door.

title: Sports of The Times; Talent Is Resurrected on Broadway
description: THE National Basketball Association lockout is officially over, training camps open today and the Knicks, of all teams, have boldly jumped ahead of the pack before so much as a shot is taken. Never in my wildest dreams did I think that Latrell Sprewell would wind up on Broadway; now that he is on the way, I find myself actually looking forward to this abbreviated season.

title: Santander Acquires Argentine Bank Stake
description: Banco Santander S.A. said yesterday that it spent $179.6 million to acquire a majority stake in Banco Rio de la Plata, Argentina's fourth-largest private bank by deposits.

title: Press Review
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Dispute at City Hall Over a Call for Access
description: Seven City Council members and 15 citizens gathered yesterday on the steps of City Hall, where the Giuliani administration has tried to ban news conferences, rallies and protests, to propose a law guaranteeing public access to the spot.

title: Study Urged On Cancer And Races
description: The National Institutes of Health needs to develop a broader strategy for finding out why poor people and some ethnic minorities are more prone to certain cancers and less likely to survive them than is the rest of the population, an expert panel said today.

title: White House Special Counsel Asserts Perjury Case Is Flawed
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by Gregory B. Craig, White House special counsel, on accusations of perjury in Article I in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton. (Today's excerpts were recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.)

title: Lover of Detail Serves Literary Searchers
description: WILLIAM A. WILLIAMS JR. is a former member of the Mormon Church, which is known for its detailed collection of genealogical information, and a former actuary, familiar with small but vital details about populations. So perhaps it figures that he has become the Internet's sovereign of citation and ruler of reference, the man who posted the Concordances of Great Books, an on-line searchable index of 86 authors and 200 full texts.

title: In Old Mission District, Changing Grit to Gold
description: Sixteenth and Mission Streets, as busy as rush hour, is still the heart of the heart of the city's Spanish-speaking community. The fruit stands are still piled shoulder high with plantanos, yucca and mangoes, the saleswomen in the discount department stores still greet customers with ''Hola'' and families still wear their Sunday best to attend services at the Pentecostal Iglesia de JesuCristo.

title: A Victory With Elegance To Erase a Bad Memory
description: A star American partnership returned from Europe this week after erasing an unhappy memory. David Berkowitz of Old Tappan, N.J., and Larry Cohen of Boca Raton, Fla., who failed to win the World Pairs Championship in Lille, France, in September after leading into the last round, won the prestigious Cap Gemini World Top Invitational in The Hague on Sunday by a wide margin.

title: Did Clinton Promise Too Much to Too Many?; What Budget Surplus?
description: To the Editor:

title: Quarterbacks Play for Sons
description: The former Buffalo Bills All-Pro quarterback Jim Kelly has faced Super Bowl pressure on four occasions, but he says it doesn't compare to the battle his son, Hunter, has waged. The child, who will be 2 years old on Feb. 14, has Krabbe's disease, a degenerative disorder whose victims usually don't survive past the age of 2.

title: Dow Falls 19.31 as Earnings News Prompts Profit Taking
description: Shrugging off the latest caution by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, stock prices marched higher during the morning yesterday but then faded in the final hour or so and ended mixed.

title: President's Counsel Dissects What He Calls 'Fudge-Making' by Prosecutors
description: Following is an excerpt from the presentation on Tuesday by the White House counsel, Charles F. C. Ruff, in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton, This section was truncated on Wednesday. The questions and answers in Mr. Ruff's presentation are his construction of a possible exchange between a prosecutor and Mr. Clinton's friend Vernon E. Jordan Jr. as a witness.

title: In Redwoods, on the Far Western Fringe of SoHo
description: ''WE miss New York all the time,'' said Jerry Harrison, the keyboard player for Talking Heads, the rock band that emerged from clubs like CBGB into the mainstream in the 1970's with hits like ''Psycho Killer'' and ''Burning Down the House.''

title: American and US Airways Report Weak Fourth Quarters
description: American Airlines and U S Airways posted disappointing quarterly earnings yesterday on weaker-than-expected revenues, while America West Airlines exceeded Wall Street estimates by a wide margin.

title: Greenspan Sees Possible Threat In Clinton Plan
description: Republicans in Congress and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that President Clinton's proposal to have the Government invest a portion of Social Security reserves in the stock market would endanger the economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECKERMAN, EDWARD R. JR.
description: PECKERMAN-Edward R. Jr. The Horace Mann community records with deep sorrow the death of our esteemed alumnus, Edward R. Peckerman, Esq., Class of 1921. Always a warm, intelligent and caring person, he served as Vice Chair and Chair of the Horace Mann Board of Trustees from 1967 to 1970. The recipient of the Alumni Association's Award for Distinguished Achievement in 1976, he later served as an exemplary Honorary Trustee of Horace Mann until the time of his death. We shall miss his presence. We express heartfelt sympathy and condolences to his wife Kristen. Michael D. Hess, '58 Chair, Board of Trustees Dr. Eileen Mullady, Head of School

title: New Wristwatch Will Tell The Time, and Add the Place
description: A new wristwatch from Casio Computer will tell not just when, but where.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGMANN, ALAN
description: BERGMANN-Alan. On January 20 1999. Beloved brother of Ellen Sue and Arnold Block. Devoted uncle of Louise Treadway, Daniel Block, Howard Block and Wendy Miller and loving great uncle. Service Friday, 10AM, at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 312 Coney Island Ave at Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

title: Editorial Observer; The 2002 Olympics and Global Provincialism
description: Every small-town kid knows, or used to know, how a town can change when the carnival sets up its rides and its plush-toy, deep-fried midway at the fairgrounds. What's so exciting isn't just the chance to get dizzy on the Tilt-a-Whirl or to spend money in a way you'll soon regret. It's the presence in your midst of a closed society of strangers conforming to a way of life -- no matter how ordinary it may be at heart -- that makes your own look dull. Soon enough, the carnival will leave and the sod beneath the midway will no longer bear its traces, but until it does your town looks larger and smaller all at once. Larger for the noise and the cotton candy and the unfamiliar glow among the trees at night, but smaller because the carnival will drive off into the enormous world it came from while you lie asleep in bed.

title: Potential Olympic Sponsors Said to Be Uneasy
description: Two prospective corporate sponsors for the 2002 Winter Olympic Games in Salt Lake City have said they will not make their deals final until all investigations into the unfolding corruption scandal have been completed, a senior United States Olympic official said yesterday.

title: Easy Way to Face Down a Grizzly: On Line
description: FOR Meriwether Lewis, the moment of truth between human and bear occurred on June 14, 1805, one day after he had discovered the Great Falls of the Missouri. (Lewis and Clark's bear lore, and their other exploits, can be followed on line at www.lewis-clark.org.)

title: Machines to Sell Metrocards on Monday
description: Metrocard vending machines will go into service for the first time on Monday at two Manhattan subway stations, the first phase of an automated sales system that is meant to do away with subway token booths, New York City Transit officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLETTI, PERUCCA, GERTRUDE GRETSCH
description: COLETTI - PERUCCA - Gertrude Gretsch. Died at Glen Cove Hospital, January 16. Loving wife of the late Sonio, devoted mother of Jackie, mother-in-law of Nick Drexel and grandmother of Nicholas. She was born in 1923, married to Jack Astor, and then to Sonio. She was a wonderful friend to all & will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be 11 A.M., Thursday, January 21, at St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley. In lieu of flowers, donations to Kips Bay Boys Club would be appreciated.

title: Many Are Caught Off Guard By Clinton's Tobacco Plan
description: When President Clinton announced on Tuesday that the Government planned to sue cigarette makers, he shocked not only tobacco producers but also some Justice Department officials as well as outside lawyers who had been lobbying them to bring such a suit.

title: Economic Scene; Clinton's plan for Social Security has its backers. But does America want the Government to be a big shareholder?
description: President Clinton's proposal to shore up the financially shaky Social Security system leans heavily on a leading Republican plan. He would grab trillions of dollars of general tax revenue and invest some of it in the stock market. The plan is attractive, since neither Mr. Clinton nor the Republicans would need to propose higher payroll taxes or reductions in retirement benefits. On this feature, Democrats and Republicans easily agree.

title: Greenspan Hints Rate Cut Is Unlikely
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today there is little evidence that the economy is slowing. But he warned for the first time since the stock market's most recent run-up that equity prices might be getting excessive.

title: A Faulty Kournikova Advances
description: There is a longstanding adage in tennis that a player is only as good as his or her second serve. If that were entirely true, Anna Kournikova would not be in the third round of the Australian Open in Melbourne, Australia.

title: In Liberal Enclave, Trial Breeds Disgust
description: Alison Levy heard the word Republican, and her eyes narrowed and body tensed in one reflexive motion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELYNN, ALAN
description: DELYNN-Alan. On January 12. He began his lifetime career in the theater and film business in 1951, when he worked as a production assistant on ''Shane'' on location in Wyoming. In the years that followed he participated in the production of over 40 plays and films including a professional relationship with David Merrick that began in the mid 60's and lasted more than a decade. Alan was an unusually astute judge of talent and material. He was an exceptional scholar of film history, able to recall entire scenes of dialogue and details of casting and production. He served on the Board of Directors of the Anthology Film Archive. He is survived by his sister, Mrs. Howard Richman of Pittsburgh, five nieces and nephews and nine grandnieces and grand nephews. Any donations in his memory can be made to the Anthology Film Archive, 32 Second Ave, New York City, New York 10003.

title: Clinton Is Right to Go Slow on Pension Investments
description: By endorsing Government-sponsored individual investment accounts outside of Social Security, President Clinton is trying to steal the thunder from those who want to revamp the current system by diverting payroll taxes to private accounts. A crucial difference between the approaches, however, is that the Clinton plan would restrict an investor's options to a few relatively tame investments, thus reducing the risk that people would make bad investment decisions.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Eyes Threat on Kosovo

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONENFELD, ISRAEL JAMES
description: DONENFELD - Israel James. Composer, pianist and teacher of music, in his 82nd year, on January 19, 1999. Beloved husband of Anne; devoted father of Ken, Howard and Jane; adored grandpa of Elissa and Jon, Gil and Ron, Shalom and Romi. Funeral on Friday, January 22 at 10:45 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Joint Passover Association, UJA.

title: Two Are Traded; Wynalda En Route?
description: The MetroStars took the first major step in improving their team yesterday under the stewardship of their new coach, Bora Milutinovic. They traded two of their five foreign-born players, Giovanni Savarese and Marcelo Vega, to open space for a new player who is expected to be of star status.

title: Did Clinton Promise Too Much to Too Many?; Elderly Have Paid
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Sales
description: MANHATTAN

title: 2 'Psychics' Charged With Larceny
description: Two women who billed themselves as psychics were arrested yesterday and accused of demanding thousands of dollars from clients who they said were cursed, the police said.

title: The President's Side
description: In two days of vigorous rebuttal before the Senate, the White House defense team put some significant dents in the House prosecutors' case for removing President Clinton. Though Gregory Craig and Cheryl Mills could not disentangle Mr. Clinton yesterday from his misconduct and false statements, they did raise technical and substantive doubts about the perjury and obstruction accusations leveled by the House. They argued that the House prosecutors had brought in extraneous charges that went beyond the articles of impeachment and the independent counsel's charges. Mr. Craig pounded at the central issue of the case -- that Mr. Clinton's actions, while reckless and reprehensible, do not meet the constitutional test for canceling the verdict of the voters who elected him.

title: Largest Study Yet Rates Effectiveness of Fertility Treatments
description: Using fertility drugs increases a woman's chances of getting pregnant, but the drugs should be used cautiously to avoid the possibility of multiple birth, said a study and an accompanying editorial in the current issue of The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: DirecTV Is Said to Be in Talks for Primestar
description: DirecTV, the high-power satellite television company, is in talks to acquire Primestar, the medium-power direct-to-home satellite company owned by several cable companies and the public.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He touched on every subject except his dog and the homeless -- and he promised everybody something, so you've got to like it.''

title: Upstate Prosecutors Often Turn to Death Penalty
description: The return of capital punishment has reinforced the long-held suspicion that New York is not one state but two. There is New York City and its suburbs, with the bulk of the state's murders but a fraction of its death-penalty cases. And there is the rest of the state, where prosecutors seek the death penalty far more often, and homicide defendants have been 10 times more likely to face possible execution.

title: Pataki Embarks on a Quest to Establish a National Image
description: Less than three months after handily winning re-election, Gov. George E. Pataki is taking his first concrete steps toward bolstering his national presence. His aides announced today that he had created two political action committees and scheduled two speeches in the Midwest next month, the beginning of a series around the country.

title: Robertson, Praising Speech, Sees Trial as a Peril to G.O.P.
description: Pat Robertson, the conservative television evangelist who has been an important leader in pressing for the impeachment and ouster of President Clinton, said today that the President had ''hit a home run'' in his State of the Union address and that the impeachment trial might as well be halted.

title: In Speech to Senators, Bush Laments Decline of Civility and Privacy
description: Addressing scores of senators who had just finished another long afternoon at President Clinton's impeachment trial, former President George Bush warned of the collapse of decorum in political debate and an ''excessive intrusion into private lives.''

title: Did Clinton Promise Too Much to Too Many?; Following the Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Rape Is Linked To Suspect in 2 Attacks
description: An Upper West Side resident reported to the police yesterday that she had been raped in September by a 6-foot-10-inch, 300-pound man who is wanted in connection with two other, more recent attacks.

description: To the Editor:

title: Dostoyevsky's Battle of Flesh vs. Spirit
description: Mother Russia finds no tourist poster in the saints and sinners of Dostoyevsky's last novel, ''The Brothers Karamazov,'' and ''The Karamazovs,'' Boris Eifman's ballet treatment, is not going to send you singing into the street.

title: The Uncle Of All Tax Sites
description: INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE

title: Slightly Smaller, but Not Cheaper
description: ''Honey, I shrunk the life style.'' Pottery Barn has downscaled, literally. It mailed its first catalogue of children's home furnishings, Pottery Barn Kids, on Tuesday. The 44-page booklet includes slipcovered rattan baskets (they're bassinets), seagrass rugs, armoires and leather club chairs ($699, below) and ottomans ($299).

title: A Major Player Goes on Line
description: WEB TURBOTAX

title: Leaving Sister Home, Along With Electronics
description: ''I used to do this a long time ago, when I was in college,'' said Nancy Wilson -- the rock guitarist, not the jazz singer -- as she strummed an acoustic guitar on a stage adorned with roses at the Fez on Tuesday night. ''Then I joined the Army and saw the world a few times.''

title: ESPN's Newest Adventure
description: Bass fishing, fly casting, tree chopping, trick-shot archery and rifle shooting will be among the 17 sports in ESPN's Great Outdoor Games, an annual four-day competition that will make its debut in 2000 in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: A Show With Legs
description: Central to the way people live, tables and dinnerware reflect who they are, what they do and what they can afford. Starting Jan. 30, the Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio, will display 27 tables, from a work table (1800) to Karim Rashid's $1,499 Tri-Spectra (1998), above. The table settings range from ironstone through Eva Zeisel's whiteware (1940) to the Reagan White House china (1981). ''The show uses the table to understand the ebbs and flows in American modernism,'' said Mark Robbins, the show's curator, who next month will become the design director of the National Endowment for the Arts. Catalogue: (614) 292-3535. LINDA LEE

title: Did Clinton Promise Too Much to Too Many?; For Better Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS WATCH; Strange Bedfellows Sue Group That Puts Sex Sites on Line
description: What do Pamela Anderson, Dr. Laura Schlessinger and the Archdiocese of St. Louis have in common? As of Jan. 8, 1999, they've all sued Seth Warshavsky and his sex-oriented on-line company, the Internet Entertainment Group, based in Seattle. The archdiocese is suing I.E.G. for sites tied to the Pope's visit to St. Louis next Tuesday.

title: Pared-Down Approach To Returns
description: ONETAX.COM

title: Hutchison to Buy Container Operator
description: Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. is planning to buy Europe's largest container handler, Europe Combined Terminals B.V., for $357 million, in a move that could double the Hong Kong conglomerate's share of the north European shipping trade.

title: Democrats Now Might Call Early Vote on Impeachment Articles
description: Buoyed by the White House's impeachment defense and hoping that Senate Republicans are starting to tire, several Democrats said today that they might propose voting on the two impeachment articles early next week in another effort to end the trial without calling witnesses.

title: Bells and Whistles For 'Healthy Home'
description: If your home is like mine, it is an imperfect thing, resistant to most efforts to make it a sanctuary, even a little tyrannical in its dogged inconveniences. The bookcase shelf isn't quite within arm's reach of the desk chair, the toaster won't release an imperfectly sliced bagel, the bathroom vent mysteriously funnels in rap music from some other apartment in the building. (I assume it's in the building.)

title: 2 Rivals Pursue Curbs on AT&T
description: MCI Worldcom Inc. and the Sprint Corporation urged United States regulators to impose conditions on the planned $3 billion joint venture of the AT&T Corporation and British Telecommunications P.L.C. before approving it.

title: Vikings Replace Billick From Within
description: The Vikings named Chip Myers, their quarterback coach, as their new offensive coordinator yesterday, replacing Brian Billick, who was hired Tuesday as head coach of the Baltimore Ravens.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Sammy Solovitz, 71, a Mentor at The Times
description: Sammy Solovitz, a wise-cracking, hard-living mentor to generations of copy boys at The New York Times, died on Jan. 12 in Houston. He was 71 and had lived in Texas since his retirement in 1984.

title: It May Still Be Certain, but at Least It's Easier
description: IT is that time of year again, when thoughts turn from the happiness of holidays to the terror of tax time.

title: Scaffold in Times Square Collapse Was Built Improperly, U.S. Says
description: A 700-foot construction scaffold that buckled and broke in Times Square last summer, killing a woman in a nearby hotel and disrupting traffic for several days, was built improperly and was missing critical support braces on 10 floors, according to citations issued yesterday by Federal safety officials.

title: Cablevision Gift Will Link 900 Schools to the Internet
description: Hundreds of public and parochial schools in Brooklyn and the Bronx will soon get high-speed access to the Internet thanks to a multimillion-dollar gift from Cablevision Systems, company officials said yesterday.
