title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRING, WALTER DONALD, THE REVEREND
description: KRING-Walter Donald, The Reverend. Died at age 82 at his home in Brookfield, MA on Friday, January 15, 1999. Dr. Kring was Minister Emeritus of All Souls Church in New York City where he served as Senior Minister from 1955 to 1978. A memorial service will be held at All Souls, 1157 Lexington Avenue, at 1PM, on Sunday, January 24.

title: India Accuses 4 of Plotting To Bomb U.S. Consulates
description: The police here say they have foiled a plot to bomb American consulates in Madras and Calcutta by arresting a Bangladeshi man and three others who they say were accomplices.

title: Unprecedented Good Times
description: The current economic expansion will soon enter its ninth year, making it the longest peacetime expansion in American history. But it is unusual in more ways than length, as Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, emphasized in Congressional testimony yesterday.

title: E-Z Pass Talks Are Held
description: Amid growing concern about a contractor's ability to install and operate New Jersey's E-Z Pass system on schedule early next year, state transportation officials met with representatives from the company behind closed doors today to try to keep the $500 million project on track.

title: In Chicago, the Story Behind the Rising Test Scores
description: Not so long ago, Chicago's public schools were considered the worst in the nation. But in his State of the Union Message on Tuesday, President Clinton held them up as a model.

title: If It Comes to Court, Salt Lake's Nonprofit Status Could Be Jeopardized
description: The allegations are tantalizing: cash payments, college scholarships, hotel suites, airline tickets, jobs and free medical operations -- all exchanged to help Salt Lake City win the 2002 Winter Olympics.

title: Did Clinton Promise Too Much to Too Many?; Taxpayers Need a Break
description: To the Editor:

title: Now, From Coach, A Couch to Match
description: Coach, the leather goods company, has been letting out its belt lately, expanding into watches, cellular telephone cases and footwear. The next step: home furnishings. On Jan. 12, the company unveiled its first collection of furniture -- leather, of course -- which will be available in June at Coach and stores like ABC Carpet and Home and Bloomingdale's.

title: Scientists Are Publishing More on Line
description: PRINT versions of scientific journals could soon be a thing of the past, as the Internet gives rise to thousands of electronic journals and helps usher in a new era for scientific publishing, according to an article published yesterday in the journal Nature.

title: Soaring Of Kindred Spirits
description: It is hard to imagine a piano program in which Liszt's B minor Sonata, at least if played well, does not dominate everything else. Much the same can be said of Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations. As one solution, you might try playing them together, if you had the necessary technical ease and stamina. Few pianists do.

title: Wanted: F.O.B.'s (Friends of Barbie)
description: IT has been many years since I felt even the slightest envy for my cousin Mary Ann's collection of Barbies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYKE, EMILY
description: DYKE-Emily on January 19, 1999 of Rye, NY. Beloved daughter of the late George and Madeline Dyke; dear sister of Gibson V. Dyke and the late George Dyke, Jr. Mass Friday, 09:30 AM at St. John and St. Mary Church, Chappaqua. For information, Maher Funeral Home, 914-769-2044.

title: Martha Stewart Designing
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Republican senators, both standing and seated, at President Clinton's State of the Union address misstated the time of the scene. It occurred during the proceedings, not on Mr. Clinton's arrival. In general, Republicans stood when he arrived.

title: State Officials Add to U.S. Criticism of New York City's Food Stamp Program
description: Even as Federal officials criticized New York City's policy of delaying the distribution of food stamp applications to the poor, state officials said yesterday that city workers had also mistakenly given food stamps to large numbers of ineligible immigrants and others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLAH, LOUISE
description: MALLAH-Louise. Born December 19, 1919, died January 19, 1999. Beloved wife of Sam for 53 years. Adored mother of Lily and Alice, and mother-in-law of Richard and Mike. CHerished grandmother of Charles and wife, Sangeeta, Shari and Laurence, Lisa and husband Stuart, and Seth. Loving great grandmother of Natalie, Rebecca and Zamir. A survivor of the Holocaust, she will be remembered for her strength, courage and love. She will always be in our hearts. Funeral services on Thursday, January 21 at 10 A.M. at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: EQUITY OFFICE TO ADD BUILDING FOR $115.9 MILLION IN CASH
description: Equity Office Properties Trust, the largest office property owner in the United States, expects to buy an office building in Bellevue, Wash., for $115.9 million in cash, the company said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The property, known as City Center Bellevue, contains 448,881 square feet of office space and 23,796 square feet of retail space, it said. As of the end of December, the building was 99 percent occupied. The Chicago-based Equity Office, a real estate investment trust headed by Sam Zell, owns 286 buildings with a total 75.8 million square feet in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ACKERMAN, JOHANNA W.
description: ACKERMAN-Johanna W. Dearest Mom. Remembering and missing you always. With love. Edie, Peppy, Alan, Mark and Michael.

title: Vaulting Toward the Ceiling On Metal Born of Hip-Hop
description: Metal continues to inch closer and closer to black music, and whereas the first few instances of hard-rock and hip-hop 15 years ago were deliberate experiments in crossover, now the idea doesn't bear much thought. Be it from Korn or Method Man, young people will take jolting, jacked-up beats in any form, and there's nothing theoretical about it.

title: Finance Commissioner to Head Grand Central Business Group
description: The Grand Central Partnership is expected to name Alfred C. Cerullo 3d, the city's Finance Commissioner, as its president today, further consolidating Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's influence over the business group, which oversees sanitation, security and other services in the area around Grand Central Terminal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPONARA, GAETANA (GAYE) NEE DEMARTINO
description: SAPONARA-Gaetana (Gaye) nee DeMartino. Died suddenly on January 17 in Paris. Beloved wife of Frank. Devoted mother of Michele and Frank III. Loving, adoring grandmother and best friend of Lara. Cherished motherin-law of Nancy. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC on Friday 7 to 9:30PM. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:30 AM, Our Lady of Pompei Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Corpus Christi Monastery, 1230 lafayette Ave, Bx, 10474 would be appreciated.

title: Metro Business; Sbarro Sale Planned
description: Sbarro Inc., the restaurant chain, said yesterday that it had entered into an agreement concerning a recent merger proposal from the Sbarro family to buy the 65 percent of the company it does not yet own for $28.85 per share or $389.5 million in cash.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Japanese Giant's Not-So-Subtle Courtship
description: FOR SALE: A piece of the world's sixth-largest car company. Excellent engineering and technical capabilities. Some $20 billion in debt, but a fixer-upper with promise. Interested parties may apply to Yoshikazu Hanawa, president of the Nissan Motor Company.

title: Rain, Sleet and Ennui: A Realtor's Scramble
description: THE customer walked into the $1.575 million duplex maisonette on Park Avenue and zeroed in on the decorative grilles on the first-floor windows.

title: Before Trial, Indulgence In Hoary Rite Of Oratory
description: There was a certain pleasure for the few listeners on hand his morning when senators began orating in the chamber about absolutely anything they pleased a full two hours before President Clinton's impeachment trial resumed.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Not Being Invited Was the Honor

title: Did Clinton Promise Too Much to Too Many?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. to Push NATO to Issue Ultimatum to Serb Leader
description: The Clinton Administration is planning to push NATO allies for an ultimatum telling President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia that he must back down in Kosovo or face air strikes within days, officials said today.

title: The Big City; Phat City Just a Passing Fashion Fad
description: WHY does the goose-down bubble jacket endure as a staple of urban street fashion? Why has down been down for five years? The customers at Dr. Jay's in downtown Brooklyn had no trouble answering that question as they tried on the puffy jackets Tuesday afternoon. Over and over they replied, ''It keeps you warm.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INSELBUCH, FRADA ''SUNNY''
description: INSELBUCH-Frada ''Sunny''. January 20, 1999. Age 93. Beloved wife of the late Samson. Mother of Elihu. Mother-in-law of Harriet. Grandmother of Adam, Frank and Lenora, Jessica and Jan. Services Friday, 12:15PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCINTYRE, JEREMY
description: McINTYRE-Jeremy. Age 26. Died on Wednesday, January 13th in an avalanche while back country skiing near Lake Louise in Alberta, Canada. He was an environmental engineer for Golder Engineers in Seattle, WA which has been his home for the last five years. He obtained his Master's from the University of Washington after graduating Stanford University. He was a world class sailor and outdoorsman. He and his fiancee had recently completed a hike of the Pacific Crest Trail. He is survived by his parents Barbara Guldi McIntyre and David McIntyre of Greenville, SC and NYC, one sister Cori McIntyre of Memphis, TN, his fiancee Alexandra Wydzga of Seattle, his grandfather Walter Guldi of Westhampton Beach, his paternal grandparents Dr. James W. and Kathryn McIntyre of Venice, FL, numerous aunts, uncles and cousins. Funeral services will be held in Greenville, SC, Saturday, January 23rd, to be arranged by the Disciple United Methodist Church and the Mackey Mortuary. Remembrance donations may be made to the Jeremy McIntyre Fund, Major Conservancy, Washington Chapter, 217 Pine Street, Seattle, WA 98101.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Chief Supports Aid for Social Security

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, DR. JOSEPH J.
description: FRIEDMAN-Dr. Joseph J. Age 93, beloved husband of the late Frances, devoted father of Alan J., dear father-in-law of Diane, loving grandfather of Neil and Lisa. Shining role model as an exemplary physician in a four generation medical family, he was an inspiration of youth in retirement to all who knew him. Service 12 noon Friday ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FARBER, SLAYTON, VIOLA
description: FARBER-SLAYTON-Viola. Sarah Lawrence College notes with great sorrow the untimely death of Viola Farber, director of the Sarah Lawrence Dance Program. She brought the beauty oand joy of dance to our lives; her integrity and her dignity inspired all of us. A woman of uncommon grace, she will be sorely missed by her students, her colleagues, and her friends. A memorial service will be held at Sarah Lawrence on March 1, 1999, at 7PM in Reisinger Concert Hall, Contributions in her honor may be made to Sarah Lawrence College, Bronxville, New York 10708. Michele Tolela Myers, President Barbara Kaplan, Dean of the College

title: Clinton Gets a Rock-Star Reception at 2 Northeast Rallies
description: An exuberant President Clinton starred today in two rollicking rallies where he amplified the themes of his State of the Union Message and attacked Republican proposals to use the Federal budget surplus for across-the-board tax cuts.

title: Sports of The Times; Super Spite: Dan Reeves Vs. Broncos
description: WHEN Dan Reeves was recuperating from heart bypass surgery last month, the Atlanta Falcons' coach got a get-well phone call from Pat Bowlen, the Denver owner who had fired Reeves as the Broncos' coach after the 1992 season.

title: HERTZ MAKES A DEAL WITH TOYOTA RENTAL OUTLETS IN JAPAN
description: The Hertz Corporation, the world's largest car rental company, has agreed to a strategic alliance with the Toyota Motor Corporation's Japanese rental outlets. Starting in April, Hertz will introduce Toyota's Rent-a-Lease network, comprising 65 companies and 1,100 outlets across Japan, to its customers who want to rent automobiles there. In turn, Toyota Rent-a-Lease will introduce the Hertz network to its customers wishing to rent cars overseas and will display Hertz's signs and stickers at all outlets. Separately, Hertz said its fourth-quarter net income jumped 38 percent, to $47.9 million, or 44 cents a diluted share. This compared with $34.6 million, or 32 cents, a year earlier.

title: MANAGEMENT TO ACQUIRE INTEGRATED CIRCUIT SYSTEMS
description: Integrated Circuit Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired in a management buyout valued about $257 million. An investor group that includes senior management, Bain Capital Inc. and Bear, Stearns & Company will pay $21.25 a share in cash for its 12.1 million outstanding shares. The company also said it had agreed to sell its intellectual property and engineering hardware and software to the 3Com Corporation for $16 million in cash. Shares of Integrated Circuit rose $1.25, to $19.75.

title: Court Calendar
description: Following is the expected schedule for the impeachment trial of President Clinton:

title: Another Portable Way To Get Access to E-Mail
description: E-mail users who cannot bear to be without the service when they leave the office now have another way for messages to follow them around. Research In Motion, a wireless modem maker, and BellSouth introduced a new E-mail-ready pager called Blackberry this week. Unlike other wireless systems, this one does not require a separate E-mail account for messages.

title: U.N. Frees $81 Million for Iraq to Increase Its Electricity Supply
description: The United Nations is releasing more than $81 million to Iraq to buy equipment to increase its supply of electricity, the director of the Iraqi relief program said today.

title: Bristol-Myers Profit Rose In 4th Quarter
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, the second-largest United States drug maker, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit rose 13 percent as it sold more drugs such as the diabetes pill Glucophage and beauty-care products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNDWERG, MOSES J.
description: GRUNDWERG-Moses J. Passed away on January 12, 1999. Survived by Matthew and Tracy, Samuel and Julia, Sylvia and grandsons, Troy and Elisha, brothers Saul and Saundra and children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESTENBERG, JUDITH, M.D.
description: KESTENBERG-Judith, M.D. The Officers and Members of the Psychoanalytic Association of New York are saddened by the passing of Judith Kestenberg, M.D. Training analyst and beloved teacher, Dr. Kestenberg will be forever remembered for her pioneer work in helping the children survivors of the Holocaust, and the children of survivors, to heal their wounds. Her late husband Milton Kenstenberg was her partner in aiding these survivors and their families. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her children Howard and Janet. Daniel Papernik, President Arthur Lew, Secretary

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR IS MIXED. The outlook for steady interest rates pushed the dollar higher against the euro, but it fell for a second day against the yen. The euro cost $1.1555, down from $1.16140. The dollar fell to 112.85 yen from 113.49.

title: Solid as a Rock
description: Let the winds blow: there's a new doorstop in town. Once it's filled with water, the plastic Rock ($55) by Marc Newson, an Australian industrial designer, will keep even a heavy door open. At Moss, 146 Greene Street (Houston Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELIN, DAVID W.
description: BELIN-David W. We will greatly miss our friend David and his wise counsel and generous spirit. He was a class act. Condolences to Barbara and the family. The Tilles Family

title: Wachusett Radio Ads Help Lure Customers
description: Not many ski areas can dig into their past and pull up anecdotes that fit tidily into their modern marketing scheme. But a Crowley has run Wachusett Mountain for 30 years, and the family history runs so deep here that it forms the foundation of the ski area's radio commercials.

title: Record Number of Heroin Deaths Casts Shadow Over Seattle
description: Seattle and its surrounding county recorded a record number of heroin-related deaths last year, according to a preliminary report compiled by local health officials that is likely to solidify the city's unwanted reputation as a prime center for heroin abuse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAHN, JEROME G.
description: HAHN-Jerome G. On January 18, 1999 in Atlanta, GA. Beloved husband of Claire. Father of David Grobow Hahn, Tina Jacobson and Michael Hahn. Adored ''Papa'' of Sam, Molly, and Max Hahn and Sada, Emily and Jackie Jacobson. Respected father-in-law of Jini Hahn & David Jacobson. Brother of Shirley Dardeck. Funeral service will be held Friday, January 22, at 10:30AM at Wien & Wien, 129 Engle St., Englewood, N.J. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hospice Atlanta, 1244 Park Vista Dr, Atlanta, GA. 30319.

title: City Opera Contract Is Settled
description: The New York City Opera and the musicians who perform as part of its national touring company have settled a contract dispute that had led to a cancellation of rehearsals on Sunday and Monday and had imperiled a tour set to begin in San Antonio on Monday. Talks had broken down when the musicians pressed the company to include a clause in their new contract guaranteeing that the touring orchestra would have at least 28 or 29 musicians. The company agreed to a minimum of 28. Spokesmen for Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians said that the new contract was ratified on Tuesday evening and that the tour would begin on schedule.

title: The Neediest Cases; Love for Abandoned Boy Makes Adoption Succeed
description: Darryl P., standing on his top bunk bed, was doing battle on Sunday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Planet Africa: Black History on Disk; Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Microsoft Produce A Long-Awaited, Much-Debated Encyclopedia
description: IN 1995, Henry Louis Gates Jr., a Harvard professor and perhaps the most widely recognized African-American scholar today, cast himself in the role of fast-talking encyclopedia salesman. Dr. Gates, who had begun dreaming of creating a comprehensive encyclopedia of the black world two decades earlier, found himself in New York presenting his proposal to executives from the giant publishing company Random House. But before he could finish his pitch, the company's chief executive, Alberto Vitale, asked him if the encyclopedia could be done as a multimedia CD-ROM, rather than in the conventional print-only manner.

title: Good Cop, Imperfect Cop: A Man Just Doing His Best
description: Sgt. Joe Turk is a cop's cop: father of two police officers and father figure to dozens more at his Chicago station house. As played by William Devane, he is the solid center of ''Turks,'' the series that begins tonight on CBS. This is a workmanlike, even imaginative blend of a family saga and a standard police drama. But in Joe Turk, the show has a rare asset that sets it apart.

title: Rebuilt Neighborhoods: A Look at Before and After
description: ''LANDSCAPES of Hope: Rebuilding New York City's Neighborhoods,'' a photography exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York, portrays stretches of Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn that have been transformed from symbols of urban decay into models of urban renewal.

title: Excerpts From Federal Reserve Chairman's Testimony
description: Following are excerpts from testimony by Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman, before the House Ways and Means Committee today as recorded by the Federal News Service:

title: Did Clinton Promise Too Much to Too Many?; Bring Back Partisanship
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, BESS ASHLEY HOUSE
description: HOPKINS-Bess Ashley House. Died January 16 in Cambridge, MA. Devoted mother and motherin-law of Terry, Mandy, Tom, Jay, Sarah and Matthew. Delighted grandmother of six and dear sister of Bina Beghe-and so loved by all who knew her. Funeral services on Friday, January 22, 1PM at Christ Episcopal Church, Garden St, Cambridge MA, 617-876-0200.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOSTIS, MILTON
description: DOSTIS-Milton. 86. Tuesday, beloved husband of Helen, cherished father of Susan and Steven, adored grandfather, loving brother of Mary. Funeral today at Hirsch & Sons Chapel, Bronx, NY.

title: Driving Drunk To Mean Loss Of the Vehicle
description: Starting within the next month, the cars of people arrested on drunken driving charges in New York City will be seized on the spot and later forfeited if the drivers are convicted, Police Commissioner Howard Safir announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAHN, JEROME G.
description: HAHN-Jerome G. On January 18, 1999 in Atlanta, GA. Beloved husband of Claire. Father of David Grobow Hahn, Tina Jacobson and Michael Hahn. Adored ''Papa'' of Sam, Molly, and Max Hahn and Sada, Emily and Jackie Jacobson. Respected father-in-law of Jini Hahn & David Jacobson. Brother of Shirley Dardeck. Funeral service will be held Friday, January 22, at 10:30AM at Wien & Wien, 129 Engle St., Englewood, N.J. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hospice Atlanta, 1244 Park Vista Dr, Atlanta, GA. 30319.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVINE, MICHAEL F.
description: DEVINE-Michael F. Age 86. Died Wednesday, January 20, 1999 at Allendale Nursing Home. Born in St. Johns, Newfoundland he grew up in Richfield Park before moving to Allendale 35 years ago. Mr. Devine was a CLU for Met Life, N.Y.C. for 43 years before his retirement in 1974. He was a WWII Coast Guard veteran and a life member of the Seventh Regiment of N.Y. He was a parishioner of St. Elizabeth's R.C. Church. Surviving are his wife Teresa (nee Rice) Devine, a brother-in-law, Rev. Patrick J. Rice, OSA & a brother, Brendan Devine of St. Johns, Newfoundland. Funeral Service Monday 10:30 A.M. from the Vander Plaat Funeral Home 257 Godwin Ave. Wyckoff, NJ. Funeral Mass 11 A.M. from St. Elizabeth's R.C. Church 700 Wyckoff Ave. Interment Maryrest Cemetery, Mahwah. Visiting Sunday 2-4, 7-9 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZARE, PAUL
description: LAZARE-Paul. On January 20, 1999. Beloved husband of Doriane. Loving father of Nicki, Nila Grutman, Sasha Grutman and the late Tony Roth. Dear grandfather of Gabriel Roth and Zachary Roth. Service Friday, 12 Noon at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Accounts
description: * Astoria Federal Savings and Loan Association, Lake Success, N.Y., part of the Astoria Financial Corp., to Brouillard Communications, New York, owned by WPP Group P.L.C., to handle its advertising and public relations account, which had been at Greenstone Roberts Advertising, Melville, N.Y. Billings were estimated at $4 million to $5 million.

title: Repsol Denies Having Plans to Take Over YPF
description: Spain's Repsol S.A. denied yesterday that it planned to take over the Argentine oil company YPF S.A. as Moody's Investors Service said it was placing Repsol's long-term debt under review for a possible downgrade in rating.

title: Warily, Cambodian Backs U.N. Plans for Khmer Rouge Trials
description: Prime Minister Hun Sen confirmed to the United Nations today that he supports its efforts to set up a tribunal to try Khmer Rouge leaders. But he raised questions about the scope that could complicate these efforts.

title: A Flurry Of Activity Marks End Of Lockout
description: Karl Malone and Charles Barkley are staying put, Latrell Sprewell and Scottie Pippen have moved on to New York and Houston, respectively, and Dennis Rodman still has no idea where he will end up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESTENBERG, JUDITH
description: KESTENBERG-Judith, M.D. The Hidden Child Foundation/ADL mourns the loss of our dear friend and benefactor, Judith Kestenberg. We will always remember her tireless commitment to the plight of children who survived the Holocaust in hiding, and all other child survivors. She validated our pain and helped us heal. Ann Shore, Hidden Child Foundation/ADL, President

title: Missile Plan Puts U.S. in Quandary on China
description: Having planned a major outlay for defensive missiles, the Clinton Administration now faces a major diplomatic and military quandary with China.

title: Sinking of Clamming Vessel and Loss of 4 Crew Members Spur 2 Federal Investigations
description: The sinking of a clamming boat and the loss of her four crew members off New Jersey on Monday have prompted two Federal investigations that will seek clues to the accident and examine safety in the commercial fishing industry and communications between the Coast Guard and floundering vessels.

title: New Safety Options On Cadillac DeVille
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would offer a package of high-technology driver-assistance features on the 2000-model-year Cadillac DeVille, which goes on sale in the spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, DAVID
description: HOROWITZ-David. The children and family mourn the passing of David Horowitz, 86, of Forest Hills, New York. Pop, you were a fighter 'til the end. You did things your way and we always loved you for it. We are proud of you and you will live in our hearts forever.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROGOVIN, SAUL
description: ROGOVIN-Saul. 1922-1995. I miss you so. With all my love, Evi

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Witnesses? Well...
description: Although the nation and the Senate seem to want a quick end to the impeachment trial, Henry Hyde and the other House managers are still holding out for testimony from witnesses. They say that this would not slow down the trial and that it would be a simple matter to call a few witnesses, hear their testimony and then be done with it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLYNEUX, JAMES
description: MOLYNEUX-James M., 78. Died of cardiac arrest on January 20 at Long Island Jewish Hospital. Devoted husband of the late Jeanne Molyneux. Loving brother of Sister Mary Matthew and brother-inlaw of Robert & Veronica Cartier. Loving father of Michael Molyneux and father-in-law of Lisa Matthews. Proud grandfather of Paul, Thomas, & Emily Molyneux. His kindness will remain in our hearts. Friends may visit at Simonson Funeral Home, 119-04 Hillside Ave., Richmond Hill, Queens today 2:30-5:00 PM and tomorrow 7:00-9:30 PM. Mass of Christian burial Monday 9:30 AM, Holy Child Jesus RC Church, 112th St. and 85th Ave., Richmond, Hill. In lieu of flowers donations to Regis High School would be appreciated.

title: In Its Victorian Glory, A World of Kitsch
description: Bournemouth, the coastal resort in southern England, may not be a world cultural capital but don't dismiss it. It is the home of the Russell-Cotes Art Gallery and Museum, among other attractions. This stronghold of conservative British Victorian painting gives the word kitsch a new dimension. Established by a hotel proprietor, Sir Merton Russell-Cotes (1835-1922), and his heiress wife, Annie (1835-1921), the collection is still displayed in the far-out (but since expanded) French-Italian pile overlooking the bay where the couple lived from 1907 until their deaths.

title: Uncorking Elgar's Essence: Five Critics Savor the Bouquet
description: Here are some favorite Elgar recordings of the classical music critics of The New York Times. CD's range in price from $16.99 for a single CD to $32 for a specially priced four-CD set. (An introduction appears on page 1.)

title: Earnings at Bankers Trust Remain Extremely Weak
description: The Bankers Trust Corporation, posting its next to last earnings report before the expected completion of its acquisition by Deutsche Bank A.G., said yesterday that profit in the fourth quarter plunged 54 percent.

title: Lottery May Decide Competition in Internet Name System
description: The nonprofit board charged with opening the Internet's domain-name registration business to competition is leaning toward an international lottery to pick the five companies that will get the first shot at ending the Government-sanctioned monopoly held by Network Solutions Inc., the board's chairman said.

title: Marketers Shift Agency Rosters
description: Two advertisers are making changes involving their accounts.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits yesterday about on-line concordances misstated the Web address of a searchable collection of T. S. Eliot's poetry. It is www.missouri.edu/tselist/cgi/ tsebase.cgi.

title: Clinton Defense Leaves Senate Sharply Divided on Next Move
description: As the White House wrapped up its three-day case today, Senate Republicans and Democrats agreed that President Clinton's lawyers had mounted a strong defense, but they remained divided over whether they needed to hear more evidence before voting on the impeachment articles.

title: SPRINT TO PROCEED WITH PUBLIC OFFERING OF WIRELESS UNIT
description: The Sprint Corporation, the telecommunications company, said yesterday that it would go ahead with a $500 million public offering of Sprint PCS Group stock to raise money to expand its wireless telephone network. The fast-growing wireless unit was spun off from Sprint in November. In the fourth quarter it added 830,000 customers, doubling sales from the previous quarter, it said. Sprint PCS, based in Kansas City, Mo., added 1.7 million customers in 1998, for a total of 2.6 million.

title: Middle-Aged Ex-Rock Stars Milk The Past for a Life-Renewing Blast
description: They are, in the words of the flashy Swedish second wife of one of them, ''an old hat.'' They are the ex-members of Strange Fruit, the fictitious, once hot English rock band that has disappeared into seemingly well-deserved oblivion. But in ''Still Crazy,'' the group members grudgingly reunite 20 years after they last dropped acid in a Druid circle, and the results are meant to be both funny and heartwarming. Not an easy mix, unless Spinal Tap really is your idea of a band that needs a second chance.

title: A Solo Turn for a Frequent Collaborator
description: Joseph Kalichstein's performances as the pianist in the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio and in collaborations with other ensembles have always been eloquent and impassioned, and his recent appointment as chamber music adviser to the Kennedy Center in Washington is clearly a measure of the importance of the chamber repertory to him. He is heard less frequently in New York as a soloist, and his recital at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening suggested that concertgoers are missing something by not hearing more of Mr. Kalichstein on his own.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The relationship between husband and wife, father and child, has been incredibly strained, if not destroyed.''

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: For Bookworms Who Want to Talk About It
description: Reading is an essentially solitary activity, but talking about books requires at least two people. Even if you live with another bibliovore, what are the chances that you will both be struck by the desire to read and discuss, say, ''Bleak House'' or ''Ulysses'' at precisely the same moment? The growing popularity of reading groups and book clubs attests to the desire to talk about books as well as read them.

title: Now Is the Time For a Tax Cut; Keeping G.O.P. at Bay
description: To the Editor:

title: Charting a Massacre: The Monitors' Report
description: Following are excerpts from ''Special Report: Massacre of Civilians in Racak,'' compiled by international monitors who were in the village before and after the killings on Jan. 15. K.V.M. is Kosovo Verification Mission; K.L.A. is the Kosovo Liberation Army; V.J. is Yugoslav Army.

title: Nassau to Sue Over Problems In Health Plan
description: Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta said today that he planned to sue the administrators of the health plan covering the county's 26,000 employees, after an investigation indicated that the company had received kickbacks from its health care subcontractors, billed for services not rendered and failed to notify the county of serious cost overruns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESTENBAUM, RALPH
description: KESTENBAUM-Ralph. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Men's Club mourn the passing of their beloved member and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Haskel Lookstein, Rabbi Joshua Lookstein, Asst Rabbi Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Profit at Exxon Down 30%; Low Crude Oil Prices Cited
description: The Exxon Corporation, the largest United States oil company, said here today that its fourth-quarter income fell 30 percent, the fourth consecutive quarterly decline, as crude oil prices dropped sharply and profit from chemical sales fell.

title: Laura Ashley Gets a New Chief Again
description: Laura Ashley Holdings P.L.C., the clothing and home-furnishings retailer has called upon the help of Pat Robertson.

title: Ex-Inmate Said to Identify 2 Guards in Beating Case
description: A man who said he overheard guards at the Nassau County jail brutally attacking another inmate who later died has identified two of the guards from a police photo lineup, the lawyer for the victim's family said today.

title: Security Council Seeks Talks With Angola Over U.N. Mission
description: Trying to save a beleaguered mission in Angola, the Security Council called today for talks with the Angolan Government on the mission's future. The Government recently resumed fighting with an entrenched rebel movement and appears to want the United Nations to get out of the way.

title: Now Is the Time For a Tax Cut; Litigate to Legislate
description: To the Editor:

title: Challenges Taken On As a Life Starts Anew
description: ''My Name Is Joe'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Here are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 30. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Uncorking Elgar's Essence: Five Critics Savor the Bouquet
description: Here are some favorite Elgar recordings of the classical music critics of The New York Times. CD's range in price from $16.99 for a single CD to $32 for a specially priced four-CD set. (An introduction appears on page 1.)

title: A New Ripple Effect
description: The American Presidency is under siege, and the world does not seem to care. Yet when Itamar Franco, a provincial Governor in Brazil, recently decided to suspend debt payments to his national Government, international markets trembled. His decision pushed the dollar down, shook up the financial markets and, a few days later, forced a devaluation of Brazil's currency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HEHIR, JOSEPH BUTLER
description: O'HEHIR-Joseph Butler, 87, died in Miami on January 20th, 1999. Husband of the late Catherine M. O'Brien. Father of Maureen A. O'Hehir and Kathleen B. Cannella. Father-in-law of Salvatore T. Cannella. Grandfather of David E. Cannella and Michelle E. Caceres. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated 10:00AM Saturday at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in Miami, Florida. Funeral arrangements entrusted to Stanfill Funeral Home (10545 S. Dixie Highway Miami, Florida 33156).

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Drug issues go from champs to chumps in a few short weeks.
description: TALK about a reversal of fortune.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unles sorthwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. *denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Workfare Doesn't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a debate in Israel over its anti-inflation policies misstated the size of the original 1999 budget proposed by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. It was $53 billion, not $214 billion.

title: CITIGROUP COMBINES 2 DIVISIONS IN DERIVATIVES REVAMPING
description: Citigroup Inc. has reorganized its derivatives unit to combine the businesses of its Citibank banking and Salomon Smith Barney brokerage divisions. The company created a derivatives capital group, run by Narayan Prasad. The group will structure derivatives and serve as a link between traders and investment bankers, according to The Wall Street Journal, which first reported the revamping. Merging the units proved contentious because both Salomon and Citibank had strong businesses that were organized differently, people inside the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICKAR, GABRIEL
description: PICKAR-Gabriel, Dr. a prominent physician and leader of the medical community of central New Jersey, died Tuesday, January 19, 1999 at age 85 after a brief illness. Dr. Pickar began the practice of internal medicine in Highland Park, N.J. in August 1946 and continued until his retirement in 1983. He was former Chief of Medicine at Middlesex General Hospital, New Brunswick, N.J. and President of the New Jersey Diabetes Society. He was among the founding clinical faculty of the Rutgers Medical School, later renamed the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School of UMDNJ. Dr. Pickar was a graduate of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh and was a Fellow of the American College of Physicians. Dr. Pickar served in the Army Medical Corps from 1941-1945, participating in the invasion of North Africa and as a Medical Officer on hospital ships in the Atlantic and the Pacific, including the USS Ernestine Koranda. He attended to an ailing Winston Churchill in Casablanca. Dr. Pickar is survived by Arline, his wife of 53 years, and sons, Ben Pickar of Silver Spring, MD, Dr. David Pickar, of Chevy Chase, MD, daughter, Elizabeth Pickar Gray of Cabin John, Md. and six grandchildren. Memorial service will be held at the Boca West Club, Friday, on January 22, 1999 at 11:00 AM.

title: The Tinderbox Career of a Legendary Truth Teller
description: David Wojnarowicz (1954-92) was a near-mythic figure in New York a decade ago, and for many people who knew him, he still is. Artist, writer, filmmaker and performer, he gained fame during the brief East Village art boom of the 1980's. But he kept himself outside the hype and went his own way. He stayed in the neighborhood after the galleries had moved out, and died there of AIDS at the age of 38.

title: Churchill Downs To Buy Calder Track
description: The trend toward the merger of race tracks continued yesterday when Churchill Downs, home of the Kentucky Derby, signed an agreement to buy Calder Race Track in Miami for $87 million.

title: Sun Microsystems' Earnings Grow 22%
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., one of the biggest makers of computers that run the Internet, said today that fiscal second-quarter earnings rose 22 percent, fueled by robust sales of its powerful machines.

title: Clinton Impeachment Isn't a Threat to Judges
description: To the Editor:

title: Son of Insurance Tycoon To Head Big Brokerage Firm
description: Jeffrey W. Greenberg, the eldest son of one of the country's most influential insurance executives, Maurice R. (Hank) Greenberg, was named president yesterday of the Marsh & McLennan Companies, the world's largest insurance brokerage, and was designated its next chief executive and chairman.

title: Sports of The Times; The Season For Naughty, And for Nice
description: THE curtain finally lifted yesterday on the pro basketball season, and rehearsals began locally for what promises to be a most fascinating morality play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CITRONBAUM, EUGENE
description: CITRONBAUM-Eugene. Classical trumpet player of great beauty, succumbed to lung cancer January 19. Mourned by family-mother Lillian Mininberg Citronbaum and brother Ronald Citron-and his many friends. His musical and personal presence will be missed. Memorial service on Monday, January 25, 7PM in the Chapel of Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Avenue, Bronx, New York. Contributions in his name can be sent to a charity of choice.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Ceremonial Textiles of the Chinese Court: 17th-19th Centuries'

title: Belichick Is Set to Stay
description: Jets' fans who feared the break-up of the team's highly skilled and admired coaching staff can continue thinking positively about next season. Bill Belichick, the assistant head coach and defensive orchestrator, will probably decide, as early as today, to remain with the team.

title: Conservatives Attack Pat Robertson's Clinton Remark
description: The remarks of Pat Robertson, the television evangelist, that the fight to oust President Clinton was all but lost set off a firestorm today among conservatives, who condemned him and asserted that Republicans should not turn back from a full trial.

title: The Dark World Of a Filmmaker
description: From the beginning, Nick Broomfield said, there was stiff resistance to ''Kurt and Courtney,'' his documentary about the rock star Kurt Cobain, who died in 1994, and his wife, the performer and actress Courtney Love. A filmmaker perpetually on the trot, his shoulder-borne camera at the ready and microphone extended, Mr. Broomfield established his aggressively persistent yet mild-mannered investigatory style in ''Heidi Fleiss: Hollywood Madam'' and other works.

title: INSIDE
description: Drunken Drivers to Lose Cars

title: Pakistan Denies Role in Plotting Bombings in India
description: The chief Pakistani diplomat here today denied that a Bangladeshi arrested here and accused of plotting to bomb American consulates in Madras and Calcutta was a Pakistani intelligence agent, as the police have charged.

title: Raul Salinas Guilty in Killing And Is Sentenced to 50 Years
description: After a tangled four-year trial, Raul Salinas de Gortari, the brother of Mexico's former President, was convicted today of ordering the 1994 assassination of a prominent politician and sentenced to 50 years in prison. The stunning verdict shattered the impunity that has shielded powerful Mexicans for decades.

title: Last Exit: Hurtling Down the Road to Ruin
description: ''So you two are Bonnie and Clyde, eh?'' Melanie Griffith asks a pair of druggy young lovebirds in ''Another Day in Paradise,'' the second unapologetically seedy feature directed by Larry Clark. ''So are we.'' That's because the one big happy pseudo-family wobbling through this improbably vibrant road movie consists of two middle-aged junkies (Ms. Griffith and a full-throttle James Woods) and two sexy young things (Vincent Kartheiser and Natasha Gregson Wagner), all in the throes of a shared case of the outlaw blues.

title: Agents Seize Nearly 5 Tons Of Cocaine Aboard Freighter
description: Footprints in a mountain of iron ore caught the eye of Coast Guard officers searching a 580-foot Panamanian freighter intercepted in the Caribbean Sea about 125 miles southwest of Jamaica while on her way to Texas from Brazil.

title: Social Security and the Market
description: One day after President Clinton proposed shoring up the Social Security system by investing a portion of its assets in the stock market, Alan Greenspan stepped forward to say ''Not so fast.'' It is not often that the notoriously circumspect chairman of the Federal Reserve Board shoots at a major new Administration plan, and his concerns were well taken. As a matter of political reality, both parties appear headed toward investment of Social Security funds in the stock market, either by the system itself or by individual participants. Forced to choose now, we prefer Mr. Clinton's approach to that of the Republicans. But Mr. Greenspan's cautionary comments should be useful in framing the debate.

title: Upbeat Calipari Opens Window of Opportunity
description: John Calipari does it at the beginning of each season. He looks his players in the eyes, speaks in his boldest, most confident tone and launches into a soliloquy about winning. And no matter how poor his club is and how farfetched the idea of success may be, the Nets coach always ends with this prediction: ''We're going to win.''

title: Israelis vs. Arabs, Arabs vs. Arabs, Israelis vs. Israelis
description: The five hours of vivid history that begin Sunday on PBS are delivered through the memories of eminent and obscure Israelis, Arabs, Americans and Russians, players all in ''The 50 Years War: Israel and the Arabs.''

title: U.S. Aides Meet With 'Inflexible' Milosevic
description: A senior American diplomat had an almost entirely unproductive four-hour meeting tonight with the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, telling him that he must meet Western demands to ease the crisis in the Serbian province of Kosovo or face military action by NATO, American officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TONNE, DR. HERBERT A.
description: TONNE-Dr. Herbert A. The NYU School of Education community wishes to express its sense of loss at the passing of a friend and colleague, Professor Emeritus Herbert A. Tonne, a nationally recognized leader in business education. We send our deepest sympathy to his wife, Dr. Elizabeth V. Tonne. The Faculty of the School of Education, New York University

title: Clinton Impeachment Isn't a Threat to Judges
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LADENHEIM, CAROL
description: LADENHEIM-Carol. Beloved sister of Gloria Klein and loving aunt of Rena Kilganon and Debbie Palazzo. Service 11 A.M. Friday at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Suing the Gun Makers
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft and the Question of Monopoly
description: The judge in the Microsoft antitrust trial asked the company's expert witness on economics a series of skeptical questions today, suggesting that the Microsoft Corporation may have a difficult time with one of its defenses -- that it does not have a monopoly in the market for personal computer operating systems.

title: Some Senators Vow Fight if U.S. Seeks Share of Tobacco Money
description: Several senators vowed today to protect the money that their states won in lawsuits against the tobacco industry from what they described as the Clinton Administration's plan to seize a share for the Federal Government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUND, ROSENTHAL, MIRIAM K.
description: FREUND - ROSENTHAL - Miriam K. The National Jewish Outreach Program mourns the passing of Dr. Miriam Freund-Rosenthal, mother of Harry and Matta Freund, devoted benefactors of NJOP, where Harry serves as a member of the Board of Directors. Dr. Freund-Rosenthal, a legendary Jewish leader, served with great vision and devotion as National President of Hadassah. Her family has followed in her footsteps, particularly her granddaughter, Rebecca who has served as an invaluable member of NJOP, both in a professional and volunteer capacity. May her memory be blessed. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday showing the relative importance of each world region to 36 multinational companies, based on their 1997 sales, labeled one regional category incompletely, provided incorrect figures for one company and misidentified another.

title: Now Is the Time For a Tax Cut
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Accuses Officers of Embezzlement
description: The executive board of a union local representing more than 2,500 New York City emergency medical technicians filed charges yesterday against its three top officers, accusing them of using union funds to buy clothes and take unauthorized trips.

title: Enron to Provide Fiber Optic Feed
description: The Enron Corporation, one of the nation's largest energy companies, and Real Networks Inc. formed an alliance to deliver high-quality video to Internet providers and companies over Enron's fiber optic network.

title: I.O.C. Member Wears A Second Hat: NBC's
description: For many years, NBC Sports was virtually a forgotten network when it came to carrying the Olympics. Its competitor, ABC Sports, led by Roone Arledge, had made the Olympics virtually its own. But that changed in 1988 when NBC carried the first of three consecutive Summer Games, and was transformed in 1995 when a startling pair of deals brought it the rights to carry all five Olympics from 2000 to 2008.

title: In President's Words: Assessing Risks of Germ Warfare
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Clinton on the threat of biological and chemical weapons, conducted today by The New York Times, as transcribed by the White House:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPER, CAROL
description: HALPER-Carol. Beloved wife, mother, daughter and friend. You are so special and an inspiration to us all. Your spirit is everywhere. We love you. Maris and Howard.

title: Astra to Reacquire Rights to Several Drugs
description: Astra A.B., the Swedish drug maker that agreed last month to be bought by Britain's Zeneca Group P.L.C., said today that it expected to pay about $800 million to the Schering-Plough Corporation to reacquire rights to certain drugs.

title: Settling Down All Over Town
description: Members of the Upright Citizens Brigade, an improvisational comedy troupe, took their mops and paint brushes to the Harmony Theater last weekend and began to scrub the former X-rated movie house on West 22d Street in Chelsea.

title: Lucia as Shimmering Heroine
description: In the new Met production of Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor,'' the heroine goes through the first two acts in a gown of silvered green, which was the vocal coloring brought to the role on Wednesday night by Elizabeth Futral in her house debut. The silver was in her brilliance of tone, accuracy of intonation and command of ornament, the green in the way her inflection could warm through, especially on held notes, and in the natural bend of her rhythm.

title: Redefining a Style As It Catches On
description: Maybe the third week in January should be designated official Outsider Art Week in New York City. The annual Outsider Art Fair, in full cry for the next three days at the Puck Building in SoHo, is now seven years old, and each year more gallery and museum exhibitions seem timed to its arrival.

title: United Air Faces Long Odds as It Pursues Merger
description: Mergers have a poor record of success in general, but they have been particularly unsuccessful in the highly regulated and highly unionized airline industry. Yet that has not stopped executives from trying, no matter how difficult the obstacles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATERS, ALFRED E.
description: WATERS-Alfred E. 80. On December 22, 1998. Retired educator and Board of Education administrator. Beloved husband of Adelaide, father of Lloyd and Alfred, Jr., grandfather of two. Memorial service Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Dr., NYC on January 30, 1999 at 2 PM. Donations to United Negro College Fund.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Richard Barnes

title: Gore Gives Details Of Aid for Elderly
description: Surrounded by 200 elderly and disabled people and those who provide care for them at a center for the elderly here, Vice President Al Gore today disclosed details of the Administration's $6 billion dollar package of tax and budget proposals for long-term care.

title: For Devils, 2 Victories in 2 Nights
description: DEVILS 3, KINGS 2

title: Mortgage Rates Are Lower
description: The interest rate on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages fell again this week, staying under the 7 percent mark since June -- the longest stretch on record, Freddie Mac reported today. The average rate on a 30-year mortgage fell to 6.78 percent in the week that ends on Friday from 6.83 percent last week, a weekly survey of mortgage rates determined. The average rate on 15-year fixed-rate mortgages dropped to 6.42 percent from 6.48 percent. Adjustable-rate mortgages fell to 5.57 percent from 5.61 percent. ''We expect that rates will remain at or near this level well into 1999, fluctuating only slightly over time,'' said Robert Van Order, chief economist at Freddie Mac.

title: Stock Prices Fall As an Internet Selloff Continues
description: Internet and other technology stocks helped lead equity markets lower yesterday as investors grappled with several uncertainties.

title: Experiment on Mice Offers Hope for Tissue Repair in Humans
description: In a bizarre experiment that demonstrates the surprising plasticity of the body's cells, scientists have converted mice's brain cells into blood cells.

title: Sighing Yet Not Moping in Solitary Daydreams
description: Even with five people playing them, Sam Prekop's songs are the sound of one person's slightly fatigued brain; they sound composed in solitude, near daybreak, careful not to disturb someone nearby in a fragile sleep. With hints of bossa nova in their rhythm and mood and Mr. Prekop's voice leaking out as a quiet sigh, the songs are very nearly sullen, but it's not mannered moping. His lyrics are fragmented, nonlinear poems, and the emotions of the music aren't so easily understood.

title: CLINTON DESCRIBES TERRORISM THREAT FOR 21ST CENTURY
description: President Clinton said today that it is ''highly likely'' that a terrorist group will launch or threaten a germ or chemical attack on American soil within the next few years.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OGILVIE, JONATHAN KIRK
description: OGILVIE-Jonathan Kirk. The Officers and Board of Managers of the St. Andrew's Society of the State of New York wish to express their profound sorrow at the untimely death of Jonathan, youngest son of our esteemed member, Peter Preston Ogilvie, his wife Pam and their sons Timothy and Douglas. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to the family. Sean Stewart Macpherson, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINLAN, DORIS
description: QUINLAN-Doris. Died on January 9, 1999 in NYC while enroute from Switzerland to her home in Hollywood, CA. A memorial service will be announced later.

title: From a New Director, a Highlights Reel
description: In his debut film, ''Six-String Samurai,'' Lance Mungia doesn't have anything to say except that he has done his homework. And he says that stylishly in a shoestring movie that amounts to a kaleidoscopic calling card intended to show prospective employers that he can handle a variety of genres.

title: Excerpts: The Clinton Case Against Article II, Subpart by Subpart
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by David E. Kendall, a private lawyer for President Clinton, on accusations of obstruction of justice in Article II in the Senate impeachment trial of the President:

title: Residential Real Estate; Special Help for Elderly Extends to Less Affluent
description: The first rental building in Manhattan to be built mainly for low- and moderate-income elderly tenants that will provide professional assisted-living services is rising on the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 108th Street in East Harlem. It will contain 127 apartments in a 14-story structure overlooking Central Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMANN, KATHLEEN FENNELLY
description: KAUFMANN-Kathleen Fennelly died suddenly on January 19th in her home in Burlington, Mass. She had been a longtime resident of Manhasset and Tuckahoe, New York. She was preceded in death by her husband Richard Kaufmann as well as her sisters Sally Lorenz, Anne Burns, brothers Martin, William & James Fennelly. She is survived by her sister Margie Grace and many nieces and nephews. In repose at The Fairchild Sons Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset on Friday from 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Saturday at 9:45 AM, at St. Mary's R.C. Church. Interment Holy Mount Cemetery, Tuckahoe, New York.

title: Sports of The Times; Samaranch Must Take the Blame for the Mess
description: IF the International Olympic Committee were a major business corporation, the directors and the stockholders would not be amused right now. The I.O.C. is essentially in disgrace, visible to the world as lacking normal discipline or, one could even say, ethics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOYLE, MARGARET
description: DOYLE-Margaret (nee Flannery). On January 20, 1999. Native of Dunmore, Co. Galway, Ireland. Loving wife of the late Dennis. Beloved mother of Sr. Margaret Doyle, SHCJ, Noreen Morris, Michael Doyle, Claire Hayes, Dennis and Edward Doyle and loving grandmother and great grandmother. Beloved sister of Katherine Hoban. Reposing Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home 6110 Riverdale Ave (at 261st) Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 10am at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KODZA, HELEN
description: KODZA-Helen, M.D. Native of Kios, Asia Minor. Lifelong resident of New York, NY. Passed away on January 19, 1999. Pathologist and researcher for Columbia University. Survived by her nieces Sophia Scopetea and Ellie Scopetea and her brother-in-law Paraskevas Scopeteas of Athens, Greece. Reposing Basis Funeral Home, 27-12 23rd Ave., Astoria NY Friday 10 A.M. to 12 noon. Funeral Liturgy St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church, Flushing, NY, 1 P.M.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Webb's 63 Puts Her In the Lead
description: Using a new cross-handed putting grip for the second straight week, the Australian Karrie Webb shot a nine-under-par 63 yesterday to take the first-round lead in the $750,000 Naples L.P.G.A. Memorial in Naples, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, REV. EAMON GERARD
description: TAYLOR-Rev. Eamon Gerard, S.J. Beloved brother of Francis Taylor, Teresa Taylor and Sister Redempta Taylor, O.P. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Loyola Hall, Fordham University Campus. Visitation Friday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Fordham University Chapel, Saturday, 10:30AM. For information, contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors 718-654-0500

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Bankruptcy the Chinese Way; Foreign Bankers Are Shown to the End of the Line
description: People boarding the Sunday morning train from Hong Kong to this southern Chinese city on Jan. 10 were treated to a novel sight: Dozens of Western bankers in suits nestled among the Chinese travelers, their briefcases stashed between lumpy bags of food and clothing.

title: When Pain and Policy Collide
description: To the Editor:

title: Squeaky-Clean Triangle In a Musical Soap Opera
description: ''Little by Little'' is soap opera as lite opera. The sudsy boy-meets-girls revue, which opened last night at the Theater at St. Peter's Church, follows a trio of lifelong friends, a man and two women, through the ups and downs of a love triangle so banal the details would put gossip-starved patrons of a beauty parlor to sleep under their hair dryers.

title: A Snow White Picture of Nagano's Games
description: High, wide and handsome on a screen as big as all outdoors, the 1998 Winter Games in Nagano, Japan, are playing an encore in the documentary ''Olympic Glory'' at Sony Lincoln Square.

title: Defense Against a Missile Attack
description: During the cold war, when the only real missile threat to America came from the Soviet Union, building missile defenses was rightly seen as a bad idea. The other side would simply build more offensive missiles so that some got through any shield. Today's world is different, with reckless lesser powers like North Korea developing long-range missiles that could one day reach American soil.

title: A Hanks Figure, Before and After
description: It is one of the more unusual shooting schedules in film history.

title: The Shakers And Movers
description: A major show of Italian Renaissance art that is on its way to the Metropolitan Museum of Art began as an effort to raise public awareness of the damage earthquakes did to precious frescoes in the Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi two years ago in central Italy.

title: Waiting in the Wings for a Senatorial Run
description: OF all the people buzzing about whether Hillary Rodham Clinton will run for Senate from New York, there aren't many more interested than Representative Nita M. Lowey of Westchester -- the Democratic ''backup,'' as her friend Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan likes to call her. If Mrs. Clinton doesn't run, Mrs. Lowey said this week, she herself may. If Mrs. Clinton does, Mrs. Lowey won't. And as it happens, the backup got to assess the situation up close on Tuesday after the President's State of the Union address, when she and Mr. Rangel went together to a White House reception and talked to the First Lady, who is Mr. Rangel's -- and Democratic New York's -- Choice No. 1.

title: Trade Deficit Rises, Setting Record Early
description: In a sign of how fast the American economy was growing at the end of the year and how quickly many other economies were slowing, the United States trade deficit widened sharply in November, setting a record for a year in just 11 months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STELMAN, MARVIN
description: STELMAN-Marvin. The Board of Directors of Circle Lodge/Camp Kinder Ring mourns the passing of its former general manager and extends condolences to his family. Eric Lange, Chairman Board of Directors Bernard Tabachnik, General Mgr.

title: Armed With His New Initiatives, President Campaigns Yet Again
description: Bill Clinton has now answered the question chewed over by his aides and friends after his last election: What would this born campaigner do without another campaign?

title: Conductor Establishes Connections With Composers and the Orchestra
description: Riccardo Muti has conducted so often in New York that it was simply a matter of time before he got around to doing it with the New York Philharmonic. Wednesday night's subscription program at Avery Fisher Hall, to be repeated tonight and tomorrow, reaffirms qualities already apparent from Mr. Muti's recent visits with the Vienna Philharmonic and his long years as head of the Philadelphia Orchestra.

title: WNYC Gets New Chairman And a Displaced Deejay
description: An investment banker with expertise in the telecommunications industry was elected chairman yesterday of WNYC, which operates the public radio stations on 820 AM and 93.9 FM that were owned by the city until two years ago.

title: Lucent Earnings Rose 26% in First Quarter
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said today that earnings before charges and gains rose 26 percent in the fiscal first quarter, more than analysts expected, but that sales growth lagged behind forecasts because the company could not complete the paperwork on some orders in time.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN TOWER CORP., Boston, an operator of wireless communications and broadcast towers, and three shareholders filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 19.3 million class A common shares.

title: Now Is the Time For a Tax Cut; Masterly Showman?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, JUDGE EUGENE
description: SULLIVAN-Judge Eugene J. On January 21, 1999. Beloved brother of Sheila Warren. Devoted companion to Frank Santiago. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Saturday & Sunday 2-5 & 7-9PM. Funeral Mass at St. Joseph's Church, 404 East 87 Street, on Monday, 11AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: New Video Releases
description: Love and Death on Long Island

title: Foreign Affairs; The Grand Bargain
description: Listening to President Clinton's perfectly focus-grouped State of the Union speech the other night, I really felt sort of cheated. I mean, he left almost no constituency untickled by his 77-minute goody-bag of proposals. There was something for older women, younger women, black women, tall women, short women, soccer moms, soccer coaches, native Americans, Hispanics, non-smokers, free-traders, short bald men and protectionists. Even the First Lady got ''I love you.'' There was something for everyone except me -- except for foreign affairs columnists who still care about things like Russian nuclear weapons aimed at us.

title: I.N.S. Moving to Cut Citizenship Backlog
description: One year after the Immigration and Naturalization Service pledged to reduce the backlog of almost two million people waiting to become Americans, the agency has announced that it will hire 300 more employees and create a national hot line to help prospective citizens.

title: 2 Tied to Mob Admit Roles in Stock Scheme
description: Two reputed mob figures pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that they had participated in a conspiracy to manipulate the price of a stock in a scheme the authorities have called the most ambitious yet by organized crime to infiltrate Wall Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWNSEND, MARY ELIZABETH
description: TOWNSEND-Mary Elizabeth, 61. Of Hopewell Township, died Friday, January 15 at the Medical Center of Princeton. Born in Kingston, NY, she was a resident of Hopewell Township, NJ. A graduate of Manhattanville College, she entered the Society of the Sacred Heart of Jesus in 1960. During her career, she was Head of the Middle School at Stuart Country Day School, Princeton, and at Greenwich, CT School of the Sacred Heart. In 1989 she retired from the Society of the Sacred Heart and in 1990, married Charles C. Townsend Jr. She was a former trustee of the Stony Brook Millstone Watershed Association and a member of the Garden Club of Princeton. She was a member of Trinity Church of Princeton. Daughter of the late Reynolds B. & Margaret M. Carr, she is survived by her husband, Charles C. Townsend, Jr., two step-children, brother Dr. Arthur G. Carr II of Hurley, NY and five nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, her family requests contributions to the Society of the Sacred Heart, NY Province for the benefit of Sprout Creek Farm, 4 Lauer, Poughkeepsie, NY 12603. Interment is private. A Memorial service will be held Saturday, January 30 at 2:30 pm at the Stuart Country Day School of the Sacred Heart, 1200 Stuart Road, Princeton, NJ 08540. For information, Cromwell Memorial Home, 71 East Prospect St., Hopewell, NJ

title: Tickets on Sale Starting Tomorrow

title: Russia Is Silent, but Unhappy, About U.S. Proposal on Missiles
description: Russian leaders responded with silence today to a White House proposal to overhaul the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty to permit the construction of defenses against missile attacks.

title: Doctoring Scores To Help the Losers
description: This was taking the ''it's not who wins or loses'' thing a little too far.

title: For a Pair of Sneakers, Longing, Lies and a Plan
description: The young hero of Majid Majidi's ''Children of Heaven'' is played by Mir Farrokh Hashemian, a desolate-looking boy with huge brown eyes and a way of sending tears suddenly rolling down his cheeks. Those tears well up with some regularity during this film about 9-year-old Ali, his younger sister Zahra (Bahareh Seddiqui) and their scheme for sharing a pair of his tattered sneakers. The children want to hide the fact that Zahra's shoes have been lost because this will be a hardship for their parents. The family's carefully detailed poverty, which reflects the filmmaker's own childhood experience, colors everything that happens in this story.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: 12% Gain in I.B.M. Profit Beats Wall Street Forecast

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DROPS ON CHINA RUMORS. Japan's currency fell on talk that China would devalue its currency, the yuan, which traders fear could lead to a new round of Asian financial turmoil. The dollar rose to 113.68 yen, from 112.85.

title: Delta and United Announce Holiday Ticket Restrictions
description: Many passengers planning to fly first class or full-fare coach over the Christmas holidays in December or to and from events welcoming in the year 2000, will find their tickets are nonrefundable on United and Delta airlines. American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation, said it was studying whether to impose similar limits, and other carriers were likely to follow.

title: The Criminal Code on Pie
description: Probably no one who has ever gotten a pie in the face thinks the event was remotely funny. But those who find themselves taking creamy globs out of their eyes rarely, if ever, seek to bring the perpetrators to justice. Some no doubt fear that would only subject them to further ridicule for being humorless. But San Francisco's Mayor, Willie Brown, had no such qualms when he pressed charges against the Biotic Baking Brigade, a protest group that pied him last November.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TISHMAN, RITA V.
description: TISHMAN-Rita V., an active leader in Jewish and civic philanthrophies, died of natural causes at her home in Manhattan on Thursday, January 21. She was 91 years old. Her involvement in civic affairs began at an early age. In 1946 she was awarded the Civilian Medal of Merit by President Roosevelt for her distinguished service to the War Bond effort. She was also cited for her exemplary services by Presidents Truman, Kennedy, and Johnson. Always interested in Jewish causes, she served on the boards of the United Jewish Appeal, the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, the American Jewish Committee, the Anti-Defamation League, and was President of the New York Section, National Council of Jewish Women. She received numerous rewards from these organizations for her efforts, including the Hannah G. Solomon Award from the National Council of Jewish Women in 1965. In 1969 the annual Rita V. Tishman Award for Civil Rights was established by the Anti-Defamation League. In 1975 Mrs. Tishman was the recipient of the Appeal for Human Relations Award from the American Jewish Committee. In her later years she was also a Board member of the National Association for the Visually Handicapped. Born in New York City in 1907, she graduated from Smith College in 1928. The widow of Norman Tishman, former Chairman of Tishman Realty and Construction Co., Inc., she is survived by three children, Margot T. Linton, Peter V. Tishman and Valerie T. Diker of New York City, ten grandchildren and eleven great - grandchildren. Funeral service will be held on Sunday, January 24, at 10 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, a memorial contribution may be sent to the New York Section, National Council of Jewish Women, 9 East 69 Street, New York City 10021. The family will receive at the home of Mr. & Mrs. Robert Linton at 141 East 72nd Street on Sunday from 4-7 PM.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Merriam-Webster's decision to remove references to homosexuals in its collegiate thesaurus misspelled the surname of an Internet consultant who raised alarms that slurs were being used as alternatives to the word ''homosexual'' in the thesaurus's on-line version. He is John Aravosis, not Aravois.

title: Ford Reports Stronger-Than-Expected Earnings
description: The Ford Motor Company reported fourth-quarter earnings today that were stronger than expected, as the giant auto maker also pressed ahead in its efforts to buy the car business of Sweden's Volvo.

description: Star prosecution witnesses in murder trials often have a skeleton or two in their closets -- skeletons that are dragged out by defense lawyers trying to undermine their credibility.

title: Boeing Reported Set to Settle Bias Lawsuit for $15 Million
description: The Boeing Company is close to settling a racial discrimination suit brought by hundreds of its workers, most of them African-American, two people close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Giuliani Names Panel for Governors Island
description: Acknowledging that his idea for a casino resort on Governors Island was unrealistic, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has appointed a task force that includes several of his critics to help plan the redevelopment of the former Coast Guard base off Manhattan's southern tip.

title: Train to Plane Is Seen Mainly As a Pain
description: IF for some reason you were hungry for outrage and skepticism, you could have done no better than to show up on Wednesday night at the Robert Ross Johnson Family Life Center, in St. Albans. The map said this was Queens. But those were unmistakably Bronx cheers coming from 400 people who packed a community board meeting to vent their anger at a planned rail link to Kennedy International Airport.

title: A Ruling Favors Bottler of Coke
description: A Federal judge yesterday denied a Maryland soft-drink distributor's request for sanctions against Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., the Coca-Cola Company's largest bottler, in connection with documents the bottler filed in a lawsuit.

description: Taunts directed at a dyslexic man by co-workers in the State Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife will cost taxpayers more than $700,000 following a decision in the man's Federal discrimination lawsuit, officials said yesterday.

description: For all his country lawyer's eloquence, the triumph in Dale Bumpers's extraordinary return to the Senate today was most evident after he finished addressing the chamber he loves so well.

description: The State Department told Congress today that the Commerce Department would have a voice but not a vote in approving the export of American-made satellites.

title: Uncorking Elgar's Essence
description: Americans march to Elgar at commencements as they march to Mendelssohn at weddings, but they probably don't think about him most of the rest of the year. To a nation with little patience for quaint remnants, he can seem an anomalous holdover of the British Empire, which much of his music appeared to embody in its doughty staunchness and solemnity.

description: NEARY-John F., Jr. Died January 8th, 1999 in Rolla, MO, at age 91. He was a graduate of Princeton University and Yale Law School. A long time resident of Englewood, N.J., he was preceded in death by his wife, Rosalia Ingham Neary. He served in the army during World War II and the Korean War and was a partner in the Patent law firm, Brumbaugh, Free, Graves and Donohue, in New York City. His survivors include daughters and sons-in-law; Patricia & Hugh Stewart of Rolla, MO; and Sheila and Wilbur Prezzano of Charleston, SC; and sons and daughters-in-law; J. Michael and Sandra Neary of Federal Way, Washington and Robert and Lettie Neary of Smithville, UT as well as seventeen grandchildren and four great grandchildren. A memorial service was held in the chapel of The Rolla First Presbyterian Church on January 10. Burial will be at Arlington, Cemetery.

title: A voice long familiar to football fans has made itself heard promoting a range of products lately.
description: TO those who have been watching football on television in recent weeks, the hottest voice-over talent in corporate America seems to be John Facenda. He narrates some of the National Football League's ''Feel the Power'' spots, which ran during the playoffs. And voices that sound like his have been popping up on commercials for Tostitos tortilla chips, AT&T and the Sunny Delight juice drink, as well as on promotions for ''The Late Show With David Letterman'' on CBS.

title: John Frederick Nims, 85, Poet, Translator, Professor and Author
description: John Frederick Nims, a poet, translator and author, died on Tuesday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 85 and lived in Chicago.

title: G.O.P. Has Few Options on Social Security
description: Republicans were quick to criticize President Clinton's proposal to invest a portion of Social Security's reserves in the stock market, but they have been slow to lay out any specific alternative for dealing with the retirement system's problems because other options have their own economic and political drawbacks.

title: Eugene Pulliam Is Dead at 84; Publisher Opposed McCarthy
description: Eugene S. Pulliam, publisher of The Indianapolis Star and The Indianapolis News, a champion of the First Amendment who signed a declaration that said Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's methods threatened press freedom and American freedom, died on Wednesday in Indianapolis.

title: Plagued By Bure, Rangers Lose Again
description: The Rangers begin the All-Star break the way they began the season: with a four-game losing streak. Last night's defeat was particularly aggravating, a 2-1 loss to the Florida Panthers at Madison Square Garden.

description: EMMA-Blanche. We mourn the loss of our member and extend heartfelt sympathy to her family. Temple Sinai of Long Island Paula Winnig, Rabbi Evelyn Maltman, President

title: Celebrated Georgia Police Officer Is Killed
description: Robbie Bishop, a 35-year-old police captain with a small-town force in Villa Rica, Ga., had developed a reputation around the South as a cop with a sixth sense for sniffing out drugs during routine traffic stops. In some innate, almost inexplicable way, associates said, he could detect secret compartments in cars and could tell when a truck was riding just a little too low.

title: Corruption Is Extensive, I.O.C. Official Finds
description: A senior official of the International Olympic Committee acknowledged yesterday that corruption in the Salt Lake City bribery scandal was extensive and involved total cash payments and benefits perhaps exceeding three-quarters of a million dollars.

title: 2 Top Ex-Officials Back Holbrooke's Nomination
description: Two former senior diplomats rallied today to the defense of Richard C. Holbrooke, whose nomination as the chief American diplomat at the United Nations has been sidetracked by a Justice Department ethics investigation, and they insisted he had done nothing wrong in the matters under scrutiny.
