description: To the Editor:

title: Bus Driver in Fatal Crash Is Cited for Recklessness
description: The driver of the charter bus that crashed on the Garden State Parkway on Dec. 24, killing eight people on their way to casinos in Atlantic City, has been given a summons for reckless driving, the State Police said yesterday.

title: KOSOVO MASSACRE IS CALLED REVENGE
description: International monitors who discovered the bodies of 45 ethnic Albanians shot execution-style concluded in their official report that the attack in a Kosovo village was an act of revenge by Serbian forces for the killing of four of their men.

title: A Caring Actress With an Affinity for Underdogs
description: In her six decades as an actress, Uta Hagen has played some unsavory characters: a former prostitute who becomes a madam; a hard-drinking, caustic wife; an insensitive therapist. Yet Ms. Hagen has made these characters likable through her ability to empathize with them in their times of need.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELIN, DAVID
description: BELIN-David. Central Synagogue mourns the passing of a wonderful friend. As a supporter of significant causes, David brought integrity, passion and strength to all his friends, and to the Jewish community. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi

title: A Secret Meeting Swayed the Knicks on Sprewell
description: Four men from the Knicks' organization boarded a flight last Sunday for a meeting in Milwaukee. They drove to an undisclosed location, sat down with Latrell Sprewell and grilled him.

description: Following is the expected schedule for the impeachment trial of President Clinton:

title: Behind Offer for Mirror Are Some Deep Pockets
description: The Regional Independent Media P.L.C.'s $:913 million ($1.5 billion) cash offer for the Mirror Group P.L.C., Britain's No. 3 newspaper publisher, is backed by the billionaire investor George Soros and the investment bank Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, people close to the deal said.

title: MERCANTILE BANCORPORATION TO CUT 7% OF WORK FORCE
description: Mercantile Bancorporation, the largest bank based in Missouri, plans to cut 7 percent of its work force, or 770 jobs, in 1999 as part of a revamping to improve profits.The bank, which has $35.8 billion in assets, said it cut 550 jobs in the fourth quarter of 1998. Mercantile, based in St. Louis, said fourth-quarter profit from operations rose 13 percent, to $119.5 million, or 75 cents a diluted share, from $105.4 million, or 70 cents, in the fourth quarter of 1997. The earnings beat the consensus estimate by analysts of 72 cents.

title: On My Mind; The Last Days
description: Then, when the screening was over and everybody in the theater sat in sick and total silence, nobody moving, I knew I could not write another column, nor want to, not about the President, or the trial, not about terrorism or Iraq, or about poor people or rich people, or anything else, until I wrote about what we had just seen and had asked myself again whether it proved that there was no God or proved that there was, or proved nothing, the most terrifying thought of all.

title: Whitman Will Not Act On Concert for a Killer
description: Despite the angry protests of the Superintendent of the New Jersey State Police, the Whitman administration will not take any legal action to try to prevent an upcoming benefit concert at the Meadowlands for a man convicted of killing a police officer, state officials said yesterday.

title: Plan to Ask Schools To Deny Promotion Rekindles a Debate
description: When President Clinton announced in his State of the Union address this week that he wanted the Federal Government to press schools to end so-called social promotion, he was stepping into a long-standing and anxious educational debate: When students fail, is it better to have them repeat the school year or promote them to the next grade to keep them with their age group?

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL RISES 5 PERCENT. Prices increased for the first time in more than a week after an industry report showed that domestic crude oil supplies were not as high as estimated. The March contract rose 59 cents a barrel, to $12.46.

title: Monsanto Profit Fell 51% in 4th Quarter
description: The Monsanto Company, the agricultural biotechnology and drug company, said today that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 51 percent, in line with expectations, as increased spending on acquisitions and research cut into revenue from its herbicide and drug units.

title: Rulings on Medicare Rights Split White House
description: A bitter dispute has broken out within the Clinton Administration over the legal rights of Medicare beneficiaries, with some officials trying to limit those rights even as President Clinton urges Congress to establish new protections for millions of other patients with private health insurance.

title: I.B.M. Earnings Beat Analysts' Estimates
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday reported a 12 percent gain in earnings, exceeding Wall Street analysts' estimates by 2 cents a share. I.B.M. said strong gains in software and services were offset by the economic turmoil in Asia and Latin America, as well as pricing pressure on key products.

title: Uncorking Elgar's Essence: Five Critics Savor the Bouquet

title: RENTAL SERVICE IN $366 MILLION DEAL FOR RIVAL
description: The Rental Service Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a rival, Nationsrent Inc., for about $366 million in stock. The deal would make Rental Service the No. 2 equipment rental company in the United States after United Rentals Inc. Rental Service is to exchange 0.355 share for every Nationsrent share, valuing Nationsrent stock at $8.25. Rental Service shares fell 62.5 cents, to $22.625, while Nationsrent rose $1.375, to to $7.9375. The combined company, to be called RSC Nationsrent, would have more than 375 branches in 38 states and Canada, employing more than 6,000 workers.

title: Ernest Schier, 80, National Critics Institute Head
description: Ernest Schier, director of the National Critics Institute at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., died on Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Corrections

Ernesto Cardenal, a former Sandinista Culture Minister whose public scolding by Pope John Paul II during a 1983 visit to Nicaragua dramatized the Pope's opposition to liberation theology. Father Cardenal is not a member of the Jesuit order.

title: Earnings for Donaldson, Lufkin Slid 32% in the Fourth Quarter
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., the eighth-biggest United States securities firm by capital, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings declined 32 percent as revenue from trading tumbled.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: WOMEN'S ROUNDUP -- CONNECTICUT
description: Connecticut, bedeviled by injuries the last two seasons, has lost two key players -- the team captain, Amy Duran, a senior, and Shea Ralph, a sophomore -- for up to a month.

title: Iomega Says Profits Fell 47% in 4th Quarter
description: The Iomega Corporation, the leading maker of removable data-storage disks for personal computers, reported today that its fourth-quarter profit fell 47 percent, and said two senior executives were resigning.

title: N.B.A. TRANSACTIONS
description: TRADES

title: Crew Plans to Tighten Screening In Hiring of Substitute Teachers
description: Responding to reports that substitute teachers who repeatedly mistreat children are regularly rehired, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that he would form a central office to conduct thorough screenings of candidates for the jobs.

title: Forest Workers Protest Logging
description: Hundreds of United States Forest Service employees have signed an E-mail petition calling for strict limits on logging in the pristine back country of the national forests.

title: Pope Is Returning to Mexico With New Target: Capitalism
description: When Pope John Paul II held a working lunch recently to prepare for his visit to Mexico that begins on Friday, one Vatican official present said that the 78-year-old Pope spoke with deep nostalgia about his first papal trip there 20 years ago.

title: New York City Admits Turning Away Poor
description: Conceding that city workers have improperly denied poor people access to food stamps and medical assistance, the Giuliani administration has agreed to retrain hundreds of employees, monitor welfare centers, revise application forms and post signs clearly outlining the public's rights to Government benefits, city officials said yesterday.

title: Theodore Tannenwald Jr., 82, Judge and Presidential Adviser
description: Theodore Tannenwald Jr., a senior judge on the United States Tax Court in Washington, a foreign-aid adviser to three Democratic Presidents and a governor of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion in Manhattan for the last 40 years, died on Sunday at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 82 and lived in Washington.

description: GARITY-Edward J. 1/22/96 Father and Pop-Pop, Lovingly remembered every day. Susie

title: Miriam Freund-Rosenthal, 92, Zionist Leader
description: Dr. Miriam Freund-Rosenthal, a former national president of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, died on Saturday at her home in Miami Beach. She was 92 and also had a home in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRING, THE REV. WALTER D.
description: KRING-The Rev. Walter D., Minister Emeritus. The Unitarian Church of all Souls, New York City. Dr. Kring served our congregation from 1955 to 1978. Educated at Occidental College and the Harvard Divinity School, the recipient of several honorary doctoral degrees, he was a U.S. Navy Chaplain in WWII in the South Pacific. Denominational leader, as Secretary, the Unitarian Universalist Association; President, Beacon Press; Director, Unitarian Universalist Service Committee. Historian, wrote ''Liberals Among the Orthodox'', ''Henry Whitney Bellows'', a biography, as well as other works. His discovery of letters written in regard to the family life of Herman Melville contributed to the field of Melville Scholarship. Skilled ceramic artist, noted especially for his glazes, his work was displayed in various museums and won many awards including a silver medal at the 1968 Brussels World's Fair. Masterful preacher, he incorporated into his sermons his wide scholarship and respect for the world's religions. On behalf of the entire congregation, we express our condolences to his wife, Sage (Mackay), and to his daughters, Beverly C. Dobbin, Suzanne E. Shapiro and Kathryn Topole and to their families. The Board of Trustees The Unitarian Church of All Souls Kami O'Keeffe, President

title: INTEL SAYS IT WILL BUY $100 MILLION IN SAMSUNG BONDS
description: The Intel Corporation, the largest computer-chip maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to invest $100 million in the Samsung Electronics Company to insure the development of technologies to speed personal computer performance. Intel will buy bonds convertible into about 1 percent of Samsung's shares. Samsung, the world's largest maker of memory chips, will use proceeds to build an assembly and test line for a new type of computer memory technology, known as Rdram. Samsung plans to produce 500,000 Rdram chips a month in the first half of this year and 5 million Rdram chips a month in the second half. Intel made a similar investment of $500 million last year in Micron Technology Inc., the No. 2 maker of memory chips.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, BESS ASHLEY HOUSE
description: HOPKINS-Bess Ashley House. Died January 16 in Cambridge, MA. Devoted mother and motherin-law of Terry, Mandy, Tom, Jay, Sarah and Matthew. Delighted grandmother of six and dear sister of Bina Beghe-and so loved by all who knew her. Funeral services on Friday, January 22, 1PM at Christ Episcopal Church, Garden St, Cambridge MA, 617-876-0200.

title: Despite Vote on Austerity Measure, Brazil's Markets Take Dip
description: A day after Congress approved austerity measures perceived by investors as a crucial test of the country's commitment to reduce systematic overspending, its currency and stock market fell, and fears mounted that Brazil is running low on dollars to pay for debts, imports and other expenses.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Neil Folberg

title: The Queen Might Still Be Amused
description: The history of the New York City Ballet is flecked with the odd enthusiasms of its founders, George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein. It was Kirstein's passionate Anglophilia that fueled Jerome Robbins's ''Fanfare,'' a celebration of the coronation of Elizabeth II in 1953.

title: 2 Companies Announce Purchases
description: Two large media and agency companies are making acquisitions.

title: Some French, Some Italian, All Baroque
description: For some time, fanciers of Renaissance and Baroque music have been suggesting that New York City could support more performances of early music and resident ensembles. The audience and the interest exist, it is said.

title: New Drug Can Induce Coma or Death, F.D.A. Warns
description: A product that is supposed to build muscles, enhance love-making abilities and help one get a good night's sleep can induce comas or even death, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'North and South Connected'

title: Ending the Arguments
description: The senators have now heard the House prosecutors and President Clinton's lawyers debate both the evidence and the Constitution. They have heard hours of argument as to whether they should be punitive or forgiving about the fact that Mr. Clinton lied under oath. But what they have not heard is a convincing argument that his misconduct, whether viewed darkly or with compassion, meets the standard for removal spelled out in the Constitution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREY, CHARLES
description: TREY-Charles, M.D. The Board of Directors of the American Liver Foundation mourn the loss of one of our founders. Charles Trey was a rare individual, a leader in the science of liver disease and the treatment of tens of thousands of patients. He was instrumental in building the American Liver Foundation and the New England Chapter. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. John M. Vierling, M.D., Chair Alan P. Brownstein, Pres/CEO

title: Software Flaw Delays F.A.A. In Replacing Radar Screen
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has all but given up its goal of replacing the radar screens in the first of hundreds of low-altitude air traffic control offices by March, because recent tests showed that the system bogs down during basic operations.

title: Death Penalty Patterns
description: To the Editor:

title: Jerusalem Journal; Labor, Likud, Move Over: Here's Pnina Rosenblum
description: A former model and successful cosmetics company owner, Pnina Rosenblum is an Israeli sex symbol, tall, leggy, blond, glamorous and independent. She is also a new political party.

title: Sanchez Vicario Upset; Novotna Is Also Ousted
description: What started on Thursday with the Stanford man Paul Goldstein and the Austrian baseliner Barbara Schett continued today with the mountain man Marc Rosset and the Spanish baseliner Maria Antonio Sanchez Lorenzo.

title: Judge to Decide on an Affidavit in Gun Lawsuit
description: A Federal judge is expected to decide today whether criticism of the gun industry by a former gun company executive will be presented to a jury in a case that seeks to hold the industry liable for shootings with illegally obtained handguns.

title: Weight of Isles' Slump Leads Milbury to Step Aside as Coach
description: Less than 24 hours after hearing chants of ''Mike must go! Mike must go!'' during a listless loss at Nassau Coliseum, Mike Milbury resigned today as the Islanders' coach for the second time in two years.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Weighing Anchor

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLNER, SYDNEY W.
description: POLLNER-Sydney W. Beloved husband of Faygie; loving father of Jessica, Priscilla and Michelle. Cherished grandfather of Michael and Amy; dear father-in-law of Mark and Dave. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, 11:30AM Friday.

title: GATEWAY BEATS ESTIMATES AS EARNINGS INCREASE 39%
description: Gateway Inc., the second-largest direct seller of personal computers, said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings rose 39 percent, beating analysts' expectations. Net income rose to $129.1 million, or 81 cents a diluted share, from $92.9 million, or 59 cents, in the corresponding period a year earlier. Sales rose 17 percent, to $2.31 billion from $1.98 billion. Gateway was expected to earn 78 cents, the average estimate of analysts polled by the First Call Corporation, a financial research firm. The company said it shipped 1.15 million PC's in the quarter, 35 percent more than in the 1997 quarter, as declines in prices abated. Gateway shares fell 50 cents, to $58. The company reported earnings after the close of regular trading.

title: 2 Who Wrote Of a Coup Plot Freed On Bail In Zimbabwe
description: Two Zimbabwean journalists, arrested for a report last week about an alleged coup plot by the army against President Robert Mugabe, were released on bail today after they had told a judge that they had been tortured while detained.

title: Metro Business; Unemployment Picture
description: New York State's unemployment rate declined six-tenths of a percentage point over the last year, the state announced yesterday, on the strength of 142,900 new private sector jobs, a 2.1 percent increase.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, DR. JOSEPH J.
description: FRIEDMAN-Dr. Joseph J. Age 93, beloved husband of the late Frances, devoted father of Alan J., dear father-in-law of Diane, loving grandfather of Neil and Lisa. Shining role model as an exemplary physician in a four generation medical family, he was an inspiration of youth in retirement to all who knew him. Service 12 noon Friday ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: A Spiritual Energy in Fanciful Realms
description: The outsider art phenomenon is like a gold rush. Driven by an irrationally enthusiastic market, speculators have been feverishly scouring the world for self-taught geniuses, looking in mental hospitals, prisons, the backwoods and flea markets for anything marked by folksy vigor if not visionary originality. Accordingly, the Seventh Annual Outsider Art Fair has the feel of a frontier boomtown. A gathering of 35 dealers from the United States and Europe, it's crowded and chaotic but lively and, at certain moments, inspirational. Plenty of fool's gold is on display, but you'll find the real thing, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, MATTHEW
description: ROSEN-Matthew. Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle records with sorrow the passing of the beloved son of our Honorary Trustee Jack Rosen. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi Dorothy Fox, President

title: Hyde Cites His War Past, Too
description: A week after he appealed for President Clinton to be removed from office on behalf of the nation's fallen veterans, Representative Henry J. Hyde told his own war story today.

title: Uncorking Elgar's Essence: Five Critics Savor the Bouquet
description: Here are some favorite Elgar recordings of the classical music critics of The New York Times. CD's range in price from $16.99 for a single CD to $32 for a specially priced four-CD set. (An introduction appears on page 1.)

title: Cutting Out, Cutting Up
description: ''Hot Feet'' is a particularly appropriate title for a revue by the Paper Bag Players. Not only do these singing and dancing actors never have cold feet (they get down to the emotional and physical level of a 4-year-old without a moment's hesitation), they also frequently cavort onstage as if the floor were strewn with hot coals. And since heat has a way of spreading, the members of the audience soon find that their toes are tapping, too.

title: CLINTON DEFENSE CONCLUDES BY WEIGHING ADMITTED SINS AGAINST GOOD OF THE NATION
description: In a speech of rare eloquence, former Senator Dale Bumpers of Arkansas concluded the defense of President Clinton on impeachment charges tonight, coupling an admission of Mr. Clinton's sins and weaknesses with a plea for his acquittal for the good of the nation.

title: Ritz-Carlton Luxury Hotel Planned at Manhattan's Tip
description: The tip of Manhattan would get a bit of gilding -- a new Ritz-Carlton Hotel -- under a development plan that the Battery Park City Authority is expected to approve today.

title: British Sears Accepts $:548 Million Cash Offer
description: Sears P.L.C., Britain's fifth-largest clothing retailer, said yesterday that it had agreed to a $:548 million ($904 million) cash offer from a group led by the Barclay family and the entrepreneur Philip Green and his firm, January Investments Ltd.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Susanna Coffey

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LASKY, ESTELLE
description: LASKY-Estelle. In memory of our mother. Always loved...Always remembered. George and Joyce

title: Italian Fare
description: Of the many hundreds of Italian restaurants in New York City, here are a dozen that rise above the everyday variety. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, and columns and articles in The Times.)

title: A Diet of Support Helps Nourish a Man With H.I.V.
description: When asked about food, Mark Stafford is likely to carry on at length: how to make soup or oatmeal cookies; the nutrient value of fresh juices and broccoli, even food safety.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, BESS ASHLEY
description: HOPKINS-Bess Ashley House. Died January 16 in Cambridge, MA. Devoted mother and motherin-law of Terry, Mandy, Tom, Jay, Sarah and Matthew. Delighted grandmother of six and dear sister of Bina Beghe-and so loved by all who knew her. Funeral services on Friday, January 22, 1PM at Christ Episcopal Church, Garden St, Cambridge MA, 617-876-0200.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EXEL LTD., Hamilton, Bermuda, a liability insurer, said its board had authorized the repurchase of as much as $500 million of its own stock.

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile yesterday about Representative Nita M. Lowey of Westchester and the possibility that she will run for the Senate misstated the year she was first elected to the House. It was 1988, not 1998.

title: Excerpts: Senators' Questions and Responses From the Adversaries
description: Following are some questions from senators and excerpts from the answers today by the House impeachment case managers and lawyers for President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service. The questions were read by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist.

title: Killings of 2 Elderly People Have Police Seeking Pattern
description: A 77-year-old man in a wheelchair was killed Thursday in his home in Orange, N.J., and investigators were trying to determine whether the slaying was related to a nearly identical killing of an elderly woman three months ago in the same neighborhood.

title: Correction
description: A chart with the Market Place column on Wednesday about Chase Manhattan's financial performance mislabeled the section on fourth-quarter trading results. It showed trading revenue and losses not trading profit and losses. The chart also misstated trading results for J.P.Morgan. Graphic shows the corrected chart.

title: 45 Die and 100 Are Hurt as Indonesian Muslims and Christians Riot
description: In the worst violence in Indonesia since May, 45 people have died in four days of rioting between Muslims and Christians on Ambon island, local officials said today.

title: With a Sudden Drop in Donors, Organ Shortage Worsens
description: The number of vital organs being donated in the New York area has fallen so precipitously in recent weeks that transplant programs across the region have virtually ground to a halt, hospital officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYENDORFF, HELENE (NEE WRANGEL)
description: MEYENDORFF - Helene (nee Wrangel), 89. Of Spring Valley, NY. Beloved mother of the late Philip K. Hills, Jr. and Daria Kerdel-Vegas, and grandmother of Marielena Jutrowski, Alexander Kerdel-Vegas, Peter Hills and Philip K. Hills, III. Died January 22, 1999 after a long illness. Funeral Services will be held Saturday at 5:30 PM and a Mass and Burial Service on Sunday at 10:30 AM at the Russian Orthodox Convent of ''Novo Diveevo'', 100 Smith Road, Nanuet, New York. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be sent to the Convent.

title: THINK TANK; The Song of the Road Leads Over the Hill
description: Consider them latter-day nomads. Or maybe, come to think of it, more like venerable turtles, who carry their homes on their backs.

title: Nassau County Called at Fault For Overruns In Health Plan
description: Administrators of Nassau County's health care plan said today that its severe cost overruns were caused by poor financial decisions by county officials, dismissing the officials' assertions that company mismanagement and kickbacks were to blame.

title: Moet Hennessy Buys Krug Champagne
description: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A., the world's No. 1 luxury-goods company, said its Moet Hennessy subsidiary had acquired Krug Champagne from Remy-Cointreau for one billion francs, or $177 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, MURIEL
description: BRENNER-Muriel. We mourn the loss of our dearest friend, although gone, but never forgotten. Heartfelt sympathy to William and the family. Martha and Effrem Arenstein

title: DaimlerChrysler Sheds Little Light on Nissan
description: A much-anticipated news conference here today by DaimlerChrysler A.G. failed to clarify the future of the debt-laden Nissan Motor Company or its more-troubled truck-making affiliate.

title: Canada, at U.N., Proposes a 'Third Way' to Deal With the Iraqis
description: The Security Council, divided by radically differing Russian and American proposals for dealing with Iraq, began discussion today of a ''third way'' proposed by Canada.

title: Fair Play for Ostersund
description: The early round of housecleaning the International Olympic Committee will undertake this weekend should sweep the shakedown artists from the governing body of the Olympic movement. But far more needs to be done to clean up after the bribery scandal engulfing the organization's choice of Salt Lake City for the next Winter Olympics. The committee will need to devise an ethically tight process for choosing future sites, and should reconsider its award of the Winter Games to Salt Lake City.

title: G.O.P. Chairman Overcomes Challenge to His Re-election
description: Jim Nicholson overcame an energetic challenge today and was overwhelming re-elected as chairman of the Republican National Committee after pleas from his supporters that he should not be blamed for the party's discouraging performance in last November's election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMITTLINGER, LOIS
description: SCHMITTLINGER-Lois, on January 22, 1999. Devoted daughter, sister and loving aunt. She will be deeply missed by Seymour, Ralph, Nomi, Kate, Victor, Robin, Michael and Eric Smallberg and Maurice Basem. Graveside service Sunday 11AM at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Internet Stocks Falter, Causing Wider Worries
description: George E. Nichols, a 22-year-old management major at the Georgia Institute of Technology, put more than $1,500 of his student loan money in a mutual fund investing exclusively in high-flying Internet stocks.

title: A Message To a Singer: More Heart
description: A perennial enigma in musical performance: How can you do so many things right, as Christian Gerhaher, a young German baritone, did on Wednesday evening at Weill Recital Hall, yet communicate so little? In this case the issue was even more puzzling, because the pianist, Gerold Huber, a young German composer, touched the heart at every moment.

title: Court Calendar
description: Following is the expected schedule for the impeachment trial of President Clinton:

title: BANK ONE EXPANDING ITS PRESENCE IN WISCONSIN
description: The Bank One Corporation, the fifth-largest American bank, said yesterday that it would hire 400 people and open a new office in Menomonee Falls, Wis., as it doubles its consumer-lending work force in that state. The Chicago-based Bank One said it planned to fill entry-level, supervisor and managerial positions to meet the increase in applications for home equity loans. The bank currently provides loan services through two offices and a staff of 340 in downtown Milwaukee and Waukesha, Wis. The new unit will include the bank's Loan-by-Phone service, which accounts for 65 percent of its loan applications. Bank One shares fell $1.625, to $50.125.

title: Royal and Sun Bids For Guardian Royal
description: Royal and Sun Alliance Insurance Group P.L.C., Britain's third-largest insurer, said yesterday that it was in talks to buy its rival, Guardian Royal Exchange P.L.C., for cash and stock.

title: Is Good Education a Civil Right?; School Is No Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZARE, PAUL
description: LAZARE-Paul. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and extend heartfelt sympathy to his family. Bandi and Susanne Gal Julie Gal

title: The Pope and the Poor
description: In a country where, according to some estimates, up to 60 percent of the people are poor, and in a region with the world's most inequitable distribution of income, Pope John Paul II's trip to Mexico and Latin America this week will inevitably sharpen the debate on the role of the Roman Catholic Church in combating poverty and inequality. From Fray Bartolome de las Casas's defense of the indigenous peoples of New Spain in the 16th century through the emergence of liberation theology in the 1960's and 1970's, the Latin American coincidence of a powerful church and widespread destitution and inequity has led to unending acrimony.

title: Lights, Camera, Apology: Sprewell Takes the Stage
description: Latrell Sprewell's image reclamation project began this afternoon about half past three as a curtain parted and his lanky figure appeared in tan pants and a peach sweater.

title: Censure Is No Longer an Option for the Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, MARY LANIER
description: GRAY-Mary Lanier. Died January 18; born 1902 in Baltimore, Maryland, daughter of Berwick Bruce Lanier and Emily Parker; wife of the late Dr. Lloyd P. Gray; mother of the late L. Lanier Gray and Mary Emily Gavahan. Survived by her daughter, Elizabeth L. Henson of South Orleans, MA, nine grandchildren, fifteen great grandchildren and her twin, Katharine L. Recknagel. Memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Force Possible If Milosevic Stays Defiant, West Warns
description: Western powers today warned the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, that simply allowing the head of the international monitoring mission to remain in Kosovo is not enough to avoid the threat of NATO air strikes.

title: DirecTV to Buy A Major Rival For $1.8 Billion
description: In a major consolidation of the satellite-TV broadcasting industry, Hughes Electronics Inc.'s DirecTV Inc. subsidiary has agreed to buy troubled Primestar Inc., its major competitor, for $1.8 billion.

title: Byrd's Statement on His Move to End the Trial
description: Following is the statement issued today by Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, about the impeachment trial of President Clinton:

title: Case for Clinton Relies on Portraying the Prosecution's Case as Trivial
description: In defending President Clinton, his lawyers portrayed the case against him as one cobbled together from events that were often trivial and open to varying interpretations. Above all, they argued that the charges fell below the constitutional standard for removing him from office.

title: After a Serious Scare, Reeves Feels Blessed
description: Dan Reeves sat in his office after practice yesterday and spoke about his remarkable recovery from quadruple bypass surgery.

title: Knicks' Fans Willing To Give Sprewell a Shot
description: To some hard-core Knicks fans, he is the long-sought scorer who deserves a second chance. To other Knicks disciples, he is a short-tempered embarrassment who doesn't belong in New York.

title: Hong Kong Blames Foreign Managers for Airport's Faulty Start
description: Seven months after Hong Kong's new $20 billion airport opened amid a riot of lost luggage and rotting cargo, a Government commission today laid most of the blame on the airport's Western managers.

title: Bill Would Tell Troopers To Report on Complaints
description: A Senate committee has approved a bill that would require the New Jersey State Police to prepare an annual report on how it handled complaints from the public.

title: PARAGON SAYS ITS PATENT DISPUTE WITH P.& G. IS SETTLED
description: Paragon Trade Brands Inc. said yesterday that it had reached a settlement in principle with the Procter & Gamble Company over two baby-diaper patent-infringement lawsuits as part of Paragon's Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization. Last January, the United States District Court in Delaware ordered Paragon to stop selling leak-proof diapers with inner-leg gatherers and said the company owed P.& G. $178.4 million for infringing its patents. Paragon, the largest maker of private-label disposable diapers, filed for Chapter 11 protection a week later. The settlement resolves all of P.& G.'s claims, Paragon said, and provides patent licenses to cover future diaper sales by Paragon. P.& G., the maker of Pampers and Luvs brand diapers, was not available for comment.

title: Corrections
description: An opera review in Weekend yesterday about ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' at the Metropolitan misstated the day of the soprano Elizabeth Futral's debut there. It was in the Jan. 8 performance of ''Lucia,'' not in Wednesday's.

title: Rehnquist Not Looking at His Watch
description: The face was familiar, the voice was familiar, the robe with the gold stripes was familiar, but could this really be the Chief Justice of the United States allowing the prosecution and defense to run way past their allotted time in answering senators' questions?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, CHARLES
description: SCHWARTZ-Charles. In his 80th year. After a courageous but brief battle with cancer. Beloved husband of Henrietta. Loving father of Carol and Ira Wallis and Steven and Claudia Schwartz. Loving step-father of Amy Tarcher and Burt and Ann Tarcher. Adored grandfather of Ben and Jason Wallis, Julian and Eli Schwartz and Christopher and Alessandra Tarcher. Also survived by his sisters Miriam Siegel and Edith Capa. Charles will be dearly remembered. Funeral services Sunday, 11:30 AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, LI.

title: Judge Approves Sweeping Settlement in Child Welfare Suit
description: A Federal judge yesterday approved the sweeping settlement of a 1995 Federal class-action lawsuit against New York City's troubled child welfare system, rejecting a last-minute objection by advocates for gay youths in foster care, and in the process ending 26 years of litigation that sought the system's overhaul.

title: CELLULAR'S DIRECTORS RECOMMEND ACCEPTING NEW OFFER
description: The directors of Cellular Communications International Inc. recommended accepting a revised $1.8 billion bid from Olivetti S.p.A. and Mannesmann A.G. yesterday, even as the company's shares traded above the offer price for a third day. Investors in the New York-based Cellular rejected the two companies' previous bid last week, prompting them to raise their offer to $80 a share from $65.75. The board had accepted the previous offer as well, setting in motion lawsuits from shareholders. Cellular's sole asset is 10.3 percent of Omnitel-Pronto Italia S.p.A., Europe's No. 2 mobile-phone network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOTE, ARTHUR D.
description: SLOTE-Arthur D. Of Stamford, Ct. Died on January 21, 1999 in Tucson, Az. He is mourned by his wife Ann Kleban Slote, his children James, Elizabeth and Nancy, his sons-in-law Ejlat Feuer and Michael Danko Slote and his six grandchildren. Services private. Contributions to the ACLU.

title: Pope, in Mexico, Urges Moral Pressure on U.S. by Bishops
description: Thousands of glinting lights, reflections of mirrors held up by Mexican followers, welcomed Pope John Paul II's airplane as he arrived in Mexico today to address Latin and North America as a whole.

title: Sports Of the Times; 'I'm Sorry, So Sorry.' Really, I Am.
description: BILLIE HOLIDAY tartly sang ''Don't Explain,'' and after listening to questions fired at Latrell Sprewell yesterday, the new Knicks player might be wise to heed that advice, sooner rather than later.

title: Confusion Follows Fanfare Over High-Speed Internet Link for Schools
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and executives from Cablevision Systems announced with much fanfare this week that the company would provide high-speed Internet access to more than 900 public and private schools in the Bronx and Brooklyn, there was just one problem: Nobody told the teachers, principals and students who will eventually use it.

title: Governor Proposes Funds For Antismoking Effort
description: The Whitman administration has proposed using $18 million of the money New Jersey will receive this year from the nationwide tobacco settlement to pay for programs aimed at reducing smoking among teen-agers, state health officials said yesterday.

title: Censure Is No Longer an Option for the Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; Reopening An Old Door To Listeners
description: ON stage at Cooper Union's Great Hall -- the very place where Abraham Lincoln delivered a speech that helped him get elected in 1860 -- Hi Brown paced among a quintet of actors in front of a few slender microphones. They were about to record ''The Naked Truth,'' a radio dramatization of another talk delivered there, by Victoria Woodhull, a feminist who scandalized the country with ideas about free love and women's rights in 1873.

title: In Questioning, 2 Sides Battle Over Witnesses
description: Assuming a more active role, senators posed questions to defense and prosecution teams for the first time today, producing the semblance of debate in the impeachment trial of President Clinton.

title: Tony Awards Are Expected to Go On
description: Officials of the 1999 Tony Awards said yesterday that this year's event would almost certainly proceed despite a lingering contract dispute between the two organizations that oversee the awards and the news that Rosie O'Donnell, a popular recent host, would not work on the show.

title: Holbrooke Denies That Embassy Visit Violated Lobbying Laws
description: Richard C. Holbrooke, President Clinton's choice to be the top American diplomat at the United Nations, denied today that he had violated Federal lobbying laws, the issue that has held up his nomination since the summer.

title: Berlin Journal; An American Jew Tries To Knit Past and Future
description: W. Michael Blumenthal has a room with a typically disjointed Berlin view. In the foreground, the gracious 18th-century dome of the German Cathedral, the work of an imperial power that ended badly. In the background, a maze of cranes, symbols of this city's latest stab at inventing a glorious future.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Central Bank Tries to Halt Slide of Brazil Currency
description: Faced with another steep fall in the value of its currency, Brazil's central bank used more of its dwindling reserves of dollars today to buy Brazilian money in the foreign exchange market.

title: Suffolk G.O.P. Chief, Facing Charges, to Quit
description: John Powell, the Suffolk County Republican leader who was charged early last month with bribery and trafficking in stolen trucks, announced today that he would step down as party chairman.

title: Legal Experts Give Edge to the 'Powerful' Defense Team Arguing for Clinton
description: After the White House completed arguments this week, experts on impeachment said the President's lawyers had offered constitutional and factual arguments powerful enough to counter the momentum of the House's case and blunt the effort to call witnesses.

title: Starr Moves to Compel Lewinsky To Meet With House Prosecutors
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, sought an emergency court order today to compel Monica S. Lewinsky to submit to interviews over the weekend by House prosecutors in President Clinton's impeachment trial.

title: A Player's Unsettling Death Leaves Others Wondering Why
description: After the death of her parents, Katrina Price did as she had always done to salve her soul in times of trouble: she turned to basketball.

title: The Political Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: Dustin Hoffman Wins Suit on Photo Alteration
description: In a decision that could affect the way magazines satirize public figures, a judge ordered Los Angeles magazine yesterday to pay $1.5 million in actual damages to the actor Dustin Hoffman for publishing a computer-altered image of him in an evening dress and high heels.

title: Tax Rebates in New Jersey
description: Like two-thirds of the nation's governors, Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey is now wrestling with the ''problem'' of fat budget surpluses brought on by a booming economy. This month, to no one's great surprise, Mrs. Whitman proposed in her State of the State Message to send money back to taxpayers in the form of a rebate for their local property taxes. The proposal is certain to be popular, but there is a worrisome catch. The cost of the rebate would grow from $200 million the first year to $1 billion annually in five years, raising questions about whether the money will be there to pay for it if the economy turns down.

title: People Are Not Commodities
description: In one way or another, human bodies have been commodities for a very long time. Prostitution and chattel slavery are, after all, biblical, while modern capitalism has opened up new markets in blood, sperm and body parts. Recently it has become possible to buy space in someone else's womb, and we are promised that embryos, and tissues grown from them, are soon to be available from the catalogue.

title: Byrd Will Offer A Motion to End Trial of Clinton
description: With a small, but important number of Republicans expressing reservations about the wisdom of calling witnesses, Senator Robert C. Byrd, a Democrat who is a leading authority on Senate traditions, said today that President Clinton's impeachment trial should come to a swift end and announced that he would offer a motion to dismiss the charges next week.

title: Corrections
description: A chart with the Market Place column in Business Day on Wednesday about Chase Manhattan's financial performance mislabeled the section on fourth-quarter trading results. It showed trading revenue and losses, not trading profit and losses. The chart also misstated trading results for J. P. Morgan. A corrected version appears today on page C2.

title: Funk Leads Bob Hope Classic by a Stroke
description: Ten years ago, Fred Funk was a 32-year-old golf coach at the University of Maryland hoping to reach the PGA Tour.

title: Attacks on Christians Unsettle Rural India
description: In this hamlet nestled in the teak forests of western India, on a recent starry night, Sitaram Devjija says he saw something that froze him in terror. A mob of raging, machete-wielding Hindu fundamentalists crested the hill above his mud hut and swarmed over the rustic Christian prayer hall where he worships.

title: McIlvaine, Newest Net, Just Knew His Next Stop
description: Three clues were all Jim McIlvaine needed to predict his next stop in the National Basketball Association.

title: Jules W. Lederer, 81, Salesman And Budget Rent-a-Car Founder
description: Jules W. Lederer, the founder of Budget Rent-a-Car and former husband of Ann Landers, the popular syndicated newspaper advice columnist, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home near London. He was 81.

title: C. G. Zubrod, 84, Oncologist Who Extended Chemotherapy
description: Dr. Charles Gordon Zubrod, a retired oncologist at the National Institutes of Health who furthered the use of chemotherapy to treat cancer, died on Tuesday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 84 and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Rafter, Still Vulnerable at Home, Falls to Enqvist
description: It is too late for Patrick Rafter to whisper in the tournament director Paul McNamee's ear about changing the Australian Open this year. Too late to suggest nicely -- this is Rafter, after all -- that the hardcourt surface be made quicker and the balls lighter so that Rafter's serve-and-volley style can play as well at home as it does in New York.

title: Edward T. Parrack, 84, Ex-Head of Ketchum Advertising Agency
description: Edward T. Parrack, an advertising executive who supervised some of the best-known campaigns in the early years of television, died Jan. 13 at his home in Oakland in western Pennsylvania. He was 84.

title: 6 Badly Injured In Boiler Explosion
description: Six city workers suffered severe burns yesterday when a boiler in a municipal building in Elizabeth exploded, police and fire officials said.

title: Led by I.B.M., Dow Closes 1.6% Lower
description: The stock market finished lower yesterday as I.B.M. fell sharply after mainframe sales in the fourth quarter disappointed some investors. The economic crisis in Brazil was also bothersome, helping send bank and financial stocks lower.

title: Parks Chief Promises a Tree for the Asking to All Homeowners
description: Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern pledged yesterday that the city would plant a free tree outside the house of every New York City homeowner who requested one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENTHAL, FRANKLYN L.
description: LOWENTHAL-Franklyn L. Briarcliff Manor, NY. Died suddenly January 17, 1999. Beloved husband of Elinor, father of James and the late Ronald. Burial January 22.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, BERNARD
description: LEVINE-Bernard. Survived by his wife Dorothy, son David, daughter Edan, son-in-law Scott Segal, brother Arthur, grandfather of Courtney and Jake. Services Sunday, January 24, 2:15 at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVINE, BERNARD
description: LEVINE-Bernard. Good friend, you'll always be remembered and dearly missed. The Birnbaum Family

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, MURRAY
description: JACOBS-Murray. Of Forest Hills, N.Y., and Princeton, NJ. Executive Officer of Celebration Trading, Inc., passed away peacefully at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, on January 22nd, leaving his beloved wife Eleanor, his devoted daughter Arlene, and son-in-law Henry Opatut, loving grandchildren Jessica & Daniel, and brother Zigmund Jacobs. A Holocaust survivor, concert violinist, and designer, known & loved in the Garment District for almost fifty years. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be sent to The Dysautonomia Foundation, 20 East 46 St., New York, NY 10017. Funeral will be held on Sunday, January 24th at 2 P.M. at The Jewish Center of Princeton, 435 Nassau Street, Princeton, New Jersey.

title: Judge Delays, at Least Briefly, Shifting Role of Welfare Offices
description: A Federal judge ordered the Giuliani administration yesterday to delay an expansion of its tough new welfare policies by one day while he considers a lawsuit filed by advocates for the poor seeking safeguards for applicants..

title: U.N. Needs Realism, Not More Platitudes
description: To the Editor:

title: In Utah, More Investigations and More Anxiety
description: When the 2002 Winter Olympics were finally awarded to this city after years of struggle, many residents said Utah's capital, long regarded as clean and quiet and little else, had finally arrived on the world stage, equal to the best.

title: Food Stamp Infractions
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's boast about cutting New York City's welfare rolls suddenly has a thinner ring to it. As Rachel Swarns wrote in The Times on Wednesday, Federal investigators from the Department of Agriculture found that the city's new rigorous welfare-to-work program was in ''substantial noncompliance'' with the Federal Food Stamp Act. In a draft report, the department criticizes the city for not immediately telling welfare applicants they could apply for food stamps. It also chastises the state for not monitoring the program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TISHMAN, RITA V.
description: TISHMAN-Rita V., an active leader in Jewish and civic philanthrophies, died of natural causes at her home in Manhattan on Thursday, January 21. She was 91 years old. Her involvement in civic affairs began at an early age. In 1946 she was awarded the Civilian Medal of Merit by President Roosevelt for her distinguished service to the War Bond effort. She was also cited for her exemplary services by Presidents Truman, Kennedy, and Johnson. Always interested in Jewish causes, she served on the boards of the United Jewish Appeal, the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, the American Jewish Committee, the Anti-Defamation League, and was President of the New York Section, National Council of Jewish Women. She received numerous rewards from these organizations for her efforts, including the Hannah G. Solomon Award from the National Council of Jewish Women in 1965. In 1969 the annual Rita V. Tishman Award for Civil Rights was established by the Anti-Defamation League. In 1975 Mrs. Tishman was the recipient of the Appeal for Human Relations Award from the American Jewish Committee. In her later years she was also a Board member of the National Association for the Visually Handicapped. Born in New York City in 1907, she graduated from Smith College in 1928. The widow of Norman Tishman, former Chairman of Tishman Realty and Construction Co., Inc., she is survived by three children, Margot T. Linton, Peter V. Tishman and Valerie T. Diker of New York City, ten grandchildren and eleven great - grandchildren. Funeral service will be held on Sunday, January 24, at 10 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, a memorial contribution may be sent to the New York Section, National Council of Jewish Women, 9 East 69 Street, New York City 10021. The family will receive at the home of Mr. & Mrs. Robert Linton at 141 East 72nd Street on Sunday from 4-7 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, HON. EUGENE J.
description: SULLIVAN-Hon. Eugene J. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Honorable Eugene J. Sullivan, a Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, the continuation of the State of the Art column on the front page of Circuits on Thursday, about the confusion often caused by software and hardware updates, omitted several words at the continuation. The affected sentence, about iMacs, should have read:

title: Uncovered Short Positions Drop By 7.6% on Big Board
description: Open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange fell 7.6 percent last month, to 3.65 billion shares, the exchange said yesterday.

title: U.N. Needs Realism, Not More Platitudes
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Needs Realism, Not More Platitudes
description: To the Editor:

title: Random Drug Testing Of Orange Police Begins
description: Police officers here yesterday became the first local law enforcement officers in the state to submit to random drug testing.

title: Swiss Banks And Victims Of the Nazis Nearing Pact
description: Lawyers for Holocaust victims, Jewish groups and Swiss banks agreed late Thursday on some key elements of the $1.25 billion settlement of a lawsuit against the banks, including identifying who can qualify for payments.

title: A New Coach, Directing Unfamiliar Bulls, in a New Era
description: On the second day, the Chicago Bulls had just enough players to get a five-on-five among themselves. When training camp opened on Thursday, the Bulls didn't have enough players who had signed contracts and passed physicals to play even three-on-three.

title: New Jersey Gets Plans For E-Z Pass Back on Track
description: After several delays in setting up an E-Z Pass system for New Jersey's toll roads, transportation officials said today that they had reached a new agreement with the contractor that would put the $500 million project back on schedule.

title: Scholarly Leader Of Smithsonian Is Ready to Retire
description: I. Michael Heyman, a legal scholar and university administrator who has led the Smithsonian Institution since 1994 through a period of growth and arguments over academic freedom, is retiring, officials of the institution said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Shortage of Donated Organs

title: A Boston Firebrand Alienates His Allies Even as He Saves Whales
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Quartey Reveals His Fight Plan
description: Ike Quartey wanted to discuss how he was going to beat Oscar De La Hoya when the two meet in a 12-round World Boxing Council welterweight championship bout Feb. 13 in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Compromise Plan on Vendors Approved
description: Seven months after the Giuliani administration backed away from a plan to ban street vending in large parts of midtown and downtown Manhattan, a city panel approved a compromise measure on Thursday that still bans food carts and other vendors during their most lucrative hours, but from far fewer blocks than its original plan did.

title: 4th-Quarter Slowing In British Economy
description: British economic growth slowed in the fourth quarter to its lowest rate since the recession of 1992, leaving the door open for further interest rate cuts.

title: Olympics Scandal Now Spreads to Australia
description: The Olympic scandal expanded to a new front yesterday when documents were made public showing that the Australian Olympic Committee offered tens of thousands of dollars to two African members of the International Olympic Committee the night before the decisive vote on where the 2000 Summer Games would be staged. Sydney was awarded the Games after it defeated Beijing by two votes.

title: Susan Strasberg, 60, Actress Lauded in 'Anne Frank,' Dies
description: Susan Strasberg, who at 17 electrified Broadway with her luminous portrayal of the title role of ''The Diary of Anne Frank'' and -- with highs and lows professional and private -- went on to a career onstage and in movies, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 60 and also had a home in Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENWALD, RUTH ISRAELS
description: ROSENWALD-Ruth Israels. On January 21, 1999, at her residence in Manhattan, at age 85. Daughter of Henry Goldstein, died 1953, and Elizabeth Traurig Goldstein, died 1985. Widow of Carlos Lindner Israels, died 1969, and William Rosenwald, died 1996. Mother of Michael Jozef Israels. Mother-inlaw of Maija-Sarmite Jansons. Grandmother of Aleksandrs Lehman Israels & Peter Carlos Israels. Stepmother of Nina Rosenwald, Elizabeth R. Varet and Alice R. Sigelman. Memorial Service Tuesday, January 26. 1999, at 12 Noon at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave & 65 St., New York. In lieu of flowers, the family request contributions either to: Congregation EmanueEl of the City of New York, or the Israels Family Fund, at Amherst College, Amherst, Mass.

title: New Coach Will Try to Sell Isles on a Trapping Defense
description: Coach Bill Stewart turned around the St. John Flames, taking them from the basement of the American Hockey League to Calder Cup contenders in one season. His formula for success was simple: defense, defense, defense.

title: Income Increases 12% at Siemens
description: Siemens A.G., Germany's biggest electronics company, said today that net income rose 12 percent in the fiscal first quarter, aided by higher sales in Europe.

title: LIFE BY DESIGN; Iceland, the Nation of Clones
description: One of the most remarkable effects of human genome mania is that it has put Iceland, previously known only for fish, back on the map. It seems that someone has dreamt up the brilliant idea of marketing Iceland's best natural resource after cod: the country's wonderfully unvarying human genome.

title: Citing Accounts of Abuse at Nassau Jail, Legislators Seek U.S. Inquiry
description: As lawyers of other former inmates came forward with accounts of what they say is rampant abuse at the Nassau Correctional Center, Democratic county legislators called today for a Federal investigation into the treatment of prisoners at the jail, where the police say a man was fatally beaten on Jan. 8.

title: Former Federal Guard Convicted of Drug Charge
description: A former guard at a Federal jail in Manhattan who was accused of offering to help an inmate collect old drug debts has been convicted of narcotics trafficking and taking bribes in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUEN, KURT H.
description: GRUEN-Kurt H. The family and friends mourn his passing on Thursday, Jan. 21. Born in Vienna, Austria, a U.S. Army veteran of World War II, he became a Certified Public Accountant servicing many clients and friends. Survived by his companion, Hanna Broz, nieces Yvonne Zaros, Susan Decker, Judy Teilhaber, and Ethel Auerbach, and his grand nieces and grand nephews. Services at Riverside, 180 West 76 Street, (362-6600), Sunday, 12:15 PM.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I am convinced that the necessary two-thirds for conviction are not there and that they are not likely to develop.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLASTER, SANFORD
description: CLASTER-Sanford. On January 21st, 1999. Beloved husband of Betsy. Loving father of Bob, Scott, Lois and Diane. Dear brother of Jean. Adoring grandfather of Max and Zoe. Graveside service on Sunday, 11 AM, at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Experts See Legal Pitfalls In Seizing Cars
description: Legal scholars and criminal lawyers yesterday questioned the legality of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to seize the cars of people charged with drunken driving, as mayoral aides acknowledged that city lawyers were still reviewing the proposal.

title: Censure Is No Longer an Option for the Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Many Pets
description: To the Editor:

title: 60's Messages in a 90's Medium; Feel-Good E-Mail Cards Emerge as a Web Powerhouse
description: It somehow comes as no surprise to learn that the headquarters of Blue Mountain Arts, a greeting card company that set up shop here in 1971, used to be a hot tub palace. The tubs are gone, but it is not hard to imagine the company's founders, Stephen Schutz and Susan Polis Schutz, kicking back in the buff in the steaming water. The image fits nicely with their self-proclaimed mission: to help people communicate their deepest emotions.

title: Salinas Case: New Attitude or Old Mexican Politics?
description: The verdict that sentenced Raul Salinas de Gortari, brother of the former President of Mexico, to prison for 50 years for masterminding a political assassination in 1994 sent the strongest signal yet that the political elite is no longer beyond the reach of justice.

title: INTEGRATED HEALTH SERVICES SELLS 32 NURSING HOMES
description: Integrated Health Services Inc. said yesterday that it had sold 32 nursing homes to Monarch Properties L.P. for $135 million and would use the money to pay down debt. Monarch, a privately held company in Naples, Fla., leased the sites to Lyric Health Care L.L.C. Integrated Health, which owns a 50 percent stake in Lyric Health, will in turn manage and operate the locations for an undisclosed fee.

title: LIZ CLAIBORNE TO ACQUIRE 84.5 PERCENT OF SEGRETS
description: Liz Claiborne Inc., the No. 1 apparel company in the United States, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 84.5 percent of the clothing maker Segrets Inc. for an undisclosed amount as part of a plan to buy and develop new brands. The Segrets businesses include the brands Sigrid Olsen Sport and Sigrid Olsen Collection. Segrets has about $60 million in annual sales. Liz Claiborne said last month that it would close 30 of its 230 stores and dismiss 400 employees, or about 5.7 percent of its work force, because of lackluster sales and earnings. Liz Claiborne shares rose 87.5 cents, to $36.1875. The announcement came after the close of trading in New York.

title: Maybe Greatness, Surely Hollywood
description: Erich Wolfgang Korngold is another of those lurkers on the sidelines of greatness not yet called upon to take the field. Korngold, who grew up Viennese but died far away in Hollywood in 1957, survives mainly by virtue of a hit European opera, ''Die Tote Stadt,'' and the scores he wrote for American films. As in so many Korngold-like cases, this one features an avid coterie of fans, their disbelief in his neglect and a wider public that nevertheless refuses to take him seriously.

title: Final Accord in G.E. Debt Collection Suit
description: The General Electric Company won a judge's final approval of a settlement valued at as much as $147 million today, ending lawsuits accusing the company of illegally collecting debts from bankrupt credit card customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARELLI, GABOR
description: CARELLI-Gabor. The Feszek Klub of New York mourns the passing of its long time President, Gabor Carelli who led our club with enthusiasm, energy and devotion. His spirited leadership made The Feszek Klub the cultural home of the Hungarian Community of New York. He was esteemed and beloved by all. Service Sunday, 2:45PM at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, JOSEPH L.
description: GOULD-Joseph L. died on January 21, 1999 at age 95. Mr. Gould was born in London, England and came to this country in 1910. He practiced law until he was 94 years old. He is the beloved father of June B. Naiburg and Arnold J. Gould, and the cherished grandfather of Jennifer and Marnie Naiburg. Graveside services will be at 2PM Sunday at Wellwood Cemetery. Any further information call Gutterman's Inc. 516764-9400.

title: Beliefs
description: Journalists all over the country are scrambling for ideas to fill out their coverage of Pope John Paul II's visit to St. Louis next week. Pity them. It is really not so easy to come up with a fresh approach after the news media blitz that surrounded the Pope's trip to the United States less than four years ago and the many overviews of his papacy, which marked its 20th anniversary last fall.

title: 2 Sides Note 26th Anniversary of Roe v. Wade
description: As 100,000 abortion opponents paraded past the White House today, calling the Clintons murderers, Hillary Rodham Clinton denounced violence against abortion practitioners as ''domestic terrorism'' and said the Clinton Administration would propose spending $4.5 million in next year's Federal budget to improve safety at abortion clinics.

title: Journal; Clinton Beats Dole (II)
description: Draft-dodging Bill Clinton beats World War II hero Bob Dole at the polls. Philandering Bill Clinton vanquishes Republican Puritans in the Senate. What's next? As our marathon culture war reaches its catharsis in Washington, it may be Hollywood's turn to provide the farcical coup de grace. The talk here -- not for attribution, since no one wants to offend Steven Spielberg -- is that ''Saving Private Ryan,'' the patriotic shoo-in of the summer, might lose the Best Picture Oscar come spring to a movie drenched in sex (and lies about sex) whose lovable hero shamelessly cheats on the wife and kids he's left at home.

title: Dozens of Tornadoes Kill 8 in Arkansas and Tennessee
description: A powerful storm system rolled across Arkansas on Thursday, spawning tornadoes that killed seven people. Another set of tornadoes struck Tennessee, killing a woman.

title: Thwarting Tomorrow's Terrors
description: Biological and chemical terrorism and disabling attacks on American computer networks are not just the stuff of novels and films. Nerve gas has already been released in the Tokyo subways. Hackers and virus programs have struck supposedly secure computer systems. President Clinton is right to plan a coordinated Federal response to what could become a major problem.

title: Rival Gains on Intel With Cheaper Products
description: The Intel Corporation's share of the microprocessor market fell to 75.7 percent in the fourth quarter as its rival, Advanced Micro Devices Inc., stole business with its cheaper products, a research firm said.

title: TOYS 'R' US GOES ON LINE IN BRITAIN
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc., the world's largest toy retailer, said yesterday that it had started a free Internet service in Britain to increase on-line sales. It becomes the second retailer in the world to offer free Internet access. The move follows the success of Freeserve, started by Dixons Group P.L.C., an appliance retailer, in September, which has since become Britain's largest Internet service provider. Toys ''R'' Us aims to make money from advertising and Internet commerce as more people shop on line. The British market for Internet retail sales is expected to rise to $5 billion by 2003.

title: Censure Is No Longer an Option for the Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR FALLS 5 PERCENT. Prices fell for a sixth day to the lowest level since Sept. 29 on speculation that Brazil's exports will surge because of its weakened currency. The March contract fell 0.37 cent a pound, to 7.1 cents.

title: Questions Yield Time For Rebuttal
description: What was to be a question-and-answer time for senators who swore an oath to be impartial jurors in President Clinton's impeachment trial turned into rebuttal time today for the opposing legal teams.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about anti-impeachment rallies organized across the country by People for the American Way, a liberal advocacy group, misidentified Barbara Handman, who organized a rally in New York at the headquarters of 1199, the National Health and Human Services Union. She is vice president of People for the American Way and director of its New York office, not director of the union local.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVARCO, LILLIAN
description: DEVARCO-Lillian, 87, FL, passed peacefully, January 17. Beloved mother of Vivian and David. Great grandmother, grandmother. Social activist, gardner, folk dancer. Vivian McDaniel and David and Sandra Bergman

title: BEATRICE AGREES TO PURCHASE BY SPANISH COMPANY
description: TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc., once the biggest African-American-owned company, agreed to be acquired by a Spanish investor, according to court papers filed yesterday. The deal was disclosed in a lawsuit to block the purchase by the Spanish company, APEG Investments. The suit was filed in New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan by a rival bidder for TLC Beatrice, Amistad Holdings L.L.C. According to the court papers, Amistad said it agreed in September to buy the closely held New York company's snack food business for $100 million, and APEG was to buy the company's ice cream business for $150 million, but APEG violated the agreement by entering a purchase agreement for all of TLC Beatrice.

title: High Court Takes Case On Districts And Rights
description: In time for the next round of post-census redistricting, the Supreme Court agreed today to resolve a long-running dispute over how the Voting Rights Act applies to new district lines that, while not making matters worse for minority voters, nonetheless fail for discriminatory reasons to make things better.

title: Tough Moll With Heart Of Mush
description: Sharon Stone may have left her heart in San Francisco, but the rest of her is strictly from Noo Yawk in a richly comic performance as the heroine of ''Gloria.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRCH, CHESTER
description: BIRCH-Chester, a former Briarcliff Manor, NY, resident, died on January 17, 1999, in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida, at the age of 86. An advertising executive, Mr. Birch became President of Dancer, Fitzgerald & Sample, Inc. in the early 1950's. He is survived by a son, Bruce Birch of Blacksburg, Virginia; a daughter, Susan Duffy of Briarcliff Manor; his grandchildren, Laura Buchanan, Margaret Birch, Keara Buck and Mark Duffy, and two great-grandsons, Connor and Aidan Buck.

title: Microsoft Executive's Testimony Attacks Accusers
description: The most senior executive of the Microsoft Corporation to testify at its antitrust trial delivered an unflinching defense of the company's practices yesterday and an attack on the testimony of industry executives who appeared as Government witnesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, C. EDMAN (BUD)
description: ADAMS-C. Edman (Bud) S.A.R., on January 22, 1999. Beloved husband of Maria. Loving son of Mary Mildred and the late Chester Adams. Funeral Mass Saturday, January 23rd, St. Francis Xavier Church, 46 West 16th Street, 10:30AM. Interment private.

title: Despite 'Don't Ask' Policy, Gay Ousters Rose in '98
description: Five years after the Clinton Administration adopted its ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy for gay men and lesbians in the military, the armed forces discharged more people as homosexuals in the last fiscal year than in any year since 1987.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPLOW, FREYDA (PECK)
description: KOPLOW-Freyda (Peck), late of Boynton Beach, FL; Former State Representative & Commissioner of Banks for the Commonwealth of MA; wife of the late Irving; mother of Richard A. Koplow of Lexington, MA., Michael D. Koplow of Woburn, MA. and Kenneth Koplow of Cambridge, MA.; sister of Edna Sulman of Madison, WI, Albert Peck of Delray Beach, FL, Mildred Robinson of Boca Raton, FL, Ruth Swatsburg of Waterford, CT; survived by seven grand and 7 great grandchildren. Services were held at Stanetsky Chapels, Brookline, MA, Wednesday, January 13. Expressions of sympathy in her memory may be donated to The Freyda P. Koplow Brookline High School Scholarship Fund, P.O. Box 380178, Cambridge, MA. 02238-0178.

title: Duncan and Mets Agree to Terms
description: The Mets agreed to terms with the veteran infielder Mariano Duncan on a minor league contract and an invitation to spring training. Should Duncan win a spot with the Mets, he would be paid $450,000 for the 1999 season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, WILLIAM
description: FRIED-William. Died Friday, January 22, 1999, at age 87. He built a successful accounting business, generously supported the Jewish community. Willie is succeeded by his wife, Norma, sons Donald and Howard, stepdaughters Barbara and Honey, and five grandchildren. Funeral service will be this Sunday, January 24, 1PM at Weinstein Funeral Home, 1283 Coney Island Ave in Brooklyn.

title: Exit Here, Byrd Tells Colleagues
description: It came as sharp as a cry from the heart. Senator Robert C. Byrd issued his terse statement declaring that he had heard enough of the impeachment case against President Clinton midway through a Ping-Pong-like Senate revisitation of the trial's familiar details.

title: Medicare Safety Nets Fail To Catch Many of the Poor
description: Many of the poorest among the nation's 39 million Medicare beneficiaries, people with incomes below $10,000 a year, are going without aid from government safety net programs that are intended to help them pay their health care expenses.

title: Devils Win Second Straight
description: Devils Coach Robbie Ftorek evaluates his players over 10-game spans. Although their last 10 games have been their worst this season, they made it respectable by winning the last two games of their three-game California trip that was completed at the Forum in Inglewood, Calif., on Thursday night.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Ernest Schier, director of the National Critics Institute at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., misstated the date of his death. It was Jan. 12, not last Tuesday.

title: Is Good Education a Civil Right?; Create a New Grade
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Greedy Landlords
description: To the Editor:

title: Riffs, Rolls, Smacks and a Wall of Sound
description: That Billy Higgins, one of jazz's great drummers, was at the Jazz Standard on Tuesday was a miracle, and that he was playing as well as ever was another. Several years ago Mr. Higgins became ill and was near death. He has recovered, and his recent appearances in New York with Ornette Coleman and other musicians, along with his own group, have been intensely emotional.

title: Income-Based Medicare Proposal Is Offered
description: Higher-income Medicare beneficiaries would have to pay higher premiums under proposals outlined today by Senator John B. Breaux, the chairman of a bipartisan commission seeking ways to avert a financial crisis in the health insurance program for the elderly.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY
description: LOST HORIZON

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, JENNIFER SUE
description: BRODY-Jennifer Sue. At age 42, formerly of Wheaton and Chicago, IL, died January 16th. Ms. Brody was a Housing Specialist for HUD in Orange County, Ca. Daughter of Attorney Lita Brody of Chicago, Illinois, and the late Dr. Arnold W. Brody, M.D, formerly of Mount Vernon, N.Y. Granddaughter of the late Lillian and Harry Brody & the late Harry and Emma Gray. Great granddaughter of the late Helen Moskowitz of Mt. Vernon, N.Y. Services were held January 22nd, in Wheaton, Illinois. Funeral information, 630-668-0016.

title: Rape on East Side Is Tied to 3 Attacks
description: A 6-foot-10, 300-pound man suspected of attacking three women on the Upper West Side of Manhattan has apparently struck for a fourth time, this time on the Upper East Side, the police said last night.

title: Is Good Education a Civil Right?
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Good Education a Civil Right?; Competition Helps
description: To the Editor:

title: Caldor, in Bankruptcy, to Shut Its Stores
description: The Caldor Corporation, the discount retail chain that filed for bankruptcy more than three years ago and has since struggled to stay afloat, announced today that it would liquidate its holdings and close all of its 145 stores in nine East Coast states.

title: U.N. Needs Realism, Not More Platitudes
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Central Bank of Brazil Acts to Stabilize Currency

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN WEAKENS FURTHER. Japan's currency fell for a second day on growing concern that neighboring China would devalue its currency, the yuan, to help invigorate the Chinese economy. The dollar rose to 114.54 yen from 113.68.

title: IMC GLOBAL TO SELL DISTRIBUTION UNIT
description: IMC Global Inc. said yesterday that it would sell its IMC Agribusiness retail and wholesale distribution unit to Royster-Clark for $300 million. The assets sold to Royster-Clark include nitrogen production sites in East Dubuque, Ill., and Cincinnati. IMC Global also signed a 10-year contract to supply phosphate and potash to Royston-Clark. The sale, expected to close by spring, means that IMC will achieve its goal of raising $700 million to pay down debt through the sale of assets. IMC recently completed the sale of its IMC Chemicals soda ash business to Mincorp, a privately held business controlled by a Citigroup venture capital unit, for more than $300 million.

title: Bankers Trust Bonuses Exceed $1 Billion
description: The Bankers Trust Corporation agreed to pay employees about $1.1 billion in bonuses for 1998 after the company, now being acquired by Deutsche Bank A.G., lost $6 million last year.

title: Is There a Book Hidden Within the Bible?
description: In the traditional interpretation of the Bible, the Five Books of Moses are exactly that: Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers and Deuteronomy, written by Moses at God's command.

title: Value America in Filing
description: Value America Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering, marking the Internet retailer's second attempt at a first-time stock sale. The Charlottesville, Va., company will seek to sell five million common shares at $15 to $17 each, according to documents filed with the S.E.C. The proceeds are estimated at a net of $72.9 million if the shares sell for $16 each.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANK, BARBARA ALLMAN
description: DANK-Barbara Allman on January 22, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Mortimer, devoted mother of Harry & Bonnie, loving mother-in-law of Shosh. Cherished grandmother of Micah & Avttal. Service Sunday 10:30AM at ''Gutterman's Inc'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI. Donations may be made to the Hospice of Howard County, 5537 Twin Knolls Road, Suite 433, Columbia, MD. 21045.

title: Censure Is No Longer an Option for the Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: President Steps Up War on New Terrorism
description: President Clinton proposed steps today to defend against unconventional terrorist warfare, including creation of 25 urban medical emergency teams to respond to germ weapons attacks and the training of a new Cyber Corps of computer specialists to detect and defeat intrusions into critical civilian and military computer networks.

title: A Challenge to Scientific Economics; An Older School Looks at a Broad, More Intuitive Picture While Modernists See Just the Numbers and Facts
description: Ask economists in the baby boom generation why they became economists, and any number will give some credit to Robert L. Heilbroner. His 1953 book, ''The Worldly Philosophers,'' which has sold nearly four million copies, is a ''Profiles in Courage'' of the great thinkers who shaped modern economics. So it is somewhat surprising to find Mr. Heilbroner increasingly critical of the economists he helped inspire. They have missed the point, he says.

title: Ex-Latin King Says U.S. Reneged; Killer Turned Informer, Seeking Leniency, Fears for His Life
description: One day a few years ago, Federal prosecutors investigating the Latin Kings, one of the most brutal and highly organized gangs in New York, got the break they were looking for. A high-ranking member of the gang offered to act as an informer.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: BankAmerica Plans Emerging-Market Cuts
description: The BankAmerica Corporation wants to cut its exposure to emerging markets by another 50 percent, though reaching that goal is not certain, its chief financial officer, James Hance, told analysts earlier this week.

title: Norwegians Win Pair Title, Enhancing Their Reputation
description: A Norwegian partnership captured the Macallan International Bridge Pairs Championship in London yesterday. Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness, who are now established as one of the world's greatest partnerships, took the lead at the start and were never challenged. They were virtually assured of victory before the start of the final day's play.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Political Notes; How to Run for Office Without Seeming to Try
