description: Suppose that you are a high-level Cabinet official wondering if you should run for elective office. Do you have a chance? Can you raise money? Will the potential of your candidacy excite party leaders and newspapers? Most important, is there a way to answer these questions without risking the embarrassment of a failed run for office?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATTEN, WILLIAM M.
description: BATTEN-William M. The Board of Directors of The New York Stock Exchange, Inc., wish to express their deep sorrow on the passing of their dear friend and esteemed colleague, William M. (Mil) Batten, Chairman of The Exchange from 1976 to 1984. His dedication and committment to The Exchange and to the securities industry will be greatly missed. Richard A. Grasso Chairman and Chief Executive Officer New York Stock Exchange, Inc.

title: Jumbled, Perhaps, but Never Dull
description: The Everett Dance Theater, from Providence, R.I., is not afraid of big issues. In the past, its collaboratively devised creations have combined dance with taped collages and texts to examine such matters as current events, urban problems and scientific research. ''Somewhere in the Dream,'' its newest offering, overflows with ideas. Too many, in fact.

title: Palestinians About to Get an Area Code of Their Own
description: In a step toward virtual statehood Palestinians are about to be granted a form of long-distance independence, their own country code for international telephone calls.

title: Trial's War of Economists Pits Student Against Teacher
description: FOR the last few weeks the Microsoft antitrust trial has heard warring economists provide sweeping overviews of each side's case. These two particular economists have a history.

title: Caryn Seidman, Marc Becker
description: Caryn Gail Seidman, a daughter of Laurie Seidman and Daniel Seidman, both of Rockville, Md., was married last evening to Marc Evan Becker, a son of Sharon and Jerry Becker of East Northport, N.Y. Rabbi David Kaye officiated at the St. Regis in New York.

title: 'Dilbert': Corporate Savior?
description: AT one point during the last year, a UPN executive summoned the creative talent behind ''Dilbert,'' a much-awaited animated comedy series then rushing toward its January premiere date (tomorrow at 8 P.M.). He had an important announcement to make.

title: Shaggy Bags
description: The furry handbag, fake or real, is just what today's sober fashion silhouette needed -- a dash of fun. With so much understatement in clothes, many designers have been focusing on pocketbooks with personality. How could a whimsical, oversize shaggy bag in synthetics or Mongolian lamb fail to lend an air of bravado?

title: Elderly Raise Canes and Get Market Back
description: After petitions and protests, older residents of Bedford Park have finally had their way. They are getting back their supermarket.

title: Rona Daniels and Mark Casey
description: Rona Daniels and Mark Anthony Casey were married last evening by Rabbi Sarah Reines at the Manhattan Penthouse, a party space.

title: Nazi Funds Estimate Put at $750 Million
description: A search by independent auditors for unclaimed deposits placed in Switzerland in the dark days around World War II is expected to conclude by the end of March and to turn up funds that would now be worth about three-quarters of a billion dollars with interest, Swiss bank officials say.

title: A Voice for Losers In the STAR Program
description: The Nassau County Board of Assessors chairman, Charles O'Shea, errs when he states that there are no losers in the STAR program [''Both Tax Relief and Good Schools,'' opinion, Jan. 17]. The losers are Nassau and Suffolk County residents who are not aware of the program or are unduly distrustful of the counties' motives. Many are elderly residents or new citizens who do not keep abreast of local government programs or do not yet have an adequate grasp of the English language. Unfortunately, these are the taxpayers who most often need tax breaks to help maintain a decent quality of life on Long Island.

title: Let's Review
description: MAESTROS OF THE PENA History of Classical Music Criticism in America.By Mark N. Grant.Eric Friedheim, consulting editor.Illustrated. 374 pp. Boston:Northeastern University Press. $37.50.

title: The World; A New Big-Power Race Starts on a Sea of Crude
description: WITH the discovery of great energy reserves in countries around the Caspian Sea, a vast new region has catapulted onto the world stage. It not only offers oil companies the prospect of great wealth. It gives outside powers a place to test their strength.

title: A Look Back and Ahead
description: HORSE OF THE YEAR

title: On the Road, Again
description: JACK KEROUAC, KING OF THE BEATSA Portrait.By Barry Miles.332 pp. New York:Henry Holt & Company. $25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARSEN, GLADYS M.
description: LARSEN-Gladys M. Age 90 of Port Washington, LI on January 22, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Andrew. Loving mother of Alan (Judy), Perry (Ilze) & the late Douglas. Adoring grandmother of five, great grandmother of four. Resposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main St., Port Washington. Visiting Sunday & Monday, 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Funeral service Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: BENEFITS
description: A Life on Stage

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERENSON, ROBERT K.
description: BERENSON-Robert K. Beloved husband of Marion; loving father of Donna and Steve; devoted father in-law of Deanna; dear brother of David; loving son of Birdie and the late Joseph. He will be sorely missed. Funeral services Monday, January 24, 1PM, Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, White Plains, NY.

title: A Mural of Trains Is a Guess-Who Game of Famous Jersey Faces
description: To enliven a wall of the banquet room in Ken's Trackside Restaurant and Supper Club, Ken Comer, the owner, commissioned a painting that was to capture the transition from steam to diesel trains. The topic was a fitting one for a restaurant in the Dover train station, built in 1901, where New Jersey Transit trains still stop. But the painting, by Bob Petillo, grew into more than a painting of trains. The likenesses of Governor Whitman and the author Mary Higgins Clark, along with other prominent New Jersey figures, also appear. Patrons can ponder what Grover Cleveland is whispering to Thomas Edison, or whether Frank Sinatra will strike up a conversation with Woodrow Wilson. Mr. Comer talked recently about ''New Jersey Rail Legacy'' which will be officially unveiled in early spring. Viewers will not have to be diners; it will be lighted around the clock and visible from the window.

title: The Style Of Elements
description: Bob Dylan was wrong: thanks to El Nino and other freaky quirks of nature, you do need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows. And so, on the premise that forecasters are expected to both talk about the weather and help us do something about it, regional offices of the National Weather Service are being encouraged to expand their vocabulary.

title: Pope Urges Bishops to Minister to the Rich
description: Pope John Paul II today urged the Bishops of North and South America gathered here to take better care of the poor. But sounding a new and somewhat uncharacteristic note, the Pope also instructed them to minister to the rich.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: I found John Tierney's presentation of the debate surrounding Julian Simon and Malthusian theory to be an affirmation of nothing but the ignorance afforded to the materially comfortable (The Big City: ''Optimism by the Numbers''). How easy it is for Tierney to side with the optimistic numbers, from the shelter of his secure life. I wonder if he would be so quick to agree with Simon's predictions if he were an AIDS victim in Africa, a starving child in Kenya or an innocent victim of stray bombs in Baghdad. Disease, famine and war. Sound familiar?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, AARON, DR.
description: KRAMER-Aaron, Dr., Ophthalmologist. On January 23, 2000, at age 93, of Cranbury, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn and White Meadow Lake, NJ. Adoring husband for 62 years of Mildred. Cherished father of Rosanne and Joe, Sydelle and Marc, Joyce and Alan. Loving Grandpa of Michelle and Marc, Michael and Elisa, Aliya and Rachel. Aaron's singing melodies and lively jokes will stay with us forever. Services Monday, 1 PM, Temple Neve Shalom, Grove Avenue, Metuchen, NJ.

title: The Different Faces Of Retirement
description: To the Editor:

title: Title Roles
description: Why is Monica now a Ms. while Madeleine is just an Albright? Because the Associated Press, the world's largest news source, has resuscitated a policy that women -- and only women -- must go by courtesy titles. The sole exceptions are athletes, top officials and females who flat-out refuse, a caveat nicknamed the Tomboy Clause. ''If you're masculine enough, A.P. grants you equality,'' one A.P. reporter says, proving that no good grumble is ruined by hyperbole. ''Otherwise, you're a Little Miss.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVICK, RICHARD
description: NOVICK-Richard. On January 21, 1999 in Dayton, OH. Loving son of Rose and the late Bernard Novick. Devoted brother of David and sister-in-law Jane. Contributions may be sent to The National Multiple Schlerosis Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, BERNARD
description: LEVINE-Bernard. Survived by his wife Dorothy, son David, daughter Edan, son-in-law Scott Segal, brother Arthur, grandfather of Courtney and Jake. Services Sunday, January 24, 2:15 at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORSE, FORBES
description: MORSE-Forbes, 81, of Pound Ridge, New York, died on January 13, 1999. He leaves his wife, Emily Potter, a daughter, Adele Forbes and a sister, Esther. A memorial gathering will be held at The Norwalk Yacht Club, Wilson Point, CT, April 17, at 5 P.M. Donations may be made in his memory to The Cruising Club of America, Bonnell Cove Foundation, C/O Dr. Kaighn Smith, 816 Castelfinn Lane, Bryn Mawr, PA. 19010, or The Corinthians Endowment Fund, c/o David McConnell, 29 Storer Avenue, Pelham, New York 10803-1717.

title: The World: Khmer Rouge Photography; Smiles Were Rare
description: THERE are no wedding pictures here. No babies. No birthdays. No graduations. No romantic moments.

title: Cabby Hits Light Pole After a Robbery Attempt
description: A cabdriver crashed into a light pole in Brooklyn early yesterday morning shortly after his passenger stabbed him during a botched robbery attempt, the police said.

title: The New Innovators
description: To the Editor:

title: True Color of Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Special Education: Mainstreaming to Surge
description: IT'S called mainstreaming. Students who once were classified as disabled enough to warrant a separate setting are now being placed in regular schools. And the process is about to accelerate in schools on Long Island and in the rest of New York.

title: AN OPEN-AIR PERCH IN THE JUNGLE
description: A RED dugout canoe floated on the calm aqua sea, orchids were blooming in the garden, large grapefruit and limes hung languorously in the orchard. And on a steep slope above, we glimpsed the edge of a deep green, mysterious Costa Rican rain forest. Nothing wrong with the view. But something was definitely amiss. A rather big something.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUEN, KURT H.
description: GRUEN-Kurt H. The family and friends mourn his passing on Thursday, Jan. 21. Born in Vienna, Austria, a U.S. Army veteran of World War II, he became a Certified Public Accountant servicing many clients and friends. Survived by his companion, Hanna Broz, nieces Yvonne Zaros, Susan Decker, Judy Teilhaber, and Ethel Auerbach, and his grand nieces and grand nephews. Services at Riverside, 180 West 76 Street, (362-6600), Sunday, 12:15 PM.

title: Gingerly, Russia's Premier Tries to Fill Vacuum at Top
description: His boss is back in the hospital, leaving him with most of the work. His budget for 1999 is dismissed as unrealistic, and it doesn't even take into account $8 billion that Russia has already promised not to pay its creditors. The economy is sure to get worse before it gets better, and the International Monetary Fund is still playing hard to get.

title: No Sure Thing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: First Shot Is Fired In Lyme Disease War
description: IN 14 years as a public health nurse for the Dutchess County Health Department, Evelyn Kaufmann spent many days giving talks at campgrounds and schools around the Hudson Valley about avoiding the tiny ticks that carry the bacteria causing Lyme disease.

title: Everyday Art in India
description: THIRTY years ago, the Philadelphia Museum of Art presented a ground-breaking exhibition titled ''Unknown India: Ritual Art in Tribe and Village.'' The show was aptly named.

title: Q. & A.
description: Liability For a Leak In a Co-op

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about a Irina Krush, who recently won the New York City high school chess championship, included several scrambled paragraphs. Readers wishing corrected copies of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or phone (212) 556-1992. E-Mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal return address.)

title: Alumni Can Help
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Social Insecurity in Brazil For Its Government Retirees
description: They have been called ''privilegiados'' who collect lavish pensions and benefits, and portrayed as budgetary vampires who drain the pension system and contribute nothing.

title: The Will to Madness
description: Nietzsche and Wagner

title: South African Assassinated, Raising Fears For Election
description: A high-level official of a South African multiracial political party, the United Democratic Movement, was assassinated today, riddled with bullets as he left a grocery store near his home in a rural area about an hour's drive north of Durban.

title: F.Y.I
description: In the Swim

title: A Club Dies; So Does Part Of Brooklyn
description: ''I feel very melancholy seeing this building,'' Philip F. Stenger, 70, said last week as he regarded the brownstone at 131 Remsen Street, between Clinton and Henry Streets. From 1915 to 1994, it was the home of the Brooklyn Club. Now it is the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue. And the club, which lingered on a few years after the brownstone was sold, is also no more. Members held their last meeting on Dec. 18.

title: A Delicate Family Affair
description: BABY boomers seem to be focused on three economic issues: their homes, their retirements and their children's college educations. But a fourth potential drain on their resources tends to sneak up on them: their parents.

title: A Guru to Wall Street's Gurus
description: Some of the savviest players on Wall Street are paying homage to one of the most popular professors at the Columbia Business School -- by going to his classes. Among those showing up this month for Bruce Greenwald's two-day crash course in value investing were Herbert Allen III, son of Herbert Allen, head of Allen & Company, the investment bank; Michael Overlock, former head of investment banking at Goldman Sachs, and Brad Patelli, a vice president with Angelo Gordon, the arbitrage firm. ''Everyone wanted to take it,'' said Mr. Patelli, who recalled that demand was so strong for the course when he was a student at the school that he couldn't get in.

title: World Team Triumphs
description: The National Hockey League's All-Star weekend began last night with the World team defeating the North Americans, 13-11, in the superskills competition at the Ice Palace in Tampa, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGELBRECHT, FRED
description: ENGELBRECHT-Fred. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Fred Engelbrecht, associated with The Times from 1934, until retiring in 1972.

title: Welfare Aides Inquiry
description: Two child welfare workers from St. Christopher's, a Dobbs Ferry foster care and social services agency, remain suspended without pay while city officials determine whether the workers properly monitored the safety of a 3-year-old Bronx girl who died of head injuries.

title: Network Trading Gains
description: Electronic stock-trading networks that allow investors to buy and sell shares anonymously accounted for 28 percent of all Nasdaq trades in 1998, up from about 24 percent in 1997.

title: In Nod to Burundi, Leaders in Region Suspend Sanctions
description: East African leaders voted today to suspend the economic sanctions they had imposed more than two years ago on Burundi, a tiny nation whose troubles have nonetheless cast a large shadow over the region.

title: Olympics' Salvation Turns Into a Threat
description: When the Los Angeles Olympics made money in 1984, it seemed to have found the answer to the problems that were threatening the future of the Games. But over the next 15 years that process became corrupted to the point that the Games are again at a critical juncture.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: It is well known that Martha Gellhorn was unhappy at being identified in perpetuity as the ex-wife of Ernest Hemingway (''War: From Both Sides,'' by Ward Just). So it is ironic that you chose to print a picture of Gellhorn, alongside Hemingway, smiling and holding a bird and gun. Why not in the field, her own field, holding a pencil and notepad?

title: The Lives They Lived
description: Mae Questel did indeed create ''A Squeak for the Ages'' (by Eric P. Nash), just as my father, Max Fleischer, created an icon for the ages when he created Betty Boop. But Mae's voice was much more than a squeak, just as Betty was much more than an animated cartoon. Together they were a dynamite combination, with Mae's remarkable voice giving a full-blown characterization to Betty Boop's sexy-innocent presence. It's unfortunate that Mae is no longer with us, but Betty Boop, I'm happy to say, is still going strong.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A singularly fine drama about the honing of a combat unit in World War II unfolds admirably in GO FOR BROKE! (1951), written and directed by Robert Pirosh. The only familiar name in the cast is Van Johnson, who plays a prejudiced Texan assigned to train an outfit comprising mostly Japanese-Americans. The picture knowingly underscores the irony of Johnson's leadership and his growing attachment to the men as they enter the combat zone -- Saturday at midnight on Channel 21.

title: Court Rejects Latest Claim Of Incompetence by Gigante
description: A Federal appeals court has rejected the latest claim by the accused mob boss Vincent Gigante that he was incompetent to stand trial, upholding his 1997 racketeering and conspiracy convictions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELMANN, PENELOPE OWENS
description: ADELMANN-Penelope Owens, CFA. Of Scarsdale, NY, on January 21, 2000, of an apparent heart attack. Beloved wife of Richard Adelmann, Ms. Adelmann was born Penelope Mildred Owens in Brooklyn, NY, on October 22, 1944. She was daughter of the late Philip and Virginia Owens. Ms. Adelmann graduated from the Brooklyn Friends School, Swarthmore College and NYU Stern School of Management. She had a diversified career in fashion, sales, securities and finance and served as president of both the NY Society of Securities Analysts and the Fixed Income Analysts Society. Her 20-year Wall Street career included Dean Witter, Nomura Securities, Gruntal and Fahnestock. Recently retired, Ms. Adelmann was exploring volunteer opportunities in Westchester County. In addition to Richard, Ms. Adelmann is survived by three loving sisters, Anne Gilde of Brooklyn, Elizabeth Dean of Wellesley. Mass., and Johanna Owens of Belle Harbor, NY. Memorial services will be held at Scarsdale Congregational Church, 1 Heathcote Road, on Tuesday, January 25 at 4 PM. A reception will follow. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to AmeriCares/Homefront, 161 Cherry St., New Canaan, CT.

title: Make Way For Grown-Ups
description: HEY, gang! Guess what kind of adult entertainment is hot -- and legal -- in New York these days. Give up? It's puppetry. Gaining more respect as an art form, puppetry seems to promise wider audiences, higher esteem and perhaps bigger money for a tight-knit group of city artists.

title: Where Steaks Are the House Specialty
description: IT was 1907 and Oyster Bay's Teddy Roosevelt was President. Nearby in East Norwich, a restaurant called Rothmann's opened. After 63 years of ownership by the Rothmann family, followed by 19 years when it was known as Burt Bachrach's, the restaurant was lovingly restored in 1989 to its early-20th-century mellow elegance. The dining room at that time was aglow with candlelight, sparkling crystal, an Edwardian roast cart and handsome crewel-design wallpaper.

title: Wrongful Death Suit
description: William Campbell, the brother of a man killed in 1986 during a fight over a parking space in a Dobbs Ferry lot, has expanded his Federal civil rights lawsuit to charge that county and municipal officials should have revoked a permit for the gun used to kill Charles Campbell before it was used as a murder weapon.

title: Philanthropic Name Game Threatens the Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, DAVID I.
description: SCHNEIDER-David I. Died January 23, 1999. Beloved father of Rona and Peter. Fond brother of Pearl. Adoring grandfather of Harley and Lauren. Services will be at Riverside; call 212-362-6600 for information.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRAUM, STANLEY E.
description: TRAUM-Stanley E. January 27, 1998. We miss you more each day. Take care of Mom. Love, Elaine, Howard, Amy and Davi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, MURRAY
description: JACOBS-Murray. Of Forest Hills, N.Y., and Princeton, NJ. Executive Officer of Celebration Trading, Inc., passed away peacefully at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, on January 22nd, leaving his beloved wife Eleanor, his devoted daughter Arlene, and son-in-law Henry Opatut, loving grandchildren Jessica & Daniel, and brother Zigmund Jacobs. A Holocaust survivor, concert violinist, and designer, known & loved in the Garment District for almost fifty years. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be sent to The Dysautonomia Foundation, 20 East 46 St., New York, NY 10017. Funeral will be held on Sunday, January 24th at 2 P.M. at The Jewish Center of Princeton, 435 Nassau Street, Princeton, New Jersey.

title: Social Security Plan Is Too Timid
description: To the Editor:

title: Imitating Thoreau in More Than One Way
description: Ah! The simplicity and quietude of Henry David Thoreau's cabin on Walden Pond, a retreat from the commercial rat race of the mid-1800's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORPE, DR. ROBERT G.
description: THORPE-Dr. Robert G. Loving husband of wife June, daughters Susan and Katherine. Devoted to his profession and patients for over fifty years.

title: SUPER BOWL XXXIII: A Rivalry Beyond the Game; Rift Makes Reeves and Shanahan More Competitive
description: That Dan Reeves and Mike Shanahan dislike each other is no exaggeration. It is a feud with an intensity that is rarely seen in the stoic coaching world of the National Football League. But instead of consuming the two men, as such emotions can sometimes do, this feud has created one of the strangest rivalries in sports.

title: On Language; Swift on Censure
description: What about censure? in the weeks after House impeachment of the President, censure promptly rented space in the halfway house between Senate conviction and acquittal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAYER, JEAN
description: BAYER-Jean. Died January 20 in her 100th year. Devoted and cherished sister, sister-in-law, aunt, great aunt and great-great aunt. She was very special and we will miss her.

title: January 17-23; An On-Line Auction With Cachet
description: The name Sotheby's usually brings to mind a collector snatching up a multimillion dollar artwork with the flick of a wooden paddle. Not any longer. Sotheby's announced it would join the Internet auction craze. At first, only items valued at less than $10,000 will be offered on the Internet www.sothebys.com but prices will climb once the technology allows close inspection of the merchandise.

title: Down But Not Out on the Family Farm
description: IN the last days of 1998, W. Michael Bennett, a citrus grower and cattle rancher in California's San Joaquin Valley, began a frenzied race against the thermometer.

title: STORM SPARED TOURISM AREAS
description: HURRICANE MITCH has come and gone, but the damage wrought by the most devastating natural disaster to strike Central America this century will take years to repair. The pattern of destruction throughout the region was capricious, however, meaning that some areas were pummeled while others were barely touched, if at all. So here is a quick assessment for potential visitors:

title: Compensation Growing From Top to Bottom
description: You have a 50-50 chance of getting a salary increase of 4 percent or more this year, according to Watson Wyatt Worldwide, a compensation company based in Bethesda, Md.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Same Gasoline Provider, Why Different Prices?
description: The prices for gasoline in the East end towns were described in an article on Jan. 10 [''As Gas Prices Fall, East End Feels Left Out'']. As a homeowner and resident of both East Hampton and Great Neck, I consider the differential in prices for gasoline to be price gouging. I have noticed a pattern to the differential in gasoline prices. If the price at the Hess station on Route 39 in Southampton is $1.169 per gallon, the price at the Hess station between Water Mill and Bridgehampton on Route 27 will be $1.199 and the price in Wainscott on Route 27 will be $1.229. The price in Wainscott is always six cents higher than the price on Route 39. It should also be noted that the price in Wainscott is always 16 cents higher than the price at the Hess station on Northern Boulevard in Great Neck. Moreover, the Hess stations in Southampton and East Hampton are self service, while the lower gasoline price at the Hess station in Great Neck is given with service.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: CONFESSIONS OF A LATE NIGHT

title: A Place To Please The Techies
description: AFTER just three years, the founders of the hot high-technology start-up were bumping against a familiar problem. They knew they had maxed out the potential of the backwater burg where they had founded the company. To keep attracting the number and caliber of skilled employees they needed, they had to move the company to where the action was.

title: Editorial Observer; Washington Brags as Trade Deficit Sets a Record
description: ''The chief business of the American people,'' said Calvin Coolidge, ''is business.''

title: Young's Legacy
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Former Workers Demand Jobs at Rainbow Room
description: When the Rainbow Room closed a month ago, New Yorkers lost a glittering and much loved nightspot, and 250 workers lost their union jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAEL, DONALD J.
description: MICHAEL-Donald J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Donald J. Michael, associated with The Times from 1967.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, TILLIE
description: EPSTEIN-Tillie. On January 23, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Rabbi Isaac Epstein. Devoted and beloved mother of Irving and Ina Epstein, and Harry and Grace Epstein. Cherished grandmother of Douglas, Jeffrey, Elyse, Allison and Audrey. Her life was an inspiration for values and faith. Graveside services Sunday, Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY. For information call Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 516-487-9600.

title: January 17-23; Differences in Cancer Rates
description: At a time when cancer death rates are generally falling, different ethnic groups and the poor are more prone to certain cancers and less likely to survive, says an expert committee from the Institute of Medicine.

title: No Innovator
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Steal This Painting
description: THE MUSIC LESSON

title: Jewel of a Shiraz; Starbright Pinot Grigio
description: Banrock Station shiraz (also known as syrah), a southeastern Australian jewel, has quietly and unsurprisingly acquired a cultish status. This delicious red resembles an earthy black- and red-berry compote. Smooth, svelte, fleshy, it delivers a vein of startling anise-like flavor, enhanced by sweet oak, when lingering on the palate. Lovely.

title: In Sag Harbor, a Traffic Roundabout Uproar
description: ONE of the classic problems of suburbia is traffic. There is too much of it and it is often moving too fast. But when the village of Sag Harbor tried to do its part in at least slowing it down, officials instead inflamed hundreds of residents, creating a rare controversy in this village of 2,100.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: A few years ago, when Frank Sinatra produced his ''Duets'' album, I wondered what all the fuss was about (''Sinatra Generations,'' by Rich Brown). After all, I had been singing duets with him (sometimes silently, sometimes aloud) for more than 50 years. You probably did too. Now, ''the Voice'' is silenced. We can still listen to his recordings, but somehow it's not the same. For now at least, it's hard to hear his voice and not think sadly about those lovely romantic days ''Long Ago and Far Away.''

title: A Divided Iraq May Not Be Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAKOW, RUTH CEDAR
description: LAKOW-Ruth Cedar, widow of Monroe Lakow, beloved mother of Ellen Lakow Georgiou, loving grandmother of Alexis Georgiou. Services today 3PM Gramercy Park Memorial Chpl 152 2 Av NY

title: Police Shootings Bring Call For Thorough Investigation
description: A coalition of churches, community groups and African-American organizations is urging a thorough investigation of the recent shootings of two young black men by the police at the Park Hill apartment complex on Staten Island.

title: Addiction Counselor Is Held on Drug Charge
description: An addiction counselor at Harlem Hospital Center was arrested Friday afternoon after police officers conducting a drug surveillance behind the hospital saw him carrying a bag of what appeared to be marijuana out the back door, the police said.

title: Dreaming the Impossible Dream
description: In 1999, things will be different: You will carry out your New Year's resolution to advance your career or resolve a workplace conflict. Well, maybe. But what about past years? How close did you come to meeting a work-related goal that you set for yourself in January? Or, how did your efforts go awry?

title: The Nation: Testimonial; Time Frees the Hollywood One
description: ON an evening this March, the ailing, 89-year-old Elia Kazan, one of America's greatest film and theatrical directors, is scheduled to receive an honorary Oscar at the 71st annual Academy Awards. It will not only crown Mr. Kazan's career but, in many ways, spell the end of the tormented legacy of the Hollywood blacklist.

title: U.S. JUDGE ORDERS LEWINSKY TO MEET WITH HOUSE TEAM
description: President Clinton's impeachment trial was thrown into turmoil today, after a Federal judge ordered Monica S. Lewinsky to submit to questioning from House Republican prosecutors or the independent counsel's office, and Senate Republicans said they would query the President in writing.

title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; A Le Corbusier Vision Blurred Over Time
description: THE city of Chandigarh owes its existence to India's first Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru. With Pakistan inheriting Lahore, capital of the truncated state of Punjab, after India's 1947 partition, Nehru decided to locate the world's finest architect to design a capital for the remaining portion of Punjab. By 1950 the choice had fallen to the controversial Swiss-born Le Corbusier, a resident of Paris since 1916.

title: Despite Several Rule Changes, It's Getting Tougher to Score in the N.H.L.
description: When North America plays the World in the National Hockey League All-Star Game today in Tampa, Fla., the two high-powered teams might combine for 15 goals, the way they did last season. They might even score 22 goals, as they did in 1993, the most ever. Even with Dominik Hasek of Buffalo starting in goal for the World, a shutout -- even for one period -- is unlikely.

title: Hitting Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki Sets Up Panel to Probe Schools in City
description: Voicing scorn for the performance of New York City education officials, Gov. George E. Pataki appointed a special state commission yesterday to investigate wrongdoing in the construction of the city's public schools and accusations that some administrators inflated student attendance to reap more government aid.

title: Fatalism of the Greeks, Transplanted to Ireland
description: REJOICE with Emily Mann in winning a real second stage for the McCarter Theater here. But that opening is two years away. In the meantime, Ms. Mann is not an artistic director who waits. To attend ''Portia Coughlan'' now, on the McCarter's makeshift second stage, is to rejoice, as the actors' mantra goes, ''in the moment.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIVOWITZ, ABE
description: PIVOWITZ-Abe. January 2, 1999 in Lake Placid, NY, age 78. A journalist and a quixotic, loveable man. Belden R. Merims

title: January 17-23; No Choking, We're Knicks
description: Some fans claimed they would cancel their season tickets, wondering aloud if the franchise had sold its soul for a shot at a championship. Others were ecstatic to learn that one of the National Basketball Association's most talented players was coming to New York.

title: Imagination That Transcends Expectations
description: GEORGE BERNARD SHAW once described Vancouver as ''the pick of Canada,'' and even his caustic fellow wordsmith Dylan Thomas, in a letter to his wife, called it ''a quite handsome hellhole.'' But a metropolis of dance? Home to an internationally ambitious ballet company?

title: A Push to Reorder Sciences Puts Physics First
description: For generations of high school students, the sequence of science has been a given: 9th-grade biology, 10th-grade chemistry and, for the minority who make it that far, 11th-grade physics.

title: EXPLORING BELIZE'S LUSH LANDSCAPES
description: KINKAJOUS and coatis, trogons and motmots -- the fanciful names of the birds and mammals of Belize intrigued me, sounding more like creatures from Lewis Carroll's imagination than real animals. Add to that visions of the Caribbean Sea lapping at the edges of a secretive jungle, and I felt compelled to visit the country. These exotic images of Belize had grown during a long New York winter when I frequently logged onto www.belizenet.com, a Web site with links for everything Belizean. In early April, when I discovered that my frequent-flier miles could get me to Central America, I grabbed a week's vacation in the Placentia district, a skinny peninsula jutting out halfway down the coastline.

title: Correction
description: An answer in the Q&A Column last Sunday about whether a landlord is required to add a spouse's name to a rent-stabilized tenant's lease misstated the legal requirements. The New York City Rent Stabilization Code indeed requires that a spouse's name be added to a lease, if the apartment is the spouse's primary residence.

title: Cleveland Plays Host To a Mexican Firebrand
description: Colorful, political, sophisticated and larger than life -- Diego Rivera was all those things. So was his art, as ''Diego Rivera: Art and Revolution'' makes clear. The exhibition of more than 120 paintings and drawings by Mexico's most celebrated artist begins a four-city yearlong tour on Feb. 14 at the Cleveland Museum of Art.

title: Amid Serene Natural Beauty, A Residue of Brutal Trauma
description: ON the fringe of Vancouver's junkie-ridden, impoverished inner city, Stan Douglas makes art that speaks of failure.

title: Funk Leads, but Others Are Following Closely
description: Fred Funk left the course today as the leader of the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic, but he did not leave very happy. After building a three-stroke lead, Funk bogeyed two of his final five holes. So instead of heading into Sunday's final round with a cushion, Funk will have a one-stroke edge and a host of competitors in pursuit.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: As a baby boomer, now approaching 52, I was one of those who was glued to the television watching ''Howdy Doody'' and Shari Lewis, as my mother cooked a brisket of beef in the kitchen (''Stand-In Parents,'' by Steven D. Stark). One of my fondest childhood recollections was the day that I searched the Peanut Gallery looking for my best friend, who was to receive her free loaf of Wonder Bread for being a participant that day.

title: The Boss From Purgatory
description: LOUSEBy David Grand.255 pp. New York:Arcade Publishing. $23.95.

title: Nice
description: The brightly tinted Baroque buildings, the turquoise waters of the Baie des Anges and the riotous profusion of flowers in the Cours Saleya market provide Nice with more than enough local color. But Nice's 115th organized Carnival, Feb. 13 to 28, promises to be one of the best two-week parties this vibrant Provencal city has ever seen.

title: RECORDINGS; A DJ Who Turns the Uncool Into Cool
description: FATBOY SLIM: 'YOU'VE COME A LONG WAY, BABY'Astralwerks, CD, ASW 66247-2.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: DANIEL DEFOE

title: A Different Look At World Danger Spots
description: Air Security International, a 10-year-old Houston company that provides security services for traveling executives -- keeping them out of trouble if possible, and trying to get them out of it if not -- has issued a list of what it considers the most dangerous business-travel destinations in the world last year. The company's listing of travel dangers is slightly different from the State Department's, according to a company spokeswoman, Kimberley Williams, though both attempt to evaluate the same kinds of safety and crime issues. Air Security's list is largely based on the detailed reports of paid agents -- including employees of airports and international corporations, and owners of overseas businesses -- working in the field.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WHITE, NATHANIEL (NAT)
description: WHITE-Nathaniel (Nat). July 26, 1913 to January 24, 1993. Forever the wind beneath my wings. Lovingly, Elino

title: Hating Hamlet, Loving Theater
description: THEATER has become more elusive on the Island in the last two decades. The nearness of Broadway's brassy and Off Broadway's brainier fare diminishes the chances for professional theater here. Call it geographical truth; call it snobbism. Come to the suburbs for better living, but not for culture: that's the attitude. And don't forget changing times, changing values and ever-present apathy. All have dealt death blows to Equity theater on the Island, especially in Nassau County.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENEDETTO, MARY MAGDALEN
description: BENEDETTO-Mary Magdalen. On January 22, 2000. Retired Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. Loving sister of Jessie. Mass of the Resurrection, Monday, 11 AM, at Church of the Epiphany (22nd St. and 2nd Ave.). Interment private.

title: Undefeated UConn Topples Seton Hall
description: No dramatic comeback was necessary. Nor was there any heart-stopping shot at the buzzer in overtime like the one that could have ended top-ranked Connecticut's unbeaten streak at Miami on Wednesday.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 27 about preparations in Greenwich, England, for the Millennium misidentified the architect responsible for a pedestrian tunnel under the Thames. He was Alexander Binnie, not Isambard Brunel.

title: The Study of Gene Machines, In Situ
description: THERE has been much talk recently about genes, gene pools and the preservation of biological diversity -- all in the context of the preservation of known species and protection of future ones.

title: In the Chamber
description: Representative Lindsay O. Graham, a House impeachment manager, said before voting to convict the President, senators must ''consider what's best for the nation,'' in the most dramatic moment of the second and last day of questioning.

title: Toledo Guard Cannot Play
description: In a severe case of out of sight, out of mind, Major League Baseball and its member teams have suffered a collective lapse of memory since the celebration 21 months ago of the 50th anniversary of Jackie Robinson's barrier-breaking exploits.

title: Seton Hall Prep Trumps Top-Rated St. Patrick's
description: As they walked onto the floor for the fourth quarter tonight, the Seton Hall Prep players could feel the pressure. They trailed by 5 points against St. Patrick's, not just the No. 1-ranked team in New Jersey, but also the team that had handed the Pirates two of their three losses last season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIMETZ, GERTRUDE
description: NIMETZ-Gertrude. On January 23, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Oscar Nimetz. Loving mother of Michael Nimetz. Devoted sister of Sam and the late Al, Nathan and Ruth. Visiting hours Tuesday, 10 AM-12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: He's at Home In the Pulpit, Wherever It Is
description: EVER since the civil rights movement forged the link between the black church and the world of politics, many African American preachers have found it to be a good policy to keep one eye on their flocks and the other on what the local politicians were up to.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHALLIS, MARK
description: CHALLIS-Mark. Unparalleled in your qualities as a professional, unsurpassed as a person, Mark, you will be greatly missed. Our condolences to the entire Challis family. Robert Freedman, Eugene DeGidio, Mitchell Berg, Debbie Garrett and the entire staff of Maxwell-Kates

title: For 134 Years, Jersey City Puts Politics Aside and Honors Lincoln
description: Six score and 13 years ago, city fathers here brought forth a new custom, an annual dinner, conceived in sorrow over the assassination of a President and dedicated to his memory.

title: When the Government Plays Investor
description: BY investing $700 billion of the Social Security trust fund's reserves in the stock market, President Clinton hopes to generate enough high-voltage returns to keep the fund solvent into the next century. Alas, the way he wants to do it almost insures failure.

title: Finding Order Amid the Chaos
description: MY recent trip from Switzerland to the Ivory Coast brought back the memory of going from Minneapolis to Manhattan nearly 20 years ago. Back then I was a young, inexperienced magazine writer whose idea of diversity came from listening to Garrison Keillor describe the difference between Lake Wobegon and ''The City.''

title: The Maestro Who Made the Philadelphians Fabulous
description: A SPECIAL fascination applies to the Philadelphia Orchestra concert this week at Carnegie Hall. The orchestra is looking for its next music director, and many believe that Sir Simon Rattle, the conductor on Tuesday evening, is the candidate of choice. Not only is Sir Simon youthful and gifted; in England, where he put the City of Birmingham Symphony on the map, he vitalized an entire cultural community. His appeal transcended the fraying boundaries of high culture. And he sharpened and heightened the orchestra's profile beyond recognition.

title: Doomsday Machines
description: Soon the turn of the millennium will come and go, and historians of technology will look back at the year 2000 computer problem -- the Y2K ''crisis,'' as this newspaper and many others now call it. They will draw from it a salutary lesson: we are a silly species, easily confused and given to sudden fits of hysteria.

title: Takeout Shop With a Russian Accent
description: On an inconspicuous street in lower Manhattan sits R. J. Max Fine Foods, a recently opened takeout, delivery and catering business that is owned by Roman Dashevsky and Roman Lozovsky, who are brothers-in-law. Situated at 55 Ann Street (between Nassau and William Streets), the two men offer breakfast, lunch and dinner to the weekday Wall Street crowd and cater parties and corporate events. Mr. Dashevsky, the chef, is trained in Russian and French cooking. He has owned La Petite Maison Russe in Woodmere, N.Y., as well as a catering company on the Upper East Side with Mr. Lozovsky. The menu, a fusion of international styles, includes harcho, a spicy Georgian soup prepared with lamb and served with country bread ($3.75); a daily roast special, either pork, veal or baby chicken, served with a vegetable, potato or rice ($6.50 to $9), or salmon coulibiac, with the fish served in a mushroom-and-dill sauce and wrapped in a pastry ($9). Tarts, pies and cakes ($2 to $3.50) are all made daily on the premises.

title: In the Region / New Jersey; A Rush to Build Assisted-Living Residences
description: LITTLE known in New Jersey just three and a half years ago, assisted-living residences -- offering the frail but ambulatory elderly housing, social services and health care -- are blossoming throughout the state.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 17 of the Arts & Leisure section today, with an article about the director JoAnne Akalaitis, misspells the given name of an actress in the 1993 Lincoln Center Theater production of ''In the Summer House.'' She is Dianne Wiest, not Diane.

title: Rap Artist Released on Bail in Shooting Case
description: A rap artist with the Wu-Tang Clan was released from jail on Friday after posting $150,000 bail on charges that he opened fire on police officers in Brooklyn a week earlier, city correction officials said.

title: Carnegie's Stage
description: To the Editor:

title: Hartford Lawsuit Recounts the Brief Shelf Life of a TV Anchorwoman
description: She was the blond, green-eyed ''Action News'' anchor who brought Hollywood sizzle to Connecticut television, racking up top ratings and zipping around town in a red Jaguar. Rival stations warred over her services, driving her yearly salary to $250,000 in the nation's 27th largest television market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRENDERGAST, JOHN W.
description: PRENDERGAST-John W. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Flushing, New York, Wednesday, January 20, 1999. Beloved husband of Catherine, devoted father of Mark. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason, 149-20 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, NY. Mass of Christian burial St. Andrew Avellino R.C. Church, 10:15AM Monday. Visiting hours Sunday 2-5 P.M.

title: POSTINGS: Redoing 55 Church St. in White Plains; High Tech In Westchester
description: Taking a cue from the successful Plug 'n' Go program in lower Manhattan, where older buildings have been rewired for high-technology needs, the owner of one of the older buildings in White Plains has decided to turn it into a high-technology center, complete with high-speed phone lines and expanded electrical capacity.

title: Next Time, Eat the Pizza After the Interview
description: Clean your fingernails. Make sure no food is stuck between your teeth. Polish your shoes. And your resume.

title: Barnes & Noble Merger Endangers Publishers, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A/John Rasmus; Out of the Armchairs, Into Adventures
description: MAYBE you do not want to get in a hot air balloon and try to circle the globe. Maybe you want to take a rain check on exploring the deepest reaches of the ocean or the outer realms of the universe. In any case the National Geographic Society thinks you may want to read about it.

title: Nancy Beth Stone And David Levine
description: Nancy Beth Stone, the daughter of Judith Stone of Ossining, N.Y., and Michael A. Stone of New York, was married last evening to David Louis Levine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Levine of New York. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum officiated at the Mark Hotel in New York.

title: The Music Endures
description: To the Editor:

title: Social Security Plan Is Too Timid
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYERSON, CHESTER D.
description: MAYERSON-Chester D. Beloved husband of Edith Rosoff Mayerson, of Rancho Palos Verdes, California. Loving father and grandfather. Also survived by his brother, Kenneth and sister, Barbara Perlman. Services were held in Los Angeles, California.

title: A Cerebral Modernist Whose Revolution Rolls On
description: ON a recent frigid afternoon in Manhattan, Agamemnon's hand was bothering the director JoAnne Akalaitis. To be more precise, what concerned her was the obscene gesture that the actor Jack Willis had been using, at her instruction, to punctuate a line from ''Iphigenia at Aulis.''

title: Social Security Plan Is Too Timid
description: To the Editor:

title: Bitter Feud Over Ruling
description: As the trial of President Clinton moved toward a critical set of votes next week, the Senate's spirit of fragile bipartisanship frayed nearly to the breaking point today and a party-line vote looked almost certain to kill a Democratic motion to dismiss the case.

title: The Labor Behind Idyllic Connecticut
description: NORTHWESTERN Connecticut presents an idyllic picture: village greens, white churches and stone walls. But such beauty comes at a price that is rarely acknowledged; if drivers slow down a bit they cannot help but notice that the workers rebuilding the centuries-old walls appear to be Central Americans. And along the roads are others, mostly wearing the uniforms of maids and dishwashers, making their daily hikes to inns and restaurants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CITRONBAUM, EUGENE
description: CITRONBAUM-Eugene. Classical trumpet player of great beauty, succumbed to lung cancer January 19. Mourned by family-mother Lillian Mininberg Citronbaum and brother Ronald Citron-and his many friends. His musical and personal presence will be missed. Memorial service on Monday, January 25, 7PM in the Chapel of Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Avenue, Bronx, New York. Contributions in his name can be sent to a charity of choice.

title: Check for Heaving; Ready Seed Orders
description: With heavy snows, then rain and springlike temperatures, some bulbs may be pushing up from the ground. Don't panic: the edges of these early leaves may burn, but flower buds are still protected. If small perennials and new plantings have been heaved up by the freezing and thawing, push them back down and firm up the soil around them. Make sure mulches are still in place.

title: Squall Lines
description: Small Craft Warnings

title: SOAPBOX; Taking Place
description: I MOVED to Washington, D.C., 20 years ago, right after my college graduation. At the time, I was engaging in active, intimate correspondence, via the nearly obsolete method now known as snail mail, with several former classmates about the many major life-defining moments we were all having. With all the precipitate profundity of 22 years, one of my friends wrote to me: ''What does happiness have to do with it? We won't be happy for at least 15-20 years -- when we're tired and have no choice.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENWALD, RUTH ISRAELS
description: ROSENWALD-Ruth Israels. On January 21, 1999, at her residence in Manhattan, at age 85. Daughter of Henry Goldstein, died 1953, and Elizabeth Traurig Goldstein, died 1985. Widow of Carlos Lindner Israels, died 1969, and William Rosenwald, died 1996. Mother of Michael Jozef Israels. Mother-inlaw of Maija-Sarmite Jansons. Grandmother of Aleksandrs Lehman Israels & Peter Carlos Israels. Stepmother of Nina Rosenwald, Elizabeth R. Varet and Alice R. Sigelman. Memorial Service Tuesday, January 26. 1999, at 12 Noon at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave & 65 St., New York. In lieu of flowers, the family request contributions either to: Congregation EmanueEl of the City of New York, or the Israels Family Fund, at Amherst College, Amherst, Mass.

title: King Hussein Stuns Jordan With Plan to Switch Heirs
description: King Hussein of Jordan is preparing to select one of his sons as his heir, Jordanian officials said today, culminating a dizzying week in which the King returned from six months of cancer treatment abroad and then dismissed his brother as Crown Prince.

title: Social Security Plan Is Too Timid
description: To the Editor:

title: A Diet of Discipline
description: The bacon is crackling and popping in the frying pan, and the man who looks carved out of a sequoia is feeling weak. But Larry Johnson has two sons sitting at the kitchen table like puppies waiting for a treat, so he keeps flipping the bacon as his mouth waters and his stomach mourns for the good old days.

title: Chamber Music Recitals
description: THE first of three recitals in the second season of Chamber Music Westchester begins today at 4 P.M. -- or 3:30 for those who attend a preconcert lecture by harpsichordist, Gerald Ranck.

title: Crime
description: Jonathan Kellerman's singular touch with wounded children pays off royally in BILLY STRAIGHT (Random House, $25.95), a brisk suspense thriller unburdened by his smug shrink hero, Alex Delaware (who makes the briefest of cameo appearances here). By comparison, Kellerman's new protagonist, a Hollywood homicide detective named Petra Connor, might seem bland, but she is blessedly free of affectation. She is also warmhearted enough to identify with, as she frantically scours the city in search of a runaway 12-year-old boy who witnessed the vicious stabbing of a woman in Griffith Park. This case quickly draws the media carrion crows when it comes out that the victim was recently divorced from the popular star of a television series.

title: A Divided Iraq May Not Be Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTINE, MELVIN
description: BERNSTINE-Melvin, MD, died January 15, 1999 after a long and happy life. He was surrounded by a loving family and dear friends. Beloved husband of Gloria for 47 years, loving father of Melvin, Jr and Jack. Dear brother of Richard Bernstine, MD. He was an attending Anesthesiologist and head of Regional Anesthesia at Saint Vincents Hospital and Medical Center. He served in the U.S. Navy during W.W. II and The Korean War. Interment private. Memorial service to held at a later date.

title: This White Knight Is Known as Chocolate Cat
description: There was the search for the identity of The Scarlet Pimpernel. People always wondered who the Lone Ranger was. And in this picturesque college town, there is the mystery of the Chocolate Cat.

title: Lend Him a Tenor? Not in This Opera
description: MUSIC composed by Philip Glass calls for visual enhancement. His concert works of the early 1970's seemed mostly defiant, but when he began adding visual aspects, his steady rhythms, rolling chords and haunting harmonies made the big leagues.

title: Over the River And to the Food
description: CHRISTOS HASAPO-TAVERNA +

title: Resistance to Argentine 'Dollar'
description: The Argentine Government's announcement this week that it would consider replacing its peso with the dollar over the next several years has soothed the concerns of international investors that Argentina might follow Brazil's example and devalue its currency.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Volvo S80; Best Solo Performance; Next, a Supporting Role?
description: PRESS kits, the glossy bundles of information that car manufacturers send to journalists, are typically triumphal documents, harking sales records broken and heralding new products born. Somewhere in the files I am sure there is a press packet that begins, ''It promises to be another banner year for Yugo.''

title: Edgar Nollner, 94, Dies; Hero in Epidemic
description: It was one of the great cliffhangers of the 20th century, one that held a nation in white-knuckled thrall for more than a week in 1925 as the world wondered whether a supply of life-saving serum would make it to icebound Nome, Alaska, in time to save the town's 1,429 residents from a raging diphtheria epidemic.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: MUSEUM

title: Paths of Glory
description: To the Editor:

title: The Night the Girls Went Out to Play (and the Boys Ran Away)
description: MY answering machine heard it first: ''Hi! I'm Lucy's maid of honor. She said the party's up to us, but she definitely wants to kiss some boys in a bar, and she also wants a stripper, so we're all chipping in to get him.''

title: The Lives They Lived
description: In response to Stephen Mihm's Endpaper on Henny Youngman (''Take My Wife''): I laughed so hard that I cried. Or did I cry so hard that I laughed?

title: Fear of Flying
description: ANGELS & ALIENS

title: JUNE KLEIN
description: It's a jumble in there, but the contents of June Klein's green canvas shoulder bag have a collective purpose: her mobility.

title: An Evening of Breath Mints, Cocktails and Art
description: THE SETTING -- The Bowery Ballroom, on Delancey Street, where some 200 artists, gallery owners and candy company executives attended a preview of the Altoids Curiously Strong Collection of Art on Wednesday night. Sponsored by Callard & Bowser-Suchard, the British candy maker owned by the Philip Morris Companies, the show highlighted 20 artists who presumably are poised to bring a breath mint of fresh air to the art world.

title: Judgment Day
description: Almost exactly a year after the nation first heard the name Monica Lewinsky, the scandal that bears her name is at a decisive juncture. In proposing to offer a motion tomorrow to end the impeachment trial of Bill Clinton, Senator Robert Byrd offered the Senate a just way to bring this tormented case to a close. The House managers' sudden move to interview Ms. Lewinsky with the help of Kenneth Starr was just what it looked like -- a desperate move to energize a flagging case. It was also a brazen attempt by the House prosecutors to hijack control of the trial from the senators and Chief Justice.

title: January 17-23; An Update on Fiber
description: Turning conventional dietary wisdom on its head, a team of Boston researchers announced that eating fiber does not prevent colon cancer. Their 16-year study of more than 88,000 female nurses found that women who ate a diet rich in fruits, vegetables and whole grains were no less likely than others to develop the disease.

title: Baby Cakes Grow Up
description: ''A lot of customers claim they're buying them for the child in the stroller,'' said David Starr, the vice president of Ecce Panis, a bakery chain. ''Usually the kid ends up with the biscotti, while the mother eats the cupcake.''

title: POSTINGS: Photo Exhibition at Museum of the City of New York; 'Landscapes of Hope': Before and After
description: Trees had taken root inside the gutted old building on Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section, their limbs seeking light through hollow-stare windows. Soot and grime caked crumbling brickwork.

title: Can Kellogg Break Out Of the Box?
description: THE Kellogg Company has been scrambling to revive its stagnant breakfast business, but its approach so far has been about as successful as trying to freshen soggy cereal by pouring on more milk.

title: Jumpin' Jade Flash
description: Jade Jagger has never even touched the white Saint Laurent smoking suit her mother, Bianca, famously wore to marry her father, Mick, in 1971. ''My mother was always very strict about her clothes,'' she explains. Less so Mick, to whom she promised that she ''wouldn't do anything stupid'' if he would lend her some favorite old glam-tock pieces to fool around with for the photographs.

title: Naturalist Keeps an Eye on Eagles, in Trees, in the Air, on the Ground
description: For the 229 bald eagles that Libby Mills counted today, the eight-mile stretch of the Skagit River between here and Marblemount is the four-star, all-you-can-eat sushi bar of Washington's waterways.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESER, SR. JULIA MARIE
description: WESER-Sr. Julia Marie. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity, educator and professor at the College of Mt. St. Vincent died on January 22, 1999. Survived by several cousins. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark St., Yonkers, NY on Monday, 1-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 9:30 AM at the convent. Interment St. Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Ave., Bronx, NY 10471.

title: Unnatural Selection
description: MR. DARWIN'S SHOOTER

title: Coaches on the Move In Turnaround Game
description: Only an hour after Brian Billick was hired as the coach of the Baltimore Ravens last Tuesday, he was on his way to Mobile, Ala., for a week of Senior Bowl practices. There were also interviews with assistant coaching candidates because he has a staff to assemble.

title: Commercial Property/Times Square; New Hotels Are Finding a Home on 42d Street
description: HOTEL owners in New York City make three times more profit for each room than the national average, according to an analysis by the accounting and consulting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers. The annual income after operating expenses for each room was $32,008 in New York compared to $10,100 for the rest of the nation.

title: Bibliotheca And Bibelots to Go
description: Though mainly in the borrow-and-return business, the Central Library in Jamaica, Queens, opened the Queens Library Gift Shop last month, where customers don't need circulation privileges to buy a variety of books, tote bags, stationery, stuffed animals, bookmarks and other items. The shop is next to the main entrance, at 89-11 Merrick Boulevard (between 89th and 90th Avenues). Library officials said all profits would be used for cultural programs. Open Mondays through Fridays, noon to 6 P.M., and Saturdays, noon to 5 P.M. (718) 990-0700. ALEXANDRA McGINLEY

title: Surf Sleuthing: How to Find the Plants You Want
description: ORDINARILY, I'm a gardener of little design. The vegetables get some advance planning, because otherwise I might forget I had already sowed the beets and plant the beans right over the top of them.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: LEONARDO'S NEPHEWEssays on Art and Artists.By James Fenton.Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.

title: Jay Pritzker, Billionaire Who Founded the Hyatt Hotel Chain, Is Dead at 76
description: Jay Pritzker, whose hunch in the 1950's that America's restless business executives would flock to hotels near airports prompted him to build the Hyatt hotel chain, died yesterday of cardiac arrest at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. Mr. Pritzker, who had a history of heart trouble, was 76.

title: 12 School-Meet Records Set
description: Anthony Ewers and Jason Morgan of Lawrence, N.Y., led 12 meet-record performances yesterday in the New York Hispanic Games at the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan. More than 4,000 boys and girls from 161 high schools in the East competed.

title: The Nation: Thanks, but I'll Have the Strip-Search; No Takers for the X-Ray Option
description: IT seemed to officials of the United States Customs Service like a good idea, no doubt. When Customs inspectors became suspicious that someone was trying to smuggle drugs or other contraband into the country, they would offer a choice: a conventional strip-search or an X-ray.

title: Albright Starts Visit to Moscow as Russia's Wariness Grows
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright embarks Sunday on a trip to a weakened but obstinate Russia, with little expectation on either side that much will improve in a relationship plagued by disagreement on everything from Russia's economic collapse to air strikes against Iraq.

title: Habitats/East 57th Street; You Can Go Home Again
description: FOR 15 years, Shirley Light was exiled from New York. She edits books for scientists, and when her employer, Academic Press, decided to move to Orlando, Fla., she had to relocate too.

title: The Millennium Glitch, and Life and Death
description: As a nurse turned computer systems manager, Laureen West is one of a crowd of consultants able to describe how year-2000 computer malfunctions could interrupt the distribution of medicines. But as a brain tumor patient who needs daily doses of synthetic-thyroid and other drugs to stay alive, the 43-year-old Mrs. West has no rivals when it comes to convincing listeners that it matters.

title: Paths of Glory
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region / Connecticut; New Powers for Towns to Protect Neighborhoods
description: THREE months ago the General Assembly passed the Connecticut Village Districts Act, an amendment to the state zoning statutes that allows municipalities to greatly strengthen the roles of their zoning bodies. The action has pleased preservationists and planning and zoning commissions, but has troubled many builders, real estate professionals and architects.

title: The Case of the Falling Mannequin
description: When the giant advertisement for Fila sportswear was being painted on the building wall facing Houston Street between Crosby Street and Broadway, passers-by were at first perplexed by the image: a sheer cliff rising out of a misty valley. The Fila logo and the slogan ''Change the game,'' only added to the mystery. Then a three-dimensional mannequin in climbing gear was hung from the painted rock, and the advertisement made sense.

title: Social Security Plan Is Too Timid
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: A Burgundian Treat

title: Q & A
description: Walking in Wales

title: Quietly, a Team of Lawyers Kept Paula Jones's Case Alive
description: This time last year, Hillary Rodham Clinton described, in a now-famous appearance on the NBC News program ''Today,'' how a ''vast right-wing conspiracy'' was trying to destroy her husband's Presidency.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: South Korea's Mood Swings From Bleak to Bullish
description: The dance floor shakes as dozens of couples wiggle to the blaring music, while others snuggle with glasses of Korean whiskey -- bought by the bottle -- on the soft blue couches of the upscale Basquia nightclub.

title: 'Reasonable People' Can Differ On Penalty, a Prosecutor Says
description: One of the leading members of the Republican prosecution conceded today that even if the Senate thought President Clinton was guilty of perjury, ''reasonable people'' among its members could disagree on whether he should be removed from office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, MURIEL
description: BRENNER-Muriel. We mourn the loss of our dearest friend, although gone, but never forgotten. Heartfelt sympathy to William and the family. Martha and Effrem Arenstein

title: Cool Awards, Chilly Audience
description: Cool Awards, Chilly Audience

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENHERZ, ALFRED
description: LOWENHERZ-Alfred, died on January 21. He leaves a loving sister Lisel, son Jack and daughterin-law Lila, and grandchildren Mark and Jennifer. An expert in photography and its history, he will be missed by his many camera comrades. At his wish, there will be no services.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: A special table was reserved at the Friars Club for Henny Youngman. When he invited you as his guest, it meant you paid for your own meal and for the privilege of being the butt of his jokes. One day, I was chosen. Henny asked me if I'd like a diamond pin. I said, ''Of course,'' whereupon he presented me with a dime attached to a safety pin.

title: Barbara Moses, Matthew Grayson
description: Barbara Carol Moses, a lawyer, and Matthew Aaron Grayson, an investment bank executive, were married last evening at the Burden Mansion in New York. Rabbi Joel S. Goor performed the ceremony.

title: PRONUNCIATION (pruh-NUHN-see-AY-shin).
description: Newscasters, forecasters, talking heads of all persuasions and everybody else at all concerned with what comes out of their mouths would do well to digest ''The Big Book of Beastly Mispronunciations,'' a witty new reference guide by Charles Harrington Elster. An abbreviated sample: ''President (PREZ-uh-dint, or -dent). Don't drop the middle syllable (-i-) from president and say PREZ-dint. That is sloppy. Also, even in your most rapid speech, don't ever, ever slur over both the i and the d and pronounce president PREZ'nt, like present. Finally, don't say PRES-uh-dint, with an s as in press.''

title: Others Recruit Parents To Help Children Read
description: I applaud the new reading program at Carrie E. Tompkins Elementary School in Croton-on-Hudson, described in ''Parents Learn Skills in Teaching'' on Jan. 10, whereby parents are instructed and guided by teachers on how to help their children learn to read.

title: What Is the I.O.C.?
description: The International Olympic Committee runs the Summer and Winter Olympics, choosing the host cities, deciding which sports will be included and negotiates the television contracts and sponsorship deals that pay for it all. It is based in Lausanne, Switzerland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARELLI, GABOR
description: CARELLI-Gabor. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Gabor Carelli, a stalwart member of our company from 1951 to 1974. During his long career with the Met he sang more than 1,000 performances of 56 roles, making an invaluable contribution to our company. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: A Midwinter Warming
'Jammin' Comes to WBIX
description: Over at Rocco's Calamari, a cafeteria-style Italian place on Fort Hamilton Parkway between 64th and 65th Streets in Brooklyn, the radio is tuned to WBIX (105.1 FM) these days.

title: Red Flags Go Up Over Public Golf Courses
description: Just how obligated are officials to provide public golf courses for residents of the Garden State? Judging from current disputes in Hudson and Essex Counties, the answers to that question are as divergent as hooks and slices.

title: Social Security Plan Is Too Timid
description: To the Editor:

title: Investors Hope to Reopen a Famous Rock Club in New Jersey
description: It was home to Bruce Springsteen, Jon Bon Jovi and Southside Johnny, not to mention an album's worth of not-so-famous Garden State Tchaikovskys, but the only sound at the Stone Pony these days is the solemn bass line of the ocean breakers slapping at the nearby shore.

title: Groening's New World, 1,000 Years From Springfield
description: MATT GROENING looks like an ordinary guy, sitting at an ocean-view table at Shutters on the Beach. At 44, he has a little gray, a little paunch and the attention to fashion of a successful hardware salesman (knit shirt and khakis). People at the hotel's restaurant are paying more attention to Tom Hanks, who is having brunch with a large group across the room. But Mr. Groening (pronounced graining) is the man who created Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa and the laconic infant Maggie Simpson, and he is not unaware of how much clout that gives him, especially as he prepares to introduce his first new series since ''The Simpsons'' became a half-hour comedy in 1990.

title: (Real) Games (Real) People Play
description: Immigration wasn't much of an issue in last fall's election, possibly because the Government has been cracking down so heavily on illegal aliens. In the two years since Congress passed tough new enforcement legislation, the Feds have deported 300,000 immigrants, twice as many as in the two years before. These days, coming to America illegally is a real crap shoot -- which is precisely the point of an interactive exhibition called ''Juegos Ilegales/Illegal Games'' that opened Thursday at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo. Created by Anaida Hernandez, the casinolike installation allows visitors to embark down the risky path of unlawful entry. ''Immigrants dream of a better life,'' Hernandez says. ''This exhibition is about the chances they take to achieve that dream.'' The artist herself arrived in New York (legally) two years ago from Puerto Rico. In her Brooklyn studio, she provided a preview of her rather idiosyncratic work.

title: Australian Officials Call for Changes
description: Australian Olympic officials, under pressure at home and abroad after revelations of questionable payments during Sydney's successful bid for the 2000 Summer Games, today called for change in a selection process that allows aspiring host cities to offer substantial aid to national Olympic committees.

title: Sensibilities of Childhood Without the Sentimentality
description: ART and medicine are not necessarily strange gurney-fellows. Although some people might find it peculiar to visit a hospital to see a serious art exhibition that is not directly health-related, the Pavilion Galleries at the Virtua Health-Memorial Hospital Burlington County here have been showing art for almost two decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, ALEX SAHAGIAN
description: EDWARDS-Alex Sahagian, M.D. On January 18, 1999. Beloved Uncle of Alex and Elyce. A wonderful man and dedicated doctor we will miss greatly. Memorial Service February 6, 1999, 11AM, St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral, 630 2nd Avenue, New York City.

title: Listening To an Earful For Savings
description: KELLY McGLAUGHLIN, an airline pilot who lives in Pittsburgh, used to run up long-distance telephone bills of $100 a month, mostly for calls to his wife. Now, he calls all he wants at no charge -- but he pays a different sort of price.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: Dear Diary:

title: Partners Design Sites for On-Line Markets
description: THEY are still in their 30's, yet Kelly Harrison and Marilyn Simes together have almost 20 years of experience in an industry that is only slightly more than a decade old: designing Web sites for on-line marketing.

title: Lesser Than Zero
description: GLAMORAMA

title: Nets Facing Challenge In Kittles Negotiations
description: John Nash, the general manager of the Nets, and David Falk, the powerful agent who represents two of the club's best players, have an unpleasant history. They bickered a few years ago when Nash was the general manager in Washington and Falk finagled a $105.5 million deal for Juwan Howard. Then they got into a public argument last season over Kerry Kittles, the Nets' third-year shooting guard and a Falk client.

title: When It Comes to Members of Minorities, How Soon Baseball Forgets
description: In a severe case of out of sight, out of mind, Major League Baseball and its member teams have suffered a collective lapse of memory since the celebration 21 months ago of the 50th anniversary of Jackie Robinson's barrier-breaking exploits.

title: Corrections
description: A picture with the Music column on Dec. 27, with a report about the Westchester Oratorio Society, was published in error. It showed the pianist Jon Klibonoff, not Harold Rosenbaum, founding director of the society.

title: Cultural Battlefields
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONAN, SEON PIERRE
description: BONAN-Seon Pierre. Real estate developer and philanthropist, best known for the ground-breaking urban renewal project, Charles River Park in Boston, died Saturday in Palm Beach, FL, of complications from a brain injury. He was 82 and maintained residences in Palm Beach, Wilton, CT, and New York City, and was a former longtime resident of Greenwich, CT. Mr. Bonan is survived by his wife of 52 years, Janet Ross Bonan, a sister, Ethel Hoeffler, a brother, Ferdinand, three children, Elizabeth Bonan, Charles Bonan and Virginia Adelson, and six grandchildren. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. NYC, Wednesday, January 26, 11:30 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Mt. Sinai Hospital Juvenile Diabetes Center.

title: Northport's Salon for Artists and Audiences
description: ECLIPSED by the cultural offerings that have made nearby Huntington Village a mecca for Long Island arts and night life, this town has long fostered its own prosperous, if modest, creative enclave. Now, that cadre of artists is finding a united voice through the Northport Arts Coalition.

title: Radiant Heating And Termites
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX; Good Old Golden Snow Days
description: THERE is a positive buzz in schools the day before a winter storm is predicted. All the teachers are cheerful and purposeful. Desks are cleaned off with care, plants are watered, the fish fed and that last pile of homework papers is corrected and handed out. The children sense something is on the horizon. They are obedient, wondering what is different.

title: U.S.A. Accounts Are New Volley in Retirement Savings Debate
description: IN his State of the Union address and, again, before a roaring crowd in Buffalo, President Clinton last week floated the idea of Universal Savings Accounts, a new type of subsidized savings for low- and moderate-income workers akin to a 401(k) plan. The Government would use 11 percent of the projected budget surplus to match money the workers would save on their own in the U.S.A.'s.

title: Tourism Figures Show a Drop
description: THE crescent of picturesque villages bordering the Hudson River was once known as Millionaire's Row, a strand of lavish vacation hideaways along the shore where the wealthy whiled away their summers. But in the last year, the popularity of the historic estates as Westchester tourist destinations has waned, and officials are wondering why.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRENBERG, MARVIN
description: EHRENBERG-Marvin. At age 71. Of Sayville, Long Island, on December 21, 1998. Beloved husband of Jean. Dear father of Evelyn Weiss, Robin Friedman, Alan and David. Dear brother of Lila Davidow, Arlene Ehrenberg & Phyllis Mettauer. Loving grandfather of nineteen. A Memorial service is at 2 P.M., on Sunday, January 31, 1999 at Sayville Community Jewish Center, 225 Greeley Avenue, Sayville, New York. Interment was in Raanana Cemetery, Israel.

title: The View From/Larchmont; Plastic Surgery Offers New Life to Disfigured Children in Haiti
description: ANYONE who thinks plastic surgery is only about cosmetics should visit Dr. Marie-ange Tardieu at her office here. Dr. Tardieu, 41, has done her share of cosmetic work, but the majority of what she does is reconstruction -- reshaping the faces and bodies of people from places like her own native Haiti and other countries who are disfigured because of genetics, trauma or disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAGALINE, EDWARD A.
description: BRAGALINE-Edward A. Age 92. At the DeWitt Nursing Home, Monday, January 18, from cardiopulmonary-arrest. Until his retirement, Mr. Bragaline was the owner/director of the firm Kent-Bragaline Inc., a supplier of decorative fabrics to the home furnishing industry. He is survived by his dear sister Olga Pedlar; his very attentive nephew Edward Speciale and five other nephews and a niece; as well as his dear friend of many years Louis W. Bowen. A private cryptside service will be held at Woodlawn Cemetery, Wednesday at 1PM, January 27. No flowers thank you, just a prayer for peace and love. A memorial tribute will be announced at a later date.
PRIMO LEVITragedy of an Optimist.By Myriam Anissimov.Translated by Steve Cox.Illustrated. 452 pp. Woodstock, N.Y.:The Overlook Press. $37.95.
