title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: LEARNING A TRADE

title: Donors Visit the Recipients of Their Generosity
description: Financial analysts from Salomon Smith Barney hesitate to sink money into unknown quantities, so yesterday, 10 young analysts who are leading Wall Street's fund-raising drive for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund took a research trip.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE; To 'Plotz' Is to Burst, and to Read
description: ''I'm not a Super Jew,'' said Barbara Kligman, ''I don't go to services. But I'm Jewish, and it's a part of my identity.'' It's also fast becoming her business. Ms. Kligman edits and publishes the zine Plotz out of her studio apartment in the East Village. With its acerbic features and kitschy clip-art, Plotz is a heady Jewish-centric mix of irreverence and devotion.

title: Streetscapes/Marvin Schneider; The Man Who Makes the City's Clocks Run on Time
description: FOR Marvin Schneider, New York City's Clock Master, the year 2000 problem is not as worrisome as brick dust, dangerous ladders and pigeon guano. That's because the timing equipment Mr. Schneider looks after is run not by microchips and microprocessors but by gears and weights.

title: Early Draws
description: To the Editor:

title: As Rivals Flail, Teardrop Golf Yells Fore and Makes More Deals
description: AS the depth of an industrywide slump the best time to go on an acquisition spree?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRASBERG, SUSAN ELIZABETH
description: STRASBERG - Susan Elizabeth. Actress and author on January 21, 1999. Beloved mother of Jennifer Robin Jones Strasberg. Loving daughter of the late Lee and Paula Strasberg. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St, Sunday and Monday 2-5 and 7-9PM with service Tuesday 1PM. Interment private.

title: Serial Drama at the Grove Street Playhouse
description: WITH volunteer actors prancing before flimsy sets of utopian forests and kingdoms, the Grove Street Playhouse has kept children laughing for years. But offstage for the last 15 years, the nonprofit Greenwich Village theater has waged a battle with the city just to stay open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, DOLLY BENN
description: EPSTEIN-Dolly Benn. On January 20, 2000. Mourned by family and friends. Funeral private at her request. Contributions may be made in Dolly's name at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center's Society Office, c/o Dr. Richard O'Reilly, 212-639-7972.

title: Which Sprewell for Knicks, The Selfless of the Selfish?
description: When the off-kilter jokes subside, and Latrell Sprewell, the basketball player, supplants Latrell Sprewell, the national anger-management spokesman, the Knicks will learn what kind of player and teammate they have gambled to acquire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, EDWARD J.
description: O'BRIEN-Edward J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Edward J. O' Brien, associated with The Times from 1965 until retiring in 1993.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACHS, MARTIN
description: SACHS-Martin. JPC mourns the loss of its beloved Board member of 35 years. He was an inspiring leader and respected professional who always conducted himself with a warmth and kindness that deeply impacted all of us that knew him. He will be forever remembered for his exemplary roles as a collegue, a mentor, and most importantly, a friend. We will miss him dearly. Board of Directors and staff of JPC

title: A More Perfect Future
description: The clues to the biggest news of the next millennium still lie scattered in the last years of the last one, like gems and beads waiting to be strung into a precious new object. You have to gather nuggets from many sources to get a glimpse of the planet's political future. Here's a revealing sampling of clippings I have recently accumulated:

title: Dreams of His Russian Winters
description: The Age of Terror

title: BEST SELLERS: January 24, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Foxy's New Best Friend
description: Tired of gold and platinum settings for diamonds? Russell Simmons, the rap entrepreneur, and his new wife, Kimora Lee, have a less precious solution: Baby Phat, their new line of colorful plastic (he prefers the word ''resin'') jewelry studded with diamonds. ''In Beverly Hills you can sell fakes, but not in New York,'' Mr. Simmons said. ''Foxy Brown wants real diamonds. She has aspirations.''

title: FOOTNOTES; Mick's Style
description: I was just a freshman in high school when I bought my first Rolling Stones album, ''High Tide and Green Grass.'' In those prehistoric, pre-MTV days, you'd be lucky to see your favorite bands a couple of times a year on the Ed Sullivan show, and so I used to study their album covers and photographs. I loved the music of the English rock groups and I loved the way they dressed. The whole British Invasion introduced a new vocabulary of personal expression: The Beatles, with their collarless suits, Chelsea boots and mop tops. The Who, who took their sleek Italian style of mod dressing to new heights, adopting the Union Jack as a symbol of youth culture. And those dedicated followers of fashion, the Kinks, with their double-breasted suits and ruffled shirts.

title: The Brazilian Bear Growls Again
description: Markets aroudn the world shuddered on Friday as Brazil's economic crisis deepened. Brazil's central bank intervened in currency markets to keep its currency, the real, from going into a free fall. Even so, the currency has fallen 30 percent against the dollar since the start of the crisis. The intervention was the bank's first since allowing the real to float last week.

title: At Last, a Ramp Links The Parkway and Route 80
description: Though Route 80 and the Garden State Parkway are major highways whose paths cross, drivers heading south on the Parkway had always had to navigate a tortuous network of side streets in Saddle Brook to connect with Route 80 east. But last week officials opened a ramp to make a direct connection and save the 15 minutes that the old route could add to a drive.

title: GUATEMALA, ON THE VERTICAL
description: I HAD brushed away a thin black dust that kept settling on the pages of the novel I was reading at least three times before I took conscious note of it and began looking around for its source. I was baffled. There were few trees near the pool deck where I was sitting; there was no construction under way. Just row upon row of splendidly lush hills, rising to the snub-nosed peaks of some of Guatemala's trademark volcanoes.

title: Social Security Investment Plan Raises a Debate
description: A proposal by President Clinton to invest some portion of Social Security reserves in stocks ignited a brushfire of criticism last week, although the attacks may have focused on easily solved problems and ignored some thornier issues.

title: A Country of the Mind
description: Jack YeatsBy Bruce Arnold.Illustrated. 418 pp. New Haven:Yale University Press. $45.

title: A Place for Discriminating Dudes
description: THE two-lane highway running from the West Texas town of Marfa south to the Mexican border passes a big stone gate marking the entrance to Cibolo Creek Ranch. I'd driven by it many times on the way to Big Bend National Park and had always been curious about its storied past and a sign advertising its luxury accommodations. Hearing that Mick Jagger and Larry Hagman had stayed there further piqued my interest. What lured these people, who could afford to stay anywhere, to such remoteness?

title: The Different Faces Of Retirement
description: To the Editor:

title: Introduction
description: Readers responded to our annual commemorative issue with mixed emotions. Some noted with pleasure that the people we salute are not always the obvious choices. But others took us to task for our omissions, pointing out the names of those they felt belonged among the tributes.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: Necessary FictionsBy Barbara Croft.University of Pittsburgh, $22.50.

title: Smoking to Be Curtailed At Newark Train Station
description: Starting tomorrow morning, those increasingly ubiquitous ''no smoking'' signs will be posted in one more spot popular for lighting up: the train platforms at Newark Penn Station.

title: Health Programs and Education Get Help in Whitman's Budget
description: With an extra $1.1 billion to spend in the coming fiscal year, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will recommend giving a quarter of it back to taxpayers and using most of the rest to cover increased spending for public schools, state colleges, open space preservation and expanded health care programs for children and the elderly, New Jersey officials said today.

title: 'The Haunted Wood'
description: To the Editor:

title: Software to Prove Everyone Can Read
description: WHEN Lew Robins created his reading program, he called it Everybody Can Read. That's because Mr. Robins -- a 66-year-old computer software designer -- believes that just about everyone can. Last June, Mr. Robins sold his Westport home and moved to Fairfield. Now he is testing his program in Norwalk, at the Colonial Village housing complex as well as in the Fox Run Elementary School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESTENBERG, DR. JUDITH
description: KESTENBERG-Dr. Judith. The American Friends of Tel Aviv University notes with profound sorrow the passing of Dr. Judith Kestenberg. Her world renowned collection of interviews of child survivors of the Holocaust is proudly housed at Tel Aviv University's Wiener Library. Our heartfelt condolences to the family. The American Friends of Tel Aviv University Alan L. Aufzien, Chairman, Board of Directors Melvin S. Taub, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Topchik, Pres. Stephen Lecker, Exec. V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YANUCK, JULIUS
description: YANUCK-Julius. Of White Plains, NY. Died Saturday, January 22, at age 85 years. Beloved by his wife Lyn Yanuck, daughter Louise, sons Bill and Sam and four grandchildren. Services were held Sunday, January 23. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Bet Am Shalom Torah Fund would be appreciated.

title: The Nation; On the Witness Question, a Cost-Benefit Analysis
description: OPENING arguments have been heard; the Senate has asked its questions. President Clinton's impeachment trial is now twisting toward its most unpredictable phase: the decision on whether to call witnesses.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CATES, JOSEPH
description: CATES-Joseph. On October 10, 1998. The New York Friars Club and the Cates family deeply mourn his passing and extend an invitation to attend a memorial service on Monday, January 25 at 2pm at Director's Guild Theater, 110 West 57 Street, NYC.

title: January 17-23; State of the President
description: For any other politician, it would have been awkward: striding into the House chamber where a month before he had been impeached. But delivering his State of the Union speech, an unbowed President Clinton proposed that the Federal Government invest in the stock market to bolster Social Security, called for programs to strengthen schools and the military, and announced that the Justice Department would sue tobacco companies to recover Government costs of treating smoking-related diseases.

title: Suzanne Spector, Robert Lawrence
description: Suzanne Spector, an editor, and Robert D. Lawrence, a violinist, are to be married today in Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Steven Bayar is to officiate at the home of Linda and William Glasofer, the bride's sister and brother-in-law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, KATHERINE SCANLON
description: ADAMS-Katherine Scanlon. Age 45, of Greenwich, CT, died January 20, at home. Services will be held Tuesday, January 25, at 12:30 PM, at the Brick Church, Manhattan. Donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Memorial Fund (#

title: Works by People on the Margins
description: THE show ''Private Worlds: Classic Outsider Art in Europe'' at the Katonah Museum of Art in Katonah, N.Y., is like a bolt from the blue. If any art is beyond criticism it is the work in this show, made by people who were really on the margins of society. Many of the artists made their work while in mental institutions.

title: Why Eco-Tourists Are Shunning Brazil
description: BLESSED with a rain forest the size of Western Europe, wetlands where rivers magically swell from 300 yards to 37 miles in the rainy season, and a dazzling string of waterfalls in the south, Brazil would seem to be a natural magnet for ecologically driven travelers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARBER, BETH
description: BARBER-Beth. 47, on January 22, 2000. Beloved wife of Jeff Sali; loving daughter of Earl and dear sister of Tris and Mary. Services Wednesday, January 26, at 10 AM at the Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28th St, NYC. Your power, courage and dignity is forever.

title: A Proud Son of Glasgow, and a Festival Favorite
description: PETER MULLAN held an unusual part-time job while studying at Glasgow University. He danced disco.

title: Enjoying Ski Resorts Without Hitting the Slopes
description: HIS mom had hot cocoa waiting when the little boy from Sparta came down off the mountain the other day at Hidden Valley Ski Resort. He was 6 years old with light brown hair and very red cheeks. A veteran of only two ski lessons, he collapsed in a chair like an exhausted working stiff. ''Ow!'' he said as his mom tugged at his ski boots. ''Watch it! My feet feel all zigzaggy!''

title: Dodging Bullets In Overseas Trade
description: WHEN the Asian financial crisis broke in July of 1997, it caused worries in Connecticut. Some of the Asian nations whose economies were hardest hit were among the state's 10 largest overseas trade partners, and while foreign trade makes up only about 6 percent of the state's economy, it is a segment that has steadily grown over the last decade.

title: A Knick's Reading List
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosperity and the Neediest Cases
description: Most of us know the charitable impulse that wells up during the holidays. The impulse may be seasonal, but the needs of the neediest persist all year long. Hunger, homelessness, disease, poverty, ignorance -- these things never waver, though our consciousness of them does. When the holidays end, we turn back to what we fondly call ''our own lives'' with a sense of relief. But there is no such thing as ''our own lives'' in that narrow sense. A mother and her children slipping into homelessness or a young man coming to the end of his senses without decent care are inescapable elements of our own lives. Whether we like it or not, the prosperity we enjoy is intolerable unless we share it with people who cannot gain even the rudiments of prosperity by themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFEK, VIOLA MABEL
description: JAFEK-Viola Mabel (Newstrom). Of Brooklyn Center, MN. Born New London, MN, 1908. Services Evans-Nordby 612-533-3000

title: With Lockout Over, Players Work Out
description: THE small fleet of sport utility vehicles in the New York Knick parking lot outside the Physical Education Building at Purchase College here two weeks ago signaled that the National Basketball Association lockout had indeed ended.

title: Liberties; King of the World
description: Bill Clinton boogied into his victory rally chewing on a Cohiba and beating on bongo drums.

title: After the Blizzard, A New Hartford Team?
description: THE New England Blizzard of the bankrupt American Basketball League may be gone, but the team, which was based in Hartford, is not forgotten by its legion of fans. Indeed the team may not be gone for good.

title: A Place to See Eagles Soar
description: Great wings outstretched, a bald eagle soared over the open water of the Mongaup Reservoir, giving the group of observers a brief, brilliant sighting before it rose behind the tall white pines. The number of eagles wintering here in the Upper Delaware watershed of Sullivan County has grown steadily in recent years. So has the phenomenon of eagle watching.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENG, DOW GEE
description: ENG-Dow Gee. 90, on January 20, 2000. Devoted mother of David, Ernest and Kenneth and daughter in-laws Lilly, Ann and June; loving mother of Jeanette and son in-law Chandler Hom; adored grandmother of Kimberly, Kristina, Kira, Keith, Karenne, Brian, Elizabeth, Christine, and Joyce; cherished great grandmother of Sullivan. Reposing at True Light Lutheran Church, 195 Worth St., 3-7PM Tuesday, January 25. Funeral service at True Light, 12 noon, Wednesday, January 26. In lieu of flowers, donations to Fourth Surgical Fund of NYU Medical Center or True Light Lutheran Church.

title: In a New Fosse Vehicle, A Headlong Joy Ride
description: EVEN as their budgets and, occasionally, their aspirations have ballooned, Broadway musicals give the impression of having grown smaller in recent years, at least in part because of the near-disappearance of dance from the American musical theater. Dance is still there, but it's either nondescript, as in ''Footloose,'' or solemnly obligatory, almost instructive, as in ''Ragtime.'' The sense of excitement and discovery has disappeared. If you have any doubt about what has been lost or, better yet, if you just want to have a terrifically entertaining night of Broadway theater, then you can't afford to pass up ''Fosse,'' now at the Broadhurst.

title: Alexandra Ewert, Rick Farnell
description: Alexandra Tucker Ewert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred P. Ewert of New York, was married yesterday to Rick Anthony Farnell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald A. Farnell Sr. of Everett, Mass. The Rev. Park McD. Bodie performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Few Willing Wallets On an Opening Night
description: It was hard to find a business leader or social bigwig at the opening-night party of the Winter Antiques Show who actually bought something. Evelyn Lauder, wife of Leonard Lauder, chairman of the Whitney Museum, proudly displayed her acquisition, a 1939 sharkskin paper cutter. But browsing was the order of the day at the party in the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan this month. . ''I'm a voyeur,'' confessed art dealer Joan Washburn. Morley Safer, the ''60 Minutes'' correspondent, said, ''I'm not buying; I'm admiring,'' And Ronald O. Perelman, owner of Revlon, uttered the classic ''I'm just looking.''

title: Police Discover Bodies of 2 Boys Believed to Be Missing Brothers
description: The bodies of two young boys were found hidden in the sub-basement of a Manhattan loft building yesterday. The police said that they believed the bodies were those of two children whose father managed the building, and who was being held in connection with their disappearance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHN, FRANCES R.
description: KOHN-Frances R. (nee Rosenbaum). Of Wyckoff, NJ, formerly of White Plains, NY, died January 23, 1999, in her 88th year. She was a 1932 graduate of Smith College, Northhampton, MA, and received her MA at Columbia University. Devoted wife of the late Stephen Van Esen who died in 1947, and John S. Kohn who died in 1977. Loving mother of Stephen Van Esen of Waterbury, VT, John Van Esen of Manhattan, NY, and Penny Craig of Ridgewood, NJ. Adoring grandmother of Jenny Evjen of Duluth, MN, Alex and Molly Craig of Ridgewood, NJ. A memorial service will be planned for a later date. Donations to the charity of your choice in Frances Kohn's name would be appreciated. For information call Feeney Funeral Home, Ridewood, NJ, 201444-7650.

title: Fresh From the Factory: Upscale Homes
description: JOHN AND BARBARA CAMPBELL aren't your conventional mansion developers. A husband-and-wife team who generally buy and renovate houses for resale, the Campbells made a foray into speculative mansion construction last summer with an 8,900-square-foot Georgian-style estate in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Britons Choose Plays Of the Century
description: The Royal National Theater in London is celebrating theater of the 20th century in a yearlong program called NT2000. Events will be held at 6 P.M. two or three times a week in one of the three theaters that make up the National's complex. The 45-minute programs will be devoted to 100 plays deemed the century's most significant by a jury of more than 800 playwrights, actors, journalists and other theater professionals, who were each asked to nominate 10 English-language plays. Arthur Miller was the most frequently nominated author, closely followed by Harold Pinter and Samuel Beckett. The plays will be considered in chronological order.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: The Book of Memories

title: Excerpts: Day 2 of Senators' Questions and Responses From Both Sides
description: Following are some questions from senators and excerpts from the answers today by the House impeachment case managers and lawyers for President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service. The questions were read by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist.

title: PUSHING THE ENVELOPE
description: * The 1-cent boost in first-class stamps is the first step-up in four years and the lowest since 1971. * The penny ante represents a 3.1 percent rise, a third the rate of inflation since the last hike. * Nondenominated stamps provided for the transition won't become collectors' items: the Postal Service printed 2.5 billion stamps worth a cent each ($25 million) and 10 billion worth 33 cents each ($3.3 billion). * The nondenominated first-class stamp goes by the letter H, but is not a self-promotion for Postmaster General William Henderson. It is the eighth in a series of alphabet stamps marking the increases since 1978 and is known at the Post Office as the Hat, after Uncle Sam's lid. * The last decrease in postal rates was in 1919, from 3 to 2 cents, and lasted until 1932, when the damage went back to 3 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNANKE, BERNICE W.
description: BERNANKE-Bernice W. (nee Cohen). Of New York City, on January 22, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Dear sister of the late Marjorie Efrus. Devoted aunt of Richard, Robert and Susan Efrus. For further information call ''Gutterman-Musicant'' 1-800-522-0588

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ERTAG, HENRI
description: ERTAG-Henri, January 27, 1964. Beloved brother. Rose Ertag Schreiber

title: Backtalk; Good Mike, Bad Mike and the Anti-Mike
description: With Mike gone, only the Anti-Mike can save us.

title: Crashing the Boys' Club
description: Reporting Live

title: The World; Israel's Divisions Splinter Its Politics
description: IF the rifts in Israeli society could be frozen in images, the images would be the violent incidents that represent the fear of what could happen here more routinely if the political order disintegrated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAYNE, LUCIA ROBINSON
description: WAYNE-Lucia Robinson. Passed away peacefully on January 6, 1999 at Englewood Hospital in Englewood, N.J. She will be remembered by friends and artists for her love of the ballet as reflected in her extraordinary film collection. Her films are being preserved by the New York Public Library For The Performing Arts. Memorial services will be held on January 30 at the Actors Fund Nursing Home in Englewood, N.J. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to the Actors Fund Nursing Home and the New York Library For The Performing Arts.

title: Foster Care Children Practice Travel Dreams
description: THE world that one 16-year-old girl has known is filled with social workers who come and go and a series of ever-changing foster home addresses. It is a world where she moves often but rarely gets anywhere.

title: Classy Intimacy and French Fare in Vista
description: EASILY holding its ground on Route 123 for more than 10 years, L'Europe has in that time beguiled diners with its intimate scale, genteel decor, soft lighting and, particularly at this chilly time of year, a cozy fireplace in the back room. This dependability has also marked the style of the kitchen, which continues to produce comfortably familiar, straightforward preparations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOROCK, SYL
description: BOROCK-Syl. We cherish the memory of our dear friend, Syl. Her warmth, generosity and spirit will be treasured always. To her beloved family, we extend our heartfelt sympathy. Gert and Charles Newman and family

title: Gore Building Network in California
description: As Vice President, Al Gore has traveled to California so many times that aides have lost count. They think his latest trip this weekend, his second of the year already, is the 52d. But they are not eager to bet on it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STADIN, LEE
description: STADIN-Lee. On January 23, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Julian. Devoted sister of Simon Askin. Loving aunt of Helene Ruddy, Joan & Stuart Bardin, Glenn & Peter Schwich, Neil Askin, Nan & Michael Cooper & Peter Askin. Graveside services Sunday, 1 PM, Mt. Judah Cemetery, Queens, NY.

title: Rain, Snow and Ice Defer Drought Emergency
description: The recent rains, and warm days causing runoff from ice and snow, have led officials to delay considering a drought emergency from the end of this month into at least next month. If there is more precipitation, an emergency, with its mandatory water restrictions, may be avoided altogether, said Christopher Roberts, public information officer for the Delaware River Basin Commission, which tracks water levels in area reservoirs and the Delaware River.

title: Women's Work, Not All of It Ladylike
description: THE Zimmerli Art Museum is known as a repository of scrupulous, slightly eccentric collections ranging from French posters to Japonisme to a trove of Soviet nonconformist art. Now, an exhibition featuring 35 new gifts is raising consciousness of the National Association of Women Artists Collection.

title: Q&A;/Lynn McPhelimy; A Plan for Life in the Face of Death
description: CANCER was diagnosed in Lynn McPhelimy's parents within a year, and they died eight months apart. Both engineers, they took a methodical approach and made careful preparation for the day when their adult daughter and two sons would be without parents.

title: Ailing Asian Companies Unload Their Hotels
description: Japan Airlines bought the Essex House, a grand Art Deco hotel on Central Park South, 15 years ago and turned it into a flagship for its Nikko hotel chain in a city where real estate always seems like a good bet for foreign investors.

title: Metro-North Ratings
description: Metro-North Railroad, which recently posted results on a satisfaction survey of 7,479 riders taken from October through December, reported that customers gave the railroad an overall rating of 7.8 on a scale of 10, with 10 representing very satisfied.

title: January 17-23; Drive Drunk, Lose Car
description: In the hands of drunk drivers, cars can be ''4,000-pound weapons,'' according to an official for Mothers Against Drunk Driving. More than 6,000 drunk drivers are arrested yearly in New York City, many of them responsible for dozens of deaths annually. The city's latest plan to seize cars of convicted drunk drivers, however, has raised some eyebrows. The forfeiture laws ''are under intense scrutiny'' just now, said Jonathan Gradess, the executive director of the New York State Defenders Association, amid accusations that some police departments see such seizures as a way to increase their fleets. In any case, where would New York City ever find parking space for 6,000 more cars? HUBERT B. HERRING

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Annadale, Staten Island; Suburban, With Its Heart in the Country
description: STANDING on the Arden Avenue esplanade overlooking Raritan Bay at the southeast corner of the Staten Island community of Annadale, the view to the west is the Atlantic Highlands of New Jersey; to the east is Great Kills Park in the Gateway National Recreation Area.

title: How a Peaceful Old Opening Got to Be a Real Rip-Snorter
description: When a chess opening undergoes a rehabilitation, it may resemble its earlier version on the outside while expressing an entirely different strategic motivation underneath. The moves that once introduced a structural battle featuring pawn play will now be used to create an open position where the main concern is slam-bang piece play.

title: New Use for Polaroids
description: One hundred and fifty Polaroid Spectra 3 cameras have been distributed to officers from 46 municipal police departments as part of County Executive Andrew P. Spano's policy of zero tolerance for domestic violence. Photographs have a proved record of contributing to increased conviction rates in family violence cases, Mr. Spano said.

title: A Divided Iraq May Not Be Better
description: To the Editor:

title: State Legislatures Across U.S. Plan to Take Up Internet Issues
description: The contentious and complex debates over protecting children from the evils of cyberspace, controlling unwanted commercial E-mail and protecting consumer privacy on line are expected to move to statehouses in the coming months as state legislatures convene around the country.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In any ninth-grade

title: Return of the Native: A Brook Trout Project
description: Tired of catching stunted brook trout? A movement is afoot to return bigger, wild brook trout to their original streams. Anyone who has ever caught a brook trout wants to bring back the natives. Now, they can.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, CLARENCE EDWIN
description: WILLIAMS-Clarence Edwin. On January 23, 1999 at 76. Beloved husband of Anne Williams. Brother of Marjorie Crothers. Loving father of Ned, Charles, Thomas, Emily Draper and Peter. Grandfather of eight. Services Tuesday, 2 pm, at Christ Church, Short Hills, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations to Christ Church are appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, DAVID R., JR.
description: WILLIAMS-David R., Jr. A cofounder of Tulsa-based Williams Cos. Died January 15, 2000, in East Hampton, NY, at age 78. A graduate of Yale University, in 1944 David flew combat missions with the 357th Fighter Group of the Eighth Air Force based outside of London. In 1949, David co-founded Williams Brothers Co., which would become the world's largest builder of pipelines. He is survived by his wife, Anne Wright Williams of East Hampton; two daughters, Pauline W. Lampshire of Camden, SC, and Rachel W. Zebrowski of Tulsa, OK; a son, David R. Williams III of Boston, MA; a stepdaughter Anne W. Baxter of Point Reyes, CA. Services will be held on January 29 in Camden, SC. Memorial services will be held at later dates in East Hampton, NY, and Tulsa, OK. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial contributions be made to The Arizona Cancer Center, PO Box 245013, 1515 North Campbell, Tucson, AZ 85724.

title: Clinton's Plan to Have Medicare Cover Drugs Means a Big Debate Ahead in Congress
description: President Clinton is proposing a major expansion of Medicare to cover prescription drugs, a change long sought by older Americans, and a Federal advisory commission may soon endorse the idea.

title: For Atlantic Clammers, Trying to Weather an Unusual Run of Tragedy
description: With a Coast Guard helicopter making the last few runs over the ocean, Bill Becica, the gruff, chain-smoking dock manager for a packing company here, summed up the two weeks that claimed a nearly unheard-of toll: four clamming boats and as many as 10 men.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TISHMAN, RITA V.
description: TISHMAN-Rita V. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Rita V. Tishman, a dedicated philanthropist and cherished leader in the Jewish community. As someone who devoted her life to Jewish and civic causes, she earned the admiration and respect of the entire community. She served as a distinguished member of the boards of United Jewish Appeal and the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, predecessors of UJA-Federation of New York. Through her remarkable commitment, she served as an inspiring role model for an extraordinary philanthropic family that has emulated her compassion and concern. We extend our sincerest condolences to her daughters, Margot T. Linton and Valerie T. Diker; her son, Peter V. Tishman; her ten grandchildren; eleven great-grandchildren; and the entire Tishman family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: Excerpts: Day 2 of Senators' Questions and Responses From Both Sides
description: Following are some questions from senators and excerpts from the answers today by the House impeachment case managers and lawyers for President Clinton, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service. The questions were read by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBY, ELSIE BAUM
description: GOLDBY-Elsie Baum. (1897-1999.) Widow of Max S. Schoenholt and Harry Goldby. Mother of Alan Schoenholt and Robert Schoenholt. Grandmother of Rustam, Zaire, Michael, Robby and Susan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEEGAN, VIRGINIA
description: KEEGAN-Virginia. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Virginia Keegan, associated with The Times from 1949, until retiring in 1983.

title: Hollywood's New Status Symbol: A Web Site
description: THE image of the ''Frasier'' star Kelsey Grammer that fans get from the celebrity press isn't pretty. For years, tawdry stories and haggard photographs have chronicled his messy divorces, his lawsuit to stop distribution of a nude videotape and his stint at the Betty Ford Clinic after a car accident.

title: Sprewell? Strickland? Rodman? Knicks Can Bring 'Em All On
description: THIS season is going to be nutty enough, so the Knicks might as well load up on characters rather than character.

title: INVESTING WITH/Phillip N. Davidson; American Century Value
description: WHAT is a nice mid-cap value fund like this doing in an aggressive growth family like American Century?

title: With Switch In Heir Plan, King Hussein Stuns Jordan
description: King Hussein of Jordan is preparing to select one of his sons as his heir, Jordanian officials said today, culminating a dizzying week in which the King returned from six months of cancer treatment abroad and then dismissed his brother as Crown Prince.

title: 'Streamline,' Is Karcher's Cry. Now He'll Put It to Practice.
description: The dining room table at Alan Karcher's condo off Nassau Street is littered with watercolors now -- feathery waterscapes, angular portraits, a few experimental doodles of a man easing his way into retirement from a life of politics. It's only when he begins to speak that any notion of Mr. Karcher's fading away quickly dissipates.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Alaska's Landscape

title: SOAPBOX; Operas in the Key of Mayor G
description: ANNOUNCER: Good afternoon -- and welcome to the first intermission feature of today's live radio broadcast from the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLAGSBRUN, DANIEL
description: KLAGSBRUN-Daniel. Your remeberance is like sweet honey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGIRR, MARGARET L.
description: McGIRR-Margaret L. On Thursday, January 21, 1999, in her 96th year. Loving aunt of Patricia A. Bastoni, John T. McGirr and Edward J. Howard. Viewing was held on Friday at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, New York. Mass of Christian Burial was celebrated on Saturday at St. Andrew Avellino R.C. Church followed by burial at Calvary Cemetery.

title: Old Timer Now With a With-It Attitude
description: CARBONE'S RISTORANTE in Hartford has been a mainstay of the local dining scene for more than 40 years. Its popularity as a political and sports hangout is evident in its gallery of celebrity photographs, portraying United States Senators, Tommy Lasorda, Mookie Wilson and many more.

title: Ideas & Trends; Rethinking a Treaty For a New Kind of Enemy
description: EVER since Richard M. Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev signed the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty in 1972, it has been a cornerstone of arms control. Its fundamental premise, which held throughout the cold war, was that limiting missile defenses limited offensive missiles.

title: A Russian Recital, An American Matinee
description: RUSSIAN music is the focus of a 3 o'clock recital this afternoon at the Hartford Seminary with the violinist Anhared Stowe, the cellist Robert deMaine and the pianist Andrzej Anweiler. The program lists Reinhold Gliere's Eight Pieces for Violin and Cello, Tchaikovsky's A Minor Trio and Rachmaninoff's Elegiac Trio.

title: A Neglected Master's Haunting Consolations
description: THERE is something so improbably consoling about the sadness at the heart of the best Vernon Duke melodies. This redemptive afterglow could be a consequence of sheer melodic sophistication. Duke knew how to construct a song, elegantly, with surpassing craft and harmonic flair. Yet the earned wisdom behind the sadness in his music transcends flair and craft and goes beyond sophistication.

title: Backtalk; Change Is Demanded to Right the Olympic Wrongs
description: The scandal surrounding the selection of Salt Lake City for the 2002 Olympics is only a symptom of a more deeply rooted problem, which will require a major shake-up of sport's international ruling bodies if we are to preserve and protect the Olympic ideal. This crisis requires a drastic reform of the International Olympic Committee and its overly pampered ''lords'' and a renewed focus on its real purpose: the athletes and fair competition.

title: An Accompanist Steps to the Fore
description: AT a lecture before a recent lieder recital in Irvine, Calif., Graham Johnson made a case for balkanizing Schubert, after a fashion. Mr. Johnson, a piano accompanist, scholar and teacher based in London, suggested that the six songs Schubert wrote to texts by Heine included in the posthumous song cycle ''Schwanengesang'' be split off and viewed as a free-standing work. The idea is vintage Johnson, unconventional yet compelling.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDMAN, HAROLD I
description: FRIEDMAN-Harold I. January 22, 1980. In loving memory. Selma, Iris, Paul, Amy, James and Meryl

title: The Intellectual Translated Into the Visual
description: 'Visual Ideas:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUEWEISS, ZANDER SMITH
description: BLUEWEISS-Zander Smith. Age 81. Widow of Henry Blueweiss. In New York City, on January 22, 1999. Loving aunt of attorney Jeffrey Blueweiss, Bruce Blueweiss, Karen Tuckman, Dr. Steven Newman, Dr. Nancy Newman, Robert Newman and sister-in-law of Edna Newman. Services Monday, January 25th, 11AM, New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York. Inquiries to Abraham L. Green & Son, Fairfield, CT.

title: This Game Has Makings Of a Doozy
description: It is true. No denying it. Most football fans yearned for a Minnesota-Denver tango in Super Bowl XXXIII. That matchup would have delivered the teams with the best records from each conference, two clubs with explosive offenses and, combined, more marquee stars. The rookie receiver Randy Moss would spice the entire affair. Purple Pride would overflow. Minnesota purple vs. Denver orange? How much more colorful could it get?

title: January 17-23; A Verdict in Delaware
description: Since it resumed executions in 1992 after a 46-year absence, Delaware has executed eight prisoners. Now a jury in Wilmington is deliberating on whether to recommend the death penalty or life imprisonment for Thomas J. Capano, a member of the state's political elite.

title: Wayward Intellectual Finds God
description: On a wintry Saturday in December, Leon Wieseltier has come to Rock Creek Cemetery to visit the tomb of Henry Adams. It is his favorite spot in Washington -- ''my sanctuary in the city,'' he calls it in his new book, ''Kaddish,'' published last fall to critical acclaim and surprisingly brisk sales. ''I used to come here every two weeks or so,'' he says as we reach the enclosure. ''In snow and rain. It was like a room.''

title: South African Assassinated, Then 11 More Are Shot Dead
description: A high-level official of a South African multiracial political party, the United Democratic Movement, was assassinated today, riddled with bullets as he left a grocery store near his home in a rural area about an hour's drive north of Durban.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: A Stone of the Heart

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: RING AROUND THE MOON

title: The Lives They Lived
description: I have never seen a better collection of short essays than the ones you publish each year in your special issue (Jan. 3). They were so good that I found myself reading pieces on people I'd never heard of and thus was introduced to remarkable individuals like Lucien E. Conein, Beatrice Wood and Dorothy West. I realize that it requires the death of more memorable men and women, but I'm already looking forward to next year's issue.

title: Why Companies Were Stingy with Payouts
description: Many investors who live off their dividend checks didn't have a heck of a lot to cheer about in 1998. Despite the overall upbeat performance of United States stocks, the total number of dividend increases actually fell in 1998, to 2,047, from 2,139 the year before, according to Standard & Poor's. Moreover, the total number of unfavorable payout actions -- either reductions in dividends or outright omissions -- increased to 145 in 1998 from 98 in 1997. That is the highest number of such negative dividend actions since 1993.

title: 'Measure for Measure,' Justice and Mercy
description: ACCORDING to notes on a production last summer at the Georgia Shakespeare Festival, ''Measure for Measure'' ''takes on issues that are as timely as tonight's newscast.'' And the notes go on to pose the question: ''Can an immoral act be justified for a good cause?''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: With Its Wallet Bulging, Suffolk Is Setting Up Open-Space Plans
description: ARMED with millions of dollars from programs that voters approved in November, county and town governments in Suffolk County are about to make long-awaited moves to preserve farms and other open spaces.

title: Fear for Students on New Regents Exams
description: MANY parents and educators remain concerned that the new state standards -- in particular the required Regents examinations -- will have a potentially harmful effect on large numbers of students.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

title: Worth Stealing: French Art of Supermarkets
description: IMAGINE this: you are standing in what they paradoxically call the express checkout line at your local supermarket. You have virtuously limited your purchases to 10 items, you have the cash ready in your hand and there are only three people in line ahead. None of them seems to be clutching a great fistful of dog-eared coupons. The signs are good. Even if the cashier works at her usual languid speed, you should be through and free in no more than 10 or 15 minutes.

title: Where Eagles Fly and People Watch
description: For the 229 bald eagles that Libby Mills counted today, the eight-mile stretch of the Skagit River between here and Marblemount is the four-star, all-you-can-eat sushi bar of Washington's waterways.

title: Hard by the Chateau, Royal Eating
description: TEN million people visit the chateau and gardens of Versailles every year. The palace, an overwhelmingly majestic ensemble of 17th- and 18th-century architecture, decor and landscaping, is an easy half-hour ride from Paris, 13 miles to the east.

title: First Shot Is Fired In the War On Lyme Disease
description: IN 14 years as a public health nurse for the Dutchess County Health Department in New York State, Evelyn Kaufmann spent many days giving talks at campgrounds and schools around the Hudson Valley about avoiding the tiny ticks that carry the bacteria causing Lyme disease.

title: Rooming With a Guy Named Mom
description: STEPHEN DeROSA, a co-star of the Off Broadway hit comedy ''The Mystery of Irma Vep,'' was catching up with a few fellow alumni of the Yale School of Drama at a midtown diner.

title: How Stocks Could Work For Social Security
description: IT'S fun to talk about what to do with 15 years' worth of projected surpluses in the Federal budget, particularly when the number in question is a tidy $4.4 trillion. That is what President Clinton was doing last week when he lobbed his Social Security proposals in front of the nation.

title: January 17-23; Hacker Destroys U.S.I.A. Web Site
description: The intruder was mean as well as clever. Not content just to invade the Web site of the United States Information Agency and leave a cryptic message, he (or she) knocked the site off the Internet. By week's end, computer experts at the agency, which oversees a variety of cultural and educational-exchange programs, were still trying to restore the site and promising better security. The intruder called himself ''Zyklon,'' perhaps after Zyklon-B, the gas used in Nazi death camps. DAVID STOUT

title: Woodman, Spare That Transvestite
description: In his eighth novel, TREE SURGERY FOR BEGINNERS (Faber/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25), Patrick Gale takes up the elements of the 18th-century comic novel - abandoned babies, characters in disguise, the wanderings of a feckless youth - and recombines them into an elegant romance that manages to be both playful and wise. Passionate but slightly dim, Lawrence Frost, an unhappily married English tree surgeon, returns home one morning after a fight with his wife, Bonnie, to discover that he has been accused of murdering her. The missing spouse soon turns up at the local police station, only to confirm Lawrence's suspicions that she has been having an affair with Craig McBridge, the kind of architect who designs everything ''down to the chopping board and shoe rack.'' His marriage and his equilibrium upended, Lawrence agrees to accompany his bachelor uncle on a bridge players' cruise to Miami. Although neither the endless rounds of cards nor the shipboard classes in vegetable sculpture win him over, he does fall in love with a transvestite chanteuse named Lala, whose big jaw and muscular legs make her look like ''Sophia Loren crossed with Tony Curtis.'' Rebuffed, Lawrence eventually makes his way to California, where he settles in as a ''glorified groundsman'' at a ranch-cum-health-spa run by a gay couple. In prose of sparkling precision, Gale serves up still more misadventures - satirical, farcical and tragic sentially comedic vision, the novel ends with lost identities revealed and multiple happy pairings of all persuasions. With its subtle interplay of dark and light elements, ''Tree Surgery for Beginners'' is infused with a smiling, Mozartean sensibility, reminding us that we can ''go so awry, break so utterly apart and still find the strength to continue.''

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about Internet retailers misspelled the surname of an executive at Bigstar Entertainment. He is David Levitsky, not Levipsky.

title: Judge Blocks Artist-less Buildings
description: It was a first: a plan to build more than 100 conventional apartments in SoHo, where for decades zoning laws have limited residential development to lofts for city-certified ''artists in residence.''

title: 'The Haunted Wood'
description: Joseph E. Persico replies:

title: Our Towns; After a Doctor's Slaying, a Clinic Struggles
description: MELINDA DuBOIS has had recurring dreams about Dr. Barnett A. Slepian, the slain mainstay of the abortion clinic she helps run, dreams in which he is very much alive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNICK, LITA. MEREDITH MONK
description: HORNICK-Lita. Meredith Monk, the Board of Directors and the staff of The House Foundation for the Arts mourn the passing of our former Board member and loyal supporter. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family.

title: In the Region/Long Island; The Movies Are the New Stars of the Mall
description: THE 15-screen Loews movie theater that opened here on Route 347 on Dec. 23 is -- for the moment -- the biggest, plushest and most elaborate on the Island.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM; Astronaut's Park Grounded
description: After the space shuttle Challenger exploded 13 years ago this Thursday, killing the seven astronauts aboard, New York City officials proposed a park in East Harlem to honor Dr. Ronald E. McNair, one of the victims and the second black American to travel into space.

title: Social Security Plan Is Too Timid
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Fearon, Mr. Pepperman
description: Elizabeth Ann Fearon, a Brooklyn assistant district attorney, and Richard C. Pepperman 2d, a partner in Sullivan & Cromwell, the Manhattan law firm, were married yesterday. The Rev. James F. Trainor performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Wilmington, Del.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Divided Iraq May Not Be Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, MURIEL
description: KAPLAN-Muriel. We will miss your warmth, your charm and your concern for others. You were our dearest friend. Mel and Clare Nadel

title: Seeking That Fair Day's Pay
description: Q. I love my job. But after five years, I am still making the minimum pay for my position as a data-entry clerk, though my workload has increased significantly. In addition to continued responsibility for my normal duties, I have been ''granted'' -- for being such an excellent employee, my boss said -- three grandiose titles that carry huge new responsibilities. But when I requested a raise, my boss declined, saying that if she gave me one, she would have to give all my co-workers one, too. Yet most of them earn more than I do. So do I quit a job I love because I am being taken advantage of, or do I ask to be relieved of some of my duties and risk angering management?

title: Corrections
description: Because of a picture agency's production error, a photograph in a collage on page 25 of The Times Magazine today, showing John Meriwether of Long-Term Capital Management, is printed in mirror image. His hair should appear parted on the right.

title: Where Have All the Great Milers Gone?
description: A year ago, there was good news and bad news in the Wanamaker Mile, the premier race in American track and field, to be run for the 74th time at the Chase Millrose Games on Feb. 5 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'REILLY, ALICE
description: O'REILLY-Alice. On January 22, 2000, of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved sister of Rose Marie, Sr. Frances Theresa CSJ, Francis and Matthew. Dear aunt of many loving nieces and nephews. Visiting Fox Funeral Home, Ascan Ave., Forest Hills, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, Tuesday. Funeral mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Wednesday, 10:30 AM.

title: January 17-23 ; Overtaxed? Depends on the Source
description: In Washington, there's a another whopper making the rounds. This one is about Uncle Sam and your wallet.

title: Best Wishes to Knicks From Golden State
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 24, 1999
description: Weeks

title: BOOKEND; Ted Hughes: A Reconciliation
description: Eavan Boland's most recent book is ''The Lost Land.'' She is director of the creative writing program at Stanford University.

title: INSIDE
description: Social Security Debate

title: Spreading the Word About Health Care for Children
description: THE state's Department of Social Services is preparing to start spending about $1 million to publicize the eligibility of up to 90,000 Connecticut young people up to age 19 for ''free or affordable'' health-care coverage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, JUDGE EUGENE J.
description: SULLIVAN-Judge Eugene J. On January 21, 1999. Beloved brother of Sheila Warren. Devoted companion to Frank Santiago. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Saturday & Sunday 2-5 & 7-9PM. Funeral Mass at St. Joseph's Church, 404 East 87 Street, on Monday, 11AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Rutgers Shot Gets Handsome at the Buzzer
description: When Geoff Billet is open, his jump shot is awkward. He shot-puts the ball on his descent, as if he is desperate to get rid of it before he lands.

title: East Hartford Officer Is Shot and Killed
description: An East Hartford police officer who was responding to a complaint of noise was shot dead last night, the police said.

title: Wheel Bag
description: ''In Europe everyone uses a shopping cart,'' said Bruce Kaminstein, the president of Casabella housewares in Blauvelt, N.Y. ''I've looked for a stylish trolley to bring to America for 10 years. Not something just for old ladies to take shopping, but one that could also be used as a piece of luggage.'' He found the Xporter, a cross between stewardess chic and student style.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRITZ, IRVING
description: FRITZ-Irving. Beloved husband of Florence. Loving father to Howard and daughter-in-law Viviane; grandsons Matthew and Michael. Veteran WWII. Died suddenly on January 12, 1999. Burial private.

title: Jay McInerney
description: A musical adaptation of his first novel, ''Bright Lights, Big City'' (1984), begins previews on Saturday at the New York Theater Workshop. The 44-year-old writer's latest book, his sixth, is ''Model Behavior.''

title: Netanyahu Dismisses His Minister Of Defense
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyhu of Israel dropped a political bombshell tonight, dismissing his popular Defense Minister, Yitzhak Mordechai, before Mr. Mordechai had a chance to quit to join a new centrist party.

title: Clean House
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELD, ISABEL
description: FELD-Isabel. Adored wife of Harold, cherished mother of Stephie and the late Gerry, loving and proud grandmother of Ben Harris, devoted sister of the late Harold Jurman. Isabel was a woman of great charm and wit, and her generosity to many worthy causes enriched the lives of the less fortunate. She will be missed. Funeral services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEAVING, CHARLOTTE A. (NEE BAUDREAU)
description: WEAVING-Charlotte A. (nee Baudreau). On Friday, January 21, 2000, of Wayne, NJ, formerly of Natick, MA. Beloved wife of Roger G. Weaving Sr.; loving mother of Roger G. Weaving Jr. of Dix Hills, NY, Ruth E. Maloney of Westfield, NJ, Diane W. Marine of Marietta, GA, David J. Weaving of Livingston, NJ; sister of James P. Baudreau, Ruth Shields, Joyce Coughlin, Mary Lou Dickson; also survived by ten grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, 9:45 AM, from the Vander May Wayne Colonial Funeral Home, 567 Ratzer Road, Wayne, NJ, then to Our Lady of Consolation R.C. Church, Wayne, NJ, where at 10:30 AM a funeral mass will be offered. Interment will be in Christ The King Cemetery, Franklin Lakes, NJ. Friends may call Tuesday 2-4, 7-9 PM.

title: 'The Haunted Wood'
description: To the Editor:

title: Stretch Market For Limousines
description: THE passengers in those limousines are not all haughty film stars sipping Cosmopolitan cocktails. In the last few weeks, I heard about a Halloween birthday party where 15 costumed 8-year-olds had a ball riding to a New York restaurant in a maximo limousine. A friend, at loggerheads with a son about who would drive the second car needed to get seven people to Connecticut for Christmas dinner, hired a stretch limo for the whole group for $240 each way and was delighted with the trip and the sociability.

title: In Praise of Bad Art
description: It's almost comical. Here we are at the end of our daring century -- the century that took the figure out of art, the plot out of fiction and the tune out of music -- and do you know who the hottest artist is? Norman Rockwell. The same Norman Rockwell whose name was once synonymous with bad taste. When I studied art history in college, Rockwell's illustrations of Santas and freckled Boy Scouts, of dogs and grandmothers, were dismissed as fluff for calendars. Professors spoke of him, if at all, with sneering disdain.

title: 'The Haunted Wood'
description: To the Editor:

title: An Appeal to Limit Depot Place Development
description: As a 45-year resident of Edgemont and former president of the Edgemont Association, the Greenville Community Council and the Edgemont Board of Education, I trust you will permit me to express my concern about the planned development at Freightway and Depot Place near the Scarsdale Metro-North station. The inevitable traffic congestion on ''break-neck hill'' is bound to have serious adverse effects not just on Edgemont residents but on anybody approaching or leaving downtown Scarsdale and hence on the entire commercial establishment downtown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACS, GILBERT
description: ISAACS-Gilbert, 82. Of Port Washington, NY died Wednesday, January 20, 1999. Beloved husband of Elvira. Loving father of Renee Weinberg of Roslyn, NY and Kim Seltzer of Montclair, NJ. Cherished grandfather of four grandchildren, Joanna, Alexa, Henry and Hayley. Dear brother of Gerard Isaacs of Syosset, NY. Uncle, granduncle and great granduncle of eleven. During World War II he was a Signal Corps Combat Photographer in the South Pacific. Both his grandfathers were Civil War Veterans. He was a prominent and well known retail jeweler in Ridgewood, Queens and Queens Village, Queens for over 50 years. An avid kayaker, he was known as the oldest kayaker in New York waters. At his and the family's request, he will be cremated.

title: State Plan to Expand Cranberry Farms Is Rejected
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency last week denied the state's application to expand cranberry bogs by 300 acres over the next five years. The plan was not specific enough on how to protect Atlantic white cedars and called for converting land to farming too quickly, the agency said. Those objections can probably be worked out in a future proposal, said an agency spokeswoman, Mary Mears.

title: Social Security Plan Is Too Timid
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, COLEMAN
description: BURKE-Coleman. Of Basking Ridge, NJ, and Oxford, NY, on Thursday, January 20, 2000. Husband of Mary Poston Burke. Father of Daniel Burke II, Coleman P. Burke and Mary B. Partridge. Also survived by nine grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Memorial service in Christ Church, 66 Highland Ave., Short Hills, NJ, on Friday, January 28, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to Hamilton College, Clinton, NY 13323 or American Bible Society, NY, NY.

title: A Scandal Tears Apart Olympic 'Family'
description: People in international Olympic circles have for many years been fond of describing the Olympics as a ''family.'' The term, combined with the ever-present logo of the five interlocked rings, suggested a shared mission, a unity that went beyond sports, a higher purpose.

title: Works by People on Margins of Society
description: PRIVATE WORLDS: Classic Outsider Art in Europe'' at the Katonah Museum of Art here is like a bolt from the blue. If any art is beyond criticism it is the work in this show, made by people who were really on the margins of society. Many of the artists made their work while in mental institutions.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: The Four-Star Chefs; Do Many Egos Spoil The Broth?
description: LAST Wednesday night, the banquet kitchen at the St. Regis Hotel felt more like a schoolyard, with cliques warily guarding their turf. David Waltuck, the chef at Chanterelle, and his team of cooks huddled by the dishwasher. Sottha Khunn, the chef at Le Cirque 2000, and nine of his cooks clung to the stove, and Christian Delouvrier, the chef at Lespinasse, stood by the elevator.

title: Where Sexual Lines Are Easily Crossed
description: WHEN it comes to issues of sexual identity, European films can be difficult for American viewers to talk about or even understand fully. We assume that Europeans, whose leaders can carry on extramarital affairs without falling from grace, are more sophisticated, more laissez- faire about sex in general and, specifically, about the blurring of hetero-, bi- and homosexuality. But we can't quite figure out how they achieve this nonchalance.

title: Tampering With the Time Clock
description: It's no secret that Americans work harder than the citizens of almost every other industrialized nation: longer hours, less vacation, more stress on the job. At least we're getting paid more money for all this extra work, we tell ourselves.

title: Rink Plan Called a Stunner
description: When bulldozers began moving earth two weeks ago in Little Bay Park, near Fort Totten, some local residents were stunned to learn that a $900,000 roller-hockey rink was on the way. They said they should have had a chance to debate the project.

title: Walter Kring, 82, Clergyman, Author and a Melville Scholar
description: The Rev. Walter Donald Kring, a Unitarian clergyman, author, ceramic artist and sleuth into the secrets of Herman Melville's private life, died on Jan. 15 at his home in East Brookfield, Mass. He was 82.

title: Lisa Cohen and Lewis Liman
description: LEWIS JEFFREY LIMAN is such a workaholic that his friends were not even sure he would make it through his wedding without having to answer a beeper, a fax or his own strong sense of obligation. During the reception, his mother, Ellen Liman, began her toast by saying: ''Lewis? Lewis, are you still there?'' When he replied that he was, she said, ''Oh, I just wanted to make sure you didn't leave for the office.''

title: Cops. Writers. Facts.
description: CRIME writing uses a language entirely its own, says Annette Meyers, a mystery writer, pictured at right. With her husband, Martin, Ms. Meyers is co-author of six books in ''The Dutchman'' series of history-mysteries about New York City, the latest of which is ''The Lucifer Contract.'' Today at 2 P.M., she will be the host of a panel of crime writers for a New-York Historical Society program, ''Cops and Writers: Cops and Citizens Who Write About Cops.''

title: A Dog's Life
description: There are about 280 dogs working in law enforcement in New Jersey, and sometimes they are placed in the line of fire. Last June, a dog named Solo, working for the Monmouth County Sheriff's Department, was killed by gunshot in a standoff with a robbery suspect in Asbury Park. So upset was Roseann Trezza, the assistant director of the Associated Humane Societies, that she began a drive to provide bulletproof vests for all the state's police dogs, all through donated money. Last month, Vested Interest, as her fund is called, presented 47 vests to dogs, and last week, an order went out for 21 more. Ms. Trezza priced vists at as much as $1,700 apiece but found a company that would see them to her for $300. That is a small investment, she points out, in an animal that often costs $5,000 to buy and thousands more to train. She has received a number of letters from police officers thanking her and reporting that the dogs moved easily and seemed comfortable wearing the vests. To meet her final goal, she needs to raise about $60,000 more. Donations may be sent to Roseann Trezza, Associated Humane Societies, 124 Evergreen Avenue, Newark, N.J. 07114.

title: January 17-23; Help for the Obese
description: It's not cheap, costing $116 a month in Europe. And it's not always pleasant, causing intestinal gas and loose stools in many who take it. But Hoffmann-La Roche, the maker of the new obesity drug orlistat, says it works and expects to get it on the American market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANK, BARBARA ALLMAN
description: DANK-Barbara Allman. On January 22, 1999. A 1938 graduate of Radcliffe College and the Harvard-Radcliffe Program in Business Administration, she was a pioneer in educating women about new and challenging roles from homemaker to business. A member of the Baldwin, LI School Board for many years, she served on the Board of the Stevens Scholarship Fund for Deserving Students at Baldwin High School. A certified financial planner, she designed and implemented the Seniors' Financial Planning Service at Family Services Association, Hempstead, LI. She retired in 1997 to develop an educational framework to include career development activities for children from kindergarten through high school. She is survived by son Harry, daughter Bonnie, daughter-in-law Shoshana, and grandchildren Micah and Avital. Services Sunday, 10:30 AM at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, LI. Donations to the Hospice of Howard County, 5537 Twin Knolls Rd., Columbia, MD 21045.

title: OPINION; Keeping All Universities Equal
description: SUNY'S board of trustees is requesting an additional $2 million in tax dollars to create a new Chancellor's Scholarship Program to attract top high school students to its campuses throughout the state. For Long Island, this effort should prompt an emergency call to action, given that higher education has become a core element upon which our regional economy is based. Even more important, our local colleges and universities reflect our best hope of retaining on Long Island the next generation of high school graduates who will power our future.

title: Plans to Preserve a Black Beach Enclave in Florida
description: A Jacksonville banker who bought an oceanfront lot in American Beach here last November plans to press for a master plan to stave off encroachment of high-end resorts on either side of an enclave that traces its special character back to the days of segregation.

title: Investing by Conscience Is Paying Off These Days
description: IT seems to have become easier for a camel to slip through the eye of a needle. That is the implication behind the proliferation of a particular kind of investor: one who considers social values as well as returns.

title: The Man Who Buckled Up the World
description: MORE than 40 years ago, a Swedish aircraft engineer was asked to observe a collision staged by Volvo to test a Y-shaped safety belt. The belt was a disappointment; its anchorages allowed a body to move under stress and its buckle could injure vital organs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREINER, WILLIAM R. (BOTANY BILL)
description: GREINER-William R. (Botany Bill), 87, died January 18, 2000. Beloved husband of Ina (nee Blanchette) Greiner for 34 years. Loving brother of Emma Greiner. He is survived by many friends and students of botany and the world of nature. His gentle and sharing manner will not be forgotten. A private Funeral will be held at graveside.

title: Ambulance Workers Fired After Man With Diabetes Dies
description: Two emergency medical technicians working for a Queens hospital were fired last week after they supposedly failed to follow correct emergency medical procedures while dealing with a man who later died, Fire Department and hospital officials said yesterday. Another emergency medical technician is under investigation for possibly mishandling a later telephone call from the man's wife

title: The Lives They Lived
description: I think Carl Perkins, who died on Jan. 19, 1998, deserved to be recognized. By writing and recording ''Blue Suede Shoes,'' in 1955, he established himself as one of the progenitors of rock and roll. Prior to this, no one had blended country, blues and pop music in quite this manner.

title: Remembering Woodrow Wilson
description: The Woodrow Wilson House in Washington is commemorating the 75th anniversary of Wilson's death with the exhibition ''Woodrow Wilson: An American Vision for the 20th Century,'' on display from Wednesday through April 12. The Georgian Revival town house, now a National Trust Historic Site and museum, was Wilson's last home.

title: A World Away From Basic Black
description: The bold colors and patterns of Lina Tsai's wares are a counterpoint to 90's minimalism and the perpetually black-clad New Yorker. The 27-year-old designer, who is from northern California, has been in New York for a year and a half. She opened her bright, tiny, self-named women's clothing store at 436 East Ninth Street, between First Avenue and Avenue A, six weeks ago.

title: 'Decadence' From the Turn of Another Century
description: AUBREY BEARDSLEY was enormously popular in his day, the final years of the 19th century, and that popularity surged in the 1960's, when many people saw the roots of psychedelia in his work. But his art has never been entirely out of favor, and one reason is that, while brash, it is also voluptuous.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: In limiting Bella Abzug's feminist politics and accomplishments to the 1960's and 1970's, Gail Collins ignores her emergence as a beloved global leader of the international women's movement in the last decades of her remarkable life (''When Politics Had Passion''). Awarded a Blue Beret by the United Nations for her peace work, Bella made her last and typically passionate speech at the United Nations, entering the hospital the next day for her final journey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLASS, SHOLOM, RABBI
description: KLASS-Sholom, Rabbi. In our generation, he, together with Rabbi J. B. Soloveichik and Rabbi P. Teitz were the giants in public dissemination of Torah. Tanchumim to Klass Greenwald Mauer families. E. Magnus Oppenheim and Family

title: BEYOND THE CANAL, PANAMA PRISTINE
description: I WENT to Panama on a hunch last September, which was pretty much the only way I could go. Reliable travel information about the country was surprisingly difficult to find.

title: In Brooklyn, Russian Jokes Keep Their Sting
description: Everyone's a comedian.

title: Q.F.R.'s to the Rescue
description: A surprising number of funds from Fidelity Investments managed to turn in impressive performances in 1998, with 10 of the fund giant's United States diversified offerings managing to beat the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for the year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVINE, BERNARD
description: LEVINE-Bernard. Good friend, you'll always be remembered and dearly missed. The Birnbaum Family

title: Pataki Offers $350 Million In Tax Cuts For Businesses
description: Gov. George E. Pataki proposed a package of new tax cuts today aimed at businesses, but like the personal income tax cuts he called for last week, most would not take effect for a year or more.

title: Decoding The Murky Rent Laws
description: WHILE most New Yorkers are aware that there are two basic forms of rent regulation -- rent control and rent stabilization -- there is often confusion about what each does and where each came from. Here are some of the more significant differences between rent control and rent stabilization, along with a brief description of their origins.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: THE ESSENCE OF THE THINGBy Madeleine St. John.Carroll & Graf, $22.

title: January 17-23; Chinese Entrepreneur Sentenced for E-Mail
description: China must be one of the few places in the world where a two-year jail term for sending E-mail can be considered light. Last week, a Shanghai court sent Lin Hai, 30, to prison for subversion. His crime was sending 30,000 E-mail addresses to an electronic publication based in the United States. In a tight political atmosphere, the Chinese authorities worried about the 10th anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown are leaning on publishers, writers and journalists. Just this month dissidents got sentences of 10 years and more. SETH FAISON

title: Jill Kaplan And Wayne Katz
description: Jill Rebecca Kaplan, the international advertising sales manager for The Wall Street Journal in New York, was married last evening to Wayne David Katz, an associate at the New York law firm of Proskauer Rose. Rabbi Meir Berger officiated at TriBeCa Rooftop in New York.

title: Spices Perk Up Sea Scallops, Shrimps or Sausages
description: SOME people crave a hot bowl of soup when the weather turns cold. Others find comfort in an old-fashioned stew or pot roast or a dish as simple as buttered toast or a baked potato. I want something spicy.

title: Virtual Higher Education. So What's New?
description: TODAY, I am opening the doors to what we call the New Jersey Virtual University. This initiative provides an on-line index of distance learning courses offered by colleges and universities across the state. And it invests $500,000 to help faculty members learn how to best incorporate this technology into their curriculum. . . .

title: Amy McGill, John Dilatush
description: Amy Crean McGill, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Harry McGill 3d of New York, was married yesterday to Edward John Dilatush, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Dilatush of Washington Crossing, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Mark S. Anschutz performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: History, and Fun, on a Carousel
description: GERRY HOLZMAN has been carving his dream for 16 years. A full-sized wooden carousel based on the history, geography and folklore of New York State. A merry-go-round of school lessons, complete with a band organ playing New York songs. Portrait panels of famous New Yorkers, murals depicting important events and places and 28 carved animals, native to the state, to ride upon.

title: Kerchiefs to Turn Heads
description: One woman's babushka is another's chapeau. At downtown boutiques like Spooly D's, at Bleecker and Lafayette Streets, and uptown stores like Bergdorf Goodman, head-kerchiefs -- little pieces of fabric typically knotted at the nape of the neck -- have become a hot-selling accessory because of their retro appeal. But retro to what? Rhoda Morgenstern? Aunt Jemima? John F. Kennedy Jr.?

title: Untangling Emerging Markets
description: EVEN with the sharp rebound in Brazilian stocks, the world's emerging markets are still down nearly 50 percent from their 1997 highs, bringing more than a few fund managers' reputations down with them. The selloff also undermined the widely held notion that emerging markets are fertile ground for active fund managers.

title: Why Grizzlies Love Twinkies
description: EVERY CREEPING THING

title: At Birthplace Of Be-Bop, Revival Blues
description: Two years ago, the actor Robert De Niro, the restaurateur Drew Nieporent and Melba Wilson, a lifelong Harlem resident who worked for years at Sylvia's Restaurant, announced plans to renovate and reopen Minton's Playhouse, the legendary jazz hall in the Cecil Hotel at 118th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. At a recent meeting of Community Board 10, several people wondered aloud what happened to those plans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBER, WILLIAM
description: OBER-William. 94, of Manchester, CT, died Thursday, January 20. He was the husband of the late Sally (Breslau) Ober. Born in New York City, he had lived in New York until moving to Connecticut in 1997. He was a graduate of City College of New York, Class of 1926, a member of the Sigma Alpha Mu Fraternity, Alpha Chapter and was also a Trustee of Sigma Alpha Mu Foundation. He was in the diamond business with A. Jaffe & Sons for 59 years. He served as a docent at the Museum of the City of New York, and he volunteered in the Public Entitlements Department of Roosevelt Hospital from 1986 to 1996. He is survived by his brother-in-law and sisters-in-law, Sam & Frances Breslau and Claire Breslau, all of West Hartford, and many nieces and nephews. Funeral services Sunday, January 23, at 1 PM, at Ladd-Turkington Funeral Home, 551 Talcottville Rd. (Rt. 83), Vernon, CT. Burial will follow. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the charity of the donor's choice.

title: Nanny's Failed Safari
description: The horror of growing up with an alcoholic is a staple of memoirs. Frank McCourt's father drank the food money; Mary Karr's mother hallucinated about killing her own children; and many recall dipso relatives who made very bad baby sitters. It's better for everybody when these people are hauled into rehab.

title: Admirers of Both
description: To the Editor:

title: Tasting the Robust, Earthy Food of Peru
description: THERE are culinary gaps on Long Island. Adventurous eaters who want to sample the foods of Hungary, Austria, Chile, the Czech Republic, Ethiopia, Sweden, South Africa, Morocco, Denmark or Norway, among others, must head for Manhattan or find a home-cooked ethnic meal. Until a few months ago, Peru was on that list. Then Rosa Gonzalez, a schoolteacher from Lima, took over a Main Street bar in Bay Shore (its last occupant was the Tropical Haven Bistro, but before that it housed a string of gin mills) and turned it into Jose Antonio.

title: Sports of The Times; Sprewell? Strickland? Rodman? Knicks Can Bring 'Em All On
description: THIS season is going to be nutty enough, so the Knicks might as well load up on characters rather than character.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOMBOS, MARIA
description: GOMBOS-Maria. Our guardian angel, Maria Gombos, passed away on January 22. We will always love her and remember her. Nita and Aurica

title: U.S Jets Attack Missile Sites in Southern Iraq
description: American jets attacked two Iraqi surface-to-air missile batteries today after encountering antiaircraft fire and MIG jets in the no-flight zone over southern Iraq, a Pentagon spokesman said.

title: Arkansas Senator Is Careful to Maintain Impartiality
description: Senator Blanche Lincoln seems anxious to show she is not in the tank for her fellow Democrat and Arkansan, President Clinton; over and over, in an interview in her office last week, she volunteered that she was trying to make good on her oath of impartiality.

title: Ms. Foreman, Mr. Kleinschmidt
description: Nell Foreman and Robert William Kleinschmidt were married yesterday at the Round Hill Club in Montego Bay, Jamaica. The Rev. Terrance Gordon of the Door of Faith Church of God officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MC CLOSKEY, CORNELIUS J.
description: Mc CLOSKEY-Cornelius J. Beloved husband of Muriel, dear father of Suzanne McLain, Cornelia McGrath and Celeste McCloskey, and grandfather of Suzannah Smith, Matthew McGrath, James McLain, and Shane McGrath died peacefully at his home on January 20th. May he dwell in the house of the Lord forever.

title: That Smell'st So Sweet
description: After all the smelling salts and perfumed-hankie waving in the movies ''Elizabeth'' and ''Shakespeare in Love,'' consumers may be ready for the 1990's version: portable aromatherapy products to re-odorize your personal space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURDMAN, SYLVIA
description: BURDMAN-Sylvia. On January 21, 1999. Beloved wife of Murray Burdman, devoted and loving mother of Meryl Levenson & Joan Josephs, loving sister of Shelley Goren, cherished grandmother of Jonathan, Glenn, Erin, and Brittany, great-grandmother of Zack. She had a deep spiritual committmemt to family, she will be greatly missed, and forever in our hearts. Our lives were blessed to have such an extraordinary mother whose love, devotion, support, had no bounds. Graveside service Sunday 12:30 at Beth Moses.

title: Everybody Says He's Special
description: Elton Brand greeted a visitor to Duke University last week by warmly reaching out to shake hands with his right hand, which is the size of a baseball mitt. Then Brand wrapped his left hand over the top of the handshake, creating a baseball mitt sandwich of sorts. He grinned and offered his official welcome to Cameron Indoor Stadium, his basketball home. It seemed natural to smile with him.
