title: Fox Logo on Sail Dimming ESPN America's Cup Deal
description: It's an America's Cup outcome easy to imagine: the New York Yacht Club's sailing syndicate prevails against 14 challengers in the cup trials. Its sailboat ends up racing New Zealand's defender next February for yachting's oldest trophy.

title: The World: Lost Horizon; The World Expected Peace. It Found a New Brutality.
description: AROUND the world the crises pile up, and the collage of headlines does not make a pretty picture. In Kosovo, babies die of cold on hillsides where mothers have fled to save their lives. In Sierra Leone, madmen posing as a rebel army cut off the hands of teen-aged boys and trap families in their homes to torch them. Angolans shoot down relief planes. A defiant Saddam Hussein watches the United Nations drift helplessly without a policy. Haiti spirals back into chaos. And the chief judge of an international tribunal is stopped cold at Serbia's border when she tries to investigate crimes against humanity in Kosovo.

title: Word for Word/Witch Hunters' Manual; Look at His Navel, He's a Devil. She's A Witch Because She's, Um, Female.
description: THE term ''witch hunt,'' much heard during the past year, is usually resurrected during cultural wars. With all the current hyperbole -- ''witches' brew'' was the term used last week by the White House counsel, Charles F. C. Ruff, to describe the charges against President Clinton in his impeachment trial -- it might be useful to reflect on the days when a witch hunt was really a hunt for witches.

title: Manhattan Cable to Drop Channel With Religious Shows
description: On Wednesday, fans of the Odyssey Channel who live in Manhattan will be able to tune in to worship services, gospel music shows, theological discussions and extensive coverage of Pope John Paul II's trip to St. Louis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLAUBINGER, ESTHER
description: GLAUBINGER-Esther. The Riverdale Jewish Center mourns the loss of our member, Esther Glaubinger. We extend profound condolences to her children, Bashie and Sam Nierenberg and Rebecca and Marc Shaffren; to her grandchildren and the family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Escalating Scandal Tears Apart 'Family'
description: People in international Olympic circles have for many years been fond of describing the Olympics as a ''family.'' The term, combined with the ever-present logo of the five interlocked rings, suggested a shared mission, a unity that went beyond sports, a higher purpose.

title: A Prescription for Success?
description: IN the Canadian Rockies last summer, Peter and Sheryl Neupert perched on a purple tandem bicycle and looked up one of the steepest hills they had ever seen. Most other bikers in their group demurred, but the Neuperts pushed on -- with Sheryl providing the kick to the top.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Haitian Art Collection

title: A Pal to Orphans
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, PHILIP
description: HIRSCH-Philip. Beloved husband of Belle (Zwiebel). Devoted father of Debra and Martin Coopersmith, Phyllis and Paul Klein, and Carl and Marilyn Hirsch. Cherished grandfather of Susan and Gerald Silberman, Robert Coopersmith, David Cohen and Louis and Bryan Hirsch. Loving great-grandfather of Emma and Jason Silberman. Dear brother of Jack Hirsch and the late Moe Hirsch and Edna Kagan. Service ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Sunday, 11:30 AM.

title: Correction
description: An article on Jan. 10 about Blue Note Records misspelled the name of its parent label. It is Capitol Records, not Capital.

title: Last-Minute Bargains For Amtrak Travelers
description: Amtrak has introduced Rail Sale, an on-line program that allows travelers to buy reserved tickets for selected one-way coach seats at substantial discounts.

title: All's Fair?
description: ALL THE LAWS BUT ONE

title: Young, Talented, Tasteless
description: ONE of the things Seth MacFarlane liked about animation when he was growing up was the way it elasticized reality. Anvils dropped without consequence and skunks sang in French, creating a sort of pluperfect pliability through which he could retreat from a world where people treated him, shockingly, like a child and enter one where he was in complete control. There, in the manner of a visiting deity, he spoke for everyone, he had all the money in the world, and a thought never entered anyone's head that he didn't put there.

title: Improving Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Planning for Putting Up a Tin Ceiling
description: TIN ceilings became very popular toward the end of the last century. Victorians were fond of ornate and decorative ceiling treatments; they found that the tin ceilings were practical because they covered up the unsightly network of cracks that often developed in plaster ceilings.

title: The View From/West Redding; Train Station Moves Down the Track
description: THE residents of Redding are usually suspicious of construction. But they made an exception for the new Metro-North Commuter Railroad station being completed a short walk from the old one, both in West Redding.

title: INSIDE
description: Social Security Debate

title: They Stand by Their Granola
description: Wandering the aisles at the Whole Foods store on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, Meg Berlin, 43, said there was a time when she was prone to follow health food fads, eating macrobiotic foods at one point, and another time trying a diet for people with her blood type.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATTEN, WILLIAM M.
description: BATTEN-William M. The Board of Directors of The New York Stock Exchange, Inc., wish to express their deep sorrow on the passing of their dear friend and esteemed colleague, William M. (Mil) Batten, Chairman of The Exchange from 1976 to 1984. His dedication and committment to The Exchange and to the securities industry will be greatly missed. Richard A. Grasso Chairman and Chief Executive Officer New York Stock Exchange, Inc.

title: In the New Russia, Comedy Lacks Bite
description: IT'S not hard to make fun of what is happening in Russia these days. New jokes about the new rich (now the new poor after last summer's financial crisis) are posted on the Internet. President Boris N. Yeltsin's fumbling speech is always an easy laugh. There may be more comedy routines about bank failures than there are solvent banks in Russia. But real humor -- the deep, biting, funny-sad satire that makes Russians laugh, usually at themselves -- has become rarer, or at least so says Mikhail Zhvanetsky, the country's premier stand-up comedian and humor writer.

title: Sports of The Times; L. T. Fits Hall of Fame Criteria
description: WHEN he was a Giants linebacker, you never had to search for Lawrence Taylor. He was always right where he was supposed to be, charging the quarterback he hoped to sack or chasing down a ballcarrier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, JOHN C.
description: MURPHY-John C. Age 72, of Alpharetta, GA, died January 23, 1999. He is survived by his wife, Alice; son, John F.; a brother, Harvey J. of Glen Cove, LI, and predeceased by a son, Thomas. Mr. Murphy retired in 1987 after 42 years of service with the Mobil Oil Corporation in New York City. In lieu of flowers contributions to ''Friends of Karen'', PO Box 190, Purdys, NY 10578 or to the American Cancer Society, 3545 Cruse Road, Suite #

title: Murals Without Walls
description: The cover of POSADA'S BROADSHEETS: Mexican Popular Imagery, 1890-1910 (University of New Mexico, cloth, $50; paper, $24.95) shows an engraving of a crazed man savagely chewing on a baby's body while a winged dragonlike creature looks down menacingly from the air. This surreal image was but one of many such gruesome pictures designed by the Mexican artist Jose Guadalupe Posada (1852-1913) and created for Antonio Vanegas Arroyo, a leading publisher of broadsheets -- single-page periodicals -- that reported on lurid crimes, executions, bullfights, cultural events and politics. A precursor of today's tabloids, broadsheets were cheaply printed and widely distributed as news and entertainment to Mexico City's urban masses. They were the most ephemeral of printed matter, bought, read and tossed away -- even Posada did not save the majority of his works. But ''taken together, they form a 'people's history' of life in Mexico City during the years bracketing the turn of the 20th century,'' writes the book's author, Patrick Frank, who teaches art history at the University of Colorado, Boulder. Posada was a hugely prolific commercial artist, designing newspaper advertisements, product labels and magazine illustrations; his work and import were rediscovered in the 1920's by the Mexican political muralists Diego Rivera and Jose Clemente Orozco and the French printmaker Jean Charlot. Posada, whose imagery is reminiscent of Goya, is now considered one of Mexico's most acerbic commentators and satirists. Although the prints are mistakenly reproduced in halftone, which diminishes the strength of the artist's powerful black line, ''Posada's Broadsheets'' nonetheless offers an insightful analysis of both the art and the history of the time when it was created. Steven Heller

title: How the Eggheads Cracked
description: A lot of unusual things have happened in the four months since Long-Term Capital Management announced that it lost more than $4 billion in a bizarre six-week financial panic late last summer, but nothing nearly so unusual as what hasn't happened. None of the 180 employees of the hedge fund have stood up to explain, to fess up or to excuse themselves from the table. Even the two Nobel Laureates on staff, who could very easily have slipped back into their caps and gowns in the dead of night and pretended none of this ever happened, have stayed and worked, quietly. The man in charge, John Meriwether, has shown a genius for lying low. Photographers in helicopters circle his house, and journalists bang on his front door at odd hours and frighten his wife. Yet whenever the question ''Who is John Meriwether?'' has demanded an answer, it has been supplied not by those who know him and work with him but by a self-appointed cast of casual acquaintances and perfect strangers. They have described Meriwether and his colleagues as reliable Wall Street stereotypes: the overreaching, self-deluded speculators. In doing so they have missed pretty much everything interesting about them.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: SUNNYSIDE

title: 'Evita' at 20: Will a Musical Be High-Flying, Adored Again?
description: DON'T try to sing ''Argentina.'' The truth is in the guttural sound. Try ''Ahentina,'' or even ''Odd-hen-tina.'' To get the second syllable right, bring it in from the back of your tongue to the front. Think of a mad chicken -- a vocal coach's tip, really -- and of the lyric ''All through my wild days.''

title: With This Ring: Women Fall for Boxing
description: WHEN Kathy Collins of Huntington wanted to shed some pounds a few years ago, she headed for the gym. But unlike the women who join plush health clubs and climb onto elaborate exercise machines, Ms. Collins climbed into the ring.

title: My Brief, Weird Life as a Stand-Up Comic
description: THERE'S only one thing more humiliating than being a stand-up comic. And that's trying to be a stand-up comic. That's the lesson I learned after six months trying to make it as a comedian. Ask Jerry Seinfeld, Rosie O'Donnell or any successful stand-up: the bottom rung of the comedy ladder can be uglier, crueler and more demeaning than in any other line of entertainment -- be it actor, model, musician, writer or clown. Sexism and racism run rampant, club-owners ask struggling comedians to scrape gum off the bottom of tables to get a booking, competition between comics is fierce, and newcomers have to pay to perform. For comedy clubs, aspiring comedians aren't a source of new talent: they're extra revenue.

title: Women's Suicides Reveal Rural China's Bitter Roots
description: Wang Xuexia remembers vividly the cool May night when the minibus raced past newly planted fields of rice and corn and dropped her high school classmate at the emergency room, disheveled and semiconscious, exuding the sickly sweet odor of pesticide.

title: New York Lends a Hand To Ailing 'Eco' Cleaners
description: LAST November, the TriBeCa Ecomat, a cleaner that shunned a potentially carcinogenic solvent used by most dry-cleaning companies, closed its doors. It was a quiet death for a shop that had had a noisy birth.

title: Jeffrey Kepnes, Elizabeth Claman
description: Elizabeth Kate Claman, a television news anchor and correspondent, and Jeffrey Scott Kepnes, a television producer, were married last evening in Beverly Hills, Calif. Rabbi Jacob Pressman officiated at the Beverly Hills Hotel.

title: Abstract Painters in a Domestic Space Under Restoration
description: THE John Slade Ely House in New Haven, which defines itself as a center for contemporary art, has long been a place to see new painting and sculpture, but the interior layout of the Elizabethan-style building makes a somewhat awkward viewing space. Some rooms have more than four walls, and some of the walls are too narrow to support art. And since wall space is what counts in a gallery, many of the windows were covered to provide it. That, of course, blocked out the light.

title: For Freshman, a Case as Novel as Job
description: Peter G. Fitzgerald spent the fall traveling across Illinois in the back of a Winnebago, plotting his campaign to unseat Senator Carol Moseley-Braun, the Democratic incumbent.

title: Starting From Scratch, Again
description: The art publisher Nicholas Callaway insists that his effort to publish high-quality books about golf will be revived, even though the enterprise is looking more and more like a missed swing. According to publishing industry sources, the project's de facto editor in chief, David McCormick, was given 20 minutes this month to clean out his desk in the old mill building at South Street Seaport that housed a dwindling staff of 20 editors, writers and designers for Callaway Golf Media Ventures. Soon afterward, the staff's computers were removed. Mr. McCormick didn't return phone calls.

title: Backtalk; Change Is Demanded to Right the Olympic Wrongs
description: The scandal surrounding the selection of Salt Lake City for the 2002 Olympics is only a symptom of a more deeply rooted problem, which will require a major shake-up of sport's international ruling bodies if we are to preserve and protect the Olympic ideal. This crisis requires a drastic reform of the International Olympic Committee and its overly pampered ''lords'' and a renewed focus on its real purpose: the athletes and fair competition.

title: Marc Falcone and Caitlin Halligan
description: Caitlin Joan Halligan and Marc Christopher Francesco Falcone were married in Manhattan on Friday. Judge Pierre N. Leval of the Federal Court of Appeals in New York officiated in his chambers. Today, Judge Patricia M. Wald of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit is to lead a celebration of the marriage at Windows on the World in Manhattan.

title: Rewrite a Classic Musical? Whatever Works Goes
description: WITH all the usual madcap agony of making theater, they are trying to fix another big-budget musical out of town. Songs that fall flat are rejected. Characters that don't click are re-thought. The running order of numbers is rejiggered, the bad jokes are rewritten, the ethnic stereotypes that crept in are removed, the bumps in the plot repaved.

title: Corrections
description: A restaurant review on Dec. 27 about Crabtree's in Floral Park included a proprietor's erroneous reference to characters and actors in the ''Our Gang'' films, and to a connection between the actors and the restaurant.

title: Through Good and Bad, the French Love Her
description: MIOU-MIOU has appeared in good films and bad, hits and flops, yet for 25 years France's affection for her has not wavered. True, being loved has been no guarantee of good screen roles or healthy box-office returns. Yet, for an entire generation of French moviegoers, she remains reassuringly familiar. Her very stage name, Miou-Miou, given to her by a lover when she was barely 18, makes her sound like the gamine next door.

title: Deep and Dishy
description: Why pie? why now, in the furrow of time between the dead of winter and any hint of spring?

title: Where the President's Sins Aren't Winked At and a Terrible Price Is Feared
description: In this stretch of the Bible Belt where highways are punctuated with billboards about ''Heaven. Hell. The Choice Is Yours,'' it has been one bad week.

title: He Gained Respect Without Honoring Convention
description: WHEN the authoritative New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians was published in 1980, the assessment of the English conductor Sir Colin Davis by the influential critic and scholar Andrew Porter seemed a bit tough. ''Davis is a conductor of powerful enthusiasms rather than of steady all-round excellence,'' Mr. Porter wrote, ''and from this come both his strengths and his failings.''

title: A 12th-Century Abbey Yields Its Secrets
description: A FEW months ago, Ward and Company, New York dealers of ancient and medieval art, sent out a lavish, fold-out booklet of photographs to display some of the rare objects from its collection. Most of the objects were from prehistoric or classical times, but an arresting one was from the medieval world: an arcade, or arch, from a 12th-century Romanesque choir screen from the church of the Abbey of Cluny in Burgundy. This architectural fragment was enticing because it conjured up an entire structure yet stood on its own as a piece of sculpture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STREINER, RUTH
description: STREINER-Ruth. Farewell, dear sister. May you find peace at last. Brothers Martin, Manny and Roy Zisser

title: Unexpected Praise From the Ivory Tower
description: SECURITIES analysts, highly paid as they are on Wall Street, often get precious little respect from academics. Perhaps the analysts' biggest ignominy was research conducted in the late 1970's, whose conclusions since have become part of the ivory tower's canon. According to those devastating studies, the average stock that has no analyst following it actually outperforms the average stock that does.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNDERWOOD, JAMES M.
description: UNDERWOOD-James M. On Saturday, January 22, 2000. Retired Chairman of the Board of Vulcan, Inc. Father of Anne Potts of Greensburg, PA, Thomas S. Underwood of Jacksonville, FL, and Charles P. Underwood of Horse Heads, NY. Calling hours on Tuesday from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM at the Hartman-Graziano Funeral Home, Inc., 1500 Ligonier Street, Latrobe, PA 15650 (724) 537-5575. Funeral services Wednesday at 11 AM in Unity Chapel, Latrobe, PA. Contributions to Latrobe Area Hospital Charitable Foundation, West 2nd Avenue, Latrobe, PA 15650.

title: Turnpike Will Give Trucks A Break on Diesel Fuel
description: Truck drivers on the New Jersey Turnpike will get an 11 cent discount on each gallon of diesel fuel starting Feb. 1, with the price dropping from $1.05 to 94 cents.

title: Symphony Space Deal Raises Plenty of Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORN, MANNY
description: KORN-Manny. Beloved husband of Helen. Loving father of Linda Yehudit Korn, Shulamis and Chona Larkin and Michelle and Robert Karin. Cherished grandfather. Admired and respected by many during his 50 year career in the housewares industry. Services today, 1 PM, at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn. Interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEWIRTZMAN, ETHEL
description: GEWIRTZMAN-Ethel (nee Kleinhaus). Daughter of the late Samuel and Sarah Kleinhaus. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Henry J. Gewirtzman. Adored and adoring mother of Joan G. Smith and the late Dr. Harold Smith. A righteous and devout woman of grace, intelligence, empathy, fortitude and loyalty. Former teacher of English at North Bergen High School and St. Peter's College of Jersey City. Lifelong Trustee and past president of Temple Beth El of Jersey City. Services Tuesday at noon, Temple Beth El, 2419 Kennedy Blvd, Jersey City, NJ. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Temple Beth El. For information ''Wien & Wien'' 800322-0533.

title: Spies Wanted
description: The phone yanked Steve Drescher from a deep slumber early on a mid-November Monday. He shook the weekend's cobwebs from his head and mumbled hello. The Central Intelligence Agency was calling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, DOROTHY M.
description: HART-Dorothy M. On January 22, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Frank J. Loving mother of Kenneth, Ronald and Gary. Devoted grandmother of Victoria, Christian, Jaclyn and Fiona. Devoted mother-in-law of Cathy and Lenore. Family will receive friends on Monday, January 24, 2000, from 25 and 7-9 PM, at Williams Funeral Home, Inc., 5628 Broadway at 232 St., Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Gabriel's Church (Riverdale), on Tuesday, January 25, 2000, at 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: I read your issue and remembered, with pleasure, the famous people who died in 1998. As I was reading, however, a name came to mind that was not included on your list -- Adolph Rothenberg, my father. He was not a famous man, but he was from a generation that was forced, and able, to stand up for what it believed in. He defended his nation in World War II, living in a foxhole in the Philippines for eight months.

title: Don't Trust Car Dealers? Here's a New Deal
description: DONALD THORNTON, a successful Ford dealer here for many years, still recalls his anger on the day three decades ago when his daughter Kathy, then 7, came home from a birthday party in tears.

title: January 17-23; Raul Salinas Found Guilty Of Assassination
description: In a verdict that signaled the end of impunity for the mighty in Mexico, a federal judge convicted Raul Salinas de Gortari, the brother of former President Carlos Salinas, of masterminding the 1994 political assassination of a prominent politician. The judge, Ricardo Ojeda Bohorquez, also sentenced Mr. Salinas to 50 years in prison.

title: About Those Alligators in the Sewers . . .
description: Alligators and coaxial cable have both found a home on New York Underground, a feature on National Geographic magazine's Web site. For anyone who has ever wondered what might lurk below the city's streets, it offers a sandhog's view of New York's innards.

title: In the Footsteps Of Ponce de Leon
description: BABY BOOMERS are aging but not gracefully. Refusing to give in to wrinkles, sags and spreading middles, both men and women are seeking cosmetic surgery in record numbers. Westchester reflects the national trend -- in the last five years, the number of people seeking the most popular form of cosmetic surgery, liposuction, more than tripled, while the number of women undergoing breast enlargements recorded a fourfold increase.

title: Classic Oratory
description: If President Clinton is acquitted in his impeachment trial, Dale Bumpers, the former Senator from Arkansas, may well receive a share of the credit. At a time when the nation had tuned out the torrent of words on both sides of this debate, Americans seem to have listened closely to Mr. Bumpers and been persuaded by him.

title: Despite Billions Spent, A History of Failures
description: After decades of neglect and deferred maintenance that left New York City schools crumbling, leaky, shabby and sometimes dangerous, the State Legislature created the School Construction Authority in 1988 with a mandate to resurrect the vast archipelago of 1,100 aging public school buildings by Jan. 1, 2000.

title: U.S. Coach Begins From the Ground Up
description: Bruce Arena, the new coach of the United States men's national soccer team, does not have a rebuilding job ahead of him. It is more like buying a new house that is a handyman's special. The foundation is there, but there is much work to be done.

title: The Public's Invited to This Hollywood Party
description: Here's the sort of scene television viewers don't get to see at the Golden Globe Awards: Two years ago Tom Cruise praised Dustin Hoffman lavishly in presenting him with the Cecil B. DeMille Award for lifetime achievement, then offered more accolades in an interview for reporters that was not on camera. Mr. Hoffman remained before the press, talking on and on about his career, while Mr. Cruise departed, then returned later, swilling a beer and shouting raucously from the back of the room, ''I just went and did two interviews, and you're still up there talking?''

title: January 17-23; Special Funds for Iraq
description: Even with oil prices at record lows, Iraq has begun to sell enough oil under a special United Nations relief program that Baghdad can make improvements in its broken-down electrical supply system.

title: The First Shot Is Fired In the Lyme Disease War
description: IN 14 years as a public health nurse for the Dutchess County Health Department, Evelyn Kaufmann spent untold hours giving talks at campgrounds and schools about avoiding the tiny ticks that carry the bacteria causing Lyme disease.

title: Olympic Ideals and the Raw Truth Are Now Facing Off Because Restraint Vanished
description: As senior officials of the International Olympic Committee completed a report on the Salt Lake City bribery scandal, they were met with a troubling reality. The financial revival that saved the Olympics 15 years ago has mutated into the big-money excesses that threaten to cripple the Games today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLASTER, SANFORD
description: CLASTER-Sanford. On January 21st, 1999. Beloved husband of Betsy. Loving father of Bob, Scott, Lois and Diane. Dear brother of Jean. Adoring grandfather of Max and Zoe. Graveside service on Sunday, 11 AM, at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYENDORFF, HELENE
description: MEYENDORFF - Helene (nee Wrangel), 89. Of Spring Valley, NY. Beloved mother of the late Philip K. Hills, Jr. and Daria Kerdel-Vegas, and grandmother of Marielena Jutrowski, Alexander Kerdel-Vegas, Peter Hills and Philip K. Hills, III. Died January 22, 1999 after a long illness. Funeral Services will be held Saturday at 5:30 PM and a Mass and Burial Service on Sunday at 10:30 AM at the Russian Orthodox Convent of ''Novo Diveevo'', 100 Smith Road, Nanuet, New York. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be sent to the Convent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOINESTER, ISAAC E.
description: MOINESTER-Isaac E. Age 86, died January 23, 1999, Sunrise, FL. A principled philosopher, writer and retired printer for The New York Times. Passionate music lover and reader. A quiet and introspective intellectual. Joins his wife Rose with God. Devoted father of Deanna, Cindy, Murray and Alice. Grandfather of eight, great-grandfather of nine. ''Go peacefully as you have lived, drive carefully.'' Graveside service Sunday, January 24, 2:30 PM, Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI.

title: A Divided Iraq May Not Be Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Milsteins' Plan for Isles Is Approved
description: Should Howard Milstein succeed in his bid to buy the Washington Redskins of the National Football League, his stake in the National Hockey League's Islanders will be purchased by his brother Edward, N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman said today.

title: What Welfare-to-Work Really Means
description: It is unfortunate that you chose the word ''jihad'' to describe Mayor Giuliani's assault on poor families in the subhead to Jason DeParle's article (Dec. 20). The word has been co-opted by terrorists, and one would hope that The Times would get it right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELL, DAVID
description: MANDELL-David. Dearly beloved husband of Beatrice died on January 12th, 1999 after a short illness. The family mourns the loss of a cherished member. He was defined by his intellect, integrity and dedication to family and friends. David will be missed by all who knew him.

title: Crime Count: Which Areas Are Safest?
description: Even more than politics, all crime is local. The news from the Police Department that New York had fewer reported killings in 1998 than in 1964 may hold little comfort for someone who was mugged or whose car was stolen last year. When it comes to personal safety, criminologists note, perception often lags behind reality.

title: Birthright for Sale
description: THE CONVERSION

title: 'The Haunted Wood'
description: To the Editor:

title: Lurching Toward Chaos, Ending With Hope
description: The grim cliche for the nation's yearlong ordeal by scandal -- all Monica, all the time -- closed in threateningly on the grandeur of the Senate today from the morning's combative exchanges in President Clinton's impeachment trial.

title: Couture, the Game for Pure Players
description: Just about everyone who comes to the haute couture collections knows that Nan is Nan Kempner, that Deeda is Deeda Blair and that Liliane Bettencourt, who was seated Wednesday in the front row at the Yves Saint Laurent show and wearing an orange muffler, is the richest woman in France. They may or may not know that the youngest couture customer at Givenchy is all of 8, or that Dodie Rosekrans, the San Francisco art patron and couture stalwart, recently bought a full-size guillotine covered with the Chanel logo for her home in Venice. But give them time. Paris is probably the only place on earth where the world's rich, titled and tucked can always count on being connected, if only through clothes.

title: Home-Grown Style at a Venerable Museum
description: THERE'S probably no single reason why hundreds of people are streaming into the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford each week to view the collection of 300-year-old paintings by Pieter de Hooch (pronounced dah HOKE). Some are no doubt enchanted with the artist's idealized visions of 17th-century life in the Netherlands. Others may go to admire his delicate treatment of light and texture. Still others may know that this is the first time de Hooch, commonly sampled in survey books, has gotten a show of his own.

title: Wearing Attitude Like Urban Armor
description: DISTRACTED, fumbling with papers on an East Side bus, clearly not taking care of business, I inserted my MetroCard upside down. The driver ostentatiously eyeballed my coat, took me for a salaryman who couldn't afford a cab, and said, ''Try to put it in the right way, sir.''

title: Laser Pointers Are Not Toys
description: In the Jan. 17 article ''Laxity in Laser Enforcement,'' the growing concern that laser pointers are being misused is appropriately noted.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: Upon hearing the news of Roy Rogers's death:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HULTS, DOROTHY N.
description: HULTS-Dorothy N. Died January 20 in Westboro, MA, at age 101. Graveside services Tuesday at 2 PM in the Alpine Cemetery, Perth Amboy, NJ. Donations to Wellesley College Alumni Fund, Wellesley MA 02181.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, JOHN C.
description: MURPHY-John C. Age 72, of Alpharetta, GA, died January 23, 1999. He is survived by his wife, Alice; son, John F.; a brother, Harvey J. of Glen Cove, LI, and predeceased by a son, Thomas. Mr. Murphy retired in 1987 after 42 years of service with the Mobil Oil Corporation in New York City. In lieu of flowers contributions to ''Friends of Karen'', PO Box 190, Purdys, NY 10578 or to the American Cancer Society, 3545 Cruse Road, Suite #

title: A Satisfied, Although Intense, Sportscaster
description: If you watch Keith Olbermann anchor cable's Fox Sports News, you are seeing what appears to be a satisfied sportscaster. This state of mind is somewhat alien to Mr. Olbermann, an intense, impatient one-man psychodrama who left ESPN in a public pique in 1997 to seek happiness in hosting news shows within MSNBC's smaller cable universe, then departed in abject frustration with two years left on his contract when each night's work amounted to discussing the Tao of Monica S. Lewinsky and Kenneth W. Starr for 14 months.

title: Group Moves to Limit Internet Music Piracy
description: In a move designed to cut down piracy of music on the Internet, three dozen software and hardware companies and on-line retailers plan today to endorse the use of a so-called certificates of authentication that would accompany songs and albums distributed digitally.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review in Weekend on Jan. 15 about ''A Couple of Blaguards,'' now at the Triad Theater on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, included an incorrect name, provided by the theater, for the club where it was first performed. A version of the play was performed by its authors, Frank and Malachy Mc Court, in the mid-1980's at the Village Gate, not at the Village Vanguard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRITZKER, JAY ARTHUR
description: PRITZKER-Jay Arthur. Age 76. Beloved husband of Cindy. Devoted father of Tom (Margot), John (Lisa) of San Fransisco, CA, and Daniel (Karen) Pritzker of Winnetka, IL, and Gigi (Michael) Pucker and the late Nancy Friend Pritzker. Adoring grandfather of Jason, Ben, David, Adam, Noah, Sam, Nancy, Zachary, Cindy and John J. Pritzker, Abby, Maggie and Jessica Pucker. Loving brother of Robert (Mayri) Pritzker and the late Donald (the late Susan) Pritzker. Services Monday, January 25th at 1 PM, at Emanuel Congregation, 5959 N. Sheridan Road, Chicago, IL. Private family interment. Please omit flowers. Remembrances may be made to the Nancy Friend Pritzker Labatory at Stanford University School of Medicine, Palo Alto, CA, or the Northwestern University Law School. For further information, please call Furth Funeral Direction, 773784-4300.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Gretzky Turns Game Into Wayne's World
description: Wayne Gretzky has never driven any of the numerous cars he has won during his two-decade career in the National Hockey League. But he said he was going to keep the sport utility vehicle that was given to him today for being named the most valuable player of the 49th annual All-Star Game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEINKMAN, EDWARD
description: SCHEINKMAN-Edward. Young Israel of Flatbush mourns the passing of its esteemed member and editor, Edward Scheinkman. He is survived by his son, Joseph and his daughter, Mindy Leventhal.

title: Cry of Halt, Unheard, Is Getting Louder
description: As she watches Republicans in Congress push ahead with impeachment proceedings against President Clinton, Ellen Mendel of Manhattan says she feels the same despair that she did as a girl in Nazi Germany when the efforts of a stubborn group of leaders snowballed, crushing the will of the people.

title: Has President Clinton Really Suffered Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURTISS, MARIE JOY
description: CURTISS-Marie Joy. Professor Emeritus, Syracuse University. Worked in Michigan State Public Schools for 38 years as a music teacher. In 1959 was awarded certificate as ''Choir Master'' by American Guild of Organists from New York, NY. Received her Doctorate in Music from Michigan State University and later worked in Syracuse University School of Music. She was awarded the honor of Professor Emeritus for her work in India in the field of Performing Arts of India.

title: The Neediest Cases; Man's Will to Work Trumps Disability
description: Leonard Zielinski does not like to talk about the failed interviews and hasty rejections he has experienced as a disabled man trying to find work in New York City.

title: Pataki Sidesteps His Role in School Construction
description: When Gov. George E. Pataki appointed a special state commission over the weekend to investigate school construction in New York City, he cast himself as an outsider busting in, almost like a new sheriff taking charge in a frontier town.

title: Jay Pritzker, Who Built Chain Of Hyatt Hotels, Is Dead at 76
description: Jay Pritzker, whose hunch in the 1950's that America's restless business executives would flock to hotels near airports prompted him to build the Hyatt hotel chain, died on Saturday of cardiac arrest at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. Mr. Pritzker, who had a history of heart trouble, was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEWIRTZMAN, ETHEL (NEE KLEINHAUS)
description: GEWIRTZMAN-Ethel (nee Kleinhaus). Daughter of the late Samuel and Sarah Kleinhaus. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Henry J. Gewirtzman. Adored and adoring mother of Joan G. Smith and the late Dr. Harold Smith. A righteous and devout woman of grace, intelligence, empathy, fortitude and loyalty. Former teacher of English at North Bergen High School and St. Peter's College of Jersey City. Lifelong Trustee and past president of Temple Beth El of Jersey City. Services Tuesday at noon, Temple Beth El, 2419 Kennedy Blvd, Jersey City, NJ. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Temple Beth El. For information ''Wien & Wien'' 800322-0533.

title: McCann May Buy Hollywood Publicist
description: PMK, the Hollywood, Calif., public relations agency known for its powerful publicist, Pat Kingsley, is in talks to be acquired by the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York.

title: Airline Spending on Lobbying Grew in 1998
description: The country's six largest airlines and the industry's trade association spent 42 percent more lobbying Congress in the first half of 1998 than during the comparable period a year earlier, according to a Washington-based group.

title: There Is No Escape From Their Different Drummers
description: There are certain American artists who just don't quite fit into neatly coded categories, peculiar and wonderful creatures protected by and sometimes driven into their own worlds where they make art by no rules, rhymes or rhythms but their own.

title: Has President Clinton Really Suffered Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: From Ink Stains to Marketwatch.com
description: Larry Kramer has stopped at most of journalism's stations of the cross: high school editor, college editor, college stringer (Time Magazine), metropolitan editor of a big-city daily (The Washington Post), editor of a respected state publication (The Trenton Times) and a noted regional newspaper (The San Francisco Examiner).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKFORT, RICHARD M.
description: FRANKFORT-Richard M. Age 71 of Delray Beach, FL. Formerly of NYC. Died on January 22, 1999, in Boca Raton, FL. Mr. Frankfort was the President of Donmoor Boys Clothing for 19 years. Beloved husband of Ruth Werkhoven Frankfort for ten years. Loving father of Jono, Jim, Peter, Adam and Ruelene Wegner. Cherished grandfather of Carlyn, Tali, Aaron, Jordon, Michael, Lauren, Nicole and Jeremy, and brother of Frederick Frankfort, Jr. Funeral services were held in Delray Beach, FL, on January 24, 1999.

title: The Guest of Honor Approaches His Last Hurrah
description: They told this joke in Denver in the late 1980's:

title: Report Cites Sharp Increase in Complaints Against H.M.O.'s
description: The number of complaints lodged against health maintenance organizations and upheld by state investigators has risen sharply in recent years, according to a report released yesterday by the New York City Public Advocate, Mark Green.

title: Latin Songs and Glamour Harking Back to the 80's
description: It's a bad sign for Latin pop stars when the women in the audience don't throw their underwear up on the stage. It means that the necessary level of adulation to make a good show wasn't reached.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOLLETT, ELIZABETH
description: FOLLETT-Elizabeth. Age 91, died January 22, 1999, Allendale, New Jersey. Formerly of Upper Montclair, New Jersey. Services April 17, 1999, from Day Funeral Home, Randolph, Vermont.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENSON, LAWRENCE ''LARRY KING OF SWING.''
description: LEVENSON - Lawrence ''Larry King of Swing.'' Died January 23. Graduate of Nichols College. Owner of Plato's Retreat. Survived by his mother Renee Levenson; his sons Daniel, Michael and Harold; sister Karen; and brother-in-law Edward M. Posner; niece Michele Berman and nephew Charles Posner; and great-nephews Jake and Scott Berman. Services 1 PM, Tuesday, Boca Raton Mausoleum. Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, 1-800992-9262.

title: Million Mexicans Bond With Pope at Mass
description: Pope John Paul II flew down from the skies in a white helicopter into a racetrack today to say an outdoor Mass for more than a million Mexicans, who chanted his Polish childhood nickname, ''Lolek,'' in greeting.

title: 47 Suspected Militants in India Charged in Missionary's Death
description: The police arrested 47 people today who are part of a militant Hindu youth group and charged them with setting a fire early Saturday that killed an Australian missionary and his two young sons as they slept inside a van in a remote tribal village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBSTER, MARY T.
description: WEBSTER-Mary T. Age 72. Of Eleuthera, Bahamas, and Park Ave. Died January 21. Beloved wife of William M. and mother of Melissa and Cecelia. She also leaves a brother, Asher Tourison of Michigan; and sons-in-law, Jay Patrick and Justin Roberts. Services will be private. Donations may be made to Roosevelt Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, MILTON
description: SANDERS-Milton. Died January 22, 1999. Attorney and Supreme Court Judge, State of New York. Beloved husband of Ruth (Amsterdam). Devoted father of Elaine Brodsky, Alison Lichstrahl and father-in-law of Dr. Alan Lichstrahl. Dear broher of Fred and Louis. Cherished grandfather. Loving great-grandfather. Friend of many, he will be deeply missed by all. For more information, Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 212-477-6334.

title: PROSECUTORS QUERY LEWINSKY, SAYING SHE'D BE GOOD WITNESS
description: In a high-stakes battle to continue their prosecution, House managers interviewed Monica S. Lewinsky for just under two hours today and said she would be an impressive witness who would help the Senate ''determine the truth'' in the trial of President Clinton.

title: Illuminating a Modern Work's Wiles
description: ''Walton Cello Concerto,'' the new work Peter Martins has choreographed for the New York City Ballet and more or less named after its music, is one of the best of a genre. It is a pure-dance response to 20th-century music.

title: Virginia Verrill, Unseen Voice Of Hollywood's Singing Stars, 82
description: Virginia Verrill, the on-screen singing voice of some of Hollywood's most famous leading ladies and later a popular radio star, died on Jan. 18 at the Mayview Nursing Home in Raleigh, N.C. She was 82 and lived in Raleigh.

title: Discovering the Dark Side of Britain's Popular Tabloids
description: The story was as irresistible as catnip to the sensation-greedy British news media. A pair of foster parents, devastated when they were told they would not be allowed to adopt the two little girls they thought of as their own, vanished from sight, taking the children with them. After living in secret for four months in a remote corner of Ireland, they wrote a letter to several tabloid newspapers, pleading to be allowed to keep the children.

title: Cross-Media Deals Mean Bonanzas for Publishers
description: The best publicity a publisher couldn't buy is airing reliably on the nightly news.

title: Quarterback Club Honors Visa Spot
description: The N.F.L. Quarterback Club has named a humorous commercial featuring Jerry Rice and Steve Young of the San Francisco 49ers as the best football-themed commercial of 1998.

title: A Mets Benefit For 2 Children
description: The Mets collected $11,200 yesterday, to benefit the children of an employee who died last fall, in an autograph session at John Franco's indoor sports facility in Brooklyn. Michelle Dougherty, a graduate of St. John's University, began working with the Mets as a public relations intern in 1982 and worked with the club for nearly 15 years, until she left the team in January 1997 for treatment of colon cancer. Dougherty died last October. The money raised will be held in trust for her two children.

title: College Freshmen's Internet Use a Way of Life, but Disparities Emerge
description: Use of the Internet as an educational tool by college freshmen has become so prevalent as to be practically a way of life, a survey of college freshmen shows.

title: Brazil's Economic Crisis Pits President Against Governors
description: As the Brazilian Government struggles to restore the stability of an economy under siege, the most intractable critics have emerged not abroad, but here at home, where the resistance to reform by a group of powerful state governors has created a dangerous impasse.

title: Riese and Restaurant Union Accept Contract After 3 Years
description: About 450 workers at Charley O's, Lindy's and several other Manhattan restaurants run by the Riese Organization have ended a three-year labor dispute by agreeing to a contract that includes long-sought job-security provisions.

title: As Arab League Urges Iraqis to Obey the U.N., They Walk Out of the Meeting
description: In an angry rupture with fellow Arabs, an Iraqi delegation withdrew from a high-level meeting here tonight as Arab foreign ministers were adopting a statement critical of Baghdad.

title: Charles Brown, 76, Blues Pianist and Singer
description: Charles Brown, the singer of the hit ''Merry Christmas Baby'' and a member of Johnny Moore and the Three Blazers, died on Thursday in Oakland, Calif. Mr. Brown, who was 76 and lived in Oakland, was to have been inducted into the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame in March.

title: Sports of The Times; Bulls' First Dance Is an Icebreaker
description: AT long last, after more than six months of lockout languor, the National Basketball Association opened yesterday with its first game, for want of a better term.

title: Legal Immigrants Would Regain Aid In President's Plan
description: The Clinton Administration is proposing a $1.3 billion, five-year program to close remaining gaps in medical and food stamp benefits for legal immigrants that have existed since the overhaul of the nation's welfare system three years ago.

title: Ayer Chief to Form New MacManus Unit
description: Mary Lou Quinlan, chief executive at N. W. Ayer & Partners in New York since 1995, is taking a new position at the company's parent, MacManus Group. Mary Beth Casey, president at Ayer, will succeed her, effective on May 1.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column on Wednesday, about the acquisition of Jordan McGrath Case & Partners by Havas Advertising, misstated the name of a vitamin brand once handled by Jordan McGrath. It is Theragran, not Theragram.

title: Trial Is Getting Under Way Today in Prozac Patent Lawsuit
description: A legal battle that could ultimately decide when Americans can pay a lower price for the popular antidepressant Prozac is set to begin today in Indianapolis.

title: Albright Seeks to Reassure Moscow on 'Star Wars' Plan
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright insisted today, on the eve of what promises to be a round of contentious talks here, that the Clinton Administration's plan to develop a missile defense system would not affect any Russian decision to ratify the Start II treaty, languishing in the Russian Parliament since 1993.

title: Equity Offerings Set
description: These equity and convertible-debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Sports of The Times; In Miami, The Words Are Super
description: TWO days before Super Bowl II, the first in Miami, Vince Lombardi looked around at his Green Bay Packers.

title: Kosovo Killings Harden Resistance and Jolt West
description: The mosque in this Kosovo village still looks like an abattoir, with thick smears of dried blood on the plastic sheeting where 45 victims of a massacre, including three women and a child, were brought from the ditch where they were found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, DAVID I.
description: SCHNEIDER-David I. Died January 23, 1999. Beloved father of Rona and Peter. Fond brother of Pearl. Adoring grandfather of Harley and Lauren. Services will be at Riverside; call 212-362-6600 for information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEPORE, LOUISE (NEE MCCORMICK)
description: LEPORE-Louise (nee McCormick). On January 23, 1999. Wife of the late Michael. Beloved aunt of Patricia A. McCormick, Katharine M. Lyon and Lisa M. O'Neill. Also, survived by two great-nieces and one great-nephew. Visiting Tuesday, 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Service Wednesday, 10 AM, at the Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Mets Hope That Patience Comes With Age
description: Tony Gwynn, the San Diego Padre All-Star who knows something about hitting, raved last March and again in October about the patience of the Yankees' hitters, about their ability to identify the strike zone and ignore those offerings thrown beyond it.

title: Has President Clinton Really Suffered Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: Vying for Guys' Remote-Control Finger
description: I am beginning to feel sorry for males ages 18 to 34. They have nothing to watch on television. Yes, they watch ''E.R.'' and ''Friends,'' as the women in their lives do, but when they're left alone in a room with a remote, channels change.

title: Pope's Visit to U.S. To Focus on Future Of Church Growth
description: When Pope John Paul II arrives in the United States on Jan. 26 for a two-day visit to St. Louis, his first major speech in that city will be at a rally of Roman Catholic youth, a group the Pope regards as vital to the church's future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLER, LORETTA
description: GELLER-Loretta (Suddenly). Devoted wife of Mel. Devoted mother of Gary (Patricia) and Jeffrey (Debra). Adored grandmother of Rachel, Eric, Samara and Jared. Dear sister of Lillian Miller and Florine Karmen. Services were held Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINDER, NATHAN
description: BINDER-Nathan. On January 23, 1999. Beloved husband of Lillian (Chickie). Dear brother of Ray. Cherished father of Barbara, Michael and Steven. Loving grandfather of Charles, Peter, Nancy, Amy and Zoey. Delighted greatgrandfather of Bradley and Emily, and devoted father-in-law of Alan, Nancy and Kristen. He was a veteran of World War II, a practicing dentist in Mt. Kisco, New York for over forty-five years, and an active member of the Jewish community. Services at Levayah-Garlick Funeral Home, 1091 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers, New York, at 10 AM, Monday, January 25. Expressions of sympathy in his memory may be donated to the American Heart Association.

title: A Defiant St. John's Falls to Duke in Overtime
description: All the signals were there for St. John's yesterday, the signs that the inevitable drubbing by a superpower was at hand. Its center was out with an injury and its best player was in foul trouble. The premier player in the nation was dominating the boards, owning the paint and, after all, this was Duke, a heavy favorite to continue rolling toward a national championship game in March.

title: Pint-Sized Deal Gave AT&T a Barrel's Worth of Challenges
description: When it comes to big deals, the AT&T Corporation can move fast. It's the small ones that can take time.

title: French Are Gearing Up to Join In Dousing the Flames of Kosovo
description: French military officers believe that if diplomacy and bombing threats fail, it would take 100,000 European and American troops to impose peace in the war between ethnic Albanian separatists and Serbian forces in the southern Serbian province of Kosovo, according to officials in Paris.

title: Albany Weighs Tobacco Funds For Health Care
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders in Albany have reached a consensus that some of the money from the settlement of the national tobacco lawsuit should be used to provide health care for New York's swelling number of uninsured.

title: Has President Clinton Really Suffered Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Is Set to Auction Bills and Notes
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and Wednesday's auction of two-year notes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNST, MAURICE, M.D.
description: DUNST-Maurice, M.D. On January 24. Devoted husband of Phoebe. Beloved father of Eric and Hilary. Devoted physician and friend. He touched many lives and will be missed.

title: INSIDE
description: A Record Round of Golf

title: Few Details Furnished By Utah Organizers
description: In the Wasatch Mountains that dominate the landscape here, snow has been falling almost nonstop the last few days, vividly illustrating the gifts of nature and meteorology that made this city appealing as a site for the Winter Olympics. And in the packed downtown meeting room where executives of the local Olympic organizing committee faced journalists from around the world today in a news conference about the latest developments in the unfolding Olympic scandal, the display was just as vivid of all the reasons the 2002 Winter Games are in crisis.

title: Under the Veil of Chaos, A Possible Resolution
description: On the surface, the impeachment trial appears to be on the verge of chaos, with Senate Republicans lacking a coherent plan, House Republicans and Kenneth W. Starr throwing Hail Mary passes, and Senate Democrats in a state of fuming outrage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, DOROTHY H.
description: WILLIAMS-Dorothy H. On January 23, 1999. Survived by her loving family. Reposing at Crestwood Memorial Chapel, 33 Spring Street, NYC, until Tuesday.

title: Buzz Kulik, 76, Director of Films and TV Programs
description: Buzz Kulik, a director whose made-for-television movie ''Brian's Song'' attained such popular success that it was released theatrically, died on Jan. 13 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 76 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAGALINE, EDWARD A.
description: BRAGALINE-Edward A. Age 92. At the DeWitt Nursing Home, Monday, January 18, from cardiopulmonary-arrest. Until his retirement, Mr. Bragaline was the owner/director of the firm Kent-Bragaline Inc., a supplier of decorative fabrics to the home furnishing industry. He is survived by his dear sister Olga Pedlar; his very attentive nephew Edward Speciale and five other nephews and a niece; as well as his dear friend of many years Louis W. Bowen. A private cryptside service will be held at Woodlawn Cemetery, Wednesday at 1PM, January 27. No flowers thank you, just a prayer for peace and love. A memorial tribute will be announced at a later date.

title: Prosecutors Foresaw Need to Hear Again From Lewinsky
description: When Monica S. Lewinsky signed her immunity agreement last July with the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, she never imagined that Mr. Starr would use the language of the deal to force her to cooperate with House prosecutors seeking the removal of President Clinton from office, several friends and associates of Ms. Lewinsky said today.

title: Seeking to Go Beyond The 'Shockumentary'
description: Bruce Nash, one of the many people trying to rescue network television from its steep ratings slide, has an idea. Actually, this boyishly enthusiastic producer of so-called reality-based shows has about a thousand ideas, and the number seems to be growing by the minute as he reveals what he believes will win back audiences: his confidential list of new ideas.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEISTEN, DAVID, M.D.
description: LEISTEN-David, M.D. January 25, 1989. Love and memories are forever. Annette and Famil

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZASLAVSKY, RUTH L.
description: ZASLAVSKY-Ruth L. Beloved aunt of Susan, Howard and Michael. Grandaunt of Lisa, David, Diane, Daniel, Jill, Jonathan, Maxine, Lawrence and Robert. Greatgrandaunt of Eden, Rachel and Samuel. Cousin of Robert, Lynn and Allan. Dearest friends Beverly, Corinne and Joan. Graveside service Monday, January 25, 1 PM, at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. For information call Schwartz Brothers at 718-263-7600.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TISHMAN, RITA
description: TISHMAN-Rita. The Board and staff of The American Federation of Arts extend heartfelt condolences to Margot Linton, Vice President of the AFA on the death of her mother. Mrs. Tishman, a longtime member of The AFA, will be missed by all who knew her. Robert Meltzer, Chairman Jan Mayer, President Serena Rattazzi, Director

title: Lewinsky to Friend: 'I Gave Them Nothing'
description: On Friday night, a friend said, the young woman cried herself to sleep. On Saturday, she had to prepare once more for another grilling as the famously expert witness on the oft-told story of the President and the intern.

title: Has President Clinton Really Suffered Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay; State of Unreality
description: Once a year I get invited to the White House for a quick brain rinse and mindset on the State of the Union. This time I wandered in the wrong West Wing door and saw what I was not supposed to.

title: Repentant King of Spam Serves Humbler Kind of Fare
description: Until his disappearance from the on-line world early last year, Sanford Wallace was easily the most reviled man in cyberspace. Mr. Wallace, the self-professed ''king of spam,'' infuriated millions of Internet users daily with his mass E-mailing campaigns and then reveled in his right to do so. In its heyday, his company sent out 30 million pieces of electronic junk mail a day.

title: Order in the Trial
description: After a weekend of turmoil, the Senate must act today to regain control of an impeachment trial that has been improperly and dangerously manipulated by the House prosecution managers. With conservative Republicans like Richard Shelby and Larry Craig eager to see the case resolved, the Senate can renew the bipartisan spirit of responsibility that united it when the trial opened two weeks ago. Its duty now is to restrain the zealous House prosecutors and, in recognition that there are not 67 votes to remove President Clinton, design a fair plan to resolve the case.

title: Cassell Has Two Roles: Jester And Gamer
description: The Nets are running sprints at the end of practice and though Sam Cassell is one of the team's quickest players, there is no way he is going to win. In fact, he is almost a sure bet to finish last.

title: Man Held in String Of Cab Robberies
description: A random stop of a taxi by police officers in Brooklyn early yesterday turned up a passenger with a knife whom the police linked to eight robberies of cabbies in the last nine days, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, BERTHA W.
description: SIEGEL-Bertha W. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Devoted mother of Richard Siegel and Jane (Gilbert) Hermann. Dear sister of Sylvia Baer. Loving grandmother of Anne, Peggy, Jill and Robert. For information, ''Wien & Wien,'' 1-800-378-1892.

title: Tequila Account Goes Under Review
description: Allied Domecq Spirits USA has placed in review the Sauza tequilas brand account, which has been handled for five years by Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. Billings for the tequilas, which include the Sauza Conmemorativo, Hornitos, Silver and Gold varieties, were estimated at $15 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAUER, WALTER E.
description: LANDAUER-Walter E. Passed away peacefully on Saturday, January 23, 1999, after a courageous battle with the after-effects of a stroke. Beloved companion of Prudence Opperman, loving father of Megan Landauer, and survived by his brother, Rolf Landauer. Graduated Cooper Union School of Engineering in 1947. In 1973 he founded Purvis Systems Inc, which he headed until his stroke in 1995. Funeral services Tuesday, 10:30 AM, at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83 St, New York, NY.

title: Steep Increases Seen In Charges for Drugs
description: Patients are facing steep increases in out-of-pocket charges for prescription drugs. Standard co-payments are often doubling for drugs that patients have been using for years. But even bigger increases, of 300 percent or more, are appearing for some remedies that are not on insurers' lists of approved drugs.

title: Sports of The Times; Red Storm Has Itself A Floor Leader
description: THE sophisticated big city always loved the judicious little man, the kind it has not seen much of the last few years. Maybe that is why, on the day they shook the cobwebs off big-time college basketball at Madison Square Garden, Spike Lee took his customary front-row seat in the jersey of Erick Barkley, No. 12.

title: Corrections
description: A music review last Monday about ''Moondrunk,'' a production based on Arnold Schoenberg's ''Pierrot Lunaire,'' misidentified the lighting designer. She was Jennifer Tipton; Scott Pask was the scenic designer.

title: Ovitz Shakes Hollywood With New Coup
description: Michael Ovitz, the man who was once Hollywood's most powerful agent, has returned as a talent manager. And after his first few weeks back, one thing is clear: no star or big-name director is off limits, not even the clients of his old agency.

title: Awards May Have Been Cool, But the Audience Was Chilly
description: There's no business like show business, unless of course you count the stock market in the age of the Internet: one part Fellini film, one part trapeze act. It was in the spirit of infusing the Web with a bit of literal high-flying that the Cool Site of the Year Awards were held in New York on Thursday at Webster Hall in the East Village. The crowd of 700 was mesmerized by a French acrobat but less receptive to the celebrity host, Robin Leach, late of the television program ''Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous.''

title: Betty Bryant, Showboat Performer, Dies at 76
description: Betty Bryant, who had such a satisfying childhood career in the backwaters of show business that she never bothered to try to top herself in the Broadway mainstream, died on Jan. 15 at her home in Park Ridge, Ill.

title: The First (and Last) Words
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARON, SAM
description: VARON-Sam. Of Long Beach, NY. Cherished son of Robert and Shirley Varon. Dear brother of Maurice Varon and Rachel Goldberg. Services were held yesterday. For information call ''Wien & Wien'' 800-322-0533.

title: Second Teen-Ager to Be Sentenced in '97 Stabbing Death in Central Park
description: Nearly two years after the eviscerated body of a 44-year-old man was found floating in Central Park Lake, the second teen-ager involved in his death is to be sentenced today, marking the end of a fiercely contested trial that outraged the victim's family and led jurors to complain bitterly that prosecutors botched the case.

title: Artfully Confiding a Songwriter's Art
description: The theater composer Vernon Duke, who died in 1969, may never be counted in the pantheon that includes Gershwin, Berlin, Porter, Rodgers and Kern, because his output was modest and none of his shows were hits. But in his great seasonal ballads of urban longing, ''April in Paris'' and ''Autumn in New York,'' Duke introduced a refined impressionism into popular song that was as adventurous as anything composed by his more renowned songwriting peers.

title: Sprewell Rusty but Happy to Be Back
description: The first jumper Latrell Sprewell took as a Knick felt about as awkward as being the new kid in school. You want to impress. You want to fit in.

title: 2 Journalists Leave CBS for Cable Networks
description: Was it mere coincidence that Harry Smith and Paula Zahn both left CBS News last week to join cable networks? Both are veteran, well-respected journalists; and both missed the cut when four correspondents were chosen for ''60 Minutes II,'' the network's new Wednesday night magazine program.

title: Roslyn Bancorp to Acquire TR Financial
description: Roslyn Bancorp Inc. has agreed to buy the TR Financial Corporation under revised terms of a stock deal that seemed dead just a few weeks ago, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Obviously, if we do proceed, we want to make sure that it doesn't turn out to be 'The Jerry Springer Show.' ''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Frustration Level Rising For On-Line Stock Traders

title: Omnicom to Acquire A Design Company
description: Omnicom Group in New York is making another acquisition by agreeing to buy the Designory Inc. in Long Beach, Calif., a design company with clients that include Mercedes-Benz and Nissan. The Designory, which owns the Miami-based design company Pinkhaus, will continue as an autonomous company under its own name as part of the Diversified Agency Services division of Omnicom. Steve Horman, president at the Designory, continues in that role, reporting to Thomas L. Harrison, chairman at Diversified Agency Services.

title: Appointees to State Panel on City Schools
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has appointed the first three members of a new state commission to investigate wrongdoing in the construction of the city's public schools. They are:

title: Gunmen Attack South African Officials After Rival's Killing
description: Two revenge attacks including one in broad daylight in the center of the town on a visiting Government delegation -- shook this small, rural town today in the wake of the assassination of a prominent local politician on Saturday.

title: China's Disabled Are Victims of a New Economy
description: The blind man in a frayed cotton jacket stood on the sidewalk, hawking cheap plastic shopping bags without much success to shoppers who scurried past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRASBERG, SUSAN ELIZABETH
description: STRASBERG - Susan Elizabeth. Actress and author on January 21, 1999. Beloved mother of Jennifer Robin Jones Strasberg. Loving daughter of the late Lee and Paula Strasberg. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St, Sunday and Monday 2-5 and 7-9PM with service Tuesday 1PM. Interment private.

title: Linux Users Planning to Take Demands Straight to Microsoft
description: Proponents of the Linux software operating system would rather not have Microsoft Windows on their personal computers -- and would most definitely rather not pay for Windows, which is standard issue on most PC's. Now with a militancy that seems to be part of the movement, a band of Linux users plans to demand its Windows money back.

title: Senators Try to Restore Status as Upper House on the Higher Road
description: A day after bipartisan cooperation in the impeachment trial of President Clinton seemed to be collapsing, senators hit the television talk-show circuit this morning to shore it up, floating new plans for concluding the proceedings quickly and stressing their common desire to reach that terminus with dignity.

title: Editorial Observer; Looking for Respect on the Campaign Trail
description: Bill Clinton has spent the last six years demonstrating that in Presidential politics, there are few things more useful than low public expectations. Now we have the perfect test case to see if the same rule will apply to the race in 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERBERICH, FRANK J.
description: BERBERICH-Frank J. Age 85. Formerly of Plandome, Long Island, died Saturday, January 24, 1999, at FirstHealth Moore Regional Hospital. A Mass of Christian Burial will be said at 11 AM, on Wednesday, January 27, from the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Pinehurst, NC, with Father Robert T. Lawson officiating. Mr. Berberich was a graduate of the City College of New York and Columbia Law School, class of 1937. He practiced law at Sullivan & Cromwell, and was Vice-President of American-Standard in charge of European Operations. He is survived by his beloved wife Mary; brothers Charles W. Berberich of Williamsburg, VA, William M. Berberich of Islip, NY; and several nieces and nephews. The family will receive friends Tuesday evening from 6:30-8:00 PM, with a prayer service beginning at 7:00 PM, at Powell Funeral Home in Southern Pines, NC.

title: Mark Warren, 60, TV and Film Director
description: Mark Warren, an award-winning television director, died on Jan. 11 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 60 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Closing a Chapter, a Missing Atheist's Belongings Are Sold
description: Jimmy Nassour was not sure why he kept raising his hand when the bidding passed the $500 limit he had set for himself. ''I guess I got caught up in the moment,'' he said.

title: Growing Up Tough and Gentle in an Irish Enclave
description: A SONG FOR MARY

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: TECHNOLOGY: MAN IN THE NEWS -- Paul Maritz; Microsoft's Star Antitrust Witness
description: It is certain to be the hot seat. But Paul Maritz, who takes the witness stand this week as the highest-ranking Microsoft official scheduled to testify in the company's antitrust trial, is an executive known for a cool, sometimes prescient, analytic style.

title: Has President Clinton Really Suffered Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: Contemporary Works With Ethnic Roots
description: The Juilliard School's annual festival of contemporary music, Focus, is widening its aperture this year to look at what has been done in the present decade by all kinds of composers working in America in what still passes for the classical tradition. Almost 50 composers are represented, ranging in age from 22 to 90, and coming from around the globe.

title: Wrestling muscles its way to the Super Bowl in an in-your-face ad.
description: YOU can almost hear an announcer proclaim in the style of those Walt Disney World commercials: ''World Wrestling Federation, your television shows are drawing larger audiences, higher ratings and more mainstream marketers. And one of your former 'bad guy' performers, Jesse Ventura, has just been elected Governor of Minnesota. What are you going to do?''

title: Just Made For People Who Hate Their Jobs
description: When you stop to think about it (and you're surely not meant to), there is something sad about the huge popularity of ''Dilbert,'' the comic strip that assumes everyone hates his or her job. Confined to their cubicles in a company run by idiot bosses, Dilbert and his white-collar colleagues make the dronelike world of Kafka seem congenial. But never mind. Whether its message is pathetic or true or both, the comic strip has obviously hit a middle-class nerve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, BERNARD
description: SCHWARTZ - Bernard. Beloved husband of Shirley. Devoted father of Eugene and Barbara Schwartz, Carol and Richard Buchwald, and Ellen and Jerry Abel. Dear brother of Carl Schwartz, and brother-in-law of Sylvia Fasulo. Loving grandfather of Lisa, Adam, Tahlia, Andrea, Sandra and Daniela. Service today, 1:30, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Has President Clinton Really Suffered Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: Trash-War Victims; Recycling the Easy Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Memo; Attention-Seeking Republicans Attack One of Their Own
description: As Republican Presidential candidates scramble for attention in a political world fixated on the impeachment trial, they have stunned many in the party by aiming their fire not at President Clinton or Vice President Al Gore but at one of their own: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.

title: Washington Post to Use Color on Page One
description: The Washington Post announced yesterday that it would begin publishing color photographs on its front page on Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Monday about an experimental computer work station for journalists developed by two Columbia University professors misstated the project's financing. It gets $200,000 a year in grants, not $120,000. Of the total, $120,000 comes from the Office of Naval Research. The National Tele-Immersion Initiative provides an unspecified amount.

title: Economic Calendar
description: MONDAY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIFER, BARRY H.
description: LEIFER-Barry H. The Partners and Employees of Schain Leifer Guralnick mourn the loss of Barry H. Leifer who passed away on January 21, 1999. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his beloved wife Lynn, his children Becky, David and Rachel and his entire family. Barry will be missed by us all. May his memory be for a blessing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, CLARENCE (EPH) EDWIN
description: WILLIAMS-Clarence (Eph) Edwin Of Short Hills, NJ, and Sagaponack, NY. On Saturday, January 23, 1999. Husband of Anne Nedland-Pedersen Williams. Father of Nedland P., Charles P., Thomas M., and Peter S. Williams and Emily R. W. Draper. Brother of Marjorie Crothers. Also survived by eight grandchildren. Memorial service in Christ Church, 66 Highland Ave, Short Hills, on Tuesday, January 26th, at 2 PM.

title: Globes to 'Shakespeare' and 'Ryan'
description: The Golden Globe award for best motion picture musical or comedy was presented here tonight to ''Shakespeare in Love,'' a whimsical imagining of how the playwright found his inspiration for ''Romeo and Juliet.'' The movie also took the award for best screenplay, which was written by Marc Norman and Tom Stoppard.

title: Has President Clinton Really Suffered Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Olympic Scandal Is Not Cleansed by Sacrifice of Small Fry
description: THERE is a morbid law school joke that goes: ''What do you call 500 lawyers at the bottom of the ocean?'' Answer: ''A good beginning.''

title: Experts Scold Decision To Question Lewinsky
description: By recruiting a Federal judge and the independent counsel to force Monica S. Lewinsky to submit to questioning this weekend, the House managers provided what legal scholars say was the first serious constitutional controversy in the Clinton impeachment trial.

title: Art Worth More Than Money Enriches Lincoln Center
description: Art and money, money and art. The two are forever linked, but it is still unfortunate when they become virtually synonymous. Right now the Jasper Johns painting ''Numbers, 1964,'' which has hung quietly in a raised area at one end of the lobby of the New York State Theater since it opened in 1964, seems to look like little more than cold cash to some people. But the Johns is a living work of art, a claim that can't be made for all the sculptures and murals in the buildings and around the plaza at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Officer Slain in Connecticut Was Called a Rising Star
description: The report about a fight was assigned to another officer on a busy, foggy night, but Brian Aselton was free and he was closer to the scene. So on Saturday he did what many eager young officers do: he took the call.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about the on-line Concordances of Great Books misspelled a word in an example of searchable words in Shakespeare's works. It is incarnadine, not incardine.

title: Questions Surround Lott's Direction
description: On Friday afternoon, Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, was fuming. Moments earlier, Senator Robert C. Byrd, a West Virginia Democrat, stunned Mr. Lott by reversing himself and declaring his support for dismissing President Clinton's impeachment trial.

title: GE Capital to Buy the Assets Of Failed Big Japanese Leaser
description: In one of the largest acquisitions by a foreign company so far in Japan, GE Capital Services said on Saturday that it was buying the leasing business of a company that collapsed with the Long-Term Credit Bank last fall.

title: High Stakes in High School: Playing for Baseball Cards
description: Stakes in a social bridge game are almost invariably money, but there are interesting exceptions. Prisoners in World War II, the Vietnam War and the Iran hostage crisis thought of something else, sometimes cigarettes. Teen-agers usually do not want to sacrifice their limited cash and may employ an alternative currency. At the Bronx High School of Science in the 1970's it was baseball cards. They were very important to the players, who therefore gave maximum concentration to the playing cards.

title: Has President Clinton Really Suffered Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENWALD, RUTH ISRAELS
description: ROSENWALD-Ruth Israels. On January 21, 1999, at her residence in Manhattan, at age 85. Daughter of Henry Goldstein, died 1953, and Elizabeth Traurig Goldstein, died 1985. Widow of Carlos Lindner Israels, died 1969, and William Rosenwald, died 1996. Mother of Michael Jozef Israels. Mother-inlaw of Maija-Sarmite Jansons. Grandmother of Aleksandrs Lehman Israels & Peter Carlos Israels. Stepmother of Nina Rosenwald, Elizabeth R. Varet and Alice R. Sigelman. Memorial Service Tuesday, January 26. 1999, at 12 Noon at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave & 65 St., New York. In lieu of flowers, the family request contributions either to: Congregation EmanueEl of the City of New York, or the Israels Family Fund, at Amherst College, Amherst, Mass.

title: An alliance with Warner Brothers Online has an upstart Web development company feeling like the Road Runner.
description: IT is the stuff Web dreams are made of. A recent start-up operating out of a makeshift office in a loft strikes a deal with an entertainment or media giant. The news media takes note. The bankers call. Suddenly, it's the hottest of properties, a celebrity start-up.

title: Constraints Over Budget Put Pataki in a Bind
description: After the fiscal drought of the early 1990's, the last two years have been a monsoon season for New York State. Lawmakers have responded to the flood of revenue with tax cuts, record increases in school spending, higher payments to pensioners and a numbingly long list of expensive pet projects, from a sports stadium in Brooklyn to bigger purses at Saratoga Raceway.

title: Administration to Seek $3 Billion to Protect Embassies Abroad
description: Scalded by criticism of security weaknesses at American embassies abroad, the Clinton Administration will seek more than $3 billion during the next five years to fortify and rebuild its missions overseas, senior White House and State Department officials said today.

title: The Diaper Incentive
description: To the Editor:

title: A new technology combines information from several sources to enhance overall accuracy.
description: CAN understanding how a cat pounces on a mouse help an air-traffic controller spot incoming planes? Or make a difference in the way a military pilot locates a ground target? Or improve a weather forecaster's ability to identify lightning strikes?

title: Who's Fiscally Responsible Now?
description: No sooner had President Clinton unveiled his plan to save Social Security than it was savaged as big government run amok.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, HARRIS
description: COHEN-Harris. You're always with us, good times and bad times. Love, Unkie, Amy and Gaby

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAUL, ROBERT
