description: JAUL-Robert. Age 75. On January 24. Beloved father of Danny, Claudia and the late Michael. Loving companion of Barbara Heitner. Also survived by his sister Felicitas. Born in Wiener Neustadt, Austria. He immigrated with his parents and sister to New York, co-founded the law practice of Jaul & Strong, and helped many people with his integrity and kindness. Also survived by many dear cousins and friends. He was loved by many. Service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam and 76th, Tuesday, 10 AM.

title: A Round for the Ages: Duval Wins With a 59
description: It was a magical round of golf, executed by a player blessed with almost mystical composure.

title: How Not to Sell a Public Painting
description: Today at 4 P.M., Lincoln Center's board of directors will meet to discuss, again, the terrible idea of selling the Jasper Johns painting ''Numbers, 1964.'' The sale is arousing intense opposition among artists, arts administrators and the general public, and the board has a chance to avoid a mistake that would haunt the institution for years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, OSCAR
description: KAUFMAN-Oscar. May 21, 1909January 23, 1999. We mourn the loss of a devoted husband, beloved father of two, dearest grandfather of nine, loving great-grandfather of seven. He was a retired attorney and owner of The Columbia Law List, a generous contributor to Jewish causes and a dear friend to many. Miriam, Ira, Hermine & Arthur Kaufman & Blumenfield Families

title: A Craze for Muscle Tone Long Before Jane Fonda
description: Exercise, a chore or bore to many, a passion for some, receives quizzical attention tonight on the History Channel. ''Quest for Fitness,'' a two-hour look at physical exertions through the ages, gives a lot of credit or blame to the Greeks, but mainly the focus is on the United States of the past couple of centuries. Although the narration and interviews are unlikely to set many cardiovascular systems racing, the old pictures of pioneers of health and fitness regimens confirm their place as national curiosities.

title: Brill's Discontent; A Media Maverick Works to Broaden A New Magazine's Mainstream Appeal
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Israel Court Weighs Legality Of What Many Call Torture
description: Shai Nitzan, a Government lawyer, had some news for the Israeli Supreme Court during deliberations earlier this month on the methods used by the Shin Bet security service during interrogations of Palestinians.

title: On-Line Trading Woes Ruffle All Sides in Deals
description: Many small investors are becoming frustrated with the limitations of stock trading over the Internet, even as they continue to pour money into the on-line brokerage firms that now account for one of every four retail stock trades.

title: Fissure in Building Forces 11 to Evacuate
description: The back half of an apartment building in Morningside Heights was evacuated yesterday afternoon, leaving 11 people homeless, after a crack was discovered running up the back of the building from the first floor to the roof, five stories up.

title: Ellington Revered And Revised
description: The audience paid a stiff price to hear Duke Ellington's pioneering work ''Black, Brown and Beige'' on Thursday at Carnegie Hall. Programmed as the second half of the concert, the rarely heard piece, played by the Carnegie Hall Jazz Band, was the bait to hold on to the audience through the first half, a set of rearrangements of pieces by Ellington and Billy Strayhorn. Rearranging Ellington and Strayhorn is an exercise in hubris, and perhaps can be pulled off one tune at a time. But to throw the compositions together was spectacularly misguided.

title: Father of Two Slain Boys Is Held on Minor Charges
description: Two young brothers whose bodies were found hidden in the coal room of a Manhattan loft building were homicide victims, officials said yesterday, as their father was ordered held on $10 million bail on minor charges related to their disappearance.

title: NBC Errs in DiMaggio Alert
description: Aware of news reports that the baseball legend Joe DiMaggio appeared to be gravely ill, the news technicians at NBC's ''Dateline'' were ready to announce his passing at any moment -- a little too ready.

title: Patients Facing Steep Increases in Drug Costs as Insurers Seek to Contain Rising Outlays
description: Patients across the country are facing steep increases in out-of-pocket charges for prescription drugs, reversing a recent trend toward more liberal coverage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEGWIN, MARTY (NEE VARGAS)
description: CHEGWIN-Marty (nee Vargas). On January 23, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Angel G. Loving mother of Ilse Stark, May Greineder and the late Fred Chegwin. Cherished grandmother of Belinda Markel, Kirsten, Britt and Colin Greineder. Loving great-grandmother of Alexis, Amy and William Markel. Religious services at Sunnyside Reformed Church, 48-03 Skillman Avenue, Sunnyside, New York, Tuesday, 12 Noon.

title: Egregious Crimes, Elusive Punishment
description: Should murderers be punished? Yes, if the crime is private, but no if it is in the public service: such is the contradictory and morally unsatisfying answer society has always given. Soldiers in wartime, like the fictitious James Bond and his fellow double-o's, are licensed to kill the enemy. In the performance of their duties, the police enjoy similar, though more circumscribed, rights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFEK, VIOLA MABEL (NEWSTROM)
description: JAFEK-Viola Mabel (Newstrom). Of Brooklyn Center, MN. Born New London, MN, 1908. Services Evans-Nordby 612-533-3000

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICH, WARREN
description: RICH-Warren. We have lost a wonderful, devoted friend and tennis partner. He spent hours every year preparing our tennis schedules. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Pat, and the entire family. The Tennis Group

title: Back Home Again, Clinton Surveys Tornado Damage
description: It is so often something so sad a funeral, a disaster -- that draws President Clinton home to Arkansas. Yet he always seems to savor the escape from Washington and the company of people who have known him long enough to call him Bill.

title: The Big City; A Fair Trade To Find Peace: Trash for Vice
description: A statesman has finally emerged to make peace between New York City and Virginia. While politicians and journalists have been busy escalating the garbage war, Jim Spencer has come forth with a bold, diplomatic initiative.

title: For Lobbyist, a Thin Line Between Work and Family
description: In the constant scrambling among Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's aides to demonstrate their loyalty, few could match Bruce Teitelbaum. He began as the administration's liaison to the city's Jewish community, then gradually ascended to become Mr. Giuliani's trouble-shooter, advance man and surrogate enforcer -- all the duties expected of a chief of staff.

title: Blast and Fire Destroy Warehouse in the Bronx
description: An explosion followed by a two-alarm fire destroyed a printing company warehouse building in the north Bronx last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAMBOR, JACK S.
description: TAMBOR-Jack S. President of M & R Tomato Distributors, Inc. Beloved husband of Bertha. Devoted father of Denise Goodman, Bonnie Tambor and Michael Tambor, and father-in-law of Philip Goodman and Lisa Tambor. Cherished grandfather of Lisa, Scott and Jessica. Loving brother of Evelyn Tambor. Services Monday, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Republicans Have a Common-Sense Agenda
description: To the Editor:

title: Ousted Aide Gets Ready To Challenge Netanyahu
description: When a secular Israeli politician whisks out a skullcap and Bible, visits the Western Wall and seeks a blessing from a top rabbi, it is clear that the fighting spirit is upon him.

title: Luanda Journal; In Angola's Capital, Life Does Not Yet Imitate Art
description: Dominating the lobby of the Hotel Continental is a mural of the city's beach esplanade by a local artist, Mario Ribeira.

title: Has President Clinton Really Suffered Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, ''RED'' HUBERT
description: LEWIS-''Red'' Hubert Passed away January 22, 1999, after a lenghty illness, at the age of 75, in Boca Raton, FL.

title: After Opening Wounds, Reeves Says He's Sorry
description: As the Falcons and Broncos arrived in the Miami area today to begin workouts for the Super Bowl, Atlanta Coach Dan Reeves apologized for ''opening old wounds last week'' involving his former protege and now rival, Denver Coach Mike Shanahan.

title: Trash-War Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Internet Firms Ride Out the Storm
description: When Go2net Inc., a Seattle-based Internet start-up, went public in April 1997, the company's stock sold for $8 a share, and a year ago, it was still trading in that range. In a single day earlier this month, it climbed more than $53 to just under $120 a share, and now it has dropped back to $92 -- all reflections of the investor frenzy that has driven Internet stocks to startling heights in recent weeks, and of the wariness that has brought many of them somewhat closer to earth.

title: HEAD OF OLYMPICS EXPELS 6 MEMBERS IN PAYOFF SCANDAL
description: Taking unprecedented disciplinary action and acknowledging widespread wrongdoing, the president of the International Olympic Committee expelled six members today for receiving improper benefits in the Salt Lake City bidding scandal.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Sun Plans Slate of Licensees
description: Hoping to herald the post-PC era, Sun Microystems Inc. plans to announce on Monday a group of nearly three-dozen licensees for its Jini software -- a technology that is meant to allow for networks of devices as diverse as computers, cellular phones and kitchen appliances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSON, CATHERINE
description: MANSON-Catherine. On January 23, 1999, of East Hampton and NYC. Beloved wife of Alan. Loving mother of Deirdre Dickinson. Dear grandmother of Nathaniel, Peter and Zoe Bisson. Also survived by two great-grandchildren, Chase and Sienna Noel. Services at the Williams Funeral Home, 99 Newtown Lane, East Hampton, Tuesday, 11:30 AM.

title: Once Again, a Wanderer in a Dream World
description: When Lynne Taylor-Corbett choreographed ''Chiaroscuro'' in 1994, she wished her ballet to show off the dramatic intensity of Jock Soto, and it did so very well. He once again looked splendid in it when the New York City Ballet revived the work on Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Can't See the Screen For the Graphics
description: In a recent skit on ''Saturday Night Live,'' the weekly NBC comedy show, it looked as if some crazed collage artist had gone berserk and taken control of the television screens. Instead, it was a case of the show's writers and cast members satirizing one of the hottest trends in television journalism: the use of multiple pictures, graphics, logos and ticker tapes in news reports.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Jan. 9 about Dr. Louis Jolyon West, a psychiatrist involved in many famous court cases, misstated the place of the execution he witnessed that turned him against the death penalty. His family says it was in Iowa, not Wisconsin.

title: By Design; Not Your Father's Fedora
description: Stylish men -- those who favor long overcoats with tailored suits -- are topping off their look this winter with fedoras. These are not their fathers' hats, but cool new versions with straight brims and narrow ribbon bands.

title: American Express Net Up 7.5% in Quarter
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 7.5 percent as card holders spent more on their cards and as its asset-management unit collected more fees from investors pouring money into mutual funds.

title: VITAL SIGNS: CHILDBIRTH; Of Mind, Body and Low Birth Weight
description: Pregnant women have plenty to worry about, including not worrying too much. A number of medical studies have found that there is in fact a link between anxiety during pregnancy and low birth weight.

title: Turning Dinosaur Theory on Its Paleobiological Tail
description: By shining ultraviolet light on the fossil of a baby dinosaur that had collected dust in a file drawer in Italy for 15 years, paleontologists have discovered astonishingly well-preserved anatomical details that have rekindled one of the most intense debates in paleobiology.

title: Griffith Clears the Path for Davis
description: He is small, heavy and does the grunt work. And that alone qualified Howard Griffith to go out with the offensive linemen tonight at the hard-to-get-into Joe's Stone Crab -- the restaurant where you have to know somebody before they let you wait on line for 45 minutes.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWENK, JEANNE ELIZABETH
description: SCHWENK-Jeanne Elizabeth. January 26, 1969. Thirty years ago her death ended our love story and initiated a fictional one. Those of you who remember her, please join me in recalling her vivaciousness and warmth. Ken Schwenk

title: 3i in Talks to Acquire Electra Investment Trust
description: 3i Group P.L.C., Europe's largest traded venture capital fund, said yesterday that it was in talks that might lead to its acquisition of Electra Investment Trust P.L.C., a company with a net asset value of $:1.1 billion ($1.82 billion). Shares of Electra, based in Britain, rose 21 percent, or 119 pence, to 682.5 pence.

title: Authorities Say Child Was a Homicide Victim
description: The Westchester County Medical Examiner ruled yesterday that a child whose body was found partly buried in the woods near the Saw Mill River Parkway on Saturday was a homicide victim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, KATHERINE SCANLON
description: ADAMS-Katherine Scanlon. Age 45, of Greenwich, CT, died January 20, at home. Services will be held Tuesday, January 26, at 12:30 PM, at the Brick Church, Manhattan. Donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Memorial Fund (#

title: Terrified, but Feeling Good About It
description: Today's amusement park rides are faster, scarier and more elaborate than ever, and some theme park visitors are clutching their stomachs and opting for the sidelines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMBERG, DREW (ANDREW)
description: BLUMBERG - Drew (Andrew). Cherished and beloved son of Gladys and Ralph, dear brother of Steven and Lynda Royce, dearest friend of Erika, esteemed and beloved trainer and teacher of many. Services today 12:30 pm at ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Drew Andrew Blumberg Foundation for Abused and Underprivileged Children, 2021 Ocean Avenue, 112, Santa Monica, CA 90405.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFKOWITZ, IRWIN J.
description: LEFKOWITZ-Irwin J., born August 30, 1933 passed away Sunday, January 24, 1999. Beloved husband of Ruth, loving father of Robert, Howard and Jennifer, grandfather of Andrew, Michael and Jeffrey, son of Rose Flam and brother of Stuart Lefkowitz and Marilyn Halpern. Services will be held at 10:00 am Tuesday, January 26, 1999 at Woodlands Community Temple, 50 Worthington Road, White Plains, NY. Interment to follow at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY.

title: Doctors in Louisville Perform Nation's First Hand Transplant
description: Surgeons in Louisville, Ky., performed the first hand transplant in the United States on Sunday, replacing the left hand of a New Jersey man with one taken from an unidentified donor who had died a few hours earlier.

title: Tchaikovsky's Ultimate Torment
description: Boris Eifman and his company are an intriguing puzzle, whatever else they are. Mr. Eifman's ''Tchaikovsky,'' performed by the Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburg on Friday night at City Center, is a work with big, simple themes of the sort Maurice Bejart specialized in, painted with similarly broad, theatrical strokes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURGER, CHARLES HAINES
description: BURGER-Charles Haines, age 70, died peacefully in his home on Hutchinson Island, FL, on January 25, 1999. Charlie previously resided in Manhasset, NY, for thirty-seven years and retired to Lord's Valley, PA, and Hutchinson Island, FL. He was a graduate of Fordham University, class of '49 and worked at Merrill Lynch for forty years in New York City. He served as a director of North Shore Hospital in the 1970's as well as a board member of Lord's Valley Country Club in Lord's Valley, PA. He is survived by his loving wife, Lois, of 42 years, and his five children, Elizabeth Brown of Pennsylvania; Charles J. Burger and wife, Darby, of Barrington, RI; Christine Purcell and husband, Patrick of Overland Park, KS; Peter Burger and wife, Stacey, of London, England; and Lorraine Apgar and husband, Scott, of Wildwood, MO. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Hospice of Martin and St. Lucie, Inc., 2030 SE Ocean Boulevard, Stuart, FL 34996. For information, Aycock Funeral Home, Jensen Beach, Florida.

title: Dolphin Tells of Attack
description: The Miami Dolphins linebacker Zach Thomas said that he was attacked this past weekend outside a Manhattan nightclub, robbed of his wallet and beaten by several men.

title: Malaysia Seems to Want Foreigners to Return
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia said yesterday that his Government wanted to woo back foreign investors and was studying ways to relax its controls on the removal of foreign capital from the country. Mr. Mahathir told foreign investment-fund managers not to expect a full removal of controls on movements of capital but said the Government was working on ''certain adjustments,'' possibly including replacement of the limits with a tax on transfer of funds out of the country.

title: Ventura and DiMaggio Share a Common Bond
description: In recent months, as Joe DiMaggio has battled lung cancer and pneumonia amid mounting concerns for his well-being, there has been renewed interest in his Hall of Fame career and a sense of wonderment once again over his legendary 56-game hitting streak.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; UBS says it will reduce international lending, as well as risks like investment in distressed loans.
description: STILL recovering from its disastrous investment in derivatives last year, UBS A.G. of Switzerland announced a broad retreat yesterday from some of its riskier areas of lending and investment banking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALBER, ESTHER (NEE LEVINSON)
description: BALBER-Esther (nee Levinson), 87, in Boston. Devoted wife of the late Henry Balber, beloved mother of Marcia Sherbell, Jay Balber, and Ellen Balber. Loving grandmother of the late Eric Sherbell, William Balber, David Sherbell, the late Ilyana Reiser, Bari Balber Cariello, Rachel Reiser, and Eric Diaz. Also leaves a son-in-law David Conlon and daughter-in-law Roberta Balber, and numerous nieces and nephews. Services at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 312 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. at 1 P.M. on January 26. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hebrew Rehabilitation Center for Aged (HRCA), 1200 Centre St., Roslindale, MA 02131.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALYO, STANLEY JOSEPH
description: CALYO-Stanley Joseph. Of New City, New York. On January 23, 1999. (Pressman for The New York Times for fifteen years; prior for Herald Tribune.) Husband of the late Mildred Schwartz Calyo. Father of Eric Stuart Calyo and Jerry Janis & the late David Calyo. Grandfather of Adeena Beth Calyo. Services Tuesday, 11 AM at Higgins Funeral Home, 321 South Main Street, New City, New York. Visitation at the funeral home on Tuesday, from 9-11 AM. Donations to American Legion Post John Fraser Bryon #

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about ways in which possible computer malfunctions in 2000 could affect health care misstated the given name of a systems manager who was concerned about the problem. She is Laurene West, not Laureen.

title: Where Millenniums Are Treated Like Centuries
description: MARA AND DANN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALTER, RUTH
description: BALTER-Ruth. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to David and Howard Balter on the loss of their wife and mother. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, ANNE
description: JAFFE-Anne. Beloved wife of the late Ben. Devoted mother of Susan Cutler and Michael Jaffe. Cherished grandmother of Lawrence, Robert, Jordana, Elana and Samara. Service today, 11:30 AM in ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue (near Avenue V), Brooklyn, New York.

title: Superclusters of Galaxies Shed New Light on Cosmic Architecture
description: Stars, galaxies of stars and clusters of galaxies, these are the more familiar members in the hierarchy of structure in the universe. But there are things much, much bigger: superclusters, agglomerations of galaxies and galaxy clusters that stretch across millions of light-years of space.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TEITELBAUM, JEROME H.
description: TEITELBAUM-Jerome H. Twelve years ago today. Deeply loved, sorely missed. Maria

title: Union Membership Rose in '98, but Unions' Percentage of Work Force Fell
description: The Bureau of Labor Statistics announced yesterday that union membership grew by 100,000 last year, after three years of decline, causing the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to boast that its efforts to revive organized labor were beginning to pay off.

title: When Spats Send the Pressure Soaring
description: Arguing with a spouse seems a sure-fire way of raising the blood pressure -- unless, a University of Utah study has found, one partner wins or loses all the arguments in the household.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS FALLS 3.6 PERCENT. Prices fell to the weakest level since Sept. 3 on expectations of abnormally warm weather, which would reduce demand. The February contract fell 6.4 cents, to $1.714 for 1,000 cubic feet.

title: Conservatives Open Drive Against Affirmative Action
description: On 15 campuses across the country, students will open their college newspapers today to a full-page advertisement with the headline ''Guilty by Admission'' and, in bold print, ''Nearly Every Elite College in America Violates the Law. Does Yours?''

title: Closing Time
description: The Senate seemed to be recovering its balance yesterday after a turbulent weekend, and in its own fashion is now moving to conclude the impeachment trial. The precise path and timing remain unclear, and unexpected turns remain possible until the final votes are cast. But the message from yesterday's convoluted proceedings on and off the Senate floor was that Republicans and Democrats alike want to bring the case, as Senator Joseph Lieberman said, to a ''dignified and civil'' conclusion.

title: Metro Business; Airport Moves Closer To Private Operation
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday that Stewart International Airport in Orange County, N.Y., was one step closer to becoming the first publicly owned airport in the nation to be privatized.

title: Sex Shops on the Defensive, But Far From Stamped Out
description: Six months after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began the most aggressive crackdown on topless bars, peep shows and adult video stores in the city's history, Dean Richards surveyed Ten's World-Class Cabaret in Manhattan on a recent night. Two dancers performed slow stripteases, and scores of others circulated among the male customers. One woman with a bottle of lotion offered $20 neck rubs.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN REBOUNDS. Japan's currency rose after the Government reported a record trade surplus for 1998, leaving Japanese exporters with a huge supply of dollars to sell for yen. The dollar fell to 113.96 yen from 114.54.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAUL, ROBERT
description: JAUL-Robert. The officers and members of the Real Estate Tax Review Bar Association mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague, Bob Jaul. He will be remembered fondly as a scholar and a gentleman. The Real Estate Tax Review Bar Association William E. Banfield, President

title: Families Pool Resources to Build Tradition of Charity
description: The Seltzer family of Manhattan believes in the importance of doing things together. The parents, Ann and Richard Seltzer, cook family dinners almost every night. Their twin children, Daniel and Sarah, had a dual bar and bat mitzvah ceremony two years ago, and they write a combined column for their high school newspaper. And together, the Seltzers make annual contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, THOMAS
description: KELLY-Thomas Michael. Of Peekskill, N.Y. Suddenly on January 23, 1999. Father of Matthew and Teresa Kelly. Son of the late Patrick Joseph and Mary Reidy Kelly. Brother of Br. Donald J. Kelly, Ph.D., Patricia Kelly McCarthy, M.D. of Long Island and Mrs. Eileen Bohan of Connecticut. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held Wednesday, January 27th, 11AM at The Assumption Church, Peekskill, N.Y. Visitation will be held today, 2-4 and 7-9PM at the Joseph F. Nardone Funeral Home, 414 Washington St, Peekskill, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDHIRSH, WENDY (MARTZ)
description: GOLDHIRSH-Wendy (Martz) entered into rest, January 24, in Manchester-by-the-Sea, Massachusetts. Beloved wife of Bernard A. Goldhirsh. Dear daughter of Lawrence and Rebecca Martz of Brooklyn; devoted mother of Elizabeth Goldhirsh and Benjamin Goldhirsh both of Manchester-bythe-Sea. Loving sister of Brian Martz of Long Beach, N.Y., and Peter Martz of NY. Services at Temple Ahavas Achim, 86 Middle Street, Gloucester, MA., Tuesday, January 26 at 2:00 P.M. Memorial Observance through Sunday evening at her late residence. In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy in her memory may be donated to the Massachusetts General Hospital Cancer Center Fund, C/O Development Office, 100 Charles River Plaza #

title: Warner-Lambert Net Rises
description: The Warner-Lambert Company, one of the world's most profitable drug makers, said today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 45 percent as it sold more of its cholesterol-reducer Lipitor and the anti-diabetes pill Rezulin. Net income rose to $341.1 million, or 40 cents a diluted share, compared with $235.7 million, or 28 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Results matched the 40-cent average estimate of analysts polled by the First Call Corporation. Sales rose 24 percent, to $2.88 billion from $2.33 billion.

title: Jury Convicts 4 Men Of Stealing Benefits
description: After deliberating for five days, a Federal jury yesterday convicted three men from Rockland County and one from Brooklyn on charges that they stole $10 million worth of Government benefits, including student grants, housing subsidies, small-business loans and Social Security benefits.

title: Unworthy Role Model
description: To the Editor:

title: TRW IS NEAR DEAL TO BUY LUCAS VARITY
description: Lucas Varity P.L.C., the maker of car brakes said yesterday that it was close to an agreement to be bought by TRW Inc. for more than $6.5 billion in cash. The purchase would exceed a potential offer by the Federal-Mogul Corporation, the maker of engine seals, of $:3.9 billion, or $6.4 billion. ''We wouldn't be announcing something unless this is a little sweeter'' than what Federal-Mogul said it might offer, said Nicholas Jones, a spokesman for Lucas Varity. TRW declined to comment immediately.TRW, based in Cleveland, makes high-technology products for the automotive, space, defense and information technology industries. Lucas Varity has $5.4 billion in annual auto-parts sales and $1.1 billion in aerospace-parts revenue.

title: Winners in the 1999 Intel Science Search
description: Following are the 40 finalists in the 1999 Intel Science Talent Search contest for high school students:

title: Trahan, Burden Wins 3 Accounts
description: Trahan, Burden & Charles in Baltimore has been awarded three accounts with combined billings estimated at almost $20 million.

title: Brazil's Ability to Repay Debt Is Downgraded
description: A major credit rating service today downgraded its assessment of Brazil's ability to repay debts, and the value of the Brazilian currency fell nearly 4 percent in a further sign of investor anxiety about Latin America's biggest economy.

title: Bonus Babies
description: In addition to wanting to win the Super Bowl because of professional pride, as well as an intense dislike of each other, Denver Coach Mike Shanahan and his Atlanta counterpart, Dan Reeves, have another incentive -- cash.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Same Date, Different Name

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELEGANT, MOIRA CLARISSA
description: ELEGANT - Moira Clarissa. Slipped her bonds in peace, on January 20, 1999. In memory of her joyous life, donations to cancer research or animal welfare, please. Faxes: 610-355-0265.

title: Accounts
description: * Mervyn's California, San Francisco, a unit of the Dayton Hudson Corp., to Martin/Williams Advertising, Minneapolis, a unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle its branding account, which had been handled in-house, and redevelop television advertising for the retail chain. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Number of Oil Rigs Down
description: Baker Hughes Inc., the third-largest United States oilfield services company, said the number of rigs drilling for oil and natural gas in the United States had fallen to the lowest level since 1947. The count has fallen for months as companies cut exploration spending because of dropping oil and gas prices. There were 588 rigs operating in the United States last week, down from 996 last year, the Houston-based Baker Hughes said. The previous low was 596, on June 12, 1992. Baker Hughes's weekly report counts inland and offshore rigs actively drilling to find or develop oil and natural gas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROVER, LEONORE K.
description: GROVER-Leonore K., 85, of Naples, FL. ''Lee'', internationally known art glass dealer/author, died in Naples on January 22. Mrs. Grover and deceased husband, Raymond G. Grover, made outstanding contributions to the art glass field. For information, Berkowitz-Kumin-Bookatz Memorial Chapel In Cleveland Hts, OH.

title: KELLOGG BRINGS IN NEW CHIEF FOR CEREAL UNIT
description: The Kellogg Company yesterday named John D. Cook to head its North American cereal operations. It was the second appointment this month of an executive from outside the company to a top post at Kellogg, which is trying to reverse declining market share and a 22 percent fall in its stock price in the last year. Mr. Cook, 45, who will immediately become president of Kellogg North America and an executive vice president of the company, has been a director of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company, where he was in charge of its consumer-goods practice.

title: High Court Says Local Phone Giants Don't Have to Sell Access
description: The Supreme Court yesterday issued a ruling that could delay efforts to open the $100 billion local telephone business to competition.

title: Former Gun Executive Faults Manufacturers
description: A Federal jury in Brooklyn yesterday heard the views of a former gun company executive who held that manufacturers and wholesalers have failed to do all they can to combat illegal trafficking in handguns.

title: New Vandals Scratching Up The Subways
description: YOU have to admire New York City Transit for the speed it generally shows in covering up graffiti whenever it pops up on buses and subway trains. It almost makes one wish that he had the agency's paint concession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURDMAN, SYLVIA
description: BURDMAN-Sylvia. Sincerest condolences to Shelley Goren, esteemed member of the Board of Governors of Friends of Yeshivat Sha'alvim, on the loss of his sister. Yeshivat Sha'alvim

description: GOLDRING-Arnold. On January 24, 1999. Husband of the late Mildred. Loving brother of Lillian Summer, dear uncle of Sharon Nowik and Esther Kashnow. Services today, 2PM at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge NJ.

title: Stately Elgar, Embodiment Of a Vanished Britain
description: If the ''new Britain'' of Tony Blair's Labor Party ever goes in search of a theme song, I doubt that it will turn to Edward Elgar. The new Britain, we are told, is sleek, fast-moving, international, able to turn on a 10-pence piece. The music of Elgar is deliberate, stately at its best, sometimes ponderous, measured in its eloquence, comfortably big, even portly if you will.

title: Banana Talks With Europe Turn Nasty U.S.
description: Prospects for a quick end to the increasingly acerbic trade row between the United States and the European Union over bananas faded today as a compromise was rejected and American efforts to move ahead with sanctions were blocked, at least temporarily.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  URIS, AUREN
description: URIS-Auren. Suddenly on January 24. Dearly beloved husband of Doris Reichbart. Devoted brother of Pearl Sheindelman and beloved father of Merka and Donald Fletcher, Victoria and John Giffin, Bettina and Daniel Uris and loving grandfather of Ethan, Addie, Lena and Will Fletcher. Services Wednesday, January 27, 2:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: LIPNICK-Rueben. Park East Synogogue mourns the passing of Rueben Lipnick, beloved brother of our devoted members Morris and Esther Lipnick and uncle of Dr. Barry Lipnick. title: Podujevo Journal; In a Kosovo Town, the Serbs Feel Persecuted Too
description: Milos Savic, one of the few Serbs left in this northern Kosovo town, says he has lost almost 40 pounds, but he does not recommend the diet.

title: Clinton's Social Security Plan Is Pure Gimmickry; There's No Guarantee
description: To the Editor:

title: Chocolate Lovers Are Made, Not Born, Science Learns
description: Dark, rich and lusciously sweet, chocolate is the most irresistible of confections, so addictive that it has been suspected of intoxicating with marijuana-like opiates and chemicals that can mimic the brain chemistry of a person in love. Chocolate seems to have a special power over women, who consistently rate it as their No. 1 food craving and whose desire for it often intensifies around the time of menstruation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, HERMAN S.
description: RUBIN-Herman S. On January 24, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Loving brother of Marion Kaminsky. Dear uncle of Ann Rubin. Services private.

title: John Paul Tells Mexicans That Faith Must Overcome Corruption
description: Pope John Paul II bade farewell to Mexico today with a spiritual message aimed straight at the country's social and political ills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONWAY, HUGH P.
description: CONWAY-Hugh P. Of Bayonne, on January 23, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Agnes R. (nee Nelson), devoted father of Clare McGarvey, Eileen Boland, and Hugh T. Conway. Also survived by nine grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Funeral from the Levis Funeral Home, 151 Ave C, Bayonne NJ on Wed., January 27. Funeral Mass St. Mary, Star of the Sea Church, at 9:30. Visiting hours, Tues, 2-4 and 7-9. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Queens.

description: SILVER-Ethel. Died peacefully at 91 on January 24, 1999. Graveside funeral. Call: 212473-4524.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about Encarta Africana, a CD-ROM encyclopedia of black history, omitted the given name of the director of entertainment and technology strategies at Forrester Research, who said the disk might do well even though the market for ''edutainment'' software was shrinking. He is Joseph L. Butt.

title: Chicago Acquires Brent Barry
description: Brent Barry, a 6-foot-6-inch guard who won the National Basketball Association's slam-dunk contest three years ago and who is known for his flashy play and no-look passes, has joined the new-look Chicago Bulls as their shooting guard. It's a position a guy named Jordan played with distinction for many years.

title: Without Beijing Nod, Town Has Election
description: Apparently without formal approval from Beijing, a remote farming region in central China has held the country's first direct elections for leader of a township.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDESCO, FREDERICK S.
description: LANDESCO-Frederick S. Age 81. Formerly of Larchmont, N.Y. Died January 14, 1999. He is survived by daughters, Joan Murphy of Minnetonka, MN; Lynn Landesco of Fort Lauderdale, FL; and Anne Landesco of New Rochelle, N.Y.; two grandchildren, Scott and Julie. Donations may be made to the Jewish Guild for the Blind. For more information, 914-576-3924.

title: Life Terms in Prison For Killer of a Couple
description: A Pleasantville man who admitted killing a young girl and her boyfriend and burying them in his basement in 1985 was sentenced yesterday to consecutive life terms in prison, officials said.

title: The Other Side of Flossing
description: To the Editor:

title: Remedy Research: Some Hints, Few Answers
description: Eager to relieve the agonizing symptoms of winter viruses, sufferers are widening the search for remedies well beyond the conventional treatments. But even as Americans gobble $12 million worth of vitamins, herbs and supplements annually, scientists and others say there is not enough solid research to evaluate their effectiveness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRASBERG, SUSAN
description: STRASBERG - Susan Elizabeth. Actress and author on January 21, 1999. Beloved mother of Jennifer Robin Jones Strasberg. Loving daughter of the late Lee and Paula Strasberg. Service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, January 26 at 1 P.M. Interment private.

title: Compaq Is Expected to Spin Off Part of Alta Vista
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation is expected to announce plans today to sell or spin off part of its Alta Vista Web site in a public offering, a person close to the company's plans said.

description: LINK-Eleanor Irene Higgins, age 83 of Spring Lake, New Jersey on January 24, 1999. Beloved wife of the late George Link, Jr. Devoted sister of the late Anne & Catherine Higgins. Entombment The Cemetery of the Ascension, Monsey, New York. Visiting on Wednesday 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Donation to Rosary Hill Home, C/O Sister of Miriam, O.F., 600 Linda Avenue, Hawthorne, New York 10532.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZE, LEWIS BARRY
description: MAZE-Lewis Barry. 54 years. On January 22, 1999 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Loving husband of Annette Popowitz. Devoted son of Charlotte Maze and the late Samuel Maze. Dearest brother of Stephanie Warshall and brother-in-law of Frederick Warshall. Loving uncle of Daniel. Lew's goodness and gentle spirit will be missed by all who knew him. We were enriched by having you as a part of our lives. Your memory will always bring comfort to those who mourn your passing. Go with laughter and love. Memorial services on Sunday, February 7, 12:30PM at the UN Chapel, 777 United Nations Plaza (44 Street and 1st Ave).

title: At Microsoft Trial, Accounts Differ on Dealings With Apple
description: The Justice Department's lead lawyer in the Microsoft antitrust case clashed today with the company's highest-ranking witness as the Government charged that the software maker had used its market power as ''a club'' in its dealings with Apple Computer Inc., while the Microsoft executive countered that his company was responding to a threat of ''patent terrorism'' from Apple.

title: Time Is Added for Nasdaq I.P.O. Pricing
description: Acting to stem the wild price swings that have become commonplace on the first day of trading of some Internet companies, the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday approved a rule extending to 15 minutes the period market makers must post prices for shares of initial public offerings on the Nasdaq stock market before those shares begin to trade. The change takes effect today.

title: INTEL ALTERS PLAN SAID TO UNDERMINE PC USERS' PRIVACY
description: The Intel Corporation yesterday reversed a plan to activate an identifying signature in its next generation of computer chips, bowing to protests that the technology would compromise the privacy of users.

title: Citigroup's 4th-Quarter Operating Earnings Plunged 27%
description: Citigroup, still struggling to revive its corporate banking business, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter operating earnings plunged 27 percent, although the weak performance was bolstered by a strong showing from the consumer banking operation and exceeded analysts' expectations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNEEN, FRANCIS M.
description: CUNNEEN-Francis M. Age 80, on January 24, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Josephine M. Devoted father of Donald, Joanne, Patricia Kowalski, Kathleen Dooley, Timothy, and Thomas. Loving brother of Mae Montgomery, Gladys McWilliams, and Charles T. Also survived by fourteen grandchildren. Friends may call at The Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th Street), NYC, Tuesday 7-9 P.M. and Wednesday 2-5, and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 11 A.M. at Saint Ignatius Loyola R.C. Church. Interment Saint John's Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Senator Robert C. Byrd's plan for a motion to dismiss charges against President Clinton misstated the title of Mike DeWine, Republican of Ohio. He is a senator, not a representative.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORRI, CATARINA
description: BORRI-Catarina, of NYC, passed away peacefully on January 24th, 1999 at JFK Hospital in Edison, NJ. Born in Biella, Pr. Vercelli, Italy in 1903, is survived by her only son, Tullio, of Metuchen, NJ, 3 grandchildren, Gregg Borri and Claire Hallock of NYC, Catherine Lyness of Summit, NJ, and 6 great-grandchildren. She was a strong, loving and caring mother. A private memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: National Grid Seen Going After U.S. Utility
description: National Grid Group P.L.C., which operates Britain's electricity transmission system, could cut costs if it bought a second American utility company, analysts said yesterday in response to a report in The Sunday Telegraph that National Grid was in talks to buy the Boston-based Eastern Utilities Associates for $750 million.

title: Whitman Budget Speech Focuses on Property Taxes
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman presented lawmakers today with a proposed budget that would return $200 million to property taxpayers, but she made it clear that any cuts in property tax rates would require tough choices by municipal officials and taxpayers about their local services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSING, TOLA
description: MESSING-Tola. Died January 24 in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. Beloved wife of Leon for 60 years. Loving mother of Lisette Nayor, Micki Joseph and Florence Messing and devoted grandmother of David, Daniel, Benjamin, Philip and Marc. Also mourned by her sisters, Zosia and Annette and her niece, Christine, in Paris, France. Services on Tuesday, January 26, at 1 PM at Star of David Funeral Home in North Lauderdale, Florida.

title: Home Resales Rose to a 3d Record in 1998
description: Yearly sales of previously owned homes surged to a third straight record in 1998, propelled by stronger-than-expected gains in December.

title: Terriers Feature Top Scorer
description: Last season, St. Francis Coach Ron Ganulin thought he had too many slashing players in his lineup, so he had Ray Minlend come off the bench most of the time.

title: Lilly and 3 Rivals to Settle Prozac Suit for $4 Million
description: Preserving the sales of its top brand, Eli Lilly & Company announced yesterday that it had reached a $4 million settlement with three drug companies that were vying to make a generic version of Prozac, the company's popular antidepressant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, ROBERT
description: SHAW-Robert. The Board of Trustees and Staff of Carnegie Hall are deeply saddened by the loss of conductor and musical statesman, Robert Shaw. In the course of a sixty-year relationship with Carnegie Hall that began in 1939, Mr. Shaw performed at the Hall more than fifty times, including his renowned Robert Shaw Choral Workshops, which have taken place every year since 1990. His legendary attention to detail in the art of choral conducting, his musicianship, his conviction, and his humanity were an inspiration to all who knew and worked with him, and his presence will be sorely missed. We extend our sincerest sympathies to his family. Isaac Stern, President Sanford I. Weill, Chairman

title: UConn Saved By Hamilton Once Again
description: The University of Connecticut players heard the chants of ''overrated,'' and ignored them in the first half. But the concrete walls could not block out the sound that reverberated through the Huskies' locker room.

title: Cendant Names Ernst & Young in Suit
description: The Cendant Corporation, the franchising and discount-shopping company burned by accounting fraud last year, has sued the accounting firm Ernst & Young L.L.P., contending that the firm violated professional standards when it certified CUC International Inc.'s false financial statements.

title: Judge Delays Giuliani Plan On Welfare
description: Ruling that the Giuliani administration had overlooked the ''urgent needs'' of the poor in its zeal to overhaul welfare, a Federal judge barred city officials yesterday from expanding their tough new welfare policies until they can guarantee prompt access to food stamps and Medicaid applications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROMER, CLAIRE
description: FROMER-Claire. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing, in Toronto, of a highly respected member of the Jewish community, beloved wife of Ralph Fromer and mother of Brenda (and Moshe) Bessin and Beverly Fromer. Moshe Bessin is a trustee of our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. Longtime friends of the University, the Bessin family are YU Guardians and Founders of our Albert Einstein College of Medicine, where they established the Marion Bessin Liver Research Center in memory of Mr. Bessin's mother. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S.Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, JOHN (B.J.)
description: JOHNSON-John (B.J.) 77, of Juno Beach, FL passed away Friday, January 22, 1999 at Palm Beach Gardens Medical Center after a brief illness. He was born in Laona, WI and had been a resident of Juno Beach for the past 12 years, formerly of Rye Brook, NY. Prior to retirement, he was the Director of Worldwide Employee Relations with IBM in Armonk, NY. He was a member of the Turtle Creek Country Club in Tequesta and a former member of Westchester Country Club in Rye, NY. He had served on the Board of Directors at United Hospital in Port Chester, NY and was a veteran of WW II, serving in the U.S. Army Air Corps. Survivors include his wife, Mary Josephine Johnson of Juno Beach; one son Steve Johnson of Annapolis, MD; one daughter JoAnn Sanchez of New Fairfield, CT; three sisters, Lorraine Woulf of Peshtigo, WI; Carol Woulf of Coleman, WI and Donna Fournier of Tomahawk, WI; 2 grandchildren and 6 nieces and nephews. A mass of Christian burial will be celebrated Wednesday, 1pm at Our Lady of Mercy Church, Port Chester, NY. Interment Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY.

title: Editorial Observer; When an Anchor's Face Is Not Her Fortune
description: In television news, as in entertainment, a pretty face can't hurt. Still, a few, mostly belonging to the males in the business, age more lucratively than others. Take Tom Brokaw, Dan Rather and Peter Jennings, for example. The visual effect of gravity on these three famous faces has been to add another layer of gravitas.

title: New Terminal Is Announced In Expansion At Kennedy
description: American Airlines unveiled plans yesterday to build a $1 billion terminal at Kennedy International Airport that will have 59 gates and a check-in area larger than Giants Stadium. Officials touted the project as a major step toward restoring Kennedy's reputation as the nation's premier international gateway.

Religious services St. Spyridon GO Church, 124 Wadsworth Ave., corner 179th St., NYC, Wednesday, 10 AM. Interment Mt. Olivet Cemetery.

title: Feisty Samaranch Takes On Scandal and Critics
description: With the Olympic movement in dishonor because of the greatest corruption scandal in its history, its leader, Juan Antonio Samaranch, appears to have convinced himself that he can restore his legacy by cleaning up the contaminated bidding process for the Games.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Although we are deeply grieved by the circumstance that brings you to our town, we welcome you as our guest, and we trust that you will find Jasper to be the warm, hospitable, God-centered town that we have all come to love.''

title: THE PRESIDENT'S TRIAL: The Case Against Dismissal ; Excerpts: 'We Haven't Had a Chance to Present Our Case, Really'
description: Following are excerpts from the presentations today by the House managers of the impeachment case against President Clinton, as they argued against the motion to dismiss the case. (Today's exerpts were recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.)

title: H & R BLOCK DROPS CREDIT CARD OPERATION
description: H & R Block Inc., the largest tax-preparation company in the United States, said yesterday that it would sell its credit card unit to the Providian Financial Corporation and leave the credit card business. Terms of the transaction, which is expected to close Friday, were not disclosed. Providian, based in San Francisco, will buy the $181 million portfolio of Webcard Visa cards, used by customers of the Compuserve on-line service, which H & R Block sold to MCI Worldcom Inc. last February. H & R Block, based in Kansas City, Mo., will use the proceeds to pay down commercial-paper debt and will take a one-time charge of $15.4 million in its current fiscal quarter. Shares of Providian rose $2.3125, to $91.9375. Shares of H & R Block rose 25 cents, to $43.25.

title: Workers' Health Care Is a Good Buy; Spread the Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Hurt Feelings and Maneuvering Before Senate Takes Crucial Vote
description: With doors closed to the public and television cameras switched off, the Senate tonight debated whether to dismiss all charges against President Clinton and bring his impeachment trial to an end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARELLI, GABOR
description: CARELLI-Gabor. The Manhattan School of Music is saddened by the loss of distinguished faculty member Gabor Carelli. A renowned member of our voice and vocal ensembles faculties since 1964, his intellect, energy and compassion enriched the lives of generations of students. His absence will be sorely missed by all. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to his family. David A. Rahm, Chairman Board of Trustees Marta Istomin, President

title: For Couture, the Show Will Go On
description: Whether because of the economy, the euro, media hype, Bernard Arnault, an infusion of new money from Germany and the former Eastern Bloc, or just the same old let-them-eat-cake attitude, haute couture doesn't appear to be a glamorous dodo bird after all.

title: Fire the Olympic Patriarch
description: The sacking of a half-dozen bribe-takers from the ranks of more than 100 International Olympic Committee members may be good face-saving public relations. The promise to test a corruption-resistant process for picking the host city for the 2006 Winter Games is welcome. But the scope of the widening scandal suggests that the I.O.C. president, Juan Antonio Samaranch, should step down. Since bribery infected Olympic site selections on his watch, he cannot now credibly supervise a cleanup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKOWITZ, GUSSIE
description: MOSKOWITZ - Gussie. Beloved wife of the late Julius S. Loving mother of Dr. Ann Lyons and the late Justice Ruth Moskowitz Gershon. Cherished grandmother of Joel and Leah Gershon. Burial in Israel.

title: A Man, a Plan, Red Lobster
description: Hip-hop in the 1990's favors a mood that is cool and hard, sometimes making it difficult to remember that one of its key ingredients is joy. The rapper's delight is that of the braggart who makes himself a new man with nothing more than words, and of the sorcerer who discovers his incantations really can momentarily alter reality. This spirit is the source of the genre's continued ability to surprise.

title: Nassau Democrats Urge Chief To Quit as He Goes on Trial
description: The Nassau County Democratic leader Stephen J. Sabbeth went on trial in Federal District Court here today on bankruptcy fraud charges, as opponents in the party called on him to step down.

title: I.O.C. Officials to Scrutinize Sydney Bid
description: The International Olympic Committee will send one of its vice presidents, Jacques Rogge, and its director general, Francois Carrard, here next month to investigate the offer of $70,000 in sports aid that was made to committee members from Africa by a key figure of the Sydney bidding team on the eve of the vote for the 2000 Summer Olympics.

title: INSIDE
description: King Hussein Names Heir

title: Catholics Try to Reseed St. Louis With $5,000 Offer
description: It was a compelling offer for Dave and Patti Patty-G'sell: $5,000 to put toward buying a house.

title: Workers' Health Care Is a Good Buy; Shortsighted Savings
description: To the Editor:

title: Ovitz's Former Agency Vows to Fight Him for Hollywood Clients
description: In an aggressive move unusual even in Hollywood, the Creative Artists Agency retaliated yesterday against Michael Ovitz, its former chairman, and said it would not share its prestigious list of clients with the new management company set up by him.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Genocide in Africa, Quibbles in the West
description: The horror with which Joseph Conrad stamped Africa a century ago persists in tonight's ''Frontline'' report on the 1994 slaughter in Rwanda. The journalists and former officials who testify affectingly in ''The Triumph of Evil'' offer evidence that policy planners in Europe, the United States and the United Nations knew what was coming but lacked the will to stop it.

title: Foreign Affairs; Broken China
description: The Middle East in recent years has been renowned for its ability to stay the same the more things change everywhere else. Well, those days are over. The sound you hear from the Middle East today is the sound of china breaking. The combination of geology (falling oil prices), biology (a generation of leaders dying off) and technology (the Internet and globalization) is starting to transform the neighborhood. Consider a few recent developments:

title: Gauges Return to Plus Column on Strong Earnings Reports
description: After meandering through much of the day, stocks closed higher, lifting major averages back into plus territory for the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWIE, EFFIE BELLE ROGERS
description: BOWIE-Effie Belle Rogers. On January 25, 1999. Beloved mother of Faith Bowie, and wife of the late Letham. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street Thursday January 28th at 9:45 A.M. Interment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery. Mrs. Bowie, an artist, graduated from Texas State College for Women, and recieved her Masters Degree in Fine Arts from Columbia University.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Drunken-Driving Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Seikaly's Injury Minor as Nets Hold Breath
description: When Rony Seikaly fell to the floor in pain tonight after stepping on Chris Gatling's foot, his Nets teammates reacted as if their hopes for a successful season had crashed down with him. Jim McIlvaine, the recently acquired center, stormed off the floor yelling words of disgust, while Jayson Williams wore a look of combined horror and sadness.

title: As Trial in Dragging Opens, Town Talks of Reconciliation
description: John William King had shed the bulletproof vest he had worn into the county courthouse today and had on a button-down shirt, untucked, its sleeves covering his racist tattoos, even the Woody Woodpecker in a Ku Klux Klan cap.

title: For Women, a Touchdown Pass to Fitness
description: A year ago, Sue Spiegel, 33, a television producer, didn't know a blitz from a blintz and assumed ''first and 10'' was a Manhattan street address. But on Sunday, after a year of weekly football workouts, she will be in front of the television, second-guessing Super Bowl strategy and empathizing with the players.

title: A Private Collector Delights the Israeli Public
description: It was quite a shock the day that Werner Merzbacher's babies left his home in Zurich for the Holy Land. All at once, exposing vast expanses of wall, they were gone: the Monet, the van Gogh, the Toulouse-Lautrec, the Matisse, the Modigliani, the Picasso, the 6 Klees, the 7 Kandinskys, the 10 Alexei von Jawlenskys.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a consensus in Albany to use some money from the settlement of the national tobacco lawsuit for health care for the uninsured misidentified a group advocating a program called Family Health Plus. It is the Greater New York Hospital Association, not the New York Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: Mayor Says Shanghai Investment Companies Are Healthy
description: In an effort to ease international concern about the health of China's financial institutions, the Mayor of Shanghai said today that state-owned investment companies in the nation's largest city were solvent, in contrast with those in the southern province of Guangdong.

title: U.S. Admits Missile Misfire May Have Hit Iraq Civilians
description: American jets attacked several air-defense sites in northern and southern Iraq today, and the Pentagon said at least one missile had misfired and might have killed several civilians in a residential neighborhood.

title: Greene to Face Training Partner
description: Maurice Greene, who set the the 60-meter world record at 6.39 seconds, believes he could run as fast 6.29 before the indoor season is over. But the record will not likely fall when he faces his training partner, Jon Drummond, at Madison Square Garden in the Chase Millrose Games on Feb. 5. Greene expects to run near the 6.46 he clocked in edging Drummond at last year's Millrose, the fastest 60 ever recorded in the United States.

title: G.O.P. Tax Plan Is Flawed, Democrats Say
description: The Republican proposal to cut income taxes by 10 percent across the board means that millions of middle-class families will get only part of the tax break and taxes will increase for large middle-income families by as much as 14 percent, House Democrats said yesterday.

title: Talking Back to Greenspan
description: I do not believe that it is politically feasible to insulate such huge funds from a governmental direction,'' Alan Greenspan told the House Ways and Means Committee last week, one day after President Clinton proposed investing a portion of Social Security funds in the stock market.

title: Eat Football, but Mostly Sleep Football
description: The warning bells inside the head of Atlanta Falcons linebacker Cornelius Bennett were ringing loudly today, as the chaotic seven days known as Super Bowl week began. He heard teammates talking about their plans -- their party plans. He heard them discuss which clubs they were going to, the beautiful women they were going to see, the sights and sounds they were going to enjoy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, LOUISE G.
description: O'CONNOR-Louise G. On January 23, 1999. Widow of Joseph A. O'Connor. Mother of Joseph A., Jr., William B. and D. Barry. Also survived by five grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Long-time resident of Roslyn Estates, New York, and former President of the Guild of St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, New York. Visiting at Fairchild Sons, Inc., 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York, on Thursday, January 28, from 7:00 PM to 9:00 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Peter of Alcantara R.C. Church, 1327 Port Washington Boulevard, Port Washington, New York, Friday, January 29, 9:30 A.M.

title: An Aggressive Push to Save Failing Hearts
description: Only about 5 percent of the five million Americans suffering from heart failure are receiving the most effective therapy, a panel of 150 cardiologists says, and this is resulting in what they estimate are 100,000 more deaths annually than would otherwise occur.

title: Top Archer Daniels Midland Executive Steps Down
description: Dwayne O. Andreas, who directed the transformation of the Archer Daniels Midland Corporation from a modest regional grain processor to a global agribusiness giant, yesterday stepped down as chairman of the company after more than a quarter of a century at the helm.

title: Rise in Infections Could Turn Mild Flu Season Nasty
description: So far the flu season has been as mild as the weather, according to the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta -- although it may not seem that way for anyone who has wrestled with a bout.

title: King Hussein Selects Eldest Son, Abdullah, as Successor
description: King Hussein of Jordan decreed on Monday that his eldest son, Prince Abdullah, would be next in line for the throne, Jordanian officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUNDERS, BAKER
description: SAUNDERS-Baker, 44, born September 23, 1954 in Montgomery, Alabama, died January 15, 1999. Survived by his father John Baker Saunders, his mother and stepfather Charleen and Peter Edge; his brother, Joseph H. (Katharine); his sister, Henrietta (Richard Day) Saunders and nephews and niece; Richard and Charlie Day, Joey and Julia Saunders and many friends. He attended North Shore Country Day School, Rye Country Day School, Fay School, Cabrillo College and Providence College. He was a bass guitar player who began his career playing with traditional blues artists in Chicago. He played with the Lamont Cranston Band in Minneapolis, Mad Season in Seattle, which received a gold record for the album ''Above''. He recorded & traveled in Europe with the Walkabouts. A gathering was held at the Library Cafe and a service was held at St. Lukes Church in Seattle. Memorial Services will be held Saturday, January 30 at 3:00 P.M. at the Church of the Holy Comforter, 222 Kenilworth Ave, Kenilworth, IL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHAC, NED
description: LEHAC-Ned, 99. Composer, teacher, anti-nuclear activist and loved husband of Jane Sherman. Englewood Hospital, January 23.

title: Movement May Offer Early Clue to Autism
description: The discovery that autistic children appear to have subtle abnormalities in body movements that can be diagnosed as early as 3 months is leading researchers to hope for new treatments.

title: Devils Seem a Shoo-In In Push for Playoffs
description: Contrary to popular perception, the National Hockey League's playoff formula is not so inclusive. Only 16 teams qualify for the tournament, and 11 do not make the cut. Six divisions this season -- instead of four -- means two more automatic berths for division winners.

title: Even if Guilty, Can Clinton Stay?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, LEWIS BERYL
description: GORDON-Lewis Beryl, age 68, on January 25, 1999, surrounded by family in his New York apartment. Beloved and dearest husband of Susan, loving father of Jonathan, Peter, Barbara, and Justin. Proud grandfather of Joshua, Jacob, Alexa, Paulina, and Perry. Uncle, cousin, brother-in-law, son-in-law, father-in-law, friend of many. Admired and treasured for his levity and love of life by his industry, friends, and family, and now also admired for his courage in battling his illness. Expressions of sympathy may be made to Visiting Nurse Service of New York Hospice Care, 1250 Broadway, 4th floor, New York, NY 10001. Services will be held Tuesday, January 26, 11:15AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street.

title: Lewinsky, Reluctant or Not, Tops the List
description: With the Senate's decision on whether to call Monica S. Lewinsky as a witness looming later this week, her lawyers said today that she did not want to participate in a proceeding that they called ''an unseemly circus.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENWALD, RUTH ISRAELS
description: ROSENWALD-Ruth Israels. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the passing of Ruth Israels Rosenwald, a cherished friend of the Jewish community. She was the beloved wife of William Rosenwald, a founder of United Jewish Appeal and former President of UJA-Federation, who held virtually every major leadership position in the American Jewish community. Her loving devotion to Mr. Rosenwald was a constant source of strength that inspired his efforts during the later years of his life. Their humanitarian concerns live on in the continuing dedication and leadership of their family. We extend our deepest condolences to her son, Michael Jozef Israels; her daughter-in-law, Maija-Sarmite Jansons; her stepdaughters, Nina Rosenwald, Elizabeth R. Varet and Alice R. Sigelman; her grandchildren; and the entire family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CALENERGY CO., Omaha, a power plant developer, agreed to sell its stakes in three geothermal electricity projects to closely held Caithness Energy L.L.C., New York, for $277 million in cash and assumed debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELDS, ERNEST W.
description: FIELDS-Ernest W. Of Morristown, New Jersey, formerly of Chatham, NJ on January 22, 1999. Husband of Maxine (Rabe) Fields. Father of Frederick of San Francisco. Step-father of Stephen Smythe of Ohio & Susan Schreiber of NJ. Brother of Ronsia of Cupertino, CA. Grandfather of Peter of San Francisco and Alexander of New York City. Step-grandfather of Lance and David Smythe of Maine, and Brian and Kevin O'Dea of Illinois. He is also survived by one step great grandson. A memorial service will be held at the Stanley Congregational Church, Chatham, NJ, Monday, February 1, 1999 at 11 AM. Those who which may contribute in his memory to the Ernest W. Fields and Friends Scholarship Fund at Lincoln Memorial University, Cumberland Gap Parkway, Harrogate, TN. 37752. For further information contact the Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, Chatham, N.J.

title: Clinton Refuses Senate's 10 Queries
description: Senate Republicans, seeking to resolve apparent conflicts in testimony by President Clinton and other witnesses, submitted 10 written questions to Mr. Clinton today. The White House promptly said he would refuse to answer them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOROSTOFF, ANNE
description: KOROSTOFF-Anne. Of Atlanta, GA. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Barney Korostoff, loving mother of Ruthe and Harry Bernhard, of Atlanta, GA, and the late Dr. Alan Korostoff, of Pasadena, CA. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Services were held in New York on January 26th.

title: People
description: * Philippe Bernard, chairman and chief executive of Ammirati Puris Lintas Spain, Madrid, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was named chairman of Ammirati Puris Lintas Paris, succeeding Alain Laurens, who left.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREYBERG, RICHARD H., M.D.
description: FREYBERG-Richard H., M.D. The Hospital for Special Surgery and its Board of Trustees deeply mourn the death of their devoted friend and colleague, Richard H. Freyberg, M.D. Dr. Freyberg served as Physician-In-Chief and Director of Rheumatology from 1945 to 1970, as well as on the Board of Trustees, and was deeply respected by his colleagues and patients. His association over so many years left a lasting impression on this institution, and Dr. Freyberg's nobility of spirit will continue to be an inspiration to us. We extend sincere condolences to his family. Richard L. Menschel, Chairman of the Board Aldo Papone, Co-Chairman of the Board John R. Reynolds, President, CEO Hospital for Special Surgery

title: Metrocard Machines' Subway Debut
description: The scene at the 68th Street station of the Lexington Avenue line yesterday looked like what could have been the makings of a bad joke: How many transit workers does it take to operate a Metrocard vending machine?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YELON, ROSE
description: YELON-Rose. Beloved wife of the late Abraham Nat. Devoted mother of Edward and Stephen and daughters-in-law Arlene and Frances. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Services were held Monday. Contributions in her memory to Temple Sholom of Flatbush.

title: Sports of The Times; Ranking Golf's New Mr. 59
description: MOST golfers are happy to break 100. Decent golfers sometimes break 90. Good golfers often break 80. Touring pros expect to break 70. But only a chosen few break 60.

title: Primakov Tries to Buy Time to Aid Yeltsin Case
description: Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov tried today to solidify the Yeltsin Government's hold on power, by proposing a new agreement with the Communist-led Parliament. The accord would remove the cloud of impeachment that hangs over Mr. Yeltsin, in the name of insuring political stability.

title: After You, Gaston?
description: Falcons wide receiver Terrance Mathis had settled down a day after loudly complaining about Dan Reeves's idea to allow the team's Pro Bowl players and 10-year veterans to exit first when the team plane landed Sunday.

title: An Insurer Goes Against the Odds; Ace Bucks the Trend and Expands in Commercial Coverage
description: This is not a good time to be selling insurance to large corporations. Companies are buying less coverage, and the competition for the remaining business -- insurance against everything from factory fires and defective products to wayward executives -- has been cutthroat, driving prices lower.

title: On Senate Floor and Off, Grave Debate
description: Upstairs, the impeachment trial was going through serial delays as the Senate once more struggled to hold off partisan meltdown. But downstairs, at the head of an escalator, the senior Senator from Iowa politely yielded basement debating time to the senior Senator from Montana.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about the presentation of the Golden Globes on Sunday night misidentified the network that broadcasts ''The Practice,'' which won the award for a drama series. It is ABC, not Fox. A complete list of winners appears today on page E6.

title: 40 Christians Killed in Revenge Riot in an Indonesian Village
description: At least 40 Christian villagers, including women and children, were killed in Indonesia last week, reportedly by a mob of Muslims seeking revenge for earlier clashes, officials and a local Roman Catholic priest said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESTENBAUM, RALPH
description: KESTENBAUM-Ralph. The sudden death of our father on January 21st, 1999 has removed the touchstone from our lives. His commitment to his family, his integrity and the regard in which he was held by all who knew him leave us with some measure of comfort. Deena and Itamar (Tel Aviv) Jonathan and Deborah (London) Daniel and Hadassah (Teaneck, NJ) Ryel (Los Angeles)

title: Just the Facts: Documentary Films Get Top Billing at Sundance
description: Forget feature films. The 15th annual Sundance Film Festival, the nation's premier showcase of independent movies, has been dominated by an avalanche of first-rate documentaries this time around.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; After 23 Years, Justices Will Revisit Campaign Limits
description: In a case that brings the debate over money and politics back to the Supreme Court's door, the Justices agreed today to decide whether the strict contribution limits the Court upheld for Federal elections 23 years ago are still constitutionally valid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPELLMAN, EDWARD J.
description: SPELLMAN-Edward J., 72, of Centerville, MA. died January 23. Husband of Mary (Comerford) Spellman, father of Lisa Spellman of NY. Mass in Our Lady of Victory Church, Centerville, Wednesday, January 27 at 10:00 A.M. Floral tributes accepted or donations may be made to Cardinal Spellman Museum, 235 Wellesley Street, Weston, MA. 02493.

title: U.S. Presses Kosovo Rebels as Violence Claims More Civilians
description: American diplomats pressed ethnic Albanian leaders today to unite behind a realistic negotiating position for the future of Kosovo, even as another grisly killing of Albanian civilians, including two children, emphasized the urgency of their task.

title: Authorities Investigate Death of Rikers Inmate
description: A 17-year-old inmate who had been placed in protective custody at Rikers Island was found dead in a cell earlier this month, and investigators are trying to determine whether his death was a homicide, the city's Department of Correction said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPPER, SERENA DEAS MURPHY CENTER, (MRS. WILLIAM CONRAD KOPPER)
description: KOPPER-Serena Deas Murphy Center, (Mrs. William Conrad Kopper), 96, of Ridgefield, CT, wife of the late Edward Livingston Center and of the late William Conrad Kopper. Daughter of the late Dr. Deas Murphy, Chief of Surgery, St. Luke's Hospital, NYC and Mary Remsen Belknap Murphy. A member of the Colonial Dames of America, Daughters of the Cincinnati and the Huguenot Society of America. Survived by a daughter, Susan Warren Center, three grandchildren; Gwendolyn Belknap Palmquist, Serena Deas Brown and Edward Fisher Brown, II and four great grandchildren; Emily Remsen Hogan, Michele Boshko Hogan, Samuel Livingston Hogan and Matthew Lenox Palmquist. Graveside funeral services will be held Tuesday at 1:30PM in the Trinity Church Cemetery, Broadway at 153rd St., NY, NY.

title: TBWA/Chiat/Day Gets New Executive
description: TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, said yesterday that Tom Carroll would join the agency's Playa del Rey, Calif., office as president and chief executive, a new post.

title: A Brash Taylor Says He Belongs In Hall of Fame
description: Saying his entrance into the Hall of Fame should be a ''no brainer,'' the former Giants linebacker Lawrence Taylor made his case to the news media today -- some of whom hold the key to whether he gets in -- stating that his myriad personal problems should have nothing to do with the decision.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Pearson Hopes to Sell Some Publishing Units
description: The British media company Pearson P.L.C. said yesterday that it would try to sell several of the Simon & Schuster reference and business publishing divisions it acquired last November from Viacom Inc. The units had sales of $250 million in 1997. They include Webster's New World Dictionary, Betty Crocker cookbooks, the medical publisher Appleton & Lange, Jossey-Bass, Macmillan General Reference, Macmillan Library Reference, Master Data Center, Prentice Hall Direct and the Bureau of Business Practice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, CLIFFORD KENT
description: ALLEN-Clifford Kent of Suffern, N.Y., January 23, 1999. Cherished son of Gladys M. Allen and the late Charles Allen Sr. Beloved brother of Charles Jr., Craig, Christopher, Carlton & Allen and Gayle Allen Brown. Dear brother-in-law of Maria Allen and Andre Brown and dearest uncle of Christina, Stephanie, Olivia and Alicia. Funeral service Thursday, 10AM from Zion Baptist Church, 521 Bramhall Avenue, Jersey City, N.J. Visitation Wednesday 2-5 & 79PM at the church. Interment Hillside Cemetary, Plainfield, N.J. For further information call Jackson Funeral Residence, Jersey City.

title: A Brutal War's Machetes Maim Sierra Leone
description: ''I asked them to kill me now,'' Mohammed Sesay remembered pleading after he was caught by rebels gripping machetes.

title: Hines Meets Baryshnikov
description: Jamal Anderson surveyed the scene with his hand-held video camera. Anderson, the ebullient All-Pro Falcons running back, wanted to set the record straight. He said he did not deserve the recognition for creating the ''dirty bird'' -- the Falcons' end-zone dance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELTZER, BEVERLY (NEE BLUMENTHAL)
description: BELTZER-Beverly (nee Blumenthal). Was a jewel, a diamond, a selfless, loving, caring and compassionate human being - a ''mensch'', who gave her heart and soul to her family, her friends, her colleagues. To her ''one and only'' child, Margery, whose life was intertwined with hers so adoringly, to her grandchildren, Joshua, Sara, and Yossi, who lit up her life, to her Judaism, her Synagogue, her charities, her teaching profession-her passing leaves a void, an emptiness. She was a true ''Aishet Chayil'', a woman of valor. ''May her deeds praise her in the gates.'' May God grant her peace, reunited now with her beloved Carl. Shiva will be observed at the Wise residence, through Sunday morning. May her memory always be a blessing. From her loving family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFKOWITZ, HELEN
description: LEFKOWITZ-Helen. Age 95. Devoted wife of the late Irving. Beloved mother of Lillian Kanfer (Herbert), grandmother of Ronni Backer (Ted) and great-grandmother of David.

title: THE PRESIDENT'S TRIAL: The Case Against Dismissal ; Excerpts: 'The Case Cannot Be Made. It Is Time to End It.'
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by Nicole K. Seligman, a lawyer for President Clinton, supporting the motion to dismiss the case.

title: Pepsico's latest strategic move in a continuing effort to be a true challenger to Coca-Cola.
description: OVER the last year, Pepsico has been engaged in an intense campaign to transform its public image from perennial second-place finisher to a true challenger to the Coca-Cola Company.

title: NOTEBOOK
description: WOMEN'S WORLD CUP

title: As New Israeli Party Emerges, Netanyahu Becomes the Issue
description: The last national election here turned into a referendum on the Israeli-Palestinian peace accord. The one set for this spring, however, is less ideological. It is a referendum on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Lincoln Center Drops Plan to Sell Its Jasper Johns Painting
description: Responding to widespread criticism, the board of Lincoln Center voted yesterday not to sell ''Numbers, 1964,'' the monumental painting by Jasper Johns that had elicited offers of more than $15 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, HOWARD S.
description: BARON-Howard S. On January 25, 1999. Of Harrison, N.Y. Husband of Frances Lauber of Harrison, N.Y. Father of Roger (Margi) of Northbrook, IL., Howard S., Jr. (Nancy) of Bloomfield Hills, MI., and Frederick U. (Susan) of Larchmont, N.Y. Brother of Lawrence Baron of N.J. Also survived by four grandchildren. Entombment private.

title: Software to Compute Women's Cancer Risk
description: It is an idea that women find either irresistible, or unbearable: a computer program that estimates a woman's personal risk of developing breast cancer.

title: Officials Say Man Took Sons After Quarrel
