description: A Queens man who is under investigation in the killings of his two young sons disappeared with them on Jan. 9 after a violent domestic quarrel in which he struck his wife and she threatened to take their children back to her native Poland, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONFELD, ADELE
description: BONFELD-Adele. Beloved mother of Lowell, of blessed memory, doting grandmother of Mara and Marc, affectionate mother-in-law of Harriet, steadfast wife, daughter, sister, and aunt, she was truly a woman of valor.

title: Tougher Standards Are Passed, Again
description: During a meeting rocked by the nearly continuous screaming and shouting of several hundred protesters, the trustees of the City University of New York last night voted for the second time to remove most remedial students from CUNY's senior colleges.

title: Mastering the Practical Curtsy, on Skis
description: What was I doing on this snow-covered hillside, trying to make artful turns on my cross-country skis? I gave up downhill skiing in the first place, nearly 20 years ago, because I was too nervous to ski with enough confident speed to carve classy turns and handle the big, steep, mogul-filled hills.

title: Parcells Shopping for Coach?
description: The conventional wisdom has been that the Jets' coaching staff will remain intact for next season. That, however, may not be the case; Coach Bill Parcells has interviewed at least one offensive coach within the past few weeks about joining his staff, according to several National Football League coaches who spoke on condition of anonymity. They would not identify the coach for fear of upsetting Parcells.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMSON, MICHAEL
description: ABRAMSON-Michael. Of Flushing, N.Y. On January 23, 1999. Beloved husband of Betty. Devoted father of Jeffrey, Mark and Diane. Loving grandfather of Rachael. Caring brother of Irene. Dear father-in-law of Elizabeth and Clara. Call Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel for information, 718-263-7600

title: Thompson Seeking A Senior Official
description: J. Walter Thompson Worldwide in New York said yesterday that Chris Jones, chief executive, was seeking a senior executive to help develop business and client relationships.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Dec. 11 about the construction of an Egyptian pipeline that may transport gas to Israel misattributed remarks about the project. The Egyptian Embassy in Washington says the comments, in a telephone interview, were made not by Ambassador Ahmed Maher El-Said but by another Egyptian diplomat, whom it has declined to identify. An E-mail message about the error was relayed from the writer to an editor who was ill, delaying this correction.

title: Enthusiasm Paired With Lots of Sound
description: The American conductor Andrew Litton is in his fifth season as music director of the Dallas Symphony Orchestra, and reportedly the cultural community of Dallas could not be more pleased with him. He is a solid, technically assured musician and a telegenic conductor who has raised the orchestra's profile through television broadcasts and well-received recordings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMINSKY, BEATRICE
description: SAMINSKY - Beatrice. Passed away Thursday, January 21, 1999 at age 87. Lover of the arts, world traveler, and Cornell University graduate. Beloved wife of the late Hyman Saminsky, survived by daughter, Susan, Eileen, and son, Robert. Also survived by sister, Ruth, many grandchildren, and one great grandchild, Ben. Services were held January 22nd.

title: Britain Details the Start of Its 'Mad Cow' Outbreak
description: Despite years of increasing worry and worldwide headlines, the British Government has only now gathered the information it needs to figure out how ''mad cow disease'' spread through the nation's dairy herds and apparently cost 35 people their lives.

title: Clinton's Consistent Poll Ratings Show Starr Report Marked Turning Point
description: Most Americans, poll takers say, made up their minds the better part of six months ago about whether President Clinton should resign or be removed from office because of his involvement with Monica S. Lewinsky. Nothing they have heard or seen since -- especially the current Congressional impeachment and trial proceedings -- has caused significant change in their thinking.

title: WITNESS WRANGLING GOES ON AS SENATE, IN CLOSED SESSION, DEBATES A DISMISSAL MOTION
description: As a weary Senate entered the third week of impeachment proceedings, Republicans in a party meeting this morning rejected a Democratic-backed proposal that would have ended the trial against President Clinton without calling any witnesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRITZKER, JAY A.
description: PRITZKER-Jay A. The Jerusalem Foundation mourns the passing of Jay Pritzker, a devoted friend and benefactor of Jerusalem. His generous spirit will forever live on in the projects he and his family helped to bring to life, especially the Pritzker Family Children's Zoo. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Cindy, and the entire Pritzker family. Teddy Kollek, International Council Chairman Alvin H. Einbender National Chairman Ruth Cheshin, Int'l President Sandra Rubin, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSKOWITZ, GEORGE
description: HERSKOWITZ-George. Adored husband of Renee, father to Richard and Elaine Herskowitz and grandfather to David, Sophie and Laura. We mourn the loss of a brilliant, articulate mind and humane soul. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association of Greater Washington.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Media Talk column of Business Day yesterday about two CBS journalists who joined cable networks misspelled the given name of an earlier transfer from a broadcast network, now Washington bureau chief for Fox News. He is Brit Hume, not Britt.

title: Molecule Study Puts Student in Finals of Science Contest
description: Nobody at the Bronx High School of Science much knows what Daniel H. Grollman is talking about when he gets going on platelet-endothelial adhesion, but the topic caught the attention of researchers at the Cornell medical college. And yesterday, it won him nationwide attention: He was one of 40 high school students chosen as finalists in the Intel Science Talent Search.

title: 3M Reports Drop Of 4.9% in Profit
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, the maker of more than 50,000 industrial and consumer products, said today that its fourth-quarter profits fell 4.9 percent.

title: U.S. Inquiry Starts in Death At Nassau Jail
description: Federal prosecutors have joined the investigation into whether an inmate serving a 90-day sentence at the Nassau County jail was beaten to death by guards, and they are also studying whether other allegations of abuse amount to a pattern of civil rights violations at the jail, officials said today.

title: Testing the Winds
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruling Favors Employers on Pension Gains
description: Companies do not have to share surpluses in their pension plans with their workers, even if the workers contributed to the plans through money withheld from their paychecks, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously yesterday.

title: So, Iphigenia, How's the Family?
description: The actress's expression says it all. When the dismal fate that awaits Anne Dudek's Iphigenia is revealed by the goddess Athena at the end of JoAnne Akalaitis's low-road ''Iphigenia Cycle,'' Ms. Dudek turns to the audience and shoots it a conspiratorial look of utter bewilderment. ''You mean,'' she seems to be asking, ''three hours of amateurish Greek drama, and all I get is this lousy prophecy?''

title: Youth in Park Killing Gets Maximum Term
description: A state judge imposed the maximum sentence for manslaughter yesterday on a 16-year-old boy in the stabbing death of a man in Central Park, saying he believed the teen-ager had carried out the killing even though a jury could not decide if he or his co-defendant actually committed the deed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDMOND, LIDA SCHOCK
description: REDMOND-Lida Schock, died at her home in Glen Cove, NY, on January 25, after a short illness. She was the wife of Geraldyn Livingston Redmond. Born in St. Louis, Missouri, in 1926, she attended the Community School and Mary Institute there and graduated from the Foxcroft School in Middleburg, Virginia. An accomplished tennis player and athlete, she was known for her verve on and off the court. Nationally ranked as a junior tennis player, she defeated Gloria Thompson, mother of tennis great Jimmy Connors, as a fourteen year old, and later won numerous club championships. She was previously married to David Wendover Riesmeyer and Anthony John Adrian Bryan. She is survived by her husband, Geraldyn Redmond; four children, Lida Higginson of White Post, Va., Carol Bryan of San Francisco, California, Pamela Bryan of Los Angeles, California, John Bryan of Los Angeles, Calif.; two stepchildren, John Redmond of Long Island, N.Y., and Joan Redmond of Pine Plains, New York, and seven grandchildren, Hadley Higginson of Burlington, Vt., Timothy McCandless, Michael McCandless and Lisa McCandless of San Francisco, Calif., and Sophie and Adrian deSelliers of Los Angeles, Calif. Funeral services will be held Thursday, January 28, at 11 AM, at the Brookville Reformed Church, Brookville, Long Island, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Foxcroft School, Middleburg, Va.

title: Boning Up on Fossil Features
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONVISER, IRVING
description: CONVISER-Irving. Beloved husband of the late Doris. Loving father of Barbara Rosenzweig and Marilyn Conviser. Adoring grandfather of Brian Rosenzweig. Graveside service was held Monday, January 25, Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, N.Y.

title: Judge Turns Trial Witness In Anchorwoman's Lawsuit
description: In a rare role reversal, a justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court found himself in the witness chair today, testifying in Federal court on behalf of a television anchor who is suing her former employer for age and sex discrimination.

title: Op-Art
Workers' Health Care Is a Good Buy; Try Universal Coverage
description: To the Editor:

title: Internet Auctioneer Facing Fraud Inquiry
description: Ebay Inc., the Internet auctioneer, is under investigation by the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs over users' complaints about fraud.

title: Sadie Delany, Witness to Century, Dies at 109
description: Sarah (Sadie) Delany, the last of the storied Delany sisters, died peacefully in her sleep at age 109 yesterday at her home in Mount Vernon, N.Y., spokesmen for her family said.

title: Fund-Raising Limits
description: A case challenging a 1994 Missouri law incorporating Federal limits on campaign contributions brought the debate over money and politics back to the Supreme Court. The Justices agreed to decide whether strict contribution limits that the Court upheld for Federal elections 23 years ago remain constitutionally valid.

title: Razorfish Files For Public Offering
description: Razorfish Inc., an interactive and digital communications agency in New York, filed yesterday for an initial public offering.

title: CNB BANCSHARES IN TALKS TO BUY NATIONAL CITY
description: CNB Bancshares Inc. said it was in talks to buy its competitor National City Bancshares for about $588.6 million in stock . Both banks are based in Evansville, Ind. CNB said that in the deal now proposed 0.91 share of CNB Bancshares stock would be exchanged for each share of National City Bancshares stock. National City operates 16 banks with 69 branches in Indiana, Kentucky, Illinois and Ohio. CNB Bancshares has 145 bank branches and consumer finance, leasing, brokerage and insurance units and does business in Indiana, Kentucky, Illinois, Tennessee and Michigan.

title: Pataki Limits Size Of PAC Contributions
description: Gov. George E. Pataki limited the size of contributions yesterday that he would accept through a political action committee that he set up to broaden his national standing. Under the voluntary restriction, the PAC will accept no more than $50,000 from each donor.

title: Split Decision Sets Stage for State and Local Battles
description: Far from putting the issue of census sampling to rest, today's Supreme Court decision is virtually certain to lead to fierce battles in Congress, state legislatures and courts nationwide over what census figures should be used to draw district lines and to distribute Federal money, elected officials and census experts said.

title: Jarring Democrats, Court Rules Census Must Be by Actual Count
description: Dealing a bitter blow to Democratic hopes, the Supreme Court ruled today that the official census for 2000, which will be used to apportion seats in the House of Representatives, must be conducted by the traditional head count.

title: Youth Move at Toyota
description: To attract young car buyers, the Toyota Motor Corporation is now considering a new brand name for its sporty cars and trucks for the Japanese market, a Toyota executive said today. Some of Toyota's recently released cars, such as the Progres sedan and the Altezza sports coupe, already do not carry the company's symbol -- an effort, analysts say, to disassociate them from the Toyota name, which generally stands for reliability and conservatism but not for sportiness. Also today, Toyota said it planned to buy back up to 12 million of its own shares, or less than 1 percent, for 38 billion yen, or about $332 million, and cancel them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENLEE, MARTIN, (AKA MORTON GREENSTEIN)
description: GREENLEE-Martin, (aka Morton Greenstein). On Monday, January 25 of cancer. He is survived by his mother Bessie, brother Eli, sisters Natalye Brown and Geri Lerner and sister-in-law Rita. He is deeply mourned by his beloved nieces and nephews, Gail Wade, Carol and Nick Epstein, Myra and Peter Cole, Beth Brown and Carol and Hal Lerner as well as six grandnieces and grandnephews. Mort loved acting and he shared his love of NYC with the public as a tour guide with Gray Lines Bus Company for almost fifty years. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. Funeral today, January 26 at 2PM at Gutterman's in Woodbury, L.I. Donations to Mercy Hospice, 1220 Front Street, Uniondale, Long Island 11553, would be appreciated.

title: COLTEC DOWN, GOODRICH UP AS DEAL IS STUDIED
description: Shares of Coltec Industries Inc. fell but those of the B. F. Goodrich Company rose yesterday. B. F. Goodrich had announced on Friday that the Federal Trade Commission wanted more information on Goodrich's $1.86 billion purchase of Coltec Inc., a sign that the deal is under close scrutiny. Antitrust lawyers say a key issue is likely to be landing gear for military aircraft. The deal would unite the two major makers of landing gear in the United States. The only other big competitor is the European alliance Messier-Dowty. Shares of Coltec fell 8.6 cents yesterday, to $18.6016, and the stock of Goodrich rose 37.5 cents to $35.

title: Amid the Antihistamines, a Quest for Logic
description: Head throbbing, nose dripping, my friend Alison made the serious error of trying to apply deductive logic to the contents of the cold and cough aisle of her local supermarket a few months ago.

title: In Breast Cancer Data, Hope, Fear and Confusion
description: When they are asked to identify the greatest threat to their health, most American women name breast cancer. Most of them are wrong.

title: 4 Accused of Robbing Livery Drivers in Queens
description: Two men and two women were arrested yesterday and charged in connection with a series of knifepoint carjackings and robberies of livery drivers in Queens.

title: Israel's New Politics
description: Israeli politics was long dominated by two traditional party groupings, Labor on the social democratic left and Likud on the nationalist right. But that pattern began to crumble in the last elections three years ago, when 48 percent of the vote went to smaller, special-interest parties, several of which joined Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's governing coalition.

title: He's 5 Feet 5 Inches But Has a Big Chance
description: If everything works out for Earl Boykins, he will initially be viewed as a curiosity. He will be the new Spud Webb, the heir apparent to Muggsy Bogues, the Mutt to 7-foot-7-inch Gheorghe Muresan's Jeff.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Intel Scraps I.D. Plan Over Privacy Concern

title: Even if Guilty, Can Clinton Stay?
description: To the Editor:

title: Workers' Health Care Is a Good Buy
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Will Not Hear Appeal of Execution
description: Without comment, the Supreme Court refused today to hear an appeal by a death-row inmate who was entitled to but never received legal assistance from the Canadian Government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, JOSEPH
description: WEISS-Joseph. Congregaton Ezrath Israel, the Actors' Temple deeply mourns the loss of our beloved member. We express our deepest sympathies to his wife and family. Robert Goldman, President Noach Valley, Rabbi

title: An Oscar for Kazan
description: To the Editor:

title: Lincoln Center Votes Not to Sell Painting
description: Responding to intense criticism, the board of Lincoln Center voted yesterday not to sell ''Numbers, 1964,'' a painting by Jasper Johns that had elicited offers of more than $15 million. The board endorsed a sale last month, but abandoned the idea because of negative reactions from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of Modern Art, major donors and the painter himself.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINNERAN, GERARD L.
description: FINNERAN-Gerard L. Born on August 9, 1909, died on January 23, 1999, in Palm Beach, FL. Formerly of New York City, and ''Robin HIll,'' Newtown, CT. Son of the late Honoria and Edward Finneran, and husband of the late Mary Ray Trimble. Gerard graduated from The University of Notre Dame. He was a member of The New York Athletic Club, The Friendly Sons of Saint Patrick, president of the Robert Mize Isa White Trimble Foundation, and Lieutenant Commander USNR (retired). Gerard was a loving uncle of many nieces and nephews, and grand nieces and nephews, whose lives were blessed to have such an extraordinary uncle, whose love, devotion, and generosity had no bounds. Frends may call at The Abbey, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday, January 26th, 5-8 P.M. Funeral Mass at Saint Jean The Baptiste Church, Lexington Avenue at 76th Street, Wednesday at 10 A.M. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: GTE TO SELL ITS GOVERNMENT SYSTEMS SUBSIDIARY
description: The GTE Corporation, which has long been a leader in military telecommunications and Federal information systems, said yesterday that it would sell its government systems subsidiary. The proposed sale is part of a plan announced last spring to raise $3 billion in after-tax revenue to help it cut costs and free cash for expansion into Internet service and other areas with greater sales growth. The military subsidiary, based in Needham, Mass., employs 7,000 people at sites in 23 states and several foreign countries. In 1998, it accounted for about $1.4 billion in sales, about 5 percent of GTE's overall sales. GTE is based in Stamford, Conn.

title: Roy Signs Extension
description: Patrick Roy, who has the most victories among active National Hockey League goaltenders, signed a two-year contract extension yesterday with Colorado, capping six months of negotiations with the Avalanche.

title: Robert Shaw, Choral and Orchestral Leader, Is Dead at 82
description: Robert Shaw, the renowned choral conductor and the elder statesman and great spirit of American musical performance, died yesterday at a hospital in New Haven, where he had been visiting one of his sons at Yale University. He was 82.

title: Bradley Gets Into the Campaign Trail Groove
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey took his first icy steps on the long march toward the Democratic Presidential nomination today, trudging for the first time through the winter snow of New Hampshire, as political custom demands in the state that holds the first primary, and throwing around basketballs and thoughtful thoughts, as befits a New York Knicks Hall of Famer and a Rhodes Scholar.

title: Head to Head, Albright and Russia's Prime Minister Do Not See Eye to Eye
description: Yevgeny M. Primakov and Madeleine K. Albright sat down to dinner tonight, nearly the 20th occasion that they have done so during the maturing of the relationship between a former university professor and a former spymaster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMAN, ALYS F.
description: HARTMAN-Alys F. Died on January 22, 1999. Beloved mother of Victoria Hartman and Elizabeth Hartman Musiker. Loving grandmother of Jake Musiker. Contributions may be made to Literacy Voluteers of Westchester, 85 Executive Boulevard, Elmsford, NY 10523 or The Historical Society of The Tarrytowns, 1 Grove Street, Tarrytown, NY 10591

title: New Lead-In for 'Seinfeld' As the Mets Move to Ch. 11
description: When the baseball season begins in April, viewers will not be able to tell the New York teams without a television schedule.

title: Administration to Urge Congress to Close More Military Bases
description: With Congress increasingly vocal about improving military readiness, the Clinton Administration sees an opportunity this year to convince lawmakers that closing more bases is critical to that effort, officials said today.

title: G.M. CUTS EXECUTIVE BONUSES AT DELPHI PARTS UNIT
description: The General Motors Corporation's Delphi Automotive Systems unit, the world's No. 1 maker of auto parts, has cut executive bonuses. G.M. could face difficulty selling the unit to investors after a loss last year. G.M. reduced the 1998 bonus of J. T. Battenberg 3d, Delphi's chief executive, by 56 percent, to $450,000, ''to reflect the year-to-year decline in reported earnings,'' Delphi wrote in a filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission on Jan. 20. The submission was part of the planned sale early next month of 17.7 percent of the parts company's stock. GM shares fell $1 yesterday, to $89.75.

title: Back to the Slides, Squeals and Mayhem of the 70's
description: A strobe light flashed through every song when Queens of the Stone Age played on Friday night at Coney Island High, signaling a streak of psychedelic nostalgia. And a red spotlight behind the band projected an enlarged silhouette of Joshua Homme toiling over his guitar, like a Platonic shadow on a cave wall of the true ideal of rock. ''From the very beginning it was wrong, and now it's time to set it right,'' Mr. Homme intoned between songs.

title: New Georgia Governor Proposes A Remedy for Atlanta's Sprawl
description: Following through on a campaign pledge to combat suburban sprawl, Georgia's new Governor, Roy E. Barnes, proposed today to create a powerful new regional transportation authority in metropolitan Atlanta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, IRVING
description: ALPERT-Irving, 82 of Palisades, NY on Sunday in Queens. Beloved husband of the late Tessie Levine Alpert; devoted father of Michael Alpert and the late Stephen W. Alpert; loved brother of Samuel and Hyman Alpert; devoted grandfather of four; great grandfather of two. Services Tuesday Jan.26,1999 at 12:30 PM in the Crabiel Parkwest Funeral Chapel, 239 Livingston Ave., New Brunswick, NJ.

title: Clinton's Social Security Plan Is Pure Gimmickry
description: To the Editor:

title: Change Ewing? The Knicks Won't Hear It
description: The sermon topic today was the maligned Patrick Ewing, as a passionate Jeff Van Gundy all but cited scripture and verse in an effort to save those who have wondered if it is time to phase out the Knicks' aging superstar.

title: MICROSOFT INVESTS IN BRITISH CABLE OPERATOR
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it planned to invest $500 million in NTL Inc., a telecommunications company based in New York that is the No. 3 cable television operator in Britain. The investment will help Microsoft promote high-speed phone, video and Internet services in Britain and Ireland. Microsoft owns the MSN Network.

title: A Quiet Voice Raised Against City Hall
description: LINDA BLYER is not the kind of person who fights City Hall. She is a former home economics teacher who speaks so softly people lean in to hear her. Her only previous encounter with city government was in 1976, when she was enlisted as a quilting instructor during the Bicentennial celebration.

title: Reeves Quickly Irritated
description: Atlanta Falcons Coach Dan Reeves expressed irritation today when asked for the second straight day about his strained relationships in Denver with Mike Shanahan then Reeves's assistant, and quarterback John Elway.

title: Giuliani Criticizes Pataki's Inquiry Into School Construction
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani complained at length yesterday about Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to investigate school construction in New York City, and he questioned the education policies of a Governor whom he has recently taken pains to please.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORSON, JEANNE VON BOECKLIN.
description: KORSON-Jeanne von Boecklin. Of Oyster Bay Cove, Long Island. On January 24th, 1999. Beloved wife of Bruce. Devoted mother of Andrew. Daughter of the late Jane Brand Allen & Oakie von Boecklin. Sister of Bill von Boecklin, Armin Allen and John Allen. Memorial service Saint John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., on Wednesday, January 27 at 12 noon. Donations may be made to AKC Canine Health Foundation, 251 West Garfield Road, Suite 160, Aurora, OH. 44202.

title: Framing the Body's Parts
description: Cut away the considerable outer wrappings of Lance Gries's new ''Scrawl,'' performed on Saturday night at the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church, and a jewel of a dance is revealed.

title: Workers' Health Care Is a Good Buy; A Hybrid Approach
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki Wants Tobacco Cash To Ease Debt
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said today that for the next five years, New York State should use 75 percent of its share of the national tobacco lawsuit settlement, or $1.5 billion, to help reduce state debt.

title: High Tech Comes to the Classroom: Machines That Grade Essays
description: Nothing personal. But if your application to the business school of your choice is rejected later this year, a cold, unfeeling machine may be at least partly responsible.

title: Tel Aviv Journal; Battling Israel's Great Divide: A Schoolgirl Is Star
description: Every day, Elinor Nagar, a spunky teen-ager with long ringlets and a sweet giggle, is bused ''uptown'' from a rundown working-class suburb to a high school in affluent North Tel Aviv.

title: As Expected, Coca-Cola Reports a Weakened 4th Quarter
description: Confirming the bad news it had warned Wall Street about last month, the Coca-Cola Company reported its fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, which showed that the global soft-drink giant suffered significant declines in volume and revenue in many parts of the world.

title: School Notes; Looking for a few willing candidates in an era of declawed community school boards.
description: Stephen Antiuk, who has lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan for 10 years, is a community police officer in Harlem. Last fall, he became president of the Parent-Teacher Association at Public School 166, where his 5-year-old son, Alexander, is a prekindergartner, and he says he has gained insight into the differences that parents can make when they are united.

title: 3 Are Accused of Using Tape-Recording to Extort
description: Three people from the Bronx were charged yesterday in an extortion plot after they surreptitiously tape-recorded a River Edge man criticizing his boss, and then threatened him with physical harm if he did not pay to keep them from revealing the tapes, officials said.

title: Remember El Nino? His Sister Has Shown Up, and She's Angry
description: Record snows in Buffalo and Chicago. Record numbers of tornadoes in the country's midsection. All-time low temperatures in Indiana and Maine. Double the normal amount of precipitation, coupled with an extended warm spell, in New York. What accounts for this month's run of extreme weather?

title: Miscellany
description: * De Novo Corp., New York, a communications and marketing company, acquired Creative Solutions International, Hockessin, Del., a direct response agency, and the Convergence Group, Hockessin, a management consulting company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: FRONTIER PLANS MOVES TO INCREASE ITS SHARE PRICE
description: The Frontier Corporation, the fifth-largest long-distance phone company, is considering spinning off operations, making acquisitions or creating a tracking stock to raise its share price, its chief financial officer said yesterday. Over the last two years, Frontier, which is based in Rochester, has expanded from a local phone company into a nationwide provider of long-distance, data and Internet hosting services. Frontier also said it would slash its dividend 78 percent so it could invest more in those businesses.

title: The Drama Turns to an Offstage Female Lead
description: ''Senators, she does have a story to tell,'' the impeachment prosecutor said politely, uttering one of the classic understatements of the nation's past year of scandal overdrive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, ROBERT
description: SHAW-Robert. Yale University, The School of Music and The Institute of Sacred Music, mourn the loss of Robert Shaw, a musician of global influence, whose artistic, scholarly, and spiritual contributions to our cultural life will be deeply missed. He was a cherished friend who unselfishly shared his unique gift for communicating the wonder and majesty of great choral masterworks with our community. We were honored to bestow the Degree of Doctor of Music upon him. To his children, and to his entire family, we extend our heartfelt sympathy and our eternal gratitude for sharing his energy and talents with us. Richard C. Levin, President of Yale University Robert L. Blocker, The Lucy and Henry Moses Dean of Music Margot Fassler, Director of The Institute of Sacred Music

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column on Jan. 19, about A. H. Belo's recent financial performance, misstated the name of its new cable venture in Texas. It is Texas Cable News, not the Texas Cable Channel.

title: The Pope and the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Best-Selling Author's Gloomy Future for Los Angeles Meets Resistance
description: On a winter Sunday morning of the sort that only Southern California seems to produce, under a brilliant blue sky scoured clean of clouds and smog, a crowd of upper-middle-class Angelenos filed into the Skirball Cultural Center and plunked down $10 each to hear a conversation with their city's reigning prophet of doom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINSKOFF, LILLIAN
description: MINSKOFF-Lillian. Dear aunt. A woman of great strength, courage, love and humor. You will be missed. All our love and our sympathies to the entire family. Jeannie, T, Alan, Royanne, Jim, and Carolina

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 16 about the effects of low oil prices on the Persian Gulf region referred incorrectly to a standard unit of measurement. The barrel, used throughout the world to measure crude oil and other oil products, is defined as a volume of 42 gallons. It does not correspond to any actual container, and has no relation to the 55-gallon steel drums that are widely used for shipping liquids.

title: Sprewell & Co. Ponder Roar of Garden Crowd
description: The unveiling of the rebuilt Knicks complete with racing stripes and chrome wheels -- will begin when Latrell Sprewell's ears perk up like antennae the moment his name is announced Wednesday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASS, MORRIS
description: NASS-Morris. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, NY, mourns with heartfelt sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, and extends condolences to the entire family. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Sheldon Steinmetz, President

title: Excerpts: 'Look Into the Eyes and Test' the Credibility of Witnesses
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by House managers in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton in favor of a motion to issue subpoenas for witnesses and to admit material not now in the record. (Today's excerpts were recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOYLE, PAUL R.
description: DOYLE-Paul R. Of Manhattan. Died at age 84 on December 23, 1998 after a brief illness. A memorial service will be held at 3 P.M., Saturday, January 30, 1999, at Holy Family Church, 315 East 47 Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Catholic Charities or other charitable organizations would be appreciated.

title: Brazil's Currency Plunges In a Day of Wide Swings
description: Brazil's currency swung wildly in foreign-exchange dealings today and briefly fell to a low of nearly two to the dollar because of growing uncertainty about the country's economic health.

title: France to Sell 17% Stake in Airline
description: France said yesterday that it would sell a 17 percent stake in Air France by early February in an initial public offering that values the airline, Europe's third largest, at about 2.8 billion euros ($3.2 billion). France will sell a total of 32.4 million shares, priced between 12 and 14.2 euros, of the 184 million shares it holds. France owns 94 percent of the airline, with the remaining 11 million shares held by employees and banks.

title: Should Students Learn Physics First?
description: To the Editor:

title: Royal Philips to Take $1 Billion Charge
description: Royal Philips Electronics N.V., Europe's largest maker of consumer electronics products, said yesterday that its 1998 profit had fallen marginally and that it was taking a $1 billion charge for its failed cellular phone venture with Lucent Technologies Inc., bad debts in Brazil and other matters.

title: A Darwin Assistant With Hints of Indiana Jones
description: MR. DARWIN'S SHOOTER

title: A Night of the Baroque With a Modern Slant
description: Baroque style, on its own terms and as filtered through modern compositional sensibilities, was the subject of the Riverside Symphony's concert at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening. Antiquarianism and neo-antiquarianism were given equal time: a suite from Purcell's ''King Arthur'' was offset by the United States premiere of ''Zoek,'' a 1993 concerto for piccolo and harpsichord by the Dutch composer Guus Janssen. A reconstruction of Bach's Concerto for Violin, Oboe and Strings (B.W.V. 1060) had a modern response in Stravinsky's ''Danses Concertantes.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNIS, SEYMOUR
description: BENNIS-Seymour. Age 82. Of Pembroke Pines, FL. on January 26, 1999. Beloved husband, father, brother and grandfather. Graveside service, Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, N.J., Thursday January 28 at 11AM.

title: G.O.P. Unity Gets Priority Over an Issue
description: In pressing forward with a call for witnesses, Republican senators often cite the Constitution or their disapproval of President Clinton. But there is a more political explanation: Senators may see it in their own best interest to maintain cordial relations with Republicans in the House.

title: Fans Storm Stadium In Ticket Give-Away
description: Spectators scrambling into a National Basketball Association preseason game at Toronto's Skydome shattered two stadium doors and ripped out a set of turnstiles last night.

title: CALENDAR
description: Lessons for Cupid

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFKOWITZ, HELEN
description: LEFKOWITZ-Helen. Age 95. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Cherished mother of Sandra Prince (LeRoy). Adored grandmother of Melissa and Jill and great-granddaughters Evin and Alexandra.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, DANIEL D.
description: STEWART-Daniel D. Landscape Architect, died on January 22, 1999, in The Burn Unit of New York Hospital, Cornell Medical Center. He was 68 years old. A Requiem Mass followed by a reception, will be held on February 1, at 6 P.M. at The Church of the Transfiguration, 1 East 29th Street, in Manhattan. Donations in his memory may be sent to The New York Botanical Garden.

title: Two Falcons Tackle Way to Top
description: Jessie Tuggle and Eugene Robinson, a linebacker and a free safety, stand tall here at Super Bowl XXXIII. Both are Atlanta Falcons. Tuggle is 33. Robinson is 35. Both have played at least 12 professional seasons and are football purists, loquacious and spirited leaders.

title: Sports of The Times; To the Broncos: Your Table for 20 Is Ready
description: NEAR the front desk at Joe's Stone Crab restaurant, three dozen people were waiting to be seated when the maitre d'hotel, Dennis Sutton, heard a voice say, ''The 20 Broncos are here.''

title: Journal; The Crybaby Party
description: It was just a year ago that America's TV anchors dumped the Pope in Cuba for a rendezvous with Monica Lewinsky in Washington. Almost all you need to know about what's happened since is that yesterday Bill Clinton flew to St. Louis to bask in the sunny glow of the Pope, while his tormentors remained mired in D.C. with Monica.

title: Atlanta Games' Organizers Set to Face Questions
description: In the Olympic family, the Atlanta Olympic organizers have often been looked on as poor relations -- the long-shot bunch from this Southern city who were, in a stunning upset, awarded the 1996 Centennial Games, then managed to make a mess of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEELER, MARY RENO FREAR, PH.D.
description: KEELER-Mary Reno Frear, Ph.D. Age 95. Of Frederick, MD. On Sunday, January 24, 1999. Former Dean of Hood College, MD. Beloved mother of Shirley Bebout, Frederick, MD. Memorial services 11 A.M. Saturday, January 30th, Robert E. Dailey & Son Funeral Home, 1201 North Market Street, Frederick, MD. In lieu of flowers, memorials to AAUW, 1111 16 St, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20036.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANZ, SALLY
description: GANZ-Sally. Of Yonkers, N.Y. and Boynton Beach, Florida. Passed away January 26. She is survived by her husband of 52 years Irving, her children Robert (Linda), Karen Ganz (Jeff Harris), two loving grandchildren Jennifer Ganz (Jeff Durand) and Kevin Ganz and a brother Joel Gennett. Services will be held Thursday January 28 at 12:30PM at Levayah Garlick Funeral Home, 1091 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers. Donations may be made in memory of Sally Ganz to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIEFEL, SYLVIA (NEE ROSENBERG)
description: STIEFEL-Sylvia (nee Rosenberg) On Sunday, January 17, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Martin. Devoted mother of Paul and Janet Stiefel. Loving sister of Lillian, Muriel and Evelyn. Dear sister-inlaw of Arthur and Betty. Services private.

title: A Useful Tool for Stokowski, A Different Benefit Today
description: New Jersey Symphony Orchestra

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  URIS, AUREN
description: URIS-Auren. Suddenly on January 24. Dearly beloved husband of Doris Reichbart. Devoted brother of Pearl Sheindelman and beloved father of Merka and Donald Fletcher, Victoria and John Giffin, Bettina and Daniel Uris and loving grandfather of Ethan, Addie, Lena and Will Fletcher. Services Wednesday, January 27, 2:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Man Is Fatally Shot After Fight at Restaurant
description: A 17-year-old was fatally shot yesterday in the parking lot of a fast-food restaurant in Newark, the police said.

title: William M. Batten, Ex-Chief Of Stock Exchange, Dies at 89
description: William Milfred Batten, a former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange and a former chairman and chief executive of the J. C. Penney Company, died on Friday in Hilton Head, S.C. He was 89.

title: Investigating How a Teen-Ager Ended Up Dead at Rikers
description: Standing just 5 feet 4 inches tall and weighing just 110 pounds at age 17, Lance Gaston was used to ribbing about his small stature. ''He would take a tease, he would laugh about it,'' his former foster mother, Annie Kennedy, said. ''Everybody knew they could tease him about his little height.''

title: Tide Turns Again, and Parties Seek Agreement on Witnesses
description: After a day of bitter partisanship, Senate Democrats and Republicans sought tonight to pull themselves back from a divisive abyss and salvage a bipartisan accord on handling witnesses and ending the impeachment trial as early as next week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Warner-Lambert to Acquire Agouron for $2.1 Billion

title: King Hussein Returns to U.S. With Possible Cancer Relapse
description: Only hours after anointing a new heir, King Hussein flew back to the United States today for urgent medical treatment prompted by what his doctors said were indications that his cancer might be recurring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRITZKER, JAY
description: PRITZKER-Jay. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of Jay Pritzker, a long time supporter of the League's agenda. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Cindy, his children, his brother, Robert, nephew, J.B., a member of our Chicago Board, and the entire family. Howard P. Berkowitz, National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

title: Four Variations on the Mandoline
description: WHETHER you are paying $24 or $159, every mandoline requires a little compromise. I tested the four brands most commonly found in cookware stores: V-Slicer Plus, Benriner, Bron and Matfer.

title: Nabisco to Close a Plant
description: The Nabisco Holdings Corporation said today that it planned to close its plant in Urbana, Ohio, where it makes Cornnuts snacks, and dismiss 75 workers. Nabisco said it would transfer the Ohio plant's production to its Fresno, Calif., site, which also makes Cornnuts. Facing slipping sales of its cookies and crackers, Nabisco said last June that it would close an unspecified number of plants and cut its worldwide work force by about 6 percent. Nabisco is 80.5 percent owned by the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation. Nabisco Holdings, based in Parsippany, N.J., had 1997 revenues of $8.73 billion.

title: Excerpts: Only Witnesses Will Provide 'the Entire, Complete Picture'
description: Following are excerpts from the presentations today by House managers in the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton in rebuttal against arguments by David E. Kendall disputing the need for witnesses:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALSCHULER, ROBERT
description: ALSCHULER-Robert. All of us at Linden Alschuler & Kaplan, Inc., record with sorrow the passing of Steven Alschuler's father. His extraordinary will to live, his dignity and courage will inspire those who knew and loved him. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADEL, SADIE
description: NADEL-Sadie. Sutton Place Synagogue extends sympathies to our devoted members Sheila and Harvey Nadel on the loss of Harvey's beloved mother. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: A Food-Borne Illness That Still Isn't Getting The Attention It Deserves
description: WHEN the first reports of a food poisoning outbreak from hot dogs and deli meats started to accumulate in state health departments across the country last August, officials could not have guessed that the effort to contain the eruption would be so ineffective that they would still be counting victims five months later.

title: EUROMONEY PUBLICATIONS TO BUY INTERNET SECURITIES INC.
description: Euromoney Publications P.L.C. said it would pay $32.2 million for a controlling 80 percent stake in Internet Securities Inc., a Boston-based provider of on-line financial information about emerging markets. Euromoney, a British publisher of finance magazines, will also invest $11 million in Internet Securities to help the company expand. Euromoney said it did not expect Internet Securities, which lost $5.7 million in 1997, to be profitable until the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, 2001. Euromoney, based in London, is a unit of Daily Mail and General Trust P.L.C.

title: Lord Lewin, 78, British Strategist in Falklands
description: Lord Lewin, the British seadog who is credited with engineering his country's victory over Argentina in the Falkland Islands war in 1982, died on Saturday in Woodbridge in the County of Suffolk in southeastern Britain, not far from the sea. He was 78.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: 20th-Century Mysticism Of 3 Distinct Varieties
description: Peabody Trio

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, EVELYN F.
description: STONE-Evelyn F. Devoted wife of the late Daniel. Beloved mother of Eve Drachman and mother-inlaw of the late Harold Drachman. Cherished grandmother of Harold, Jr. and David J. Loving great grandmother of six. Services are private.

title: Shock to Replace Dummies In TV Ads on Seat Belt Use
description: Convinced that friendly persuasion has reached its limit, the Transportation Department is switching to shock in its effort to persuade people to wear seat belts. The department's new television advertisements drop the clownish crash-test dummies Vince and Larry, which have been smashed in countless advertisements, in favor of the everyday activities of live actors who, in the last seconds of the advertisement, fall prey to heart-stopping crashes.

title: Metro Business; J. P. Morgan Closes Unit
description: J. P. Morgan & Company, the fourth-largest bank in the United States, closed its energy trading unit yesterday, affecting 35 traders and clerks in New York, London and Singapore.

title: Florida Tries DNA Sampling to Protect Children
description: Lying in a hospital bed a day after giving birth to her second child, Yanith Martinez has only the highest hopes for her baby, Valeria.

title: Sports of The Times; For Martin, New Team but Same Goal
description: FOUR years ago, Tony Martin and I were on the same wavelength in this very same city at this very same stadium. Martin was with San Diego; the Chargers were playing the San Francisco 49ers in Super Bowl XXIX.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLIGAN, ROBERT D.
description: MULLIGAN-Robert D. Beloved husband of the late Alice (nee Henry). Loving father of David, Susan and Nancy. Devoted grandfather of Thomas. Memorial service to be announced at a later date at the Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC.

title: Solstice Observers Given Another Reason to Celebrate
description: Pagans often chant to Mother Nature to work her magic, but yesterday a group of them got a more down-to-earth decision when a judge on Staten Island dismissed trespassing charges against celebrants who danced on a public beach through the winter solstice.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: Star Turns By Star Teachers; Classes in the Callas Tradition
description: Every once in a while the performing arts come up with a whole new category. Music, having explored the concert, the opera and the liederabend, now brings us the master class: the solo recital with a difference. Thomas Hampson and Marilyn Horne starred in their own master class productions just recently at the Juilliard Theater. Leontyne Price, Roberta Peters, Regine Crespin, Joan Sutherland and Elly Ameling had preceded them, and Sherrill Milnes takes the boards next week.

title: Intensity and Deftness In a Mixture of Styles
description: Flamenco Latino

title: Board of Medical Journal Defends an Ousted Editor
description: Editors and members of the editorial board of the Journal of the American Medical Association are defending the dismissed editor of the publication in its next issue.

title: Mexico's Central Bank Is Optimistic on Economy
description: Mexico has already weathered the worst blows of the global economic crisis and is not likely to suffer severe trauma from the instability in Brazil even if it deepens, top finance officials said today.

title: U.N. Report: 'Confusion Reigns' On Details
description: Following are excerpts from a report by the United Nations Special Commission for disarming Iraq, as provided to The New York Times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWIE, EFFIE BELLE ROGERS
description: BOWIE-Effie Belle Rogers. On January 25, 1999. Beloved mother of Faith Bowie, and wife of the late Letham. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street Thursday January 28th at 9:45 A.M. Interment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery. Mrs. Bowie, an artist, graduated from Texas State College for Women, and recieved her Masters Degree in Fine Arts from Columbia University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSKI, SIDNEY
description: KOSKI-Sidney. Loving husband of Sylvia. Devoted father of Dina and Kenneth. Cherished grandfather of Bryan and Jason. Great-grandfather of David. Dear brother of Blanche Greenberg. Funeral services Thursday, 10:00 AM, at I.J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, New York.

title: War Crimes Can't Just Be Forgotten
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about King Hussein's selection of his eldest son, Prince Abdullah, as his successor misstated the adopted name of the King's second wife, Toni Avril Gardiner. She was known as Princess Muna, not Musa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENBERG, REGINA
description: GOLDENBERG - Regina. The members and staff of the Falls Country Club wish to express their sincere condolences to our fellow member, Marvin Goldenberg and family on the passing of his beloved wife Regina. The Board of Governors, Bernard Howard, President

title: At Site of Indonesia Riots, Few Signs of Life
description: The hands on the broken white plastic wall clock show 10 minutes past 11, almost the exact time that an enraged Muslim mob entered this village on Wednesday and began killing Christian residents, sending the entire population fleeing for their lives.

title: Old Auction Rivalry Jumps to Internet
description: In an apparent attempt to undermine its archrival Christie's entry into the potentially lucrative on-line auction business, Sotheby's is asking art dealers to sign exclusive contracts that would prevent them from selling wares through other auction houses on the Internet for at least two years.

title: Jarvis Keeps His Focus On Tough Road Ahead
description: ST. JOHN'S

title: INSIDE
description: Pataki's Plan on State Debt

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the financial troubles at Chinese investment trust companies misidentified a creditor of the Guangdong International Trust and Investment Corporation. It is Sumitomo Bank; Sumitomo Trust and Banking is a different company.

title: Hot Chocolate: Eat It or Drink It
description: WITH a legitimate winter on their hands, restaurant and cafe owners are pushing hot chocolate. There's the good (foamy and chocolaty) and the bad (a watery slurry of cocoa and stale marshmallows). Then there's the just plain naughty.

title: Markets Up On Strength Of Blue Chips
description: Better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings reports and stock-split announcements by a number of blue-chip companies helped push stock prices higher yesterday.

title: TENNECO TO SELL STAKE IN CONTAINERBOARD UNIT
description: Tenneco Inc., the maker of Hefty trash bags and Monroe shock absorbers, agreed to sell a majority stake in its containerboard business to Madison Dearborn Partners for $2.2 billion and use the proceeds to reduce debt. Tenneco will keep a 45 percent stake in the business, which will be renamed the Packaging Corporation of America. With annual sales of $1.5 billion, it will be the sixth-biggest American maker of the heavy brown paper used for layers of cardboard. Madison Dearborn is a Chicago investment firm that manages about $4 billion of assets. Tenneco, based in Greenwich, Conn., is struggling to lift the price of its stock after shedding some divisions.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Wednesday about Frances Gershwin Godowsky, an artist and the sister of George Gershwin, misstated the nationality of her father-in-law, the pianist Leopold Godowsky. He was born outside Vilna, in an area that once belonged to Poland but was then part of Russia and is now in Lithuania; he was not Austrian.

title: Raging Against An Unusual Benefit Concert
description: When the rock group Rage Against the Machine heard that the final appeal of Mumia Abu-Jamal, a journalist who was sentenced to death in Pennsylvania for killing a police officer in 1981, had been rejected, the band decided to hold a benefit concert. After all, celebrities, governments and human rights organizations -- from Amnesty International to the European Parliament -- have been clamoring for a new trial for Mr. Abu-Jamal.

title: Salo Continues to Save His Job as Well as Shots
description: Shots have been fired at the Islanders' Tommy Salo from all angles this season.

title: Romanowski Still on a Hitting Streak
description: When last seen on a football field, Bill Romanowski was being ever so gingerly helped to the sideline to find his sense of direction after losing it in a violent collision with Curtis Martin.

title: State Will Increase Aid to Most, but Not All, Schools
description: The Whitman administration announced today that it would budget $5.2 billion in state aid to public schools for the coming fiscal year, the highest allocation ever in a state that already spends more per pupil than any other in the nation.

title: With Terreri in Goal, Devils Stop Senators
description: Nothing discouraged the Devils tonight, not the three losses to Ottawa earlier this month, not even a sore neck to Martin Brodeur that developed just before the game and forced him to sit.

title: Trial: What's Next
description: MOTION TO DISMISS -- Trial resumes today at 1 P.M., and senators vote on motion to dismiss charges.

title: Head of South Africa's Election Commission Resigns Suddenly
description: After months of fighting over the way South Africa's second post-apartheid election should be run, the chairman of the country's Independent Election Commission resigned suddenly today.

title: The Pope and the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties; The Apostle Of Hype
description: The only real question was: How far would Bill Clinton go to ingratiate himself with the Pope?

title: 16-Year-Old Pitcher Gaining Interest
description: Yankee officials will monitor a workout held today for Henry Perez, a 16-year-old pitcher from the Dominican Republic who will be eligible to sign a professional contract on July 2. Perez is 6 feet 4 inches and 200 pounds, according to his agent, Rob Plummer. A major league executive confirmed that Perez does appear to be a front-line prospect. Perez's workout will take place at Legends Field, the Yankees' spring training home in Tampa, Fla., and the agent expects that representatives from as many as 25 to 28 teams will attend. Plummer also represents the pitcher Ricardo Aramboles, who signed with the Yankees last spring with a $1.52 million bonus before hurting his arm in the summer. BUSTER OLNEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESS, JACK
description: PRESS-Jack. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Roberta and Richard Garfield and the late William Press. Cherished grandfather of Wendy and Billy. Devoted brother and uncle. Former coach of the Redwings and Hall Oldsmobile baseball teams of the Coney Island Sports League. Services today, 1:45PM at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRY, ROGER
description: PERRY-Roger. Age 70. Died at his home in Rye, NY, on January 26, 1999. He was educated in the New Rochelle public schools, at Harvard College, and Yale Law School. After his early retirement from the practice of international law in 1975, he managed real estate designed by his late father, architect Lee Perry of New Rochelle, and devoted himself to many organizations reflecting his lifelong interest in the oceans and the environment. He served on the boards of Bermuda Biological Station for Research, Organization for Tropical Studies, ACCION, Nature Conservancy, and Planned Parenthood. He also served on the Rye City Boat Basin Commission and the Zoning Board of Appeals in his home community of Rye. Known for his quick wit, Mr. Perry enjoyed birding, skiing, and sailing his small boat on Long Island Sound. He is survived by his wife Isobel, his sister Ellen Perry Berkeley of Shaftsbury, VT, & children Roy (& Gigi) Perry of Bryn Mawr, Lisa (and David) Hellerstein of Larchmont and Amy Perry (and Josh) Basseches of Quincy, MA, and grandchildren Alex and Leah; Sarah, Ben and Jason; and Jake and Sophie. Memorial contributions may be sent to Planned Parenthood, Hudson Peconic, 11 Skyline Drive, Hawthorne, New York 10532, or Nature Conservancy, 415 Moger Avenue, Mount Kisco, New York 10549. A memorial service will be held at the Friends' Meeting House, Purchase Street, Purchase, New York at 7PM on Saturday, January 30.

title: Chemical Maker Purchase
description: Tetra Technologies, a maker of specialty chemical products for the gas and agriculture industries, announced yesterday that it had purchased Cozinco Inc. for $12 million. Cozinco, a manufacturer of water-soluble products for use in fertilizer and feed, is expected to generate 1999 sales of over $20 million. Tetra, based in The Woodlands, Tex., said the deal included Cozinco's assets and production facilities in Salida, Colo., and Cheyenne, Wyo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, PAUL E.
description: GRAY-Paul E. 92. Of Wolfeboro, N.H. died Tuesday, January 19, 1999 at Huggins Hospital in Wolfeboro. Born July 9, 1906 in Machiasport, Maine. Son of the late Lee T. and Carrie (Trafton) Gray. He was an accomplished landscape artist who began his pursuit of painting in Portsmouth, N.H. after studying art at Harvard, Vesper George School, Boston and Grand Central Art School, NYC. He held shows at the A.C.A. and Montross Galleries in NY and maintained studios at the Hotel Chelsea in NYC (1928-1958), and in Woodstock, NY, and more recently, in North Wolfeboro, N.H. He exhibited throughout N.H. and the coast of Maine and belonged to many art associations in these areas. He was a WW II Veteran.

title: Three Honored For Display Work
description: Three executives have been named as the 1999 inductees of the Point-of-Purchase Hall of Fame, administered by the Point-of-Purchase Advertising Institute in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNITZER, HILDE (MAIER)
description: SCHNITZER-Hilde (Maier), of Montclair, NJ, died on January 26, 1999. Beloved wife of Rabbi Jeshaia Schnitzer, cherished mother of Rabbi Jonathan and Beverly Schnitzer of Rockville, Maryland, and Lisa and Rabbi Richard Plavin of Manchester, Connecticut, caring Oma of Aviva, Ariel, Shira, Ilana and David. An extraordinary & courageous woman. Services at Congregation Shomrei Emunah, 67 Park Street, Montclair, NJ, Wednesday, January 27, 1999 at 1 PM. Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, NJ.

title: 5 New Yorkers Win Prizes for Unsung Work
description: A former gang member turned community activist, a homemaker who led the cleanup of her contaminated neighborhood and New York's senior Senator are among seven Americans who will share $1.25 million from the Heinz Family Foundation, which honors work that it believes has had an unheralded impact on society.

title: Budget Offers Rise in Municipal Aid
description: Aid to New Jersey's 566 municipalities would rise $16.3 million for the fiscal year that begins in July under the state budget proposed Monday by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, the state announced yesterday.

title: Soft-Shoe And Other Silliness And Spirit
description: Forget your troubles, as the song says. The weird and wonderful ''Vaudeville 2000'' is back in town, with five more performances at La Mama E.T.C. (74A East Fourth Street, in the East Village) beginning tomorrow. Laraine Goodman, who produced and designed the scrappy extravaganza and presides over it like a worried but irrepressible mother hen, is onto something good.

title: A Hostage in the Political Wars
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Gov. George Pataki both have national ambitions, and New York City is getting caught between them. Their relationship got off to a spectacularly bad start when Mr. Giuliani endorsed Mario Cuomo, the Democratic incumbent, in the 1994 gubernatorial election. The Mayor has made reparations since, but Mr. Pataki and his aides have not forgotten. Now both these Republican politicians have political action committees aimed at raising their profiles for 2000, and New York State hardly seems large enough for both of them.

title: Further shrinking its agency roster, Procter & Gamble moves five accounts from Euro RSCG.
description: THE Procter & Gamble Company, the world's largest advertiser, is reducing its agency roster again in a paring that ends a relationship with one shop dating back 43 years.

description: To the Editor:

description: NEWS

description: To the Editor:
