description: To the Editor:

title: Edward J. Kiernan, 77, President Who Strengthened Police Union
description: Edward Joseph Kiernan, a retired New York City police officer who headed the city's police union and two international police organizations, died on Saturday at Castle Point Veterans Hospital near Newburgh, N.Y. He was 77 and lived in Congers, N.Y.

title: Owners to Pay $500,000 For '90 Oil Barge Explosion
description: The owners of an oil barge that exploded in New York Harbor in 1990, closing and polluting a busy shipping channel, have agreed to pay $500,000 in penalties and payments for programs restoring shoreline ecology, environmental officials said yesterday.

title: Group Rethinks Ratings on Year 2000 Readiness
description: Fearing that they might inadvertently cause a flight of capital and destabilize some large developing countries, a group of international banks, securities companies and insurers is weighing a retreat from plans to publicly rate the readiness of more than 30 nations to avoid major Year 2000 computer disruptions.

title: War Crimes Can't Just Be Forgotten
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORF, LILLIAN
description: DORF-Lillian. Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, N.J. mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi Gail Billig, President

title: Managers' Motion
description: Following is the motion offered today by the House managers to issue subpoenas for witnesses and to admit material not now in the record in the impeachment case against President Clinton.

title: BROADCOM TO BUY MAKER OF NETWORK SWITCHES
description: The Broadcom Corporation, the leading maker of cable-modem chips, said yesterday that it would buy the closely held Maverick Networks for $111.9 million in stock to acquire new technology and expand its business. Broadcom, based in Irvine, Calif., also said that its fourth-quarter net income had risen by 419 percent because of strong demand for its chips and that it would split its common stock 2 for 1. Broadcom, based in Irvine, Calif., said it would issue 864,200 shares of class B common stock for all of the shares of Maverick, which is based in San Jose, Calif. Maverick makes inexpensive network switches that can handle voice, video and data on business networks. Broadcom's earnings in the fourth quarter of 1998 rose to a record $12.8 million, or 26 cents a share, from $2.5 million, or 6 cents a share, a year earlier. Shares of Broadcom rose $9.25 yesterday, to $129.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Charting a Course Through a Muddle of Identities
description: In ''Simon Boccanegra'' Verdi has written music of great dignity in support of a plot best followed by means of graphs and charts. The Metropolitan Opera's four-year-old production has been revived, and on Monday night two of its principals cut through the murkiness of motive and connection with clear and shining performances. They were Karita Mattila and Placido Domingo.

title: 59 With a Bullet
description: If you watch televised golf, you have either hit the wrong button on the remote or you are part of an audience with plans, as Bernard Darwin once put it, of ''drinking into our own disjointed system[s] the rhythm of a great player.'' Golf differs from most other sports in that respect. Virtually none of the Super Bowl spectators this coming Sunday will be wondering what John Elway can teach them about releasing a pass. But many people who watch golf are actually golfers, and they keenly appreciate the virtuosity of players excelling at a game whose difficulty seems to vanish when seen through the foreshortening lens of a TV camera.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Brazil Effect On Commodities; Steel and Soybean Prices Dive (And Forget the New Tractor)
description: From a pit on the floor of the Chicago Board of Trade, Steven P. Bruce has been watching events in Brazil make the prices of wheat and soybeans swing with impunity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILCH, TODD, M.D.
description: PILCH-Todd, M.D. The Mount Sinai Children's Center Foundation wishes to send our deepest condolences to our Board member, Susan Friedman on the tragic and untimely death of her brother, Dr. Todd Pilch.

title: DURA AUTOMOTIVE TO BUY BRITISH AUTO PARTS MAKER
description: Dura Automotive Systems Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Adwest Automotive P.L.C. for $210 million to increase its European sales. Dura will also assume $210 million in debt. Adwest, based in Britain, makes gear shifts, parking brakes, engine thermostats and other parts for most of the world's major auto manufacturers and has annual revenue of about $400 million. Dura, based in Minneapolis, makes driver-control systems and components for major car makers. Earlier this month, Dura said it had agreed to acquire Excel Industries, an automotive components supplier based in Elkhart, Ind., for $311 million in cash and stock.

title: On Appeal, Judges Let Starr Press His Case Against a Clinton Friend
description: In a significant victory for Kenneth W. Starr, a divided Federal appeals panel today reinstated a tax fraud case he brought against Webster L. Hubbell, a longtime Arkansas friend of President Clinton and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton. The court majority said a lower court judge was wrong when he threw out the case on grounds that the independent counsel had overreached, essentially conducting ''a fishing expedition.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ATLANTIC RICHFIELD CO., Los Angeles, the oil and natural gas company, said its Indonesia unit planned to eliminate up to 1,000 jobs, or about 58 percent of its work force, to cut costs in the wake of the slump in oil prices.

title: Gabor Carelli, 83, Opera Singer
description: Gabor Carelli, a Hungarian tenor who sang at the Metropolitan Opera between 1951 and 1974, and was on the vocal faculty of the Manhattan School of Music for 35 years, died on Friday. He was 83 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Again, Clinton Creates His Own Political Aura
description: With Pope John Paul II at his side, Bill Clinton declared today that the United States was striving to be ''an example of justice and civic virtues'' -- as he once again adroitly harnessed the Presidency to save his Presidency.

title: Last Year, Cost Per Pupil In City Schools Jumped 9.3%
description: New York City spent 9.3 percent more per pupil last year than the year before, with much of the additional money going toward classroom computers and after-school tutoring, the Board of Education reported yesterday.

title: Immobilized, and Energized, by an Illness
description: JENIFER ESTESS was working on the New York Film Festival when she noticed involuntary trembling in her legs. The therapist she was seeing for help to get the six-figure salary, to get married, to make her -- as Ms. Estess says with view-from-the-wheelchair amusement -- ''the perfect New York girl,'' told her the trembling was stress-related. Perfection is viewed differently when in two years' time you go from being a high-powered ''Equinox girl'' to a 37-year-old woman who lacks the strength to cut up her food.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIE, MING (YO)
description: NIE-Ming (Yo). We mourn his sudden passing on January 21st. Beloved husband of Sim Seto and father of sons Nicholas, Norman, Herman. Born Oct. 7, 1924 in Canton China, W.W. II survivor, came to U.S. in 1952 to fulfill dreams of family, academics, career. Artistically gifted, yet a modest, kind hearted, private man. Always made time to serve his community. He will be greatly missed. Services at Cheung Sang Funeral, 22 Mulberry St, NYC, 10013, on January 29, 3-7pm & January 30, 10am

title: BP AMOCO BEGINS REORGANIZATION WITH JOB CUTS
description: BP Amoco P.L.C. said yesterday that it had begun a revamping that included cuts of 2,475 jobs in Texas, Alaska and Canada, and the closing of its New Orleans and Denver offices. The Denver office employs 380 and the New Orleans office 280. BP said it would cut 1,600 positions in Texas, 600 in Alaska and 275 in Canada. The British Petroleum Company said in August that it would cut 6,000 jobs worldwide after its acquisition of the Amoco Corporation, which was completed in December.

title: The Difference Between Sex And Sexy
description: Sex isn't sexy anymore. This has become a glum and widely accepted fact of cultural life in these United States, where people tend to gag and reach for the remote when another graphic description of Presidential activity emerges from the television. Even the New York theater, hardly known in recent years for keeping its fingers on the national pulse, is reflecting this sensibility.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Tiny Child Grows, and Grows Happier
description: When Robert Beebe of Brooklyn learned that his infant daughter Norma had an extremely rare, crippling disease, he vowed to do everything he could to make her life as joyful as it could be.

title: So Lucrative That It's Almost Profitable
description: Eureka! I've been trying for months now to work out a way to capitalize on the Internet stock roller coaster. And I've finally hit on the perfect scheme.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RISKIN, PHILIP
description: RISKIN-Philip. Of Nutley, New Jersey, on Monday, January 25, age 90. Beloved husband of the late Jean nee Sapperstein. Devoted father of Jane Riskin Bean of Tenafly, NJ. Loving grandfather of Matthew & Jacob Bean. Services Jewish Memorial Chapel, 66 Howe Ave, Passaic, NJ today 10:30 AM.

title: After Ruling, New York Vows to Amend Application Process for Needy
description: The Giuliani administration reiterated its promise to improve New York City's new welfare application process yesterday, one day after a Federal judge ruled that the process endangers the poor by denying prompt access to food stamps and Medicaid.

title: Buchanan's Spiked Collar Is Good for Some Laughs
description: Ray Buchanan took the dog out of underdog today. The Atlanta cornerback, playing with the fact that his team is the underdog to Denver in Sunday's Super Bowl, showed up for media day wearing a dog collar. It was a thick collar with silver spikes, and Buchanan smiled for all the cameras at Pro Player Stadium.

title: BLOCKBUSTER RENEWS AGREEMENT WITH TIME WARNER
description: Blockbuster Entertainment, the world's No. 1 video-rental chain and a unit of Viacom Inc., has renewed its revenue-sharing agreement with Time Warner Inc., one of several partnerships Blockbuster has with Hollywood studios. Blockbuster said yesterday that it had signed multiyear agreements with Warner Home Video for the distribution of new Warner Brothers, HBO and Turner releases on VHS. The revenue-sharing agreements reduce the amount Blockbuster must pay up front for each copy of a movie, allowing it to put more copies on its stores' shelves. In exchange, Blockbuster shares movie rental revenue with the film's studio.

title: Boeing Beats Estimates and Renews Promises
description: The Boeing Company released quarterly results yesterday that were better than expected, and it tried to assure investors made wary by a string of unpleasant surprises over the last 16 months that it was finally turning itself around. But Wall Street remained skeptical.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORSON, JEANNE VON BOECKLIN
description: KORSON-Jeanne von Boecklin. Of Oyster Bay Cove, Long Island. On January 24th, 1999. Beloved wife of Bruce. Devoted mother of Andrew. Daughter of the late Jane Brand Allen & Oakie von Boecklin. Sister of Bill von Boecklin, Armin Allen and John Allen. Memorial service Saint John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., on Wednesday, January 27 at 12 noon. Donations may be made to AKC Canine Health Foundation, 251 West Garfield Road, Suite 160, Aurora, OH. 44202.

title: Door Opens, Exit Sought
description: Senate Republican leaders today took the gamble that they can open the door to witnesses and still bring the trial of President Clinton to a relatively quick, dignified and civil conclusion.

title: Commercial Real Estate; After One-Tenant History, Lever House Opens Up
description: The lid has been opened on Park Avenue's oldest glass box.

title: Kozlowski Adjusts Easily to Reeves
description: In the Giants' training camp in the summer of 1993, tight end Brian Kozlowski was a smart rookie with talent. But he was behind the starter Howard Cross, the No. 1 draft pick Derek Brown and the established veteran Aaron Pierce. Frustrated, Kozlowski lashed out.

title: Mirror Group Chief Resigns In Showdown
description: After a remarkably public showdown with board members and stockholders, David Montgomery resigned today as chief executive of Mirror Group P.L.C., opening the way for a takeover battle for one of Britain's oldest tabloid newspapers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINN, MARGARET MARY
description: QUINN-Margaret Mary. January 25th, 1999. Beloved daughter of Donald & Margaret Quinn. Loving sister of Diane, Eileen, Mary, Denis and James. Devoted aunt of ten nieces, three nephews and one grandniece. She was the Principal at St. Vincent Ferrer High School, NYC. Friends may call at the Abbey Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, January 29, 10:30AM at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Margaret M. Quinn Scholarship Fund at St. Vincent Ferrer High School, 151 East 65 Street, NYC 10021.

title: A Detour Into Constitutional Absurdity
description: Just when we thought there could be few constitutional assaults more dangerous than the Clinton impeachment, the Republicans are promoting another: the prospect of a Senate vote that would not ''convict'' the President on impeachment, but would simply declare him guilty of a criminal offense.

title: Chemical Industry to Spend $1 Billion to Assess Product Safety
description: For years -- maybe decades -- the chemical industry has argued that its products are safe, and environmentalists have hollered back, ''prove it.'' Today, the Chemical Manufacturers Association will announce that the industry is spending more than $1 billion to do just that.

title: Pope Reaches Out to Jews in St. Louis Events
description: When Pope John Paul II presides at a prayer service at this city's Roman Catholic cathedral on Wednesday afternoon, a local rabbi will read from Scripture, and a Polish-born Jew who fled her homeland during the Nazi invasion will be among the guests.

title: Warner-Lambert to Acquire Agouron Pharmaceuticals
description: The Warner-Lambert Company, one of the hottest drug companies in the industry, announced yesterday that it would acquire Agouron Pharmaceuticals Inc., a small biotechnology concern, for $2.1 billion in stock.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil futures sank amid expectations that warm weather would cut demand at a time the world remains awash in oil. In New York, crude oil for March delivery fell 25 cents, to $12.44 a barrel.

title: Corrections
description: The ''Eating Out'' column in Weekend on Friday misstated the credit card policy at Ribollita, in Manhattan at 260 Park Avenue, near 21st Street. In addition to cash, it accepts American Express.

title: War Crimes Can't Just Be Forgotten
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCAFFREY, HOWARD AUGUSTINE
description: McCAFFREY-Howard Augustine, S.J. Beloved brother of John. Dear uncle of Wynne O'Conor and Ray McCaffrey. Cherished friend of Marlene Jennings. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray-Weigel Hall, 515 E. Fordham Road, Bronx, N.Y. Visitation Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, Thursday, 11:30AM. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEACOCK, EVELYN PEELER
description: PEACOCK-Evelyn Peeler. January 25. Beloved wife of the late Kenneth, revered mother of Allen, Meleny and Carrie, adored grandmother of Will, Caroline, Hannah, William and James. Memorial service Saturday, January 30, 1PM at St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Nazareth Children's Home, Crescent Road, Rockwell, N.C. 28138

title: Russia and U.S. Urge Kosovo Talks; Albright Weighs Troops
description: Russia and the United States today called on both sides fighting in Kosovo to hold talks toward achieving a political settlement in the Serbian province, while the United States spoke more openly of using force to compel the talks.

title: When the Tide Turned in the Clinton Case
description: Events tend to look inevitable in retrospect. We've now all come to accept that Bill Clinton will survive the Lewinsky scandal. But if you cast your mind back over the past year, you see several moments when things could have turned out differently -- a fateful choice here, a failure to speak up there.

title: Presenting Beethoven To Help Foster Elgar
description: London Symphony Orchestra

title: Amidst the Rubble of Ruined Cities
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
description: A senior executive of the Microsoft Corporation testified today that his company tried to convince its main rival in the Internet software market to become less of a head-on competitor.

title: Lewinsky Returning to California
description: Declining to wait for a Senate subpoena, Monica S. Lewinsky checked out of the Mayflower Hotel here today and returned home to Los Angeles.

title: Amazon.com Loss Less Than Expected
description: Amazon.com Inc. said today that its fourth-quarter loss widened less than expected, while sales almost quadrupled, to $252.9 million, as more holiday shoppers used it to buy gifts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNST, MAURICE, M.D.
description: DUNST-Maurice, M.D. The members of the Catholic Medical Centers Physician Organization mourn the passing of Dr. Maurice Dunst, former vice president of the physician organization. We offer our heartfelt prayers and our deepest sympathy to the Dunst family on their great loss. Steven C. Garner, M.D., President Catholic Medical Centers Physician Organization

title: Dismiss Impeachment? There's No Reason Not To
description: To the Editor:

title: Sales at LVMH Moet 2% Higher in Quarter
description: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A., the world's largest maker of luxury goods, reported its first quarterly sales increase in a year as demand for its goods rebounded in Asia, helped by a stronger yen. LVMH, the maker of luxury products, said its sales in the fourth quarter of 1998 were 14.3 billion francs ($2.5 billion), 2 percent higher than in the quarter a year earlier.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMEISTER, ANNE (SCHAETZEL)
description: HOFFMEISTER-Anne (Schaetzel), age 87, formerly of New York City, died on January 23, 1999 in Plymouth, NH. The widow of Theodore H.C. Hoffmeister. Sister of Helene Genzmer. Also survived by one nephew. She was the administrative assistant to the Dean of Students at Hunter College, until retirement in 1969. A private graveside service will be held in the New Hampshire Veterans Cemetery. Memorial donations maybe made to the Pemi Baker Home Health Agency, 258 Highland Street, Plymouth, NH 03264

title: Reputed Leader of Crime Family Is Convicted of Jury Tampering
description: The reputed head of the Colombo crime family was convicted of jury tampering and obstruction of justice yesterday for trying to communicate with an alternate juror in his son's 1994 racketeering trial and then trying to impede a resulting inquiry.

title: Ivy Leaguers With a P.D.; Highly Educated Officers Fight Crime and Skepticism
description: When Adam Kasanof arrived on the campus of Columbia University, he was a budding Latin scholar, a fan of Catullus, a student of declensions and dactylic hexameter who was there to pursue the life of the mind.

title: Multi-Use Service Is Introduced by AT&T
description: The AT&T Corporation introduced a service yesterday that allows businesses to combine voice, video and data traffic on one phone network. The service will compete with similar products from MCI Worldcom Inc. and the Sprint Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAUER, WALTER
description: LANDAUER-Walter. Congregation Rodeph Sholom records with sorrow the passing of our devoted long-time member, Walter Landauer. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his companion Prudence Opperman, his daughter, Megan, brother Rolph and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Senior Rabbi Mark Biderman, President

title: Iraq Still Trying to Conceal Arms Programs, Report Says
description: President Saddam Hussein, who barred the return of arms inspectors to Iraq after American and British air strikes in December, is still actively trying to conceal past and present illegal weapons programs, the chief inspector told the Security Council in a report this week.

title: A Worthy Rhone Neighbor for Hermitage
description: IT'S an American story, actually. A fellow becomes disillusioned with the corporate grind and decides to change his life. He buys a nice piece of ground, plants some vines and, presto change-o, becomes a wine maker. In California, it seems it happens every other day.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: A Complete Makeover

title: McDonald's Earnings Up; Stock Split Set
description: The McDonald's Corporation said today that fourth-quarter earnings were robust, increased by strong international sales and a rejuvenated restaurant business in the United States.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I've been looking for five coffins for relatives since 8 o'clock this morning and I couldn't find any, so we're going to have to bury them in plastic.''

title: Missing Pastor Is Charged In Violent Shaking of Boy, 2
description: The pastor of a Colorado church whose wife reported him missing on Jan. 3 was arrested in New Jersey on Monday night after he violently shook the 2-year-old son of a New Jersey woman he met over the Internet, officials said yesterday.

title: Time Warner Adds Channel On Living in New York City
description: A fledgling local cable television channel that has been serving up light features and entertainment tips to Cablevision subscribers since August has been revamped and will be carried on Time Warner Cable of New York beginning tomorrow, company officials said yesterday.

title: THE CHEF
description: I TAKE football seriously, and so do the people who work with me, which is why I close the restaurant on Super Bowl Sunday and invite my staff and their families to eat, drink and cheer their favorites on big-screen televisions set up around the dining room. I've always been a football fan (my hometown team is the Buffalo Bills), I've always had friends in to watch the game and I've always cooked something special -- but easy -- for halftime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDMOND, LIDA SCHOCK
description: REDMOND-Lida Schock, died at her home in Glen Cove, NY, on January 25, after a short illness. She was the wife of Geraldyn Livingston Redmond. Born in St. Louis, Missouri, in 1926, she attended the Community School and Mary Institute there and graduated from the Foxcroft School in Middleburg, Virginia. An accomplished tennis player and athlete, she was known for her verve on and off the court. Nationally ranked as a junior tennis player, she defeated Gloria Thompson, mother of tennis great Jimmy Connors, as a fourteen year old, and later won numerous club championships. She was previously married to David Wendover Riesmeyer and Anthony John Adrian Bryan. She is survived by her husband, Geraldyn Redmond; four children, Lida Higginson of White Post, Va., Carol Bryan of San Francisco, California, Pamela Bryan of Los Angeles, California, John Bryan of Los Angeles, Calif.; two stepchildren, John Redmond of Long Island, N.Y., and Joan Redmond of Pine Plains, New York, and seven grandchildren, Hadley Higginson of Burlington, Vt., Timothy McCandless, Michael McCandless and Lisa McCandless of San Francisco, Calif., Gwendolyn McCaw of Seattle, Wash., Sophie and Adrian deSelliers of Los Angeles, Calif. Funeral services will be held Thursday, January 28, at 11 AM, at the Brookville Reformed Church, Brookville, Long Island, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Foxcroft School, Middleburg, Va.

title: After 24 Years, Subway Line for Second Avenue Gets Another Look
description: It was a grand idea left in a shambles by New York City's fiscal crisis of the 1970's: a subway running under Second Avenue, from the northern Bronx all the way to Wall Street, connected to a new tunnel under the East River. Started in 1972, the project was abandoned three years later, with only the river tunnel and three short links finished.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MAHONEY, ELIZABETH ANN
description: O'MAHONEY-Elizabeth Ann. Of New York City on January 25, 1999. Loving sister of John O'Mahoney, Bill O'Mahoney, and Mary Joh Giasone. Devoted aunt of Laura Giasone, Debbie O'Mahoney, Brian O'Mahoney, Sean O'Mahoney and Frank Giasone. Funeral services will begin 9:30 am Friday from the M. John Scanlan Funeral Home, 781 Newark Pompton Turnpike at Route 23, Pompton Plains, and a Mass will be celebrated 10:30 am at Our Lady of Magnificat R.C. Church, Kinnelon. Entombment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, East Hanover. Friends may call Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Donations to the American Lung Assoc. of N.J. would be appreciated by the family.

title: Taking the Census Two Ways
description: The Supreme Court's ruling against the use of statistical sampling to supplement the traditional head count in the 2000 census is disappointing. Sampling has long been endorsed by experts, including panels convened by the National Academy of Sciences, to produce an accurate population count. But the ruling, based on the wording of the Federal Census Act, is actually quite narrow.

title: The Bustle Is Back On Madison Square
description: THE settlement of Manhattan began at the southern tip and moved slowly north. By the turn of the century the community extended so far uptown that its center was a 6.2-acre square of green at the foot of Madison Avenue. Edith Wharton lived on Madison Square Park at one time; Theodore Roosevelt did, too. They had no need to venture far in search of a good meal. The city's finest restaurants, Sherry's and Delmonico's, were right there, as was the city's most elegant hotel.

title: Seles Stays Perfect Down Under as Graf Wilts
description: For reasons stranger than fiction, the Monica Seles and Steffi Graf rivalry never fulfilled its potential.

title: Body Shop to Quit Manufacturing Business
description: Body Shop International P.L.C., the British company that makes environmentally friendly cosmetics, is getting out of the manufacturing business to focus on reviving its struggling retail stores. The company's peppermint foot lotion, hemp hand lotion and other products will be manufactured by an outside company that the Body Shop did not name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOETTINGER, DOROTHY (NEE JOHNSTON)
description: BOETTINGER - Dorothy (nee Johnston) on 7th January 1999. ''Theo'', beloved mother of only daughter Ellie. Memorial service to be held at Emmanuel Church, Baltimore on Saturday, 30th January, 11:00 a.m. Inquiries to Seitz Funeral Home, 410-235-0803

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARRETT, BARBARA
description: JARRETT-Barbara. 84. Died peacefully on January 25, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Robert E., cherished mother of Renne Bilson, Jan Jarrett Grimaldi, and Denise Jarrett Dow; loving grandmother of Drew Stauffer, Todd, Jonathan and Alison Samter, Gavin and Keith Dow. She was the owner of Jarrett Management from 1960 until her retirement in 1997. Services Saturday, January 30, 11:30, St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Ave. and 51 St. Donations may be made to Alzheimer's Assoc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURBIN, ELIZABETH
description: DURBIN-Elizabeth. 62. Of NYC and Shelter Island. Suddenly, on January 25. Beloved wife of Seymour Weissman. Loving grandmother of Zachary, Vanessa, Hannah, Jenna, Kyle, Laura and Nicholas, stepmother of Judy, Eric, David and Adam. Courageously outspoken in defense of the vulnerable, humanist, Professor of Economics at NYU's Wagner Graduate School of Public Service for nearly 30 years. She was a devoted friend, colleague and teacher to many, and a caring, compassionate and generous person. She will be missed by all who knew her. Services on Friday, January 29th, 12 noon at ''The Riverside'' West 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations to Shelter Island Senior Council, Shelter Island, New York 11964.

title: Northern Telecom's Net Beats Expectations
description: Northern Telecom Ltd., the big manufacturer of telephone equipment, reported a quarterly profit today that exceeded expectations, helped by sales of Internet gear and revenue from its new Bay Networks unit.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about Web sites with tax information misstated the standing of Turbotax, by Intuit, in the tax software market. Its various versions account for more than 70 percent of the market, not 50 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUFEL, MORTON
description: TUFEL-Morton. On January 26. Devoted father of Alex, loving brother of Gilbert and Sherman, brother-in-law of Saundra and Ann, and dear uncle. Services are today, 1:45 PM at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expswy, Fresh Meadows, Queens, N.Y.

title: Most Schools Fall Short In New Tests In Virginia
description: With the eraser dust finally settled on New York State's star-crossed fourth-grade reading exam, given for the first time this year, here comes what might be a prophesy: nearly every school in Virginia has flunked its new battery of standardized exams in English, math, science and social studies.

title: Private Debates, Rare and Remarkable
description: When their gazes drifted upward, toward a four-sided gallery recently packed with reporters, foreign tourists and even the stray Hollywood celebrity or two, senators saw only empty seats and, behind those vacant rows, something that had been invisible to them for the last few hectic weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, REGINA K.
description: BROWN-Regina K. January 25,1999. Beloved wife of the late William Brown. Devoted mother of Ruth B. Glaser and the late Alan K. Brown. Beloved grandmother and great grandmother.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, DONALD D.
description: WOLF-Donald D. Died Saturday January 23, 1999 in New York City. Born February 22, 1912 in Bat-Nauheim, Germany. He received a Doctor of Laws Degree from Giessen University in Hesse, Germany. He became an anti-Nazi activist in the early 1930's and, in 1933, fled to Holland under threat of death. There, in 1938 he met his future wife Margot Caan. After the German invasion of Holland, the two joined the Dutch Underground where, for several years he smuggled endangered Jews across the German/Holland border and, she, forged I.D. cards for the escapees. The couple married in 1942 at the height of the War. They continued working in the Underground and, after a few narrow escapes from the Gestapo and their Dutch sympathizers, the couple was forced to find refuge by hiding in a loft. They remained there for more than two years surviving the Holocaust. In 1980, Donald Wolf was invited back to Holland to be honored for his work with the Underground at a nationally televised event. After the War, the couple immigrated to the United States and became a successful book designing team: known for their expertise in editing and designing educational books for children. These included: Simon and Shuster's, the Fireside World Encyclopedias; Grosset and Dunlop's, How and Why Wonder Books and Parent Magazine's, New Wonderworld Encyclopedia. The couple won the Publisher's Award for the most successful teamwork in designing books in both 1958 and 1961. He is survived by Margot, his wife of 57 years, and mourned by his numerous friends and admirers.

title: Pretax Profit Off 15% For SAP in Quarter
description: SAP A.G., the largest maker of business-management software, said its pretax profit fell 15 percent in the fourth quarter of 1998 as slumping demand in Japan outweighed gains in the United States and Europe. SAP shares rose nearly 6 percent yesterday, however, as investors appeared relieved that the worst might be behind the company. Shares of SAP fell 15 percent on Jan. 5, when it unexpectedly said that profit for the quarter would fall.

title: Correction
description: A picture in a chart on Jan. 6 with an article about Latin root vegetables was published in error. It showed a sweet potato, not a true yam. A true yam is shown above.

title: Smashed, Not Mashed, Potatoes
description: SMASHED potatoes, as opposed to mashed potatoes, could almost be called a natural phenomenon. They appear to be hand-hewed and unprocessed, seemingly at odds with a technological age. Yet, smashed potatoes can also be viewed as a victory of the pro-lumpers over the anti-lumpers, a triumph of the slap-dash over the careful.

title: Israeli Parliament Deals Setback to Non-Orthodox Movements
description: Efforts by the Conservative and Reform Jewish movements to gain official recognition in Israel suffered a setback today when the Israeli Parliament passed a bill intended to bar non-Orthodox Jews from the country's powerful religious councils.

title: A Much-Shunned Terrorist Is Said to Find Haven in Iraq
description: Abu Nidal, one of the world's most infamous terrorists, moved to Baghdad late last year and obtained the protection of President Saddam Hussein, according to intelligence reports received by United States and Middle Eastern government officials. The reports have raised questions about whether Iraq is pushing to establish a terrorism network, American and Middle Eastern officials say.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Salted Soybean Pods Seek a Niche in the Home

title: About New York; Year of Rabbit Gives an Artist Some Luck
description: LIKE many artists, Francisco Cardenas came to New York intent on making his mark in SoHo. ''You have to go outside of the familiar so that people will pay attention to you,'' he said. In his case, he had to go outside to help pay the bills. Recently, he took a construction job installing a smokestack at a restaurant at Houston Street and Second Avenue. But when he looked at the long, black tube he couldn't help thinking like an artist.

title: Gun Wholesalers Removed From Liability in Suit
description: A Federal judge dismissed 15 gun wholesalers yesterday from a lawsuit that sought to hold them and 30 gun manufacturers liable for shootings committed with illegally obtained handguns. The manufacturers remain as defendants in the suit.

title: Women Join in Folky Empathy, With More Than Words
description: Anyone looking at the lineup of ''Women in Music, 1960-1999,'' which assembled eight singers in a benefit for Zero Population Growth on Monday night at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, could have predicted doses of empathy, folky guitar picking and sweet-voiced sing-alongs. Those were all part of the headlining set by Jewel, whose fans joined in on ''Foolish Games'' and ''You Were Meant for Me,'' and they had their place during sets by Paula Cole, Judy Collins, Phoebe Snow and Janis Ian. Most of the songs were about romantic longing and healing the wounds it left behind. But the gist of the concert had to do with wordless music: the power of voices swooping, growling, breathing heavily or holding high notes proudly aloft.

title: Italy Sets Ownership Limit on Soccer Rights
description: Italy's ruling coalition agreed today to limit ownership of soccer pay-television rights, dealing a blow to the News Corporation's plan to broadcast matches of the nation's two top leagues.

title: War Crimes Can't Just Be Forgotten
description: To the Editor:

title: Appealingly Mediterranean, Like a Basket of Figs
description: ''I'M a fig freak,'' Gus Theodoro will tell you if you ask him about the name of his new restaurant, Figs, which opened about six weeks ago in the shadow of the Fashion Institute of Technology in Chelsea. He'll also tell you that the restaurant's name is an acronym for French-Italian-Greek, the culinary ground covered on the menu, but I prefer to think he went with his passion. That says so much more about the lively, delicious food and about Mr. Theodoro, himself.

title: Texaco Posts 80% Plunge in Earnings
description: Texaco Inc., the third-largest oil company in the United States, said today that fourth-quarter earnings fell 80 percent because of lower crude oil prices and narrower profit margins on fuel sales.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Dining section last Wednesday with an article about the financial difficulties of restaurants in France with three-star ratings from the Guide Michelin gave their telephone numbers incorrectly. They should have omitted a zero that is used only when dialing long distance within France itself. For example, the number for Alain Ducasse is (011) 33 1 47 27 12 27, not (011) 33 01 47 27 12 27.

title: Lucas Varity Weighs Bids Worth $6.5 Billion
description: Shares of Lucas Varity P.L.C., the world's second-largest maker of brakes, rose 17 percent, or 42 pence, to 286 pence, in London trading yesterday after TRW Inc. of Cleveland and the Federal-Mogul Corporation of Southfield, Ohio, made competing bids that valued it at $6.5 billion.

title: Doctor's Note Allows Parcells to Stay Home
description: Only a couple of weeks after saying that he wondered how much he would be fined if he did not go to the Pro Bowl, Jets Coach Bill Parcells today got a doctor's excuse to skip the game. The league accepted it, and now Bill Belichick, the Jets' assistant head coach, will run Parcells's staff in Hawaii.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AIELLO, DANNY
description: AIELLO-Danny. We will miss a loyal steadfast friend and mentor. The de Roulets

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Vatican's Revised Exorcism Rite Affirms Existence of Devil
description: Reaffirming that the Devil exists and is at work in the world, the Vatican today issued a revised rite of exorcism, the Roman Catholic ritual for driving out demons.

title: Moody's Downgrades Rating On Mazda's Unsecured Debt
description: Moody's Investors Service, the credit rating agency, lowered its ratings on the Mazda Motor Corporation's long-term unsecured debt to below investment grade today, citing continued deterioration in the Japanese car market.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; S.E.C. Official Takes Position At Bear Stearns
description: Richard R. Lindsey, the director of market regulation for the Securities and Exchange Commission, is stepping down to join a unit of the Bear Stearns Companies that is being investigated by the Manhattan District Attorney and Federal regulators.

title: A New Gauntlet: Cognac, Made in America
description: WHEN I first visited the Napa Valley, in 1965, it was still the bucolic place pictured in Frank Loesser's musical ''The Most Happy Fella.'' There was no wine train. There were no restaurants with gastronomic pretensions, and no fancy-pants grocery stores or shops. Only a half-dozen vineyards caught your eye as you drove up sleepy Route 29.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Commission Nears a Consensus on Redesigning Medicare
description: A Federal advisory commission inched toward a fragile consensus today on a plan to redesign Medicare as a marketplace in which the Government would compete with private insurers. But Democrats insisted that elderly people get coverage for prescription drugs, raising doubts about whether the plan would save money.

title: Dismiss Impeachment? There's No Reason Not To
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAGAZINO, ELVIRA
description: MAGAZINO-Elvira. This is your second anniversary at peace in heaven with Momma and Daddy. You are always remembered and never forgotten. Love always, Ron and Famil

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASKEL, RUTH ANN
description: KASKEL-Ruth Ann. On January 26, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Devoted mother of Frederick & Jonathan. Loving grandmother of Kimberly, Elizabeth, Jessica and Erica. Dear sister of Richard and the late Selma. Cared for by the devoted Beverly. Services are private. Contributions may be made to National Kidney Foundation of N.Y./N.J.

title: The Pope's Message
description: Today Pope John Paul II completes his eighth visit to North America. In his appearances in recent days in Mexico City and St. Louis, he spoke haltingly at times and walked unsteadily. But his message -- the primacy of the human being -- rang out. Early in his papacy he attacked the dehumanization of Communism, and now he sounds warnings about the human costs of hard-edged capitalism. World events have risen and fallen around John Paul, but his theme has never changed.

description: TASSONI-Joseph P. Sr., Ph.D. of Wayne, NJ died Monday. Director of Admissions and Dean of Students at NJ Medical School, Newark. Vander May Funeral Home, Wayne, New Jersey (973-696-2900).

description: LAMARQUE-Abril. The Members and Officers of the Parent Assembly of the Society of American Magicians are deeply saddened by the loss of our compeer, who died January 26, 1999. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to his family. Dr. Bruce J. Lish, President Albert C. Lasher, Secretary

title: People

title: Excerpts: 'There's Simply No Need to Go Outside This Record'
description: Following are excerpts from the presentation today by David E. Kendall, a lawyer for President Clinton, opposing a motion by the House impeachment managers to issue subpoenas for witnesses and to admit material not in the record:

title: The Tool That Chefs Love, And Home Cooks Barely Know
description: IT appears to be a simple gratin. It is a tall, square stack of yams, browned on top and sagging on the edges. As you sink your fork into it, though, it reveals layer upon fine layer, like a piece of puff pastry. And when you bite into it, the layers, separated by a smoky chipotle-scented cream, fall apart in your mouth.

title: Renault Truck Unit Seeks Scania Alliance
description: RVI, the truck unit of Renault S.A., wants to forge an alliance with Scania A.B. of Sweden, one of RVI's top executives said today.

title: Surprise! Gretzky's Birthday Is a Bash
description: Two days after winning a truck as the most valuable player in the National Hockey League All-Star Game, Wayne Gretzky observed his 38th birthday. He celebrated tonight by giving out the gift of goals to his teammates. Gretzky assisted on two scoring plays by Adam Graves and on one by Mathieu Schneider to help the Rangers gain a 4-1 victory over the Capitals in MCI Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NERENBERG, BENJAMIN, O.D.
description: NERENBERG - Benjamin, O.D., optometrist, 82, on January 26, in Los Gatos, CA. Loving husband of Lillian for 55-1/2 years, father of Dr. Lewis T. Nerenberg, Dr. Alan V. Nerenberg, Nancy R. Nerenberg, writer, of California, and Mark E. Nerenberg, attorney, of Manhattan. Loving brother of Hannah Drucker of Oakland, CA., and Frances Yohay of Bayside, Queens. Grandfather of Mara, Renee, Devin, Maya, Miles and Kiara Nerenberg. Loving father-in-law to Debby Bank, Hanina Levin and Jens Sehm. Loving uncle, great uncle and friend to many. Born in Manhattan in 1917, went West to attend the University of California. Long-time Clinical Professor of low vision at U.C. Berkeley as well as active community leader in many organizations. In lieu of flowers, the family would prefer donations to U.C.S.F. Prostate Cancer Research, U.C. Berkeley School of Optometry Low Vision Research, and Senior Adult Legal Assistance of Santa Clara County, or a charity of your choice

title: TV NOTES
description: An Office Drone Becomes a Star

description: Ignoring the moral lapses of President Clinton, Pope John Paul II flew to St. Louis today and addressed the broader moral issues facing the nation.

title: Healing War Scars With Romance
description: Lessons in life, love, forgiveness, racial tolerance and global economics are delivered with comic flair by an expert cast in the winning new revival of ''A Majority of One'' at the Jewish Repertory Theater.

title: Streamlined Poaching For Perfect Fish Fillets
description: THIN fish fillets can be tricky, mostly because they fall apart the instant they're overcooked. But the fact that quarter-inch-thick fillets of flounder, sole and other flatfish take so little time to cook can be turned to your advantage.

title: Business Travel; Delta Cancels a Criticized $1 Fee on Most Tickets
description: Delta Air Lines has withdrawn the $1 surcharge it imposed earlier this month on one-way domestic flights purchased anywhere but on its own Web site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINKUS, NETTIE E.

title: Colombian Immigrants Worry and Wait
description: Cristina Marquez couldn't stop crying on Monday night, worrying about her grandmother, who had just narrowly escaped being crushed to death in her family home in Armenia, Colombia.

title: U.S. Pilots Over Iraq Given Wider Leeway to Fight Back
description: As a response to Iraq's concerted challenge to United States planes, President Clinton has expanded the powers of military flight crews to fight back when threatened in the no-flight zones over northern and southern Iraq, the President's national security adviser acknowledged today.

Services 1pm today at Riverdale Temple, 246 Street & Independence Ave, Bronx, N.Y.

title: Compaq to Sell Small Stake In Alta Vista Search Site
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said yesterday that it would sell a minority stake in its Alta Vista service to the public as part of an effort to build a leading player in advertising and shopping on the Internet.

title: Papal Visit Spotlights Clinton's Bully Pulpit
description: Standing with Pope John Paul II yesterday in St. Louis, President Clinton declared that the United States was striving to be ''an example of justice and civic virtues.'' In using the powers and majesty of his office, performing his duties and ignoring impeachment, Mr. Clinton showed once again that he can create his own political atmosphere.

description: JAUL-Robert. The Partners, Associates and Staff of Brandt, Steinberg & Lewis, LLP mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, Bob Jaul. Our deepest sympathy to Claudia and her entire family. Hubert J. Brandt Richard A. Steinberg Willa I. Lewis

description: Muscovado Sugar

title: Lott Picks Six Scouts To Hunt Exit
description: Searching for a graceful ending to the impeachment trial, Senator Trent Lott, the Republican leader, named a six- member working group today to examine how the Senate could vote to express a view that President Clinton committed perjury and obstruction of justice without removing him from office.

Dr. Strax served the hospital for over 50 years and was involved in many activities in the wider medical community. He will be missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Blanche and his children. Wayne S. Fuchs, M.D., President Avi Barbasch, M.D., Vice Pres. Maria Padilla, M.D. Secretary William G. Stein, Treasurer

title: A Laconic, Tall Blond Swede as Carmen?
description: When the Swedish mezzo-soprano Anne Sofie von Otter was a young girl, she knew nothing about classical music and cared less. ''I couldn't tell the difference between Bach and Mahler,'' Ms. von Otter said recently.

title: Accounts
description: * CB Richard Ellis, Los Angeles, to Horizon Media, Los Angeles, to handle media planning and buying for the company, which offers such real estate services as property sales and leasing. Billings were estimated at $4 million to $5 million. Creative duties continue in-house.

title: A New Dan? An Old Dan? Simply Never Knew Dan?
description: After Dan Reeves left the Giants, he went through an evolution . . . wait. Check that. Don't use the ''e'' word around players who were with Reeves when he was coach of the Giants from 1993 to 1996 and migrated with him to Atlanta. Do so, and a harsh stare will come your way.

description: TISHMAN-Rita. The Board of Directors and shareholders of 14 East 75 Street express their deepest sympathy at the sudden passing of its friend and neighbor. 14 East 75 Street Paul McNamara, President

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: REAL CONTINUES TO SINK. Brazil's currency continued its slide as the ratings agency Fitch IBCA downgraded the nation's debt, adding to investors' worries. In New York, the real traded at 1.85 to the dollar, down from 1.78.

title: XEROX SHARES CLIMB 10.2% ON NEWS OF HIGHER EARNINGS
description: Shares of the Xerox Corporation rose 10.2 percent yesterday, to $116.125, a day after the company said its fourth-quarter profit had risen 17 percent. Net income for Xerox, the largest maker of copiers, based in Stamford, Conn., rose to $615 million, or $1.69 a diluted share, in the quarter, from $525 million, or $1.46 a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Profit was helped by cost cuts and increased sales in Europe and the United States that offset weakness in Asia and Brazil. Revenue rose 7.1 percent, to $5.8 billion, meeting analysts' estimates. Xerox also declared a 2-for-1 stock split and raised its quarterly dividend 11 percent.

title: Officer Kills Himself Near Grave of Friend
description: The morning after he was seen joshing with colleagues in the Capitol cafeteria, State Representative B. Scott Santa-Maria, the only police officer in the Connecticut legislature, was found dead today of a self-inflicted gunshot wound near the grave of a friend, the authorities said.

title: Census Ruling Reignites a Partisan Battle
description: Partisan lines hardened today over the 2000 census, as the White House said it was strongly considering a proposal to produce census figures using statistical sampling that states could use for drawing legislative districts, while Republicans vowed to fight any such plan in the courts and Congress.

title: Nets-Knicks Exhibition Won't Tell the Full Story
description: The story line for Wednesday night's exhibition game between the Nets and the Knicks is intriguing. The young, upstart Nets are determined to establish themselves as one of the league's best teams, and the perennially contending yet revamped Knicks are eager to see if their talented cast will share the basketball and play as a unit.

description: To the Editor,

title: For Falcons, Dwight Takes Flight
description: Atlanta's little big man, the kick returner Tim Dwight, likes to think of himself as a little crazy. He takes trips to Mexico for cliff-jumping, leaping some 90 feet into the rolling water. His friend tried once, but didn't quite have the kind of body control that Dwight possesses. ''He landed on his back after a jump,'' Dwight said. ''He had red marks all over it. It was pretty funny.''

description: SO much depends on the proper typing of a string of abbreviations, interrupted by an @. Business deals, jobs, romantic affairs: the fates of them all can rise or fall on a single typo.

title: As On-Line Trading Increases, So Do Complaints

His order was filled for 2,300 shares, at a price of $90 a share and a bill of $207,000 -- nearly $150,000 more than he expected.

''Beyond party loyalties,'' the Rev. Lloyd J. Ogilvie said, ''those on both sides of the aisle long to do what ultimately is best for the nation.''

title: State Criticized on Funds For Pregnancy Programs
description: The state has failed to provide enough money to carry out recommendations about how to reduce teen-age pregnancies and to assist teen-agers who are pregnant or have children, a Rutgers University study released yesterday reported.

title: Outside the Chamber of Justice, the Crucial Halls of Spin
description: During the impeachment trial, senators in the unnatural position of being gagged on the floor of their chamber have embraced an alternative performance style with an odd resemblance to an old Broadway hit.

title: Silver Charm Is 8-5 Choice From the Outside for the Donn
description: Silver Charm, who won the Kentucky Derby two years ago and the Dubai World Cup one year ago, made his appearance at Gulfstream Park today after crossing the continent in his new role as the horse who might ''save'' the racing business. But, after his travels, the 5-year-old warrior drew the No. 12 post position on the far outside for Saturday's $500,000 Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

title: How Lobbyist Became Player On Olympics Bidding Teams
description: After Salt Lake City lost the 1998 Olympics to Nagano, Japan, the Salt Lake Olympic organizers vowed to change their strategy for the 2002 Games. One of their first moves was to hire a former member of Egypt's national volleyball team who had close personal contacts with athletic officials in North Africa.

description: In announcing his retirement yesterday, the Knicks' Buck Williams joked about how he will soon sit down with his son, Julian, and brag about how remarkable he was on the basketball court.

description: The Ford Motor Company plans to announce today that it will acquire the passenger car operations of Sweden's A.B. Volvo for between $6 billion and $7 billion, people close to the talks said last night.

description: A picture of Nicholas Oppenheimer, chairman of the De Beers diamond company, in Business Day on Jan. 12 carried an erroneous credit. Jon Hrusa made the photograph for The Sunday Times of Johannesburg, not for The New York Times.

title: Devil in Details As Sides Seek Deposition Deal
description: Senate Republican and Democratic leaders met into the evening today with their top lieutenants as they tried to hash out a bipartisan agreement that would map the questioning of witnesses in the coming days and perhaps pinpoint a target date to conclude President Clinton's impeachment trial.

title: Davenport Is Upended By Unseeded Teen-Ager
description: The brush fire that has transformed unseeded men's tennis players into worldbeaters jumped genders today, and Lindsay Davenport was the one who got burned in the semifinals of the Australian Open against a French 19-year-old named Amelie Mauresmo.

title: Reproducing the Past
description: FUTURE generations may discover that Charleston, S.C., exists more in reproduction than reality. With a vigorous 22-year-old licensing program that now includes 34 licensing partners, the Historic Charleston Foundation, the largest preservation organization in the 18th-century city on the sea, has struck deals for manufacturing everything from Baker furniture to local needlepoint.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRONG, HELEN W.
