She had lived in Seattle, Hansville, WA., and Portland, OR since 1951 and is survived by many loving children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. Memorials may be sent to Pomfret School.

title: Slain Child Found at Parkway Is Identified as Missing Boy, 12
description: The body of a child found last week on the edge of the Saw Mill River Parkway was identified as that of a 12-year-old boy who disappeared nearly three months ago after he went to get a haircut, the Westchester County District Attorney said yesterday.

title: Exclusivity Piled as High as Snow at Resort
description: As mountain resorts struggle these days with the vagaries of modern life -- lift lines, crowded trails, ski-gear thefts, road traffic and now, even terrorism -- an oasis of tranquillity is being offered to the rich. But for a price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINN, MARGARET MARY
description: QUINN-Margaret Mary. January 25th, 1999. Beloved daughter of Donald & Margaret Quinn. Loving sister of Diane, Eileen, Mary, Denis and James. Devoted aunt of ten nieces, three nephews and one grandniece. She was the Principal at St. Vincent Ferrer High School, NYC. Friends may call at the Abbey Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, January 29, 10:30AM at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Margaret M. Quinn Scholarship Fund at St. Vincent Ferrer High School, 151 East 65 Street, NYC 10021.

title: A Homicide Tears at Yale; Police Suspicion About Slain Senior's Adviser Shakes World of Small-College Fellowship
description: When a 21-year-old Yale University senior was found slain on Dec. 4 in a residential neighborhood of porticoed homes and ample lawns two miles from campus, the New Haven police invested the crime with an intimacy that deepened its intrigue.

title: New Domain Names Set a Record in 1998
description: Internet users who registered a domain name in 1998, the first step in publishing a Web site, were in good company. Network Solutions, the Herndon, Va., registrar of .com, .net, .org and .edu names, said it logged a record 1.9 million new domain names in 1998, nearly double the 1997 total of 960,000.

title: Surfing Their Way to the Holy Land
description: SIX months ago, Marina Azimova, a 36-year-old single mother, wanted to pray for her autistic son, Joey. And she really wanted God to hear. A Russian Jewish immigrant who lives in Wilkes Barre, Pa., she knew that with only a part-time job, she could not afford a trip to Jerusalem to visit the Western Wall, where Jews for centuries have stuffed handwritten notes in the crevices of what many believe to be Judaism's holiest site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZEAR, ROBERT ALLEN
description: LAZEAR-Robert Allen. Aged 75. Of West Hartford, Connecticut, and Cuttyhunk Island, Mass. Died on January 26th. ''Dean of New England Headmasters'' and ''Squire of Cuttyhunk,'' Bob Lazear lived a life devoted to education. He started his career as a history teacher at the Pomfret School in 1951, and in 1962 moved to Hampton Institute in Virginia as assistant to the President, dedicating the next several years to the Civil Rights movement. From 1967-1986 he was headmaster of the Kingswood-Oxford School. Upon his retirement, he served the Renbrook School and then the Mooreland Hill School as interim headmaster, Bob Lazear dared generations of young people to live life with gusto, introduced them to the world's joys, exposed them to the world's injustices, and incited students to fight for their beliefs with compassion as well as passion, wisdom as well as fire. He had a wonderful life and a beautiful voice, and was as likely to burst into a Gershwin lyric as he was to offer a hearty greeting. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, the former Dorothy Rector; by his daughters Barbara Lazear Ascher and Rebecca Lazear Okrent; sons-in-law Robert C. Ascher and Daniel Okrent; grandchildren Rebecca and Charles Ascher-Walsh, and John and Lydia Okrent; his brother, Thomas Lazear, & sister Margaret Weidaw. His son Robert Allen Lazear, Jr., died in 1989. A memorial service will be held on the Kingswood-Oxford campus on Saturday, February 6, at 5:00 PM, at Seaverns Hall. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to: The Robert Lazear Scholarship Fund, Kingswood-Oxford School, 170 Kingswood Rd, West Hartford, CT 06119; The Hartford Hospital, Development Dept., 80 Seymour Street, P.O. Box 5037, Hartford, CT 06102-5037; or The McLean Home, Hospice Unit, 75 Great Pond Road, Simsbury, CT. 06070.

title: Nafta Invoked to Challenge Court Award
description: Some business executives have argued for years that large jury verdicts against big companies show that American courts are out of control.

title: Ex-Livent Officials, Now in Canada, May Not Make Court Date
description: Garth H. Drabinsky and Myron I. Gottlieb, the two Canadians who founded Livent, Inc., the Broadway theater company, said through their lawyers yesterday that they will not come to Manhattan to face the criminal fraud charges brought against them by U.S. prosecutors early this month.

title: From Sincere to Slick, Ambitions Flicker at Sundance
description: Mark Borchardt is a long-haired guy from Milwaukee who has been fanatically obsessed with filmmaking since childhood. While supporting himself by delivering newspapers and working as a cemetery caretaker, he was able to wheedle enough money out of his uncle to make the slasher film of his dreams, ''Coven.'' He shot it in black and white and roped his reluctant mother into helping out. Now here he is, suddenly famous enough to be spotted on Main Street in this town, but a far cry from the camera-toting Cinderellas who once made such hot copy here. The increasingly important and businesslike Sundance Film Festival has long since outgrown its favorite fairy tales.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SAFEWAY INC., Pleasanton, Calif., the food and drug retailer, filed a registration statement with the S.E.C. for the sale of 19.75 million shares of common stock held by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company.

title: The Big City; Ah, Those 'Special' Tenants
description: IN the fine New York tradition of social justice and investigative journalism -- specifically, The Village Voice's lists of the city's 10 worst landlords -- nominations are hereby solicited for a new list: The 10 Worst Tenants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNITZER, HILDE M.
description: SCHNITZER-Hilde M. Congregation Shomrei Emunah in Montclair, NJ mourns the passing of our ''Rebetzin of distinction'', Hilde M. Schnitzer. Her devotion to the Congregation, to the community, and to Judaism's highest principles is her legacy for generations to come. Shirley R. Grill, Pres. Michael A. Monson Rabbi

title: Kennedy Opens Attack on Plan by Chief of Medicare Panel
description: Staking out a position for liberal Democrats, Senator Edward M. Kennedy plans to criticize the work of a bipartisan Federal advisory commission that would give private health insurers a much bigger role in running Medicare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, LEAH
description: GORDON-Leah. The members, Board of Governors, and staff of Pine Hollow Country Club mourn the passing of our long time member and good friend. We extend our sympathies to her husband, Robert, and the family. The Board of Governors Pine Hollow Country Club

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; All in the family? National Presto to face analyst scrutiny.
description: INVESTORS can be forgiven for having never heard of National Presto Industries. The Eau Claire, Wis., company is known for being run more like a private company than a publicly held one. While consumers may be familiar with its wares -- an assortment of pressure cookers, corn poppers and microwave bacon cookers -- its stock has been a lackluster performer. No analyst from a leading Wall Street firm follows it.

title: China's Suicide Rate
description: To the Editor:

title: Shanahan Does Crossword Puzzles in Ink
description: Terrell Davis is splendid, John Elway is like fine wine and Bill Romanowski leads a ferocious defense. But with the Denver Broncos, they are chess pieces in Coach Mike Shanahan's head, to be artfully used on game day.

title: Euro Hits 2-Week Low Against Dollar
description: The euro fell to a two-week low against the dollar yesterday on expectations the United States economy's growth will keep growing at a faster rate than those of the 11 nations that have joined Europe's single currency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELWELL, ETHEL OLIVE NEE JOSEPH
description: ELWELL-Ethel Olive nee Joseph on January 25, 1999 in Lawrence, NY. Beloved mother of Richard Derby Elwell and David Henry Elwell. Funeral services will be held at Trinity-St. Johns at 3:00PM on Friday the 29th, 1142 Broadway, Hewlett, New York. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the North Shore Animal League Adoption Services, 25 Davis Ave, Port Washington, N.Y. 11050.

title: The Doppelganger; Errors Lead to a Cyberbond as Comfy as an Old Shoe
description: I WAS blessed with the kindest of cybersisters, and though I have never met her, I have frequently imagined her. Wrongly, as it turns out.

title: Group of Brokers Is Facing Charges of Insider Trading
description: A group of Long Island stockbrokers has been charged with insider trading in a scheme involving nonpublic information about coming articles in Business Week magazine, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department announced yesterday.

title: A German Is Named Carnegie's New Director
description: Franz Xaver Ohnesorg, a widely admired German arts executive, has been named executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall, officials announced yesterday. Mr. Ohnesorg succeeds Judith Arron, who died on Dec. 18 and had run the hall since 1986.

title: Social Security: The Basics, With a Tally Sheet
description: When President Clinton unexpectedly used his State of the Union Message last week to propose vast changes in the way Social Security is financed, he touched off what may become the hottest policy debate of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, ELINOR
description: ADLER-Elinor of Tenafly, NJ. Beloved wife of Bela. Devoted mother of Richard & Philip. Dear sister of Phyllis Robinson and Jean Wollan. Loving grandmother of Evan and Isabel. Services ''GuttermanMusicant'' corner of Passaic and Park Streets, Hackensack, NJ today at 12:30 PM. Contributions to Elly Adler Music Fund, C/O Sunny Simels, 280 Prospect Avenue, Hackensack, New Jersey 07601.

title: Jordan Nervously Awaits Royal Drama's Outcome
description: Banners welcoming King Hussein home still adorn the streets of this capital. Full-color posters depict a smiling, relaxed monarch, his arm slung over the shoulders of his brother, the Crown Prince.

title: Residential Sales
description: MANHATTAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUAL, HENRIETTE (NEE MENKES)
description: SHUAL-Henriette (nee Menkes). Of Forest Hills, Queens, NY, on Tuesday, January 26, 1999. Longtime Administrative Assistant with the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, New York, NY. Beloved wife of the late Henri Shual. Dear mother of Ingrid Shoenfeld of Mountain Lakes, NJ. Dear sister of Suzanne Menkes of Forest Hills. Also survived by 3 grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Friday, January 29th at 1:00pm at the Mackey Funeral Home, 107 Essex Ave, Boonton, NJ. Memorial contributions to the Valerie Children's Fund, c/o Newark Beth Israel Medical Cntr, 201 Lyons Ave, Newark, NJ 07112 would be appreciated.

title: SENATE REFUSES TO DISMISS CASE AND AGREES TO CALL LEWINSKY; DASCHLE SEES CLINTON SURVIVAL
description: Dividing almost precisely along party lines, the Senate voted today to summon Monica S. Lewinsky and two other witnesses for depositions in the impeachment trial of President Clinton. Minutes earlier, it had voted against dismissing the charges against Mr. Clinton.

title: Seagram Division Consolidates Duties
description: Seagram Americas in New York, a unit of the Seagram Company, has consolidated the media planning and buying responsibilities for all liquor brands except Absolut vodka at the Mediacom unit of Grey Advertising. Billings for those duties, which had been divided among several agencies, including Mediacom, were estimated at $46 million to $50 million.

title: 'Get Your Hot Dogs! Peanuts! Screen Wipes!'
description: Five hundred football fans will be able to attend Sunday's Super Bowl in Miami and simultaneously remain couch potatoes.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DOLINSKY, JOSH
description: DOLINSKY-Josh May 14, 1964-January 28, 1992. His spirit lives on in all who knew and loved him.

title: When Your Past Comes Calling, There's No Escape
description: WHILE I WAS GONE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKALETSKY, IRA
description: SKALETSKY-Ira. Of Goulds, Florida. Formerly of Manhattan, N.Y. On January 26, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathryn. Father of Chris and Steven. Brother of Rhea and dear friend to many. Memorial service on January 29, 1999 at Branam Funeral Home, Homestead, Florida. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Nature Conservancy would be appreciated.

title: Profit Is 10% Higher at Reader's Digest
description: Reader's Digest Association Inc., the publisher of the world's most widely circulated general-interest magazine, said today that adjusted fiscal second-quarter earnings rose 10 percent, helped by cost cuts.

title: Pit Vipers Of the 30's, And Echoes Of Today
description: What plays in the nation's capital? Why, infidelity, innuendo and gossip, of course -- and not just as aspects of the hit melodrama now running on (and off) the floor of the United States Senate. At the estimable Arena Stage, the director Kyle Donnelly has cannily revived ''The Women,'' Clare Boothe Luce's blood-drawing comedy, in a tart and snappy production that seems eerily well suited to these tawdry, scandalmongering times.

title: Microsoft Official Defends Company's Strategy at Trial
description: A senior executive of the Microsoft Corporation delivered a forceful defense of the company's actions in the Internet software market today, saying it had acted mainly in the pursuit of a ''Holy Grail of software development'' by making its products more powerful, easier to use and seamlessly integrated.

title: The Wrong Play in Theory Can Turn Out to Be Right
description: One of the most remarkable recoveries of 1998 occurred last month in the semifinal of the Gold Cup, Britain's equivalent of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams. Playing in London with 40 of 64 deals completed, a team led by Howard Cohen trailed by 57 imps against a group headed by David Price. An impressive resurgence followed, but with one deal remaining Cohen was still 8 imps in the hole.

title: No Currency Devaluation, China Reiterates
description: With world markets once again jittery about a possible devaluation of China's currency, the yuan, the governor of the Chinese central bank said today that there were no plans to do so, pointing out that there is even less pressure on the currency, also known as the renminbi, than there was last year.

title: For School Nurses, More Than Tending the Sick
description: Ritalin, Ritalin, seizure drugs, Ritalin. So goes the rhythm of noontime for Mary Jane Kemper, nurse at the Donald McKay School in East Boston, as she trots her tray of brown plastic vials and paper water cups from class to class, dispensing pills into outstretched young palms.

title: Testaverde Will Fly In To Please His Coach
description: Vinny Testaverde, the Jet quarterback, said today that he had enlisted another kind of jet for off-season workouts. He bought a jet plane for commuting to the team's drills from his home in Tampa, a move that should keep both player and coach happy.

title: Photos Record Sky's Brightest Burst
description: Astronomers for the first time have photographed the visible glow of a gamma ray burst at the peak of its brightness, capturing the most powerful cosmic eruption ever detected.

title: No Radiation Effect Found At Northwest Nuclear Site
description: In research ordered by Congress after revelations of huge radioactive gas releases at the Hanford nuclear reservation during the cold war, an intensive study of 3,400 adults who grew up near the site has found no difference in thyroid abnormalities between those estimated to have received high doses and those believed to have gotten none.

title: Democrat Joins the G.O.P. On 2 Impeachment Votes
description: For weeks, the feverish guessing game had focused on whether a swing group of as many as a half-dozen Republican senators might buck their colleagues and side with Democrats in trying to end or truncate the impeachment trial against President Clinton.

title: Violence Erupts as Colombia Learns What Was Lost in Quake, and What Remains
description: Angered by delays in the delivery of food and other assistance after one of the worst earthquakes here in more than a century, residents in this town and nearby Armenia looted supermarkets and stores today and threw stones at soldiers and police officers.

title: CHARTER COMMUNICATIONS TO PICK UP NEW CABLE SYSTEMS
description: The Charter Communications Corporation, the cable-television operator owned by the billionaire Paul G. Allen and Tele-Communications Inc., will acquire cable systems from Intermedia Partners in a transaction valued at $2.4 billion, the companies said yesterday. Charter will gain 400,000 of Intermedia's 1.2 million subscribers and give TCI, the No. 2 cable-TV operator and co-owner of Intermedia, cable systems in Montana and Indiana with 140,000 customers. Intermedia will also receive an additional 300,000 subscribers in Nashville. Mr. Allen's part of the transaction involves $1.3 billion in cash and exchanged systems, a person close to the negotiations said. TCI's acquisition will be noncash and will involve its partnership in Intermedia.

title: Gun Liability Suit Is Built On Poor Data, Analyst Says
description: In a lawsuit seeking to hold gun manufacturers liable for shootings with illegally obtained handguns, an economist testified yesterday that the plaintiffs' main contention was based on flawed statistics.

title: Clinton Scandal Is No Watergate
description: To the Editor:

title: Life After The VCR
description: MY videocassette recorder, like many modern electronic devices, apparently has a special chip that detects the moment the warranty expires and then causes things to go haywire. In this case, it ate the fifth of six videotapes composing the ''Brideshead Revisited'' epic and could not be coaxed into giving it back. It was a rental tape, and the video store was charging by the day. It was an expensive six-tape set, and no place would sell ''Brideshead/Book Five'' alone.

title: WESTERN INVESTORS TEAM UP TO BID ON ISRAELI PROPERTY
description: The investors Leon Black, principal owner of Apollo Advisors L.P. in New York, and Leo Noe, former chief executive of Bourne End Properties P.L.C. in London, are teaming up to buy property in Israel's slumping real estate market, bidding $200 million for Amot Investments Ltd. and looking for future acquisitions. Israel's Histadrut labor federation, which is trying to sell its pension fund's 80 percent stake, said it would announce a winning bidder this week. If they win, the two businessmen would become the most powerful foreign owners in the Israeli property market.

title: Everything but a Dial
description: IF it's true that choice can be a curse, then curses are raining down on consumers these days as they go to Best Buy and Circuit City to purchase what used to be the most elementary of instruments: a telephone.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Polish theater director Jerzy Grotowski on Jan. 15 misstated the year he first visited New York. It was 1967, not 1969.

title: Clinton to Back L.I.R.R. Tunnel, Officials Say
description: In the first step toward building an East River tunnel that would connect the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal, President Clinton will include $20 million in planning funds for the long-sought project in his budget proposal to Congress next month, Congressional officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Chemical Manufacturers Association's program to research the safety of products misstated the group's Web address. It is www.cmahq.com (www.cma.org is the site for the Communications Managers Association).

title: HCC INSURANCE CANCELS 'GROSSLY INADEQUATE' CENTRIS BID
description: HCC Insurance Holdings Inc. withdrew its unsolicited $156.2 million takeover offer for Centris Group Inc. yesterday, a few hours after Centris rejected the bid as ''grossly inadequate.'' HCC, a property and casualty insurance company, wanted to broaden its product line with the addition of Centris, which covers unexpected medical claims against employers that self-insure employees' health care. On Jan. 11, HCC offered $13.25 a share for the 11.8 million outstanding Centris shares, a 20 percent premium over their value at the time. The shares have since traded up, closing yesterday at $14.0625, up 25 cents.

title: BELL CANADA PROPOSES TO BUY 20% OF MANITOBA TELECOM
description: Bell Canada, the largest telephone company in Canada, said yesterday that it would spend $221 million for a 20 percent interest in Manitoba Telecom Services Inc. in a move to expand Bell Canada's services into western Canada. Bell Canada's new national broadband and Internet protocol company, named Bell Nexxia, will form an operating alliance with Manitoba Telecom to serve the Manitoba area. Bell Canada and Manitoba Telecom will also create a new telecommunications company called Newco, which will compete in the $1.4 billion Alberta and British Columbia market, starting in the spring. Manitoba Telecom will own two-thirds of the new company, while Bell Canada will own one-third.

title: Sprewell Stumbles And Then Soars In Winning Debut
description: As his awkward early appearance morphed into a sight so sleek and silky last night -- a Knick vision formerly uncommon in Madison Square Garden -- Latrell Sprewell rode the swells and curls of the crowd's mood swings like a surfer.

title: A Giant's Generosity
description: To the Editor:

title: Smart Cards Coming, And Smart Hackers
description: Just about now, someone who will be a malicious hacker in the 21st century is leaving homeroom, heading off to the junior-high cafeteria. By the time the student graduates, the people at Schlumberger Test and Transactions hope they will have figured out a way to stop the mischief.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ford Said to Be in Deal For Volvo's Car Business

title: Missile Defense Won't Deter Rogues
description: To the Editor:

title: Hearst Is Seen Joining Project Of Tina Brown
description: The Hearst Corporation is close to assuming a significant ownership stake with Miramax Films in Tina Brown's Talk magazine, which is scheduled to start publication in the fall.

title: Sprewell and Williams In a Transition Game
description: When No. 8 from the University of Alabama was introduced last night at Madison Square Garden, the smattering of boos was drowned out by the raucous applause. So much for disgust and indignation. Latrell Sprewell, back from basketball purgatory after more than a year, received the loudest ovation of any Knick.

title: Scripting the Last Act
description: Now that the Senate has definitively established that it lacks the votes to remove President Clinton, it owes the nation a swift completion of the impeachment trial. The aggressive talk by the House managers and their Republican brethren in the Senate about further truth-seeking cannot change the fact that 44 Democrats voted yesterday to dismiss the case, leaving the Senate at least 11 votes short of the 67 required to discharge Mr. Clinton. The actions of the Senate and the White House in the days ahead should be guided by that granite fact.

title: Albright to Meet Jordan's Heir
description: In a surprise change of plans intended to put the American seal of approval on King Hussein's heir, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright plans to drop in on Prince Abdullah of Jordan on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVERDING, AUGUST
description: EVERDING-August. The Metroplitan Opera deeply mourns the death of August Everding, who created five of our most successful and acclaimed productions. His imaginative use of the Metropolitan's great stage, backed by a superlative mastery of modern stage techniques, brought vividly to life our new production of ''Tristan und Isolde'' for his 1971 debut. As well as a striking ''Lohengrin,'' he created productions which are still favorites of our audiences today, such as his magnificent ''Boris Godunov'' and ''Der Fliegende Hollaender.'' His much-admired production of Mussorgsky's ''Khovanshchina'' will be revived in March. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Gustava and his four sons. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: Big Venezuela Job To Oilfield Concern
description: Ensco International Inc., a Dallas-based oilfield services company, said today that it had received a $190 million contract from the Chevron Corporation to build three large barge drilling rigs in Venezuela.

title: The Cordless Options
description: Cordless phones act as small radios, sending signals between the handset and the receiver. For many years, cordless phones operated on frequencies around 49 megahertz in the radio spectrum. When that part of the spectrum grew crowded, manufacturers began making phones that send signals at 900 MHz, a less congested frequency. Cordless phones can also be analog or digital. The difference isn't in what part of the radio spectrum they use -- it is in how the sound information is packaged for transmission. Here are the cordless options:

description: This was not your average Central Park pigeon.

description: EUROPE

title: Washington Could Learn From Texas, Bush Asserts
description: Gov. George W. Bush, who has sometimes expressed discomfort with the relentless speculation over whether he will run for President in 2000, brought the matter up himself today in his State of the State address, saying legislators should seize this ''national spotlight'' to teach Washington lawmakers a thing or two.

title: Clinton Scandal Is No Watergate
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in Business Day on Monday described the efforts of Steven Brill, chairman and editor in chief of the media magazine Brill's Content, to make it successful.

title: Art History 101, Continued
description: THE ART HISTORIAN

title: Six From Jets' Past Like Turnaround
description: They played for the Jets as long ago as 1988 and as recently as 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLITTNICK, JACK
description: KLITTNICK-Jack. At 94 years, beloved husband of Ida Klittnick, brother of David Klittnick, father of Arthur Klittnick and Estelle Gellman, grandfather of Doug, Russell and Beth Gellman. Services at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Queens, at Noon on Thursday, January 28th.

title: Germany's Pragmatic Ex-Radical Thinks Globally
description: Funny place, Germany. An environmentalist is about to direct the country's foreign policy from a Nazi-era Berlin building where Hitler stored gold stolen from Jews and the East German Communist leader Erich Honecker later held court.

title: Storm Overcomes Slow Start to Beat Stubborn Syracuse
description: It may be the most highly anticipated Big East matchup of the season, but St. John's meeting with Connecticut at Madison Square Garden on Saturday is going to have to include something like computer-generated special effects to live up to the last two games the Red Storm has played.

title: Charles Luckman, Architect Who Designed Penn Station's Replacement, Dies at 89
description: Charles Luckman, an architect and businessman who had the misfortune to design the building that replaced New York's Penn Station but who also helped to create Lever House,the landmark Park Avenue skyscraper, died on Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 89.

title: In the Deep Midwinter, Plans for Spring Take Root
description: SPRING fever can begin in strange ways. It hit me hard last week, when a friend brought over a bunch of Swiss chard purchased at an expensive natural-foods store on Second Avenue.

title: Rikers Island Jail Death Is Ruled a Homicide
description: The death of a 17-year-old inmate at Rikers Island earlier this month was ruled a homicide yesterday by the City Medical Examiner's office.

title: Crowd of 200 Greets Suspect In the Slaying Of an Officer
description: Police dogs lunged and growled, officers and dispatchers wept with relief and citizens applauded as detectives led a homeless Hartford man into the police station here today where he was charged with murder in the shooting of an East Hartford police officer on Saturday night.

title: Odes to Opera's Stars
description: TAKE two of the most obsessive afflictions known -- Web surfing and opera -- then develop sites devoted to their stars, and you have created an opportunity for a serious on-line wallow.

title: A Painter and Her Art Trade Places; A Change in Style, and Provocative Works Find Success
description: After more than an hour of art talk one recent day, Lisa Yuskavage, 36, a painter whose often shocking work deals with sex, misogyny and self-loathing, got up from the couch in her studio above a used-furniture warehouse in TriBeCa and fetched the secret of her latest success.

title: Judge's Ruling Frees Players
description: A United States District Court bankruptcy judge in San Jose, Calif., ruled yesterday that the contracts between the American Basketball League and its players and coaches could be terminated.

title: Pope, in St. Louis Mass, Urges U.S. Catholics to Oppose Death Penalty
description: Preaching consistency in moral values, Pope John Paul II today urged America's Roman Catholics to extend the crusade to protect human life to include murderers on death row.

title: AT&T to Offer Single Rate For All Users
description: Removing the price distinction between wireless and traditional phone calls for the first time, the AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it would offer long-distance and wireless service at a single rate of 10 cents a minute on a single bill.

title: Chief Is Denied Pension After Police Scandal
description: The chief who was in charge of the West New York Police Department during a widespread corruption scandal has been stripped of his $80,000 annual pension after pleading guilty to bribe taking, state officials said yesterday.

title: BIGGEST DROP IN SEVEN YEARS FOR SHARES OF FIRST UNION
description: The First Union Corporation shares had their biggest drop in more than seven years yesterday after the sixth-largest United States bank said a slowing economy, higher expenses and an accounting change would reduce 1999 earnings. First Union fell $4.875, or 8.5 percent, to $52.1875 yesterday, its third-biggest decline in at least 15 years, after its chairman and chief executive, Edward E. Crutchfield, said late Tuesday that per-share earnings would rise less than 10 percent this year. Mr. Crutchfield said First Union would stop using an accounting method that allows it to immediately record gains when it sells pools of loans. The bank also faces expenses for strategic initiatives that will reduce profit growth, he said.

title: U.S. Examines Samaranch Role and I.O.C.
description: The United States Olympic Committee, divided about the future of Juan Antonio Samaranch, is exploring ideas about the restructuring of the International Olympic Committee, including recommendations for term limits and democratic elections by outsiders, American officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BURROWS, JUDITH
description: BURROWS-Judith. Mother, two years ago you left us, yet your invincible spirit surrounds us with joy. I love and miss you. Lauren.

title: Clinton Scandal Is No Watergate
description: To the Editor:

title: America Online's Profit Rises Significantly
description: America Online continued to show vigorous growth and improving profitability in the latest quarter, earning $122 million on sales of $960 million, the company said yesterday.

title: U.S. PUSHES PLAN TO END FIGHTING IN SERB PROVINCE
description: The Clinton Administration today announced a far-reaching plan to end the fighting in Kosovo that calls for NATO air strikes if the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, refuses to grant Kosovo autonomy.

title: Working (Too) Hard for Less; Labor Department Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, ROBERT
description: SHAW-Robert. The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers joins with the entire music world in mourning the passing of our distinguished member, Robert Shaw. He was Music Director of the Atlanta Symphony for over 20 years, a major champion of American music and our country's greatest choral conductor. We extend our most sincere condolences to his family. Marilyn Bergman, President & Chairman, ASCAP

title: Passion Prevails in Russians' Premieres
description: As a choreographer, Boris Eifman continues to surprise. There was a very different side to the Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburg in the two United States premieres that this company from Russia presented on Tuesday night.

title: The Last Gasp For the American Living Room
description: WITH the nonchalance of Zeus and Hera leaning over the balcony of Olympus, Chris and Vivian Tai, two prospective house buyers visiting a model home in Mount Kisco, N.Y., peered down from a landing and hurled a few thunderbolts at the living room below.

title: Angola Says It Will Abandon Treaty With Rebels
description: In a further sign of the deterioration of peace efforts in Angola, a high-level Government official said today that the ruling party would abandon a four-year-old peace treaty with mainstream rebels and deal only with a splinter group.

title: Sports of The Times; One Empty Envelope, One Ex-Jet
description: ONE had not been a quarterback for four years, the other was out of football during the 1996 season after the Jets released him. Their combined ages total 80, but Steve DeBerg and Bubby Brister each is now a fallen starter away from being the opposing quarterbacks in Super Bowl XXXIII.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAPELL, KATE
description: NAPELL-Kate. On January 24, 1999 in Oakland, CA. Born New York City, 1906. Graduated Sargent School, Boston University. Resident Walnut Creek and Oakland. Beloved mother of Herb and David Napell; mother-in-law of Sondra Napell and Elsie Napell; grandmother of Bruce Napell, Lisa Dicksteen, Andrew Napell, Odette Walsh, Adam Napell, Michael Napell. Great-grandmother of Isaac and Tova Napell, Jordan Dicksteen, Colton, Brody and Shayna Walsh, and Harrison Napell. Sister (twin) of Revy Levine and Judy Stein. Funeral was January 27, Rolling Hills Memorial Park, Richmond, CA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRY, ROGER
description: PERRY-Roger. Age 70. Died at his home in Rye, NY, on January 26, 1999. He was educated in the New Rochelle public schools, at Harvard College, and Yale Law School. After his early retirement from the practice of international law in 1975, he managed real estate designed by his late father, architect Lee Perry of New Rochelle, and devoted himself to many organizations reflecting his lifelong interest in the oceans and the environment. He served on the boards of Bermuda Biological Station for Research, Organization for Tropical Studies, Israel Oceanographic and Limnological Research, ACCION, Nature Conservancy, and Planned Parenthood. He also served on the Rye City Boat Basin Commission and the Zoning Board of Appeals in his home community of Rye. Known and loved by many for his quick wit and sense of humor, Mr. Perry enjoyed birding, skiing, and sailing his small boat on Long Island Sound. He is survived by his wife Isobel, his sister Ellen Perry Berkeley of Shaftsbury, Vermont, and children Roy (& Gigi) Perry of Bryn Mawr, Lisa (and David) Hellerstein of Larchmont and Amy Perry (and Josh) Basseches of Quincy, MA., and grandchildren Alex & Leah; Sarah, Ben & Jason; and Jake and Sophie. Memorial contributions may be sent to Planned Parenthood, Hudson Peconic, 11 Skyline Drive, Hawthorne, New York 10532, or Nature Conservancy, 415 Moger Avenue, Mount Kisco, New York 10549. A memorial service will be held at the Friends' Meeting House, Purchase Street, Purchase, New York at 7PM on Saturday, January 30.

title: Giuliani Proposes Tough Law on 'Dangerous' Dogs, Angering Owners
description: The Giuliani administration has trained its quality-of-life sights on the city's dogs with a bill that would increase fines for harboring dogs deemed to be dangerous, deny dogs any consideration for being provoked into barking or biting, and require the owners of pit bulls to obtain $100,000 in liability insurance before being granted a dog license.

title: Hard Hitter With Clout Left
description: The day before he left Denver for Super Bowl XXXIII, Steve Atwater lounged on the carpet at home with his sons A. J., 6; DiAndre, 4, and Paris, 2. Fun time, a frequent time, was about to begin. Time for Dad to spout stories about his biggest football hits once again.

title: An Ordeal for Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Bryn Jones, 38, Musician Known as Muslimgauze
description: Bryn Jones, who recorded dozens of CD's of experimental music under the name Muslimgauze, died on Jan. 14 in Manchester, England. He was 38.

title: CD-ROManticism and Computer Classicism
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGAN, FRED
description: MORGAN-Fred. Beloved and devoted husband for 45 years to the love of his life, his wife Catheryne. He was the most caring and loving brother of Elaine Herta Klein, the admired uncle of Ingrid, David, Tony, Michael, Matthew and Lance. Fred is a survivor of the Holocaust and Dachau Concentration Camp. He was a pioneer of ''The Fashion Watch'' in America, earning the respect and friendship of the Trade. The funeral service will be held at ''The Riverside'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave., Thursday, 12:15 PM. His warmth and friendship will be sadly missed by everyone who knew and loved him.

title: Flush With Cash, Harvard Is Planning Up to $200 Million for Science
description: Flush with billions of dollars from its capital campaign and a flourishing endowment, Harvard University plans to pump as much as $200 million over the next five years into new science programs, including a new center on the sizzling field of genes and how they work, a Harvard dean said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACK, HELEN
description: MACK-Helen, 97. Died peacefully at home January 27, 1999. Beloved sister of the late Beatrice M. Goldberg. Loving aunt of Alan Mack and Jack Goldberg. Devoted great and great-great aunt.

title: Elgar, Beethoven and a 'Dance Mix'
description: The players of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra earned their keep on Monday evening, when David Zinman led them in a long, demanding program at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Zinman, the orchestra's music director emeritus -- Yuri Temirkanov takes over as music director next season -- led a conventional first half that consisted of Elgar's blustery ''Cockaigne'' Overture and the Beethoven Third Piano Concerto.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS 2.85 PERCENT. Coffee declined to a three-month low as Brazilian roasters urged the Government to sell stockpiles to ease shortages. Coffee for March delivery fell 3.05 cents, to $1.038 a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENBERG, REGGIE
description: GOLDENBERG-Reggie. Thank you for blessing us with the sunshine and joy of your friendship. You'll always be with us. Bev and Stan

title: Did Briton, Wielding Sibelius, Audition For a Job?
description: It was hard not to treat the English conductor Simon Rattle's concert with the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night as a tryout for the job of music director, to replace Wolfgang Sawallisch, who is to retire.

title: Thinking of Now and Later, Clinton Defense Seems to Split
description: President Clinton's defenders took seemingly contradictory positions today, demanding a rapid end to the President's impeachment trial while insisting that they would need an extended period of legal fact-finding to respond to any new information produced by the witnesses approved by the Senate.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERLBINDER, ARNOLD
description: PERLBINDER-Arnold. January 28, 1994. In death as in life, we are surrounded by his love. Perlbinder Famil

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEYSAR, FRANKLIN
description: KEYSAR - Franklin. Broadway production stage manager, on January 25, 1999 of liver cancer. Born in Warren, New Hampshire January 22, 1939. Survived by his mother Bertha Keysar & three brothers, Philip, Donald, & Gary, three sisters, Phyllis, Colby-Mudgett, & Virginia Keysar. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, January 31, 1PM at Park Avenue United Methodist Church, 106 E. 86 Street. Donations may be made to Broadway Cares/EFA or the Park Avenue United Methodist Church.

title: Operating Profit Down at DuPont
description: DuPont, the largest United States chemical company, said today that operating profits fell a less-than-expected 9 percent in the fourth quarter as declining costs and rising white pigment sales partly offset lower prices for fibers and chemicals.

title: Cardiff Journal; Mr., Make No Mistake, This Mrs. Is Decidedly Ms.
description: Liz Shankland, a 35-year-old public relations executive here, was thrilled to marry her longtime love, Gerald Toms, last November. But she was not thrilled when people started to call her by the name of a person she does not believe exists.

title: G.E.'s Comments on Disposal of PCB's Draw Objections
description: To many people in the Hudson Valley, the scenario is familiar: A stain of PCB's, toxic industrial chemicals, lies buried along the river. Environmental officials and residents are eager to dig it up, and General Electric presses to let the contaminants stay where they are.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Jan. 18 about Sam L. Ginn, chairman and chief executive of Airtouch Communications, misstated his holdings of stock and options and their value under Vodaphone P.L.C. Group's $97-a-share deal to buy the company. Airtouch's last proxy statement shows that Mr. Ginn owns 490,790 shares, worth $47.6 million -- not 1.55 million shares, worth $150 million. Mr. Ginn also has 2.61 million options, worth $178.3 million -- not 1.75 million options, worth $170 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURBIN, ELIZABETH
description: DURBIN-Elizabeth. 62. Of NYC and Shelter Island. Suddenly, on January 25. Beloved wife of Seymour Weissman. Loving grandmother of Zachary, Vanessa, Hannah, Jenna, Kyle, Laura and Nicholas, stepmother of Judy, Eric, David and Adam. Cherished daughter of Marjorie. Sister of Jocelyn and Geoffrey. Courageously outspoken in defense of the vulnerable, humanist, Professor of Economics at NYU's Wagner Graduate School of Public Service for nearly 30 years. She was a devoted friend, colleague and teacher to many, and a caring, compassionate and generous person. She will be missed by all who knew her. Services on Friday, January 29th, 12 noon at ''The Riverside'' West 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations to Shelter Island Senior Council, Shelter Island, New York 11964.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DONSKY, MARILYN
description: DONSKY-Marilyn Your love and spirit lingers with us from day to day. Happy Birthday, Dear One. Mom, Dad, Lauren, Eric, Carly and Jared

title: Assembly to Subpoena Former Pataki Appointee
description: State Assembly leaders have decided to subpoena the Governor's former appointee to the School Construction Authority in an attempt to force him to testify at a hearing on construction problems at New York City schools, an aide to the chairman of the Assembly Education Committee said yesterday.

title: Promoting Light, Art and Brooklyn
description: TWO years ago, when Arnold Lehman left Baltimore to become the director of the Brooklyn Museum of Art, he and his wife, Pamela, knew exactly what kind of home they wanted.

title: Lawmaker Says Americorps Workers Can Help With Census
description: To help count Americans for the 2000 census, a House Republican leader said today that he would call on volunteers from Americorps, the national service program that, as a favorite of President Clinton, House Republicans have tried to eliminate.

title: The Delicate Voice of a Sensual Spirit
description: At the start of her program with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, singing Ravel's ''Three Mallarme Poems,'' Anne Sofie von Otter was soft enough to suggest a disembodied spirit, hovering in the distance, and at the same time soft enough to be the voice coming from the head on the next pillow. Ravel's music, simultaneously so chaste and so sensual, could not have been better done.

title: Straying Fiscal Conservative Returns to His Roots
description: In presenting a spartan budget, Gov. George E. Pataki sought today to reclaim his reputation as an unwavering fiscal conservative and to expunge the memories of a spending surge during his re-election campaign that caused some of his most faithful supporters to grouse that he was as eager to sign checks as any old Democrat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FYBISH, PEGGY R.
description: FYBISH-Peggy R. On January 26, 1999. Beloved wife of Stephen Fybish, dearly loved mother of Emily Prager and Nora Elcar, cherished grandmother of Lulu Prager. Memorial Service of Fond Remembrance on Friday, January 29th at 11AM, at Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street, Manhattan.

title: The 3X Credit Card
description: SOMETIME in 1995, Jack Nicholson sat down to dinner with a friend, Alan Finkelstein. At the end of the meal, when the check came, Mr. Nicholson took out two cards -- a credit card and a card-size magnifying glass to read the figures on the bottom line. Mr. Finkelstein, an inventor, saw an opportunity to combine the two, and the Lenscard, the perfect innovation for a prosperous and increasingly aged America, was born.

title: Buildings, And Trees Take Shape
description: Images of Architecture

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULMAN, IDA
description: SCHULMAN-Ida. Peacefully on January 27, 1999. Beloved mother of Nelly Salomon. Adored grandmother of Philippe Marc Salomon. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made in Ida's memory to the Jewish Home & Hospital, The Ethics Committee, 120 West 106th Street, NYC 10025. Services to be held privately.

title: THE PRESIDENT'S TRIAL: THE SCHEDULE
description: DEPOSITIONS

title: MEDPARTNERS AGREES TO SELL DOCTOR-MANAGEMENT UNIT
description: Medpartners Inc., working to transform itself from the largest United States manager of group medical practices to a drug distributor, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its hospital-based physician-management unit for $335 million to a group of private investors. Medpartners said it would sell Team Health, the provider of billing and payroll services to radiologists and emergency room doctors at 385 hospitals in 31 states, to Madison Dearborn Partners, Cornerstone Equity Investors L.L.C., Beecken Petty & Company and the management of Team Health. Medpartners will retain 7.3 percent ownership. Sale profits will be used to reduce the company's debt.

title: Earnings at Compaq Computer Set a Record
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter results reached a record and surpassed Wall Street estimates.

title: Skis. Poles. Palm Pilot.
description: Three cousins, an aunt and an uncle, two parents, two brothers, a girlfriend and myself. Our annual winter vacation in Utah had begun. By the time the last person arrived, every flat surface in the condo was buried in equipment -- but not by gloves and goggles as in years past.

title: Man Charged in Throat Slashings That Killed 2 Elderly People
description: Five days after setting up a task force to investigate two separate throat-slashing deaths in Orange since November, the Essex County Prosecutor today charged a 32-year-old man who lived near the elderly victims.

title: GARDEN Q. & A.
description: Winter ColorQ. In a memoir of growing up in England in the 1880's, there is a description of an early-blooming shrub with mauve and yellow blossoms that is called chimonanthus (wintersweet). Could you tell me if this plant is available in the United States and whether it would do well in central Connecticut?

title: Jordan's Next King
description: It was a moment of potentially great consequence in the Middle East. A week after returning home, King Hussein of Jordan unexpectedly flew back to the Mayo Clinic for treatment of a recurrence of cancer. Just before departing he overturned long-established succession plans and named his eldest son, Prince Abdullah, as Crown Prince and heir to the throne. The change relegated Prince Hassan, King Hussein's younger brother and longstanding heir apparent, to a lesser role and exposed a bitter family quarrel that could resurface after the King's death.

title: Highlights From the Governor's Spending Proposal
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's $72.66 billion spending proposal would increase the size of the state budget by 1.8 percent, or $1.3 billion, figures that include Federal aid for programs like Medicaid and welfare. The total derived from the state's own money would also increase by 1.8 percent, to $49.3 billion.

title: 2 Coke Bottlers In Japan Link
description: The Coca-Cola Company has taken another step in its push to consolidate bottling operations in its second-most-profitable market, with two Japanese bottlers saying they will cooperate on production as the soft-drink maker moves to cut costs.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Bad News for E-Mail Addicts: It's Play-by-Mail Scrabble
description: Until the world's dictionaries formally embrace ''E-mail,'' it may not be appropriate to use on a Scrabble board. But it is possible to use a Scrabble board in E-mail.

title: National News Briefs; Doles Buy Apartment Of Lewinsky's Mother
description: Bob and Elizabeth Dole are buying the next-door apartment in the Watergate complex that was occupied until recently by a young woman named Monica S. Lewinsky and her mother, Marcia Lewis, who rented it from the owner.

title: The Story the Pope Wants Told
description: When the Presidential sex scandal broke a year ago, I was in Havana for the visit of Pope John Paul II. I remember the reaction of many American journalists when they suddenly had to pack up and fly to Washington. An anchorman told me: ''History is being made here. But money will be made there. I suppose sooner or later we'll catch up with history.''

title: Mr. Pataki's Return to Austerity
description: After coasting to re-election last year, Gov. George Pataki has suddenly discovered that New York State is in a fiscal jam. Looming budget deficits, he declared yesterday, will require cuts in school aid, college tuition assistance and payments to hospitals, nursing homes and community health clinics -- not exactly the feel-good message he delivered a few months ago. Mr. Pataki's new $73 billion budget penalizes New York City, reversing his pledge to bring the city up to its fair share of state school aid. It also fails generally to address the underlying causes of the state's problems, which are of Mr. Pataki's own making.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, PAUL STUART
description: KAPLAN-Paul Stuart, 38. On January 24, 1999. A brilliantly creative and sensitive young man. Beloved son of George and late Sandra Kaplan, brother to Rena, Ellen, and Dana. Devoted husband & father. Service February 6, 12-2 at Ethical Humanist Society, Garden City, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIPLEY, LINWOOD PARKS
description: SHIPLEY-Linwood Parks. Of Hightstown, New Jersey. Formerly of Summit, N.J. On January 26, 1999. Husband of the late Emily Shipley (nee Herzog). Father of L. Parks Shipley, Jr. of Saint Michaels, MD., Frederick H. Shipley of Ripley, W.VA., Walter V. Shipley of Summit, N.J. and Emily Shipley Davis of Ottowa, Canada. Also survived by ten grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. A funeral service will be held on Saturday, January 30, 1999 at 11AM from Central Presbyterian Church, Summit, N.J. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name may be made to Young Life, Up With People or The American Cancer Society.

title: Of Infidelity and the Original Sin
description: Ballet British Columbia, an adventurous Canadian troupe from Vancouver, came to the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night with four works rich in dramatic implications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, CATHRYN V. (NEE MCCARTHY)
description: RYAN-Cathryn V. (nee McCarthy). On January 26, 1999. Beloved wife of the late William. Devoted mother of Mary, Kathleen Montgomery, and the late Peggy. Also survived by three grandchildren and one great grandchild. Reposing at Quinn-Fogarty Funeral Home, 162-14 Sanford Ave., Flushing, NY. Funeral mass Friday, 9:30 AM, St. Michael's RC Church. Visitation Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9:30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAVON, MURRAY
description: NAVON-Murray. Dearest husband of Renee, loving father of Sheri (Paul) Farber, Dr. Jeffrey (Vicki), Dr. Richard (Shari), and Steven, cherished grandfather of six; beloved brother of H.J. and Barbara of FL. Services today, 12 noon at Congregation Beth Sholom, 390 Broadway, Lawrence, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEALLY, PHILIP J.
description: KENNEALLY-Philip J. Of Los Angeles, Chicago and New York City. WWII Veteran and veteran actor of stage, film and television, 1934 Welter Weight Golden Glove Champion and long time member of the Actors Studio, died December 14, 1998, at Cedars Sinai Medical Center, Beverly Hills, CA after a long illness. He is survived by Jerri (nee Josephine Balistreri), his devoted wife of 44 years. A Funeral Service was held in Chicago and a Memorial Mass was held in Los Angeles.

title: The Eagles Look Best
description: Boston's midwinter salute to college hockey, the Beanpot Tournament, starts Monday with the opening doubleheader at the Fleet Center. Harvard faces Northeastern in the 6 P.M. game, followed by Boston College and Boston University at 8 P.M.

title: Indonesia Says It's Ready to Give Independence to East Timorese
description: Indonesia said today that it was willing to grant independence to the troubled province of East Timor if a majority of islanders reject an offer of more limited autonomy.

title: Turmoil Fazes Philip Morris Only a Bit as Revenue Rises
description: Despite domestic price increases for cigarettes and weaker demand from overseas, revenue at the Philip Morris Companies increased 6.4 percent and underlying earnings rose 9 percent in the fourth quarter of last year, the company reported yesterday. Full-year earnings for 1998 grew by 8.9 percent, to $3.17 a share.

title: BORDERS SHARES FALL NEARLY 15% AT NEWS OF SLOW SALES
description: Shares of Borders Group Inc. tumbled almost 15 percent yesterday after the company issued its second profit warning this month, blaming winter storms for hurting January sales. Borders now expects to earn $1.11 to $1.13 a share for the fiscal year ended Jan. 24, down from the $1.14 to $1.18 range expected just a few weeks ago. Before Borders started guiding analysts down, Wall Street's average estimate was $1.22 a share, according to the First Call Corporation. Borders, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., will report earnings on March 8. Shares of Borders fell $3.125 yesterday, to $17.125.

title: Giuliani Wants More Police
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will propose a budget that includes money for hiring 1,000 new police officers, city officials said. Page B1.

title: Working (Too) Hard for Less; A Worthy Sacrifice
description: To the Editor:

title: To Err Really Is Human, DNA Analysis Shows
description: Biologists analyzing human genetic data in the DNA data banks have given fresh meaning to the saying that no one is perfect. Harmful mutations have accumulated so fast in the human genome, according to a new study, that the immediate question is why the human species has not become extinct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSSE, GEORGE L.
description: MOSSE-George L. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum mourns the death of George L. Mosse, the Museum's first J.B. and Maurice C. Shapiro Senior Scholar in Residence. A pioneering Holocaust scholar and remarkable educator, his generosity as a colleague, teacher, and mentor will be deeply missed. Miles Lerman Chairperson, United States Holocaust Memorial Council Ruth B. Mandel, Vice Chairperson Sara J. Bloomfield Acting Director, United States Holocaust Memoral Museum

title: INSIDE
description: The Harsh Aftermath Of Colombia Earthquakes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSCHILD, ZELDA
description: ROTHSCHILD-Zelda. We mourn the loss of a dear friend who deeply cared about the State of Israel and the future of its children. As a founder of the hospital, together with her husband Arthur, she made a vital difference to the people of Jerusalem and throughout Israel. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President

title: Pataki Presents A Tight Budget, Despite Surplus
description: After a two-year detour into government largess, Gov. George E. Pataki today returned to the conservative path of his early years, proposing a $72.66 billion state budget with substantial cuts in health care and education. He proposed eliminating programs aimed at expanding prekindergarten classes and lowering class sizes.

title: Fatal Crash Means Return To Grieving for L.I. School
description: It happened again Tuesday night. A car carrying two sisters and a friend, all students at Sachem High School, crashed into an oncoming pickup on Route 25 in nearby Commack. One of the girls died, the fifth student to be killed in a traffic wreck in less than a year.

title: Better Way of Tracking Criminals on the Run
description: A new technology that uses Global Positioning Systems could make it easier to track criminals who escape from their own homes and jobs. The technology, called the Satellite Monitoring and Remote Tracking System (Smart), is a high-tech twist on the ankle bracelets worn by criminals sentenced to home arrest and work release. Those ankle bracelets use radio waves to warn the authorities when a criminal on parole or sentenced to home detention leaves his assigned premises.

title: When Hot Air Is What You Need
description: For anyone who is wary of electric heaters, there's good news: A new generation of space heaters is safer and more efficient than ever. Before you invest in one, however, it's important to be realistic. A space heater will not warm an entire house; it will not necessarily warm an entire room, unless the room is very small, though manufacturers sometimes claim that their products will heat spaces as large as 12 by 18 feet. And to heat even a small room may take time.

title: A 10-Disk Survey With an Emphasis on Historical Contexts
description: HISTORY THROUGH ART

title: In High-Profile Race of Maybes, Add Pirro
description: ''IF I run,'' said Jeanine Pirro, ''the race will be about me.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDLANDER, SAM
description: FRIEDLANDER-Sam. July 2, 1911-January 28, 1995. Remembered always. Ruth

title: Contractor for a Bridge Job Is Faulted for Safety History
description: In a case that he said pointed up a need to revise state procurement policies, Mark Green, the New York City Public Advocate, said yesterday that a company with a long history of safety violations had been awarded a $33.7 million contract to paint the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, RUTH
description: GOLDBERG-Ruth. Loving and loved wife of the late Bernard Goldberg. Mother of Barbara and Herman Engelberg, and Richard Goldberg. Grandmother of Larry and Judy Engelberg, Wendy Engelberg, Amy & Joseph Cigliano, Suzanne Goldberg, and Paula Ettelbrick and Andrew Goldberg, great-grandmother of Daniel, Rebecca, Rachel and Isaac Engelberg, and Adam Ettelbrick, sister of Sidney and Terri and Marvin and Elaine Goldstein and Sylvia Levine. A warm, engaging and generous spirit and keen and creative intellect, who with gracious elegance and humor indelibly enriched the lives of her family and friends. Services on Thursday, January 28th, 11:30 A.M., at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, TIBY KOCH
description: KAPLAN-Tiby Koch. Beloved mother of Victoria Heilweil and Donald Koch, devoted grandmother of six, adored sister and aunt.

title: A Rare Tiger On the Loose Is Shot to Death
description: A rare Siberian tiger that escaped into a densely wooded area in Jackson Township, N.J., was shot dead last night after tranquilizer darts apparently failed to subdue the animal, the police said.

title: Pentagon Seeks Command For Emergencies in the U.S.
description: The Pentagon has decided to ask President Clinton for the power to appoint a military leader for the continental United States because of what it sees as a growing threat of major terrorist strikes on American soil, Defense Department officials say.

title: Screening Screenplays
description: To the Editor:

title: Sierra Takes Major Step And Recalls Football Game
description: Sierra Sports last week issued a recall of its new PC game, NFL Pro Football '99, because of several dozen software glitches that seriously hampered play. Bugs are common in new software, of course, and pity the poor consumer who fails to check for updates. But until recently, Sierra's action of removing a game from store shelves nationwide and offering consumers a full refund was unheard of.

title: BB&T TO GET FIRST CITIZENS IN $125.9 MILLION STOCK SWAP
description: The BB&T Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the First Citizens Corporation in a stock swap valued at $125.9 million. First Citizens shareholders will receive 1.0789 BB&T shares, worth $40.53 based on BB&T's closing price on Jan. 25. First Citizens' shares rose $8.25, or 27 percent, to $38.375, in response to news of the deal, while BB&T shares fell $1.25, to $37.1875. First Citizens, based in Newman, Ga., has $421 million in assets and operates 13 branch offices and one mortgage loan office in metropolitan Atlanta. BB&T, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., has $35 billion in assets and 534 branches in North and South Carolina, Virginia, Maryland and Washington.

title: Strawberry Invited To Spring Training
description: The Yankees have included outfielder Darryl Strawberry and pitcher Jeff Juden among the 18 nonroster players invited to spring training next month.

title: Clinton Scandal Is No Watergate
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Panel Passes Bill to Increase Military Pay and Benefits
description: Challenging the Clinton Administration in a bidding war to give more money to the armed forces, a Senate committee quickly approved a bill today to raise military pay and increase benefits.

title: Clouds Over Future of an Alcoholism Treatment Center
description: Amid a swirl of court papers and bitter feelings, the future of the Smithers Alcoholism Treatment and Training Center, a Manhattan institution with a celebrity-studded patient roster, is in doubt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONAUER, MILTON HERBERT
description: ARONAUER-Milton Herbert. Age 84. Died January 26th, 1999. His sister Charlotte, brother Irwin and family remember him with love.

title: Rangers Enjoy Graves's Turnaround
description: Every Canadian boy, Adam Graves said, dreams of playing on the same line with Wayne Gretzky. Graves recalled his first chance at training camp with Team Canada before the 1996 World Cup. With Mark Messier on right wing and Gretzky at center, Graves passed the puck to the Great One from the left wing.

title: Blue Chips Decline 124.35 In a Profit-Taking Session
description: Stocks fell for the first time in three sessions yesterday as investors took profits before Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve.

title: Taiwan's Human-Friendly Technology : Putting People First
description: TAIPEI  The powerful organization that steered Taiwan to dominate global computer production has now set its sights on human-friendly technology.

title: Trial Begins for 2d Suspect in Slaying of Manhattan Teacher
description: The trial of a second man accused of torturing and murdering Jonathan M. Levin, a popular public high school English teacher, opened yesterday with the defense saying that prosecutors cannot link the defendant in any way to the Upper West Side slaying.

title: Let Us Play: Tinder to Fuel Musical Sparks
description: THE first kind of play is the discovery of rules and effects.

title: New Product From I.B.M.
description: I.B.M. said today that it would introduce two notebook personal computer models with a radio system to guard against theft. I.B.M.'s Thinkpad 770Z and 600E notebooks feature radio-frequency identification tags that set off alarms if the PC's are taken from the office. The tags carry information about the type of notebook and software loaded on it so that businesses can use a special scanner to take inventory. Last year, $8 billion worth of computers were stolen, I.B.M. said. It first introduced the radio system, called Asset ID, for desktop PC's in October.

title: Clinton Scandal Is No Watergate
description: To the Editor:

title: New President Is Selected by BankAmerica
description: The BankAmerica Corporation today named Kenneth D. Lewis president, as the leadership of the old Nationsbank consolidates power after its merger with BankAmerica last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPPAS, ANDREW C.
description: PAPPAS-Andrew C. On January 27, 1999. Musician, entrepreneur, and social philosopher. Esteemed brother and President Emeritus of Estia-Pindus Chapter of AHEPA. Fiance and mentor of Maria Fiore. Beloved son of Helen and Chris. Beloved brother of Penny and Alekos. Devoted uncle of Artemis and Christina. Reposing at Thomas M. Quinn & Sons, Inc. Funeral Home, 35-20 Broadway, Long Island City, NY. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9:30. Funeral service is on Saturday, 11 A.M., St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church, Bayside. Interment Flushing Cemetery.

title: Metro Business; Caldor Rejects Asset Bid
description: The Caldor Corporation and its creditors have turned down as inadequate a $425 million bid for the company's assets, a lawyer for Caldor said.

title: Police Say They Seized 2,600 Pounds of Cocaine
description: The State Police said yesterday that they had arrested six drug traffickers and seized a shipment of more than 2,600 pounds of cocaine packed in boxes labeled ''frozen cauliflower.''

title: Working (Too) Hard for Less
description: To the Editor:

title: Lessons on the Masterworks and the Mundane
description: WALKING through a gallery, you notice a dark painting of a Biblical scene executed with a touch of gore. Is it by Caravaggio or Rubens? A nearby tour guide mentions the word modernist. Could she have meant Mannerist instead? And what is the difference between Hellenic and Hellenistic and why can't you remember?

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When I used to call a parent 25 years ago there was usually a big apology. 'I'm sorry, I didn't know they were sick, I'll come and get them.' You could feel that guilt coming through. Whereas now, the pressures are otherwise: 'Is this really important? Do I have to leave work?' ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINK, ELEANOR IRENE HIGGINS
description: LINK-Eleanor Irene Higgins, 83, of Spring Lake, N.J. Formerly of New York, New York, and Tenafly, N.J. Died Sunday, January 24, 1999 at her home. Mrs. Link was pre-deceased by her husband George ''Judge'' Link, who died in 1980. She was also pre-deceased by her sisters Anne Higgins and Catherine Higgins. Prior to retiring in the late 1950's, Mrs. Link was a Registered Nurse working in hospitals and private practice in New York City. She was a former consultant to NIAS Foundation, a charitable foundation. For eighteen years she was Chairperson of George Link Jr. Foundation, Inc., a charitable foundation which was founded by and named for her late husband. As Chairperson, she exercised general supervisory authority over the affairs and policies of the Foundation and presided at all meetings of the Board of Directors. Through her leadership and professional guidance, the Foundation provided needed funds for organizations in the fields of medicine, religion, education and humanities. She was honored by several institutions for her philanthropic support. Funeral services Thursday, 8:30AM from O'Brien Funeral Home, Highway 35, Wall, N.J. followed by a 9:30AM Mass of Christian Burial in St. Mark's R.C. Church in Sea Girt, NJ. Entombment to follow in the Cemetery of the Ascension, Monsey, New York. Visitation on Wednesday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM. Donations to Rosary Hill Home, C/O Sister Miriam, O.F., 600 Linda Avenue, Hawthorne, N.Y. 10532.

title: The Roots Of Corruption
description: Q. I use America Online and cannot open many E-mail attachments. I often see: ''This is not a valid WIN32 Apps.'' Why?

title: Doner and Ikon Part Company
description: Doner in Southfield, Mich., said yesterday that it had resigned the account of Ikon Office Solutions, which the agency has handled since summer 1996. However, a spokesman at Ikon described the decision as ''a mutual agreement.''

title: Body of a New Jersey Model Is Found in a Swamp in Greece
description: A former model who had become something of a local celebrity here was found dead and dismembered in a swamp in Greece on Wednesday, and the Greek man she left New Jersey to live with was charged with her death.

title: Working (Too) Hard for Less; Employers' Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Scandal Is No Watergate
description: To the Editor:

title: Renting? Pay Here, And Here, And Here
description: STEVEN AHN and his housemate, Pekka Kauranen, didn't expect to spend much time hunting for a place to rent. But as they went from open house to open house, their hopes began to dim. ''Everyone was there before us, in hot pursuit,'' Mr. Ahn said.

title: Partisan Parade in the Capitol Corridors
description: In a way, the two impeach ment court votes footnotes in history -- offered the only moment's peace in an otherwise frenetic day in President Clinton's trial.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- Trying to Score Big in 'Ad Bowl'; Companies Jostle to Reach Consumers on Super Sunday
description: When 130 million or so viewers tune in on Sunday for Super Bowl XXXIII, they will watch first-time enthusiasm confront longtime experience, with players new to the big game pitted against those who have learned the hard way what it takes to win.

title: Jordan's Suddenly Uncertain Future
description: On the face of it, the decision by King Hussein of Jordan to dismiss his brother, Crown Prince Hassan, as heir to the throne and replace him with the King's oldest son seems meant to put the royal house in order. But the ouster of Prince Hassan on Friday, after 34 years of loyal service as the King's understudy and closest confidant, will have critical implications for the legitimacy of the Hashemite dynasty and its long-term stability of the Jordanian monarchy.

title: Airtouch Names Campbell Mithun
description: Airtouch Cellular has named Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis to handle the creative portion of its account, which had been divided among several agencies. Billings were estimated at $100 million.

title: Yahoo Said to Be Buying Geocities in Union of Top Sites
description: In a move meant to defend its position as the world's leading site on the Internet, Yahoo Inc. has agreed to buy Geocities, another popular site, financial executives briefed on the deal said last night.

title: Senate Is Told an Accord Is Near In Holbrooke Lobbying Inquiry
description: The Administration has notified members of the Senate that Richard C. Holbrooke is close to a deal with the Justice Department to settle conflict-of-interest allegations, and that his nomination as chief American delegate to the United Nations is likely to be sent to the Senate within days for confirmation, Government officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCHENBAUM, ZELDA CELIA. (NEE ROSENBLUM)
description: KIRSCHENBAUM - Zelda Celia. (nee Rosenblum) November 4, 1899-January 26, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Gabriel Kirschenbaum. Devoted mother of Deby Salama and Dr. J. Michael Kirschenbaum (Paulenne). Cherished grandmother of Michael Foster Shapiro (Stacey) and Sasha Aelise Salama, Lisa, Nina and Jill Kirschenbaum. Died peacefully at her home in Pembroke Pines, Fla. Affectionately known as Cele, she was a Hunter college graduate and at one time danced with Martha Graham's troupe. Taught English and Physical Education at Seward Park High School in NYC.

title: Racing's Brains: Handling the Bets at Tracks and Elsewhere
description: AND they're off!

title: Unified Phone Rate, Wired and Wireless
description: AT&T said it would offer long-distance and wireless service at a single rate of 10 cents a minute on a single bill, removing the price distinction between wireless and traditional phone calls for the first time.

title: Relationships and E-Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Follow the Soaps By Watching a P.D.A.
description: One downside of always being on the go is that it's tough to follow the latest murder plots, marital affairs or the sudden appearance of an evil twin. No, not the normal doings in your office -- we're talking about television soap operas, and the fans who really want to keep track of each episode's events. Now, they can do so through their handheld computers.

title: Toward a Table Etiquette Upgrade
description: IF I had not viewed the wreckage my three brothers routinely created in restaurants when we were little, I would probably not be so concerned about my own children's table manners.

title: MICROSOFT TO INVEST IN DUTCH CABLE-TELEVISION COMPANY
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it would invest $300 million in United Pan-Europe Communications N.V., the largest Dutch cable-television company, to push high-speed Internet access in Europe. The investment will be made through U.P.C.'s initial public offering, where it will sell as much as $1.25 billion in shares, representing about a third of the company. Microsoft will get a 7 percent to 8 percent stake. U.P.C and Microsoft will also develop digital video and Internet-based telephone services in Europe.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Injury-Depleted UConn Has Reason to Celebrate
description: When the final buzzer sounded with Rutgers desperately trying to get one more shot off, the University of Connecticut players began to celebrate, dancing on the floor of the Louis Brown Athletic Center as if they owned the place. And after this performance, it was clear they still do.

title: Introduction to the Louvre Is Mixed With Fun and Games
description: THE LOUVRE MUSEUM

title: Jacques Lecoq, Director, 77; A Master Mime
description: Jacques Lecoq, a mime, theater director and influential teacher, died on Jan. 19 at a hospital in Paris. He was 77 and lived in Paris.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAVERMAN, HARRIS
description: BRAVERMAN-Harris. Beloved husband of Ettie and father of Roslyn and Edward. Father-in-law of Myra. Beloved brother of Hannah and Fanny and sister-in-law Peggy. Beloved grandfather of 11 grandchildren and seven great grandchildren. Funeral service today, 12 Noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St, New York, NY. Donations may be made to the Hebrew Home for the Aged, 5901 Palisade Ave., Riverdale, New York 10471.

title: Knee Injury Shelves Kittles for a Month
description: The suggestion came as an afterthought. The Nets' Kerry Kittles was going to the hospital to have a magnetic resonance imaging test taken on his back yesterday afternoon, and Coach John Calipari told the team trainer, Ted Arzonico, to have the doctors look at his knee as well.

title: Lost in Cyberspace: How to Hold On to Your Address
description: I TOOK the existence of E-mail and my 6-year-old E-mail address for granted until I found out last month ago that my Internet service provider was discontinuing my address.

title: Essay; School for Scandal
description: Americans are afflicted with the notion that we should be embarrassed by the Clinton Impeachment Follies. We think that sophisticated Europe is going tut-tut at our seeming constitutional instability and tsk-tsk at our obsession with what Dale Bumpers brushed off as a mere ''sex scandal.''

title: Economic Scene; It's hard to tell who won in the High Court local phone ruling.
description: JUDGING from reactions, it was hard to figure out exactly who won this week's decision by the Supreme Court to uphold Federal rules designed to open up the local telephone market to competition.

title: Keeping Tabs on Flu Outbreaks
description: SICK of all those persistent warnings about viruses on line? Here's one that is certified by bona fide medical doctors: the on-line Flu-o-Meter, which indicates the prevalence of influenza state by state.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Working (Too) Hard for Less; Shaky Union Connection
description: To the Editor:

title: Replaying The Days Of Black Vaudeville
description: Song, dance, comedy, eloquent prose and fine music are mingled with nostalgia, bitterness and sadness in ''Rollin' on the T.O.B.A.,'' the potent and instructive entertainment that opened last night at the 47th Street Theater.

title: Women's Work: Still Never Done
description: Grace Santos (played by Rosie Perez, above) has it all: marriage, baby, high-powered job and high-powered headaches. In ''The 24-Hour Woman,'' the new film from Nancy Savoca that opens today and opened ''The Feminine Eye: Twenty Years of Women's Cinema'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Rose Cinema, Grace's balancing act yields a homespun satire full of talking points about work and parenthood in the 1990's.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PFIZER INC., -- New York, the maker of the anti-impotence pill Viagra, said it would hold a vote in April that could authorize a 3-for-1 stock split.

title: Fluffs, Tremors and Skeletal Noises
description: The German electronic-music composer Carsten Nicolai -- known as Noto -- makes you think about the future of music, and when he performed his work at Tonic with the disk jockey Craig I-Sound on Wednesday night, it was easy to feel that he was part of a much larger societal movement.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD TO SELL NEW ORACLE COMPUTER SYSTEM
description: The Oracle Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard company plan to announce today that Hewlett-Packard will become the first computer maker to sell the Oracle 8i Database Appliance, which includes both hardware and software.
