The system is intended to simplify the complexity of running corporate computers by hiding the operating system function and offering a computer that is tailored to a single application. Applications for the new system will range from Internet Web and mail servers to specific business applications such as accounting packages. Prices have not been set.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIPLEY, LINWOOD PARKS
description: SHIPLEY-Linwood Parks. Of Hightstown, New Jersey. Formerly of Summit, N.J. On January 26, 1999. Husband of the late Emily Shipley (nee Herzog). Father of L. Parks Shipley, Jr. of Saint Michaels, MD., Frederick H. Shipley of Ripley, W.VA., Walter V. Shipley of Summit, N.J. and Emily Shipley Davis of Ottowa, Canada. Also survived by ten grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. A funeral service will be held on Saturday, January 30, 1999 at 11AM from Central Presbyterian Church, Summit, N.J. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name may be made to Young Life, Up With People or The American Cancer Society.

title: Culver and Crunch Change Agencies
description: Two advertisers are changing agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, CHARLOTTE
description: PETERS-Charlotte. On January 27, 1999. Age 93. Beloved mother of Barbara and mother-in-law of Peter Rothholz. Loving grandmother of David, Tom and Julie Margules. Memorial services will be announced at a later date.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: A generation shaped by digital media presents fresh marketing challenges, a study finds.
description: TO effectively reach the youngest generation of Americans, whose lives are being shaped by digital media, marketers must deliver smarter, more sophisticated messages and build brands with them rather than for them, a new study by Saatchi & Saatchi suggests.

title: Series Trophy Goes To the Hall of Fame
description: Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman will present the team's 1998 World Series trophy to the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y., today.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about attacks on Christians in India misspelled the name of a state where attacks have occurred. It is Maharashtra, not Maharastra.

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile yesterday about Jeanine Pirro, the Westchester County district attorney, misspelled the surname of a former Chemung County district attorney. He is John O'Mara, not O'Hara.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCKINLEY, SELMA ANDERSON
description: McKINLEY-Selma Anderson. On this day, dearest Momma, we celebrate the many happy memories of your birthday celebrations. Skal!

title: Scientists Warn Against Ignoring Climate Change
description: The American Geophysical Union, the nation's most broadly based professional organization in earth and space science, said in an official policy statement yesterday that there was a ''compelling basis for legitimate public concern'' about human-induced climatic change.

title: Search for Punishment
description: Republicans are pushing for a resolution acknowledging that President Clinton committed perjury or obstructed justice, while Democrats are seeking a censure resolution.

title: U.S. Lawsuit Accuses Yankees of Bias
description: The Federal Government announced yesterday that it had filed a lawsuit charging that the New York Yankees and the City of New York discriminate against fans who have disabilities, especially those who use wheelchairs, because Yankee Stadium is so inaccessible to them.

title: 3 Days After Quake in Colombia, a Tapping in the Rubble Tells of Life
description: The Andalucia Apartments collapsed when the first powerful tremor hit here on Monday afternoon. But under tons of rubble where the five-story building once stood, someone was still alive today.

title: Residential Real Estate; 1924 Building Is Restored in Midtown
description: After a $3.5 million yearlong modernization and restoration program, a 75-year-old building at 40 West 55th Street in midtown Manhattan, used mainly for offices and clothing showrooms for the last three decades, has been returned to its original role as a rental apartment building.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GAYLE, MICHAEL
description: GAYLE-Michael. February 29, 1960-January 29, 1996. Our hearts still ache in silence and the secret tears still flow. What it means to lose you, only those who truly love you really know. Sadly missed by mother, Dolores; father, Dudley; sister, Andrea; wife, Sonia; son, Christopher; Gladstone, nieces and nephew.

title: Niagara Mohawk in Talks to Sell Nuclear Plant Near Syracuse
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, a large utility in upstate New York, is in discussions to sell its holdings in the troubled Nine Mile Point nuclear plant to the Amergen Energy Company, which last year bought the only functioning unit at Three Mile Island, the site of the nation's worst nuclear accident.

title: Metro Business; 2 Companies to Move Offices to Jersey City
description: Eight months after he began construction of an office tower on the Jersey City waterfront, the developer Richard S. LeFrak has lured two companies and almost 1,000 employees from Manhattan to the building.

title: Draw Districts Using Voter Rolls, Not the Census
description: To the Editor:

title: World Bank Cuts Off Loans to 2 Brazilian States
description: The World Bank today froze development loans to two Brazilian states that are locked in an economic war with the central Government.

title: Deregulation of Utilities Approved by Legislature
description: Both houses of the State Legislature approved a bill yesterday that would deregulate New Jersey's energy market and cut commercial and residential electricity rates by 10 percent over the next three years.

title: Behind Tragic Guises
description: In ''Julia Margaret Cameron's Women,'' an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, the world is all tragic women -- Ophelias, Echoes and Guineveres. But who were they really?

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVERDING, AUGUST
description: EVERDING-August. The Metroplitan Opera deeply mourns the death of August Everding, who created five of our most successful and acclaimed productions. His imaginative use of the Metropolitan's great stage, backed by a superlative mastery of modern stage techniques, brought vividly to life our new production of ''Tristan und Isolde'' for his 1971 debut. As well as a striking ''Lohengrin,'' he created productions which are still favorites of our audiences today, such as his magnificent ''Boris Godunov'' and ''Der Fliegende Hollaender.'' His much-admired production of Mussorgsky's ''Khovanshchina'' will be revived in March. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Gustava and his four sons. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: New Video Releases
description: There's Something About Mary

title: Making the Familiar Seem Strange
description: Like a visitor from another planet who has landed on Earth, the color photographs of Jan Staller mirror an urban landscape that is eerily, often spectacularly alien. Again and again he shows that the trappings and detritus of 20th-century life can be as mysterious as the glyphs of giant creatures and geometric patterns left on the desert floor in southern Peru by an obscure pre-Incan culture.

title: Why Do the Republicans Ignore Centrist Voters?; Flouting the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELSON, JEROME
description: SAMUELSON-Jerome. On January 28, 1999. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Loving father & fatherin-law of Paula & Dr. Salva Roga, Diane & Marvin Beck, and Susan Samuelson. Loving grandfather of Harold, Corey, and Felicia, and great grandfather of Gerald and Manny. A great lover of music and the arts, a raconteur and a writer of children's stories who will be missed by all. Funeral service on Sunday, 11:30 A.M., Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills, New York. Interment Beth David Cemetery.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Elkem Manganese Units To Be Sold to Eramet
description: Elkem A.S.A., a Norwegian maker of aluminum and alloys for the steel industry, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its manganese businesses to Eramet S.A. of France for 1.5 billion kroner ($201 million) to focus on other businesses.

title: G.O.P. TRIAL PLAN PASSES IN SENATE ALONG PARTY LINES
description: Closing ranks along party lines, Senate Republicans today forced through a plan to finish President Clinton's impeachment trial that opens the door for Monica S. Lewinsky, or her videotaped image, to appear before the Senate.

title: At UConn, He Spins, Sparkles, Scores
description: Coach Jim Calhoun smiled as he described the impact Khalid El-Amin has had on his Connecticut team since his arrival last season.

title: Sport's Future A Positive Force
description: Michael Grant, widely regarded as the world heavyweight champion-in-waiting, said he didn't bother to watch Mike Tyson's bout against Francois Botha two weeks ago.

title: CBS Granted More Tax Cuts to Stay Put
description: Six years after New York City granted CBS Inc. nearly $50 million in tax breaks to stay in Manhattan until the year 2008, the city has given it an additional $10 million in subsidies -- after being told the company was considering relocating to New Jersey.

title: Privacy Advocates Ask F.T.C. To Force Recall of Intel Chips
description: Privacy advocates who object to the Intel Corporation's plan to put identification numbers in its next generation of computer chips went to the Federal Trade Commission today to seek a recall of the Pentium III's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENKRANTZ, FRANCES
description: ROSENKRANTZ - Frances. On January 28, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Devoted sister-inlaw of Terry Slade. Loving mother of Roger and the late Josi. Dear sister of Sophie Bettoja. Adoring grandmother of Adam, Joshua and Kurt. Cherished aunt of Edward and Judy, Richard, Michael and Doren, Toni and Valerie, Esther, Miriam and Angelo, Bobbie and Marilyn, Joan, Ruth, Gloria and Lynn. Beloved cousin of Will and Bea Maslow, Bertha Maslow and Edith Lunn. Service Sunday 11AM, at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Meola and Lalas Are Traded Amid a MetroStars Shake-Up
description: A renovation is taking place on the MetroStars. After compiling losing records in their first three years in Major League Soccer, the MetroStars are determined to put together a competitive team in a knowledgeable and demanding soccer market.

title: Inspiration From India
description: Indian food is taking a turn in the spotlight as more and more chefs add Indian seasonings and techniques to their repertory. Here are a dozen restaurants with Indian and Indian fusion menus. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: H.I.V. Peril and Rising Drug Use
description: Phillip, a 41-year-old gay man in Atlanta, had always been scrupulously safe in his sexual practices until one night last October.

title: Why Do the Republicans Ignore Centrist Voters?; Jones and the I.R.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Library Treasures, Bound for Eternity
description: When is a book more than a book? Anytime it does its job, you might well answer. That is, when its contents awaken the mind with some combination of guidance, insight, knowledge and pleasure. But there are concrete ways that books can be more than books: when they combine aspects of painting, sculpture and architecture to become works of visual art.

title: Anchorwoman Wins $8.3 Million Over Sex Bias
description: Challenging the common television practice of choosing news anchors on the basis of their sex, a Federal jury awarded $8.3 million today to a Hartford anchorwoman who contended that she had lost her high-profile and high-paying job because she was a woman.

title: Why Do the Republicans Ignore Centrist Voters?; Finding a Scapegoat
description: To the Editor:

title: Genamerica Life to Become Pure Stockholder Company
description: The Genamerica Corporation, one of the first mutual life insurers to sell shares to the public under a hybrid structure two years ago, said yesterday that it was becoming a company owned completely by stockholders.

title: Award in Hoffman Suit
description: A judge awarded $1.5 million in punitive damages today to the actor Dustin Hoffman, doubling the amount Los Angeles Magazine must pay him for using a digitally altered photograph of him in a 1997 fashion article.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: For Rangers, Bruises And a Tough Defeat
description: From a Ranger perspective, tonight's conclusion was crushing, a 3-2 defeat on an overtime goal by the Carolina Hurricanes, a result that knocked the Rangers further back in the multiteam chase of the Eastern Conference playoff race. But for anyone who enjoys hockey for hockey's sake, this match was enthralling, as tense and tough as any in post-season play.

title: I.O.C. Drug Chief Calls for Shift in Bans
description: With international sports facing legal defeats and a lack of uniformity in doping sanctions, the drug chief of the International Olympic Committee has proposed a radical change in the way athletes are disciplined for using performance-enhancing substances.

title: Calipari Polishes His Pitch and Goes After Burrell
description: John Calipari refers to the eight years he spent coaching at the University of Massachusetts as his past life. On Friday afternoon, however, the Nets' coach will revisit that life and return to the role of the clever recruiter one more time.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Greenspan Tells Congress Not to Rely on Surpluses

title: INSIDE
description: Municipal Tax Break for CBS

title: Barbara Steppe
description: The Drawing Room

title: Fed Chief Sees Hard Choices To Preserve Social Security
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned Congress today not to count on projected Government budget surpluses to solve Social Security's problems, and he suggested that the two parties would still have to cut benefits or raise taxes to insure the retirement system's future.

title: Broncos' Defense Shows That It Belongs
description: When you score 501 points, and your quarterback is a legend, your running back amasses 2,000 yards, your tight end redefines the position, does anyone care who plays defense?

title: A Proposal For Cameras In Nassau Jail
description: The Nassau County District Attorney, Denis Dillon, called upon the County Legislature today to order the installation of video cameras throughout the county jail in East Meadow, where the authorities say an inmate was beaten to death earlier this month by guards.

title: Con Ed to Sell Power Plants For $1.1 Billion
description: In the latest step in the gradual breakup of its power monopoly, Consolidated Edison announced yesterday that it would sell off most of its generating plants in New York City to two energy companies for $1.1 billion.

title: Learning Life's Lessons On the Football Field
description: Varsity Blues

title: After Escaped Tiger Is Shot, Town Finds It Has a Lot More
description: The day after the authorities shot and killed a 600-pound Bengal tiger that had escaped into the woods, residents awoke today to learn that a one-square-mile area here has a surprising concentration of tigers.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Hingis Favored for 3d Straight Title
description: Monica Seles's winning streak at the Australian Open is over. Martina Hingis's is not, and shortly after she had defeated Seles by 6-2, 6-4, in the semifinals at Melbourne Park yesterday, Hingis turned to Seles in the locker room and observed that she was almost not allowed to lose now.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR HIGHER VS. YEN. A stock market rally and batch of robust economic reports lifted the dollar against the Japanese currency. In New York, the dollar traded at 116.40 yen, up from 115.82 on Wednesday.

title: WITH ITS STOCK PRICE UP, INTEL ANNOUNCES 2-FOR-1 SPLIT
description: The Intel Corporation, the world's largest computer chip maker, said yesterday that it would split its shares 2 for 1. The new shares will be distributed on April 11 to shareholders of record on March 23. Shares of Intel climbed $4.4375, to $137.1875. Shares touched a record $143.6875 on Jan. 20 after trading as low as $65.65625 on June 3. Intel benefited in the fourth quarter as consumers bought 27 million personal computers, most of which run on the company's chips.

title: A Journey Back to Judaism, Thanks to the Dalai Lama
description: ''The Jew in the Lotus'' is a documentary that suggests that film may be far from the ideal medium for portraying a spiritual journey that takes a man back to his religion.

title: FRANKLIN MUTUAL ADVISORS REDUCES STAKE IN DOW JONES
description: The investor group Franklin Mutual Advisors Inc. has cut its holdings in Dow Jones & Company to 5 percent, or 3,678,100 common shares, from a 5.4 percent stake reported in a 1997 filing in which it also disclosed its intention to press Dow to shed its Telerate division. The fund group has sold 373,000 shares since that filing, reporting sales of 125,000 shares between Jan. 5 and Jan. 6, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The group said in the filing that it no longer had intentions to press Dow Jones and that it would file its holdings with the S.E.C. as a passive investor. Dow Jones sold the Telerate division to Bridge Information Systems last year.

title: Draw Districts Using Voter Rolls, Not the Census
description: To the Editor:

title: Growing Up Midwestern With Kern, Rodgers And Martin
description: You can take the girl out of Kalamazoo, but you can't take Kalamazoo out of the girl. In the case of Nancy Ford, the composing half of the songwriting team Cryer and Ford, that turns out to be a good thing. Ms. Ford, who is appearing through Feb. 6 at the Firebird Cafe (363 West 46th Street, Clinton), where she made her cabaret debut on Tuesday evening, has an engaging story to tell about the evolution of a prim Midwestern-schooled pop sensibility.

title: Brodeur Records 40 Saves As the Devils Top the Bruins
description: The soreness in the neck that prevented Martin Brodeur from playing in goal against Ottawa two nights ago disappeared against the Bruins tonight at the Fleet Center. Instead, Brodeur was able to irritate Boston time after time as he came up with 40 saves to lead the Devils to a 2-0 triumph.

title: Lifting the Veil From Beauties Cloaked in Tragic Guise
description: Take the men away from Julia Margaret Cameron's body of photographic work and a curious thing happens. It is like turning down the lights in a room and adjusting to the darkness. As the visible universe shrinks and then expands, strange details emerge in the gloom. In ''Julia Margaret Cameron's Women,'' an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, the world is all tragic women. But once the eyes adjust to that dim realm, shades of experience become distinct, and ''tragedy'' becomes too simple a word.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Next to This, Norman Looks Sane
description: The year 1960 brought two cinematic shockers about handsome, homicidal young men, and ''Psycho'' was the tame one. Though Michael Powell saw his ''Peeping Tom'' as no less than ''a film about the cinema from 1900 to 1960,'' it was instantly reviled (by critics who later ate crow) and ruined his career and reputation.

title: Present at the Birth of a Salesman
description: Willy Loman started small.

title: 'A Brief History' To 'Zebrahead'
description: Every January independent film celebrates its high season at the Sundance Film Festival, now in its 15th annual session, in Park City, Utah. This year, in need of an independent infusion itself, home video checked in, too.

title: A Home for Families
description: To the Editor:

title: 8 Killed in Explosion in China; Bomb Is Suspected
description: An explosion on Monday in a county seat in southeastern China killed at least 8 people and injured more than 60, according to local officials.

title: National Black Fine Art Show
description: Puck Building

title: TV Weekend; Where Matricide Is a Family Value
description: Little Stewie sits in his highchair playing with something that looks like a toy ray gun. It is, in fact, the mind-control device he is inventing.

title: 70.20 Rise on Nasdaq Leads Gains Across the Board
description: Buoyed by Intel's fourth split since 1993 and other evidence of prosperity for high-technology companies, the Nasdaq stock market rocketed to a gain of nearly 3 percent yesterday, pacing a broad market rally.

title: Recruit Organ Donors; Registry Is Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs; Quite A Pair
description: Bibi and Bill, two politicians running for their lives. One the Prime Minister of Israel. The other President of the United States. So different, yet so much alike.

title: Governor Grants Pope's Plea For Life of a Missouri Inmate
description: After an extraordinary personal appeal from Pope John Paul II, Gov. Mel Carnahan, a supporter of capital punishment, today commuted the death sentence of a convicted murderer to life in prison without parole.

title: Falcons Call Broncos' Blocks Illegal
description: Defensive end Lester Archambeau of the Atlanta Falcons is usually a calm man. Just a guy from Montville, N.J., who is part of one of the best -- and mostly unheralded -- defensive lines in football. But when Archambeau starts discussing the blocking styles of the Denver offensive linemen, his blood boils.

title: Grace Move Will Cut Jobs
description: W. R. Grace & Company, the specialty chemicals concern, said today that it would eliminate as many as 90 jobs when it relocates its headquarters to Columbia, Md., from Boca Raton later this year. W. R. Grace, with annual sales of about $1.5 billion from chemicals used in oil refining, building materials and other products, said it would move 40 people, including senior management, to the new location. The company will close its office in Boca Raton, where it employs about 130 people. The consolidation is part of a plan to lower costs and increase productivity.

title: Recruit Organ Donors
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHAWK AGREES TO ACQUIRE BRITISH IMAGING COMPANY
description: Schawk Inc., a supplier of digital imaging for the packaging, advertising and promotion industries, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Wace Group P.L.C. for $:94.6 million ($156 million) in cash and bonds to expand in Europe. Schawk, based in Des Plaines, Ill., said it would pay 70 pence for each Wace share, or $:55.4 million, a 20.6 percent premium over Wace's closing price on Wednesday. Schawk will also exchange one subordinated note, or bond, for each share of Wace preference stock, for a total of $:39.2 million.

title: Having a Fling With a Jig (Maybe It's Vice Versa)
description: A special feature of the New York City Ballet's 50th-anniversary celebration is the revival of works long absent from the repertory.

title: Suit Says Canada Imported Tainted Blood From U.S. Inmates
description: A group of Canadians who claim they were infected by tainted blood products collected from prisoners in the United States filed a $660 million lawsuit today against the Canadian Government and several private companies for failing to adequately safeguard the blood supply.

title: Matchup: Why Denver Will Win
description: DENVER (16-2) vs. ATLANTA (16-2)

title: In Boston, a Boom and New Hurrahs
description: Boston is the most historic city in America, a repository of our national past, yet it has an extraordinary capacity to reinvent itself.

title: On My Mind; Define Deviancy Up
description: On just one condition, journalists and lesser Americans have every right to deride the way the Senate is conducting the trial of President Clinton. If they don't, they should.

title: Interrogators and Witnesses Prepare for Face-Off
description: A day after the Senate voted to summon three witnesses in President Clinton's impeachment trial, the interrogators honed questions they hoped would turn their case around, and their targets prepared to say nothing new.

title: A Global Heartbeat On CD's
description: World music thrives on misunderstandings. As a marketing category, it's a grand hodgepodge. The world-music bins of any well-stocked store are likely to hold field recordings from remote villages as well as pop songs concocted in 64-track digital studios, and practitioners of traditional styles end up next to hybrids of, say, didgeridoo and Brazilian percussion and synthesizer. The confusion may baffle new fans, but it's true to the history of music, where no category stays intact very long.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUER, CHARLES KENNETH, M.D.
description: BRAUER-Charles Kenneth, M.D. Of Jersey City, NJ. Loved forever by wife Evelyn (nee Shugar). Cherished son of the late Rose and Abe. Adored father of Dr. Richard Brauer and Joyce Weston. Esteemed father-in-law of Jon Weston and Mary Brauer. Dear brother of Florence Wiener and Sylvia Chessler. Loving and adored grandfather of Samantha, Alexander and Philip. Services will be held at Temple Beth-El, 2419 Kennedy Blvd., Jersey City, NJ, on Sunday at noon. Contributions may be made to Temple Beth-El, Jersey City. For Info: Wien & Wien, 1-800-322-0533

title: The Principal Wants Honor, Not Tenure
description: WITH all the political posturing over New York City's troubled schools, it is sometimes hard to get beyond the web of pointed fingers to see that the system also produces people like Ruth Swinney, the principal of Public School 165 on West 109th Street.

title: Kukar Named Game's Referee
description: The National Football League has named Bernie Kukar the referee for Sunday's Super Bowl game.

title: Barney's Ends Its Bankruptcy Proceeding
description: Barney's Inc., one of the leading United States fashion retail chains, said yesterday that it had completed a reorganization and emerged from two years of bankruptcy protection.

title: Why Do the Republicans Ignore Centrist Voters?; Clinton's Worst Enemy
description: To the Editor:

title: India Orders Inquiry Into Missionary's Killing
description: The Indian Cabinet today ordered a judicial inquiry into the killings of an Australian Christian missionary and his two young sons -- who were burned to death in their van on Saturday in a tribal village -- after a team of Government ministers who visited the village said they had found no local people with a motive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRACKLEY, PATRICIA A. (NEE SHARKEY)
description: BRACKLEY-Patricia A. (nee Sharkey), on January 28, 1999 at her residence after a long illness. Graduate of Purdue University, recipient of the Paul Harris Fellow from the International Rotary Foundation, and active in horticulture work at the national and state level. Beloved wife of Albert, devoted mother of Albert IV, Ryan and Patrick. Loving daughter of Flora. Dear sister of Penny Simler, Peggy Shaw and Portia Roberts. Cherished grandmother of Kate Erin and Fiona Patrice. Reposing at Denis O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, New York. Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday, 9:30AM at St. Francis de Sales Church, Belle Harbor, New York. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting Friday 2-5 and 7-10 P.M.

title: Outliving The Groundhog
description: February may be the shortest month, but it might be plenty long for a few Broadway shows.

title: Only a Fifth of Teachers Say They Feel Qualified
description: Only 1 in 5 full-time public school teachers said they felt well qualified to teach in a modern classroom, according to a new report, and Secretary of Education Richard W. Riley said that represented ''a cry for help.''

title: The Ford Ka Faces Hurdle In Japan
description: The steering wheel is on the right-hand side and the air-conditioning system was specially designed to stand up to Japan's sticky summers, but the Ford Ka, the most visible plank of the Ford Motor Company's efforts to resuscitate its gasping business here, may have a tough road ahead.

title: Ericsson Introduces AA Battery-Sized Phone
description: Ericsson A.B., the third-largest cellular telephone maker, introduced a mobile phone the size of a ''AA'' battery yesterday and said that profit fell less than expected in the fourth quarter, lifting the stock 9 percent.

title: Ford-Volvo Tie: Europe Rivals at Risk
description: The Ford Motor Company's victorious bid for Volvo A.B.'s car business increases the pressure on other European automobile companies to either buy or be bought, industry executives and analysts say.

title: Peter Flaccus
description: Monique Knowlton

title: Bomb in Cape Town Injures 11 Outside the Main Police Station
description: A bomb, the third in five months, went off in central Cape Town today, wounding 11 people at the doors of the city's main police station.

title: U.S.-Russian Team May Have Created Ultra-Heavy Element
description: Collaborating Russian and American nuclear physicists believe they have created a new ultra-heavy element that may open the door to a host of new elements once considered impossible.

title: Where Time Stands Still, Not Prices
description: Palm Beach, Fla., is beloved for its Spanish-style shopping arcades and 1930's Mediterranean Revival mansions designed by society architects like Addison Mizner and Maurice Fatio. The Historic Preservation Society of Palm Beach has strict guidelines to protect these old buildings as well as the town's charming wooden bungalows. Very few houses are modern or contemporary. It's not Miami Beach, you know.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, MARY THURMAN
description: MARTIN-Mary Thurman, 100, on January 27th, 1999 of Locust Valley, NY. Widow of the late Milward W. Martin and mother of Mary Lee Fletcher of New York City and Dugald A. Fletcher of Locust Valley. Grandmother of three and great-grandmother of seven. A memorial service at Saint John's Lattingtown on Sunday, January 31st at 3 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Grenville Baker Boys & Girls Club, Locust Valley, NY.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'll have to say I was moved by his concern for this prisoner.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, EPHRAIM, M.D.
description: STEIN-Ephraim, M.D. On January 28, 1999. Beloved husband of Crissy. Devoted father of Margery, Jonathan and Bruce. Cherished grandfather of Peter, Whitney, Mariel, Joshua and Benjamin. Services Friday, 12:15 PM at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: MASON-DIXON STOCK RISES 70% ON NEWS OF DEAL WITH BB&T
description: The stock of Mason-Dixon Bancshares soared 70 percent yesterday after the BB&T Corporation said it had agreed to acquire Mason-Dixon for $248.5 million in stock. Shareholders of Mason-Dixon, a Maryland bank holding company, are to receive 1.3 BB&T shares for each Mason-Dixon share, a 74 percent premium over Mason-Dixon's closing price of $27.75 on Wednesday. Shares of Mason-Dixon, which has $1.1 billion in assets, rose $19.50, to $47.25. On Wednesday, BB&T, a Winston-Salem, N.C., bank holding company with $35 billion in assets, said it would buy the First Citizens Corporation for $125.9 million.

title: Uniphase and JDS Fitel Agree to Merge
description: The Uniphase Corporation and JDS Fitel Inc. of Canada said today that they had agreed to merge in a stock swap that values JDS Fitel at about $3.2 billion (United States). The merger creates one of the biggest makers of parts used in phone equipment.

title: A Brighter Side of Bacon Glints Amid the Darkness
description: After closing for a year to spruce up its Louis Kahn-designed home, the Yale Center for British Art has reopened with a trio of exhibitions devoted to three giants of modern British art: Francis Bacon, Lucian Freud and Henry Moore. The last two are minor sideshows: one dedicated to Mr. Freud's etchings, the other a survey of small bronze studies for monuments produced by Moore from the 1930's to the 1970's. But the Bacon show, an imperfect but ultimately dazzling 60-painting retrospective, makes a trip to Yale well worth it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, ETHEL. ETHEL EDWARDS
description: EDWARDS-Ethel. Ethel Edwards, an artist, friend, and teacher, died on January 24, 1999, at her home in the Gainsborough Studios, New York City. A native of New Orleans, Ethel attended Newcomb College, where she met her husband, of 62 years, the artist Xavier Gonzalez who passed away in 1993. Ethel and Xavier were both instructors at the Art Students League, where they were both dedicated supporters of the school and generations of students. Ethel was for many years on the board of the Truro Center for the Arts at Castle Hill, MA, and the Artists' Fellowship. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club and the Century Association in New York City where she exhibited. She will continue to inspire and encourage others through her exuberant works of art in the collections of the Baltimore Museum of Art, the Newark Museum, Colby College, and many other collections. Ethel and Xavier embodied their art with a style and lust for life, a spirit they shared with all who met them on their many travels and at their homes in New York and Wellfleet. Ethel was an artist for all seasons, full of warmth and with an intense discipline to create.

title: Under Order, Pataki Releases Records on 1995 Inaugural
description: Under order by New York's highest court, Gov. George E. Pataki's 1995 inaugural and transition committees have made a thick stack of financial records public, but the Democrats who forced their release say that at first glance, they contain nothing notable.

title: Camby Earning a Spot On the Knicks' Bench
description: In an intrasquad scrimmage the Knicks staged mainly for the benefit of a small group of adoring fans today, Marcus Camby saw an opening. It may have simply looked like a crack in the defense that left a clear path to the basket, but for Camby, it could have also been an opening into fans' hearts.

title: Nine West Plans To Cut More Jobs
description: Nine West Group will cut 144 jobs in its corporate offices, the latest attempt by the struggling maker of women's shoes to reduce costs and improve its profitability.

title: Politician, Business Leader and 'Thug No. 2'
description: IN its simplest form, the resume of Alfred Carmine Cerullo 3d -- which he recently dusted off -- might read something like this:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, HARRY MARTIN
description: KELLY-Harry Martin. New York University's Stern School of Business mourns the passing of good friend and former Associate Dean, Harry M. Kelly at age 86 on January 27, 1999 in Florida. Joined the faculty of the then School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance in February 1947. Served as Assistant Dean and Associate Dean from September '58 through August '73, and as Secretary of the Faculty from 1971 through 1973. Served as Vice Chairman of the Finance Department. We send our sympathies to his wife Claire. George G. Daly, Dean

title: The Neediest Cases; Troubles Eased, Time Now for Books
description: If Mazilee L. had her druthers, she would pass her days with tales of terror: supernatural and technological thrillers, especially those written by John Saul and Dean Koontz, her favorite authors.

title: An Unmatched Pair United for a Series
description: There has been much head-scratching about the pairing of Elgar and Beethoven in Lincoln Center's split-focus mini-series, which ended on Tuesday evening when Colin Davis led the London Symphony Orchestra in Beethoven's Fourth Piano Concerto and Elgar's First Symphony. An essay in the program booklet invokes the opinion of George Bernard Shaw and other Elgar contemporaries that the English composer was upholding the symphonic tradition for which Beethoven stood. But even forgetting the vast differences between Beethoven's world and Elgar's -- differences that are not irrelevant to their creative impulses -- the musical relationship between them is not so simply drawn.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: A Crash Course In Economics; Rethinking What's Driving The Emerging-Markets Crisis
description: Among the movers and shakers gathered here for the World Economic Forum, a striking metaphor is helping to frame the debate over the global financial crisis that began in Asia and has spread to several other developing countries. The debacle, some say, brings to mind a slick stretch of highway, scene of a half-dozen recent auto accidents. So is it careless driving or the highway that is the cause of the accidents?

title: Monitor Rejects Bid to Overturn Hoffa Victory
description: A Federal monitor yesterday rejected appeals to overturn James P. Hoffa's election to the presidency of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, but he barred a Hoffa running mate from taking office.

title: Mr. Congeniality Croons and Cuts Up
description: Most male cabaret singers project a combination of the suave and the sweet, edged with some variation of a Sinatraesque toughness. But instead of pursuing the standard pop-star mystique, Charles Cermele, a hefty-voiced baritone who can also croon smoothly in a high head voice, conveys a good-humored homeyness.

title: Triumphal Homecoming
description: Tony Bui was only 2 when his family fled Vietnam in 1975 shortly before the fall of Saigon. He grew up in Sunnyvale, Calif., and studied film at Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles. When he was 19, he returned to Vietnam for two weeks to visit ailing relatives. ''I hated it,'' he recalled. ''I hated the dust, the heat, the humidity. I hated the fact that my grandfather didn't have a real toilet. I was very ignorant.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, WILLIAM
description: WOLF-William. January 28, 1999. Husband of Inge (Obermeier) of Medford, N.J. Father of Dr. Susan (Dr. James Weinstein) MillerWeinstein. Grandfather of Alexander Weinstein. Funeral services Sunday, 10AM, Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc., 2001 Berlin Road, Cherry Hill, N.J. Interment Roosevelt Memorial Park. Contributions can be made to the Max Mainzer Memorial Foundation, C/O Carlos Doernberg, 180 West End Avenue, Apt 27R, New York, N.Y. 10023.

title: 'A Meditation on the Year 1960'
description: D'Amelio Terras

title: Scott Reeder
description: Pat Hearn Gallery

title: Man Admits Controlling Loan Shark Rackets
description: A Hawthorne man who Federal prosecutors contend is the leader of the Bergen County arm of the Genovese crime family pleaded guilty yesterday to running the organization's loan sharking and illegal gambling operations for about three years.

title: A New State for Inuit: Frigid but Optimistic
description: The day the map of Canada is redrawn and native people in the frigid north start to govern themselves is still more than two months off. But this frontier city, which will become North America's newest capital on April 1, is already undergoing a strange Arctic boom.

title: David Dupuis
description: Derek Eller Gallery

title: New Ears For an Epic's Old English
description: Benjamin Bagby's recitation of the first quarter of the epic poem ''Beowulf'' -- in Old English -- was staged for three evenings as part of the 1997 Lincoln Center Festival. Here are excerpts from D. J. R. Bruckner's review, which appeared in The New York Times on July 22, 1997. ''Beowulf'' returns to Lincoln Center with performances tonight and tomorrow and Tuesday and Wednesday at the Clark Studio Theater.

title: A Hot Player, and It Isn't Duval: Leonard Leads
description: David Duval endured one of his most difficult rounds of 1999 today, but Justin Leonard enjoyed his best.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARVIS, WILBUR, M.D.
description: JARVIS-Wilbur, M.D. On January 8, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Vivian Jarvis. Father of Mady McSweeney and Kerry Nadel. Father-in-law of Eli Nadel. Brother of The Hon. Donald Jarvis. Grandfather of Jennifer, Daniel, Andrew and Rachel. Great grandfather of Kayla, Callie and John. Any donations in his memory should be made to Doctors Without Borders, 6 E. 39 St, 8th Flr, N.Y., N.Y. 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSSE, GEORGE L.
description: MOSSE-George L. The Officers, Directors and Staff of the Leo Baeck Institute are deeply saddened by the loss of our great and generous friend, George L. Mosse. We are proud to have awarded him the Leo Baeck Medal just this past November honoring his scholarship on a wide range of subjects dealing with European history, especially the German-Jewish dialogue. He taught us how to understand the irrationality of the Twentieth Century, how to distinguish between good nationalism and bad. His unswerving commitment to Judaism was characterized by an attitude toward life, a belief in the humanism and enlightenment that led the way to modernity. His analyses were consistently original, thoughtful and provocative, conveyed with humor and great style. We remember him with profound affection and admiration. Ismar Schorsch, President Carol Kahn Strauss, Exec.Director

title: Boy, 11, Drowns On Class Trip to Pool
description: An 11-year-old Brooklyn boy on a class trip was found unconscious in shallow water at an indoor swimming pool in Canarsie on Wednesday and later died, the police said.

title: Tobacco-Related Issues Cause Drop in RJR Nabisco Earnings
description: Buoyed by the improving fortunes of its cookie and cracker business but battered by the cost of tobacco-related litigation, the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation posted fourth-quarter earnings yesterday of 58 cents a share, 9 percent lower than a year ago, excluding unusual charges.

title: GIULIANI BROADENS SPLIT WITH PATAKI WITH BUDGET PLAN
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani stepped up his criticism of Gov. George E. Pataki's spending practices yesterday as he proposed a $35.4 billion budget for New York City, setting the stage for a rancorous battle with Albany over school aid.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Ultimatum on Kosovo
description: The ultimatum that NATO is due to hand both sides in the Kosovo conflict this week could be the last chance to prevent a full-scale war. Tomorrow NATO is likely to endorse a plan to bomb Serbian targets if the Serbian leader, Slobodan Milosevic, does not cease hostilities in Kosovo and agree to an interim peace plan in two weeks. If the ethnic Albanian guerrillas do not sign the plan, NATO will impose an arms blockade. Peace still remains agonizingly distant, but it may be closer now that the West, with some support from Russia, has come up with the right balance of diplomacy and force.

title: Deutsch Is Named Agency of the Year
description: Deutsch Inc. in New York has been named agency of the year for 1998 by the trade publications Advertising Age and Adweek, for achievements that included landing the $250 million consolidated account of Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEYSAR, FRANKLIN
description: KEYSAR - Franklin. Broadway production stage manager, on January 25, 1999 of liver cancer. Born in Warren, New Hampshire January 22, 1939. Survived by his mother Bertha Keysar & three brothers, Philip, Donald, & Gary, three sisters, Phyllis Colby-Mudgett, Patti Bartlett and Virginia Keysar. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, January 31, 1PM at Park Avenue United Methodist Church, 106 E. 86 Street. Donations may be made to Broadway Cares/ EFA or the Park Avenue United Methodist Church.

title: Ford Buys Volvo Car Unit in Bid To Lift Profile of Luxury Models
description: The Ford Motor Company, by agreeing yesterday to buy the car operations of Volvo A.B. of Sweden for $6.45 billion, has taken its biggest step yet toward becoming a large-scale seller of high-profit luxury cars as well as more humble vehicles like the Escort and pickup trucks.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Sunday about Edgar Noller, the last of the 20 mushers who carried life-saving serum 674 miles to Nome, Alaska, in a diphtheria epidemic in 1925, misstated the distance covered by another, Leonhard Seppala. He and his lead dog, Togo, ran the 18th leg, not the first. They covered 91 miles (260 miles was the total distance they traveled, including a 169-mile run from Nome to the start of their relay leg).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERG, COPY
description: BERG-Copy. Of Manhattan and Bridgehampton. Age 47. On January 27, 1999. Copy was active in the Gay civil rights movement for many years. He attained his M.A. from Pratt Institute, then began his career as an artist. He was in numerous exhibitions and in 1998 the Robeson Gallery at Rutgers University held a retrospective of his work. A large collection of his work is housed in the Rare Books and Manuscripts sections of the NY Public Library. His long-time partner, Paul Nash, predeceased Copy in 1993. Copy is survived by partner Dub Williams, his grandfather Vernon Berg, Sr., his mother Vera Berg, siblings Valerie Berg Rice, Victor Berg, and Vincent Berg, and by his nephew and niece Elia and Kiran. A memorial service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Chapel, on Saturday, January 30, at 3:30 P.M. Copy requested memorial donations be made to The Lamba Legal Defense Fund (212-809-8585) or Visual Aids (212-627-9855).

title: JAMESON SAYS IT IS BUYING SIGNATURE INNS FOR $44 MILLION
description: Jameson Inns Inc., a real estate investment trust that owns 82 hotels in the Southeast, said yesterday that it would buy Signature Inns Inc. for about $44.1 million in stock and cash, plus $61 million in assumed debt. Jameson is to pay half a share of common stock and $1.50 in cash for each share of Signature common stock, or $12.8 million based on Wednesday's stock price. It will also swap Signature's preferred stock for a new Jameson convertible preferred at about the same terms for $31.3 million. Both chains cater to business travelers looking to pay $50 to $60 a night. Signature Inns has 25 hotels in Illinois, Iowa, Ohio, Kentucky and Tennessee. Shares of Jameson Inns fell 12.5 cents, to $9. Signature Inns rose $1.25, to $5.125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFKOWITZ, ELLIOT J.
description: LEFKOWITZ-Elliot J. The Board of Directors, the faculty, and the staff of The American Musical and Dramatic Academy are deeply saddened by the loss of Board member, Elliot J. Lefkowitz. He was a beacon of wisdom, steadfast strength and support, with humor and unmatched warmth. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Barbara (Bobbie), and to his children Elisa and Ken Greenberg, Aaron, and Stacy. We shall miss him. David Martin, President Jan Martin, Executive Director

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Why Do the Republicans Ignore Centrist Voters?; Playing to the Cameras
description: To the Editor:

title: Lean Times on the Hog Farm
description: The next time you buy a pound of pork chops for $3.99, consider that a hog farmer would have sold you the entire pig for $20. An oversupply of pigs has driven the prices farmers get from packing houses down to Depression-era levels.

title: In Disputed Move, Netanyahu Creates a National Security Council
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced today the creation of an American-style National Security Council to coordinate military and intelligence strategy, a change long urged by defense analysts here but criticized now as a last-minute political maneuver by a Government entering its final months in office.

title: Voters Angered by Impeachment Put a Republican on Early Notice
description: Representative Tom Campbell knew his vote to impeach the President would make some people unhappy.

title: Statewide Tests Draw Local Outcries; Some Schools Say Their Own Requirements Beat the Regents'
description: To earn her diploma, Vanessa Gravenstine, a senior at the Beacon School, a small alternative public school in New York City, has been going through a process more familiar to doctoral candidates at a university than to most teen-agers: to prove that she met the New York State foreign-language requirement, she wrote a play in French and presented it to a committee of teachers, speaking French the whole time.

title: Michigan's Cusser Deluxe
description: Since the defendant's name is Timothy Boomer, it is difficult to resist a certain lightness of tone about the freedom of speech case now being considered by a Michigan judge. After Mr. Boomer's canoe bellied up in the Rifle River north of Detroit, he began yelling several crude words -- O.K., maybe a whole carload of crude words, some of which could be heard a quarter of a mile away. His vocalizing offended a family canoeing nearby, provoking the mother to put her hands over her child's ears. Then a sheriff's deputy, on what must have been a fairly crowded stretch of river, issued Mr. Boomer a ticket under an 1897 state law prohibiting cursing in front of women and children.

title: From Humor to Drama, a Woman's View From Around the World
description: ''The Feminine Eye: 20 Years of Women's Cinema,'' a film series featuring works by more than 20 filmmakers, continues through Feb. 7 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Rose Cinemas, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Fort Greene, Brooklyn. The series, which also features four panel discussions, is presented by New York Women in Film and Television. Tickets to each screening and panel discussion are $8.50 ($5 for members of New York Women in Film and Television or of the Brooklyn Academy of Music Cinema Club). Many of the filmmakers will be present at the screenings. Information: (212) 679-0870. Tickets: (718) 623-2770. Here is a schedule:

title: Some Friendly Mingling in the Chamber Despite a Day of Hard Party Division
description: Senator Strom Thurmond slowly came down the aisle today with a wide smile and two pieces of candy sweets for Cheryl D. Mills and Nicole K. Seligman, lawyers at President Clinton's defense table. The 96-year-old Senator regularly finds courtly delight in chatting with the women when he is not sitting mutely in judgment of the President's fate.

title: A Mistress For the Frick
description: Regular visitors to the Frick Collection will notice some changes to the grand interiors of the limestone mansion at 1 East 70th Street. Several paintings in its collection that had been out of sight for years were rehung this week in prominent places. Some of the Frick's fine porcelains, too, have found temporary new niches.

title: Benefit for Convicted Killer Draws Rock Fans
description: Unbowed by angry criticism from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and law enforcement officials, several alternative-rock bands performed a benefit show tonight for Mumia Abu-Jamal, the activist and former radio journalist who is on death row for killing a Philadelphia police officer.

title: Asked About Internet Issues, The Fed Chairman Shrugs
description: He has made a habit of worrying in public that stock prices are getting out of hand, but when Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, was asked today about the highest-flying investments of all, Internet companies, his answer was tinged as much with fascination and even enthusiasm as with caution.

title: Albright Introduces a New Phrase to Promote Hussein's Ouster
description: On every stop on her quick trip to moderate Arab states, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright explained the Administration's new goal for Iraq: ''regime change.''

title: Why Do the Republicans Ignore Centrist Voters?; Mistakes All Around
description: To the Editor:

title: Yasuda Trust Bailout Sealed With Stock Offer
description: A bailout of Yasuda Trust and Banking Company by Japan's Fuji Bank was sealed yesterday with the announcement of a 300 billion yen ($2.6 billion) stock offering that will be absorbed solely by Fuji Bank. The move will make Yasuda a consolidated subsidiary and leave Fuji holding the biggest outstanding balance of home loans in Japan.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: In Senate as in House, Partisanship Lives On
description: Not us, senators of both parties have been saying since impeachment proceedings against President Clinton began in December; we will never descend to the kind of lockstep partisanship you saw in the House of Representatives.

title: Report Finds Banks Failed To Oversee Big Hedge Fund
description: A handful of the world's largest commercial and investment banks failed to adequately oversee lending and trading activities with the hedge-fund giant Long-Term Capital Management, a regulatory study has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOYLE, PAUL R.
description: DOYLE-Paul R. Of Manhattan. Died at age 84 on December 23, 1998 after a brief illness. A memorial service will be held at 3 P.M., Saturday, January 30, 1999, at Holy Family Church, 315 East 47 Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Catholic Charities or other charitable organizations would be appreciated.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; Cars With Star Quality, Rat Pack to Fab Four
description: THIS may be the biggest weekend of the year in sports, but for car collectors, the Super Bowl has come and gone.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Regulators Take a Closer Look at Spinoffs
description: Investors in Peoplesoft, the large California software company, opened their mailboxes this month to find a bonus: shares of stock in Momentum Business Applications, the technology concern's new subsidiary. True to its name, Momentum's stock almost doubled in its first day of trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKENSON, KATHERINE NICHOLS
description: DICKENSON-Katherine Nichols on January 27, 1999 in Shelburne, VT. Beloved wife of the late William M., Jr. Loving mother of 3 daughters and 3 sons-in-law Leslie and Nils Blataz, Karen and Barry Smalstig and Jane and John Lawlis. Loving grandmother of Lisa, Andrew, Amy, Daniel, Scott, Eric, Ryan, Katherine and Chad. A memorial service will be held 4 PM Saturday, January 30, 1999 at Grace Church, 254 Hicks Street, Brooklyn Heights, N.Y. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Arbors, 687 Harbor Road, Shelburne, VT. 05482 or Community Mainstreaming Associates, Inc., 165 Station Road, Kings Point, N.Y. 11024.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUNSTEIN, JEAN
description: BRAUNSTEIN-Jean. Our deepest sympathies to our beloved Trustee, Harry Braunstein, on the loss of his mother, Jean. We send our deepest condolences to the whole family. Michael R. Stoler, Pres., AFRMC International Pres., Friends of Rambam Medical Center Abraham Unger, Executive Dir.

title: Why Do the Republicans Ignore Centrist Voters?; Mr. Popularity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MIHLRAD, JACK
description: MIHLRAD-Jack. 5/17/14-1/29/95 Four long years of remembering and loving you every day. Remembering your spirit, courage and determination. Love always, Diane and Mo

title: Patriot Games
description: Lured by a $350 million stadium, guaranteed revenue from luxury seating and a $1 billion riverfront redevelopment, the National Football League's New England Patriots will move to Hartford beginning with the 2001 season.

title: Microsoft Told to Turn Over A Key Internal Document
description: The Federal judge in the Microsoft antitrust case today ordered the company to turn over an internal document to the Justice Department that Government lawyers said could undermine one of the software giant's defenses.

title: Crew Plans Charter Schools, His Way
description: Just six weeks after Gov. George E. Pataki pushed a charter school law through the State Legislature, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew is proposing to set up his own charterlike school districts in Brooklyn, granting them freedom from the central school bureaucracy in an effort to improve student achievement, school officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINNERAN, GERARD L.
description: FINNERAN-Gerard L. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Gerard L. Finneran, a Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: General Criticizes U.S. Policy on Iraq
description: The general who commands American forces in the Persian Gulf openly questioned the Administration's new policy of supporting Iraqi opposition groups in the hope they will overthrow President Saddam Hussein.

title: A Republican Blunder
description: Senate Republicans acted unwisely yesterday by exercising their majority power to impose an open-ended and ill-defined set of procedures for the remainder of the impeachment trial. They are now perilously close to turning the trial into a purely Republican spectacle that poorly serves the nation and demeans the Senate itself.

title: Fight After Basketball Game Ends Life of Promising Brooklyn Student
description: When Rosemary Bennett walked toward Jackie Robinson Intermediate School in Brooklyn on Wednesday night, she was not going to see her promising son, Michael, play in a basketball scrimmage; the game was long over. Instead, it was because she had a premonition that something was wrong.

title: Clinton to Seek $1 Billion for 'Skills Gap'
description: To rare Republican praise, President Clinton proposed today to narrow a ''skills gap'' by spending nearly $1 billion more next year on job training and adult education, as well as programs to cut dropout rates and to prepare poor children for college.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: One person meets you at the door. Another takes your coat. A third leads you to the maitre d'hotel, who sends you off with yet another to your table.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: First Name Only,

title: Clark to Compete In Her 21st Games
description: Joetta Clark will become the first athlete in the 92-year history of the meet to compete in 21 Millrose Games when she goes after her seventh title in the 800-meter run next Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: August Everding, 70, Director Of Hamburg an Munich Operas
description: August Everding, the German opera director and administrator who once ran the Munich and Hamburg State Opera companies and created five productions for the Metropolitan Opera, died on Wednesday in a Munich hospital. He was 70.

title: Jerzy Turowicz Is Dead at 86; Anti-Communist Polish Editor
description: Jerzy Turowicz, who skirmished with Communist censors for nearly four decades to produce a Polish Catholic weekly that became widely known as ''the only free newspaper from Berlin to Vladivostok,'' died on Wednesday in Cracow. He was 86 and had suffered a heart attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  READ, EDWARD C.K.
description: READ-Edward C.K., public relations executive and freelance writer, died of cancer this past December in NYC. He was 80. Born in Villanova, Pa., the son of Dr. Conyers Read, a professor of English History at the University of Pennsylvania, and Edith Coulson Kirk, Mr. Read graduated from Harvard College in 1940. Following a brief stint as a screenwriter with MGM Studios in Hollywood, and service with the Army Signal Corps in Europe during WW II, Mr. Read began a career as writer, editor and journalist that would span the next 50 years. A senior public relations executive with Hill & Knowlton and Freeport McMoran, Mr. Read also found time to author a variety of books and magazine articles on the side. Mr. Read retired from Freeport in 1985 and continued as a freelance writer for Epicure, Bon Appetit and the New York Post. A longtime resident of NYC, he was married to Louise Geary and had an older brother, William, both now deceased. He is survived by his sister Elizabeth Foster, his sons Cameron and John Conyers, a daughter Edith Coulson and seven grandchildren.

title: Germ Warfare Isn't Easy
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. General Warns of Dangers in Trying to Topple Iraqi
description: The general who commands American forces in the Persian Gulf today openly questioned the Administration's new policy of supporting Iraqi opposition groups in the hope they will overthrow President Saddam Hussein.

title: Next Steps in Trial
description: DEPOSITIONS -- The three witnesses subpoenaed, Monica S. Lewinsky, Vernon E. Jordan Jr. and Sidney Blumenthal, are to be deposed starting on Monday, with a senator from each party present. Deposition material, which may include videotapes, is to be made available as soon as Tuesday for all senators to review.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREIBER, DOROTHY
description: TREIBER-Dorothy. Formerly of Bayside, Queens, died on January 27, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Abraham Treiber. Devoted mother of the late Mark and Matthew Treiber. Loving mother of April LeBlang and cherished grandmother of Lisa, Adam, Justin and Alyssa. Donations to the Hebrew Home for the Aged, 5901 Palisade Avenue, Riverdale, N.Y. 10471.

title: Stock Mutual Fund Deposits Remained Light Last Month
description: Mutual fund investors remained relatively unimpressed last month with the stock market's sharp rebound, pouring just $3.4 billion into stock funds in December even as the market continued a steady climb back from its late-summer selloff. But industry officials say that January -- traditionally a strong time for mutual fund sales -- is shaping up much better.

title: Why Do the Republicans Ignore Centrist Voters?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACAS, ROSA
description: MACAS-Rosa. January 28, 1999, age 81. Born Vienna, Austria. Beloved wife of the late Rudolf Macas, devoted mother of Christina Rose and Ellie Silverman, motherin-law of Allen Silverman and Allan Rose, loving grandmother of Andrew, Marisa and Alex. We all love you and you will always be with us. As we say in Vienna ''Servus.'' Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Friday, 6 to 8 and Saturday 2 to 5 PM. Service Sunday, January 31, 1999, 11 AM at Frank E. Campbell.

title: Possession Is Nine-Tenths Of a Title
description: It remains a piercing thought for Cornelius Bennett, now an Atlanta Falcon, once a Buffalo Bill. Actually, any choice among his Super Bowl memories is painful. Bennett and the Bills lost four straight Super Bowls in this decade, but we are talking about the first one. Super Bowl XXV. Giants 20, Bills 19. The last-second 47-yard field-goal attempt by the Bills that missed wide right into a dark Tampa, Fla., night eight years ago.

title: Nine Easy Pieces: A Writer's Exercises
description: HEAVY WATER AND OTHER STORIES

title: Women's Work: 9 to 5 In Daydreams Only
description: Talk shows and women's magazines are full of the matters raised by Nancy Savoca in her new film, ''The 24-Hour Woman,'' in which a woman with a high-powered job tries to cope with the high-powered hassles of balancing career and family. But somebody on the other side of the camera has clearly been here and done this, and boy, does it show on screen.

title: Life of a Stage Man
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Democrats Report Fund-Raising Gains
description: Democratic Party officials said today that the impeachment matter had been something of a fund-raising bonanza.

title: Mayor Says Adding Officers Is Key to City's Health
description: For Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, every aspect of the city's revitalization -- from the demonstrable growth in tourism to the impressionistic sense that residents feel better about their hometown -- can be attributed to its dramatic crime reduction. And that is the reason he gave yesterday to justify his plan to add as many as 1,500 officers to what is already the largest police department in the nation.

title: Big Songs Plus Big Voice Equals Reinvented Recital
description: The soprano Renee Fleming seems intent on rethinking the way opera singers present recitals. Usually, there is a built-in problem: art songs are best sung in an intimate manner in small spaces, whereas operatic voices are oversize and charismatic, usually with personalities to match. The typical old-fashioned prima donna recital consists of obligatory renditions of Italian art songs and familiar lieder that serve as warm-ups to the string of hit arias most fans have really come to hear.

title: Orlando Looks Good to Rodman
description: For Dennis Rodman, it's Orlando or bust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGELUS, SUZETTE
description: ANGELUS-Suzette. On January 26th, 1999. Beloved wife of Ted, cherished mother of John and Joe, and devoted grandmother of Jillian. Also leaves behind sister Annette, daughter-in-law Kelley and stepsons Ted and Jim. A private memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Defendant in Slashings Is Charged in Burglaries
description: The Essex County Prosecutor's Office filed additional charges yesterday against a man already in custody for the throat-slashing deaths of two elderly Orange residents, accusing him of breaking into four apartments in a building just blocks from the victims' homes.

title: TRW, Outbidding Federal-Mogul, to Buy Lucas Varity of Britain
description: TRW Inc., the leading maker of automobile air bags, agreed today to buy Lucas Varity P.L.C. of Britain for $6.6 billion in cash, outbidding the Federal-Mogul Corporation with the largest offer ever for an auto-parts company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARATTA, MARYLOU
description: BARATTA-Marylou. On January 27th, 1999. Beloved daughter of Thomas and Vera Baratta, and devoted mother of Peter and the late Katherine Corradi. Loving sister of Thomas and the late James. Cherished grandmother of Peter, Jr. Mass on Saturday, Regina Pacis, at 10:15 A.M. Reposing at Ralph Aievoli & Son, 1275 65th Street, Brooklyn, New York. Visiting hours 2-4:30 PM and 7-9:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, EDWARD
description: ABRAMS-Edward. Beloved husband of Naomi. Loving father of Susan and Howard. Dear brother of Estelle. Cherished grandfather of Sean Michael and Alyssa Gayle. Services today, 10:15 AM, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expy., Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Scandal Touches African Athletes
description: In the West African nation of Senegal, there is one all-weather running track, one indoor basketball court and one Olympic-sized pool, filled with seawater and located not at a training center, but at a hotel.

title: Inflated Stocks Cushion Pitfalls Of Net Mergers
description: A handful of leading companies will come to dominate cyberspace.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about suicide by women in rural China misstated the finding of a study by the World Bank, Harvard University and the World Health Organization. The study found that the suicide rate in China is 30.3 per 100,000 people, not 30.3 per 100,000 deaths.

title: The Four A's Nominates Officers
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York has nominated executives to serve as top officers for the 1999-2000 year.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR RISES 4 PERCENT. Sugar futures jumped 4 percent on big purchases by Iran and Tunisia that bolstered demand. In New York, sugar for March delivery rose 0.27 cent, to 6.92 cents a pound.

title: Parties Looking to Other Ways To Say the President Did Wrong
description: With the prospects of President Clinton's removal from office all but gone, Senate Democrats and Republicans began arguing today about how to say that he still did something wrong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMARQUE, ABRIL
description: LaMARQUE-Abril. The Officers and members of the Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing of beloved member Abril LaMarque. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: F.C.C. Offers Low-Power FM Stations
description: The Federal Government proposed new rules today to permit hundreds, if not thousands, of small broadcasters to run inexpensive, low-power FM radio stations.

title: 'Selections Winter '99'
description: The Drawing Center

title: Mayors Help Draft a Handgun Crackdown Bill
description: In a sign that the assault on the gun industry is gaining political momentum, mayors from around the country announced today that they were helping prepare Federal legislation to slow the circulation of handguns and were urging additional cities to sue manufacturers and dealers.

title: Rita V. Tishman, 91, A Civic Benefactor
description: Rita Valentine Tishman, a New York benefactor of Jewish and civic causes, died on Jan. 21 at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 91.

title: Damian Loeb
description: Mary Boone Gallery

title: ADELPHIA IN DEAL FOR CABLE STAKE AND SHARES
description: The Adelphia Communications Corporation, the No. 7 United States cable operator, said yesterday that it would pay $257.2 million in cash to FPL Group Inc. for Adelphia shares held by FPL and FPL's stake in a Florida cable company. Adelphia, based in Coudersport, Pa., said it would buy back common and preferred shares owned by FPL, the owner of Florida Power and Light, for about $150 million and pay $107.5 million for FPL's one-third interest in Olympus Communications L.P., a partnership formed in 1995 to provide cable service to 550,000 customers in central and eastern Florida. Shares of FPL fell 25 cents, to $55.50. Adelphia rose $2.25, to $59.0625.

title: When 'Pygmalion' Meets MTV, the Bookworm Turns
description: No matter how much the world changes, the caste system of a typical American high school seems inviolable. The jocks, cheerleaders and pretty people rule, while the nerds, bookworms and arty types remain the untouchables.

title: NATO Threatens Military Action To Stem the Violence in Kosovo
description: The NATO allies warned today that they are fully ready to take military action to stop further violence by both sides in Serbia's ravaged Kosovo province, and Britain and France said they are willing to send in ground forces if they are needed to reinforce a political settlement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFIELD, HOWARD
description: GARFIELD-Howard. Died on January 23, 1999 in Boynton Beach, Florida. Beloved husband of Rebecca. Loving father of Arthur, Lawrence and Jeffrey. Father-inlaw of Carol, Patricia and Lynne. Grandfather of Michele, Nicole, Tracy, Lee, Jason, Rob and Adam. His gentle spirit and devoted caring will be missed by all who had the good fortune of knowing him.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Slain Officer Is Mourned By Thousands At Funeral
description: Sleet fell like cold, hard tears today on this small suburban town on the outskirts of Hartford, where thousands quietly gathered to lay to rest Brian A. Aselton, the East Hartford police officer who was shot to death Saturday night when he responded to what he thought was a routine call.

title: Is That a Doll In My Lasagna?
description: After a few minutes on Klickitat Street, you're bound to think you're in ''Leave It to Beaver'' territory: the characters include a full-time mother who's always baking cookies, a beaming paterfamilias who dotes on his wife, and their two daughters, who have a loving if often argumentative relationship. The only working women are schoolteachers.

title: Serbs' Talk of Killings Was Intercepted, U.S. Says
description: American officials said today that conversations among senior Serbian officials about a massacre of 45 civilians in Kosovo were intercepted and that this underscored the need for an international war-crimes investigation.

title: Trustees Attacked by Pataki Open Fire on Each Other
description: Already under attack from Gov. George E. Pataki, the trustees of the New York City School Construction Authority trained their fire on each other yesterday in a public meeting punctuated by spoken jabs and sharp disagreements over how best to raise the agency's credibility.

title: Sports of The Times; N.F.L.'s Silent Majority Afraid to Force Change
description: As the National Football League prepares for its final championship game of the 1900's, the league celebrates a boom that has transformed pro football from a game played on muddy fields before sparse crowds into the national signature. As it prepares for the next millennium, the N.F.L. is entangled by the same nagging issue that has plagued the nation for the last 100 years: race, racism and an African-American presence in a white power structure.

title: It's All in a Day's Work For Hard-Tapping Hard Hats
description: Dein Perry has upped the ante exponentially in ''Steel City,'' which opened its 40-city American and Canadian tour on Tuesday night at Radio City Music Hall. Mr. Perry, the creator of the smaller and more intimate ''Tap Dogs,'' crams the Music Hall stage with steel stairways, huge steel grids that get flipped every which way, and trucks and cars of all descriptions. A steel-mesh front curtain rises and descends, and an immense reflecting disk opens to frame the show's culminating rock-club scene. Colored lights and smoke are everywhere.

title: Windfall City
description: Even at this moment of prosperity, New York City faces mounting budget deficits and municipal debt in the years ahead. Yesterday Mayor Rudolph Giuliani proposed some clever fiscal acrobatics to address these problems and still meet the city's needs. He wants to roll over a $1.6 billion budget surplus into next year to pay for operating expenses. He also wants to use money expected from the tobacco lawsuit settlement as collateral for $2.5 billion in loans to build schools. Both steps raise questions that need to be analyzed thoroughly before the City Council approves them.

title: Race Mix-Up Raises Havoc For Capital
description: The new black Mayor's decision to accept the resignation of a white aide who upset a black colleague by using the word ''niggardly'' has turned into a major embarrassment for the young administration.

title: Why Do the Republicans Ignore Centrist Voters?; Long-Term Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: 15 New Charter Schools To Open by End of 2000
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced the formation of 15 new charter schools yesterday, raising to 54 the number of the independent but publicly funded schools that the state has approved since 1997.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Gonzalo Torrente Ballester, Award-Winning Novelist, 88
description: Gonzalo Torrente Ballester, a novelist who drew heavily on the myths and witchcraft lore of his native Galicia and won top literary prizes, died on Wednesday at his home in Salamanca. He was 88.

title: Gay2K, Janet Reno's Hair And Overzealous Parents
description: Kate Clinton thinks reaction to Ellen DeGeneres's sitcom was pretty funny. Even some gay men and lesbians, she points out, thought the show was ''too gay.'' Maybe, she suggests, ''it should have been gay every other week.''

title: Sunken Boat Had Hose Caught in Its Propeller
description: Divers who found the clam boat Adriatic off the New Jersey coast on Jan. 19 believe a hose got entangled in the boat's propeller before the vessel sank in rough seas, a Coast Guard officer testified yesterday at a hearing in Philadelphia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREY, LESTER
description: GREY-Lester. On Wednesday, January 27th, of Chestnut Hill. Beloved husband of Adabelle (Gibbs). Loving father of Gilbert Maker and June Ogden, and Charles and Gail Maker. Cherished grandfather of Adam and Reid Maker. Dear brother of Isabell Appell, Eleanor Farber, and the late Bernard Goldberg. Mr. Grey was a thirty-five year employee of The New York Times. He retired in 1990. His career began in the School Service Division and progressed to work as an Advertising Department Account Manager. Service at the Levine Chapel, 470 Harvard Street, Brookline, on Friday, January 29 at 10 AM. Memorial observance through Sunday at his late residence. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to Make-AWish Foundation, 99 Bedford St, 3rd Floor, Boston, MA. 02111.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECK, ALFRED
description: BECK-Alfred. A longtime resident of Yonkers, NY on January 29, 1999. Husband of Margit (Vogel) Beck, father of Robert and William Beck, grandfather of Lisa Rosenfeld, Tracey Ruth, Julie Behar, David and Michael Beck. Funeral service Sunday 12:30PM at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York. Interment in Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: In the Red. No, Black.
description: Republicans leaders are accusing President Clinton of budget gimmickry, saying his plan to shore up reserves in the Social Security trust fund is an accounting trick.

title: New York Tourist Guide To Be Printed in Canada
description: The $544,000 contract to produce the 1999 ''I Love N.Y.'' travel guide has gone to St. Joseph Printing in Concord, Ontario, according to the Empire State Development Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCANN, HELEN M.
description: McCANN-Helen M.. The Barnard College Community mourns the death of Helen M. McCann, class of 1940, and Director of Admissions at the College from 1952 until 1977. To College counselors and school heads across the country, and to twenty-five classes of Barnard Alumnae, the name of Helen McCann was synonymous with Barnard. In her years at the College, Ms. McCann supported and advanced the mission of the College with her uncompromising committment to excellence and to access based on individual promise and achievement. We remember her fine intelligence, wit, and devotion to the College and extend our heartfelt sympathy to her sister Maureen McCann Miletta, class of 1950 and nieces Alexandra Miletta and Jennifer Miletta Adams, class of 1986. Judith Shapiro, President Gayle Robinson, '75 Chair, Board of Trustess

title: Children Go to Foster Care Needlessly, Suit Charges
