description: A group of parents filed a class-action lawsuit against New York City's child welfare agency yesterday, charging that child-abuse investigators routinely violate the law by taking children from their families and placing them in foster care even when they are not in danger.

title: Ruth R. Mott, 97; Led Family Charities
description: Ruth Rawlings Mott, who oversaw an array of charitable organizations, died on Monday at her home in Flint, Mich. She was 97.

title: Trade Center Terrorist Ends Hunger Strike Under Threat
description: One of the men convicted in the World Trade Center bombing ended a two-week hunger strike yesterday after a Federal judge in Manhattan threatened to return him to a Texas prison from New York, where he had been brought to prepare for a court hearing next month.

title: Trade Body Resolves Banana Battle, for Now at Least
description: After five days of intense wrangling, members of the World Trade Organization reached a compromise tonight in the politically charged banana dispute, which appears to have averted, at least for now, a major rift between the United States and the European Union.

title: Nokia Reports Profits Soared in 4th Quarter
description: Nokia, the world's largest producer of cellular phones, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose a greater-than-expected 72 percent.

title: Back on Track, With a Friend's Help
description: Terrance T. remembers how he spent his 10th birthday: sitting beside the phone in his mother's apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant, waiting for his father to call.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPMAN, CARROLL FERGUSON
description: CHAPMAN-Carroll Ferguson. , 90. Of Mount Kisco, NY died January 27th at Phelps Memorial Hospital, Tarrytown, New York, after a short illness. She is survived by her daughter, Diana Kamilli of Tuscon, AZ., and grandchildren, Daniel Chapman of Pleasantville, NY, and Robert Kamilli, two great grandchildren, Emily and Alice Chapman and by her sister Ruth Woolfe of Camden, SC., Mrs. Chapman was born in Greenwich, CT in 1908. She attended Rosemary Hall and Miss Porter's School (1927). She married Daniel K. Chapman of Greenwich in 1927 and was a resident of Mt. Kisco for 62 years. She was a warm and generous spirit who with gracious elegance and humor enriched the lives of those around her. Friends may call at The Oelker & Cox Funeral Home Inc., Mount Kisco, New York, on Saturday (today) from 7-9PM. A memorial service will be held Sunday, January 31 at 3 P.M., at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, 85 East Main Street, Mount Kisco, New York. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations may be made to St. Mark's Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLANTZ, STEVEN W.
description: GLANTZ-Steven W.. January 16, 1943 to January 29, 1999. Beloved husband of Dottie. Loving father of Alissa and Jason. Dear brother of Melvin. Devoted son of Lillian. Steven was a Certified Public Accountant and partner of Smallberg Sorkin & Company, LLP. Steven was a true symbol of the qualities for which a CPA is known: integrity, knowledge and trustworthiness. He was a loved and respected member of the professional community. Steven was an involved and highly regarded member of Temple Emanuel. Steven embraced all who knew him with his loving and charitable nature. All of his clients, business associates, friends and family will deeply miss him. Funeral to be held on Sunday, January 31, at 11:30 AM at Temple Emanuel, 147 Tenafly Road, Englewood, NJ. 201-567-1300. Please make all contributions in his name to Cancer Care of Ridgewood, NJ.

title: DANCE
description: Wrestling, Prancing, Falling: Is There a Meaning? Or Not?

title: For Grant, a Partner Becomes a Foe
description: When the trainer Don Turner was looking for a sparring partner to toughen up the young heavyweight Michael Grant for two important bouts last year, Turner brought in Ahmad Abdin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAGLIAMONTE, AUGUST
description: TAGLIAMONTE-August. Of New York City and Richmond, Massachusetts. Died tragically in an automobile accident on January 28, 1999. He is survived by his wife, Lee Lamont; daughter, Leslie Lamont; sisters, Flora Amorello, Vivian Petretti and Mary Tagliamonte Shiller; and brother, Edmund Tagliamonte. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. TAGLIAMONTE-August. The entire staff of ICM Artists extends our deepest sympathies to our Chairman, Lee Lamont on the tragic loss of her husband, Augie. We also offer our heartfelt condolences to their daughter, Leslie Lamont, and to his whole family. David V. Foster, Pres. and CEO Stewart J. Warkow, Exec. V.P. Byron Gustafson, Sr. V.P. Jenny Vogel, Sr. V.P. TAGLIAMONTE - August (La mont). The Board of Trustees and Staff of Carnegie Hall extend our condolences and heartfelt sympathy to cherished colleague, Lee Lamont, on the sudden and tragic death of her husband, August. Our thoughts are with you. Isaac Stern, President Sanford I. Weill, Chairman TAGLIAMONTE - August (La mont). We are deeply saddened by his tragic death and wish to express heartfelt condolences to our very dear friend Lee Lamont and their daughter, Leslie. Bella and Leonard Linden TAGLIAMONTE - August (La mont). To our beloved friend, Lee Lamont, we extend our arms and our hearts to share your pain. Linda and Isaac Stern

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRHARDT, HELEN M.
description: EHRHARDT-Helen M.., on January 28, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Lloyd. Dear mother of Lloyd, Helen and Donna. Devoted grandmother of seven and great-grandmother of two. Religious service at the David J. Hodder & Son Funeral Home, 899 McLean Ave. (near Kimball), Yonkers on Sunday, 8PM. Funeral Monday, 10AM. Interment Kensico Cemetery. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-4PM and 7-9PM.

title: Can the U.N. Take A Stronger Role?
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore Seeks to Protect Trade From World's Fiscal Crisis
description: Vice President Al Gore warned today that the world had to ''prevent the financial crisis of 1998 from becoming the trade crisis of 1999,'' and said the United States would seek the ''outright elimination'' of the huge and politically sensitive subsidies that European nations provide to farmers.

title: Nasdaq Passes 2,500 as G.D.P. Rise Revives Profit Hopes
description: Stocks advanced yesterday on news of a surprising surge in United States economic growth, which raised confidence in the outlook for corporate profits. The Nasdaq composite index wrapped up its biggest monthly gain in 24 years.

title: Mayors Applaud President and His Urban Proposals
description: President Clinton took advantage of a meeting with mayors from more than 200 cities today to announce that he is seeking a hefty raise for the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUNDBERG, HELEN
description: LUNDBERG-Helen., 83. Died on Thursday, January 28, 1999 at her home in Briarcliff Manor, NY. Longtime resident of Briarcliff Manor. She was born in Manhattan and had been a longtime member of the Junior League. She was the wife of the late Nils A. Lundberg, whom she married on January 16, 1937. She is survived by her daughter Linda Mosbarger of Green Valley, AZ, and her sons Jon Lundberg of Briarcliff Manor and Anders Lundberg of Birmingham, MI. She is also survived by her seven grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Visiting hours are on Sunday, January 31, from 2-4 and 7-9PM at the Waterbury and Kelly Funeral Home, Briarcliff Manor. Services will be at 10AM on Monday at the funeral home with a private interment at Kensico Cemetery.

title: 5 Teen-Agers Arrested After Slaying That Followed Ball Game
description: Five Brooklyn teen-agers were arrested early yesterday morning in connection with the stabbing death Wednesday night of a 14-year-old basketball player, as new details emerged in a tale of how disrespect turned to disaster, with a fatal result far out of proportion to the original argument.

title: SHOP AT HOME SAYS IT WILL CONSIDER TAKEOVER OFFERS
description: Shares of Shop at Home Inc. rose 44 percent yesterday after the company, the third-largest home-shopping specialty retailer in the United States, said it would consider an acquisition offer from a broadcast competitor or Internet company. Shop at Home rose $5.25, to $17.125, in trading of 10.9 million shares, more than eight times its three-month daily average. The company, which sells merchandise like electronics, jewelry and sports collectibles on television and the Internet, said it might consider an offer made by Home Shopping Network Inc., QVC Inc., Broadcast.com Inc. or another company.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Modano And Hull Take Lead
description: STARS 3, LIGHTNING 1

title: CITIGROUP DROPPING PLANS TO ACQUIRE G-TECH UNIT
description: Citigroup will drop its plans to acquire the electronic benefit transfer business of the Transactive Corporation, averting an antitrust lawsuit, the Justice Department said yesterday. The decision comes six months after the department filed suit to block the acquisition, arguing that it would eliminate competition in the electronic benefits business. Transactive, a unit of the G-Tech Corporation, is the primary provider of electronic benefits services in three states. Citigroup is the chief contractor in 29 states. The Justice Department said yesterday that it would drop its antitrust suit in light of the decision.

title: L. C. Lewin, Writer of Satire Of Government Plot, Dies at 82
description: Leonard C. Lewin, whose Vietnam-era satire of a supposed secret Government study on the dangers of peace, ''Report From Iron Mountain,'' resurfaced nearly 30 years later as proof of Government conspiracies for right-wing paramilitary groups, died on Thursday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 82 lived in Guilford, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  INNISS, CHARLES E
description: INNISS-Charles E. June 13, 1935January 30, 1997. You are remembered, today, tomorrow and forever. Love, Marjorie

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, RUBIN, , DONNA, M.D.
description: LEVY-RUBIN--Donna, M.D.. The attorneys and staff of Mazur, Carp & Rubin, P.C., deeply mourn the sudden and untimely passing of Donna Levy-Rubin, beloved wife of our esteemed member, Gary L. Rubin, and mother of Adam and Zachary. She was a brilliant and dedicated physician who will be remembered and missed by all who knew her. Her devotion to her husband, children and patients, and her intellect and energy were boundless. Services Sunday, January 31, 10 A.M., Memorial Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey.

title: Big Ferry Operator to Enter New York Market
description: Adding corporate muscle to New York Harbor's passenger-ferry industry, a British shipping and hotel company said yesterday that it had paid $5 million to acquire Express Navigation Inc., which operates ferry service from Monmouth County, N.J., to Wall Street.

title: Long-Term Plan Shown in Salt Lake City Bid
description: The leaders of Salt Lake City's effort to win the Olympics committed themselves as early as 1991 to a four-year campaign that included financial assistance to people who could influence the awarding of the 2002 Winter Games, planning documents show.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Surge in 1998's G.D.P. Pushes Market Gauges Up

title: Judge Allows Death Penalty Case to Proceed
description: Facing trial next month in the first Federal death penalty case in Manhattan in more than 40 years, a man suspected of being a Bronx gang leader has lost a bid to have the charges against him dismissed.

title: Officials Say Man Posing As Officer Molested Boy
description: A 31-year-old dishwasher has been arrested and accused of molesting an 8-year-old boy he lured into a Fairview apartment building by producing a phony police badge and claiming to be a police officer, county prosecutors said yesterday.

title: MASCO IN TALKS TO ACQUIRE SEVERAL RIVAL COMPANIES
description: The Masco Corporation, the largest maker of kitchen cabinets and bathroom fixtures in the United States, said yesterday that it was in advanced talks to acquire seven or eight smaller rivals for a total of more than $1 billion. The target companies would add between $800 million and $900 million to Masco's estimated 1998 revenue of $4.33 billion and allow it to meets its goal of increasing revenue between 5 and 7 percent a year. Masco's products include Delta and Peerless faucets and Merillat cabinets. The company, based in Taylor, Mich., declined to identify the companies it hoped to acquire but said it expected to announce the acquisitions in the first half of the year. Masco has about $500 million in cash on hand, and analysts said it should have no trouble financing the acquisitions.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FRANKLIN MUTUAL ADVISORS INC., Short Hills, N.J., a mutual funds company, said it held 2.59 million shares of UST Corp., a Boston-based community bank, or 6.1% of outstanding common stock, at the end of 1998.

title: CHECKERS TO BUY RALLY'S HAMBURGERS
description: Checkers Drive-In Restaurants Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Rally's Hamburgers Inc. for $29.3 million in stock, to make the companies more competitive in the quick-service restaurant business. Checkers also plans to complete a 1-for-12 reverse stock split in an effort to increase its share price and preserve its listing on the Nasdaq stock market. Shares of Checkers fell 9.375 cents, to 43.75 cents, on Nasdaq; Rally's fell 3.125 cents, to $1. After the reverse split, Checkers shares should trade around $5.25, which is above the minimum $1 required for Nasdaq listing. Rally's and Checkers combined their headquarters in Clearwater, Fla., last year, but said they would still see some cost savings from their merger.

title: Matchup: Why Atlanta Will Win
description: DENVER (16-2) vs. ATLANTA (16-2)

title: 2d Sitter Caught on Tape Hitting Child, Police Say
description: A Bergen County baby sitter was arrested on Thursday after being caught on videotape striking a child in her care, the police said yesterday. It was the second such incident in the county this month.

title: Can the U.N. Take A Stronger Role?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Stout Haydn, Well Groomed And in a Hurry
description: With the last of its three Haydn concerts due in March, the Orchestra of St. Luke's seems intent on giving us the great man's music from as many viewpoints as possible. Two events will have been conducted by period-instrument advocates happy also to apply historical practices to modern orchestras: Franz Bruggen in late December (whom I was not in town to hear) and, coming in early March, Roger Norrington.

title: Ms. Reno Does It Again
description: It is no surprise that Attorney General Janet Reno decided not to let an independent counsel pursue allegations of perjury against Harold Ickes, the former White House official who ran President Clinton's 1996 campaign. The decision is consistent with her other efforts to prevent the thorough investigation of White House fund-raising recommended by the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and by Ms. Reno's top campaign-finance prosecutor. The Reno cover-up is now complete and will become a shameful page in Justice Department history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEYSAR, FRANKLIN
description: KEYSAR - Franklin. Broadway production stage manager, on January 25, 1999 of liver cancer. Born in Warren, New Hampshire January 22, 1939. Survived by his mother Bertha Keysar & three brothers, Philip, Donald, & Gary, three sisters, Phyllis Colby-Mudgett, Patti Bartlett and Virginia Keysar. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, January 31, 1PM at Park Avenue United Methodist Church, 106 E. 86 Street. Donations may be made to Broadway Cares/ EFA or the Park Avenue United Methodist Church.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PLUMB, PATRICIA GOWING
description: PLUMB-Patricia Gowing. The family of Patricia Gowing Plumb and The Congregation of St. Thomas More Catholic Church, 65 East 89th Street, New York, announce a Memorial Mass, Saturday, January 30, 1999, at 3:00.

title: U.S. Planning to Seek Further Sanctions on Libya
description: A month before a United States deadline for Libya to hand over two suspects in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland in 1988, Administration officials say they are planning to seek tougher economic sanctions against the country.

title: Young Turks Rediscover A Game They Helped Invent
description: Ask a contract bridge expert when and where the game developed, and the answer is likely to focus on Harold Vanderbilt's celebrated cruise through the Panama Canal in 1925. That great yachtsman certainly codified the modern form, but he did not invent it. The contract idea was popular in France a decade earlier, under the name plafond, and four English officers in India were perhaps earlier still.

title: Mystery of Stray Tiger Leads Officials to a Preserve
description: Armed with search warrants and a forensic arsenal worthy of a murder investigation, state wildlife agents descended today on the property of a woman known to many as the ''Tiger Lady,'' seeking to confirm their suspicion that she was the owner of the tiger that was shot Wednesday night after wandering loose for several hours.

title: Can the U.N. Take A Stronger Role?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rusty Ewing Injures A Knee
description: Patrick Ewing's opportunity to work himself into shape hit a snag in the second quarter tonight when he limped into the tunnel and disappeared for the rest of the Knicks' exhibition game against the Nets.

title: Star-Crossed Pakistani Couple Diverted From Flight to 'Happy Ever After'
description: True love may never run smooth, but rarely is the road as treacherous as it has been for Humaira and Mehmood Butt, Pakistani lovers who, though joined in marriage, have a powerful man trying to tear them asunder.

title: Lakers' Bryant Signs for $71 Million
description: Kobe Bryant signed a six-year contract extension, believed to be worth nearly $71 million, with the Lakers yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACAS, ROSA
description: MACAS-Rosa. January 28, 1999, age 81. Born Vienna, Austria. Beloved wife of the late Rudolf Macas, devoted mother of Christina Rose and Ellie Silverman, motherin-law of Allen Silverman and Allan Rose, loving grandmother of Andrew, Marisa and Alex. We all love you and you will always be with us. As we say in Vienna ''Servus.'' Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Friday, 6 to 8 and Saturday 2 to 5 PM. Service Sunday, January 31, 1999, 11 AM at Frank E. Campbell.

title: Waving Off a Rivalry, Woods Is Making a Run
description: In recent weeks, many have called David Duval the world's No. 1 golfer. Tiger Woods, who is still No. 1 in the world ranking, claims he has not been bothered by the talk.

title: New Haven Renaissance
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BEG, PROFESSOR MIRZA ABDUL BAQI
description: BEG-Professor Mirza Abdul Baqi. Sept. 20, 1934-January 30, 1990.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO SLUMPS. New evidence of surging United States growth pushed the euro to the lowest level since the single European currency was introduced less than a month ago. The euro fell to $1.1345 in New York from $1.1410.

title: The Oneidas' Claim on New York
description: The sins of Albany's political forebears are being visited on 20,000 property owners in upstate New York who have deeds or property rights on about 270,000 acres now being claimed by the Oneida Indians. The Oneidas argue that between 1795 and 1840, the state purchased the large territory east of Syracuse from their tribe but failed to seek Congressional approval. Without that approval, today's Oneidas assert, the land could not be sold legally. Therefore, the tribe argues, with some support from the courts and the Federal Justice Department, the land still belongs to the Oneida Nation, which has about 1,000 members in New York State, 15,000 in Wisconsin and 3,000 in Ontario.

title: Allies Call Kosovo Rivals To Peace Talks in France
description: In an unusual show of unity, the United States, four Western European nations and Russia today summoned the warring sides in Kosovo to a peace conference in France next Friday and suggested that if they did not reach agreement within two weeks, air strikes would follow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, FRED C.
description: MILLER-Fred C.. On January 29, 1999, died at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital. Beloved husband of Martha Miller.

title: White House Leans Against Calling Witnesses
description: The White House will probably forgo witnesses of its own in President Clinton's impeachment trial unless the three witnesses giving depositions next week present damaging new evidence against him, White House advisers said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, STANLEY
description: LERNER-Stanley., 92, passed away on Friday, January 29, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Janet. Survived by sister Irene Lerner Opalek and by many nephews and nieces, grand-nephews and grandnieces. Funeral services will be held cryptside Sunday, January 31st at 10:30AM at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, 7800 Myrtle Ave., Glendale, NY. Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapel, 2230 Hollywood Blvd., Hollywood, FL 33020.

title: SUPREME INTERNATIONAL AGREES TO ACQUIRE PERRY ELLIS
description: The Supreme International Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Perry Ellis International, the privately held men's clothing designer, for $75 million in cash. The New York-based Perry Ellis International licenses Perry Ellis trademark products in the United States and abroad. The Miami-based Supreme International designs and sells men's and boy's sportswear under the Crossings, Natural Issue, Munsingwear, Andrew Fezza and Ping brands. Its shares rose $1.625, to $16.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINESTONE, EVERETT
description: FINESTONE-Everett., on January 28, 1999. Adored soulmate of Roberta. Loving, devoted father of Ronnie, Steven and Jerry. Cherished Papa of Erin, Morgan, Katarina and Dylan. Dear brother of Chester and friend to so many. Service Sunday 11:15AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. FINESTONE-Everett. The Friends of the Israel Defense Forces deeply mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend, Everett, a devoted supporter of the soldiers of Israel. He will be deeply missed by all of us. To his beloved wife, Roberta and to the entire family, our sincere condolences. John Klein Brig. Gen. Eliezer Hemeli FINESTONE-Everette.You were always the life of the party, a very good friend, kind, generous, and the love in Roberta's life. We will miss you forever. Ruth, Fred, Evan and Jason Schwalbe FINESTONE-Everett. On January 28, 1999. A gentle giant of a man, my business partner, my mentor and my friend. Thank you for preparing me. I will think of you every day of my life. I love you, Zack.

title: Can the U.N. Take A Stronger Role?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jitters Anew in Brazil as Currency Plunges Again
description: From Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, who warned today that Brazilian leaders appeared to be underestimating the financial crisis confronting them, to congressional employees who lined up to empty their bank accounts on rumors that the Government would freeze personal savings, signs of alarm deepened across Brazil today.

title: Taking New Wave's Smirk And Doubling It for Today
description: It's no wonder that Marvelous 3's ''Hey! Album'' (Elektra) starts with a song called ''You're So Yesterday.'' The band, which is from Atlanta, wore its influences with pride when it performed at the Mercury Lounge on Wednesday night. Marvelous 3 are dedicated to the New Wave moment of the late 1970's and early 80's, when punk's brutal economy spurred musically ambitious bands to rediscover concise, catchy tunes.

title: Justice Inquiry Of Clinton Aide Closed by Reno
description: Ending an inquiry that has haunted her for months, Attorney General Janet Reno declined today to appoint an independent counsel to investigate whether a former White House aide, Harold M. Ickes, lied to a Senate committee two years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCH, THELMA
description: KIRSCH-Thelma. On January 27th, 1999. Beloved wife of Bertram. Devoted mother of Joshua and David. Dear sister of Joseph Kauanay. Graveside services on Sunday 1:30 PM at Mount Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, New York.

title: House Chafes at Senate Dictates and Decorum
description: Senate Republicans say they have given Representative Henry J. Hyde just about everything he could ask for: an impeachment trial, depositions from witnesses, even the possibility that Monica S. Lewinsky may be summoned in person, or on videotape, to testify on the Senate floor.

title: Tagliabue Has His Say: Taylor Belongs in the Hall
description: Usually, Commissioner Paul Tagliabue's annual Super Bowl news conference produces few surprises. But today, Tagliabue shocked many at his annual state of the league address by making a passionate plea to elect Lawrence Taylor, the former Giants linebacker, to the Hall of Fame.

title: No to 'Physics First'; Use the Real World
description: To the Editor:

title: AT&T MAY CUT $45 MILLION FROM OFFER FOR SMARTALK
description: The AT&T Corporation may shave as much as $45 million from its offer for the prepaid calling-card seller Smartalk Teleservices Inc. because of slumping sales at that company. AT&T offered $192.5 million in cash for Smartalk on Jan. 19, the day Smartalk filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors. Court papers show that the sales agreement stipulates $45 million as the maximum amount the sale price could be cut. Smartalk said yesterday that Erich Spangenberg was stepping down as its chief executive and Jeff Lindauer was leaving his post as president and chief operating officer. Shares of AT&T rose 81.25 cents yesterday, to $90.75.

title: Settlement Bars Au Pair From Profits in Baby's Death
description: Boston witnessed the likely final chapter in its nanny murder case today: a civil-suit settlement barring the convicted British au pair, Louise Woodward, from ever profiting from the death of the baby in her care.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CASEY, ELIZABETH F
description: CASEY-Elizabeth F. We love and miss you, Mommy and Lizzie, but we know your love and strength continue to shine down on us. Forever in our hearts. Steven, Catie and Maxx

title: Ex-Officer Gets 9 Years In Fatal Beating of Man
description: A former Jersey City police officer was sentenced on Thursday to nine years in prison in the fatal beating of a handcuffed man in 1995, county prosecutors said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARATTA, MARYLOU
description: BARATTA-Marylou. Local 137 and The Service Trade Association of Greater New York mourn the loss of our dear friend Marylou Baratta, proprietor of Marylou's restaurant. We will always remember her compassion and generosity. Our sincerest and deepest sympathies are with Marylou's family and many friends during this time of profound loss.

title: Can the U.N. Take A Stronger Role?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEETER, J. SARAH (FRIEDMAN)
description: TEETER-J. Sarah (Friedman), 28, of Franklin, Mass and Cresskill, NJ. Deeply loved and loving wife of Joshua. Cherished daughter of Elizabeth Friedman. She fought and overcame so many road blocks placed in her path by a terrible disease with courage and humor. Sarah's concern for others was reflected in her work with the Cresskill Volunteer Ambulance Squad and in her nursing career. A fine musician, she was the melody of our lives. Services will be held at ''Wien & Wien'', Englewood, New Jersey, Sunday, January 31, at 11am. In lieu of flowers please send donations to: L. A. M. Foundation, 1010 South Beacon Hills Drive, Cincinatti, Ohio 45241 or sign up as an organ donor.

title: U.S. ECONOMY GREW AT FAST 5.6% RATE AT THE END OF '98
description: A year of pleasant economic surprises ended with the biggest one of all: a last-minute burst of growth that surpassed even the most bullish predictions.

title: Flunking Students Is No Cure-All
description: President Clinton's latest education proposals have been getting him enthusiastic applause. But on one point, at least, we should be wary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHBERG, FANNIE
description: ROTHBERG-Fannie. aka Red and/or Rusty to friends at the 92nd Street Y. Died January 28, 1999 at age 96. Beloved sister of Hannah R. Lesser, devoted aunt. Graveside service 10:30am at Bayside Cemetery, Ozone Park Queens.

title: The World Reintroduces Beauvoir to the French
description: This is where Simone de Beauvoir lived and loved, marched and wrote, so Paris is the natural place for scholars to gather to start celebrating the 50th anniversary of her seminal feminist book, ''The Second Sex.'' For four days here last week, they debated Beauvoir with a mixture of joy and reverence, and their unsurprising conclusion was that ''The Second Sex'' is as topical and worthy of study as ever.

title: CNN Seeks to Open Impeachment Deliberations
description: Cable News Network asked the Senate today to open its deliberations in the impeachment trial of President Clinton, declaring that ''no subject of the Senate should be subject to more -- and more informed -- public scrutiny.''

title: In a 'Disappointing' Report, Kellogg Says Profit Fell 40%
description: The Kellogg Company said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit excluding one-time adjustments fell more than 40 percent, reflecting stiffer competition and diminished consumer appetite for cereal.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Soprano Whose Recital Reaches From Spain to Wales

title: No to 'Physics First'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, MORTIMER J. JR.
description: FOX-Mortimer J. Jr.., 89. Of Montclair, on January 27, 1999. Beloved husband of Mary Lou (nee Yoder) Fox. Devoted father of Barbara McWilliams of Pinehurst, N. Carolina, James of Montclair, Phil of Hysham, Montana, and Robert of Potomac, Maryland. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Family services will be held privately. For information Arthur K. Brown, Inc., Bloomfield. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Montclair Volunteer Ambulance Unit, 86 Valley Rd, Montclair, NJ 07042 or the Mountainside Hospital Foundation, Dedicated to Geriatrics and Diseases of Aging, 1 Bay Ave., Montclair, New Jersey 07042.

title: Russia Again Delays Space Station Project
description: Launching of the next section of the International Space Station, a Russian-made module with laboratory and crew space, will be delayed until at least September because of technical problems with the component, NASA officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZBERG, WILLIAM BRUCE
description: SALZBERG-William Bruce. Beloved husband of Ann (nee Politziner). Devoted father of Howard and Marc. Cherished son of Muriel and the late Herbert. Loving brother of Nancy Blorian and Robert Salzberg. Services Sunday, 1 PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, N.Y.

title: Vernon Berg 3d, 47, Gay Ensign Who Fought Navy on Discharge
description: Vernon E. (Copy) Berg 3d, an artist who was one of the first military officers to challenge a discharge on the ground of homosexuality, died Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 47 and lived in Manhattan and Bridgehampton, N.Y.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: THE GODFATHER JR.
description: Smart Mafia bosses always tried to shield their sons from the mob. John Gotti wasn't a smart Mafia boss, and his son John Jr. is paying for it. A report by Jeffrey Goldberg, in the magazine.

title: Pope's Appeal Not Enough to Bridge Divide on Executions and Other Issues
description: When Pope John Paul II condemned capital punishment in his brief pastoral visit here, the 100,000 people gathered before him in an indoor stadium roared with applause, not once but three times, during that section of his homily.

title: INSIDE
description: In Brazil, More Distress

title: Skating Rink to House New Media Company
description: The skating rink that used to be Sky Rink, on the 16th floor of a building at 450 West 33d Street at 10th Avenue, will be converted into the headquarters of a rapidly growing new media company called Doubleclick.

title: Editorial Notebook; Picking the Parliament's Hottest Hits
description: Everywhere in the former Communist world, the transition to democracy and the free market depends on the young. While older people tend to feel threatened by the risk and responsibility demanded by capitalism, those in their 20's relish them. For the most part, the young are more tolerant, less nationalistic and more interested in European normality than their elders. They do not support the Slobodan Milosevics of the region. But their views count little, because like young people everywhere, they tend not to vote.

title: Hingis Wins Her Third Straight Australian Title
description: Martina Hingis has her own Rebound Ace court in Switzerland, and one glance at the Grand Slam record books will make it clear that the Rebound Ace courts in Melbourne belong to her, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABEL, LILLIAN CHERNOK
description: SABEL-Lillian Chernok. On January 29, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Joseph E. Sabel. Adored mother of Charles, David & Janet. Adoring grandmother of Claire, Henry, Alexander and Emma. Receiving visitors at 355 Riverside Drive (108th Street), Apt. 15C, from 5-8 P.M., Tuesday and Wednesday, February 2nd and 3rd.

title: For Radio City Restoration, a $2.5 Million Sales Tax Break
description: As a part of Rockefeller Center, where the rents for prime retail space are now on a par with Madison Avenue, Radio City Music Hall may not seem to be situated in a blighted neighborhood.

title: POP
description: Both Longing and Dignity, Grounded in Celtic Forms

title: Several Major U.S. Airlines Lift Fares Across the Board
description: Several major airlines made across-the-board increases in their fares yesterday, sending stock prices in the industry soaring as investors apparently believed that a price increase would finally stick after numerous abortive attempts in recent months.

title: With Help, Climbing Back From Schizophrenia's Isolation
description: Even now, after the voices have been silent for four years and he has built a life for himself much like the lives that other people live, Ken Steele speaks gingerly, as if talking about those times in too much detail might somehow bring them back.

title: Back in the Saddle, With Gusto or Fear?
description: When last seen riding in a race, Mike Smith was hurtling through the air from the saddle of a horse at Saratoga on Aug. 31. He crashed through the hedges lining the rail, fractured two vertebrae in his upper back and began an agonizing five-month exile from his career as one of the leading jockeys in America.

title: Royal Ahold to Sell Securities in U.S.
description: Royal Ahold N.V. and an affiliate filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell as much as $2.09 billion of securities. Royal Ahold, the world's No. 6 supermarket owner, is based in the Netherlands. It would be able to sell debt securities, warrants, and preferred and common shares under the shelf registration filed with the S.E.C.

title: And at Halftime, a Jousting Demonstration
description: In the Age of Football Chivalry, three men formed a legendary triangle in a most congenial spot called Denver.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOMINGDALE, LYMAN G.
description: BLOOMINGDALE-Lyman G.., on January 28, 1999, in Canton, MA. Beloved father of Gwen Bloomingdale, Jennifer B. Nelson, Penny B. Baker and Billie B. Logan. Loving grandfather of Andrew B. Bloomingdale, Gwendolyn R. Walker, Angus M. Walker, Mollie A. Nelson, Stephen A. Koshland, Andrew J. Logan and John P. Logan. Great-grandfather of three. Dear brother of George N. Cowen, the late Alfred S. Bloomingdale and Arthur Cowen, Jr. Services Monday, February 1st at 12:00 Noon at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Brown University or the American Friends of Hebrew University. BLOOMINGDALE - Lyman G. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Lyman G. Bloomingdale, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of his passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. May all who loved him be comforted. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: Value-Free Economics
description: To the Editor:

title: As Anthologies Duel, Women Gain Ground
description: The first stone in the war between Longman and W. W. Norton, the David and Goliath of the anthology publishing world, has been cast. With the recent publication of ''The Longman Anthology of British Literature,'' Longman has mounted a challenge to Norton to become the literary anthology of choice in colleges and universities around the country.

title: Ford-Volvo: A Deal for All Sweden
description: Having heard and read rumors for months that Volvo A.B. was in merger talks with one big car company or another, Bengt Persson was almost relieved to finally know that his employer would soon be the Ford Motor Company.

title: Officer Is Charged In a Sexual Assault
description: A New York City narcotics detective was arrested yesterday and accused of raping a woman in the Fordham section of the Bronx while he was off duty, the police said.

title: Ruling Backs Release of Microsoft Trial Material
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that all the deposition transcripts and videotapes in the Microsoft antitrust trial must be made public.

title: Some Relief for Kittles: His Knee Is Just Bruised
description: For once, the Nets received some good news regarding an injury. Kerry Kittles, the third-year shooting guard who was thought to have torn cartilage in his knee, received an incorrect diagnosis.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE SURGES 2.9 PERCENT. Prices jumped for a seventh day on speculation that some Brazilian exporters may raise prices because of a smaller crop. The March contract rose 2.9 cents, to $1.04 a pound.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: An obituary Jan. 23 of Jules W. Lederer, former husband of the advice columnist Ann Landers, misstated his involvement in the early days of Budget Rent-a-Car. Morris Mirkin, a distant relative of Mr. Led erer, founded the first business with the Budget Rent-a-Car name in 1958, and Mr. Lederer formed the Budget Rent-a-Car Corporation in 1960. Mr. Lederer was not the founder.

title: Playful Geniuses and French Music
description: George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins may have been world-class geniuses, but they could be as sunny and playful as the rest of us. That side was on display when the New York City Ballet performed on Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: A Credit Card for Every Occasion
description: Every January, inch-thick credit card statements clog the mailbox, the unwelcome aftermath of year-end celebrations. But it could be worse -- $5.7 million worse.

title: Freedom Combined With Invention
description: Jacky Terrasson's band this week at Iridium is, for the moment, a short-order affair: it's not organized around a new recording or a tour. But in its first set of the week, on Tuesday night, the group rode on such a high level of invention that it would be surprising if this were the last we heard of it. As a pianist, Mr. Terrasson was reliably brilliant; as a spontaneous organizer of music, he was at his best yet.

title: Internet Bubble Is Ready to Burst
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with an obituary of the architect and businessman Charles Luckman referred incorrectly to his involvement with Lever House. Although he did design the current Madison Square Garden and masterminded the creation of a new headquarters while president of Lever Brothers, the architect of Lever House was Gordon Bunshaft of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, as noted in the article. The obituary also misstated the completion year of Lever House. It was 1952, not 1956.

title: Sports of The Times; Already, Falcons Are Big Winners
description: THE time has come to lay the cards on the table. We've done a week's worth of storytelling, laid out all the Super Bowl nuances, explored the peripheral issues. Now there is a championship to decide.

title: Trading on Hollywood Magic; Celebrities Push Models Off Women's Magazine Covers
description: Linda Wells, the editor of Allure, a monthly fashion magazine published by Conde Nast, assembled her staff for a meeting in early December. The magazine, she said, would be changing its direction, placing more emphasis on celebrities.

title: Success on Sex Shops
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AIDES PUSHING PLAN TO USE G.I.'S IN A KOSOVO TRUCE
description: President Clinton's top national security advisers decided today that the United States should commit several thousand ground troops to an international force in Kosovo to monitor any eventual cease-fire there, according to Administration officials and members of Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNER, REBECCA JORDAN S.
description: HORNER-Rebecca Jordan S.. It is with sorrow that we note the passing of a woman whose life spanned nearly a century. As the mother of Mrs. Thomas A. Saunders III, a devoted and well-respected member of our Board of Trustees, she is included in our prayers as a member of the hospital's extended family. Mrs. Horner, whose home was in Norfolk, VA. was a descendant of two of our nation's founding families. She was the widow of Major General Matthew Charles Horner. We extend our most sincere condolences to her family members. Saul B. Katz, Chairman Board of Trustees John S.T. Gallagher, CEO David R. Dantzker, President North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: MEDTRONIC PLANS TO CLOSE PLANTS AND CUT JOBS
description: Medtronic Inc., the world's biggest pacemaker company, said yesterday that it would close five manufacturing sites and cut or relocate 1,600 jobs after buying Arterial Vascular Engineering Inc. Medtronic said on Thursday that it had completed its acquisition of Arterial Vascular, which makes products used in the artery-clearing procedure known as angioplasty. Medtronic valued the acquisition at about $4.1 billion in stock and debt. Medtronic is combining Arterial Vascular with its own division that makes products used to treat problems with blood vessels. Shares of Medtronic rose $4.0625, to $79.6875.

title: No to 'Physics First'; Put Math in Context
description: To the Editor:

title: Before Tripp, a Long Line of Denouncers; From the Salem Witch Trials to Serpico to the War on Drugs
description: As the impeachment trial progresses, historians, pundits and Senators are trying to cast President Clinton and his actions in historical context. No one is doing the same for Linda Tripp, but perhaps they should. For just as the President has been portrayed as following in various traditions, be it Presidential philanderer, accused liar or victim of partisan attack, Ms. Tripp has a historical lineage of her own: the citizen denouncer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENKRANTZ, FRANCES
description: ROSENKRANTZ - Frances. On January 28, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Devoted sister-inlaw of Terry Slade. Loving mother of Roger and the late Josi. Dear sister of Sophie Bettoja. Adoring grandmother of Adam, Joshua and Kurt. Cherished aunt of Edward and Judy, Richard, Michael and Doren, Toni and Valerie, Esther, Miriam and Angelo, Bobbie and Marilyn, Joan, Ruth, Gloria and Lynn. Beloved cousin of Will and Bea Maslow, Bertha Maslow and Edith Lunn. Service Sunday 11AM, at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. ROSENKRANTZ-Frances. Congreation Rodeph Sholom records with sorrow the passing of our devoted longtime member, Frances Rosenkrantz. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her son Roger and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Sr. Rabbi Mark Biderman, Pres.

title: Journal; Betty Currie's P.C. Pass
description: If you can't beat 'em, join 'em. Bill Clinton, aspiring to be President Pothole, gives a focus-group-driven laundry list of a State of the Union speech that stops just short of promising every citizen a health-club membership -- and what do Republicans do to counter it? Both members of Congress giving the G.O.P. televised response advertise that they've had Clintonesque marital fissures in their own families, and one of the pair, Jennifer Dunn, goes on and on about how ''sound,'' ''strong'' and ''prosperous'' the country is on Mr. Clinton's watch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNER, MURRAY
description: HORNER-Murray. 85. Of Vestal, N.Y. Formerly of New York City. On January 28, 1999. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Survived by his wife Lillian, daughters Paula Horner and Ellen Badger and brother Martin Horner. Founding member of Nathan Straus-Naphthali Lodge #

title: Invigorated Islanders Stage Rare Late Rally
description: Everything about the Islanders is different under Bill Stewart. It's in their preparation, their attitude and, ultimately, it's in the final score.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENSTEIN, JOE
description: ROSENSTEIN-Joe. 10 years have not dimmed your family's love. Oh how we miss the sparkle in your eyes

title: TRADING IN NEW INTERNET COMPANY IS HALTED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading in the securities of USA Talks.com Inc., a start-up Internet telephony company, after its shares almost quadrupled in less than a month, to a market value of $1.3 billion. The agency said questions had been raised about ''the accuracy and adequacy of public information'' about the company, including questions about the status and extent of its business operations. Trading in the securities of five other high-flying companies was also halted by the S.E.C. While USA Talks.com has 25 million shares outstanding, fully diluted the actual number of free-trading shares is only about 600,000, said the company's president, William Ervine. Its shares last traded at $52.25.

title: Linwood P. Shipley, 93, Investment Banker
description: Linwood Parks Shipley, a partner in the investment banking firm of Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, died in Summit, N.J., on Tuesday. He was 93.

title: Internet Bubble Is Ready to Burst
description: To the Editor:

title: T. C. Mann, 87, a Maker of U.S. Latin Policy
description: Thomas C. Mann, a career diplomat and an architect of a switch to an American policy in Latin America in the 1960's that emphasized free enterprise, died last Saturday at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 87.

title: Lewinsky's Testimony May Pose A Setback for Barbara Walters
description: The decision by the Senate's Republican majority to require Monica S. Lewinsky to testify in President Clinton's impeachment trial means that Barbara Walters of ABC News may have lost her opportunity to be the first to present Ms. Lewinsky answering questions on national television.

title: Autism Has a Town Struggling With Fear; With Causes Unclear, Parents Doubt Safety
description: Holding her tiny 6-month-old daughter close to her shoulder, Heather Howarth talked about Government scientists who had come into her town to study whether anything in the environment was causing local children to develop autism, a disorder that affects a child's ability to communicate and function socially.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLUFF, WARREN SUTHERLAND
description: CLUFF-Warren Sutherland. Of Long Valley and Brant Beach, New Jersey, on January 1st, 1999. A memorial service was held January 9th in Fairmont Presbyterian Church, Long Valley. Mr. Cluff was an organ and body donor for the University of Medicine and Dentistry of Newark.

title: Students And Teachers Fall Ill Again At a School
description: For the second time in two days, about 1,200 students were forced from a Bronx middle school yesterday morning after about 80 pupils and teachers suddenly and mysteriously fell ill with stomach and chest pains, school officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ARLENE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Arlene. January 28, 1999. Beloved aunt. She fought tirelessly on behalf of the healthcare consumer as a member ofthe State Board of Nursing, NYC Health and Hospital Corporation Board, Bellevue Community Board and NENA Health Council. Her work exemplified selfless public service, intellectual honesty, fearlessness in challenging the powerful on behalf of the powerless and absolute integrity. Services Tuesday 10:30AM, Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 W. 83 St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, LENORE
description: HARRIS-Lenore. of Forest Hills on January 26, 1999. Former NYC Corrections Deputy Warden. Beloved wife of the late James Harris. Reposing Glascott Funeral Home, 102 - 03 Metropolitan Avenue, Forest Hills, Sunday 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Mass Our Lady of Mercy Monday 9:45 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Beliefs; A social ethicist carries the language of economics into the world of religion, and, though history's tide opposes him, finds benefits for both.
description: Over the last 300 years, religion and economics have come to constitute distinctly different spheres, talking two conceptually different languages. They may address each other, as when Pope John Paul II called again in Mexico City for solidarity with the hemisphere's poor. But economists, however sympathetic to such appeals, bristle when morals get mixed up with economic analysis. And theologians turn very nervous when someone like William James begins to talk about the ''cash value'' of religious beliefs, as if the sacred could be given a price tag.

title: Chicago Board Seat Is Sold
description: The Chicago Board of Trade said today that a full membership on the world's largest futures exchange sold this week for $545,000, the highest in seven months. While membership still costs a third less than the record sale of $857,500 in May 1997, the price is up from $500,000 on Jan. 19 and has risen the last few months as trading volume set a record last year. A holder of a seat can buy and sell the exchange's contracts, like futures linked to United States Treasuries, corn and the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: Internet Bubble Is Ready to Burst
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; Trash Piles Up On Hopes Of Parolees
description: SEVERAL years ago, a pristine plaza sprang up on Second Avenue near East 118th Street, attracting crowds for free food, weddings, parties and revival meetings. The plaza, built by a group of ex-convicts who lived next door at the United Christian Prison Ministry, was a luminous sight in East Harlem. What was once a dumping ground for junk and junkies became a haven lined with skinny palm trees, murals of dreamy clouds and elegant arches. Hovering above it all -- O.K., bolted to the side of an adjoining building -- was a big wooden dove.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't think about the years gone. I try to think about what I can do now.''

title: After 2 Sinkings, Coast Guard to Speed Up Overhaul of Radio Gear
description: To Coast Guard radio operators, the frantic Mayday calls from crippled and sinking boats on two occasions were useless. The calls were muffled and no vessel names were discernible, the Coast Guard said. They gave no location, and were too brief to allow operators to get a directional bearing.

title: Don't Tell The Nets This Game Didn't Count
description: It will not count in the standing, and in a few days no one will remember that it happened. But the Nets will not belittle their 92-90 exhibition victory tonight over the Knicks.

title: Colombia Sends Troops to Quake Zone to Control Looters
description: Army and police units clashed repeatedly with roving bands of looters in the heart of this ravaged city today, slowing the delivery of supplies to thousands of residents left homeless by the earthquake on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARTH, MIDI
description: GARTH-Midi. On January 29, 1999. Dancer, teacher and friend. Dear sister of the late Ruth, Paula, Sally, Morty, Lily, Irv and sister-inlaw of Elly. Caring aunt to Linda, Barbara, Caroline, Richard, Robert, Kathy and David . Graveside service Sunday, 10AM at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRY, ROGER
description: PERRY-Roger. The Lower Hudson Chapter of The Nature Conservancy sends heartfelt condolences to the family of Roger Perry who served as a chapter trustee. The Nature Conservancy wishes to express appreciation for the wonderful contribution of expertise and energy that Mr. Perry made in the name of conservation L.F. Boker Doyle Chairman of Bd. Kathleen Moser Exec. Director

title: In a Word
description: An unfortunate incident reached an unfortunate conclusion in the office of the Mayor of Washington D.C., Anthony Williams, this week. Mr. Williams, who is black, permitted his newly appointed ombudsman, David Howard, who is white, to resign after using the word ''niggardly'' in the presence of two co-workers who looked shocked at the phrase. The word means ''miserly,'' and Mr. Howard, explaining how tight his office budget was, said, ''I will have to be niggardly with this fund because it's not going to be a lot of money.''

title: As Clinic Blast Is Recalled, Chilling Evidence Emerges
description: Emily Lyons had another operation last week, fresh scars to mingle with the old ones, her 13th surgery in the past year. It has been that long since a nail bomb exploded outside a Birmingham clinic that performed abortions, since the shrapnel put out one of her eyes, shredded her legs and coated her face and body with slashes and deep puncture wounds.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: CENTRIS TO SELL USF UNIT TO FOLKSAMERICA
description: The insurance holding company Centris Group Inc. will sell its USF Re Insurance Company unit to the Folksamerica Holding Company, a unit of Fund American Enterprises Holdings Inc., for $97.5 million, in an effort to concentrate on its medical and specialty insurance lines. The sale, announced yesterday, comes two days after Centris rejected an unsolicited takeover offer from HCC Insurance Holdings Inc., a rival seller of medical stop-loss insurance, for $156 million. Medical stop-loss insurance protects corporations that self-insure from excessive losses. Centris, whose shares fell 16.4 percent on its rejection of the HCC bid Thursday, dropped again yesterday, $1.25, to $10.50.

title: Paris Journal; In 25 Years, Pen Has Hit Ripe Targets
description: More than one French chief of state has felt the felt-tipped sting of Plantu, a cartoonist who is one of the most powerful political institutions not found in the 1958 French Constitution.

title: Testimony Implicates Bear Stearns
description: In court documents filed last week in United States District Court in Manhattan, a former executive of the Bear Stearns Companies describes the role the firm played in the violations of Federal securities laws committed by a small brokerage firm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALENTA, LEONARD
description: VALENTA-Leonard. Of Staten Island on Jan. 28, 1999. Loving wife of Nancy (nee Foltz). Dear sister of Lillian Poston. Also survived by many nieces and nephews and many grand nieces and nephews. Funeral service Harmon Home for Funerals, 571 Forest Ave, Staten Isl., NY, Sunday Jan. 31, 8PM. Friends will be received Sunday and Monday 2-4 and 7-9PM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, ROBERT D
description: KLEIN-Robert D. Sept. 25, 1930Jan. 30, 1994. More than the greatest love the world has known, we love and remember you.

title: Can the U.N. Take A Stronger Role?
description: To the Editor:

title: Duke? This St. John's Game Is Really Big
description: Pardon St. John's Coach Mike Jarvis if he's sounding a bit weary after spending the week talking about matchups and polls and the pressures of playing the top two teams in the nation, plus a difficult Big East road game, in a six-day span.

title: Buchanan Revels in Role as the Predictor
description: Atlanta Falcons Coach Dan Reeves this week has taken to calling Ray Buchanan Broadway Ray, after the former Jets quarterback, Broadway Joe Namath, who 30 years ago also guaranteed a Super Bowl victory.

title: Driver on L.I. Saves A Woman Trapped In Her Burning Car
description: Driving to work early this morning, Martin A. Sullivan, 37, saw a car smoldering on the side of Longwood Road in Middle Island.

title: Sharpe Talks and Plays a Big Game
description: It will be a difficult emotional, cerebral and physical job for the Atlanta Falcons on Sunday when they face the Denver Broncos. For in confronting Shannon Sharpe, who is going into the Pro Bowl for the seventh straight year, they are dealing with someone who defies easy answers. Sometimes, in fact, Sharpe doesn't understand himself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHO, SUZIE S.
description: CHO-Suzie S.. Died suddenly on January 25, 1999 in Belize in her 34th year. Wife of Marc Lambrechts, daughter of Edward and June Cho. She is also survived by her sister Juli Cho and her brother Joseph Cho. Calling hours at the Cho-Lambrechts residence, 158 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn, Sunday, January 31st from 2-4 PM. Funeral service at 4PM.

title: Britten-Norman to Buy Romanian Company
description: The British aircraft producer Britten-Norman Group agreed to buy Romaero S.A., Romania's biggest aircraft maker, for $80.5 million in cash and investment in the company.

title: Political Notes; Relationship Begins to Warm Between Friends Turned Foes
description: For nearly two years, their feud has been at the center of an assortment of political dramas in Brooklyn, its battle lines shaping virtually every contest in the borough. But now the tension between Representative Edolphus Towns and Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., the Brooklyn Democratic Party chairman, shows distinct signs of easing.

title: Canary Wharf Weighing Public Stock Offering
description: Canary Wharf Ltd., the 80-acre London financial center, may sell stock to the public, people close to the situation said.

title: Transforming Woyzeck Into a Black Soldier in the Racist South
description: It was inevitable that one day Jeff Cohen would come to Georg Buchner. In the last couple of years Mr. Cohen has updated two Chekhov plays and a Greek tragedy to punch holes in the self-satisfaction of the 90's. Buchner's ''Woyzeck,'' a play about a soldier driven by personal abuse and social corruption to kill his mistress, which Buchner wrote as a protest against injustice, must have been irresistible to Mr. Cohen -- even more so, perhaps, because it is so fragmentary that Buchner's friends assumed it was unfinished when he died in 1837. It waited 76 years to find its first producer.

title: January 24-30; With Sweets, It's Nurture, Not Nature
description: In recent years, scientific studies have demonstrated what everyone else has always known: Women love chocolate. In study after study, women rate this most irresistible of sweets as their No. 1 food craving. So intense is this peculiarly female devotion that scientists have suggested a woman's burning desire for chocolate might have a biological basis. Researchers have even suggested that opiates or other chemicals in chocolate thought to be capable of mimicking the brain chemistry of a person in love might be what makes women reach for that extra truffle.

title: Poetry in Motion: Bill Would Establish Laureate
description: A bill that cleared the Assembly State Government Committee last week would add a position to the state bureaucracy: poet laureate. A New Jersey poet would be named every two years by a panel of the New Jersey Council for the Humanities and would receive the newly created Williams Carlos Williams Citation of Merit and $10,000. The laureate would be required to give at least two public readings a year and to otherwise promote poetry throughout the state.

title: POSTINGS: New York Realtors' Figures; Home Sales Set a Record
description: Sales of existing single-family homes in New York State set a record last year, according to data compiled by the New York State Association of Realtors, with the 86,661 recorded transactions surpassing by 14.3 percent the previous record of 75,796 sales set in 1996. The 1997 figure was 71,011.

title: Ockham's Razor's Close Shave
description: Agreement on the meaning, if not the spelling, of Occam/Ockham is universal. The antonymic figure of speech is ''Rube Goldberg invention,'' after the cartoonist who drew up the most complex methods of completing a simple task. But it falls to this column to answer the question unasked by readers who do not want to appear unread: Who was Ockham, anyway, and what made him the Gillette of his day?

title: How Not to Get Killed on Deadline
description: 1) The number of ways to die is unlimited.

title: Backtalk; Trial Balloon Has Evolved Into Religion
description: The Super Bowl may indeed be the quintessence of American boys behaving badly, but it has never pretended to be anything else. Because it is the national holy day of a secular religion linked to illegal gambling, domestic violence, steroid abuse and institutional racism, it is beyond scandal and star-fall. We should be particularly grateful in these days of Olympic disgrace and pro basketball depression.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODELL, MIRIAM H.
description: GOODELL-Miriam H. On January 29, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Loving mother of Rozanne and Ted. Dear grandmother and great grandmother. Services Friday, February 5, 1999, 12:15 PM, at ''The Riverside'' West 76 St. and Amersterdam Ave.

title: New Jersey Legislators
description: SENATORS:

title: Charter Schools: The Road to Segregation
description: Charter schools [''Charter Schools: The Road Ahead,'' Jan. 17] are the beginning of privatization of all public schools. The public school system will surely be as extinct as the dodo bird if charter schools are permitted to become a reality.

title: Correction
description: The Vows column last Sunday, about the marriage of Lisa Goodman Cohen and Lewis Jeffrey Liman, misspelled part of the name of the hotel in Katmandu where the couple planned to stay on their honeymoon. It is the Yak and Yeti, not Yetti.

title: Culinary Trade Results In Indian-Pakistani Restaurant
description: It was a fair exchange. Marcus Medina, from Mexico, stayed in a London youth hostel with some Indians. He introduced them to Mexican cooking and in return was schooled in the ways of Indian cuisine.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Click Here To Volunteer
description: Some New Yorkers might like to volunteer a bit of their precious time to help others, but don't have the time to find out how. They could spend hours calling charities, churches, schools, youth groups and the like to figure out how to help and where to go.

title: Word for Word/Succession in Jordan; Uneasy Lies the Prince Who Gets a Letter From the King
description: EVERYONE knows that Shakespeare artfully used royal intrigues and jealousies to weave tales almost dizzying in scope. But however much he invented dialogue and situations, people have always suspected that when it came to the motives and character of kings and queens, Shakespeare got it right. He showed royalty to be larger than life, but in the end very human.

title: Historic Farm's Owner Offers Demolition Plan
description: A plan to partly demolish historic East Farm, a National Register of Historic Places site in the incorporated village of Head of the Harbor, has been presented without objection to Mayor Daniel Shybunko and the village Board of Trustees.

title: Where to Get Information
description: ABERCROMBIE & KENT INTERNATIONAL, 1520 Kensington Road, Suite 212, Oak Brook, Ill. 60523; (800) 323-7308, fax (630) 954-3324; the site on the Internet is www.abercrombiekent.com.

title: The View From / Westport; Show of Comic Strips From Yesterday and Today
description: RARELY does laughter interrupt the arduous task of hanging an exhibition. Yet, on a recent morning, the works being readied for display at the Westport Historical Society drew smiles and giggles, even the occasional guffaw -- as well they might. The assembly was contemplating illustrations gathered for the current show ''Westport Cartoonists: A Collection Past and Present,'' which examines the work of more than 50 artists dedicated to making people laugh, as well as think.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, H. KENNETH
description: LEVINE-H. Kenneth. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its Honorary Trustee and devoted servant and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Michael Tannenbaum, President Amiel Wohl, Rabbi

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's not a cool thing to stay back. Kids really tease you, and treat you like you don't know anything. But I think you should be left back if you really need to. Like if you never know your times tables, you'll never catch up. You'll just fall more behind. You could be in trouble if you don't know a lot of multiplication.''

title: After Bowling Over an Audience
description: THE SETTING -- Leisure Time Recreation in the Port Authority, where, each Thursday at midnight, after the theater curtains fall and the makeup comes off, the Broadway Show Bowling League takes over the alley's 38 lanes. It is a time for directors, stagehands, actors and ushers to unwind and mingle over beer and rosin bags.

title: Sharp-Eyed Collectors Drive Up the Price of Folk Art
description: OUTSIDER art continues to upstage American folk art in gallery and museum exhibitions as well as in the press. But at the auctions, traditional American folk art chalks up spectacular prices for the choicest examples, while the quirky, visionary Outsider art lags far behind in prices fetched at auction.

title: The Candidate
description: In 1960 I felt pretty much as Matthew Yglesias did. Thirty years later, however, I was asked to compile a questionnaire for my reunion (Sarah Lawrence, '65), and I thought it would be fun to ask similar questions and compare the answers with what we'd written on our applications all those years before. The school wouldn't release the originals to me -- frankly, I was surprised it had them. I think it wasn't so much a privacy issue as a retrieval task.

title: BEST SELLERS: January 31, 1999
description: Weeks

title: I Can't Go On, Alan. I'll Go On.
description: NO AUTHOR

title: A Piquant Pale-Gold Pleasure
description: Hunter's White Reserve, 1996. (About $11.)

title: IN PERSON; A Salon, Hoboken Style
description: THERE are bars, there are art galleries, and then there's the Liquid Lounge. Like Hoboken itself, this hybrid watering hole is an amalgam of styles and life styles, the sort of place where comfort is clearly as important as attitude, although both are in good supply.

title: The Rose, Ultimate Seduction
description: WHAT is it about roses? When in full bloom, little else in the garden can meet their challenge. The flower is just about perfect. The colors are true. And the foliage is waxy and clean.

title: Excluding Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Subway Construction Pitches Neighborhood a Curve
description: One of the city's most important fire safety mechanisms is so entrenched that many New Yorkers do not even know it exists: an elaborate system of fans in subway tunnels that, in the event of a fire, would draw out deadly smoke and rush in fresh air. But the Lenox Avenue line for the No. 3 train, connecting upper Manhattan to the Bronx, has never had such a fan system.

title: Margaret W. Owings, 85, Defender of Wild Creatures
description: Margaret Wentworth Owings, a California artist and conservationist who fought for the survival of sea otters, sea lions, mountain lions and other wild creatures, died on Jan. 21 at Wild Bird, her clifftop home above the Pacific in Big Sur, Calif. She was 85.

title: Ma Non Troppo
description: CANONE INVERSOBy Paolo Maurensig.Translated by Jenny McPhee.202 pp. New York:Henry Holt & Company. $21.

title: January 24-30; Good News for the Lazy
description: Tomorrow it's February. If traditional patterns hold, half the people who resolved on Jan. 1 to stick to an ambitious exercise regime will have relapsed into guilt-encrusted sloth. But must it be all or nothing? Not at all, says a study in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: The Devil's Miracle Man
description: HITLER

title: The Battle Is On: Whose Kids Need the Most Help?
description: In doling out about $4 million a year to the city's many youth groups, the Department of Youth and Community Development has used something called the Fair Share Formula since 1983.

title: William E. Hunt, 77; Neurosurgeon Developed Aneurysm Classification System
description: Dr. William E. Hunt, a retired neurosurgeon at Ohio State University who devised a widely used system for the clinical evaluation of brain aneurysms, died on Tuesday at his home in Columbus. He was 77 and also had a home in Gouldsboro Point, Me.

title: Adding Meaty Flavor From Swiss Chard to Pastas and Frittatas
description: BUNCHES of sturdy greens beckon in cold weather. My favorite is Swiss chard. Braised or sauteed, this attractive vegetable, with leaves that look like spinach on steroids branching from meaty white or ruby stems and ribs, provides a slightly meaty texture and a flavor that is herbaceous but more sweet than bitter.

title: 5 Charged in Killing of a Boy After a Game
description: Five Brooklyn teen-agers arrested in connection with the stabbing death of a 14-year-old boy and the beating of his friend on Wednesday night were charged as adults yesterday, with one facing life in prison if convicted.

title: Hong Kong Ruling on Children May Open a Door From China
description: In a landmark decision that could open this enclave to thousands of mainland Chinese, a court ruled Friday that four children born in China to Hong Kong parents have the right to live here.

title: Reporter Finds Russia Has Not Outlived Secrecy
description: Shackled in handcuffs, Grigory Pasko was rushed past the small knot of fellow reporters who gathered outside the military courtroom, hoping to observe his trial.

title: My Private Screening With Pauline Kael
description: Wes Anderson, the director and co-writer of the new offbeat comedy ''Rushmore,'' is a lifelong fan of the New Yorker magazine film critic Pauline Kael, who is now retired. Wanting to show her his film, he tracked her down last fall at her home in the Berkshire Mountains. The following account of his visit is from the introduction to his ''Rushmore'' screenplay, to be published on Friday by Faber & Faber.

title: A Stake in Every Pot
description: Staking each American to a share of the nation's accumulated wealth is the only way to take equal opportunity seriously, the authors say. Fixing the schools could take decades; redistributing income year after year is a political loser. Far better, at the dawn of adulthood, to share the wealth instead. Thus the stake. It could be used to start a business or pay for college, to help a parent stay home when the children are young or tide a family over after a breadwinner's layoff. Some might stash the cash for retirement; others would plunk it down on black or red in Las Vegas. The choice would be the individual's, but in a world where too much already depends on the womb from which you drop, the moral and financial commitment to a fair start would be the nation's.

title: Delayed Start for the Referees, Too
description: THOUGH he loves his profession, one of Bennett Salvatore's biggest regrets over the years has been that he has never been able to spend the Christmas season at his Stamford home with his wife and their four children. ''And it's my favorite time of the year, too,'' Mr. Salvatore said. ''I really love Christmas.''

title: Love Me Tender
description: But the distinction between carnivores and connoisseurs may soon be breaking down, now that those parts, once regarded as barely edible, are being transformed into something chic and fashionable. For instance, if you simmer bits of beef tail slowly, you get a thick, rich stew. The process cannot be hurried, and the arc of scent, from raw and gamy to cooked and tantalizing, challenges the chef and invites him to reconcile his animal instincts with his more civilized sensibility.

title: Hey, Where's the Action?
description: Just two teams left. Seven hours of discourse by all manner of talking heads, interviewing and analyzing anything that moves. Sundry visuals. New TV ads. An excuse for believers and infidels alike to gather the gang, lay out a spread and restock the bar. Liberation Day for football widows. Super Bowl Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, ARLENE G.
description: WOLFF-Arlene G. Beloved wife of the late Richard. Devoted mother of Rina Schnaufer and Adam Wolff. Cherished grandmother of Ryan and Jacob. Loving daughter of Frieda Gold. Dear sister of Richard Gold. Proud of her infectious disease research, her zeal for science and her published accomplishments, we will always be proud of her. Services Sunday, 10 AM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Seton Hall Is Humbled by the Orangemen
description: After a listless first half against No. 17 Syracuse tonight, Seton Hall point guard Shaheen Holloway came out of the locker room and on the opening possession of the second half fired up an errant 3-point attempt. Seconds later, he raced up the floor as a teammate dribbled beside him on a fast break, and as he passed his bench, Holloway lost his footing and skidded past Coach Tommy Amaker.

title: Young Performers in the Spotlight
description: YOUTHFUL talent and professional experience join together on Saturday evening at 8, when the Greater New Haven Youth Orchestra (based at the Neighborhood Music School) meets the Wallingford Symphony, and four young performers get their chance in the concerto spotlight.

title: Catch Them if You Can
description: Expect styles that are scrappy and clever and then look for fighters and holders and even biters when the Denver Broncos and the Atlanta Falcons meet in Super Bowl XXXIII on Sunday at Pro Player Stadium.

title: End of Debate: Hall of Fame Voters Reward Taylor's Accomplishments
description: The former Giants linebacker Lawrence Taylor, considered by many to be one of the greatest players of all time, was voted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame today in his first year of eligibility, despite the objections of some voters who felt his history of drug abuse should have kept him out.

title: Police Detail Would Make Serene Spot Even More So
description: To the Editor:

title: Co-ops and Liability for Harassment
description: MANY business owners are aware of the legal and financial perils of sexual harassment in the workplace and have taken steps to help prevent it. Co-op and condominium associations, however, lawyers say, have generally failed to guard against the possibility of such claims, despite the fact that some buildings have many employees.

title: Bridging a 'Generation Next' Gap
description: A YEAR ago, Pepsi-Cola was marking its 100th anniversary, but no amount of corporate merrymaking could conceal the problems plaguing the brand. Bottlers attending a company extravaganza in Hawaii spent much of their time fuming about Pepsi ads, particularly one set to the Rolling Stones song ''Brown Sugar.'' Pepsi was losing market share to its perennial rival, Coca-Cola Classic. And it was going through an identity crisis. Just who was supposed to be buying it -- teen-agers? Generation X'ers? Retirees?

title: Miss Cassidy and Mr. Chamberlin
description: LIKE the actress Katharine Hepburn, Charlotte Mary Cassidy is partly regal, partly tomboyish. Now 60 and a learning specialist at the Trinity School in New York, Miss Cassidy wears her long gray hair in a Hepburnesque bun and loves fresh air so much she opens the windows even in winter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARATTA, MARYLOU
description: BARATTA-Marylou. Local 137 and The Service Trade Association of Greater New York mourn the loss of our dear friend Marylou Baratta, proprietor of Marylou's restaurant. We will always remember her compassion and generosity. Our sincerest and deepest sympathies are with Marylou's family and many friends during this time of profound loss.

title: In the Region / New Jersey; Another Link for Barnegat Bay's 'Emerald Necklace'
description: FOR the last two years there have been competing visions for the 365 acres of salt marsh and woodlands that jut into Barnegat Bay in Berkeley Township in Ocean County. But the matter was resolved earlier this month when the Trust for Public Land, bought the site from the local representative of a Dallas land investor, insuring that it will never be turned into housing.

title: Dr. Richard H. Freyberg, 94, an Arthritis Expert
description: Dr. Richard Harold Freyberg, a leading rheumatologist who helped organize the Arthritis Foundation and build it into today's 700,000-member organization with a professional staff of 750, died Jan. 23 at his retirement home in Venice, Fla. He was 94 and formerly lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Vendome's Past
description: To the Editor: On Dec. 6, writing about the Hotel du Vendome (''A Prestigious Address, With Prices to Match'') you said it ''succeeds the Vendome, an unimpressive hotel that existed on the site'' previously.

title: Politicians in Utah Expressed Concerns About Olympic Bid
description: In the late summer or early fall of 1997, more than a year before the Olympic bribery allegations emerged that have since shaken this state to its core, two of Utah's senior state politicians invited the president of the Salt Lake Organizing Committee, G. Frank Joklik, to a get-acquainted meeting at the state Capitol.

title: Books From The Times
description: The fifth and sixth volumes in a series of collected reporting from The Times's weekly science section are now available from Lyons Press as THE SCIENCE TIMES BOOK OF INSECTS and THE SCIENCE TIMES BOOK OF GENETICS ($25 each). Both edited by Nicholas Wade, they deal with recent discoveries and developments about the pyramid of creepy crawlies underlying the bees and butterflies everybody loves, and the microscopic arrangements of chemicals that make bugs and humans at least superficially different. The insect volume contains an entire section on the rituals of insect courtship (often much more disappointing, for one party, than the worst of human marriages), examines the structural principles of insect wings and the organization of spider webs, and anoints the scarab beetle as the earth's indispensable recycler of animal waste. Reports on the amazing performances of life's genetic materials include exploration of the future of gene therapy, the possible applicability of genetics to life extension, a look at of the architecture of DNA itself and the original report on the first known successful cloning of an adult mammal, the case of the lamb known as Dolly -- published, it may be frightening or exhilarating to observe, just two years ago next month.

title: How Public Does a Public Library Have to Be?
description: SOON after Leonora Weintraub, a public school librarian, moved into her new home in North Valley Stream in 1968, she went to the library less than a mile away.
