title: Outer Space Is Inspiration But the Store's Name Is Juicy
description: Christina Ramirez, 26, says the name of her month-old store should not be confused with fruit. ''It refers to something choice.'' the designer said. At 85 Kenmare Street (between Mulberry Street and Cleveland Place), Plum triples as a retail shop, design studio and wholesale showroom, inspired by outer space and made from high-tech fabrics. But prices are not stratospheric. Offerings include an iridescent poly-nylon taffeta wrap skirt in red, silver or purple ($68). ALEXANDRA McGINLEY

title: Briton Issues An Ultimatum To Both Sides Over Kosovo
description: Foreign Secretary Robin Cook of Britain told Yugoslav and ethnic Albanian leaders today that they must show up in France next weekend to negotiate effective self-government for Serbia's battle-ravaged Kosovo province or face NATO bombing and other military action to force them to negotiate agreement.

title: Through data ports of call on the Web
description: THE building boom in the cruise industry has been matched by the proliferation of cruise-related Web sites. And while navigating the Internet is often called surfing, the term does not quite capture the spirit of trying to work through all the cruise-related sites available. There is, after all, a lot of territory to cover -- the Yahoo search engine found 43 categories and 2,373 sites for ''cruises.''

title: The World; One Defense Against Quakes: Build Homes of Wood
description: AMERICANS viewing the devastation caused by Monday's earthquake in Colombia might be tempted to knock on wood. Wood-frame houses, the type generally built in the United States, can stand up far better in quakes than the outwardly solid masonry homes that crumpled so quickly in Colombia.

title: Endangered Species
description: WEREWOLVES IN

title: No Mixed Reviews Here
description: To the Editor:

title: Confidently Riding the Technology Bubble
description: IT is pretty easy to be excited and amazed about exciting and amazing technology stocks. It is equally easy to be scared to death of them.

title: Money Is at the Root of Trial's Partisanship; Why Have Witnesses?
description: To the Editor:

title: Not So Fly (for This White Guy)
description: ON a recent wintry morning, walking a desolate strip of Flatbush Avenue in downtown Brooklyn, I heard a baritone voice growl my name, followed by an emphatic, ''Yo! What's the deal?'' The menacing bark emanated from the driver's side of a passing Mercury Sable, the tinted window of which was now rapidly descending.

title: The Candidate
description: Yglesias says that students waste countless hours writing college-application essays. Wouldn't it make more sense for admissions officers to administer impromptu essay questions to candidates during interviews? This would insure that the student, and not a well-meaning parent, was indeed the author.

title: Experts Seek Cause of Illness at Bronx School
description: Environmental testing continued yesterday at a Bronx school that was evacuated twice last week after students and teachers became ill there.

title: Television and the Holocaust: An Odd Couple
description: WHAT millions saw that day in May 1953 from El Kapitan Theater in Hollywood was a classic scene from the raw, unpolished days of early television. Primitive microphone in hand, the host of ''This Is Your Life,'' Ralph Edwards, plucks a pretty young woman out of the studio audience, ostensibly at random. He then asks the actor Jeffrey Hunter, sitting strategically at the woman's side, to read the cover of the book Mr. Edwards is holding. ''This Is Your Life, Hanna Bloch Kohner,'' Mr. Hunter declares. Mrs. Kohner's eyes open wide and her jaw drops. ''Oh, no! Oh, my God!'' she exclaims in an Eastern European accent before sinking her head into her gloved hands. The music swells, the audience applauds and Mrs. Kohner is then escorted to the stage.

title: Trying to Beat the Clock
description: Alice Hector, a Miami lawyer who lost primary custody of her children to her ex-husband because of her long hours, has quit her job as a partner at a high-powered law firm. Ms. Hector said she decided to open her own firm with three other lawyers from Miami's Steel, Hector & Davis because she wanted to be able to leave work early a couple of afternoons a week to be with her two young girls.

title: Clemency for Killer Surprises Many Who Followed Case
description: For three days, hiding in a hunting blind, wearing camouflage and face paint, the killer lay in wait. Then, on a gravel path snaking through the dense woods of this hilly Ozark town, he saw the victims and he pounced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, MARY THURMAN
description: MARTIN-Mary Thurman, 100, on January 27th, 1999 of Locust Valley, NY. Widow of the late Milward W. Martin and mother of Mary Lee Fletcher of New York City and Dugald A. Fletcher of Locust Valley. Grandmother of three and great-grandmother of seven. A memorial service at Saint John's Lattingtown on Sunday, January 31st at 3 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Grenville Baker Boys & Girls Club, Locust Valley, NY.

title: Lawrence Taylor's Final Riff
description: LAWRENCE TAYLOR was elected to the pro football Hall of Fame yesterday. But far from being the no-brainer L.T. had predicted, the vote was a wrenching moral wrestling match -- a match that is far from over.

title: The January Barometer Points Upward
description: With all major stock market indicators climbing on Friday, one of Wall Street's favorite phenomena, the buoyant January effect, came through again.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GALLAY, ALAN D.
description: GALLAY-Alan D. Mike is becoming a father, and Paul's child Amelia is five, and so sweet and dear. Renee

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGORAD, HENRIETTA
description: BOGORAD-Henrietta. Beloved wife of Seymour. Dear mother to daughters Priscilla Fadale and Gary, Susan Gordon and David, Nina Palmer and Jonathan, Bess Amione and John, and precious grandmother to Jonathan, Daniel, Andrew, Michael, Sarah, Brett, Sammy and Emily. She enriched us. She was the love of our lives. She's locked in our hearts forever. Services Monday, 12 noon, Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue (one block north of Tuckahoe Road), Yonkers, 1-800-468-3232.

title: Bronx Man Charged in Rapes And Robberies of Masseuses
description: A 6-foot-10, 340-pound security guard from the Bronx was charged with rape and robbery yesterday after four masseuses identified him as their attacker in four separate incidents, the police said.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Children's Choir

title: It's Winter in New Hampshire, And the Trail Is Warming Up
description: The campaigning for President never really ends in New Hampshire, home of the nation's first primary for the better part of half a century.

title: How to Build With a Firm Foundation
description: AS a child William Bellafatto played with toy trucks. Now he is 31 and running a 175,000-pound hydraulic excavator that is gouging the earth for a project ponderously named the Flushing Bay Combined Sewer Overflow Retention Facility. Every time he drives the machine's claw into the ground, the bucket pulls up seven tons of soil. Trucks haul it away.

title: INSIDE
description: Missing Key Mideast Leader

title: January 24-30; U.N. Cautioned on Iraq
description: As the Security Council tried to decide how to keep Iraq from re-arming with nuclear, biological or chemical weapons, the body created to disarm the nation, the United Nations Special Commission, delivered a lengthy report full of cautions about taking Saddam Hussein at his word.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKER, ESTHER
description: DICKER-Esther. Age 93, on January 30, 1999, of Clifton, NJ. Predececeased by her husband Max Saul in 1952. Loving mother of Mildred and Morris Liebhaber and Harriet and Eugene Seidner. Beloved aunt and great-aunt. Devoted grandmother of Karen, Maxine, Elyse, Martha and Robin. Cherished great-grandmother of Jennifer, Carolyn, Michael, Seth, Jordana, David, Sam, Erica, Sydney and Jake. She was a member of Hadassah and Congregation Agudath Israel of Caldwell, NJ. The week of Shivah will be observed at Seidner Residence in Caldwell, NJ. Services are today, 12 Noon at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rte. 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Watershed Grant
description: The town of Mamaroneck and 10 other shoreline communities will share a $50,000 matching grant from the New York Department of State, which is responsible for managing coastal zone management programs, to study the Long Island Sound watershed and reduce pollution entering the estuary.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Father Testifies at Gun Makers' Trial
description: When he left his home in Japan for a business trip to California in 1994, Koichi Sunada could not have imagined the sudden decision he would face in America: whether to authorize doctors to remove his 22-year-old son from life-support machines. The young man, who had been living in New York after immigrating to the United States, was shot by a robber while Mr. Sunada was in California, and was left brain dead in a Queens hospital.

title: As Aid Is Reduced, the Rodent Problem Explodes in Urban Areas
description: Henry Jones, an exterminator for the Camden County Health Department, could smell the rats as soon as he entered the dilapidated East Camden row house on Wednesday morning.

title: Two Protests By Students Over Wages For Workers
description: Students at Duke University and Georgetown University held raucous protests on Friday against a proposed code of conduct for apparel makers that they say does too little to insure that products bearing the names of their schools are not made in sweatshops.

title: Nets Applying the Pressure to Improve Defensive Scheme
description: They are not quite the Chicago Bulls, the Miami Heat or the old Bad Boys from the Detroit Pistons, but the Nets are showing improvement defensively. In their 92-90 exhibition victory over the Knicks on Friday night, they proved that Coach John Calipari's increased emphasis on defense is bearing fruit.

title: Attacks on Christians a 'Blot' on India, Premier Tells Nation
description: In a somber address to the nation, Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee today made his strongest condemnation yet of the recent attacks on Christian places of worship in India and the killings of an Australian missionary and his two young sons as ''a blot on our collective consciousness.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, BESS R. (NEE SILBERG)
description: GOODMAN-Bess R. (nee Silberg). Died on January 29, 1999, of East Hills, NY, and Boca Raton, FL. Beloved wife of the late W. Vald Goodman and mother of the late Kay Elsa Bard. Loving grandmother of Michael and wife Lisa, Amy and Rachel Bard. Devoted sister of Dr. Arnold and Lillian Silberg and the late Robert and Helen Silberg, Ada and the late Charles Silberg, and Jean and the late Bernard Silberg. Services Monday, 12 noon, at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Ideas & Trends; Probing Disease Clusters: Easier to Spot Than Prove
description: THE trouble began when Bobbie Gallagher noticed that her 2-year-old daughter was behaving strangely, obsessively spinning and scrupulously setting her toys in rows. Alanna Gallagher turned out to have autism, a rare neurological disorder of unknown cause.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEDINSKY, EDWARD
description: WEDINSKY-Edward. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Edward Wedinsky, associated with The Times from 1962, until retiring in 1989.

title: Liberties; Niggardly City
description: Once Ross Perot wanted to make the Patsy Cline song ''Crazy'' his campaign theme.

title: Eileen Rosen and Ethan Miller
description: Eileen Rosen and Ethan Dorr Miller were married last evening by Rabbi Robert A. Raab at the 200 Fifth Club in New York.

title: Brian Hines and Tracy Shevell
description: Dr. Tracy Shevell and Dr. Brian Jonathon Hines, both residents in obstetrics and gynecology at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, were married last evening. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman performed the ceremony at Temple Israel of Great Neck (N.Y.).

title: Nature Conservancy Adds Tract in Maine
description: At year's end, the Maine Nature Conservancy closed on its largest land purchase, 286 square miles of forest along the state's northwest border with Canada. The purchase of the two tracts from the International Paper Company is part of an effort to preserve the wilderness and save rare plants.

title: Ready for Prime Time?
description: Avicious wind was buffeting Mel A. Sachs as he held his ground outside the frozen gray granite of the busiest courthouse in the city, 100 Center Street. Hatless, heedless of the wind chill in his Italian alpaca overcoat, Mr. Sachs was sermonizing -- and, yes, basking -- in the warm embrace of the Pack. Calling ''Mel! Mel! Mel!'' the sharp-elbowed scrum of 32 reporters and news-crew linebackers was desperate for some word, any word, of the tabloids' favorite courtroom demons, the pair known as the Grifters.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: BRING US THE OLD PEOPLE

title: There Is Life After Mortimer's
description: EVER since the sudden death of Glenn Bernbaum last September, closing down Mortimer's, the public outpost for the rich and socially registered that he ran for 22 years, the social flock have been desperately circling the Upper East Side, looking for a new place to alight.

title: Peconic Bay: A New Owner, Same High Standards
description: PECONIC BAY VINEYARDS in Cutchogue has been sold to a Manhattan investment consultant and his wife. The transaction, completed last week, foreshadows the gradual expansion of Peconic Bay, a 19-year-old boutique winery that on average has produced 5,000 cases of wine a year.

title: Money Is at the Root of Trial's Partisanship
description: To the Editor:

title: Yonkers Bias Case, the 'Ongoing Saga'
description: IN retrospect, Judge Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan may have spoken prematurely last December when he predicted that two decades of frustration over housing desegregation here would soon draw to a close.

title: The Number of Longtime Town Supervisors Is Dwindling
description: THERE was a time when many of the supervisors of Westchester's towns were re-elected again and again. Whether they were Democrats or Republicans, they were institutions. Last month with the death of Anthony L. Veteran, who served nine two-year terms from 1974 to 1991 as supervisor of the county's largest town, Greenburgh, the coterie of Westchester supervisors who have served more than a decade has dwindled to five. Just one of them, John A. Lombardi of North Castle, remains in office, completing his 19th two-year term.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYES, CATHERINE JUSTINA (NEE BARRY)
description: HAYES-Catherine Justina (nee Barry). On January 29, 1999. Beloved wife of James. Devoted mother of Margaret Maddalena, Reverend James Hayes, S.S.S. and Mary Anne Gorman. Cherished grandmother of Derek, Jessica, Jeffrey and Nora. Reposing Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 E. 87 St., NYC, Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Monday, 10 AM at the Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home, 1339 York Ave. Burial Calvary Cemetery.

title: The Candidate
description: Matthew Yglesias (Lives, Jan. 10) appears to believe that the essays on college applications should entertain him. He complains about the ordinariness of the questions and the brevity of space allowed.

title: An Inspiration Compounded of Hands and Feet
description: IMOGEN CUNNINGHAM photographed Martha Graham in the summer of 1931, in Santa Barbara, Calif. They worked outside, in front of the barn at Graham's mother's home. The afternoon was hot, the smell unpleasant and the flies bothersome, but together they managed to produce a collection of nearly 90 images, an extraordinary double-portrait of both photographer and choreographer.

title: M.B.A. Magic Is a Fiction
description: Q. After deciding that the insurance industry was not where I wanted to be, I took night classes for four years to complete an M.B.A. in market research. Alas, the degree seems to make no difference to prospective employers, who focus instead on my lack of experience and as a result are talking about salary levels way below what I now earn. Is there any way to make this less painful?

title: An Overseas Stake In the American Dream
description: Last May, Israel declared its currency, the shekel, freely convertible, making it easier for citizens to own foreign bank accounts and invest overseas. One unexpected result: Israelis with spare cash are snapping up property in America.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Wakefield, the Bronx; Hugging Westchester At the Subway's End
description: WAKEFIELD is a border town, a bulge on the map of the Bronx that protrudes a bit into Westchester County. It's also at the very end of the line, the last stop on the No. 2 subway train.

title: Streetscapes / The Ottendorfer Branch of the New York Public Library, 135 Second Avenue; A Victorian Interior Gets Ready for the 21st Century
description: THE Ottendorfer branch of the New York Public Library, at 135 Second Avenue between St. Marks Place and Ninth Street, was built in 1884 as the Ottendorfer Library, serving the German-American community in the area. Now the library interior is being renovated, exposing the history of this unusual Victorian interior as it collides with modern requirements.

title: Lives; No Regrets
description: It all began in Pontiac, Mich., in 1959, although for a long time I didn't know the precise year. All I remember was a soulful ballad on the radio. I heard it only once, I can't even remember where, but the tune stuck in my head, along with this fragment of lyric:

title: With His Eyes Open
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation: Obligations; The Deficit's Gone, but Not the National Debt
description: THE Federal budget deficit is gone, transformed by a strong economy into a string of projected surpluses that should grow larger for years to come -- at least by the reckoning that passes for fiscal forecasting in Washington.

title: From Seedy Barroom to the Toast of Katonah
description: LONGTIME residents can recall when this building was a dusty watering hole whose main attraction was the pool table in the dining room. Several variations on that seedy theme have come and gone since those days, but none had been successful in overcoming the rude origins and reputation of the place. Now, however, Cornerstone Grill has rescued the building and has thoroughly banished the ghosts of barrooms past.

title: Pupating
description: Shaped like bears, mice, carousels and hearts, Pupa Make-Up Kits were coveted by preadolescent girls in the 70's. Now, they've resurfaced at Sephora (Broadway between Prince and Spring Streets), where they're appealing to the inner adults of a new generation of girls and to the inner children of their nostalgic mothers. The glitter kits, from $18 to $180, are especially hot. They may seem like ''the Easy Bake oven version of a makeup counter,'' said Martha McCully, beauty editor at Allure magazine. ''But they're not junky makeup,'' she continued. ''The lip glosses are great.'' Customers from 4 to 45 are buying them. ''It's so cool how it looks like a bear, and the eye shadows are shaped like paws,'' said Hope Krause, 11, of her Teddy Bear Kit. ''I use mine really carefully, to save it.'' Her mother, Meg Krause, whose own kit resembles a small vanity, called it irresistible. ''I find myself opening and closing all the little compartments, even when I'm not using them,'' she said. ELLEN TIEN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSKIND, RUTH (LIPPMAN)
description: SUSKIND-Ruth (Lippman). A memorial service will be held on Sunday, February 7, 1999 at 11 AM at the Riverside Memorial Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett. For further information call, 516 295-3101.

title: Machine Dreams
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Are Members Of Melville Organization?
description: ''Stony Brook: Living History or Mausoleum?'' [Jan. 17] did an excellent job of documenting the frustrations those of us who live in Stony Brook have experienced with the Ward Melville Heritage Organization. The statement by the Heritage Organization's spokeswoman, Pam Cordes, that it is a private entity and did not have to answer to the community certainly sums up the situation, especially given the fact that the group was previously named the Stony Brook Community Fund.

title: Show of Russian Treasures Will Make Debut in Trenton
description: About 300 objects from the Russian State Historical Museum in Moscow will start an American tour in Trenton next fall. The New Jersey State Museum will be host to ''Unseen Treasures: Czarist Russia and the New World,'' Sept. 25 through Jan. 15. Among the items shown will be the 18th-century coronation sleigh of Catherine the Great (pictured here), official court portraits, gem-encrusted church icons, Faberge cigarette cases and decorative menus from Imperial dinners. One section will be devoted to the culture of the Russian winter, particularly Siberia, including some very warm clothing.

title: St. John's Emotions Overcome at End by UConn
description: At the end, the frustration leaked out. The Connecticut defense had taken St. John's out of its game, and the scoring opportunities were being frittered away as quickly as the clock. St. John's Ron Artest and Erick Barkley, two players schooled in the gritty games of the New York playground, were jawing at each other across the lane even as the Huskies' Khalid El-Amin did a little shimmy for his fans. Afterward, Artest would speak darkly about choking and not playing hard.

title: Tiger Mystery Still Unsolved In New Jersey
description: New Jersey wildlife agents continued yesterday to count tigers at a private refuge in Ocean County, trying to confirm suspicions that a 431-pound Bengal tiger shot to death as it wandered loose last Wednesday had escaped from the compound. But there were no signs that the mystery was nearing solution.

title: Ideas & Trends: Hard Right -- Voters All Over Take the Wheel From Conservatives; A Matter of Trust For Europeans
description: IF the waning years of this decade have produced a dirty word in Europe, it is perhaps ''conservative.'' The right-of-center ideology that played an important role in stripping European states of vast industrial holdings, advancing the market economy and facing down the former Soviet Union with medium-range missiles has fizzled.

title: Sweet Bay, a Mediterranean Fit for a Crown
description: RECENTLY, while looking through a new cookbook, I noticed that the term ''imported bay leaf'' was used throughout. The book later explained that only imported bay leaves, often from Turkey and sometimes called Turkish bay, were to be used in the recipes because these were the leaves of Laurus nobilis, the sweet bay of the Mediterranean, so full of flavor and indispensable in Mediterranean cooking. Domestic bay leaves, which come from a different tree, Umbellularia californica, commonly called California laurel and Oregon myrtle, were to be avoided.

title: Worries About Big Brother at America Online
description: Like the divided generations of Irish before them, the two opposing camps of contributors to America Online's discussion group on Ireland rarely agree on anything. But when the world's leading on-line service suspended their contentious electronic debate last month, participants on both sides were united in their dismay.

title: IN MY... SATCHEL: DOMENICO DE SOLE
description: He spends 65 percent of his working life on the road, so the shape and texture of his satchel are almost as important as what's inside. That's because Domenico De Sole, chief executive of Gucci Group N.V., uses the creamy-leather case -- a Gucci, of course -- as a headrest on airplanes and as a footrest in airport lobbies. The rough treatment takes its toll; the seams came undone on his old one and his secretary made him throw it away. He predicts that this one will last just two years.

title: Bus Drivers Should Dress Like Their Passengers
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends: Hard Right -- Voters All Over Take the Wheel From Conservatives; An Identity Crisis In the U.S.
description: WITH great confidence and some justification, Republicans have long proclaimed that theirs is the party of ideas. So it seemed quite a turn when Representative Steve Largent, in the Republicans' response to the State of the Union address this month, found himself having to pose this question: ''What does the party of Lincoln and Reagan stand for today?''

title: Charter Schools Attract Early Interest
description: The phone calls are already coming in, 50 or 60 a week, to the State University of New York and the State Department of Education, asking what it takes to start a charter school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABENSKY, LARRY
description: LABENSKY-Larry. Beloved husband of Lory. Loving father of David and Rachel. Devoted son of Harry and Thelma. Dear brother of Steve. He will be sorely missed.

title: Stratford's Memorable Moments, and Its Dreams
description: STRATFORD, the home of an old Shakespeare Festival that was nowhere near festive, goes on waiting for a new Shakespeare Festival to materialize. What else is not new? It's only been waiting 10 years, or perhaps 16; it depends on who is counting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SORGE, ROD
description: SORGE-Rod. The Harm Reduction Coalition and the activists and participants in the harm reduction community profoundly grieve the loss of a dear friend, clever thinker, and a persistent and brave voice. Setting forth on the ''heavenly connection to the starry dynamo in the machinery of night,'' Rod died at 30 in his home in Manhattan of AIDS-related causes. We wish you a peaceful journey, and we'll miss you more than words can express.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREAVES, JEMIMA K.
description: GREAVES-Jemima K. Passed January 31st, 1995. Alive always in our hearts. Son Reynold and Family

title: French Supermarkets Not All They Seem
description: The almost nostalgic view of the Carrefour Supermarket in France [Out of Order, Jan. 24] overlooks a few facts. French supermarkets are not allowed to advertise on television. Zoning keeps many firms from expanding. The author complains about the parking problems, no doubt limited by local zoning regulations. Shopping days and hours are also limited. Such restrictions are typical in Europe, where governments spends a great deal of energy on protecting the small retailer.

title: The Princess Line
description: But first, let's admit that Princess Leia would be mistaken for sexy only by the severely irony-challenged, by, say, a George Lucas or a Bill Gates. With only one costume change in the entire first episode (sorry, purists, ''Episode IV''), she's a girl a thrifty billionaire would love. ''Star Wars'' was released in 1977 -- for all intents and purposes a galaxy far, far away -- when feathered Farrah hair was all the rage. And there was poor Leia having to run around with hirsute bagels strapped to her head.

title: A Test Case Of Internet Exuberance
description: WITH share prices inevitably soaring after the initial public offerings of just about any business related to the Internet these days, it is no surprise that a flood of upstart Internet companies have joined the rush.

title: Money Is at the Root of Trial's Partisanship; Controlling the Cameras
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM; Even in Independent Film, A Suit Is a Suit Is a Suit
description: WHATEVER happened to Lizzie Borden? Claudia Weill? Joyce Chopra? Donna Deitch? Whatever happened to Julie Dash, Tamra Davis, Stacy Cochran, Leslie Harris, Kelly Reichardt? What all these women share is that each directed at least one -- and, in some cases, two or more -- provocative, critically acclaimed independent films, only to essentially disappear from the scene. With the exception of Ms. Davis, who went from the sexy neo-noir ''Guncrazy'' in 1992 to directing slobbering studio comedies like ''Billy Madison,'' most of these women have spent most of the last decade relegated to near obscurity, cable television or developmental limbo. Not one of these women has the sort of sustained filmmaking career enjoyed by their male counterparts, independent directors such as John Sayles, David Lynch, Jim Jarmusch, Spike Lee, Hal Hartley, Gregg Araki and Richard Linklater. Not one has graduated from footnote status to chapter heading.

title: Automatic Promotion: Motivator or Deterrent?
description: It is not on the standard list of childhood phobias, but an overblown fear of being kept back and made to repeat a grade afflicts almost every member of Bonnie Kornblatt's fourth-grade class at Meredith Elementary School.

title: Looking For the Tidy Mind, Alas
description: SO it has come to this. The essay, the great literary art form that Montaigne conceived and Virginia Woolf carried on, that the writer Edward Hoagland likens to jazz or a butterfly's flight, has sunk to a state where someone thinks it is a bright idea to ask a computer if an essay is any good.

title: In the Region / Long Island; Riverhead Moves Ahead on Marketing Navy Site
description: LAST week, within five months of Riverhead's securing ownership of 2,550 acres at the Navy-owned Naval Weapons Industrial Reserve Plant in Calverton, the Town Board approved offers totaling $36 million on 1,625 acres of its property.

title: Q & A
description: Lights Over Manitoba

title: Beating Trial Begins For Ex-Police Officer
description: An off-duty New York City police detective involved in a racially charged melee outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub in May 1996 drew his handgun to defend himself, not to aid in a beating, his lawyer said as the long-delayed trial commenced last week in Riverhead.

title: European Diplomats Use Sticks
description: By summoning the warring parties in Kosovo to the peace table next weekend, virtually at gunpoint, the European allies hope to duplicate the feat of the United States in imposing a peace settlement on Bosnia in Dayton, Ohio, more than three years ago.

title: In the Wily Style of Petrosian: Lull the Defense, Then Pounce
description: It must not be assumed that opponents are in a conciliatory mood when they adopt a slow-paced opening. Of the world champions, Jose Raoul Capablanca, Vassily Smyslov, Tigran Petrosian and Anatoly Karpov all favored a leisurely start to the game. They generally reserved their subtleties for the middle game or the endgame. None was alarmed about the prospect that he would not get his chance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEADER, WILLIAM, DR.
description: LEADER-William, Dr. Of Pound Ridge, NY. Died January 29 at Northern Westchester Hospital, Mt. Kisco, N.Y. Beloved husband of Carolyn A. (nee Kassel). Cherished father of Andrew, Brian, Kenneth, and Ingrid Leader. Predeceased by a son, Dr. Robert Leader. Visitation Monday, 2-4 and 6-9PM, at Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home, Mt. Kisco, N.Y. Services Monday, 7:30PM at the funeral home. Interment private.

title: Money Is at the Root of Trial's Partisanship; Why We're Embarrassed
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Property / Retail; National Chains Are Discovering Brooklyn Heights
description: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS has long been an extension of Manhattan, tied to what is invariably referred to as ''the city'' by seven subway lines and isolated from the rest of the borough by the complex of courts and other government buildings to the east of Cadman Plaza.

title: Another Film Festival Heard From
description: To the Editor:

title: Sounds of Almost Another World
description: LADYSMITH, after all, has been the pre-eminent mbube group for some 20 years,'' says the CD booklet. Mbube. Uh-oh, the urban parochials are left out in the cold again -- that is, until they put on a Ladysmith Black Mambazo CD. Suddenly, not knowing Zulu isn't so important as they lose themselves in soothing close harmony of South African male voices. A feeling of peace settles in.

title: Awaiting a Cut in Auto Rates? You'd Better Look Both Ways
description: Will all of New Jersey's ''good drivers'' find a 15 percent reduction in their auto insurance bills, now that the long-awaited rate cut is to take place in March?

title: Taking a Pan-Asian Approach With Flair
description: THE proprietors of Ching's Table in New Canaan seem to be operating under the rule that if a restaurant does not work, change its name. This attractive storefront space began life as Asie, with a tentative stab at pan-Asian cooking, a limited menu and high prices. In a small town with three other Asian restaurants, Asie didn't survive more than a few months. Then presto! It became Sentosa, which didn't last long enough for us to sample it.

title: Lewis J. Gorin Jr., Instigator of a 1930's Craze, Dies at 84
description: Lewis J. Gorin Jr., a Princeton-educated, Harvard-trained lawyer who had a long, respectable and thoroughly obscure career as a business executive, gentleman farmer and amateur military historian, died on Jan. 1 at his home in Louisville, Ky. He was 84 and all but forgotten as the man who had tickled a dispirited nation's funnybone in 1936 with a tongue-in-cheek tour de force that created a brushfire national student movement and made Mr. Gorin the most famous collegian in America who did not actually play football.

title: The Island: Don't Vacation Without It
description: TWO more months of winter to go, and we're already dreaming about summer vacations. Travel agency brochures are scattered over the coffee table, providing a delicious hint of the pleasures that may or may not be ours in the not-too-distant future.

title: Dreaming the Impossible Dream
description: In 1999, things will be different: You will carry out your New Year's resolution to advance your career or resolve a workplace conflict. Well maybe. But what about about past years? How close did you come to meeting a work-related goal that you set for yourself in January? Or, how did you efforts go awry? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become propery of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: POSTINGS: School of Interior Design Solves a Design Problem; Combining Two Buildings
description: When the New York School of Interior Design acquired a building that partially backed up to its headquarters at 170 East 70th Street in the Upper East Side Historic District, officials of the school and their architects were confronted with a classic design problem: how best to reuse the space at 161 East 69th Street, a building that had been a garage, office space and a duplex apartment.

title: BENEFITS
description: 'The Last Days'

title: Restaurateur Puts His Game Face On
description: HISTORICALLY, New York has had two models,'' said Danny Meyer, trying not to sound smug in his championship season. ''One model is really nice to its people and never quite makes it to the top. The other holds its people to the highest standards but tramples on their self-esteem, which is classic in the restaurant business.

title: Are You Nuts?
description: WOMEN DRINKING BENEDICTINEBy Sharon Dilworth.215 pp. Columbus:Ohio State University Press. $22.

title: Caught in the Undertow
description: SUMMER and winter are different here only because of the weather. The ocean breeze blows across an empty boardwalk and right through the spectral hulk that was supposed to become a condominium building. The streets off Ocean Avenue are lined with parking meters that rarely see a car, in January or in August.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUGUST, ANNE ATKATZ
description: AUGUST-Anne Atkatz. Of West Palm Beach, Florida, formerly of NYC, passed away on January 28, 1999. She is survived by her loving children: Susan (Frederic) Rubinstein and Neil (Joan) August. She is also survived by her sister Leah Brecher. She will be lovingly remembered by her grandchildren Nicolas, Edythe, Karen, and Deborah, and her great-grandchildren Michelle, Allison, Jeremy, and Lindsay. Anne was a teacher at P.S. 48 in Bronx, NY for many years. Services were held in Florida. Memorial donations should be made to The Stanley Isaacs Neighborhood Center for The Jack & Anne August Education Fund, 415 East 93rd Street, New York, NY 10128 (212) 360-7620. For information Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapels, West Palm Beach, Florida 1-800-94-SHALOM.

title: New Jersey Challenges Mapmakers
description: It happens more frequently in New Jersey than almost anywhere else, experts say: drivers stare in confusion at maps that tell them to turn left onto a street that doesn't exist, or to drive straight through a shopping center.

title: The Courthouse as a Bastion Against Terror
description: CIVILITY, urbanity, grandeur without arrogance. If public architecture in America was civic art raised to the pinnacle of dignity, then the ambition of the courthouse was to infuse that art with a spirit of democracy informed by access. Judge, jury and suspect alike entered it. Everyday citizens passed by. And though set on a lofty eminence in the town or a commanding spot in the city, the courthouse knew how to soften its role as a Temple of Justice to fit into the public realm.

title: Q&A/Sister Jean Baptiste Nicholson; Principal Keeps Her Appointed Rounds
description: SNOW and sleet kept her students home from school two days in mid-January, but almost nothing keeps Sister Jean Baptiste Nicholson, the principal of the Ursuline School in New Rochelle, from her appointed rounds. For 25 years, Sister J. B. as she is known by her students, faculty and staff (''It's easier to say,'' she said. ) has overseen this Roman Catholic school that serves about 700 girls from grades 6 to 12. During her tenure, which began as President Richard M. Nixon was about to leave office in 1974, many things have changed: for nuns, for girls' education and for the role of women in the Roman Catholic Church. Education is neither better nor worse, just different, Sister Jean Baptiste said.

title: Wendy Levine, Mark Mitzner
description: Wendy Levine, a retail advertising executive, and Mark S. Mitzner, a retired media executive, were married last evening by Cantor Howard Stahl at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARIENBERG, STELLA
description: MARIENBERG-Stella. 87, at her home, January 29, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Leon Marienberg. M.D. Devoted mother of William Marienberg and Evelyn S. Marienberg-Miceli, M.D., and loving grandmother of Lauren Miceli and Max Marienberg. Donations may be made in memory of Stella to ''SBF/Leon Marienberg Family Practice Award,'' c/o Office of Alumni Affairs, U.M.C., SUNY at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, NY 11794, or the ''Granat Alzheimer's Center,'' c/o Parker Jewish Geriatric Institute, 271-11 76th St., New Hyde Park, NY 11040. Services January 31, 2 PM, at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, NY, 516-486-2500.

title: Riding Amtrak
description: To the Editor: My husband and I are college professors and we take long-distance Amtrak trains at least five times a year. The article referred to one dissatisfied couple and not to the countless others who are happy.

title: United, Now, Against Lounge
description: Opposition to a planned lounge on West 20th Street has united neighbors who have been squabbling over a residence for people with AIDS scheduled to open on the block between Seventh and Eighth Avenues this spring.

title: Bringing Tonality, and Fans, to Contemporary Music
description: CALL them neo-Romantics, neo-tonalists or post-modernists. None of the labels are adequate. All are attempts to define the music of those American composers -- Richard Danielpour, Aaron Jay Kernis, even John Adams -- who look to the past for inspiration and care little about the modernist obsession with originality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, PHYLLIS
description: SCHNEIDER - Phyllis. Beloved daughter of the late Rose and Ben; cherished sister of the late Robert, Eleanor and Shirley; devoted and adored aunt of Patty, Mimi, Janie, Michael, Sharon and Randi; dear great and grand-aunt and selfless friend. We were all her first priority and our lives were truly enriched and blessed by her love and devotion. Funeral services Monday, 10 AM, at I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead.

title: How I Went to Short Hills and Got Malled
description: I was on my way to the Mall at Short Hills when the cell phone rang. It was my husband. ''Your mother called, and your sister-in-law called, too.''

title: To Stop the Whispers, Principal Speaks Out
description: SHELLEY WILLIAMS is getting divorced. The tawdry details of her personal affairs are nobody's business, but as founder and executive director of Ms. Shelley's Upward Prep School in Roosevelt, the news is all over town.

title: THEATER; A Mentor With Wisdom And a Drive to Learn
description: ON Jan. 14, in Pontedera, Italy, Jerzy Grotowski died at the age of 65. To some, he stands with Konstantin Stanislavsky, Vsevolod Meyerhold and Bertolt Brecht as one of the great figures of 20th-century theater. To others, he is unknown. A strange paradox: this theater figure whose influence derives not so much from public productions but from the hundreds, probably thousands, of individuals he encountered, touched and changed.

title: Italian Hit Parade, With a Few Misses
description: ONE of the most exciting restaurants of 1997 was a stylish cafe on Merrick Road in Massapequa called Opal Basil. This storefront surprised even the most jaded of diners with its unexpectedly elegant ambience and sit-up-and-take-notice contemporary American food. But while scores of mediocre spots that opened that year are still with us, Opal Basil closed after nine and a half months.

title: Corrections
description: An essay on Dec. 27 about reading books in other people's homes misspelled the surname of an author. A reader's letter dated Jan. 11 points out that she is M. F. K. Fisher, not Fischer.

title: Fire Safety In High-Rises
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIMER, JANICE WOLK
description: OPPENHEIMER-Janice Wolk. We greatly mourn the passing of Janice Wolk Oppenheimer, beloved mother of Carol Kurtz and mother-in-law of Michael S. Kurtz, Treasurer of the American Friends of The Hebrew University (AFHU). Both Carol and Michael are dedicated supporters of AFHU and of the Lautenberg Center for General and Tumor Immunology. We extend our deepest sympathy to Carol and Michael, and to their children Randy and Jason in their time of sorrow. We know that Mrs. Oppenheimer will be deeply missed by her family. American Friends of The Hebrew University Keith L. Sachs, President Fred S. Lafer, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive Vice President The Lautenberg Center Paul M. Densen, Chairman Carmi Schwartz, Vice Chairman

title: Money Is at the Root of Trial's Partisanship; Limits of Forgiveness
description: To the Editor:

title: The Stifled Life
description: FALLING SLOWLY

title: January 24-30; Introducing La Nina
description: El Nino, the big pool of warm water that appears from time to time in the tropical Pacific and disrupts weather patterns around the world, became a household word a year ago. Its opposite number, La Nina, which makes the tropical Pacific colder than normal, may be less familiar but is solidly in place now, Federal scientists say, altering atmospheric circulation in a different way than El Nino did.

title: San Juan
description: Sanjuaneros have been through a lot in recent months, starting with Hurricane Georges in September, followed by weeks of thunderous downpours and then a grueling political campaign culminating in a referendum in December that only served to show how deeply divided Puerto Ricans are over their future.

title: Our Towns; In a Crisis, It's Woodstock To the Rescue
description: FOR people who feel trapped by city life, who daydream about living without woes among the dharma spirit shops and tie-dyed jogging tights of a rural arts colony like this one, the reality is that even here, weird and sad things happen. It's just that Woodstockers seem to be pretty good at coming to the rescue.

title: The Wrong Term
description: To the Editor:

title: Less Than Elementary
description: LAST May the state Supreme Court mandated preschool education for 3- and 4-year-old children in 28 of New Jersey's poorest urban districts, to begin no later than fall 1999. The court found that such programs were necessary to insure that children in these communities had an equal opportunity for success. Moreover, they were impressed by research showing that high-quality preschool education could save taxpayers money in the long run by reducing school failure and education costs, decreasing crime and delinquency, and increasing employment and earnings.

title: Evaluate and Prune Leafless Trees
description: An ideal time to evaluate the shape and health of trees is while they're dormant and bare of leaves in a quiet winter garden: do it with pruners, loppers and a pruning saw at hand, on a dry day when the bark is not wet.

title: An American In Paris, Painting With a Saxophone
description: SINCE the be-bop era, jazz musicians seeking a better life have landed with their suitcases on the shores of Europe. In cities like Paris, Stockholm and Berlin, they have found steady work, low rents, congenial audiences and a more hospitable racial climate. But for all its attractions, living abroad has seldom advanced the art itself.

title: Janet Milligan, Rodney Viccari
description: Janet Kruk Milligan, a real estate broker, was married yesterday to Rodney Peter Viccari, an executive in the cosmetic accessories industry. The Rev. Avery Manchester, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Israel's New Centrist Leader Bows to Religious Right
description: Roni Milo, the former Mayor of Tel Aviv, is Israel's Mr. Secular. A former member of the conservative Likud Party, he founded the political center last spring partly to create an enlightened middle-of-the-road movement that would not capitulate to religious coercion by strictly Orthodox Jews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENZA, JOHN G.
description: MENZA-John G. Of Hempstead, NY on January 28, 1999. He is survived by his wife, Antonina, daughter Claudia of Manhattan, daughter Valeria of Rome, and sister Lucia of New Jersey. Memorial donations may be made to the Sierra Club.

title: Photos Rooted In Realism
description: STAMFORD WALKER EVANS (1903-1975) is indelibly associated with the Depression and the photographs of Southern sharecroppers he took for the 1941 book by James Agee, ''Let Us Now Praise Famous Men.'' But Evans's career was long, and more varied and contradiction-filled than the collaboration indicates. His output from 1927 through 1974 is surveyed at the Whitney Museum's branch here in the exhibition ''Simple Subjects.''

title: Governors Island: Many Proposals, No Consensus
description: NEW YORK has a Y2K+2 problem, cyber-shorthand for the year 2002. That is the deadline for the city and state to come up with a plan for Governors Island. If nothing is in the works by then the Federal Government, which owns the island, can sell it to a developer. City Hall is convening a task force of public officials and private citizens next month to weigh the options and search for a consensus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHO, SUZIE S.
description: CHO-Suzie S. Died suddenly on January 25, 1999 in Belize in her 34th year. Wife of Marc Lambrechts, daughter of Edward and June Cho. She is also survived by her sister Juli Cho and her brother Joseph Cho. Calling hours at the Cho-Lambrechts residence, 158 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn, Sunday, January 31st from 2-4 PM. Funeral service at 4PM.

title: Ideas & Trends; Shoring Up Satan, Closing Limbo
description: IT seemed like a season for traditionalists.

title: Shimmering Orchestral Tapestries
description: IT may not be helpful to living musical practitioners to know this, but death does wonders for a composer's reputation, at least as measured by representation on CD. Numerous recordings of works by Luigi Nono, John Cage, Witold Lutoslawski and Toru Takemitsu have come too late for them to hear, and the posthumous crescendo is even more spectacular in the case of Morton Feldman. At the time of his death, in 1987, the CD catalogue included barely a handful of his pieces. Now his whole immense output is heaving into view, and the peaks are beginning to become evident. Most recently, three releases have started to repair the neglect of his orchestral compositions.

title: Living With Mother
description: To the Editor:

title: PULSE; G-Strings For the Feet
description: The thong's the thing for many designers this spring, even though the sexy sandals are hard to walk in, often wince-producing and best suited to those blessed with beautiful feet.

title: The View From/Purchase; Celebrating a Dream With Harmony
description: POSSIBLY the best thing about Music America 1999 was that it was no big deal. The music was fabulous, the party was festive, but the event's philosophical underpinning -- the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s message of racial harmony -- seemed, quite simply, to be taken for granted in the best sense of the word.

title: Martha Kollar, Stuart Malina
description: Martha Ann Kollar and Stuart Charles Malina are to be married today by Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. of Charleston, S.C., at the Charleston Place Hotel.

title: In the Region / Westchester; Changing Times: Office Developer Shifts to Houses
description: ON a recent almost spring-like day Lowell M. Schulman, one of the pioneer developers of Westchester's office market, was walking through a 60-acre property straddling Tarrytown and Sleepy Hollow that he had purchased last month and talking about his new approach to real estate now that he's given up almost all of his office property.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about dry cleaners who use solvents other than perchloroethylene, a suspected carcinogen, misstated the application deadline for finanical aid for cleaners to buy machines that use alternatives. It is April 1, not April 30.

title: Bygone Era's Revival: Hauling Goods by Rail
description: AS Long Island Rail Road commuter trains zip by on the main track just east of the Deer Park train station, the engineer, Alex Raia, and conductor, Mark Myers, get their 19-car freight train into position so they can drop off three rail cars loaded with 159 rolls of paper weighing 465,000 pounds.

title: Salon Offers 'Smart Card' For Tanning Clients
description: It's not Miami Beach, but Sun Point, opening in the dead of winter two weeks ago, can tan you just the same. The salon at 344 East 63d Street (between First and Second Avenues) is run by a German company. At the East Side site, the first in the United States, clients get a ''smart card'' that stores information including skin type, preferred tanning bed, dates of prior visits and number of minutes bought. ''You only pay for the time you are actually tanning,'' said Heike Muschik, the salon's president. Amenities include music, piped into the tanning bed cushion.

title: G.O.P. Leaders Hope Plan for Wide Tax Cut Will Unite Party
description: In placing income tax reductions at the heart of their agenda this year, Republican leaders are hoping to rally their fractious party around an issue they have long believed is economically sound as well as politically appealing.

title: Ferry Run Halted
description: To the Editor: A short article appeared Dec. 6 about a new international ferry service, ''Ferry From Tampa to the Mexican Coast.'' I purchased passage on this American Viking Lines ferry for Jan. 20, with a return Jan. 27. When I called early in January to check on something, I got a recording saying service was suspended.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELDMAN, SAM
description: FELDMAN-Sam Jan 26, 1998. Missing and remembering you with love. Gunny, Sara, Debbie, Jo, Bruce and Paul

title: January 24-30; Olympic Scandal Widens
description: The fallout continued from the biggest corruption scandal in Olympic history as the International Olympic Committee expelled six members for receiving improper benefits in the bidding for the 2002 Winter Games in Salt Lake City.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 31, 1999
description: Weeks

title: The Micromonarch
description: THE GRAND STRATEGY

title: Age of Ideology: Murray Kempton on the 30's
description: Christopher Hitchens is a columnist for Vanity Fair and The Nation. His latest book, ''No One Left to Lie To: The Triangulations of William Jefferson Clinton,'' will be published in April.

title: Wadleigh Wins One For the Goat
description: The Wadleigh High School basketball team and Earl (the Goat) Manigault both thrived on second chances. Manigault, who soared on New York's playgrounds in the 60's while plummeting into heroin addiction, counseled Wadleigh athletes and others before he died of heart failure last May at the age of 53.

title: The New Stay-Put Era Warms Stern's Heart
description: Kobe Bryant is not going anywhere for at least five years, remaining with the Lakers in Los Angeles until at least 2003. The same goes for Allen Iverson in Philadelphia, Shareef Abdur-Rahim in Vancouver and Antoine Walker in Boston. The rash of young stars signing lucrative extensions with their original teams has curbed player movement and may signal a new era in the National Basketball Association -- one with fewer monster deals but more permanence on the roster.

title: Sharing Their Talents and Their Dollars
description: WHEN Social Venture Partners of Seattle, a sort of Project Head Start for junior philanthropists, decided last year to donate $65,000 to a program that gives local children from poor families tutoring, computer training and social skills, it did more than just send a check. One member of the group, a seasoned real estate agent, negotiated new leases for the project. Another member took a jumble of outdated computers, added some newer machines bought with donations and wired together an up-to-the-minute network.

title: Nassau College Cancels Season
description: A raucous road trip to Florida has cost the men's and women's basketball teams at Nassau Community College the rest of their seasons.

title: Shunning Emerging Markets, Except One
description: DIEGO ESPINOSA, the co-manager of the Scudder Global Fund, is not interested at the moment in Brazil or most of the rest of the world's major emerging markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPMAN, ALFRED J.
description: LIPPMAN-Alfred J. 98 of Highland Beach, FL. Formerly of Newark, NJ. Died Friday, January 29, 1999. A veteran of WWI and WWII and a life long active Republican. Mr. Lippman's international politics extended to Mexican-American relations. He was the founder (1971) and past president of the United States-Mexican Chamber of Commerce. Mr. Lippman was involved in countless, benevolent and civic interests. Contributions to the American Heart Association and Temple B'nai Jeshuran, 1025 So. Orange Ave., Short Hills, NJ 07078. Services Monday, February 1, 1999, at Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, FL.

title: Azerbaijan Asks the U.S. To Establish Military Base
description: With foreign powers competing for influence in the soon-to-be-rich lands surrounding the Caspian Sea, Azerbaijan, potentially the richest of them, has made a startling offer. It wants the United States to open a military base there.

title: Caterwauling Over Shelter For Felines
description: A white clapboard house on 28th Street that is a haven for dozens of cats has neighbors howling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCANN, HELEN MARY
description: McCANN-Helen Mary. Age 83, died on Friday, January 29, at Rosary Hill Home. Beloved sister of Maureen Miletta and devoted aunt of Alexandra Miletta, Jennifer Miletta Adams, Peter Paul McCann and Kathleen Des Maisons. Visitng hours Sunday from 1 to 4 PM, McGrath Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY. Funeral Mass Monday at 10 AM, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Rosary Hill Home, Hawthorne, NY 10532 or to Barnard College.

title: Money Is at the Root of Trial's Partisanship; Scandal Is Political
description: To the Editor:

title: What War Has Wrought: Sierra Leone's Sad State
description: Issa Alison-Konteh sat at an intersection in this capital, an unsteady stool beneath him, the gutted Piccadilly chicken grill behind him, a crumbled house beside him and two burned-out buildings before him.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Steve Zahn; Making A Getaway On Skis
description: STEVE ZAHN had been to the Sundance Film Festival a few times, but this was the first time he was equipped with a cell phone. The actor, known for quirky roles like his part as a bookstore worker in ''You've Got Mail,'' pulled out a brick-size early-model Motorola and searched futilely for the button to access his number.

title: Getting the Republicans Back on Track
description: While Senate Republicans spent much of the past week searching for an ''exit strategy'' from the trial of President Clinton, the public seemed to be holding Republican politicians responsible for the entire impeachment quagmire. When the battle on Capitol Hill is over, what will the party do next? Here are some suggestions from various quarters on how the Republicans might shake off the impeachment funk.

title: Never Marry a Dog
description: In 1993, Yoko Tawada won the Akutagawa Prize, one of Japan's highest literary awards, for the title story in THE BRIDEGROOM WAS A DOG (Kodansha, $19). Here a schoolteacher's retelling of a randy fairy tale -- involving a young princess promised in marriage to a dog -- makes her a favorite subject of local gossip. Yet the tale takes on an unsettling reality when a doglike mystery man quietly but firmly seduces the teacher, even taking over her housework and cooking. His aura of mystery dissipates, however, when she learns that her accomplished lover is on the lam from a wife and a job, and is carrying on a homosexual affair with the father of one of her students. In ''Missing Heels,'' a poor mail-order bride, spiritual sister to Kafka's K., travels by train to an unfamiliar city, where she moves into the eerie house of her new husband and finds only circumstantial evidence of his existence: a morning cup of tea, her daily cash allowance on the night stand, the sounds of quickly disappearing footsteps. She begins to imagine her husband as a hideous old man or, more hopefully, a shy, orphaned young heir -- until her curiosity drives her to break into his locked room and she finds a reality much stranger than her imaginings. In the last of this trio of stories, ''The Gotthard Railway,'' it is the journey rather than the destination that matters when a quirkily philosophical woman takes a surreal railroad trip through a Swiss mountain tunnel. As translated by Margaret Mitsutani, Tawada's slender accounts of alienation achieve a remarkable potency. Each one sustains a masterly balance between the tenuous but meaningful connections of dreams and the direct, earthy storytelling of folk tales. Michael Porter

title: Three Exhibits Focus on Black History
description: New England will celebrate Black History Month, beginning tomorrow, with exhibitions focusing on African-American leaders and artists, including Frederick Douglass and the sculptor and printmaker Elizabeth Catlett.

title: Stay Is the Word For Pet Pictures At Train Station
description: A snapshot of a 20-year-old cat named Annie Wortman and pictures of more than two dozen other neighborhood pets are back on the elevator wall of the A train's 190th Street station.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREY, LESTER
description: GREY-Lester. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Lester Grey, associated with The Times from 1956 until retiring in 1990.

title: Hal David
description: David, 77, was the first to ask ''What's it all about, Alfie?'' ''Do you know the way to San Jose?'' and other indelible phonographic questions in lyrics for songs he wrote with (the resurgent) Burt Bacharach. He and Bacharach reunited to write for the coming Bette Midler film ''Isn't She Great?''

title: Clinton Backs Environmental Power-Sharing
description: The environmental proposals that the Clinton Administration is sending to Congress in its budget request for 2000 include new ways of delivering money to state and local governments to spend as they see fit, a sign that environmental power-sharing is taking a firmer hold than ever before.

title: Polishing Their Image
description: FRAMED in the waiting room of Drs. Marc Lowenberg and Gregg Lituchy is a New York magazine cover, with their photograph, touting a listing of ''The 100 Best Dentists in New York.'' It's a fake, a Spy magazine parody from 1991, when the idea of celebrating dentists still seemed ridiculous.

title: Skulking Around in the Swamp
description: WHISPER the words ''Key Largo'' in my ear and I am suddenly tanned and barefoot, toes curled around the rung of a bar stool, nodding at the tall tales of marlin fishermen and watching a fat red sun sinking into the bay. When two guys in baggy linen suits push through the screen door and put a round into the jukebox, the bartender, who is a friend of mine, casually advises me to slip out the back. A drug bust? A movie conference? I just laugh and toss another beefsteak to the big bull alligator who lives at the far end of the dock.

title: Techies Discover The Joys Of Giving
description: THE lights glistened, the stallions pranced and the Lyndon Baines Johnson High School Band played ''Jingle Bells'' and ''Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer.'' Here, at the opening parade for the annual Trail of Lights Festival, Austin's proudest Christmas tradition, a refreshment stand served hot chocolate and nachos fragrant with jalapeno peppers and melted cheese. And waving with his family from a horse-drawn carriage, thanks to a $120,000 contribution from his company and his own growing celebrity, was Michael S. Dell.

title: Teen-Age Birth Rate Seventh Lowest in Country
description: New Jersey has the nation's seventh lowest birth rate among teen-agers, according to a study released by Rutgers University last week.

title: The Test Under Stress
description: Contrary to your article asserting that the College Board says that ''no amount of studying'' will increase S.A.T. scores, the board has always emphasized that rigorous academic preparation over time -- including the completion of challenging academic high-school courses and extensive outside reading -- is helpful for success in college and on the S.A.T.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Historical Societies See Role as Keepers Of Culture for Future
description: CARS streak past Andrew Batten's small office at the Rye Historical Society all day long, their drivers generally more absorbed with getting to the nearby Cross Westchester Expressway than considering his quaint building on the corner -- the place where George Washington liked to stay when he was in town, where John and Samuel Adams enjoyed several meals and where, Mr. Batten said seriously, the ghosts of other former occupants still wander.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOMINGDALE, LYMAN G.
description: BLOOMINGDALE-Lyman G., on January 28, 1999, in Canton, MA. Beloved father of Gwen Bloomingdale, Jennifer B. Nelson, Penny B. Baker and Billie B. Logan. Loving grandfather of Andrew B. Bloomingdale, Gwendolyn R. Walker, Angus M. Walker, Mollie A. Nelson, Stephen A. Koshland, Andrew J. Logan and John P. Logan. Great-grandfather of three. Dear brother of George N. Cowen, the late Alfred S. Bloomingdale and Arthur Cowen, Jr. Services Monday, February 1st at 12:00 Noon at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Brown University or the American Friends of Hebrew University.

title: The Don Is Done
description: There is no one associated with organized crime who doesn't believe that Gotti ordered Castellano's death. Joseph Castellano, whose life was turned inside out by the murder, says he doesn't believe it. ''I know they say that Mr. Gotti'' -- he is careful to employ the honorific -- ''was the one who murdered our father,'' he told me recently. ''But I don't know. I have no proof of this. The Government says this is true, but what do you want from the Government? My father was watched by the Government for 40 years, and then on the day he gets killed, what happened? Where was the F.B.I.?''

title: Quest for Witnesses A Matter of Presedent
description: Senator Gordon H. Smith, Republican of Oregon, knows that President Clinton is almost certain to be acquitted on the articles of impeachment, because the Senate lacks the two-thirds majority necessary for a conviction.

title: January 24-30; Ford Buys Volvo Car Unit
description: Henry Ford took pride in building Model T's that the common man could afford. But the market for basic transportation is increasingly unprofitable as manufacturers in places like South Korea churn out lots of cheap cars. So the Ford Motor Company has announced that it will also try to become a larger maker of luxury cars by buying the car operations of Sweden's Volvo for $6.45 billion.

title: He Never Wanted to Hurt Music, Just Help It Evolve
description: FOR a brief period in the spring of 1898, Arnold Schoenberg, then 23, thought that his music just might be received by the public with some degree of sympathy. His String Quartet in D, a piece steeped in Brahms but using a more wide-ranging harmonic language, was performed by a new-music ensemble in Vienna and greeted with something approaching enthusiasm.

title: For Open Doors in the Senate
description: With the final debates and deliberations in President Clinton's impeachment trial not far off, the television news broadcaster CNN has rendered an important service by reminding the Senate of its constitutional duty to conduct the critical remaining portions of the trial in public.

title: The Test Under Stress
description: I find it very interesting that so many admissions officers quoted in your article play down the significance of S.A.T. scores, as well as the ability of preparation courses to help students increase those scores. Many of these same schools will use their record of how well their students do as selling points when it comes to graduate-school admissions, which, for many, mean taking more standardized tests: L.S.A.T., G.R.E., M.C.A.T., etc. Companies like Kaplan offer these students expensive courses to help them prepare as well. Some colleges see this as enough of a ''win-win'' situation that they even allow these companies space on their campuses, free of charge, to offer preparation courses to their students.

title: The Nation: Reprising Zero Tolerance; History Shows That Tough Talk Is Cheap
description: WHEN New York City Police Commissioner Howard Safir announced a tough new plan this month to seize the vehicles of drunk drivers, he might have had a talk first with Dick Weart.

title: Easy does it: floating down the rivers of the world
description: Barge and riverboat travel is about as leisurely a means of travel as one can find, and it continues to gain popularity with travelers intent on becoming acquainted with the countryside, especially in Europe, where cruises on rivers and canals are generally offered from April to November.

title: Ideas & Trends; Why Sex Works
description: IT is hard to see why economics is called the dismal science when the title is so much better deserved by evolutionary biology.

title: Ode to Language
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Is at the Root of Trial's Partisanship; Two-Tiered Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: But Is It Art?
description: MY favorite Susan Cianciolo design is called a Change dress. It is made of muslin and has several features: a snap-on pompom at broach level (choose a pink, yellow or blue one), a dangly bit of crocheted string that attaches in two places and a handy little muslin bag filled with little rectangles of fabric. These are called snappers, because of their snap-on capabilities. You can snap them over your waist, as the designer suggests, or wing it, snapping a corner of one, for example, where the pompom usually goes, so that the rectangle flies about like a little hanky on your chest.

title: The Test Under Stress
description: Colleges need a test like the S.A.T. to distinguish among the relative value of grades from the approximately 20,000 high schools. Yet, why can't colleges use S.A.T.'s to grade high schools, rather than individual students? Colleges could use the school's average score to adjust (normalize) its students' grade-point averages to reflect the quality of the school, enabling the adjusted G.P.A.'s to replace the S.A.T. as a uniform national benchmark.

title: Money Is at the Root of Trial's Partisanship; Mr. Hyde's Thesaurus
description: To the Editor:

title: January 24-30; Hubbell Tax Case Reinstated
description: When a Federal judge threw out a tax fraud case last year against Webster L. Hubbell, it was a signal defeat for Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater prosecutor. The judge described Mr. Starr in terms that delighted his enemies, calling him a runaway prosecutor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAGLIAMONTE, AUGUST
description: TAGLIAMONTE-August. Of New York City and Richmond, Massachusetts. Died tragically in an automobile accident on January 28, 1999. He is survived by his wife, Lee Lamont; daughter, Leslie Lamont; sisters, Flora Amorello, Vivian Petretti and Mary Tagliamonte Shiller; and brother, Edmund Tagliamonte. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Anatolia's Ancient Ports of Call
description: DURING a memorable cruise along Turkey's Mediterranean coast last June, I saw Odysseus only in my mind's eye. This was almost odd, because his presence is palpable among the islets, bays and ancient ruins that make this trip so rewarding. Here the sea truly is wine-dark and the dawn does have rosy fingers. It takes almost no imagination at all to envision not only Odysseus but also Alexander, Cleopatra, Hadrian and other titans of antiquity gazing on the same sights that await visitors today.

title: Runner-Up's Revelation Likely to Test the Waters
description: After her first Grand Slam final had ended in a 6-2, 6-3 loss to Martina Hingis, Amelie Mauresmo sat at a table outside the players' lounge today and talked calmly and confidently about her decision to make her homosexuality public knowledge.

title: Court Ruling Boosts Private Holocaust Lawsuits
description: Mor Stern, a wine and spirits maker in Hungary who was sent to Auschwitz in World War II, died at the hands of Nazi Germany but left behind insurance policies that would have taken care of his survivors. His heirs, who say they have been trying to collect on those policies for more than 50 years, are taking the case to court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VIDOCKLER, MURRAY
description: VIDOCKLER-Murray, 79. Of Boca Raton, Florida, and New York. Passed away Jan. 29, 1999. He was the husband of Ruth. Father of Stuart (Lynda Clare) Vidockler of Boston, MA., and Francine (David Krigman) Vidockler of Newton, MA. Grandfather of Eliza and Rachel. Brother of Arthur (Belle) Vidockler of Lake Worth, Bernard (Helen) Vidockler of Wellington & Gertrude (Stanley Papkin) Hirsch of West Palm Beach. Mr. Vidockler was founder of Brighton Travel Bureau and British Caledonian Airlines, and a member of ASTA. He served in the Navy during WWII and was a graduate of Townsend Harris High School and City College of NY. Funeral service will be at 11 A.M., Tuesday, February 2, 1999 at Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 312 Coney Island Avenue ''at Prospect Park'' Brooklyn.

title: IN BRIEF; 7 L.I. Students Reach Intel Competition Finals
description: While other teen-agers were sleeping late last Sunday morning, Alex Wissner-Gross and six other Long Island high school seniors received a phone call that changed their lives.

description: TINA FU will never fit the popular movie and book image of the librarian: quiet spoken as the traditional mouse, reserved as a character in a Victorian novel. Try instead bubbly, engaging, enthusiastic, even comical, for she is surely that.

title: Shattering Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; After Calhoun Fumes, The Huskies Respond
description: MIKE JARVIS's team more than weathered the game-opening tornado, but even with a 12-point lead three minutes into the second half, he understood the forecast remained cloudy with a 90 percent chance of a heavy Connecticut run. Beyond the youthful tendencies of his own players in games against higher-ranked teams, he knew Jim Calhoun wasn't going to just go away without a burst of hot air.

title: Merry Company and More From a Golden Age
description: SOMETHING for everybody doesn't have to mean compromise. The exhibition ''Pieter de Hooch 1629-1684'' at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford will appeal to those who enjoy watching one painter's progress, to those interested in the painting and culture of Holland's Golden Age, and to those who are simply cheered by depictions of strong family life.

title: Sunscreen Serenade
description: Imagine Mary Schmich's surprise when the Chicago Tribune columnist and writer of the ''Brenda Starr'' comic strip discovered that a mock graduation address she wrote had turned into the feel-good anthem of the Internet set, somehow misattributed to the novelist Kurt Vonnegut in its race down the info superhighway.

title: Big Feet: Andersen Takes On Elam, the 63-Yard Man
description: One is probably headed for nomination to the Hall of Fame. The other has a shoe that will be going to the Hall of Fame. That's just one of the striking differences between the place-kickers in Sunday's Super Bowl.

title: Robin Pollak, Peter Reiser
description: Robin Diane Pollak, the daughter of Joan and Lee Pollak of New York, was married last evening to Peter Jacques Reiser, the son of Inez Reiser and Dr. Albert Reiser, also of New York. Rabbi David Posner officiated at Le Cirque 2000 in New York.

title: 2 Cleared on Some Counts In 1996 Slayings at Scores

But the jurors continued to debate more serious charges, signaling that they were wrestling with the credibility of the main prosecution witness, a Mafia turncoat.

description: Isabelle Autissier is as amazed as anyone at the success she has resurrected from failure in sailing alone around the world.

description: A late goal by Niklas Sundstrom gave the Rangers a 3-2 victory tonight over the Detroit Red Wings, the two-time defending Stanley Cup champions, in Joe Louis Arena. It gave the Rangers two victories for a three-game road trip, and it lifted them within 3 points of the Florida Panthers in the race for the eighth and final playoff berth in the Eastern Conference. These things, normally, would be reason for unmitigated happiness.

description: CHURRASCARIA PLATAFORMA **

title: Updated 'Alice in Wonderland' at Purchase College
description: CHILDREN able to appreciate the wit and whimsy of Lewis Carroll (those 7 and older) will find an updated version of ''Alice in Wonderland'' today at 3 P.M. at Purchase College. The Underground Railway Theater production follows Alice through the looking glass as she meets the Mad Hatter, the White Rabbit and the Red Queen, among other literary personages. The tale is told through puppetry and unusual staging.

title: Lifetimes Of Giving and Art
description: A philanthropist's birthday, funds for ballet and salutes to decoratative arts.
