description: The people who run hedge funds -- those highflying but arcane investment vehicles that touched off a financial panic last year -- want you to know they care. In fact, a group holding a charity banquet on Feb. 9 at the Pierre Hotel at Fifth Avenue and 61st Street in Manhattan is called Hedge Funds Care.

title: Listen Closely
description: To the Editor:

title: After Tobacco, Handgun Lawsuits
description: SINCE the beginning of the Industrial Revolution, Connecticut has been a leading producer of guns, the birthplace of the Colt revolver that tamed the West. But now the state's cities are turning against the industry and joining a wave of lawsuits aimed at taming handguns at the expense of their manufacturers.

title: Rebuilding the Martha Graham Legacy
description: THE incestual bed that Isamu Noguchi designed for Jocasta and her son, Oedipus, in Martha Graham's ''Night Journey'' is no longer parked in a corner of a studio; it has been packed away. Outside, the earth in Graham's beloved garden has been dug up in anticipation of the wrecker's ball.

title: A Pox on the High-Rates 'Cure'
description: WHEN financial crisis strikes and a currency plunges, the Clinton Administration and the International Monetary Fund press the suffering country to raise interest rates. Sometimes the currency recovers, but the higher interest rates always produce a recession. Critics of this remedy, ever more vociferous, are suggesting that high rates are akin to the 18th-century medical practice of bleeding patients to try to cure disease. George Washington's last illness was a bad cold; doctors bled him, and he died within a week.

title: January 24-30; NATO Issues Kosovo Threat
description: The NATO alliance threatened warring Serbian and ethnic Albanian forces in Kosovo with military action unless they agreed to a call by the United States, Russia and four of the European allies for peace talks on autonomy for the province.

title: Lives; No Regrets
description: It all began in Pontiac, Mich., in 1959, although for a long time I didn't know the precise year. All I remember was a soulful ballad on the radio. I heard it only once, I can't even remember where, but the tune stuck in my head, along with this fragment of lyric:

title: The Bilingual Barrier
description: Left to his own devices, Montauk's principal, a silver-haired veteran educator named James Hayden, would be teaching children pretty much this same way today. The school is a stubbornly old-fashioned institution that greets visitors with a big sign that reads, ''A Traditional School, and Proud of It.'' But Hayden is not left to his own devices. I.S. 223, like schools everywhere, is obliged to offer bilingual instruction to its nonnative speakers. What makes the Montauk school unusual is that it offers bilingual classes not only in Spanish but also in Russian and Chinese.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOINESTER, ISAAC E.
description: MOINESTER-Isaac E. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Isaac E. Moinester, associated with The Times from 1954, until retiring in 1975.

title: Silver Charm Is a Surprise Loser, Upsetting a New Racing Series
description: Silver Charm, cast as the ''national champion'' in a new series of races for senior horses, ran third as the favorite today while the Chilean star Puerto Madero won the $500,000 Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

title: N.F.L. Confronts Crimes by Players
description: In recent months the National Football League, embarrassed by its players being involved in violent episodes, has been zealously enforcing its new policy on violent crimes. While critics at first said the policy was nothing more than a public-relations move, it turns out that the program has teeth, and some players believe it could significantly curb the violent acts committed by players.

description: American, Continental, Northwest and US Airways have recently changed their frequent-flier programs.

Although we had driven for nearly an hour in order to try the low-cost, high-value lounge menu at the popular new Belgian restaurant, it was almost a relief to hear that it was not yet being served.

title: ON SUNDAY: JANUARY 31, 1999
description: Once in a blue moon *blue moon n. [from rarity of moon's having a blue cast]: the second full moon in a calendar month. *Will the blue moon tonight be blue? Nope. Unless, say, some atmospheric brouhaha kicks up dust that scatters moonlight in blue wavelengths. *But it was blue for all earthlings in 1883 when Krakatau blew its top and for U.S. observers in the 1950's after a run of forest fires in British Columbia. *Tonight's moon is part of a 19-year cycle of two full moons in January, none in February and two in March. *''Once in a. . .'' made its literary debut in the 1800's as a metaphor for a rare event, but astrotypes didn't glom onto ''blue moon'' as the second full moon of the month's doubleheader until 1980, when an N.P.R. commentator beamed the idea onto the airwaves. *To lunar-tics, ''once in a. . .'' isn't that rare. As a mathematical probability, it means 8 chances in 228.

title: Winners and Losers in the Governor's Budget
description: After years of trimming various projects and programs, Governor Whitman offered a budget last week that recommends spending a little more here and a little more there for the second year in a row.

description: THE only skills required to install a tin ceiling are the ability to drive screws and nails and cut sheet metal. Nevertheless, the job can be tedious because you have to bend over backward to nail the panels in place. This is definitely a two-person job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPMAN, CARROLL FERGUSON
description: CHAPMAN-Carroll Ferguson, 90. Of Mount Kisco, NY died January 27th at Phelps Memorial Hospital, Tarrytown, New York, after a short illness. She is survived by her daughter, Diana Kamilli of Tuscon, AZ, and grandchildren, Daniel Chapman of Pleasantville, NY, and Ann and Robert Kamilli, two great-grandchildren, Emily and Alice Chapman and by her sister Ruth Woolfe of Camden, SC., Mrs. Chapman was born in Greenwich, CT, in 1908. She attended Rosemary Hall and Miss Porter's School (1927). She married Daniel K. Chapman of Greenwich in 1927 and was a resident of Mt. Kisco for 62 years. She was a warm and generous spirit who with gracious elegance and humor enriched the lives of those around her. A memorial service will be held Sunday, January 31 at 3 PM, at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, 85 East Main Street, Mount Kisco, New York. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations may be made to St. Mark's Church.

description: ALTHOUGH the seeds that grew into the modern minivan were initially planted at the Ford Motor Company, that auto maker has usually lagged behind the Chrysler Corporation in the minivan race.

description: THE small-town bank, a fading institution that's been written off as a victim of mergers, is making a comeback.

She thought it made sense to tap the maternal expertise of these 30 ''Windstar moms,'' most of them engineers, and she consulted them routinely as the design progressed.

title: Hamptons Burial: The Plots to Die For Are Fully Booked
description: Death has begun to imitate life out here on the East End of Long Island, where the rich, the gifted and the beautiful gather each summer to calibrate status. The most fashionable place to be dead in the Hamptons is fully booked.

title: Omaha Oracle Taps a Medium Of Wall Street
description: SUCH is the renown of Warren E. Buffett that 10,000 admirers flocked to last year's shareholder meeting in Omaha for his conglomerate, Berkshire Hathaway. Many of them regard publication of the company's annual report, whose main feature is Mr. Buffett's folksy philosophizing, as a highlight of their financial calendar. And people gladly shell out $30 for two decades' worth of the chairman's collected letters.

description: Children do not go to bed hungry in the fine homes of suburban Spring Valley's cul-de-sac neighborhoods. But hunger is on their minds.

title: A Little Here, a Little There
description: Jackson Pollock (1912-56), who had little native talent for art and none for words, revolutionized painting and provoked more words about his work, and himself, than he probably spoke in his lifetime. His celebrated ''drip paintings'' -- executed on the floor, in a series of dancelike movements that became almost as famous as the canvases themselves through Hans Namuth's photographs -- have been interpreted as everything from sublimely lyrical works of art to violent assaults on the whole tradition of painting; certainly they influenced any number of ''subversive'' artists -- sculptors and performance artists as well as painters -- who came after him. And Pollock's life, filled as it was with emotional turmoil that ended with his death in a drunken car crash, has been variously depicted as the apotheosis of romantic suffering and a cautionary tale about the dangers of fame in an age of mass media. All these contradictory theories about the man and his work are scrupulously explored and evaluated in JACKSON POLLOCK (Museum of Modern Art/Abrams, $75). Kirk Varnedoe, chief curator of painting and sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art, and Pepe Karmel, an adjunct assistant curator, have also made an original contribution to Pollock scholarship by analyzing the techniques he used to produce the poured paintings -- techniques that were much more varied and complex than once was thought. Ironically, as Varnedoe acknowledges, the beautiful reproductions of these paintings, which are the centerpiece of the book, can only remind us how much their extraordinary power depends on their physical presence. The sense of explosive energy, the feeling that these strangely rhapsodic objects were never exactly made but simply are, gets lost in reproduction. So, far from being abstract, they may be the most concrete paintings ever made. Evelyn Toynton

title: January 24-30; Newswoman Wins Bias Case
description: Janet Peckinpaugh, once the top-rated anchorwoman in Connecticut, had set out to become an avenger for women denied the chance to grow gray on the air. Instead, a Federal jury in Hartford found that the city's CBS station had let her go because of her sex -- not her age -- and awarded her $8.3 million.

title: Riding Amtrak
description: To the Editor: About the article ''On Amtrak, Full Speed Ahead'' by Betsy Wade (Dec. 13): As a Thanksgiving (Wednesday and Sunday) traveler on Amtrak from Springfield, Mass., to Washington, I was not impressed.

title: The Rose, Ultimate Seduction
description: WHAT is it about roses? When in full bloom, little else in the garden can meet their challenge. The flower is just about perfect. The colors are true. And the foliage is waxy and clean.

title: Paul Metcalf, 81; Wrote Experimental Tales
description: Paul Metcalf, who made his mark as an experimental writer of prose, poetry and plays, died on Jan. 21 near Pittsfield, Mass. He was 81 and lived in Chester, Mass.

title: Corrections
description: An essay on Dec. 27, ''Southern Exposure,'' reviewing books about Antarctic exploration, misstated the United States availability of Roland Huntford's ''Nansen,'' a British biography of the Norwegian explorer Fridtjof Nansen. In a telephone call in mid-January, the author said it is indeed published in the United States, by Barnes & Noble Books. It is a $19.95 paperback, available only in Barnes & Noble's stores and through its catalogues and Web site, www.barnesandnoble.com.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A sophisticated comedy, a graphic World War II story, a milestone of the silent screen and a tense melodrama are among the highlights of this week's films on television. Danny Kaye is in top form as a royal scapegoat in Norman Panama's COURT JESTER (1956). Set in Old England, this smooth spoof of knights and derring-do dispatches the comedian in the guise of jester to the court of a conniver who has usurped the throne from an infant. Adding to the farcical fun is a fine supporting cast, including Glynis Johns, Basil Rathbone and Mildred Natwick -- Tuesday at 6 P.M. Tu/Early Wednesday at 1:15 A.M. on AMC.

title: Cuba Draws the Curious, Despite the Law
description: AT the Marina Hemingway, a complex of hotels, restaurants and shops in Havana, the grocery store's shelves are stacked with Kellogg's Corn Flakes and Rice Krispies, Nestle chocolate bars and American cigarettes. English is spoken along the aisles. The sights and sounds are so familiar that Americans may have to remind themselves that they are in Cuba.

title: Tower of Romance, Tower of History
description: FOR the better part of this century, Heublein Tower has been one of the most dramatic, mysterious sights in the central part of the state. There it is, rising 165 feet in the air atop Talcott Mountain, west of Hartford, a scene out of Germany somehow transported to Yankee Connecticut.

title: Walking Tour Of Gay London Sites
description: A new statue of Oscar Wilde is among the many sites on a new walking tour devoted to gay London. The Soho district is the center of gay London. The tour, run by a nonprofit London organization called Kairos in Soho, offers a glimpse of the lives of gay men and lesbians as well as an overview of the events that led to Britain's partial decriminalization of homosexual acts in 1967.

title: Well Served
description: I CHOSE Esty Street in Park Ridge for numerous reasons, and the restaurant met all of my needs. My family needed to gather in northern New Jersey, a reasonable compromise since my father, whose birthday we were celebrating, lives in Connecticut. He likes hearty fare in a tasteful environment with informative service. Esty Street pleasantly surprised and stimulated us with its outstanding menu, quaint setting and impeccable service. It is a place I would like to revisit.

title: Adding Meaty Flavor From Swiss Chard to Pastas and Frittatas
description: BUNCHES of sturdy greens beckon in cold weather. My favorite is Swiss chard. Braised or sauteed, this attractive vegetable, with leaves that look like spinach on steroids branching from meaty white or ruby stems and ribs, provides a slightly meaty texture and a flavor that is herbaceous but more sweet than bitter.

title: Wouldn't You Like to Fly? 37 (Count 'em) Jimmy Webb Songs
description: THE setting: the lobby of the Paper Mill Playhouse. The time: intermission at a Sunday matinee of ''Up, Up and Away: The Songs of Jimmy Webb.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARLUCK, WENDY JEAN
description: ARLUCK-Wendy Jean. 43. Died January 27, 1999 with her family at her side. Beloved wife, partner and companion of Paul Badalucca, adored daughter of Arthur and the late Wanda, cherished ''kid'' sister of Curtis, treasured friend of Betty, Lisa, cousin Lori and so many more. Services are on Saturday, February 6th at 11AM, Hungerford & Clarke, 110 Pine St., Freeport, New York. Please send donations in Wendy's memory to Cancer Care or the Humane Society.

title: The Test Under Stress
description: The S.A.T. measures nothing more nor less than one's facility with written English and basic math. These are both partly aptitudes, but also true measures of what one has been doing -- or not doing -- over one's life. So it is that college-admissions officers pay attention to this test, as well they should. So, too, arise the panicky catch-up efforts.

title: A Month to Celebrate A Truly Dual Heritage
description: ULRIC HAYNES Jr. didn't start out 41 years ago to become a collector of African art. But as a young man working for the United Nations and later as an American diplomat, he casually began buying ''things that pleased my eye'' in the marketplaces of the countries where he served.

title: Not-So-Fast Food, to Stay
description: WANT breakfast at 9 P.M.? Crave a filet mignon at 6:30 A.M.? Or a six-course meal for $9.95 or two dinners for the price of one and a half? Go to a Long Island diner and you will find deals, warm personal service and every dish from bacon and eggs to baklava, soups to salmon.

title: Pataki Faces Balancing Act On Superfund
description: New York's Superfund program, which has been responsible for cleaning up more than 300 hazardous-waste sites across the state, is running out of money, putting Gov. George E. Pataki in a quandary.

title: A Risky Business
description: To the Editor:

title: About the Tables
description: The Times is reorganizing and revising its financial tables in Money & Business today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBER, MEYER J. ''MIKE.''
description: GARBER-Meyer J. ''Mike.'' Died in Palm Beach on January 27, age 86. Co-founder of Axton-Cross Chemicals, Masters fishing champion and long time race car enthusiast. Husband of the late Nettie, father of Joan, grandfather of Julia, Allison and James, brother of Harriet Klein. Memorial services will be annouced at a late date.

title: Mary Rockefeller, Jeremiah Milbank
description: Mary Gillett Rockefeller of Rye, N.Y., and Jeremiah Milbank of Greenwich, Conn., were married on Monday at the home of the Rev. and Mrs. Ralph Ahlberg in Easthampton, Conn. Mr. Ahlberg, who retired as the senior minister at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, performed the ceremony.

title: Facing Up to Medicare's Future
description: President Clinton and Republican leaders are devising plans to shore up the Social Security system. But neither the President nor his opponents are saying much about how to rescue Medicare, the entitlement program that is in deeper fiscal peril and poses even more unappealing political choices.

title: Suffolk Is Urged to Settle Shoreham Tax Bill
description: THE chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, Richard M. Kessel, is warning Suffolk County to quickly accept the authority's offer to settle a tax case involving the excess assessment of the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: As Logo Dies, Voices Live On
description: It's been a year and a half since Nynex merged with Bell Atlantic and began operating in New York City under that name. Almost immediately, the Nynex logo was replaced by the blue and teal Bell Atlantic emblem, which can be seen on repair trucks, phone books and pay phones.

title: Smith Unlucky, But Feels Great
description: Mike Smith fulfilled his dream of returning to racing today, five months after he broke two vertebrae in his back in a spill at Saratoga. He also got back to racing's reality: he lost an allowance by a nose, and he rode the long shot Truluck to sixth place in the Donn Handicap.

title: Anderson Proves His Durability
description: Jamal Anderson strolled with relative ease through the weeklong blitz of anticipation for Super Bowl XXXIII. He smiled a lot. Talked a lot. Smiled some more. Quite charming. Easy. Reflective. Enlightening in his conversation. Easy.

title: The Foot Connection
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Kalamarides And Mr. Norgaard
description: Jessica Farmer Kalamarides, the daughter of Kathleen and John Kalamarides Jr. of Wilton, Conn., was married there yesterday to Thor Thompson Norgaard, the son of Dr. Corinne T. Norgaard and Dr. Richard Norgaard of Mansfield Center, Conn. The Rev. James Breen performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church.

title: Davis Makes Late Picks Proud
description: Terrell Davis, like Jamal Anderson, was nearly a forgotten man when his time arrived for the National Football League draft. Anderson was overlooked in 1994 -- 200 players were selected before him. And the following year, Davis lasted until the sixth round and was the 196th player chosen.

title: Computers and Early Physics Won't Unlock the 'Fun' of Science; Eighth-Grade Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Broncos' Commitment Came From Celebration
description: Twelve months ago, the Denver Broncos had been Super Bowl champions for a matter of minutes when, in the midst of the celebration, Coach Mike Shanahan warned them of how difficult it would be to repeat.

title: Snow Days Are Not Golden for All Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Girl, 14, Is Struck And Killed by a Car
description: A 14-year-old Bronx girl was struck and killed by a car last night as she crossed the street near her home, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERWILLIGER, ROBERTA
description: TERWILLIGER - Roberta. Of Bronxville, NY. Died January 29 at age 91. Devoted wife of the late Charles Terwilliger and beloved mother of Anne T. Olsen of Laramie, WY, and Robert Terwilliger of Coconut Grove, FL. An active volunteer in Planned Parenthood, Radcliffe in Westchester, the Urban League, the United Negro College Fund, and the Girl Scouts. Services private. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to a local Planned Parenthood center or any of the charities she supported so tirelessly.

title: The Test Under Stress
description: Shouldn't colleges take an honest look at the reality that parents are buying test scores for their children? What if colleges insisted that students inform them that they had been tutored as part of their application?

title: Coming Apart, As an Art Form
description: THE woman looks at the man who may or may not be her son and asks: ''T b k k k k l?''

title: How One Man Fights City Hall
description: THE characters and interests that run this city of 17,000 City Hall and school board, landlords, politicians -- are all intertwined. Robert L. Sanders keeps tugging at the twine.

title: Cruise Lines' Mantra: More, More
description: DURING the Persian Gulf war almost a decade ago, cruise lines hastily improvised alternative itineraries while moving their ships as fast and as far away from the war zone as possible. Within days, the Mediterranean was being referred to in cruising circles as the Dead Sea. But last month's bombing of Iraq by the United States and Britain created scarcely a ripple.

title: PULSE; The Allure of the Sea
description: Karrie Webb took a two-shot penalty on the 17th hole and fell into a three-way tie for the lead yesterday after the third round in the Office Depot in West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LATELLA, GLORIA
description: LATELLA-Gloria. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Gloria Latella, associated with The Times from 1957 until retiring in 1983.

title: How Movie Magic Is Made
description: Want to watch yourself travel through Venice Beach, Calif., on a dinosaur? Care to step into the submarine from the movie ''The Abyss,'' and feel yourself submerging in the ocean? How is this possible, you ask? Learn all about computer-generated imagery and other special effects, starting Saturday at ''Special Effects 2'' at the New York Hall of Science. Visitors can see how special-effect ideas are developed and storyboards created. They can examine items like a Klingon mask from ''Star Trek: Deep Space Nine'' and models of snow walkers from ''The Empire Strikes Back.''

title: A Hundred Years of Conflict and Creativity
description: ON Monday, public television will begin its celebration of Black History Month with the first two parts of the six-part documentary ''I'll Make Me a World: A Century of African-American Arts.'' Produced by Blackside in association with Thirteen/WNET, and broadcast at 9 P.M. for three consecutive days on Channel 13 in the New York area, the series traces the evolution of black arts and artists from the turn of the century to the present.

title: Accolades for Two Students in Science Contest
description: THIS week, when 40 high school students across the United States were chosen as finalists in the Intel Science Talent Search, there may have been no winners for Westchester.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MATTUS, JOHN DAVID
description: MATTUS-John David. Even after three years, you still are my sunshine! Eternal memory, my dearest friend and soulmate. Kevin

title: Recognition for Regional Artists
description: SINCE 1960, the Rye Arts Center has been home to a multitude of cultural events and activities. Their Annual Regional Exhibition, which began in 1995, gives under-recognized artist groups an opportunity to display their work in a professional setting. Last year's exhibition, titled ''Teaching Artists,'' consisted of works by Westchester secondary school teachers. The current show, ''The Artists of Upstream Gallery,'' features the art of a gallery in Dobbs Ferry.

title: Why Gasoline Costs More Here
description: DRIVERS in Westchester may be wondering why record low oil prices have not translated into commensurate savings at the pump. By year's end, county drivers were paying $1.23 for a gallon of unleaded regular gasoline, according to a survey of gas stations provided by the County Department of Weights and Measures. At the same time, the nationwide average retail price fell to 93.7 cents, the lowest inflation-adjusted level since record keeping began in 1920, according to the United States Department of Energy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAIRBERG, LAWRENCE A.
description: FAIRBERG-Lawrence A. Of Scottsdale, Ariz., on January 15, 1999. His sister, Henny Nathanson, and nieces, Mary and Rona, will remember him always with love.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Giving Writers an Open Mike to Offer Odes and Oddities
description: Paul Violi, a poet, glanced around the small windowless room and took in the fluorescent lights, the foam-covered walls, the prominently placed ''No drinking or smoking'' sign. ''It's not like reading at KGB, is it?'' he commented.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAYOVITZ, IRENE GERTZMAN
description: SAYOVITZ-Irene Gertzman. 89, on January 29, 1999, at home, 18446 Aberdeen Rd., Jamaica Estates, NY. Devoted wife of David. Beloved mother of Carol Brennan and Paula Beck. Adored grandmother of Richard Beatty, Joanna Maddock, Bonnie Roston and Wendy Sauer. Proud greatgrandmother of Sarah, Andrew, Steven, Thomas, Lauren, Elyse, Brett and Jenna. Love and loyalty were the creed she lived by. We who basked in her warmth are deeply grateful. We will remember and miss her for the rest of our lives. Services at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, NY, Sunday, 12 noon.

title: Independent Minds
description: THE BURDEN OF RESPONSIBILITY

title: Seas of Possibilities
description: WHAT do cruise passengers want on their ships? More of everything, it seems. The cruise lines are determined to provide it, with each new ship trying to outdo the other. Carnival's 102,000-ton Carnival Triumph, carrying 2,758 passengers, and the 47,900-ton Mistral, carrying 1,200 passengers for First European Cruises, are scheduled to arrive in July. Norwegian Cruise Line's 78,000-ton Norwegian Sky, accommodating 2,002 passengers, plans to sail in August, as does Disney Cruise Line's second 83,000-ton ship, the Disney Wonder, carrying up to 1,750 passengers. Royal Caribbean International's 142,000-ton Voyager of the Seas, the largest of all to date, is expected to arrive in November, accommodating 3,100 passengers, but at 1,017 feet, she will still be shorter than the 1,035-foot Norway.

title: Rushing to the Top
description: The Atlanta Falcons and the Denver Broncos kick off in Miami at 6:25 P.M. today, and their hopes will ride on the National Football League's two best runners: Jamal Anderson of Atlanta, right, and Terrell Davis of Denver, left. A Super Bowl preview includes a comparison of the teams' running games, key matchups and rosters. SportsSunday

title: Computers and Early Physics Won't Unlock the 'Fun' of Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Speak No Evil? Quixote Had It Easy.
description: SOME say it all started in the Garden of Eden, when the snake hissed, ''Hey, Eve, you won't believe what I heard about Adam.'' But today, here in the Domain of Dish, the Hub of Hubbub, the Burg That Buzz Built, there is no denying it. Gotham is Gossip Central.

title: F.Y.I.
description: What's Your Sign?

title: New York Hospitals Struggle With Flu Surge
description: New York City hospitals are struggling to manage a widespread flu epidemic that is stretching their emergency rooms and wards to overcapacity and forcing workers to ratchet up the overtime, doctors to cancel some elective surgeries and administrators to air out unused wards for patients who are flowing through the doors.

title: PULSE; On to Cloud-Cuckoo-Land
description: According to one popular school of dream interpretation, a woman who dreams of ostrich feathers will advance in society in an inimitable way. And in this season of down-accented accessories, wearing feathers can work, too. For a really big social splash, two downtown milliners are offering bold feathered headgear.

title: New York City Has Several Large Public Pools
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrating Two Cultures: Black History Month
description: The historian Carter G. Woodson initiated Negro History Week in 1926 to counteract misrepresentations of the history of black people in America and elsewhere. Since then, the week has grown into an international celebration known as Black History Month. This year, New Jersey artists are observing the tradition in full force. These are among the highlights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALENTA, LEONARD
description: VALENTA-Leonard. Of Staten Island on Jan. 28, 1999. Loving wife of Nancy (nee Foltz). Dear sister of Lillian Poston. Also survived by many nieces and nephews and many grand nieces and nephews. Funeral service Harmon Home for Funerals, 571 Forest Ave, Staten Isl., NY, Sunday Jan. 31, 8PM. Friends will be received Sunday and Monday 2-4 and 7-9PM.

title: Technological Twists on Conventional Media
description: 'Electronic Kink'

title: Money Is at the Root of Trial's Partisanship; Paula Jones's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ASTORIA; Site's the Rub for Topless Club
description: The temperature in the lower atmosphere of Venus, the planet, averages 870 degrees Fahrenheit, but if the city's Buildings Department and some residents of Woodside, Queens, have their way, the temperature inside Venus, the Gentlemen's Club, will be lukewarm at best.

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; Time Is Not the Essence
description: I WAS a principal in a consulting engineering firm for many years before I retired. Everyone from the receptionist to the bosses had to fill out a time record every week. Time is money, and that's how we earned ours, by accounting for every hour so that clients could be charged for the time we had spent working for them.

title: At Last, Printing of the Green for City Hall
description: Attention bureaucrats, reporters, community leaders and assorted fighters of City Hall: the new Green Book has arrived, better late than never. Last week, nearly 40,000 copies of the city's official directory were delivered from the printer, though some were rushed out on New Year's Eve, allowing city officials to announce they got the 1998-99 edition out on time, technically speaking. (Never mind that there was no 1997-98 edition.)

title: The World: Plumbing the K.G.B. Files; For Russia, Bumbling Agents and Friends in High Places
description: THE President of the United States springs the nation's top Communist from jail. Behind the President's back, America's top spymaster swaps secrets with the Soviets. The Secretary of Commerce bares his soul to Moscow's station chief in Washington. Meanwhile, Federal agents are hunting down Communist file clerks and coatholders.

title: Mediate Hopes to See What He's Made Of
description: Instead of making excuses today, Rocco Mediate made birdies.

title: Gold Dispute With the Swiss Declared to Be At an End
description: Vice President Al Gore and the new President of the Swiss Federation, Ruth Dreifuss, declared today that the dispute over the disposition of Nazi gold and the treatment of Holocaust survivors by Swiss banks was over.

title: Devils Take Early Lead, But Falter in Overtime
description: The Devils scored the first two goals today against the expansion Nashville Predators, then lost in overtime by 3-2, and afterward they were looking for answers for their lackadaisical performance.

title: Where The Boys Are; Networks' Huge Bet On Football Provides Must-See TV for Men
description: TT was the most expensive deal in the history of network television -- and the riskiest, carrying predictions that it might come close to bankrupting the companies that agreed to it.

title: A Yearning for History Is Fulfilled
description: I GREW up in a Levitt-era tract house, identical to the ones across the street, with wall-to-wall carpet, hollow doors and a postage-stamp yard bulldozed of the slender birch trees that once grew there.

title: BILL MURRAY, IN ALL SERIOUSNESS
description: ''It's a cliche,'' says Lorne Michaels, the producer of ''Saturday Night Live,'' ''but Bill is always Bill. So much of my generation's approach to comedy was a reaction against the neediness of performers. When Bill was onstage, he didn't much care whether they liked him. Because of that, he had enormous integrity. When Bill's good, it's the same as when DeNiro's good. And you wouldn't have said that about any comedian in the last generation.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, MOE
description: MOORE-Moe. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Moe Moore, associated with The Times from 1936 until retiring in 1967.

title: Girl Interrupted at Her Music
description: AMY BEACH

title: Q&A; / Judith Anne Porter Thompson; An Education, On Line and Otherwise
description: THE dean of Southern Connecticut State University's School of Extended Learning, Judith Anne Porter Thompson, talks with a missionary's zeal. She wants to ''capture'' students, take university courses into business offices, fill underutilized time in the school calendar and make the university accessible to anyone regardless of time or distance. It all adds up to marketing Southern as an attractive option to the rapidly increasing number of part-time adult students.

title: A Neighborhood Closes Ranks to Mourn 2 Slain Brothers
description: Most of the people who filled St. Stanislaus Kostka Church did not know Richard Short, 7, and his 3-year-old brother, John, the two slain children whose bodies rested in small white coffins near the altar. But in a 55-minute funeral that evinced the sorrow of an entire community yesterday, many mourners said they had come to close ranks around the boys' grieving mother and resolve the pain in their own hearts and minds.

title: At 90, a Veteran Remembers It All
description: AT the little-known Mercury Gallery in Boston, a mostly forgotten group of American artists from the 1930's is the focus of an exhibition that also turns attention to the group's sole surviving member, a very fine painter named Joseph Solman. Having just turned 90 last week, Mr. Solman, you should be glad to know, is still painting in his cluttered studio above the Second Avenue Deli in the East Village of Manhattan, where he has worked more or less since Jackson Pollock was a new name on the American scene.

title: Glenn Miller's New Haven Connection
description: PETER COFRANCESCO of Hamden says everyone has a hero. Yet few people go to the extent that he did recently to honor someone's memory.

title: Wary U.S. Broods on a Peace Effort Minus King Hussein
description: With King Hussein of Jordan lying gravely ill from cancer in a hospital in Minnesota, senior Clinton Administration officials say they are alarmed at the prospect of pursuing a comprehensive peace in the Middle East without the Arab leader widely seen as most committed to the goal.

title: Trans-Atlantic Flights
description: HEAVY WATER

title: Reality in the Balance
description: Bowing to complaints that it was luring customers into taking out unintended loans, Summit Bank, the largest New Jersey-based bank, began last week to give clearer receipts for its customers' transactions at automated teller machines. The designation ''available balance'' now applies only to money on deposit in a checking account, with the amount available on an overdraft credit line listed separately. Previously, with these amounts combined in a single figure, some customers wrote checks or made withdrawals for more than their deposited balances and unwittingly touched off costly overdraft loans. ROBERT D. HERSHEY JR.

title: Alycia Bartley, Franz Heinsen
description: Dr. Alycia Jennifer Bartley, a medical resident, was married last evening to Franz Arturo Heinsen, an investment banker. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman officiated with the Rev. R. John Nelson, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Essex House in New York.

title: Machine Dreams
description: To the Editor:

title: An American Hero's Human Face
description: PROCESSIONS and widespread mourning followed George Washington's death in December 1799. Richard Henry Lee's famous eulogy -- ''First in war, first in peace and first in the hearts of his countrymen'' -- characterized the nation's first President in words, but other talented commentators used visual images to project his strengths.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 3 about kayaking in the Marlborough Sounds in New Zealand misstated the name of a native bird. It is takahe, not takehe.

title: Rocky Path To Market For Edible Foe Of Cholesterol
description: TT had all the makings of a fairy tale. A small company in an obscure corner of Finland discovered a natural substance that can lower cholesterol levels. The company devised and patented ways to extract it from wood pulp, make it flavorless and dissolve it in food. A new margarine made with the magic ingredient was an instant, runaway hit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALYO, STANLEY J.
description: CALYO-Stanley J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Stanley J. Calyo, associated with The Times from 1969 until retiring in 1984.

title: Editorial Observer; Brazil's Economy: Moscow on the Amazon?
description: Close your eyes, and it feels like Russia all over again.

title: Trump Cuts Back
description: Donald J. Trump has scaled back his plans for a golf course and luxury housing development at his Seven Springs estate in the northern Westchester towns of Bedford, New Castle and North Castle.

title: Medical Center Report
description: For the fifth year in a row, the Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla ended 1998 with the highest number of organ donations in the state. Among 117 hospitals, the Valhalla center ranked in the highest position for the state, recovering organs from 25 donors.

title: A Rough-and-Tumble Dudley Is Ready to Roll for Knicks
description: Chris Dudley clamped the rebound between his hands, and using his elbows like a machete, cleared the space around him Friday night. Along the way, he caught the Nets' Keith Van Horn right in the goatee.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Playing in the Neighborhood column last Sunday about a program of Mexican folkloric music, song and dance, continuing through Feb. 28 at the Thalia Spanish Theater in Sunnyside, Queens, misstated the telephone number for information. It is (718) 729-3880.

title: S.E.C. Explores Directors' Roles
description: Arthur Levitt, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has made it a point in recent years to call on mutual fund directors to stand up for the interests of fund shareholders against those of the companies that market funds and manage their portfolios. But increasingly, directors who have taken Mr. Levitt's admonitions to heart have found themselves in heated disputes with all of those parties.

title: SOAPBOX; The Fugitive in the Mirror
description: UNTIL recently, I have occasionally felt guilty gratitude toward Mayor Giuliani for improving the quality of life in the city. Gratitude for improvements that I know are sometimes made at the expense of innocent people swept up in the wide police net set out to trawl for the disorderly and the disruptive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGELSMITH, BERNICE
description: NAGELSMITH - Bernice. Died peacefully at home on January 30, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Louis Nagelsmith. Loving mother of Barbara Nagelsmith and Carole Greenberg. Grandmother of Danna Greenberg and the late Michael Jon Greenberg, great-grandmother of Micaela Tobin and a caring friend. Services Monday, February 1, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Please call 212-288-3500 for service time. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to Kids in Crisis, 1 Salem Street, Cos Cob, CT 06807.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PESKIN, ESTHER ZACHAREVITZ
description: PESKIN-Esther Zacharevitz. On January 28, 1999 in her 102nd year, of Passaic, New Jersey. Beloved wife of the late Louis, mother of Arthur Peskin and Doris Levine, grandmother of Sally Anne Levine and Andrea Ostroff, great-grandmother of Arlene and Jennifer. Services today 1PM, ''GuttermanMusicant,'' Hackensack, NJ.

title: Shorting With Agouron
description: Were they lucky or smart? A little more than a month ago, Agouron Pharmaceuticals was one of the most heavily shorted stocks on the Nasdaq market. Based on mid-December data, fully 20.5 percent of its shares outstanding were held by short-sellers, according to Short Alert, a research firm in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Backtalk; Super Bowl by the Numbers
description: I. Catches in Percey Howard's National Football League career. Howard, a rookie wide receiver for the Dallas Cowboys, scored a Super Bowl touchdown on his only N.F.L. reception, a 34-yard pass play from Roger Staubach late in the fourth quarter of Super Bowl X.

title: Some Words of Praise For a Fabled Pet Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: January 24-30; First U.S. Hand Transplant
description: Surgeons in Louisville, Ky., performed the first hand transplant in the United States, and the world's third. The recipient of the donor hand is Matthew David Scott of Absecon, N.J., who lost his own in a firecracker accident in 1985. The rarity of hand transplants largely reflects an ethical controversy over the benefits of a procedure that is not essential to life and results in a lifelong need for anti-rejection drugs, which can lead to infection and other illnesses. But if recipients regain sufficient use of their new hands, such transplants might become more common. LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BESTERMAN, JACK
description: BESTERMAN-Jack. Died on January 25, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Claire. Devoted father of Catherine (Michael). Also survived by many nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. Jack was a survivor of the Holocaust leaving behind his wife and son, mother, father and several siblings. Retired printer of The New York Times, which he loved. He was also a member of the New York Typographical Union and several Jewish organizations. Published poet and editor of several community newspapers including The New York Times, Sunshine/Pensioners and The Big Six Towers Reporter. Burial and services were held at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to a charity of your choice or the planting of trees in Israel would be greatly appreciated.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Talk about range -- these are just a few of the great looks in white that designers offered for spring.

title: A Caravaggio Leaves Its Dublin Home to Visit Boston
description: SINCE it was rediscovered in the Jesuit Residence in Dublin in 1990, Caravaggio's ''Taking of Christ'' has left Ireland only twice. In 1995, the painting spent a month at the National Gallery in London and two months in Rome. ''The Taking of Christ'' was not scheduled to leave Dublin -- where the Jesuit Fathers have left it on indefinite loan at the National Gallery of Ireland -- for the next 25 years. Yet tomorrow it will be on view in Boston, as the centerpiece of ''Saints and Sinners: Caravaggio and the Baroque Image,'' a show of 17th-century Italian religious art that opens at the McMullen Museum of Art at Boston College, through May 24.

title: January 24-30; A Warning on Social Security
description: The easiest way to shore up Social Security is to use the Federal budget surpluses now anticipated by both parties. But Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned Congress and the Administration that the surpluses are not a sure thing. If Washington really wants to be sure of putting the retirement system on a sound footing, Mr. Greenspan said, it will probably have to do it the old fashioned way, through politically painful tax increases and benefit cuts. RICHARD W. STEVENSON

title: In Mexico, Will Zedillo Keep Hands Off Election?
description: President Ernesto Zedillo earned international applause last year when he said he would be the first Mexican President in modern times to refuse to handpick his successor. But just how his party intends to nominate its candidate for the July 2000 presidential balloting remains one of Mexico's intriguing mysteries.

title: In the City of Virgil, Food Is Poetry
description: Occupying a country house 23 miles outside Mantua, this superb restaurant is one of the trio in Italy awarded three Michelin stars. Besides the elegant, spacious dining room, dominated by a fireplace, there are two small sitting rooms, to which smokers are requested (not ordered) to repair. The eclectic decor juxtaposes rustic artifacts like old wooden agricultural implements with fashionable touches like sponged yellow walls.

title: A Half-Century of Quality, Paid for by Greeting Cards
description: IF advertisers believed in 1951 that sponsoring televised opera would make them some money, next Sunday's telecast of ''Night Ride Home,'' a CBS movie about a couple who become estranged when their son dies, might have been a presentation of the Alka-Seltzer Hall of Fame. But only Hallmark did. And while billing this film as its 200th presentation must have required the creative accounting services of ''The Producers' '' Bialystock and Bloom, there's no argument that for nearly 50 years the world's leading purveyor of iambic saccharine has set an unparalleled record for producing quality drama.

title: On the Ground Floor Of the American Dream; At New York City's Only Trailer Park, Affordable Homes and Rules to Live By
description: ''Griswold!'' Bill Henrich barked. ''You know they don't like loose pets!''

title: MUSIC; Lincoln Center Creates a Home For American Pop
description: IN a sense, Ella Fitzgerald's recording of the Harold Arlen songbook, like all her songbook albums, doesn't exist to glorify her innovative virtuosity. Rather, the albums systematically codify the soul of American popular music, creating a framework by which generations of listeners could appreciate Arlen, George Gershwin, Cole Porter, Irving Berlin, Jerome Kern and all the masters.

title: Giving Mouth-to-Mouth to 'The Pimpernel'
description: RATHER like the hero of ''The Scarlet Pimpernel,'' who rescues doomed French aristocrats from the jaws of the guillotine, Robert Longbottom seems to have saved the musical by Frank Wildhorn and Nan Knighton from certain death.

title: The Test Under Stress
description: As a test official who finds the claims of test coaches difficult to swallow, I nonetheless applaud Arun Alagappan for using a high-stakes test like the S.A.T. to motivate students to rigorous study (Tony Schwartz, Jan. 10). But it is ridiculous that so many parents pay the equivalent of a year's college tuition so their kids can learn good work habits. Alagappan is teaching kids the value of rigor and discipline. These values, however, can be learned at home and at school for a lot less money.

title: College Recognized
description: Citing the number of minority faculty members at Westchester Community College in Valhalla, a new study in a Washington trade journal says the the college is one of the country's top 50 two-year colleges.

title: Cape May County Jail Settles Discrimination Suit
description: A lawsuit filed by four corrections officers in the Cape May County jail who said they were routinely the subjects of sexual and racial harassment and discrimination was settled for $2 million last week and has led to changes in the way the jail is operated.

title: January 24-30; Pope's Plea for Clemency Spares Life of Inmate
description: When the ailing Pope John Paul II visited St. Louis briefly -- it was his fifth American trip -- high on his agenda was to urge this nation's often restless Roman Catholics to follow Vatican teaching more closely. In a special plea, he called the death penalty ''cruel and unnecessary,'' even for ''someone who has done great evil.'' And he didn't balk at specifics, asking Gov. Mel Carnahan to spare the life of Darrell J. Mease, a triple murderer set to die on Feb. 10.

title: What to Do With the Bonus Check?
description: IT'S bonus season again, and not just on Wall Street. Sure, the financial-services bonus babies are as numerous as ever, offering up silent ''show me the money'' prayers that last fall's market gyrations will not eat too far into the six- or seven-figure checks they are counting on to finance a swank Upper East Side duplex or a little place in the Hamptons. But though the dollars in other industries do not approach the lofty heights enjoyed on Wall Street, the culture of bonuses is spreading steadily through the ranks of corporate America.

title: Oh, Those Pesky Little Financial Details
description: THIS is a tale of two earnings reports from Micron Technology Inc., one of the world's largest makers of semiconductor chips. Micron also happens to be a very hot stock.

title: Waves of Trouble Are Lapping at Chelsea's Piers
description: AS the new year begins, winds of economic change are blowing on West 23d Street at the Hudson River. Ill winds, it seems.

title: New Questions on Safety In Mexico Are Raised
description: THE torture and murder of a Texas journalist last month as he hiked alone through a remote mountainous area in western Mexico has raised new questions about how safe the country is for foreign tourists.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: BERNARD SHAW

title: Credit Cards Get Tough On the Tardy
description: AFTER five years of using the same credit card to buy gasoline and paying the entire balance each month, Michael S. Lamar got a rude awakening from his card issuer, First USA Bank: a $29 late fee on charges of $21.66.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: Shimmer

title: NATO AUTHORIZES KOSOVO AIR RAIDS IF SERBS BAR TALKS
description: NATO allies removed restraints today on military action against Serbia if it does not agree by Feb. 6 to start talks next weekend in France with the ethnic Albanian leaders in Kosovo about autonomy for the province.

title: Airport Hotels
description: To the Editor: My thanks to Betsy Wade and Emily Laurence Baker for highlighting the practical aspects of airport hotels (''Hotels at J.F.K. Buff Their Image'' and ''When Proximity's the Thing,'' Dec. 6). Few who travel for pleasure, not business, are aware of how much they offer the ordinary vacationer.

title: Judge Is Reassigned
description: A Westchester County Family Court judge who was criticized by women's groups for her decision in a domestic-violence case last summer has been reassigned to oversee civil trials. But Judge Francis A. Nicolai, the judge in charge of reassignments, said Judge Adrienne Hofmann Scancarelli's new responsibilities have nothing to do with her controversial decision.

title: SPRING-SUMMER CRUISES; A Round-the-World Voyage Of More Than 80 Days
description: WHEN the British naturalist Sir Joseph Banks was planning his obligatory Grand Tour in the 18th century, only a round-the-world voyage would do: ''Any blockhead can go to Italy,'' he declared. Not sharing his scorn for Italian travel, but being retired and unencumbered, my friend Barbara Kamm and I decided last year to circle the globe ourselves.

title: Camel Racing in Dubai
description: The deals at the Dubai Shopping Festival start with the trip to that Arab emirate. African Travel and Mastercard are offering airline tickets to Dubai for the festival and four nights in the Sheraton Deira -- all breakfasts included -- for $2,590 for two people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHWELL, NELLIE GRANT CRONAN
description: ROTHWELL-Nellie Grant Cronan, 82, January 16 at La Jolla, CA. Widow of Col. Franklin G. Rothwell (U.S.A.), mother of Teresa, daughter of Capt. William Cronan (U.S.N.) and Nellie Grant, and great-granddaughter of President U.S. Grant. Interment later at West Point, NY.

title: Baylor Has Some Hitting Projects for Braves
description: When Don Baylor suddenly became open to job offers last September after his dismissal as manager of the Colorado Rockies, he had a host of opportunities, but one clearly stood out.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: IN THE PONDBy Ha Jin.Zoland, $20.

title: The Millennium
description: To the Editor: Re ''Mass Millennial Movement'' (Dec. 27), since when have we adopted a numbering system that commences with zero?

title: Quality, Not Quantity, In Investment Information
description: To the Editor:

title: A Visit to Greece in a Glass
description: Wintertime nostalgia for that sweet vine-clad taverna in Greece knows few sadder words than ''the wine didn't travel well.'' But '97 Kouros Patras Dry white wine and '96 Kouros Nemea Dry Red Wine mix memory and desire.

title: For Studios, 'Director' Is A Male Noun
description: WHEN the Hollywood studios announced their 1998 grosses earlier this month, women there raised a quiet cheer. Both Mimi Leder (''Deep Impact'') and Betty Thomas (''Dr. Dolittle'') had made films that earned more than $150 million domestically. It was the first time ever that two female directors had simultaneously surpassed the magic $100 million mark that certifies a blockbuster.

title: Buying Opportunities In Tax-Free Bond Funds
description: A SPATE of initial offerings of closed-end municipal bond funds is hitting the markets, helping to depress the shares of many such funds and creating opportunities for investors hungry for tax-free yields. Last week Eaton Vance issued nine closed-end muni funds with a total of $615 million in assets. Six more such funds, with more than $450 million in assets, are expected from Merrill Lynch in February.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-11

title: Istanbul Choices
description: To the Editor: Our visit to Istanbul was a success, due in part to Sherry Marker's informative article ''A Whirl Through Istanbul'' (Aug. 16).

title: Seeing the Sound
description: A motion picture isn't moving if viewers can't hear the dialogue. People with hearing problems have a chance to get caught up in the action if they catch captioned films, usually available one weekday a month at four theaters in New Jersey owned by Clearview Cinema Group. Clearview, which has headquarters in Chatham and runs 60 theaters in the New York metropolitan area, gets the prints from Tripod Films in California, which adds subtitles, including dialogue and sound effects. In pilot runs in May in theaters in Upper Montclair and Bergenfield, the response was much greater than anticipated, said Bud Mayo, Clearview's chief executive. Although the program has been expanded, Tripod can spare just one print of each film for Clearview, which sends it to the Bellevue in Upper Montclair, the Bergenfield Cinema Five, the Headquarters 10 in Morristown and the Middlebrook Galleria Cinema 10 in Ocean Township, plus others on Long Island and in Manhattan and Westchester and Rockland Counties. This month's captioned feature was ''A Bug's Life''; February's will be ''Patch Adams.'' Mr. Mayo says the movies appeal to people with only slight hearing impairments (the sound stays on) and those for whom English is a second language.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: AMERICAN ARIA

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: PROSPECT HEIGHTS

title: A Seventh Grader Catches the Bus And the Limelight
description: Cindy Volpe does not think she will get any credit toward driver education when she gets to it in high school, but the seventh grader has a head start. When the driver of her school bus blacked out recently, Cindy, 13, grabbed the wheel, steered the bus across four lanes of traffic and made sure the passengers got out safely.

title: Not Such a Bad Year For Hedge Funds
description: Hedge funds posted modest profits last year on the way to being trounced by the broad stock market. But considering that 1998 was the year that Long-Term Capital Management nearly pulled down the world capital markets, such funds didn't do as poorly as might have been expected.

title: A Philosophical Precedent
description: To the Editor:

title: Q. & A.
description: Cigarettes Landing on A Terrace

title: Stacy Susman and Thomas Kuhn
description: Stacy Margraeta Susman, a management consultant, and Thomas Jeremy Kuhn, a media executive, were married in New York last evening. Rabbi Samuel Karff officiated at Cipriani Wall Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINGOLD, LILLIAN
description: FEINGOLD-Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Lew. Devoted mother of Ellen Math and William Feingold. Loving sister of Mildred Josephs. Adored grandmother of Robert and Nicole, and greatgrandmother of Jennifer and Lauren. Services 12:30, Monday, at ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Sports of The Times; The Broncos' Sharpe Is Talking Things Up as the Model Tight End
description: UNTIL the kickoff, the Super Bowl is always a talk show. Yak, yak, yak. And Super Bowl XXXIII's most eloquent, or at least its most voluble, talk-show guest has been Shannon Sharpe, the Broncos' tight end. When asked anything, he always had something to say, especially about himself.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Plenty of Reasons To Be Happy
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Food Distributor's New Chief Performs Emergency Surgery
description: LIKE a surgeon wielding a scalpel, Mark S. Hansen has cut swiftly and deeply into the Fleming Companies, closing plants, eliminating departments and dismissing workers.

title: Not the Same Old Song And Dance
description: How far have the Super Bowl halftime shows come? Befitting the National Football League's desire to book stars, tonight's show on Fox, which is to start around 8 after the 6:18 kickoff in Miami's Pro Player Stadium, will star Gloria Estefan, Stevie Wonder, the swing band Big Bad Voodoo Daddy and 750 dancers. But for most of the Super Bowl's history, halftime entertainment was skewed to stodgy traditionalists, as if Lawrence Welk were booking the acts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOFFER, WILLIAM I.
description: SOFFER-William I. A loving and caring husband, father, and grandfather. He touched many lives and will be greatly missed.

title: The Candidate
description: I sympathize with Yglesias's frustration at the essay questions posed by college applications, but I would urge him to prepare himself for the ''real world,'' where he will encounter interviewers asking equally inane questions like, ''Why do you want to work at Megacorp?'' ''What are your best and worst qualities?'' ''Where do you want to be five years from now?''

title: At Sea, Extras Can Add Up Fast
description: AS for the all-inclusive cruise: there is no such creature. No matter how high up the caviar chain is a cruise line, with Silversea and Seabourn probably at the top, there is always something to be paid for at the end.

title: Looking Over Jordan
description: PLAYING FOR KEEPS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRONBERG, LOUIS
description: KRONBERG-Louis. 90, died January 27, 1999 at his home in New York City. Beloved husband and companion to his devoted wife Nina and loving step-father to Thomas Paris of Manhattan and Robert Paris of Rye, NY. Lou Kronberg was Founder and President of Club ABC Tours, an international leisure travel company, established in 1967. Through his vision and leadership, Club ABC Tours became one of the most important private tour organizations in the United States with a nationwide club membership. He lived a life devoted to improving the lives of people around him. He attended New York University and in the early 1940's became President of the Wine and Liquor Salesmen of the state of New Jersey, Local Union No. 19, AFL-CIO, a position he held for over 40 years. His great enjoyment of different cultures inspired his decision to develop a travel club on an international scale. Mr. Kronberg had an especially keen interest in Italy which had developed over the past 30 years. He was an avid supporter of the Boys Town of Italy. In 1985 he was made Cavaliere by the President of Italy. The Vatican presented Mr. Kronberg with the Holy See Award for his appreciation of Italy and the furthering of ecumenical principles. He has been awarded numerous times for his development of American tourism into Italy. His friendship, love and exuberance for life will be greatly missed by all those who knew him. He was laid to rest in a private ceremony on Thursday, January 28, at Riverside Cemetery in Saddlebrook, NJ. Memorial contributions can be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Money Is at the Root of Trial's Partisanship; Censure Conundrum
description: To the Editor:

title: STARR IS WEIGHING WHETHER TO INDICT SITTING PRESIDENT
description: The independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, has concluded that he has the constitutional authority to seek a grand jury indictment of President Clinton before he leaves the White House in January 2001, several associates of Mr. Starr said this week.

title: Feeling the Spirit: Preserving a Culture in an Alien City
description: The drums pulsed like a heartbeat as a dancer with a smile stretched across her face fell backward into the crowd. A South Bronx political hall had been transformed into a Central American village.

title: Family Office Concern Goes Beyond Tradition
description: HIS father did it before him. And his father did it before him. And so nine years ago, when Alan Levy succeeded his father, Gordon, as president of Hudson Office Supply in Tarrytown, he was the fourth-generation family member to head the business founded by his great-grandfather.

title: Making Money, Giving Money
description: Jeff Reifman thinks one reason Microsoft hired him when he was 20 was the ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoon on his resume. Eight years later, he's still operating in a humane, slightly offbeat way, splitting his time between the software giant, where he is a manager, and Giving.org, a nonprofit group he created to funnel profits back to the Seattle community. Its cornerstone is Habitat Espresso, a cafe that opened in the city in November 1997.

title: The Nation; Secrecy Is a Working Tool in the Hands of the Senate
description: THE cameras were yanked, the lights unplugged and the doors slammed against the public and the press last week, leaving the country's premier deliberative body to deliberate by itself. The Senate had concluded that the only way to resolve several thorny procedural issues surrounding President Clinton's fate was to seal itself off.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Talk about range -- these are just a few of the great looks in white that designers offered for spring.

title: In Bid to Survive, Hong Kong Retailers Try Customer Loyalty Clubs
description: THE keys to retail success in boom times are well known: attracting new customers, identifying their needs and satisfying them with new stores and new products. When the going turns rough, though, those bets are off, and retailers often find themselves under pressure to slash prices to maintain volume, a tactic that can set off price wars that obliterate profits.

title: After a Long Journey, Chandler Finds Success
description: Quarterback Chris Chandler of the Atlanta Falcons was outside a restaurant here this week when some autograph-seekers began sticking small pieces of paper in his face. While Chandler politely signed, one man watching the scene, from several feet away, stared with a puzzled look. Finally, he asked, ''Who are you?''

title: An Original at Ease in the Studio System
description: MAX FISCHER, the 15-year-old protagonist of Wes Anderson's comedy ''Rushmore,'' is hardly your typical teen. A dapper, bespectacled young man, Max (the newcomer Jason Schwartzman) is fanatically devoted to his prep school, Rushmore Academy. President of most of the school's extracurricular activities, he is failing his classes but nonetheless plans to apply to Oxford and the Sorbonne.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAYLES, VIRGINIA C.
description: BAYLES-Virginia C. February 1, 1995. In ever loving memory. Sister, Marilyn

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: How the Mind Works

title: O Democracy!
description: YOUNG AMERICA

title: Nude in the Sun
description: To the Editor: What fun to read about someone else's sail (''Under Sail Through the Grenadines,'' Dec. 20, by Carey Goldberg) and figure out what has changed and what not since we were there, in February 1984, when we chartered a 44-foot bareboat for two weeks with our younger son, Charlie.

title: A Woman Learns to Manage Motherhood and Minimize Frustration
description: An African proverb, made popular as the title of a book by Hillary Rodham Clinton, says that it takes a village to raise a child.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASAHOW, MORRIS
description: PASAHOW-Morris. February 12, 1910-January 26, 1999. Late of the Bronx and Massapequa. Resided in West Palm Beach. Passed away suddenly. Survived by son Eugene E. Pasahow of Corpus Christi, Texas, and son Jerry Pasahow. Dear friend Dora Pariser of Palm Beach and granddaughter Lori J. Golden of New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRY, ROGER
description: PERRY-Roger. Age 70. Died at his home in Rye, NY, on January 26, 1999. He was educated in the New Rochelle public schools, at Harvard College, and Yale Law School. After his early retirement from the practice of international law in 1975, he managed real estate designed by his late father, architect Lee Perry of New Rochelle, and devoted himself to many organizations reflecting his lifelong interest in the oceans and the environment. He served on the boards of Bermuda Biological Station for Research, Organization for Tropical Studies, Israel Oceanographic and Limnological Research, ACCION, Nature Conservancy, and Planned Parenthood. He also served on the Rye City Boat Basin Commission and the Zoning Board of Appeals in his home community of Rye. Known and loved by many for his quick wit and sense of humor, Mr. Perry enjoyed birding, skiing, and sailing his small boat on Long Island Sound. He is survived by his wife Isobel, his sister Ellen Perry Berkeley of Shaftsbury, Vermont, and children Roy (& Gigi) Perry of Bryn Mawr, Lisa (and David) Hellerstein of Larchmont and Amy Perry (and Josh) Basseches of Quincy, MA., and grandchildren Alex & Leah; Sarah, Ben & Jason; and Jake and Sophie. Memorial contributions may be sent to Planned Parenthood, Hudson Peconic, 11 Skyline Drive, Hawthorne, New York 10532, or Nature Conservancy, 415 Moger Avenue, Mount Kisco, New York 10549. A memorial service was held at the Friends' Meeting House, PurPurchase, New York on Saturday, January 30.

title: PULSE: TO DIAL FOR
description: RestorationHardware: (800) 762-1005

title: New Tests Are a Stressful Measure
description: OVER the past weeks, we have read almost daily accounts of the new three-day fourth-grade language arts tests and a seemingly unrelated New York Times Magazine feature story entitled ''The Test Under Stress'' [Jan. 10], describing the ubiquitous use of Scholastic Achievement Test preparation courses. Similarities between these two otherwise very different tests were striking: the high anxiety levels felt by both the 9-year-old fourth-graders and the high school juniors, the extensive tutoring being purchased by both groups and the high-stakes consequences of doing poorly on these tests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABIN, FRANCES
description: RABIN-Frances. Beloved wife of the late William Rabin, married for 61 years, passed away on January 29, 1999. A longtime resident of Teaneck and Fort Lee, NJ, and Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Frances leaves behind daughters Maxine and Arlene, as well as loving grandchildren Jeffrey, Robin, Monica, Stephen, Alyssa, Ricky and Anne, and adoring great-grandchildren Beckett, Brett, Sophie, William and Harry. We all loved her and will miss her terribly.

title: FILM
description: EARLY last month at the New York Public Library's Donnell branch, a standing-room-only screening was held of ''The Kindness of Strangers,'' a 104-minute documentary that provides a close look at organ donation and transplantation from the personal perspective of donors, survivors, recipients and their families.

title: Traces of an Urban Love Affair
description: Seymour Durst was a hard-nosed real estate developer who was instrumental in changing New York's skyline. But he also had a passion for the city's past, as a walk through his extensive collection of New York memorabilia shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CULLINAN, RALPH, JR.
description: CULLINAN-Ralph, Jr. Captain USN, Ret., age 89, died peacefully in San Antonio, Texas on January 20, 1999. He is surived by his sister, Mrs. R. Morton Adams of Bloomfield, CT and his daughter, Julia C. Ballerini of New York City. Interment will be at the U.S. Naval Academy, Annapolis, Maryland at a later date.
